title: Why Not a Blockbuster?
description: To the Editor:

title: AT N.Y.U., A CRASH COURSE
description: WHEN the students need a breather or something for the stomach, the really good place to go is Over the Counter. Not the market, but the cafeteria on the 14th floor of Merrill Hall. While you eat your sandwich, you can watch the two illuminated tickers on the wall, where the trades on the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange scamper by in fits of symbols and digits.

title: LANDOWNERS TO BUILD WITHIN NATURE PRESERVE
description: LEAD: TWO Weston residents have announced plans to build houses on land they own within an undisturbed 1,540-acre nature preserve. It would be the first construction in the Lucius Pond Ordway Nature Preserve, popularly known as Devil's Den, and it has set off a furor.

title: Borough President To Give Arts Awards
description: Borough President David Dinkins of Manhattan will present awards for excellence in the arts in a ceremony tomorrow night at 7:30 in Davis Hall at City College, Convent Avenue and 134th Street.

title: How Reagan Created the Crash
description: Start with the French theologian Georges Bernanos: ''The worst, the most corrupting lies are problems poorly stated.''

title: G. S. Makela, Stockbroker, Weds Elizabeth Porter Hill
description: Elizabeth Porter Hill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Hill of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Gregory Strickler Makela, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Makela of New Smyrna Beach, Fla. The Rev. Anne Kimball performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: Ann Morris Colin And Peter Herbst Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Ann Morris Colin to Peter Herbst, a son of Eugenia V. Herbst of New York and the late Frank F. Herbst, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Cynthia Green Colin and Justin Colin, both of New York. A March wedding is planned.

title: CAN THE CONTRAS GO ON?
description: James LeMoyne's article ''Can the Contras Go On?'' (Oct. 4), was an impressive portrayal of a sad band of young people who are neither ''freedom fighters'' nor terrorists but, rather, the inevitable dispossessed losers in a long-finished revolutionary war. They are not unlike the Loyalists of our own Revolution, who were forced to flee to Canada and elsewhere.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WILTON;
'DRY' TOWN FACES LIQUOR BALLOT AGAIN
description: LEAD: WHEN Prohibition was repealed in 1933, most of Connecticut's towns voted to legalize liquor sales. But Wilton did not. Its residents feared that letting the town go ''wet'' would cause unsavory roadhouses and liquor stores to spring up along Route 7 and bring the wrong elements into the bedroom community.

title: SYRACUSE WINS NO. 8
description: As they were coming off the field after the game, the two coaches hugged and Mike Gottfried of Pitt said to Dick MacPherson of Syracuse, ''Go win the national championship.''

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Miscellany of Anxieties What are the ingredients of a contemporary short story? Ann Beattie offers her answer to this question in her introduction to ''The Best American Short Stories 1987'' (Houghton Mifflin), edited by Ms. Beattie and Shannon Ravenel.

title: Dance: Joffrey Offers Stevenson's 'Preludes'
description: SOME ballets are like gems: their full value comes through when they are completely polished. Certainly that is what has happened during the Joffrey Ballet's opening week in its performances of a 19th-century excerpt, the pas de six from ''La Vivandiere'' by Arthur Saint-Leon.

title: Beth Fuchs Becomes Bride Of R. M. Brenner, Lawyer
description: The marriage of Beth Lois Fuchs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lewis Fuchs of Roslyn, L.I., to Robert Meade Brenner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Brenner of Roslyn, took place last evening at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Robert Widom officiated.

title: CAN THE CONTRAS GO ON?
description: James LeMoyne's sympathetic account of the battle-weary contras needs to be balanced by some coverage from the other side.

title: Language in 'Sting of the Bee'
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The brick fireplace in our home had been painted by previous owners. We want to remove the paint and restore the natural brick. What is the best way to do this?

title: BACK-TO-BACK DINNERS
description: BACK IN THE NEAR-MYTHIC PAST -at least 10 or 15 years ago - the dinner party was a happy ornament of middle-class life. In the modern world, however, with the two-career family becoming the national mode, many couples are finding precious little room in their lives for these kinds of social gatherings, and the prospect of giving a dinner party, let alone two, may well throw them into a panic.

title: Gulotta: Tireless Executive
description: THOMAS S. GULOTTA'S schedule one recent Sunday included appearances at a bicycle ride for charity, a civic association award ceremony, a Columbus Day parade, a ribbon-cutting at a new photography store and a party for a Long Beach man celebrating his 102d birthday.

title: A Decisive Struggle Looms in Chile For a 'New' Pinochet and His Foes
description: At a luncheon some months ago, the leader of one of Chile's small center-right parties turned to a Socialist leader and raised an issue that has plagued Chilean public life for more than two decades.

title: DADDY HAS THE BEST GOSSIP
description: THE LAST OF HOW IT WAS By T. R. Pearson. 362 pp. New York: The Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: HARVARD TAKES FIRST PLACE
description: Brown, whose two previous defeats were before parents' day crowds on the road, made it 3-for-3 today - this time at home - when the Bruins fell to Harvard, 14-9, before a Parents' Day gathering of 16,800. The defeat knocked the Bruins out of a three-way tie for first place in the Ivy League and elevated Harvard, which has a 4-1 record.

title: Deborah S. Pilla, A Dentist, Is Wed
description: Dr. Deborah Susan Pilla, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick A. Pilla of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Dr. David O. Volpi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Orlando Volpi of Belle Vernon, Pa., were married yesterday afternoon at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan. The Rev. Thomas Joyce performed the ceremony.

title: THE FORMALITIES
description: CHOOSING A PROPER EVENING shirt is a straightforward affair. Or so says Alex Kabbaz, a partner in Pec & Co., the Manhattan custom shirtmaker.

title: FROM THE LEFT: Victor Perlo; Protect Jobs, Not Profits
description: Excerpts from an interview with Victor Perlo, chairman, economic commission, Communist Party, U.S.A.

title: ENSLAVED BY PALSTIC, FREED BY CALLIGRAPHY
description: THE GOLDEN DROPLET By Michel Tournier. Translated by Barbara Wright. 206 pp. New York: Doubleday. $16.95.

title: SAG HARBOR STUDIES SEWER TAKEOVER
description: CONTENDING that the municipal sewage treatment plant is too costly to operate at the local level and must soon be expanded, the Sag Harbor Village Board is considering asking the county to take over.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bellport$120,500 17 Third Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,200. Commack $247,000 5 Leslie Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old ranch; basement, C/A, deck, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $4,600. Hauppauge $215,000 41 Eva Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, porch, patio, 1-car garage; taxes $3,200. Oakdale $230,000 84 Idle Hour Boulevard 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old Dutch colonial; fireplace, patio, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,500. Plainview $270,000 11 Pasadena Drive 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 31-year-old split level; family room, marble fireplace, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $5,800. Shirley $118,000 183 Concord Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 13-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $1,900. OTHER AREAS New Rochelle, N.Y. $287,500 59 Darling Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, terrace, skylight, playroom; taxes $3,621. Yonkers, N.Y. $220,000 42 Custer Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial; family room, screened porch; taxes $3,444. Scotch Plains, N.J. $179,900 423 Warren Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, full basement; taxes $2,020.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
PHOTOGRAPHIC COMPETITION
description: LEAD: When Alice Lengers, a member of Ferry Sloops/ Sojourner Truth, decided to focus attention on the Hudson River, she chose to do it through a camera lens. But she wasn't just taking her own pictures -she initiated the first Hudson River photography competition and exhibition, co-sponsored by Ferry Sloops/Sojourner Truth and the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and

title: Diana Gaston Weds
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., Diana Brooke Gaston, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Keiley Gaston 3d of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Christopher Arthur Lindon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hopkins Lindon of Rockville Centre, L.I. The Rev. Stephen Parker performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Robert Champagne, a Roman Catholic priest. Mrs. Lindon and her husband are with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York. She is in the corporate bond department; he is in the compliance department.

title: Allyson Sass, a Violist, Marries Bradley Sklar
description: At Temple Beth-El in Cedarhurst, L.I., Allyson Beth Sass, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Lawrence Sass of Tappan, N.Y., and Lee, Mass., was married last night to Bradley Frisch Sklar, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Barrett Sklar of Plainview, L.I. Rabbi Reuben Katz performed the ceremony.

title: PORTRAITURE AND PERILS
description: IT'S the kind of offer you can't refuse. A friend calls - one of the nicest people you know - and explains that she needs her picture taken in a hurry. She knows you're a capable photographer; you've done it before and she liked the results. How soon does she need it? ''How about tomorrow?''

title: WIRETAPS LINK LARRY DAVIS TO PLOT TO SLAY A MAN AND ELUDE POLICE
description: Larry Davis, who is charged in the murders of four suspected drug dealers, discussed a plot to kill a man who resembled him in order to trick the police and elude one of the biggest manhunts in New York City history.

title: Question Of the Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
description: What will the Yankees changes mean? A little more press coverage for Steinbrenner when halfway through the season he says he's unhappy with Martin's managing and is thinking of replacing him with Reggie Jackson. MITCH NADEL Danville, Pa.

title: GROUP HELPS DISABLED FIND WORK
description: A YOUNG organization is telling employers that disabled people make good workers.

title: Prosecutor Resigns in Florida
description: Florida's first statewide prosecutor has resigned, saying his effectiveness was undermined by an investigation into his purchase of stolen suits from a Miami tailor.

title: Report Links Youths to 40% of Arson Arrests
description: Juveniles accounted for 40 percent of arson arrests last year, with 6.6 percent of those arrests involving children under 10 years old, according to a report by the National Fire Protection Association.

title: McEnroe Sounds Off
description: THEY have their fans, but there are those who resent the likes of pampered professional tennis players who earn huge sums while public servants struggle. There those who think that professional tennis has lost its dignity as a sport and has generated into a crass business enterprise.

title: U.S. Skater Trails Canadian
description: Debi Thomas, who lost her United States and world figure skating championships earlier this year, took a big step toward regaining her former prominence today by winning at Skate Canada, a major pre-Olympic competition.

title: FORDHAM RALLIES BEHIND FRESHMAN
description: Dave Olsakowski, a freshman quarterback who replaced the injured Bob Hagen in the second quarter, ran for one touchdown and passed for another to lead Fordham to a 38-13 victory over Iona in a Liberty Conference game yesterday in the Bronx.

title: GROTON FIGHTING TO REGAIN THE CROAKER
description: THE submarine Croaker is gone from Groton, and Groton wants it back.

title: High-Quality Audio at Midprice
description: THOSE IN SEARCH OF sound equipment at this season will, as always, find optimal dollar values in the midprice range rather than among the least expensive models, which were discussed in this space last week.

title: Patricia Turner Is Married To Reginald E. Kavanaugh
description: Patricia Claire Turner and Reginald Edward Kavanaugh, newspaper reporters in New Jersey, were married yesterday at Three Mile Run Church at East Jersey Olde Towne in Piscataway, N.J., by Judge Richard S. Cohen of the Appellate Division of Superior Court in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: A FAIRY-TALE MUSICAL GROWS UP
description: OFTEN A SONG CAN BE THE KEY TO THE evolution of a musical. With ''Into the Woods,'' the new Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine show opening Thursday at the Martin Beck Theater, the turning point came when the composer wrote the second-act ballad, ''No One Is Alone.'' The song is sung by Cinderella after her prince has disappeared, to Little Red Ridinghood, as they huddle together in the wake of a cataclysm.

title: FUELING THE PASSAROLA
description: LEAD: BALTASAR AND BLIMUNDA By Jose Saramago. Translated by Giovanni Pontiero. 336 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: CLOTHES MAKE THE MEN AND WOMEN AT HISTORIC HUDSON VALLEY
description: LEAD: FINE white linens, printed cotton calicoes, deep mustard-yellow woolens. These fabrics will be transformed into the bonnets and aprons, dresses and jackets worn by the interpreters at Historic Hudson Valley, formerly known as Sleepy Hollow Restorations.

title: MEN AND MOLES
description: As an ardent nature lover and reluctant city dweller, all my sympathy was with the mole.

title: Inspired Islanders Clobber Rangers
description: The result had been decided long ago, but at last the rout was complete. In the locker room, there was talk of redemption and enthusiastic conversation of a renewed commitment. Brent Sutter moved through the motivational mayhem, patched up a cut and left quietly.

title: Tuscany
description: To the Editor: Enthused by the piece about the Fattoria La Loggia in Firidolfi, I reserved and paid by last February the entire amount of the rental for an apartment consisting of two twin-bedded rooms and a living room. Upon arriving at La Loggia at the end of June this year, I was made to wait for Mr. Baruffaldi in the kitchen of the the villa for a good half hour. When he appeared, he told me that due to a ''difficulty'' he could not give us an apartment at La Loggia but that he had reserved one for us 10 kilometers away, which would be ''delightful.'' He added that, of course, the apartment had two bedrooms with twin beds, but . . . that in one of them the beds were ''one on top of the other.'' I realized that these must be two bunks and asked to use his telephone to disinvite a couple we had asked to join us.

title: EXPECTING THE WORST LESSENS THE DISTRESS OF REMODELING
description: BEFORE we decided to have an addition put on our house, we had heard so many tales of horror that I'm still amazed that we went ahead and did it. I put it right up there with our bravest acts, like picketing Richard Nixon in 1968 and adopting a pregnant cat in 1979.

title: N.A.A.C.P. FACES SUIT ON ELECTION
description: LEAD: IN THE 30 years she has been with the N.A.A.C.P. - 22 of them as state president -Irene Hill-Smith said there had been several times when she heard bullets thud against her house in Wenonah and that she had lost count of the telephoned death threats.

title: Race for Kentucky Governor Growing Personal
description: After weeks of debating such serious state issues as a lottery, a budget deficit and taxes, the most expensive gubernatorial campaign in Kentucky history has got back to the sort of personal attacks that have been traditional in the state's politics.

title: Softening Tone, Jackson Delivers Dual Message
description: As he campaigns tirelessly across the country, the Rev. Jesse Jackson is presenting a dual message, as a mainstream politician reaching for the support of a broad spectrum of voters and as a candidate whose positions are well to left of the others seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Synagogue in Mahopac Is Defaced for 3d Time
description: A synagogue in Mahopac, N.Y., was spray painted with swastikas and Nazi slogans Friday night or early yesterday, the third such attack on the synagogue in recent months, the police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-29 Moscow may be adopting a strategy for limiting President Reagan's program for a space-based defense system that is subtler and more diplomatic, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, indicated before leaving Washington. Page 1 A Soviet state of transition, in which the country is wary of its past and uncertain of its future, coincides with Moscow's 70th anniversary under Communism next week. The commemoration promises to be a time of introspection. 1 News analysis: The planned meeting between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan will include the signing of the first treaty banning a category of nuclear arms, but it is less assured of success in substantive terms than symbolic ones. 22 A survey of Moscow residents, using Western polling standards to measure public opinion, has found that they rank Mr. Gorbachev ahead of Stalin in importance to their country and do not expect much from the forthcoming summit meeting. 22 Ethnic friction in Yugoslavia has reached such levels in portions of the country's south that Yugoslavs have begun to talk of the possibility of ''civil war'' between Albanians and Slavs in a land decimated by World War II. 14 Pakistan's perceived tilt toward Iran in the Iran-Iraq war, including criticism of the American buildup in the Persian Gulf without condemnation of Iranian attacks, has provoked expressions of irritation by some senior Administration officials. 26 Communist officials from Tibet accused the Dalai Lama, its exiled spiritual leader, of fomenting the recent Tibetan riots, in the first official Chinese comments to foreign reporters since the unrest last month. 8 Japan will not ban Iranian imports 3 Africa nation opens doors to the French 11 Mozambique rebels burned bus passengers 3 Traumas from the past in Chile 20 Frank talk on AIDS bring praise for Uganda 25 NATIONAL 30-44, 58-60, 65 President Reagan's latest nominee for the Supreme Court, Douglas H. Ginsburg, is likely to find his confirmation hearings focusing on his work as the White House official in charge of Federal regulations, Senate aides said. 1 The President insisted again that the Senate should act quickly on his nomination of Judge Ginsburg, saying in his weekly radio address that he wanted ''no delays to gear up opposition or support.'' 35 Iowa's voters are more liberal than other Americans on many campaign issues, they like President Reagan less and they are skeptical of promises candidates make to them about farm spending, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows. 1 Lowering cost-of-living increases in some Government programs, which could affect pensions and veterans benefits, was discussed by negotiators from Congress and the White House as a deficit-cutting measure, officials said. 1 The Rev. Jesse Jackson's message to voters is a dual one, as a mainstream politician reaching for support from a broad spectrum and as a candidate whose positions are well to the left of the other Democratic Presidential contenders. 38 In the Pacific Northwest's drought, the worst since records have been kept, stranded salmon languish, seedlings die in the ground and residents brace for expected multimillion-dollar losses as the browning of the region continues. 30 Rise in executions widens debate 30 66 injured in toxic leak 30 Ex-Wedtech official testifies 37 Nastiness in Kentucky campaign 38 A town that likes a good fight 42 REGIONAL 46-56, 61-64, 66, 80 The New York Yankees will continue to play in the Bronx for at least 45 more years under terms of an agreement announced last night. The accord ended 15 months of negotiations and headed off a move of the club to New Jersey. 1 A drop in the rate of subway felonies has been recorded so far this year by New York City's transit police department, which is in the midst of a major reorganization that puts more authority in the hands of its borough commanders. 1 A homosexual studies conference was held at Yale University, a month after a Wall Street Journal article calling Yale ''a gay school'' sparked a campuswide controversy and attracted nationwide attention. 53 Governor Kean is traveling across New Jersey with only days remaining before elections on a quest for something that has eluded him in his six years in office: Republican control of the state Legislature. 46 A presentencing hearing for a judge who resigned after pleading guilty to a Federal racketeering charge brought testimony that he had sought to harass and evict elderly tenants in a rent-stabilized building he owned in Queens. 56 Clash of styles in Nassau race 46 Mario Merola eulogized as a man of conscience 52 Karpov and Kasparov agree to draw 52

title: Train Crash Kills Crewman
description: A slow-moving freight train struck a tanker truck filled with 8,000 gallons of gasoline Friday, killing a train crewman and injuring four other men, officials said. The crash ignited an explosion and fire that shot flames 100 feet into the air; smoke could be seen 16 miles away, witnesses said. The truck was straddling the railroad tracks, waiting to turn onto a highway, when the train hit it, splitting the vehicle in two, the authorities said.

title: SHAKE-UP IN THE FRONT OFFICELEAVE SOME HOT SEATS EMPTY
description: SEVERAL winters ago, Dave Bristol was dismissed as the San Francisco manager on his way into the managers' luncheon at the annual December baseball meetings. Two winters later, the managers gathered for their luncheon with reporters who covered their teams, but the Yankees' table had an empty chair. The Yankees, at the time, had no manager.

title:
GARDENING;
QUESTIONS OF THE GARDENERIN AUTUMN
description: LEAD: PROFESSIONAL horticulturists have learned to expect a wave of questions each fall, many of which are asked year after year. It might be helpful to list some of these questions and answers.

title: ADVERSARIES AT THE START
description: PRINTERS AND PRESS FREEDOM The Ideology of Early American Journalism. By Jeffery A. Smith. 233 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title:
GARDENING;
QUESTIONS OF THE GARDENERIN AUTUMN
description: LEAD: PROFESSIONAL horticulturists have learned to expect a wave of questions each fall, many of which are asked year after year. It might be helpful to list some of these questions and answers.

title: Midnight Comes, And King's a Bullet
description: Bernard King, once the pride of the Knicks, officially became a Washington Bullet last night.

title: TRENDY MOUNTAIN BIKES POSE UNEXPECTED THREAT TO WILDERNESS TRAILS
description: THE bicycle once seemed the environmentalist's dream machine, a solution to air pollution, traffic jams and flabby muscles. But that was before bicycle makers here in Marin County added gears to some old fat-tire Schwinns and launched the latest rage to roll out of California: the mountain bike, a machine capable of climbing trails and scaring hikers as it roars like a roller coaster in a cloud of dust.

title: Directors' Operas: Sport for Lazy Minds
description: AS I SAT AT ''AIDA'' IN HOUSTON the other evening watching a throng of dangerously inept spear carriers trying to persuade me that they were ferocious Egyptian warriors celebrating a victory over the Ethiopians, I was struck by how much energy and money opera houses regularly expend nowadays to dispel illusion. This triumphal scene, staged by Pier Luigi Pizzi, was disarmingly witty here and there (four huge toy elephants on wheels took part in the battle ballet) and far less inanely pictorial than most. But, it did indulge in its share of self-defeating, literal detail. Perhaps the ''Aida'' public, reared on such mock pageantry, will have it no other way.

title: Home Prices Surge Upward
description: THIS sleepy town of two general stores, three gas stations and 1,600 residents is experiencing an upsurge in new home construction.

title: Poll Finds Iowa Voters More Liberal Than Nation
description: Iowa's highly influential voters are more liberal than other Americans on many campaign issues, they like President Reagan less and they are skeptical of the farm spending the candidates regularly promise them, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Margaret M. Hearn Engaged to Steven P. Fischer
description: The engagement of Margaret Mary Hearn, the manager of training and development at the Harvard Community Health Plan in Boston, and Steven Patrick Fischer, the chief financial officer and the vice president of financial services at the Milton (Mass.) Medical Center, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George H. Hearn of Garden City, L.I., and Point Lookout, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald C. Fischer of Cincinnati.

title: PRINCETON DEFENSE HALTS PENN
description: Princeton, controlling the game on offense and defense, beat Penn today, 17-7, the Tigers' first victory over the Quakers since 1982.

title: Sipping Whiskies
description: LIKE FINE WINE, PREMIUM WHISKY should be sipped and savored. And, like fine wine, each variety and brand of premium whisky is distinguished by its own color, bouquet, flavor, texture and lingering taste.

title: BABY BOOM HITTING NURSERY SCHOOLS
description: LEAD: NOVEMBER is the month many Westchester parents begin searching for the right preschool program for their children for the following September. But Carol Fine, a Chappaqua mother, doesn't have to worry . Last winter, when her youngest son was 6 months old, she registered him for The Pace Little School, a program in Briarcliff that he will enter in

title: Greek Role as Refugee Haven Brings Problems
description: For seven days or so, until he seemed too tired to do so, Newi Celali told his story to anyone who would listen as he protested his plight by staging a solitary and largely unnoticed hunger strike outside the United Nations refugee office here.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, Peter Ackroyd's essay about Oscar Wilde in The Times Book Review today quotes the Marquess of Queensberry incorrectly in some copies. His note to Wilde read, ''To Oscar Wilde posing somdomite [ sic ] .''

title: INTERIOR DESIGNERS AND WHAT THEY DO
description: Re: ''Decorate Till You Drop,'' Long Island Sound, Oct. 11: Barbara Klaus's article on her ''design experience'' is little more than ''kaffeeklatsch'' humor to be relegated to her local circle of acquaintances, hardly worthy of the space it received. She appears to have very little factual information on the design industry as a professional organization.

title: Jordana Pomeroy To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lee Harris Pomeroy of New York and Garrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jordana Pomeroy to Tyler Anbinder, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Anbinder of New York and Washington, Conn. The couple plan to wed May 22.

title: HEWLETT ASKS AID TO SAVE OLD HOUSE
description: LEAD: FORTY-SEVEN years before the Constitution was ratified in 1787, the Hewlett family built a small Dutch-style farmhouse on what was then called Long Neck Road on land that was theirs under a 1650 grant from the British King. The land was to become the community of Hewlett in southwestern Nassau County.

title: TRANSIT NOTES
description: LEAD: PATH trains between Hoboken and New York City are running more frequently during rush hours now that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has placed 85 new cars and 125 rebuilt ones into service.

title: Fashion; IMITATION OF LIFE
description: FABRICS THAT ARE STRIPED, SPOTTED AND scaled with animal and reptile prints never seem to fade into extinction. But there are times when their presence is as difficult to ignore as a thundering stampede. Now, for instance.

title: World Cup Belongs in U.S.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MEN AND MOLES
description: As a suburban homeowner with a ''mole problem,'' I found Richard B. Elsberry's ''A Farewell to Arms'' right on the mark (About Men, Sept. 27). As the movie ''Caddie Shack'' demonstrated as well, there is no way to win the battle when trying to eliminate the mole. A good sense of humor will go a long way. MICHAEL S. APTON Setauket, N.Y.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
SPORTS
description: LEAD: Los Angeles Dodgers/Dodger Stadium: The First 25 Years Scotch Sports Collectors Edition. 70 minutes. $19.95. This celebratory video - a rundown of the 25 years the Dodgers have played in Dodger Stadium - is probably for Dodger fans only. The first part, which deals with the Brooklyn Dodgers' arrival in Los Angeles and how the ranking locals took them to heart, can be flashed forward for maximum enjoyment.

title: Group Shares Lotto Jackpot
description: A hectic, record-setting week for the Connecticut state lottery came to an end today when it was disclosed that three winning tickets worth more than $7.5 million each were sold in Newington, Hartford and Milford. Al Carbone, 42 years old, of Newington, owner of Carbone's Auto Body, apparently holds one of the winning tickets along with nine employees, relatives and friends. The 10 people chipped in $50 apiece for $500 worth of Lotto tickets and will divide the prize equally, said Virginia Carbone, 35, Mr. Carbone's wife.

title: RACING FOR LIFE
description: I read with mixed emotions Joshua Korman's article about heart transplants (''Racing for Life,'' Sept. 20). Andrew Dela Pena is a beautiful child and certainly has the right to a full life.

title: 'The Foreigner,' Romantic Comedy
description: IT has been tough going at the Studio Theater recently, as this once innovative, adventuresome theater has turned to a more lucrative schedule of producing lightweight work with amateur casts. Fortunately, light entertainment can, when it is well done, make for a delightful evening in the theater, and the current production of ''The Foreigner,'' by Larry Shue, is as good as it can be.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: A New Floor For the Dollar?

title: A Day or a Night At the Ball Park?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the music page of the Arts and Leisure section today about the soprano Elly Ameling misidentifies the pianist who will accompany her at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. He is Rudolf Jansen, not Dalton Baldwin.

title: MOZART MILESTONE SLIPS BY IN PRAGUE
description: With a minimum of fanfare, Prague let one of the great anniversaries of operatic history slip by on Thursday night. Two hundred years ago, in this city, Mozart conducted the first performance of ''Don Giovanni.''

title: WHY VICTORIAN DRAB? TRY TANGERINE GABLES!
description: IT seems that some of the preservationists in my cliffside village are having a midlife crisis. Finding themselves in a rut, they have chosen to change their colors. As far as I'm concerned, it's not a moment too soon.

title: By TODD S. PURDUM
description: A 22-YEAR-OLD white man and two white women are walking down a street in Brooklyn. Five black youths approach.

title: Streetscape: The Corn Exchange Bank; A 'Noble Monument to Thrift' With an Unusually Modern Air
description: MOST landmark controversies close with a bang not a whimper, the end of a crescendo of angry public hearings and threatened lawsuits. But the old Corn Exchange Bank's unusual skyscraper complex at 11-15 William Street, in an area with more businesses than block associations, is scheduled for demolition without a determination by the Landmarks Preservation Commission on whether it is a landmark.

title: Nassau Executive Foes Clash in Style and Views
description: The battle for Nassau County Executive matches two candidates with clashing styles and divergent views on the future of the county.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
PRESERVE THE PREPOSITION!
description: LEAD: ''YOU'VE come a long way since you graduated high school,'' began a letter sent to my daughter by one of the largest communication companies in the country. Had someone inadvertently left out the word from before high school? I doubt it. Similar omissions in speech have now turned up in writing, business writing at that.

title: 'The Bonfire of the Vanities'
description: Now comes Tom Wolfe, aging enfant terrible, with his first novel, (his first novel!), six hundred and fifty-nine pages of raw energy about New York City and various of its inhabitants - a big, bitter, funny, craftily plotted book that grabs you by the lapels and won't let go. As in much of his other work, such as ''The Right Stuff,'' Mr. Wolfe's strategy is to somehow batter the reader into submission, using an incantatory repetition of certain emblematic phrases, (HIS FIRST NOVEL!), detailed description of people's clothing, hyperbole, interior monologue whenever he feels like it, and various other New Journalism devices he is apparently too fond of to give up. What is amazing is that he gets away with it. I read ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' straight through, in two sessions on two consecutive days, and enjoyed it enormously. It swept me right up. When he writes about process he knows what he is writing about, whether it's the Wall Street bond market, the Bronx District Attorney's Office, print and television journal-ism, or the working habits of sleazy lawyers -the man knows how to prepare and he knows how to research. As well, he knows how to tell a story, and how to make us laugh, qualities not always present in the work of some of the more polished, more literary or ultimately more ambitious novelists of his generation.

title: About Men; One Man's Kids
description: I TEACH FIRST GRADERS. I LIVE in a world of skinned knees, double-knotted shoelaces, riddles that I've heard a dozen times, stale birthday cakes, hurt feelings, wandering stories and one lost shoe (''and if you don't find it my mother'll kill me''). My work is dominated by 6-year-olds. It's 10:45, the middle of snack, and I'm helping Emily open her milk carton. She has already tried the other end without success, and now there's so much paint and ink on the carton from her fingers that I'm not sure she should drink it at all. But I open it. Then I turn to help Scott clean up some milk he has just spilled onto Rebecca's whale crossword puzzle.

title: Vermont's Homeless Double
description: Vermont's homeless population has more than doubled in three years, largely because of soaring housing costs, a new state report says. The surcosts, a new state report says. The survey of services for the homeless also said that in Bennington, Franklin, Grand Isle and Essex counties, there are no homeless shelters. The report by the Agency of Development and Community Affairs estimated that 3,600 people in the state were without a home at some time.

title: Colombia Says Rebels Killed Ten Policemen
description: Ten police officers, including a captain, were killed when their vehicle was blown up by a mine in an ambush by guerrillas in northeastern Colombia, a military spokesman said today.

title: Jazz: Buck Clayton Band
description: THE 13-piece band that Buck Clayton is leading at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue at 17th Street, through today reflects his years of experience as one of the major stars of Count Basie's orchestra during its rise to fame in the late 1930's and early 40's and his work as a composer and arranger that began in his Basie days and has continued ever since. But given this foundation, the essential spark of this band comes from the enthusiastic mix of youth and experience that Mr. Clayton has brought together.

title: APARTHEID'S PRISONER
description: LEAD: FOR NELSON MANDELA Edited by Jacques Derrida and Mustapha Tlili. 256 pp. New York: Seaver Books/ Henry Holt & Company. $17.95.

title: A WELL-STAGED EVENT
description: THE world team championships that ended in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, eight days ago were, perhaps, the most completely satisfactory ever staged.

title: Interesting Facts Finally Noticed
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHITMAN HOME IS SITE OF RALLY FOR BOND ISSUE
description: LEAD: A SIX-CITY series of whistle-stop news conferences to promote the Green Acres, cultural centers and historic preservation bond issue paused in Walt Whitman's backyard here earlier this month so Governor Kean could come aboard.

title: DINING OUT MEXICAN, WITH ALL THE TRIMMINGS
description: ONE swallow does not a taste trend set, but Pancho's and Gringo's in Brookfield shows promise of setting new standards of authenticity for Mexican restaurants in Connecticut.

title: Whose Words Are They, Anyway?
description: IN the past 20 years, J. D. Salinger has undoubtedly become the most famous - as well as the most read - recluse in the world. He has rarely been sighted in public, has not given an interview since 1953 and, although he continues to write fiction, hasn't published any of it since a short story appeared in The New Yorker in 1965. But even in his obsession with privacy, the author of ''The Catcher in the Rye'' continues to exert a profound influence on American letters. Last month the Supreme Court upheld (by refusing to review) a Federal appeals court decision that barred the publication of an unauthorized biography of him. The appeals court had held that by quoting from, and paraphrasing, large portions of his unpublished letters the British literary critic Ian Hamilton had effectively appropriated Mr. Salinger's work.

title: Question Of the Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
description: Meddlesome George and Billy the Unprintable are bad news. How can the Yankees - in spite of their enormous talent and character - be winners with a pair of losers calling the shots? L. A. BROOKS Lancaster, Pa.

title:
GARDENING;
QUESTIONS OF THE GARDENERIN AUTUMN
description: LEAD: PROFESSIONAL horticulturists have learned to expect a wave of questions each fall, many of which are asked year after year. It might be helpful to list some of these questions and answers.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The brick fireplace in our home had been painted by previous owners. We want to remove the paint and restore the natural brick. What is the best way to do this?

title: TURTLE BACK PURSUES 'STATE ZOO' STATUS
description: DESPITE criticism that it is not happening fast enough, Turtle Back Zoo on Northfield Avenue here is said to be on its way to becoming the official state zoo, a modernized showplace comprising only species and habitats native to New Jersey.

title:
ART;
SHOW BY 6 ABSTRACTIONISTS IN SEARCH OF A STATEMENT
description: LEAD: ''STATEMENTS IN THE ABSTRACT,'' the six-artist exhibition at the East End Arts and Humanities Council in Riverhead, suggests by its title that the featured works have something to say, and indeed they do. Some communicate their message with more authority than others, but all deserve a fair hearing, for this is the strongest show the council has mounted in some time.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Amnesty Offered By Harrisburg

title: THE GUIDE
description: PRINTMAKING TODAY Printmaking has come a long way since flat photographic-images were reproduced by the thousands at low cost, permitting people of limited means to own a ''work of art.'' The Katonah Gallery's new exhibit, ''View From a Workshop: Selections From Tyler Graphics 1974-1987'' will ''give people a sense of how much time and effort goes into prints today, and how original each print has become; It takes weeks and months to create a single print,'' said Carolyn Mandelker, publicist for the gallery.

title: BEIJING IS GLIDING EVER MORE WESTWARD
description: IF not capitalism, at least a capitalist ethic is seeping into the marrow of China.

title:
GARDENING;
QUESTIONS OF THE GARDENERIN AUTUMN
description: LEAD: PROFESSIONAL horticulturists have learned to expect a wave of questions each fall, many of which are asked year after year. It might be helpful to list some of these questions and answers.

title: Greece to Study Charges of Bugging the Press and Politicians
description: A parliamentary panel is to investigate opposition charges that Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's supporters ordered the bugging of telephones used by journalists and politicians, including those of former allies in the Greek Communist Party.

title: Dance: Susan Murphy's Trapeze Program
description: SUSAN MURPHY called her program of trapeze-dances ''Up Is a Good Place,'' on Thursday at the Anita Shapolsky Gallery, and ''up'' did look like a serene place to be.

title: Theater
description: The Wooster Group, the SoHo-based experimental collective that has nurtured talents as diverse as the monologuist Spalding Gray and the film star Willem Dafoe, remains one of the last bastions of intense avant-garde seriousness in the contemporary theater. Guided by its intrepid director Elizabeth LeCompte, the troupe has refined a non-narrative style of theatrical collage that forces unrelated texts and styles of performance into an often jarring collision in which they thematically amplify and comment on one another.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'DISTINGUISHED ARTISTS' Just in case anyone has any doubt about what Oyster Bay thinks of the performers it books for its music series, the town provides a lavish hint. The programs come under the umbrella of Distinguished Artists Concerts, and today, when the current series opens, that distinction falls upon Mike Carubia and the Great South Dixeland Jazz Band. A familiar fixture on the local popular music scene, the band specializes in traditional jazz, with some swing and be-bop added for variety. Today, when it appears at 3 P.M. at the Hicksville Public Library, 169 Jerusalem Avenue, the program includes ''Basin Street Blues,'' ''Sweet Lorraine'' and ''Avalon.'' All 20 concerts in the series, which continues Saturday at 8:15 P.M. with the violinist Beverly Somach at the Bethpage Public Library, 47 Powell Avenue, are free. Subsequent performers will include Laura Hamilton, violinist; the American Chamber Ensemble and Robert Swenson, tenor, in free performances at libraries and halls. ALL TALK

title: WHERE HAS ALL THE FLOATING ENERGY GONE?
description: LEAD: DOWN AND IN Life in the Underground. By Ronald Sukenick. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: Tuscany
description: To the Editor: An article entitled ''Fattoria La Loggia is a farm that also welcomes guests'' appeared in the Travel section on Oct. 12, 1986. It was written by Mary Davis Suro and described a captivating scene midst the Tuscan hills of Italy - ''a setting evocative of Medici banquets and medieval hunting parties . . . small stucco cottages for visitors . . . decorated with 19th-century antiques and equipped with modern kitchens and bathrooms . . . eggs, milk and poultry delivered to your doorstep each morning . . . bread and cake baked each morning in the medieval brick oven that is adjacent to the main villa.''

title: Involvement Found Up Among Reform Jews
description: A new study of Reform Jewish leaders has found them more religiously involved than their parents and generally more liberal on social issues than other American Jews.

title: Now Just Suppose Mrs. Reagan Had Been a Medicare Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Leinsdorf Offers Mozart and Stravinsky
description: FOR his current New York Philharmonic subscription program, Erich Leinsdorf has chosen to bracket Mozart with Stravinksy, and in particular early Stravinsky in late revisions. This interesting concept -Mr. Leinsdorf has long been about the most stimulating program-builder among present-day conductors - allows one to hear Mozart refracted through the prism of a young Stravinsky colored by his own mature reflections (as well as the hyper-modernist clarity of Avery Fisher Hall's acoustics).

title: Debra Lynn Feldman Marries Bruce Kaliner
description: The St. Regis-Sheraton in Manhattan was the setting last evening for the marriage of Debra Lynn Feldman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Feldman of Boca Raton, Fla., and Bruce Richard Kaliner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kaliner of Purchase, N.Y., and Boca Raton. Rabbi David Benedict performed the ceremony.

title: Alaska Outbreak May Signal What's Ahead in Flu Season
description: Federal flu-watchers say the Taiwan flu, which plagued the nation last winter, may not be the dominant strain this winter.

title: Escaping To the Freedom Of the Seas
description: If the addicts of ocean cruising, those who need their marine fix two or three times a year, were to devise an emblem, it would surely feature an empty suitcase.

title: Nicaragua Leader Seeks More Aid in Moscow
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra departed today for Moscow, where he is expected to seek a renewal of Soviet aid commitments.

title: The Reagan-Bush Accord
description: Vice President George Bush is constantly asked to demonstrate how he is independent of President Reagan. When the question came up again in the Republican candidates' debate in Houston last Wednesday, his answer pro-duced both an exclamation mark and a question mark.

title: Providence Rallies Around Targets of Anti-Semitic Incidents
description: An outbreak of vandalism against synagogues and Jewish-owned businesses in Providence, R.I., last month raised concern there about anti-Semitism but also brought support from other religious, ethic and racial groups for those who were the objects of the acts. .

title: What's Doing in Sydney
description: Five years ago, when tourism to Australia was just beginning to take off, the Australian writer Germaine Greer observed that ''what most people mean when they say they'd like to go to Australia is that they'd like to go to Sydney and its suburb, Ayers Rock.''

title: Works in Progress; THE GIFT OF GARB
description: ''WE FIGURED 250 COSTUMES, give or take a few,'' says Patricia Zipprodt. A celebrated costume designer whose achievements include three Tony Awards, she's referring to the mammoth production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' that the New York City Ballet is planning for an unspecified future season. Lincoln Kirstein and George Balanchine, co-founders of the City Ballet, conceived of the project more than a decade ago. After Balanchine died in 1983, Ms. Zipprodt says, ''Lincoln wished to bring it to fruition. He got in touch with me two years ago.''

title: 66 Are Injured By Toxic Leak At Texas Plant
description: Sixty-six people were seriously injured and 3,000 residents fled their homes Friday after a leaking tank at an oil refinery sent up a cloud of toxic acid vapor.

title: HALPIN: RELENTLESS CHALLENGER
description: PATRICK G. HALPIN, the first Democrat to win in his State Assembly district in 112 years, shocked the political establishment in Suffolk County four years ago by coming within 22,000 votes of defeating the incumbent County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan.

title: Streaks Continue
description: Bergen Catholic's strong team kept two impressive streaks alive yesterday as it turned back St. Joseph of Montvale, 17-0, at Oradell.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
ART
description: LEAD: Ming Garden Home Vision. 28 minutes. $29.95. This is a gentle documentary about the installation of the Ming Garden in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1980. The first permanent cultural exchange between China and the United States, the garden was created using ancient methods and designs by 21 Chinese craftsmen with a team of

title: U.S. Sees 'Troubling' Tilt by Pakistan to Iran
description: Some senior Administration officials have expressed irritation over what they call Pakistan's tilt toward Iran in the Iran-Iraq war, manifested most recently in criticism of the Reagan Administration's military buildup in the Persian Gulf without condemnation of Iranian attacks on shipping.

title: A KOREAN DIPLOMAT RANSOMED IN BEIRUT IS SILENT ON CAPTIVITY
description: A South Korean diplomat taken hostage in Lebanon 21 months ago and freed after payment of a ransom arrived in Geneva today, looking exhausted and declining to speak with reporters who greeted his plane.

title: YANKEES TO STAY IN NEW YORK CITY
description: New York Yankee baseball in the Bronx, a 64-year tradition that spans 22 world championships, will continue for at least 45 more years under terms of an agreement announced last night.

title: Howard Beach Lawyers to Attack 2 Accounts
description: Defense lawyers in the Howard Beach murder trial have signaled the ways they will attack the accounts of two key prosecution witnesses who are expected to testify this week.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bedminster $172,000 7 Wendover Court 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old condominium; fireplace, 2 decks, C/A; monthly maintenance $91.50; taxes $1,462. Livingston $400,000 32 Knollwood Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old colonial; family room, C/A, fenced yard, eat-in kitchen; taxes $3,921. Millburn $175,000 28 Glen Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old ranch; patio, fireplace, 1-car garage; taxes $2,470. Newton $145,000 Hibler Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, 2-zone heating, 2-car garage; taxes $1,931. Scotch Plains $179,900 423 Warren Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, full basement; taxes $2,020. West Orange $208,000 15 Porter Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old expanded ranch; den, finished basement, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $3,306. OTHER AREAS New Rochelle, N.Y. $287,500 59 Darling Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, terrace, skylight, playroom; taxes $3,621. Yonkers, N.Y. $220,000 42 Custer Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial; family room, screened porch; taxes $3,444. Bellport, L.I. $120,500 17 Third Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,200.

title: For Coaches, Ties Don't Always Bind
description: EARLIER this season, Florida State tried a 2-point conversion with 42 seconds remaining in its football game against Miami. The 2-pointer failed, and Coach Bobby Bowden's Seminoles lost, 26-25.

title: THE ECONOMIC HISTORIANS' VIEW: Comparing the Collapses; C.P. Kindleberger: Watch Prayerfully
description: IN the cascade of comment on the stock market debacle of the last two weeks, it is hard for an economic historian who has written on 1929 and on 18th and 19th century booms and crashes to find something to say that is not entirely banal. Nonetheless I try:

title: CONNECITCUT GUIDE
description: 'SHOWMAN AND SCIENTIST' ''The Showman and the Scientist,'' a new exhibition that will run from Saturday through Feb. 8 at the Yale Peabody Museum, pairs the showman P. T.Barnum, the founder of the P. T. Barnum Museum in Bridgeport, and O. C. Marsh, a paleontologist and the nephew of George Peabody, the founder of the Peabody museum Disparate as their occupations and aims were, the two men frequently found themselves competing to acquire the same objects - Barnum seeking oddities for exploitation in his circus, Marsh coveting them in the name of scientific research. Between them, they managed to amass a treasury of natural and man-made objects worth millions of dollars.

title: HELPING THE POOR IN TRENTON TO HELP THEMSELVES
description: LEAD: FOR 17 years, the Rev. Brian McCormick has been telling some of this city's poorest familes that they can own their own homes if they will work together and help one another.

title: ITALIAN FOOD IN AN UNLIKELY SPOT
description: GREAT RIVER, known for trees, country clubs, the Connetquot River and nearby Heckscher State Park, is an unlikely spot for a restaurant. Monte Cristo Italian Restaurant and a nearby deli are the only beacons of light, as early autumn darkness settles among the houses and trees.

title: CRIME
description: By now Jonathan Valin's series about Harry Stoner, the Cincinnati private eye, is well established. It started in 1980 with ''The Lime Pit,'' and the new FIRE LAKE (Delacorte, $14.95) is the seventh Stoner case. Stoner is in the classic tradition of the American private eye. He is a big, tough man who does not throw his strength around but nevertheless is not one to be trifled with. He is dogged, competent, rather sensitive and completely honest. And since Mr. Valin is an expert writer who provides coherent plots and believable dialogue, it comes as no surprise that his Stoner books have taken hold.

title: WILDE IN NEW YORK: BEAUTY PACKED THEM IN
description: THE Arizona docked in New York Harbor on the evening of Jan. 2, 1882. It was too late to clear quarantine until the following morning. The press, avid to see Oscar Wilde, could not wait. Enterprising reporters ''came out of the sea,'' as Wilde picturesquely noted, their pens still wet with brine. In fact, they chartered a launch to bring them aboard. Wilde was in the captain's cabin and emerged to greet them clad in a great green coat that hung down almost to his feet. It was subjected to close inspection: the collar and cuffs were trimmed with seal or otter, and so was the material for the round cap, variously described as a smoking cap or a turban. Beneath the coat could be discerned a shirt with a wide Lord Byron collar and a sky-blue necktie, vaguely reminiscent of the costume of a modern mariner. He wore patent-leather shoes on his small feet.

title: Miss Timmons to Wed T. F. Gibson 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Timmons of Washington have announced the engagement of Mr. Timmons's daughter Kimberly Anne Timmons to Thomas Fenner Gibson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gibson Jr. of Indianapolis. The couple plan to marry in February.

title: Wildlife Refuge Named For Stewart McKinney
description: A Federal wildlife refuge consisting of four islands in Long Island Sound was renamed and rededicated today as the Stewart B. McKinney National Wildlife Refuge, in honor of the late Representative, who led efforts to preserve the area.

title: Ann Walden and Scott Corwin to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. William D. Walden of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Elizabeth Walden, to Scott Laurence Corwin, a son of Mrs. Herbert M. Greenberg of Princeton, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass.

title: DOCUMENTARY
description: World Without Walls: Beryl Markham's African Memoir Narrated by Diana Quick and Lyle Talbot. Wild Wing Productions. 60 minutes. $29.95. Beryl Markham, who in her youth looked as striking as Vanessa Redgrave, died last year in Nairobi. Suddenly, she is more acclaimed in death than in life. Her memoir, ''West With the Night,'' rediscovered and reprinted after 40 years, has been on the best-seller charts all during 1987, with a half-million copies in print from North Point Press of Berkeley, Calif. In a letter to his publisher in the 1930's, Ernest Hemingway once wrote that Miss Markham could ''write circles around all of us who consider ourselves as writers.''

title: MANAGING AN ORCHESTRA: A FEW 'RELATED POINTS'
description: Congratulations on Robert Sherman's ''How an Orchestra Fell Silent: Postlude'' [ Oct. 11 ] . Mr. Sherman goes beyond fund-raising to highlight critical, common problems of nonprofit management.

title: 'The Bonfire of the Vanities'
description: Now comes Tom Wolfe, aging enfant terrible, with his first novel, (his first novel!), six hundred and fifty-nine pages of raw energy about New York City and various of its inhabitants - a big, bitter, funny, craftily plotted book that grabs you by the lapels and won't let go. As in much of his other work, such as ''The Right Stuff,'' Mr. Wolfe's strategy is to somehow batter the reader into submission, using an incantatory repetition of certain emblematic phrases, (HIS FIRST NOVEL!), detailed description of people's clothing, hyperbole, interior monologue whenever he feels like it, and various other New Journalism devices he is apparently too fond of to give up. What is amazing is that he gets away with it. I read ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' straight through, in two sessions on two consecutive days, and enjoyed it enormously. It swept me right up. When he writes about process he knows what he is writing about, whether it's the Wall Street bond market, the Bronx District Attorney's Office, print and television journal-ism, or the working habits of sleazy lawyers -the man knows how to prepare and he knows how to research. As well, he knows how to tell a story, and how to make us laugh, qualities not always present in the work of some of the more polished, more literary or ultimately more ambitious novelists of his generation.

title: AMNESTY FOLLOWS SLAYING OF RIGHTS LEADER
description: THE National Assembly of El Salvador last week approved an amnesty that will free hundreds of leftist guerrillas and prevent the prosecution of any members of rightist death squads. The law was approved the day after the murder of a prominent advocate of human rights, Herbert Anaya Sanabria.

title:
NOTEBOOK: COLUMBUS, GA.;
Arsenal Place Sets the Pace
description: LEAD: WHEN Ralph Cole, of the Winn Development Company in Boston, decided to turn a century-old armaments factory into an office complex, he did not realize he was changing more than the character of a dormant downtown block.

title: WHY BLACK ENGLISH DOESN'T ADD UP
description: TWICE AS LESS Black English and the Performance of Black Students in Mathematics and Science. By Eleanor Wilson Orr. 240 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $15.95.

title: Ruthann Pritchard to Wed in February
description: The engagement of Ruthann Mary Pritchard to Howard Alan Silverstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Silverstein of New York and Delray Beach, Fla., has been announced by the future bride's mother, Margaret Pritchard of Oakville, Ontario. A February wedding is planned.

title: THE MINNESOTA TUNES THE NEW YORK BOY
description: WHEN Sweet Music Viola - who, it happens, never played a musical instrument in his life, other than to drum fastballs into a catcher's mitt - came to town the other day to pick up a car from Sport magazine for being selected the Most Valuable Player in the World Series, he touched on differences between life in Queens, where he grew up, and life in Minnesota, where he is now employed.

title: SOUTH DAKOTA MUSIC SHRINE
description: LEAD: The signs luring the driver from Route 29 in the southeastern corner of South Dakota to the Shrine to Musice Museum in Vermillion are enigmatic, much harder to focus on than the billboards advertising car dealerships and fast-food chains.

title: ROCK 'N' ROLL PILGRIM
description: LEAD: NOT FADE AWAY By Jim Dodge. 291 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. Paper, $6.95.

title: Douglas Yeager Wed To Rev. Linda Higgins
description: The Rev. Linda Higgins, the daughter of Betty Higgins of New York and the late Elliott Higgins, was married yesterday to Douglas Yeager, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Yeager of Paramus, N.J. The Rev. Patricia DeJong, assisted by the Rev. Robin Bickel, performed the United Church of Christ ceremony at the Riverside Church in New York.

title: Nehemiah Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Where a Good Squabble Mellows the Ozark Chill
description: Now that the seasonal tide of tourism is starting to ebb, it is time for this town to turn its attention, once again, to contention.

title: SOUTH; AUBURN ROUTS FLORIDA AND LIMITS SMITH TO 72 YARDS
description: Jeff Burger, who regained his eligibility last Thursday, passed for 218 yards and a touchdown to lead Auburn to a 29-6 rout of Florida in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: PINPIN CHOSE THE GOOD LIFE
description: LEAD: HOME AGAIN By Jose Yglesias. 180 pp. New York: Arbor House. $15.95.

title: MOVIES
description: 52 Pickup Starring Roy Scheider and Ann-Margret. Directed by John Frankenheimer. Media Home Entertainment. 111 minutes. $69.95. In this movie, based on the Elmore Leonard novel of the same name (and with a script co-written by Mr. Leonard), Roy Scheider is a steel executive who's being blackmailed for his fling with a young woman he met in a bar. It's hard to imagine a good time to be blackmailed, but for Scheider, this is the all-time worst: his loving wife, played by Ann-Margret, has just decided to run for the City Council.

title: Traficant of Ohio Planning Regional Presidential Effort
description: Representative James Traficant Jr. has decided to mount a regional campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination that will put him on the ballot in ''rust belt'' states like Pennsylvania and his native Ohio.

title: Signing Up Einstein
description: To the Editor:

title: Stepping Up the War on Discrimination
description: THE tactics used to combat housing discrimination in New York City are expanding, city officials and fair-housing watchdog groups report.

title: CARING FOR THE CONDOR
description: Is it possible that the endangered condors are unsuccessful in mating because of those awful names, AC-4 and UN-1?

title: SEPTEMBER COUPLES
description: SURVIVING THE SEASONS By Fern Kupfer. 327 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $17.95.

title:
DINING OUT;
LITTLE OLD MEXICO IN MEYERSVILLE
description: LEAD: MEXICAN restaurants in New Jersey seem to be undergoing a metamorphosis, just as Chinese restaurants did a few years ago. At one time, most Chinese restaurants primarily served chop suey and the blander, less-authentic Cantonese dishes. Then along came Szechuan, Hunan, Peking, Mandarin and the glories of true Cantonese dishes, and Chinese restaurants were revitalized.

title: TOWN TO VOTE ON WARD PROPOSAL
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of the Town of Southampton will vote Tuesday on a proposition that would make Southampton the only town on Long Island, and only the 10th in the state, to have a ward system of government.

title: GRUNEWALD: OUTSPOKEN ADVERSARY
description: AS a trial lawyer and formal Federal prosecutor, Raymond B. Grunewald has earned a reputation as a tough and savvy courtroom foe.

title: Anne Garland Is Married To S. M. Collins, a Lawyer
description: Anne Frances Garland and Steven Morse Collins were married yesterday at the Northside United Methodist Church in Atlanta by the Rev. William Floyd.

title: Miss Amoscato, Lawyer, Marries
description: Barbara-Jo Amoscato, a lawyer in the investment law division of the New England in Boston, formerly the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, and James T. Sabaitis, an associate in the Boston law firm of Csaplar & Bok, were married yesterday. The Rev. Kevin Hanbury performed the ceremony at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J.

title: Data Update
description: HOUSING COSTS/N.Y.-Northeast N.J. area*

title:
ART;
RETROSPECTIVE OF IDA APPLEBROOG AT THE WADSWORTH ATHENEUM
description: LEAD: THE compact retrospective of the work of Ida Applebroog in Matrix, the gallery of the Wadsworth Antheneum devoted to spotlighting contemporary artists who cause comment and controversy, is there for more than its intrinsic qualities. The major attraction at the Hartford museum currently is a survey of art made by American women through 1930; this is an absorbing show, but quite well behaved.

title: Why It's Time for Public TV to Go Private
description: PUBLIC TELEVISION IS SUP-posed to be in crisis: Where is its soul, its reason, its purpose, the spirit that would make it, as E. B. White once wrote, ''our Lyceum, our Chautauqua, our Minsky's and our Camelot''? It is hard to say, although for some time now the crisis has been cast in terms of God overcome by mammon. Public television is supposed to be broke. Phrases like ''declining Federal support'' and ''chronic underfinancing'' figure in almost all descriptions. If public television gets more money, truth, justice and beauty will win. Consequently, the Senate Commerce Committee recently took a giant step toward what it says will correct things: It approved legislation that would levy a tax of 2 percent and more on the sale of commercial radio and television stations, with the new money to be used for our Lyceum and Chautauqua. Well, perhaps.

title: Should You Include the Kids?
description: LEAD: I LOVE MY CHILDREN. IN FACT, I like them - which may be a truer test of affection. At 9 and 11, they are great company, bright and beautiful. They are not, however, always great in company - adult company, that is. Children are incompletely civilized, an impatient tribe; their tastes in amusements are primitive, and they do not suffer boredom in silence.

title: Parched Conditions Drying Northwest's Economy
description: Everywhere you look in the Pacific Northwest, in the year of the worst drought since records have been kept, nature appears to have been turned inside out and the economy turned upside down.

title: Umpire's Work Not Up to Par
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Offices Grouped With Homes
description: Bernard and Marc Nevas are taking advantage of a special zoning district in Westport, Conn., in which developers may combine clusters of apartments and offices on a single plot as long as they limit building size and height.

title: CRITIC OF GORBACHEV OFFERS TO RESIGN HIS MOSCOW PARTY POST
description: A top Communist Party official confirmed today that the Moscow party leader, Boris N. Yeltsin, offered to resign last week at a meeting of the party Central Committee.

title: Headliners; Into Philanthropy
description: For 17 years, as president of Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., Colin G. Campbell has had all the college administrator's usual concerns about fundraising.

title: CONFERENCE EXPLORES PUBLIC-ART PROBLEMS
description: LEAD: THE controversies surrounding public art were explored last weekend at a symposium at the Neuberger Museum on the campus of the State University of New York that brought together artists and architects, developers and scholars, arts administrators and the public.

title: Dance: By Linda Mussmann
description: LINDA MUSSMANN'S ''Blue Scene Grey,'' performed by her Time and Space Limited company on Friday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, operates on a number of levels. The first part of a four-part piece called ''Civil War Chronicles,'' the cantata jogs through 80 years of American history, from 1781 to 1861, in a manner that often makes schoolroom history come alive.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINIONBASEBALL-STADIUM BONDS: PRO AND CON;
YES - THE ECONOMY HASMUCH TO GAIN
description: LEAD: AS BOTH a buinesssman and citizen proud of New Jersey's new economic vitality and positive image, I strongly support the baseball bond-issue referendum on the Nov. 3 ballot.

title: Telling Players By the Numbers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
DINING;
ELEGANCE RETAINED IN WHITE PLAINS
description: LEAD: NEWLY settled in the quarters last occupied by Corniche, Jean Pierre has wisely changed little of the old restaurant's elegant surroundings. Against a sophisticated, dark teal plush background, new, comfortable, upholstered chairs match peach linens and cheerful bouquets provide bright notes. Heavy metallic window hangings have been removed to expose a clean sweep of window wall.

title: L.I.R.R. RITUAL
description: EACH morning on the Long Island Rail Road's Hicksville 7:15, 7:29, 7:35 and 7:40 trains, women who appear neither sirens nor hussies (many wear navy suits and sensible shoes, whatever those are) whip out foot-long ermine brushes with martinet precision.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''So I say to the leaders in Congress, let's roll up our sleeves, pull together.'' - President Reagan, on the budget talks.

title: FROM THE RIGHT: Henry G. Manne; Let the Markets Settle
description: Excerpts from an interview with Henry G. Manne, dean of law and director of the Law and Economics Center at George Mason University.

title: The George Factor
description: DURING a visit to the Meadowlands Sports Complex several years ago, George Steinbrenner surveyed the football stadium, the indoor arena and the race track.

description: Excerpts from an interview with George Gilder, author of ''Wealthy and Poverty'' and ''The Spirit of Enterprise:''
