description: The Soviet Union enters its eighth decade under Communism next week in a state of transition, wary of its past and uncertain about its future.

title: Question Of the Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
description: If the Yankees go into the next season with the same team as last season Billy Martin won't last the year. If they get a pitcher and a frontline catcher he will. But he better take the dugout phone off the hook because we all know someone will be calling. ROBERT A. NISSEN New York

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 6 about the Sea Islands off Georgia referred incorrectly to Clifford West, former chairman of the Georgia Marshlands and Islands Association. Mr. West is alive, in Norwich, Vt.

title: In Defense of the Sweet
description: SAUTERNES AND BARSAC FROM France, trockenbeerenauslese from Germany, late-harvest riesling from California: all luscious sweet wines, all masterpieces of the winemaker's art - and all virtually ignored by the wine-drinking public.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: CRAFTS IN PHILADELPHIA

title: Ex-Judge Is Accused of Tenant Harassment
description: The former superintendent of a Queens apartment house has testified that the owner of the building - who later became a judge - had asked him if he knew anyone who would rape, rob or assault elderly tenants so they or assault elderly tenants so they would move out of their rent-stabilized apartments.

title: San Francisco's Own Bread
description: San Francisco sourdough is a proud tradition in the city by the bay, dating back to the 19th century when Basque shepherds and 49-ers arrived in the tent town with a bit of sourdough starter, or ''mother,'' bundled in their knapsacks. They sustained themselves in the mountains and remote gold country by making a simple bread. They'd add flour and water to this ''sour'' dough, leave it to rise, and save a lump of dough to start the next day's bread before baking it in a heavy Dutch oven in the coals of their campfire. The bread was sometimes even cooked in the same pan used to pan their gold.

title: In the Region: New Jersey
description: LEAD: A Business Park May Be Totowa's Last

title: Bottle Bill on Ballot in Capital
description: A ballot initiative to require deposits on beverage containers sold in the District of Columbia could spur action in other states because of the high profile of the nation's capital, proponents say.

title: Special Today:
description: Entertaining/Magazine Part 2 The Party Season: How to Make It a Success, includes these special reports: A host's guide to the well-planned cocktail party. When and how to include the children. An unusual idea that makes dinner for 30 workable. Tips from floral designers on how to make inexpensive arrangements. Using the microwave oven for an elegant low-calorie guest menu.

title: SERMON BECOMES BOOK ON RAISING A 'MENSCH'
description: LEAD: THREE years ago, when delivering his Rosh ha-Shanah sermon, Rabbi Neil Kurshan had an experience that most clergymen dream about: a congregant really listened to his words. And listened so carefully that this month the rabbi will take some weekdays off from the Huntington Jewish Center to travel throughout the United States promoting ''Raising Your Child to Be a

title: WILTON GIRL LIFTS U.S. SOCCER HOPES
description: KRISTINE LILLY of the Wilton High School girls' soccer team is on a breakaway, ahead of her teammates but confronted by two defenders and the goalkeeper as she dribbles toward the Greenwich goal at a sprinter's speed last Monday in Greenwich. Seemingly, it is a mismatch. But, given Miss Lilly's skills, she has the edge in such a situation.

title: Americans in Philippines Face Security Curbs
description: President Corazon C. Aquino flew to Clark Air Base today to demonstrate her concern over the killing of three Americans on Wednesday, as Americans in the Philippines faced heightened security restrictions.

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
MERCY MARATHON
description: LEAD: AN ENGLEWOOD dentist, Dr. Milton Houpt, will be running in the New York Marathon today to raise money for children with cancer.

title: The Tango Meets Jorge Luis Borges
description: TWO BROTHERS, SO CLOSE IT was said that to quarrel with one of them was to reckon with two enemies, fall in love with the same woman, who comes to live with them in their shack. They try to share her, but jealousy begins to fester between them. They try to get rid of her, selling her to a whorehouse - but each sneaks off to visit her in secret, so the brothers finally buy her back, the trust between them now tainted by mutual deception. The woman is submissive and eager to please, but aren't her smiles brighter for the younger man, her embraces more fervent? The triangle becomes unbearable; there is no question which of the three must die.

title: Halfway Through A 2-Year Quest For Greatness
description: THE last remaining magnums of champagne were still on ice when Pat Riley began implementing his plan, his blueprint for success. The red lights above the dozen or so minicams in the victorious Laker locker room were still beaming. And the players, just minutes after achieving their fourth title in this decade, were still wallowing in their euphoria.

title: CAN THE CONTRAS GO ON?
description: James LeMoyne's rendering of the contras and his experience of chumming with them and giving away his T-shirts is a strangely naive portrait of a group that has become notorious for the war atrocities it has committed against the Nicaraguan people.

title:
FOCUS: THE ELDERLY;
Resolving A Housing Challenge
description: LEAD: A FEW weeks ago, Van Adriance's crew put the final touches on one of the nation's smallest housing projects for the elderly, 10 one-bedroom apartments in two long, low buildings that face each other and back up to the piney New Hampshire woods.

title: AMID TURMOIL, YALE'S GAY STUDIES CENTER HOLD CONFERENCE
description: One of the nation's first centers for homosexual studies held its inaugural conference at Yale University Friday and today, a reaction to an article in The Wall Street Journal calling Yale ''a gay school.''

title: DEVELOPMENT: STRIKING A BALANCE
description: IT is not very difficult for most of us to agree that overdevelopment has a negative impact on our lives and tranquillity, but have we considered properly what benefits could be derived from continued expansion?

title: Worse Is Imaginable
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoors; Focusing Clearly On Deer Hunting
description: DEER hunting has begun in portions of the Northeast, including the Adirondacks, and if you are planning to join the venison seekers you should make sure that your rifle shoots where you aim it.

title: Sorry Spectacle at Lincoln Center
description: COMPARED TO THE MAJOR FES-tivals at Cannes, Berlin and Venice, the New York Film Festival has always seemed to be pure -devoted to art, good works and the sanctity of cinema. New York doesn't give prizes to film makers. To be invited to participate is the honor it confers. For 25 years, it has stood tall and serene above the kind of divisive politics and pressures experienced at competitive festivals, which dole out Golden Whatnots (sometimes made of glass) and depend on the support of government bureaucrats.

title: Kenyan Police and Moslems Fight After Rally Is Canceled
description: Police used tear gas to quell a riot by thousands of Moslems that began after officials broke up an Islamic religious rally in Mombasa, a witness and newspaper report said today.

title: GORBACHEV'S STYLE VEILS HIS SUBSTANCE
description: WITH last week's announcement that Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be coming to Washington Dec. 7 for a summit meeting with President Reagan, Americans are promised a closer look at one of the world's most provocatve figures.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
A SONG IN THE HEART
description: LEAD: GETTING together to make a little music were Lola Hall, also known as Lo-Nika; Seanna Griffin, known as Twinkie to her friends; Tosha Vinson, Lady T, for short; Carmine Scott, or Cool Carmello Shortie C; and Wanda Rogers, who answers to Wanda-Bee.

title: AN OFFICIAL'S LOT IS NOT AN EASY ONE
description: LEAD: CANDIDATES seeking election Tuesday to municipal office are running for positions that will probably include middle-of-the-night snow-removal telephone calls, meetings with irate voters - some of them close neighbors - not having the time the job requires, frustrating political hassles and the knowledge that, in many situations, there is not much they can do.

title: TIBET COMMUNISTS LINK RIOTS TO DALAI LAMA
description: Communist officials from Tibet today accused the Dalai lama, its exiled spiritual leader, of fomenting the recent Tibetan rioting.

title: Securing the Lean In Tower of Pisa
description: NOBODY in the Italian Government wants to straighten the Leaning Tower of Pisa; its tilt keeps the tourist lire flowing. But in January, the Government approved a $25 million project to keep the 800-year-old tower from tipping farther.

title: NOT ALL BLACK MAYORS HITCH FORTUNES TO JACKSON'S STAR
description: WITH the Democratic National Convention still nine months away, Mayor Harold Washington has done what he would not do in 1984: He publicly endorsed the candidacy of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a fellow Chicagoan, for President. In contrast, for two other black Mayors, W. Wilson Goode in Philadelphia and Harvey Gantt in Charlotte, N. C., the last campaign on their minds these days is Mr. Jackson's. Both so far have remained neutral on his candidacy. Mr. Goode is in an acrimonious rematch Tuesday with Frank L. Rizzo, Philadelphia's flamboyant Mayor of the 1970's. Mr. Gantt, who is seeking a third term in a city where seven of 10 voters are white, is facing a strong challenge from Sue Myrick, a popular Republican.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE NANTUCKET DIARY OF NED ROREM: 1973-1985. By Ned Rorem. (North Point, $30.) Frank O'Hara is said to have remarked that Ned Rorem's ''Paris Diary'' ''reads like 'The Alice B. Toklas Cook Book' without the recipes.'' In his ''Nantucket Diary'' Mr. Rorem corrects this omission. Kept between the ages of 49 and 62, a period during which Mr. Rorem took up part-time residence on Nantucket, ''The Nantucket Diary'' is where the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer does his personal, professional and household accounting. Mr. Rorem catalogues meals consumed, physicians consulted, guests entertained, music commissioned, reviews written, books read, grudges nursed, memories savored. For all the proper names, musical, famous and otherwise, that appear in these pages, the book does not trade in gossip; there are but one or two anecdotes one itches to repeat. This volume, less sexually and emotionally charged than earlier installments of his ''Diary,'' chronicles the postdrinking, postsmoking, and seemingly postprofligate years; by his own admission, Mr. Rorem has come to value discretion. ''The mood is quieter. After a certain age, certain subjects become embarrassingly dull and nobody's business. One of these is sexual intercourse, the other is the injustice of personal sorrow.'' The intimacies recounted here are those of daily life, and, not unlike daily life, the entries often repeat themselves. The author's subjects are, for the most part, disarmingly benign: work, his sweet tooth, friends and his elderly parents, about whom some of the most affecting passages in the book are written. Mr. Rorem's candor and wit help relieve the self-consciousness and stiltedness that diaries written to be read are susceptible to. ''The Nantucket Diary'' is engaging, not profound. For this Mr. Rorem makes no apology: ''As though the very nature of diaries were not based on the Importance of Unimportance.''

title: Summit Meeting: Just a Handshake?
description: Now that Mikhail S. Gorbachev has finally set a date for visiting the United States, the next question is what kind of summit meeting it will be.

title: 'The Chalice and the Blade'
description: To the Editor:

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Custom Cufflinks Made in London
description: LEAD: On Bury Street, St. James's, London, there is a jewelry shop that specializes in cuff links, that curious, yet stylish fashion sported by gentlemen as long ago as 1684, according to a reference in The London Gazette. The shop, called Longmire's, has the largest collection of cuff links and dress sets to be found, with 800 pairs ranging from about $165 to $16,500 in price.

title: Social Events
description: Having Fun, Aiding Others Exotic Fare in Newark Nov. 1 - ''A Night in Old Lhasa'' with Tibetan food, fashions, music, folk dancers, jewelry and art will benefit Tibet House in Manhattan and the new Tibetan galleries at the Newark Museum. The party, from 5:30 to 9, will be at the museum, 49 Washington Street in downtown Newark. Tickets $100, from 201-596-6550. Ray Charles Performs Nov. 1 - Since 1958 the Deafness Research Foundation has awarded almost $10 million in research grants. To Ray Charles, who has been blind from the age of 6, deafness would be the greatest of all handicaps, and this year he established the Robinson Foundation for the Hearing Impaired in Los Angeles to treat deaf people (Robinson is his surname). The research group will honor the musician, who will also perform, at a dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria starting with 5 P.M. cocktails. Tickets $400, from 212-684-6556. Hadassah Celebrates Nov. 1 - Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, is celebrating its 75th anniversary with a black-tie dinner-dance at the Plaza starting with cocktails at 5:30. Proceeds will benefit the Hadassah Medical Organization in Jerusalem. Among those to be honored are Dr. Michael Zasloff, who discovered a chemical defense system in the body separate from the immune system. Tickets $250, at the door. Evening of Nostalgia Nov. 2 - Jimmy Durante, Ted Lewis, Sophie Tucker and Fanny Brice will be among the stars of the past who will be imitated at a 7:30 P.M. show at the Great Hall of Cooper Union, Astor Place and Third Avenue. The evening will benefit Project Ezra, which has been helping elderly Jewish people of the Lower East Side for 13 years. Tickets $18 at the door for performance alone, $75 for a 6 P.M. buffet and the show, and $125 for buffet, show, and Champagne and desserts after the show, from 212-982-4124. Briefly Noted: Nov. 2 - Sleepy Hollow Restorations, renamed Historic Hudson Valley, is holding a benefit dinner-dance at the Plaza starting with cocktails at 6:30. Joanne Woodward will read from Washington Irving. Tickets $500, from 212-874-4098. Nov. 2 - The Central Park Conservancy will benefit from a cocktail party and exhibition of portraits spanning four centuries at the Garrick C. Stephenson Gallery, 50 East 57th Street, from 5 to 8 P.M. Tickets $50, from 212-315-0385. Nov. 3 - The New York Foundation for the Arts is the host of a benefit for minority students starting with the 7:30 P.M. performance of the Garth Fagan Bucket Dance Theater, a jazz modern dance group, at the Joyce Theater, Eighth Avenue at 19th Street. A reception at the Tower Gallery, 45 West 18th Street, follows. Tickets $75, from 212-233-3900. Nov. 3 - Bobby Short will entertain at a black-tie dinner-dance at the Plaza to benefit the International Peace Academy, which promotes peaceful solutions to regional and international conflicts. Tickets $250, from 212-580-5511. Nov. 4 - The Churchill School and Center for children with learning disabilities is holding a 15th-anniversary benefit dinner at the Pierre starting with Champagne at 6:30. Mariette Hartley, a Churchill parent, will make presentations, and Phyllis Newman will entertain. Black tie. Tickets $500, from 212-722-0610. Nov. 4 - The Guggenheim Foundation is 50 years old, and a spectacular black-tie birthday party will be held at its namesake museum starting with cocktails at 7, followed by dinner and entertainment. Tickets $300, from 212-874-2460. Nov. 4 - The New York City Mission Society will honor Hicks B. Waldron, chairman of Avon Products, at its dinner-dance and silent auction at the Waldorf-Astoria. Bill Cosby will entertain. The black-tie benefit starts with cocktails at 6:30. Tickets $350, from 212-997-0100. Nov. 5 - Myrna Loy, a co-founder and trustee of the American Place Theater, will be honored at a 6 to 9 P.M. Champagne and caviar party to benefit the theater at 111 West 46th Street. Harry Belafonte and Tony Randall are among several performers scheduled to entertain. Tickets $175, from 212-246-3730. Nov. 5 - Cocktails at 7 P.M., followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria, will benefit the Children's Blood Foundation. Black tie. Tickets $250, from 212-935-1840. Nov. 6 - Champagne at Cartier, Fifth Avenue at 52d Street, from 6 to 8 P.M. will benefit the American Horse Shows Association. Tickets for the reception $125, from 212-972-2472. Family Affair Nov. 6 - For 30 years the Paper Bag Players have brought their exuberant productions into New York City's public schools, as well as presenting plays from January through March at Symphony Space on Broadway near 95th Street. Its audience is children 4 through 9 years old, and the company involves them in the productions, which are often their first taste of the theater. A preview of their next production and a birthday party with goodies for children, drinks for adults and dinner for all, will be held from 6 to 8:30 at the Equitable Center, on Seventh Avenue near 51st Street. Tickets $75 for children age 3 to 10, $100 for those older, from 212-362-0431.

title: Search of Pittsburgh Pupils Leads to a Suit by A.C.L.U.
description: Parents of 21 elementary pupils who were ordered to disrobe partially during a search for a missing watch have sued a school district.

title: Guests at Breakfast: In a Restaurant...
description: NOTHING HELPS SCENERY LIKE ham and eggs,'' said Mark Twain, one of this country's most perspicacious travelers. Americans have always regarded breakfast as a serious and uplifting meal, whether it is a prelude to a Twain-like country excursion or the setting for a high-powered corporate confab.

title: GREEN ACRES BONDS WIN WIDE BACKING
description: LEAD: THE Green Acres bond issue, which Governor Kean has called the ''quality of life'' referendum (Public Question No. 2 on Tuesday's ballot), has drawn considerable attention.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: PHILADELPHIA;
Fair Skies For Fairmount
description: LEAD: RESIDENTIAL construction has surged in Fairmount, a tight-knit community just a mile northwest of City Hall that is known for its three historic brewery buildings, converted into apartments a few years ago, and its proximity to Fairmount Park.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lendl vs. Mecir: Ivan Lendl struggled past Pat Cash and Miloslav Mecir overwhelmed Mats Wilander yesterday to advance to the final of the $923,000 European Community Championship in Antwerp, Belgium. Lendl relied on stamina to power him past Cash, 6-4, 7-6. Mecir, ranked fifth in the world, used a variety of daring strokes to beat Wilander, 6-1, 6-3. Wilander and Cash earned $100,000 each in the world's richest exhibition tournament. Lendl and Mecir will vie for $215,000 in today's final. Last year, Mecir lost to John McEnroe in the final. (AP) U.S. Clinches Wightman Cup: The United States clinched its ninth straight Wightman Cup championship Friday night when Gigi Fernandez and Robin White defeated Sara Gomer and Clare Wood of Britain, 6-4, 6-1, giving the Americans a 4-0 margin in the seven-match competition in Williamsburg, Va. In yesterday's first match, Pam Shriver defeated Anne Hobbs of Britain, 6-4, 6-3. Then, Jo Durie snapped the Americans' 23-match winning streak with a 7-6, 6-3 victory over Zina Garrison. The British thereby avoided a third consecutive shutout in the annual challenge. In the last match, Durie and Hobbs beat Garrison and Lori McNeil, 0-6, 6-4, 7-5. The Americans hold a 49-10 lead in the series, which switches venues each year. (AP) Graf Reaches Zurich Final: Top-seeded Steffi Graf overcame a sluggish start to defeat third-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-4, 6-7, 6-1, yesterday in the semifinals of the $150,000 European women's indoor tournament in Zurich. Graf will meet second-seeded Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia in the final today. Mandlikova defeated Nathalie Tauziat of France, 6-1, 3-6, 6-3, in the other semifinal.(AP) Teltscher to Play Fitzgerald: Eliot Teltscher of the United States beat Darren Cahill of Australia, 7-5, 6-0, yesterday to advance to today's final of the $200,000 Seiko Super tournament in Hong Kong. John Fitzgerald of Australia beat Jeremy Bates of Britain, 6-3, 6-4, in the other semifinal.(AP) Golf Japanese Men Maintain Lead: Masahiro Kuramoto eagled the par-5 ninth hole en route to an eight-under-par 64 in Kobe, Japan, yesterday to take a three-stroke lead in the individual competition of a $464,000 match between American and Japanese teams. The first-round leader, Andy Bean, shot a 68 and was in second place at 204 after three rounds over the 6,850-yard, par-72 Sport Sinko Country Club course. In the team competition, the nine-man Japanese team took a 14-stroke lead, with a total of 1,668. The two teams began the day tied at 1,109. The match ends today.(AP) American Women Are Ahead: In Tokyo, a 14-member American team won four matches, drew once and lost twice yesterday to take a 9-5 lead in a $200,000 match between squads of American and Japanese women. Sherri Turner and Colleen Walker shot two-under-par 70's to share a one-stroke lead in the individual competition. Shirley Furlong and Yuko Moriguchi shared third place at 71. The second round of the three-day competition was played on the 6,263-yard, par-72 Tsukuba Country Club course. (AP) Cross Country Barry of Iona Wins Title: Garrett Barry, a junior at Iona College, broke away at the four-mile mark and captured the individual title in the 33d annual Collegiate Track Conference Cross Country championship yesterday. Barry covered the five-mile course at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx in 24 minutes 58.1 seconds, and won by some 50 yards. John Schwab, a junior at LaSalle University, finished second in 25:06.8, ahead of Pat Lavery of Fordham, at 25:24.7. Schwab's performance helped the Explorers to defend their team title; they placed four runners in the top 10, and wound up with 39 points. Jeannie Radice of Fordham captured the women's title, covering a three-mile course in 18:17.6. Horse Racing Steeplechase Title to Gacko: Gacko captured the $250,000 Breeders' Cup Steeplechase II yesterday at Fair Hill, Md., winning by nine lengths in the world's richest race over jumps. Flatterer, the four-time Eclipse Award winner as steeplechase Horse of the Year, went off as the 4-to-5 favorite, but he had trouble at the eighth jump and was pulled up by his English jockey, Richard Dunwoody. When Flatterer was pulled up, the Irish-bred Le Ronceray was leading the 10-horse pack. But as the horses passed the stands for the second time, Le Ronceray had to give way to Gacko, a 6-year-old French gelding ridden by Roger Duchene. Gacko maintained his lead over the remainder of the 19 jumps, leaving the battle for second place to Inlander and Gateshead, who finished a head apart in that order. Gacko covered the two miles and five furlongs in 5:15 1/5. He paid $15.60 for $2 to win. Sacahuista Captures Spinster: Sacahuista led all the way yesterday to capture the $228,300 Spinster Stakes at Keeneland in Lexington, Ky. The 3-year-old filly, trained by D. Wayne Lukas and ridden by Randy Romero, covered the one and one-eighth miles in 1:48 3/5 in scoring a three-length victory and paid $4.80 for $2 to win. Ms. Margi was second and Tall Poppy was third. (AP) Blew by Em Wins: Blew by Em, ridden by Chris Antley, closed strongly for a two-length victory yesterday in the $92,850 Pilgrim Stakes for 2-year-olds at Aqueduct. The son of Air Forbes Won and Mistress Kipling, bred in Ireland, went the mile and an eighth in 1:53 3/5. Cefis finished second and Smart Lad was third. The victory was Blew by Em's third in four career starts. (AP) Saratoga Passage Takes Norfolk: At Santa Anita in Arcadia, Calif., Saratoga Passage, a 12-to-1 shot who was nearly scratched from the race, ran through the rain over a sloppy track yesterday to win the $301,900 Norfolk Stakes for 2-year-olds. Ridden by Joe Steiner, Saratoga Passage beat Purdue King by 2 1/2 lengths while the 3-2 favorite, Success Express, finished fourth. Saratoga Passage, a son of Pirateer owned by Saratoga I Stable of Oak Harbor, Wash., ran the mile and a sixteenth in 1:45. He returned $27 for $2 to win.(AP)

title: NASSAU AND SUFFOLK HEAD FOR THE POLLS
description: AN a rare electoral coincidence, Long Island voters will elect chief executives of both Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Tuesday.

title: On the Firing Line
description: Hey, the field of Republican candidates looks pretty good. At the debate conducted on Bill Buckley's ''Firing Line'' last week, our six-pack came across as both more experienced and comfortable in its own skin than the Democratic six- pack did on the same program.

title: Separated Twins Gain Weight And Are Off the Critical List
description: The West German twins who were joined at the head at birth have been taken off the critical list and have gained weight steadily since they were separated in a 22-hour operation Sept. 6, officials at Johns Hopkins Hospital said Friday.

title: Lois M. Perelson To Wed Nov. 29
description: Lois Marion Perelson, an associate in the municipal finance department at Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Stewart Koerner Gross, an associate at E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company, plan to be married Nov. 29. The future bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Perelson of New York, who have announced her engagement to a son of Merle Gross-Ginsburg of New York and New Milford, Conn., and Bernard Gross of Plainfield, N.J.

title: Budget Negotiators Consider Cuts In Some Cost-of-Living Increases
description: Budget negotiators from Congress and the White House, who met today on ways to reduce the deficit, have discussed the possibility of lowering cost-of-living increases in some Government programs, officials said.

title: RENAISSANCE TONES IN WILTON
description: THE concert week includes more than a dozen choice entries. Starting with today's, the avid music lover can first escape to the tonal niceties of an earlier era with Calliope, then bask in the classical-romantic delights promised by Music from Marlboro.

title: T. P. Kikis to Wed Laura Best Yorke
description: The engagement of Laura Best Yorke to Thomas Peter Kikis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter T. Kikis of New York and Lyford Cay, the Bahamas, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Lane Harvey Yorke of New York and Aaron Jones Yorke 4th of New York and Southampton, L.I. A January wedding is planned.

title: 'Double' Wedding At the George St.
description: IT'S April 19, 1956, the wedding day of Grace Kelly and Prince Rainier in Monaco and of and Rosemary Fazzari and Sal McDonald in Perth Amboy.

title: MARKET DROP MAY AID LILCO TAKEOVER EFFORT
description: LEAD: AS investment capital flows from stocks to bonds in reaction to the record collapse in stock prices, prospects for a buyout of the Long Island Lighting Company may have improved, according to officials of the Long Island Power Authority.

title: A DIRECTORY OF WINTER SAILINGS
description: LEAD: The following directory of cruise ships is arranged by destination and basically covers sailings from Dec. 1 to Feb. 29. Another directory will appear on Feb. 7 covering most of the rest of 1988.

title: Ed Bradley's Variation on a Classic
description: FOR THE LONGEST TIME, THE ''60 Minutes'' regular Ed Bradley would not eat shrimp. In fact, he could barely stand to look at the stuff, an aversion that lingered from the time he spent peeling the tiny creatures in his father's Detroit restaurant.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in some copies of Business Day yesterday showing how 10 mutual funds have performed since Oct. 15 listed Nova-Total Return, Bartlett Corporate Cash and Rightime Fund in the wrong category.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The brick fireplace in our home had been painted by previous owners. We want to remove the paint and restore the natural brick. What is the best way to do this?

title: NO -- IT'S THE WRONG IDEA AT THE WRONG TIME
description: Perhaps the most important vote that New Jerseyans will cast on Tuesday is on the $185 million bond issue to build a baseball stadium in Lyndhurst, in the Meadowlands.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SCHOONER SAILINGS The Richard Robbins, a schooner built in 1886 in Greenwich, has returned for a few days of sailing on the Cohansey River. Two-hour trips aboard the restored vessel are being sponsored today, tomorrow and Tuesday by the Cumberland County Historical Society of Greenwich, which numbers among its members Rebecca Robbins Lore, the daughter of the man who commissioned the schooner.

title: FOR 'MYSTIC PIZZA,' TOWNS AND RESIDENTS 'JUST ACT NATURAL'
description: SOME people couldn't cross the bridge. Some handled odiferous fish, and others found strangers playing pool at their social club. But they had few complaints - after all, they were helping to make a movie.

title: Dance
description: Dancing tends to be a youthful art, but maturity does out. There is nothing quite like the wryly lovable and yeasty performance of Stanley Holden, formerly of England's Royal Ballet, as the Widow Simone in Sir Frederick Ashton's ''Fille Mal Gardee,'' which he will perform Sunday, Tuesday and Wednesday with the Joffrey Ballet at City Center. And the rest of the Joffrey week suggests once more the remarkable richness of its repertory, with performances of Arthur Saint-Leon's 19th-century ''Vivandiere Pas de Six,'' an historic all-Diaghilev program on Friday and Sunday nights and an all-Ashton program on Saturday night - cheek by jowl with modern dance from Paul Taylor and Laura Dean and ballet from Gerald Arpino and Ben Stevenson.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: WHITES, by Norman Rush. (Collier/Macmillan, $6.95.) From 1978 to 1983, Norman Rush was co-director of the Peace Corps in Botswana, an experience that led him to write short stories about the invisible barriers separating black Africa from its would-be saviors. This ''admirable collection'' is about ''disillusionment and loss of conviction,'' Leslie Marmon Silko wrote in The Book Review last year. But it is not a simplistic anti-American screed. ''It isn't just whites who must face up to moral and political failures in the third world today, Mr. Rush seems to be saying.'' LEARNED PIGS & FIREPROOF WOMEN, by Ricky Jay. (Warner, $12.95.) Among the carnival oddities examined by Ricky Jay (curator of the Mulholland Library of Conjuring and the Allied Arts in Los Angeles) is one Harry Kahne, who, using his hands, feet and mouth, could write five different words simultaneously. Mr. Jay, it seems, is something of a wonder himself. When our reviewer, James

title: Unwelcome Man In California
description: WHEN Lawrence Singleton was paroled in California in April after serving 8 years of a 14-year term as a rapist, he became a man no one appeared to want as a neighbor.

title: A SHIFT BY SOVIET TOWARD SUBTLETY ON ARMS FORESEEN
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, has left Washington after raising the possibility that Moscow may be adopting a new strategy for limiting President Reagan's program for a space-based anti-missile defense.

title: THE BEASTS AT BAY
description: Lizard picture frame, $30. At Bloomingdale's. Tortoise glass, $12. At Frank McIntosh at Henri Bendel. Italian horn cup, $100. At Barneys New York. Antique English mastodon tooth box, $900. At A. Smith Antiques, 235 East 60th Street. Italian horn salad servers, $150. At Barneys New York. Snakeskin-patterned tile, $10 a tile. At Rico Tile & Marble, 979 Third Avenue. Vase in the shape of a monkey figure, $75. At Bergdorf Goodman. Stenciled leopard-patterned rug, 6 by 7 feet, $1,800. At Hanmars Potpourri, 979 Third Avenue. Velvet tiger-patterned fabric, $75 a yard. At Roger Arlington, 979 Third Avenue. Antique crocodile mirror, $4,500. At Bergdorf Goodman. One of a pair of American Empire chairs, $1,900 for the pair. At Bergdorf Goodman. Snakeskin pillow, $135. At Hanmars Potpourri. Velvet leopard-patterned pillow, $390. At Yale Burge Antiques, 305 East 63d Street. Striped wooden vases, $390 a pair. At Yale Burge. An English hand-painted wooden bowl in the foreground, $95. At Marco Polo Antiques, 1135 Madison Avenue. Wooden ginger jar, $135. At Bergdorf Goodman. Snakeskin pillows in the left-hand corner, $330 for the larger one, $135 for the smaller one. At Hanmars Potpourri. OUIS XVI'S BROTHER, the Comte D'Artois, was thought to have a racy bedroom. It featured leopard-skin upholstery set against blue taffeta walls and fabrics fringed in gold. Marie Antoinette also had such animal passions. In her Turkish boudoir, animal skins were draped over the arms of several settees.

title: QUEENS JUDGE FINDS CHANGE TO HIS LIKING
description: Judge Nat H. Hentel of the Queens Civil Court switched from the Republican to the Democratic Party three years ago, and the change paid off this year with a Democratic nomination for the State Supreme Court in Queens. He was also endorsed by the Conservative and Liberal Parties but not his former colleagues, the Republicans.

title: CAN THE CONTRAS GO ON?
description: Mr. LeMoyne discounts the possibility of the contra leaders' returning to Managua, saying, ''The fight for popular support inside Nicaragua promises to be extremely risky, testing the rebels where they have been weakest.'' In other words, the contras have little support inside Nicaragua. Mr. LeMoyne forgets that guerrillas with popular support inside their own country do survive on scant funds. Witness the resistance in France and the present-day Afghan rebels. If the contras were popular in Nicaragua, they would not need American support to survive. JOHN BECHHOEFER Chicago

title: Concert: Barattelli Group
description: THERE is always a danger of provincialism on the new-music scene. New York performing groups naturally tend to favor local or at least American composers, with only occasional representation from abroad. And since new music doesn't ''sell,'' visits by entire foreign ensembles devoted to the new are rare.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: Windham Hill in Concert Paramount Home Video. 1986. 68 minutes. $29.95. It's Windham Hill, all right, but not necessarily in concert. Here is an assemblage of interviews and performances by four mainstays of Windham Hill Records, long-time purveyors of ''new age'' music, the subspecies of pop whose airy melodicism, ''ethnic'' colorings and broad consonances maintain a certain blandness no matter how rollicking things get.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: THE SEARCH FOR ECONOMIC STRATEGIES;
NOT HIGHER TAXES, FASTER GROWTH
description: LEAD: THE stock market collapse has awakened the nation and the world from a long dream of economic unreality. We have now been challenged more forcefully and more visibly than at any time since the Sputnik era of a generation ago.

title: Question Of the Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
description: The return of Billy Martin brings new excitement and anticipation to New York baseball. We can all sit on the edge of our seats waiting for Billy to make his inevitable indiscretion. Will he punch out a fan, another of his players, an opposing player or perhaps even an umpire? Or will 1988 see Billy make the ultimate move? Will he tie on a really good one some night and pop George Steinbrenner in the kisser? I can't wait! ROBERT E. BILLMEYER Rowayton, Conn.

title: TUTORING CENTERS: SUCCESSES DEBATED
description: LEAD: JOSHUA COHEN had had no schooling, knew no English and spoke a Spanish heavily laced with a Miskito Indian dialect when he was adopted from a strife-ridden Central American country just before his eighth birthday.try just before his eighth birthday.

title: Headlines and Stock Quotes on Call
description: THERE I was, sitting at my desk, when the phone rang. The better to exercise, I stood up to answer it. ''Are you sitting down?'' my friend asked. ''You'd better sit down.'' I sat, fearing the worst. ''The Dow is down 500 points.''

title: Catering's New Role
description: IF ''CATERED AFFAIRS'' HAVE ALWAYS seemed too costly and complicated, but a full schedule makes cooking by yourself impractical, you might investigate the approach of a new breed of entrepreneurs. These professionals may have attended cooking schools, or worked for restaurants or large caterers, or they may be moonlighting corporate chefs. Some are just good cooks. Whatever their background, they sell the personality of their cooking, adding an individual touch to the catered party. Their rates are less than full-service - about $25 to $35 a head, as opposed to as much as $85 or more - and depend completely on the menu and work desired. Whereas the bigger businesses need to make a per-party minimum to cover their overhead, these new cooks-cum-caterers can serve as a quasi-takeout restaurant, delivering food of your choice, or as chef-for-a-night, shopping, then cooking and serving in your apartment.

title: Film Is the Weapon, Apartheid the Target
description: IT WAS SPRINGTIME IN PRETORIA, THE SOUTH African capital, a time when the city is ablaze with the purple of jacaranda trees, the air on the highveld clear and crisp. But in the somber, wood-paneled office of the Prime Minister, Balthazar Johannes Vorster, it was the onset of another, more bitter kind of season. Five days earlier, on Sept. 12, 1977, Stephen Biko had died of brain injuries, face down and foaming at the mouth, on the floor of Pretoria Central Prison. He was 30 years old and the most talented young black leader in South Africa. Outrage flared around the world, but Mr. Vorster - in an interview with Seymour Topping, then the managing editor of The New York Times, and with this correspondent, at that time the bureau chief for the newspaper in Johannesburg - took what comfort he could from what he called ''a very, very unfortunate affair.''

description: How Mutual Funds Have Performed Best and worst performers since Oct. 15.
