They were among the bet performers

title: FEMALE COMPOSERS SEEKING PARITY
description: WHEN Elizabeth Bell was in college in 1950, she was told that women couldn't be composers. ''Women don't have the strength,'' a teacher said.

title: UP IN ARMS IN ARIZONA
description: THE NOTION OF CON-servative Barry Goldwater, the most prominent politician in Arizona history, calling for the resignation of an Arizona Republican Governor would once have seemed less likely than a blizzard in Phoenix. Yet when he did so, on Oct. 9, nobody was deeply shocked.

title: A DIFFERENT INDEPENDENCE DAY
description: For many black Americans, the anniversary of the day their ancestors were freed from slavery is an independence day meriting at least as much to-do as the Fourth of July. In O FREEDOM! Afro-American Emancipation Celebrations (University of Tennessee, $24.95), William H. Wiggins Jr., a fellow of the Folklore Institute at Indiana University, brings much-deserved scholarly attention to the longstanding black American tradition of emancipation celebrations. While many of the ''freedom jubilees'' in the book are tied to the signing of the Emancipation Proclamation on Jan. 1, 1865, or to other state or local abolitions of slavery, Mr. Wiggins points out that ''like many of their slave celebrants, these celebrations have no recorded date of birth. And . . . the historical circumstances which gave birth to these events are also not known.'' He cites at least 15 different celebration dates around the country and points out that there is no consensus as to which should be ''the official day.' '' The celebrations, which are nowadays held primarily in rural and smaller urban communities, range from church ceremonies to secular good-time parties with baseball and barbecue. The author makes clear the links between current styles of celebration and various slave festivities and points out how the politics of protest and the successful campaign to have Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday named a national holiday also continue the freedom jubilee tradition. In this lively study - part history, part ethnography, and part personal reminiscence -Mr. Wiggins has combined painstaking research and detailed interviews with a relaxed, readable writing style to produce a richly textured and fascinating account of a little-known slice of Americana.

title: MAVERICK SCULPTOR MAKES GOOD
description: I'M BASICALLY KIND OF A MAVER-ick,'' Martin Puryear says. ''I've always felt - and maybe this goes way, way back to my earliest years - I really feel like an outsider. I never felt like signing up and joining and being part of a coherent cadre of anything, ideologically, or esthetically, or attitudinally. I never felt compelled to do that.''

title: BICYCLISTS FIND FUN AND HEALTH IN CLUBS
description: A TORRENTIAL rain did not deter Dan Weaver and Mark Covello from going out for a nine-mile bike ride one recent Sunday. ''When you're hooked on riding like we are, the rain doesn't bother you,'' said Mr. Weaver.

title: Turkish Press: Dailies in Display of Freedom
description: Turkey's eight main daily newspapers, some with a panchromatic flourish of news and some with near-naked flesh, hit the streets each day in a robust display of freedoms gathered since the military withdrew from power four years ago.

title: CARING FOR THE CONDOR
description: ''Caring for the Condor'' certainly feathered our nest of bird lore, joyously informing us that endangered California condors are finding refuge at the San Diego Wild Animal Park and the Los Angeles Zoo (Works in Progress, by Bruce Weber, Oct. 4).

title: Nyerere, in Shift, Remains Tanzania Party Leader
description: Julius K. Nyerere, who ruled Tanzania for 24 years, was overwhelmingly re-elected chairman of his country's sole political party today, casting doubt over the future of current economic changes that moderated his Socialist principles.

title: TOLL IN SRI LANKA SHAKES INDIA AIDES
description: Indian Army losses to Tamil rebels in Sri Lanka this month have shaken the Indian military establishment and raised questions among many experts about the quality of New Delhi's military intelligence and planning.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Libel Suits: Protection or Intimidation?
description: LEAD: UNTIL last May, Betty Blake and Eva Bressack, both longtime residents of a south Hempstead neighborhood called Wantagh Woods, knew each other only casually. Today, they are in constant, and anxious, touch.

title: FOR EQUESTRIANS, EVERY DAY IS A DAY FOR RIDING OR PRACTICING
description: ALONG with the glut of people in New Jersey, the most heavily populated of the 50 states, there are now more than 100,000 horses, whose growing population includes standardbreds and thoroughbreds, ponies and palominos, many born and raised on horse farms in the state.

title: Chicago Mother Traded Her Child for Cocaine
description: The authorities have started paper work to deny a pregnant drug addict custody of her two babies. The work began one day after the mother looked through a glass partition and identified a 22-month-old boy as the child she had traded for $50 worth of cocaine.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
MINERVA J. CHAPMAN
description: LEAD: Even among those knowledgeable in the history of art, Minerva J. Chapman's name is not a household word. Born in 1858, Miss Chapman attended the University of Chicago and Mount Holyoke College and later studied at the Art Institute of Chicago, in Paris and in Munich. She died in 1947.

title: Prospects; Battling the Budget Deficit
description: America's stubborn budget deficits - roughly $150 billion in the last fiscal year - are widely blamed for contributing to the Crash of '87. New York Times reporter Lawrence M. Fisher asked three former members of the Council on Economic Advisers for their views on what should be done about it. William A. Niskanen Member of the council, 1981-85. Now chairman of the Cato Institute.

title: N.F.L.'S Integrity Hurt by Owners
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Next Week; Who Should Be the M.V.P.'s In Baseball?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: URBAN RATS IN FASHION'S MAZE
description: THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES By Tom Wolfe. 659 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: Frank Talk on AIDS Brings Praise for Uganda
description: The people of this verdant East African country are being admonished to practice ''zero grazing.''

title: STOLEN LOVES, MANLY VENGEANCE
description: LEAD: HEY JACK! By Barry Hannah. 133 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton/Seymour Lawrence. $15.95.

title: Miss Pomerantz Planning to Wed
description: John J. Pomerantz of New York, Palm Beach, Fla., and Harrison, N.Y., and Mrs. Sanford Furman of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Andrea Gayle Pomerantz to Mitchell David Lynn, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerry Lynn of New York, Palm Beach and Demarest, N.J.

title: The Cocktail Party
description: ATTENTION TO SMALL details can make a cocktail party anxiety-free and just as enjoyable for you as it is for the revelers. Here are some tips to help you plan successfully.

title: South Shore Goes to 3-0
description: Arthur Davis ran for two touchdowns as South Shore beat Sheepshead Bay, 15-6, yesterday at South Shore's home field in Brooklyn. The victory was South Shore's third without a defeat in the Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn A Division I, and it makes next week's game against Midwood, also 3-0, a pivotal one.

title: No-Visa Voyage to Leningrad
description: Throughout the 180-mile boat trip from Helsinki to Leningrad I kept thinking that there would be some foul-up at the Soviet end, some piece of red tape that would prevent us from setting foot in Leningrad without visas. The voyages, which resumed earlier this year after an eight-year hiatus, had been advertised as visa free, providing a daylong tour of the second-largest Soviet city (population five million) after an overnight trip on the Finnish ship Sally Albatross.

title: Other Solutions
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE TRIES ASIAN CARP TO CURB GROWTH IN PONDS
description: LEAD: IN an effort to curb vegetation overgrowth in lakes, ponds and other enclosed waterways, the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation is conducting an experiment that involves stocking ponds with grass carp.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: How Zoos Compare
description: TURTLE BACK ZOO'S 195 species of animals, 16 acres and $840,000 annual operating budget are modest when compared with those of the Bronx and Philadelphia Zoos.

title: Repeal Possible On Contractor Law
description: LEAD: THE East Hampton Town Board is considering a proposal to repeal a 1975 law that provided for the local licensing of home-improvement contractors.

title: Tuscany
description: To the Editor: My family and I recently spent about six weeks in Tuscany, three of them at the Fattoria La Loggia.

title: Home Rule Debate Stirs Vermonters
description: T. Hunter Wilson lives on the land that his ancestor, Boomer Jenckes, farmed after the American Revolution.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about dissension among Republicans misidentified one group that Pat Robertson hopes will support his Presidential bid. The group should have been identified as opponents, not advocates, of gun control.

title: DANCING DAYB, THEN
description: RARELY have I come home from a movie with such an urge to write.

title: MARKET SLIDE WORRIES RETAILERS
description: LEAD: THE stock market debacle may turn Christmas shoppers into Scrooges in the coming weeks, as unsettled consumers grow more reluctant to part with their money or assume more debt, according to many retailers in the state.

title: BEST SELLERS: NOVEMBER 1, 1987
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 2 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 2 2 19 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 3 4 5 LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) A collection of Lake Wobegon monologues, from the radio program ''A Prairie Home Companion.'' 4 3 5 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A tale of two families, the Mains of South Carolina and the Hazards of Pennsylvania, in the aftermath of the Civil War. 5 5 14 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles international terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 6 6 7 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 7 12 3 A SOUTHERN FAMILY, by Gail Godwin. (Morrow, $18.95.) The effect of a violent death on the Quicks, an eccentric North Carolina clan. 8 8 6 HOT FLASHES, by Barbara Raskin. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) At a friend's funeral, three women who had it made in the 60's reflect on their past and future. 9 7 11 SARUM, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Crown, $19.95.) Ten thousand years of English history, seen through the experiences of five families. 10 9 9 LEGACY, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $16.95.) The ordeal of a military officer, charged with high crimes, whose family heritage covers 200 years of constitutional history. 11 10 22 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 12 13 50 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina and New York City. 13 * 11 H 8 FREEDOM, by William Safire. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The early years of the Civil War and Lincoln's developing commitment to emancipation. 14 * 1 BLUEBEARD, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A painter's life in the artists-and-writers world of Long Island's Hamptons. 15 3 TEAM YANKEE, by Harold Coyle. (Presidio, $17.95.) American tank soldiers fight World War III. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 3 VEIL, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the helm of the C.I.A., 1981 to 1987. 2 2 5 TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $15.95.) The television star muses on life at 50. 3 3 14 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former member of the British secret service. 4 4 8 MAN OF THE HOUSE: The Life and Political Memoirs of Speaker Tip O'Neill, with William Novak. (Random House, $19.95.) The former Speaker of the House tells his story. 5 7 17 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 6 5 8 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 7 6 27 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 8 8 7 THE MAKING OF ''THE AFRICAN QUEEN,'' by Katharine Hepburn. (Knopf, $15.95.) The actress's experiences while filming the classic movie. 9 9 8 IT'S ALL IN THE PLAYING, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $18.95.) Behind the scenes during the filming of the television series ''Out on a Limb.'' 10 11 8 STRAIGHT ON TILL MORNING, by Mary S. Lovell. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) The life of Beryl Markham, the pioneer aviator. 11 12 30 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. 12 10 22 CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) Information - history, literature, politics - that you need to read with. 13 14 2 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses how companies can survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 14 15 5 AN AMERICAN CHILDHOOD, by Annie Dillard. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) An introspective account of the author's youth, set mainly in Pittsburgh. 15 1 THE DISCOVERY OF THE TITANIC, by Robert D. Ballard with Rick Archbold. (Madison Press/ Warner, $29.95.) Recent findings about the sinking of the legendary ship 75 years ago. 16 * 2 CRYSTAL WOMAN, by Lynn V. Andrews. (Warner, $16.95.) The author, on a quest for inner knowledge, travels to the heart of Australia. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 17 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 112 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 3 3 13 HOW TO MARRY THE MAN OF YOUR CHOICE, by Margaret Kent. (Warner, $14.95.) Ways to find a mate. 4 4 21 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. 5 5 3 THE TERRIBLE TRUTH ABOUT LAWYERS, by Mark H. McCormack. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $17.95.) Advice from a 1954 graduate of Yale Law School on how to deal with attorneys. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE TRULY DISADVANTAGED: The Inner City, the Underclass, and Public Policy, by William Julius Wilson. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) Mr. Wilson, a sociologist, argues persuasively that black urban poverty persists mainly because of changes in the economy that elude both liberal and conservative analysis. MIAMI, by Joan Didion. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life with Miami's Cuban majority, a community of fierce anti-Communists who feel betrayed by deception and bad faith in Washington. CHAOS: Making a New Science, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) A New York Times reporter's lucid explanation of developments in mathematics that have illuminated a number of annoying situations in the physical world - the weather, for example. FORTY STORIES, by Donald Barthelme. (Putnam, $17.95.) Mr. Barthelme's dream logic is as reliable and persuasive as ever in this collection of narratives, incantations, explanations and hexes. ECONOMICS IN PERSPECTIVE: A Critical History, by John Kenneth Galbraith. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) A survey by the distinguished economist and wit that will instruct and amuse lay readers and provoke the professional economics establishment. THE BIG STORE: Inside the Crisis and Revolution at Sears, by Donald R. Katz. (Viking, $22.95.) Exhaustive and fascinating, this account follows the efforts since 1978 of Sears' chairman, Edward R. Telling, to reinvigorate the fading merchandise empire. CHINESE LIVES: An Oral History of Contemporary China, by Zhang Xinxin and Sang Ye. (Pantheon, $18.95.) Sixty interviews with more or less ordinary Chinese portray a people in the throes of a national transition; many are fatalistic, some banal, but the total inspires a respect for the resilience of humankind.

title: HOW MANY DEBATES ARE ENOUGH?
description: In ''Two Party Chiefs Vie for Office'' [ Politics, Oct. 11 ] , Frank Lynn writes that Joseph N. Mondello ''is trying to ignore his opponent, limiting debates, for example, to a maximum of three.'' Who is he to say that three is not enough?

title: 1917: WHEN WOMEN WON RIGHT TO VOTE
description: WHEN Westchester women go to the polls Tuesday, they are unlikely to cause the stir they created 70 years ago in the election of Nov. 6, 1917.

title: Woman Held in Philadelphia In Kidnapping of an Infant
description: A woman was arrested here Friday on charges of kidnapping a baby boy from his mother's Baltimore hospital room in June. The infant was being tested to confirm his identity, Federal agents said.

title: HOSPICE WILL OFFER CARE TO THE HOMELESS
description: LEAD: WHEN the Connecticut Hospice in Branford opens its new building in January, it will provide care not only for more terminally ill cancer patients, but also for patients who are homeless or have no one to care for them. .

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH referendums calling for more prisons and a baseball stadium have received most of the attention, there are two public questions on the ballot Tuesday that are aimed at preserving the state's rapidly diminishing open spaces.

title: Headliners; Out of the Running
description: Louisiana's gambling Governor, Edwin Edwards, decided early last Sunday morning that a fourth term was not in the cards. Mr. Edwards, known for scandal-scarred administrations and a love of high-stakes recreation in Las Vegas, dropped his bid for re-election after finishing second in the Democratic gubernatorial primary. With his withdrawal, Representative Buddy Roehmer, a conservative Democrat who was considered an underdog, became the Governor-elect. Mr. Edwards's decision not to face Mr. Roehmer in a runoff election astounded many.

title: Lions Glimpse Promised Land
description: Columbia managed to get a lead for the first time in a year, but the edge didn't last long yesterday and by the end of the afternoon the Lions had been beaten for the 38th straight time.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
GETTING PERMISSION TO HAVE AN ABORTION
description: LEAD: IN the 15 years since the Supreme Court ruled that women have a constitutionally protected right to an abortion, much of the national debate on the subject has focused on an issue of particular emotional import: abortions performed on minors.

title: How Ugliness Led to Happiness
description: HERE IS DANIEL AUTEUIL, arguably France's hottest young actor these days - or, at least, the one who got the best actor award at the French version of the Oscar ceremonies in Paris this year -and he doesn't look it.

title:
ANTIQUES;
ELEGANT HOUSE TOUR OF RURAL AMERICANA
description: LEAD: FROM the floor-to-ceiling bay window in her early 19th-century kitchen, Virginia Petree enjoys a panoramic view of hills and farmland that stretch in curves and patchwork to a distant barn and silo.

title: Practical Traveler; Calming the Jitters About Tipping on Cruises
description: It takes no graduate student of body language to see how awkward many people feel about tipping. They go through pockets and purse, pulling out handkerchiefs, house keys and credit cards, but never come up with a bill of a suitable denomination for the bellman poised by the door. Eventually, they find a crumpled bill, or mumble something about catching the employee later, and retreat in embarrassment.

title: The Point of Contention
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ON THE POLITICAL SIDELINES PETER F. COHALAN and Francis T. Purcell will be working Tuesday, Election Day, but not rounding up votes. The former Suffolk County and Nassau County Executives will spend what could have been their re-election day busily engaged in new careers.

title: The Flight to Money Market Funds
description: THE rout on Wall Street has produced at least one clear winner: money market funds. ''Panic in the equity markets creates a flight to safety, and money funds are one of the few groups to benefit from the general market turmoil,'' said Glen King Parker, publisher of Income and Safety, a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., newsletter covering fixed-income investments.

title: Compact Disk Shrinks
description: THE COMPACT DISK IS about four and a half inches in diameter - or it was until now. Two record companies, Delos and Rykodisc, have issued a three-inch compact disk, but it is designed to be an adjunct, rather than a replacement, for the four-inch version.

title: 3-Day Blizzard in Himalayas Strands Nearly 200 Climbers
description: Heavy snow kept nearly 200 foreign climbers from leaving Himalayan mountains after a freak snowstorm, but sketchy reports reaching Beijing today said the mountaineers were well-equipped for the stay.

title: Guest Observer; A Magazine Junkie
description: I'M HOPELESS WHEN IT comes to books. I can't go past a bookshop without slipping in to buy some classic I've never read before -one of those handsome Penguin editions of Dickens or Jane Austen, a volume of Henry James's correspondence or the poems of Wordsworth. The old-fashioned illustrations on the cover, the crisp pages, the unbroken spine: they give off powerful emanations of culture, promise self-improvement, a subtle deepening of the mind. I can hardly wait to get home and sink into my easy chair that night with my new acquisition. To think that all these years I never got around to reading ''Jane Eyre''!

title: KARPOV AND KASPAROV AGREE TO DRAW IN GAME 7 OF SERIES
description: The challenger, Anatoly Karpov, and the titlist, Gary Kasparov, agreed to a draw today in the seventh game of the world chess championship after a 79-move struggle.

title: HOSPITAL USES TRIVIA IN PURSUIT OF FUNDS
description: LEAD: IT CAN take less than an hour to go from the state's southernmost point, Cape May, to its northernmost, High Point, and pick up bits and pieces of information along the way. By plane? No, by board - the board of a new game that promotes New Jersey and raises funds for a hospital.

title: HOW TO MAKE IT A SUCCESS
description: THIS IS THE TIME of year to think about festive gatherings of family and friends. But it is also the time when holiday chores and social and business commitments can reach daunting proportions. An entertaining success, then, lies less in creating ''the perfect party'' with the maximum amount of time and resources than in working out a plan to bring pleasure and a sense of celebration to the party giver as well as to the guests. On the following pages are several strategies, culled from hosts and hostesses around the country.

title: FROM THE RIGHT: Arthur B. Laffer; A Time to 'Undo'
description: Excerpts from an interview with Arthur B. Laffer, a member of President Reagan's Economic Policy Advisory Board and chairman of A. B. Laffer Associates, a brokerage firm.

title: Toy for Cribs Being Recalled As a Hazard of Strangulation
description: Crib Soft Playgrounds for cribs and playpens are being recalled because a Minnesota child died after catching his head between the loosely tied toy and his crib's mesh, the Consumer Product Safety Commission reported Thursday.

title: Race Looks Short on Stars, but Long on Intrigue
description: There are no big names to boast about. And it is extremely doubtful that today's New York City Marathon will be run in the best of times, challenging the course record or the world best. But this could be one of the more intriguing runs through the five boroughs in recent years, perhaps offering a sprint to the finish in Central Park or even a surprise winner, overlooked by the race officials and news media alike.

title: WHAT'S ALL THIS DYING, HELMUT?
description: BREAKERS By Martin Walser. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. 305 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

title: Filtering Airwaves For Indecency
description: ELEVEN years after issuing an order banning indecency in broadcasting, the Federal Communications Commission acted six months ago to enforce the order.

title: DEBATE ON TUTORING CENTERS
description: LEAD: TO the observer wandering into this classroom, it might at first seem odd to see a student asking - begging, actually - her teacher to give her a test.

title: WEST; AIKMAN RESCUES U.C.L.A.
description: Troy Aikman passed for two touchdowns to Paco Craig during a 17-point third-quarter surge as U.C.L.A. overcame Arizona State, 31-23, in a Pacific-10 Conference game today.

title: Q&A
description: A Caveat on Co-ops Question: I read recently about an improperly managed cooperative apartment house where the owners lost their equity to a bank and became renters of their apartments instead of owners. I am considering buying a co-op apartment and want to know if there is any type of insurance I can buy to cover this contingency. . . . N. G., Rockville Centre, L.I. Answer: Ted Kleinman, a mortgage broker with the firm of Donald Zucker Company, says that he is not aware of any type of mortgage insurance that individual shareholders could buy that would cover their losses if the residential co-op they belong to defaulted to a bank.

title: Coming to Our Economic and Military Senses
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Finch, Psychiatrist, to Wed
description: The engagement of Dr. Elizabeth Lathrop Finch to Peter Goodwin Coe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm D. Coe of Bassett, Va., has been announced by her parents, Elizabeth J. Finch of New York and Quogue, L.I., and Edward R. Finch Jr. of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: BOSTON;
The City Wants A Lower Profile
description: LEAD: ''WE'D like to do another building of 500,000 to one million square feet in the next two years,'' said Joshua Massey of Metropolitan Life, which has 340,000 square feet opening this winter in the financial district. ''I'd love to do five million to 10 million in the next five years. I'm just hot on this area.

title: A Baritone Cancels Dates And the Met Cancels Him
description: RENATO BRUSON, the Italian baritone who had previously withdrawn from three scheduled appearances as Iago in the Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Otello'' in September, has canceled all his dates with the company this season.

title: Miss von Strasser Weds Fabian Graf von Einsiedel
description: At Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., Daisy Felicitas von Strasser became the bride yesterday of Fabian Graf von Einsiedel, a son of Walburga Grafin von Einsiedel of Frankfurt and the late Wittigo Graf von Einsiedel. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolf von Strasser of Pelham Manor and Vienna. The Rev. Joachim Kerssenbrock performed the ceremony.

title: AMID ETHICS STRUGGLE, PORT CHESTER TURNS TO FIGHT CONNECTICUT
description: Hard-pressed Port Chester officials, facing breach-of-ethics charges for buying condominiums before they became available to the public, have received some good news in another dispute in their village.

title: Smoking vs. Life Expectancy
description: A Federal study blames cigarette smoking for 315,120 deaths around the nation in 1984, which represents a loss of 3.6 million years in terms of shortened lifespans, the researchers say.

title: Are Rent Vouchers a Boon or a Bust?
description: SINCE they were authorized by Congress in 1983, housing vouchers - cash substitutes given directly to tenants - have become the centerpiece of Federal policy on low-income housing.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in Travel Advisory on Oct. 11 incorrectly listed the languages included in a new book, ''The Wander Woman's Phrasebook.'' The phrases in the book are translated into Spanish, not German, as well as into French and Italian. In addition, the publisher was misidentified; it is the Shameless Hussy Press.

title: Cole Porter's Lyrics Depend On the Music, But Even Solo They're So Easy to Love
description: IF YOU'VE FORGOTTEN WHAT it's like to leave a theater walking on air, a remedy lies ready to hand. The revival of ''Anything Goes'' at the Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater is wonderfully exhilarating and euphoria-inducing; Patty LuPone's Reno Sweeney is only one - though the most memorable - of an array of fine performances, and whatever minor imperfections the production may have are soon lost sight of in the glow cast by its energy and joie de vivre.

title: IS THERE LIFE AFTER FOOTBALL?
description: Peter Applebome's article ''Is There Life After Football?'' (Oct. 4) was well done, but it didn't address the issue: Did Southern Methodist University do anything wrong?

title: CARROUSELS FAST BECOMING JUST A MEMORY
description: IN LINE with what experts say is a trend, the final remnants of old-time carrousels - the ones with artfully carved wooden horses and menagerie figures that made children merry as they went 'round and 'round - were sold here 'round and 'round - were sold here recently.

title: U.S., CONTRAS AND SANDINISTAS FACE A RECKONING ON PEACE PLAN
description: A HISTORIC deadline arrives in Nicaragua this week. The deadline on Thursday closes the first phase of the ambitious Arias plan designed to bring peace to Central America generally and particularly to end the guerrilla erally and particularly to end the guerrilla war that has killed 40,000 Nicaraguans since the Sandinistas took power in 1979.

title: India Is Battling Pornographic Movie Posters
description: Dozens of policemen swept through the capital's movie theaters last week, pulling down movie posters showing semi-nude women and sexually explicit scenes, to show the authorities' determination to enforce a new law on obscenity.

title: PLAN FOR OLD MINE ROUSES CORTLANDT
description: WOMEN smoothed their fingernails for three-quarters of a century with emery, a substance almost as hard as diamonds, that came from the mines of Cortlandt, once among the largest producers of emery in the world.

title: Vermont Moves to Decertify Former Bennington Educator
description: The State Education Commissioner, Stephen Kaagan, has asked for the decertification of George Sleeman, the former Bennington area school superintendent.

title: GIANT'S LINEBACKING CORPS HAS ONE NEW MEMBER: TURMOIL
description: Think of the Giants' locker room as shaped like a human, and the first thing you see - the head, so to speak - is Harry Carson's locker. And one stall away is Lawrence Taylor's locker.

title: Where the Sick Lie in Chains
description: The images lend a grim whiff of the Middle Ages to modern New York City hospitals: Patients in desperate straits - devastated victims of AIDS, pregnant women on the verge of labor - lie shackled and chained to their beds.

title: Linda Bradshaw To Wed in April
description: The engagement of Linda Patrice Bradshaw to David Karim Lakhdhir, the son of Noor and Ann Hallan Lakhdhir of Westport, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Gail Bradshaw of Derwood, Md., and Thomas T. Bradshaw of Rockville, Md. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: Therapists Protest Award to Member of Reagan AIDS Panel
description: Dr. Theresa Crenshaw, a member of the President's commission on AIDS, drew renewed criticism at a meeting of 3,400 family therapists here this weekend.

title: COMPUTER SHOWS IT CAN BEAT A HUMAN MASTER
description: The most significant finding on the progress made by chess-playing computers was the victory in the recent Pennsylvania State Championship Tourney by Hitech, a program by Dr. Hans Berliner of Carnegie-Mellon University. Hitech scored 4 1/2- 1/2 to share first

title: WAS MAN MEANT TO FLY?
description: AMERICANS have always been on the move, but never have so many moved so far so fast.

title: DEAN OF NEWSCASTERS IS PROUD OF LEGACY
description: LEAD: DOUGLAS EDWARDS, who has lived in Connecticut for about 37 years, has lived up to one of the state's nicknames, ''The Land of Steady Habits.'' In December, the much-honored pioneer radio and television newsman will have completed 45 years with CBS News.

title: Books From The Times
description: CITY SLICKERS. By William E. Geist. (Times Books, $16.95.) He came from the Midwest to a city he suspects is ''as different from mainland America as Botswana.'' William E. Geist's impressions filled the About New York column of The New York Times as he explored a city he found ''exciting, yes, but in a terrifying kind of way.'' In this collection, the former Times columnist walks the dreamscape streets and talks to, besides Donald Trump, Lee Iacocca and Ralph Lauren, among others, a ''car shepherd'' who will find you a legal parking spot, guerrilla golfers who play in sixteensomes to intimidate muggers, and a woman who teaches a course in ''How to Lose Your Noo Yawk Accent.''

title: Talking: Closings; Surviving Market's Turmoil
description: THE recent turbulence in the stock market is causing many concerns for buyers who are poised to close on a home or an investment property.

title: White at The New Yorker
description: To the Editor:

title: MEMOIRS OF WEEQUAHIC JEWS
description: LEAD: FRANCES GARFINKEL remembers the time when children coming out of the Hebrew school at Temple Oheb Shalom in Newark's Weequahic section used to throw snowballs at her hat because it ''had these birds on it, and the children would try to hit them.''

title: Building of Arts Center Progresses at Columbia
description: Columbia University's undergraduate art center is taking shape on the lower two floors of a new 17-story dormitory under construction on campus.

title: Gillian Drake Angle, a Director, Wed To James B. Moorhead in Connecticut
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., Gillian Drake Angle, a daughter of Joan M. Angle of Westport, Conn., and Ludlow, Vt., was married yesterday to James Barr Moorhead, a son of Mrs. William S. Moorhead of Washington and the Plains, Va., and the late Representative Moorhead of Pennsylvania. The Rev. Stephen J. Chinlund, the church's rector, and the Rev. Stephen Arpee performed the ceremony.

title: UNIFORM RULES ON SENTENCING TO TAKE EFFECT IN U.S. COURTS
description: Despite the objections of some judges and lawyers, a new and, some say, stricter uniform system of sentencing will go into effect Sunday in Federal district courts.

title: EAST; B.C. UPSETS TENNESSEE, 20-18
description: Willie Hislop and Tim Frager ran for touchdowns in the first nine minutes of the second half as Boston College upset Tennessee, 20-18, today.

title: Stephen G. Bowen Jr. Wed to Susan B. Stout
description: At the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church in Plainfield, N.J., Susan Bohlen Stout, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Stout of Plainfield, was married yesterday to Stephen G. Bowen Jr., the president of J. Walter Thompson USA Inc., the advertising agency in New York. The Rev. William R. Harvey, the pastor of the church, and the Rev. Joseph F. Barbone, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: B. D. Smith To Be Wed To Miss Day
description: The engagement of Beverly Billings Day to Bradford Delano Smith, a son of Mrs. Frank Y. Larkin of Greenwich, Conn., and David Shiverick Smith of Washington, has been made known by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mrs. Vincent C. Banker of Locust Valley, L.I., and Richard W. Day of New York. The couple plan to marry in February.

title: The Reagans Attend Funeral For Her Mother in Phoenix
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy attended funeral services for Mrs. Reagan's mother here today, and Mr. Reagan delivered the eulogy.

title: Q AND A
description: Dialing Weather Question:I believe there is a telephone service for travelers who want to know what kind of weather they are going into. How do you get it? -R. H., Mahwah, N.J. Answer:The service called WeatherTrak gives weather information for 190 cities in North America and 60 overseas. To get information you first need to call WeatherTrak (800-247-3282) to find out the nearest access number - there are several across the country. In New York, for example, it's 212-355-1212. On reaching the access number, travelers -using a touch-tone phone - dial the area code for the United States or Canadian city for which information is needed or the first three letters of a foreign city - PAR for Paris, for example. Callers with rotary phones can only get local weather.

title: HOW RISK RATTLED THE STREET
description: ONCE upon a time, there were mostly stocks, bonds and bank accounts, and it was a much simpler age.

title: Blast Theory in Titanic's Sinking Is Disputed
description: The suggestion that an explosion played a critical role in the sinking of the Titanic 75 years ago is incompatible with accounts by survivors, according to Dr. Robert Ballard, leader of the expedition that found the wreckage of the giant ocean liner in 1985.

title: Question Of the Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
description: TweedleBoss and TweedleBilly. The other Yankees are only supporting players in their perpetual drama. Nothing changes. TREBOR LLOYD New York

title: A VOTING MACHINE LEVER CAN ALSO BE A SAFETY VALVE
description: THIS is an off year in national politics, but there is one element of the electoral process that never quite shuts off.

title: Brunswick Goes to 7-0
description: Brunswick moved its record to 7-0 with a handy 27-12 win over Salisbury, setting up next week's Fairchester League showdown with Fieldston, who shut out Dalton, 21-0.

title: ONLY HE COULD LIVE WITH HIMSELF
description: LEAD: IMAGES OF DESTRUCTION By David Wigoder. 272 pp. New York: Routledge & Kegan Paul. $17.95.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.,
description: JOHN MAZZOLA is convinced that his wife, Sylvia, lives by the maxim ''Don't get into any vehicle that's not moving.'' If this maxim is not a familiar one, it is not surprising because, he said, his wife made it up.

title: Piano: William Wolfram
description: WILLIAM WOLFRAM seems to have survived the competition process with most of his sensibilities intact. He is a busy warrior in the field, and fresh from his victory in the William Kapell piano contest at the University of Maryland, Mr. Wolfram gave a piano recital at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night.

title: Generous Servings
description: BIG IS BOLD, BIG IS GENEROUS, BIG IS welcoming - and so are the oversize objects that are asserting themselves on the most fashionable table tops across the country. ''In the old days, everything had to be on a small scale, but today, overstatement is what looks good,'' explained Mario Buatta, the well-known New York City interior decorator. ''Nothing looks better on a buffet table than a very large plate.'' ''Big objects make a statement, don't get lost in the shuffle and have a lot of presence,'' added Peri Wolfman, a co-owner of Wolfman-Gold & Good Company, which operates two Manhattan home-furnishings shops.

title: Le Glorieux, the Favorite, Takes the D.C. International
description: The strains of ''Deutschland Uber Alles'' wafted through Laurel Race Course today, signaling that Le Glorieux had provided West Germany with its first victory in the history of the Washington D.C. International. But the colt's triumph was multinational. The 3-year-old represented West Germany because that is the nationality of his owner, Werner Wolf, but Le Glorieux was sired by an Irish stallion, born in England, trained by a Frenchman and ridden by a Panamanian.

title: Alice Albright Wed in Capital
description: Alice Patterson Albright, a daughter of Madeleine Korbel Albright of Washington and Joseph Medill Patterson Albright of Rome, was married at the Washington Cathedral yesterday to Gregory Bigelow Bowes, the son of Judith G. Bowes of Chevy Chase, Md., and David B. Bowes of Washington. Bishop John T. Walker of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington performed the ceremony.

title: Recital: Levine and Noda
description: Museum on Thursday night.

title: Researchers Report Progress In the Treatment of Cirrhosis
description: A drug used to treat gout has significantly extended the lives of cirrhosis victims and even reversed the damage that cirrhosis does to the liver, researchers working in Mexico have reported.

title: Hat Whimsies
description: THE outrageous cocktail hat - the kind that leads to conversation betwen strangers and breaks the ice at parties - bobbed about last week at the opening of an exhibition called Surrealism that will run through Jan. 23 at the Fashion Institute of Technology Galleries, 27th Street and Seventh Avenue. Jana Jagondorf, left, an artists' representative, wore a sculptured fish wrapped around her head much like a coronet. And a foot-long branch of pink silk morning glories pierced the black velour toque worn by the theatrical costume designer Willa Kim. Fashion fantasies like these become decorative elements of the parties themselves.

title: ANTISMOKING CAMPAIGN IS PLANNED FOR NEW YORK
description: Speakers at an antismoking conference said Friday that an advertising campaign would target members of the New York City Council who fail to support a bill to restrict smoking in public places.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: NOVEMBER 1, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE GOLDEN CUP, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.95.) title: Robbie Robertson Waltzes Back Into Rock
description: ROBBIE ROBERTSON, WHO WAS the guitarist and producer for the Band and wrote ''The Weight,'' ''The Night They Drove Old Dixie

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CATHOLIC GIRLS. By Kit Reed. (Donald I. Fine, $17.95.) ''Is it terribly Catholic to want to make wrong things right?'' muses one of Kit Reed's characters. Such questions are raised but never answered in her engaging 11th novel, which takes a comic look at what happens to graduates of a Roman Catholic school when they grow up.

title: Cash in the Till at a Discount
description: LEAD: AS a measure of how gun-shy investors have become, money managers are beginning to spot a few stocks selling for less than the cash held in the corporate till. Spotting them, but not necessarily buying them. The Chicago Milwaukee Corporation, a former railroad holding company, traded last week on the New York Stock Exchange at $118 a share, down from a 1987 high of $156.25.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FOUND IN THE STREET. By Patricia Highsmith. (Atlantic Monthly Press, $16.95.) Patricia Highsmith writes compellingly about those ambiguous boundaries that are supposed to separate rational behavior from irrationality and beautiful lives from grotesque ones. Her 19th novel centers on Elsie, a pretty 20-year-old waitress who has moved to Greenwich Village from upstate New York, dreaming of modeling or becoming an actress.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: LOGRANDE: PLANNER'S PHILOSOPHY
description: MICHAEL A. LoGRANDE, the Acting County Executive in Suffolk County and the Republican nominee for the post, came to Long Island in 1967 as a registered Democrat. ''I was a registered Democrat when I lived in Flushing,'' he said in a recent interview, ''and I was still a registered Democrat when I moved to Hauppauge.''

title: A Lively Diversity Marks a New Label
description: WHEN THE CD CATALOGUE of a small independent record company features such dissimilar entries as ''Lisztronique: Electronic Performances of Music by Franz Liszt,'' four volumes of Bach preludes and fugues with the organist Anthony Newman, and ''Larry Adler Live at the Ballroom,'' you just know that a lively imagination is at play behind the scenes. The catalogue is that of Newport Classic Ltd., of Providence, R. I.; the imagination belongs to Lawrence Kraman, the firm's founder and principal producer.

title: Verbatim:; Hard Times
description: ' Any major calamity affects fund-raising. I remember when George Wallace was shot, when John Kennedy was shot, even when Reagan was shot, people stopped giving. This time it's even worse. People are old enough to remember the Depression. ' Bruce W. Eberle Republican fund-raiser, noting the plunge in political contributions since the stock market debacle.

title: INTERIOR DESIGNERS AND WHAT THEY DO
description: The Dorises of the article bear as much resemblance to professional interior designers and architects as the Tammy and Jim Bakkers look like the Pope and the Vatican.

title: Cash-Rich Funds Hold Out for Fire Sale
description: MONEY managers who had built substantial cash positions as a defensive strategy before the stock market's collapse were in no hurry last week to return to buying common stocks. Even in the face of prices that would have appeared irresistible a month ago, the prevailing feeling among some of the country's more conservative investors, some of whom had as much as 50 percent of their portfolios in cash, was that the risk of a further decline outweighed any opportunity.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SUFFOLK DEBATE
description: FOLLOWING are excerpts from a debate between two candidates for Suffolk County Executive: Michael A. LoGrande, Republican, who also has Conservative and Right-to-Life Party backing, and Patrick G. Halpin, Democrat, who is also running on the People Against Lilco line. The Liberal Party candidate, John DiLavore Jr., did not attend. The candidates were questioned by reporters and editors at The New York Times. SALES TAX

title: HOLY CROSS ROLLS TO A RECORD OF 8-0
description: Led by Jeff Wiley's 438 yards passing, including four touchdown tosses, Holy Cross rolled over the University of Massachusetts, 54-10, today to remain the only undefeated football team in Division I-AA, at 8-0.

title: Hysteria Goes On
description: IT was a long time coming, and they wanted it so much they could taste it. Now that they have it, fans of the Minnesota Twins apparently plan to keep on savoring their World Series victory, at least until Wheaties gets tired of printing ''Breakfast of Champions'' boxes showing the champion Twins celebrating their triumph.

title: BRITISH STAMPS THAT LOOK BACK INTO HISTORY
description: THAT stamps can be used as concise history lessons is demonstrated in three recent issues from Britain. In September, the British issued a set of four stamps titled ''Victorian Britain: Great People; Great Times;'' In July, they released a set of four ''Scottish Heraldry'' stamps and in June, the 100th anniversary of the St. John's Ambulance Brigade was used to honor 100 years of medical care in Britain.

title: FROM THE LEFT: Harry Magdoff; A Free-Market Failure
description: Excerpts from an interview with Harry Magdoff, co-editor, with Paul Sweezy, of Monthly Review, a socialist magazine:

MUSIC;
AMERICAN MUSIC WEEK TO BE OBSERVED
description: LEAD: SEVERAL New Jersey organizations will participate in the third annual American Music Week, which will be celebrated internationally tomorrow through next Sunday.

title: Hits on Parade: Some Lessons of a Top-10 Countdown
description: TAKING THE PULSE, RAN-dom-testing the product, sampling for pollutants -you pick the metaphor, but occasionally it's amusing to look at the Top 10 singles and see how American popular music is doing.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Rome-Milan Rapid Trains

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: OUTLAWS. By George V. Higgins. (Henry Holt, $18.95.) It is always a pleasure to find a new George Higgins novel in the bookstores. He has developed a technique of storytelling in which almost all the exposition comes in the form of rhythmical and repetitious dialogue that can be fun and even exciting to decipher.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT took my friend Judy Huttner to open my eyes to what was happening all around me, without my noticing. Judy is an artist, but primarily she is an art-tour guide, conducting trips to museums and galleries and studios for Long Islanders interested in the graphic arts.

title: Felonies Down As Transit Police Reorganize
description: New York City's transit police department, in the midst of a major reorganization, is on its way to recording one of the lowest annual subway felony rates in recent years.

title: MIDWEST; INDIANA SLIPS AS IOWA RALLIES, 29-21
description: Chuck Hartlieb led a 86-yard drive that was capped by a 1-yard dive in the fourth quarter by David Hudson as Iowa rallied to stun Indiana, 29-21, today in a rain-drenched Big Ten game.

title: Old English Conductors
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Ekberg Wed To Gerald Tsai Jr.
description: Cynthia Ann Ekberg, a vice president of Kidder Peabody & Company in San Diego, and Gerald Tsai Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of the Primerica Corporation in Greenwich, Conn., formerly the American Can Company, were married yesterday at the Hotel del Coronado in Coronado, Calif. Judge Runston G. Maino, presiding judge of the Municipal Court in the North San Diego County Judicial District, officiated.

title: A Nominee With a Short 'Paper Trail'
description: PRESIDENT Reagan's last-minute selection of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg for the United States Supreme Court left combatants in the long battle over Judge Robert H. Bork scrambling to learn new lines.

title: Traveling With a Touchy Tooth
description: ''Ouch!''

title: Pleasantville Struggles
description: Pleasantville - undefeated and ranked first in the C Division - faced what seemed to be an inferior opponent but found its stiffest challenge of the season yesterday, managing to hold off Valhalla in the closing minutes by a score of 13-12.

title: Symbols That Matter
description: A financial world fearful of incompetence in the American Government is looking desperately for reassuring symbols. People want a sign that Washington understands the seriousness of the economic threat. They want to see a willingness to put aside political fancies in a search for common purpose.

title: Food Banks
description: To the Editor:

title: FINDING GRACE IN THE AWKWARD HUMANITY OF PEOPLE
description: HELEN LEVITT WAS THE FIRST American photographer to fully comprehend the essence of Henri Cartier-Bresson's photographic message and put it into practice. Like Cartier-Bresson, she understood how to combine intuition and intellect to forge sophisticated, lyrical compositions from commonplace events. With the encouragement of her friend Walker Evans, she haunted the streets and subways of New York City in the early 1940's in much the same way that Cartier-Bresson traversed Paris in the early 30's, infatuated with the possibilities of the hand-held camera.

title: DIOXIN: HOW MUCH IS TOO MUCH?
description: THE state has picked incineration as the technology to rescue Connecticut from a mounting pile of trash, but safety questions are growing about the smokestack emissions and the ash.

title: A MODERN-DAY 'MEDEA' IN YALE DRAMA SERIES
description: CREON'S queen descends upon Corinth in a helicopter. His daughter has a jeep, operated by remote control. Jason bears gifts of BB guns and toy aircraft carriers for his sons. And the Chorus lunges into a rap number.

title: Rock: The Cars, A Quintet
description: THE Cars were purring at Madison Square Garden on Thursday like a custom-built engine fresh from a tuneup. Over the years, the Boston-based quintet has achieved a streamlined consistency that is most impressive in person, with one meticulously crafted hit song following another.

title: Eternal Vigilance Is the Price of Feminism
description: To the Editor:

title: A Send-Off From This 'Vale of Tears'
description: LEAD: At the funeral for the 28-year-old cancer victim, the priest sounds very much like a National Aeronautics and Space Administration official: Something unspeakably horrible has occurred, our hearts are heavy, but the system - whatever its seeming imperfections - works. The tragedy is part of an indecipherable plan, but it is not without meaning, and from this we can take comfort.

title:
NOTEBOOK: HONOLULU;
1901 Restoration For Waikiki
description: LEAD: EXTENSIVE restoration of the turn-of-the-century Moana Hotel began in August, and its owner, the Kokusai Kogyo Company, hopes to restore the ''first lady of Waikiki Beach'' to its original splendor.

title: TENSE MANILA DEBATES HOW BEST TO FIGHT THE REBELS
description: WHETHER the gunmen who killed three American servicemen and a Filipino businessman near Clark Air Base in the Philippines last week were Communists is not certain. An anonymous caller claimed responsibility for the Communists' Alex Boncayo Brigade. American and Philippine authorities said the ambush followed the pattern of assassinations by Communists, but it was still possible that a right-wing group had killed the Americans, hoping the Communists would be blamed.

title: Kimberly Ann Flahive Wed to Mark E. Wasik
description: Kimberly Ann Flahive, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Henry Flahive of Yardley, Pa., and Mark Eugene Wasik, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Eugene Wasik of Montpelier, Vt., were married yesterday at St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Yardley. The Rev. John C. Marine performed the ceremony.

title: COURT CHOICE IN FOCUS: A PORTRAIT OF GINSBURG
description: Douglas H. Ginsburg, President Reagan's new choice to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court, is best known in Washington as an advocate of a conservative philosophy of government regulation, prodding agencies to decide regulatory questions according to a strict comparison of the social costs and benefits.

title: 'MOBY DICK' MEANINGS AND MISQUOTATIONS
description: When Herman Melville, in ''Moby Dick,'' attributed the line ''I only am escaped alone to tell thee'' to Job, he was referring to the Book of Job, and not to the character. Actually this line was uttered in the Bible by four separate messengers to Job. There is quite a difference between having the victim cry that he has escaped alone and having a servant tell the victim of the latter's losses.

title: PIERPOINTE PROJECT CALLED BOON TO YONKERS
description: Critics of the plan to build a new residential community on the Hudson River with shops and public waterfront access [ ''High Rises Draw Protest in Yonkers,'' Sept. 27 ] completely lose sight of this proposed development's most significant impact: it will provide stimulus to the well-being and economy of all of Yonkers.

title: Question Of the Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
description: What will the new or rather renewed Yankee changes mean? Suffering for the fans, pressure on the players, field days for the media and finally - reruns of that old sitcom in the Bronx called the Yankees. ANDREW SIFF Middletown, Conn.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE RING MASTER. By David Gurr. (Atheneum, $25.) This ambitious, highly elaborate work of historical fiction by the British-born novelist David Gurr, who lives in Canada, conflates Wagnerian motifs and Jungian archetypes, Nazism and the Holy Grail, brother-sister incest and Hitler's power to fascinate.

title: MOUNTAIN HIKES, NOW
description: 'Aw c'mon, Mom! It's an easy climb. Even you can make it.'' Ever since we bought our cabin near the trail head of Crane Mountain in the Adirondacks, our son Jon has been after me to go up Crane.

title: Pension Funds Weather the Market Collapse
description: DESPITE some staggering losses, the nation's pension funds, and their beneficiaries, have come through the great market collapse of 1987 in relatively good shape - so far.

title: THE LAWYER'S SIDE OF THE MALPRACTICE ISSUE
description: I would like to respond to ''Curing Those Who Sue Their Doctors'' [ Opinion page, Sept. 27 ] . Dr. K. J. Lee suggests that plaintiffs' lawyers are bringing too many groundless medical malpractice cases and are being unjustly enriched in the process. I disagree.

title: Lakers Own the West, but East May Be Wide Open
description: The following analysis of the National Basketball Association teams was prepared and written by Sam Goldaper.

title: Headliners; Out of the Market
description: A decade ago, a crooked Kansas City lawyer named Arthur H. Katz began, with the help of the Federal witness protection program, a metamorphosis that turned him into Arthur Kane, a Miami civil servant with a talent for playing the stock market. But when the market crashed, Mr. Kane's new life went with it. Mr. Kane, who was given a new identity by Federal authorities in return for testifying against his co-conspirators in an insurance fraud scheme, apparently made a fortune in the stock market while working as a $30,000-a-year civil servant. His double life became public with his death last week. Distraught over losses that reportedly ran as high as $15 million, Mr. Kane went to his stockbroker's office and shot two executives, one of them fatally, before killing himself.

title: AFRICA NATION OPENS DOORS TO THE FRENCH
description: Three nights a week, the President of this Spanish-speaking country retires to a quiet room in the palace, flicks on his tape recorder, and practices his French.

title: ELIZABETH STRIKE: SHAME ON ALL OF YOU
description: As you enter Elizabeth on Route 1, there is a sign that reads, ''Elizabeth - A Proud Lady.'' After the performance on the school dispute, or lack thereof, by those responsible for the leadership in our city, I suggest the sign be redone to read: ''Elizabeth -A Lady of Shame.''

title: Article 520487 -- No Title
description: Calling it a commitment to the inner city, Federal officials this week announced plans to build a $55 million courthouse in the heart of the downtown area near City Hall.

title: Estate Affairs
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
description: Good news for the Yankees! Billy Martin is a skilled and demanding manager. He will unify this team and push each talented player to his limit. Piniella is a quick study and will learn the general-manager business faster than most. Lou is the perfect buffer between the ''Boss'' and the volatile Martin. If Martin lasts the season, nothing can stop the Yankees! A. DOWNING New York

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE DEVIL'S OTHER STORYBOOK By Natalie Babbitt. Illustrated by the author. 82 pp. New York: Michael di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: Commercial Property: Warehouses; An 'Ugly Duckling' Starts to Get Investors' Respect
description: LONG shunned for their lack of glamour and grandeur, warehouses now produce some of the highest annual returns in the nation's real-estate market.

title: LASDON PARK HOTEL TERMED 'RUMOR'
description: LEAD: COUNTY officials and the Hilton Hotels Corporation said last week that a 150-room hotel was not planned for Lasdon Park on Route 35 in Somers.

title: 200 REPORTED HELD BY POLICE IN CHILE
description: The police detained about 200 dissidents today in several Santiago neighborhoods as they passed out pamphlets that called for an open presidential election, witnesses reported.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Luxury Builder Explores a New Market
description: ONE of Connecticut's best-known builders, whose projects have been almost entirely in the affluent communities of Greenwich and Stamford, has ventured for the first time into a more remote location and a lower price range.

title: THE ECONOMIC HISTORIANS' VIEW: Comparing the Collapses; Moses Abramovitz: No Panic Now
description: EVERY serious depression in business, and virtually every recession in American economic history, has been accompanied by a serious decline of stock prices. Not every serious decline of stock prices has led to a depression or even a recession. Moreover, when the two came together, it cannot be said that the stock market collapse was the cause of the business contraction. They responded to common causes. Viewed over a year or two, in fact, the reverse was more important. Business contraction, when it came, pushed stock prices down. In the past, many of the great stock market declines were incidents of more general financial panic. Recurrent waves of bank failures and a great decline in the money stock were central features of the Great Contraction from 1929 to 1932. Reduced spending meant reduced employment in a vicious cycle that led to further reductions in demand for goods and workers.

title: TIPS ON REPLACING FLOORBOARDS
description: REPLACING sections of tongue-and-groove wooden floorboards is not difficult if you use the proper tools and work carefully.

title: Amy K. Connolly Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Amy Kendall Connolly to Michael Peter Doherty has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur G. Connolly Jr. of Wilmington, Del.
