description: To the Editor:

title: HITLER AND THE DEMONIC
description: William Safire's article ''Long Time No See'' (On Language, Sept. 20), on the joint communique issued by Roman Catholic and Jewish leaders contained some astute observations.

title: MEROLA, BRONX DISTRICT ATTORNEY, EULOGIZED AS A MAN OF CONSCIENCE
description: Hundreds of Mario Merola's friends, relatives and political colleagues - as well as some of his most bitter courtroom enemies - filled a Bronx parish church yesterday to pay their final respects to Mr. Merola, who died Tuesday after a political career that included more than 15 years as the Bronx District Attorney.

title: DON'T RULE OUT TAX INCREASES
description: AN arcane, theoretically fail-safe procedure called ''program trading,'' in which investment decisions involving hundreds of millions of dollars can be taken and implemented without human intervention, has been indentified as a factor in the stock market collapse. Computer-driven program trading raised the peaks, deepened the valleys and compressed market cycles.

title: Watson Retains A 4-Stroke Lead
description: Three years and three months since his last victory, Tom Watson played just well enough today to maintain his four-shot lead going into Sunday's final round of the richest golf tournament, the $3 million Nabisco Championships.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I made a fortune and lost a large part of it, and now I've got to hunker down.'' Alfred Frank, editor of The Prudent Speculator, an investment newsletter

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about the Old Dutch Church in North Tarrytown misstated the amount of a state grant to help restore the church. The state provided a matching grant of $120,000 toward the project, which is expected to cost $500,000.

title: On Language; Goons and Ginks and Company Finks
description: SCAB BALL'' WAS THE label pinned on the professional football played by replacements or substitutes by such sportswriters as Tony Kornheiser of The Washington Post. The owners' use of scab labor -usually a union member's derogation of an employee who works during a strike -prevailed, and the players' strike was broken.

title: Pretoria Acts to Improve Ties With Zimbabwe
description: The South African Government made an unexpected move this week in an attempt to improve its icy political relations with Zimbabwe, its black-ruled neighbor.

title: In Yugoslavia, Rising Ethnic Strife Brings Fears of Worse Civil Conflict
description: Portions of southern Yugoslavia have reached such a state of ethnic friction that Yugoslavs have begun to talk of the horrifying possibility of ''civil war'' in a land that lost one-tenth of its population, or 1.7 million people, in World War II.

title: An Elegant, Low-Calorie Feast
description: HOLIDAY FARE IS GENERALLY laden with richness - and calories. With a microwave oven, however, you can create a low-calorie meal so festive and delicious that no one will miss the usual indulgences. Because microwave cooking requires no fat, and allows vegetables and herbs to retain their flavor, and fruits their sweetness, you won't be tempted to add extra butter, salt or sugar.

title: RISING COST OF HEALTH CARE STILL OUTSTRIP MDEICARE GAINS
description: WHEN legislators and lobbyists win a battle on Capitol Hill, they usually exult in triumph.

title: Pierre Franey's Holiday Supper
description: EVERY YEAR, I LOOK FORWARD TO the marathon of holiday entertaining with both anticipation and trepidation. The season's social calendar overflows with cocktail parties, concerts, theater, sports events and the like, which often leave few moments for serious cooking. This is also the time, however, when hosts are expected to show off their plumage with dazzling dishes. While I welcome the challenge, I have sometimes spent the greater part of the holidays tethered to a range, coming up for air just long enough to share a toast with the merrymakers before heading back to the galley.

title:
MUSIC;
Elly Ameling's Devotion To the Art of the Art Song
description: LEAD: OF ALL PERFORMANCE genres, the art song has always seemed the most highly respected and least appreciated by the public. Because art songs concentrate on detail rather than grand emotional gestures, they tend, like chamber music, to be regarded as too sophisticated for widespread consumption. They are often masterpieces of inspiration and craftsmanship, but they are treated as little masterpieces in a world that usually clamors for big things.

title: FIGHTING ELM DISEASE THE NATURAL WAY
description: WHEN he was growing up in Oklahoma, George Ware remembers, his mother once stood at the door telling a traveling tree salesman that she didn't have several years to wait for his seedlings to begin bearing fruit. ''Well, why not?'' asked the salesman, ''You're going to be waiting anyway.''

title: 158 MUNICIPALITIES TO VOTE ON OFFICES
description: FROM Greenwich to Thompson, voters in 158 of Connecticut's 169 cities and towns will go to the polls Tuesday to choose their municipal officials for the next two years.

title: 'First Amendment Demands a Hide That Tough'
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Jacoby Is Affianced
description: Tamar Jacoby, a senior writer for Newsweek magazine, and Eric M. Breindel, a columnist at The New York Post and the editor of its editorial page, plan to be married Jan. 16. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Irving Jacoby of Guilford, Conn.

title: Super-VHS Enters the Market
description: OFTEN THERE IS A LAG of several months between the announcement of a new product and the time it appears in the shops. That is why Super-VHS video recorders, hailed earlier in the year as one of the few genuine advances in the field, are only now beginning to reach the retailers. Supplies may still be short for a while, but anyone considering a new VCR this fall should definitely keep in mind this superior option, despite its relatively high cost.

title: THE FATHERS OF FINANCIAL FUTURES
description: LEAD: ON Aug. 15, 1971, President Nixon announced that the United States would scrap the 1944 Bretton Woods agreement, which tied international currency rates to the dollar.

title: HOW TO VISIT THE COLLEGE OF YOUR DREAMS
description: THIS is the time of year when many high school juniors start devoting a good deal of thought to their future and the college application process, part of which consists of becoming familiar with the colleges you think you are interested in and that - joy of joys -might return the interest.

title: Economicsese
description: To the Editor:

title: WRIGHT'S VISION OF THE CIVILIZED WORKPLACE
description: THERE ARE TWO KINDS OF COR-porations that embark on serious building projects - those that believe, with not a little cynicism, that the chief benefit of architecture is its publicity value, and those that go about the business with more earnestness. The Johnson Wax Company was firmly in the latter camp 50 years ago, when it began work on an extraordinary complex of buildings designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.

title: Who Fines OSHA?
description: If the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is correct, the building collapse that killed 28 workers in Bridgeport, Conn., last April could have been prevented for far less than $5.11 million. Now it will cost the companies involved that much just to pay OSHA's fines.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: POLITICS, POWER, AND THE CHURCH: The Catholic Crisis and Its Challenge to American Pluralism. By Lawrence Lader. (Macmillan, $22.95.) Render unto Caesar what is Caesar's, unto God what is God's. But what if God and Caesar start dealing in the same coin? This is the conundrum that Lawrence Lader, an author of several books on social issues, examines in his almost too impassioned study of the uneasy relationship between the Roman Catholic Church and the First Amendment.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ARE U.S. OLYMPIC COINS APPROPRIATE FOR 1988?
description: LEAD: COINS have become a major source of revenue for the Olympics. When three United States coins were issued to commemorate the Los Angeles Summer Games in 1984, they raised $73.5 million to help defray Olympic-related expenses.

title: Perspectives: Taxes on Offices Raising the Burden on 'Unsold' Buildings
description: THE property-tax burden on office tenants in older buildings in Manhattan that have not recently changed ownership may soon rise sharply.

title: Quandary in Gulf: Success Brings Escalation
description: Iran's decision to resort to the use of Silkworm missiles, because all other military options have been neutralized by United States operations in the Persian Gulf, illustrates the quandary of American military strategists in the region: Military success only seems to lead to escalation.

title: 'MASTER HAROLD' ON EMELIN STAGE
description: IN its own sure way, the Emelin Theater has not only established a noteworthy record of sensibly selected and impressively produced plays but also is building an honorable tradition of consequential professional theater in the county.

title: Chinaware
description: To the Editor: When my wife and I returned from England in July, the next issue of the Travel section (Aug. 2) carried an Advisory item regarding the bankruptcy of Reject China Company in London. We were aghast, having just placed a rather large order for Coalport china. I wrote to Reject China Shops, 33-35 and 56-57 Beauchamp Place, in London, to cancel our order. We received a phone call from Geoffrey Edward, who said they had no connection with the original Reject China Shop, which was in bankruptcy, or their successors. So we let our order stand, and before long we received our china, intact and sent by airmail (free to show their good will). HOWARD MARKS East Meadow, L.I.

title: Dickerson Is Happy to Become a Colt
description: ''I'm ready to play,'' an exhausted Eric Dickerson said today after a whirlwind chain of events made him a member of the Indianapolis Colts.

title: THE HIT MAN'S KARMA
description: LEAD: UNDER COVER OF DAYLIGHT By James W. Hall. 288 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: 'NEW VERSIONS OF THE FIGURE,' FROM THE WHITNEY COLLECTION
description: ''NEW Versions of the Figure'' is Lehman College Art Gallery's new show, but the newness of its contents - a score or so figural sculptures drawn from the Whitney Museum's collection - is only relative.

title: Rebels Burned Bus Passengers, Survivors in Mozambique Say
description: Survivors of an ambush on a convoy said rebels burned buses that were crowded with passengers, the national press agency reported today. At least 211 people were reported killed.

title: Opera: First 'Boheme' of Met Season
description: FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI'S ''Boheme'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera Friday evening for its first performance of the season. The director's six-year-old staging of the Puccini opera remained the most striking characteristic of the production. Rodolfo's garret continued to pose a challenge for the singers, who had to project their voices from far back on the stage as well as engage in some uncomfortable swordplay on some uncomfortable swordplay on the rooftops of Paris. Cafe Momus looked like Grand Central Station at ever, was as painterly and elegant as the two previous scenes had been awkward and overblown.have outdistanced Mr. Zeffirelli in what seemed a race for attention. Friday's ensemble, conducted by Julius Rudel, did not fit the bill. Puccini created with ''Boheme'' an opera that comes as close as any to being foolproof, with the appropriate melodramatic effects built securely into the score. And yet the Met cast's mostly soporific performances managed to lull an audience into a state of near indifference.

title: Baby M's Mother Is Pregnant Out of Wedlock, Lawyer Says
description: Mary Beth Whitehead, the New Jersey surrogate mother who lost custody of Baby M after a bitter court fight, has become pregnant by a man other than her estranged husband, the court-appointed lawyer for Baby M said today.

title: Jakarta
description: To the Editor: Barbara Crossette's ''Neighborhood Tour of Jakarta'' (Travel, July 5) provides first-time visitors with a fine introduction to Jakarta's historical districts. On my first trip, though, I was disappointed that this bustling third world city had so little of historical interest still standing.

title: Two Worlds in the South Seas
description: The South Pacific archipelago of Vanuatu is charmingly schizophrenic: some people wear gowns or three-piece suits, others wear only grass skirts or grass sheaths. Some carry gold cigarette lighters, others carry smoldering sticks. Some drink Bordeaux, others drink kava, a local intoxicant with less cachet but more effect.

title: FOOD INSPECTION RESULTS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 14 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Jersey Republicans Seek To Control Legislature
description: With only days left before the legislative elections, Governor Kean is traveling the state on a quest for something that has eluded him in his six years in office - Republican control of the Legislature.

title: U.N. Agency Faces a Bitter Election
description: In a bitter election campaign for the top job at the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, the incumbent's personality and management style have become a matter of global politics.

title: INSIDE
description: Challenge for Chile The confrontation between ideological purity and political compromise is much on the minds of Chileans as they struggle to frame their political future. Page 22. Ethnic Strife in Yugoslavia Acts of violence by ethnic Albanian nationalists are increasing in Yugoslavia, leading to fearful talk of civil war. Page 14. Liberal Views in Iowa The Iowa caucuses will be a key event in the 1988 Presidential race. But how well do voters there reflect the attitudes of the nation? Page 36. Delay on Schools Chief Selecting a new schools chancellor for New York City is taking longer than expected, and an acting chancellor may have to be named. Page 50. Colts Get Dickerson The Los Angeles Rams traded Eric Dickerson, professional football's top running back, to the Indianapolis Colts in a three-team deal. Section 5. News Summary, page 2

title: Looking Ahead, With Statistics and Tea Leaves
description: ON Wednesday, when car makers report their sales for the last 10 days of October, those seeking to divine the course of the economy will pore over the figures as never before. As the first solid piece of statistical evidence of consumer behavior since the stock market collapse, the numbers, depending on their strength or weakness, are sure to be seen as harbingers of continued moderate economic expansion or impending malaise.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Some meaty dramas adapted from best sellers await viewers this week. ''The Snake Pit'' (1948) - Wednesday at 2 A.M. on Channel 5 - is a bold, forceful drama about a young woman's collapse and confinement in a mental institution, from Mary Jane Ward's book. Olivia de Havilland was cited by the New York Film Critics.

title: Correction
description: The author identification accompanying an article last week on political aspects of the stock market collapse was incomplete. Amitai Etzioni, a professor at George Washington University, is the Thomas Henry Carroll Ford Foundation Professor for 1987-88 at the Harvard Business School.

title:
NOTEBOOK: DORSET, VT.;
Home Prices Surge Upward
description: LEAD: THIS sleepy town of two general stores, three gas stations and 1,600 residents is experiencing an upsurge in new home construction.

title: Uniondale Ends Hempstead Streak at 34
description: The 34-game unbeaten streak of the powerful Hempstead Tigers (5-1) ended yesterday as the Tigers lost to Uniondale, 13-12.

title: RETHINKING PAX AMERICANA
description: BEYOND AMERICAN HEGEMONY The Future of the Western Alliance. By David P. Calleo. 288 pp. New York: A Twentieth Century Fund Book/ Basic Books. $20.95.

title: Devils' Latest Victim Is the Cup Champion
description: The Edmonton Oilers, the defending Stanley Cup champions, are the latest team to find out how much the Devils have improved.

title: Tokyo Bars Sanctions Against Iranians
description: Japan told the United States today that it would not go along with American sanctions on trade with Iran, but suggested that it would at least try to hold imports of Iranian oil at present levels.

title: Maria Ascione Marries
description: Maria Lisa Ascione, a daughter of Francine Goode of Riverhead, L.I., and Richard Ascione of Fairfax, Va., was married yesterday at the Ethical Culture Society in New York to David Lambert, the son of Julia Vieland of Philadelphia and Robert Lambert of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and Bute, Scotland. Dr. Robert Berson, a leader of the Ethical Society of Northern Westchester, officiated. The bride is a second-year medical student at the State University Health Science Center at Brooklyn. The bridegroom is a songwriter and a freelance musician and sound engineer.

title: TURNING OVER NEW LEAVES - IN GOLD
description: ''GOLD LEAF,'' observed Charles Prendergast early in this century, ''is like a half-solidified piece of sunlight.''

title: SWISS TO PROVIDE RECORDS OF CONTRA AID ACCOUNTS
description: Records of secret bank accounts held by Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and other major figures in the Iran-contra affair will be handed over to the United States next week, Switzerland has announced. week, Switzerland has announced.

title: Exchange Is Facing Clerical Staff Strike
description: Officials of the New York Stock Exchange, trading companies and the New York Futures Exchange, who are facing a possible strike by most of their clerical workers, continued contract negotiations with union officials yesterday and are scheduled to resume their talks tonight, a spokesman for the exchange said yesterday.

title: Lawmakers Act to Bar Inmates' Book Profits
description: The embarrassment of law-enforcement officers over a police captain who robbed a bank and stole Civil Service examinations has scarcely faded before the former officer has infuriated Massachusetts lawmakers by turning a profit on the robbery.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; Turtle Bay
description: THE past is not only inscribed in the minds of the loyal, longtime residents of Turtle Bay; it is reflected in the streets themselves.

title: THE NEED TO ESCAPE AND THE PLACE TO DO IT
description: WHEN my mother needed to escape from the noise and confusion generated by five children, she would go out and work in the yard. She couldn't have picked a better refuge. We children considered trimming, raking and mowing akin to torture. We always offered to help, though, knowing full well that Mom would decline the offer. ''No thanks,'' she would say. ''I need to be alone to think.''

title: THE ECONOMIC HISTORIANS' VIEW: Comparing the Collapses; John A. Garraty: Contradictory Signs
description: AT first glance, there are many similarities between the extraordinary collapses of stock prices that occurred in October 1929 and the declines we have recently experienced. Both hit after extended bull markets and amid general prosperity that tempted investors to ignore underlying weak spots in the economy: agriculture, coal mining and textiles in the 1920's, agriculture again and the smokestack industries today.

title: BUTOH: DANCE OF DARKNESS
description: BUTOH IS NOT FOR THE FRAIL. THE AVANT-garde dance form that today is Japan's most startling cultural export does not aim to charm. Instead, it sets out to assault the senses. The hallmarks of this theater of protest include full body paint (white or dark or gold), near or complete nudity, shaved heads, grotesque costumes, clawed hands, rolled-up eyes and mouths opened in silent screams.

title: POSTINGS: New Complex for Trenton; Bullish on Offices
description: As more and more corporations settle in the New Jersey suburbs, Trenton, the state capital, is making its own push to become a first-class office center. Already, about 10 office buildings - with two million square feet of space - are under construction, a bullish pace considering that the entire private sector now occupies only a half-million square feet.

title: Ten Days That Shook the World
description: The 70th anniversary celebration of the Bolshevik Revolution opens tomorrow, with Mikhail Gorbachev expected to start weaving back into Soviet history some of the many pages long ago torn out. The Bolsheviks thought themselves the vanguard of a Socialist movement that would sweep the world. Those who commemorate the Revolution now struggle with a troubled system.

title: MORE WOMAN SEEK X-RAYS OF BREASTS
description: In the two weeks since Nancy Reagan's surgery for breast cancer, more women have been seeking mammograms, the X-ray tests that can detect breast tumors before they can be felt palpably.

title: Question Of the Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
description: What changes? Steinbrenner dismissing a Yankee manager? Steinbrenner rehiring Billy Martin? Steinbrenner publicly criticizing Yankee players? Steinbrenner threatening to leave the City of New York? Sadly, they are all too predictable. Nothing has really changed in the Steinbrenner years except maybe a little loss of Yankee legend. BOB JOYCE Provincetown, Mass.

title: THE VOICE OF HELEN HAYES
description: LEAD: AT first glance, it would seem that Helen Hayes, often called the First Lady of the American theater, and Marion Glasserow Gladney, a Manhasset housewife-turned-communications executive, would have little in common.

title: Washington and Managua: A chronology
description: July 1979 Sandinistas oust Somoza regime; Carter Administration starts economic aid. January 1981 U.S., disillusioned, suspends $75 million in economic aid. March 1982 C.I.A. plans to give covert aid to Nicaraguan opposition groups are disclosed. May 1982 Nicaragua announces $166.8 million Soviet aid pact. April 1984 C.I.A. mining of Nicaraguan harbors is disclosed. October 1984 Boland Amendment bars all U.S. Government aid for the contras for one year and military aid for two years. June 1985 Congress approves $27 million in nonmilitary aid for the contras. March 1986 House rejects Reagan proposal for $100 million in aid for contras. August 1986 Congress approves $100 million in aid for contras. November 1986 President Reagan admits U.S. secretly gave millions of dollars to contras, contrary to Congressional intent. November l987 First phase of peace plan signed in Guatemala in August by the presidents of Nicaragua and four other Central American countries to take effect Nov. 5.

title: An Evening of Song
description: WITH A LOG FIRE CRACKLING in the fireplace and delicious aromas emanating from the pear tarte tatin in the oven and the saddle of venison just roasted, Hugh and Tiziana Hardy's Greenwich Village town house was a welcoming place.

title: SOUTHWEST; Texas Reaches 3-0 In Conference, 41-27
description: A Texas safety, John Hagy, returned both an interception and a punt for touchdowns as Texas defeated Texas Tech, 41-27, to remain atop the Southwest Conference.

title: EVENTS TO CELEBRATE CHEMISTRY DAY
description: LEAD: TO highlight chemistry's contributions to the well-being of society, Friday has been designated National Chemistry Day. But the celebration in the county will extend for more than a week, during which science enthusiasts are expected at a number of events, including tours of the chemical industry and demonstrations at local colleges.

title: LEARNING TO DEAL WITH AIDS AT WORK
description: ''THE first time I realized he had an AIDS-related illness is when I went to visit him in the hospital,'' said the president of a manufacturing company in lower Westchester, referring to one of his clerical employees. ''Two weeks later, he was able to come back to work. However, due to a company restructuring that took place before he went to the hospital, he works on the night shift, alone, so I really don't know how our other employees would have felt about working side-by-side with him in the office.

title: LOVE IN THE BACK 40
description: DANCING AT THE RASCAL FAIR By Ivan Doig. 405 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

title: PREPARATIONS FOR SPRING
description: RAKE, rake, rake, blow, sweep or whatever to get the leaves off the lawn; if not kept off the grass, they will smother it and mat; what is more they will be extremely difficult to remove in spring and may even kill a lawn. If finished using hand tools, wipe them and clean blades by rotating them in a box of sand; rub metal parts with oil or rust preventive. Make sure garden chemicals are clearly labeled and stored properly. Tulips

title: Jakarta
description: To the Editor: I appreciated reading Barbara Crossette's ''A Neighborhood Tour of Jakarta'' since I returned a year ago from having lived in Jakarta for nine months, and because of the truth in her comment about its seeming inexhaustibility for ''unadvertised corners.'' Unfortunately, I didn't visit all of the sites she described.

title: The Woman Who Beat The Klan
description: IN HER DREAM, THERE was a steel-gray casket in her living room. Who was the dead man laid out in a gray suit? She couldn't tell. And every time she moved closer to the coffin, someone she didn't know said, ''You don't need to see this.'' But Beulah Mae Donald knew that she did, and so she woke from her dream at two in the morning in Mobile, Ala., on March 21, 1981. The first thing she did, she later said, was to look in the other bedroom, where her youngest child slept. Michael, 19, wasn't there. She telephoned one of her six other children. Though Michael had watched television with his cousins earlier in the evening, he had left before midnight.

title: Radio Days
description: A PRAIRIE HOME COMPANION: THE LAST SHOW Starring Garrison Keillor (in photo), with Chet Atkins, Leo Kottke and Jean Redpath. Walt Disney Home Video. 114 minutes. $29.95.

title: Staging an Open House
description: AN OPEN HOUSE IS NOT YOUR everyday kind of affair,'' said Roulhac Toledano, as she rushed around her family's 10-room apartment, trying to tie up loose ends before her 60 guests arrived. ''But it's good for lots of different people who may not know each other.'' She might have added that it is also good for hosts: Because people tend to arrive at different times, it's possible to entertain large numbers in the space of a day or an evening. (Some party givers even invite their guests to come at staggered hours.) Much of the preparation can be done in advance, and the event's informality permits both family and friends to assist.

title: The Disturbing Power Of Duchamp's Epiphanies
description: A PROTECTIVE DISCRETION SUR-rounds what is in effect, though not in name, the Marcel Duchamp museum within the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Though known to enthusiasts the world over as the largest single repository of Duchamp's work, the galleries in question occupy a distant and almost a secret place in the huge congeries of the Philadelphia Museum. But it was there, as much by right as by long affection, that the centenary of Marcel Duchamp's birth was celebrated two weekends ago.

title: Dance: Ballet Hispanico In Bill of Five Works
description: BECAUSE the members of Ballet Hispanico of New York simultaneously took pleasure and gave pleasure by dancing on Friday night, it was appropriate that three of the five works they presented at Davis Hall of City College celebrated the act of dancing itself.

title: WALL STREET'S AGONY: THE VIEW FROM AFAR
description: While the upsetting news from Wall Street battered world stock markets from London to Tokyo last week, the editorial thinkers of major newspapers vigorously assigned blame and prescribed cures. Excerpts follow from a sampling of written and pictorial comment in 10 countries. Tokyo

title: LOW TURNOUT PREDICTED FOR LOCAL ELECTIONS
description: POLITICAL observers expect a low turnout Tuesday when Westchester voters go to the polls to select county legislators, supervisors, mayors, judges and city and town councils.

title: THE CITY'S PROSPECTS SEEM DOWN WITH THE DOW
description: IN the wake of the stock market's crash two weeks ago and its erratic behavior since then, economists and market analysts have been unable to agree whether New York's economic future, which is so closely linked to the fate of the securities industry, looks disastrous or merely dim.

title: SUFFOLK LEGISLATURE FACING EXTENSIVE CHANGES
description: LEAD: THE Suffolk County Legislature, the bedrock of Long Island opposition to the Shoreham nuclear power plant, is about to be transformed by Tuesday's election.

title: Question Of the Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
description: More chaos and nerve-wracking tension! The Yanks desperately need frontline pitching, a slick-fielding shortstop and a power-hitting catcher - not a disruptive, recycled manager or a figure-head of a general manager who seems to have very little self-respect. NICHOLAS D. DeCURTIS New York

title: Heyden White Wed to Charles Rostow
description: Ariana van der Heyden White, a daughter of Mrs. Louis J. Hector of New York and Coconut Grove, Fla., and the late Theodore H. White, was married last evening to Charles Nicholas Rostow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene V. Rostow of Washington and Peru, Vt. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York. He was assisted by Rabbi David Teutsch and Cantor Ephraim Biran.

title: Writing One For the Gipper
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: AUDUBON GUIDE TO WALKS IN COUNTY
description: A NEW Audubon walking guide will both appeal to and inform Westchester residents who are hikers, bird watchers and nature lovers. The guide covers 26 places, among them Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River, the Arthur W. Butler Memorial Sanctuary in Mount Kisco, the Marshlands Conservancy in Rye, the Eugene and Agnes Meyer Nature Preserve in Armonk, the Mianus River Gorge Wildlife Refuge and Botanical Preserve in Bedford, the Edith G. Read National Park and Wildlife Sanctuary in Rye, the Rockefeller State Park Preserve (a 1983 gift to the state) in Pocantico Hills; and others in the county and the neighboring Greenwich, Conn., area.

title: PRACTICING VEGETARIANISM
description: As a vegetarian, I was deeply disturbed and offended by Priscilla Feral's remarks about animal issues in general and Friends of Animals policy in particular [ ''Connecticut Q&A,'' Oct. 11 ] .

title: DATA BANK: NOVEMBER 1, 1987
PUERTO RICAN PAINTING AT SQUIBB GALLERY
description: IF DOUBTS remain about the symbiotic relationship between art and politics, ''Puerto Rican Painting: Between Past and Present'' should put them to rest once and for all.

title: NEW YORK'S POLICE FEEL THE CHILL OF RACIAL TENSION
description: NEW York City has experienced a widely perceived increase in racial tensions this year - notably in connection with the Howard Beach trial, in which four white youths are charged with murder in connection with an allegedly racially motivated attack on three blacks - and tensions within the police department have to some extent reflected those of the city.

title: Cruises Shifting From Global To Regional
description: LEAD: The annual parade of world cruises is growing shorter and shorter, as fewer ships make a complete circle of the globe. There are only three doing so this season, down from six last year, along with two passenger-carrying freighters.

title: Items Treasured By China's Sages
description: TIMED TO COINCIDE with the impressive presentation of art works from the Shanghai Museum on view in ''The Chinese Scholar's Studio: Artistic Life in the Late Ming Period,'' at the Asia Society, is a dealer's exhibition organized by James J. Lally that expresses in a generous assortment of art and objects the traditional taste of the educated elite in China over a thousand years.

title: St. Anthony Not Caught in Chase
description: With only this weekend of action remaining before the playoffs, most of the teams in the Catholic High Schools Football League are still scrambling for position. But not St. Anthony of South Huntington, L.I.

title: LOCAL ROLE CALLED VITAL
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY'S reliance on local government is an unusually heavy one, according to Dr. Ernest Reock, director of Rutgers University's Bureau of Government Research.

title: Housing Group Rebuilds in Newark
description: Begun in the smoldering ruins of the riots here 20 years ago, the New Community Corporation has developed into a veritable city-within-the-city on 45 acres of the Central Ward.

title: A Very Moving 'Night, Mother'
description: DOWNSTAIRS from the Main Stage at Theater Three in Port Jefferson is a smaller, cabaret-style open space in which shows geared to a more theatrically sophisticated audience are presented. So, while Theater Three offers Neil Simon comedies or musicals such as the recent ''Show Boat'' on the Main Stage, it balances its own artistic needs by using the downstairs space for more challenging, creative endeavors.

title: John Brown's Landscape
description: LEAD: Few historic sites offer as compatible a marriage of unique scenery and distinctive human events as that presented by Harpers Ferry, W. Va.

title: HOW TO SPARKLE
description: MAKING PEOPLE TALK Larry Farber. 263 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $14.95.

title: Martha Graham's Ongoing Affirmation of Life
description: THE ETERNAL MYSTERIES that lie at the heart of Martha Graham's work came to the fore during the splendid season that closed last week at the City Center with an audience cheering Miss Graham and her company to the rafters. It was an unusual season, with the powerful level of performance signaling a breakthrough for many Graham dancers in their mastery of technique and dramatic presence. It was also an engagement marked by the impact of certain unexpected revivals.

title: REPUBLICAN CONTENDERS MEET IN ROUND 1
description: ''WE'RE HERErrxh to get the flavor of six candidates,'' said William F. Buckley Jr. last week, and at times the flavor was peppery in the first debate of the contenders for the Republican Presidential nomination. Vice President Bush slipped several verbal punches and hit back strongly, protecting his front-runner status, according to polls and politicians. The other contenders - Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader; Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York; Pat Robertson, the former television evangelist; Alexander M. Haig Jr., the former Army general and former Secretary of State, and Pete du Pont, a former Governor of Delaware - also found reasons to crow. But the debate, on the Public Broadcasting System's ''Firing Line'' program, drew a much smaller audience than did a live show on the opening of the Titanic's safe.

title: FROM THE LEFT: Anwar A. Shaikh; The Crisis Underneath
description: Excerpts from an interview with Anwar A. Shaikh, professor of economics, graduate faculty, New School for Social Research, and member, Union for Radical Political Economics.

title: FOR A PLEASANT REPAST, DUCK, SALAD AND MOUSSE
description: SOMETIMES after the theater or movies, it is more fun to eat at home than in a restaurant. The menu given below is perfect for a late-night meal, not too heavy and easy to prepare ahead of time. It also makes a pleasant weekend lunch. Ducks are roasted with thyme, ginger, garlic and soy sauce and served at room temperature with a salad made from yellow split peas and collard greens. You can follow it with a regular green salad and cheese. For dessert, there is a frozen strawberry mousse made with yogurt. This is good with sugar cookies or shortbread.

title: HOUSE PANEL STALLS BID TO SHIFT U.S. WATER AGENCY TO DENVER
description: The House Appropriations Committee has voted to block the Bureau of Reclamation's plans to move its headquarters from Washington to Denver as part of a major reorientation of the bureau.

title: Postings: Codes to Live By; Looking It Up
description: Three new real-estate reference works are now for sale, two that will interest those involved in technical aspects of the industry - the actual construction of apartments - and one that should prove helpful to people looking for a place to live.

title: Amy Harless Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Amy Elisabeth Harless to James Stillman Rockefeller Rose, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Harden Rose of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mrs. Ricardo Deambrosio of Lyme, Conn., and Montevideo, Uruguay, and Theodore James Harless of Port Chester, N.Y.

title: Cable TV
description: For movie fans who nourish their habit via cable, this is the week that justifies the subscription - three of last year's most talked-about films served up for the first time: ''Hannah and Her Sisters,'' ''Peggy Sue Got Married'' and ''Top Gun.''

title: Maine Sees a Crossroad, and It's Busy
description: Just after daybreak each morning, Weyman Billings sits before his living room window to watch a solitary loon swimming in the clear waters of Donnell Pond. He wonders how long the loon will be there.

title: Diane Hallock, A Banker, Wed To B. P. Winder
description: At St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., Diane Baird Hallock, a daughter of Charles H. Hallock of Darien and Lucy T. Hallock of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Bayly Philip Winder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Bayly Winder of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Walter Taylor performed the ceremony.

title: Question Of the Week; What Will The Yankee Changes Mean?
description: What will the Yankee changes mean? Answer: More changes. JAY KREISBERG New Rochelle, N.Y.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
TEACHERS NEED THE PERSPECTIVE OF OUR HISTORY
description: LEAD: THE State of Connecticut is considering whether to dispense with the certification requirement for new teachers that they take one course in United States history for their classroom preparation. It would be a puzzling way for our educational gatekeepers to climax the bicentennial year of the Constitution.

title: Ms. Leonard to Marry A Physician on Dec. 6
description: Suzanne Kathleen Leonard, a tax associate at the New York law firm of Proskauer, Rose, Goetz & Mendelsohn, plans to be married Dec. 6 to Dr. Karl-Walter Sykora, a second-year resident in pediatrics at New York Hospital.

title: HOW A BOLD DIRECTOR HAS TRANSFORMED A REGIONAL THEATER
description: IN THE SPRING OF 1983, WHEN MANY of his peers in the nonprofit theater were embarking on hard-won sabbaticals, Adrian Hall was named artistic director of the Dallas Theater Center. The head of the Trinity Square Repertory Company in Providence, R.I. - one of the country's best resident professional theaters -Mr. Hall had a reputation as one of the theater's most audacious yet enduring directors. He was not about to change his stripes: The Theater Center's board of directors, yielding to an unprecedented demand, agreed to share him with the Rhode Island theater he had founded in 1964.

title: Market Turmoil: 2 Vital Concerns
description: As the markets fluctuated wildly last week, the debate over stock market volatility intensified. Questions focused on the role of program trading and portfolio insurance and on the sophisticated instruments called stock index futures that make those techniques possible. The debate raises an issue that goes right to the heart of capitalism: How to insure that the speculative element inherent in financial markets does not overwhelm the entire system. Business, Section 3

title: Farms' Future On Pennsylvania Ballot
description: People who are alarmed that houses and industrial parks are sprouting where crops once grew are campaigning for passage Tuesday of a $100 million state bond issue that would encourage farmers to stay on their land.

title: FICTION
description: THE AUTOMOTIVE HISTORY OF LUCKY KELLERMAN. By Steve Heller. (Chelsea Green, Paper, $9.95.) ''On his sixty-fifth birthday Frank Kellerman locked himself inside an old stone schoolhouse filled with honey bees,'' begins Steve Heller's subtle first novel. For the next seven days, Frank (or Lucky, as he was called before old age, diabetes, injury and loneliness took their toll), tells his life story to his only friends, the bees. As a boy in Missouri, Frank sold newspapers outside the political boss Tom Pendergast's Kansas City headquarters, and Al Capone once gave him a ride. He's also been an electrician, a diesel mechanic, a gandy dancer, a janitor and the best auto mechanic in Yukon, Okla. Frank's father, a German immigrant, tried to crush his son's spirit; throughout his life, without wanting to, Frank has done the same to his own son, Curly. Now, facing death, he wants to leave something behind - a 1932 Model 18 Ford Deluxe Roadster, like the one his father once destroyed. Frank thinks his car will power Curly's dreams, and Mr. Heller hints that it may. But these hints are confusing, part of a portentous ending that doesn't fit comfortably with the rest of the book. Instead, ''The Automotive History of Lucky Kellerman'' is strongest in a succession of vivid scenes from Frank's life on the job and at home. Most haunting is ''the pretend season,'' when Frank, trapped in a hip cast, watches day by day through his window as 10-year-old Curly acts out the progress of the 1961 home run duel between Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle. Like a number of vignettes in Mr. Heller's quiet and often beautiful book, such unspoken moments between father and son create an unforgettable image.

title: FOOTBALL IS BACK, AND A HUSBAND RUNS WITH THE WIND
description: ''MARVELOUS! Did you see that?'' my husband shouts. He's sitting alone in the den watching TV. It's a Sunday afternoon and it's football time. Close by, in another part of the house, I'm reading or painting. Sometimes during a game, I'll hear my husband on the phone talking to our son. ''Can you believe that run?'' he says. ''Can you believe that call?''

title: Garbo Talks
description: CAMILLE With Greta Garbo and Robert Taylor (both in photo). MGM/UA Home Video. 110 minutes. $24.95.

title: FROM STRIFE AND COMPROMISE, THE COUNTY'S GOVERNMENT EMERGED
description: LEAD: THEY were among the best and the brightest in the land, a group of respected citizens from all regions, convened to consider a new form of governance.

title: NONFICTION
description: BORN TO PAY: The New Politics of Aging in America. By Phillip Longman. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Phillip Longman is a young writer and Washington activist who worries a lot. He believes his generation, baby boomers born from the mid-1940's to the early 1960's, are destined for hard times indeed. Pulling together worst-case scenarios drawn from Census Bureau projections, testimony to Congress, books and articles, he warns that many of his contemporaries will end up old and poor. In his view, middle-class women are especially vulnerable. Social Security and Medicare will either be bankrupted or drastically reduced, because we are not saving to pay for the vastly increased numbers who would qualify under present laws. Young people who waited to start families until their late 30's will discover, when they grow old, that the working population will by then be too small and poor to support them. He warns of an ethnic gulf in some parts of the country, with elderly whites looking in vain for support from a largely black and Hispanic working population with other priorities. And everybody, young and old, will be staggering under the trauma of Government debt. Mr. Longman's approach has been denigrated as ''granny-bashing.'' He argues that age-based entitlement, notably Social Security, should be replaced with programs limited to the needy. These should be financed by taxes on consumption, with incentives for savers to help support the elderly, and for potential parents to alter the demographic curve. Mr. Longman addresses real issues, but his analysis is skewed by his experience in the fiscally erratic Reagan era. New taxes and reductions in swollen defense budgets might clear away at least some of the shadows in his crystal ball.

title: BOARD MIGHT NAME TEMPORARY CHIEF
description: The search for a new Schools Chancellor, which New York City officials had originally hoped to complete by early this month, will almost certainly not be finished when Nathan Quinones leaves the post Dec. 31, according to the head of the search committee.

title: Soviet Survey of Moscow Residents Finds a Wide Range of Political Views
description: Moscow residents approve of giving exit visas to Soviet citizens who want to emigrate, but they disapprove of releasing dissidents from prison or exile.

title: Lori and Debra Miller to Marry Medical Students
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Miller of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagements of their daughters Lori Beth Miller and Debra Sue Miller to Daniel Jay Kase and Alan Jay Schefer, respectively.

title: AN ELECTION INSPECTOR FILES REORT FROM THE FRONT LINES
description: I'M an election inspector.

title: OSCAR WILDE: COMEDY AS TRAGEDY
description: GEORGE MEREDITH once described Oscar Fingal O'Flahertie Wills Wilde as ''a mixture of Apollo and a monster.''

title: Sally Keenan is a Bride
description: Sarah Marie Keenan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willis J. Keenan of Port Washington, L.I., was married there yesterday to Joseph Sferrazza, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Sferrazza of Manhasset, L.I. Msgr. Walter Simmons performed the ceremony at St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Sferrazza, known as Sally, and her husband are associates at the law firm of Shaw, Licitra, Eisenberg, Esernio & Schwartz in Garden City, L.I.

title: MOVIES
description: That Hamilton Woman Starring Vivien Leigh, Laurence Olivier. 1941. Embassy Home Entertainment. 125 minutes. $19.95. When we first see Lady Hamilton, she is an impoverished, sepulchral creature. Asked to tell her story, she painfully relates one of history's most tragic love affairs - her momentous liaison with Adm. Horatio Nelson. Based on this ill-fated alliance, ''That Hamilton Woman'' shows how Emma Hamilton, the wife of the British Ambassador to Naples, helped Nelson secure men and provisions. A country girl turned social butterfly, she is immediately struck by his determination. The narrative deftly recounts their steadfast affection - and the repeated risks the married war hero took for his beloved Emma.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Playtime Closeout: Up to 50% Off Playtime Toys and Bicycles in Larchmont is going out of business with a closeout sale Monday through Saturday this week, but the same owner's Bronxville store remains open under the name Robert's Toytown.

title: WHICH PEAK IS UPPERMOST?
description: THE two subjects of the debate in northwestern Litchfield County are lofty ones: which of two local mountains can rightfully be called the state's highest.

title: Can Nations Set Aside Their Parochialism in Time?
description: IN placing their money, modern investors leapfrog national frontiers. From Tokyo to London to New York, bankers shift billions daily at the shiver of a Eurodollar rate or the flick of an arbitrager's computer keys. Today the sun may set on the British Empire, but never on the pulsing financial markets.

title: Reagan Renews Appeal to Act Soon on Nominee
description: President Reagan insisted anew today that the Senate should act quickly on his nomination of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg to the Supreme Court, saying he wanted ''no delays to gear up opposition or support for this nomination.''

title: HERBERT MAYES, 87, A FORMER TOP EDITOR OF MAGAZINES, DIES
description: Herbert R. Mayes, who built a reputation as one of the country's most respected magazine editors at Good Housekeeping and McCall's, died of pneumonia Friday evening at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 87 years old. Having headed Good Housekeeping, a Hearst publication, for 20 years, Mr. Mayes took over at McCall's, one of its main rivals, in 1958. He retired as president and chief executive of the McCall Corporation in 1965.

title: Navy Lieutenant Wed To Janet L. Weinstein
description: Janet Lynn Weinstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen D. Weinstein of Teaneck, N.J., and Otis, Mass., was married yesterday to Lieut. (j.g.) Richard Mercadante, U.S.N., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent James Mercadante of Randolph, Mass. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Harold L. Brooks, an American Baptist minister, at the Governor Morris Inn in Morristown, N.J.

title: DICKERSON TRADED TO COLTS
description: In an extraordinary three-team deal that could alter the balance of power in the American Conference East, the Los Angeles Rams sent Eric Dickerson to the Indianapolis Colts yesterday.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: MARIA: Callas Remembered. By Nadia Stancioff. (Dutton, $19.95.) These reminiscences of Maria Callas, published to coincide with the 10th anniversary of her death, are a hornet's nest of memories - as controversial as the diva's own performances. Hired as publicist for Pier Paolo Pasolini's ''Medea'' (Callas's only film), Nadia Stancioff, a writer and public relations consultant, claims to have been the singer's close confidante, but she writes with a veiled vindictiveness that leaves the reader wondering just whose side she's on.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: JANE S. GARBACZ;
'PEOPLE THINK THEIR VOTE DOESN'T COUNT'
description: LEAD: SHORTLY after women got the right to vote in 1920, the nonpartisan League of Women Voters was formed to promote political responsibility through participation in government and to act on selected governmental issues.

title: 'FEDERALIST' BIRTHDAY
description: LAST week was a busy one for the first Chief Justice of the United States, John Jay. His constitutional contributions were discussed by Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court in a speech in Justice Jay's home town of Rye, while the debate over the future of Jay's boyhood home continued in Albany.

title: DREAMING OF BUFFALO
description: SECOND SEASON By Joseph Monninger. 245 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: Rise in Executions Widening Debate
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 31 -

title: GROWING UP THANKLESS
description: THE RADIANT WAY By Margaret Drabble. 408 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

description: THE parallels between the crash of the stock market in 1929 and 1987 are too strong to ignore. Nevertheless, the recent collapse does not necessarily portend a new Great Depression. The 1929 crash shook the economy, but it was other problems - some similar to today's dilemmas - that caused the collapse.

title: AN UPBEAT MCNEIL IS TRYING TO GET BACK IN STEP

description: BREAKFAST CAN EASILY BE COUNTED my favorite meal of the day, and so it is an especially enjoyable one to share with guests.

description: EVERY PERSON'S LIFE IS WORTH A NOVEL By Erving Polster. 193 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.

title: SOVIET CRITICIZES U.S. ROLE IN GULF
description: A senior Soviet envoy on a peace mission in the Persian Gulf criticized the United States Navy's presence here today, saying that one nation acting alone cannot bring about a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq.

title: WATCHING HER BODY WORK
description: RUNNING TIDE By Joan Benoit with Sally Baker. Illustrated. 213 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Winner Laments
description: THERE is more than one way to win a driving championship, and Nelson Piquet of Brazil, who won his third Formula One title yesterday, was lamenting that he could not have found a better way to his. Piquet, who came to the Grand Prix of Japan with 73 points, 12 more than his teammate and closest rival, Nigel Mansell of Britain, captured the title by default when Mansell, who could have taken the championship by winning the Japan and Australian races, was injured and forced to withdraw from the Japanese race. ''Winning the Formula One driving championship was very exciting,'' Piquet conceded after getting the news, ''but winning the other way would have been much better.''

title: MONTH LATER, STORM CLEANUP GOES ON UPSTATE
description: Dozens of 200-year-old hemlock trees lie across the rushing waters of Wappinger Creek at the Cary Arboretum here, their roots jutting into the air, reflecting the light of the midday sun.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE ENGINE OF OWL-LIGHT. By Sebastian Barry. (Carcanet, $18.50.) Sebastian Barry's epigraph from Sir Thomas Browne provides a welcome clue to a complex first novel. ''There is nothing new under the sun,'' he quotes and, like Ecclesiastes, suggests that regardless of time and place, the imponderables of life and the limits of human achievement remain fixed.

title: With a Little Bit of Luck, a Conducting Career Flourishes
description: ''OPPORTUNITIES IN THE music world are a combination of reputation, of people watching you work, and perhaps a bit of luck and timing,'' observes Kent Nagano, the 36-year-old conductor who is making his debuts with both the Brooklyn and New York Philharmonic in the next couple of weeks. His career certainly illustrates the theory. ''I know that in the case of Brooklyn, which wanted to present an all-Steve Reich program, I was recommended by other conductors and composers who thought I would be right for it. But I have no idea which of those elements were behind the invitation from the New York Philharmonic. I just got a call one day.''

title: Street Fashion; Bear Market in Hemlines
description: FOR those seeking signs of stability on Wall Street, there is some good news. Despite the heavy volume in recent trading that has turned the Dow Jones into a roller coaster, skirt lengths in the financial district have held steady, closer to the ankle than the knee.

title: BILLS SEEK CLEARER ADDRESSES
description: IT IS 1:40 in the morning, and a rural volunteer ambulance squad, responding to a call for help after a traffic accident, is having trouble finding the spot.

title: MARKET EXPECTED TO INFLUENCE ELECTIONS
description: VOTERS will go to the polls Tuesday to elect all 120 members of the State Legislature and scores of county and local officials, and to decide six statewide public questions, including three new spending proposals that could be affected by the stock market decline. The polls will be open from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. Although the final campaign spending figures could approach $10 million and set a record for a legislative election, state election officials predict a light turnout of about 46 percent of the state's 3.6 million registered voters.

description: Every year, on the last Sunday of October, hikers from New Jersey join those of neighboring states to memorialize Raymond H. Torrey, co-founder of the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference and one of the area's legendary outdoorsmen.

description: Mayor William H. Hudnut has acknowledged that he is seeking the presidency of the University of Tennessee, but he says he will withdraw his application if he is re-elected to a fourth term next week.

title: BRIDGEPORT HELPS ILLITERATE ADULTS
description: LEAD: THE sleeves of James Watson's pink oxford shirt were rolled up to his elbows one Monday night as he sat in the Bridgeport Public Library. His forearms, massive from changing tires each day at a garage, rested on the table as he leaned over a book, mouthing the letters he saw.

title: MEN AND MOLES
description: I would like to point out that there is a safe method for ridding the home garden of moles.

title: Former Wedtech Executive Testifies About Bribery
description: A former vice chairman of the Wedtech Corporation, testifying in a conspiracy and mail fraud trial here, has outlined widespread illegal activity involving officials of the South Bronx military contractor.

title: Postings: Home Builders Forum; Looking at 1988
description: In planning its conference on the outlook for the real estate industry, the National Association of Home Builders could not have predicted that the stock market would take a nose dive two weeks ago.

title: Beneath the Glitter of Tinseltown's Golden Days
description: WHEN BUDD SCHULBERG, F. Scott Fitzgerald and John O'Hara wrote about prewar Hollywood, their fiction helped create the imperishable fable of Tinseltown, the land of the studio mogul in the heyday of the picture palace. Certainly, too, there was a legendary aspect to these writers' close and complex relationship: It was Mr. Schulberg's riotous weekend with Fitzgerald at Dartmouth College, for example, that ''formed the spine of 'The Disenchanted,' '' said Mr. Schulberg in a recent interview, referring to his 1950 novel. As for O'Hara, ''Well, John was godfather to my daughter Victoria,'' Mr. Schulberg said, ''and for years out there I saw him almost every day.''

title: Agatha Christie's Canon
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Arrangements - For Under $25
description: WHILE IT IS TRUE THAT THE IS-land of Manhattan was bought in 1626 for less than what most people pay for a floral arrangement today, according to several Manhattan floral designers it is not necessary to pay top prices - or use fancy flowers - for holiday decorations.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The brick fireplace in our home had been painted by previous owners. We want to remove the paint and restore the natural brick. What is the best way to do this?

title: A CONCERT OF MINSTREL'S POETRY AND SONG
description: FROM ''Travels With Oswald'' to ''Marriage at the Eiffel Tower,'' the music week promises an unusually wide variety of tonal fascinations. Oswald von Wolkenstein, as Grove's Dictionary tells us, was an Austrian ary tells us, was an Austrian minnesinger, a minstrel, in the first very stirring and adventurous life, in the course of which he traveled over the greater part of Europe. Many of his poems are spring and love songs, very fresh and pleasing, with a popular lilt about them.''

title: A GUIDE TOFANCY TRADING TACTICS
description: LEAD: Stock options give their owners the right - but not the obligation - to buy or sell a specified number of shares of an individual common stock. They can do so at a set price, called the strike price, within a certain period of time, typically within a few months. An investor buys an option for several reasons.

description: EVERY BIG AMERICAN CITY HAS ITS LIGHTED Christmas trees and its Thanksgiving or New Year's parades. But most cities also have their own, characteristic ways of celebrating. A selection follows: BOSTON

HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC

This dramatization of the life of Charles Ives (1874-1954), the iconoclastic American composer, is at its best when showing the places and events that Ives tried to capture, while his music fills the soundtrack.

title: Anne C. Weisner Weds Patrick Joseph Dooley

description: Treasury auctions this week run the gamut from short-term bills to 30-year bonds.

title: Concert: The Toronto
description: THE middle, therefore the bottom, just about fell out of Sunday afternoon's concert by the Toronto Symphony at Carnegie Hall. Jon Vickers, who was to have sung Mussorgsky's ''Songs and Dances of Death'' reported in ill Saturday night, leaving the ever-present Itzhak Perlman with his ever-present Beethoven Violin Concerto to substitute. Mr. Perlman and his Canadian colleagues had played the piece in Carnegie barely 18 hours earlier.

Memorial Church, Gabrielle Christina Giordano, the daughter of Mrs. Anthony Giordano Jr. of Colts Neck, N.J., and the late Mr. Giordano, was married yesterday to Robert Ernest McGill 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. McGill 3d of Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. James Pruner, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

description: A plan by the Soviet Union to export cars with Volkswagen engines to the United States is drawing criticism from the Reagan Administration.

title: How to Stand Out In a Sea of Runners
description: Running a marathon would seem to be difficult enough with both hands free, but several of yesterday's runners chose to do it a hard way, carrying flags attached to heavy poles. One was the banner of the Charlottenburg Sports Club of Berlin; it was carried in turn by four club members, including Ralf Schultz. The flag may have made the going rough, but it did call attention to the Berlin contingent. As a mass of runners approached the finish line just after the 4-hours-30-minutes mark, the public-address announcer spotted the banner, checked the bearer's number and told the spectators, ''The man with the flag is Ralf Schultz.'' Runners a bit less resourceful relied on T-shirts to set them apart. One woman had ''Stella'' on her chest and ''Is That You, Stanley?'' on her back, a reference, she didn't quite have to explain, to the characters in the play ''A Streetcar Named Desire.''

description: The company said its sales increase resulted largely from the acquisition of McCord Gasket Corp. in September 1986 and the engine parts division of Clevite Industries in February 1987.

Reilly of Mattituck, L.I., to John E. Alle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil J. Alle of Pacific Palisades, Calif. Msgr. Paul Dotson, assisted by the Rev. Robert Stagg, performed the ceremony.

title: Reform Jews Weigh Mideast Plan
description: A leader of Reform Jews in America urged Israel yesterday to seek an international ''umbrella'' for direct negotiations with Jordan and other Arab governments to settle the dispute over the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Stake in Savings Unit
description: The Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara said Friday that a Los Angeles couple had acquired a 9.9 percent interest in it, making them the company's largest shareholders. Leonard M. and Merri Jean Ross said they intended to seek permission to increase their stake in the thrift institution holding company above 10 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Rosses said they had paid $3.5 million for 599,200 shares of Financial Corporation and had made the purchase for investment purposes. The couple, who list a business address in Beverly Hills, Calif., said they began buying stock last month. On Oct. 19, the day of the market's collapse, the couple bought 480,000 shares from Joseph H. Moss, an Atlanta investor, who had been the largest stockholder. Financial Corporation has 48 branches and assets of $5.5 billion.

title: Stage: From Gershwin, 'Reaching for the Moon'
description: THIS year's many theatrical commemorations of George Gershwin on the 50th anniversary of his death have already brought us the Brooklyn Academy of Music's concert productions of ''Let 'Em Eat Cake'' and ''Of Thee I Sing,'' the American concert premiere of the English musical ''Primrose'' at the Library of Congress and a spiffy revival of ''Lady, Be Good!'' at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn. The latest and certainly the most esoteric theatrical tribute took place this weekend in Rochester, under the auspices of the Eastman School of Music's opera theater program. A large cast of singers and a 27-piece orchestra gathered to present the world premiere of a ''new'' Gershwin musical, ''Reaching for the Moon.''

title: DENG STEPS DOWN AMID SIGNS POLICY WILL SURVIVE HIM
description: Deng Xiaoping retired in triumph today from the Central Committee of China's Communist Party as part of a sweeping overhaul that seems to promise continuation of his policies for economic change.

title: Sandinista Turns His Efforts to Down's Syndrome
description: The life of Omar Cabezas, a Sandinista leader and ex-guerrilla, has been full of political and military action. But none of his exploits prepared him for the personal crisis he now confronts after discovering that his infant sons have Down's syndrome.

title: BOSTON EDISON CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Ronald Reagan's Luck
description: The President's famous faculty for coming up a winner seems to have deserted him. His party lost the Senate last year, just as the Iran-contra story started trickling out. He bet a pile on Robert Bork for the Supreme Court, and lost. World stock markets crashed. Waves of criticism surge in daily. Just when a sound, inspiring leader is needed, he appears more out of touch than ever. What else is new? It's not Ronald Reagan who has changed; it's the rest of us. The fault has not been only in the movie star but in ourselves. Americans wanted Norman Rockwell values so badly that they projected them onto a man who for six years reflected those values back to us brilliantly.

title: Holiday Tomorrow

Transportation: Subways and buses on regular weekday schedule. Schools: Closed. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Sanitation: Local option. Governmental offices: Federal offices open; state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Regular deliveries. Banks: Closed. Transportation: New Jersey Transit on regular weekday schedule. Schools: Closed. CONNECTICUT Sanitation: Regular collection schedule. Governmental offices: Federal, state and municipal offices open. Post offices: Regular deliveries. Banks: Open. Schools: Open. Transportation: Metro-North on regular weekday schedule.

title: Hanna Nickel to be Sold
description: The United Consolidated Companies of Fremont, Ohio, plans to buy the Hanna Nickel Smelting Company, reopen its smelter here and produce a steel-making agent instead of mining nickel. United Consolidated has signed a contract with the M.A. Hanna Company of Cleveland to buy Hanna Nickel's assets, most of which will be sold, Bill Niggemeyer, United's president, said last week. Terms of the sale, which Mr. Niggemeyer expects to be completed at the end of this month, were not disclosed. Hanna Nickel will be owned by a new Delaware-based United subsidiary, Nickel Mountain Resources, and will employ 50 to 75 people within six months, Mr. Niggemeyer said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allied-Signal Inc., Morris Township, N.J., an advanced-technology company, said Forrest N. Shumway, vice chairman and a director, would take early retirement, effective Jan. 1. Butler National Corp., Lenexa, Kan., which provides aircraft-modification products and has acquired HSD Inc., a Kansas City, Mo., consulting engineering firm, named HSD's chairman, John Dixon, president of Butler. He succeeds Gerald R. Smith, who remains chairman and chief executive. Central Louisiana Electric Co., Pineville, La., appointed William F. Terbot chairman and chief executive and Scott O. Brame president, chief operating officer and a director. Esterline Corp., Bellevue, Wash., a maker of factory automation equipment, elected its recently named president and chief executive, Carroll M. Martenson, its chairman. He succeeds Charles H. Dyson, who will be chairman emeritus. Also elected were Wendell P. Hurlbut as executive vice president of operations and Robert W. Stevenson as executive vice president and chief financial officer. First Union Corp. of Georgia, Atlanta, named Harald R. Hansen president and gave him the additional title of chief executive. It also appointed him chairman and chief executive of its Georgia banking subsidiary, First Union National Bank of Georgia. Kentucky Utilities Co., Lexington, Ky., named John T. Newton chairman, president and chief executive. He will succeed W. B. Bechanan, who is retiring but will remain a director. Keycorp, Albany, a bank holding company, elected as a director Minoru Makihara, president and chief executive of Mitsubishi International Corp. Northern Telecom Ltd., Toronto, named Terry M. Nickerson chief financial officer and senior vice president of finance, succeeding Donald K. Peterson, who become group vice president of Meridian Business Systems for Northern Telecom Inc., the American unit of Northern Telecom Ltd. Norton Co., Boston, a supplier of abrasives and advanced-technology ceramics, plastics and chemical process products, announced the retirement of its chairman and chief executive, Donald R. Melville, at the end of the year, and the election of its president and chief operating officer, John M. Nelson, to those additional posts effective upon Mr. Melville's retirement. Norwest Corp., Minneapolis, a diversified financial services organization, elected John T. Thornton executive vice president, chief financial officer and controller. Worlds of Wonder Inc., Fremont, Calif., which manufactures Teddy Ruxpin and Lazer Tag toys, announced the resignation of William F. X. Grubb, executive vice president and general manager.

description: Joseph Brodsky, the winner of this year's Nobel Prize in Literature, will read from his works at 7:30 P.M. Susan Sontag will read English translations of some of Mr. Brodsky's poems; he will read in Russian and in English. Tickets are $10; a series ticket is $35. Information: 280-2820.

description: If Douglas H. Ginsburg is confirmed to the Supreme Court, it will represent a watershed for the economics-based legal theories associated with the University of Chicago Law School.

description: Voters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will select the officials who run their counties, towns and villages tomorrow in elections that will very likely confirm the one-party domination of most areas in the three states.

description: BLOSSOM DEARIE has developed a repertory of songs that are so perfectly suited to the superficial innocence of her high sweet voice that there is rarely any room for expansion in her programs from year to year.

description: For all the suffering she endured, for all the anguish that lingers, Karen Straw was one of the lucky ones. Invoking the so-called battered woman defense, she was acquitted by a Queens jury in September of murdering her estranged husband.

description: NBC, its longest strike now over, will begin a long-range job-reduction plan today to eliminate about 700 network jobs by the end of next year, according to officials at the company.

title: No Offer for Calmat
description: - A group of companies led by Industrial Equity Ltd. said it had decided not to make a takeover bid for the Calmat Company. Industrial Equity of Hong Kong already owns 19.1 percent of the common stock of the Los Angeles cement maker. Industrial Equity said its decision is a result of the stock market's volatility and litigation brought by Calmat against the group.

title: Advertising; Four Agencies Win Additional Accounts
description: Levine, Huntley Schmidt & Beaver, a Grey Advertising subsidiary, will be working for the friendly folks at the Beneficial Management Corporation, known for their willingness to lend money. Although no new ad budget has been set, it is known that the client spent about $10.8 million last year. The former agency, Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, had benefited from Beneficial since 1983.

title: TV Review; 'First Eden,' Mediterranean History
description: ''THE First Eden,'' a four-part series, is an excursion to the Mediterranean and all the lands around it. Tonight's episode, on Channel 13 at 10 P.M (and on Channels 21, 31 and 49 at 8), looks at the distant past. Continents collide, an ocean is formed, new animals proliferate. The episode, ''The Making of the Garden,'' is really a wildlife documentary.

title: U.N. Criticized by Iranian Official Over Efforts to Settle War in Gulf
description: A senior Iranian leader accused the United Nations of procrastination and deception in its Persian Gulf peace effort today, proclaiming that Iran will answer a cease-fire proposal with a new offensive.

description: Surgeons completed the transplant of a liver, a pancreas and part of a stomach and intestine today into a 3-year-old girl who has never eaten solid food because of a defect in her digestive system.

description: A public assertion by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's top foreign affairs adviser that Bonn must shoulder a greater share of Western security has highlighted anew the predicament of a nation torn between the obligations of its economic might and memories of its role as an aggressor in World War II.

description: To the Editor:
