New and Mighty Piano Makes Carnegie Debut
description: Yesterday's Carnegie Hall concert of the Leningrad Philharmonic, conducted by Aleksandr Dmitriev, was completely traditional. But not so the instrument upon which Lazar Berman played the Liszt Piano Concerto in A. It was a Fazioli F 308 concert grand, a 10-foot-2-inch monster with four pedals, a tripartite lid propped by three sticks and a fighting weight of 1,518 pounds. If nothing else this weight makes it the heavyweight champion of contemporary grand pianos. In recent weeks there has been much word of mouth about this new entry, and even something of a media blitz. In the audience were representatives of major piano companies.

title: Facts About Fat
description: Federal dietary guidelines recommend that Americans reduce cholesterol intake by avoiding highly saturated palm, palm kernel or coconut oil. Yet, the Food and Drug Administration permits food producers to disguise them.

title: VISUAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: CHESTER, PA.;
Vacant Houses Used for Poor
description: LEAD: AT least 600 homes in Chester are empty and boarded up, a constant reminder of the blight and rising unemployment that have plagued this city of 45,000, a dozen or so miles south of Philadelphia, over the last 15 years.

title: USACAFES LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
One-Woman Race With a New Soloist
description: A one-woman race is old hat bynow. In the last 15 years of the New York City Marathon, the female champion has crossed the finish line unchallenged, alone in the spotlight, at least one minute ahead of her nearest competitor. Yesterday, beneath a blue autumn sky, it was Priscilla Welch of Britain, a 42-year-old former member of the Royal Navy, who transformed the annual race into another athletic soliloquy.

LEAD: Tom Watson, who once dominated the PGA Tour the way Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer did in their prime, got back into the PGA Tour's winner's circle today for the first time since July 8, 1984 as he won the richest tournament in golf history.

title: Academic and Parental Pressure
description: According to a Brandeis University researcher, a drug commonly used to control high blood pressure may also relieve the extreme anxiety that paralyzes some students when confronted with a test. The finding could mean welcome relief for those few young people who are profoundly afflicted. But it also raises a disturbing question about parental pressure to achieve.

title: Shot Into Apartment Kills Boy, 5
description: A 5-year-old boy was killed yesterday when a friend of the child's mother, angry that he had been locked out of their apartment, shot a .45-caliber pistol into the apartment hitting the boy, the police said.

title: Sports of The Times; The N.F.L.'s Biggest Trade
description: AFTER only 24 hours with the Indianapolis Colts, Eric Dickerson was familiar with only six plays: four runs, two passes. But during yesterday's 19-14 victory over the Jets, he moved straight upfield to the line of scrimmage, cut to his right, turned and caught a short pass from Jack Trudeau, hurried away from the lunging arms of Troy Benson and faked Rich Miano into sprawling on the artificial turf before other Jets finally stopped him after a 28-yard gain.

title: Radiation Team Sent to Brazil Saves Two With a New Drug
description: Members of the international medical team that treated victims of the Chernobyl disaster have spent more than two weeks in Brazil where they used an experimental technique to save two of the most gravely injured victims of a radiation accident.

title: An Iran Affair Is Emerging in France
description: In an affair that echoes the furor over the Reagan Administration's secret arms sales to Iran, French Defense Ministry officials have charged that a Defense Minister in the former Socialist Government approved sales of 450,000 artillery shells to Iran in violation of French law.

title: ADIA SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VIRATEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $230,000. c-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $252,000.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Graf Tops Mandlikova: Top-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany swept past second-seeded Hana Mandlikova, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday to win the $150,000 European Indoors women's tournament in Zurich. Graf opened the match with a service ace and never looked back in winning the $27,000 first-place money. The 18-year-old broke Mandlikova's first service game to grab a 2-0 lead in the first set, then fought back from love-40 in the third game to win, again with an ace. Mandlikova, in contrast, had difficulties with her service. The 25-year-old had trouble getting her first service in, and several times double-faulted on crucial points.(AP) Teltscher Triumphs: Third-seeded Eliot Teltscher of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., outlasted John Fitzgerald of Australia, 6-7, 3-6, 6-1, 6-2, 7-5, to win the $200,000 Seiko Super tournament in Hong Kong. The American, ranked 23d in the world, needed more than three hours to win. (AP) Lendl Prevails: Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, defeated fellow Czechoslovak, Miloslav Mecir, 5-7, 6-1, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday to win the $923,000 European Community Championship in Antwerp, Belgium. It was Lendl's fourth victory at the annual exhibition tournament since it began in 1982. He needed 3 hours 18 minutes to capture the $215,000 first-place prize.(AP) Auto Racing Austrian Wins Japan Prix: Gerhard Berger of Austria brought Ferrari back to the victory circle, winning the Japan Grand Prix at Suzuka by about 17 seconds. The 28-year-old Berger took the pole position for the event, got an early lead and was in control, losing the lead only briefly for a pit stop. It was the second victory in 51 grand prix races for Berger, who lives in Worgl, Austria. He also won the 1986 Mexican Grand Prix. Berger completed the 51 laps of the 3.64-mile circuit in 1 hour 32 minutes 58.072 seconds, averaging 119.565 miles per hour. Ayrton Senna of Brazil was second in a Camel Lotus-Honda in 1:33:15.456.(AP) Michael Andretti Is First: Michael Andretti drove through the rain to easily win the Nissan Indy Challenge at Tamiami Park in Miami. The season finale of the 15-race CART-PPG Indy-car series was red-flagged to a halt nine laps before its scheduled conclusion after what had been a steady rain turned into a downpour. Andretti, who led from lap 49 until the race was stopped at the end of lap 103, crossed the finish line on the soaked 1.784-mile, nine-turn circuit 56.045 seconds ahead of Al Unser Jr. The winner, who collected $67,410, averaged 94.873 m.p.h.(AP) Baseball Seibu Takes Title: The Seibu Lions beat the Yomiuri Giants, 3-1, yesterday to win their fourth Japanese Series championship in six years. The Pacific League champion Lions received three-hit pitching from Kimiyasu Kudoh as they won the four-of-seven-game series four games to two. They also were the Japanese champions last year. The final game was played before a crowd of 32,000 at Seibu Stadium. Kudoh, who picked up his second victory and had one save, was chosen the most valuable player of the series. Kudoh also was chosen most valuable player last year.(AP) Dog Show Bearded Collie Is Best: Ch. Ha'Penny Moon Shadow, the top-winning bearded collie in the history of the breed in the United States, was selected as best in show yesterday at the all-breed fixture of the Union County Kennel Club in Dunn Sports Center in Elizabeth, N.J. It was the 20th major award for the dog, who is owned by Robert Greitzer and Richard Schneider of New York and handled by Cliff Steele. On the way to the victory, the charcoal and white 6-year-old won his 96th group. Horse Show Predent Beats Jenkins: Rodney Jen-kins of Rapidan, VA., show jumping's top rider, could not beat Katie Mona-han Predent in the President's Cup at the Washington International Horse Show in LaNDOVER, Md., last night. Jenkins, a three-time winner on his horse Monroe, had the time of 29.33 seconds but kicked out the last rail on the jumping course. Predent, of Mid-dleburg, VA., won the class on Special Envoy in a faultless round made in 30.42 seconds. The Grand Prix jump-ing event closed the Washington In-ternational Horse Show. Team competition went to the French with 70 points. The United States was sec-ond with 39 points, Canada third with 8 points.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL G.O.P. ON POLLUTION
description: Five candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination gathered here today to talk about environmental protection. They all were strongly for it.

title: Dawkins's Wife Dies
description: Police were investigating the death this morning of the estranged wife of Darryl Dawkins, the former New Jersey Nets player, authorities said.

title: New Yorkers to Decide on Changes to Constitution
description: New York State voters will decide tomorrow whether to enact two amendments to the State Constitution, one dealing with ski trails and the other with civil service examinations.

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,887,000 and $5,594,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $1,811,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Sports World Specials; Extra Effort
description: On Oct. 15, the women's basketball team at Fordham filed into the Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx and began to stretch out their off-season kinks. Jeanine (J. J.) Radice was among them, still very much in the playing shape that has allowed her to amass 1,000 points in her first two seasons at the school.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The leadership role that has been played by Comrade Deng Xiaoping has not been determined by his post. Though he has left the Party Central Committee now, his prestige and wisdom will insure him a major role in the work of both the party and the state.'' - Zhu Muzhi, a spokesmanfor the party congress. [ A15:3. ]

title: BROWN & SHARPE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Put Supertrains On Northeast Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph Campbell, Writer Known For His Scholarship on Mythology
description: Joseph Campbell, one of the most knowledgeable writers on mythology and folklore, died Saturday at his home in Hawaii after a brief illness. He was 83 years old and had homes in Honolulu and Greenwich Village.

title: Futures Shock, Misplaced
description: What caused the Black Monday stock market crash on Oct. 19? The search for reasons, and scapegoats, has turned to ''portfolio insurance,'' ''program trading'' and other computer-paced investment strategies linked to hybrid securities called stock index futures.

title: Rate of Violent Crime Reported on the Wane
description: The rate of violent crime nationwide has declined substantially in recent years, according to a report made public today by the Justice Department.

title: Amgen Chief Confident On Biotechnology Gains
description: Seven years after leaving the cushion of a corporate research post to catch what he saw as the ''wave of the future,'' George Rathmann is beginning to feel confident that biotechnology will fulfill its promise.

title: Dance: Japanese Group at La Mama
description: ''THE GARASHA'' possessed a theatrical split personality. One sign of it could be found in the printed program for this dance-drama, which a cast of dancers and actors from Japan presented Saturday night at La Mama.

title: Devils' Success a True Team Effort
description: THERE is fresh paint on the walls of the Devils' locker room and the lighting is brighter. And the room has been filled with victory celebrations this season by a group of bigger and stronger players.

title: Rene Levesque, Separatist Leader And Quebec's Ex-Premier, Is Dead
description: Rene Levesque, who led an often bitter and ultimately unsuccessful struggle to separate Quebec from Canada and who served as the province's Premier from 1976 to 1985, died at his home in Montreal today after a heart attack, a police spokesman there said. He was 65 years old.

title: DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago quarter and 6-month results are restated to reflect acquisitions accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: MISSION WEST PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes a charge of $48,000 from reversal of a tax credit for the quarter, and the 9-months includes a tax credit of $220,000.

title: SYLVAN LEARNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $311,906 for the quarter and $913,386 for the 9 months. c-Net loss The year-ago third quarter and 9 months' results were reduced by $767,449 and $1,708,310, respectively, by an accounting change.

title: Israel Cabinet Defers Issue of Security Agency
description: The Israeli Cabinet today postponed discussion of an official inquiry's report that concluded agents of the Shin Beth internal security service had routinely committed perjury to convict terrorist suspects.

title: TV Review
description: 'Shaka Zulu,' a 5-Part Mini-Series

title: Recital: Lynn Harrell, Cellist
description: LYNN HARRELL'S evening of cello solos at the Metropolitan Museum on Saturday night had a sandwichlike symmetry to it - Bach suites at the beginning and end and in between, two 20th-century pieces.

title: Outdoors: Hunting Deer Indirectly
description: ALTHOUGH I enjoy a venison steak singed on the outside and red in the middle more than any other fare save rare wild duck, most of the deer meat I eat has been given to me.

title: U.S. Official Says Missile Treaty With Soviet Is Nearly Completed
description: Frank C. Carlucci, President Reagan's national security adviser, confirmed today that the Soviet-American treaty to eliminate medium- and short-range nuclear weapons is now all but completed.

title: Gibraltar Loss Of $155 Million Special to The New York Times
description: The Gibraltar Financial Corporation said it had a third-quarter net loss of $154.6 million, after taking a $147.1 million write-down and adding $92 million to its loan loss reserves. A year earlier, Gibraltar earned $13.3 million, or 69 cents a share.

title: A Moment of Truth
description: During his quick visit to Havana and Moscow, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua has a decision to make that shouldn't be hard. Either he returns to Managua this week ready to negotiate a cease-fire with the so-called contras, as he agreed when he accepted the Arias peace plan for Central America, or the world will hold him responsible for subverting it.

title: Midland Bank Closure
description: Britain's Midland Bank P.L.C. is closing its off-shore banking unit in Bahrain in a move to rationalize its operations, a bank official said today. The unit, which has operated in Bahrain for 11 years, is the bank's sole branch in the Middle East and has a staff of seven, according to Collin Pettit, the manager. The bank plans to pull out by Nov. 30. Mr. Pettit said the branch was originally set up to generate corporate business in Saudi Arabia, but has now decided that operations could be handled by other offices in the Midland group.

title: PRIAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DIVERTING ATTENTION FROM CITY'S WOES
description: The night before, humiliation loomed. I was sure I hadn't trained diligently enough to be able to go the distance. It began to seem like one of the more ill-conceived ideas I'd ever had, to run a marathon.

title: NORTHWEST NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Art of the Chinese Scholar
description: A man sat at a desk and wrote down what he considered the essential conditions for a full and happy life:

title: YES, CHARLES HAS AN ITCH; IT'S TO SQUELCH THE PRESS
description: So, after days of frenzied speculation in the tabloid press about the state of his marriage, what do you suppose is on the Prince of Wales's mind about newspapers these days?

title: SCIENTIFIC SYSTEMS SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Korean Takes Campaign to Rival's Door
description: Kim Dae Jung ventured today into the home province of his chief rival in the opposition and drew enthusiastic crowds, showing that he could be a political force on alien terrority as he campaigns in South Korea's first direct presidential election in 16 years.

title: Recital: The Kavafians
description: IDA and Ani Kavafian have an aggressive, deep-in-the-strings, excited way of playing their violins that is intended to please a crowd, but what they provide is a shallow, unrewarding pleasure and it quickly wears thin. The sisters' dual recital Saturday evening at the 92d Street Y - at which Ida played both violin and viola - included lots of energetic, virtuosic bowing and emotionalism of an easy, general sort. Small, telling details were repeatedly glossed over in favor of broader effects. The Kavafians' Bach resembled their Mozart, Schumann and Sarasate.

title: Cultures Clash as Farms Become Suburbs
description: Don Bowlby, Paul Kuhl and Roger Everitt have rejected offers of millions for their farmland. They are the minority, the last of the old guard. Most of their farming friends have sold to developers, pocketed their profits and left.

title: Relationships; After A Child Is Molested
description: THE plight of women whose mates have sexually abused their children is painful and poignant. Rage, bewilderment and a sense of helplessness were palpable as six women in that situation gathered in Brooklyn to discuss their trauma and its aftermath.

title: GROSSMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,756,000 for both the quarter and 9 months related to the premium paid on the purchase of outstanding debentures, and tax credits of $5,213,000 and $6,354,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $62,147,000 and $78,004,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and gains of $226,072,000 for the quarter and $225,072,000 for the 9 months from a reorganization settlement.

title: The Stage: 'Conversations in Exile'
description: ''I AM sick of all the virtues,''

title: Lawyer for Whitehead Defends Custody Fight
description: Mary Beth Whitehead's chief lawyer said today that the recent disclosure that Mrs. Whitehead had become pregnant out of wedlock does not change her effort to regain custody of the 19-month-old girl she bore as a surrogate mother.

title: New York City Hospitals Fail To Get Heart Transplant Unit
description: The New York State Department of Health has rejected competing applications by the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan and the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx to become the state's second heart transplant center.

title: REPUTED MOB FIGURE IS FOUND SLAIN IN BROOKLYN
description: A man whom law-enforcement authorities called an associate of the Gambino organized-crime family was found shot to death yesterday morning behind the bar of the Brooklyn tavern he owned. The police said they knew of no motive for the slaying.

title: GENENTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $333,000 and $1,222,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: IDAHO POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Maxwell to Buy Alco-Gravure
description: The Maxwell Communication Corporation P.L.C. said it had agreed to acquire Alco-Gravure Industries, an American commercial printer, for an undisclosed amount of cash. Maxwell Communication, which recently changed its name from the British Printing and Communication Corporation P.L.C., said the acquisition was being executed by its American subsidiary, the Maxwell Communication Corporation.

title: Election Day
description: NEW YORK Polls: Open 6 A.M. to 9 P.M. Parking: Alternate-side parking rules suspended. Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning. Governmental offices: Federal offices open; state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Regular deliveries. Banks: Option to close. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways and buses on weekday schedule; Long Island Rail Road on regular weekday schedule; Metro-North on regular weekday schedule. Schools: Closed. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Polls: Open 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. Governmental offices: Federal offices open; state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Regular deliveries. Banks: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on regular weekday schedule. Schools: Local option. CONNECTICUT Polls: Open 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. Governmental offices: Federal, state and municipal offices open. Post offices: Regular deliveries. Banks: Open. Schools: Open.

title: Pro Basketball Notebook; Richardson Question Looms
description: In less than four months, the National Basketball Association and its players' union will be confronted with a problem they would rather avoid. And that problem will have nothing to do with discussions on a new collective-bargaining agreement.

title: Takeover Activity Resuming; SINGER GETS HOSTILE OFFER
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, a Florida investor with a history of unsuccessful takeover bids, offered $50 a share yesterday for the Singer Company. Analysts and some arbitragers said they believed that Mr. Bilzerian's aim was to elicit a higher bid, enabling him to make a big profit on the 9.99 percent he already owns.

title: Gorbachev on History; A Signal to Keep Exploring Dark Episodes and Banned Ideas
description: A few days ago, Fyodor M. Burlatsky was uncertain whether the censors would approve the broadcast of his latest television drama, a politically daring play sympathetic to the views of the Bolshevik theorist Nikolai I. Bukharin.

title: LOTUS INTRODUCES AGENDA PROGRAM
description: The Lotus Development Corporation today introduced Agenda, the much-talked-about software program that it calls a personal information manager and that others have described as a ''spreadsheet for ideas.''

title: PAM TRANSPORTATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Action Must Be Taken in the Nursing Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: Arbitrager Had Loss of $100 Million
description: Comdisco Equities is one of the biggest arbitrage houses in the country, and Martin A. Weinstein, its head, is truly a big spender, quick to buy 300,000 shares or more of a takeover stock at a clip. In the volatile market days of the last two weeks, Mr. Weinstein and Comdisco lost $100 million, or half the firm's capital, then quickly made back $20 million.

title: People
description: * Peter Renfrew-Hill has joined FCB/ Leber Katz Partners as senior vice president, director of human resources.

title: Revolutionary Restraint
description: In Beijing, Deng Xiaoping quietly passes power to the next generation to continue a new and pragmatic economic course. He won the battles to do so over the last decade. In Moscow, Mikhail Gorbachev struggles to follow a similar path. His speech to commemorate the Bolshevik Revolution was littered with the historical warfare of 70 years that still resonates in the Kremlin.

title: Volcanoes and Ships
description: ON Oct. 11, an undersea volcano erupted directly under the research ship Melville, making the ship tremble and resound as giant bubbles of volcanic gas burst against its hull. Oceanographers, including those at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in San Diego, which operates the ship, were unable to recall any other such occurrence.

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,009,000 from the decrease in the value of securities and from the early retirement of long-term debt for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $8,169,000 from the sale of securities for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary credit of $1,283,000 from the dissolution of a pension plan for the quarter an 9 months.

title: Deng's Dapper Heir> Zhao Ziyang
description: Twice in recent months, Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said he did not want the job. ''I'm not that fit to be the General Secretary,'' he told an American television interviewer just one month ago. ''I'm more fit to look after economic affairs.''

title: Homer M. Byington Jr.
description: Homer M. Byington Jr., the first American Ambassador to newly independent Malaya, now Malaysia, from 1957 to 1961, died of a heart attack Sunday aboard the Vista Fjord, a Norwegian cruise ship, in the Atlantic Ocean. He was 79 years old and lived in Soto Grande, Spain.

title: Corrections
description: A short profile in Business Day last Wednesday of Koji Yoneyama, the new president of Daiwa Securities America, reported his additional title incorrectly. He will also serve as chief operating officer.

title: Innovations of '87
description: Each year at this time, tens of thousands of people who make, sell, buy or use personal computers descend into Las Vegas for the Fall Comdex trade show. Comdex is a showcase for the new PC products that will be in the stores next year.

title: 19 Children of Muslim Leader Battle a Bank for $5.7 Million
description: Nineteen children of Elijah Muhammad, the late Black Muslim leader, have squared off against the world's largest bank in a legal dispute with a $5.7 million bank account at stake.

title: Recital: Pavarotti
description: HOW easy it would be to admire Luciano Pavarotti if he could keep the tasteless image-mongering from interfering with his performances! The famous Italian tenor sang his very best Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall: the voice untiring and in magnificent condition, the inclination to suavity stronger than it has often been, the concentration of expression often unmarred. Marred it was at other times, in ways we have come to expect - but Mr. Pavarotti reminded everyone how he won all those opera-house triumphs before the superstar career began to make opera-house standards irrelevant for him.

title: US TRUCK LINES INC OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chess Game Is Adjourned
description: The eighth game of the world chess championship was adjourned tonight with the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, sealing his 42d move.

title: Driver Takes the Stand In Howard Beach Trial
description: Dominic Blum, the driver of the car that struck and killed Michael Griffith last December in Howard Beach, Queens, testified yesterday that he heard a ''big bang'' and that his windshield shattered at the moment of impact. But he said he left the scene because he did not know what he had hit.

title: Slow Recovery on Washington Avenue
description: Like many of the merchants and residents along Washington Avenue's commercial corridor in Brooklyn, Gus Vlahavas waits eagerly for the economic revitalization that has already come to the surrounding communities.

title: Savannah Electric
description: The Southern Company said that its board had agreed to buy the Savannah Electric and Power Company for stock in a deal valued at more than $230 million. Southern said that 1.05 shares of Southern common would be exchanged for each of Savannah Electric's 10.6 million shares. The deal must be approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the shareholders of Savannah Electric.

title: HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $11.9 million and $22.1 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Effervescent Betsey Johnson
description: ''Pure terror!''

title: MARATHON MYSTERY UNSEEN WINNER
description: AT least nobody can accuse ABC of being a front runner.

title: College Football; Holy Cross in a Scoring Mode
description: Stopping their own offense has become a problem for Holy Cross. After the Crusaders have a game locked up, they replace Jeff Wiley, their passing wizard, and the other regulars. But the momentum is such that the score keeps mounting.

title: High Capital Gains Tax And a Volatile Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Samples Of Smallpox Pose a Quandary
description: TEN years after smallpox ceased to exist as a human disease, virus experts and public health officials are in a strange and unprecedented quandary: what to do with the last surviving smallpox viruses.

title: Ethics Agency Sets Ginsburg Inquiry
description: The Office of Government Ethics said today that it would open an inquiry into the conduct of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, President Reagan's nominee for the Supreme Court, in handling a major case for the Justice Department bearing on the cable-television industry while he held stock in a cable company.

title: MULTI-COLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lessons of the NBC Strike
description: LEAD: We're back at work. For four months, 2,800 members of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians have been on strike against NBC, a subsidiary of General Electric. Now it's over and the union lost. Not only did the union fail to gain substantial contract concessions, but NBC managed to get along remarkably well without its union employees.

title: ECONOMY FRAMES DEMOCRATS' FORUM
description: The six Democratic Presidential contenders debated social welfare policy here tonight, trying to restate their party's traditional commitment to expanded antipoverty and health care programs while demonstrating their fiscal responsibility.

title: Advertising; Goodyear To Leave Thompson
description: GOOD to its word, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company will withdraw most of its advertising from the J. Walter Thompson Company, now British-owned, on Feb. 1. This year's billings could be around $40 million.

title: Jackson Is Pleased
description: ''It's still there,'' Bo Jackson said of the speed, quickness and power that won him the Heisman Trophy as college football's best player in 1985. His comment came after he had played his first football game since the 1985 season, for the Los Angeles Raiders in their loss on Sunday against the New England Patriots.

title: FOXBORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Addendum
description: U.S. News & World Report will raise its rates but not its circulation 5.8 percent with the Jan. 11 issue.

title: U.N. Idea Could Be Reborn in the Persian Gulf; Not Easy to Carry Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Price of Gas Stirs Concern
description: Natural gas can remain an abundant, cheap and environmentally attractive fuel, but its low price has ended the incentive to explore for new gas, an Arthur Andersen & Company study released today says.

title: Alaska Air and Pepsi Are Winners at Festival
description: When the names of the winners of the best TV campaign and best TV commercial were read at the International Film and TV Festival of New York on Friday, it was just like old times.

title: Gary Cummings Dead; Former CBS Executive
description: Gary Cummings, a former vice president and general manager of CBS's Chicago television affiliate WBBM and an Emmy award-winning broadcaster, died of complications resulting from melanoma, a type of skin cancer, on Saturday at the University of Illinois Hospital in Chicago. He was 46 years old.

title: BASIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net of $846,000 and a loss of $5,432,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After a loss of $199,000 for the quarter and net of $1,144,000 for the 9 months both from discontinued operations.

title: ECHO BAY MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in July 1987. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Should the Board of Education Be Abolished?
description: As the seven members of the New York City Board of Education scour the country for a new Schools Chancellor, questions are being raised about the board itself. To whom is it responsible? Should it be abolished? Should it be expanded? What should be its relationship to the Chancellor?

title: Elders Calls Off Stock Offering
description: Elders I.X.L.

title: Illinois Agency Offering Bonds
description: The Du Page County Forest Preserve District of Illinois is tentatively offering $126 million of general obligation bonds with yields ranging from 6.40 percent in 1992 to 7.30 percent in 1997 and 8.23 percent in 2007. The underwriters, led by the

title: Stage: 'Riverside Drive,' In Yiddish and English
description: THE setting is 50 years ago and the question at hand deals with assimilation, with conflict between old-country Orthodox Jews and their Americanized, less rigid compatriots. The show, in Yiddish, with lots of English necessarily involved, is Leon Kobrin's ''Riverside Drive,'' and it is, despite the weighty issues it tackles, done with charm and humor as this season's production by the Folksbiene Theater.

title: Ogilvy Profit Rises
description: The Ogilvy Group, whose subsidiaries include Ogilvy & Mather and Scali, McCabe, Sloves, said yesterday that third-quarter net income rose 12.8 percent, to $5.7 million, or 38 cents a share, from $5 million, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier, while revenues rose 29.1 percent, to $171.4 million, from $132.8 million.

title: Accounts
description: * Victory Optical, Newark, to Franznick & Cusatis.

title: Book Award Nominees To Read at City Center
description: Four writers who have been nominated for the National Book Award in Fiction - Toni Morrison, Larry Heinemann, Alice McDermott and Howard Norman - will read from their works next Monday at 5:30 P.M. at City Center, 131 West 55th Street. The winner of the award will be announced at a ceremony at the Pierre hotel later that evening.

title: Goldome to Add Parts of Rainier
description: The Goldome Realty Credit Corporation said that it had agreed to acquire parts of the Rainier Mortgage Company. Goldome, with headquarters in Buffalo, said it would buy 22 of the Seattle-based Rainier's mortgage origination offices in Washington, Oregon, California, Arizona, Idaho, Hawaii and Alaska.

title: NWA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
H.R.A. Office to Coordinate Soup Kitchens and Pantries
description: As director of an organization that distributes food to soup kitchens and food pantries, Pamela E. Green has done a great deal to feed hungry New Yorkers.

title: JOSEPHSON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $146,000 from repurchase of debentures and a tax credit of $924,000. c-Includes net of $160,000 from discontinued operations; a $20,750,000 gain on the sale of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $581,000.

title: Results Plus
description: Hockey

title: INSIDE
description: Progress in Chips Dispute Washington said that Japan has stopped dumping computer chips. As a result, trade sanctions may end as soon as this week. Page D1. A foundation started by the founder of the United Parcel Service is providing $100 million to help children in need. Page A20. Navy Fires on Boat in Gulf A United States Navy frigate opened fire on a suspected Iranian patrol boat that was speeding toward an American tanker. Page A3. Baseball: Who Made What A look at the salaries and bonuses for major league baseball players, including a chart of what every player made in 1987. Pages A25 and A27.

title: Military People Favor States Without Tax as Legal Home
description: A disproportionate number of the nation's military people are claiming legal residence in states that do not tax their income, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: Michael Parloff, Flutist, Solos at Alice Tully Hall
description: Michael Parloff has been principal flutist at the Metropolitan Opera for 10 years but has also established a workable career outside the house. As a soloist, Mr. Parloff had a busy evening Sunday with the Solisti New York chamber orchestra at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Qaddafi Will Boycott Arab Summit
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today that he would boycott an Arab summit meeting next week, calling it an event ''dictated by America and held specifically to combat Iran.''

title: Don't Let the Amnesty Door Slam
description: Congress passed the Immigration Reform and Control Act last year to make it harder for new illegal aliens to stay in this country - and easier for old ones. The act provided amnesty for aliens who had been here since at least 1982. But they were given only 12 months to apply, and even that time has been constricted. Fairness alone would impel Congress to keep the legalization door open an additional year, to May 4, 1989.

title: Lotas Wins Account
description: Lotas Minard Patton McIver has become agency for S.C. Johnson & Son's Halsa-line hair-care products. Billings should be about $5 million. The business had been with the J. Walter Thompson Company in Chicago, which as the incumbent was in a creative shootout with the winner.

title: New Ads From Nynex
description: In a couple of weeks Nynex, the telecommunications and information systems company, will start running a fanciful set of three 30-second commercials from Young & Rubicam that should leave a residue of awe in the viewer's mind. That's a handy ploy when a company is out to impress senior and middle managers at potential corporate customers coast to coast. And for the first time Nynex will hit TV in 15 major markets coast to coast. Viewers of news shows, prime-time shows and some upscale sports programs will see ads that should implant in the subliminal silt the idea that maybe Nynex is a gift from heaven without which earth might stop and the skies fall. There are worse reputations.

title: Sports People; Price Files
description: San Francisco's Joe Price, the winning pitcher in Game 5 of the National League playoff, and three other players filed for free agency yesterday. Two members of the Montreal Expos, Vance Law and Reid Nichols, and Phil Garner of the Los Angeles Dodgers also filed.

title: JEFFERSON-PILOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes captial gains of $44,895,000 for the quarter and $58,817,000 for the 9 months. c-After capital losses of $217,000 and capital gains of $3,475,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Nation Steps Up Productivity
description: The nation increased its efficiency in producing goods and services at an annual rate of 2.6 percent in the third quarter - more than double the productivity improvement of the last year, the Government said today.

title: CHINESE PREMIER WINS APPOINTMENT TO TOP PARTY POST
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang formally became General Secretary of the Communist Party today, establishing himself as the man to lead China toward the next century.

title: CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $400,000 and $66,000,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; net from discontinued operations of $19,900,000 for the quarter and $52,100,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $7,700,000 and $33,900,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $40,700,000 and $114,900,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; net from discontinued operations of $20,300,000 for the quarter and $39,100,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $19,200,000 and $42,600,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago third quarter and 9-month are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Two Firefighters Hurt In Incident With Police
description: Two firefighters were slightly injured last night in an incident involving firefighters and police officers who were responding to separate false alarms in the South Bronx, officials said.

title: WOLOHAN LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kuwait's Loss Put at $5 Billion
description: Kuwait may have lost $5 billion when global stocks plunged, a leading Kuwaiti economist said today.

title: Battling AIDS From the Stage
description: In a field that knows more than its share of rivalry and spite, next Sunday evening's ''Music for Life'' concert at Carnegie Hall will represent an uncharacteristic - indeed startling - spirit of cooperation among classical musicians.

title: KENTUCKY CENTRAL LIFE INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $7,321,384 and $10,167,460 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; and tax credits of $100,000 for the quarter and $2,600,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes capital gains of $979,481 for the quarter and $1,521,006 for the 9 months. Share earnings reflect 200 percent stock dividend declared in April.

title: NAC RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $109,000 and a $188,000 reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $596,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $165,000 for the quarter and $2,243,000 for the 9 months.

title: MOLSON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted; primary share earnings were not immediately available. The company said net earnings for the first quarter this year included a $4.7 million after-tax gain from sale of real estate; last year's second quarter included an after-tax gain of $2.7 million from the sale of Perolin-IWC Inc. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: After Delays, Sessions Becomes Chief of F.B.I.
description: After two postponements due to a stomach ulcer, William S. Sessions was sworn in today as the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. He succeeds William H. Webster, who left the post to become Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the first New York public performance on a Fazioli F 308 concert grand piano misidentified the orchestra and the place of the concert. The concert was given by the Leningrad State Symphony of the U.S.S.R., at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: EX-CONTRA LEADER CALLS FOR A TRUCE
description: Arturo Cruz, a former anti-Sandinista leader, said today that the United States-supported guerrillas in Nicaragua should ''put their activities on hold'' to enhance the prospects of the Central American peace plan.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE SECRETS OF THE SERVICE. A story of Soviet Subversion of Western Intelligence. By Anthony Glees. Illustrated. 447 pages. Carroll & Graf. $22.95.

title: CONTINENTAL MATERIALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

description: To the Editor:

title: Rene Levesque, Ex-Premier of Quebec, Dies at 65#
description: Rene Levesque, who led an often bitter and ultimately unsuccessful struggle to separate Quebec from Canada and who served as the province's Premier from 1976 to 1985, died of a heart attack Sunday in Montreal. He was 65 years old.

title: Japanese Chip Dumping Has Ended, U.S. Finds
description: The Commerce Department said yesterday that Japan had ceased dumping computer chips, a finding that Administration officials predicted would allow President Reagan to lift by the end of the week many of the sanctions that he imposed on Japanese electronic goods in April.

title: Dean Witter Hires 27 From Salomon
description: Rebuilding its municipal-bond operation, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said yesterday that it had hired 27 municipal-bond specialists, including two managing directors, from Salomon Brothers Inc. Salomon recently announced it was abandoning the municipal-bond business because of low profits.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''WHAT do we all have in common?'' Karl Lagerfeld wanted to know.

title: Miami's Mayor Favored In Election Race Today
description: By his own estimate, Mayor Xavier Suarez of Miami receives remuneration for his City Hall hot seat at the rate of $2.40 an hour, far below the Federal minimum wage, for a 40-hour week.

title: INDIANA ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,479,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: NASA Delays 4 Contracts
description: NASA said today that it was delaying for several weeks selection of companies for billions of dollars worth of space station contracts.

description: The Markets

description: To the Editor:

title: Ad Pages Increase
description: The Publishers Information Bureau said advertising pages for its magazine members had risen 2 percent, to 14,756, in September from a year earlier, while revenues had increased 2.3 percent, to $485.8 million.

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,594,000 for the quarter and $10,273,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $794,000 for the quarter and $1,381,000 for the 6 months.

description: For any Dallas Cowboy fan who believes that history repeats itself, the best news about the team this season may be all the bad news.

Zuckerman, chairman of U.S. News & World Report, invited a small group to the magazine's offices last week for a screening of the Soviet Georgian film ''Repentance,'' which has sent political shockwaves throughout the Soviet Union.

description: Governors

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''To remain faithful to historical truth we have to see both Stalin's incontestable contribution to the struggle for socialism, the gross political errors and the abuses committed by him and those around him.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A10:2. ]

title: Theater: A Revival of 'Company'
description: SO it's side by side with Sondheim, sort of, once again. As Stephen Sondheim's newest work, ''Into the Woods,'' prepares for its Broadway opening Thursday night, his 1970 ''Company'' has settled into the York Theater a couple of miles uptown. Settling down is what Robert, the 35-year-old hero of the sourly sentimental book by George Furth, cannot do; instead of keeping company with a nice girl, he hangs around with five married couples, who have him in to dinner and worry over whether he's going out enough.

title: Big Stock Loss For Briton, 23
description: A leading British investment firm said today that it was holding an inquiry into how a trainee accountant was allowed to run up debts of more than $1.2 million in last month's stock market plunge. A spokeswoman for County

title: Gorbachev on History; Revolution's Road From 1917 to Now: The Leader Takes Stock
description: Following are key sections of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech in Moscow yesterday, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass: It is 70 years since the unforgettable days of October 1917, those legendary days that started the count of the new epoch of social progress, of the real history of humankind.

title: Panel Says Caesareans Are Used Too Often
description: About half of all women who gave birth by Caesarean section last year did so unnecessarily and perhaps dangerously, according to a report issued today by a non-profit organization founded by Ralph Nader.

description: b-After tax credits of $617,700 for the quarter and $802,200 for the 9 months.

description: Hu Qili#

title: Interpublic To Buy Gross
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the United States operation of Britain's Geers, Gross P.L.C., which it plans to merge into McCann-Erickson, its largest network. None of the financial details were disclosed.

title: Average Raise Under 5%
description: The average salaried worker received a raise of 4.8 percent this year and can expect an increase of 4.9 percent in 1988, according to a survey of more than 1,200 American companies released today. This is the first year since the early 1970's that salary increases have been below 5 percent, said Bill James, chief compensation consultant for Hewitt Associates of suburban Lincolnshire, which issued the report. But more salaried workers will probably receive performance-based bonuses this year, Mr. James said.

title: ATLANTIC CITY ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Bonuses Bolster Baseball Salaries
description: By staying healthy all season, Steve Balboni of the Kansas City Royals earned more money in bonuses, $525,000, than the baseball income earned in all ways by 473 major league players this year.

title: Dollar Low Vs. the Yen And Mark
description: The dollar fell to a 40-year low against the Japanese yen and moved close to a postwar record low against the West German mark yesterday in the wake of indications from European central bankers that they would allow the dollar to continue to fall.

title: GORBACHEV ASSAILS CRIMES OF STALIN, LAUDS KHRUSHCHEV
description: Resuming a painful examination of Soviet history that was all but suspended for the last 25 years, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that Stalin was guilty of ''enormous and unforgivable'' crimes and praised two Soviet figures who had been officially repudiated.

title: Grady B. Wilson
description: The Rev. Grady B. Wilson, an evangelist and close associate of the Rev. Billy Graham, died of heart failure Friday at a hospital in Charlotte, N.C. He was 68 years old and lived in Charlotte.

title: TEXAS AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary tax credit of $18.5 million for the quarter and 9 months.

title: U.S. Designs Spy Satellites To Be More Secret Than Ever
description: A BATTERY of new technologies, some mature, others on the drawing board, will help the United States overcome Soviet efforts to deceive Western spy satellites, according to former Government officials, space experts and private scientists.

title: Careers; Wanted: College Presidents
description: THE turnover in presidencies and other executive positions at the nation's colleges and universities has grown rapidly in recent years.

title: JMB Completes Cadillac Bid
description: In one of the largest commercial real estate deals ever, a unit of the JMB Institutional Realty Corporation said that it had completed its previously announced acquisition of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation, a Toronto-based real estate developer, for $2 billion.

title: DELMARVA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Selection of Jurors In Smuggling Case Is Closed by Judge
description: - A Federal district judge closed the jury-selection process today in the cocaine-smuggling trial of Carlos Lehder Rivas at the request of defense and prosecution attorneys.

description: b-After a charge of $3.3 million from early retirement of debt. c-Includes charges of $10.2 million for the quarter and $23.7 million for the year on the early retirement of debt; the year also includes a gain on disposal of $148.8 million.

title: Bill Rates Advance Sharply
description: Treasury bill rates rose sharply yesterday as fears of a financial crisis diminished enough for some investors to sacrifice the safety of Treasury bills for the higher yields available on other securities.

title: FROM THE BUREAUCRATIC BUZZING, A REPORT WITH STING
description: In assessing the leadership and management of the Defense Department, the Secretaries of the Army, Navy and Air Force have produced an analysis with an unusual sting, given the pablum that often comes from the Government's bureaucratic blender.

title: FOR BETTER LIVING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Yet Again, Subsidies For Water Become An Issue in Congress
description: The seemingly endless battle in Congress over subsidized water for farms is flaring again on several fronts.

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Islanders Showing Respect for Devils
description: The story of the Devils is slowly spreading to hockey's heartland like a titillating political rumor. People smile, shake their heads and laugh, at once convinced it can't be true while savoring every outlandish detail.

title: U.S.-Soviet Unsung Gains
description: ARMS control negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union may make the headlines but, on a less dramatic level, negotiations over the exchange of students have a long and successful history.

title: No Author Autographs
description: The Soviet Embassy held a highly unorthodox book party yesterday: neither the book nor the author was available. But then, it was an unusual literary occasion, the publication in the United States of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new volume, ''Perestroika.'' The title is the Russian term for restructuring, which describes Mr. Gorbachev's effort to reshape some of the political and economic dynamics of the Soviet Union.

title: Texas City Journal; Where a Chemical Leak Seems an Accepted Risk
description: Morris Galloway came home today to find his beloved grapevines an eerie dead thicket, turned from green to brown by the hydrofluoric acid leak that caused the evacuation of 3,000 residents from their homes last weekend.

title: '84 JACKSON UNIT WILL PAY PENALTY
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's 1984 Presidential campaign has agreed to pay the Federal Election Commission a civil penalty of $13,000 for election law violations.

title: Sports People; New Investigation
description: Nevada-Las Vegas has been formally notified that the National Collegiate Athletic Association is investigating its recruitment of Lloyd Daniels.

title: Sports People; Suicide Suspected
description: A preliminary autopsy report on the body of the estranged wife of Darryl Dawkins of the Utah Jazz yesterday listed the cause of her death as possible suicide.

title: Thomas G. Bergin, 82, An Authority on Dante
description: Thomas G. Bergin, a professor emeritus of Yale University who was an authority on Petrarch, Dante and the medieval Provencal poets, died Friday at his home in Madison, Conn. He was 82 years old.

title: Banks Learning a Hard Lesson
description: The stock market collapse is raising fundamental questions about the pace of banking industry deregulation, especially the move into investment banking.

title: A Guide to the National Horse Show
description: The 104th National Horse Show runs today through Sunday at Madison Square Garden, with competition in several categories and three types of exhibition performances. There are sessions at 9 A.M. (except Friday), 1:30 P.M. (1 P.M. Thursday) and 7:30 P.M. daily, but the most interesting events for the non-specialist are in the afternoon and evening sessions. Following are highlights of each day's schedule. Afternoon International and Open Jumpers Event - The jumpers compete over the highest and most difficult obstacles in the show, and nothing counts but clearing the jumps and, in some events, doing so in the fastest time. This class include entries from the four international teams -the United States, Britain, Canada and France - competing here, as well as ''open'' jumpers, the professionals competing individually. Saddlebred Three-Gaited Event; Saddlebred Five-Gaited Event - Saddlebreds evolved from horses bred by farmers and ranchers who needed to traverse many acres quickly yet comfortably. Now they are bred for showing, some with three ''natural'' gaits (walk, trot, canter) enhanced by high-stepping hooves, arched necks and other flourishes; others with two additional gaits taught by man, the slow-gait and the rack. There are saddlebred events daily except Sunday. Evening Open Jumper Power and Speed Event - Combining big obstacles with fastest times on the first round (no jumpoff) makes this a difficult event. Parade of the International Teams - This is the show's formal opening ceremony, done Olympic-style, with the national anthems of each team played by a brass band that always makes the horses prance skittishly around the arena. Tomorrow Afternoon New York City Mounted Police Musical Ride - This is an exhibition by a score or so of New York's Finest equine pairs, the riders carrying flags, the horses executing drill-team movements to brisk, big band-style music. One of the most delightful events of the show. Repeated Wedneday night, Friday afternoon and as the final event Sunday night. Evening Bank of Montreal Nations' Cup for International Teams:This is jumping at its finest, with the four teams here representing the same nations that were the top four finishers in this year's world championships. Open Jumper Event: Similar competition to the international event, featuring individual professional riders. Thursday, Nov. 5 Afternoon International and Open Jumpers Event: Note the half-hour earlier starting time, on this day only. Evening Regular Working Hunter Formal Attire Event:Hunters compete over jumps that resemble obstacles found while fox hunting. Unlike the Open division, entries are judged on their jumping form, pace and behavior. In tonight's event, the rider must wear formal fox-hunting attire, the equestrian equivalent of top hat and tails. Dressage Exhibition: Often described as ballet on horseback, dressage is what the famed Lippizaner horses perform. Reiner Klimke, an Olympic gold medalist in 1984, will give this exhibition performance, to be repeated Friday evening and both Saturday and Sunday afternoon and evening. International and Open Jumpers, Puissance Stake: In French, puissance means power; the highlight of this contest is an imitation stone wall that is raised with each round until only the winner clears it. The world indoor record for the wall is 7 feet 7 1/2 inches. Friday, Nov. 6 Afternoon U.S. Pony Clubs Mounted Games: These are reminiscent of ''field day'' in elementary school, with games such as carrying eggs on spoons, sack races and other relays for children on ponies. The kids compete again Friday evening, Saturday afternoon and evening and for their championship on Sunday afternoon. Evening International and Open Jumpers, Gamblers Choice Stake: Here, obstacles are assigned a point value, depending on their difficulty, and the rider may jump them in any order he wishes within a prescribed time limit, trying to accumulate the most points. It always features some slapdash, quick-turning, hair-raising rides. Saturday, Nov. 7 Afternoon International and Open Jumpers: The team riders and individual professionals compete in a class where speed is emphasized. N.H.S. Saddle Seat Championship, ''Good Hands'' Final: This is the national championship for riders 18 and under in saddlebred-type competition, but with the rider's form, not the horse's, being judged. Evening International and Open Jumpers, Mercedes Grand Prix of New York: Along with the Nations' Cup, this is perhaps the most glamorous jumping event of the show. Sunday, Nov. 8 Afternoon International and Open Jumpers, Fault and Out: As the name implies, in this event one rail knocked down or one refusal immediately eliminates the entry. Time will decide among ties. A.S.P.C.A. Maclay National Championship Finals: This is the national championship for riders 18 and under in hunter-type competition, with the rider's form, not the horse's, being judged. Evening International and Open Jumpers ''Big Apple'' Grand Prix: Points earned here count toward the American Grandprix Association's Rider and Horse of the Year awards. Awards Ceremonies: Awards will be presented to the leading Open Jumping division rider, leading International division rider, leading Foreign International rider, and to the winning International Team.

title: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $2.5 million from the company's discontinuing the operations of its Transtar unit and disposing of its assets.

title: Broker Group Leader to Stay
description: The Securities Industry Association said yesterday that John W. Bachmann, the managing partner of Edward D. Jones & Company of St. Louis, had been nominated for a second term as chairman of the association - the first to serve consecutive terms.

title: New York City Plans First Sale Since Plunge
description: New York City plans to test the waters in the financial community this week with its first bond sale since Wall Street was hit by a sharp drop in stock prices during October.

title: WEINBERGER PLANS TO LEAVE CABINET, REAGAN AIDES SAY
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has decided to resign for personal reasons, Administration and Congressional officials said tonight.

title: Videotape Shows Officer Accepting $500 Payoff
description: A suspended Brooklyn police officer was seen, in a videotape played at her corruption trial yesterday, accepting $500 from an undercover investigator she thought was a drug dealer. She was then heard to say ''beautiful'' and ''thank you.''

title: Rise in U.S. Drilling Rigs
description: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States last week rose by one, to a total of 1,131, Baker Hughes, the Houston-based oil tool maker, said today. The rig count was down by four the previous week, the company added. A year ago, the count totaled 860. The count reflects the number of rigs working as of last Friday. It is a tally of the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, and not rigs producing oil.

title: As the Dow Hops
description: From the woman who gave us the term, ''Teflon President,'' for Ronald Reagan, comes a new definitional foray. Representative Patricia Schroeder, the Colorado Democrat, told her House colleagues last week:

title: Philharmonic Ensemble At Merkin Concert Hall
description: The most affecting piece on the program by the New York Philharmonic Ensembles on Sunday afternoon at Merkin Concert Hall came just before intermission with C. G. Rex's four unpublished songs for soprano, string quartet and piano. Based on poems about love and death by A. E. Housman, they date from 1945 and reflect in their touching sentimentality the spirit of a society emerging from war. Rex, who died in 1973, wrote these works at the age of 36 as a college student.

title: WESTERN AUTO SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an after-tax gain from the early retirement of debt of $200,000.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $922,000 from debt retirement.

description: A senior Sandinista military officer apparently defected to the United States last week, diplomats and politicians said today.

title: Why NASA Left the Launch Business
description: To the Editor:

title: 7th Avenue Forecast: Shorter and Shorts
description: Bill Blass showed brilliantly beaded, Matisse-inspired short dresses in patterns as intricate as a Persian carpet. Carolyne Roehm's ribbons of fringe swirled around the body with all the abandon of a flapper's dress of the 1920's. Carolina Herrera's glittering shorts were glimpsed under billowing silk damask evening dresses; some crepe shorts were accompanied by matching black and white jackets.

title: Stage: Kafka's 'Trial,' By Cocteau Repertory
description: JOSEPH K. sleeps on a narrow plank, the size of a coffin, between two high walls; he works in an equally confined space. Even before a couple of pseudosinister types come to arrest him, he is a prisoner in a deeply shadowed world. That is basic to the Jean Cocteau Repertory's intelligent new production of ''The Trial,'' Franz Kafka's novel, dramatized by Andre Gide and Jean-Louis Barrault.

title: Manhattan Couple8 Are Charged In Beating of 6-Year-Old Daughter
description: A Manhattan lawyer and a former children's book editor were charged yesterday with the attempted murder of their 6-year-old daughter after the police answered a call for medical help at the couple's Greenwich Village apartment and found that the girl had been severely beaten.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What happens to the bullet when a warning gunshot is fired in the air? Could the bullet kill or injure someone on its way back to earth? A. Theoretically, if you fired a shot straight up, the bullet would fall right back down on you, according to Officer Frank S. DiMario, master firearms instructor at the New York City Police Academy. In fact, however, the size of the bullet, the angle at which it is fired and factors like wind and humidity alter a bullet's path. Even fired at a very slight angle, ''a simple little .22-caliber bullet will land over a mile away,'' he said. ''As bullets get bigger and heavier, the distance could be multiplied two, three or four times.''

title: OGILVY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The earnings for 1987 include the results of Decisions Center Inc., which was acquired in August 1987 and is accounted for as a pooling of interests. Earnings for 1986 restated to conform with 1987 presentation. Revenue represents commission and fee income.

title: A 'BREAKTHROUGH' SOUGHT IN SUMMIT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that he would press at the summit meeting next month in Washington for ''a palpable breakthrough'' on a treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons and banning weapons from space.

Art Sales Outlook: Up in the Air
description: Two weeks after Black Monday, the New York art world this week begins what is traditionally one of its biggest business seasons - the month of November - with hope and trembling.

title: American Let Go by Contras Says He Was Not Mistreated
description: An American who was released Friday after being held by Nicaraguan guerrillas for two weeks said today that he had not been mistreated.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW MEXICO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
HUNTS AND I.R.S. BEGIN $385 MILLION TAX TRIAL
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt and Caroline Hunt went to Tax Court today in a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service, which is seeking $358 million in back taxes and penalties related to the crash of the silver market in 1980.

title: City Opera: 'Zauberflote'
description: THE New York City Opera's current production of ''Die Zauberflote'' remained a pleasure from beginning to end despite the uneven cast that occupied the stage at the New York State Theater Sunday evening. Here was a case of the total being greater than the sum of its parts: most of the singers were replacements for last summer's opening night ensemble and though a couple of principal roles fell to unsteady voices, the cheerful good spirits of the entire affair managed to carry the day.

title: Foes Report Over 380,000 Names In Drive to Oust Arizona Governor
description: Opponents of Gov. Evan Mecham today concluded a four-month drive to oust him from office by filing petitions that they said had 388,988 signatures, nearly twice as many as needed to force an election.

title: Boxer's Widow Wins 7-Year-Old Legal Fight
description: A lawsuit filed by the widow of Willie Classen - a boxer who died of head injuries after a fight at Madison Square Garden in November 1979 - was settled out of court yesterday for a ''substantial six-figure'' sum, according to attorneys and court officials involved in the case.

title: Greyhound Begins Rural Bus Service
description: Greyhound Lines Inc. began a pilot program for rural bus service in Tennessee that is expected to spread nationwide and revive the flagging public transportation industry, its officials said. The project links vans from eight rural transportation agencies statewide with Greyhound buses in larger cities, similar to the hub system used by airlines.

title: New Commerce Post Stirs Up Storm
description: A power struggle has broken out in the Commerce Department under its new Secretary, C. William Verity Jr., over his choice to fill the new job of Under Secretary for Export Administration, Commerce officials said today.

title: Chelsea Discount Shopping Gets Local Board Backing
description: A proposal to convert a refrigerated warehouse on the Chelsea waterfront into an enormous factory-outlet shopping center has returned to the New York City Planning Commission with a nearly unanimous endorsement of the local community board.

title: Article 144887 -- No Title
description: On a tree-shaded avenue lined with Victorian houses, a little-known family foundation is about to take James E. Casey's legacy public by spending more than $100 million to help children.

For Journalism Dean, Questions About Objectivity#
description: H. Joachim Maitre, the newly appointed dean of the Boston University College of Communication, is not the sort of person to allow the academic life to tie him to a desk or imprison him in detached scholarship.

title: Small Imps, and Tall Ones
description: Remember Tootie Smith? The Tootie Smith of the marvelous old movie musical ''Meet Me in St. Louis,'' who set out one Halloween to show her mettle. Dressed to scare and scared to death, she ''got'' an old man with a fistful of flour and strutted home the self-styled ''wickedest of them all.''

description: Naturally, there was a lot of talk about the role of the press and its responsibilities during the annual Journalism Week at the University of Missouri's School of Journalism. It is the oldest school of its kind, founded in 1908, and proud of its contribution to professionalism.
