Share earnings computations for the 1986 quarter and 9 months include net income of 3 cents a share resulting from satisfaction of interest expense related to working capital loans from Warner Communications by issuance of a portion of these shares.

title: Takeover Activity Resuming; SANTA FE AND HENLEY TALK
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said today that it was negotiating to be acquired by the Henley Group in a deal valued at $63 a share, or $8.4 billion for the portion of Santa Fe that Henley does not already own.

title: G.M. Holding Engine Talks
description: The General Motors Corporation said it was nearing a decision on whether to combine its diesel engine operations with another manufacturer. ''I would have hoped to have it done a month ago,'' said Ludvik F. Koci, the general manMger of G.M.'s Detroit Diesel Allison division. Mr. Koci said the company had been talking with parties, which he would not name, since a venture with Deere & Company fell through in March. He said the possibilities included joint development, mutual marketing of complementary products, joint ventures and equity participation.

title: Erotic Films in AIDS Study Cut Risky Behavior
description: SHOWING explicit, erotic, films of safer sex practices is more effective than other techniques of encouraging gay men to avoid sexual behavior that places them at high risk for infection with the AIDS virus, according to a new study.

title: Talking Business with Palmer of the Wharton School; Drop Expected In Job Offers
description: The Wharton School of Management in Philadelphia is one of the nation's premier business schools, where 6,000 appplicants compete annually for some 700 places. Its graduates include such financial pioneers as Michael Milken, the creator of junk bonds, and Saul P. Steinberg, who gained fame for his takeovers.

title: Party Leader Favors a Black Successor to Merola
description: Assemblyman George Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, said yesterday that he would prefer that a black Democrat succeed the late Mario Merola as the Bronx District Attorney.

title: CABOT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $1,956,000 and $10,541,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the early retirement of debt. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary charge from early retirement of debt of $2,010,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said the latest fourth quarter loss is after an after-tax restructuring charge of $12.3 million and a special charge of $9.1 million to provide for additional exposure the company has from certain natural- gas contract disputes.

title: TV Screen as a Teacher
description: ''PROFESSOR, that's amazing!''

title: Paine Webber Gives Up Unit
description: Paine Webber Inc. is handing over its profit-starved commercial paper business to Citicorp, the two financial service companies announced yesterday.

title: Former Nurse's Aide Admits 9 Killings in Hospital
description: Donald Harvey, a former nurse's aide who has confessed killing dozens of patients at hospitals in Ohio and Kentucky, pleaded guilty today to charges of killing nine patients at a hospital here and was sentenced to life in prison plus 20 years.

title: Market Place; Trading Range Seen for Dow
description: AS might be expected after the market's October massacre, estimates in the investment community vary widely as to where the Dow Jones industrial average might be headed.

title: Upsets in '87 Primaries Hint At Further Surprises Today
description: Off-off-year elections are poor guides to the future of national politics. But this year's contests have offered some striking evidence of an electorate given to sudden shifts in allegiance and of local political establishments in deep disarray.

title: Polling Hours
description: New York's most closely contested races include those for Suffolk and Erie County Executive. Hours are from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: 573 New Units to Replace A Newark Housing Project
description: Columbus Homes, the Central Ward housing project that has been synonymous with crime and urban decay for the last decade, is to be demolished and replaced with mixed housing, including condominiums selling for up to $100,000, city officials said today.

title: DART DRUG STORES reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $22,700,000 from debt restructuring. c-Includes a charge of $5,900,000 from pre-payment of long-term debt. The company went public in July.

title: Corrections
description: A Denver dispatch on Saturday about the trial of four members of a white supremacist organization in connection with the killing of the host of a radio talk show, incorrectly described a contention in the case. It is lawyers for the defense, not the prosecution, who say the victim, Alan Berg, was murdered by another white supremacist, who died in a shootout in 1984. Prosecutors say he was killed by one of the trial defendants.

title: Writers to Discuss James
description: William Gass, Elizabeth Hardwick and Susan Sontag are to speak about Henry James as part of the Great American Writers series sponsored by PEN. The program begins at 7 P.M. Sunday at PEN American Center headquarters, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, fourth floor. A reception follows the program. The public is invited, with admission $4. Additional information: 334-1660.

title: KEY RATES
Election Day Choices
description: Here is a summary of our recommendations in selected races. Polls in New York are open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.; in New Jersey from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. Manhattan CIVIL COURT

title: Political Marketing; FRANCHISES GIVE ADVICE TO HOPEFULS ON A BUDGET
description: This offer is not available in any store, but if you order now, you too can use the latest in space-age campaign technology in your race for State Legislature, City Council or even School Board.

title: Duro-Test Offer
description: The Duro-Test Corporation said its board rejected as inadequate a $13 a share offer from William P. Lyons, a Yale University professor, and the TCA-IV Limited Partnership. The company also said it had filed suit in Federal District Court in Newark against Professor Lyons and TCA-IV, seeking the enforcement of Securities and Exchange Commission disclosure requirements and of Federal Reserve Board margin requirements regarding the investors' purchase of Duro-Test shares.

title: U.S. Frigate Fires on Boat Moving Near Gulf Tanker
description: A United States Navy frigate opened fire Sunday night on a suspected Iranian patrol boat that was speeding toward an American tanker, American military officials announced today.

title: Rise in Tobacco Buyer Age Proposed in Jersey
description: A study commission on smoking today recommended increasing New Jersey's tax on cigarettes by 5 cents a pack and raising the legal age for buying tobacco products to 18 years, from 16, as part of a strategy to discourage smoking among children.

title: Building Outlays Rise 1.5%
description: Construction spending increased 1.5 percent in September, the biggest advance since April, the Commerce Department said today.

title: A Set of Rules For Conflicts
description: The Justice Department has established these guidelines for dealing with possible conflicts arising from private financial interests:

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $18,000 for the quarter and $8,495,000 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $4,502,000 and $7,363,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Sports People; Abdul-Jabbar Ailing
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was suffering from a sinus infection and did not travel to Springfield, Mass., with the Los Angeles Lakers for tonight's Hall of Fame exhibition game against the Chicago Bulls, the Lakers announced yesterday.

title: Texaco Loses in Texas High Court
description: The Texas Supreme Court today rejected a request by Texaco Inc. for a hearing to overturn the Pennzoil Company's landmark $10.3 billion award against Texaco.

title: Stocks Advance on a Wide Front As Volume Continues to Moderate
description: The stock market, which began the last two weeks with declines that rocked investors around the world, sounded a different note yesterday, moving broadly higher in a much quieter session.

title: New Computer Company Set
description: Steve S. Chen, the supercomputer designer who left Cray Research in September after his project was canceled, announced the formation of his new company today.

title: Factory Orders Posted 1.1% Gain for September
description: Orders to factories for manufactured goods jumped 1.1 percent in September, rebounding after an August setback, the Government said today.

title: Dyncorp Buyout
description: Dyncorp said its board had accepted a management-led leveraged buyout proposal calling for each of its 10.8 million common shares outstanding to be exchanged for $19.50 in cash and for $3.50 principal amount of a new junior-subordinated, pay-in-kind debenture due in 2007. After the withdrawal of a buyout offer from its chairman, the company announced Oct. 26 that it had received several acquisition proposals after soliciting bids.

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
When the Kremlin Says Yes
description: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's newfound enthusiasm for using the United Nations as an instrument of achieving peace and security once again confronts the Reagan Administration with a bothersome question: what to do when the Kremlin agrees to a longstanding American demand?

title: Leo Goldberg, Astronomer, Dies
description: Dr. Leo Goldberg, a noted astronomer and the former director of the Kitt Peak National Observatory in Arizona, died of cancer Sunday at the Tucson Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Tucson.

title: Worries About Intimacy Are Rising, Therapists Find
description: INTIMACY, that combination of self-disclosure and emotional closeness, is carrying more of a premium than ever. Since the 1950's, surveys show, more and more people have come to see intimacy - in friendship, at work and at home - as increasingly important to their sense of satisfaction with life.

title: Days Inn Sale
description: The Days Inn Corporation said that its principal stockholder, the Reliance Capital Group L.P., might periodically buy up to one million Days Inn common shares in the open market or in privately negotiated purchases. The company also said it had agreements to sell 10 hotel and motel properties to two investor groups for about $97 million. Days Inn said about 49 percent of its 20.3 million shares outstanding were now beneficially owned by Reliance and its affiliates. Days Inn stock closed at $5.875 today, up $1.125, in over-the-counter trading.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1987
description: International A3-13 Stalin committed 'enormous' crimes, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said in a speech that resumed a painful, long-suspended examination of Soviet history. Mr. Gorbachev also praised two Soviet figures who had been repudiated by the party. Page A1

title: Bell & Howell Up on Rumors
description: The Bell & Howell Company's stock has jumped after reports that two large shareholders were increasing their holdings fueled speculation that it may be a takeover target, Wall Street analysts said. Bell & Howell, an information services company based in Skokie, Ill., rose $3.50 to close at $55 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on Oct. 22 about the opening of the Bahai lobby misstated the office's plans and the status of Bahais in Morocco. The office has no plans for public demonstrations. There have been no arrests of Bahais in Morocco since 1983.

title: Seymour Vall Is Dead; A Theatrical Producer
description: Seymour Vall, a theatrical producer and playwright, died of cancer Friday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: A Few Pluses Seen From Stock Crisis
description: Wall Street investment strategists and portfolio managers say the stock market's trauma of late last month could set the stage for a healthier investment climate. While no one welcomed the panic and is well aware there are many painful case histories, some professionals argue that ultimate benefits might include these:

title: TV Review; Story of Panama Canal
description: THE title, ''A Man, A Plan, A Canal, Panama,'' is a famous palindrome, reading the same way front and back. That's clever, and the documentary itself is even better. The ''Nova'' presentation, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, uses scope and imagination to tell a compelling story: the Panama Canal is infinitely more than a ditch.

title: Negotiators Are Frustrated by Pace of Deficit Talks
description: Negotiations between Congress and the Reagan Administration to reduce the deficit ran into problems today as Democrats charged that the White House was being inflexible and Republicans worried about achieving significant spending reductions.

title: BROCK HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,609,000 for the quarter and $2,798,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $288,000 and $15,781,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also includes a gain on extinguishment of debt of $20,675,000. The company said share earnings for the year-ago 9 months are restated to reflect shares issued under the company's restructuring plan as if the shares had been outstanding for all of 1986.

title: Creativity and Mental Illness
description: There is a strong link between mental illness and outstanding creativity in writing, a new study shows. But the mental illness is manic-depression, not schizophrenia, as some theories have held.

title: Cigna Reports Better Results
description: The Cigna Corporation, a Philadelphia-based insurance company, said yesterday that its third-quarter operating income from continuing operations rose 23 percent, to $163.3 million, or $1.94 a share, from $132.3 million, or $1.52 a share, a year ago.

title: German Currency Intervention Unlikely
description: Karl Otto Pohl, the president of West Germany's central bank, indicated in New York last night that Germany did not intend to act decisively to keep the dollar from falling further in currency markets.

title: Giants' Woes Continue: Lose Game and Simms
description: When it seemed that the Giants' long years of frustration here finally had ended, and even this season suddenly started looking brighter, the Cowboys produced a record-tying four field goals in the fourth quarter, along with an interception return for a touchdown, to produce a 33-24 victory.

title: Pace Halts Trading
description: Pace Securities Inc., a small brokerage, has temporarily ceased doing business because of financial difficulties, but the firm said that it expected to be back in operation soon. The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday morning that Pace had shut down, but Pace officials said later that they had brought in more capital to meet the Big Board's net capital requirements. Pace has about 12,000 customer accounts, the exchange said. The company clears its trades through Edward A. Viner & Company.

title: Our Towns; A Proper Fadeout For a Remnant Of Another Time
description: The Clinton Grange has given away its money and is closing. About $7,000 was in the treasury from the last few harvest suppers and card parties, but not enough members were making it to the meetings for a quorum.

title: WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $783,000 and $1,061,000 for the quarter and after an extraordinary credit of $2,535,000 and an extraordinary loss from bond refinancing losses of $1,061,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income

title: Slump Baffles Walton and Jets
description: Everyone is talking, but no one seems to know what is causing a tailspin that threatens to make a shambles of the Jets' season.

title: Abominable Snowman Wins Another Believer
description: MOST of the unicorns, griffins, sea serpents and other fabulous creatures that once tinged the everyday world with romantic mystery have succumbed to the withering touch of rational inquiry. But the Himalayan yeti (and his American cousins, sasquatch and bigfoot) die hard, and an English physicist is offering skeptics what he considers to be fresh evidence that abominable snowmen may, in fact, exist.

title: REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports of The Times; Bernard King Of the Bullets
description: BERNARD KING and his magical shooting touch and stiff cigar-store Indian game face and his rebuilt Model-T knee have gone south.

title: Quest for Slice of Comet
description: IN an important engineering milestone toward sending an unmanned spacecraft to explore a comet, a prototype of an instrument-bearing projectile designed to take a bite out of an icy comet nucleus has been tested successfully at the Sandia National Laboratory in New Mexico.

title: PUERTO RICAN CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter includes a $371,000 charge which was primarily the result of writedowns of obsolete and idle equipment. The latest quarter sales included $677,000 of revenue realized from realty operations, compared with $4,000 in the year-ago period. The latest 9 months' sales included $696,000 from realty operations, compared with $9,000 in the year-ago period.

title: Ginsburg> A Quiet Life Turns Public
description: Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg and his wife, Dr. Hallee Morgan, were living quietly in northwest Washington, enjoying classical music, good books, daily swims in their backyard pool and occasional forays into the kitchen to concoct what their friends describe as gourmet dinners.

title: Hospitalization of Homeless Challenged
description: Lawyers and psychiatrists clashed in a courtroom at the Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday over whether New York City had the right to take a homeless woman from the streets and treat her against her will in a psychiatric ward.

title: A VIEW THAT'S AS ROSY AS RED INK> STEPHEN MARRIS
description: He walks with shoulders stooped, head tilted forward, gray locks slightly disheveled as if he were bearing the woes of the world. In a sense he is, as the Cassandra of Dupont Circle.

title: Reagan to Nominate Former Interior Aide As Labor Secretary
description: Ann Dore McLaughlin, a former Under Secretary of the Department of Interior, is expected to be nominated by President Reagan to become the next Secretary of Labor, White House officials said tonight.

title: Sewage Project Could Turn Waste Into Profit
description: AGRICULTURAL engineers at Cornell University have devised a new system for treating sewage that can produce reservoir-quality water at little or no cost, according to researchers here.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in July.

title: Webb Chairman Steps Down
description: Robert K. Swanson has resigned as chairman, chief executive and a director of the Del E. Webb Corporation. He mentioned health reasons.

title: Seoul Journal; A Whiff of Fall, Not Tear Gas, in the Campus Air
description: It is quiet for a change at Yonsei University.

title: Margaret Price Sings At Avery Fisher Hall
description: Margaret Price is a spirited and honest song recitalist at her best, and those who remember her disappointingly muted concert at Avery Fisher Hall two seasons back will be glad to hear that she was much nearer that best on Sunday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Quarterbacking the Market
description: Amid the gyrations of the world's stock markets, so bewildering and frightening to all concerned, there is available one statistical barometer that can be watched with comparative calm for the next few weeks. It is the Super Bowl stock theory, first outlined in the sports pages of The New York Times (by me) in 1978.

title: MDT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $410,000 and $554,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $89,000 for the quarter and $183,000 for the 6 months.

title: MEM CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $103,100 for the quarter and $62,200 for the 9 months. Results for the third quarter and 9 months reflect the disposition of Lebanon Packaging in August 1986.

title: ZYCAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $837,000 for the quarter and $1,668,000 for the 9 months; the quarter also includes a pre-tax gain of $743,000, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of a facility. c-Net loss

title: PARK-OHIO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Girl Given 5 Organs Wakes
description: A 3-year-old girl wakened today after she became only the third person in the nation to receive a five-organ transplant.

title: Former Head of Peoples Will Lead Dart Drug
description: Sheldon W. Fantle, who made his fortune by building up Peoples Drug Stores Inc. and selling it, is getting back in the drugstore business.

title: Sports People; Peters to Cleveland
description: Hank Peters, who was dismissed as general manager of the downtrodden Baltimore Orioles on Oct. 5, after helping the team to a pair of pennants and one World Series victory in his 12 years on the job, was named president of the Cleveland Indians yesterday.

title: Hong Kong Client in Schwab Case
description: A Hong Kong investor was identified today as the customer who was largely responsible for a $22 million loss announced last week by Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount stockbroker.

title: Bridge: At Tournament on Riviera, The Beach Is a Distraction
description: Many of the tournaments around the world that are organized by local, national and international organizations have very long histories.

title: U.S. and Soviet Scientists Plan Joint Studies on Ozone
description: Scientists from the United States and the Soviet Union will conduct more than 30 joint climate research projects next year, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced today.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alco Health Services Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., appointed John A. Kurcik Jr. controller.

title: Robert Phillips, Guitar
description: Robert Phillips, who is active in the guitar world not only as a player but also as a composer, journalist and broadcaster, gave an interestingly varied program Saturday night at Weill Recital Hall. He concentrated on 20th-century music and might have made a stronger impression if the concentration had been exclusive, since the opening works by Napoleon Coste and J. S. Bach brought enough passing faults in finger work to remind us that Mr. Phillips is not a virtuoso performer. But in suites of short, varied pieces by Ned Rorem and Frank Martin he showed an aptitude for putting across character.

title: Has Marathon Reached Peak?
description: From his vantage point in a fire-engine-red convertible, Fred Lebow could see nothing but success. For those who subscribe to his theory that more is better in the New York City Marathon, Sunday's race was indeed the most successful of the 12 that have been run through the five boroughs.

title: Bid to Lift OPEC Output
description: Four Gulf Cooperation Council nations that double as OPEC members will seek an increase of at least 900,000 barrels a day in the group's production ceiling, the Kuwait News Agency said today.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Agree to Hear Virginia Lawyers Case
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments on the extent to which a state may discriminate in admissions to the bar against nonresident lawyers who wish to practice there.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1987
description: The Markets

title: Adopt-a-Monument Program Takes In 13 Statues in New York City
description: Thirteen monuments that New York City put up for private adoption last spring have found benefactors, but six orphans remain - on Staten Island, in the Bronx and Queens, and in the heart of Manhattan.

title: Taste and Nutrition
description: To The Living Section:

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL CHICAGO (NBA) - Waived Doug Altenberger, guard-forward, and Pete Myers, guard. CLEVELAND (NBA) - Placed Kent Benson, center, on injured list. HOUSTON (NBA) - Waived Michael Kennedy, forward. Placed Robert Reid, forward, on injured list. KNICKS (NBA) - Waived Geoff Huston, guard, and Leo Rautins, forward. Placed Louis Orr and Bob Thornton, forwards, on injured list. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Activated Larry Emery, running back, from injured reserve. Waived Steve Griffin, running back. BUFFALO (AFC) - Waived Durwood Roquemore, safety; Don Sommer, guard; Gary Wilkins, tight end, and John Diettrich, kicker. CHICAGO (NFC) - Waived Mike Hohensee, quarterback; Garland Rivers, defensive back, and Sean McInerney, defensive end. DALLAS (NFC) - Waived Chris Duliban, linebacker, and Sebron Spivey, wide receiver. Waived Robert Lavette, running back. DETROIT (NFC) - Traded Jimmie Giles, tight end, to Philadelphia for an undisclosed 1988 draft pick. Waived Eric Truvillion, wide receiver, and John Bostic and Kevin Grom, defensive backs. Placed Rich Strenger, offensive tackle, on injured reserve. GREEN BAY (NFC) - Waived Lorenzo Freeman, defensive tackle; Alan Risher, quarterback; Scott Fulhage, punter; Vince Rafferty, center, and Dan Knight, tackle. Placed Lee Morris, wide receiver, on injured reserve. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Placed Tony Eason, quarterback; Pete Brock, center; Steve Doig, linebacker, and Ron Shegog, defensive back, on injured reserve. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Waived Lyneal Alston, wide receiver; Jim Boyle, offensive tackle; Paul Oswald, center; Chuck Sanders, running back, and Chris Sheffield, defensive back. ST. LOUIS (NFC) - Waived Charles Wright, cornerback; Jeff Paine, linebacker; John Preston, safety, and Adrian McBride, wide receiver. Placed Jay Novacek, tight end, on injured reserve. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Waived Ty Allert, linebacker, and Danny Greene, wide receiver. Placed Louis Brock Jr., defensive back; Karl Wilson, defensive end, and Dan Rosado, guard, on injured reserve. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Waived Craig Swoope, defensive back; Bobby Bankton, wide receiver; Greg Davis, place-kicker; Charles Gladman, running back, and David Jordan, guard. Placed Tyrone Keys, defensive end, and Adrian Wright, fullback, on injured reserve. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Waived Cliff Benson, tight end, and Lionel Vital, running back. Placed Eric Cole, center; Brian Davis, defensive back, and Craig McEwen, tight end, on injured reserve.

title: Dollar Up After Fall To Lows
description: The dollar rallied on world currency markets yesterday after traders pushed it to new lows against the West German mark and the Japanese yen.

title: Sports People; Smith Suspends Reid
description: Dean Smith, coach of the University of North Carolina basketball team, has suspended two players, J. R. Reid, center, and Steve Bucknall, forward, from its season-opening game against Syracuse after the players' arrests on assault charges.

title: Abused Girl's Father Denies Wrongdoing at Hearing
description: The lawyer for a Manhattan man accused of trying to kill his 6-year-old daughter asserted last night at an arraignment that his client was not guilty of wrongdoing.

title: Gulf Fisherman Says U.S. Fired at Him
description: The vessel hit by a United States Navy frigate on Sunday night was an unarmed Arab fishing boat, not an Iranian patrol boat, a fisherman who said he was aboard the fishing boat asserted today. He said an Indian on the boat had been killed.

title: A Weekly for Doctors To Begin in February
description: Gerald L. Taylor, former publisher of Harper's Bazaar and National Lampoon, is starting a publication of his own, The New York Doctor, a weekly scheduled to make its debut Feb. 29.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: ONE of the most endearing qualities of the microwave oven is its ability to make risotto perfectly with a minimum of stirring. I have friends who have bought an oven just because they tasted my risotto. Although I love this traditional dish of Italian arborio rice slowly cooked to creamy succulence, it had almost dropped out of my repertory because I didn't like the fussiness involved in standing and stirring for 40 minutes as I gradually added liquid.

title: Olympia May Bid for Santa Fe
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the Canadian real estate and investment concern, said today that it might be willing to pay $63 a share in cash, or more, for the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, heating up a takeover battle that could be the largest ever outside of the oil industry.

title: Soviet Seeks to Enhance U.N. Peacekeeping Role
description: The Soviet Union is pressing the General Assembly to help it draw up ''a new comprehensive system of international security'' that would give the United Nations an enhanced role in preserving peace, according to diplomats here.

title: Cans, a Man, a Plan: New Redemption Center Struggles
description: Guy Polhemus had an idea of how to help the poor that was almost too good. It is helping them, but for a period it nearly left him bankrupt.

title: KELLY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August.

title: Saudi King Won't Attend Parley
description: Saudi Arabia announced today that King Fahd would not attend an Arab League summit meeting opening Sunday in Amman, Jordan.

title: LIFE IN THE 30's
description: THE painters. Don't the very words strike fear into your heart? We've all seen it happen. A colleague comes into the office.

title: Zulu Chief Defends His Role In New South African Panel
description: The paramount chief of six million Zulus in South Africa, Gatsha Buthelezi, today defended his participation in the South African Government's experiment in interracial administration here.

title: BUILDERS TRANSPORT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $200,000 from unamortized debt discount and interest penalties.

title: In Search of a Meal Near Javits Center? Good. Read This.
description: More than 2 million conventioneers pass through the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center each year (85 percent of them from out of town), and they need the doggedness of an archeologist to uncover interesting dining spots amid the industrial tundra surrounding the center. The year-and-a-half-old structure at 11th Avenue and 34th Street is hardly at the epicenter of Manhattan's gastronomic universe.

title: Sports People; Signs of Improving
description: Kelley Lyons, the wife of Marty Lyons, the Jets' defensive lineman, has shown signs of improvement since she was seriously injured in an automobile accident last week and is listed in stable condition in the intensive care unit of Bryan Whitfield Memorial Hospital in Demopolis, Ala.

title: Hartford Elects Black Woman As New Mayor
description: Carrie Saxon Perry, a Democrat, won Hartford's mayoral race tonight to become the first black woman to be elected mayor of a major Northeastern city.

title: EXPEDITORS INTERNATIONAL OF WASHINGON reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Reagan Plan For Banks
description: The Reagan Administration has decided against pushing for new real estate and insurance powers for banks, focusing instead on persuading Congress to grant banks permission to underwrite securities, a top Treasury Department official said today.

title: MARINE TRANSPORT LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains of $23,000 and $1,686,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, on the sale of vessels. c-Includes a loss of $9,672,000 on the writedown of a vessel.

title: WHEN THE MUSIC STOPS, 7 CHAIRS ARE MISSING
description: Job security for civil servants isn't what it used to be.

title: New Wave Ballet Delayed
description: The first performance of ''Elena's Aria'' by Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker, an experimental Belgian choreographer, in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival was canceled last night. The New York premiere of the work was rescheduled for 8 o'clock tonight.

title: Corrections
description: A Boston dispatch yesterday, about the dean of the College of Communciation at Boston University, misstated Osborn Elliott's affiliation with the Columbia University School of Journalism. He is its former dean and remains a professor there, on sabbatical.

title: The Sweet Smell of Progress
description: How do you demonstrate to investment bankers a new drug delivery system that uses a patch on the skin to slowly release nitroglycerine to patients with heart disease or antibiotics to a wound?

title: Stage: Goethe's 'Stella' In New Directors Project
description: ''STELLA'' begins in a cloud of mystery. A wife, long ago abandoned by her husband, arrives with their daughter in a small town where the daughter is about to begin working as a servant to a baroness. The baroness (the title character) lives alone in a mansion. She, too, has been abandoned - in her case, by her lover. On this increasingly momentous day, a man named Fernando appears and turns out to be the one woman's husband and the other's lover.

title: Voters Approve $68 Million Jail For Westchester
description: Westchester County voters tonight approved a $68 million bond issue to build a 530-bed jail intended to relieve overcrowding at the county's correctional complex at Valhalla.

title: Calvin Klein: Chic For the Shapely
description: Calvin Klein has inherited the position Yves Saint Laurent occupied some 20 years ago when he made pants suits fashionable and transported lowly styles like the pea jacket to the upper echelons of chic.

title: New Day Is Dawning in Tiny Pacific Palau
description: To the Editor:

title: EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 4
description: b-Includes $40 million and $100 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, of pre-tax pension income as a result of adopting the new pension standard. c-After pre-tax charges of $98.3 million, of which $62 million was related to the company's reduction-in-force program and $36 million for facilities closures for the quarter; the 9-month is after pre-tax charges of $378.2 million, of which $315 million was related to the company's reduction-in-force program and $63 million for facilities closures. Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Oct. 19, 1987.

title: Arizona Governor Granted Delay Of Grand Jury Inquiry Into Loan
description: Gov. Evan Mecham today won a temporary delay of a grand jury investigation of a $350,000 loan he received, allowing him to seek to remove the State Attorney General from the case.

title: Caps Continue Mastery of Canucks
description: Bob Gould scored his first goal of the season with 2 minutes 53 seconds left in the third period tonight, giving the Washington Capitals a 3-2 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: FINANCIAL NEWS NETWORK reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
3 Fannie Mae Offerings Yielding 8.40% to 9.57%
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association yesterday announced yields for three issues of debentures totaling $2.3 billion. As expected, the yields on the quasi-government agency's debt were higher than for Treasury issues of similar maturity.

title: Pragmatic Revolution in China
description: The distinguishing mark of China's 13th Communist Party Congress was its steadiness, the legacy of a decade under the skillful hand of Deng Xiaoping. ''The Big 13,'' as the Beijing press called it, brought few real surprises.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of a brief music review yesterday about Margaret Price's song recital on Sunday afternoon misstated the site. It was the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Shutdown of Nuclear Plant Is Rejected by Maine Voters
description: The beleaguered nuclear power industry won a victory in Maine yesterday, where voters rejected an effort to shut down the state's only nuclear power plant.

title: Market Place; Plunge Derails New Offerings
description: THE October plunge in stock prices has brought the new-issue market to a virtual standstill. Few deals have reached the public. And prices are off sharply for corporations that had made initial offerings just before the market collapse.

title: Sports People; Canucks' Fine Reduced
description: The British Columbia Supreme Court has reduced by $300,000 the fine that the Vancouver Canucks were assessed by John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, over the signing of Pat Quinn as general manager. The Canucks were fined $310,000 and Quinn was suspended on Jan. 9 from coaching in the league until 1990.

title: Sports People; Chin Quits Amateurs
description: Tiffany Chin, who in 1985 won the United States women's figure skating championship and finished third in the world competition, has retired from amateur competition and signed a two-year contract worth more than $1 million with Holiday on Ice, according to a report yesterday in The Los Angeles Times.

title: Swiss Bank Records In Iran-Contra Case Are Released to U.S.
description: Switzerland turned over thousands of pages of secret bank documents today to the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, removing a final obstacle to the anticipated indictment of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and others. According to investigators, the documents, which have been the subject of nearly a year of litigation here and in Switzerland, detail an elaborate scheme to funnel money to Nicaraguan rebel groups out of the profits from American weapons sales to Iran.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Missile Pact Prompts Talks On West's Nuclear Defense
description: Western defense ministers met here today to consider options for improving NATO's nuclear defenses in light of the emerging treaty to eliminate medium- and shorter-range missiles.

title: Sports of The Times; Has Parcells Surrendered?
description: FOR the Giants it has come to this: if they are to qualify for the Super Bowl XXII playoffs, they must do it without Phil Simms for at least the game Sunday night against the New England Patriots and possibly for two or three more games. As if that were not difficult enough, they must overtake both the Tampa Bay Bucs and the New Orleans Saints, each with a 4-3 record now, for the National Conference's second wild-card spot.

title: NO OCTOBER SURPRISES
description: The Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, responding to inquiries about the campaign's financial health, announced yesterday that it raised more than $1.05 million in October, bringing total receipts to $9.3 million.

title: INSIDE
description: Shakespeare, All of It Plans for a six-year, $33 million series of all 36 of Shakespeare's plays were announced by Joseph Papp, the producer of the New York Shakespeare Festival. Page C21. Ginsburg on the Defensive Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg's nomination to the High Court appeared to be on the defensive over conflict-of-interest questions. Page D30. Falwell Quits Moral Majority The Rev. Jerry Falwell said he was resigning as president of Moral Majority and would work full time for his church and TV ministry. Page A14.

title: Stage: A 'Kismet' Revival
description: THE Equity Library Theater's ''Kismet'' is always exuberant and often hilarious, but at times the pedestrian direction of Russell Treyz reduces its whimsies to mere absurdities. People who like this musical, dreadful rhymes and all, will believe anything, and the higher a director lets his imagination fly, the better.

title: Brazil and Banks Near Agreement on Interest
description: Brazil and its creditors appeared close to agreement last night on a plan for the country to resume interest payments on its $100 billion foreign debt nearly nine months after the Government suspended them.

title: Opposition Politician Seized by Malaysians
description: The Government announced today the detention without trial of another member of the opposition Democratic Action Party.

title: WHY IT'S SO HARD TO SAY GOODBYE
description: The rapid pace of turnover in the Cabinet-level ranks of the Reagan Administration in recent days comes as a bracing counterpoint to another less visible phenomenon, the officials who cannot say goodbye.

title: FHP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Insurer's Ads Are Said To Lead to Trial Loss
description: Maybe there is a time when advertising can be too good.

title: Star Role for Hollywood Offices
description: Dawn Steel, the new president of Columbia Pictures, does not have David Puttnam's job, but she will probably use the former Columbia chairman's office. And when Ms. Steel moves onto the studio lot, she will undoubtedly put Mr. Puttnam's Biedermeier burlwood sofa into mothballs and remodel his recently remodeled suite.

title: JOSLYN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest third quarter includes a non-recurring after-tax charge of $16.8 million to establish a reserve for estimated additional future environmental remedial actions and clean-up costs at wood- treating sites previously owned or operated by the company.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Cash Advances: Pat Cash of Australia, the Wimbledon champion who is seeded second in this tournament, survived a second-set struggle yesterday to beat Paul Annacone of the United States, 6-4, 6-4, and advance to the second round of the $840,000 Paris Open. In other matches, Brad Gilbert of the United States, seeded seventh, defeated Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland, 6-0, 6-3; Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands beat Thierry Tulasne of France, 6-3, 6-3; Tomas Smid downed another Czechoslovak, Marian Vajda, 6-3, 6-3; Alexander Volkov of the Soviet Union, upset Martin Jaite of Argentina, seeded sixth, 6-7 6-3, 6-1; Yannick Noah, of France, seeded third, eliminated Australia's Wally Masur, 6-3, 6-4; Kevin Curren of the United States downed Christo Van Rensburg of South Africa, 6-4, 6-4, and Brad Gilbert of the United States, seeded seventh, defeated Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland, 6-0, 6-3.(AP) Edberg Prevails: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg was extended to three sets by Richey Reneberg of the United States before winning yesterday's second-round match in the $525,000 Stockholm Open-Scandinavian championships. Edberg, the defending champion from Sweden, downed Reneberg, 6-7, 6-0, 6-2.(AP) Evert Beats Torres: Chris Evert had to fight off a young challenger yesterday in the opening round of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of New England tournament in Worcester, Mass. The 32-year-old Evert, seeded first, needed 91 minutes to defeat 20-year-old Michelle Torres, 6-3, 6-3. In other matches, Jo Durie of England defeated Heather Ludloff, 6-1, 6-4; Hu Na downed Anna Maria Fernandez, 6-1, 6-3, and Andrea Holikova of Czechoslovakia defeated Brenda Schultz of the Netherlands, 6-2, 6-4.(AP) Horse Racing Laser Lane Is Winner: Laser Lane mowed down five opponents in the final sixteenth of a mile to win the $99,600 Knickerbocker Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday on a special Election Day card. The winner, dismissed at 8-1 despite three straight victories and two straight stakes scores, circled the leaders in the stretch and prevailed by three-quarters of a length over Yankee Affair, the 2-1 favorite in a field of 12. Wanderkin finished another 1 1/4 lengths back in third and a head in front of Sure Dad. Midnight Cousins, Duluth, Broadway Tommy, Forest Fair, Dark Flood, Majestic Roberto, Ski Fleet and Cold Feet completed the order of finish. Laser Lane carried 113 pounds, three fewer than Yankee Affair, and covered the mile and an eighth on the grass in 1:51 3/5 under Jose Santos. Soccer Hartwick Beats Columbia, 1-0: Any chance Columbia had for posteason play disappeared yesterday in Oneonta, N.Y., in a 1-0 loss to Hartwick. David Gregson, a freshman, scored the goal four minutes into the game for Hartwick, which is a leading candidate for a playoff spot after its 2-1 victory over Long Island University last Saturday.

title: Rio Algom Says Little On Ouster of Chief
description: George R. Albino, the chairman and chief executive of Rio Algom Ltd., a large Canadian mining company, has been ousted by the company's board.

title: THE DIFFICULT BIRTH OF THE LOTUS AGENDA
description: MITCHELL D. KAPOR, the man who introduced spreadsheets to the computer industry, was grappling with a particularly vexing problem in 1985 when he was chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation: little slips of paper. The little notes intended to help him organize his life were everywhere - on his desk, stuck to his telephone, stuffed in the pockets of his brightly patterned Hawaiian shirts.

title: JIFFY LUBE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Kodak's Profit Jumps 50.6%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company reported today that its third-quarter profit had risen 50.6 percent as it continued to rebound from last year's belt tightening and restructuring.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Rise
description: Treasury bond prices rose nearly a point yesterday, cutting the yield of the 30-year issue to slightly above 9 percent.

title: East Bloc Seems Divided on Speech
description: One day after Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Kremlin speech on the Bolshevik Revolution, Moscow's closest Eastern European allies appeared to be applying a selective approach to its message, depending on whether their own policies reflected or clashed with Mr. Gorbachev's campaign for political and economic change.

title: KEY RATES
Virginia Electric Offers 7-Year Bond
description: The Virginia Electric and Power Company, a subsidiary of Dominion Resources Inc., is offering $100 million of 9 3/8 percent first and refunding mortgage bonds, due in 1994, at a price of 99.125 to yield 9.55 percent through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Capital Funding.

title: A Suicide Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: New Violence Erupts in Haiti As Election Council Bars
description: Violence flared again today in Haiti hours after a dozen associates of Francois and Jean-Claude Duvalier, the former dictators, were rejected as presidential candidates.

title: ABORTION RIGHTS OF MINORS WEIGHED
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on the emotionally charged issue of how far states may restrict minors' access to abortions so as to promote consultation with their parents.

title: MacGregor Avoids Bankruptcy Action
description: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc. said a Federal Bankruptcy Court had ordered the dismissal of an involuntary bankruptcy motion filed against the company by three unsecured creditors. The company said that, in connection with the dismissal, it had agreed to pay 20 percent of the debt owed to unsecured creditors on invoices that were past due as of Oct. 30. The three creditors made their bid to force MacGregor into bankruptcy last week, claiming debts of $340,000.

title: A Punitive Food Plan
description: To The Living Section:

title: 2 Sides Still Far Apart In El Salvador Conflict
description: Despite recent efforts to seek reconciliation under a new regional peace accord, El Salvador today appears as deeply polarized as ever.

title: MOORE MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
Vast Changes in Environment Seen
description: Changes in the environment brought about by human activity are now occurring globally or over broad regions at a speed that may exceed the ability of people and their institutions to respond, according to and social scientists who attended a meeting last week.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Vacherin Arrives

title: Democrats Capture Top Posts In Suffolk, Erie and Monroe; SWEEP ALL 44 RACES IN NEW YORK CITY, BUT LOSE IN NASSAU
description: Democrats scored major victories across New York State yesterday, ousting Republican county executives in Suffolk, Erie and Monroe Counties and the longtime Republican Mayor of Yonkers.

title: KANSAS CITY LIFE INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $775,000 and $1,622,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $773,000 for the quarter and $3,822,000 for the 9 months.

title: His Honor, the Diplomat
description: What better place for New York's Mayor Koch to be now than Central America? The stock market crash and the city's impending financial difficulties, the search for a new Schools Chancellor, the quarrel between the Police and Fire Departments on handling emergencies, NBC's renewed threat to leave the city - all apparently can wait. The Central American presidents are having a difficult time with their peace plan and could use help.

title: High Tech Gets a Test At the Polls
description: Some voters on the Upper West Side and in Greenwich Village got a look yesterday at the latest solution to the problems of voting the old-fashioned way: state-of-the-art electronic voting machines.

title: Calling Mr. Baker
description: Relations between President Reagan's chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., and Congressional conservatives have never been particularly warm, but in recent weeks things have grown downright frosty. Viewing Mr. Baker as something less than a faithful guardian of the Reagan doctrine on such issues as tax increases, military spending and the nomination of ideologically correct Supreme Court justices, conservatives these days rarely bother to hide their frustration. The latest complaint, from Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, a New York Republican who serves on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, is that Mr. Baker doesn't return phone calls.

title: Sympathy, 42 Years Later
description: More than 42 years after a Japanese balloon bomb killed five children and a pregnant woman on a picnic in southern Oregon, seven of the Japanese women who made the balloon have sent letters of condolence to the victims' families.

title: INDEPENDENT INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $2,096,000 and $3,281,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $420,000 for the quarter and $7,395,000 for the 9 months.

title: Economic Scene; Rescuing The Dollar
description: THE stock market had a worrisome day yesterday, and analysts rounded up the usual suspects: Some feared that the dollar might plummet if the central banks were unwilling to support it. Others worried that, in Washington, cutting the budget deficit was stalled. Still others feared the budget cuts might be too little (to rally the markets) or too much (for the economy to sustain). Some felt that the United States and West Germany were locked in a conflict over how to deal with the crisis. Others saw indecision in the Reagan Administration on the currency question. And some cited the nervousness of stockholders, still shocked by Black Monday, rushing to take profits.

title: Senate Backs Renewal Of Special Prosecutors
description: The Senate voted 85 to 10 today to renew the law authorizing special prosecutors to investigate allegations of wrongdoing by senior government officials after rejecting, by a vote of 49 to 46, an attempt to make the bill apply to members of Congress.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Wells, Rich Is Losing Two of Its P.&G. Brands
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, which rarely moves accounts except as a form of discipline, has switched two brands out of Wells, Rich, Greene and into the Leo Burnett Company and N. W. Ayer, which joined its roster last year when it acquired Cunningham & Walsh.

title: NEW MAXWELL DEAL
description: The Maxwell Communication Corporation said it had agreed to buy a 70 percent stake in Nimbus Records Ltd., a privately owned company, for $:24 million, or about $42 million. The deal marks the British printing and publishing group's third acquisition this week. Maxwell on Monday announced the purchase of United Trade Press Holdings Ltd. for $:34.8 million, or about $60.6 million, from Ladbroke Group P.L.C., as well as the purchase of Alco Gravure Inc. in the United States for an undisclosed sum.

title: Art Bidders at Christie's Wary, but Not Scared
description: Two Francis Bacon paintings brought the highest prices in Christie's contemporary art auction last night. Overall, the auction showed the market for postwar art was reacting with tremors - not shock waves - to the turbulence that has characterized the stock market since the collapse on Oct. 19.

title: Assault on the Ice
description: In hockey they call it a cross-check, but if Dave Brown had done what he did to Tomas Sandstrom anywhere except on the ice, it would be called assault. Mr. Brown has been given a 15-game suspension without pay, while his team, the Philadelphia Flyers, may sign another player to replace him. Both player and team got off too lightly. During the Oct. 26 game between the Flyers and the New York Rangers, Mr. Brown jabbed his hockey stick hard into the head of his unsuspecting victim. It was the second game this year that Mr. Brown attacked Mr. Sandstrom. The earlier offense earned him a five-game suspension. The new one was clearly deliberate and unprovoked, said Brian O'Neill of the National Hockey League. Mr. Sandstrom suffered a mild concussion.

title: A Foundation Led by Carter Honors a Chile Rights Group
description: A foundation headed by former President Jimmy Carter and the Houston philanthropist Dominique de Menil announced today that the annual $100,000 Carter-Menil human-rights prize would go to La Vicaria, a Roman Catholic group that aids political prisoners, torture victims and their families in Chile.

title: China Says It Will Stop Arms for Iran
description: China has again told the United States that Beijing will try to stop its weapons from reaching Iran, a senior American official said here today.

title: America Whets Its Appetite For Hearth-Baked Breads; Sources for Good Loaves
description: THE following hearth bakers supply shops and restaurants in the New York City area. Most also sell breads on their premises. Baldwin Hill Bakery, Baldwin Hill Road, Phillipston, Mass. 01131; 617-249-4691.

title: Moses Files Are Opened
description: The New York Public Library has opened the Robert Moses archive, containing 160 linear feet of papers and photographs dating from 1912. Included is personal and professional correspondence with such figures as Franklin D. Roosevelt, Al Smith, Fiorello La Guardia, Benjamin Cardozo and Herbert Lehman.

title: National Horse Show; Best Loses on Final Obstacle
description: The seven Merchant Marines lifted their hunting horns and provided a musical announcement. With the flourish customary to this event, the 104th National Horse Show officially started last night at Madison Square Garden, which had been hastily transformed from a hockey rink to a hunt course.

title: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRSTCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Britain Sees 4% Growth
description: Britain's economy will grow about 4 percent this year despite the recent stock market plunge, but growth may slow to 2.5 percent in 1988, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, said today.

title: Elbow to Elbow at a Wine Experience
description: There were booths with bottles, glasses, ice buckets and corkscrews in all directions.

title: MANITOWOC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
An Updated Boot and a Breakfast-Table Whimsy
description: 1. Boot for Today This updated classic black leather boot has tiny metal studs on a patchwork design, stylishly created with strips of black suede. The boot, which has a gracefully shaped low heel, costs $240 at Maraolo, 782 Lexington Avenue (61st Street) and 1321 Third Avenue (76th Street). 2. Cows in Ceramic Add a touch of whimsy to your table with this sleekly designed cow pitcher. It is black and white ceramic. The pitcher, which costs $29, is part of a collection that includes matching salt and pepper shakers, a creamer and sugar bowl, a teapot and a butter dish. At Aris Mixon & Company, 381 Amsterdam Avenue, between 78th and 79th Streets. 3. Mantel Tick-Tock Nothing warms up a room faster than a traditional-looking clock. This graceful mantel clock has a pine cabinet and a baked enamel face decorated with pale flowers. It has a quartz movement and costs $200. Larger styles for the wall are also available. In housewares on the sixth floor at Bloomingdale's, Lexington Avenue and 59th Street. Not available at branch stores.

title: Kerkorian Gain Seen On Pan Am
description: Four of the principal unions at Pan American World Airways have decided to support Kirk Kerkorian, the West Coast investor, in his effort to take over Pan American World Airways, union sources said yesterday.

title: Corections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Dean Witter Reynolds's expansion in the municipal-bond business misstated the role of another Wall Street firm, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, in that area.

title: BRANSCAN LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: 8 Charged in Schemes To Divert Technology
description: A Federal grand jury in Asheville, N.C., indicted two Japanese businessmen and two Hungarian diplomats today, charging them with diverting an American-made laser system used in making semiconductors to Hungary in violation of United States export control laws.

title: The Abuse of History
description: An American lawyer in Moscow in 1965 asked his Intourist guide-guards the way to the men's room, slipped out the back of a restaurant and took a taxi to an address he had been given by a Canadian newsman. The politically defunct lawyer was seeking a rendezvous with a former Soviet leader he had spoken with in a kitchen six years before.

title: ABC Joins Venture With Weintraub
description: The Weintraub Entertainment Group and ABC News said they would pool their news film archives into a single library. The joint venture, called ABC/ Weintraub Pathe, will use the film archives to develop new programming for home video cassettes and cable television, the companies said. They declined to disclose specific applications or terms of the deal.

title: Change in Name Is Rejected By Voters in Dover Township
description: Voters in this Ocean County community balked today at changing the name of their municipality to Toms River, a move opponents said would be too costly. The vote was 8,969 to 7,748.

title: Advertising; People Magazine Campaign
description: PEOPLE magazine, which averaged 3.3 million in weekly sales in the third quarter, will begin a trade campaign on Monday with the theme ''Nothing grabs people like People.''

title: JAI ALAI: AN IMPORTED SPORT FOR ALL-AMERICAN DREAMERS
description: It was Halloween night, but the strangest sight at the Milford Jai Alai Fronton was simply the size of the crowd. Most evenings this time of year, the courtside stands are freckled with fans. The house was packed, though, crammed all the way up to the smoke-choked $2 seats with some 6,000 screamers, dreamers and get-rich-quick schemers.

title: Caspar Weinberger's Mixed Legacy
description: With Caspar Weinberger's expected departure after seven years as Secretary of Defense, President Reagan will lose a loyal counselor who tirelessly championed greater military spending. But Mr. Weinberger leaves a mixed legacy. He strengthened America's defenses, yet with enormous profligacy. He had little appreciation for the positive role of arms control in Soviet-American relations. Yet he understood when American forces could be useful, as in the Persian Gulf, and when they could not, as with the Marines in Lebanon.

title: Poland's $8 Billion Pact
description: The debt rescheduling accord struck last week between Poland and its Paris Club group of creditor governments covers more than $8 billion, a Polish Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said today. The amount covers almost a quarter of Poland's total $35 billion foreign debt, two-thirds of which is owed to Paris Club members, he said. Under the pact, Poland's repayments of principal and interest falling due between 1986 and 1988 will be spread over 10 years.

title: HEIRESS SEEKS HOLDINGS OF CHURCH SHE SUED
description: A chain store heiress who is trying to get $6.6 million back from a fundamentalist church offered $1.8 million today for the church headquarters. The property, appraised at $6 million, was abandoned after a Federal Bankruptcy Court held that undue influence had been exerted to get her to donate the money to the church.

title: Debt Swaps In Mexico
description: Mexico is reviewing its debt-for-equity conversion program to assess the inflationary impact, but the program has not been suspended, the central bank governor said.

title: Britons Hail a Comeuppance
description: For the London financial district, the recent slide in stock prices has been a source of understandable distress. But beyond the Victorian palazzos and pin stripes of the City of London, Britain's equivalent of Wall Street, there has been an altogether different - and, in some ways, distinctively English - reaction to the travails of the financial markets.

title: HARLEY-DAVIDSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-After a charge of $9,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $3,060,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After a charge of $706,000 and a tax credit of $1,188,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss on refinancing of $847,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Tokyo Stocks Fall 1.3%
description: Tokyo stock prices dropped 1.3 percent today after the sharp decline on Wall Street on Tuesday. Dealers said large securities firms had stepped in with buy orders to stabilize the market.

title: The Pop Life
description: For Benefit of Music

title: MARSH SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 10
HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Officials Said to Ignore Pleas for Abused Girl
description: Neighbors and co-workers of a Manhattan couple charged with attempted murder in the beating of their 6-year-old daughter say that repeated calls were made to the police and a child-abuse hot line over many years. But to their knowledge, they said, nothing was done to separate the couple or to protect the children.

title: The Right Question To Ask About AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Valley National Corporation is offering $100 million of 9 percent notes, due in 1989, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Challenges for Jordan: New League Rule and New Role
description: Through the years, rule changes in basketball have often been made with a particular player in mind. George Mikan's dominating center play was responsible for widening the lane from 8 to 12 feet. When Wilt Chamberlain was piling up points, the lane was widened again, this time to its present 16 feet. While Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, then known as Lew Alcindor, was playing at U.C.L.A., the dunk shot was eliminated from the college game.

title: Nathan's to Open 23 New Outlets
description: Nathan's Famous Inc. and two New York restaurateurs, Irving and Murray Riese, said they had signed an agreement to open 23 franchised Nathan's fast-food restaurants in Manhattan in the next five years. The new units would more than double the number of Nathan's restaurants.

title: AUTODIE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Falwell Quits as Moral Majority Head
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, founder and leader of the fundamentalist Christian political group Moral Majority, announced today that he was giving up politics and returning full time to his church and television ministry.

title: 2 Policemen Slain in Frankfurt Protest
description: Two policemen were killed Monday night during a demonstration at the Frankfurt Airport, and this appears certain to stiffen demands by conservatives for tougher measures against violent radicals.

title: Khrushchev's Son-in-Law Is Elated With 'a Wind of Change'
description: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech ended Monday, Aleksei I. Adzhubei got an excited phone call from his youngest son, a biochemist.

title: Man Held in Threat On Cabinet Member
description: An unemployed chemist the police say was armed with three guns and at least 600 bullets was arrested today after a report that he had told his mother that he was going to kill Secretary of State George P. Shultz, the authorities said.

title: THE TIGER ROARS
description: Mr. Carlucci, is a graduate of Princeton University, an institution with the motto: ''Princeton in the Nation's Service.'' Whether you believe in conspiracy theories or are just keeping score, Mr. Carlucci as Defense Secretary would put Princeton graduates in the nation's top three economic and national security posts. Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and Secretary of State George P. Shultz are also Princeton alumni, although Mr. Shultz is apparently the most fervent. It is he after all who has the Princeton tiger tattoed on his posterior.

title: Sports News Briefs; Clark Declares As Free Agent
description: Jack Clark, who missed the World Series and perhaps a chance for the National League most valuable player award because of an ankle injury, was one of eight players who filed for free agency today.

title: Music: St. Paul Orchestra
description: GOOD ideas never die, but they do change faces. The two most fertile instrumental groupings to develop out of the Classical period, the symphony orchestra and the string quartet, each spawned its own rich literature. Inevitably, the thought occurred to composers to unite the ensembles in one piece. That was not a revolutionary idea, but an outgrowth of the Baroque concerto grosso style, which typically set off a small group, known as the concertino, against a larger orchestral body, the ripieno.

title: Stop This Headlong Rush To Judgment on Ginsburg
description: LEAD: In the first few days after President Reagan nominated Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg to the Supreme Court, my phone rang off the hook. Everyone wanted to know what the early ''line'' would be on Judge Ginsburg, and whether the American Civil Liberties Union was going to oppose him.

title: The Stage: 'Sing Hallelujah!,' a Gospel Musical
description: GOSPEL, like every other popular style of vernacular music, reflects the whims of pop style and the evolution of pop technology. What gives the music its special classic quality is its unchanging subject matter: praising the Lord. While today's evangelical Christian music movement has begun to produce gospel songs that address contemporary social problems, the essence of the gospel message - jubilant spiritual and physical exaltation - hasn't changed over half a century.

title: Clash of Police And Fire Dept. Brings Warning
description: First Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff, warning that continued clashes between New York City police officers and firefighters ''could be a prescription for disaster,'' summoned the heads of both agencies to City Hall yesterday to ease the tension.

title: Taishan Journal; The Wellspring of Chinatowns Still Bubbles Over
description: The dilapidated brick villages and bright green rice paddies in this corner of southern China sometimes seem as American as chop suey.

title: Wall Street Job Outlook Dims
description: Investment banks, shaken by layoffs and the stock market collapse, are likely to reduce hiring for next year at the undergraduate and graduate levels, according to Wall Street recruiters and college placement officials.

title: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in July 1987.

title: Monroe Nominated to Hall of Fame
description: Earl Monroe, who spent almost nine seasons with the Knicks, was one of four players and five coaches nominated today for election to the Basketball Association Hall of Fame.

title: Market Inquiry In Hong Kong
description: A Government committee will examine the operation of the Hong Kong stock and commodity exchanges, an official disclosed today.

title: An Unsuitable Response
description: To The Living Section:

title: Bringing the Movies to Life
description: MOVIES today boast spectacular special effects, the latest in sound systems and ever-improving color and clarity. But Douglas Trumbull is not impressed.

title: Curb on Program Trading Is Eased
description: Relaxing one of its key bans on program trading since the stock market plunge two and a half weeks ago, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would now allow major brokerage houses to execute program trades for their own accounts.

title: Going Out Guide
description: Old Horns, New Sounds

title: FIRST MISSISSIPPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain from Melamine Chemical public offering of $8.8 million. c-After a tax credit of $6.6 million.

title: 3 Top U.P.I. Editors Quit, Citing Doubts On Assuring Quality
description: The three top editors at United Press International resigned today after less than a year at the news service, praising its staff but saying they could no longer assure the quality of its report.

title: Donna Rice Ends Talks On a Film for ABC
description: Donna Rice, the actress-model whose relationship with Gary Hart ended the former Colorado Senator's 1988 Democratic Presidential campaign, has broken off negotiations with ABC to make a film about Mr. Hart and herself.

title: Kentucky and Mississippi Pick Democratic Governors
description: Democrats won governorships last night in Kentucky and Mississippi, completing a shutout of the Republicans in this year's gubernatorial elections.

title: About Real Estate; Office Project in Yonkers Getting a Second Chance
description: When a promised $6.6 million Urban Development Action Grant needed to turn an unused tract of land at the northern edge of Yonkers into an office park fell through three years ago, it seemed that the project had been derailed for good.

title: Bridge: Pair and Team Competition: The Gulf Between Strategies
description: As all tournament players know, there is a considerable gulf between the strategy called for in pair play, scored by match points, and team play, scored by imps, or international match points. The pair player is concerned with small profits and losses, but when he shifts to a team event, his focus is on large ones.

title: INDONESIA DROUGHT TOLL
description: Indonesia's vital rice crop has been saved from drought, but other cash crops have suffered and the nation may have to import some crops, Achmad Affande, Agriculture Minister, said today. Indonesia, which has the largest farm area in Southeast Asia, anticipated the cyclical drought and took some preventative measures, Mr. Affandi said. ''We chose which commodities should be rescued,'' he said. Corn and soybean fields were switched to rice paddies as one expedient. More than 640,000 acres of rice paddies were damaged by the drought, the worst since 1982, he said. But the goal of 27.3 million metric tons of rice, needed for self-sufficiency in 1987, would be reached.

title: Sandinista Defector Being Questioned by U.S.
description: United States officials said today that they were intensively questioning a Nicaraguan military defector to determine his value to them.

title: Younger Chefs Add Fitness to the Menu
description: GARY FUMICELLO was cheered to victory as he ran in an event here in 1986, holding a pan of eggs in one hand and waving aloft his other hand, which was swathed in bandages after an encounter with a kitchen knife. The injury was work related. Mr. Fumicello is a student at the New England Culinary Institute. The event - called a quadrathalon because it combines running and bicycling, cooking and food service - was extracurricular. But it was symbolic of a school that since its inception has been fighting the ''fat chef syndrome,'' according to its vice president, John Dranow.

title: About New York; Year of the Panda Is Lengthened By a Few Days
description: It's been quite a season at the Bronx Zoo. New York City's two most distinguished - and cuddly - visitors downed 6,800 pounds of bamboo, 736 eggs and 2,208 apples and carrots.

title: BERCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $80,000 from an accounting change.

title: Goode Claims Victory Over Rizzo In the Philadelphia Mayoral
description: With nearly all of the vote tallied unofficially, Mayor W. Wilson Goode claimed victory Tuesday night in his effort for re-election.

title: Texaco's Best Hope: U.S. Supreme Court
description: The price of Texaco Inc.'s stock fell almost 10 percent while the Pennzoil Company's shares soared more than $10 yesterday as the financial and legal communities pondered the significance of the Texas Supreme Court's decision to let stand the $10.53 billion judgment against Texaco.

title: Bucks to Retire Bridgeman Jersey
description: The Milwaukee Bucks will retire the uniform of Junior Bridgeman, who played in more games with the National Basketball Association team than any other player in its 20-year history.

title: Sports People; Lopes's Options
description: Because the Houston Astros have decided against renewing the option year on his contract, Davey Lopes says he is considering coaching a farm team in the Astros' minor-League system.

title: Celtics Confident Despite Key Loss
description: It has become rather fashionable in recent years to dwell on why the Boston Celtics won't be as strong as they were the previous season. About a year ago, Larry Bird's uncertain health, especially his back and elbow, was the trendy topic of concern. At other times, the issue may have been Robert Parish's age, Dennis Johnson's poor shooting, Danny Ainge's wild streak or the team's lack of depth.

title: CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $6,000,000 and $10,500,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and realized capital gain of $2.2 million for the quarter and a capital loss of $10 million from a pre-tax loss on the sale of tax-exempt U.S. treasury bonds, which was partially offset by a pre- tax gain from the sale of common and preferred stocks for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $6.7 million for the quarter and $11.1 million for the 9 months, and realized capital gains of $31.4 million and $183.9 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest quarter net includes 9 cents a share as a result of the ''fresh start'' provision of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: Secretary? Not Yet
description: Although the White House has yet to announce it, official Washington is sure Mr. Weinberger will step down and Frank C. Carlucci, the national security adviser, will take his place. Like many others in the drama, Mr. Carlucci is holding his cards close to the vest. A reporter who chased him down a Capitol corridor for comment yesterday finally got his attention by shouting, ''Mr. Secretary.'' Stopping dead in his tracks, Mr. Carlucci turned and yelled back, ''Not me.''

title: EMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
G.E. Discloses Irregularities
description: The General Electric Company said today that it had notified the Pentagon of accounting irregularities in contracts involving nuclear missiles.

title: Reagan Plans Sanctions End
description: President Reagan is likely to soon lift some of the trade sanctions imposed on Japan seven months ago during a dispute over Japanese dumping of computer chips, the Administration said today. The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said $84 million of sanctions would be lifted ''probably this week,'' leaving $165 million in sanctions.

title: Sports News Briefs; Division III Bowl Set by E.C.A.C.
description: The Eastern College Athletic Conference said today that the inaugural E.C.A.C. Division III Football Championship Bowl will be played on Nov. 28 between the winners of the North and South championship games of Nov. 21.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: The Utah Jazz cut Billy Donovan, the rookie guard from Providence. . . . The Portland Trail Blazers cut Ron Rowan, the former St. John's guard. . . . The Cleveland Cavaliers placed Kent Benson, the center, on the injured list because of a hyperextended elbow. . . . The Houston Rockets placed the forward Robert Reid on the injured list for 30 days to rehabilitate his right knee.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: CHANGES in American society are drawing new attention to the form of sexual expression most widely practiced, yet least talked about: masturbation. Compared with the 1940's and 50's, when Alfred Kinsey did his studies, many more people today say they approve of sexual self-stimulation and perform it fairly often.

title: Deaver Jury Hears Why He Was Hired
description: Tobacco industry witnesses at the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver said today that their key reason for paying $250,000 to obtain Mr. Deaver's ''political influence'' was to counter the formidable lobbying talents of another former Reagan Administration official.

title: Sports People; McMahon Questionable
description: It didn't keep him from throwing three touchdown passes in the Bears' 31-28 victory over the Kansas City Chiefs last Sunday, and it may not keep him out of action against the Green Bay Packers next Sunday, but Jim McMahon, the Chicago quarterback who returned to the lineup just 10 days ago after recovering from shoulder surgery, is nursing a new injury, a pulled groin muscle.

title: Cambridge Journal; After the Vote is Cast, Where Does It Land?
description: By the time the votes from Tuesday's City Council and School Committee elections are counted, many voters may have long since lost track of which candidates they voted for. For Cambridge, a city known for the intellectual giants of Harvard University and Massachusetts Institute of Technology, uses a controversial voting system that challenges even the strongest intellect.

title: CILCORP INC reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $7,500,000, or 55 cents a share.

title: West German Jobless
description: The number of West Germans out of work fell slightly last month, but the job market has apparently stagnated, the Federal Labor Office said today. The office said the total number of jobless, adjusted for seasonal factors, fell to 2.25 million in October, from 2.26 million in September. The Labor Office president, Heinrich Franke, told reporters in Nuremberg, ''Taking all the data together, my overall verdict for October is stagnation.''

title: Sippican to Be Sold
description: The Plessey Company said it planned to acquire Sippican Inc., a maker of oceanographic products based in Marion, Mass., for about $80 million. Plessey, an electronics company based in Ilford, near London, described Sippican as a leader in the construction of antisubmarine equipment. It said it had agreed to pay $18.50 for each Sippican share. Sippican's shares jumped $6, to $16.75, in over-the-counter trading today.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
