Picking Crackers For Health Value
description: LEAD: POLLY, are you completely clear on this? When you say you want a cracker, do you mean one of those artificially flavored things loaded with saturated fats and salt, or a nice piece of, say, salt-free flatbread?

title: Ousted Merrill Trader Hired
description: Bear, Stearns & Company said yesterday that it had hired Howard A. Rubin, the mortgage securities trader who was dismissed by Merrill Lynch & Company earlier this year after Merrill experienced a $377 million trading loss.

title: Plan to Quit Confirmed By Weinberger's Wife
description: Jane Weinberger today confirmed reports that her husband, Caspar W. Weinberger would resign as Secretary of Defense later this week, but she said that her health was not the reason.

title: How to Protect the Global Economy
description: The task of governments now is to protect the ''real'' economy - production, income and employment - from the downward pressure exerted on private spending by the shocking loss of recently acquired financial wealth (about one trillion dollars in the United States alone, $14,000 per family). That small reductions in wealth have typically caused only very small reductions in spending offers no ground for complacency. The odds on a recession in 1988-89 have shortened substantially. In a debt-ridden world, the consequences could be devastating.

title: WORKERS ACCUSE TRANSIT AGENCY OF HARASSMENT
description: Several current and former Transit Authority employees accused the agency yesterday of sexual discrimination, harassment and mismanagement.

title: Gorbachev Presses as Far as He Can
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's stated vision of a more open and democratic Soviet Union has emerged from two tests in recent days somewhat battered by the realities of the Communist system. The two tests - Mr. Gorbachev's review of Soviet history Monday and the handling earlier of Boris N. Yeltsin's threat to resign as head of the Moscow party organization - have demonstrated the limits of openness and served as a reminder of how different Mr. Gorbachev's concept of democracy is from Western practices.

title: China's New Style and Substance
description: When Zhao Ziyang, trailed by the other four members of the new Politburo's Standing Committee, met the world press in the Great Hall of the People on Monday afternoon, not one of the Chinese leaders wore the familiar, high-collared Mao suit.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: FRESH tuna has become something of a national passion -a pleasantly surprising development, since until a decade or so ago most of the tuna eaten came out of a can and went into tuna salads.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., said it had sold two of its gift and glassware companies for an undisclosed amount of cash. Alco said Silvestri Corp. and Toscany Imports Ltd. had been sold in leveraged buyouts. The units contributed about $84 million in revenue in the 1987 fiscal year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If all internal party matters are discussed by one and all, then there will be no sense in having a party. This, I think, is understood.'' - Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, a member of the Soviet Politburo. [ A12:5. ]

title: The Reactions To Gorbachev
description: A day after Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech on the Bolshevik Revolution, American scholars drew sharply differing lessons about its meaning.

title: Simms Out Sunday and Maybe Longer
description: Phil Simms, whose spectacular Monday night performance against the Cowboys ended abruptly when he was sandwiched between two defenders, will miss the game next Sunday night against the Patriots and, by the way Coach Bill Parcells described the injury today, he could be out even longer.

title: DOW FALLS BY 50.56 AS FIVE-DAY RALLY ENDS FOR WALL ST.
description: The stock market lurched downward yesterday as a return of volatile trading ended a fragile, five-day rally.

title: LAWTER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Boxing Notebook; Leonard Still Has Hagler's Number
description: The mind of a fighter is a fragile item, especially when forced to come to terms with defeat. A case in point is Marvin Hagler.

title: TV Review; Chain-Gang Classic Remade as HBO Film
description: CLEARLY, Daniel Mann, the director of ''The Man Who Broke 1,000 Chains,'' had a strong contract. Nestled in the opening credits, right between the names of the stars, is the following statement: ''After director completed director's cut, final version was supervised by production company.'' In short, there was trouble in the editing room and this may account for some of the film's nagging shortcomings.

title: PENTAGON'S STYLE LIKELY TO CHANGE AFTER WEINBERGER
description: The resignation of Caspar W. Weinberger as Secretary of Defense, which is expected to be announced later this week, seems likely to change the chemistry of policy making during the final 14 months of President Reagan's term.

title: 2 Exxon Divisions Get New Presidents
description: The Exxon Corporation announced new presidents yesterday for two major divisions.

title: Politics, Labels and Judge
description: Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, who was nominated last week to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court, has been described variously as a conventional conservative and as a libertarian.

title: Court Won't Delay Airlines' Merger
description: A Federal appeals court refused to delay the merger of USAir Group Inc. and Piedmont Aviation Inc. while it considers a competitor's challenge to the Transportation Department's approval of the deal. The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia rejected the petition, filed by America West Inc. of Phoenix, for an emergency stay of the merger.

title: 3 Rangers Hurt in Loss
description: Brett Hull scored two goals tonight as the Calgary Flames beat the Rangers, 5-3, in a game in which three New York players were injured.

title: Koch Keeps Embassy Busy, But Sandinistas Are Wary
description: At the American Embassy here, a political officer had a tired greeting for a visitor a few days ago.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MEDUSA FREQUENCY. By Russell Hoban. 143 pages. Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 4, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: William Styron Named To Legion of Honor
description: The author William Styron has been awarded the medal of the Commander of the Legion of Honor, the highest degree of the highest honor the French Government can bestow on a French or foreign citizen.

title: I.B.M. Moves Up OS/2 Shipping Date
description: Putting an end to months of speculation, the International Business Machines Corporation said today that it would begin to ship the first release of its OS/2, the next generation of its personal computer operating system, in December, a few months ahead of schedule.

title: How We Got Into This Economic Gridlock; In Defense of Keynes
description: To the Editor:

title: Interfirst Bank Is Repaid
description: Edwin L. Cox Jr., a Dallas businessman who was under Federal investigation earlier this year for loans received while a director of the Interfirst Bank of Dallas, said today that he has repaid the remaining $36 million owed the bank.

title: Growing Up to Be Queen of the Rodeo
description: Sawdust flies when Joni James gallops into an arena. Wearing a cowboy hat and fitted western shirt and pants, she has smiled through years of interviews and modeling sessions.

title: Film: 'Broken Noses,' From Bruce Weber
description: BRUCE WEBER, known for his photographs of athletic looking fellows posed sexily in underwear advertisements, demonstrates in ''Broken Noses'' that shorts do not make the man.

title: Pepsico Agrees To Buy Calny
description: Pepsico Inc. has agreed to buy Calny Inc., the operator of 142 Taco Bell restaurants on the West Coast, for about $36.2 million, Calny said. Under the agreement, Pepsico would pay $11 for each of Calny's 4.8 million shares outstanding, valuing the company at $52.8 million. Calny said the Taco Bell Corporation, a subsidiary of Pepsico, already owns 31.5 percent of its common stock. Calny's shares gained $1.125, to $10.25, in over-the-counter trading today.

title: High Fat, Low Cost
description: To The Living Section:

title: Graf Is No. 1 for '87, but Debate Goes On
description: Her lead in the computer rankings and the Virginia Slims points standings is now insurmountable. Thus, Steffi Graf, the 18-year-old West German, will finish the year as the top-ranked tennis player in the world, ending Martina Navratilova's five-year reign as No. 1. But is it that clear-cut?

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $10 million from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $3.5 million for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $16.6 million and $24 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a $4.3 million tax credit.

title: Ginsburg Faces Queries Over Cable TV
description: Concern grew among Republican senators today that Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg's nomination to the Supreme Court could be imperiled by charges of conflict of interest, and the Senate Republican leader summoned the nominee to the Capitol to explain his involvement in decisions affecting regulation of the cable television industry.

title: Citicorp Rates Down Again
description: Interest rates declined at Citicorp's regular weekly commercial paper auction yesterday. It was the third consecutive week of declines, totaling more than a percentage point in that period.

title: Reagan Names Ex-Government Aide to Labor Post
description: President Reagan today named Ann Dore McLaughlin, a veteran of many Government public relations posts, to the job of Secretary of Labor.

title: INSPIRATION RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains of $11.4 million reflecting the capitalization of exploration expenses related to the company's decision to begin production at its high-grade nickel property in Northern Manitoba in 1988, as well as the sale of mining properties. c-Net loss d-Includes gains of $20.5 million related to the sale of an interest in a mining property, and a credit of $7.2 million for the capitalization of exploration expenses at the company's Nome, Alaska, gold operation.

title: Who Was Who in Weekly Reader's Early Days
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Knicks Waive Huston
description: The Knicks trimmed their roster yesterday to the required 12 players by asking waivers on two veterans and placing two others on the injured list. Geoff Huston, a guard, and Leo Rautins, a forward, were released after practice at the team's camp at the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: STADIUM LOSES IN JERSEY; DEMOCRATS KEEP SENATE AND GAIN IN ASSEMBLY
description: New Jersey voters yesterday rejected a proposal supported by Governor Kean to spend $185 million for a major league baseball stadium, and elected all 120 members of the State Legislature.

title: How We Got Into This Economic Gridlock; In Defense of Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 in the Warsaw Ballet Defect While in Canada
description: Five members of the Warsaw Ballet Company will seek asylum in Canada after defecting during a North American tour, it was reported today.

title: LOW RATINGS FOR U.S. AIRLINES
description: United States airlines fared poorly against European and Asian carriers in a worldwide survey of almost 30,000 passengers who fly often.

title: Enforcing of Height Limit Is Urged for Tower
description: The Manhattan Borough President and the mid-Manhattan community board have called on New York City to enforce the height limit for the nearly completed Cityspire tower, which is almost 11 feet taller than approved and the subject today of a City Planning Commission review.

title: GCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $46,957,000 from a financial restructuring. c-Net income d-After gains on the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,676,000 and $3,279,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; tax credits of $404,000 for the quarter and $1,366,000 for the 9 months and the 9 montha also includes a loss of $107,000 from discontinued operations. Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 1-for-50 reverse stock split.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1987
description: International A3-13

title: EMERSON ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect acquisition accounted for as a pooling-of-interests.

title: Schwab Gets Loan Waiver
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation said today that it had been forced to obtain a waiver of a provision of its bank loan agreement because the stock market downturn had put it in danger of violating the minimum-capital requirement.

title: Beber, Silverstein Gets Humana Promotion Job
description: Humana Inc. of Louisville, Ky., a major company in the health-care field, is giving all of its hospital promotion business to Beber, Silverstein in Miami, which already works for it.

title: America Whets Its Appetite For Hearth-Baked Breads
description: Americans are ready for better bread.

title: Devils No Match For the Islanders
description: After slightly more than four years in the National Hockey League, Pat Flatley of the Islanders says he believes he has learned at least one lesson. Whatever you do, never take the game home with you. It's an admirable maxim, but it gets a little difficult to employ when you've got nowhere else to take it.

title: G.M.'s Progress On Job Reductions
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had eliminated 12,000 American salaried jobs in the first nine months of 1987, putting it well ahead of schedule in its plans to eliminate 40,000 jobs by the end of next year. The company, which said the job cuts would save it $2 billion a year, said it expects to reduce salaried employment by another 7,200 in the final three months of the year. G.M. had 114,000 salaried employees in the United States as of Sept. 30, down 32,800 from last year.

title: A Weinberger Echo
description: News that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will be stepping down has set some of his long-time Congressional foes to thinking about legislative battles they had in the good old days before he set eyes on the Pentagon.

title: Telex Set Back In Legal Fight
description: A Federal judge issued a temporary restraining order today that prevents the Telex Corporation from using a state anti-takeover law to block the New York financier Asher B. Edelman's $65-a-share bid for the company. Judge David L. Russell of the

title: 7 Artists and Art Groups Hailed for Cultural Role
description: Seven Manhattan artists or arts organizations were honored Monday for their contributions to the cultural world of the borough at an awards ceremony sponsored by Borough President David Dinkins of Manhattan, at Davis Hall at the City College of the City University of New York.

title: Books; Risible Reading
description: LAUGHING MATTERS: A CELEBRATION OF AMERICAN HUMOR. Selected and edited by Gene Shalit. 622 pages. Doubleday & Company. $24.95. THE PORTABLE CURMUDGEON. Compiled and edited by Jon Winokur. 299 pages. New American Library. $15.95.

title: Professors Study the Plunge
description: On Monday, Oct. 19, when most of the investing world saw disaster, two professors of finance at Cornell University saw opportunity - the chance to test out fundamental market analysis theories in a free-falling stock market.

title: Reaction Is Low-Key to Ban on Flyer
description: Coaches and other team officials have been choosing their words carefully when asked to comment on the National Hockey League's 15-game suspension of Dave Brown for cross-checking Tomas Sandstrom of the Rangers in the neck and jaw.

title: JOHNSTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $61,000 from discontinued operations.

title: How We Got Into This Economic Gridlock
description: To the Editor:

title: Recital: Jean Deis, Tenor
description: JEAN DEIS, a tenor and professor of voice at Indiana University, gave a recital at Merkin Concert Hall Monday evening that marked his return to performing after a protracted struggle with cancer. When Mr. Deis was first reviewed in these pages 31 years ago, he was praised for ''wonderfully assured upper tones,'' and he has them still. His voice sounded robust and healthy through the demanding program of Handel, Liszt (the three Petrarch sonnets), Massenet, Strauss, Puccini and David Baker (an Indiana University composer, represented by three Romantic-sounding songs).

title: Charles F. Bonilla, 78, a Professor at Columbia
description: Prof. Charles Francis Bonilla, who retired in 1978 after 30 years on the faculty of Columbia University's department of chemical engineering, died of a heart attack Saturday at Morristown (N.J.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: DIASONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,616,000 for the quarter and $4,320,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $1,328,000 and $2,538,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Scholars Say Gorbachev Fell Short on Objectivity
description: The speech Monday by Mikhail S. Gorbachev on the 70th anniversary of the Russian Revolution provoked sharply differing interpretations among historians and political scientists who specialize on the Soviet Union.

title: CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results were restated.

title: From Papp, All of Shakespeare
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival will present all 36 plays in the Shakespeare canon, in a six-year, $33 million series that will also include television and book adaptations of the stagings, Joseph Papp, the producer of the festival, announced yesterday.

title: Kasparov Wins Game 8
description: Gary Kasparov incisively won the eighth game of his world championship chess match against Anatoly Karpov in Seville, Spain, yesterday to level their series.

title: PESSIMISM GROWS ON DEFICIT TALKS
description: Democratic negotiators from the House and the Senate today proposed a deficit-reducing package intended to save about $31 billion in the current fiscal year. But it was quickly rejected by both the White House and Senate Republicans, increasing concern among Democrats that the top-level budget talks involving the Reagan Administration and Congressional negotiators of both parties were in trouble.

title: Stock Index Contracts Take Toll on Traders
description: In another wild day in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index futures pit, price swings bloodied some local traders.

title: BRINTEC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIBERTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net realized investment gains of $2,607,000 for the quarter and $6,882,000 for the 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a loss of $1,031,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,000 for the quarter and $1,070,000 for the 9 months and net realized investment gains of $2,092,000 and $5,157,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: CBS Asks Advice on Cronkite Show on Apartheid
description: CBS News, concerned that a secretly taped Walter Cronkite documentary about apartheid in South Africa might jeopardize the organization's news bureau there, has taken the unusual step of getting the opinion of an independent South African lawyer before approving the program for broadcast.

title: Israel's Arab-Jewish Percentage Is Stable
description: To the Editor:

title: ST PAUL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public May 15.

title: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,906,000, which is related to an exchange offer under which about $25 million of its debt was extended several years, for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Transportation Dept. Starts Random Worker Drug Tests
description: The Department of Transportation disclosed today that it had begun random drug testing of its employees in safety-related jobs.

title: Economic Spotlight Is on Bonn
description: Wherever the Germans turn, someone is telling them what to do.

title: Raphael Soyer, Social Realist Artist, is Dead at 87
description: Raphael Soyer, an artist whose gently rendered portraits of New York artists, dancers and the city's lonely and dispossessed won him fame that lasted from the 1930's to the present, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: AMERICA WEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and the quarter includes non-operating gains of $2,291,000.

title: Fake Hunger Strikers Caught in Jersey Jail
description: Four county jail inmates were moved to isolation after the sheriff said he found they were eating candy bars and sandwiches while maintaining they were on a hunger strike.

title: BONRAY DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Avco Financial
description: Avco Financial Services is offering $100 million of noncallable 9 3/8 percent notes due in 1992 at a price of 99 5/8, to yield 9.47 percent, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The five-year notes are rated A-3 by Moody's and A by S.&P. and were offered to yield 1.2 percentage points more than Treasury notes of similar maturity.

title: HERITAGE-NIS BANK FOR SAVNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in October 1986.

title: MBS TEXTBOOK EXCHANGE reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
2 Are Slain as a Gang Opens Fire In a Chinatown Gambling Parlor
description: Two men, including the president of a Chinatown community association, were killed early yesterday when a group of 7 to 10 men burst into a basement gambling parlor and sprayed the room with gunfire, the police said.

title: Surgery for Well's Victim
description: Jessica McClure, the 19-month-old girl who survived 58 1/2 hours stuck in an abandoned well, underwent her fifth operation today at Midland Memorial Hospital. The surgery was to help repair a severe scrape on Jessica's forehead. Skin grafts were also taken from the little girl's thigh to be transferred to her right foot, which was wedged in an awkward position and suffered reduced blood flow. Hospital officials have said it will probably be another month before Jessica can go home.

title: BIOSPHERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Let's Have True Repeal Of McCarran-Walter
description: To the Editor:

title: PRIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tougher Student Loan Rules Planned
description: Calling the rate of default on student loans intolerable, Secretary of Education William J. Bennett said today that he planned to draw strict new guidelines that could make hundreds of schools ineligible for Federal student aid.

title: Emigres Reunited in U.S.
description: Two Jewish families were reunited in Capitol Hill ceremonies today after long battles to leave the Soviet Union. Lev Pevzner, 73 years old, a Russian-born resident of Indianapolis, was reunited with his son, daughter-in-law and granddaughter after eight years. Keith Braun, 28, a Detroit lawyer, was reunited with his wife, Svetlana.

title: BURRITT INTERFINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $182,000 represents a loss of $182,000, net of tax effect, for a prepayment penalty on a Federal Home Loan Bank advance.

title: Advertising; Louis Dorfsman Retires From CBS Design Post
description: Louis Dorfsman, vice president and creative director for advertising and design at CBS Inc., and one of the best-known graphics people in the business, has retired after 41 years with the company to start his own studio.

title: BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring after-tax charge of $523,000 from the write-off of call premiums associated with an economic refunding of long-term debt.

title: DOMINION RESOURCES INC reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
REAGAN EXPECTED TO SEEK MORE AID FOR THE CONTRAS
description: On the eve of a crucial two-month period for carrying out a Central American peace plan, the Reagan Administration has decided to seek $30 million in new non-lethal aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: INSIDE
description: New Student Loan Policy Education Secretary William J. Bennett said he was planning new guidelines that could make many schools ineligible for Federal aid. Page A16. Random Drug Tests Begin The Transportation Department said that it had begun random drug testing of employees, but that only one had been found to use drugs. Page A16. CBS Delays Cronkite Show CBS News took the unusual step of consulting an independent South African lawyer about a Walter Cronkite special on apartheid. Page C34.

title: Cuomo, at Capitol, Renews His Request For Economic Plan
description: Governor Cuomo of New York, saying the Presidential race was not the best forum for debating the country's economic future, today pressed his plan for the creation of a commission that would issue economic recommendations after the 1988 election.

title: Delay at Southland
description: The Southland Corporation, which is in the middle of a $4.9 billion leveraged buyout by the company's founding Thompson family, said that it would postpone its Nov. 5 shareholder meeting until Nov. 12. The Dallas company, which owns the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, said that the meeting had been delayed ''to provide time to complete the sale of the $1.5 billion of subordinated debt necessary to finance the merger.'' The JT Acquisition Corporation, the concern formed by the Thompsons to merge with Southland, completed a partial $77-a-share tender offer on July 31. It controls 72 percent of Southland's common stock.

title: MARK CONTROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $400,000 and $680,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Exchanges Giving Chicago a Lift, Too
description: Just as New York has flourished in recent years from the boom on Wall Street, so has Chicago prospered from the rising fortunes of its options and futures exchanges.

title: Instead of Pursuing a Career, You Could Let It Pursue You
description: LEAD: I WAS broke, unemployed and had no direction. So I bought one of those colorful life-planning workbooks and made an appointment with a career counselor.

title: Georgia Power To Appeal Ruling
description: The Southern Company said its Georgia Power Company unit would appeal a regulatory agency's decision to disallow a portion of its investment in Unit 1 of the Vogtle nuclear power plant. The Georgia Public Service Commission denied the utility's request to reconsider its decision to disallow $951 million of investment in the plant. The appeal will go to the Superior Court of Fulton County.

title: CATALYST ENERGY DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $3,000,000 charge to reserve for certain development projects and investments, including the sofar hydroelectric project in Eldorado County, Calif. c-Net income The company said its latest quarter loss is also attributable to Catalyst Thermal Energy Corp.'s loss for the quarter; the latest quarter includes a gain of $5.7 million, or 34 cents a share, from the initial public offering of 17 percent of Catalyst Thermal's common stock.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Key Hearing In Robins Suit
description: The A.H. Robins Company, maker of the Dalkon Shield, and the thousands of women who say they were harmed by the contraceptive will square off Thursday in a long-awaited hearing to determine how dearly Robins will have to pay.

title: For Shoppers, More Doubts
description: The stock market plunge has prompted nearly one-third of Americans to postpone, cancel or cut spending on such things as vacations, houses and cars, according to a poll published today.

title: OCCUPATIONAL-URGENT CARE HEALTH SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $304,400 for the quarter and $610,600 for the 9 months; the 9 months also includes a loss of $220,068 from discontinued clinic operations. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued clinic operations of $42,759 for the quarter and $104,117 for the 9 months.

title: Suffolk Democrats Stun G.O.P., Taking Top Post and Legislature
description: Suffolk County Democrats stunned Republicans on Tuesday by capturing the County Executive's office for the first time in 16 years, upsetting two longtime Republican Town Supervisors and gaining a plurality in the County Legislature.

title: MAYFAIR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $552,000 for the quarter and $1,449,200 for the 9 months.

title: ON BEING JILTED BY THE DIVA
description: Luciano Pavarotti and Piero Cappuccilli did it in Chicago, Jose Carerras and Ghena Dimitrova in Pittsburgh, Renato Bruson in New York, Ms. Dimitrova and Luis Lima in San Francisco. Major opera stars have been canceling their appearances this season with leading American companies at a distressing rate and are doing so even at the risk of ''burning their bridges in this country,'' according to company directors and officials. Moreover, many factors are now conspiring to make the problem worse than ever.

title: Publishing: Author Rebuffed by Court
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has upheld Random House in its suit to recover the $150,000 it had advanced to Leo Damore for a book to be titled ''Senatorial Privilege: The Chappaquiddick Deception.''

title: BUFFETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rising Nuclear Trade Stirs Fear of Terrorism
description: The risk that terrorists will obtain commercial nuclear materials as they are transported between nations is likely to increase in coming years, according to a review of security measures conducted by the Pentagon.

title: PLYMOUTH FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in July 1986.

title: CCC INFORMATION SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK (ALABAMA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $144,000 for the both periods. c-After an extraordinary gain of $73,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $306,000 for the year. The company converted to stock ownership in December 1986.

title: The Dance: Garth Fagan Troupe
description: THINGS may have seemed a little noisier than usual at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, with whistles and tumultuous applause at the start of the evening and whoops and cheers at the close. Garth Fagan's Bucket Dance Theater is back in town.

title: Pop: Mamas and the Papas
description: ALTHOUGH ''Papa'' John Phillips is the only original member of the Mamas and the Papas, who opened a monthlong engagement at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, on Tuesday, the group seems even more an extended family today than in 1966, when its first hit, ''California Dreamin','' beckoned the world to the lotus land of Los Angeles.

title: Concert: New Works By Musical Elements
description: ROBERT BEASER and Daniel Asia, who run the new-music group Musical Elements, set about to have fun Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y, and by and large they - and those members of the audience willing to unburden themselves of modernist solemnities - did, too.

title: Bond Prices Rise Cautiously
description: The bond market ended yesterday on a cautious note after the Treasury announced the results of the $9.25 billion 10-year note auction, showing that demand for the issue was not as strong as expected.

title: Voters in Referendums Protect the Pocketbook
description: From Maine to California, Americans voted their economic worries Tuesday, rejecting environmental efforts because of the accompanying costs and approving gambling measures as an alternative to taxes and a spur to growth.

title: KIROV PRINCIPAL DANCER TO PREFROM IN 'GISELLE'
description: Olga Likhovskaya, a principal dancer with the Kirov Ballet of Lenin-grad, will appear as guest artist in ''Giselle'' with the Warsaw Ballet to-night at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx, Bed-ford Park Boulevard West and Goul-den Avenue.

title: CORNERSTONE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIRSTFED AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings not available; the company converted to stock ownership on Dec. 18, 1986.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Smoothing the Edges
description: Marion C. Blakey, director of public affairs at the Education Department, is taking a similar post at the White House, a job that entails coordinating public events between the White House and other agencies.

title: Gretzky Overpowers Rangers
description: Wayne Gretzky scored three goals and increased his career assist total to 1,000 tonight to lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 7-2 whipping of the struggling Rangers.

title: SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures are restated.

title: SENDING PAINTINGS ABROAD HELPS RAISE PROFITS AT HOME
description: Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises'' - a glowing study of a patch of purple irises and one white bloom - was returned to New York last week after a four-week, 17,500-mile journey to Tokyo, London, Geneva and Zurich.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As a barometer at home there has not been great turmoil among the people outside the stock market. It has not created great aggravation and worry in the public, and to the extent that there is no urgency in the grass roots, maybe we're reflecting that.'' - Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon and a budget negotiator. [ A1:3. ]

title: Restoring Baronial Splendor in Pittsburgh
description: ''I WANT to put back as much as possible - the smells, the sounds, the flowers,'' said Thierry Despont, the architect who is restoring Clayton, home of the coke and steel baron Henry Clay Frick. ''I want the telephone to ring.''

title: POE & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $800,000 from discontinued operations of its underwriting subsidiary for the quarter and 9 months.

title: INDIANA BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Swapo Denies Pretoria Fight
description: The South-West Africa People's Organization said today that its guerrillas were not involved in a battle in Angola in which South Africa reported its forces suffered 12 fatalities and killed 150 guerrillas. The South African military command initially announced that its troops had overrun two Swapo bases in southern Angola and killed 150 guerrillas, and later released news of casualties.

title: U.S. Regrets Death of Fisherman in Gulf
description: The State Department expressed regret today that an Indian fisherman was killed when a United States Navy frigate opened fire on three Arab fishing boats in the Persian Gulf.

title: Defense Hints at Fake Story By a Howard Beach Witness
description: A defense lawyer suggested yesterday that before a motorist returned to the scene where his car had killed a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, the motorist and his father concocted a phony story about the accident.

title: Deaver 'Made No Special Demands,' Witness Says
description: Acting Secretary of Transportation James H. Burnley testified at the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver today that Mr. Deaver ''made no special demands'' on him in telephone conversations in 1985 in connection with Trans World Airlines.

title: Lower Growth In G.N.P. Seen
description: The United States will not come close to reaching its 3.5 percent economic growth target in 1988, although it probably will not enter a recession either, despite recent turmoil on financial markets, economists said here today.

title: HERS
description: ''I WANT to be white, like Brant,'' my 3-year-old said to me the other day. We were on our way home from the Denver Zoo.

title: Crime and the Constitution
description: President Reagan hails Judge Douglas Ginsburg, his nominee for the Supreme Court, as a crime fighter. At the swearing-in of F.B.I. Director William Sessions, Mr. Reagan said: ''The next justice on the Supreme Court better be ready to deal with that challenge [ of crime fighting ] , and Judge Ginsburg is ready.''

title: 5-Transplant Child Better
description: The 3-year-old Kentucky girl who received five new organs in experimental transplant surgery was taken off a respirator today, a sign of steady improvement, hospital officials said. The child, Tabatha Foster, was able to breathe on her own and talk for the first time since the 15-hour operation began Saturday, said a spokesman for Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh. Her condition was upgraded to critical but stable from critical. The girl received a new liver, pancreas, small intestine and parts of a stomach and colon.

title: Wide Fraud Is Found Among Illegal Aliens Who Seek Amnesty
description: Immigration officials said today that they had detected fraud in thousands of the applications for legal status filed by illegal aliens who said they had worked in the United States as farm laborers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank One, Lexington, an affiliate of the Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, elected William R. Guthrie president and chief executive.

title: Transplant Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Opportunity Has Rutledge Excited
description: Since he is so unaccustomed to a starting role in his nine years as a quarterback in the National Football League, Jeff Rutledge had no intention today of talking about his new assignment with the Giants.

title: 30 Are Indicted in Miami in Drug Smuggling
description: After a three-year investigation, Federal agents today arrested more than a dozen people accused of belonging to a sophisticated ring smuggling drugs in Colombia, the Bahamas and Florida.

title: UDC-UNIVERSAL DEVELOPMENT LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Don't Count the Yuppies Out
description: LEAD: As the stock market crashed on Black Monday, a street-corner prophet outside the New York Stock Exchange denounced M.B.A.'s and yelled that the day of the yuppies was over.

title: 5 More Broadway Theaters Classified as Landmarks
description: Five Broadway theaters were granted landmark status yesterday by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, almost doubling in one afternoon the number of houses designated in the theater district.

title: KAY JEWELERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: NICARAGUANS HOPE FOR PEACE STEPS
description: Political leaders and many ordinary Nicaraguans are hoping that major announcements expected Thursday will begin to change the course of their country's violent history.

title: Director of Guggenheim Retiring After 27 Years
description: Thomas M. Messer, the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation and of its museums in New York and Venice for 27 years, has announced his retirement. He said yesterday that he had no specific plans, adding, ''But my 68th birthday is coming up and although, like most Aquarians, I tend to fall in love with institutions, I just want to look at myself and see what's left of Tom Messer.''

title: Greenspan Basel-Bound
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, will meet next week with central bankers of other countries at the Bank for International Settlements in Basel, Switzerland, the Fed said today.

title: ALLEN ORGAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
General Dynamics Names President
description: The General Dynamics Corporation yesterday named Herbert F. Rogers president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 1.

title: CITIZENS BANK (NORTH CAROINA) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Program Trading Getting a Rebirth
description: After dropping off sharply because of New York Stock Exchange restrictions, program trading is on the rise again. That is partly because the Big Board lifted some of its curbs, but also because program traders have improvised to make up for the continued ban on automatic execution of stocks through the exchange's computers.

title: Hector To Start For Jets
description: He may have lost a half-step during the strike, but Freeman McNeil's telepathy was certainly on target.

title: G.O.P. to Report on Iran Deal Special to The New York Times
description: Republican members of the House committee on the Iran-contra affair have concluded that President Reagan did not know about the diversion of profits from the Iran arms sales to Nicaraguan rebel groups, Congressional officials said today.

title: Argonaut Buyout In Financing Snag
description: Argonaut Group Inc. said that because of market turmoil, it is unclear when suitable financing can be arranged to complete its planned $620 million buyout led by the New York firm of Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd. Argonaut's stock closed at $31.50 today, up 75 cents, in over-the-counter trading.

title: GREAT SOUTHERN FEDERAL SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gentle Shapes From a Young Ceramist
description: The refined shapes of Nicholas Bernard's ceramics are the result of 15 years of experience, yet he is only 28 years old. Now that his work is shown in galleries around the country, he hopes that his parents will stop asking, ''How are you going to feed yourself making pots?'' His current exhibition of ceramics at the Wallengren/ U.S.A. Gallery in SoHo has been extended two weeks.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Missing Deadlines
description: A key deadline is about to be missed on Capitol Hill: the date of Congressional adjournment.

title: Corrections
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about the prospects for change under the next Secretary of Defense gave an incorrect date for the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. It was signed in 1972.

title: Fossil of the Largest Sea Bird Is Discovered in the Carolinas
description: Fossils of the largest sea bird ever known, an extinct creature with a wingspan of more than 18 feet, have been discovered in South Carolina and identified by scientists of the Charleston Museum and the Smithsonian Institution.

title: CITY SAVINGS BANK OF MERIEN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings are not available; the bank went public Sept. 4, 1986.

title: Weinberger Insisted His Plans Be Secret, A High Official Says
description: The capital has been caught in an odd position this week over the departure of Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Defense.

title: Why So Many Losers
description: To The Home Section:

title: Endowment Offers Teachers Sabbaticals for Humanities
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities said Monday that it would sponsor paid sabbatical leaves for one elementary or high school teacher from each state to study the humanities.

title: Stocks Fall In Seesaw Session
description: The stock market continued to slump yesterday in another edgy session marked by wide price swings.

title: SOUTHHOLD SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The remaining per share earnings are not available, bank converted to stock ownership on April 28, 1987.

title: In Texas, Contempt by Court
description: By refusing to hear the $10 billion dispute between Texaco and Pennzoil, the Texas Supreme Court offends federalism and fairness. Contempt of court is one thing; this refusal amounts to a contempt by a court.

title: Indian Museum Move
description: To the Editor:

title: McCray Reaches Terms
description: Rodney McCray, the 6-foot-8-inch small member of the Houston Rockets' starting front line, reached agreement with the team yesterday on a six-year contract for an undisclosed amount of money. McCray, who led the Rockets in assists, field-goal percentage and free-throw percentage last season while complementing the Twin Towers - Ralph Sampson and Akeem Olajuwon -said that contract negotiations picked up speed after he changed agents, replacing Howard Slusher with David Falk. ''The attorney I had before had a different strategy,'' said McCray. ''I decided it was time to change for the benefit of Rodney McCray.''

title: Dollar Tests New Lows In Spite of Intervention
description: The dollar fell today to at a record low in Japan against the yen after softening in nervous trading yesterday.

Brain Graft on Elderly Tested
description: Researchers operated today on the first elderly person to undergo an experimental brain graft technique against Parkinson's disease. The operation was the first of six intended to see whether the new technique, already tried on younger patients, could help older victims of the disease.

description: President Reagan today appointed four executives, each apparently selected to represent a different sector of the investment community, to the task force he created two weeks ago to study the turmoil in the financial markets.

description: A panel of Soviet historians said today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech on Soviet history this week opened the way for a more intensive study of past problems but that restricted access to archives remained a serious obstacle.

It is a system in which individual jurists weigh the fate of accused terrorists by sitting as judge and jury.

title: Cenith Group Sets Joint Bid for Ionics
description: A Boston partnership with a 5.8 percent stake in Ionics Inc. has criticized the company's recently announced stock buyback plan and proposed a joint buyout that values the concern at $62.8 million. In a letter on Tuesday to Ionics' chairman, Averell Daniell, Cenith Partners L.P. proposed a buyout of the company at $17 a share in a deal involving Cenith and Ionics' management and employees.

title: Belgium's Jobless Rate
description: Belgium's unemployment rate fell to 12.1 percent in October, from 12.2 percent in September, the National Labor Office said today. Belgium's jobless rate is one of the highest in the European Community, surpassed only by Ireland and Italy.

title: French Honor Levesque

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Wilander Upset by American: Jim Grabb of the United States used a strong serve-and-volley game to upset second-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden, 7-5, 6-4, last night in the second round of the $525,000 Stockholm Open-Scandinavian Championships. Grabb, a 23-year-old former all-American at Stanford who is ranked only 76th, eliminated another Swede, Thomas Hogstedt, 7-6, 7-6, in the first round Monday. ''I never found my rhythm,'' said Wilander, who is ranked third in the world.(AP) Cash and Mayotte Advance: Pat Cash, Tim Mayotte, Amos Mansdorf and Henri LeConte advanced to the quarterfinals of the $840,000 Paris Open with second-round victories yesterday. The second-seeded Cash, the Wimbledon champion, had a tough second set before topping Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland, 6-3, 7-6. Mayotte defeated Slobodan Zivojinovic of Yugoslavia, 4-6, 6-2, 6-2. In the final first-round match, top-seeded Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia defeated Guy Forget of France, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4. (AP) Sukova Defeats Inoue: Fourth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia stumbled against unranked Etsuko Inoue of Japan yesterday but advanced in the Virginia Slims of New England tennis championships at the Centrum in Worcester, Mass. Sukova, an easy 6-1, 6-1 victor in her opening-round match Monday, needed a rare three sets and 1 hour 25 minutes to defeat Inoue, 5-7, 6-2, 6-4.(AP)

description: A United States Army private who defected to the Soviet Union seven months ago returned to the West today and said he would surrender to the American authorities.

title: Decision on Harmon
description: Based on a ruling by an arbitrator, John Culver, a former Senator from Iowa, Ronnie Harmon does not have to repay Norby Walters most of the money he received from the agent with whom he had a contract from March 1985 until August 1986. According to a report yesterday in The Atlanta Constitution, Culver voided the contract that Harmon signed on the ground that Walters and Lloyd Bloom, an associate, had violated regulations of the National Football League Players Association regarding agents. Since Harmon was a junior at the University of Iowa, signing a contract and accepting money from the agents violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. Culver's 30-page decision held that Harmon must repay only $5,869.47 of the $54,924.42 that Walter gave him in cash, airline tickets and an automobile. Culver, however, said that he did not consider Harmon to be an innocent party in the dealings with the agents and reprimanded the running back, who was the top draft pick of the Buffalo Bills in 1986. . . . The arbitrator's ruling also said that Ron's brother, Kevin Harmon, a senior running back who leads Iowa in rushing yardage this season, had also received gifts from the agents. Officials of the Big Ten Conference and Iowa said they would investigate the situation.

title: Index Futures Tied By Ruder to Plunge
description: David S. Ruder, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that various forms of index futures trading played a significant role in the recent collapse of the stock market.

title: Suffolk County's Evolution
description: The rare election of a Democrat, Patrick Halpin, as Suffolk County Executive, adds weight to the party's triumphs in Tuesday's election. Governor Cuomo, who campaigned for Mr. Halpin, was quick to claim credit. But it's also important to heed the county's changing character.

title: Nixon Injured Again
description: Norm Nixon, the veteran guard who missed the 1986-87 season because of an injured left knee, ruptured his right Achilles' tendon during practice yesterday and will be sidelined for the 1987-88 season, the Los Angeles Clippers announced. Nixon, a two-time All-Star guard, was injured near the end of the practice session after he passed the ball and made a quick cut. Nixon will undergo surgery this morning and will be placed in a knee-length cast for six weeks. Nixon, 32 years old, has a career scoring average of 16.4 points per game in nine National Basketball Association seasons. He played with the Lakers for six seasons before being traded to the Clippers Oct. 10, 1983. He suffered a ruptured quadriceps tendon above the left knee while playing in a softball game in Central Park in July 1986.

description: An article yesterday about efforts to enforce a New York City height requirement for the Cityspire tower misstated the record of Manhattan's Borough President, David N. Dinkins, on the issue. He has taken no position.

description: The Rev. Dr. R.B.Y. Scott, an Old Testament scholar and former William H. Danforth Professor of Religion at Princeton University, died Sunday at a home for the elderly in Toronto, where he had lived for several years. He was 88 years old.

title: Ecuadorean Debt Bought
description: The World Wildlife Fund said today that it would buy up to $10 million in Ecuadorean debt from commercial banks and use the money to finance conservation projects in the South American country.

title: Larry Davis Accused of Threatening Woman by Letter to Stop Her From Testifying
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that Larry Davis, who faces trial on charges of killing four suspected drug dealers in the Bronx, mailed a threatening letter from jail to the mother of his 2-year-old child to deter her from testifying against him.

title: Kerkorian Bid Opposed in Poll
description: An overwhelming majority of Pan American World Airways pilots in New York are opposed to having the pilots union pursue a proposal made by Kirk Kerkorian to take over the airline, a union official said yesterday. The New York base accounts for about half of the carrier's pilots, and the official said sentiment was running 20 to 1 against the proposal in a poll of the pilots.

title: Wood Radiator Covers Can Add Sitting Space
description: NOAH BLOCK, a co-owner of the Building Block, a cabinet shop, says that customers find plenty of reasons to order his custom-made radiator covers. The covers can create extra sitting space, cover up unsightly radiators, protect skin and clothing from hot coils and provide additional shelf space.

description: b-Includes a realized gain of $243,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. The 1986 results are pro foma and are provided for comparative purposes, and are based on the assumption that the December 1986 reorganization in which MBIA Inc., through its wholly owned subsidiary MBIA Corp., became the successor to the Municipal Bond Insurance Association was effective on Jan. 1, 1986. These pro forma statements are intended to reflect the insurance business of the Association as if it had been written by the Company.

title: Airline Ticket Fraud
description: Ticket fraud costs the world's airlines up to $500 million a year, according to estimates by the International Air Transport Association published today. In its latest quarterly magazine, the I.A.T.A. said it had begun a training program to help staff from its 168 member airlines spot fraudulent tickets. The report said that in most cases, criminals enlisted the help of unscrupulous travel agents. In exchange for a small cut, the agents would alter stolen or false tickets. The report recommended that airlines offer rewards to employees who intercept the fraudulent tickets.

title: N.A.M. Called Hopeful on '88
description: American manufacturers are still confident about economic prospects for next year despite the stock market plunge, Jerry Jasinowski, chief economist of the National Association of Manufacturers, said today.

title: Yields Are Mainly Off
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds were down for the week ended yesterday, while bank money market accounts remained unchanged.

COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic Research Co., Alexandria, Va., said it would buy the liquid rocket propulsion business of the Bell Aerospace division of Textron Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

Hanging A Vivid Jungle
description: MOST of the jungle of plants and hanging baskets filling the abundant number of east windows in my house are foliage plants: true ferns, various asparagus ferns (which aren't ferns at all, but are close kin to the tasty edible kind) and spider plants.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; An Actor on the Hill
description: E. G. Marshall, the actor, had some advice this week for the top negotiators from the White House and Congress who are struggling to reach a compromise on a deficit-reducing package.

title: Market Place; Few Earnings Estimates Cut
description: THERE have not been many downward revisions by analysts for 1988 corporate earnings in the wake of the stock market's Oct. 19 debacle, according to companies that gather such information.

title: Leonard H. Steibel, 72; International Lawyer
description: Leonard H. Steibel, a founding partner and senior member of the New York City law firm Smith, Steibel, Alexander & Saskor, died of cordoma, a rare form of cancer, Saturday at his home in Sands Point, L.I.. He was 72 years old.

title: GMAC Notes
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering $300 million of notes due in 1990 at a price of 99.93, to yield 8.90 percent through Morgan Stanley & Company. Rated Aa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the issue yields about 95-hundredths of a percentage point more than three-year Treasury notes.

title: Trucks Need More Inspection, Not Regulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Keep the Anglo-Irish Pact
description: The Protestants and Catholics of British-ruled Northern Ireland agree on one rare point: Both would do away with the one-judge, no-jury courts that now try terrorist cases. They would accept as a sensible alternative the system that is used in the Irish Republic: three judges, one usually of a different faith from the accused. But Britain resists, and the sad result might be to undermine Prime Minister Thatcher's landmark 1985 Anglo-Irish agreement.

title: ANTIQUE TEXTILES AT COOPER-HEWITT
description: WE wear them, we decorate with them but ''no one knows precisely when printed fabrics were first done,'' said Gillian Moss, associate curator of textiles at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, who has organized a show called ''Color by the Yard: Printed Fabric, 1760-1860.''

title: Marathon Completed
description: Bob Wieland of Arcadia, Calif., who lost his legs in Vietnam, completed the New York City Marathon yesterday and lowered his 1986 time for the event from 98 hours 48 minutes 17 seconds to just over 81 hours.

title: National Horse Show; Canada Wins Cup in Jumpoff
description: The Nations' Cup, a horsemanship contest among international teams from the United States, Britain, France and Canada, had to be decided by a timed jumpoff between France and Canada last night at the National Horse Show. The Canadians won on the strength of clear rounds from three of their four riders.

title: Rams Suspend Irvin
description: The Los Angeles Rams have suspended the All-Pro cornerback LeRoy Irvin for conduct detrimental to the team. He will not play Sunday when the Rams meet the New Orleans Saints, but Coach John Robinson said Irvin's status would be re-evaluated after he meets with the eight-year veteran next Monday. Irvin, who has been complaining about his contract since early in training camp, called in sick with the flu last Thursday and the Rams responded by placing him on the inactive list and cleaning out his locker.

title: Corrections
description: A Paris dispatch on Friday about a device used in French taxis to deter muggers misstated the electric charge involved. It is 52,000 volts of current at a very low amperage -0.02 amperes - not at low tension.

title: An Arrest in German Killings
description: A 33-year-old man was detained on suspicion of killing two policemen in a protest near the Frankfurt airport two days ago, the Government said today. The man, Andreas Eichler, was arrested hours after the killings, during a protest by extremists wearing masks.

title: I.B.M. Is Optimistic Despite Problems
description: The chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation predicted today that ''we should return this company to operating margins in the range of 20 percent,'' the strongest indication yet that I.B.M. now believes its three-year slump is ending.

title: Test Set for AIDS Antibodies In Recipients of Tainted Blood
description: Tests for antibodies to the AIDS virus will be offered to people who received transfusions from a San Francisco blood bank where officials estimate up to one out of every 100 blood units supplied from 1981 to 1983 was tainted with the virus.

title: Gilford: Jack Gilford At Ballroom
description: JACK GILFORD is in the tradition of the great silent clowns, the comic masters of the early days of films. He may be the last of them, and even he depends on speech and song for most of his performance at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, where he is making his first cabaret appearance in 39 years.

Roth Jr. Mr. Beard, a wealthy 48-year-old businessman, said the key issues for 1988 would be the creation of jobs and economic growth, and he attributed the declining economy to the a tax-cutting bill sponsored by Mr. Roth.

title: Q & A
description: Q. My year-old fir deck was stained with a semisolid stain instead of a deck stain. As a result it is now peeling, bubbling and splotchy and looks 10 years old instead of almost new. The cost of sanding off this stain so the deck can be restained properly is exorbitant. What can be done now and next season to correct this problem?

title: Forcibly Hospitalized Woman Identified
description: The first person hospitalized under an effort to remove mentally ill homeless people from Manhattan's streets was identified by her relatives in a court hearing yesterday as a 40-year-old former secretary from a middle-class family in Livingston, N.J.

title: Army Accepts Copters Despite Some Problems
description: The Army has accepted delivery of 285 new Apache helicopter gunships even though it is still working with the manufacturer to correct a number of problems on the aircraft that were identified two years ago, officials say.

title: Recital: Sylvia Kahan
description: SYLVIA KAHAN put together what is uncommon on New York recital stages: a well-organized, stimulating mix of piano music, played in like fashion. Ms. Kahan's recital Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall included three song variations by William Byrd, Yehudi Wyner's Sonata for Piano from 1954 in a slightly revised version, Beethoven's Sonata in E-flat (Op. 27, No. 1) and Frederic Rzewski's ''North American Ballads'' of 1978-79.

title: Ginsburg's Legal Philosophy
description: Following are answers by Douglas H. Ginsburg to two of the questions posed by the Senate Judiciary Committee in connection with his nomination last year to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia: Judicial Activism Q. Please discuss your views on the following criticism involving ''judicial activism.'' . . . A. In my view, the only appropriate function of the Federal judiciary is to resolve cases and controversies, as authorized by Article III of the United States Constitution. The Courts have no authority to engage in ''problem-solving'' apart from the resolution of such cases and controversies. While I do not think there is any wholesale tendency by the judiciary in recent years to ignore the ''case or controversy'' requirement, the Courts do seem to have relaxed such jurisdictional and prudential requirements as standing (and perhaps ripeness); narrowed the range of the ''political question'' doctrine, by which the Courts have historically avoided the resolution of controversies properly resolved by the political branches; and used their remedial powers in ways that constrain the legitimate roles of the legislative and executive branches. These tendencies may accot.for some of the recent controversy surrounding the role of the Federal Courts in our system of government. When the standing and ripeness requirements are loosened too much, the Courts are in danger of entertaining mere grievances rather than actual cases or controversies. When the political question doctrine is narrowed too much, or the Courts order legislatures to appropriate and executives to expend monies in particular ways, they are in danger of resolving issues that, in a democratic government, should be resolved through the democratic political process established by the Constitution.

title: Crash Kills Man, and Another Is Accused of Oiling the Road

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Dale Murphy, outfielder, signed three-year guaranteed contract extension. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Ruppert Jones, outfielder, became free agent. DETROIT (AL) - Jack Morris, pitcher, became a free agent again. HOUSTON (NL) - Dave Smith, Larry Andersen and Danny Darwin, pitchers, became free agents. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Announced that Terry Collins will return as manager of Albuquerque of Pacific Coast League, Brent Strom will be pitching coach, Ben Hines hitting coach and Len Currier trainer. Kevin Kennedy will move from Bakersfield of California League to manage San Antonio of Texas League. Pat Zachry will be the pitching coach at San Antonio, Von Joshua the hitting coach and Mike LoPriore the trainer. Gary LaRocque will move from San Antonio to Bakersfield to manage. Guy Conti will serve as pitching coach, Mark Sheahy will be the hitting coach and Stan Johnston will be the trainer. Joe Alvarez will return as manager at Sarasota of Gulf Coast League. Tim Johnson will return as manager at Great Falls of Pioneer Rookie League. MONTREAL (NL) - Bob McClure, pitcher, became free agent. SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Atlee Hammaker, pitcher, became free agent. BASKETBALL HOUSTON (NBA) - Rodney McCray, forward, agreed to six-year contract. MILWAUKEE (NBA) - Waived Bob McCann, forward, and Keith Smith, guard. NETS (NBA) - Acquired Dallas Comegys from Atlanta for second-round draft choice in either 1989 or 1990. Announced that Tony Brown, forward, underwent surgery on right foot and will miss entire season. COLLEGES PHOENIX - Named Dave Babcock interim basketball coach. FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Signed Aaron Brown, linebacker. CLEVELAND (AFC) - Signed Vyto Kab, tight end. JETS (AFC) - Signed Glenn Dennison, free agent tight end; released George Radachowsky, safety; Bill Ransdell, quarterback; Bill Sanders, tight end; Skip Peete, wide receiver, and Vince Amoia, running back. LOS ANGELES RAIDERS (AFC) -Cut Henry Lawrence, offensive tackle. LOS ANGELES RAMS (NFC) - Suspended LeRoy Irvin, cornerback, for ''conduct detrimental to the team.'' HOCKEY RANGERS (NHL) - Acquired Michel Petit, defenseman, from Vancouver for Willie Huber and Larry Melnyk; recalled Ron Talakowski and Jeff Brubaker, forwards, and Mark Tinordi, defenseman, from Colorado farm club in International League. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Recalled Doug Evans, wing, from Peoria of International League.

title: ACETO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Williams Rejects Job
description: Miffed after learning that he was not under consideration to become the new manager of the Chicago Cubs. Billy Williams, the Hall of Fame outfielder, has told the Cubs he will not manage in the club's minor-league system as planned. Williams, who played for the Cubs nearly all of his 18-year major-league career and served as a coach with the team for six years, has talked with John Madigan, the club's new chairman. ''I told him I played with the Cubs and I am a Cub and I am concerned about what has happened to the team,'' said Williams, who was upset that the team's former general manager, Dallas Green, resigned last week after executives of the Tribune Company, which owns the Cubs, had vetoed Greeen's choice for manager - John Vukovich.

Gorbachev Fills In Some Blank Pages
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech on the 70th anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution was a microcosm of the reform process he has been leading. The speech shows how far he has come in his willingness to tell the truth about Soviet history, and how far he still has to go. It also raises serious doubts about whether he can get there - the same sorts of doubts that arise concerning his prospects for reforming the Soviet system in general.

title: Ancient Boats Still Ply a Tense Gulf
description: Visibility in the shipping lanes of the Persian Gulf was dropping in the amber dusk. Suddenly, a young, twangy American voice came over the marine radio: ''Unidentified dhow one mile off my port bow, this is a U.S. Navy warship. State your intentions.'' The admonition was repeated once, then again, and each time the sailor's voice grew more insistent. But there was no response from the dhow, one of the local wooden boats that ply the gulf in uncounted hundreds.

A Rescue Devised for Specialists

title: Europe Jobless Rate Up
description: The jobless rate for nine member states of the European Community, excluding Spain, Portugal and Greece, rose to 10.9 percent in September, from 10.8 percent in August, the community's statistical office said today. The figures are seasonally unadjusted. The total number of job seekers for the nine countries rose to 12.62 million, from 12.53 million.

description: Spain has turned down a last-minute compromise proposal by the United States to salvage the 34-year-old defense treaty that permits American military installations on Spanish soil.

title: WURLITZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Landscapes That Recall Rural Simplicity
description: THE landscape architect Michael Van Valkenburgh recalls first fantasizing about the land as a boy when he brought the cows home from pasture in the Catskills to his family's modest dairy farm in Lexington, N.Y. Today, his work retains what he sees as ''the deliberate simplicity of that remembered agrarian landscape,'' as in the way a plantation of trees is angled into the hillside. For him, beauty and elegance are found in the straightforward solution rather than in the picturesque.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1987
description: THE MARKETS The stock market continued to slump in another session marked by wide price swings. Selling by institutions helped drag down share prices, analysts said, but there were indications that some stability may be returning. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled more than 50 points early in the day, then rose as much as 17 points above Tuesday's close, but ended down 18.24 points, or 0.93 percent, at 1,945.29. [ Page D1. ] The dollar continued its steady slide today, dropping to yet another record low of 135.35 yen in Tokyo. At one point, the dollar also sank through an important psychological barrier of 1.70 West German marks. The dollar's tumble persisted despite determined attempts to prop it up by the Bank of Japan. According to Japanese news reports, the bank purchased $200 million within just the first 30 minutes of trading today. [ D1. ] The dollar moved lower yesterday in seesaw trading on world markets. [ D20. ] President Reagan appointed four executives, each apparently selected to represent a different sector of the investment community, to his task force to assess the turmoil in the financial markets. The selection process had apparently been the subject of fierce lobbying by rival factions in the financial community and among regulators. [ D7. ] Index futures trading played a role in the recent collapse of the stock market, the S.E.C. chairman told a Senate committee. [ D7. ] Program trading is on the rise again, partly because the Big Board has lifted some of its curbs, and partly because traders have learned to compensate for the continued ban on automatic execution of stocks through the exchange's computers. [ D6. ] The Administration is devising a plan to rescue specialist brokers should the market plunge again, a senior Treasury official said. In an emergency, Wall Street firms and large corporations would be asked to contribute to a pot of $2 billion to $3 billion. [ D7. ] The bond market ended on a cautious note after the Treasury announced the results of the $9.25 billion, 10-year note auction, showing that demand for the issue was not as strong as expected. Prices for Treasury notes and bonds rose, but dealers said investors were not buying with the same urgency as they had late last month. [ D19. ] Yields on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds were down for the week. Bank money market accounts were unchanged. [ D21. ] Platinum futures prices plunged the daily limit on expectations of an economic slowdown, and oil futures fell sharply. [ D20. ] COMPANIES American auto makers reported strong sales in the days following the market's collapse. Buyers appeared were undeterred by the stock market's 508-point plunge on Oct. 19 and the subsequent turmoil, as sales of cars and light trucks were up 10.8 percent from the year-ago period. But analysts said many sales had been in the pipeline before the stock market fell and they predicted sales would decline in coming months, possibly as early as in the next 10-day period. [ D1. ] G.M. will indefinitely close its assembly plant in Framingham, Mass., and lay off 3,700 workers because of slow sales of the Chevrolet Celebrity and Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera. [ D4. ] I.B.M. predicted a return to 20 percent operating margins, the strongest indication yet that it believes its three-year slump is ending. John F. Akers, I.B.M.'s chairman, gave no timetable for when I.B.M. would reach its goal in a briefing to analysts. [ D1. ] Bell Atlantic came of age, becoming the first of the regional phone companies to report profits from its nonregulated businesses. Bell Atlantic said its enterprises, which include cellular telephones and financial services, earned $29 million on revenues of $643 million in the first nine months of the year. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL President Reagan lifted some trade sanctions against Japan that were imposed in April after the Administration accused Japan of failing to comply with an agreement on semiconductors. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The English channel tunnel project moved forward as the company behind it signed an $8.75 billion loan package put together by 198 banks. But there's a catch. The money will not be disbursed unless the company raises an additional $1.3 billion from an equity offering. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Analysts' earnings forecasts have not been reduced for many companies following the stock market's tumble and some people are surprised. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: 9TH GAME IN CHESS MATCH IS DRAWN
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov drew a long, grim battle yesterday in the ninth game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain. The contest remains tied, now at 4 1/2 points.

title: A System That Couldn't Save A Child From Lethal Abuse
description: The case of Elizabeth Steinberg, a 6-year-old, sandy-haired victim of child abuse, has focused public outrage and criminal investigations on the girl's adoptive parents, who are accused of beating her to death in their Greenwich Village apartment.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of New York regional election results yesterday incorrectly reported the result in the race for town supervisor in Pelham, N.Y. The winner was Paul A. Daronco, a Republican, who received 1,431 votes.

title: Fending Off Burglar, Dog Is Killed in Dryer
description: A 4-year-old chihuahua died trying to protect her owner's property when a burglar threw her into a dryer and turned it on, Tompkins County sheriff's deputies said.

title: AUCTION HOUSES EXHIBITING A BONANZA OF MASTERWORKS
description: THE November art auctions - organized over the summer long before the stock market collapsed almost three weeks ago -move into high gear next week with sales that are expected to be the first to show how the financial crisis has affected the international art market. Unlike this week's auctions of contemporary art, at which United States buyers dominated, the sales next week at Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips were organized to attract the bids of collectors and dealers from Europe, Japan, Australia and elsewhere.

title: Sports People; Slaney Set to Go
description: When Mary Slaney begins her attempt to come back from an injury next Jan. 23 in the 2,000-meter run at the Pacific Northwest Bell indoor track meet in Portland, Ore., it will mark her first competitive race in more than two years.

title: Film: 'Less Than Zero,' Young Lives
description: THE smartest thing that the makers of ''Less Than Zero'' have done is the thing that they didn't do: stick very closely to Bret Easton Ellis's novel, no matter how trendy and best-selling that book may have been. For all its shock value, Mr. Ellis's story of bored, jaded, affluent California teens-agers would have been paralyzingly downbeat on screen, if not worse. Indeed, by the time it got to the book's scenes of ultimate depravity - the snuff film watched as casual entertainment, the gang-rape of a 12-year-old girl - a faithful film version would have cleared the house.

title: Film: Attenborough's 'Cry Freedom'
description: THE mantle of greatness does not fall lightly onto the heroes of Sir Richard Attenborough's epic film biographies. It is placed there by a heavy hand. A great statesman, as in the director's ''Gandhi'' or his new ''Cry Freedom,'' about the murdered South African leader Stephen Biko, is apt to be bathed in beatific light as he delivers important speeches, and to be making speeches even when he talks with intimate friends. He will be surrounded by acolytes, who often nod their approval as one. When he moves the masses, thousands of people will appear on screen. And he will speak to them in clear, helpful, eminently instructive tones. Everyone else in the film will speak that way, too.

title: Article 271187 -- No Title
description: New York Telephone has given the New York City Ballet $730,000, to be spent over three years, for the maintenance of costumes and sets for ''The Nutcracker'' and for a special program on the company's production of the ballet that will be taken into a school in each of the five boroughs of New York City. The corporation currently supports other educational programs of the City Ballet, including the annual ''Ballet for Young People'' event for children from the city's public schools. Some 1,800 children are expected to take part over the three years in the ''Nutcracker'' program, which includes lecture-demonstrations, a party at the theater and a performance of the ballet. In addition, 1,200 children in special-education programs will see the performance under the sponsorship of New York Telephone.

title: Big East Pact Extended
description: Madison Square Garden and the Big East Conference announced a three-year extension of their agreement to hold the conference's postseason basketball tournament at the Garden. The extension assures that the Garden will continue to host the popular four-day tournament through the 1990-91 season.

description: Brain dead from a fierce beating, 6-year-old Elizabeth Steinberg was taken off life-support systems and died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. Her adoptive parents, a Greenwich Village lawyer and a former writer and book editor, were charged with murder.

description: SEEING ''Manon of the Spring'' four months after having been thoroughly enchanted by ''Jean de Florette'' is like going back to bed in an attempt to continue an interrupted dream. Sleep may come, but the dream is gone.

title: London Curbs 3 Firms
description: London's Stock Exchange said today that it had placed trading restrictions on three unidentified brokerage firms that have not made sufficient progress in reducing backlogs of unsettled trades. The restrictions were not related to the London market's tumble in the last few weeks, a stock exchange official said. The stock exchange has told the three firms to restrict trading ''by a certain amount,'' but it will be up to the firms to decide how to limit their trading.

description: Yesterday morning at 6:10 Joe Levy was heading south through Westchester on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. He seemed a little subdued - there weren't any good traffic jams. ''All smooth,'' he radioed back to Shadow Traffic headquarters.

description: Lawyers representing the A. H. Robins Company and some 200,000 women who say they suffered infertility or other injuries from its Dalkon Shield birth control device offered sharply divergent estimates of the value of the claims in a bankruptcy hearing here today.
