title: Dining Out Guide; New Classic Italian
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CHELSEA TRATTORIA ITALIANA, #108 Eighth Avenue, at 16th Street (924-7786) - **(Aug. 7, 1987) This trattoria serves some stellar pastas at affordable prices. Specials include terrific whole-wheat-flour-and-spinach ravioli, called cappelletti, filled with minced vegetables in a fresh tomato puree, and aromatic linguine with pesto sauce and tender young string beans. For desserts, try the orange layer cake. Entrees $10 to $21. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 to 11:30 P.M. DIECI X, #1568 First Avenue, at 82d Street (628-6565) - **(July 18, 1986) This is a swanky East Side restaurant offering urbane Italian ambiance. Seafood is fresh and prepared with care, such as an appetizer of sauteed jumbo shrimp. Veal comes in several forms, notably a breaded paillard topped with a zesty salad. For dessert, it would be difficult to find a better tiramisu, this one an espresso-soaked vanilla cake that is pumped up with custard and mascarpone cheese. Entrees $13.95 to $24.95. Fridays and Saturdays, 5:30 to 11:30 P.M.; Sundays, 5 to 10 P.M. MARCELLO, #1354 First Avenue, at 73d Street (744-4400) - **(Feb. 7, 1986) A contemporary dining room done in shades of beige and rose. An unusual Sardinian pasta called malloreddus alla Sarda is a gnocchi-like version sauteed with fresh herbs, tomato and sausage. The chef respects good quality veal, as in his veal Milanese. Don't miss the tiramisu for dessert. Entrees $12 to $19.50. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5 to 10:30 P.M. PRIMOLA, #1226 Second Avenue, at 65th Street (758-1775) - **(Feb. 20, 1987) While the setting is somewhat spare, the food is skillfully prepared and vividly seasoned. An outstanding appetizer is good lean carpaccio of beef with well-aged Parmesan. Spinach gnocchi are resilient under a gratineed mozzarella and tomato sauce. First-rate entrees include sauteed veal with wild mushrooms. For dessert, try the ricotta cheesecake. Entrees $11.50 to $20.50. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays and Sundays, 5 P.M. to midnight. TOSCANA RISTORANTE, #200 East 54th Street (371-8144) - **(Sept. 4, 1987) This establishment is worth a detour both for its evocative design and for the food, some of which is outstanding. A dependable appetizer is the vitello tonnato, cold veal under a refined tuna and anchovy sauce. A luxurious dish is the thin zucchini-and-arugula-filled ravioli. A recommended entreeis filet mignon with a brassy mustard-and-scallion sauce. You might punctuate the meal with an exemplary creme caramel. Entrees $18 to $24. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 to 10:30 P.M.; Saturdays 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. What the stars mean, page C28.

title: Stage: 'Into the Woods,' From Sondheim
description: WHEN Cinderella, Little Red Ridinghood and their fairy-tale friends venture into the woods in the new Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical, you can be sure that they won't miss the subconscious forest for the picturesque trees. The characters of ''Into the Woods'' may be figures from children's literature, but their journey is the same painful, existential one taken by so many adults in Sondheim musicals past.

The 93 broker-dealer funds decreased $78.8 million, to $108.11 billion.

title: Vincent J. Malone
description: Vincent J. Malone, a matrimonial lawyer for many years, died of emphysema Tuesday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 83 years old.

title: Adams's Goal Topples Flyers
description: Greg Adams's second goal of the game with only 11 seconds left gave Vancouver a 4-3 victory over the slumping Philadelphia Flyers tonight, breaking the Canucks' seven-game streak without a victory.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; AN AIMLESS SEASON AT HIALEAH
description: It seems like celebrating Thanksgiving in June or Christmas in July: Hialeah Park, the jewel of Florida racing, opens Wednesday.

title: Vernon Evans
description: Maj. Gen. Vernon Evans, United States Army, retired, a former chief of staff of the China-India-Burma theater, died of kidney failure Wednesday at the Carriage Hill nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He lived in Washington and was 94 years old.

title: PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No TV? Israel Is Savoring the Silence
description: Israeli radio and television workers walked out on strike four weeks ago, counting on the traditional Israeli addiction to news to force the Government into conceding quickly to their wage demands.

title: At the Movies
description: A Deceiving Incident

title: Film: 'Hiding Out'
description: IT'S surprising that ''Hiding Out,'' which opens today at the Criterion Center and other theaters, has so little high style, since its director is Bob Giraldi, one of the reigning kings of rock video. Mr. Giraldi, who also directs commercials, takes a fairly ordinary approach to this easygoing teen-age comedy about a stockbroker in his mid-20's who must pretend to be a high-school student. Why? Don't ask, because the screenplay doesn't offer much of an explanation. It only takes a few minutes before Jon Cryer, as the stockbroker, has dyed stripes into his hair, given away his expensive suit, and begun trying to keep up with the teen-age Joneses.

title: MITEL CORP reports earnings for 13wks to Sept 25
description: b-Includes special gains of $3.5 million and $7.5 million for the 13 weeks and 26 weeks, respectively. c-Net loss d-After a special charge of $37.3 million for both the 13 weeks and 26 weeks. The company said the year-earlier 13 weeks have been restated to reflect the write-off of operating losses incurred by Expertel Inc.

title: DAMON BIOTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The latest periods include revenues and net income of $1,000,000 associated with the favorable settlement of litigation, and also includes a net loss of $1,400,000 resulting from the company's acquisition of Damon Biotech Europe Ltd.

title: U.S. ACCUSES MAN OF NAZI CAMP PAST
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had begun deportation proceedings against a Chicago man accused of working as a guard in three Nazi concentration camps. It cited evidence that he ''participated in the Nazi program of persecution'' of Jews and others in World War II.

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rate Cuts Push Dow Up by 40.12
description: Stock prices rebounded strongly yesterday, encouraged by interest rate cuts in the United States and West Germany. Stocks also closed higher in Tokyo.

title: C.H. HEIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Simms's Season Is Stuck in Neutral
description: The symbolism was inadvertent, but fitting.

title: ONE PRICE CLOTHING STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share data reflects 3-for-2 stock split paid Sept. 30.

title: A Chronicler of Revolt, Defiant Behind Bars
description: Govan A. Mbeki, the 77-year-old former chairman of the African National Congress, wrote his last book on tissue paper and smuggled it to a publisher. He will not need to be so secretive with future manuscripts, for he was freed yesterday after 23 years in a South African prison.

title: RITZY'S, G D INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago periods' revenue restated for a change in accounting.

title: U.S. Is Sending Stinger Missiles to Chad
description: The United States has agreed to supply Chad with Stinger missiles and has sent an American team to Ndjamena to train its army to use them, Administration officials said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; 99 Cents on the Dollar
description: Joseph R. Mehrkens, who recently left the United States Forest Service after 17 years, today fired a broadside at the way it manages the Tongass National Forest in Alaska.

title: STOCKS, BONDS GAIN
description: In the first strong sign of international economic cooperation after a month of turbulence in the financial markets, West Germany ordered reductions in interest rates today to speed up its economy. The Reagan Administration and other governments had urged Bonn to lower its rates because they feared the onset of a worldwide recession caused partly by high interest rates.

title: AIDS Memo Stirs Both Parties
description: Democrats today released a memorandum purportedly from a Republican consultant, saying Republicans should exploit public fears to help their party in 1988. The purported author, Charles Rund, a poll taker, vigorously denied that he had written it.

title: Art: Fernand Leger Paintings at Acquavella
description: THE loan show of ''Fernand Leger'' at the Acquavella Galleries is a remarkable achievement. For the two rooms upstairs, the gallery has been able to borrow no fewer than 28 paintings that are dated between 1905 and 1921. From the beginnings of Leger's Cubism in the ''Compotier'' of 1909, through a great series of ''Contrastes de Formes'' and some incisive allusions to Leger's later preoccupation with the factory, the level crossing, the circus, the machinist and the big city as a whole, the standard is remarkably high. We come away from those two rooms with an understanding of Leger's great early work that falls short only in the context of his war service, with all that it brought to him in the way of revelation, both human and mechanical.

title: Iran-Contra Committees Approve the Final Report
description: The Congressional committees on the Iran-contra affair approved a final report today concluding that President Reagan was responsible for allowing the normal processes of Government to be disregarded, committee members said.

title: Senator Simon Looks Strong, Says an Uncommitted Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo, who had for months hinted a preference for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis as the Democratic Presidential nominee, indicated today that he might not endorse Mr. Dukakis and expressed strong interest in Senator Paul Simon of Illinois.

title: Deal Signed To Fill Tower At Union Sq.
description: A major financial services concern, Integrated Resources Inc., signed a long-term lease yesterday to occupy all of the office space at Zeckendorf Towers, the 27-story office and apartment complex that dominates the Union Square area.

title: What Should the Neighbors Do?
description: It's all too common to hear the sounds of fierce battle in a neighbor's home - and not know quite what to do. Does one call the police? Or respect the family's privacy? The brief life of Elizabeth Steinberg, age 6, who died yesterday in New York, makes clear the answer: One calls the police.

title: New Report Shows More Cocaine in Howard Beach Victim's Body
description: The black man killed by a car in the Howard Beach incident had 10 times as much cocaine or its residue in his blood than originally reported, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Bonn Delays Sale Of Stake in VW
description: The West German Government said it was postponing the sale to the public of its 16 percent stake in Volkswagen A.G. as a result of a sharp plunge in the car maker's stock price during the recent rout on world stock markets. The Government's 4.8 million VW shares were worth 1.76 billion marks, or $1 billion, on Oct. 16, the Friday before world stock markets plunged. They have since lost more than a quarter of their value.

title: Budget Deficit Talks Shouldn't Be Adversarial
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSELEY HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes pre-tax charges of $2 million and $2,150,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, to establish a reserve for settlement related to securities litigation. c-Net income and includes tax credits of $174,000 and $327,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and pre-tax charges of $150,000 for the quarter and $200,000 for the 6 months.

title: MAINE PUBLIC SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a cumulative effect of accounting change of $830,300. c-After a charge of $943,674 from partial write-off of Seabrook interests for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: The year-ago first quarter includes a gain of $143,000 from the sale of assets in July 1986.

title: Minister With Wide-Ranging Goals
description: The Rev. Patricia Ann McClurg, the first female minister to head the National Council of Churches, was installed yesterday in Jacksonville, Fla., but amid the celebration that followed she was quick to say that her election did not signal the end to what she sees as a persistent problem of sexism in the nation's churches.

title: Fugitive Held In VW Case
description: A West German man sought in a currency exchange scheme that defrauded the auto maker Volkswagen A.G. of more than $280 million has been arrested in Hollywood, the F.B.I. and West German authorities announced today.

title: Aquino Doesn't Have Much Time
description: LEAD: A game of tragic consequences is being played out in the Philippines. It is played in the shadows, with the measure of who is ahead difficult to take either from Washington or Manila. In this game, American lives become pawns and American policy has little impact. And on its outcome hangs the future of a stable

title: A Pan Am Suitor Plans Huge Outlay
description: One of the groups seeking control of Pan American Airways plans to spend $320 million for an initial restructuring program if it wins control, one of the investors said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1987
description: International A3-13 Bonn ordered cuts in interest rates to accelerate its economy. Stocks and bonds rallied. The dollar plunged again, especially against the West German mark. Interest rates also were lowered by Britain and Switzerland and by American banks.

title: About Real Estate; New Haven Projects Built To Blend With Old Area
description: Turnbridge Crossing and Phoenix Landing, two condominium projects under construction diagonally across from one another in the Fair Haven area of New Haven, are going forward under design restraints meant to preserve the section's historic character.

title: KEY RATES
HYPONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Toyota U.S. Plant
description: The Toyota Motor Company plans to invest about $200 million to build engines and axles in addition to cars at its new Kentucky plant site, a published report said. The Louisville Courier-Journal, quoting unidentified sources, said Japan's leading auto company's planned addition to its plant near Georgetown, Ky., could create up to 500 jobs. Toyota said today that it will make a ''major announcement regarding operations'' at the plant on Monday.

title: Tokyo Helm: A New Style
description: Noboru Takeshita's supporters, recognizing that there are widely shared doubts about his abilities, are offering him up as a potential Harry Truman of Japan. There are surface resemblances. Like Truman, Mr. Takeshita will take over as Japan's Prime Minister on Friday in an atmosphere of lowered expectations.

title: Posner Cedes At Sharon Steel
description: Victor Posner, the financier facing a prison term for tax evasion, has agreed with the Sharon Steel Corporation's creditors to give up control of the bankrupt steelmaker.

title: Elsa de Brun Is Dead; Signed Art as Nuala
description: Elsa de Brun, who painted under the Gaelic name of Nuala, died last night at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old and had suffered from Alzheimer's disease.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $11,540,000 for the quarter and $15,035,000 for the year; the quarter also includes an extraordinary gain of $13.1 million from the sale of tax benefit leases acquired in prior years. c-After an extraordinary credit of $3,259,000 for the quarter and the year; the quarter also included a one- time charge of $7.6 million for an environmental contingency.

title: Deaver Hired to Influence Dole, Witness Says
description: A former vice president of Trans World Airlines testified today that a few weeks after Michael K. Deaver left his top White House post in 1985, T.W.A. hired him as a lobbyist to ''make direct contact'' with Secretary of Transportation Elizabeth Hanford Dole. Mr. Deaver was a former White House deputy chief of staff.

title: PRATT & LAMBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Oct. 1.

title: VITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $63,000 for the quarter and $92,000 for the 9 months.

title: U.S. and Mexico in Trade Pact
description: The United States and Mexico will sign a trade accord on Friday that falls considerably short of the more comprehensive commercial agreement that both sides had envisioned when they began negotiations earlier this year.

title: Social Security Brought Up In the Deficit Talks Again
description: A proposal to reduce Social Security cost-of-living increases came up again today in talks on reducing the Federal deficit. Several negotiators said that such a cut, although politically touchy, was the key to reaching a serious agreement.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 6, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Grey Profits Up 20.8%
description: Grey Advertising yesterday reported its third-quarter earnings. Net income rose 20.8 percent, to $2.9 million, or $1.48 a share, from $2.4 million, or $1.32 a share. Revenues were $76.4 million, up 23.6 percent from the $61.8 million in the period last year.

title: Art People
description: Awaiting Schnabels

title: Hal Riney Is Chosen By Good Housekeeping
description: Good Housekeeping magazine has selected Hal Riney & Partners, New York, to handle its advertising after a monthlong, four-way competition. The budget is in the $1.5 million to $2 million range. Baron & Zaretsky was the agency for the last three years.

title: GENERAL SCIENCES reports earnings for Year to July 31
Einstein Manuscript
description: Sotheby's will auction on Dec. 2 a 72-page unpublished manuscript by Albert Einstein. The work has been described by John Stachel, professor of physics at Boston University and editor of the Einstein papers, as ''the most detailed review of the special theory of relativity that Einstein ever wrote.'' The undated manuscript, believed to have been written in 1911 or 1912, is said by physicists and scholars to be the earliest and longest Einstein manuscript on relativity known to exist, according to the head of Sotheby's rare books and manuscripts department, David Redden. Mr. Redden said he was told that the manuscript was acquired before World War I directly from Einstein by a member of the present owner's family. Sotheby's estimates the manuscript will bring $500,000 to $700,000.

title: RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1987
description: The Markets

title: In Poll, Confidence Slips Little
description: Despite widespread fear that the stock market collapse will lead to a recession, overall public confidence in the national economy has slipped very little in the last two weeks, a New York Times Poll shows.

title: Pretoria Frees A Black Leader Jailed 23 Years
description: A longtime leader of the outlawed African National Congress was freed today by the Government after 23 years in prison.

title: Banks Cut Prime Again, To 8 3/4%
description: The nation's leading banks yesterday lowered their prime lending rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 8 3/4 percent, reflecting the Federal Reserve's continuing efforts to contain the negative effects of last month's plunge in stock prices.

title: WEINBERGER, AS EXPECTED, RESIGNS POST
description: President Reagan today accepted the resignation of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, a friend and trusted adviser for 20 years, and nominated Frank C. Carlucci, his national security adviser, as Mr. Weinberger's successor.

title: ENVIROPACT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated.

title: People
description: * Suzanne M. Tongue has been promoted to senior vice president and management supervisor at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL FAVORS DIRECT TALKS
description: A State Department official expressed hope tonight that the announcement that Nicaraguan officials were prepared for indirect negotiations with contra leaders meant that direct talks would begin soon.

title: Drop Seen In Demand For Steel
description: American steelmakers, who have enjoyed higher prices and a return to profitability for much of this year, face a downturn in demand because of the collapse of stock prices, some steel analysts and economists predicted yesterday.

title: Program on AIDS Is Aimed at Heterosexuals
description: ''AIDS: Changing the Rules'' is aimed at heterosexuals. Are they at risk from acquired immune deficiency syndrome? If so, what can they do about it? The one-hour program, on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, presents Ron Reagan, the model Beverly Johnson and the salsa star Ruben Blades, followed by a discussion among public-health experts. The principal message is that heterosexuals should use condoms.

title: CHEMICAL LEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 4
Film: 'Slamdance,' With Tom Hulce
description: WAYNE WANG, the gifted Chinese-American film maker (''Chan Is Missing,'' ''Dim Sum''), goes straight if quite gracefully to the bottom with his first mainstream movie, ''Slamdance,'' a Los Angeles-based tale of corruption and cover-up that's less interesting for its characters than for its fancy decor and images.

title: Arsonists Damage Haiti Ballot-Printing Plant
description: The wave of violence aimed at disrupting Haiti's first elections in 30 years continued this morning with arsonists heavily damaging one of the main printing plants for producing ballots.

title: 12 Tamils Reported Killed, 150 Captured in Indian Drive
description: Indian troops killed 12 guerrillas and captured 150 in their drive to disarm Tamil separatists in northern and eastern Sri Lanka, the state radio said today.

title: The Board of Education Surrenders to Janitors
description: Imagine reading that a large New York corporation had signed a contract with its janitors union and that under the terms of the contract the janitors were given virtual control over the corporation's physical plant.

title: Carlucci a Tough Pragmatist in Pentagon's Corner
description: When President Reagan was considering several ideas about how to retaliate against Iran's attack on a Kuwaiti tanker flying the American flag last month, he accepted the option proposed by his national security adviser, Frank C. Carlucci.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: LOOKING like someone ready for a quiet evening in front of a television set, Bill Cosby sauntered into the spotlight in the Waldorf-Astoria ballroom in baggy gray pants and an orange and blue crew neck sweater. He was not unaware that his audience - more than 900 people at a dinner-dance benefiting the New York City Mission Society - was a sea of black ties and sequins.

title: WARWICK INSURANCE MANGERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment gains of $81,287 for the quarter and $332,598 for the 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $86,390 for the quarter and $566,585 for the 9 months.

title: FILM: 'RUSSKIES,' A COMEDY ADVENTURE
description: ALL the dopey, daffy, dizzy fun of glasnost is captured by ''Russkies,'' the heartburning adventure-comedy that opens today at the Manhattan Twin and other theaters.

title: SHOPSMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The year-ago figures reflect a change in accounting methods.

title: Moseley Set To Shed Unit
description: The Moseley Holding Corporation said yesterday that it would quit the retail brokerage business and seek a buyer for that part of its operations because of mounting trading losses.

title: Commercial Drivers and Drink
description: A panel of the National Academy of Sciences has called for tighter penalties against commercial bus and truck drivers who are found to be drinking, urging license suspensions even when a small amount of alcohol use is discovered.

title: Philip C. Katz
description: The nation's oldest Medal of Honor winner, Philip C. Katz, who was awarded the medal for rescuing a wounded comrade under fire in World War I, died here on Oct. 29, a month short of his 100th birthday.

title: UNIVERSAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $4.5 million related to consolidation of facilities and inventory adjustments.

title: Polish Police to Question Walesa And Others Opposing Referendum
description: The Polish authorities, apparently concerned over a Solidarity appeal for a boycott of a national referendum, have ordered eight people who signed the appeal, including Lech Walesa, to report for police questioning.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Fed Reins May Stay Loose
description: The Federal Reserve, in its efforts to head off a recession, may have to keep pouring lavish amounts of money into the economy for several months, various economists and other analysts maintain.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Moscow dispatch on Monday about Tass's coverage of the threat by a Politburo member to resign described Western reporting on the case incorrectly in some editions. At least two Western newspapers, The Christian Science Monitor and El Pais of Madrid, reported on some elements of the episode a day before Friday, when The New York Times published its account.

title: IN HOSPITAL COURTROOM, PLEA FOR FREEDOM
description: The first person hospitalized under a new effort to remove mentally ill homeless people from Manhattan streets told a state judge yesterday that she was a ''professional'' street person, well able to care for herself, and longing to get ''back to the streets.''

title: Black Youth Is Beaten Outside a High School
description: A black high school student in Brooklyn was beaten Wednesday during what the police are describing as a racially motivated attack.

title: SCEPTRE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sine Nomine Singers
description: Sine Nomine Singers are to present a concert of music by Monteverdi tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. Tickets are $12. Information: 362-8719.

title: Joel Barnet Steinberg
description: The portrait of Joel Barnet Steinberg, who has been charged with the beating death of his 6-year-old adopted daughter in their Greenwich Village town house, is an incomplete image of an intense and complex man who closely shielded his inner life.

title: On 7th Ave., Fashion Is Lively and Exotic
description: Classic American styles, exotic African themes and echoes of the 1960's appear in Seventh Avenue collections as the week of spring and summer fashion openings enters the homestretch.

description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $149,865 from discontinued operations.

title: Exploding Star Studied By High-Altitude Fleet
description: Hoping to peer deeper than ever before into the mystery-shrouded core of an exploding star, astrophysicists have begun launching an armada of instrument-laden aircraft, balloons and rockets over Australia and New Zealand.

title: A GOSPEL-FILLED WEEKEND AT THE TRIPLEX
description: THOSE theatergoers who were fortunate enough to attend the Lee Breuer-Bob Telson musical ''The Gospel at Colonus'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's 1983 Next Wave Festival are not likely to forget the role played by the legendary gospel singer Clarence Fountain. In this retelling of Sophocles' ''Oedipus at Colonus,'' set in a black Pentecostal church, the blind singer and his group, the Original Five Blind Boys of Alabama, collectively sang the role of Oedipus, the sightless exiled king of Greek tragedy, who achieved redemption and enlightenment at the end of his tormented journey.

title: Welfare-Reform Bill Imperils Long-Won Gains; Encourages Workfare
description: To the Editor:

title: STORAGE EQUITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $1,995,200 on the sale of real estate. The company said net income in the 1986 third quarter was higher than normal because of a one-time reduction in the advisory fee in the amount of $450,000.

title: BLOCK DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Central American Peace Accord Goes Into Effect
description: Central American governments announced a series of measures today to be carried out over the next two months to comply with a new regional peace treaty.

title: Import Quotas
description: An international trade tribunal has ruled that some Japanese import quotas on food are illegal, and the United States is expected to use the ruling to put pressure on Tokyo to end other farm-trade barriers, American trade officials said today. The ruling by a three-member panel established by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade was said to have been quietly conveyed to Tokyo and Washington this week.

title: Welfare-Reform Bill Imperils Long-Won Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: The number of baseball players filing for free agency grew to 47 yesterday when Bill Almon of the Mets, Steve Garvey of the San Diego Padres and Dennis Martinez of the Montreal Expos added themselves to the list. Martinez, the former Baltimore star, made a strong comeback with an 11-4 record for the Expos. . . . Joe Cowley, the former Yankee pitcher, has signed a Class AAA contract with the Philadelphia Phillies. . . Missouri Coach Woody Widenhofer pleaded guilty Thursday to driving while intoxicated, saying he wanted to put the matter behind him. Widenhofer, 44, was fined $500 and told that $100 of the fine would be suspended if he completed an alcohol-related traffic offense program within 90 days. Widenhofer was arrested for speeding at a Columbia intersection early on the morning of Oct. 11, just hours after the Tigers' football team defeated Kansas State.

title: New Toy Job For Backer
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates, the agency for Fisher-Price's Little People playsets, has now been named to promote some related fun things to the young of the nation. New World Video and Marvel

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Pentagon After Weinberger: Cuts and Restraints
description: Caspar W. Weinberger's legacy to the military, after seven years in which the Pentagon spent a total of $2 trillion, appears to be a future in which budgets will expand slowly or not at all.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MAKERS OF THE NEW: The Revolution in Literature, 1912-1939. By Julian Symons. 295 pages. Random House. $19.95.

title: Soybeans Up Sharply; Soviet Rumor a Factor
description: Soybean oil and soybean meal futures soared at the Chicago Board of Trade today on rumors that the Soviet Union had bought a large quantity of American soybean meal. Meal for December delivery jumped $6, to $183.60 a ton, off its high for the session of $186.50.

title: FGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $56,000 and $807,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the quarter also includes a $2.2 million writeoff in connection with the company's conversion from a mainframe to a micro-mini-based computer system. c-Include realized investment gains of $1,000 for the quarter and $542,000 for the 9 months.

title: STEVENS GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said 1986 figures pro forma to include acquisition of Hamilton Tool in December 1986.

title: Officer Is Guilty Of Taking Bribe In 77th Precinct
description: A suspended 30-year-old police officer from the 77th Precinct in Brooklyn was convicted last night of taking a $500 payoff from an undercover investigator pretending to be a drug dealer. She was also convicted of official misconduct.

title: Sports of The Times; WHERE FLUTIE BELONGS
description: IN the fourth quarter of last Monday night's game, Ed (Too Tall) Jones deflected two of Phil Simms's passes as the Dallas Cowboys rallied for a 33-24 victory. Too Tall was too much for the Giants' quarterback. But as Doug Flutie watched television in his Natick, Mass. home, he shook his head.

title: Brazil and Its Creditors Reach Debt Agreement
description: Brazil reached an agreement last night with its bank creditors on a plan to make past-due interest payments on its foreign debt.

title: Gores See Hollywood Leaders On Issue of Lewd Rock Lyrics
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr., a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, and his wife, Tipper, appeared privately before entertainment industry leaders in Los Angeles last week to discuss Mrs. Gore's campaign against pornographic rock lyrics.

title: POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $12,068,000 for the quarter and $42,236,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary gains of $7,784,000 for the quarter and $77,568,000 for the 9 months.

title: New York City Raises Offering to $750 Million
description: Strong investor demand led New York City to increase the size of its bond sale to $750 million, from $600 million, and allowed securities dealers to reduce interest rates a tenth of a percentage point for some maturities.

title: ACTION AUTO STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an accounting change gain of $241,172.

title: David L. Goldring
description: David L. Goldring, a stockbroker, died Tuesday at his home in Litchfield, Conn. He was 44 years old and also lived in Manhattan. His wife, Nancy, said the cause of death was undetermined.

title: ACCOUNTS
description: * Brown Egg Council of New England to Theodore J. Charron Advertising.

title: Lebanese Begin a General Strike
description: Lebanese began a general strike today to protest the 12-year-old civil war and the nation's economic crisis.

title: M.I.T., Pressed by U.S., Won't Buy Computer
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology said yesterday that it was canceling plans to buy a multimillion-dollar supercomputer after Federal officials strongly objected to the prospect that the university might buy Japanese technology.

title: SERVICE FRACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
N.F.L. Matchups; Surprise: Colts and Chargers Spotlighted
description: If there is a game that symbolizes the utter futility in predicting how National Football League teams will do based on last year's record, it is the San Diego-Indianapolis affair Sunday. It is a battle of division leaders, no less.

title: Art: Sigmar Polke's Witty Disappearing Act
description: THE career of Sigmar Polke, a well-known West German painter whose art was a focal point of the most recent Venice Biennale, is being revealed to the New York art public in bits and pieces. Over the past three years, there have been three shows of Mr. Polke's recent paintings, one at the Marian Goodman Gallery and two at the Mary Boone Gallery. The latest installment, at the newly opened David Nolan Gallery in SoHo, is a large survey of drawings and watercolors from the 1960's, when Mr. Polke, then in his 20's, was just starting to exhibit his work.

title: MONTANA SPECTACLE A DUD
description: The annual spec-tacle of hundreds of bald eagles con-verging on Glacier National Park to feast on spawning salmon is proving to be a dud this year, park officials said, with the number of eagles down 80 per-cent and salmon almost nonexistent. Riley McClelland, wildlife biologist for Glacier Park, cited the unusually warm fall. Park officials say they do not know why the salmon run has dropped off so precipitously.

title: MEDCO CONTAINMENT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results have been restated to reflect the merger of Porex Technologies Corp. into Medco and a 5-for-2 stock split in October.

title: Contra Leaders Term Move a Victory
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders tonight greeted the news that Managua has agreed to negotiate with them indirectly as a major political victory that vindicates their six-year war against the Sandinista Government.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Curren Upsets Mecir: Kevin Curren used his big serve to upset the No. 1 seeded player, Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, in the second round of the $840,000 Paris Open yesterday. Curren, a native of South Africa now living in Austin, Tex., beat the world's fifth-ranked player, 7-5, 6-4, serving nine aces and numerous service winners. Curren next meets Brad Gilbert of the United States in the quarterfinals. Gilbert, seeded No. 7, beat Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-2. Yannick Noah of France, seeded third, struggled to beat Mansour Bahrami of Iran, 7-6, 6-4. Noah was hampered by a pulled abdominal muscle and applied ice to it during the changeovers. In another match, Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands defeated Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3. (AP) Grabb Rolls On: Jim Grabb of Tucson, Ariz., continued his winning ways in the $525,000 Stockholm Open-Scandinavian championships yesterday, outlasting Sergio Casal of Spain to reach the quarterfinals. Grabb, who upset Mats Wilander Wednesday, won, 7-6, 4-6, 6-3 in a match that lasted 2 hours 39 minutes. It was the third tiebreaker for Grabb in three matches, and he has won them all. Martin Laurendeau of Canada was another surprising quarterfinalist. He beat Christian Bergstrom of Sweden, 7-6, 6-4. Also reaching the round of eight was Matt Anger of the United States, who surprised fifth-seeded Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, 6-3, 3-6, 6-1. McNeil Gains: Fifth-seeded Lori McNeil of Houston easily defeated unseeded Anne Hobbs of England, 6-2, 6-1, in a 58-minute, second-round match yesterday at the $250,000 Virginia Slims of New England championships. West Germany's Eva Pfaff defeated Hu Na of San Diego, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4. Golf Europeans Top U.S.: Sandy Lyle, Jose-Maria Olazabal and Nick Faldo led a European team to a 7-5 victory over the United States yesterday in the first round of the $950,000 world championship at Inagi, Japan. Japan and Australia-New Zealand tied, 6-6, on the first of three days of round-robin play among six-member teams representing the four major Professional Golf Association tours. The two best-scoring teams on the first three days will compete Sunday for the $360,000 first prize. The remaining two teams will play for third place. In yesterday's matches, Lyle defeated Lanny Wadkins, 68-72, Olazabal edged Scott Simpson, 68-69, and Faldo, the 1987 British Open champion, beat Curtis Strange, 70-73. Bernhard Langer of the European team and Mark Calcavecchia of the United States tied at five-under-par 67. Payne Stewart, who beat Ian Woosnam, 68-71, and Tom Kite, who beat Ken Brown, 68-71, were the American winners. Each victory counts 2 points, a tie 1 point. (AP)

title: Dollar Dips Still Lower In Tokyo
description: Despite repeated intervention by the Bank of Japan to prop up its value, the dollar dipped briefly today to a new postwar low of 134.40 yen.

title: PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Chrysler Closes Troubled Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation has closed its Bramalea, Ontario, assembly plant indefinitely to correct quality problems with the Premier car it inherited from the American Motors Corporation and Renault.

title: Film: 'Made in Heaven,' a Love Story
description: HEAVEN is the place where movie directors go to test their whimsy, and Alan Rudolph's whimsy doesn't need testing - he's got fancifulness to spare. In ''Made in Heaven,'' which opens today at the Manhattan Twin and other theaters, Mr. Rudolph envisions a sweetly colored alternative to a black-and-white world. Mike (Timothy Hutton) is leaving behind a life of almost comical bleakness when he dives into a river to save a woman and her children, losing his own dreary life in the process. The film blossoms into pastels when Mike arrives in a place where the decor is inviting, the scenery can be changed at will, and one's full potential can be realized in a wink. Mike's Aunt Lisa, with whom he is happily reunited, has developed into quite a good painter during her stay there.

title: TEJON RANCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rabid Calf Causes Shortage Of Vaccine in El Paso, Tex.
description: Health officials said Wednesday that they used up the city's supply of rabies vaccine to inoculate more than 100 people who might have come in contact with a school farm's rabid calf.

title: TRACOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Film: 'Hello Again'
description: ''HELLO AGAIN'' is a high-concept comedy with a terminally low laugh content. This may be why the ads, which publicize the gimmick, are slightly funnier than the movie that must dramatize it.

title: PERCEPTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Antique Collectors Lured by Reels
description: IN recent years, antique angling gear and associated memorabilia, including old catalogues, fishing and hunting magazines and prints, have become hot items for collectors.

title: SANDINIST AS AGREE TO INDIRECT TALKS ABOUT CEASE-FIRE
description: In a step that could lead to a breakthrough in the Nicaraguan conflict, the Sandinista Government announced today that it was prepared to negotiate indirectly with rebel leaders on a cease-fire.

title: Big Paper Concern Fills Operating Post
description: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation announced yesterday that James G. Crump Jr. had been named executive vice president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 1.

title: Biaggi Is Given A Prison Term Of 30 Months
description: Mario Biaggi was sentenced yesterday to 30 months in prison and fined $500,000 for accepting an unlawful gratuity - vacations at a Florida spa - and obstructing justice.

title: National Horse Show; Spirited Puissance Ends in a Tie at 7-5
description: The National Horse Show's $10,000 puissance stake, an event that pits horse and rider against a wall far too tall to be seen over, was so diligently contested last night at Madison Square Garden that four jumpoff rounds were needed before two co-champions - Buddy Brown on Aramis and Nick Skelton on Raffles Apollo - emerged.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ONE of the new productions on the Broadway theater district's Restaurant Row is called Grand Sea Palace (346 West 46th Street, 265-8130). The theme of this pleasant-looking turquoise-colored establishment is Thai, although the plot gets awfully muddled when they offer everything from pasta primavera to salade Nicoise.

title: Moderate Activity Said to Cut Heart Deaths in Men at Risk
description: Middle-aged men at high risk of heart disease who engage in moderate physical activities such as walking, gardening, yard work and swimming reduce their chances of death from heart attack by one-third, a new study has found.

title: Jets Are Hoping To Hold the Line
description: After watching their replacements turn a 2-0 record into a 3-2 slump, the Jets' regulars came back from the strike last month and drew the line. Washington crossed it. Last Sunday, the Jets drew another line, and Indianapolis crossed it.

title: MEESE'S WIFE WRITES TO A JUDGE IN PRAISE OF CONVICTED FRIEND
description: The wife of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d wrote a letter to a Federal judge last June in which she and ''my husband, Ed'' praised the son of a Tennessee Congressman, who was awaiting sentencing after his conviction for tax fraud.

title: Custody of Boy Awarded To His Father's Gay Lover
description: A judge today awarded custody of a 16-year-old youth to his late father's homosexual lover, saying this was what the youth wanted and that it would give him the ''stable and wholesome environment'' his mother could not provide.

title: Film: 'Fire And Ice'
description: ''FIRE AND ICE'' must be the fanciest skiwear commercial ever made. Willy Bogner, who designed the costumes as well as directed, produced and wrote this fashion show, belongs to a prominent West German ski apparel family. He also filmed the ski scenes for a couple of James Bond movies. ''Fire and Ice,'' which opens today at the U. A. Eastside Cinema and Cine 1, runs only 83 minutes, but unless you have a thing for snow, it's endless winter.

title: Sailor Finishes Global Course in Growing Up
description: At the time, the choice seemed simple. Eighteen-year-old Tania Aebi was a rebellious teen-ager, a high-school graduate with no plans for the future who was working as a bicycle messenger in Manhattan. Her father gave her an unusual option: he would send her to college or he would buy a small boat for her to sail around the world.

title: Utilities Panel Won't Let Lilco Raise Its Rates
description: The State Public Service Commission said today that it would not grant the Long Island Lighting Company a rate increase this year and suggested that Lilco abandon its effort to open the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TABBACO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $219,000 for the quarter and $319,000 for the 6 months; the 6 months also includes a gain of $585,000 from reversion of a pension surplus. c-After a charge related to a tax loss carryforward of $70,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $82,000 for the 6 months.

title: Market Place; Stocks to Buy Now, Perhaps
description: ROBERT DAVID, a New York advertising executive, is not about to forsake the purchase of securities, despite the October market plunge. ''I probably will increase my holdings in some mutual funds, those that basically do long-term investing,'' he said.

title: INTERNATIONAL HYDRON reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $32,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $288,000 for the 9 months.

title: OAK HILL SPORTSWEAR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tor Halvorsen
description: Tor Halvorsen, chairman of Norway's 780,000-member Federation of Trade Unions, died of cancer on Wednesday. He was 56 years old.

title: A Money Manager's Long Day
description: J. Richard Walton, a professional money manager who invests in American stocks, is now beginning his business days with a 6 A.M. telephone call to London from his home in Irvington, N.Y. Yesterday he learned that Japanese institutions were selling American stocks and that the dollar was once again under attack in the currency markets - factors he would have to consider in deciding whether to buy or sell stocks during one of the most turbulent times in financial history.

title: Penguins Catch Islanders
description: The conventional wisdom holds that the Pittsburgh Penguins will go as far as Mario Lemieux takes them. Tonight, with Lemieux gone after one period, the Penguins followed an improbable route to a 4-2 victory over the Islanders.

title: Film: 'Steel Dawn'
description: EARLY in ''Steel Dawn,'' a mysterious fighting man (Patrick Swayze) arrives at a hardpressed frontier farm run by a beautiful widow (Lisa Niemi), who has a spunky little son (Brett Hool), who soon grows attached to the stranger. No, the mysterious fighting man's name is not Shane; it is Nomad. And it is not the Old West; it is the new post-nuclear-war world beloved of new movie makers. Meridian is a barren place, but close enough to civilization so hard-working Ms. Niemi can maintain her million-dollar hairdo and her curve-fitted designer wardrobe.

title: ROBINSON WILL RECEIVE &26 MILLION FROM SPURS
description: He didn't get a promotion, but David Robinson got a big, a very big, raise yesterday.

title: College Football Notebook; Two Running Backs Who Are Making Big Gains
description: Mike Gottfried, the head coach at Pitt, is not one to fuss. He is indifferent to Craig Heyward's weight, although he suspects it may be more than the advertised 260 pounds, maybe as much as 275.

title: Devils Rebound on Home Ice
description: The Devils came back strong tonight after their worst game of the season two nights ago, for a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Blues.

title: Sports People; Nordique Suspended
description: Gord Donnelly, a Quebec Nordiques defenseman, has been suspended for five games by the National Hockey League after a match penalty he received in a game against the Boston Bruins Oct. 29.

title: ARMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a restructuring charge of $47.1 million.

title: Art: Religious Works By Michael Tracy
description: ''MICHAEL TRACY: Terminal Privileges,'' currently at P. S. 1, and ''John McCracken: Heroic Stance.'' in the same galleries last year, are complementary shows. In both, the curator Edward Leffingwell has focused attention on an artist outside New York whose career defines a forceful and fertile response to Abstract Expressionism. Mr. McCracken's planks have something of the purity of the paintings of Barnett Newman, but they are cooler and less metaphysical, and his sculptural surface or skin is seamless and impenetrable.

title: 15 Horses Die in Gary Fire
description: At least 15 horses were killed Wednesday when fire swept through a stable, but as many as 18 others were led to safety by nearby residents, fire officials said.

title: PATTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday IMPASSIONED TANGO

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $8,571,000 from premiums to refund high-cost debentures. c-After an extraordinary charge of $4 million from the sale of a distribution unit.

title: ALBA-WALDENSIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,447,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $258,821 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: BIOMEDICAL DYNAMICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Trade Panel Urges Curbs on Japan
description: A Reagan Administration trade committee recommended today that the Government retaliate against Japanese exports after negotiations broke down with Tokyo over foreign participation in Japanese construction projects, Administration officials said.

title: British and U.S. Unions To Cast 'Carrie' Equally
description: Officials of the American and British actors' unions announced yesterday an agreement to share equally in the casting of the musical ''Carrie.''

title: Piecemeal Peace in Central America
description: Never mind the conflicting signals buzzing around Central America as the first phase of a regional peace plan came into effect yesterday. No single piece of good news or pessimism can do justice to what is now happening in five nations, three of them bloody battlegrounds.

title: Washington Talk: Profile: John C. Stennis; PLOWING A STRAIGHT LINE TO THE END OF THE ROW
description: As the overnight train from the Deep South pulled into Union Station, a tall, spare gentleman of 46 years descended the steps, his right hand raised in greeting to his new home. Within hours John Cornelius Stennis of Mississippi was sworn into office as the newest United States Senator. That was Nov. 5, 1947. He is still here 40 years later, chairman of the all-important Senate Appropriations Committee. But at 87 he is an increasingly frail man, forced to use a wheelchair after amputation of one leg a few years ago, a casualty of a battle with cancer.

title: Sports People; Shelton Jones Back
description: For three seasons, Shelton Jones, a 6-foot-9-inch forward from Amityville, L.I., has been making versatile but generally undervalued contributions to the basketball program at St. John's. Spotlights were focused on such teammates as Chris Mullin, Walter Berry, Mark Jackson and Willie Glass.

title: High Court Nominee Admits Using Marijuana and Calls It a Mistake
description: President Reagan's latest Supreme Court nominee, Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, saidtonight that he smoked marijuana once as a college student in the 1960's and on ''a few occasions'' in the 1970's.

title: Restaurants
description: GREAT SHANGHAI RESTAURANT is a bustling Chinatown spot that specializes in the maritime cuisine of the south called Soo-Hang. The extensive menu carries a little of everything, however, from the familiar to the exotic - and the overall quality is impressive.

title: Ladbroke Group's Offering Lags
description: Ladbroke Group P.L.C. said that only about 1.68 million of the 70.4 million new shares that it offered at 378 pence a share, about $6.61, had been taken up. The British property and leisure group's $:256 million, or about $448 million, offer was to help finance its $:645 million (about $1.13 billion) acquisition of the Hilton International Company hotel chain from the Allegis Corporation. Charterhouse Bank Ltd. was Ladbroke's adviser and underwriter for the issue and Charterhouse said subunderwriters would be informed of the extent of their take-up on Friday.

title: Edwards Journal; Black Tactic Is Adopted By White Mississippians
description: For years in this tiny speck of a town halfway between Jackson and Vicksburg, blacks outnumbered whites but whites controlled the town government. But by 1985 blacks had come to dominate local government, holding all five of the seats on the Town Council and the office of Mayor.

title: Dance Open House
description: Dance Theater of Harlem will hold its first open house of the 1987-88 season Sunday at 3 P.M. at the company's headquarters, 466 West 152d Street. Among the performers are Ellis Larkins, the jazz pianist; Marie Brooks's Caribbean Dance Theater, and Jennifer Chase, the soprano. Dedicated to the late Hector Tello, a member of the company's choreography workshop, the program will include a performance of Mr. Tello's ''Preludes.'' The monthly open-house program is underwritten by Philip Morris Inc. Information: 967-3470 or, on the day of performance, 690-2800.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Can Gorbachev Trust Us?
description: Hopping across the country, the question people keep asking me is, ''Can we trust Gorbachev?''

description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $80,000 and $148,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After an extraordinary loss of $29,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $108,000 for the year.

title: Treasury Issues Rise Sharply
description: Treasury note and bond prices rose sharply yesterday, as prospects of a more generous Federal Reserve policy and lower interest rates created strong demand by investors.

title: Washington Talk: Presidential Politics; THE BALANCE OF POWER MEANS A LOT OF FOOTWORK
description: It was, Bob Dole says, the worst 48 hours of his Presidential campaign.

title: Liang Shih-Chiu, a Shakespeare Translator, Dies
description: Liang Shih-chiu, a popular Chinese writer who devoted about 30 years to the translation of all of Shakespeare's works into Chinese, died Tuesday in a hospital here after suffering a heart attack, family members said today. He was 86 years old.

title: Time Saved, Time Lost, Time for a Sundial
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadway
description: The Roosevelts Are Coming

title: Thatcher Plea On U.S. Budget
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, after intervening in the American budget crisis with a message to President Reagan, said today that she was ''very anxious'' that the United States budget-cut talks succeed.

title: Senator Icon
description: ''Teddy came to see me the other day and he said he was really tired of being referred to as the younger brother of the President,'' John Kennedy grinned during a talk in Boston in October 1963. The new Senator from Massachusetts, the President said, was ''going out on his own. Instead of being Teddy Kennedy, now he is changing his name to Teddy Roosevelt.''

title: Suprema Picks Agency
description: Franznick & Cusatis has become the first agency for the Suprema Specialties Company, which makes Suprema Imported Parmesan and Pecorino Romano grated cheeses. Both products are distributed nationally. The promotion budget, the agency said, will be about $1 million. Print advertising, particularly in food publications, will be used, the agency said, and perhaps radio and television.

title: Byrd Expects Trade Action
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, predicted today that lawmakers would approve a trade bill before year-end. Mr. Byrd's statement on the

description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Exchange Student Says It With Tulips
description: When residents stroll in Ardmore's Central Park next spring, they will know that Gunilla Lonnqvist DeLang, a foreign exchange student from Sweden 20 years ago, was here.

title: TV Weekend; O'Hara Tale Opens Series Based on Short Stories
description: BEGINNING at 9 tonight on Channel 13, ''Tales From the Hollywood Hills'' is an umbrella title for a series of short-story adaptations, three this time around, more to come in other seasons. The premiere entry, adapted by Andy Wolk and directed by Paul Bogart, is John O'Hara's ''Natica Jackson.'' Next week there is Budd Schulberg's ''Table at Ciro's'' and the following week F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Pat Hobby Teamed With Genius.''

title: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 27 about the views of writers and scholars from Communist countries on recent changes in the Soviet Union and China incorrectly described the circumstances under which a Budapest statue of Stalin was removed in 1956. It was torn down by demonstrators, not by the authorities.

title: Rescue Democracy in Haiti
description: At the voting urns and in the streets, Haiti's people have declared themselves emphatically in favor of a free presidential election later this month. But Gen. Henri Namphy's ruling junta is not impressed. This week it showed itself, at best, barely willing to lift a finger to safeguard the democratic process. Once again, the democrats have the people but not the guns.

title: About New York; Family Violence: Seeking Answers By Sharing Pain
description: ''For me, it was a beautiful, beautiful day,'' one man recalled, ''the first time I've seen my daughter in eight months.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

description: The thrift converted from mutual to stock form in May.

title: After Circling Globe, Home Is the Sailor
description: For Tania Aebi, the young solo sailor from New York, yesterday was a time for exchanging the harsh realities of a global voyage for the make-believe world of a heroine.

title: Gore Steps Up Bid for Center in Race
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. is intensifying his efforts to cast the 1988 Democratic Presidential race as a contest between one moderate in the center of the party spectrum, himself, and five other candidates on the left.

title: A Way Is Reported Found To Activate the AIDS Virus
description: Scientists for the first time have demonstrated a mechanism that can activate the dormant AIDS virus in human cells placed in a test tube.

description: A report in the Business People column of Business Day on Thursday, about General Electric's sale of assets of its venture capital operation, misidentified the company that arranged the financing. It was the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

description: b-Net income The latest third quarter loss was attributed principally to a writedown of certain real estate in connection with a reduction in the activities of Turner Development Corp. and to losses of the company's Trans-Con subsidiary, which will no longer operate as a separate unit. The year-earlier periods' results have been restated to reflect the company's investment in an air cargo facility from the equity method of accounting to full consolidation.

title: Analysts Differ On Gold Safety
description: OCTOBER'S stock market plunge brought gold to center stage once more as individual investors and their advisers argue for and against it as an investment medium. Gold has traditionally been considered a safe haven when there is turmoil in the financial world and expectations of rising inflation - and some advisers therefore believe that this is the time for investors to begin or augment a gold buying program.

title: Debt Plan Allowed In Placid Oil Case
description: A Federal Bankruptcy Court judge has allowed the bank creditors of the Placid Oil Company, the Hunt brothers' company that owes $803 million, to file their own debt reorganization plan for the company. But Judge Harold Abramson said the banks could not solicit bids without Placid Oil's support because it would drive down the bid price. The banks had asked that they be allowed to use Shearson Lehman Brothers of New York to find a buyer.

description: Magic Johnson scored 10 of his 26 points in the fourth quarter, and A. C. Green added 21 tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers opened the defense of their championship with a 113-109 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: Illegal Aliens Slowly Finding Path to Citizenship
description: At the immigration office on Mill Street here, about 50 people gathered today to receive their temporary-residency cards, the first step in achieving citizenship under the amnesty law for illegal aliens.

title: Gephardt Trying to Jump-Start Stalled Campaign
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt is confronting one of the iron laws of politics: A candidate who is not going up is in grave danger of coming down.

title: Walcott Recovering
description: Jersey Joe Walcott, the former heavyweight champion, was reported to be in stable condition with a favorable prognosis yesterday at Howard University Hospital in Washington, after undergoing surgery Tuesday night to relieve pressure on his spinal cord.

title: In the Surreal World, Fashion Imitates Art
description: Like Montague and Capulet, high art and fashion are not supposed to keep company. Among people who see themselves as the guardians of high art, ''fashionable'' is the universal, boilerplated, multipurpose insult. ''Unfashionable,'' by contrast, is a brevet of integrity and can be conferred upon enterprises no matter how dingy.

title: Lawyer Indicted In the Slaying Of His Daughter
description: A Manhattan grand jury indicted a Greenwich Village lawyer yesterday in the murder of his 6-year-old adopted daughter, who died Thursday of a brain hemorrhage and other injuries suffered last weekend in what authorities called a savage beating.

title: Royals and Reds Trade
description: The Kansas City Royals and the Cincinnati Reds yesterday swapped starting pitchers and shortstops, all of whom had disappointing 1987 seasons.

title: UNITED BANKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes provisions of $11,057,000 for the quarter and $16,084,000 for the 9 months for loan and other real estate losses. c-Includes provisions of $6,804,993 for the quarter and $10,374,000 for the 9 months for loan and other real estate losses. The latest quarter provision also reflects expected losses incurred in United Bankers' previously announced plans to dispose of substantially all of its non-performing assets, along with a portfolio of performing loans.

title: CABINET OFFICIAL BIDS GINSBURG END HIGH COURT QUEST
description: With President Reagan's consent, Education Secretary William J. Bennett telephoned Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg today to urge him to withdraw from consideration for the Supreme Court, Administration officials said.

title: Pact on Milk Prices Is Termed Illegal
description: A recent price-setting agreement between a major Northeast dairy farmers' cooperative and a New York area milk dealers' group violates Federal antitrust laws and must be voided, the New York State Attorney General said yesterday.

Patents;
Changing the Style Of a Musical Score
description: LEAD: Manfred Clynes, who heads the Music Research Center in Sydney, Australia, was granted patent No. 4,704,682 this week for a computerized system of ''importing expressivity'' to a musical score. It is said that ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' could be reproduced to sound like the music of Mozart or other composers.

title: Trump Casinos' Design For New Housing Gains
description: Donald J. Trump, the casino owner and developer, received preliminary approval today to build a 1,200-unit housing project on the Boardwalk.

title: Senator Helms's Callousness Toward AIDS Victims
description: ''We have got to call a spade a spade,'' said Senator Jesse Helms in offering an amendment to the fiscal 1988 appropriations bill for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, ''and a perverted human being a perverted human being.'' Ironic comments, indeed, given the profound perversity of the policy his amendment advances.

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 35.

Meese's Wife Wins Backing
description: The chief White House spokesman said today that the wife of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d had ''every right'' to write a letter to a Federal judge in which she used her husband's name in seeking leniency for a Congressman's son convicted of tax fraud.

title: Lobbying For Safer Bunk Beds
description: IN Dayton, Ohio, Drew Harbur, 3 years old, was playing on the top of a bunk bed when he slipped between the slats designed to support the mattress. His body went through the space, but his head did not. A tragedy was averted only because his older brother was there and called for their mother.

title: MICKELBERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $4,756,000 representing that portion of the gain on the sale of the C&W Group that is allocable to 1987. c-Net loss d-Includes losses attributable to the C&W Group which was sold as of Dec. 31, 1986 of $570,000 and $803,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the year-ago quarter and 9-month revenues includes $8,717,000 and $26,434,000, respectively, attributable to the C&W Group. The company also said that the one- time after-tax gain on the Oct. 13, 1987 sale of the company's wholly owned advertising subsidiary, Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson Inc., is estimated at $1.40 to $1.60 a share; this gain, which had been previously announced as eligible for inclusion in the third quarter results, will be reported instead as a fourth quarter transaction.

Year-ago results are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: On Supreme Court Hearings; Unfair Code Words Against Judge Bork
description: To the Editor:

title: Jack L. Boulton, Buyer Of Art for Chase Bank
description: Jack L. Boulton, an arts adviser to the Chase Manhattan Bank, was found dead in his Chelsea apartment on Thursday by the police, who had been summoned by associates concerned about Mr. Boulton's absence from his office. Mr. Boulton was 43 years old and had been suffering from AIDS, according to colleagues. A spokesman for the Medical Examiner's Office said the exact cause of death had not yet been determined.

title: Pension Ruling In Texaco Case
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge ruled today that state employee pension boards holding Texaco stock could represent the company's equity shareholders committee as nonvoting, ex-officio members of the board.

title: Director Is Named For Holocaust Museum
description: Dr. David Altshuler, formerly a professor of Judaic studies at George Washington University, has been named director of A Living Memorial to the Holocaust - Museum of Jewish Heritage, which is to be built in Battery Park City in 1990, it was announced this week.

title: Cuba Still Broadcasting Radio Shows to Iowa
description: To the Editor:

title: Robinson Signs
description: David Robinson, the top pick in the 1987 National Basketball Association draft, signed a contract with the San Antonio Spurs yesterday that reportedly will pay him at least $24 million in eight years.

title: Sakharov Emerges, Freer but Still in Limbo
description: On a typical day, two or three supplicants find their way to the unmarked apartment of Andrei D. Sakharov.

title: Consumer Debt Spurts
description: Americans, borrowing heavily to purchase new cars, took out $6.06 billion in credit in September, the biggest increase in a year, the Government said today.

title: David Starobin
description: David Starobin, a guitarist and composer, is to present works by Michael Starobin, Schubert, Lukas Foss, Norma Beecroft and others tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. He is to be joined by Patrick Mason, a baritone; Susan Palma, a flutist; Linda Moss Eddy, a violist, and Timothy Eddy, a cellist. Tickets are $7.50 to $10. Information: 996-1100.

title:
Patents;
Monitoring the Flow Of Blood in the Brain
description: LEAD: A non-invasive method of measuring blood pressure and flow in the brain has been invented by Dr. Yoshiaki Omuia of New York, who serves with the Heart Disease Research Foundation and other institutions. He was granted patent No. 4,703,758 this week. Without the use of a needle, arteries are monitored on the left and right forehead.

title: Bridge:; Von Zedtwitz Knockout Play Lasted More Than One Year
description: An event that lasts more than a year is a great rarity, but one such was the 1986-87 Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, which ended Thursday night.

description: In the wake of the October stock plunge that had a shattering effect on markets around the world, global money managers have been devising new strategies.

title: Heroism Runs in the Family
description: Marty Lyons, the Jets' veteran defensive end, rejoined his teammates this afternoon after a weeklong stay in Alabama and told reporters of the harrowing early morning accident that his wife, Kelly, and their son, Marty Jr., survived last Saturday.

title: A FESTIVAL OF BOOKS BY OR ABOUT JEWS OPENS TOMORROW
description: The Jewish Heritage Book Festival - the largest literary bazaar devoted to books by Jews, or about Judaism or Jewish culture - comes to the Seventh Regiment Armory, on Park Avenue and 67th Street, tomorrow and Monday. More than a hundred publishers and booksellers are expected to be joined by scores of authors and performers.

title: Private Pilots to Get Freedoms at Los Angeles
description: An agreement in principle that would again guarantee that private pilots could make flights in good weather through a restricted zone in the Los Angeles area was reached yesterday by the Federal Aviation Administration and private pilot groups.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the International Business Machines Corporation's profit expectations incorrectly described the company's estimated relationship between revenue growth and earnings growth. Revenues would need to grow 4 to 6 percent next year before each dollar of revenue would result in an additional dollar of profit, the company said. Two years ago, a revenue increase of 13 to 15 percent was needed before profits would grow dollar for dollar.

Judging the Judge, and the President
description: By acknowledging that he has smoked marijuana, Douglas Ginsburg neither adds to nor subtracts from his qualifications for the Supreme Court. Whether or not he now withdraws from consideration, the episode tells a great deal about the President. Mr. Reagan has been more interested in pushing politics and punishing opponents than in appointing judges of compelling merit.

description: Georges Franju, a French film director and co-founder of the Cinematheque Francaise, died on Thursday in Paris. He was 75 years old.

description: The General Motors Corporation's experimental solar-powered car, the Sunraycer, has won the World Solar Challenge, a 1,950-mile race across the Australian continent. The company said the Sunraycer averaged about 40 miles an hour for the five-and-a-half-day event and finished 600 miles in front of its nearest competitor.

Lebanon Strike Vow Issued
description: Labor leaders vowed today to step up a two-day-old nationwide strike to protest runaway inflation, but some merchants and enterprises defied the stoppage, saying it was harmful to an already crippled economy. Some grocers, butchers, vegetable vendors and larger businesses resumed work in Beirut and other cities.

title: Student Credit Unions Change the Loan Picture; Income Tax Mechanism
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonn Urges U.S. to Cut Its Deficit To Help Stabilize World Markets
description: A day after West Germany's central bank succumbed to international pressures and lowered interest rates, German and other European officials challenged Washington to make the next move to stabilize world financial markets.

title: STAGE: 'OIL CITY SYMPHONY,' THE ETERNALLY STAGESTRUCK
description: For ''Oil City Symphony,'' Circle in the Square (Downtown) has been transformed into a high school gymnasium, complete with basketball hoops and hardwood floor. Bathed in the soft glow of nostalgia, this could be the setting for the senior prom scene in the movie, ''Peggy Sue Got Married.'' As the show begins, four musically inclined graduates of the 1960's have reunited to give a recital in honor of a favorite teacher.

title: PITTWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Financial Corporation Draws a Citicorp Offer
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, has submitted an offer to acquire the Financial Corporation of America, the troubled operator of the nation's largest savings and loan institution, a spokesman for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Rhetoric vs. Reality In the Ginsburg Case
description: The disclosure by President Reagan's nominee for the Supreme Court, Douglas H. Ginsburg, that he smoked marijuana in the 1960's and the 1970's has caught the President in one of the most difficult of political snares: the conflict between rhetoric and reality.

title: FIRST AMERICAN SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The bank converted to stock form in July 1987.

Both year-ago periods' results restated to reflect the Feb. 17 acquisition of First Bancshares Corp. of Illinois, which was accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: New Exxon Wells
description: The Exxon Corporation said it planned to increase its drilling activity in West Texas, with 350 new wells over two years. Randall Meyer, the president of the nation's largest oil company, said Exxon was trying to gradually rebuild its drilling program after the 1986 price collapse. While prices have ranged between $18 and $20 per 42-gallon barrel in recent weeks, they dipped below $10 a barrel last year.

description: b-Includes a pe-tax gain of $169,748,000 on the sale of the casino- hotel in Atlantic City. c-Net loss and after extraordinary losses from debt retirement of $19,642,000 for the quarter and $17,903,000 for the 9 months.

title: Film: 'Blind Trust,' A Canadian Thriller
description: In the men's room of a small coffee shop, a mannish-looking woman peeks from inside a stall and sees a burly security guard nuzzling a young blond waiter. These three will become central to the action of ''Blind Trust,'' an intelligent thriller by Yves Simoneau, a Canadian director, and the confusions of gender in the men's room give a clue that the story will resonate with tangled relationships and thwarted plans. We enter a mirror world of betrayed trust when an undercover policeman, on Government orders, persuades a just-released prisoner to rob an armored truck; the Government officials want some mysterious documents and the robbers will keep the cash. The prisoner, Theo, recruits his teen-age son, already a minor street-criminal, and his former cellmate, who now owns a theatrical scenery company. The cellmate brings in his old girlfriend.

title: WESTERN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Western S & L said its loan loss provisions for the latest periods totaled $13.7 million for the quarter and $41 million for the 9 months, compared with the year-ago quarter of $6.2 million and for the 9 months, $11.8 million.

title: Santiago Journal; Chile's Press Wonders: Just How Free Is Free?
description: In a recent interview, a freelance magazine writer asked a leading member of Chile's political opposition what he thought of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the President.

title:
Patents;
A Device to Control Computers by Voice
description: LEAD: A method and apparatus for voice control of a computer were patented this week for Texas Instruments Inc. of Dallas. A program is to be regulated by audible voice commands, and operations can be stopped and restarted.

title: Kasparov and Karpov End 10th Match Game in Draw
description: The 10th game of the world chess championship was drawn today after only 20 moves, at the suggestion of the champion, Gary Kasparov, who was playing White.

description: The Economy

title: The Right Way to Teach Children to Read
description: The education reform movement is dying.
