The latest 9 months also includes $5.1 million because of benefits from significant tax transactions.

title: Sergeant Is Suspended Over Report of Beating
description: A Bronx police sergeant was suspended Thursday night for ''failure to supervise and control'' an incident in September in which officers under his command were accused of beating a grocery store owner and a deliverer.

title: OSMONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Obstacles to Budget Compromise: the Case of the Harrier Jet
description: The word swept a Capitol Hill party Thursday celebrating the Marine Corps' birthday: Democratic and Republican leaders of the Armed Services Committees in both houses of Congress, meeting privately, were planning to end production of the corps' primary attack plane.

title: NASTA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago per share figures not available; the company went public in December 1986.

title: BABY BELLS MAY BID AGAINST A.T.& T.
description: Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene today allowed regional telephone companies to bid against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on a $25 billion Government telecommunications contract.

title: Interest Rates Increase a Bit
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose modestly yesterday as a larger-than-expected rise in employment during October cast doubt on expectations that weak economic activity would lead to lower interest rates later this year.

title: Student Credit Unions Change the Loan Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: Exchanges Seek Ways to Heal Split
description: The top executives of the New York Stock Exchange, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade held an unannounced breakfast meeting at the Big Board's Wall Street headquarters on Thursday to iron out the increasingly bitter differences over responsibility for the stock market crash two and a half weeks ago.

title: Recital: Elly Ameling in Works of 18 Composers
description: Elly Ameling is that certified rarity, a singer who knows what she does best and spends virtually an entire career refining a special talent. Although the Dutch soprano has occasionally ventured afield (Ilia in Mozart's ''Idomeneo'' in the 1970's, programs of concert arias and, more recently, a misguided recording of American popular tunes), her gifts have been mostly spent on the song recital. She deserves the music world's thanks for that. Returning to Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, she demonstrated the ability to shrink physical distances, to draw listeners close and establish a sense of community among strangers, something that cannot be taught in music schools.

title: Baseball, Si
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: 'Kids Like These,' About Down's Syndrome
description: The parents are told their newborn child is mentally retarded. The signs include slanted eyes, simian skin creases, flabby muscle tone. Using the term mongoloid, the doctor urges immediate institutionalization of the baby. Later, a specialized nurse describes an ''early intervention'' program intended to help victims of Down's syndrome, a chromosomal accident that occurs in one out of 800 births. She urges the parents to get started as quickly as possible.

title: 49ers Say No
description: A trade last Tuesday between the San Francisco 49ers and the Seattle Seahawks has been voided because Dave Wyman, a linebacker who had been sent to the 49ers, was suffering from a chronic shoulder injury that prevented him from passing San Francisco's physical examination.

title: Adoption of Slain Girl, 6, May Not Have Occurred
description: The Greenwich Village couple accused of beating Elizabeth Steinberg to death and neglecting their 16-month-old boy may not have adopted the two children, child welfare and law-enforcement authorities said yesterday.

title: Dance: Warsaw Ballet in 'Giselle'
description: It may be true that the Warsaw Ballet from Poland was seen for the first time in New York when it performed ''Giselle'' on Thursday night at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts at Lehman College.

title: Syracuse Receiver: New Start in Life
description: HOCKEY was Tommy Kane's favorite sport, but it was football in the United States that provided his avenue of escape from trouble on the streets of Montreal and what he said was probably a future in jail.

title: Rutledge Likely to Be on Run
description: The Giants' line that could not protect Phil Simms from pass-rushers or open holes for Joe Morris to scoot through now is attempting to band together for Jeff Rutledge at quarterback.

title: Anti-Boesky Lawsuit Loses
description: A Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit today that contended the arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky was liable for investment losses suffered by two people because of his illegal insider trading.

title: Argentina Gets Waiver For Emergency Loan
description: Argentina yesterday was granted a a waiver from meeting economic performance targets set by the International Monetary Fund, Treasury and international monetary officials said. , The waiver would allow Argentina to receive a $500 million emergency loan from governments around the world. The loan had been contingent upon continued compliance with the I.M.F. targets on inflation, interest rates, government spending and currency exchange rates. Argentina had met virtually none of those goals but has adopted new policies intended to bring it into compliance.

title: MASSBANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months' per share earnings was not available; the bank converted to stock form of ownership in May 1986.

title: A Twice-Dead Man, Alive, Faces Charges
description: A Brooklyn man who died twice - first of hepatitis, then of an accidental gunshot wound - has been arrested, very much alive, outside his Sheepshead Bay home and indicted by a Manhattan grand jury on insurance fraud charges.

title: Probation Employee Accused Of Housing Dozens of Aliens
description: A probationary investigator for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office was charged yesterday with harboring dozens of Mexican nationals who are in this country illegally in two houses he owns in the Greenpoint section of the borough.

title: HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax loss carryforward of $135,000.

title: U.S. Says Contra Aid Could Come If Sandinistas Don't Meet Accord
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were pleased by Nicaragua's willingness to negotiate a cease-fire because it enhanced the political stature of the American-backed rebels.

SANDINISTAS NAME CLERIC TO MEDIATE CEASE-FIRE TALKS
description: The Government today appointed Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, the Roman Catholic Primate of Nicaragua and a strong critic of Sandinista rule, to mediate in cease-fire talks between the Government and American-backed guerrillas.

title: Bottleneck for Foreign Stocks
description: As trading surged wildly in stock markets around the world in late October, American investment firms found that the already formidable job of settling trades in foreign stocks had become even more difficult.

title: Billy Williams Says No
description: A FIRST-BASE coach in baseball must know how to blink not only with one eye, but with two. These are among his essential functions, along with being nimble enough to dodge foul balls.

title: SOUTHSTATE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The thrift, which converted to stock form April 21, said the latest third quarter includes a $133,000 provision for possible loan losses and a $243,000 income tax provision, while the year- ago quarter had no provision for loan losses and an $8,000 income tax provision.

title: Group Buys Stake In Standard Brands
description: Investors led by Sid R. Bass and Lee M. Bass, two members of the wealthy Bass family of Texas, have purchased a 7.2 percent stake in the Standard Brands Paint Company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Bass group said it had paid $16.7 million for its 806,000 Standard Brands' shares, or an average of $20.17 a share. The group said the shares were acquired for investment purposes only.

description: b-Net income

title: With Prague, Glasnost Comes in a Fainter Echo
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's advocacy of extensive change in the Soviet Union is finding an echo even in Czechoslovakia, where until recently the very word ''reform'' had been under unofficial but rigorous ban.

title: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, Please Read This Article
description: LEAD: I was born in Brooklyn, lived a good part of my life there and, until recently, I liked to boast that I would die in Brooklyn. But three months ago, I was offered a situation in the city -the kind of situation that sane people do not pass up if they dream of living here - and I didn't look back.

title: Dr. Henry Young
description: Dr. Henry Young, a physician who practiced in Manhattan for more than 50 years and was an assistant professor of medicine at New York Medical College, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Bloomingburg, N.Y. He was 74 years old.

description: The most frenzied jumping event at the National Horse Show, last night's Gambler's Choice, came down to a flash finish as the last horse of the 27 entrants, Mill Pearl, was guided to victory by Joe Fargis of Southampton, L.I.

title: Salvadoran Guerrillas Attack, Rejecting Truce

title: Piano: Tcherepnin Program
description: To commemorate the 10th anniversary of Alexander Tcherepnin's death, the Tcherepnin Society sponsored a program of the composer's piano music, performed by Bennett Lerner, Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. Tcherepnin, born in St. Petersburg in 1899, lived in Paris, Chicago and New York and spent time in the Far East, marrying a Chinese pianist, Lee Hsien Ming. Forward-looking in many ways, he sought a kind of universal musical language, but his use of the pentatonic scale to evoke the East has today a charmingly dated, innocent quality about it. Whatever bits of chinoiserie or other folk elements flavor Tcherepnin's compositions, his works bear the distinctive stamp of Russian music.

title: More Saurian Than Simian

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Red Wings 3, Whalers 1: Brent Ashton scored the go-ahead goal midway through the second period and Joe Kocur added a goal in the third last night as Detroit defeated Hartford, 3-1. Greg Stefan turned back 28 shots for the Red Wings, who broke a four-game streak without a victory and moved to 6-5-2. Hartford, which had won five games and tied two since dropping the first five games of the season, fell to 5-6-2. (AP) Nordiques 4, Capitals 1: Michel Goulet scored on power plays in the first and third periods and set up Lane Lambert's goal late in the second as Quebec defeated Washington, 4-1, last night. The victory, which improved Quebec's overall record to 7-5-1, enabled the Nordiques to maintain the distinction of being the only team in the National Hockey League not to have lost on the road this season. Quebec has four wins and a tie away from home. Washington is 7-5-1.(AP) Golf Europeans Lead: Europe overwhelmed Japan, 10-2, yesterday to take the lead in the $950,000 World Championship of Golf in Inagi, Japan. The European team, which won the Ryder Cup in the United States in September, took the lead with 17 points, followed by Australia-New Zealand with 13 points, the United States with 10 and Japan with 8. The Australia-New Zealand team beat the Americans, 7-5, on the second of three days of round-robin play among six-member teams. The top two teams after three days of play will meet tomorrow for the $360,000 top prize.(AP) Skinner One Stroke Ahead: Val Skinner of the United States shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after the first round of the $350,000 Japan Classic in Hanno, Japan. Skinner had six birdies and one bogey on the 6,376-yard, par-72 Musashigaoka course, about 21 miles northwest of Tokyo. Tied for second at 68 were Ayako Okamoto, Yuko Moriguchi and Jane Geddes. The tournament is a Ladies Professional Golf Association event.(AP) Tennis Leconte Surprises Cash: Henri Leconte upset Pat Cash, 6-4, 6-7, 6-3, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the $840,000 Paris Open, leaving the tournament without any of its top four seeds in the semifinals. Cash, the second seed, followed top-seeded Miloslav Mecir, third-seeded Yannick Noah and fourth-seeded Andres Gomez to the sidelines. Noah defaulted yesterday because of a pulled stomach muscle, and Mecir and Gomez were eliminated earlier in the week. Tim Mayotte, seeded No. 5, defeated Amos Mansdorf of Israel, 6-4, 6-2. He will face Leconte. Brad Gilbert defeated Kevin Curren, 7-5, 6-4. Gilbert will meet Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands.(AP) Edberg Advances: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg overcame a slight hand injury to defeat Peter Lundgren, 6-1, 7-6, yesterday and set up an all-Swedish field in the semifinals of the $525,000 Stockholm Open. Edberg slipped on the court and injured his racquet hand. Anders Jarryd, Edberg's doubles partner, beat a Canadian qualifier, Martin Laurendeau, 6-2, 6-4, in another quarterfinal match. Earlier, Jonas Svensson beat Jim Grabb, 6-1, 6-3, and Magnus Gustafsson defeated Matt Anger 6-2, 6-4.(AP)

THE SEARCH FOR THE STATUS WINTER TAN
description: LEAD: ''GO west, young man,'' said Horace Greeley - which shows what he knew. Come November, Long Islanders go south -to the Caribbean, the Bahamas, the anything-but-Long-Island islands.

title: Ebbets Field Lives On
description: LEAD: Though it has been a couple of weeks since the final out of the World Series, the inhuman roar of the Minnesota Twins' Decibeldome still echoes in our ears. Visually, too, it was distressing to see the Series played on artificial turf. There were no familiar images and sounds to take into winter. As I watched, my thoughts drifted to the bright grass and true dirt of Ebbets

title: TEARS AND RIOTS, LOVE AND REGRETS
description: THE SIXTIES Years of Hope, Days of Rage. By Todd Gitlin. 513 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
MAGIC GOOD, BAD AND ROTTEN
description: LEAD: HECKEDY PEG By Audrey Wood. Illustrated by Don Wood. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95. (Ages 4 to 8) THE MOUNTAINS OF QUILT By Nancy Willard. Illustrated by Tomi dePaola. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8) THE PORCELAIN CAT By Michael Patrick Hearn.

title: Stage: Corporate Competition, in 'The Downside'
description: In ''The Downside'' by Richard Dresser (at the Long Wharf Theater), a new anti-stress drug is about to be introduced on the American market, and a New Jersey pharmaceutical company has speeded up production in order to beat its competition. Careers and lives are at stake. As one suspects, the drug itself has damaging side effects - the ''downside'' of the title.

title: Cutting At the Core
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Midwood Rallies, 20-19
description: Chris Davila scored two of his three touchdowns in the fourth quarter as Midwood rallied yesterday to beat South Shore, 20-19, in a game that broke a first-place tie in the Public School Athletic League's Brooklyn A Division I. Midwood's record is now 7-1, and it has a berth in the playoffs that start in two weeks.

title:
MUSIC;
ONE-ACT OPERAS DUE IN MADISON
description: LEAD: ''OPERA AT FLORHAM,'' a professional company in residence at Fairleigh Dickinson University here, will present a pair of unusual one-act operas, each preceded by a ''Living Libretto.''

title: VERIFICATION: WILL IT WORK?
description: Verification of the absence of mobile missiles such as the SS-20 is impossible (''Verification: Will It Work?'' by David Aaron, Oct. 11). Not just difficult - impossible. The reason is simple. No one in the West knows how many were produced or are being produced or how many assembly points and subcontractors are involved.

title: DINING OUT
description: DINING out in Wilton presents a challenge, and the paucity of restaurant choices is usually blamed on the town's prohibition of liquor sales in public places.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: Santos Passes to Record
description: Todd Santos became the National Collegiate Athletic Association career passing leader in Division I-A today, but his San Diego State team lost to Brigham Young, 38-21, in a Western Athletic Conference game.

title: In Orange County, a Plan to Build $22,800 Houses
description: In an area where new homes sell for more than $136,000, a rural housing agency says it will build 200 condominiums costing as little as $22,800 each for Orange County residents.

title: MOVIES
description: Cromwell Starring Richard Harris and Alec Guinness. Directed and written by Ken Hughes. 1970. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 139 minutes. $69.95. This is a large-scale movie that a critic called ''shapeless'' in 1970 when it came to theater screens. It is a truncated biography of Oliver Cromwell, who is portrayed as a last, if not only, angry man by Richard Harris.

title:
ART;
ARCHITECTURAL IMAGES IN ART
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH architecture is a highly developed art in its own right, its forms often find their way into other areas of creativity, such as painting and sculpture. Nine artists who incorporate architectural elements in their work are featured in ''Architecture as Image,'' the current exhibition at the Islip Art Museum in East

title: WILLIAMS'S 'STREETCAR' AT FESTIVAL IN MADISON
description: BLANCHE DuBOIS is one of the most extraordinary creations of a playwright's art, and it is gratifying to report that Ellen Barry is offering an enlightening, lucid view of this most cherishable role.

title: Wiretap Found on Phone of Bork Opponent
description: A wiretap has been discovered on a Harvard University law professor's telephone, and the professor said today that the surveillance might have led to public disclosure of his misgivings about Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, who ended his bid for Supreme Court today.

title: AGENCIES DRAW UP THEIR WISH LISTS
description: LEAD: THE holidays are coming and children across the state are making up their Christmas lists. The state's agencies are making up lists, too, although Christmas won't come for them until February, when Governor O'Neill submits his 1988 budget to the General Assembly.

title: FICTION
description: HEAVEN AND HELL. By John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The concluding volume of John Jakes's North and South trilogy takes place in the years immediately following the Civil War. Once again, the story centers on two families, the Hazards of Pennsylvania and the Mains of South Carolina, who become embroiled in the bitter social and political disputes of Reconstruction. By and large, the Hazards prosper: George returns to the family ironmongering business and his brother Stanley rises within the Republican Party while profiting financially from the ruin of the Confederacy. The Mains, who fought on the losing side, find life more difficult. Orry Main's widow, Madeline, struggles to save the family plantation while combating racial prejudice and the enmity of her brother-in-law Cooper. Devastated by the death of Augusta, the mother of his son, Charles Main journeys west, where he joins in the army's war against the Indians. Meanwhile, his estranged sister, Ashton, now a prostitute in Santa Fe, dreams of wreaking revenge on her family. As usual, Mr. Jakes sets this fictional action against a meticulously detailed historical backdrop. Although his characters are not as vivid as his storytelling, his portrait of a divided, demoralized nation, inflamed with hatred, still emerges as an enjoyable work of popular historical fiction.

title: Nervous Allies Fear a Leadership Gap in America
description: IT often falls to the British to say most forthrightly what is on the minds of Europeans when they worry about the United States. Last week in London, Nigel Lawson, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, said it was imperative for the health of the world economy that America slash its huge budget deficit and raise taxes. These steps, he continued, are ''necessary in economic terms but also because this has now become the touchstone of whether the United States has the political will to make hard choices and do what needs to be done.''

title: Headliners; On Stage
description: What theater lovers these New Yorkers be! The New York Shakespeare Festival will present all 36 plays of William Shakespeare in a six-year-long, $33 million series, Joseph Papp, the festival producer, announced last week. They will be performed by an all-American company, including such stars as Meryl Streep, James Earl Jones, Robert De Niro, Raul Julia and Kevin Kline, who honed their craft in the Shakespeare festival at one time or another during its 34-year history. The series of plays at the Public Theater in Greenwich Village and the Delacorte Theater in Central Park is to be augmented by books and television shows about the new productions.

title: A Falling Dollar Can Only Help
description: LAST weekend, 32 economists from around the country and from Europe gathered at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute at Bard College to discuss the work of the late British economist Nicholas Kaldor. Much of the discussion was concerned with the more esoteric aspects of Lord Kaldor's work - his theories about money and economic growth.

title: WHO SHOULD BE THE M.V.P.'S IN BASEBALL?
description: Though the Cubs finished in last place, Andre Dawson deserves the National League m.v.p.

title: NEW MAYOR SAVORS UPSET IN YONKERS
description: LEAD: FOR the third consecutive year, Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke is expected next week to propose a county budget with a sharp increase in property taxes, cutbacks in some county services and few, if any, new programs.

title: Dr. Leavitt to Wed A Navy Physician
description: The engagement of Dr. Jacqueline Anne Leavitt to Lieut. Scott Latham Stafford, U.S.N., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Carlton Leavitt of Washington and York Beach, Me., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Jim Stafford of Seattle and the late Alice Stafford.

title: BRIDGEPORT PUPILS DIAL FOR SCHOOL HELP
description: LEAD: LATCHKEY schoolchildren everywhere must often puzzle in solitude over homework questions and problems of everyday life. But in Bridgeport, such children now have somewhere to turn other than in the direction of the television.

title: Diane E. Hutchinson, a Bank Officer, Is Married to Paul Christopher Reilly
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Diane Elizabeth Hutchinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ashton Hutchinson Jr. of Wilton, Conn., and Vineyard Haven, Mass., was married yesterday to Paul Christopher Reilly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Reilly of Locust, N.J., and Kiawah, S.C. The Rev. Thomas Burns performed the ceremony.

title:
ART;
Thomas George At State Museum
description: LEAD: A TRUISM of Abstract Expressionist painting is that it relies heavily on nature. In the exhibition of Thomas George's paintings at the State Museum here, covering 35 years, an unusually clear and strong indebtedness to the phenomenal world can be seen.

title: BEST SELLERS: NOVEMBER 8, 1987
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 3 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 2 2 20 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians. 3 3 6 LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) A collection of Lake Wobegon monologues. 4 4 6 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A tale of two families in the aftermath of the Civil War. 5 5 15 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 6 6 8 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the helm of the C.I.A., 1981 to 1987. 2 5 18 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 3 3 15 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) Counting his blessings and his losses, the television star muses on life at 50. 5 4 9 MAN OF THE HOUSE: The Life and Political Memoirs of Speaker Tip O'Neill, with William Novak. (Knopf, $15.95.) The actress's experiences with Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall and John Huston while filming the classic movie. 10 10 9 STRAIGHT ON TILL MORNING, by Mary S. Lovell. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) The life of Beryl Markham, pioneer aviator and author of ''West With the Night.'' 11 15 2 THE DISCOVERY OF THE TITANIC, by Robert D. Ballard with Rick Archbold. (Madison Press/ Warner, $29.95.) Recent findings about the sinking of the legendary ship 75 years ago. 12 3 THE RENEWAL FACTOR, by Robert H. Waterman Jr. (Bantam, $19.95.) Information - history, literature, politics - that you need to read with. 14 11 31 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) BALTASAR AND BLIMUNDA, by Jose Saramago. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $17.95.) A full-bodied novel from Portugal, knitting together harsh realism, jokes, aphorisms, a more than convincing love story and an 18th-century flying machine. IMAGES OF DESTRUCTION, by David Wigoder. (Routledge & Kegan Paul, $17.95.) The experience of madness dominates this turbulent autobiographical novel by a victim of manic-depressive disorder; it invites compassion for a man who lacks it himself. BEYOND AMERICAN HEGEMONY: The Future of the Western Alliance, by David P. Calleo. (Twentieth Century Fund/Basic Books, $20.95.) The post-1945 order reflecting American omnipotence is creaking. Mr. Calleo proposes a restructuring that would raise European military forces while reducing ours. THE LAST OF HOW IT WAS, by T. R. Pearson. (Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The completion of Mr. Pearson's fine North Carolina trilogy offers murder, idiocy and other family failings, all rendered in a comic voice of high velocity. THE TRULY DISADVANTAGED, by William Julius Wilson. (University of Chicago, $19.95.) A persuasive argument that black urban poverty persists mainly because of changes in the economy that elude both liberal and conservative analysis. MIAMI, by Joan Didion. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life with Miami's Cuban majority, a community of fierce anti-Communists who feel betrayed by deception and bad faith in Washington. CHAOS: Making a New Science, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) A New York Times reporter's lucid explanation of developments in mathematics that have illuminated a number of annoying situations in the physical world - the weather, for example.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Pan Am, Aeroflot To Fly Jointly To Soviet Union

title: Elmont Pulls Upset, 10-6
description: Elmont (2-5) upset New Hyde Park (5-2) by 10-6 in a Nassau County Conference III game yesterday. With six minutes remaining, a running back, John Michel, scored the winning touchdown on a 12-yard run. For the Spartans, the conference champions the past three years, the victory is the highlight of their most dismal season in several years.

title:
FILM;
Portraits of the Artist As a Young Woody Allen
description: LEAD: PRECOCIOUS AND KNOWING, HE peers out his thick, black-framed glasses, taking stock of the lunatic world of adults. Life's big questions nag at this familiar kid with the red hair and freckles, and he is forever fretting about the universe expanding, his own mortality and scoring with girls. Though still a boy, the signature qualms of his older self are already much in evidence.

title: Susan Gayle Regine Wed
description: The marriage of Susan Gayle Regine and Gregory Eugene Hagin, who both graduated with the class of '84 from Hofstra University, took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in New Brunswick, N.J. The Rev. William Arnold 3d performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Regine of Ronkonkoma, L.I., and the bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Hagin of East Brunswick, N.J.

title: VOLCKER ON THE CRASH
description: PAUL VOLCKER'S TELEPHONE keeps ringing. The callers ask for his advice or sound him out on how much damage has been done. Even out on the street, Volcker can't escape his questioners. At 6 feet, 8 inches, he is hard to miss. So people stop him to ask, ''Are we going to be all right?'' or to say, ''We need you back in Washington.''

title: Giant Lobster Is Liberated
description: A 22-pound lobster escaped the fate of many lobsters when an Alaskan doctor paid to have it taken from Anchorage to Maine and set free in the Atlantic.

title: DATA BANK: November 8, 1987
Prosecution Rests in 7-Month-Old Genovese Trial
description: Federal prosecutors have rested their case after presenting more than 100 witnesses, 360 taped conversations and 1,000 exhibits in a trial focusing on the Genovese crime family.

title: JURY TOLD OF PLAN TO KILL RADIO HOST
description: The former mistress of a neo-Nazi gang leader has told a jury her lover confided to her that his gang planned the killing of a Denver radio talk show host.

title: Jenny Engles Is Wed
description: Jenny Angela Engles, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Engles of Providence and Little Compton, R.I., was married yesterday to Charles William Anderson, a son of Mrs. Randolph Erland Anderson of Peace Dale, R.I., and the late Mr. Anderson. The Rev. Everett H. Greene performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I. The bridegroom is the president of Charles W. Anderson & Associates, a real-estate brokerage and development firm in Narragansett, R.I., where the bride was until recently in residential real-estate sales.

title: MOVIES
description: Tai-Pan Starring Bryan Brown, Joan Chen, John Stanton. 1986. Vestron Video. 127 minutes. $79.98. ''Tai-Pan,'' a misguided film epic set in the early 19th century, attempts to recount British maneuverings in the China trade and the seizure of Hong Kong. Based on James Clavell's best-selling novel, the movie offers a somnolent story notable only for its lethal concentration of swaggering merchants and sniveling ingenues.

title: Thievery
description: To the Editor: I am writing in the hope that what happened to me won't happen to someone else.

title: HIS DREADFULNESS, THE CZAR
description: FEARFUL MAJESTY The Life and Reign of Ivan the Terrible. By Benson Bobrick. Illustrated. 398 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.

title: IN VICTORIES, DEMOCRATS SEE OMENS OF 1988
description: IF there is one reliable result of state and local elections, it is the claim by interested parties that the outcome is a reliable guide to the course of a coming national contest. And so last week, after two gubernatorial races and a handful of mayoral ones, the Democrats hailed good omens for 1988, and the Republicans, ''bittersweet success.'' (Democratic glee in the region, page 7.) The Democrats' jubilation was over the victory of their candidate for the Statehouse in Mississippi, Ray Mabus, a 39-year-old Harvard-educated lawyer, over Jack Reed, a 63-year-old businessman. And in Kentucky, Wallace Wilkinson, a 45-year-old self-made millionaire, took 65 percent of the vote, the highest ever recorded in a Governor's race there. John Harper, a Republican state Representative, won 35 percent.

title: What Happened to The Market?
description: ON BLACK MONDAY, crash was the word most frequently used at first to describe the 508-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average that occurred Oct. 19, 1987, a day that many investors think will live in infirmity. Donald T. Regan, former Treasury Secretary, called C-Day ''black and blue Monday,'' a nice play on the battered image of ''black and blue'' with the traditional bad-news sense of ''black [ whatever ] day'' and the don't-want-to-go-back-to-work sense of ''blue Monday.''

title: FINDING PEACE AT THE SINK
description: PACO'S STORY By Larry Heinemann. 210 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Cloth, $15.95. Penguin Books. Paper, $4.50.

title: SOVIET YOUTH UNIT SEEKS TO REIN IN POLITICAL GROUPS
description: Officials of the Komsomol, the 40-million member youth arm of the Soviet Communist Party, have drafted a proposal to assert control over independent political groups that have sprung up in answer to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's call for a measure of democracy.

title: America's New Brain Gain
description: GEOFFREY Parker opened the letter and could scarcely believe his eyes. Professor Parker, a historian at St. Andrews University in Scotland, was being offered a job at triple his salary. He had not applied for it. ''This is not an invitation to apply,'' he said, paraphrasing the wording in the letter, from the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana. ''The post is yours. We've created it for you.''

title: Spot Checks For Components
description: ALARMED BY THE present perturbation of the economy, many circumspect audiophiles have postponed planned purchases. To be sure, the more passionate music lovers usually manage to persuade themselves that buying stereo equipment falls into the same budgetary bracket as rent and groceries. But some who have toyed with the notion of revamping their entire sound system are now more likely to think in terms of selective updating -changing only those components that have clearly outlived their allotted span. That way, they hope to reconcile good sound and solvency.

title: Commercial Rent
description: To the Editor:

title: DEFENDANT BACKED BY 500 WITNESSES
description: The lawyer for a union leader charged with 12 others in a bribery case faced the problem of countering secretly recorded tapes portraying the defendants as thugs. The answer was nearly 500 character witnesses, many testifying in groups.

title: Julie J. Shemitz Wed to J. B. LeBow in Connecticut
description: The marriage of Julie Jane Shemitz, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, to James Brian LeBow, an associate in the New York law firm of Grutman Miller Greenspoon & Hendler, took place last night at the Quinnipiack Club in New Haven. Judge Alan H. W. Shiff of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Bridgeport, Conn., the uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony. Rabbi Robert E. Goldberg gave a blessing.

title: Running on Empty
description: WHAT WE NEED is a candidate for the Presidency of the United States who doesn't want the job.

title: Jersey Agency Seeks New Laws to Deal With Incompetent Doctors
description: Calling incompetent and impaired physicians ''a potentially lethal minority,'' the State Commission of Investigation has recommended new laws and regulations intended to bring them to the attention of the State Board of Medical Examiners.

title: COMPUTER FALLOUT
description: I laughed until I had tears in my eyes when I read Russell Baker's column ''Computer Fallout'' (Sunday Observer, Oct. 11). The word processor reigns supreme in my house, and many's the time that writing a brief paragraph stretches into two hours of painstaking adding, deleting and. . . .

title: Brodsky's Nobel: What the Applause Was About
description: THERE was applause in Stockholm when Joseph Brodsky was named the winner of this year's Nobel Prize in Literature. There probably always is at these occasions, since applause is what they are all about, but this particular outbreak of handclaps was reported to have been more animated and partisan than usual. Not partisan in any political, East-West, superpower sense, but in the singularly personal, converted, parti pris manner some poets inspire - for with poets the reader is constantly invited to cross a line that usually allows for some distinction between being a reader and being a supporter.

title: Melissa I. Althoff Wed To Jonathan A. Schein
description: The marriage of Melissa I. Althoff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Althoff of Maytown, Pa., to Jonathan A. Schein took place last evening at the Carlyle Hotel in New York. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Barbara R. Herman of Westport, Conn., and Gerald D. Schein of New York.

title: RENTER LAW ROILS GARDEN CITY
description: LEGISLATION to protect tenants has recently been a source of controversy in Garden City.

title: A SLATTERN AND A SCHOLAR
description: FELICITY By Coral Lansbury. 189 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $16.95.

title: Yale Grabs a Share of First
description: For the first time since 1981, Yale reached the top of the Ivy League in November as the Elis scored a convincing 28-9 victory today over Cornell.

title: Q AND A
description: Interhostel Question: I understand there is an organization called Interhostel that is similar to Elderhostel but specializes in overseas programs. How can I get its catalogue? - E. E. O., Chevy Chase, Md. Answer: Both Interhostel and Elderhostel offer travel and educational programs for older adults. Interhostel, which is part of the University of New Hampshire, travels to universities and educational institutions overseas. Elderhostel's programs are in the United States and Canada as well as overseas.

title: What Survives in History
description: To the Editor:

title: Teach 13-Year-Olds Lincoln Freed Slaves
description: To the Editor:

title: MIDDLE SCHOOLS TEST SOCIAL SKILLS PLAN
description: CAN students be taught the social skills needed to get along with one another and with adults and, ultimately, to help them find employment?

title: LONG ISLAND FOLLOW-UP
description: LEAD: BEACH FOR THE STARS TO the consternation of amateur astronomers, the Long Island State Park Commission decided to close the two observing sites on the South Shore, Robert Moses and Jones Beach West End II, during the winter, when night skies are at their best.

title: The Burden Of Setbacks For Kasparov
description: It is difficult to know what Gary Kasparov's intentions were in Game 10, a draw, of his world championship chess match with Anatoly Karpov in Seville, Spain, Friday.

title: ONE OF THE ALL-TIME BEST
description: IF one polled the bridge cognoscenti and asked them to identify the best player of all time the result would be in doubt. But there is no doubt at all that B. Jay Becker, who died last month at his home in Flushing, Queens, at age 83 would be on every short list.

title: P. R. Williams Jr. Weds Susan Fiske
description: Susan S. Fiske, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Fiske Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to P. Russell Williams Jr., a son of Mrs. Eugene Stringham of Newtown, Conn., and Peter R. Williams of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Anne Kimball performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: Bing Quon Chu Dies; Leader in Chinatown
description: Bing Quon Chu, a businessman and leader of Chinese-American organizations, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 65 years old and a resident of Flushing.

title: The N.H.L.'s Indifference
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Fieldston Comes Back
description: Fieldston came from behind yesterday to snap Brunswick's winning streak and capture the Southern Division title of the Fairchester League with a 24-13 victory. Fieldston meets Hopkins-Grammar next Saturday for the championship.

title:
ART;
LATEST IDEAS IN 'IMAGES ON PAPER'
description: LEAD: AT a time when so much artistic innovation is executed on paper rather than canvas, an exhibition bringing noteworthy examples to our attention is welcome.

title: A Radical Proposal For English Schools
description: WHEN William J. Bennett, the United States Secretary of Education, emerged from a meeting with Kenneth Wilfred Baker, his opposite number, in London not too long ago, his first words spoke volumes. ''I was impressed,'' he said, ''by his use of the first person pronoun. 'I shall do this. . .' How nice to be able to do that and speak like that!''

title: COURTS: WHAT PRICE SWIFTER JUSTICE?
description: LEAD: EIGHT years after it was overhauled, the New Jersey court system, despite a relentless increase in caseloads, is now more manageable and the wheels of justice move more quickly, court officials say.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Beaverton, Ore.;
Building a Town Within a Town
description: LEAD: PERHAPS in deference to the state's natural grandeur, Oregonians tend not to build on a grand scale. But the Murrayhill project in this Portland suburb is an exception.

title: HEART PROGRAMS GET STATE CLEARANCE
description: LEAD: CITING a steady growth in the demand for coronary bypass surgery and other sophisticated treatments for heart disease, the state's top health-planning agency has cleared the way for a major expansion of open-heart surgery programs.

title: For Small Planes, More Buyers Think Brazil
description: IN a cavernous hangar at the headquarters of Embraer, as the Brazilian Aerospace Corporation is known, work has begun on the first of 20 twin-prop Brasilia aircraft on order from Texas Air. Near the plant's runway, technicians are testing five single-engine Tucano trainer planes, with the colors of the Peruvian Air Force. In another building, preparations are going ahead for construction of the external flaps for McDonnell Douglas's new MD-11 tri-jet.

title: THE MEN WHO WOULD BE PRESIDENT
description: THE GREAT TRIUMVIRATE Webster, Clay, and Calhoun. By Merrill D. Peterson. Illustrated. 573 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $27.95

title: Next Week; Will Free Agents Be Signed in Baseball?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: CRIME
description: If THE BLACK DAHLIA by James Ellroy (Mysterious Press, $16.95) were a play, it would be reviewed as overwritten, overdirected, overproduced and overwrought. It is a big, sprawling novel about the relationship of two cops - Bucky Bleichert and Lee Blanchard -in the 1940's. Both were highly regarded professional boxers before entering the Los Angeles Police Department. Blanchard knocks Bleichert out in a fight organized to publicize the L.A.P.D. They become friends. They enjoy, if that is the word, a nonsexual menage a trois with Blanchard's girlfriend. They become partners on the street and work up an enviable record. Then comes the case of the Black Dahlia.

title: Rev. Orlando Costas, 45; Protestant Theologian
description: The Rev. Orlando Enrique Costas, dean of the Andover Newton Theological School and a prominent Hispanic Protestant theologian, died of stomach cancer Thursday night at his home in Newton Centre, Mass. He was 45 years old.

title: Thievery
description: To the Editor: I usually take a cab to the airport. However, I recently had extra time and thought I'd try the Carey bus service from Grand Central.

title: WHERE TECHNOLOGY AND POETRY MEET
description: TO find the place where poetry and technology meet, one need only go as far as the Hastings-on-Hudson Middle School. There, in a basement laboratory, students have been working with holography - the young science that confounds logic with its optical magic.

title:
MUSIC;
BEETHOVEN CONCERTOS SCHEDULED IN PRINCETON
description: LEAD: THE pianist Robert Taub will be soloist with The Chamber Symphony of Princeton this season in a three-concert series of the complete Beethoven piano concertos.

title: Moscow's Eloquent Silence
description: Just imagine what Mikhail Gorbachev's predecessors would have made of the stock market fall. Capitalism's rottenness is now painfully obvious, they would have proclaimed. Yet, as the world's Marxist-Leninists gathered in Moscow to commemorate the revolution that brought them to power 70 years ago, no such ideas were put forward.

title: Democrats Stress Differences in Final Push in Iowa
description: Gathering here in the names of Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson, Iowa's Democrats today celebrated their party's six Presidential candidates and the happy news that in just 94 days, campaigning for one of democracy's most unusual exercises would be over.

title: Miss Ferdon Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Jay Ferdon of San Francisco of the engagement of their daughter, Maggie Ferdon, to John Withrow Cooley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Cooley of West Hartford, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass. The couple plan a January wedding.

title: MOVIES
description: Half Moon Street Starring Michael Caine and Sigourney Weaver. Directed by Bob Swaim. 1987. Embassy Home Entertainment. 90 minutes. $79.95. To supplement her paltry earnings at a foreign-policy think tank in London, Lauren Slaughter hires herself out to an escort service. Lauren is a young American Ph.D., beautiful and witty. She's also a nymphomaniac who is willing to go along with the kinkier side of escort duty, which gets her mixed up in some nasty business between a group of Arabs and one of her regular clients, an avuncular British lord for whom she develops a genuine fondness.

title: A DANCER'S NIGHTMARE
description: DURING THE PERFORMANCE of Balanchine's ''Who Cares?'' on Nov. 18, 1986, the opening night of the New York City Ballet's season, Sean Lavery took an uncertain step.

title: Surprise! OS/2 Is Practically Here
description: THE waiting for OS/2 is almost over. The International Business Machines Corporation announced here on Tuesday that the first version of OS/2, the advanced operating system for the more powerful members of its personal computer family, will be in the stores Dec. 4.

title: A VETERAN OF VIETNAM IS WELCOMED HOME
description: VETERANS DAY marks the culmination of the period preceding Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's that I have come to think of as Minor Holiday Season I. Before our older child, Elizabeth, entered public kindergarten five years ago, Columbus Day and Veterans Day had been seen by my husband, Tom, and I as an extra day to sleep late, hit the sales racks or catch up on household chores.

title: SINGLES HAVE 2 ROLES
description: I KNEW that becoming single midway through my life would change my economic and social status, but I was not prepared for the root-deep shake-up it would be to my gender identification.

title: THE VIEW FROM AXE CASTLE: OPTIMISTIC
description: DESPITE the tumult on Wall Street, the Axe Castle in Tarrytown is not under seige. In the Great Hall, beneath its beautiful rose window, the research department is quietly at work. And it is business as usual in the formal ballroom below, now used by the Axe computer department. The 18th-century Oak Room, unchanged since it was brought intact from a Paris mansion, is being readied for a meeting.

title: NONFICTION
description: WHITTLE: The True Story. By John Golley with Sir Frank Whittle. (Smithsonian Institution, $24.95.) Frank Whittle, the Englishman who fathered the jet engine, is to airplanes as Robert Fulton was to ships: he made them less glamorous but a lot faster and more reliable. Born in Coventry in 1907 to a working-class family, he joined the Royal Air Force at the age of 16 in the hope of bettering his prospects. The R.A.F. made him an officer, then sent him to Cambridge, where he took a splendid degree in engineering. As early as 1928 he had proposed the propellerless gas turbine - the jet - as a power source for faster planes, and throughout the 1930's continued to propose it, without, it seems, nearly enough encouragement from official sources. By 1937, however, a hand-made Whittle jet was running on a test stand and in 1941 - already too late to affect the course of World War II - a British experimental jet airplane made its first flight (the Americans were quick to see the point, borrowed an engine and some engineers, and from a standing start had their first jet aloft in a year and a day). The Germans, meanwhile, produced inferior but functional jet engines in time to cause some trouble before war's end. ''Whittle: The True Story'' may well be true, but it's all Sir Frank's truth. Old scores against various fuddy-duddies who obstructed him are settled with such rough justice as this: ''Why then did Griffith . . . damn the project? Sheer incompetence. . . ? Professional jealousy? Intellectual dishonesty? Or a combination of these things? We shall never know!'' John Golley, a journalist who has written several aviation books, is presumably responsible for the prose, not the facts. He weaves a dazzling garland of cliches and extinct metaphors; whenever the handwriting is on the wall, it isn't far from the frying pan to the fire. ''Having had the thumbs down from those in high places and the door slammed in his face, Whittle was at the cross-roads and didn't quite know what to do next.'' That sentence ought to be exhibited at county fairs.

title: Brooklyn Neighbors Mourn Slain Woman, 92
description: To her friends and neighbors, 92-year-old Ida Saltzman was sweet, friendly, sometimes headstrong but, like many grandmothers, always concerned about how you were and whether you were eating right.

title: PIANISTS TO OFFER PIECES KNOWN AND NEGLECTED
description: FOUR masters of the keyboard are to perform in the state this week, including Karl Haas, who is far better known for his national radio broadcasts than for his infrequent recitals.

title: ANSWER TO QUIZ
Jet Hijacking Suspect Said He Feared Mafia
description: A man who took control of an Air Canada jetliner here for three and a half hours Friday before surrendering to the authorities is being held at the city jail on charges of attempted hijacking, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BETWEEN PICTURES. By Jayne Loader. (Grove, $16.95.) The heroine of this first novel by the co-producer and co-director of the acclaimed documentary film ''The Atomic Cafe'' is Katherine Anne Porter O'Shea, and although she's a writer she has little in common with her namesake. There's nothing ladylike or refined about her, and no symbolism in her story.

title: SONO MERCHANTS ARE STILL WAITING FOR PROSPERITY
description: LEAD: THERE have been a lot of parties in South Norwalk in recent days, but not all the partygoers have been having a good time.

title: Walter Jones Taylor Wed To Connie Elizabeth Dean
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday Connie Elizabeth Dean, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jimmy Dean of Tenafly, N.J., was married to Walter Jones Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Zachary Taylor Jr. of Jackson, Miss. The Rev. Carl Nelson performed the ceremony.

title: Neck and Neck
description: THEY'RE off, and as they come out of the March gate and head into summer it's Steve Cauthen in the lead with Pat Eddery keeping it close and the others trailing far behind. As they round the turn into September and head toward fall, Cauthen with a mighty effort, extends his lead to 10 races. It seems all over for Eddery, but what's this? Cauthen falters, Edderly closes and takes the lead. Now Cauthen, going to the whip, takes it back. It's a see-saw battle, and surely the most exciting two-jockey race the British flat-racing jockey's championship has ever seen.

title: Correction
description: An article Oct. 11 about the rise of computers in typography misspelled the name of a classic typeface. It is Goudy Old Style.

title: NUCLEAR PLANTS SEEK IMPROVEMENT
description: LEAD: AFTER setbacks in the early 1980's that included incessant equipment breakdowns, rising construction costs and charges of inadequate management, managers of the state's three nuclear power plants are seeking improvements.

title: Dollars for Housing
description: A total of $1.4 million for housing for the homeless has been awarded to three nonprofit organizations in Westchester and will be used to help create apartments for 26 families and a communal house for five individuals. The money came from the New York State Homeless Housing Assistance Program, which gave $20 million for 24 projects across the state.

title: Skepticism Is as Deep as Any Tunnel
description: In East Boston, opposing major public construction projects is an avocation for some and a spectator sport for others.

title: LIGHTSCAMERA, ACTION! -- ON L.I.
description: LEAD: WHEN Long Islanders curl up with their popcorn in movie theaters to see the comedy ''Hello Again,'' which opened last week, they may recognize more than the familiar face of the actress Shelley Long.

title: GRADUATION DATE CHALLENGED
description: A DECISION by a Federal District Court judge that the North Babylon School District must reschedule its annual date of graduation is being appealed by the district, which wants to maintain the tradition of holding graduation exercises on Saturday morning.

title: Please Don't Disturb the Leviathans
description: LEAD: While naturalists fear that whale watching and other off-shore activities may be threatening populations of humpback and right whales off Hawaii and the Northeast, they are less concerned about the more abundant gray whale in the Pacific.

title: THE LOS ANGELES CLUB SCENE
description: This man, Mark Lindquist, can write (''Diary of a Lost Weekend,'' Oct. 11). His words, the very phrasing, bring this funny/sad scene to a level of reality I wouldn't have thought possible. Sight, sound and movement are built into the article. SALLY T. PETIT Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Thievery
description: To the Editor: I recently had my passport wallet stolen from my jacket on a night train from Cologne to Stuttgart. What ensued might interest your readers. I reported my loss to the Stuttgart railway police about 6:30 A.M.: my passport, first-class German rail pass (with six days' validity remaining) and cash. While one officer took my deposition, the desk sergeant telephoned to the train's next stop to advise the conductor of my loss. A search of all trash containers - especially those in the toilets - was undertaken, but reports from the next two stops (Augsburg and Munich) were negative.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
GOING AROUND ONCE - OR TWICE
description: LEAD: THE MOUNTAINS OF TIBET By Mordicai Gerstein. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row. $11.95. (Ages 7 and up) THE FLAME OF PEACE A Tale of the Aztecs. By Deborah Nourse Lattimore. Illustrated by the author. 40 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: Constance Schlitz Plans April Wedding
description: Warren J. Schlitz of Shaker Heights, Ohio, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Constance Ann Schlitz, to Worth Daniels MacMurray, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank G. MacMurray of McLean and Madison, Va. An April wedding is planned.

title: PLENTY OF BLAME TO GO AROUND
description: AND THE BAND PLAYED ON Politics, People, and the AIDS Epidemic. By Randy Shilts. 630 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title: Returned From the Brink of Extinction
description: By the time large-scale commercial whaling ended in the early part of this century, gray whales had been hunted almost out of existence. ''Twice, the population was thought to be extinct,'' said Don Wilkie, director of the aquarium-museum at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at La Jolla, Calif.

title: Social Events
description: Dining and Dancing Back to School Nov. 8 - A dinner with music at 6 P.M. will raise money for an endowment for La Guardia High School, 65th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, which was merged in 1984 with the High School of Music and Art and the School of Performing Arts. Alumni and friends of the schools are sponsoring the dinner by candlelight in La Guardia's marble lobby. Awards for career achievement will be given to the architects Charles Gwathmey and Robert Siegel and to Eliot Feld and Cora Cahan of the Feld Ballet, all alumni. An award will also go to Lawrence A. Wien, the real-estate developer and philanthropist, for his support of the arts. Tickets, $125, from 212-546-1655. For Lupus Research Nov. 9 - Rosemary Clooney and the cabaret entertainers Montgomery, Plant & Stritch will entertain at the 10th annual dinner-dance benefit for lupus erythematosus research, sponsored by the S.L.E. Foundation, a chapter of the Lupus Foundation of America. The party begins at 6:30 P.M. at the Equitable Center, Seventh Avenue and 51st Street. Suggested dress: black tie. Tickets, $250 and $300, from 212-685-4118. For the Homeless Nov. 9 - The first annual dinner for the Legal Action Center for the Homeless, a three-year-old advocacy group, will take place at 7:30 P.M. at the Baja Club, 246-A Columbus Avenue (71st Street). Music will be provided by Ken Dashow, a disk jockey, and food by Students Fight Against Hunger of the New York Restaurant School. Tickets, $75 and $85, at the door. Under the Golden Tree Nov. 10 - The Golden Tree boutique of the New York Junior League will officially open to holiday shoppers at a black-tie preview at 6 P.M. at the league's headquarters, 130 East 80th Street. The boutique will be open again from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Nov. 11 and 12 and from 6 to 9 P.M. on Nov. 12, when there will be music and wine. This is the 16th year that the nonprofit service organization, run by volunteers, has sponsored the boutique as a fund-raising project. Tickets for the preview, $25, and for the evening of Nov. 12, $10, from 212-288-6220, extension 238. Tickets, $5, for the daytime hours on Nov. 11 and 12. Image Awards Nov. 12 - The Men's Fashion Association of America will present its 1987 American Image Awards at a black-tie dinner dance at 6:30 P.M. at the Sheraton Centre. Some well-known men, including Harry Belafonte and Governor Kean of New Jersey, will be honored with awards, which will be presented by such well-known women as Celeste Holm, Lynn Redgrave, Jane Powell and Dr. Ruth Westheimer. The party will benefit the Clothing Bank of the Mayor's Voluntary Action Center, which collects new apparel from manufacturers for distribution to the homeless in New York City. Tickets, $250, from 212-683-5665. Under a Heated Tent Nov. 13 - Festivities will begin at 6:30 P.M. with a box supper, followed by the opening performance of ''A Thousand and One Nights at the Big Apple Circus'' in a heated tent pitched in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center. After the performance, dessert will be served, and there will be dancing in the ring at this benefit for the New York School for Circus Arts and for the circus's Clown Care Unit, which entertains hospitalized children. Children's tickets, $50 and $100; adults' tickets, $150, $250 and $350, from 212-391-0760. Frolic at the Waldorf Nov. 14 - Dancing and an opportunity to do some holiday shopping are promised at the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation's 15th annual Promise Ball, to be held at 7 P.M. at the Waldorf-Astoria. A 50-minute Broadway-type show, produced by the composer and lyricist Jerry Herman, will star Barbara Cook, George Hearn, Gene Barry, Chita Rivera, Andrea McArdle, Lee Roy Reams and Dina Merrill. Black tie. Tickets, $375, from 212-689-2860. Briefly Noted: Nov. 9 - The career advancement of women will be the theme of Barnard College's annual awards dinner at 7:30 P.M. at the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. The Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger Award will be presented to James E. Olson, the chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, will receive the Frederick A. P. Barnard Award. Tickets, $300, $500 and $1,000, from 212-280-8337. Nov. 10 - A dinner dance at the Stanhope Hotel for the New York Landmarks Preservation Foundation's plaque and medallion program starts at 7 P.M. Black tie. Tickets, $500 and $1,000, from 212-874-4098. Nov. 14 - The Friends of the Mount Sinai Children's Center will hold a benefit at the 4 P.M. performance of the Big Apple Circus in Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center. Tickets, $20, $50, $75 and $100, from 212-241-6976.

title: No Parliament Role in Peace Prize Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Kamen Wed To Dr. D. L. Siegel
description: Leslie P. Kamen and Dr. Donald L. Siegel were married last evening at the Copacabana in New York by Rabbi Stanley A. Dreyfus.

title: Stephanie Blau Plans To Be Married in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey R. Blau of Old Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie Elizabeth Blau to Craig L. Koenigsberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maynard Koenigsberg of Kings Point, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: HOW PLANTS COMPARE
description: LEAD: THE state's nuclear-power plants do not compare favorably with the rest of the country's nuclear facilities, but have shown rapid increases in productivity this year.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''This is a country where people think 2 percent inflation is already too high.''

title: FACULTY POSITION RESCINDED FOR C.I.A. AGENT IN CALIFORNIA
description: University of California officials have reversed their decision to appoint a Central Intelligence Agency agent as a political science lecturer, ending two weeks of faculty and student protest.

title: In Search of a Lightweight Tomato
description: POPCORN is a favorite low-calorie snack - but many people sneak a little butter on for flavor. Soon it may be possible to have buttery tasting popcorn without the calories or the guilt.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a lot of oil stains on my asphalt driveway. What should I use on these stains before I apply a sealer?

title: MOZAMBIQUE IS OFFERED HELP AGAINST REBELS
description: Britain and other Commonwealth nations are offering military and economic assistance to Mozambique to protect railways, ports and other development projects against attack by South African-backed guerillas.

title: PARKWAY PROPOSAL DRAWS OPPOSITION
description: LEAD: COMMUNITY opposition to a State Department of Transportation proposal to rebuild the Northern State and Meadowbrook Parkway interchange is threatening the start of construction on the project, due to begin in March.

title: Islanders Atone in Overtime
description: It was an evening full of alarming scenes. With 10 minutes left in the second period, Bill Smith's ankle gave out, leaving the Islander goaltender in a heap in front of his net. Thirty minutes later, it looked like the entire team had collapsed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Nov. 1 about a cruise from Helsinki to Leningrad gave an incorrect telephone number for Cosmos International Tours; it is 800-556-5305.

title: ARREST ALL MIMES!
description: IF YOU CAN'T SAY SOMETHING NICE By Calvin Trillin. 257 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $16.95.

title: HE WHO IS MOST ALONE
description: LEAD: Arthur Miller has done it all wrong. He grew up white and Jewish in Harlem and went to college in Michigan He worked in a shipyard and wrote a full script with Ernie Pyle to redeem his 4-F status in World War II. ''Death of a Salesman'' dumped fame on him at the age of 34. He has never turned his back or his wrath on the Marxists and Communists he knew as a young man.

title: U.C.L.A. a 52-17 Winner
description: Eric Ball, playing in place of injured Gaston Green, rushed for 128 yards and three touchdowns today as U.C.L.A. routed Oregon State, 52-17, in a Pacific-10 Conference game.

title: DEMOCRATS SCORE UPSETS
description: SOMETIMES it is the winners who proclaim, ''Wait till next year.'' Certainly that was the underlying gleeful tone of New York State Democratic leaders last week as they savored upset victories in important city and county elections and declared that the results boded well for Democrats nationally in the 1988 elections.

title: Who Will Lead New York Schools?
description: Should New York City's Board of Education be expanded, replaced or abolished altogether? Such questions are properly raised as the board struggles to find a successor to Chancellor Nathan Quinones, who retires on Jan. 1. The stumbling search exemplifies a crisis of competence for the nation's largest school system, a crisis that begins with the board president, Robert Wagner Jr. New York's schools suffer from a dropout rate of at least 30 percent, depending on who's counting, and graduate youngsters unable to qualify for entry-level jobs. Reformers despair of ever bestirring a bloated central bureaucracy that often seems incapable of administering the simplest programs.

title: H. E. Knoblock 3d, Lawyer, Is Married to Ellen Harris
description: Ellen DaCosta Harris, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Harris of Winnetka, Ill., and Henry E. Knoblock 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Knoblock Jr. of Duxbury, Mass., were married last evening at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Cambridge, Mass., by the Rev. Gerald P. Cohen.

title: A Fairer Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: UNFOLDING HORROR
description: A STATE OF FEAR By Menan du Plessis. 190 pp. New York: Pandora Press/Methuen. Cloth, $25. Paper, $7.95.

title: About Cars; Mazda Adds Zip With GTX
description: THE letters about what is right and wrong with today's automobile continue to flow in. It has been a month since that column ran, and the torrent has slowed to a trickle, two to three letters a day now. But it is obvious that people across the country have some definite ideas about what they are not getting in the way of dandy transportation.

title: Haiti Terror: The Old Order vs. the New
description: For the last week, Haitians have been witnessing the unfolding of a campaign of terror apparently intended to disrupt elections and preserve the old order of the Duvalier family dictatorship.

title: Got Ten Dollars for a Cup of Coffee?
description: If push comes to shove, says Treasury Secretary Baker, Washington won't raise interest rates to protect the value of the dollar. Mr. Baker has his priorities right: The risk of high interest rates causing recession exceed the risk of a falling dollar leading to a punishing inflation.

title: Reagan Asks Filipino Military To Back Aquino Government
description: President Reagan today appealed to the Philippine military to support President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: A Slave Island Draws Descendants of Slaves
description: Exploring this low island in the mouth of Africa's largest harbor, a black American visitor mused, ''This island almost belongs more to America than to Africa.''

title: THE YEAR'S BEST ILLUSTRATED BOOKS
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from The Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1987.

title: WHO SHOULD BE THE M.V.P.'S IN BASEBALL?
description: Ozzie Smith and Alan Trammell should be the m.v.p.'s. Smith hit .303, drove in 75 runs (without a home run) and played his usual brilliant shortstop, saving many runs with his glove. More importantly, he missed only four games and kept the Cardinals together when key players like Jack Clark and John Tudor were out.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN AUSTIN
description: Like an oasis in Texas, Austin rises green and lush between the swamps of Houston and dusty plains of West Texas. Its hills and mesas buck and ripple along the Balcones geologic fault, which rises from the south near San Antonio and reaches heights of 300 feet or more just north of Austin. From the cliffs and upper slopes of the hills, with hawks wheeling high overhead, one can look down on two major lakes created from the Colorado River as it snakes its way through the city and countryside. Often in the mornings the Hill Country is covered with a purple haze, the color of sage in bloom, and for that reason the Comanche and Lipan Apache Indians who lived in the area more than a century ago thought it was enchanted. Many people still do.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: I go to Spain - and only to Spain - three times a year. And I do so because I love the Spanish people and their culture.

title: Korean Reportedly Saw Waite
description: A Moslem militia representative said today that Terry Waite, the kidnapped British church envoy, was apparently seen by a freed South Korean diplomat while the diplomat was a hostage in Lebanon.

title: In Writing
description: Ursula Meese said it was no worse than her husband's writing that ''Ursula and I send our best regards'' without consulting her first. But some legal experts saw it differently. What the wife of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d had written to a Federal judge last June - without, she said, consulting Mr. Meese - was that ''my husband, Ed, and I'' recommended ''very favorable consideration'' in the sentencing of Joe S. Duncan, a family friend and son of Representative John J. Duncan, Republican of Tennessee, for tax fraud. A White House spokesman defended Mrs. Meese's right ''to express herself,'' but critics alluded to ''Caesar's wife,'' saying Mrs. Meese should have been aware of the possible appearance of impropriety. In August, Mr. Duncan was sentenced to a three-year prison term, all but six months of it suspended.

title: THE PUMPKIN: NOT JUST A PRETTY FACE
description: NOW that Halloween is over, most Americans look forward to only one more use for the abundant pumpkin crop: in the Thanksgiving pie. That is a pity, because this estimable member of the squash family has a multitude of other delicious uses.

title: At Dartmouth, A Helping Candor
description: DURING registration at Dartmouth College, students can pick up forms, course material and a sex-education packet containing a condom, a dental dam for oral sex, and an explicit pamphlet explaining how to have safer sex in the era of AIDS. When they go to the library they can also get a condom when they check out a book.

title: FORGING LINKS WITH PRISON INMATES
description: LEAD: THE miniature clothes and bright decoration of Father Goose, a children's clothing store on Main Street in Mount Kisco, seem far away from the world inside a prison. But, in fact, the store is in close contact with the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, the state's 787-bed maximum security prison for women five miles north on Harris Road.

title: Attack Kills One at Meeting Of Opposition in Bangladesh
description: Attackers threw bombs and sprayed gunfire at members of an opposition party who were meeting today, killing one person and wounding more than a dozen, the police and witnesses said.

title: CAN THE MENNONITES SURVIVE SUCCESS?
description: A HANDFUL OF MEN come coasting down the hill on gearless bicycles. They are wearing dark wide-brimmed straw hats, plain blue workshirts and black pants held up by suspenders. They round the corner at the end of the cornfield and pull up to a half-constructed church where 40 or so men, most of them farmers, are already at work. Horses hitched to shiny black buggies snort and swish their tails. A table saw whines and hammers pound as freshly cut siding is handed up the scaffolding.

title: TRAVEL
description: Washington Monuments Narrated by Robert Prosky. Produced and written by Peter D. Edwards. Atlas Video Library. 30 minutes. $19.95. This is a dull, slow-moving, plodding and superficial attempt at a tourist guide or souvenir that, despite its pretty pictures, captures none of the historical or present-day excitement of our nation's capital.

title: DESIRE SET TO MUSIC
description: LEAD: A SONG OF LOVE AND DEATH The Meaning of Opera. By Peter Conrad. 384 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $19.95.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Relativity of Saints Einstein was a reluctant culture hero - yet he saw that he could be a useful symbol as well as a famous scientist. This is from ''Dreams and Delusions: The Drama of German History'' by Fritz Stern (Knopf).

title: A Newsman In Divinity School
description: IN THE first days of the 1985-86 school year at Harvard, the course called ''World Religions, Diversity and Dialogue'' was so popular that all the seats were taken and some students were sitting cross-legged on the floor of a great lecture hall. With two hands, the professor pushed her blonde hair behind her ears and made a statement that was to reverberate in my mind for the rest of the school year. ''If you know one religion,'' she said slowly, looking at us with intensity, ''you don't know any.''

title: A Compromise on Arms Reached in Washington
description: White House officials and Congressional leaders have worked out the basic elements of a compromise over arms control issues that until now had placed the two sides on a collision course, Administration and Congressional officials disclosed today.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: RULES FOR EAGLE WATCHERS Ever since the Shepaug Eagle Observation area was set up in 1985, bird lovers in the state have been swarming to the site and unwittingly disturbing the eagles' privacy. This year, however, the Department of Environmental Protection has set up some regulations to protect wintering bald eagles from the overwhelming number of visitors.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Bruins 4, Penguins 1: Rick Middleton scored two goals, one on a short-handed breakaway, as Boston snapped a six-game streak without a victory last night in Boston. The Bruins limited the Penguins to two shots in the first period and 17 in the game. The Penguins were without Mario Lemieux, their top scorer, who had returned to Pittsburgh with a bruised shoulder and back.(AP) Canadiens 5, Flyers 4: Stephane Richer and Mike McPhee each had a goal and an assist to lead the Canadiens over last-place Philadelphia at Montreal. The victory stretched Montreal's unbeaten streak to six games. The score was tied, 3-3, late in the third period when Montreal's Mats Naslund picked up a loose puck in his own end and cleared it up to Richer on the right-wing boards. Richer drilled a 45-foot slapshot past Ron Hextall for the go-ahead goal at 16:58.(AP) Oilers 5, Sabres 0: Wayne Gretzky scored twice to move into a tie for sixth place on the N.H.L. goals list and lead Edmonton in the home game. Gretzky scored the game's first two goals, giving him 556 for his career and a tie with Johnny Bucyk. Grant Fuhr made 26 saves.(AP) Tennis Mayotte and Gilbert in Final: Tim Mayotte and Brad Gilbert set up an all-American final as both took three-set semifinal victories yesterday in the $840,000 Paris Open. Mayotte defeated Henri Leconte of France, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3, and Gilbert beat Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands, 7-5, 5-7, 6-4.(AP) Edberg vs. Svensson: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg defeated Anders Jarryd, 6-4, 6-2, and seventh-seeded Jonas B. Svensson beat Magnus Gustafsson, 6-3, 6-4 to reach the singles final of the $525,000 Stockholm Open-Scandinavian championships. (AP) Evert Tested but Wins: Chris Evert was pushed to her limits by 17-year-old Gabriela Sabatini in the semifinals of the $250,000 Virginia Slims of New England championships at Worcester, Mass. Evert eventually won, 6-4, 7-6, and extended her perfect record over the Argentine to five straight matches. Evert ran away with the tiebreaker. The marathon victory put Evert into today's final against Pam Shriver, the second-seeded player, who earlier in the day defeated Helena Sukova, 7-5, 6-3. (AP) Golf American-European Final: United States and European PGA teams clash today for the title in the $950,000 World Championship in Inagi, Japan. The teams secured the first two positions yesterday at the conclusion of round-robin play in team competition among the world's four largest professional tours. The Europeans beat the Australia-New Zealand team, 7-5, for a three-round total of 24 points. The United States, which was 3 points behind the Australia-New Zealand team on Friday, won five matches and lost one against Japan for 10 points and total of 20. Australia-New Zealand finished with 18. In yesterday's matches, Payne Stewart of the United States fired the day's best score of 65 and beat Tateo Ozaki of Japan, who had a 70.(AP) 5-Stroke Lead in Japan: Yuko Moriguchi of Japan shot a bogey-free six-under-par 66 for a 10-under-par 134 total yesterday and a five-stroke lead entering the final round of the $350,000 Mazda Classic, Japan's most lucrative women's tournament, in Hanno. The 32-year-old Moriguchi carded six birdies - one on a 54-foot putt. Ayako Okamoto, a regular on the American circuit and the second-leading money winner on United States Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, shot 71 to share second place with her countrywoman Atsuko Hikage.(AP) Horse Racing Ferdinand Rallies to Win: Ferdinand, the 1986 Kentucky Derby winner, tuned up for the $3 million Breeders' Cup Classic by rallying from last place to win the $156,500 Goodwood Handicap at Santa Anita's Oak Tree meeting yesterday in Arcadia, Calif. Ridden by his regular jockey, Bill Shoemaker, Ferdinand beat Candi's Gold by a length. Last year's Classic winner, Skywalker, was third in the field of five. Timed in 1:50 4/5, Ferdinand returned $5.20 for $2 to win. Shoemaker pushed his record victory total to 8,702, with 982 stakes victories and 244 victories in races worth $100,000 or more. It was Ferdinand's third straight victory.(AP)

title: THE GUIDE
description: IN CHAMBERS Chamber music comes in many sizes and sounds, and those who like to sample a little of everything can go from big to small this week when two of the major professional Long Island-based groups take to the stage. Today, the New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony, under Kenneth Klein's baton, transports its audience from Brookville to the Mediterranean when it performs ''In the Gardens of Spain and Italy.'' The ensemble will be joined by the guitarist Eduardo Fernandez and the cellist Michelle Djokic in a program of works by Rodrigo, Boccherini, Rossini and Falla. The concert is at 7 P.M. at the Hillwood Commons Theater on the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University. For ticket information call 299-2947.

title: Charles C. Steidel Wed to Miss Hoyt
description: Sarah Nichols Hoyt, a daughter of Gayle C. Hoyt of Chatham, N.J., and Charles O. Hoyt of New York, was married yesterday in Sierra Madre, Calif., to Charles Colville Steidel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Steidel of Scottsdale, Ariz. The Rev. Michael A. Bamberger performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension.

title: STATE AGENCY'S ROLE IN SOLID-WASTE DISPOSAL
description: I hasten to respond to a quote by Suffolk County Legislator Ed Romaine [ ''Suffolk Debates Toxic-Ash Bill,'' Oct. 4 ] . In it, Mr. Romaine says that the problem of solid-waste disposal ''is so large it requires a state or regional approach, and the fact is the state has miserably neglected its responsibilities. It should be helping the towns with technical assistance and money, but it's done nothing.'' He says that the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation ''has failed the local governments.''

title: Williams's 'Milk Train' Stops Here Once Again
description: ''I NOW FIND MYSELF DOING THE most demanding, difficult, massive, Gothic role that even I have ever attempted,'' says the actress whom Tennessee Williams called ''the great Elizabeth Ashley.''
