Ms. Ashley is speaking of one of the least famous and most ferocious of the Williams heroines - and one of the only fantastically wealthy women he wrote - Flora Goforth, known as Sissy, whom Ms. Ashley is playing in the W.P.A. Theater's revival of ''The Milk Train Doesn't Stop Here Anymore,'' scheduled to open Wednesday.

title: Dawkins Suspended
description: THE Utah Jazz have indefinitely suspended Darryl Dawkins in a move that the team president, Dave Checketts, said was not disciplinary in nature. Checketts, in announcing the suspension of the center last night, said Dawkins was upset over the death of his estranged wife, Kelly Barnes Dawkins, on Nov. 1. Preliminary findings of an autopsy listed the death as a possible suicide. Checketts said that Dawkins was in New Jersey for the funeral yesterday morning and did not report for last night's home game against Sacramento. He said Coach Frank Layden talked with Dawkins during the day. Checketts said he was unsure how long Dawkins would be on the suspended list. He also did not say whether the Jazz would sign a replacement in the interim. . . .Michael Cage, a Los Angeles Clipper power forward who had become a free agent, signed a mutliyear contract with the Clippers after receiving a bid from the Detroit Pistons. The Pistons had offered him a four-year deal worth a reported $3.2 million, and the Clippers' contract had to be worth at least as much.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: WOODWORKING SHOW At noon Friday, the enthusiasts will start coming out of - or going into -the woodwork at the Hyatt Hotel on Route 70 in Cherry Hill for a show sponsored by the Woodworking Association of North America. (The association, with headquarters in Plymouth, N.H., has 6,700 members, 1,200 of them in New Jersey.) There will be 105 booths of makers, distributors and retailers of woodworking equipment and free talks and demonstrations by experts on marquetry and inlay, stains and finishes, furniture repair and veneering, router, scroll-saw and band-saw techniques and chip - yes, chip, not ship - carving.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CHANGING TRAINS
description: LEAD: Despite the controversy that preceded the decision, Amtrak's switch to the New Rochelle train station, replacing the stops its trains had made in Rye, has not created much stir among the shopkeepers at either site.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
NUMISMATICS;
AN AUCTION FOR THE WORLD'S LARGEST COIN
description: LEAD: A 17th-century Islamic coin, said to be the largest gold coin in the world, will be offered for sale by Habsburg, Feldman S.A., at an auction to be held tomorrow in Geneva, Switzerland. The company expects the coin to bring $10 million. It has also placed a $4 million estimate on a smaller companion piece.

title: Fear of AIDS Surfaces in Permissive Bangkok
description: In Bangkok, where by conservative estimates several hundred thousand people make their living in the sex industry, fears of AIDS have been slow to surface. But the complacency may soon be over.

title: Guilt in the Lindbergh Case
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Exhibition on Old Chinatown Is Enhanced by Families' Artifacts
description: Fay Chiang's father summarized his life in 10 minutes shortly before he died of cancer in 1974. Only then did the daughter learn that he had started working in this country at the age of 10 in a laundry.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: According to the letter about Spain on Aug. 30, there is ''nothing'' doing in Madrid, Cordoba, Granada, Seville or the Costa del Sol. The writer compiled a long list of grievances during a short stay. Not only did the Spaniards speak Spanish, they closed a national monument on the flimsy pretext that a national election was being held that day. And where are the bargains?

title: NEW RULE SOUGHT ON CONTRIBUTIONS
description: The Federal Election Commission has been asked to condone a practice used by political action committees that has been criticized as a way to circumvent Federal limits on campaign contributions.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: GREAT AND DESPERATE CURES: The Rise and Decline of Psychosurgery and Other Radical Treatments for Mental Illness, by Elliot S. Valenstein. (Basic Books, $10.95.) In 1949, Egas Moniz, a Portuguese neurology professor, won the Nobel Prize for helping to invent the prefrontal lobotomy, an operation that became so popular as a treament for mental illness that it was sometimes performed as an office procedure, using an ice pick thrust through the bony socket behind the eyeball. The author's account of this and other cases of medical excess ''is not a pretty tale, but it is well told,'' Stanley W. Jackson said here last year. ''His views are balanced, judicious and based on the evidence.'' THE JOURNEY DOWN, by Aline Bernstein. (Swallow Press/Ohio University, $12.95.) When Thomas Wolfe was writing his first novel, ''Look Homeward Angel,'' he was as dependent on his lover, Aline Bernstein, for financial support as he was on Maxwell Perkins for editorial help. So familiar are the unflattering portraits of this generous but possessive woman provided by Wolfe in his later autobiographical novels that it is nice to know Bernstein recorded her side of the story.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: GEMS AND SPORTS The Westchester County Center in White Plains, reopened after extensive renovations, will feature two attractions next weekend that in past years have drawn up to 8,000 people, according to Gloria Rothstein, the promoter.

title: Learning The Facts of Life
description: RON MOGLIA wants every 5-year-old in America to play the ''birthing game.'' It goes like this: A kindergarten class chooses a girl to be the ''adult mommy'' and a boy to be the ''adult daddy.'' The teacher asks the ''adult mommy'' when she wants to have her baby - before lunch, before recess or before going home. When the big moment arrives, the mommy stands by a plastic tube labeled ''mommy's birthing tunnel'' and starts a classmate, who has been designated ''baby'' of the day, on his or her crawl through. As the baby emerges from the end of the tunnel labeled ''mommy's vagina,'' a ''doctor'' and a ''nurse'' welcome the baby into the world. They weigh the child and tell the class whether it's a boy or a girl. Then everyone runs off for milk and cookies. Fifteen years ago, the ''birthing game'' would have been unthinkable. Now, with disturbingly high teen-age pregnancy rates, the AIDS epidemic and widespread fears about other sexually transmitted diseases, many public-school educators believe that sex education is a must. Some experts - including Mr. Moglia, director of the Human Sexuality Program in the Department of Health Education at New York University, and Mary S. Calderone, a co-founder of the Sex Information and Education Council of the United States - argue that the earlier sex education begins, the better. Sandra Ludlow, executive director of E.T.R. Associates, a California consulting group that has helped more than 300 school districts plan sex-education programs, agrees. ''Schools are recognizing,'' she said, ''that their role involves more than showing girls a movie about menstruation in a home-economics class or offering a unit on human reproduction in high school biology.''

title: GLASNOST COMES TO THE CABARET, AND POLITICAL SATIRE TAKES CENTER STAGE
description: TO FIND THE PFEFFER-muhle, just follow Bach's disapproving gaze. Standing on his sooty granite pedestal by the side of Leipzig's old St. Thomas Church, where he used to direct the choir, he glowers at a wooden door across the way from which, in the evening, come muffled bursts of laughter.

title: Carolyn Pharr Vinson Weds
description: Carolyn Pharr Vinson and Stephen Alfred Bou, lawyers in Washington, were married at the Washington Cathedral yesterday by the Rev. Henry Harris, associate rector of All Saints Episcopal Church in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: WITH GIANT DAMS ALL BUILT, AGENCY SEEKS NEW WORK
description: ''TOUCH water and you touch everything'' in the West, John Gunther wrote in ''Inside USA'' in 1947. And the engineers of the United States Bureau of Reclamation did not just touch the West's great rivers, they transformed them, turning dry and dusty wastelands into a modern-day Mesopotamia.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
OLD LANDFILLS NEED NOT DIE -- THEY CAN BE RECYCLED
description: LEAD: AT ONE time, they were as much a part of local New Jersey life as Town Hall or the Memorial Day parade, but today municipal dumps are just about extinct.

title: Conflicting Goals Dwell In Philadelphia Mansion
description: High on a plateau of the west bank of the Schuylkill, overlooking Fairmount Park and the city beyond, stands a butter-colored mansion.

title: Gentle Strength of Horses Heals Children's Spirits
description: Sherry is an 8-year-old for whom it is an achievement to sit upright, strapped into her wheelchair. She has profound mental and physical disabilities. She cannot feed or dress herself. She cannot talk. She cannot walk.

title: Rising Prices Hit Library Shelves
description: THE QUALITY of library services at the nation's major universities is being threatened by recent steep rises in subscription prices of research journals and periodicals, according to reports by the Association of Research Libraries.

title: DAY CARE ENTERS THE MAINSTREAM
description: IN the past, day care has been perceived by critics as service for people outside of mainstream family life - ''people with problems,'' professionals in the field say. When nuclear families were intact and most mothers could stay home, day care, it was thought, met the needs of only a few.

title: WHO SHOULD BE THE M.V.P.'S IN BASEBALL?
description: Who should be the m.v.p.'s in baseball? Tony Gwynn and Dwight Evans. GREG GOLDSTEIN Fresh Meadows

title: BERGEN'S NEW SHERIFF HAS HIS WORK CUT OUT
description: DETERMINATION and persistence are qualities that Capt. Robert R. Herb says he has in abundance, and both his critics and backers say he will need them to correct problems in the Bergen County jail system.

title: MISHA'S AUTOGRAPH
description: ''I WAS really very pleasantly surprised,'' said Mikhail Baryshnikov, after members of the American Ballet Theater danced the parts of fashion models at a show of Mr. Baryshnikov's signature body- and dancewear collection.

title: TRYING A CITY FOR ITS VIOLENT CRIMES
description: THE murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr., for which jury selection continued in Manhattan last week, had all the makings of an old-fashioned, straightforward, good-versus-evil courtroom drama.

title: William B. Beam
description: William B. Beam, a retired executive vice president of the American Express International Banking Corporation, died of kidney failure Tuesday at Baylor Hospital in Dallas. He was 62 years old and lived in Dallas and Swiftwater, Pa. Until 1985, he also lived in Manhattan.

title: Appeals Court Restricts Immunity For Congressmen on Defamation
description: A Federal appeals court panel has ruled that a member of Congress may be sued for defamatory statements made in a letter to the executive branch even if considers the comments part of his official duties.

title: A GIRL'S BEST FRIEND IS HER SKATE
description: I WANT A DOG By Dayal Kaur Khalsa. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Clarkson N. Potter/Crown Publishers. $10.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Trainer Under Scrutiny
description: Six horses trained by Peter Ferriola, Aqueduct Race Track's leading trainer, were ordered scratched by track stewards yesterday because of a state investigation involving the possible illegal medication of his horses.

title: A Lost World Interred in Berlin
description: BEFORE World War II, Berlin ranked among the great cities of the world, and many images from that time are familiar to us: the grandeur of Unter den Linden, the cosmopolitan elegance of the Hotel Adlon, the brimming activity of Potsdamer Platz and Alexanderplatz. But these places were destroyed, surviving today only in photographs that scarcely represent their grand subjects. Nonetheless, there remains in Berlin today an artifact less familiar than the others, but no less evocative of Berlin's prewar years, in part because it survived the war, and then East-West politics, relatively unscathed.

title: It Should Be a Wand, Not a Weapon
description: A hockey stick, like a surgeon's scalpel, can provide great satisfaction when used skillfully. Yet for a player the stick also carries with it a tremendous responsibility.

title: GREAT NECK PLAZA SUES NASSAU RENT BOARD
description: THE Village of Great Neck Plaza has filed suit against the Nassau County Rent Guidelines Board, accusing the board of discriminating against renters in a cooperative or condominium building. The board has allowed owners of co-ops and condominiums who lease the apartment units to charge higher rents than landlords of other rental units.

title: Soviet's East: New Window On the Pacific
description: Visitors from Moscow, a city that gravitates west toward Europe and the Atlantic, find the eastward inclination of this Pacific port disorienting at first.

title: The Big Dig
description: THE LEGENDARY PROJECT, TO construct a tunnel beneath the English Channel, dates to 1881, the most recent effort having been aborted in 1974. This year, however, a most auspicious beginning has been made. Photographed above, the access shaft at Sangatte - 55 meters across, 62 meters deep (about 180 by 200 feet) - on the French side of the channel, has solved a problem that dogged engineers in the past. It is now nearly ready for the tunneling machines that should create, at last, an underground link between Britain and France.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: TRY to get Celso Gonzalez-Falla on a horse on Good Friday. Try, but there's no way it's going to happen. That's the one day of the year that the tax and securities lawyer, who commutes between New York and Texas, won't even consider riding.

title: Don't Alter The Flow
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BRODSKY'S NOBEL: WHAT THE APPLAUSE WAS ABOUT
description: THERE was applause in Stockholm when Joseph Brodsky was named the winner of this year's Nobel Prize in Literature. There probably always is at these occasions, since applause is what they are all about, but this particular outbreak of handclaps was reported to have been more animated and partisan than usual. Not partisan in any political, East-West, superpower sense, but in the singularly personal, converted, parti pris manner some poets inspire - for with poets the reader is constantly invited to cross a line that usually allows for some distinction between being a reader and being a supporter.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a lot of oil stains on my asphalt driveway. What should I use on these stains before I apply a sealer?

title: Facts Don't Always Give the True Story
description: AS ITS TITLE MAKES CLEAR, and the film itself makes even clearer, ''Gaby - A True Story'' is about a real woman and her real travails. Gabriela Brimmer was born with cerebral palsy, and without command of any muscles except those in her left foot. That foot became her only means of communication: she could spell out words by pointing her big toe at an alphabet board. Ms. Brimmer, with the help of an extremely devoted nanny, was able to overcome this handicap in a very big way. She demanded to go to regular schools, attended the University of Mexico, adopted a child, and became the subject of a best-selling book in her native country. Now she's a film heroine as well.

title: FULFILLMENT IN AUTUMN OF HER LIFE FOR WRITER
description: At the age of 90, Dorothy O. White is the author of a book, her first.

title: A ONCE-UPON-A-TIME QUIZ
description: THE opening sentence of a novel is always important, but perhaps never more so than in novels for young readers. A novel that gets off to a slow start can get off to no start for people with homework to do, television to watch, rock groups to follow, parents to please, chums to phone, places to go, chores to be done. To compete with all this, a novel for young readers must have a hook - not in the third paragraph, the fifth page or at the end of the chapter, but in the very first sentence. For children the best hooks (and best books) have rhythm, allure and that storyteller's voice of electrifying authority.

title: New York Ski Trails to Be Widened
description: By a narrow margin, New York voters have approved extending and widening trails at three state-operated ski centers in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains.

title: O'ROURKE READIES BUDGEt
description: LEAD: FOR the third consecutive year, Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke is expected next week to propose a county budget with a sharp increase in property taxes, cutbacks in some county services and few, if any, new programs.

title: Deborah O'Connell Marries
description: Deborah Ann O'Connell, the daughter of Paulette Leclair O'Connell of San Francisco and Philip Joseph O'Connell of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married yesterday to Tyler Roberts Carder, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roberts George Carder of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Wayne Lavender performed the ceremony at the Rowayton (Conn.) United Methodist Church.

title: Susan Goodyear To Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Daniel M. Goodyear of Robesonia, Pa., and Lynne P. Goodyear of Gulph Mills, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Susan Rumsey Goodyear to Edward Mandell de Windt Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. de Windt of Melvin Village, N.H. A June wedding is planned.

title: Dr. Park to Marry Fellow Physician
description: Dr. Felicia Kyung Park and Dr. David Eustace Cummings, who graduated with the class of '87 from the Harvard Medical School and are in the medical residency program at the University of Washington Affiliated Hospitals in Seattle, plan to be married next month.

title: FICTION
description: BLACK SWAN. By Christopher Hope. Illustrated by Gillian Barlow. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) This moving, lyrical novel, the author's fourth, is set in South Africa in 1965. Its hero, 17-year-old Lucky, is an idiot savant who lives with his adoptive grandmother in a black township. The boy is able to mimic perfectly the voices and manners of movie and radio personalities, but defies all outside attempts to pull him out of his dream world. Ilse, a sensitive young German woman who has become completely disillusioned with her native land after seeing her father at a Nazi reunion dinner, comes to South Africa to work with disturbed adolescents. Deciding that the way to reach Lucky is to enter his dreams, Ilse shows him a film of ''Swan Lake.'' Lucky is enchanted with the ballet, and the story of Lucky and Ilse becomes that of Prince Siegfried and Odette, with the wicked sorcerer taking the form of the South African authorities. The sympathies of the author, who was born in Johannesburg and now lives in London, clearly lie with the blacks, but the novel avoids romanticizing the oppressed. Instead, it shows that a brutal system quite often leads to a brutal response: after a screening of ''Swan Lake'' at the Bantu Men's Social Center, the dissatisfied audience rips the film from the projector, sets it on fire and tries to throw Lucky into the flames; Comrade Joe, a rebel leader whom Lucky joins after he and Ilse are forced to part, is merciless in executing deserters. Through such scenes, this spare 90-page tale in the Harper Short Novel series is deftly transformed from the story of a detached and overwhelmed young man into a remarkable parable of a cruel state.

title:
DINING OUT;
IN SUFFERN, CLASSIC ITALIAN CUISINE
description: LEAD: MARCELLO'S is not only a restaurant to watch as it perfects its style - and certainly it has all the marks of becoming one of the area's better dining spots - but a place to remember even now, when moderately priced, carefully and lovingly prepared food is the order of the evening. In fact, this Rockland County eating place is something of a bargain.

title: Science Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: Where to Watch the Great Whales
description: In the mid-19th century, when the slaughter of the California gray whale was in full swing, whalers called them ''devil fish.'' Like monsters sent straight from hell, the 40-ton creatures would charge straight down the muzzle of a harpoon gun and, even mortally wounded from harpoons, defend their young until their last breath, holing many a stout whaling boat with their huge bodies.

title: RUNNING AFTER RAINBOWS ON THE FRINGES OF FAME
description: WHEN I was 13 years old, I took tap-dancing lessons from Gene Kelly's sister Louise at her studio in Johnstown, Pa.

title: SHE RUNS TO CONQUER
description: A WHITE ROMANCE By Virginia Hamilton. 191 pp. New York: Philomel Books. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Ovid's Best Sellers
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUTH IN TRANSIT
description: AN ARTIFICIAL WILDERNESS Essays on 20th-Century Literature. By Sven Birkerts. 430 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $20.95.

title: WHERE THE REAGAN REVOLUTION WENT AWRY
description: PRESIDENT Reagan's reconstructed tax system is intact; he has won his big budgets for the Pentagon, although they are subject to raid; all his inveighing against other Government spending has paid off in the sense that even liberal Democrats advocate restraint. Last week, West Germany buckled to American pressure and cut interest rates, helping American banks to cut theirs. All told, the President's friends might argue that in times that invite comparisons with those of Herbert Hoover, Ronald Reagan has built a respectable record.

title:
GARDENING;
THE APPEAL OF THE MUSTARD FAMILY
description: LEAD: ONE of the more interesting and youthful plant species is Brassica oleracea. Native to western and southern Europe, it has yielded many interesting and useful forms in cultivation. This is the species of such diverse and familiar vegetables as collards, kale, broccoli, cauliflower, cabbage, brussels sprouts and kohlrabi, among others.

title: TEACHERS TO CONVENE IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Education Association, a 125,000-member teachers' union, will hold its annual convention here Thursday and Friday.

title: Slain Girl Was Abused for Weeks, Evidence Shows
description: Forensic evidence indicates that 6-year-old Elizabeth Steinberg was subjected to several weeks of physical abuse before the battering last weekend in which her fatal injuries were inflicted, a top official in the investigation said yesterday.

title: On a Gulf Tanker: Waiting for the Worst
description: ''All ahead full,'' the command was given quietly. A button was pushed. A bell rang. The big oil tanker headed for the Strait of Hormuz, and at that moment it became a strategic target in the Persian Gulf war.

title: Music: Recent Pieces by Steve Reich
description: ANYONE interested in understanding the importance of Steve Reich's music had only to look around at Thursday night's audience in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The people were there to hear three of Mr. Reich's newer pieces, played by the guitarist Pat Metheny with a conglomeration of Brooklyn Philharmonic musicians and the composer's own corps of percussion players. Both groups were conducted by Kent Nagano.

title: PIED PIPER ON THE COMPUTER
description: IT WAS A SUNNY afternoon in Los Angeles, and the researchers at Alan Kay's computer lab were outside on the playground, shrieking their way through recess. Inside, in the art room of a rather down-at-the-heels elementary school in West Hollywood, a group of local technologists - people from the University of California at Los Angeles, the Rand Corporation, the International Business Machines Corporation, Pacific Telesis, the Times Mirror Company - were gathered around Formica-topped tables to hear Kay talk. A visionary scientist who has become a sort of Buckminster Fuller of personal computing, Kay was outlining his latest and most ambitious project.

title: DRUG USE EMERGES AS CAMPAIGN ISSUE
description: Saying that he would ''much rather be here talking about arms control or the stock market crash,'' Senator Albert Gore Jr. volunteered at a state convention in Miami yesterday that he had occasionally smoked marijuana as a student and as a soldier in Vietnam.

title: Mozambique Downs Plane
description: Armed forces shot down an unidentified plane near Mozambique's border with Malawi on Friday, Maputo radio said today. The radio quoted military sources as saying the plane was violating the country's airspace about 10 miles from Malawi's western border. The radio said the authorities were still trying to identify the plane. Its report made no mention of casualties, but an official said one body was found in the wreckage.

title: Alvin Dewey Dies; Investigated Killings Depicted by Capote
description: Alvin A. Dewey, chief investigator of the 1959 killings chronicled in the book and movie ''In Cold Blood,'' died Friday at a hospital here after suffering a stroke at his home. He was 75 years old.

title: UPWARD PRESSURE ON THE U.S. MINIMUM WAGE
description: SINCE 1981, the Federal minimum wage has been frozen at $3.35 an hour, which translates to an annual income of less than $7,000. Fearing inflation and opposing Government encroachment on the marketplace, the Reagan Administration has been dead set against increasing the figure.

title: Talking: Co-ops; Updating Clauses On Usage
description: CONTROL of New York City co-ops -who lives in the apartments and how they are used - has long been a prime concern for tenant-shareholders.

title: TAKING IT LIKE LITTLE TROOPERS
description: AN ACTOR By Brooke Goffstein. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: A Charlotte Zolotow Book/ Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 8) AN ACTOR'S LIFE FOR ME! By Lillian Gish. As told to Selma G. Lanes. Illustrated by Patricia Henderson Lincoln. 80 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $14.95. (Ages 10 and up) ON CAMERA The Story of a Child Actor. By Joan Hewett. Photographs by Richard Hewett. 56 pp. New York: Clarion Books/Ticknor & Fields. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Dance: Joffrey Recasts 'Three Preludes'
description: EVERY ballet company repertory needs a slight romantic pas de deux, and the Joffrey Ballet has one in Ben Stevenson's ''Three Preludes,'' a crowd-pleaser created in 1969 and acquired this year by the company, which presented it with a new cast on Thursday at City Center. Set to piano music by Rachmaninoff that was performed here by Stanley Babin, ''Three Preludes'' offers a pastel vision of a studio flirtation between two young dancers and its extension into ballet partnering. Tom Mossbrucker and, particularly, Deborah Dawn made the most of the ballet's slender pickings.

title: The Paternal Pride Of Maurice Sendak
description: MAURICE SENDAK ON children: ''I have none.

title: Tunisia's Premier Seizes Power, Declaring Bourguiba to Be Senile
description: Prime Minister Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali took power in Tunisia today on grounds that Habib Bourguiba, its President for life, was too ill and senile to govern any longer.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Dover $167,500 44 Daniel Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; full carpeting, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,678. Mantoloking Shores $380,000 333 Barkentine Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old ranch; fireplace, C/A, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500. Old Bridge $175,000 26 Tulip Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 21-year-old contemporary; new roof, C/A, security system; taxes $2,586. Short Hills $288,000 22 Baltusrol Way 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old expanded ranch; enclosed porch, den, fireplace; taxes $3,380. South Orange $335,000 7 Stonehill Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old split level; family room, 2-car attached garage, fireplace; taxes $6,828. Watchung $682,500 70 Acorn Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 2-year-old colonial; deck, sunken living room, 2-car garage; taxes $4,899. OTHER AREAS White Plains, N.Y. $279,000 61 Ogden Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 59-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, sun room, playroom, deck; taxes $2,099. Simsbury, Conn. $269,900 10 Merrywood 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old contemporary; interior balconies, 3 decks; taxes, $4,057. Massapequa, L.I. $310,000 200 Cedar Shore Drive 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 30-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $6,000.

title: Holiday Gifts For the Thinker
description: IF THERE IS an ideal time to buy a gift for Christmas or Hanukkah, it is undoubtedly before Thanksgiving. Stores and mail-order-catalogue houses are fully stocked with merchandise, salespeople are relaxed and the throngs of holiday shoppers are still a gleam in a shopkeeper's eye. For the student or educator in the family, gifts this year can be both fun and educational. While many of them help the scholar get the work done, educators believe gifts for young people should be given in a light-hearted rather than earnest spirit.

title: What Survives in History
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Leinsdorf Offers Britten and Debussy
description: BOTH ends of the New York Philharmonic's Friday night concert at Avery Fisher Hall brought us to the edge of the sea. But we were shown it from very different sides. People share equal billing in Britten's ''Peter Grimes'' (we heard the Passacaglia and the four ''Sea Interludes''). Debussy's ''La Mer'' rises beyond human passions and depicts the sea itself.

title: Women Are Reshaping The Field of Public Art
description: CINCINNATI, Nov. 7 - When residents and merchants in this city's Hyde Park neighborhood decided that a small piece of roadside parkland known as the Mudhole needed a better image, they set out to dress it up with a piece of public sculpture.

title: Dr. Elliot Regenbogen Weds Melissa Epstein
description: At the Beth El Synagogue Center in New Rochelle, N.Y., Melissa Epstein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Epstein of Yonkers, was married last evening to Dr. Elliot Regenbogen, the son of of Helen Regenbogen of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Irving Regenbogen. Rabbi Melvin Serner officiated.

title: FLOAT AND SLITHER
description: THE YELLOW UMBRELLA By Henrik Drescher. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Bradbury Press. $9.95. (Ages 2 to 5) RAINBOW RHINO By Peter Sis. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95. (Ages 3 to 5)

title: Administration Renews Struggle To Agree on an Acceptable Choice
description: After the successive failures of two nominations to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court, the White House and the Justice Department must again search for a nominee whose ideological credentials can satisfy Republican conservatives and still permit confirmation in a Democratic-controlled Senate.

title: ACTIVE BIDDING HIGHLIGHTED RECENT SALES
description: THE rare stamp department of Christie's/Robson Lowe, international auctioneers, conducted three sales of stamps and covers last month. The sales, dominated by hard-to-find material that collectors seek, drew active floor and mail bidding which resulted in a $2,484,454 total for the 1,500 lots.

title: Sandinista Offer Of Conciliation: Is It a Bid for Peace or Just to Buy Time?
description: THE Arias plan for peace in Central America registered an accomplishment last week that had eluded the United States Government in nearly seven years of political and clandestine military conflict with Nicaragua. The Sandinista Government was placed on the defensive and obliged to accept indirect negotiations with the contra rebels.

title: Contradiction In Terms
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: HOMOSEXUALS AND THE CHURCHES
description: In his article ''Homosexuals and the Churches'' (Oct. 11), Edward Tivnan writes that ''research seems now to indicate [ that ] one has no choice in being homosexual.'' The premise is an astonishingly broad one and cannot be allowed to pass unconsidered.

title: STATE'S RADON DRIVE RUNS INTO APATHY
description: LEAD: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection can induce a public outcry with the mere hint of a landfill site, but its officials admit they have yet to find words to inspire widespread concern about radon.

title: A CIVILIAN RECALLS HIS 'GOOD WAR'
description: IT was my examination for the draft in 1940 that saved my life - just as that ceremony led to the opposite outcome for so many of my generation. My chest X-ray revealed advanced tuberculosis, and the news that there were to be more germs than Germans in my future. Being infected in both lungs I was considered unlikely to recover -a bit of trivia not revealed to me at the time. My fate, as that of my sounder brothers, was left a mystery.

title: A Neighborhood
description: A COMMON QUESTION among many women, I'm told, is ''Where are all the single men?''

title: MOVIES
description: The Left-Handed Gun With Paul Newman, directed by Arthur Penn. 1958. Warner Home Video. 102 minutes. $19.98. If you think a movie starring Paul Newman and directed by Arthur Penn can't be all bad, you don't remember ''The Left-Handed Gun,'' which came and went in 1958 and, like the bad guys in westerns, now returns to put a new generation to sleep. Saddled with a pretentious and senseless screenplay about Billy the Kid, this lame oater drags all parties down with it. The direction is awkward-arty, and young Mr. Newman, as Billy, is moody-manic, as he goes about killing four baddies who murdered his kindly boss. The intention seems to be to turn the Kid into a 1950-ish mixed-up delinquent with a soul, James Dean with spurs. Maybe they should have given Mr. Newman a motorycle; at least he could have escaped. Hurd Hatfield wanders mystifyingly through, dressed in black, probably in mourning for Billy's reputation.

title: THEATER 'THE SOUND OF MUSIC' IS IN EAST WINDSOR
description: TRANSFUSING ''The Sound of Music'' with a fresh, youthful renewed point of view doesn't seem easy, or even essential, since the last of the Rodgers and Hammerstein collaborations has been doing just fine, pleasing audiences in its own staid, old-fashioned style for almost 30 years.

title: ALCOHOLISM COURSE FOCUSES ON PARENTS
description: ''A LOT of parents don't know what to tell their kids about using alcohol, except to 'be responsible,' '' said Deirdre M. Breen, a community-education specialist with the Westchester chapter of the National Council on Alcoholism and Other Drug Addictions. ''They believe that they are good kids, and then cross their fingers when they go out to a party. But kids need specific guidelines.''

title: Antarctic Map Alters as Giant Iceberg Breaks Off
description: An iceberg twice as big as Rhode Island has broken away from Antarctica and is drifting in the Ross Sea, the National Science Foundation says.

title: CARLUCCI'S FIRST PROBLEM IS A PARALYZED MILITARY BUDGET
description: WHEN Frank C. Carlucci succeeds Caspar W. Weinberger as Defense Secretary, his most pressing problem will be to untangle the budgetary gridlock that has practically immobilized the Pentagon's planning, say senior officials in the Administration and Congress.

title: Violin: Grigory Zhislin
description: THIS season, Town Hall and Classical Artists International have been co-sponsoring a series of concerts entitled Russian Nights, featuring prominent Soviet musicians unfamiliar to American audiences. The first installment came last month with a recital by Vladimir Krainev, a pianist, and the second concert took place Friday evening with the debut of Grigory Zhislin, a violinist. Both performances confirmed that the Russian school, with its emphasis on virtuosity, lives on.

title: Nancy Perry Marries Lieut. R. T. Webster
description: Nancy Elizabeth Perry and Lieut. Russell Todd Webster, U.S.A., were married last evening at the Unitarian Church in Westport, Conn., by the Rev. Harris Riordon.

title: LIBRARY, 100, LOOKS BACK AT ITS ROOTS
description: LEAD: FORTUNATELY for the Pequot Library in Southport, Christopher Columbus was a conscientious letter writer. The library's most prized possession is his 32-page letter describing his voyage and experiences in America, which he wrote in Portugal in 1493. It was printed in Barcelona in Spanish and taken to Rome, where it was translated and printed in Latin.

title: LOTS OF PACHYDERMS
description: 17 KINGS AND 42 ELEPHANTS By Margaret Mahy. Illustrated by Patricia MacCarthy. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers. $10.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: 'OUR DEMOCRACY IS DIFFERENT'
description: CONDEMNED TO REPETITION The United States and Nicaragua. By Robert A. Pastor. Illustrated. 392 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $24.95.

title:
Film;
London, as Seen Through the Eyes of an Angry Outsider
description: LEAD: HANIF KUREISHI, REBEL spirit, retired pornographer, angry young Anglo-Pakistani, voice of Britain's disenchanted and disinherited, scenarist of last year's ''My Beautiful Laundrette'' and this season's newly opened ''Sammy and Rosie Get Laid'' has a sturdy, no-nonsense approach to the art of cinema.

title: Roosevelt Rallies to Top White Plains in Showdown
description: In a battle between two undefeated teams in Westchester County, Roosevelt High School of Yonkers roared back from a 17-0 first-period deficit yesterday to defeat White Plains, 26-23, at the losers' field.

title: Countless Copies of Choice Cattle
description: IN the last decade, beef has steadily lost ground to chicken as a component of the American diet. But University Genetics, in Westport, Conn., hopes to reverse the trend by using biotechnology to breed leaner beef cattle. ''We already have beef that's actually lower in cholesterol and fat than chicken,'' said Randal Charlton, company president.

title: THE IRRESISTIBLE JINGO
description: GUNGA DIN By Rudyard Kipling. Illustrated by Robert Andrew Parker. Introduction by Kingsley Amis. Unpaged. San Diego: Gulliver Books/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) THE JUNGLE BOOK By Rudyard Kipling. Illustrated by Michael Foreman. 175 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $13.95. (Ages 7 to 11) JUST SO STORIES By Rudyard Kipling. Illustrated by Michael Foreman. 128 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $12.95. (Ages 7 to 11) JUST SO STORIES By Rudyard Kipling. Illustrated by Safaya Salter. 96 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $15.95. (Ages 7 to 11)

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: ORANGES ARE NOT THE ONLY FRUIT. By Jeanette Winterson. (Atlantic Monthly Press, Paper, $6.95.) This short, first novel by Jeanette Winterson, who is British, explores a large theme - an adolescent's rejection of the religious fanaticism that has been an integral part of her life ever since she was adopted.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
GREEN-CARPET TREATMENT FOR BOSTON'S NEW IMMIGRANTS
description: LEAD: IRISH immigration has figured so prominently in this city's past that its influence is all but taken for granted. In recent years, however, a new group of immigrants has appeared with brogues so thick that they have added a lilt even to downtown Boston.

title: Ginsburg Had Two Roles in a Pension Case, Documents Show
description: Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, who withdrew today as President Reagan's choice for the Supreme Court, sat for two months this spring as a judge on a pension regulation case arising from actions in which he had been directly involved as a Government official two years earlier, according to court documents.

title: CORRECTION
description: An essay on the Opinion page on Oct. 25 about the radio drama ''War of the Worlds'' misstated the year it was first broadcast. It was 1938.

title: VERIFICATION: WILL IT WORK?
description: David Aaron misstates both the Administration's motives in raising the problem of Soviet noncompliance as well as my own reasons for choosing to leave Government service.

title: 'PUBLIC ART' FINDING A PLACE IN THE STATE
description: IT WAS like a family celebration.

title: Postings: East Bronx Colony; 11 Single-Family Homes
description: A new development of 11 single-family homes, called the Estates at Country Club, has just been opened near Eastchester Bay in the East Bronx by Ruffalo Associates. The homes are along Country Club Road north of the Throgs Neck Bridge.

title: A SHOP FULFILLS A DREAM
description: NAVIGATING the winding roads of Litchfield County without the aid of a map, Francine Scherer zeroes in on farms tucked snugly in the hills and invisible from the main road.

title: Through Socialist Woods in Gorbachev's Troika
description: To the Editor:

title: Keep Banks From the 'Muni' Market
description: ON Oct. 12, Salomon Brothers Inc. announced plans to discontinue its municipal bond department and dismiss 12 percent of its work force. News that the company with the largest share of the business was pulling out of the ''muni'' business was the hottest topic - until Oct. 19 when the stock market made history.

title: Bigger Than Perry?
description: THE Chicago Bears, leading the Central Division with a 6-1 record, are favored to win their game against the 3-3-1 Packers in Green Bay today, but, win or lose, one cherished Chicago record is likely to fall.

title: GEORGE RICKEYAT THE NEUBERGER: MOVEMENT AND BALANCE
description: IT would seem that all is law and order in George Rickey's art, with the law that of gravity and the order the way in which the sculptor uses it. Confirming this up to a point is the Neuberger Museum's ''George Rickey: Projects for Public Sculpture,'' a show that examines nine major works by way of models, drawings and photographs.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
HUCKLEBERRY FINN: OR, SOMETHING EXOTIC IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: LEAD: THERE are not many great writers who manage to become part of a child's imagination - a process that, since imagination may enter many but not all realms, eventually leads to mystery. The reason is simple: no parent in his or her right mind would give an ''Anna Karenina'' or a ''Madame Bovary'' or a ''Moll Flanders,'' or even a ''Pride and Prejudice'' for that matter, to a child who has just learned to read and is beginning to be bored with the colorful but simple-minded exploits of humanoid animals.

title: By Boat Up the Bosporus
description: THE day dawned dull and chill, summoned to a kind of life by the muezzin's call.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a lot of oil stains on my asphalt driveway. What should I use on these stains before I apply a sealer?

title: Art
description: In the front of the darkened room, slides blink on and off. On the floor are three television sets and several dozen icepicks, their business ends dangerously vertical. On the back wall are two glowing figures lighted by ultraviolet lamps. It sounds like a torture chamber, but it's a multi-media installation called ''Common Mistakes.'' The work of Jeanne C. Finley, a young San Francisco artist, it can be seen on the third floor of P. S. 1, 46-01 21st Street in Long Island City, Queens, through Dec. 20.

title: On the Streets Where We Live
description: SHAKER LANE By Alice and Martin Provensen. Illustrated by the authors. Unpaged. New York: Viking Kestrel. $14.95. (All ages) NEW PROVIDENCE A Changing Cityscape. By Renata von Tscharner and Ronald Lee Fleming. Illustrated by Denis Orloff. San Diego: Gulliver Books/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $10.95. (Ages 8 and up) THE STORY OF A MAIN STREET By John S. Goodall. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books. $14.95. (All ages) SKYSCRAPER GOING UP! By Vicki Cobb. Design and paper engineering by John Strejan. Unpaged. New York: Thomas Y. Crowell. $14.95. (Ages 6 to 8)

title: Discovery Jolts an Island Where Time Stands Still
description: For most of the three centuries that people have inhabited this marshy island in the middle of Chesapeake Bay, daily life has been governed by tide, wind, season, isolation and the Methodist church.

title: A POWER IN PERFUME: Robin Burns; Creating Obsession and Making It Last
description: ''I'VE come a long way from Cripple Creek,'' Robin Burns said cheerfully, reminiscing about the Colorado mining town where she spent her earliest years. She ticks off favorite memories: riding a horse to school, collecting chunks of turquoise off the dirt streets to sell to tourists.

title: The Beauty Of Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHAT THE LOVE BOAT LEFT BEHIND
description: HE called the other day to check upon the whereabouts of our daughter. As our conversation meandered through the trivialities of which we always speak - my mother, his aunt, the dog, the kids, our recent travels -he casually mentioned that he was giving a party to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the company.

title: Larry Davis's Companion Cites Police Threat
description: The mother of Larry Davis's 16-month-old daughter was picked up by the police after Mr. Davis's arrest last December and warned that she faced separation from her four children and prosecution for aiding a fugitive, she said in a three-hour court interview last week with Mr. Davis's lawyers.

title: Young Transplant Patient Reaches Milestone
description: Jamie Fiske, whose parents drew wide attention in 1982 with public appeals for organ donors, turns 6 years old on Thanksgiving Day, which doctors consider an important milestone in the girl's recovery from a liver transplant operation five years ago.

title: Follow-Up On the News; Another Shooting In the Subway
description: IT was, in some respects, a New York City subway shooting with similarities to the Goetz case. But it has a different ending. Like Bernhard H. Goetz, James Grimes, a subway token clerk in Brooklyn, carried an unlicensed pistol because he said he had been mugged before. And like Mr. Goetz, Mr. Grimes fired the weapon at four men he said were trying to rob him.

title: Commercial Property: Office Space; Stock Market Turmoil Scares Prospective Tenants
description: UNTIL the stock market plunge three weeks ago, banks and stock brokers consumed Manhattan office space like hungry boys at a Sunday morning buffet. But now they are running scared, seeking to slim down.

title: SMALL MOMENTS OF GRACE AND CHANGE
description: HEREDITY By Patricia Storace. 80 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $7.95. QUIET MONEY By Robert McDowell. 68 pp. New York: An Owl Book/Henry Holt & Company. Paper, $9.95. SNUG HARBOR By Richard Katrovas. 77 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $17. Paper, $8.95.

title: Chinese Professors Inspect Criminal Justice in U.S.
description: When the four professors from Beijing arrived at Logan Airport in Boston for a flight to New York, they found themselves faced with a travelers' quandary: flight attendants told them that unless they left behind dozens of criminology textbooks, gifts from an American colleague, they would be over the weight allowance.

title: Patricia A. Kriger Wed To Michael G. Schaffer
description: Patricia Ann Kriger and Michael Glenn Schaffer were married last evening at the Elmwood Country Club in White Plains by Rabbi Jacob Sodden.

title: Sports of The Times; Czars Under Siege
description: In the good old days when sports were sports, the czars were czars. Watching the World Series with his chin on the box-seat rail, as Kenesaw Mountain Landis did. Running the National Football League from his suburban Philadelphia home, as Bert Bell did. Setting the 24-second clock, as Maurice Podoloff did. Answering his bedside telephone in Montreal after midnight whenever a hockey writer called, as Clarence Campbell did. Even when the days that followed weren't quite so good, some of their successors occasionally were described as czars.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago; River North Is Taking Off
description: PLANS are taking shape for new headquarters for the American Medical Association west of Michigan Avenue and north of the Loop, signaling the long-awaited, full-scale redevelopment of the River North district into a mixed-use adjunct to the rapidly expanding downtown.

title: Troyat's Real Nationality
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A front-page picture caption last Sunday about budget negotiations between Congress and the White House incorrectly stated the place of the meeting. It was at the Capitol.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Hudson, N.H.;
Animal Farm Yields to Homes
description: LEAD: AFTER a seven-year struggle against rising costs and stagnant attendance, Benson's Animal Farm, one of northern New England's largest zoos and amusement parks, has ceased operations. Part of its original 400 acres is to be developed by its owner and another parcel by a local builder.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN AGRICULTURAL BIOTECHNOLOGY
description: THE first wave of products stemming from the biotechnology revolution focused mainly on human health care. But now agricultural biotechnology - the genetic manipulation of crop plants and farm animals - is blossoming as never before. True, only a few products of genetic engineering are on the market, including vaccines to prevent diseases in calves and piglets. But this is just the beginning.

title: A CARETAKER NOMINATED TO OVERSEE THE BROCK LEGACY
description: IN 1981, when President Reagan dismissed striking air traffic controllers who had refused to return to work, he noted that he had once led a strike as head of the Screen Actors Guild. But it was his swift, firm response to the controllers' strike, not his background as a Hollywood labor leader, that set the tone for labor relations in his first term. The labor movement and Mr. Reagan's first Labor Secretary, Raymond J. Donovan, appeared to have little use for or contact with each other.

title: L. I. Laughlin 3d Weds Ms. Clifford
description: At St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Middlebury, Vt., Sarah Clifford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas R. Clifford of Cornwall, Vt., was married yesterday to Ledlie Irwin Laughlin 3d, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Laughlin Jr. of New York and South Woodstock, Vt. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Rosalie Richards, vicar of the Church of the Ascension in New Haven, who was assisted by the Rev. Addison Hall, rector of St. Stephen's.

title: Malaysian Leader Won't Lift Shutdown of a Popular Daily
description: The Government of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has rejected an appeal by The Star against the shutdown of the popular English-language daily on Oct. 28.

title: Checking A House For Radon
description: LEAD: THE BEST time to test for radon is during the winter, when windows are shut and radon levels can build up.

title: Ruth H. Kennedy Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Kennedy of Alexandria, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ruth Hefren Kennedy, to Robert Sloan Bowers, a son of Dr. Malcolm B. Bowers of Branford, Conn., and Rebecca Sloan of New Haven.

title: COUPLE UNVEIL THE 'PRINCESS' IN HOMES
description: LEAD: COLLECTING stamps or works of art might be worthy diversions for some, but for Bruce and Rosine Mims, renovating houses is what enhances, and often consumes, their lives.

title:
GARDENING;
MASTERS IN THEIR FIELD
description: LEAD: A NEW sign has begun to appear on sidewalks around Rockland County, N.Y.: ''Master Gardeners at Work.'' The sign bodes well for beauty; it has appeared in front of the County Courthouse in New City, where Master Gardeners, organized by the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Rockland County, helped a Girl Scout

title: Soviet Says Special Push Is Needed in Arms Treaty
description: Senior Soviet officials said today that high-level attention would be required to resolve remaining technical differences in a treaty to eliminate intermediate range missiles.

title: Slumping Giants Search for What Went Wrong
description: It is obvious what is wrong with the Giants. Isn't it? They spent too much time writing books. Or, they did not spend enough time putting a strike team together. Or, everyone points for a Super Bowl team.

title: New Heights For the City?
description: THIS city on Casco Bay, a center of new construction and renovation in the last decade, is to decide whether to allow construction of taller buildings now that land on the Portland Peninsula has become expensive and scarce.

title: A LEFTIST LEADER SURGING IN CANADA
description: When President Reagan visited Canada's capital in April, White House officials declined a request for a meeting with Edward Broadbent, leader of the New Democratic Party. Protocol required the President to meet with the country's official opposition Leader, John Turner, but not with Mr. Broadbent, whose party has been a left-wing minority in Parliament for 52 years.

title: FROZEN MOMENTS IN A FOREST OF ICE
description: FOX'S DREAM By Tejima. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Philomel Books. $13.95. (Ages 3 and up)

title:
THEATER;
Crossed Lines: Father, Son and a Telephone
description: LEAD: ''I DIDN'T SET OUT TO WRITE A father-son play, but when I had the father saying, 'My son is an imbecile,' it just seemed logical to see the other side of the coin,'' said Joe Cacaci, whose play, ''Old Business,'' opens the season Tuesday at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Susan Stein Shiva Theater.

title: Black Quarterbacks Find A Smoother Path to the Pros
description: ONCE the effects of pro football's recent power struggle between the owners and the players subside and a new National Football League champion is crowned, the current season will most likely be remembered for strikeball, as well as the sudden demise of the Giants. But in future years it might also be remembered as the season when pro football showed signs of overcoming its most lingering phobia: apprehension over the use of the black quarterback.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Recycle or Repent ''THEY can put me in jail - I'm not paying any fine because of garbage.'' Marie Lawrence of Bohemia, the 24-year-old mother of Christopher, a 3-month-old, is to appear in court tomorrow morning as Long Island's first non-garbage-sorting offender. Mrs. Lawrence failed to separate her recyclables.

title: HOW MUSIC PAINTS CHARACTER
description: OPERA IS DRAMA, AND, AS JOSEPH KER-man argued more than 30 years ago in his provocative ''Opera as Drama,'' the composer is the dramatist. That is still one of the trickiest truths of opera to understand. Misunderstanding it can skew performance priorities, and often does. What does it mean that the composer is the dramatist? Nothing less than that the drama of opera lies in the score, the notes of the score, rather than in the words of the libretto. And how is it that notes in a score can express character, emotion, meaning?

title: INCINERATOR IMPASSE AT STONY BROOK
description: LEAD: A THREE-WAY struggle between the State University of New York at Stony Brook administration, the regional office of the State Department of Environmental Conservation and Stony Brook residents over an incinerator that university officials intend to build on campus has reached an impasse. The development came after university officials announced that the approval that they said the state had granted was no longer effective.

title: Karen Donfried to Wed Alan Untereiner
description: The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Karl P. Donfried of Amherst, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Erika Donfried, to Alan Edward Untereiner, the son of Dr. Wayne Whitlock Untereiner of Rancho California, Calif., and the late Ann Yeomans Abbott. A June wedding is planned.

title: MODERNIZING ELECTRICAL WALL OUTLETS
description: IN many older homes, electrical wall receptacles possess only two slots per outlet. Modern three-slot receptacles, which have a semicircular hole centered beneath each pair of slots, are more convenient. And because they provide better grounding for plug-in appliances, they are safer.

title: BISTRO MAESTROS
description: THE FRENCH BISTRO - A small, traditional family restaurant - has become synonymous with hearty, no-nonsense food. Celeri remoulade, giant bowls of herring in cream, terrines of gamey pates, french fries and grilled steak, hearty cassoulets, beef stewed in red wine, chocolate mousse and tarte Tatin are served in an equally unpretentious atmosphere. Wooden chairs are stiff and worn, and the handwritten menus are so faded that they are almost illegible.

title: HORSES BACKSTAGE
description: WHEN THE FAT MAN SINGS By William Murray. 216 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $14.95.

title: Forget Cholesterol and Explore Other Heart-Disease Theories
description: To the Editor:

title: Maria T. Mariaca Becomes a Bride
description: Maria Teresa Mariaca, the daughter of Janette Kling Mariaca and Alberto C. Mariaca, both of New York, was married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York to William Kinne Barnett, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis B. Barnett of Blacksburg, Va. The Rev. William D. Roberts officiated.

title: Meeting on Minorities
description: SOME 60 minority-group members with professional baseball ties are meeting in Irving, Tex., this weekend to promote hiring of black and Hispanic persons in the major leagues. The group, calling itself The Baseball Network, was organized by Frank Robinson, Willie Stargell, Ray Burris and a former scout, Ben Moore. A meeting between the group's executive committee and representatives of Commissioner Peter Ueberroth is scheduled for Monday. ''The focus of the meeting centered on the conspicuous absence of blacks and other minorities in decision-making positions on the field, the front office and umpiring,'' said Moore, the group's acting executive director.

title: Old Masters Offer Fresh Lessons at Yale
description: FIRST LOVE IS THE REAL THING, tradition says. But looking at works of art is also a form of love, and we never forget the moment at which we first found out how much can come of it. For this reason, every university museum should be designated as a sacred place - one in which the guards go disguised and can reveal themselves when we least expect them. In museums of that sort, where young people rather like to stalk one another, it can happen that art itself does the stalking. Those who walk into the Yale Art Gallery in search of Winslow Homer's adorable little painting of a croquet game may find, instead, that it is the Roman marble figure of Leda (second century A.D., after the Greek sculptor Timotheus) that has opened a new valve of feeling within them.

title: Dr. W. H. Montgomery 3d Is Married to Cynthia Hart
description: Cynthia Ruffner Hart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alden S. Hart of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., was married yesterday at the Congregational Church in Short Hills, N.J., to Dr. William Harland Montgomery 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Montgomery Jr. of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. Gregory Schmidt officiated.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Oct. 24 MANHATTAN East Midtown $200,000 150 East 56th Street 1-bedroom. 1-bath, 880-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, hardwood floors; common charge $649, taxes $2,853 (Broker:

title: Chinese Carpets Fit for a Prince
description: ALONG with its many other treasures, Hong Kong is the home of the Tai Ping carpet, already as famous in only 30 years as some of those precious floor coverings that came out of pre-revolutionary China. The hand-woven carpets of Tai Ping, made by Hong Kong Manufacturers Ltd., in the New Territories ''new town'' of Tai Po, about 25 miles north of Kowloon, are to be found in Buckingham Palace, Windsor Castle, the headquarters of the United Nations in Geneva, the Ritz Hotel in London, the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia and the Loews Regency Hotel in Manhattan, the Los Angeles Music Center, the palace of the Sultan of Brunei, the Royal Government Palace in Thailand, the Hotel George V and the Cinema Berlitz in Paris, and even the Epcot Center theater in Walt Disney World.

title: Jonathan L. Mechanic Wed to Wendy Levine
description: Wendy Sue Levine, the daughter of Jane N. Levine of Clifton, N.J., and Dr. Frank L. Levine of Saddle Brook, N.J., was married last evening to Jonathan L. Mechanic, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Mayer Mechanic of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi David Panitz and his son, Rabbi Michael Panitz, officiated at the Park Lane Hotel in New York.

title: Army Worker's $8.70 Gadget Could Save $6.3 Million a Year
description: A civilian who works at a National Guard base has created a device that could save the Army more than $6 million a year, military officials say.

title: POPS ORCHESTRA TO MAKE ITS DEBUT IN TARRYTOWN
description: THE county has a new orchestra, the all-professional Empire State Pops, and if you would like to be able to say you heard it when, now is the time: at 8 P.M. Saturday at the Music Hall Theater in Tarrytown.

title: Ailing Illinois Congressman Announces His Retirement
description: Representative Kenneth J. Gray, a 12-term Democrat, said today he will not seek re-election next year in his Southern Illinois district because of health problems and political opposition.

title: A SHIFT TO CHANGE IS SEEN IN CHINA
description: Advocates of change in China won a solid victory at its 13th Congress of the Communist Party, but the balance between them and more cautious leaders has been carefully preserved, according to a number of academic specialists on China.

title: NEW SCHOOL PLAN IS WEIGHED
description: LEAD: AS White Plains public school officials move closer to deciding how to reorganize the school district for at least the fifth time in 24 years, community reaction ranges from impatience to apathy.

title: Echoes of Revolution and New Change in Red Square
description: The Soviet Union celebrated its 70th anniversary today with a martial parade of the old trappings of the Bolshevik Revolution and the new watchwords of the Revolution's latest leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Realism, Without Sentimentality
description: LEAD: THOMAS EAKINS: A MOTION PORTRAIT Home Vision. 60 minutes. $39.95.

title: THE CONTRADICTIONS OF BOB DOLE
description: BOB DOLE WAS adamant. The budget deficit, he had said since the beginning of the Reagan Presidency, was ''the nation's No. 1 priority.'' Now, standing on the floor of the United States Senate, the tall, crisply tailored Kansan was elaborating on that theme. Health programs, he said, were ''just another instance of how Congress puts spending on automatic pilot.''

title: WHERE TO BUY BOOKS
description: IT'S the time of year when I start feeling sorry for the man from United Parcel Service. Almost daily he has to lug an armload of coffee-table sized photography books, still warm from the presses, into my apartment. It's getting close to Christmas, which means (to book publishers, at least) that it is a grand time for luxurious, eye-catching books.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE BERG-SCHOENBERG CORRESPONDENCE: Selected Letters. Edited by Juliane Brand, Christopher Hailey and Donald Harris. (Norton, $35.) The relationship between Arnold Schoenberg and Alban Berg, two composers largely responsible for the second coming of Vienna at the turn of the century, extended far beyond that of teacher and student.

title: Corrections
description: A map of Chicago on Sept. 27 misidentified a road south of Congress Parkway; it is Balbo Drive, not Balboa Drive.

title: Pro Hockey; Devils Go to 8-0 At Home
description: The Byrne Meadowlands Arena is turning out to be a truly sweet home for the Devils this season. Tonight, they beat the Washington Capitals, 4-1, to remain undefeated after eight games here.

title: California Quake Smaller Than First Thought
description: The earthquake in Southern California last month was smaller than first estimated, but it also showed that faults hidden by a fold in the earth's crust may make the city more quake-prone than once believed.

title: New Unesco Chief Wants the U.S. to Rejoin
description: Unesco's General Conference voted overwhelmingly today to elect Federico Mayor Zaragoza, a former Spanish Education Minister, as its next Director General.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: INCIDENTS IN THE LIFE OF A SLAVE GIRL, Written by Herself, Harriet A. Jacobs. Edited by Jean Fagan Yellin. Harvard University Press. 306 pages. Hardcover $37.50, paperback $9.95.

title: WHO SHOULD BE THE M.V.P.'S IN BASEBALL?
description: The m.v.p. doesn't just mean the best player, but the man who did the most to help his team win. In the National League, I think Will Clark should win the trophy. In the American League, I think George Bell should win because he was the best offensive and defensive producer in the league. EVAN KANTOR Scarsdale

title: A Canadian Becomes the 26th U. S. President
description: THE PINCE-NEZ AND THE PUSH broom mustache have a lot to do with the visceral response of the audience to Len Cariou's entrance, in ''Teddy and Alice.'' The generous sprinklings of ''Bully!'' through the dialogue don't hurt, either.

title: EXPLORING THE ARTIST-MOTHER BOND
description: LEAD: FOR whatever reason, psychological need or economic necessity because they were free models, artists have been painting, drawing and sculpturing their mothers at least since 1514, when Albrecht Durer immortalized his on canvas. But until Saturday, when ''The Artist's Mother: Portraits and Homages'' opens at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, no museum or gallery had ever explored the theme in a full-fledged exhibition that examined the why and how of the intensely personal artist-mother relationship.

title: What Do People Want, Anyway?
description: THE Campbell Soup Company, like most consumer products companies, has always asked its customers lots of questions. Last year alone, its field researchers contacted close to 110,000 people to talk about food - taste, preparation, nutritional value, the works. On the basis of what they said, Campbell changed the seasonings in five Le Menu dinners and introduced a line of low-salt soups called, appropriately enough, Special Request.

title: A Nod (Zzzz) To Sex Ed
description: IT CAME to my attention recently that October had once again been designated by sex-education groups as National Family Sexuality Education Month. Not knowing quite how to mark the occasion or whether businesses would be closed, I stayed put and gave it a little thought: What should the young learn about sex that they do not already know? When should they learn it? Who should be forced to teach it? In the murky world of sex, good teachers are hard to find. The willing and the able are usually not the same people. Arguments go on constantly over who should do the honors. Educators accuse parents of neglecting their duties; parents accuse educators of much the same thing. No one seems eager to step forward and take responsibility. Like mud wrestling, sex education appears to attract many spectators but few volunteers.

title: DECLARING WAR AT HOME
description: CHRISTINA KATERINA And the Time She Quit the Family. By Patricia Lee Gauch. Illustrated by Elise Primavera. Unpaged. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: Holy Cross Now 9-0
description: Jeff Wiley passed for two touchdowns and Gordie Lockbaum ran for one and passed for another today as Holy Cross defeated Harvard, 41-6.

title: Larger Collapse Inquiry Urged
description: An engineering consultant who helped Federal agencies investigating the collapse of L'Ambiance Plaza in Bridgeport says the investigation should be expanded.

title: THE MARSHALL LODE STILL YIELDS TREASURES
description: MOST openings go through cycles of rise and decline whose duration cannot be concretely predicted, but the Marshall Gambit accelerates the process to roller-coaster speed.

title: 3 Indicted on Bomb Charges
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted three Lebanese-born Canadians for trying to smuggle a bomb into the United States, the authorities said. The three men, Walid Nicolas Kabbani, 30 years old, Walid Majiv Mourad, 39, and Georges Fouad Nicolas Younan, 44, were arrested Oct. 24, a short time after they crossed the border at Richford. The suthorities said the three, who are being held without bail, live in the Montreal area and are in the textile business.

title: Music
description: Small-orchestra concerts at the beginning and the end of this week catch the critic's eye. Monday night the Jupiter Symphony, directed by Jens Nygaard, plays one of its expected programs of the unexpected at Alice Tully Hall. Strauss's Horn Concerto will show up, the Bach Double Concerto, here in its oboe-violin version, also out-of-the-way pieces by Dvorak, Tchaikovsky and Weber. Either by accident or design, Mr. Nygaard remains an iconoclast in New York's music world - operating around its fringes but still able to create orchestra concerts that are unusually convincing and deeply felt. He has organized his own group and gives a series every year; and in a music world that pressure and workload has rendered a little callous, these events are usually pockets of warmth and caring. This particular Jupiter Symphony concert uses quite a few soloists - Robert Routch, horn; Gerard Reuter, oboe; Catherine Metz and David Kim, violins; Vivian Barton, cello; and Alan Kay, clarinet.

title: G.O.P. IN TRENTON FACING NEED FOR MORE CONCILIATION
description: THE results of New Jersey's record $12 million legislative elections held few surprises: Voters rejected a proposal to build a $185 million baseball stadium backed by state tax revenues and left the State Senate under Democratic control and the Assembly in Republican hands.

title: The Litigious Groves of Academe
description: AT THE TRIAL, Shyamala Rajender had to endure what she calls ''a pack of lies'' hurled at her by the University of Minnesota, where she used to teach chemistry. ''They said I was not a good teacher, that I was not a good researcher, that I didn't compare with any of the bright stars in the department,'' she recalled, the anger barely veiled in her voice after more than a decade of grievance procedures and litigation that finally forced the university to grant her tenure.

title: Tunisia At a Glance
description: Geography

title: ORPHEUS AT THE WORD PROCESSOR
description: THE MEDUSA FREQUENCY By Russell Hoban. 143 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

title: Pacers Overrun Woeful Knicks
description: The Knicks have been hoping to shake up professional basketball a bit this season. Faced with the prospect of relentless defensive pressure and a motion-oriented offense, their opponents were supposed to be wary of an evening that could result in frustration.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Making Growth and Green Acres Coexist
description: LEAD: DEVELOPMENT pressure in the last seven years has pushed the expansion of New Jersey's central suburbs deep into the countryside of Somerset County. So when the Old Pine Brook Country Club in Montgomery Township was for sale a few years ago, it was thought that the 18-hole golf course and its 157 acres of open space would be lost.

title: Chamber Concert
description: Judith Pearce, a flutist, Elizabeth DeFelice, a pianist, and Donald Palma, a double-bassist, will play works by J.S. Bach, Vaughan Williams, Varese, Ives, Wallingford Riegger and Carl Reinecke tomorrow at 8 in Weill Recital Hall. Tickets at $10, or $5 for students and the elderly, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: LITHOGRAPHS OF THE KELLOGGS OFFER A GLIMPSE OF VICTORIAN ERA
description: LEAD: IN 19th-century America, lithographs decorated the walls of homes and offices, hotels and business establishments. More than 900 American companies turned out lithographs of landscapes, portraits of heroes, images of home life and re-enactments of current events quickly and inexpensively after the lithographic process was introduced from

title: Seoul Is Alive With Sounds Of Politicians
description: In this city loud with the blare of car horns, the cries of hawkers and the late-night bang of construction, there is a new sound: the talk of politics.

title: East Harlem Residents Concerned About Dwindling Bank Services
description: More than 200 people, concerned about dwindling bank services in East Harlem, met yesterday to assess the impact of the problem on the predominantly black and Hispanic community.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $152,000 1502 St. Louis Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 32-year-old split level; den, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,400. Freeport $110,000 204 East Seaman Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement with bar, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300. Levittown $145,000 17 Blue Spruce Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, oversized master bedroom; taxes $3,000. Massapequa $310,000 200 Cedar Shore Drive 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 30-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $6,000. Smithtown $275,000 30 Stony Hill Path 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 17-year-old ranch; den with fireplace, basement, 2-car garage, 1.5 acres; taxes $5,100. West Islip $137,000 815 Udall Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $3,500. OTHER AREAS Mantoloking Shores, N.J. $380,000 333 Barkentine Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old ranch; fireplace, C/A, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500. White Plains, N.Y. $279,000 61 Ogden Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 59-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, sun room, playroom, deck; taxes $2,099. Simsbury, Conn. $269,900 10 Merrywood 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old contemporary; interior balconies, 3 decks; taxes, $4,057.

title: Rock Grows Up, Gracefully And Otherwise
description: SEVEN YEARS AGO I ATTENDED a concert by the late blues giant Muddy Waters that forever changed my assumption that rock music made by musicians over 50 could only look foolish. Mr. Waters, then 66, looked every day of his age. But when he barked out such bump-and-grind blues classics as ''I'm Your Hoochie Coochie Man'' and ''Got My Mojo Working,'' the singer-guitarist exuded a gruff charisma that was commandingly ferocious. One of the secrets of aging well in rock, I realized, was the performer's deep engagement with his music. Mr. Waters didn't simply play the blues. He had lived them all his life, and his spiritual and physical connections to his activity were total.

title: FAT, 13 AND BASICALLY O.K.
description: JUST AS LONG AS WE'RE TOGETHER By Judy Blume. 296 pp. New York: Orchard Books/Franklin Watts. $12.95. (Ages 10 to 13)

title: PROSPECTS
description: Post-Crash Careers

title: Molly Fergusson Wed in Richmond
description: Mary Spencer Fergusson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell G. Fergusson of Richmond, was married at St. James's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Graham Yoshio Tanaka, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Y. Clifford Tanaka of South Pasadena, Calif. The Rev. Frank F. Fagan, assisted by the Rev. Thomas R. Smith, performed the ceremony.

title: GIULIANI: THE PUBLIC RECORD OF A HIGHLY PUBLIC PROSECUTOR
description: WHETHER it's the nature of the job or of the people who fill it, a United States Attorney is typically on the quiet side. Because Rudolph W. Giuliani is not, the Federal prosecutor's office in Manhattan is probably more in the public mind than ever before. Mr. Giuliani's own image has been well-exposed, too, which should not hurt if he decides, as is widely speculated, to seek the Republican nomination for the Senate next year.

title: A VOODOO GUIDE TO THE MARGINAL
description: REUBEN By John Edgar Wideman. 215 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $16.95.

title: Patricia Taylor Bride Of Antonio P. Salazar
description: Patricia Taylor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund R. Taylor Jr. of Pocantico Hills, N.Y., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary Magdalene to Antonio Patrick Salazar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Salazar of New Britain, Conn. Msgr. Stephen J. Fitzgerald, pastor of the church, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Joseph M. Kilmartin, an uncle of the bride.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: LINCOLN, R.I.;
Cluster Project On Rural Tract
description: LEAD: FOR years developers have approached Tom Davis, trying to buy 102 acres that have been in his family for 50 years. The property is thick with woods, there is a large pond and sheep graze on gentle slopes, and Mr. Davis has been hopeful of maintaining its rural atmosphere.

title: Dance: Karen Monson
description: IT'S easy to say what Karen Monson's ''Blood on the Saddle'' wasn't. Despite its title, it wasn't a Western. But it's harder to determine just what it was.

title: Guilt in the Lindbergh Case
description: To the Editor:

title: The Teen Years: Time of Mixed Messages
description: THEY ARE the children of the children of the 60's, growing up in an age when much of what seemed outrageous then is commonplace. Yet in many ways, today's teen-agers are having to sort through an ambiguous and contested legacy. The sexual revolution in America bequeathed them a social code that is explicit yet no longer liberated, and an atmosphere in which adolescents are scrutinized more publicly than ever before, yet given little guidance by the adults they must answer to.

title: VOLUNTEERS' MOTIVES CHANGE
description: LEAD: ''I DO a lot of volunteer work,'' said Joe Bartolf of Garden City, a retired elementary-school principal. ''It's like love - the more you give, the more you get.''

title: Architect's Response
description: To the Editor:

title: TRACING STEPS OF LEATHER MAN
description: HE looked so peculiar that ''high strung horses stopped and wouldn't move'' until he passed, or so the legend goes. He trudged his 365-mile route for 30 years so punctually that housewives in Westchester County and Connecticut had a plate of food waiting every 34th day.

title: Koreans View Their Election With Hope - and Cynicism
description: SOUTH KOREANS are enjoying a novel sensation: being courted by politicians eager for their votes. As campaigning accelerates for next month's election, their first chance in 16 years to vote directly for a president, hundreds of thousands of Koreans are turning out at the candidates' rallies.

title: The Politician As Educator
description: WHEN Robert F. Wagner Jr. was a young New York City Councilman at Large he suggested, only half jokingly, that a fire alarm be set off at 110 Livingston Street, the turn-of-the-century building in downtown Brooklyn that houses the city's Board of Education. The offices would be emptied and the doors locked, and the school bureaucrats should never be allowed to return.

title: Plan for a Mall Jolts Downtown Syracuse
description: LEAD: INTENT on bolstering the tax base of Syracuse, city officials have embraced a plan for the redevelopment of a 750-acre industrial tract on the fringe of the city that some local businessmen say would adversely affect the economically weak downtown area.

title: THE FORGOTTEN WAR
description: LEAD: AMONG THE AFGHANS By Arthur Bonner. Illustrated. 366 pp. Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press. $27.95.

title: A REPUBLIC OF LETTERS
description: THE ARK IN THE ATTIC An Alphabet Adventure. By Eileen Doolittle. Photographs by Starr Ockenga. Painted backgrounds by Eileen Doolittle. Unpaged. Boston: A Floyd Yearout Book/David R. Godine. $18.95. (All ages) THE Z WAS ZAPPED By Chris Van Allsburg. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95. (All ages) ANIMALIA By Graeme Base. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $14.95. (All ages)

title: THE LOS ANGELES CLUB SCENE
