description: Angst and anomie appear to permeate late-night adolescence and early adulthood, at least in the narrow band represented by the Los Angeles club scene.

title: BARE KNUCKLES ON MADISON AVENUE
description: IT WAS THE LAST OF THE BIG killings in advertising,'' says Robert E. Jacoby. He sits in the brightly lit living room of his sprawling ranch home in Saddle River, N.J., puffing on one of the large cigars he habitually smokes.

title: GULF PEACE HOPES ARE CALLED BLEAK
description: In light of tougher positions by Iran and Iraq on how to end their war, the chances for an American-led initiative to impose a global arms embargo against Iran seem increasingly bleak, according to White House and State Department officials.

title: Follow-Up On the News; As the End Nears For Noted Hotel
description: THE Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles, host to vivacious movie stars and ambitious politicians in a glittering era now gone, prepared its last rites.

title: Follow-Up On the News; Trying to Return Land to Indians
description: ''THE legislation has a simple purpose: to right a wrong committed by the United States 100 years ago.''

title: Jazz Piano: Pete Malinverni
description: IF Pete Malinverni were slightly more explicit about the melodies he plays on the piano, he might be accused of being a cocktail pianist. But the melodies in his improvisations are elusive, and his running, single-note lines sometimes have a Count Basie touch or a suggestion of Willard Robison's down-home reminiscences.

title: After the Fall
description: To the Editor:

title: Caroline Starr Weds
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York, Caroline Hopping Starr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herald B. Starr of Orange, N.J., and Thomas William Boylan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew M. Boylan of Westfield, N.J., were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert T. Sheeran, the assistant provost of Seton Hall University. The bride was until recently an associate in the syndicate department at Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day in New York. Mr. Boylan is an associate in project finance at the National Westminster Bank in New York.

title: NEW EFFORTS SEEK TO TAP COUNTY'S POTENTIAL FOR TOURISM
description: HISTORIC Hudson Valley, the new name of the historic preservation group better known to county residents as Sleepy Hollow Restorations, celebrated its expanding role last week with a festive dinner dance in Manhattan. But it promised that Westchester's historic sites will not be ignored as the organization sets out on its mission to encourage tourism throughout the region.

title: RACING'S RECORD-BREAKER
description: ALAIN PROST MUSCLED THE TITANIUM SHIFT into sixth gear, dialed up the 1,200-horsepower turbo booster and flung his iridescent red-and-white Formula One race car past the Estoril grandstands at 180 miles per hour, faster than an F-15 jet fighter on takeoff. Prost, twice the world champion, was waging a record-breaking duel with Gerhard Berger in the dramatic closing minutes of the 70-lap 1987 Portuguese Grand Prix, one of 16 races in the Formula One Grand Prix championship, the World Series of car racing.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
Keeping Alive The Hopes of The Lebanese
description: LEAD: WHILE poor, beleaguered Lebanon continues to be racked by war, a charitable organization with offices in Washington, Paris and Beirut is trying to patch up the educational lives of Lebanese war-generation students.

title: How O'Keeffe Painted Hymns to Body and Spirit
description: THE GEORGIA O'KEEFFE CENTENNIAL exhibition at the National Gallery of Art is an attempt to allow the work of one of America's best- known artists to speak for itself. The 10 galleries devoted to 120 of her works offer no meditations on the artist's glamour and theatricality, on her love affairs with Alfred Stieglitz and the Southwest, or on her particular blend of sensuality and abruptness, exhibitionism and reclusiveness. The show wants to make the case for someone who apparently never thought she would die and almost didn't (she was 98 when she died last year; this Nov. 18 would have been her 100th birthday).

title: Haste and Ideological Fights Set Nomination on Course Ending in Its Doom
description: The complete account of how and why President Reagan surprised many in the Senate and the Administration nine days ago by choosing for the Supreme Court a little-known 41-year-old judge championed by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is not yet known.

title: A Victim, First of Nazi Anger, Now of Time
description: Forty-five years ago, right after the destruction of this village 15 miles west of Prague, great homage was paid to its martyred people.

title:
INVESTING;
A Failed Growth Fund Disbands
description: LEAD: BY the end of this month, the Westergaard Fund Inc. will disband, returning depleted assets to investors who had hoped to find riches in small, emerging companies promising superior earnings growth.

title: The Hand-Held Calculus
description: NOT SO MANY years have passed since arithmetic teachers faced up to the grim prospect of classrooms full of cheap electronic calculators, enabling students to sidestep the painstaking memorization of multiplication tables. What would happen, educators wondered, when these students went on to try the rigors of calculus? If they skipped the agony of long division, how would they manage such necessities as the differentiation of sine functions and the graphing of polynomials?

title: Stay Out of My Head
description: Two million times a year, American citizens are subjected to ''lie-detector'' tests. This explosion of the use of machines that measure nervousness (and that fail to catch the cool, practiced liar) is the most blatant intrusion into personal freedom in this country today.

title: FOOD INSPECTION RESULTS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 25 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Japan Asks Why Scientists Go West to Thrive
description: National pride was ample and undisguised last month when Susumu Tonegawa became the first Japanese to win the Nobel Prize in medicine.

title: A REPORTER'S REPORTER
description: PIERRE-MARIE DOUTRELANT DIED earlier this year while jogging in the Bois de Boulogne, in Paris. He was 46 years old, left a wife and a couple of kids, and may have been the best wine journalist of our time.

title: A FEW IMPORTANT CHORES FOR THE SEASON
description: LAST call to plant bulbs, especially tulips; use fertilizer at the base of planting holes and water bulbs if the ground seems dry. Continue raking leaves and don't forget to use a bamboo rake or power blower to brush them off groundcovers such as myrtle and pachysandra; shake shrubs and young trees so leaves filter down to the ground; leave them there. Last call to gather seed pods from perennials and vegetables; store in a cool dry place for winter. Pot up a few bulbs to be forced into bloom indoors in January or February; water well and allow roots to grow by keeping pots in a cool place such as a coldframe or dark basement. Go Native

title: G.O.P. Debate Sets Off Missing Persons Alarm
description: The debate among Republicans over the debate today was whether to debate at all.

title: Postings: Computer Surveys; Shopping For Loans
description: If you have access to a computer and want to find the latest mortgage data in 36 areas around the country without scurrying from bank to bank or making a lot of phone calls, you might consider a new service offered by HSH Associates of Riverdale, N.J.

title: Out of Prison
description: Govan A. Mbeki, who was confined in a South African prison 23 years ago for talk of taking arms against the system that ordered his imprisonment, was released last week. Mr. Mbeki, a longtime leader of the outlawed African National Congress and a close associate of Nelson R. Mandela, is now 77 years old and in ill health. But his thoughts about the South African Government have not changed. ''The ideas for which I went to jail and for which the A.N.C. stands, I still embrace,'' he said after his release. Officials said the unconditional release was simply humanitarian, but it was also seen as a gesture toward the A.N.C. and as a move to pave the way for Mr. Mandela's eventual release. Mr. Mbeki, Mr. Mandela and six other A.N.C. leaders were convicted in 1964 of plotting the violent overthrow of the white Pretoria Government.

title: Broadcast TV
description: A heady assortment of films awaits buffs this week - from more recent fare such as ''Altered States'' to long-absent classics like ''The Lost Weekend'' and ''La Dolce Vita.''

title: FICTION
description: TALKING TO STRANGE MEN. By Ruth Rendell. (Pantheon, $16.95.) ''They are just like schoolboys,'' observes Mungo Cameron's father as he watches a televised report on a spy trial. ''Like so many schoolchildren playing games.'' But what this staid English doctor doesn't know is that the youngest of his children, teen-aged Mungo, is busily proving the truth - and the dangerous consequences - of that statement. For Mungo is the leader of a league of public school boys whose game-playing has steadily moved from a simple stunt concocted by two friends to an intricate mock war of secret messages, safe houses and elaborately planned maneuvers against their rivals. To Mungo and his cohorts, all this is still an innocent, albeit very serious hobby. But when a lonely garden-shop manager stumbles on one of their drop points and diverts himself from his failed marriage by trying to break their codes, a more ominous chain of events is set in motion. Thus one of England's most subtle practitioners of psychological suspense splices the movements of what the gardener believes to be a ring of drug smugglers into the schemes of a random sampling of adults who themselves may be much more - or less - than they appear. Is one of them responsible for a long-unsolved murder? Is one the child molester who has cautious parents like Mungo's warning their offspring against talking to strange men? As the answers are discovered, one character will be led to a bizarre confession, another to an attempt at suicide - and a third to an unwitting act of arson and a quite deliberate killing. Boys will be boys, after all. And innocence, at any age, can be just as destructive as experience.

title: Lions Miss by A Yard
description: They have been ridiculed, laughed at and branded losers, but yesterday, the long blue line of Columbia Lions was given a respectful round of applause as the players trudged quietly from the field to the locker room after the game. The Lions, though, did not acknowledge the fans. Some, like Matt Sodl, the senior defensive end, were crying. Others appeared to be in shock, drained of all emotion.

title: Amherst Helps Salamanders
description: Workers have begun installing tiny tunnels on a street to protect migrating salamanders from cars.

title: CHESAPEAKE LIVES
description: BAY COUNTRY By Tom Horton. Illustrated by Charles R. Hazard. 223 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $16.95.

title: We Must Expand Into New Fields
description: AMERICANS are paying too much for their financial services. But America's commercial banks are willing, and able, to help lower prices by hundreds of millions of dollars by increasing competition. The missing ingredient is Congressional authority to give banks the capability to move into new markets that will strengthen our banking system.

title: Shoppers Shrug Off Market Turmoil
description: Consumers don't seem too worried about the general state of the economy, to judge from the first indicators of their sentiments since the stock market collapse. Polls produced mixed, somewhat puzzling responses, but none of them seemed to portend a widespread movement to swear off spending. A similar reading emerged from the sales indicators. Auto sales came in with a surprising 10.8 percent gain for the last 10 days of October. Car buying was under close scrutiny for signs that customers would avoid big purchases after the market's tumble on Oct. 19. The more cautious analysts, however, said that many of the purchases were probably in the works before the big Wall Street selloff. On the other hand, sales at the big retailers also held up in October, even after the 19th. The figures were not generally robust, but that continues a months-long anemic trend. Gains ranged from 1 percent at Sears to 40 percent at Wal-Mart.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have a lot of oil stains on my asphalt driveway. What should I use on these stains before I apply a sealer?

title: 5 Held in Jerusalem Clash
description: Five militantly Orthodox Jewish youths were arrested today after a policeman was wounded in violent demonstrations in Jerusalem against what the Orthodox regard as desecration of the Jewish sabbath. Protesters at a busy intersection threw stones and bottles at drivers who were violating religious law by driving on the holy day, and the policeman was struck on the head by a stone.

title: A HOLE IN THE FAMILY
description: THE YEAR WITHOUT MICHAEL By Susan Beth Pfeffer. 164 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $13.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title:

'WE HAVE THE AUDIENCES FOR THE ARTS'
description: LEAD: THIS year, the Connecticut Commission on the Arts has financed more performing arts groups and supported more artistic development and diversity than ever in its 22-year history.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SO WHAT'S NEW? COME AND FIND OUT
description: LEAD: THE premise behind the question ''What's New in Antiques?'' will be explored here Saturday by Wendell Garrett, editor and publisher of The Magazine Antiques.

title: Two 13-Year-Olds Accused of Setting Man on Fire
description: Two 13-year-old boys who had a brief argument with a man in an abandoned car in a Brooklyn lot Thursday night returned moments later with a container of gasoline and set the car on fire, fatally burning him, the police said yesterday.

title: FOOD
description: Annemarie Colbin's 'The Basics of Healthy Cooking' The Natural Gourmet Cookery School. 101 minutes. $39.95. Annemarie Colbin, who runs a cooking school in New York that specializes in natural foods, has put together a video on grains and beans that is stunningly complete. It would be especially useful for a total novice, let's say a dyed-in-the-wool carnivore who has been told to take up a diet rich in beans and grains and has no idea where to begin.

description: Eugene Rowley

description: LEAD: JEREMIAH DONOVAN'S restaurant, established in 1889, assures potential customers with a sign in the window that there are ''tables for ladies.''

title: DAY-CARE PROVIDERS STRIVE TO MEET NEEDS
description: FOR thousands of Long Island women, the business day begins with a stop at a baby sitter's house, or a day-care center, or a reminder to a school-age child not to miss the bus. Many more women who would join the Long Island work force cannot because there is no one to care for their children.

title: Syracuse Group Refuses to Cut Off Funds for Farrakhan Talk
description: Student leaders at Syracuse University refused today to cut off money for a speech by the Nation of Islam leader, Louis Farrakhan, a spokeswoman said.

description: Under enormous pressure from Administration officials and his own conservative supporters on Capitol Hill, Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg today asked President Reagan to withdraw his nomination to the Supreme Court.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
FEZZIWIGS
description: LEAD: IT pains Dr. Nancy Engbretsen Schaumburger to contemplate the fact that the creations of Charles Dickens are - well, creations.

title: Perspectives: Waterfront Development; Green Light for Condos on Gravesend Bay
description: SOMETIME next year, probably in the summer, condominiums at a new waterfront development called Jonathan's Landing are to go on sale. To find them, prospective buyers will drive along a new road on a sliver of landfill that juts into Gravesend Bay on the South Brooklyn shore.

title: Maine Hoping to Preserve the Good Life With the Good Earth
description: The state of Maine is now in the real estate business, joining 17 other states in setting up an aggressive program to buy land before the crush of development takes away more scenic spots and wildlife areas.

title: Arab Summit Talks Opening Today
description: The presidents, kings and emirs of the Arab world began to converge on this hilly capital today amid concern that failure to close ranks behind a united policy could polarize the Arab world into blocs of moderates and radicals for a long time to come.

title: A Nature Group in Vermont Moves to Safeguard Loons
description: The Vermont chapter of the Nature Conservancy is stepping up efforts to protect the state's endangered common loons, having acquired one nesting site recently and hoping to purchase another one soon.

title:
GARDENING;
THE APPEAL OF THE MUSTARD FAMILY
description: LEAD: ONE of the more interesting and youthful plant species is Brassica oleracea. Native to western and southern Europe, it has yielded many interesting and useful forms in cultivation. This is the species of such diverse and familiar vegetables as collards, kale, broccoli, cauliflower, cabbage, brussels sprouts and kohlrabi, among others.

title: Dance: A Joffrey Bill Of Three by Diaghilev
description: THE Joffrey Ballet's treasure house of 20th-century classics is often opened up in ''theme'' programs, and the most popular of these have been the revivals from Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes.

title: RAIDING THE TITANIC
description: William F. Buckley Jr.'s account of his adventurous descent to the graveyard of the Titanic kept my interest (''Down to the Great Ship,'' Oct. 18). But it did not whet my enthusiasm for any further raiding of the lost ''ark.''

title: WHO SHOULD BE THE M.V.P.'S IN BASEBALL?
description: Although the m.v.p. award usually goes to a member of a division champion, I feel that Andre Dawson was such a dominant force in the National League (almost 50 home runs, more than 130 runs batted in) that he deserves to win it.

title: Alabama Upsets L.S.U.
description: Bobby Humphrey ran for 161 yards and a touchdown to lead Alabama to a 22-10 upset of previously unbeaten Louisiana State tonight.

title: Offer to Wright on Nicaragua Talks Reported
description: House Speaker Jim Wright turned down a request by Nicaraguan officials to serve as an intermediary in cease-fire talks between the Sandinista Government and Nicaraguan rebels, diplomatic officials said today.

title: NEW HAVEN RAISES PAY TO LURE OFFICERS
description: THE New Haven Police Department plans to increase the starting pay and shorten the time it takes to certify a potential recruit to combat its chronic shortage of officers.

title: DISCOVERING THE OPPOSITE SEX
description: THE GOATS By Brock Cole. Illustrated by the author. 184 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Ben Itkin
description: Ben Itkin, a co-founder and past president of Itkin Brothers Inc., a distributor of office furniture, died Friday at the Miami Heart Institute after heart surgery. He was 78 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla., and Hillsdale, N.Y.

title: UNDEFEATED SYRACUSE POUNDS NAVY FOR 9TH VICTORY
description: Coach Dick MacPherson of Syracuse got into a rather heated discussion with the Naval Academy's deputy commandant, Capt. Ed Kristensen, on the field today. It seems that the coach and his quarterbacks, going through warm-ups, were standing in the way of the brigade of midshipmen marching into the stadium before the kickoff. The Orangemen refused to move until the Marines were called in.

title: Geese Dyed to See Where They Fly
description: More than the foliage is changing color in Delaware this autumn.

description: Three weeks after the stock market collapse, most corporate economists are firmly optimistic that consumers will recover their confidence and spend enough to avoid a recession next year.

title: American Autos
description: To the Editor:

description: WITHOUT a single tuba, trombone or saxophone, Meredith Gilfeather admits that the Stamford High School marching band does not exactly strike up a rousing rendition of the National Anthem before the fans at home football games.

description: Where were all those insouciant, club-crazed Angelenos last year, when several hundred other people were beginning their march of over 3,000 miles across the United States in the cause of peace?

title: SCHOOLS' AIDS BAN IS FACING ATTACK
description: New Haven's policy of excluding children with AIDS from public school classes has come under attack from the Connecticut Civil Liberties Union, which says it will use every legal remedy available to halt the practice.

title: Perils of Following the Electronic Lieder
description: SOME PRESS RELEASES FLY almost unaided into the wastebasket. Others stick to the fingers, and sometimes in the throat. Consider one in behalf of the Milwaukee Symphony, which this weekend is taking part in ''an innovative and revolutionary idea-come-to-life that could change the face of all symphonic concerts to come.'' A bold vision, that, capable of making the blood run hot or cold, depending on one's musical tastes. For the first time, we are advised, the audience of a major orchestra may experience ''large-screen video enhancement of the concert by an unprecedented four cameras on stage and two 18-foot video screens.''

title: Bear Seized at Private Club
description: The police seized a 400-pound bear after learning that customers at a private club were being encouraged to pay $5 to wrestle with the bear. The police intervened Thursday night at Ms. Kitty's after Toby, a defanged brown bear, had wrestled his first match, officials said. No one was hurt. The bear's owner, Burlie Webb of Hot Springs, Ark., was charged with one count of illegal exhibition of a wild or exotic animal. A court hearing was set for Dec. 2. Club patrons were to compete for a $100 prize.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Bay Shore; $152,000 1502 St. Louis Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 32-year-old split level. den, eat-in kitchen, 1-care garage; taxes $2,400 Freeport; $110,000 204 East Seaman Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement with bar, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300 Levittown; $145,000 17 Blue Spruce Road 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, oversized master bedroom; taxes $3,000 Massapequa; $310,000 200 Cedar Shore Drive 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 30-year-old colonial family room, fireplace, deck, 2-car garage, 1.5 acres; taxes $5,100 West Islip; $137,000 815 Udall Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod fireplace, eat-in kitchen, den; taxes $3,500 OTHER AREAS Mantoloking Shores, N.J.; $380,000 333 Barkentine Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 15-year-old ranch; fireplace, C/A, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500.

title: CAN ARTS AND SCIENCE COMPETE WITH SPORTS AT SCHOOL?
description: EVEN WITH all the funds that New Jersey provides for the arts, something's eating at me. It has to do with how we regard the arts, particularly when it concerns young people. Here in Sussex County, sports - especially high school sports - are a big deal. There is wide coverage in the local newspapers, with feature articles, color photographs, all-county teams, athlete-scholar dinners, ''Athletes of the Year'' and even editorials devoted to young men and women who run faster, throw farther and jump higher than others.

description: SOME SOUL TO KEEP By J. California Cooper. 211 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $14.95.

description: I was deeply disappointed by the Oct. 18 article [ ''Democrats Face Loss of 6 More Judgeships'' ] concerning the result of the Republican Party's refusal to grant cross-endorsements to qualified sitting Democratic judicial candidates in this area.

description: SONGS don't have to be number one on the charts to be hits in Wisconsin, as Gov.

description: LEAD: THROUGH the blinds of his turn-of-the-century office, Theodore J. Moss can see all of the Detroit's riverfront, from historic Stroh River Place to the gleaming, modern towers of the Renaissance Center.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-29

title: THE DARK PLAYGROUND
description: It's not that I doubt Daniel Voll's sincere intentions in trying to understand what his female friend suffered from being raped (About Men, ''The Dark Playground,'' Oct. 4). However, I fail to see the ''shared vulnerability'' he speaks of, after his experience of lying on the very spot, tasting the dirt and recalling his own anxious fear at the idea of homosexual prison rape, after he was almost busted for drugs in college.

title: OKLAHOMA WINS, BUT LOSES 2 STARS
description: Oklahoma beat Oklahoma State, 29-10, today in a Big Eight Conference game but lost its two most productive backs, Jamelle Holieway and Lydell Carr, for the remainder of the season with knee injuries.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BLOODSTAINS. By Giuliana Morandini. Translated by Blossom Steinberg Kirschenbaum. (New Rivers, Paper, $8.95.) The renaissance of interest in Italian fiction among American publishers is a welcome event, but the appearance here of Giuliana Morandini's slender and altogether minor 1978 novel can hardly be greeted with much enthusiasm.

title: MEDICINE IS SUFFERING FROM CHANGES
description: I am writing to comment on the article ''Decline in Students at Medical Schools'' that appeared Oct. 4. As a board-certified family practice physician of 25 years, I have seen the changes occurring in medicine that are deterring the best students of the best colleges from choosing medicine as a lifelong profession.

title: State's Nuclear Plants: A Chronology of Events
description: LEAD: Following is a brief chronology of the state's nuclear-power plants:

title: GINSBURG EPISODE REVIVES DISCORD OF THE 60'S GENERATION
description: IT was perhaps predictable that the members of the generation of the 60's and 70's would come to regret some of their youthful indulgences when they traded in their tie-dyed T-shirts and stashes of marijuana for gray suits and chardonnay. But the Douglas H. Ginsburg episode has shown that generational bygones cannot be entirely forgotten.

title: Gorbachev Speech: Playing to a Wary Public
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV gave a politician's speech last week on the troublesome topic of his country's history. It did not play very well in the West, where many expected a historian's speech, but it was probably not intended to. It was a speech for domestic consumption, crafted for a society with a willful reverence for its version of the past.

title: Signs of Child Abuse, and How to Get Aid
description: State and city officials urge anyone who suspects that a child has been abused or neglected, or is in risk of such mistreatment, to report the suspicions immediately to one of three special telephone hot lines that have been set up specifically to respond to child-abuse reports.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE CONTINENTAL AFFAIR: The Rise and Fall of the Continental Illinois Bank. By James P. McCollom. (Dodd, Mead, $21.95.) Shortly before Mother's Day, 1984, Reuters ran a story on its international wire that brought down the seventh-largest bank in the United States. That, at least, is the argument made by James P.

description: PRINTMAKING IN FRANCE

description: Imagine that someday the Mets and the Yankees really do play a Subway World Series. Could the Series actually be decided by Randy Velarde?

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
In Miami, Saturday's Child May Choose School
description: LEAD: SINCE school started in September, some children in Miami have been voluntarily turning off their TV's on Saturdays and tuning into learning. At Charles R. Drew Elementary School, more than 200 children from kindergarten through sixth grade have attended three-hour Saturday morning sessions to continue their study of reading, writing and arithmetic.

title: 'COLOR: PURE AND SIMPLE' IS DISPLAYED IN STAMFORD
description: COLOR is a sensation caused by the action of light on the retina. It is also definable as an entity that affects its observers physically as well as psychologically, although color choices are generally regarded as reflections of the chooser's mental state.

title: Getting Up Close in Baja
description: LEAD: EVERY autumn, when Arctic waters start to turn to ice, one of the world's most remarkable migrations begins. Thousands of gray whales set out on a 6,000-mile journey south. These are the whales that are known to scientists as Eschrichtius robustus, and to West Coast residents as the California gray whale.

title: A WOMAN AT OLD EXETER
description: It was with great interest that I read Fran Schumer's article. As a young faculty member during the early days of coeducation, I can recall many incidents in which male chauvinism, either intentional or unintentional, prevailed.

title: Kirkland Graham Is Wed To Timothy F. DeLaney
description: Kirkland Graham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Graham Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King to Timothy Frederick DeLaney, a son of Robert J. DeLaney of New York and the late Irene Dolbear DeLaney. Msgr. John F. Corr officiated. The bride, a graduate of the Kent Place School and Lafayette College, is a researcher in the news archives department of NBC News. Her father is a senior partner in the law firm of Ribis, Graham, Verdon & Curtin in Morristown, N.J.

title: THE WORD FOR CHILDREN

title: PENN STATE WINS, 21-16
description: Dwayne Downing returned an interception 38 yards for a touchdown and Blair Thomas ran 58 yards for another score today as Penn State defeated Maryland for the 23d consecutive season, 21-16.

title: VOTE RESULTS FORCE 5 SPECIAL ELECTIONS
description: AS Democratic and Republican leaders differed over the significance of the municipal elections across the state last week, both parties began preparing for a round of special elections spawned by the Election Day results.

title: RAIDING THE TITANIC
description: Senator William Alden Smith may not have known that a ship's ''bow'' is different from a ship's ''head,'' but William F. Buckley Jr. apparently does not know that a ship's bulkheads are different from a ship's watertight doors.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE COUPLE stalked the cedar in the corner of the parking lot and came to a stop. One studied the small, drab bird that was searching for insects; the other leafed through field guides.

title:
IN THE REGION: WESTCHESTER CONNECTICUT;
ISLIP'S LAND BANK IS NOW PAYING INTEREST
description: LEAD: IN the best of times, the eight-square-block Carleton Park area of Central Islip was never more than a development of 300 mean little houses, hastify thrown together after World War II to meet the housing needs of veterans and of workers at the nearby psychiatric center, the Central islip State Hospital.

title: The Looming Crisis With Bonn and Tokyo
description: LEAD: As the panic on Wall Street fades, another crisis is brewing, this time between Washington, Bonn and Tokyo. It may be of more lasting significance than the financial debacle.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have today asked President Reagan not to forward my nomination to the Supreme Court.'' - Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg. [ 1:6. ]

title: Hollis Kegg Wed To Lewis C. Knox
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, Hollis Beaven Kitson Kegg, a daughter of Mrs. J. Michael Farrell of New York and Point o' Woods, L.I., and the late William Boyd Kegg Jr., was married yesterday to Lewis Cass Knox, a son of Mary Jane Walters Knox of Swarthmore, Pa., and the late Lewis Cass Knox. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, performed the ceremony.

title: Can Steve Jobs Do It Again?
description: GLIDING across the stage, a huge screen behind him, Steven P. Jobs has his audience mesmerized. He is expounding on his vision of computerized education. In the future, Mr. Jobs says, sophisticated computer simulations will allow students to walk through Athens with Plato, experience life in 17th-century France or perform biochemistry experiments normally requiring a $5 million laboratory.

title: World Bank Giving New Drought Aid to India
description: The World Bank announced today that it was giving drought-related assistance of more than $500 million to India, saying it was seeking to ease this nation's growing balance-of-payments squeeze.

title: U.N. Food Agency Convenes For the Election of Director
description: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization began a three-week conference today that will vote whether to give its Director General an unprecedented third term in office.

title: FELD AND RODRIGUEZ COMING TO PRINCETON AND MONTCLAIR
description: LEAD: THE choreographer Eliot Feld began his dance career by vanquishing the seven-headed Mouse King in the New York City Ballet's ''Nutcracker'' 30 years ago.

title: Pop: An English Band, The Jesus and Mary Chain
description: THE Jesus and Mary Chain keeps simple pop pleasure and simple emotions at a distance. At the Ritz on Thursday, opening a two-night stand, the English band had catchy tunes, long-suffering lyrics and alienation strategies aplenty.

title: DESIGNS THAT REACH HIGH FOR PEOPLE WITH LOW INCOMES
description: THE COMMON RESPONSE TO the question of what architects can do to solve the crisis of affordable housing for middle- and lower-income people is: not much. Architects really do not have the power to alleviate this problem on their own, the reasoning goes, and significant solutions will have to wait for the time when the Government decides to spend some money.

title: In Career Goals, Female Valedictorians Fall Behind
description: NANCY was valedictorian of her suburban Chicago high school class when she graduated in 1981. She wanted to be a lawyer. Mike was also his high school's valedictorian that year. He too wanted to be a lawyer.

title: Rangers Are Striving To Get Much Tougher
description: Have the slumping Rangers, weary of having sand kicked in their faces, decided to get even instead of getting mad?

title: Arms Scandal Puts Mitterrand on Defensive
description: An Iran arms scandal that has exploded on the French political scene has thrown President Francois Mitterrand and his Socialist Party on the defensive just as he is deciding on whether to run for a second term.

title: BEYOND THE MALL: SUBURBS EVOLVING INTO 'OUTER CITIES'
description: IT happened incrementally, and for a long time few realized the magnitude and import of what was going on. But over the last quarter-century and especially in the last decade, the American metropolis has been transformed into something new and different. Suburbs, once dependent on the central city, have metamorphosed into vast, glittering, independent ''outer cities'' that rival and often surpass the traditional big-city downtowns as centers of economic power and vitality.

title: TAKE POWER LINES OUT OF NATURE'S WAY
description: On Oct. 11 you printed an article entitled ''Criticism for Utility Follows Snowfall.'' Year after year, the lives of thousands of Connecticut residents are disrupted when storms result in the loss of electric power. These incidents are not ''acts of God.'' They are exacerbated by the failure of the utility companies to bury power and telephone lines.

title: POLITICS AS SPETTACOLO
description: DEMOCRACY, ITALIAN STYLE By Joseph LaPalombara. 308 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $25.

title: Liver and Cabbage, With Chicken Soup
description: BRIGHTON BEACH MEMOIRS Written by Neil Simon. Starring Blythe Danner, Bob Dishy, Judith Ivey, Jonathan Silverman (in photo). Produced by Ray Stark. Directed by Gene Saks. 1986. MCA Home Video. 110 minutes. $79.95.

title: BLUE MUSINGS AFTER BLACK MONDAY
description: THE realization that I might not be coming back to that playground of the rich and famous, the Hamptons, much longer hit hard in, of all places, Ithaca, N.Y.

title: AN ARCHIVE AT UCONN ON JEWS OF POLAND
description: LEAD: AN archive of Polish-Jewish materials, most of which was presumed to have been destroyed during the Holocaust, will be established at the University of Connecticut.

title: An Artist Finds Poetry in Videotape
description: IN 1973, FRESH OUT OF SYRA-cuse University, the video artist Bill Viola went to visit a friend in San Francisco who took him straight from the airport to a camping trip in the desert. ''We drove down to Death Valley and arrived at Zabriskie Point at midnight under a full moon. In the next two days, my life was changed,'' Mr. Viola recalled recently. ''I realized that, growing up in New York, I'd never seen 75 miles straight in front of me in all directions at once.

title: Olivia Bell Mason And C. J. Beukers Planning to Wed
description: Olivia Bell Mason and Christopher John Beukers, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Beukers of Stony Brook, L.I., and Longborough, England, plan to marry next month, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Mason of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced.

title: Moore P. Huffman
description: Moore P. Huffman, a retired partner of Morgan Stanley & Company, investment bankers, died of a heart attack Oct. 31 at his home in Woody Creek, Colo. A former resident of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and of Aspen, Colo., he was 77 years old.

title: In Praise of A Nature Series
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM BRITAIN, A 'NO-HOLDS-BARRED' APPROACH TO MUSIC
description: WHEN THE LUMBERING figures of Maurice Sendak's ''wild things'' stagger to life to the music of the 35-year-old Oliver Knussen at the New York City Opera Thursday night, it will signal a week in which contemporary British music will be unusually prominent in New York. The same night that Mr. Knussen's one-act opera, ''Where the Wild Things Are,'' is receiving its New York stage premiere (it has previously been heard in concert at the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Zubin Mehta), the Philharmonic will be introducing ''Ringed by the Flat Horizon,'' the first orchestral work by George Benjamin, who is 27 years old. And, on Nov, 18, Mr. Benjamin's ''A Mind of Winter'' will be getting its American premiere with the Atlantic Sinfonietta at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Protecting Plants from the Inside Out
description: THE appearance of such desirable crop traits as disease resistance was once a very gradual process, governed by the laws of natural selection and aided, perhaps, by tedious selective breeding by farmers. Now agricultural scientists are doing in the laboratory in a matter of days or weeks, what once took years.

title: What the Bears of Summer Sensed
description: LAST August, when the weather was hot and stocks were high, Edward M. Kerschner, an investment strategist at PaineWebber Inc., felt that something was wrong. With the precision of a seismograph, Mr. Kerschner's indictors showed the stock market was headed for a fall. To his clients, he issued a warning: ''Stocks are now unattractive for the first time since 1984.''

title: After the Fall
description: To the Editor:

title:
TELEVISION;
A Son's Disability, Through His Mother's Eyes
description: LEAD: TWENTY-FOUR YEARS AGO, Allan Sloane was 49 and writing hard-edged, socially conscious scripts for George C. Scott's short-lived television series ''East Side, West Side.'' Emily Perl Kingsley was a 23-year-old, new-to-the-business researcher on the same show. Mr. Sloane, impressed with Ms. Kingsley's dedication in searching through newspapers to uncover potential story lines for the show, told her, ''Someday, I'm going to teach you all I know about writing for television.

title:
GARDENING;
THE APPEAL OF THE MUSTARD FAMILY
description: LEAD: ONE of the more interesting and youthful plant species is Brassica oleracea. Native to western and southern Europe, it has yielded many interesting and useful forms in cultivation. This is the species of such diverse and familiar vegetables as collards, kale, broccoli, cauliflower, cabbage, brussels sprouts and kohlrabi, among others.

title: WHAT HAS HAPPENED TO BEST FRIENDS?
description: RECENTLY I was invited to lunch by a new friend, Fran. The invitation was for the same day I planned to visit my best friend, Judy. Judy lives in a fourth-floor walk-up in the Bronx. She had had surgery a few weeks ago, and needed help with shopping. When I declined the invitation, and told Fran why, she stared at me, surprised. ''Perhaps another day when you're not too busy,'' she snapped. ''I don't rate my friends.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A map of Mystic on Oct. 25 showed incorrect locations for Mystic Seaport and the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium. They are on the east bank of the Mystic River, south of Interstate 95; the aquarium is almost a mile north of the seaport.

title: Nouvelle New England
description: THE land of boiled dinners, baked beans, codfish cakes and brown bread has undergone a metamorphosis so dramatic that gustatory adventurers will be delighted to find themselves in New England at mealtime. Talented chefs in dozens of restaurants are making remarkable meals from local farmstead cheeses, free-range chickens, a variety of meticulously smoked fish and meats, game birds, shiitake mushrooms and, of course, the things for which New England has always been famous, a wide variety of finfish and seafood including the world's best lobsters, and fresh fruit and vegetables in season, especially berries and apples.

title: Quick Transition
description: THOSE who can, do, and as for those who no longer can, well, if they're lucky they do what Dave Lewis did after the 34-year-old defenseman realized that he no longer had the skills that sustained him for most of his 15 seasons with four teams. Lewis, a former Islander who joined the Detroit Red Wings before the 1986-87 season, retired after Friday's loss to the Minnesota North Stars and promptly began a new career as a Red Wing assistant coach.

title: DROP ME OFF IN THE RIVER
description: WEARING DAD'S HEAD By Barry Yourgrau. 128 pp. Salt Lake City: Peregrine Smith Books. Paper, $7.95.

title: Administration Ready to Discuss Wide Tax Rises, Negotiators Say
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d has told Congressional budget negotiators that he is ready to discuss a substantive package of tax increases but that in return he wants a commitment from Democrats on how much domestic spending they are willing to cut, participants in the talks said today.

title: A Conversion Plan Roils the Ansonia
description: LIMESTONE demons with wicked smiles decorate the landmark Beaux-Arts facade of the Ansonia Hotel on Broadway at West 73d Street. The faces are fitting symbols of discord for this building, which has been a battleground for tenants and landlords for several decades. Squabbles have revolved around rents, services and repairs, and now a possible conversion to a condominium.

title: FICTION
description: OCCUPATION. By John Toland. (Doubleday, $19.95.) ''In war,'' Omar Bradley wrote, ''there is no second prize for the runner-up.'' But what about Japan? Maybe the American occupation at the end of World War II wasn't a prize. But it began a political and social revolution that made Japan the economic power it is today. John Toland's second novel is about Japan's redemption and rebirth under the occupation. Mr. Toland, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, turned to fiction in 1985 with ''Gods of War,'' which presented the conflict in the Pacific through the lives of two families, the McGlynns of America and the Todas of Japan. ''Occupation,'' a Rube Goldberg contraption of fact and fiction, picks up the families at the end of the war. There are 42 historical characters and 40 fictional ones (the ubiquitous McGlynns especially strain the imagination). Unfortunately, the facts are more fascinating than the fiction. But it may even be worth plodding through the book just for the portrait of Admiral Tojo, who goes contentedly to the gallows, giving up his life for the rebirth of his country: ''It is time for farewell,'' he declares, ''I shall wait beneath the moss, / Until the flowers are fragrant again.'' Historians have grumbled about the constraints of their craft since Thucydides lamented (and then defended) the absence of romance in his account of the Peloponnesian War. But history can be just as dramatic as fiction. Or, in this case, more so.

title: The Streaks Are Over
description: Bergen Catholic, which had been unbeaten and unscored upon in nine games since Thanksgiving Day last year, saw both streaks end yesterday in Ridgewood.

title: Sands Is to Build a 2d Casino Hotel in Atlantic City
description: The owner of the Sands Hotel and Casino has announced that it will build a second casino hotel here, saying the 1990's will bring ''exploding'' growth in Atlantic City.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
AND HORROR, BEAUTY SIDE BY SIDE
description: LEAD: DURING World War II, on July 21, 1944, the United States Marines landed on Guam to take it back from Japan. I was one of those Marines. The memories of that day recur more often than any others of the 29 months I spent on Pacific islands; the contrast between the clear, brilliant beauty of the island and the day, and the bloody horror of the landing.

title: U.S. WELCOMES GORBACHEV HINTS AT A NEW ERA
description: IF many in the West found Mikhail S. Gorbachev's keenly anticipated speech on Monday timorous in its reappraisal of the Soviet past, it also contained suggestions of flexibility in the Soviet future - suggestions that will further complicate the problems of Western policy makers who wish to exploit new opportunities while maintaining a healthy skepticism.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: I SHALL LIVE: Surviving Against All Odds, 1939-1945. By Henry Orenstein. (Beaufort, $16.95.) Like its title, Henry Orenstein's autobiographical account of survival in the Holocaust is artless and touchingly detailed. Beginning with the courtship of his parents, Lejb and Golda, and ending with the dedication of the ''Lejb and Golda Orenstein Building'' (housing elderly poor) on the Lower East Side in their memory, the author calmly narrates his horrifying tale.

title: New Hampshire in Motion to Revive Moose Season
description: NEW HAMPSHIRE'S Fish and Game Department is planning a moose season - the state's first since 1901 - for next year, and it appears as if the event will take place on schedule.

title: Ellen O'Boyle Marries William C. McCahill Jr.
description: At St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, N.J., Ellen Teresa O'Boyle, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David J. O'Boyle of Glen Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to William C. McCahill Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. McCahill of Huntington, L.I. Msgr. Vincent P. Coburn performed the ceremony.

title: Cynthia Hawkins And John Guarino Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Hyde Hawkins of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Cleveland Hawkins to John Mitchell Guarino of Lausanne, Switzerland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Guarino of Fairless Hills, Pa.

title: Correction
description: An article Oct. 11 about a forum involving several possible candidates for New York City schools chancellor incorrectly described one of the participants, Dr. Peter Negroni. Dr. Negroni had previously stepped down as Superintendent of Community School District 12 in the Bronx.

title: Roommates 101: Course of Adjustment
description: THIS FALL there is at least one pair of happy freshmen roommates at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass. ''It was a perfect match,'' said Melissa Telzer, a New Yorker, about her roommate from Mount Vernon, N.Y. ''We were both assistant managers at Benetton stores. We both enjoy going to parties and sleeping late. We never get on each other's nerves.''

title: Not a Departure
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools in Chicago Are Called the Worst By Education Chief
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett says Chicago's public schools are the worst in the nation and parents should consider private schools for their children.

title: ISRAELIS SEEM AMBIVALENT ON VILENCE IN DOMESTIC WAR
description: THERE is a war going on here. It is an intercommunal war between Israelis and Palestinians. In Lebanon a similar war between ethnic communities has resulted in the destruction of buildings and whole cities, which makes it easy to detect. But in Israel the Government and its security force are strong, the lid is more tightly sealed, and so, day to day, the war is harder to see. It is not carried out by marching armies, but by individuals, soldiers and civilians, and it is usually confined to the underground or the back alleys or the Government interrogator's office. The toll is not measured in the destruction of buildings but in the damage to people's souls and in the erosion of norms of behavior.

title: Listen to Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Verbatim; Cheering Others On
description: 'Today, probably for the first time ever, there are about as many people, women, prepared to vote for you because you are a qualified woman as there are people, meaning men, ready to vote against you because you are a woman. Sex prejudice, you might say, the proclivity to either accept or reject you as a woman, is more closely balanced today than it has ever been - which is to say that being a woman is less of a disadvantage now than it has ever been. . . .

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Islip's Land Bank Is Now Paying Interest
description: LEAD: IN the best of times, the eight-square-block Carleton Park area of Central Islip was never more than a development of 300 mean little houses, hastily thrown together after World War II to meet the housing needs of veterans and of workers at the nearby psychiatric center, the Central Islip State Hospital.

title: EFFECT OF SHOREHAM RULE CHANGE DEBATED
description: LEAD: THE dispute over how New York State and Long Island officials would respond to an accident at the Shoreham nuclear power plant was heightened last week in the wake of a change in Federal rules for emergency planning.

title: Dance: Lorn MacDougal
description: ON Friday night at the Triplex Theater of Manhattan Community College, Lorn MacDougal danced the premiere of a solo about matters many people might prefer not to think about. Choreographed by Lee Connor, her former partner, ''Daily Living: A Tribute, a Transfiguration'' was based upon Mr. Connor's own battle against AIDS.

title: Decoding A Genius's Enigma
description: EVERY NOW AND THEN THE DRAMATIST Hugh Whitemore and the actor Derek Jacobi would meet for lunch and ruefully wonder if they weren't jointly launched on an impossible project. ''Breaking the Code'' just didn't seem writable, and its protagonist, the British mathematician and inventor Alan Turing, just didn't seem performable. Indeed, both the play and the character promised to break rules of drama so obvious that no manual on the subject would bother to mention them.

title: John Francis English, 61, Is Dead; Top Political Adviser to Kennedys
description: John F. English, a national, state and Long Island Democratic leader for many years, died yesterday of liver cancer at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 61 years old and lived in Muttontown, L.I., and on Fire Island.

title: France's Past Cast in Wax
description: AMID the impatient traffic, waves of pedestrians, overflowing cafes, multi-screen cinemas and pasta and pizza parlors of the Boulevard Montmartre in Paris lies a tiny building of rococo splendor that is one of the oldest wax museums in Europe. Since its founding in 1882, the museum has closed its doors just once - on the day the Germans occupied Paris. Today, to pass beneath the arresting gold facade of the Musee Grevin is to enter a world that still remains spellbinding.

title: A SUMMER HOUSE WAITS FOR ITS TURN
description: THE sun was gradually losing its summer strength, its warmth was diminishing and it seemed to know it had lost its importance. The flowers didn't seem to care about it as much. There were no beachgoers who cared, no worshipers.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: NOVEMBER 8, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 WHIRLWIND, by James Clavell. (Avon, $5.95.) Iran during the month following the Shah's departure. 2 5 THE GOLDEN CUP, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.95.) Continuing the saga of a turn-of-the-century New York family begun in ''Evergreen.'' 3 1 GARDEN OF SHADOWS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The beginnings of the evil that beset the Dollanganger family in four previously published novels. 4 4 FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts. (Pocket, $4.95.) Navy aviators in the Vietnam War. 5 6 A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Warner, $4.95.) Comdr. Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder. 6 2 KENTUCKY! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $4.50.) The latest in the ''Wagons West'' series tells of a plot to assassinate President Grant. 7 12 IT, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 8 17 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 9 3 PAPER MONEY, by Ken Follett. (Signet/NAL, $3.95.) Crime, high finance and journalism form the threads of this newly reissued 1977 thriller. 10 * 5 FOUNDATION AND EARTH, by Isaac Asimov. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.95.) The hero of the ''Foundation'' series searches for Earth. 11 6 VALE OF THE VOLE, by Piers Anthony. (Avon, $3.95.) Esk, the son of an ogre and a nymph, defends the inhabitants of a paradise. 12 * 5 I AM THE ONLY RUNNING FOOTMAN, by Martha Grimes. (Dell, $3.95.) Scotland Yard's Superintendent Jury on the trail of a strangler. 13 78 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A family crisis after a tycoon decides to sell his business. 15 6 DREAMS ARE NOT ENOUGH, by Jacqueline Briskin. (Berkley, $4.50.) A California family dynasty out to conquer the world. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 3 28 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Berkley, $6.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations by the television star. 4 37 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 5 53 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 6 1 PAT NIXON: The Untold Story, by Julie Nixon Eisenhower. (Zebra, $4.50.) The biography of the former First Lady, written by her daughter. 7 4 ONE MORE TIME, by Carol Burnett. (Avon, $4.50.) The comedian's autobiography, taking her up to age 26. 8 * 7 THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Avon, $5.50.) Rooney. (Berkley, $3.95.) Essays on contemporary life by the journalist and television commentator. 11 * 3 ONE KNEE EQUALS TWO FEET, by John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Jove, $3.95.) Observations on football. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 THE FAR SIDE OBSERVER, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) A new collection of cartoons. 2 11 BILLY AND THE BOINGERS BOOTLEG, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) More ''Bloom County'' cartoon strips. 3 1 GARFIELD SWALLOWS HIS PRIDE, by Jim Davis. (Ballantine, $5.95.) The 14th collection of cartoons about a fat cat. 4 22 THE BOOK OF QUESTIONS, by Gregory Stock. (Workman, $3.95.) Provocative and challenging questions to ask yourself in order to learn more about yourself. 5 28 CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $6.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Q&A
description: Rent-Stabilized in a Hotel

title: POSTAL PLAN IN ARMONK IS DELAYED
description: LEAD: THE United States Postal Service is at a temporary standstill in its plan to build a new 500,000-square-foot, two-story regional mail distribution center in Armonk's Westchester Business Park.

title: INSIDE
description: Consumer Confidence Seen Economists are optimistic that consumers will recover confidence and spend enough to avoid a recession next year, a survey found. Page 30. A Breakthrough on Arms White House officials and Congressional leaders have reportedly worked out basic elements of a compromise on arms issues. Page 15. Democrats Differ in Iowa The six Democratic Presidential candidates, meeting at a party celebration in Iowa, gave the clearest picture yet of where they differ. Page 40.

title: Halpin, Gulotta: The Torch Passes
description: THE election of Patrick G. Halpin and Thomas S. Gulotta as the County Executives of Suffolk and Nassau Counties signals the emergence of a new generation of politicians on Long Island.

title: A Return To Elegance
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Savoring the Distinctiveness of Korean Art
description: THE WEST HAS LONG been familiar with the art of China and Japan, but Korean art remained relatively unknown until the mid-1970's. Viewed as a mere imitation of its two neighbors, the culture was generally overlooked. One effort to correct this situation is an exhibition of 100 works - ''From the Land of Morning Calm: Korean Art at the Brooklyn Museum.'' The exhibition, which opened recently and continues until Jan. 4 testifies to the distinctness of that culture, maintained throughout a 5,000-year history of occupations by China and Japan as well as internal feudal turmoil.

title: 'My Husband, Ed, and I . . .'
description: The defendant before Federal Judge R. Allan Edgar was the son of a Congressman, so pleas for leniency from influential quarters could be expected. But the Judge still must have been startled by a letter from Ursula Meese urging ''very favorable consideration'' for Joe Duncan, who stood convicted of tax fraud. The behavior of Edwin Meese, Ursula's husband and the Attorney General of the United States, remains as startling.

title: Feminism vs. Civil Liberties
description: Karen Straw killed her husband, but in September a Queens jury acquitted her of murder after hearing defense evidence that she was a battered wife. Soon, a Manhattan jury is to begin to hear testimony in the trial of Robert Chambers for the murder of Jennifer Levin in Central Park. Mr. Chambers claims Ms. Levin's death was the accidental result of rough sex. What do Karen Straw and Robert Chambers have in common? Plenty.

title: College Students Take Up Cause of Homeless
description: College students across the country are attending forums, signing petitions and staying outside in sleeping bags in an effort to focus college campuses on the plight of the homeless.

title: THE COMBUSTIBLE LAWRENCE, STILL SMOLDERING
description: WHEN ''Women in Love'' was first published in 1920, it was the book of a man who had been burned. ''The Rainbow,'' Lawrence's previous novel, was suppressed by the Government in 1915 and his frightened publisher actually incinerated, or cremated it. Lawrence chopped ''Women in Love'' in a last-minute attempt to make it less combustible and it was riddled with errors of transcription as well. Now, 67 years later, Cambridge University Press is offering a splendid corrected edition with copious notes. Poor Lawrence has had his own way at last.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
THE PEAK OF ROOFTOPS
description: LEAD: A SELECTION of Rye's houses spanning three centuries - from a 1660 saltbox said to be the oldest house in Westchester to a contemporary home by Gwathmey, Siegel and Associates - is featured in a photographic exhibition, ''Miles of Styles: Rooflines as Timelines.'' The show, sponsored by the Rye Historical Society, is at the Square House, 1 Purchase Street, through Feb.

title: Political Notes; Balancing Act In Replacing Mario Merola
description: As he considers candidates to succeed Mario Merola as interim Bronx District Attorney, Governor Cuomo is confronted with a politically sensitive decision.

title: Postings: Hilton at Short Hills; 300-Room Hotel
description: Yet another hotel is under construction in northern New Jersey, the 300-room Hilton at Short Hills, and it is scheduled for completion early next year. The hotel is at 41 John F. Kennedy Parkway, directly across from the Short Hills Mall about 12 miles west of Newark International Airport, and near both the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway.

title: MOVIES
description: The Bedroom Window Starring Steve Guttenberg, Elizabeth McGovern, Isabelle Huppert. 1987. Vestron Video. 113 mins. $79.98. You can give ''The Bedroom Window'' points for bravery; here's a romantic-suspense story that plunges into Hitchcock territory, where shrewder, more stylish films fear to go. Mild-mannered Steve Guttenberg has an affair with his boss's glamorous wife, Isabelle Huppert. From her lover's window she sees a man - a murder suspect it turns out - attack a young woman (Elizabeth McGovern). Ever chivalrous, Mr. Guttenberg pretends he is the witness.

title: A NEW PLAY EXPLORES FANTASIES OF A MAN AT 60
description: AT 60, a man's thoughts turn to what might have been, and he fantasizes about second chances. It is on that premise that Elliott Caplin of Mamaroneck has based his play, ''One Way to Ulan Bator,'' which is being performed on Off Off Broadway (at the Riverwest Theater at 155 Bank Street in Manhattan) through Saturday.

title: TROTSKY STILL SHROUDED IN NON-PERSONALITY CULT
description: HE was guardian of the Bolshevik Revolution, defender of its faith, a disciple whose oratory enthralled the masses.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
THE TRIALS OF CHINLESS LEONARD
description: LEAD: THE ZABAJABA JUNGLE By William Steig. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Michael di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 8)

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: Tina Turner - Break Every Rule HBO Video. 1987. 60 minutes. $19.95. Beyond the swooping, gliding, intercutting cameras, above the choreographed exultation of the audience, there is Tina Turner, tinting pop tunes of struggle and redemption with sly, bluesy shadings. It's regrettable that the makers of this simulated concert video weren't more mindful of this, for their attempts to fabricate a frenetic celebration most often serve to obscure the strong performance at its center.

title: 'New York Intellect'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Refreshing Breeze of Wind Music on Disks
description: COMPARED WITH VIOLINISTS, cellists or pianists, players of wind instruments have a paucity of music to choose from when they seek solo materials. Although there are a number of masterly works by great composers, most music for winds has been written by players who regarded themselves primarily as performers and composed only to provide themselves with something to play. Equally popular was (and is) the practice of taking works composed for other instruments and arranging them for winds. Yet, as can be seen by a number of recently released recordings, wind soloists can put together highly enjoyable programs.

title: STUDENT SEX POLL TABLED IN LAWRENCE
description: LEAD: A SURVEY of the sexual attitudes of teen-agers at Lawrence High School has been tabled because of community opposition to the research project. But the doctor-researcher of a local adolescent health service said he will consider instead surveying Five Towns parents on what they think their teen-agers know about sex - and what their children should know.

title: MOB TIES STILL SEEN IN CARTING INDUSTRY
description: LEAD: THREE years after law-enforcement officials opened criminal cases to rid the Long Island garbage carting industry of organized-crime influence, much about the industry appears unchanged, according to prosecutors and local officials.

title: Molly Heminway Engaged to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Reid Heminway of Middlebury, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Molly Lewis Heminway to Charles Edward Keeble Moseley, the son of Mrs. Richard Curtis Miles of New York and Greenwich, Conn., and the late Charles Guy Moseley.

title: A LA CARTE
description: WITH winter's icy blasts just weeks away, the fickle sun-and-fun crowds have retreated. Restaurants at ferries and on the East End have battened their hatches. Some hope to weather winter storms by enticing the boys and girls of summer back to their warm-weather haunts by offering meals and prices difficult to resist.

title: Reserve Mobilization Begins
description: About 34,000 members of the Army Reserve, National Guard and civilian employees were moving out this weekend for a two-week test of their ability to mobilize for war. Mari M. Perrotti, spokeswoman for the 99th Army Reserve Command, based near Pittsburg, said the exercise would cover 12 states from Maine to Virginia.

title: THE DARK PLAYGROUND
description: By surrendering - even for one dark hour - to the powerlessness from which his maleness is likely to protect him, Daniel Voll has shown unusual sensitivity. Willingly descending into his friend's pain, humiliation and vulnerability to understand it from within is an act of profound caring that indeed surpasses 1980's rhetoric. LYNN WOLF Plantation, Fla.

title: Jazz/Pop
description: Henry Butler, a pianist from New Orleans, will be reunited with one of his teachers and inspirations this week at Sweet Basil. The teacher is Alvin Batiste, one of the most distinctive and virtuosic modern jazz clarinetists. Mr. Batiste, an early associate of Ornette Coleman, is a player who has been heard too infrequently in New York. Mr. Butler's playing is an increasingly confident synthesis of modal modernism and New Orleans blues roots; he is also a gifted singer in a gospel-inspired mode. The Butler Quartet with Alvin Batiste is playing Tuesday through next Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South near Sheridan Square.

title: Lauren Rachel Shapiro Is Wed to Steven Paul Beck
description: Lauren Rachel Shapiro, a daughter of Susan B. Braver of New York and Michael D. Shapiro of Northport, L.I., and Steven Paul Beck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Felix Beck of Livingston, N.J., were married last evening. Rabbi Azriel Fellner and Cantor Henry Butensky officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Notre Dame Rallies
description: Mark Green carried eight consecutive times, the last for a 2-yard touchdown, to complete a three-touchdown Notre Dame rally for a 32-25 victory over Boston College today. Green, who rushed for 152 yards, led a second-half rushing attack that brought Notre Dame back from a 25-12 deficit.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: HOW FAR can the State Planning Commission go in limiting growth before it must compensate landowners for destroying the value of their property?

title: Anne Lewis Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Anne Beals Lewis and J. William Drake 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Drake Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Lewis of Southport, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

title: True Price Comparison
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH WILL SOFTEN LINE ON MANAGUA
description: Mayor Koch is not preparing to join the Sandinista Front, but his three-day visit to Nicaragua clearly softened his perception of the Sandinistas.

title: LIVING WITH GERMANY ON RIVERSIDE DRIVE
description: LEAD: ANNIVERSARIES II From the Life of Gesine Cresspahl. By Uwe Johnson. Translated by Leila Vennewitz and Walter Arndt. 644 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $29.95.

title: Playing With The Court
description: The collapse of his second successive nomination to the Supreme Court tells us much about Ronald Reagan. It shows us the price we pay for having a President who in even his most solemn appointing function is driven by narrow interests of politics and ideology.

title: An Optimistic Forecast for Bonds
description: THE stock market has been the chief object of investor attention for the last two weeks. But investors in the fixed-income securities market, which is larger than the equity market by at least a trillion dollars, have enjoyed a monthlong rally that propelled bond prices up as much as 12 percent. The rally continued into last week.

title: HEARTLAND FOOD IN HICKSVILLE
description: HICKSVILLE is Long Island's middle ground. Similarly, Wickers, a restaurant in a Hicksville shopping center, is close to the center of Long Island's restaurant spectrum. It's not a fancy place offering haute cuisine at haute prices, nor is it a fast-food spot with a tab to match. Wickers is the kind of place that most Long Islanders gravitate to when dining out: a pleasant restaurant where the check won't break the bank.

title: Melissa B. Rutkin Plans To Wed Michael Kaplitt
description: The engagement of Melissa Beth Rutkin to Michael Gordon Kaplitt, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin J. Kaplitt of Kings Point, L.I., and North Miami Beach, Fla., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Philip Rutkin of Kings Point, parents of the bride-to-be.

title: Glittering Creatures Great and Small
description: SNAKES, BUTTERFLIES and tigers - encrusted with jewels, carved of stone or crafted in gold - coexist handsomely in ''Antique Animal Jewelry: 1700-1940,'' at the gallery of J. Mavec, 52 East 76th Street. The exhibition, which opens Wednesday, will be on view through Nov. 21.

title: East Meets West on a Bus To Leningrad
description: ''THE bus from Moscow to Leningrad,'' we were informed by Irma, the Finnish guide who had taken charge of our 30-member tour group on our arrival at Helsinki airport about a week earlier, ''was made in Finland.'' Not an exciting piece of news, but very much in the spirit of Irma, who had introduced us to Finnish history by emphasizing the effort of the Finns to remain independent of the big neighbor we were about to visit. Irma (pronounced EER-ma) wore a black suit during much of the time in the Soviet Union, as though she were in mourning. She knew that the contrast between Helsinki, with its well-stocked shops and gray, somewhat shabby Moscow, would not be lost on the American visitor.

title: A Free Mandela Could Aid Peace, Nationalist Tells South Africans
description: Nelson R. Mandela, the 69-year-old jailed leader of the outlawed African National Congress, would ''bend all his efforts'' toward a peaceful solution in South Africa if he were freed, his colleague Govan A. Mbeki said today.

title: Deco and Decadence
description: Today, the stylized, sleekly androgynous Art Deco portraits that the Polish-born artist Tamara de Lempicka painted and exhibited in Paris during the 1920's and 30's exist primarily as period pieces. They don't hold a candle to the era's great paintings nor to Art Deco's major achievement - which occurred largely in the area of design. But they do capture much of the decadent narcissism found in certain quarters of European society as the world slid from one war to another. Furthermore, these paintings are of a piece with their creator's Garboesque looks, unwavering self-absorption and a sensational style of life that included suits by Chanel, a studio by Mallet-Stevens and numerous affairs with members of both sexes, among them a rather sordid if unconsummated encounter with d'Annunzio. This of course is the stuff of television movies, and PASSION BY DESIGN: The Art and Times of Tamara de Lempicka (Abbeville Press, $29.95), as told by the artist's daughter, Baroness Kizette de Lempicka-Foxhall to Charles Phillips, a freelance writer, seems created with television in mind. Chapters often end with freeze-frame flourishes that make you think of Joan Collins's Alexis: ''She simply was not a woman to go for long unnoticed.'' ''From the start, she banked on style.'' De Lempicka's two husbands and daughter remain shadowy figures; her place in the Parisian art scene is never seriously broached. Only the artist's insatiable ambition and the misery it seems to have caused her and those around her, give this book its reality. As for the paintings, usually reproduced here in full color, they suffer by comparison with the high-style movie star photos of the artist herself, suggesting that the kind of hothouse, artificial beauty she sought was better captured by the photographers of the time.

title: THE SOUND OF MUSIC
description: HANDEL'S OPERAS 1704-1726. By Winton Dean and John Merrill Knapp. Illustrated. 751 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $59.95.

title: A Widening Pattern of Abuse Exemplified in Steinberg Case
description: For more than a decade, friends and police investigators say, Joel B. Steinberg physically and emotionally abused his lover, Hedda Nussbaum. And in that time, they say, a woman who once was an intelligent and effective editor and author seemed to lose all self-respect and become unable to extricate or defend herself.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: HUDSON N.H.;
Animal Farm Yields to Homes
description: LEAD: AFTER a seven-year struggle against rising costs and stagnant attendance, Benson's Animal Farm, one of northern New England's largest zoos and amusement parks, has ceased operations. Part of its original 400 acres is to be developed by its owner and another parcel by a local builder.

title: Mixing Liquids and Illiquids for Stability
description: IN recent years, individuals have been pouring liquid assets into their portfolios. Their emphasis has been on stocks, bonds and mutual funds, all of which are easily converted to cash.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in some copies of the Travel section today carries an incorrect description of a Chevrolet Bel-Air. The car, on display at the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., is a 1956 model, not a 1955.

title: After the Fall
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
REWRITING AN OLD UNWRITTEN RULE
description: LEAD: AN UNWRITTEN rule in New Jersey used to be that any restaurant with the word inn attached to its name would invariably be long on atmosphere but short on commendable cuisine. That perception is slowly changing, as ambitious restaurateurs and preservationists take over historic buildings, especially along the Delaware River, and install capable chefs in the kitchen.

title: BOTANIST-SLEUTH SEARCHES OUT LONG-HIDDEN PLANTS
description: LEAD: A TINY, brown, flower-topped plant, not seen on Long Island in more than half a century, was recently discovered in the East Hampton area by a Nature Conservancy botanist, Robert Zaremba.

title: James Evans Is to Marry Barbara Jean Bellantoni
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Bellantoni of Monroe Township, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Jean Bellantoni to James Evans, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Evans of Washington Township, N.J.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: I THINK I DON'T REMEMBER. By Art Buchwald. Illustrated by Steve Mendelson. (Putnam, $16.95.) Some things, Art Buchwald among them, don't change. You can count on Art to a) take the idea all the way to its most logical and absurd conclusion; and b) not worry about getting too silly. He writes to be read in small doses, but it is nonetheless interesting to read a whole book of Buchwald columns in one or two sittings.

title: LET THE LOCALS DO IT
description: LEAD: THE RISE OF URBANIZATION AND THE DECLINE OF CITIZENSHIP By Murray Bookchin. 300 pp. San Francisco: Sierra Club Books. $22.95.

title: A BETTER LIFE WHEN THE LIGHTS GO OUT
description: I MUST be the only person who loves it when the power fails.

title: Postings: Watch the Clock; Coming Attraction
description: Site clearance is under way in preparation for the construction of a $10 million shopping center on the site of an old drive-in theater in the Village of Fishkill in Dutchess County. The site is at the intersection of Routes 9 and 52, one mile north of Interstate 84.

title: Trail Purchase Is Set
description: The Green Mountain Club will make its first major land purchase along the Long Trail, thanks to a $120,000 state grant awarded this week. The purchase of three miles of trail in Lowell also will be made with a $120,000 loan from the Vermont chapter of the Nature Conservancy. About 35 miles of the 265-mile trail is up for sale, jeopardizing the continuity and integrity of the foot path.

title: STUFF AS DREAMS ARE MADE ON
description: GUESTS at the recent opening of the ''Fashion and Surrealism'' show at the Fashion Institute of Technology really dressed for the occasion. Forget Fendi. Never mind Lagerfeld. Lacroix? No way.

title:
BLACKBOARD NOTES;
Her Videos Star The College
description: LEAD: TWO YEARS AGO when Shelly Spiegel, a 28-year-old Washington attorney, offered to help her teen-age brother, Brad, shop for the right college she discovered few bargains in the process. ''Poring through brochures, studying applications and mapping out campus visits was time-consuming and costly,'' she said.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Burglars Coveting Rhinestones

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; The Far West Village
description: AS the sun sets over the Hudson River a few blocks away, a woman walks her dog down a cobblestone street. Outside his brownstone, a man beats a rug with a broom. It is 1987, but the setting is turn of the century, for history has left its mark on the Far West Village.

title: Judge Ginsburg's Statement
description: Following is a statement by Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg yesterday afternoon in Washington as recorded by The New York Times.

title: A Redevelopment Rescue
description: The Brooklyn Army Terminal, completed as World War I drew to an end, served the Army in World War II and the Korean War. Then the waterfront facility fell into decay as goods and manpower began to move by air.

title: Judge Rejects a Donor's Bid on Property of The Bible Speaks
description: A Federal judge has rejected an heiress's bid for the property of a fundamentalist church that the woman had forced into bankruptcy through a lawsuit.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: Antique Show Benefits Junior League The Junior League of Central Westchester is sponsoring The Westchester Antiques Show for the second year, with 37 exhibitors from across the country. The location is the ballroom of the Crowne Plaza Hotel in White Plains, from 11 A.M. to 9 P.M. Friday and Saturday and 11 A.M.

title: Canadian Wins Grand Prix
description: The $50,000 Mercedes Grand Prix, the first of the two major jumping competitions at the National Horse Show this weekend, was captured by Ian Millar of the Canadian equestrian team last night on his towering 11-year-old Belgian-bred gelding, Big Ben. The pair staged a repeat performance of their victory in this event here last year.

title: Fordham Clinches
description: Interception returns of 85 yards by Ralph Rios for one touchdown and 18 by Mark Mullen for another carried Fordham to a 45-26 victory over Pace yesterday at Finnerty Field in Pleasantville, N.Y., to give the Rams their first championship in the three-year-old Liberty Conference.

title: A WOMAN AT OLD EXETER
