description: It is no doubt a tribute to ''Old Exeter'' that they have chosen an obviously qualified woman to lead them (''A Woman at Old Exeter,'' by Fran R. Schumer, Oct. 11). But what a sad commentary on the process of evaluating and choosing a woman principal that one of the women on the search committee felt compelled to justify the choice by stating that Kendra Stearns O'Donnell was not ''some ditz who was going to throw her hands up and say, 'I don't know 'bout nothing but babies and birds.' ''

title: Data Update
description: BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED/(Housing units)

title: HOMOSEXUALS AND THE CHURCHES
description: It is laudable that many homosexuals are striving to fill a spiritual need and draw closer to God, and it is the obligation of the churches to assist them in their quest. But, are they?

title: Japanese Leader Urges U.S. to Reduce Deficit
description: Noboru Takeshita, Japan's new Prime Minister, urged the Reagan Administration and Congress today to move quickly to reduce the United States budget deficit.

title: President of Israel to Make First Visit to U.S.
description: President Chaim Herzog of Israel will meet President Reagan at the White House Tuesday at the start of the first state visit by an Israeli President to the United States.

title: THANK GOD FOR RASHES AND TOOTHBRUSHES
description: THE RABBI OF LUD By Stanley Elkin. 277 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $17.95.

title: WINNERS IN TOWNS PROMISE CHANGES
description: LEAD: THEY were serving baked ziti, breaded mushrooms and sausage and peppers last Tuesday evening at Madera's Restaurant in Thornwood, but while he sampled all of them, Michael L. Rovello said the only thing he could taste was victory, which he pronounced ''very, very sweet.''

title: Tiffany Bluemle Wed to Todd Purdum
description: The Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Tiffany Windsor Bluemle, the director of development for the National Civic League in Manhattan, and Todd Stanley Purdum, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times. The Rev. Sue Anne Steffey Morrow, the assistant dean of the chapel, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Nancy Garfinkel Married To Martin S. Eller on L.I.
description: At Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., Nancy Ellen Garfinkel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Garfinkel of Plainview, L.I., was married last evening to Martin Scott Eller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Eller of Morganville, N.J. Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman officiated.

title: STUDENTS FACE HOUSING WOES
description: LEAD: THE most difficult problem that students at many of Long Island's colleges face is outside their classrooms, as they attempt to grapple with soaring dormitory and off-campus housing costs and, in some cases, no housing at all.

title: WHO SHOULD BE THE M.V.P.'S IN BASEBALL?
description: Year after year the selection of baseball's most valuable players is an almost arbitrary choice between two players equally worthy of the award - one seemingly deserving on the basis of statistical achievement, the other for leadership of a pennant winning ball club. Why not establish a new annual award to honor the ''Slugger of the Year'' in each league? Let's call it the Babe Ruth Trophy. So, for 1987 let's award Andre Dawson a Babe Ruth trophy and save the m.v.p. honor for Ozzie Smith, or (as some have suggested) Will Clark.

title: Jail Riot Quelled in Brussels
description: The police restored order at a prison in Brussels today after 50 people were injured in rioting by inmates, officials said. A police spokesman said about 100 inmates at the Forest Prison smashed furniture and lit fires Friday night. He said order was restored after a few hours when police entered the jail and freed four guards who had been taken hostage. Inmates were said to be protesting preferential treatment of British soccer fans awaiting trial on charges stemming from the 1985 Heysel Stadium riots.

title:
GARDENING;
THE APPEAL OF THE MUSTARD FAMILY
description: LEAD: ONE of the more interesting and youthful plant species is Brassica oleracea. Native to western and southern Europe, it has yielded many interesting and useful forms in cultivation. This is the species of such diverse and familiar vegetables as collards, kale, broccoli, cauliflower, cabbage, brussels sprouts and kohlrabi, among others.

title: When the Name of the Game Is Murder
description: PRIME-TIME TELEVISION'S preoccupation with sociopaths is more intense than ever these days.

title: Listen to Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Governor's Bid Complicates Puerto Rico Race
description: From the moment former Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo lost his post in the 1984 gubernatorial election, few people on this highly politicized island doubted that he would attempt a comeback.

title: Of Black Leather, Body Stockings And Barbie Dolls
description: IN ''ORPHEE,'' HIS 1949 FILM TREAT-ment of the Orpheus legend, Jean Cocteau pictured Hell as an administrative office run by French bureaucrats. This French penchant for mordant allegory and metaphor should be kept in mind with respect to the two dance-theater pieces performed by the Compagnie Maguy Marin in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's current Next Wave Festival.

title: Man in the News; Strong Hand for Tunisia: Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali
description: Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, the 51-year-old army general who yesterday became Tunisia's second President since it won independence from France in 1956, started out to become an electronics engineer.

title: Practical Traveler; Club Discounts From Eastern
description: THE woods are filled with clubs for discount travel.

title: Another Face Of Argentina
description: ARGENTINA is a lot more than Buenos Aires, its cosmopolitan capital. Its million square miles stretch from the Tropic of Capricorn almost to the Antarctic, and from the Atlantic deep into the Andes. The two-hour air journey from Buenos Aires to Salta, where the mountains meet the tropics, is a voyage into a different geography, climate and culture.

title: Heyward's 175 Yards Help Pitt to Victory
description: Craig Heyward, impressive in Pitt's homecoming loss to unbeaten Syracuse a week ago, staged a personal homecoming today, running for 175 yards and his eighth touchdown of the season as the Panthers beat Rutgers, 17-0.

title: Blast Jolts Earthquake Area
description: Residents were awakened early today by what some thought was an earthquake when scientists blew up 1,200 pounds of dynamite underground to study the fault that caused the powerful temblor in the Los Angeles area last month. The explosion occurred at 4:10 A.M. near the epicenter of the Oct. 1 earthquake that killed seven people.

title: A Tide of Coast Contamination
description: LEAD: The deterioration of the nation's bays and estuaries cannot be addressed piecemeal. Not enough attention has been paid to the problems of these coastal waters, and not nearly enough action has been taken to avert what could become another environmental crisis.

title: Cunningham Leads Eagles to an Upset
description: The Philadelphia Eagles upset the Washington Redskins today with their wide-open style of play that Philadelphians have taken to calling Buddy Ball, an admiring reference to the team's coach, Buddy Ryan.

title: Walton Hopes Jets Play With Emotion
description: The Jets had their final workout today for Monday night's game against the Seattle Seahawks, but for all that he had said and done during the week, Coach Joe Walton still was unsure if his attempts to shake up the team had been successful.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a tax credit reversal of $15,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $321,000 for the year. c-After losses from the disposal of the automated systems division of $278,000 for the quarter and $353,000 for the year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1987
description: The Economy

title: CHICAGO RIVET & MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Donald Trump's Circus, and Bread
description: After an ardent 18-month courtship, Donald Trump has failed to win the hand of NBC as owner-tenant for 10 acres of his dramatic 76-acre development proposed for Manhattan's West Side. That adds urgency to efforts by Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo to keep NBC in New York, the way they have now succeeded in keeping the Dreyfus Corporation. And it leaves Mr. Trump wondering what to do with the 10-acre site now.

title: SUN STATE SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; SecondHome Owners Get a New Publication
description: Northeast Second Home is an every-other-month tabloid that has just made its debut as a joint venture of Thomas H. Forbes, 34-year-old editorial director of Adweek, and A/S/M Communications, the company that publishes Adweek.

title: SIFCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $815,000 on disposal of capital assets and investments. c-After a gain of $736,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Resistance Is Seen To Penney's Shift
description: The J. C. Penney Company, which announced last July that it would move its headquarters from Manhattan to Plano, Tex., has run into considerable reluctance by employees to make the 1,500-mile move, according to sources close to the giant retailer.

title: TV Review; 'The World's a Stage,' Theater History on 31
description: BEGINNING tonight at 9, WNYC, Channel 31, begins ''All the World's a Stage,'' a 13-part BBC series that is an attractively packaged history of the theater, a sort of electronic Theater 101 course. Actually, it is, as a subtitle indicates, ''one man's journey'' through that history. The man is Ronald Harwood, the writer whose credits include ''The Dresser,'' both play and film, and, more recently, the HBO movie ''Mandela.''

title: Bangladesh Chief Bans March
description: The Government banned demonstrations today to thwart a planned march in the capital by protesters seeking the ouster of Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad as president.

title: 'So Old a Friend'
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Concert Series
description: Carnegie Hall and the Department of Cultural Affairs of the City of New York are presenting a season of 30 programs in the Neighborhood Concerts Series, to take place in libraries, community centers, churches and synagogues in the five boroughs through May 1988. There will be jazz, classical and folk-music concerts, all open to the public free of charge, with seating on a first-come, first-served basis. The next concert - by the New York Strings, a jazz string quartet with bass and guitar - is Wednesday at 1 P.M. at the Harlem School of the Arts, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue near 147th Street. A complete schedule of events may be obtained by writing to Neighborhood Concerts, Carnegie Hall, 881 Seventh Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10019.

title: STOCKHOLDER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 New York Officers Arrested at a Pit Bull Fight
description: A New York City police detective and a police officer were arrested yesterday with 25 other people at a farm in Orange County that the state police said was used for pit bull fights.

title: CMX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $89,000 and $31,000 for the latest quarter and year- earlier period, respectively.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm satisfied beyond doubt that this was the work of the I.R.A.'' - Sir John Hermon, chief of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. [ A1:1. ]

title: Report Assails U.S. Helicopter
description: Crashes of the Army's most modern troop-carrying helicopters have been caused by ordinary radio waves from microwave towers, radio attennas and radar, a published report says. But a military spokesman has vehemently denied the report.

title: Yachting; Powerboat Final Plans Grueling Course With Safety in Mind
description: Don Johnson, the slick crime buster of the television show ''Miami Vice,'' doesn't need a stunt man when it comes to driving the program's powerful 38-foot speedboat on camera. In fact, Johnson has taken to the part so well that he plans to carry it into real life; he will be a co-driver this week in the powerboat world championship in Key West, Fla.

title: TENURE AS COURT NOMINEE STRETCHED BY A TRAFFIC JAM
description: Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg was stuck for an hour in traffic Saturday as he headed to the White House, delaying his announcement that he was ending his bid to join the Supreme Court, the White House says.

title: Risk Is Too High in AIDS Patient Surgery
description: To the Editor:

title: Vallone Urges Jail For Homeless People Who Decline Help
description: People who live on the streets and refuse to be taken to a shelter or a hospital should be subject to arrest and a night in jail, the majority leader of the New York City Council, Peter F. Vallone, said yesterday.

title: Al Richmond, Leftist Ex-Editor
description: Al Richmond, a former editor who was convicted of subversion and imprisoned during the McCarthy anti-Communist era, died of pneumonia Friday. He was 73 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. Sabres 6, Flames 3: Buffalo got a pair game streak without a victory. (AP) Tennis Mayotte Outlasts Gilbert: Tim Mayotte won the final of the $840,000 Paris apen yesterday by beating a fellow American, Brad Gilbert, 2-6, 6-3, 7-5, 6-7, 6-3. Mayotte captured his fourth tournament of the year and won $140,000. Gilbert won $70,000. It was the fourth straight time that Mayotte had beaten Gilbert. (AP) Edberg Defeats Svensson: Top-seeded Stefan Edberg defeated another Swede, Jonas Svensson, 7-5, 6-2, 4-6, 6-4, yesterday to win the singles title in the $525,000 Stockholm Open for the second straight year. Edberg, ranked second in the world, needed almost three hours to win the final. It was his seventh Grand Prix singles crown of the year, more than any other player. Edberg won $72,250 and surpassed top-ranked Ivan Lendl in the money standing for the year with a total of $925,992. (AP) Shriver Tops Evert: Pam Shriver, who broke an 18-match losing streak to Chris Evert earlier this year, defeated Evert, 6-4, 4-6, 6-0, yesterday to win the $250,000 New England Virginia Slims championship in Worcester, Mass. The 25-year-old Shriver said that age might have been a factor in the match. Evert, 32 years old, played a tough match Saturday night against Gabriela Sabatini and was exhausted. Shriver had beaten Evert in a semifinal of this year's Canadian Open. With the $50,000 first-place prize, Shriver, ranked No. 5 in the world, increased her winnings for the year to $525,710. (AP) Golf Strange Lifts U.S. Over Europe: The United States team, helped by a key match victory by Curtis Strange, beat Europe, 10-2, yesterday for the title in the $950,000 World Championship of Golf in Inagi, Japan. The Americans won five matches and lost one. Each of the six United States players received $60,000; the Europeans got $35,000 apiece. Australia-New Zealand beat Japan, 9-3, to finish third among teams representing the four Professional Golf Association tours. Sandy Lyle beat Mark Calcavecchia, 70-72, but the Americans then won three matches: Payne Stewart defeated Ian Woosnam, 70-72; Lanny Wadkins beat Bernhard Langer, 70-71, and Scott Simpson defeated Nick Faldo, 68-72. Ken Brown led Strange by one shot after the 17th hole. But on the 224-yard 18th hole, a par 3, Strange rolled in a 13-foot birdie putt for a 70, while Brown missed a 3-foot par putt. (AP) Significant Second for Okamoto: Yuko Moriguchi shot a par 72 yesterday and beat Ayako Okamoto by three strokes in Japan's richest golf tournament for women, the $350,000 Mazda Japan Classic in Hanno, which was the final official Ladies Professional Golf Association event for 1987. With second prize of $32,375, Okamoto overtook Betsy King and finished atop the L.P.G.A.'s 1987 winnings list, becoming the first non-American to finish there. Okamoto ended with $466,034. King won $18,375 for fourth place yesterday, and finished the year with $460,385. Okamoto also became the L.P.G.A. Player of the Year with 68 points, followed by King with 66 and Jane Geddes with 64. (AP) Biathlon Californian Is Champion: Ken Souza, a 22-year-old from Covina, Calif., won the third annual Goldome New York City Biathlon - also the United States national biathlon championship - in a course record time of 1 hour 12 minutes 5 seconds yesterday in Central Park. The event consisted of two three-mile runs sandwiched round an 18-mile bicycle race. Twenty-nine-year-old Liz Downing of Portland, Ore., was the women's winner in 1:21.21. Auto Racing Wallace Triumphs: Rusty Wallace benefited from Geoff Bodine's misfortune yesterday and won the Winston Western 500 Nascar stock-car race at Riverside, Calif. Bodine dominated most of the 119-lap, 500-kilometer race and appeared well on the way to his first victory of the season when his right-rear tire went flat 11 laps from the end. Bodine's car spun off the course and Wallace found himself leading the race, just ahead of Benny Parsons and Kyle Petty. He was able to stay in front the rest of the way, and picked up his second victory of the season and the fourth of his Winston Cup career. (AP) Soccer Seton Hall 2, Connecticut 1: Pat O'Kelly and Ian Hennessy scored goals within a span of 1 minute 44 seconds in the first half yesterday to lift Seton Hall to a 2-1 victory over Connecticut and the Big East Conference championship in Storrs, Conn. The victory gaves Seton Hall (14-3-3) a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I tournament. The remainder of the 24-team field will be announced today. The Huskies fell to 13-6-3. (AP) Penn State 1, Rutgers 0: Penn State defeated Rutgers, 1-0, yesterday to win the first Atlantic-10 Conference men's soccer championship at Rutgers Stadium in New Brunswick, N.J. (AP)

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Italy Voting on Atom Power and Other Issues
description: Italy began voting today on five referendums that could produce important changes in nuclear energy policies and the criminal justice system.

title: Metro Matters; Lindsay Reunion: Good Old Days Of Urban Strife
description: Not many New Yorkers recall the era punctuated by transit, school and garbage strikes, by snow-choked streets and urban strife two decades ago as the good old days, if they recall it at all.

title: DRESHER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CENTRAL BANKERS IN TALKS
description: As the presidents of the central banks of the major industrial nations gather here today, their major concern is when the dollar will stop falling.

title: FRANKLIN RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid July 15.

title: Federal Judge Orders Professor Reinstated At Boston University
description: A Federal district judge has ordered Boston University to reinstate with tenure a professor of English who was found to have been the victim of sex discrimination.

title: Diversion Case Pleas Offered
description: Two brothers have pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiracy to sell supercomputer technology to the Soviet Union.

title: Key Setback For Lilco; P.S.C. Action Viewed as Death of Shoreham
description: The usual turmoil surrounding the Long Island Lighting Company and its Shoreham nuclear power plant has increased in the last several months, to the point where analysts and government officials seem certain that the plant will never receive its commercial operating license.

title: Small Drop In Gas Prices
description: The average price of gasoline dropped only one-tenth of a cent a gallon during a two-week period, but a decline in wholsesale prices may bring greater reductions, an industry analyst said today.

title: Declining Strength Seen in Reagan's Loss on Court
description: President Reagan's second failure in two weeks to place his nominee on the Supreme Court demonstrates his declining political influence and ability to shape public policy in his final 14 months in office, political analysts in both parties say.

title: ENEX RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Congressmen Show Off
description: Members of Congress like to show off local products. New Yorkers, for example, have been known to import deli from Brooklyn, and Hawaiians nearly bury the Capitol in macadamia nuts, while Floridians seem intent on floating it on a sea of orange juice. Senator Christopher J. Dodd the other day brought something from his home state of Connecticut that will be hard to match. He brought a Gershwin musical.

title: COTTON STATES LIFE & HEALTH INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $246,923 and $766,775 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After realized investment loss of $70,800 for the quarter and captial gains of $498,120 for the 9 months. Earnings for the year-ago 9-month are restated to reflect a correction of an error in the computation of future policy benefits; the correction increases earnings by $242,000, or 9 cents a share.

title: Sports World Specials; A Crusader Looks Back
description: Forty years after Jackie Robinson broke the color line in major-league baseball, there are few left from the small band of firebrands and visionaries who laid the groundwork for his triumph.

title: The 60's Meet the 80's; Disclosures on Marijuana Widen Debate Over Public Standards and Private Lives
description: Once again, the focus of the 1988 Presidential campaign has veered away from the matter of how the country should be governed toward highly personal questions about those who would govern it.

title: INTERFACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September.

title: Stocks Prices Slide in Tokyo
description: Share prices fell in very light trading this morning. Brokers said the decline came amid concern over the future direction of the American economy and the dollar.

title: I.R.A. IS SUSPECTED
description: Eleven people were killed today when a huge bomb exploded as crowds gathered in Enniskillen for a wreath-laying ceremony honoring Britain's war dead.

title: SCIENCE DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rush for Money on Road Spurs Debate
description: Columbus is a city buzzing with talk of mystery and morality two weeks after hundreds of thousands of dollars fell from an armored truck and were scooped up by passers-by.

title: Amoco Clears Dome Hurdle
description: The Amoco Canada Petroleum Company said Friday that its proposed $3.87 billion takeover of Dome Petroleum Ltd. would not face a legal challenge from Canada's director of investigation and research, Calvin S. Goldman. He found that competition in the crude oil, natural gas and sulphur markets would not be diminished by the merger, said the Canadian subsidiary of the Amoco Corporation. He said, however, that

title: BALLET THEATER SEASON TO PRESENT NEW WORKS
description: American Ballet Theater will present the world premieres of bal-lets by Agnes de Mile, Mark Morris and Clark Tippet during its 1987-88 season. It will also present the com-pany premiere of George Balan-chine's ''Ballet Imperial'' and re-vivals of Antony Tudor's ''Gala Per-formance'' and Leonide Massine's ''Gaiete Parisienne.''

title: Nicaraguan Cardinal Seeks Pledges Before Mediation Starts
description: Just two days after the Sandinista Government agreed to name Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo as intermediary in talks with guerrilla leaders, the Cardinal said he was not sure he would accept the job.

title: ESCAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in April 1987.

title: T-Arms and Teardrops: Restoring Street Lights
description: It is a brilliant collection and ubiquitous, marked by tall civic sentinels whose names are cobra head and bishop's crook, teardrop and shoe box. It is also shabby, neglected, rusting and vandalized.

title: ELDORADO MOTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
Olympic Notebook; Proposal for a Joint Team of 2 Koreas
description: The International Olympic Committee is reviewing a proposal by North Korea to have North Korea and South Korea be represented by a joint team in the 1988 Seoul Olympic games. Under such an arrangement, all the Games would be held in Seoul, the capital of South Korea.

title: Horse Show; British Rider Wins Big Apple Jumping
description: The $50,000 Big Apple Grand Prix, the international jumping competition that closed the National Horse Show last night, was won by John Whitaker, a member of the British team, atop Next Milton, a snowy horse who looked as if he had flown from the pages of a fairy tale.

title: Moralism Wins Again
description: Numerous valid reasons appeared to be developing for the rejection of Douglas H. Ginsburg, President Reagan's second-choice nominee for a Supreme Court seat. In the end, however, Judge Ginsburg became one more victim of a moralistic new standard that is more deplorable than the private behavior it condemns.

title: Bombing of Dresden Hastened End of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Libya Assails U.S. Decision To Provide Weapon to Chad
description: Libya said today that a United States decision to supply Stinger anti-aircraft missiles to Chad was a direct threat to Libya's security.

title: KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,509,000 and $719,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $1,590,000 for the quarter and $928,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $13,000 for the quarter and $382,000 for the 9 months.

title: Horse Racing; 3 of Trainer's Horses Fail Drug Tests
description: Three horses trained by Peter Ferriola who raced at Aqueduct last week subsequently tested positive for the prohibited medication Lasix, the track stewards said yesterday.

title: School Football; Chaminade Edges Cardinal Spellman
description: Chaminade, getting a safety to go with its four touchdowns, defeated Cardinal Spellman, 29-28, yesterday in a quarterfinal game of the Catholic High Schools Athletic League playoffs.

title: STEVEN GIRDEN IS MARRIED TO LYSSA ANN RAICHELSON
description: Lyssa Ann Raichelson, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Raichelson of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Steven Scott Girden, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Girden of Stamford, Conn. Rabbis Norman Patz and Alex J. Goldman officiated at the Headquarters Plaza Hotel in Morristown, N.J.

title: COMPUTER AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $136,000 for the latest quarter and $37,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Ground Broken in Louisiana For Jail for Cuban Criminals
description: The new Federal Detention Center for illegal aliens here will soon have an addition, an outgrowth of the nation's new immigration law.

title: Stage: Satirical 'Medea,' By the Ludlam Troupe
description: OF all the memorial tributes the theater has bestowed upon its fallen giants this year, perhaps the most painful to watch was the one given in July by the Ridiculous Theatrical Company for Charles Ludlam, who died at age 44 last spring. The tribute was in part dedicated to demonstrating the continuity of the company Mr. Ludlam left behind, and to this end, Ridiculous troupers nobly performed scenes from past triumphs. But Mr. Ludlam was not merely the igniting spirit, artistic director and playwright-in-residence of the Ridiculous - he was also its foremost performer. Instead of affirming the company's artistic survival, each of the memorial's haunted sketches seemed to accentuate the enormous size of the vacuum left by Mr. Ludlam. One kept waiting for the star entrance that would never come.

title: BLACK VOTERS KEY TO MIAMI ELECTION
description: The tangled runoff election Tuesday for Mayor of Miami is between two Hispanic politicians who have held the office, but it may be black voters who decide which one returns to City Hall.

title: HIGHER ESTIMATES FOR ROBINS
description: The A.H. Robins Company should be required to set aside up to $2.3 billion to compensate 163,000 women who contend that they were injured by Robins's Dalkon Shield birth-control device, an expert witness testified today as a bankruptcy hearing continued in Federal court here.

title: CHURCH & DWIGHT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Crash With Fire Engine Kills One
description: A 24-year-old woman was killed last night when a car she was riding in was hit broadside by a fire engine responding to a fire in Ozone Park, Queens, the police said.

title: DELPHI INFORMATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $50,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: BERNICE NAPACH IS WED
description: The marriage of Bernice Napach, a reporter for the Reuters news agency, and Charles Paikert, a freelance journalist, took place yesterday at the Swan Club in Roslyn, L.I. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony. The bride, the daughter of Lillian Napach of Little Neck, Queens, and the late Alex Napach, was formerly the New York bureau chief for Commodity World News. Mr. Paikert, formerly a senior editor at Investment Dealers Digest magazine, is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Geza Charles Paikert of Syracuse.

title: Palestinians Hijack Boat With 8 Aboard
description: The Palestinian guerrilla group led by Abu Nidal announced here today that one of its units had seized a French-registered boat with eight people aboard off the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: BASF Corp., Parsippany, N.J., named Peter R. Heinze executive vice president and president of the chemicals division, succeeding Edwin L. Stenzel. Bass & Co., a division of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corp. that manufactures leather footwear, named John S. Thorbeck president. Bowater Inc., Darien, Conn., a maker of newsprint and a producer of coated publication papers, bleached kraft market pulp, and continuous computer business forms, elected as a director Hugh D. Aycock, president and chief operating officer of Nucor Corp., Charlotte, N.C. Dime Savings Bank, Garden City, L.I., named Jenesta Marlin first senior vice president, banking division. Emerson Electric Co., St. Louis, appointed Dennis J. Moore president of the Electronics and Space division and elected as a corporate director Robert B. Horton, vice chairman and chief executive of BP America Inc. Hadron Inc., Fairfax, Va., a high-technology company, said L. Kenneth Johnson had resigned as president and chief operating officer to pursue other business and personal interests. Assuming the additional position of president will be Dominic A. Laiti, chairman and chief executive. Hemotec Inc., Englewood, Colo., a maker of medical instruments and disposables, named Jerry W. Nigh president and chief executive, succeeding Walter J. Braun, who will continue as chairman. Home Group Inc., Newark, Del., a property, casualty and life insurance concern, elected Bruce W. Bean senior vice president. International Dairy Queen Inc., Minneapolis, elected Michael Sullivan president and chief executive, replacing Harris Cooper, who will devote his efforts to the development of a subsidiary, Telechef Corp., of which he is president and a shareholder. Mazda Motors of America (East) Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., appointed Mizuhiko (Mitch) Nishida executive vice president, succeeding Takao Sekino, who returned to Japan to accept an assignment at Mazda Motor Corp. National Data Corp., Atlanta, a provider of electronic and voice transaction processing services, named Mark L. Braunstein president and chief operating officer. Pharmakinetics Laboratories Inc., Baltimore, a holding company that deals in the clinical testing of drugs, appointed Dr. Melvin Sharoky to the newly created position of senior vice president. United States Life Insurance Co., a subsidiary of USLife Corp., promoted James D. Martin to senior vice president, field marketing. University Science Partners Inc., Detroit, appointed Richard S. Garard president and chief executive of its Wavemat Inc. subsidiary, which was formed to promote commercial use of microwave technology. Warnaco Inc. appointed Stephen L. Ruzow president and chief executive of the company's Activewear division, replacing Thomas J. Bienemann, who will remain a consultant.

title: 6 Held in Drug Scheme; $7.5 Million Is Seized
description: Federal agents seized $7.5 million in cash and arrested six men Thursday in connection with what they said was a scheme to launder profits from drug sales.

title: CHRISTOPHER FINN WED TO MARGARET CHISHOLM
description: Margaret Mary Chisholm, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Chisholm of Westfield, N.J., was married there yesterday to Christopher Charles Finn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Michael Finn of Bronxville, N.Y., and Flagstaff, Ariz. The Rev. William Morris performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Helen.

title: PRAISE FOR TWO MEN
description: The departing Defense Secretary, Caspar W. Weinberger, has been making a point to applaud William Howard Taft 4th, his deputy secretary, as often as he compliments Frank C. Carlucci, his replacement. At the Rose Garden ceremony for Mr. Weinberger, at a Pentagon news conference and on television, Mr. Weinberger has said how happy he is that the Pentagon will be run by Mr. Taft and Mr. Carlucci. The reason he mentions Mr. Taft so often, according to Administration insiders, is that the deputy secretary was Mr. Weinberger's first choice as a successor. But he is not displeased by the selection of Mr. Carlucci, the President's national security adviser, who was Mr. Weinberger's deputy from 1981 to 1983.

title: TRAVELERS REAL ESTATE INESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
United Stand by Arabs Against Iran Is Urged
description: The first major summit meeting of Arab heads of state in five years opened here today with a condemnation of Iran for its determination to carry on with the seven-year-old Persian Gulf war and an appeal to end Egypt's isolation from other Arab governments.

title: Market Place; Big Stock Sale By Japanese
description: THE largest single entity on the Japanese stock market, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, is scheduled to begin selling tomorrow an issue of 1.95 million shares with an estimated value of about $38 billion.

title: SUNLITE INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The latest year results include a provision for contingent loss of about $900,000 related to litigation. Sunlite said the results include amounts for impairment of the company's oil and gas assets of $75,000 in 1987 and $1,132,000 in 1986.

title: Race Driver, 65, Killed in Florida
description: Jim Fitzgerald, the driver with the most victories in the history of the Sports Car Club of America, was killed this afternoon in the early stages of the Trans-Am race at the St. Petersburg Grand Prix.

title: STRATEGIC MORTGAGE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
College Football; L.S.U. Loss Clouds Forecast for Bowls
description: Alabama's 22-10 upset over previously unbeaten Louisiana State on Saturday night scrambled the post-season bowl picture, raising doubts about how highly ranked a team the Sugar Bowl can attract to play the Southeastern Conference champion.

title: GUARANTY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $165,000 and $891,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $831,000 for the quarter and $2,852,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes capital gains of $68,000 for the quarter and $1,511,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $688,000 and $3,092,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest quarter and 9-month include tax benefits of $700,000 and $2.4 million, respectively, related to 1986 Tax Reform Act.

title: Budget Meeting With President Puzzles G.O.P.
description: Republican leaders left a meeting with President Reagan on Friday confused about what was said and without a clear direction on budget priorities, reflecting a split among Republicans and indecision in the White House, participants in the meeting said today.

title: British Faster Again
description: The Marines found a few good runners for yesterday's 12th annual Marine Corps Marathon, but as it turned out, they weren't quite good enough. For the fourth year in a row, the British Royal Marines defeated the United States Marines.

title: Irked Condo Considers Seceding From a Town
description: Residents of a condominium complex that attracts retired people have been been battling their town for years over perceived slights, like the denial of a bingo permit. Now, feuding again with the town fathers, they say they are studying plans to secede and form their own city here in Fairfield County.

title: SCICOM DATA SVC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNITED SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION-MISSOURI reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Concert: 'Music for Life,' a Benefit
description: ONE watched with interest the faces of last night's elegant audience entering Carnegie Hall. It was a benefit event called ''Music for Life,'' raising $1.7 million to support and care for victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: SYNALLOY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After net of $42,000 for the quarter and $237,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations, gains on the sales of operations of $1,420,000 and $1,746,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $340,000 for the quarter and $460,000 for the 9 months.

title: Actively Seeking Stardom in Manhattan
description: On her first trip to Manhattan, 19-year-old Melissa Tomaini was standing where so many in this town of big dreams and stardust hope to be: under the stage lights of a New York City theater. But her big chance turned out to be an especially small one.

title: SOUTHEASTERN SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHARLOTTE MAYOR'S DEFEAT ECHOES FAR
description: Harvey Gantt is a compelling symbol of the New South. In 1963, he became the first black to enroll at Clemson University. Twenty years later, he became the first black Mayor of Charlotte, elected by a city that was 70 percent white.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE LIFE OF THE PARTY. Democratic Prospects in 1988 and Beyond. By Robert Kuttner, 265 pages. Elisabeth Stifton/Viking. $18.95.

title: Tax Proposal Affects Bonds
description: Investors in old bonds valued at less than their face value would be hit with a new tax under provisions of the tax bill passed last month by the House of Representatives For investors buying those bonds, known as ''market discount'' issues, the House bill proposes to tax the difference between the purchase price and the bonds' value at maturity. The tax would apply to bonds purchased after Oct. 13.

title: Prices of Some Imports Can't Help but Go Up
description: The latest plunge in the value of the dollar against other major currencies means that the prices of imported goods - ranging from German wines to Italian shoes to Japanese cars - will rise in coming weeks and months, according to importers, industry officials and economists.

title: International Report; Swiftly Rising Prices Alarm China's Leaders
description: There is a new ugly word in China: inflation.

title: LINDA SCHECHTER IS MARRIED ON L.I.
description: Linda Schechter, an associate in the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, was married in Garden City, L.I., yesterday to Stephen Giove, an associate in the law firm of Shearman & Sterling in New York. Rabbi Stuart Geller performed the ceremony at the Garden City Hotel.

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 Youths Arrested in Painting of Swastikas on Mahopac Synagogue
description: The 16-year-old son of a Russian Orthodox priest, wearing a makeshift Nazi uniform, and a 12-year-old companion have been arrested in the spray painting of Nazi symbols on the only synagogue in Mahopac, N.Y., said police officers, who had been staking out the synagogue after a series of such incidents.

title: Business and the Law; Rising Costs Of Texaco Case
description: THE fight between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company over the Getty Oil Company took another turn last week, insuring that the legal meters will keep ticking in a case that has already produced some fat bills from Texas and New York law firms.

title: Gorbachev Lends an Ear To Proxmire's Hearings
description: Soviet specialists here say they cannot recall a previous instance in which a Soviet leader made direct references to American Congressional testimony, let alone in a speech inside the Soviet Union.

title: DR. DAVID R. HENSEN WED TO DR. DEIRDRE MUNISTERI
description: At the Setauket Presbyterian Church in Setauket, L.I., Dr. Deirdre Munisteri and Dr. David Roy Hensen, who are veterinarians, were married yesterday by the Rev. Theodore J. Wardlaw.

title: First Look at Homeless: A Raw Sight for Tourists
description: They march through Grand Central Terminal or the Port Authority bus station, headed for Macy's, the South Street Seaport or a Broadway matinee. But first, they must pass the homeless men numbed by Thunderbird who snore under newsprint blankets and the ragged women who rant incoherently about Jesus, Ronald Reagan or their lost loves.

title: NOBLE DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ELDON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today: Nov. 9, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Preventing Child Abuse: When Early Hints Are Not Enough
description: When she was fatally beaten one week ago, 6-year-old Elizabeth Steinberg was no stranger to New York City social workers. Over four years, they had twice visited her home to investigate reports of possible mistreatment and had at least once inspected her body for bruises and other signs of abuse.

title: TIC INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $38,000 for the quarter and $95,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $76,000 for the quarter and $180,000 for the 6 months.

title: ALLOY COMPUTER PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Five Choreographers Get New Awards
description: The National Corporate Fund for Dance Inc. has announced the first recipients of its American Choreographer Awards, which will be given in a ceremony at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Nov. 23. The choreographers - John Kelly, Ralph Lemon, Susan Marshall, Patricia Olalde and Stephen Petronio - will share a total of $20,000.

title: Facing Facts on Conventional Forces
description: Throughout the West the wails are heard: Eliminating medium-range missiles from Europe will soon lay pitilessly bare the West's weakness in conventional forces. That's baloney. Many a nuclear layer will survive the prospective Euromissile agreement, and in any case destroying missiles so recently deployed isn't the cause of NATO's conventional arms worries. These go back decades.

title: Gamble and Lockbaum Race for Award
description: Two of the leading candidates for the Walter Payton Award, given to the best player in Division I-AA, are Kenny Gamble of Colgate and Gordie Lockbaum of Holy Cross.

title: MUSIC: GOSPEL AT TRIPLEX
description: THE World Music Institute's Grass-Roots Gospel Festival presented three groups Friday night, in the first of two weekend programs at the Triplex Theater of theBorough of Manhattan Community College. The Original Blind Boys of Alabama, who won a local following outside the gospel community with their performances in the musical ''Gospel at Colonus,'' were the headliners. But the evening's most traditional, grass-roots music was provided by the newest group on the program, the No Name Gospel Singers, who will be celebrating their sixth anniversary as a group later this month.

title: COMAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DR. CAROL GOLDMAN WEDS A NEUROLOGIST
description: The marriage of Dr. Carol Marcia Goldman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George D. Goldman of Jericho, L.I., to Dr. Ross Alexander Reife, the son of Diane Reife of Hallendale, Fla., and the late Irving N. Reife, took place yesterday at the Water's Edge in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Martin Zion officiated.

title: DH TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bears' General Has Returned As Promised
description: BEFORE the season, Jim McMahon posed for a poster in a bomber jacket and sunglasses, smoking a pipe and invoking the pledge, ''I shall return.'' The allusion seems apt, although Gen. Douglas MacArthur, as far as anyone can recall, never wore a punk hairdo. The Bears' quarterback, like MacArthur a cantankerous field commander who doesn't always agree with the boss, has also made good on his promise.

title: Dickerson Fumble Helps Drop Colts
description: When the National Football League schedule was determined months ago, this game looked to be an inconsequential meeting between two lackluster teams: the aging San Diego Chargers and the hapless Indianaplis Colts.

title: A Hot Ticket Is Round Trip, to or From Moscow
description: Dr. Zara Khetagurova and Tamara Abova, members of a delegation of Soviet women traveling from Moscow to the United States, suffered an indignity familiar to many an American traveler: They were bumped from their Aeroflot flight, on which they had been booked for six weeks.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 8, 1987: MONDAY Minnesota Mng & Mfg Stone Container Pitney-Bowes Inc TUESDAY Advest Group McDermott Intl Eldon Indus Mickelberry Corp Fleet Fin'l Group Russ Berrie & Co Household Intl Staley Continental Intl Paper SunTrust Banks WEDNESDAY CSX Corp Marlon Laboratories Cincinnati Milacron Meredith Corp Esselte Business Sys Sears Roebuck Fireman's Fund USG Corp Gerber Products USLIFE Inc Fd THURSDAY Allegheny Ludlum Corp Maytag Co Arvin Industries Oakite Products Cooper Tire & Rubber Pacific Amer Inc Shs KeyCorp Singer Co Lincoln Natl Sysco Corp Louisiana Genl Svcs Tultex Corp Manhattan Industries Unifirst Corp MAPCO Inc Van Dorn Co QFRIDAY Alco Standard Eastman Kodak Bandag Inc Lee Enterprises Chelsea Industries Williams Cos

title: Pitino System to Take Time
description: Nearly a month ago, Rick Pitino began trying to alter five years of bad Knick habits. He introduced a system of basketball that asked the players to move, react and interplay with one another. It was completely contrary to much of what had been drilled into the Knicks under Hubie Brown, who preached constraint and control during his five seasons as the team's head coach.

title: TECHNOLOGY LEAK TO SOVIET FOUND
description: The Soviet Union has acquired equipment and technology needed to produce an advanced material that can increase the accuracy of nuclear warheads by buying the items from the Scottish subsidiary of a New Jersey company, Government officials said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Distant Fires Create Haze In New York
description: The air smelled of autumn wood smoke and leaf-burning, and the sky had an eerie quality, as it does just before an eclipse or a tornado. And for anyone who saw it go down, the sun was an oversized orange ball reminiscent of a science-fiction orb on the rim of a strange planet.

title: Rate Drop Is Viewed As Cushion
description: The sudden decline in interest rates that began when stock prices plunged on Oct. 19 has been large enough to help assure many economists that turmoil in the stock market will not lead to a recession.

title: Panel Says Peace Is Advancing in Central America
description: The panel charged with verifying compliance with the Central American peace agreement said today that the accord was working.

title: SKYLINK AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. AUTO MAKERS GET A LIFT
description: When the stock market collapsed last month, American auto manufacturers braced themselves for a sharp downturn in their already sliding sales.

title: City Opera: 'Student Prince'
description: GRANTED that there is an apparently limitless audience for kitsch and that it supplies the New York City Opera with full houses and increased revenues. But if the company steadfastly avows that operettas and musical comedies have enough artistic merit to be presented alongside the standard operatic repertory, it might at least offer consistently polished performances of such works. There was a slap-dash quality to Saturday afternoon's presentation of Romberg's ''Student Prince,'' in which three new performers joined the cast.

title: Robbery Suspect Hurt Fleeing in Subway Tunnel
description: A 20-year-old robbery suspect who fled into a Times Square subway tunnel, was arrested yesterdy after he fell against the third rail and was critically burned, the police said.

title: ADAM J. CIOTH MARRIES BETH FRANCES COBERT
description: Beth Frances Cobert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Cobert of Montclair, N.J., and Adam Julian Cioth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Boguslaw B. Cioth of Rolling Hills Estates, Calif., were married yesterday at the Chanticler in Short Hills, N.J. Cantor Robert Abelson and the Rev. Salvatore Umana, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Mexican Ambivalence
description: Repeatedly over the last seven years, the Reagan Administration has expressed hopes of creating a North American common market that would link the United States and its neighbors. But in concluding a bilateral commercial accord here on Friday, Mexico and the United States showed that an enormous gap remains between that dream and current reality.

title: GENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DATAREX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Asian Markets Meeting
description: Senior officials from nine Asian markets - including those in Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan - are scheduled to hold a one-day conference here Monday. Taiwan stock exchange officials said the conference would focus on technical issues of trading stocks.

title: Sports of The Times; 'NINE YEARS IS A LONG TIME'
description: UNTIL the Giants' 17-10 victory over the Patriots last night, Jeff Rutledge had not been the starting quarterback in a game his team won for nearly nine years. Not since the 1979 Sugar Bowl when he was the University of Alabama quarterback. In his five previous starts in the National Football League, one with the Los Angeles Rams and four with the Giants, his team's record had been 0-4-1, including a 6-3 loss to the Buffalo Bills in one of the replacement games during the recent strike.

title: Hong Kong, Wary of China, Sees Its Middle Class Fleeing
description: Four decades after their parents and grandparents swarmed from revolutionary upheaval in China to the safety of Hong Kong, a wave of young Chinese professionals is again fleeing Communism, packing their bags for Canada, the United States and Australia.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Now that the Minnesota Twins and the St. Louis Cardinals have furnished the first World Series in which the home team won every game, the following thought occurs: Has there been a World Series in which the home team lost every game?

title: Crushing the Drug Dealers of Washington Square
description: The neighbors around Washington Square Park, once one of New York City's most blatant drug bazaars, now tell a story with an unusual, happy ending: Greenwich Village won, the drug dealers lost.

title: Study Says Nursing Home Costs Impoverish Many
description: The high cost of nursing home care forces many elderly patients into poverty a few months after they enter the homes, a Congressional survey reported today.

title: Pop Music: Simply Red
description: MICK HUCKNALL, the redheaded lead singer and chief songwriter of the pop group Simply Red, is one of the most emotionally intense vocalists to emerge out of the British blue-eyed soul movement. The waifish young singer from Manchester, whose hair color inspired the group's name, has a raw piercing countertenor that he pushes with a punishing urgency. When singing material that lets his voice flex and show its colors, Mr. Hucknall can be a compelling balladeer who suggests a boyish English echo of Aretha Franklin.

title: DONEGAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $118,063 and $498,971 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company was formed in August 1986 and began operations in October 1986.

title: Cowboys Cut Off At Pass by Lions
description: James Griffin's 29-yard interception return set up the 4-yard go-ahead touchdown run by Garry James as the Detroit Lions upset the Dallas Cowboys today, 27-17.

title: VM SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gottlieb Reign Alters The New Yorker
description: Nine months after taking over as editor of The New Yorker, following a tumultuous outcry by authors and editors protesting the ouster of his predecessor, Robert Gottlieb is beginning to put his stamp on one of the nation's best-known magazines.

title: AMAX GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3,721,000 and $9,178,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Startup Journal; Low Odds and High Perils of Logging
description: The men who cut down 200-year-old trees on the steep slopes of the Cascades don't go for a lot of romanticizing and myth-making about a job with an injury rate of one in three. Every logger has a horror story and a scarred forehead or a missing finger to prove it.

title: World Bank Move Faulted
description: A tribunal of the World Bank has determined that the bank's management acted improperly during a recent reorganization in which it dismissed nearly 10 percent of its staff.

title: Schools of Social Work Swamped by Applicants
description: In what some scholars are calling a return to the social activism of the 1960's and others fear is opportunism, the nation's graduate schools of social work are seeing significant increases in enrollment after nearly a decade of decline and stagnation.

title: NUCLEAR SUPPORT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dance: All-Ashton Program by the Joffrey Ballet
description: THE tenderness and wit for which Sir Frederick Ashton is justifiably famous as a choreographer were much in evidence in the all-Ashton program that the Joffrey Ballet presented Saturday night at the City Center Theater. The program also featured several dancers in roles for which they had not been previously reviewed this season.

title: Stage: Bel Canto Troupe In Pizzetti's 'Cathedral'
description: AMONG the benefits of reviving forgotten works is that the passage of time and the concurrent shifting of taste tend to cast these pieces in wholly new lights, occasionally making what had seemed worthless or uninteresting now evocative and engaging. So it appears to be with Ildebrando Pizzetti's ''Assassinio Nella Cattedrale,'' an opera that was not much admired when it received its American premiere in 1958 but that provided reasonable pleasure at its revival Saturday evening by the Bel Canto Opera, at St. Bartholomew's Church. The work, based on T. S. Eliot's ''Murder in the Cathedral,'' was presented in an English re-translation that drew heavily from the poet's original text.

title: VESTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNGERMANN-BASS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-Net loss and after a tax credit of $1,503,000.

title: Puzzling Out Foreign Profits
description: The dollar's accelerated decline against the yen last week foreshadows bigger profits for Avon Products Inc. Japan is Avon's largest foreign market, and the stronger yen will translate into more dollars when the money is accounted for at the company's New York headquarters.

title: A TIE WITH FLYERS SATISFIES THE DEVILS
description: The Devils will be satisfied any time they can get a point on the road. They got one tonight at the Spectrum, where points have come the hardest for them over the years.

title: THE GOOD LIFE IS HARDER FOR AMERICANS IN ROME
description: American expatriates who have succumbed to the charms of Rome realize that their passion for the city is subject to ups and downs. Sometimes it flames; sometimes it flickers. Right now it is burning low.

title: Mandela's Release Linked to Freed Colleague
description: The Pretoria Government said today that the release of Govan A. Mbeki Thursday was a ''trial run'' for the release of the jailed African National Congress leader, Nelson R. Mandela.

title: AMERICAN INDEMNITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title:
N.F.L.;
Defensive 'Missile' Guides Seahawks
description: LEAD: FREDD YOUNG tackles with a pure joy of hitting. He launches himself into opposing runners, a 6-foot-1-inch, 233-pound missile waiting to explode. Young, the starting left inside linebacker for the Seattle Seahawks, may not have the notoriety and megadollar contract of his teammate Brian Bosworth, but he has become the on-field leader by bruising example.

title: Poland's Foreign Debt
description: Poland said that its foreign debt had reached $36 billion and that it did not expect to come to grips with its repayment problems until the mid-1990s. The official Polish news agency quoted the deputy finance minister, Andrzej Dorosz, as saying over the weekend that Poland's continuing inability to pay the full interest due on its loans was contributing to the growth of the debt. Mr. Dorosz said that about 40 percent of the interest remained outstanding. At the end of May, Poland's debt to Western governments and commercial banks was $35 billion. Poland attributed the jump from $33.5 billion at the end of 1986 in part to the fall in value of the American dollar.

ARX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Two Plead Not Guilty In Murder-Arson Case
description: Two 13-year-old boys who are accused of setting fire to an abandoned car in a Brooklyn lot on Thursday, fatally burning a man inside, pleaded not guilty to second-degree murder and arson charges early yesterday.

title: Israel Won't Prosecute Security Unit's Agents
description: Agents of the Shin Beth security agency will not be prosecuted for lying in court about the methods they used to extract confessions from prisoners, under a series of findings adopted by the Cabinet today.

title: Jack Gilford, Malleable Mirthmaker
description: With his malleable face and gentle ways, Jack Gilford, the actor and comedian, has returned to cabaret for the first time in 30 years, and the way he talks, you would think it was an act of masochism.

title: Stage: 'Old Business,' On Father-Son Conflict
description: THE eternal battle between fathers and sons is examined in Joe Cacaci's ''Old Business,'' as Abe Fleischer, a septuagenarian real estate tycoon, reluctantly makes way for his son to become head of the family empire. In retirement in Florida, Abe keeps close watch on the son's activities and, predictably, returns to action. The conflict is multigenerational, having begun with Abe's father, who founded the firm, and presumably extending to Abe's grandson - like father like son like son.

title: Bridge: Little-Known Players Given Chance to Seek U.S. Honors
description: Players little known to fame can take the first step on a long road to national honors during the next seven weeks. Those who are not yet life masters can play in clubs in New York City and on Long Island with the possibility of advancing through local finals of the Grand National Flight B to national playoffs in Salt Lake City in July.

title: Suitor Undaunted By Pan Am Doubts
description: Fifteen years ago Steven Hoffenberg started a credit business with $2,000 in a small downtown New York office with a couple of employees. Now he is the head of a modest financial group, the Towers Financial Corporation, which is leading investors in a bid to control Pan American World Airways.

title: Advertising; With Merger, McCann Is Losing Haagen-Dazs
description: The Haagen-Dazs Company, the premium ice cream maker, is regretfully leaving McCann-Erickson as a result of the planned merger of Geers Gross Advertising into McCann. That is because Geers Gross is the ad agency for Kraft's Frusen Gladje premium ice cream. That is a conflict without a doubt.

title: Johnson and Scott Pace the Lakers
description: Magic Johnson and Byron Scott each scored 23 points and A. C. Green grabbed a career-high 18 rebounds tonight to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 101-92 victory over the Houston Rockets.

title: De Laurentiis Plans to Quit
description: Dino De Laurentiis, chairman and chief executive of the financially troubled De Laurentiis Entertainment Group, plans to resign from the company and is currently negotiating his release from a contract that pays an annual base salary of $850,000.

Sports World Specials; Tossing Them a Bone
description: Last March, when the evangelist Oral Roberts said that God might ''call me home'' if he did not reach a lofty fund-raising goal, Jerry Collins wrote him a check for $1.3 million. Animal-welfare groups suggested that Collins, a Florida dog-track operator, might have better spent some money for research and treatment of the greyhounds who race at his tracks in Sarasota and Orlando.

title: BRONCOS BEATEN BY BILLS, 21-14
description: Robb Riddick ran for a touchdown and blocked a Denver punt to set up one of two Buffalo safeties as the Bills defeated the Denver Broncos, 21-14, today.

title: Treasury Sales Limited This Week
description: Treasury auctions are limited this week to the three- and six-month bill issues sold every Monday. Except for a two-year note issue and one-year bills expected next week, government securities dealers do not expect any Treasury offerings other than short-term bills until the last half of December.

title: A BATTERED WIFE'S FIGHT, IN AND OUT OF COURT
description: ''The other day,'' said Charlotte Fedders as she sank back on the couch at her home in Potomac, Md., ''someone asked whether I would have any feeling for John Fedders if he walked into this room.''

title: Sports World Specials; New Lesson
description: It's not that there aren't plenty of perfectly good golf magazines on the market, each packed with features designed to appeal to recreational golfers and chock full of ads designed to dispose of some of their often extensive disposable income.

title: Music: Chamber Society
description: THE delicate balance of Saturday afternoon's program by the Chamber Music Society was upset by a sore throat. Dawn Upshaw, the society's visiting soprano, decided not to chance the Liszt songs she had planned, but there were the Seven Romances of Shostakovich - settings for voice, two strings and piano to poetry by Alexander Blok. Miss Upshaw sang these dark, wistfully romantic songs with a kind of eloquent caution (read also cautious eloquence), their sad beauty more implied than expressed out loud. One longed to have her healthy.

title: Deeds and Words in South Africa
description: Jail doors open slowly in South Africa. It's been nearly three years since President P.W. Botha first mooted the possibility of releasing long-jailed leaders of the African National Congress. One has now been freed, Govan Mbeki, a former president of the Congress, sentenced to life along with Nelson Mandela in 1964 on sedition charges.

title: Our Next Step In Central America
description: With the first phase of the Arias peace plan in place, the question continues to be what role the United States should play in furthering the peace process, both in the short term and in the years to come.

title: 4-Year-Old Boy Kills Mother After Finding Loaded Pistol
description: A 4-year-old boy shot and killed his mother after he found a loaded .22-caliber pistol hidden in a closet, the police said Saturday.

description: Two years ago, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Government, fresh to power and bubbling with new ideas, introduced a revered Western concept to ancient India - the weekend.

title: U.S.-Yugoslavia Talks
description: The United States Deputy Secretary of State, John C. Whitehead, arrived here on Saturday for talks on Yugoslavia's economy and measures to restructure the country's $19.5 billion foreign debt, the Tanjug News Agency reported. The agency said Mr. Whitehead was received by the Croatian leader, Ante Markovic. Mr. Whitehead was invited to Yugoslavia by the Deputy Federal Foreign Minister, Budimir Loncar, with whom he will hold talks during the next two days.

title: Advertising; The Search For Expert Spokesmen
description: THE more astute television viewers of the day are certainly aware of the increasing popularity of celebrity endorsements. But are they equally aware of the company spokesmen who fill a lot of time on local news and talk shows and whose corporate affiliation is not always apparent?

title: SENILE BOURGUIBA DESCRIBED IN TUNIS
description: Supporters and opponents of Habib Bourguiba, the ousted President, offered details today of his mental deterioration, which prompted Prime Minister Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali to depose him and appoint himself President on Saturday.

title: Toni Morrison to Teach at Princeton
description: Toni Morrison has been appointed to the Robert F. Goheen Professorship in the Humanities Council at Princeton University, effective in the spring of 1989, according to the university. She is to teach in the creative writing program and participate in such other programs as Afro-American studies, American studies and women's studies.

title: Advertising; Ayer Says U.S. Inquiry On Army Ads Is Ended
description: Louis T. Hagopian, chairman of N. W. Ayer, announced to his people Friday that the United States Attorney had closed the investigation into the agency's 20-year handling of the Army recruiting account.

title: A Dim View of Justice
description: First Bork, then Ginsburg. Not since Richard Nixon responded to the Senate's rejection of Supreme Court nominee Clement Haynsworth in 1969 by nominating the unqualified G. Harrold Carswell, has a President acted as if he held the American people in such utter contempt. Surely in the wake of the bruising Bork battle, it was incumbent upon President Reagan to offer a confirmable nominee of demonstrated judicial vision and high moral character. Instead, Mr. Reagan made good on his promise to nominate someone ''they will dislike just as much.''

title: Full Program Trading To Resume on Wall St.
description: Program trading, a sophisticated form of securities trading that critics have blamed for contributing to the stock market plunge three weeks ago, will resume today, leaving some analysts concerned about renewed volatility in stock prices.

title: Relationships; Teaching Children The Value Of Money
description: YOUR 12-year-old daughter wants a Benetton sweater just like the one (she assures you) all the other girls are wearing to class. Your 16-year-old nephew is pestering his parents for a new set of Rossignol skis. Both children know that their parents can afford the items; it does no good to suggest that they are beyond the family budget. Yet both sets of parents have second thoughts: how to justify priorities and limits where money is concerned.

title: LISA BELKIN IS MARRIED TO DR. BRUCE D. GELB
description: Lisa Beth Belkin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron D. Belkin of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Bruce David Gelb, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen G. Gelb of Westfield, N.J., and New York. Rabbi Charles Klein performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in South Merrick, L.I.

description: Jeff Rutledge finally won his first National Football League game at the age of 30 tonight. And it came just in time to keep alive the Giants' bruised playoff hopes.

title: Ulster Ordeal: The Bad Years
description: Dec. 4, 1971 - A bomb planted by Protestants kills 15 Roman Catholics in a Londonderry bar. an. 30, 1972 - In what is remembered as ''Bloody Sunday,'' 13 Catholic demonstrators are killed in Londonderry by British soldiers fearing an I.R.A. ambush. Feb. 22, 1972 - Bombs kill 7 British soldiers and civilians in Aldershot, southwest of London, in what is believed to be revenge for ''Bloody Sunday.'' May 17, 1974 - Car bombs, believed to be the work of Protestant extremists, kill 22 people in Dublin. Nov. 21, 1974 - Bombs in two pubs kill 21 people in Birmingham, England. Jan. 4, 1976 - Five Catholics are murdered in County Armagh. The following day, a reprisal ambush kills 10 Protestants workers on a bus.

title: John F. English, Political Adviser To Three Kennedys, Is Dead at 61
description: John Francis English, a national, state and Long Island Democratic leader for many years, died Saturday of liver cancer at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 61 years old and lived in Muttontown, L.I., and in Kismet on Fire Island.

title: In an Ulster City, Grief for 11 and Rage
description: With 11 of its citizens dead from a bomb blast Sunday, this town turned today to the rituals of mourning and sectarian rage that are a commonplace part of life in this tortured province For James Mullan, a tall pharmacist with a faced reddened by grief, that meant contemplating a dreadful irony. Moments after a bomb estimated at 30 pounds ripped open the community center here, he located his 10-year-old son in a thick fog of dust. The boy was terrified but alive.

title: Bank of Boston
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation, the nation's 15th-largest bank holding company, said it had agreed to buy the BankVermont Corporation in a one-for-one stock swap valued at around $60 million. The acquisition is the first under Vermont's new interstate banking law. BankVermont, based in Burlington, has assets of $667 million. Its principal subsidiaries are the Bank of Vermont, the state's second-largest bank, with 16 offices, and Oxford Bank and Trust, which has five offices in Maine. Bank of Boston, with $30.46 billion in assets, owns banks in Maine, Rhode Island, Connecticut and Massachusetts.

description: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy is a judicial conservative, but one whose style more closely resembles that of Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., the pragmatic centrist who retired from the Supreme Court in June, than that of Judge Robert H. Bork, the thundering critic of liberal judicial activism whose nomination for the vacancy was defeated last month.

title: FLORENCE SUSSMAN MARRIES HARRY GEORGE FLETCHER 3d

Judge Albert M. Rosenblatt, the chief administrative judge of the State of New York, per-formed the ceremony in his cham-bers.

Professor Nye argued that many Europeans are reluctant to rely on conventional deterrence and would therefore resist a ''triple zero'' agreement removing all nuclear weapons from Europe.

title: GAY CULTURE SEMINAR
description: A symposium on New York City gay and lesbian history and culture will be held next Tuesday at the City University Graduate Center audi-torium (lower level) at 33 West 42d Street. The symposium is sponsored by the faculty Committee for Lesbian and Gay Studies at the school and will include a lecture on ''Creating Cul-tural Legacies'' and talks on the his-tory of lesbians in Cherry Grove, Fire Island, and of relations between the state and New York City gay bars. The symposium will begin at 6 P.M. and will be followed by a social hour from 8 to 9 P.M. Admission is free.

description: An unarmed Minuteman 2 missile was destroyed because of technical problems seconds after liftoff tonight, the Air Force said. Base firefighters battled a blaze caused by the explosion, but no injuries were reported. Officials said they did not know what caused the problems.

One Killed as Trains Collide
description: Two Union Pacific freight trains have collided head-on, destroying the lead engines on both trains and killing a conductor, officials said. Six crew members were injured, some when they jumped before the crash. The collision occurred around 6:15 A.M. Sunday, about 10 miles west of Kemmerer, when a westbound train heading from Chicago to Seattle collided with an eastbound train going from Seattle to Chicago. A Union Pacific spokesman said the eastbound train might have passed a signal on the main line.

Concert: London Ensemble
description: THE arrival of the touring London Phiharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening provided an opportunity to check on the progress of Semyon Bychkov, one of the most generously praised of the world's under-40 conductors. Mr. Bychkov, who was born in Leningrad in 1952 and emigrated to the United States in 1975, is music director of the Buffalo Philharmonic and beginning in 1989 will hold the same post with the Orchestre de Paris. He has guest-conducted the Berlin Philhamonic and made at least two recordings with that orchestra. As you may gather, Mr. Bychkov is a hot property in the music business.

title: SCHMIDT AND RIPKIN STAY PUT

Schmidt agreed to a deal with Philadelphia that guarantees him $2.5 million if he plays only one year. Ripken accepted a one-year contract for $1.7 million from Baltimore.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Canadiens 3, Maple Leafs 1: Stephane Richer's ninth goal of the season proved to be the game-winner as the Canadiens defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs last night in Montreal to to extend their unbeaten streak to seven games. The Canadiens got some breathing room when Chris Nilan scored an insurance goal at 9 minutes 53 seconds of the third period.(AP) Nordiques 6, Bruins 4: Anton Stastny scored twice and Michel Goulet added a goal and three assists as the Nordiques, playing on their home ice in Quebec, defeated slumping Boston. Mike Eagles, on a penalty shot, Alan Haworth and Gaetan Duchesne also scored for the Nordiques, who won their fourth straight game and took second place in the Adams Division.(AP) Tennis Lindqvist Upset: Unseeded Barbara Potter staged the first upset of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament yesterday, employing an accurate ground attack to defeat No. 8 Catarina Lindqvist of Sweden, 6-3, 6-2. Potter, of Woodbury, Conn., stayed on the baseline and passed Lindqvist repeatedly.(AP)

Yugoslav Economic Ills
description: Yugoslavia today reported slackening industrial output, a declining currency and rising inflation as its economic crisis continues to escalate. The state press agency, Tanyug, said industrial output would fall short of a 3.6 percent target for the year, having risen 2 percent in the January to September period. It also quoted Branko Dragas, the National Bank vice governor, as saying the Yugoslav currency had fallen 140 percent this year. Mr. Dragas said the dinar's decline reflected inflation. Retail prices jumped 12 percent in October to stand 135 percent higher than a year ago.

title: Foreign Cars Up in Japan
description: Foreign car sales in Japan rose to 6,627 in October, a 34.8 percent increase from a year earlier and the 46th straight year-on-year increase, the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today. But October sales fell from a record 10,089 automobiles in September. West German-made cars, accounting for 70 percent of the October total, rose 27.3 percent from a year earlier, to 4,637. British-made cars accounted for 9.1 percent of the import market. French cars took 6.4 percent of the market in October, while Swedish cars accounted for a 5.4 percent share.

title: PIPELINE COMPANY TO CLEAN PCB SITES
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation tentatively agreed today to clean up PCB's and other toxic wastes disposed of at 89 sites in 14 states along its 10,000-mile natural gas pipeline. The cleanup will cost an estimated $400 million. Under an ''agreement in principle'' with the Environmental Protection Agency, Texas Eastern will also pay penalties and costs of $15 million for violating regulations on the disposal of PCB's, or polychlorinated biphenyls, along the pipeline.The pipeline, operated by the company's Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation subsidiary, stretches from Texas and Louisiana into the Northeast.

title: Commodore's Odd 128
description: THE Commodore 128, introduced a few years ago, is an odd bird. It is, in effect, three different computers in one box. In its first mode, it is completely compatible with the enormously popular Commodore 64 (now 64c), and you can plug all of the 64 peripherals into the 128 or run any of the thousands of programs written for the older machine. In its third mode, it is a CP/M computer, with a separate central processing unit that can run zillions of the programs written for that venerable operating system, many of them ranging down from quite reasonable in price to darned near free, and use disks formatted on other CP/M computers, KayPros and Osbornes among them. Only in its second configuration is it a Commodore 128 proper, with faster disk drives available (the latest version has one drive built in), more memory, a crisper and more professional display, improved graphics and sound and an advanced version of the BASIC language built in.

Advertising; New Breed Of Small Agencies
description: EVERY once in a long, long while, out of a client-agency relationship evolves an agency compensation plan directly related to the client's sales. But such systems of payment have never gained wide acceptance.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Is Given A 2d Toothpaste Brand
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt now has a second toothpaste assignment from S. C. Johnson & Son's Rydelle Laboratories. It is Zact, which is formulated for heavy smokers. The client is not releasing budget figures.

title: HEALTH IMAGES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $1.8 million non-cash charge relating to the exchange by an officer and director of 554,000 shares of common stock for 443,000 shares of common stock and a 10-year warrant to purchase 250,000 shares of common stock at $4.50 a share. c-Net loss

title: Peruvian Leader Finds His Charm Is Slipping
description: Having spellbound this country with his charismatic populism during most of his first two years in office, Peru's young President, Alan Garcia, is now seeing his popularity tumble amid growing disenchantment with his Government.

title: Two Bears Injured
description: Two members of the Chicago Bears' defensive unit will be lost for at least four weeks with injuries suffered in the team's victory at Green Bay on Sunday. Dan Hampton, a defensive end, injured his left knee in a pileup in the first quarter. Otis Wilson, a linebacker, injured his right knee in the fourth quarter.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Say They Will Rule On Teen-Ager Chastity Law
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a law intended to encourage chastity among unmarried teen-agers violates the Constitution by promoting religion.

title: DIAMOND CRYSTAL SALT co reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
McFarlane, Testifying at Deaver Trial, Tells of Unannounced Visit
description: Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser, testified today that Michael K. Deaver, after leaving his White House job to become a lobbyist, made an unannounced visit to Mr. McFarlane's White House office even after being told that such a visit would be improper.
