title: Shuttle Cargo Weight
description: The allowable landing weight for a space shuttle has been increased from 211,000 to 230,000 pounds, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

title: DIAGNOSTIC-RETRIEVAL SYSEMS inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said during the second quarter it was awarded new contracts valued at about $24.4 million.

title: 1,100 Held as Bangladesh Bans Protest in Capital
description: Bangladesh outlawed public demonstrations in the capital today and said more than 1,100 people had been arrested for political activities. The arrests were made to thwart a huge anti-Government protest scheduled for Tuesday.

title: Careers; Fish Farms Providing New Jobs
description: SPACE AGE farmers of the seas.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: THE GRAY FOX
description: ONCE upon a time there was a college football coach who believed, unlike many before him and after him and during him, that football should not be all war and brutality and win-at-any-cost.

title: Massive Clusters of Galaxies Defy Concepts of the Universe
description: AS Hamlet would say to an astrophysicist these days, without drawing an argument, there are more things in the heavens ''than are dreamt of in your philosophy.''

title: IDEAL BASIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Getting Out
description: The image of the savvy Congressional staff member - plugged in, knowledgeable, often better connected than his or her boss - was dealt something of a blow in a new survey by the Congressional Management Foundation.

title: SENSOR CONTROL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Austin Journal; The Home of Hormel: A Town Still Divided
description: The strike may be over. The old union local may have been replaced by a new one. And Spam may be selling better than ever. ''It's business as normal - better than normal,'' said David A. Larson, a vice president of Geo. A. Hormel & Company.

title: Q&A
description: Q.What would happen if a thermonuclear bomb exploded on the surface of the Moon? Could a large number of explosions alter the orbit of the Moon and affect our tides? A.In order to disturb the Moon's orbit of the Earth, you would have to produce and focus enough energy to overcome the force of the gravitational attraction between the two bodies. Ken Libbrecht, an assistant professor of astrophysics at the California Institute of Technology, estimated that it would take 10#10 100-megaton bombs - a million at a time 10,000 times - to perturb the moon's orbit.

title: Continental Cuts
description: The chairman of the Continental Illinois Corporation, Thomas Theobald, told securities analysts that the holding company's exit from the mass-market retail banking business would lighten its payroll by 1,100 employees, banking sources said. Continental's decision to leave the retail banking business was announced Oct. 28.

title: For Dubcek, A Brief Brush With Politics
description: Once again this week, Czechs and Slovaks were reminded that a man who retired some years ago from a petty bureaucrat's job is still among them, and memories were reawakened.

title: New York Collections: Starring Sexy Dressing
description: When it comes to inventiveness, New York designers stacked up quite well against their European counterparts this season. In the spring and summer fashion openings that began in Milan, Italy, at the beginning of October and ended here Friday, they all embraced short skirts with the same sort of gleeful abandon. They experimented with stretch fabrics with the same variable results - sometimes glorious, sometimes gauche. Collections on both sides of the Atlantic exploded in bursts of riotous colors and romantic prints.

title: NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INSURNCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Less Density Sought in Theater Area
description: A proposal that would reduce allowable density for buildings along Broadway, Seventh Avenue and more than a dozen side streets around the theater district was submitted yesterday to the New York City Planning Commission.

title: A Pre-Summit Push on Emigration
description: Rarely has there been as much harmony between an administration and an interest group as there is now between the Reagan Administration and the organizations campaigning on behalf of Soviet Jewry.

title: Conrail to Buy Locomotives
description: Conrail will buy 30 new high-horsepower locomotives from the General Electric Company for more than $36 million, the freight railroad said. The 4,000-horsepower, four-axle B40-8 locomotives will be built at General Electric's plant here and will be delivered in the second quarter of 1988, Conrail said.

title: FRESH PUSH ON BASEBALL JOBS
description: Officials of the newly formed Baseball Network met in Dallas for three hours yesterday with representatives of Commissioner Peter Ueberroth to discuss the low number of minority-group members in non-playing jobs in baseball.

title: Birth Control That Few Are Able to Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Facing A Difficult Encore
description: Kelly Hrudey remembers it as the strangest of things, which in a sense is appropriate considering it closely followed one of the longest, most amazing games.

title: IRWIN UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV Reviews; 'NAPOLEON AND JOSEPHINE,' A MINI-SERIES
description: AS the producer of the opening and closing ceremonies for the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, David L. Wolper became the country's uncontested King of Kitsch. Who will ever forget those dozens of eager pianists pounding out ''Rhapsody in Blue''? Now, Mr. Wolper secures his position even further with ''Napoleon and Josephine: A Love Story,'' a six-hour mini-series getting under way tonight at 9 on ABC and continuing tomorrow and Thursday evenings.

title: WEINGARTEN REALTY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FEDERAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Allis-Chalmers
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation said it intended to propose a Chapter 11 reorganization in which its major businesses would be sold together or individually. The diversified industrial company, which filed for protection from creditors last June, said it had retained the investment banker Lazard Freres & Company to assist it in the effort to sell the company. Allis-Chalmers said in a statement that it was likely that ''pre-Chapter 11 claims cannot be paid in full.''

title: Laurence, Charles Adds 2 McDonald's Groups
description: Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson has added two more McDonald's owner-operator groups to its client list and about $2 million in billings along with them.

title: Corrections
description: A dispatch on Friday from Port Elizabeth, South Africa, about the release of Govan Mbeki, an African National Congress leader, misstated the length of Mr. Mbeki's imprisonment.

title: Corrections
description: A Washington dispatch on Friday and a picture caption on Saturday about the Supreme Court nomination of Douglas S. Ginsburg misstated arecollection of Prof. Hal S. Scott of Harvard. Professor Scott said that he found out about Mr. Ginsburg's smoking of marijuana at a party in Cambridge, Mass., in 1978 but did not see it, and that he later confronted Mr. Ginsburg about it.

title: Zulu Chief Agrees to Meet With Freed Nationalist
description: The Zulu leader, Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, said today that he would welcome talks with Govan A. Mbeki, the newly freed African National Congress veteran, on the civil strife in Natal Province that has killed more than 170 people this year.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Tomorrow is Veterans Day, and closings vary. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Begins at 9 A.M. at 39th Street and Fifth Avenue, heads south to 24th Street and ends about noon. Parking: Alternate-side parking suspended. Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning. Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Open at 90 Church Street, 909 Third Avenue, Grand Central Terminal, 610 Fifth Avenue, and 33d Street and 8th Avenue. No deliveries, except express mail and special delivery. Banks: Option to close. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular weekday schedule. Schools: Closed. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal offices, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed; no deliveries except for express mail and special delivery. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: New Jersey Transit on regular weekday schedule; schedules of some bus routes may be adjusted. Schools: Local option. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed. No regular deliveries, except express mail and special delivery. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed.

title: DOSKOCIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $178,000 for both the quarter and 9 months and tax credits of $402,000 and $1,705,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $28,000 for the quarter and $26,000 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $617,000 and $2,930,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Reagan Says New Steps May Lead To Direct Talks With Nicaragua
description: President Reagan said today that the United States could soon hold direct talks with the Nicaraguan Government if the Sandinistas begin ''serious negotiations'' with American-backed rebels.

title: GORMAN-RUPP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WAXMAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LAWSON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WORLDCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: HEIN-WERNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Who's in Charge Here?
description: It was a funny fad that started in 1962: picture books called ''Who's In Charge Here,'' mocking political figures like Ronald Reagan with fake speech balloons on real photographs. In 1987, the title has stopped being funny. People are asking, on one issue after another, Is President Reagan truly in charge?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1987
description: International

title: Stage: 'Sophie,' Musical Drawn From Tucker
description: ''SOPHIE'' describes itself as ''being loosely based on the life of Sophie Tucker.''

title: Gore's Fears Are Eased On Issue of Marijuana
description: On his way to meet Senator Albert Gore Jr. this morning, DuBose Porter stopped by Ma Hawkins's Coffee Shop to hear what the folks were saying about the Presidential candidate, who has admitted that he smoked marijuana years ago.

title: INTERSTATE POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $6,817,000. The latest period includes a charge to bad debts from bankruptcy of a major industrial customer of $3.6 million.

title: Philadelphia School Bonds
description: The Philadelpia School District is tentatively offering $73.5 million of insured general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Palestinian Group's Captives Are Not Israelis, Israel Says
description: Israeli officials said today that the eight people reported Sunday to have been taken hostage at sea by the Palestinian guerrilla group led by Abu Nidal were not Israeli citizens.

title: HILB, ROGAL & HAMILTON reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Few Program Traders Return
description: Many money managers and individuals stayed away from the stock market yesterday out of fear of the return of computerized program trading. But, ironically, program traders did not return in full force after the New York Stock Exchange lifted its restriction on the use of its trading floor computer system for the execution of such trades.

title: Telex Extension
description: The investor Asher B. Edelman said he had extended until Nov. 20 his $65-a-share offer for the outstanding shares of the Telex Corporation. Meanwhile, the Tulsa, Okla., computer concern said it expected its pretax earnings and revenues to rise steadily from 1988 to 1993. The company said the projection had been reviewed by its board in determining to submit a $775 million recapitalization plan to shareholders if the takeover offer from Mr. Edelman were not consummated promptly. Mr. Edelman's offer had been scheduled to expire last night. On Friday, Telex dropped an appeal of a court ruling favorable to Mr. Edelman's offer, worth $876 million.

title: KDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $162,000 and a gain from disposal of discontinued operations of $6,334,000. c-After net of $156,000 for the quarter and income of $173,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: Rates Steady in Quiet Trading
description: Interest rates were little changed in very quiet trading yesterday as traders and investors waited for a budget agreement in Washington and for more data showing the effects of the stock market's decline on the economy.

title: NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company stated that 1987 was a turnaround year insofar as operating results were breakeven before the company reserved $250,000 against its partially discontinued waste collection operations.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a net writedown of $25,237,000 for oil and gas properties.

title: 2 Plead Not Guilty in Using Funds for Campaign Aides
description: A state senator from Rochester and a former state senator from Brooklyn pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they had conspired to steal thousands of dollars of public money to finance election campaigns.

title: EASCO HAND TOOLS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest third quarter and 9-month net reflect a pro forma tax expense as if Easco had been taken as a C corporation for the entire period. The company elected to be taxed as an S corporation from Jan. 1 to May 2. The company also said the latest 9-month results reflect the impact of its initial public offering of common stock and the refinancing of certain indebtedness for the period subsequent to the effective date of May 15. Year-ago 9-month figures reflect the pro forma results of the operations of Easco's predecessor, Hand Tools Group of Easco Corp., as if the acquisition took place Jan. 1, 1986, instead of its effective date, Aug. 13, 1986.

title: Savings Units' Rate Risk Seen
description: Savings and loan associations, despite a post-stock plunge reprieve from rising interest rates, face significant risk if rates begin climbing again, a Federal regulator said today.

title: Manila's Push for Common Policy On U.S. Bases Surprises Its Allies
description: An unexpected bid by Manila to forge a common Southeast Asian policy in support of American military bases in the Philippines has brought consternation to neighboring capitals, according to regional officials and private analysts meeting here to discuss Pacific security.

title: The Editorial Notebook; AIDS, in Harsh Review
description: The AIDS epidemic spread so far because initially no one took it seriously enough: Government, the media, researchers, blood banks and the gay community each found their own reasons to ignore or deny the threat. That's the compelling theme of ''And the Band Played On,'' by Randy Shilts. It's a highly readable account, full of valuable reporting and insight. But the theme, despite strong elements of truth, is a selective exercise in hindsight.

title: SECURITY TAG SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Past Marijuana Use Held Insufficient Reason to Rule Out Candidate
description: A majority of Americans say that having tried marijuana is insufficient reason to disqualify someone from serving as either President or as a Supreme Court Justice, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Corrections
description: The manuscript of an article by Theodore Friend on Oct. 26, ''Aquino's Mixed Success,'' carried the phrase ''some months before those around President Marcos murdered him [ Benigno S. Aquino Jr. ] .'' Because of an editing error, the words ''those around'' were dropped.

title: 8% Gain for Newspapers
description: Newspaper advertising increased 8 percent in August over August 1986, according to estimates by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. The figure was $2.5 billion. Retail was up 3.2 percent; classified, up 15.5 percent, and national, up 5.4 percent.

title: Food Agency Chief Wins a Bitter Vote
description: The Director General of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization was elected to a third six-year term today over the opposition of many donor nations, including the United States, Canada and Britain.

title: The Dance: Rachel List Company
description: WHEN Rachel List and Company performed Sunday night, dancers made music and musicians danced in a jolly get-together that sometimes resembled a barn dance. But instead of occurring in a barn, it took place at the Emanu-El Midtown Y. A former member of Les Grands Ballets Canadiens, Ms. List is also an expert in Appalachian clogging dances, and she based ''Crazy Quilt'' upon them. Six couples paraded and stamped to country music arranged by Michael Sansonia, Terry King and Robert Mastro and played by Mr. Sansonia, Mr. King and Tigger Benford. The women swirled their skirts; the men pretended to be riding horses. But the dance was more than horseplay, for the way Ms. List wove patterns in space made it a choreographic crazy quilt.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GRAMERCY PARK. An American Bloomsbury. By Carole Klein. 330 pages. Illustrated. Houghton Mifflin. $19.95.

title: Worlds Seeks New Capital
description: Battered by declining sales of key products, Worlds of Wonder Inc. said today that it would explore various refinancing alternatives, including a merger.

title: Our Towns; Housing Decree: Moderate Homes For Mere $149,000
description: When the full story of the Reagan Administration's housing policies is written, Glastonbury will be a prime example of what happens if no one is willing to tell a wealthy suburb it must build housing for the poor.

title: Democrats Prepare a Counteroffer To Republican Plan to Cut Deficit
description: Democratic budget negotiators from the House and Senate decided this evening to offer an alternative deficit reduction proposal Tuesday in the hope of nudging the talks, now in their third week, toward a compromise, several officials said.

title: County Bills an Estate For Aid in Depression
description: Rock County has placed a lien against a woman's estate because it says she owed $100.21 for public assistance received in the Depression.

title: BANCTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $332,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: CCX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge $19,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $126,000 and an extraordinary charge of $26,000.

title: WAJAX LIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Dr. Frederic M. Wheelock; Professor, 85
description: Dr. Frederic M. Wheelock, a retired classics professor who had taught at Brooklyn College and City College, died of a heart attack on Oct. 29 at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Kent, Conn.

title: Gift of a Great Teacher
description: TESSIE is different from the other teachers,'' a 9-year-old boy told his parents at dinner. When he was asked how she was different, he replied, ''Tessie knows how we children think.''

title: Stage: Borges Stories In 'Tango Apasionado'
description: IN his story ''The Intruder,''

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a capital gain of $3.3 million from the sale of certain assets of International Rectifier's Crydom division and the stock of the company's Crydom de Mexico subsidiary to Silicon Power Tube of Long Beach, Calif. The company's year-ago first quarter sales include a $7.3 million contribution from B.V. Diode, its former European distributor subsidiary.

title: Ballet: Cast Shifts in Joffrey 'Sacre' and 'Parade'
description: ROBERT JOFFREY has given balletgoers many reasons to be grateful, prime among them his interest in collecting ballets of other times. And the Joffrey Ballet's program of dances created for Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, presented on Sunday night at City Center, is one of our happiest windfalls.

title: Visa Teller Link
description: Visa International, the international organization of Visa card-issuing banks, said it had exercised its option to link up with Plus, the network of automatic tellers. The move means that holders of Visa cards from outside the United States will be able to use Plus machines, many of which are in this country. The decision comes on the heels of an agreement that opened the Plus network to Visa's United States card holders.

title: REFAC TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPENT CORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Fights a New Battle of Antietam
description: On Sept. 17, 1862, the cornfields and wooded ridges surrounding Antietam Creek ran with blood as the Union and Confederate armies clashed in the most savage single day of fighting in this country's history. As darkness fell, 23,000 Americans lay dead or wounded in the fields and woods.

title: Unions in Lebanon Call Off Five-Day-Old General Strike
description: Lebanon's trade unions called off a five-day-old general strike today after the Government pledged that the workers' demands would be met.

title: Senator Chiles Admits Marijuana Use in Past
description: Senator Lawton Chiles, a Florida Democrat, smoked marijuana once in private, his chief spokesman said today after the Senator's expected Republican challenger in the 1988 election, Representative Connie Mack, admitted using the drug.

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring pre-tax charge of $1.1 million from the relocation of a manufacturing operation and a reserve for possible charge related to an environmental matter. c-Includes a non-recurring gain of $2,628,000, or 46 cents a share, from the termination of the company's salaried pension plan.

title: After Decades, Inventor's Work Is Still Felt in the Laboratory
description: When Dr. Arnold O. Beckman devised a gadget in 1934 to help a colleague measure the sourness of lemon juice, he little suspected that he was founding a family of laboratory instruments that would change the course of science.

title: Cannon Settles S.E.C. Case
description: The financially troubled Cannon Group Inc. said today that it had settled a yearlong Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into the company's accounting practices without the need for further financial adjustments.

title: Paul K. Cook, 62, Ex-U.S. Official And Analyst of Soviet Hierarchy
description: Paul K. Cook, one of the country's leading specialists on the Soviet Union, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 62 years old and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: Panel Studies Third World Health Woes
description: An international commission of experts will spend the next two years developing programs to fight health problems in developing countries, the Harvard School of Public Health has announced.

title: Longer Prison Terms Are Backed in Survey
description: A new Government survey shows strong support for longer prison terms than criminals have been receiving.

title: Troopers Took Photos of Child In Abuse Case
description: Ten days before she was found near death in a coma, 6-year-old Elizabeth Steinberg was questioned and photographed by the state police on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway after a toll taker saw her with a bruised forehead, sobbing and alone in a car with her father.

title: Arab Talks: Topic Is Iran
description: The Arab summit talks that opened here Sunday could signal a turning point. For the first time since the Arab League was founded in 1944, the primary focus of such a meeting is not Palestine and Zionism, but rather Iran and Islamic revolution.

title: Charles M. Heistand; Boy Scout Executive, 90
description: Charles M. Heistand, a retired national executive of the Boy Scouts of America, died Friday at the Willow Valley Health Center in Lancaster, Pa. He was 90 years old and lived in Lancaster, where he was born.

title: In a Polish Forest, Neglect and Study
description: THE thin yellow stripes on the four towering, vaguely spiral oaks barely pierced the forest's thinning autumn foliage.

title: Don't Play a Shell Game With Social Security; Twice Taxed
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CENTRAL BANKERS CALL FOR REDUCING TRADE IMBALANCES
description: The central bankers of the major industrial nations today called on their governments to adopt budgetary policies aimed at reducing trade imbalances and stabilizing exchange rates.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Going Out Guide on Saturday about a songwriters' forum at New York University carried an outdated list of participants supplied by the organizers. Dana Suesse, one of those scheduled to participate, died Oct. 16.

title: Despite Progress, Giants Aren't in Clear
description: With a facial expression as tightly controlled as a game plan designed for Jeff Rutledge, Coach Bill Parcells conceded today that the Giants were doing some things right, he but added that they were also having ''problems in some areas.''

title: ENTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public Aug. 12. The company said results reflects signficantly smaller shipments of its machines to two customers, Southland Corp. and Circle K Corp.

title: Beneath a Street, Art Soothes
description: Times Square is many things to too many people, but one thing it is to everybody is noise. The noise comes from every direction, and it is of every kind -squealing, honking, rumbling traffic, above all, but also the murmur and babble of thousands of people, the rush of wind, the blaring of street musicians, the roar of the subway from beneath the sidewalk.

title: DAVOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss The company said its latest third quarter results were affected by one- time expenses associated with the acquisition of TBS International.

title: UTILITECH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Signoff
description: Senator Bob Dole's formal declaration of candidacy yesterday for the Republican Presidential nomination will have many ramifications, among them his departure from the Washington-based radio program ''Face-Off.''

title: V.A. Reduces Its Loan Rate
description: The Veterans Administration said today that it was lowering its maximum interest rate for federally backed home mortgages by half a percentage point, to 10.5 percent, the first rate reduction in 10 months.

title: ASPEN RIBBONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
JIM WALTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes net of $690,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $2,625,000, or 6 cents a share, for the year from reduced pension expense following adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 87 as of Sept. 1, 1986. All share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split, in the form of a 25 percent stock dividend, distributed July 12, 1987 to shareholders of record June 15, 1987.

title: PANTERA'S CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net income Latest quarter includes results for Pizza Inn Inc. acquired in July.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS PROBABLE NOMINEE IS JUDGE KENNEDY
description: The White House said today that Judge Anthony M. Kennedy would probably be nominated for a seat on the Supreme Court.

title: Judge Dismisses 3 Suits On Comex's Silver Role
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan has dismissed three lawsuits seeking some $500 million in damages from the Commodity Exchange Inc. for its role in the Hunt silver crisis.

title: FOOTE CONE & BELDING COMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUDGET RENT A CAR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NOBLE INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $94,738 and $900,730 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $195,558 and $726,951 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Harmon Is Cleared
description: The University of Iowa said yesterday that the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Big Ten Conference have cleared Kevin Harmon, the Hawkeye running back, of any wrongdoing in connection with reports that he received money from sports agents.

title: VALLEY FORGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $239,000 and $1,533,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the quarter includes a loss from discontinued operations of $7,766, and the 9 months include net from discontinued operations of $758,095. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $248,399 and $279,733 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and also includes a tax credit of $207,198 and $727,274 for the same periods, respectively.

title: Robert C. Allen; Disney Executive, 55
description: Robert C. Allen, vice president of Walt Disney World, died Sunday, apparently after a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

title: Hero of the Metropolis
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The headline of a dispatch from Oakdale, La., yesterday about the Federal Detention Center there misstated the reason for the center's expansion. The additional space will be used for aliens from countries other than Cuba who have criminal records.

title: CBS Names New Head Of Entertainment Unit
description: Earle H. (Kim) LeMasters 3d was appointed president of the CBS Entertainment division yesterday, replacing B. Donald Grant, who resigned Oct. 30.

title: BLOCKBUSTER ENTERTAINENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Year-ago results are restated to reflect acquisition of Southern Video.

title: Charles Holland, American Tenor And Emigre in Europe, Dies at 77
description: Charles Holland, an American tenor who pursued his career primarily in Europe and was rediscovered by the American avant-garde late in life, died Saturday at his home in Amsterdam. He was 77 years old.

title: ERC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $831,000 for the quarter and $1,872,000 for the 9 months.

title: Vallone Denies Urging Policy to Jail Homeless
description: The City Council majority leader, Peter F. Vallone, who said Sunday that homeless people refusing to go to shelters should be arrested and ''accommodated in a cell overnight'' for their own protection, yesterday denied that he meant to suggest jailing them.

title: Belgian Dance Festival To Open at the Kitchen
description: ''The Face, the Body and the Beast,'' a festival of Belgian avant-garde dance and performance art at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, opens Thursday with ''Face a Face,'' a program by Michele Anne De Mey, a choreographer and a member of Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker's Rosas company. It will also be presented Friday.

title: Exchange Staff Goes on Strike
description: Clerical employees at the New York Stock Exchange said they would strike today over what their union termed inadequate pension benefits.

title: Swiss and U.S. In Insider Pact
description: American and Swiss officials are scehduled to sign an agreement Tuesday giving the Americans greater access to the records of suspected insider traders who are trying to shield their transactions by taking advantage of Swiss bank secrecy laws.

title: STOCK INDEX PIT CALM IN PROGRAM TRADING
description: Trading was relatively calm in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures pit today, despite fears that the resumption of program trading would increase volatility in the financial markets.

title: PRECISION RESOURCES reports earnings for
description: b-Net income

title: Contel Sets Write-Off
description: The Contel Corporation, the big telecommunications company, said today that it would write off up to $200 million in the fourth quarter to restructure its ASC subsidiary, formerly the American Satellite Company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1987
description: International A3-17

title: WHITEHALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IDLED FARMLAND MAY RISE IN 1988
description: The Agriculture Department projects that farmers next year may come close to the record for the amount of land idled under Government programs.

title: Major Shift at ITT Raising Questions
description: Edmund M. Carpenter was perhaps the single most important person at the ITT Corporation, in the eyes of securities analysts, until last week. Mr. Carpenter, ITT's president, is credited with the turnaround in the conglomerate's performance in the past year and was considered the heir-apparent to Rand V. Araskog, the company chairman.

title: ALEX BROWN & SONS INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter includes a $1.3 million one-time charge in connection with the termination of about 50 employees and the disposition of certain assets which resulted from its decision to discontinue a project to expand its in-house data processing capacity.

title: Avery Reorganizes
description: Avery International Inc. said it planned a restructuring in 1988 that would affect about 1,000 workers, cut the revenue base by 9 percent and result in a $25 million write-off and an unspecified loss in the fourth quarter. Avery, a manufacturer of self-adhesive labels and office products based in Pasadena, Calif., said the overhaul would mean the first earnings decline in 12 years. By month's end, Avery intends to discontinue its Avery Tape and Note products and lay off about 50 workers at its plant in Rancho Cucamonga, Calif. Two other divisions will be sold. They are 20th Century Products, based in Los Angeles, and Permacel Tape of New Brunswick, N.J.

title: DIRTY LYRICS: WORSE THAN DIRTY
description: Now that Albert Gore Jr. is running for President, he'd like to cultivate the entertainment business - Los Angeles being a deep well for Democratic fund raising. But the business has come to know his wife, Tipper, as a leading critic of raunchy rock music lyrics. Such criticism is not the sort of thing that gets entertainment dollars flowing.

title: WSHINGTON TALK: Capital Ethics; After Ginsburg, Where Do the Questions Stop?
description: As the list of lawmakers and candidates who admit to having smoked marijuana grows longer, many political leaders are beginning to wonder whether this latest litmus test for personal character goes too far.

title: Stage: Pound's 'Elektra'
description: IN the early 1950's, while confined in St. Elizabeth's Hospital for the criminally insane in Washington, Ezra Pound worked on a contemporary version of Sophocles' ''Elektra.'' Until now, Pound's adaptation (written in collaboration with Rudd Fleming, a classics scholar) has been unproduced and unpublished. Carey Perloff, as artistic director of the CSC Theater, has rectified that oversight with a production starring Pamela Reed in the title role.

title: A Menu of Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPE-PRETORIA TRADE
description: European Community imports from South Africa were one-third lower in the first quarter of 1987 than in the 1986 period last year, according to community figures released today. The fall reflects trade in general, an European Community commission report said, and not just restrictions on imports of iron, steel and gold coins from South Africa, which com-munity foreign ministers agreed to September 1986. Imports from South Africa were worth about $1.7 billion in January to March this year, com-pared with about $2.5 billion in the first three months of 1986, according to the report. Exports to South Africa were only 2 percent lower, or about $1.3 billion in the first quarter of 1987.

title: STAGE II APPAREL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Court Recognizes L.I. Woman As Mother of Slain 6-Year-Old
description: A judge in Manhattan, in a ruling that ended a week-long debate over who would have the right to bury Elizabeth Steinberg, ruled early this morning that a 26-year-old Long Island woman was the natural mother and could claim the body of the child.

title: VIPONT PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Keeping Cozy
description: 1. Sweaters for Less rrA new wool sweater for $18? You'll find it at Repeat Performance, the thrift shop benefiting the New York City Opera. The blue crew-neck sweater shown here is from a collection that was donated by a Fifth Avenue store. Repeat Performance is at 220 East 23d Street. 2. Functional Ceramics This decorative porcelain honey jar costs $50 and is among a collection of ceramic pieces - including teapots and coffeepots -that can be found at Potters' Gallery, 168 Thompson Street, between Houston and Bleecker Streets. 3. Elegant Snuff Bottles This delicately painted blue and white porcelain snuff bottle, circa 1900, has a serpentine top and an ivory spoon. It costs $150 and is from a large selection that also includes glass and cinnabar snuff bottles, at the Regal Collection, 5 West 56th Street. 4. Nonmusical Jukebox It looks like an old-fashioned jukebox, but it's a night light for a teen-ager's room. Measuring eight and a half inches tall, it is made of aqua glass in a silver frame, and costs $35 at Serendipity 3, 225 East 60th Street.

title: Bertha Sperber Stein, Political Leader, 74
description: Bertha Sperber Stein, a longtime leader in Queens Democratic affairs, died last Wednesday in Long Island Jewish Medical Center from complications following a stroke. She was 74 years old and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Bridge: Some Jump Shift Responses Have Fallen From Fashion
description: An obvious bid that has become unfashionable is the direct jump shift in response to a suit opening, hinting at a slam.

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''When Mr. Ortega agreed to have indirect talks, it was an acknowledgment of the importance of the contras, and now he is attempting to take back that acknowledgment.'' - Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State or Inter-American Affairs. [ A14:3. ]

title: ACCEPTANCE INSURANCE HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $236,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $91,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $21,000 and $37,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and tax credits of $170,000 for the quarter and $720,000 for the 9 months.

title: Dow Off 22.05 on Dollar Fears
description: Stock prices eroded on Wall Street yesterday amid concern that a falling dollar would drive away foreign investors.

title: CINCINNATI MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONNECTICUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a cumulative effect from a change in accounting principles of $1,911,000.

title: ORBITING OBJECT HINTS AT OTHER PLANET SYSTEMS
description: The first strong evidence of a large object orbiting a star other than the Sun was reported yesterday by American astronomers. They said the object, hotter, brighter and more massive than Jupiter, was most likely the first discovery of a brown dwarf, one of a type of hypothesized celestial objects that are intermediate between a planet and a star.

title: 60,000 Jobs to Be Cut In Moscow Ministries
description: A national newspaper said today that 60,000 Moscow residents would be dismissed by 1990 under Mikhail S. Gorbachev's campaign to streamline government by cutting 50 percent of all ministry jobs.

title: THERMO ENVIRONMENTAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $71,000 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: Boy,3, Shot to Death; Mother's Friend Seized
description: The body of a 3-year-old boy who had been shot numerous times in the head and stomach was found early yesterday in a Brooklyn apartment where his mother and her boyfriend had been smoking crack, the police said.

title: Mikhail I. Tsarev, Actor and Director, 83
description: Mikhail I. Tsarev, a leading actor who was director of Moscow's Maly Theater for 37 years, has died at age 83, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported today.

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $285 million from the repositioning of the company's government securities portfolio. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $8,516,000 for the quarter and $14,271,000 for the 6 months; the 6 months also includes a gain of $25,711,000. d-Net income

title: Restore the Wolves to Yellowstone Park
description: To the Editor:

title: The 2 1/2 No's
description: The Chinese have taught us that not every problem in diplomacy has to be solved in a hurry.

title: Finley, Kumble, Major Law Firm, Facing Revamping or Dissolution
description: The nation's fourth-largest law firm, Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Underberg, Manley, Myerson & Casey, long rocked by internal rivalries and increasingly concerned about mounting debts, is about to undergo a dramatic reorganization, if not a total dissolution, according to lawyers in the firm.

title: Shift in Public Assistance Urged At a Meeting on Minority Children
description: Government officials and scholars, discussing the plight of the state's black and Hispanic children, called today for changing the emphasis of public assistance to focus more on neighborhoods than individuals.

title: Stark Hesseltine Dies; Was Theatrical Agent
description: Stark Hesseltine, a theatrical agent who represented some well-known actors and actresses in his career, died of an AIDS-related illness last Wednesday at New York University Medical Center. He was 58 years old and a resident of Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.

title: CF&I STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $63,000 and $2,842,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Pop Culture Embraces Hispanic Images
description: LEAD: HISPANIC stars and themes, symbolized by the well-publicized success of the film ''La Bamba,'' appear to be permeating American popular culture as never before.

title: DISC TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said it recorded certain non-recurring charges totaling about $1 million re-evaluation of certain inventory and reserves related to equipment that will not be transferred when the company relocates its manufacturing operations.

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $1.2 million writeoff from project costs for the Space Works, a multimedia presentation previously under development. c-Net income and includes income of $16,000 for the quarter and $262,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations, and income of $7,876,000 from disposal of discontinued operations for both periods.

title: Jordan Leads Bulls Past Hawks, 105-95
description: Michael Jordan scored 29 points for Chicago, and the Bills took advantage of 38 percent shooting by the Atlanta Hawks for a 105-95 victory tonight.

title: MS CARRIERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Southland Buyout Hits Snag
description: The owner of the 7-Eleven chain, the Southland Corporation, said today that it could not proceed with its plan to become a private company because of the unreceptive climate for high-risk bonds.

title: MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ROCKWOOD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income c-Includes a tax credit of $1,972,000. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: HCC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Includes a loss of $39,000 from settlement of an EPA Superfund claim. c-After income of $94,000 and a loss of $8,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.

title: Dole Faults Reagan, Meese and Bush
description: Bob Dole came to the South today and chided President Reagan, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and, above all, Vice President Bush.

title: KOMAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $958,000 for the quarter and $2,095,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: A Sweepstakes for Brighter, Lighter and Cheaper Subway Cars
description: The New York City Transit Authority is readying plans for a new generation of subway cars that officials say would have wider seats and smoother rides and be brighter, lighter and substantially cheaper to run.

title: House Votes Bill to Require Simultaneous Poll Closings
description: The House, concerned that television network projections of election winners discourage voter turnout in Western states, voted 208 to 189 today to require a simultaneous poll-closing time of 9 P.M., Eastern standard time, in Presidential general elections.

title: From One Cookbook, an Expert Chef Was Made
description: WHEN Faye Levy went to France in 1976, she figured she would stay for six weeks - just long enough to take a course at La Varenne, the newly opened cooking school that had been recommended to her by Julia Child.

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances; A Reactor That Can't Melt Down?
description: MORE than a decade after the last order was placed in this country for a commercial nuclear plant, some engineers and utility analysts think it is time to start developing a second generation of reactors that would be meltdown-proof. Their hope is that these reactors would be available when the demand for power picks up and when cost or environmental impact makes fossil fuels unattractive.

title: An Arab Consensus Is Seen on Opposition to Iran
description: A meeting of Arab leaders here appears to have realigned the balance of power in the Middle East in favor of the pragmatic policies and moderate forces opposed to Iran and led by Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Arab oil producers in the Persian Gulf.

title: An Early Chance to End the Courting
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's one-week period for the early signing of basketball players begins today, offering high-school stars an opportunity to make early commitments to colleges deeply interested in tapping and refining their abilities to dribble, pass, rebound and shoot.

title: LAUREL ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $103,984 for the quarter and $404,896 for the 6 months.

title: Japan's Unusual Recovery
description: Despite the turmoil in its stock and currency markets, Japan's economy is continuing to rebound from nearly two years of sluggish growth caused by the soaring yen. But economists have begun to worry that the dollar's rapid fall against the yen in recent days could slow the robust recovery.

title: Veterans Day
description: NEW YORK Parade: Begins at 9 A.M. at 39th Street and Fifth Avenue, heads south to 24th Street and ends about noon. Parking: Alternate-side parking suspended. Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning. Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Open at 90 Church Street, 909 Third Avenue, Grand Central Terminal, 610 Fifth Avenue, and 33d Street and 8th Avenue. No deliveries, except express mail and special delivery. Banks: Option to close. Financial markets: Open. Transportation: Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular weekday schedule. Schools: Closed. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal offices, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed; no deliveries except for express mail and special delivery. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: New Jersey Transit on regular weekday schedule; schedules of some bus routes may be adjusted. Schools: Local option. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed. No regular deliveries, except express mail and special delivery. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed.

title: Harold Goldberg, United Jewish Appeal Official, 50
description: Harold Goldberg, associate executive vice chairman of the United Israel Appeal, died of cancer on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Nanuet, N.Y.

title: Art Center For Tower In Midtown
description: AFTER more than six years of planning and construction, a 32-story office tower at the northwest corner of Lexington Avenue and 57th Street, which will have an opulent marketplace for art and antiques as its centerpiece, is nearly finished. The antique center opens next week and the office space early next year.

title: ORTEGA PROPOSES TALK WITH REAGAN AND THE CONTRAS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua said today that if President Reagan agreed to receive him he would consent to the presence of rebel leaders at the meeting.

title: FOOTE MINERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,326,000 and $4,094,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and losses from disposition of discontinued operations of $3,043,000 for the quarter and $2,903,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $1,770,000 for the quarter and $1,481,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the discontinued operations and a new pension accounting method.

title: Lincoln Center Seeking Funds for New Tower
description: With a ceremonial shovel and a luncheon, Lincoln Center opened a campaign yesterday to raise money for its first new building in 20 years. Officials said $45.6 million of the estimated $85 million needed had already been promised.

title: Lest We Forget
description: They walk as if on hallowed ground. They touch the stone and speak with the dead. They come to mourn and to remember - an old ritual made new, creating in this time another timeless moment.

title: Arbitrage Role Appears Small
description: Few shares of stock were sold on Oct. 19 by firms using computers to shift investments between stocks and stock index futures, a regulatory agency said today.

title: Fire, Unreported for Half-Hour, Kills 6
description: Six people, including a 23-year-old woman and her three children, were killed this morning when they were overcome by smoke from a fire that had gone unreported for 30 minutes, the authorities said.

title: INTELLICORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gore Everybody's Ox
description: After two weeks of push and shove, the pieces of a credible budget deficit-reduction deal lie scattered on the negotiating table in Washington. What White House and Congressional negotiators need to put it together is the courage not to compromise too readily and settle for too little.

title: Real Men May Use Umbrellas in Navy
description: After almost two decades of debate, the Navy has decided that its men may carry umbrellas while in uniform.

title: Impact of the Prince of Prints
description: Kenneth Tyler, the fine-art printer, remembers that a mere 30 years ago prints in this country were small, timidly black and white and mainly collected by book lovers. Now they are large, bold and done by first-rank artists, thanks in part to Mr. Tyler himself. Thinking big and in glorious color, he has worked with such talents as Robert Motherwell, Frank Stella, Roy Lichtenstein and David Hockney to extend their vivid imagery into the graphic arts. And in the process, he has helped revolutionize the look of the American print.

title: A Chorus of Cheers for Knicks' Jackson
description: Lou Carnesecca sat in the den of his Jamaica Estates home Monday night and watched Mark Jackson, the Knicks' top draft choice, make his first start as a point guard in the National Basketball Association.

title: A Magazine Insert Pioneer
description: Nowadays, with preprinted magazine inserts an expected part of the publishing business, it's hard to think of a time without them. But, according to Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, that would have been prior to 1937, the year before its client Hammermill Papers ran what is believed to be the first of the species in Banking magazine.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $4,124,000 from an excess provision for future losses of discontinued operations for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $9,633,000 from an excess provision for future losses of discontinued operations for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: First Interstate
description: First Interstate Bancorp is offering $150 million of 9 3/8 percent notes due in 1992 for 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes, rated Aa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, are not callable and yield about 1 1/8 percentage points more than Treasury issues of similar maturity.

title: Mother Sued Over Payment For Son's Liver Transplant
description: The Pittsburgh hospital where 7-year-old Ronnie DeSillers died last spring while awaiting his fourth liver transplant is now suing the boy's mother for $261,189 in unpaid bills.

title: Layoffs Are Seen At Chrysler Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to lay off more than 1,700 workers at the automaker's plant in Newark, Del., a union official said. A Chrysler spokesman in Detroit said, ''We informed the union there is a possibility. The assembly plant schedules are always in review. Nothing is etched in stone.''

title: Concern Lifts Cadbury Stake
description: The General Cinema Corporation, a company that owns both movie theaters and soft drink bottling operations, has increased its stake in Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. to 18.5 percent, from 8.3 percent.

title: About New York; Where Liberals Feel Under Siege From Homeless
description: Just about the saddest thing an old good-hearted New York liberal could imagine doing would be taking a stance against the homeless, which is what about 800 of them have done down on the Lower East Side, or the East Village, or the Bowery, depending on the cartographer who is doing the talking (the boundaries in this case are Houston to 14th Streets and Broadway to the East River).

title: KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $265,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss The latest third quarter includes a pre-tax gain of about $500,000 from the move of a division and the sale of its former building.

title: Addendum
description: Business Week magazine will raise its North America rate base 4.9 percent, to 850,000, and its ad rates 8 percent next year.

title: CENTURY PAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in September.

title: INSIDE
description: Judge Kennedy Is Checked

title: Market Plan For Mexico
description: Brokerage houses, the central bank and the Government's development bank are working on a rescue plan to stabilize the Mexican stock market, one of the world's fastest-rising trading arenas until last month's plunge, analysts said today.

title: Patty Duke Re-elected By Screen Actors Guild
description: Patty Duke has won a second two-year term as president of the 70,000-member Screen Actors Guild.

title: Refining the Art Of Fingerprinting
description: Despite the myths created by Hollywood, large police departments have traditionally had a tough time identifying suspects based on fingerprints.

title: Saudi Says Goal for Oil Is to Keep Price at $18
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister said today that his country would try to keep the price of oil at $18 a barrel, the level set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries a year ago, ''for some time to come.''

title: DAISY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After pre-tax charges of $8,300,000 incurred in the second quarter and third quarters to cover fixed asset and inventory writedowns associated with the introduction of the company's new 80386-based product line, provisions for severance and other employee benefits related to staffing changes and provisions to cover the anticipated costs of subleasing idle and excess facilities at the company's headquarters. c-Net loss

title: F.B.I. Uncovers No Problem In Check on Judge Kennedy
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation completed an exhaustive background check today on Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, the probable nominee for the Supreme Court, and reported to the White House that no significant problems had been found, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Abdel Sharkawi, 67, Egyptian Leftist Writer
description: Abdel Rahman Sharkawi, an Egyptian writer and left-wing political figure, died of a heart attack today, his 67th birthday, the Middle East News Agency said.

title: Reagan Wants Dollar to Halt Fall, But U.S. Doesn't Take Any Action
description: President Reagan said today that he did not ''want a further decline'' of the dollar, but beyond the President's remarks the Administration did nothing in the markets to stabilize it.

title: FIRST CONTINENTAL REAL ESATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income

title: HASTINGS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Votes Against U.N. Slander
description: Just 12 years ago, the United Nations adopted an ugly resolution equating Zionism with racism. Voting on the anniversary, the House joined the Senate in unanimously approving a resolution calling on the General Assembly to repudiate that resolution. Congress rightly condemned it for offending the U.N. Charter, slandering Zionism, escalating religious hatred and hampering the quest for peace in the Middle East.

title: TV Reviews; 20 Years After 'Sgt. Pepper'
description: IT really was 20 years ago -June 1, 1967, to be exact, when the Beatles released ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'' in Britain. Was it the greatest and most influential rock album ever made? ''Sgt. Pepper: It Was 20 Years Ago Today'' declares it was all that and more. The two-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, revisits a time and place. It says they were unparalleled.

title: Even Rivals Agree, Kings Sets Pace In Food Marketing
description: NEW JERSEY has spawned a number of supermarket chains but when it comes to innovation in marketing and a reputation for quality and service, Kings Super Markets, a 16-store chain, is often ahead of the pack.

title: A Choreographer's Full Life
description: There will be new works with new music and new sets on the program when the Nina Wiener Dance Company opens tonight for a week at the Brooklyn Academy of Music opera house. That is the stuff, after all, of major New York seasons.

title: Exchange Employees Begin Strike
description: Hundreds of employees went on strike at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, seeking improved pension benefits.

title: G.E. Credit Notes
description: The General Electric Credit Corporation is offering $300 million of 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1992 for 99.562 to yield 8.86 percent through underwriters led by its affiliate, Kidder, Peabody & Company. The triple-A-rated notes are not callable and yield about six-tenths of a percentage point more than five-year Treasury notes.

title: William C. Pahlmann, Decorator Known for Eclectic Designs, Dies
description: William C. Pahlmann, a leading interior decorator and the first to design model rooms for department stores, died last Friday in a hospital in Guadalajara, Mexico, where he had a home. Mr. Pahlmann, who suffered for many years from arteriosclerosis, was 86 years old.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Includes tax credits of $700,000 for the quarter and $2,031,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and includes losses on exchange of long-term debt for common stock amounting to $2,780,000 for the quarter and $4,090,000 for the 9 months.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch yesterday from Russell, Kan., about the formal Presidential declaration of Senator Bob Dole misstated his relationship to Robin Dole. She is his daughter by his first marriage.

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Latest quarter and 9-month earnings include the effect of a reduction in the quantities of silver inventories valued under the LIFO method of $1,120,000. Year-ago quarter and 9-month results are restated to reflect favorable adjustments of $1,300,000 and $3,900,000, respectively, for a change in accounting for pension costs in accordance with FASB No. 87; the effect after taxes amounted to $700,000 for the quarter and $2,100,000 for the 9 months. The company said the year-ago 9-month results also include a special after-tax charge for a doubtful account of $2,700,000. Year-ago results are restated also to reflect an after-tax gain of $1,115,000 from the sale of a building. Sales represent total sales.

title: FIRST AMFED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TRIMEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: c-Net loss

title: UNIFORCE TEMPORARY PERONNEL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago share earnings were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend, distributed May 15, 1987.

title: War Heroes, War Powers
description: The essence of battle, says the historian John Keegan, is ''the behavior of men struggling to reconcile their instinct for self-preservation, their sense of honor and the achievement of some aim over which other men are ready to kill them.'' Most Americans are never called to endure this fearful struggle. Veterans Day salutes the 28 million people for whom the call came, and honors those who died in the country's wars.

title: U.S. Indicts 7 in a Police Case
description: Seven present and former Boston police detectives have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of taking bribes in exchange for overlooking violations at certain restaurants and nightclubs, the authorities announced today.

title: The Pop Life
description: Squeeze Has a Hit The saga of Squeeze, the embattled English pop group that is appearing Friday evening at Madison Square Garden, is one rock-and-roll story in which artistic self-examination and the faith of a record company (A&M) have worked together to create an unexpectedly happy ending.

title: Hanson Unit Gains Control of Kidde
description: Hanson Industries, the American arm of Hanson Trust P.L.C., said that more than 24.3 million shares of Kidde Inc. common stock had been accepted for exchange under the offer that expired Monday.

title: Market Place; G.M.'s Allure: Hefty Dividend
description: YEARS ago, the mighty General Motors Corporation was regarded as the quality leader and low-cost producer in the automobile industry. But times have changed. Nowadays, many analysts see as G.M.'s chief attraction its hefty dividend yield of slightly more than 8.5 percent.

title: Dollar Ends the Day Higher
description: The dollar rose yesterday on supportive remarks from President Reagan.

title: Phillies' Bedrosian Cy Young Winner
description: In the closest voting in the history of the National League Cy Young Award, Steve Bedrosian of the Philadelphia Phillies won the 1987 honor yesterday and in the process became the 59th player to earn $1 million or more this year.

title: MOBAY TO ACQUIRE DENKA CHEMICAL
description: The Mobay Corporation, a subsidiary of Bayer USA Inc., said it had agreed to acquire the Denka Chemical Cor-poration of Houston. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Denka has sales of nearly $100 million and em-ploys about 400 workers.

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $600,000. c-Includes tax credits of $384,000 and $1,699,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $89,000 of equity in earnings for the quarter and $534,000 from equity in loss for the 9 months of a spun-off subsidiary.

title: Economic Scene; Europe Wants Leadership
description: AFTER the Wall Street plunge, which is still reverberating in markets around the world, Europeans are again looking to the United States for leadership to prevent the financial crisis from becoming a worldwide slump. But they are fearful that sufficiently strong leadership will not be forthcoming either in Washington or Bonn or Tokyo or in the West collectively. ''Age makes me pessimistic,'' said Pierre Uri, a builder of the Marshall Plan in France after World War II.

title: Albert Kreindler, Real Estate Lawyer, 59
description: Albert Kreindler, a real estate lawyer and former member of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He was 59 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: RAYTHEON CONTRACT
description: The Raytheon Company has re-ceived a $790.4 million military con-tract for 884 Patriot air defense guided missiles and 15 sets of ground equipment, the Army said. It said the work on the antiaircraft missiles, which will be performed at Andover, Mass., is expected to be completed by the end of 1990.

title: PANEL URGES SALE OF PUBLIC HOUSING
description: A Presidential commission is recommending that the Federal Government gradually get out of the public housing business and arrange for the sale of public housing to either tenants or private investors.

title: MEDIA PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Music: 'Salsa Meets Jazz'
description: WHEN salsa meets jazz at the Village Gate, it's usually a coming-together of disparate points of view, however sympathetic and compatible. Jazz-trained improvisers and musicians whose roots are in Latin music tend to approach phrasing, rhythm, and the organization of solos quite differently. The jazz musician plays on the chords,the structure, the thematic material. The Latin-jazz improviser plays from the clave, the underlying pattern of rhythmic organization that knits Cuban-derived pop and jazz together.

title: Three Manhattan Theaters Are Given Landmark Status
description: The inside of the Biltmore Theater and the outside of the Broadhurst Theater became New York City landmarks yesterday, bringing to 13 the number of houses in the theater district to be designated by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a headline in some copies on Saturday about a man charged with harboring illegal aliens misstated his occupation. He is an investigator for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Republican Politics; Complaints From the Right Flank Fall Squarely on the White House
description: In a city that relishes political paradox, few examples were more exquisite than the sight of Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Reagan loyalist par excellence, standing in front of television cameras Monday and railing against ''gutless wonders'' in the White House.

title: 2,000 Hippopotamuses Die In Zambia Anthrax Outbreak
description: An outbreak of anthrax has killed more than 2,000 hippopotamuses in the Luangwa Valley wildlife sanctuary in the last two weeks, the Government said today.

title: SAVANNAH FOODS & INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for 1987 include Colonial Sugars Inc., which was acquired at the end of 1986.

title: Islanders Capitalize on 3 by LaFontaine
description: There are drawbacks to making history, among them having to explain it, being required to assess it and forever being asked to relive it. For the last three days, Pat LaFontaine, microphones stuck in his face and television cameras blinding his eyes, has wanted to do nothing so much with history as make it a thing of the past.

title: Advertising; S.&S. Gets Toyota's Lexus Car
description: TO nobody's surprise, Toyota Motor Sales, U.S.A., didn't stray far from home to find an agency for Lexus, the luxury car it proposes to introduce in 1989. It chose Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, with which it has been working for 12 years as the agency for the Toyota models.

title: The Short Life of a Former Foster Child
description: For a brief time two years ago, Reggie Brown, known as Gizmo to his friends, emerged from the ranks of the anonymous young homeless to enjoy an unlikely celebrity. His tragic odyssey through the foster-care system had cast him as a plaintiff in a lawsuit that held out the promise for sweeping changes in what happens to children after they become too old for foster care.

title: Under Pressure, Agency Rescinds Dismissals
description: An independent Federal agency today rescinded the dismissal of its seven-member professional staff, saying it regretted ''any inconvenience or embarrassment which may have been caused to the commission's employees and their families.''

title: 2 More Top Aides Quit Arizona Chief's Staff
description: Two more top aides left Gov. Evan Mecham's staff Monday. One, facing extortion charges, resigned shortly after his trial date was set, and the other took a leave of absence to head the Mr. Mecham's fight against a special election to oust him from office.

title: Sports of The Times; THE MCHECTOR BACKFIELD
description: IN this strike-snarled season, the real Jets had not won a game in seven weeks, not since they stunned the New England Patriots for a 2-0 start. But in their 30-14 victory over the Seattle Seahawks on Monday night after that dreary display against the Indianapolis Colts, the real Jets reappeared. And when they returned to their locker room, Joe Walton addressed them.

title: DIBRELL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ELIE WIESEL IN PLEA TO GERMANS
description: Speaking, he said, from the ''very rostrum'' from which his death and that of his people were ''decreed and predicted,'' Elie Wiesel, chronicler of the Nazi crimes, appealed to German youths today to ''fight forgetfulness'' about their past.

title: Standard Brands Recapitalization
description: The Standard Brands Paint Company, which rejected a takeover bid last month, said it had begun a $193 million recapitalization plan that would increase the company's debt and adopted a poison-pill style shareholder rights plan to deter an unfriendly takeover.

title: PEGASUS GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Small Bank's President Looks to Foreign Cash
description: Leeds Hackett said yesterday that he realized that a collapse in the stock market and a falling dollar did not herald the best time to open a small bank aimed at helping foreigners invest in the United States.

title: Farmers vs. Banks: New Tactics on Unpaid Loans
description: Kenneth M. Leffelman, the 59-year-old head of a beleaguered family, is in the county jail, the third farmer to be jailed in this area in disputes pitting them against lenders, officials and the courts.

title: HOWELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Results for the year-ago 9 months includes a non-cash writedown of about $20 million on oil and gas properties.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day last Wednesday, about the legal hopes of Texaco Inc. in the Supreme Court, erroneously described shareholder suits related to the litigation with the Pennzoil Company. While Texaco shareholders have sued company directors for their handling of the dispute, Pennzoil shareholders have not.

title: Blues Top Slumping Flyers
description: Tony McKegney scored two goals and added an assist, leading the Blues to a 5-2 victory tonight over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Some of the Best To Miss Cup Races
description: The seven Breeders' Cup races at Hollywood Park Nov. 21 drew 106 preliminary entries yesterday, but several of the nation's very best runners were not among them.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: NASH FINCH CO reports earnings for 16wks to Oct 10
description: All share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a stock dividend paid June 12.

title: Ex-Goveror of Virginia To Seek Seat in Senate
description: Former Gov. Charles S. Robb, a Democrat, said today he would seek the United States Senate seat of Paul S. Trible Jr., a Republican who has said he would not run for re-election next year.

title: Walker Out at Least 6 Weeks
description: The Jets' victory over Seattle on Monday night, a decision that changed the team's outlook from dark to bright, was nevertheless costly. Two luminaries went down.

title: LET THEM EAT GLASTNOST, FRENCH COMMUNISTS SAY
description: In this crumbling bastion of the French Communist Party, where Marx's prophecies are being confounded, the only real hope for Communist comrades is a movement of renewal begun by Mikhail S. Gorbachev in distant Moscow.

title: Ere Virtue Ruled
description: Of the many amazing things about the latest Supreme Court fiasco, the most amazing is the revelation that there are grown-up people in the United States who have never smoked marijuana. A number of mildly notorious persons, including some of the Presidential yearners, have, in fact, seized this occasion to announce that they have never smoked marijuana.

title: Los Angeles Begins $125 Million Offering
description: Los Angeles yesterday offered its first issue of waste-water system revenue bonds, a new category of debt for the city.

title: HAKO MINUTEMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.N. Today: Nov. 11, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: GENERAL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brooklyn College Joins Conference
description: Brooklyn College will be among five charter members of a Division III league to be known as the Atlantic Collegiate Football Conference that will begin play in 1988.

title: INTERSTATE GENERAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures reflect a change in the company's fiscal year to Dec. 31 from June 30. The share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title:
FOOD & FITNESS;
To Cut Your Calories, Try a Low-Fat Sauce
description: LEAD: SAUCES can be a problem for the diet-conscious. This is not at all in keeping with their mission, which is to add flavor, visual appeal and textural interest to a dish.

title: Two Foremen Accused Of Illegal Renovation
description: Two construction foremen were arrested yesterday and accused of illegally renovating a landmark building on East 79th Street, city officials said last night.

title: 38 Arrested in Inquiry Of Hells Angels Gang
description: Thirty-eight members of the Hells Angels in five states were arrested today on charges related to drugs, weapons, explosives and conspiracy to murder members of a rival gang, the Justice Department said.

title: Griffin Puts Yanks On Trade Veto List
description: The Yankees and five other teams seeking a shortstop will receive a rude jolt when they learn that Alfredo Griffin, who has demanded a trade, has included them on a list of teams to which he will not be traded.

title: State Guidelines Try to Bring Equity To Child Support
description: IN coming months, there will be a new and potentially influential factor to deal with on the issue of child-support payments: a set of numerical formulas to spell out for courts around the nation how much money is to be allocated to children.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $19,628,000 for the quarter and $30,946,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also includes an extraordinary loss of $33,000 from early retirement of debt. c-After capital gains of $12,295,000 for the quarter and $32,875,000 for the 9 months, and extraordinary losses of $1,120,000 and $3,736,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the early retirement of debt.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; On Second Thought . . .
description: When two supporters of Governor Cuomo filed papers last month with the Federal Election Commission, establishing a draft committee in an effort to persuade the Governor to run for President, they didn't realize what they were getting into.

title: 'A Feeling of Self-Control'
description: A former smoker, a writer who has gone two and a half years without a cigarette, offered this description of her efforts to quit, in hopes that others can better appreciate what it takes. She asked not to be identified.

title: TV Reviews; 'Divided Union,' Series On Civil War, on A&E
description: IN the midst of a ''Celebration of America'' campaign, cable's Arts & Entertainment Network is presenting, beginning tonight at 9 o'clock, a five-part series entitled ''The Divided Union.'' As a co-production of A&E and Peter Batty Productions, this account of the Civil War is one of those sometimes confusing television exercises that mixes comments by historians and genuine archival photographs with ''actual re-enactments'' of battles, filmed on locations from Fort Sumter to Appomattox. A certain amount of confusion, if not downright irritation, is inevitable. Patience, however, is rewarded.

title: Reagan Would Elevate V.A. to Cabinet Level
description: President Reagan, who criticized his predecessor's creation of the Departments of Education and Energy, said today that he wanted to make the Veterans Administration a Cabinet-level department to give veterans ''the recognition they so rightly deserve.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1987
description: International A3-15

title: Shearson Reports Loss Of $70 Million in October
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had suffered after-tax losses of $70 million in October, becoming the latest securities firm to disclose the extent of its losses from the recent market turmoil.

title: Copper Producers Raise Their Prices
description: Copper producers, responding to increasingly tight supplies of the metal, raised their prices yesterday to their highest point in seven years.

title: The Vote In Assembly
description: Following is the roll-call vote today in the General Assembly on a resolution calling on the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from Afghanistan: IN FAVOR - 123 Albania Antigua & Barbuda Argentina Australia Austria Bahamas Bahrain Bangladesh Barbados Belgium Belize Butan Bolivia Botswana Brazil Britain Brunei Burma Burundi Cambodia Cameroon Canada Central Af.

title: IOWA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $7,332,000. The year-ago net from discontinued operations includes a gain of $5,898,000 on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: Kasparov Wins After Karpov Error
