description: Gary Kasparov capitalized on a blunder by Anatoly Karpov to win the 11th game yesterday and take the lead for the first time in their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain. The 24-year-old champion now has six points to his 36-year-old challenger's five.

title: Niger Head's Death Costs West Ally Against Libya
description: President Seyni Kountche of the West African country of Niger died of a brain tumor in a Paris hospital today after 13 years in office.

title: U.S. SEES RUSSIANS LAGGING ON PACT
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were concerned that Soviet negotiators were not forthcoming enough in talks aimed at wrapping up the treaty banning medium- and shorter-range arms.

title: Supreme Court Backs I.R.S. On Refusal to Disclose Data
description: A ruling by the Supreme Court today will make it easier for the Internal Revenue Service to withhold material that individuals or organizations seek under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock split paid in August.

title: IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $270,000 for the quarter and $575,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $55,000 for the quarter and $259,000 for the 9 months.

title: Deaver Jury Told of Conflict Over Reagan Visitor
description: Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, testified today that he ''hit the overhead'' when he learned that he had failed twice in 1985 to have the visit of a middle-level South Korean trade official struck from President Reagan's appointment schedule.

title: DATASOUTH COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Olympics for Coffey?
description: As Paul Coffey's holdout and suspension from the Edmonton Oilers nears the end of a second month, the National Hockey League all-star defenseman is considering an attempt to join the Canadian Olympic hockey team. ''We felt if we can't work things out with the Oilers and they won't trade him, why not play for Canada?'' said Gus Badali, Coffey's agent, who admitted that Coffey would need the approval of the Oilers.

title: Graham D. Mattison, Investment Banker, 81
description: Graham D. Mattison, a retired investment banker, died Nov. 3 at his home in Rio de Janeiro after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: HEALTH CARE PROPERTY INVESORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,348,000 and $6,911,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $22,000 for the quarter and $1,480,000 for the year.

title: B.U. Coach Dismissed
description: Steve Stetson was dismissed yesterday after three losing seasons as Boston University's football coach, effective after the team's last two games.

title: KENWIN SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
E.P.A. Plans Flexible Deadlines on Air Pollution
description: The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that the agency would propose a new plan that would set flexible deadlines for cities to meet Federal standards for ozone and other forms of air pollution.

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes an after-tax non-recurring charge of $558,000 from settlement of pending litigation.

title: NORD RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $380,000. c-Includes tax credits of $100,000 and $470,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Noon Dance

title: The Supercomputer Rivalry
description: No sooner had the Massachusetts Institute of Technology started shopping for a supercomputer earlier this year than its technical experts reached a quick conclusion: Japan's first offerings were at least as capable as America's fastest processors. Last week, after behind-the-scenes pressure from three Federal agencies and the White House for M.I.T. to eliminate the Japanese from the running, the university decided to buy nothing at all.

title: Why the Crash Is Good for Us
description: LEAD: With the benefit of a few weeks' hindsight, it is clear that the stock market crash was just the tonic the American and global economies needed.

title: DURAKON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHASE MEDICAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Poll Puts the Economy Over Military in Importance
description: Americans see economic strength as far more important than military strength in assuring United States influence in the world, a poll by a liberal research organization has concluded.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1987
description: Markets

title: Roberta Peters to Head Music-Theater Institute
description: The soprano Roberta Peters has been named chairman of the National Institute for Music Theater, an organization dedicated to raising money to help creators and artists in the fields of opera and musical theater in the United States. The institute, which was founded in 1969 by Roger L. Stevens, established the George London Grant for opera singers and the Mary Martin Prize for artists in the musical theater.

title: Hamilton S. Gregg, 63; Investment Firm Owner
description: Hamilton S. Gregg, an investment executive, died of a heart attack Thursday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan and Falls Village, Conn.

title: Westies' Informer Links Gotti to Labor Shooting
description: An informer testified yesterday that members of the Westies gang shot a union official as a favor for John Gotti, whom the authorities have called the boss of the Gambino crime family.

title: DATA SWITCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $630,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and a charge of $198,000 and a gain of $87,000, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both related to minority interest. c-Includes tax loss carryforwards of $568,000 for the quarter and $825,000 for the 9 months.

title: Jackie Vernon, 62; Comic in Television, Film and Nightclubs
description: Jackie Vernon, a television and nightclub comedian, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Hollywood. He was 62 years old.

title: LUMEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Elusive Rebels Are Spreading Fear Across Peru
description: Decorating the walls of the University of San Marcos here, revolutionary graffiti, informational bulletin boards and huge mural paintings of Mao and Marx testify to the presence of Shining Path guerrillas in Peru's oldest center of learning.

title: BLACK & DECKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net loss c-Includes extraordinary losses on early extinguishment of debt of $19 million for the quarter and $21.2 million for the year.

title: Acting Webb Chief May Be Permanent
description: Philip J. Dion, a financial executive, will probably succeed Robert K. Swanson as chairman and chief executive of the Del E. Webb Corporation when its directors convene next week, industry analysts said yesterday. The 42-year-old Mr. Dion is already serving as acting chief executive.

title: PARTY IN QUEBEC LOSES ITS LEADER
description: Barely a week after the death of Rene Levesque, the party's founder, the leader of the Parti Quebecois has been forced to resign by militants who want to revive the campaign for Quebec's independence.

title: Case Raises Questions In Homless Roundup
description: When Mayor Koch began an effort to hospitalize mentally ill homeless people against their will last month, he called it the ''single most important program'' of his administration. Instead of clarifying the issue, the case of Joyce Brown - the first person picked up under the program aimed at treating homeless people who cannot care for themselves - has sharpened the debate over how government should care for the homeless.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Three days after Ron Harper severely sprained his left ankle and chipped a small bone in his foot, the Cleveland Cavaliers learned their star guard would be out eight to 10 weeks, not the four weeks physicians originally predicted. So the Cavaliers signed 6-foot-11-inch Johnny Rogers, who was the second-round draft choice of the Sacramento Kings in 1986 and averaged 10.4 minutes and 4.2 points a game last season. . . . Tatu, the Dallas Sidekick forward who was most valuable player in the Major Indoor Soccer League last season, is out for the season after undergoing knee surgery yesterday. Tatu damaged a ligament of his right knee last Wednesday during the Sidekicks' opening game at Tacoma. . . . Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria, who has withdrawn from two Virginia Slims tennis tournaments in the United States in the last two weeks, has denied that Bulgarian officials are not allowing her freedom to travel. She said that the withdrawals came about because of her preference and visa problems. She said she planned to compete next week in the Virginia Slims tournament at Madison Square Garden. . . . The St. Louis Cardinals' owner, Bill Bidwill, has been presented with an offer aimed at trying to lure the National Football League team to the Phoenix area. Brent Brown, an Arizona State University vice president, said he had offered a proposal for lease of the school's Sun Devil Stadium in Tempe.

title: Sales to Soviet Bloc Charged
description: Representative Duncan L. Hunter, Republican of California, said today that in the last seven years, the Toshiba Company of Japan, whose subsidiary had violated export control laws by selling silent propellers to the Soviet Union, and other Japanese companies have been ''heavily involved in illegally enhancing the microelectronic capability of Warsaw Pact nations.''

title: Judge Weighs Texaco Plea
description: A Federal judge reserved decision today on whether to grant Texaco Inc.'s request to disband one of the two creditors committees in its Chapter 11 bankruptcy case.

title: FASTENAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Industrial Advertising Study by McGraw-Hill
description: McGraw-Hill has released the findings of a study on industrial advertising that should make some converts to the cause.

description: b-Net loss

title: LAWSUIT SETTLED IN TEAMSTER CASE
description: The Labor Department today announced the settlement of a lawsuit filed nearly 10 years ago against the former trustees of the principal pension fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

Airplane Owner Group Cited As Failing to Report as Lobby
description: The influential group that defends the interests of private airplane owners has failed to register as a lobby for the last eight years and maintains questionable connections with former Federal aviation officials, Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, asserted today.

U.N. Urges Soviet to Pull Forces From Afghanistan
description: The General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today for the immediate withdrawal of Soviet forces from Afghanistan, brushing aside Moscow's first concerted attempt to deflect such criticism by the United Nations.

title: Coliseum Urged To Keep Raiders
description: By a 10-1 vote, the City Council today urged the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission to use the $19.6 million it received from an antitrust lawsuit settlement with the National Football League to improve the stadium and persuade the Los Angeles Raiders to remain there.

title: Ellisville Journal; Can-Do Classic in Midwestern Town By ANDREW H. MALCOLM
description: For 59 of her 60 years Helen Myers has loved books.

title: Question on Gooden
description: Judge John P. Griffin, who placed Dwight Gooden on two years' probation last January after the pitcher pleaded no contest in an altercation with the police in Tampa, Fla., said Monday that he is concerned the results of drug tests the Mets' pitcher is taking under the supervision of major league baseball are not being sent to probation officials in Florida or New York.

title: KINNARD INVESTMENTS reports earnings for
description: b-Net loss

title: Madeline Levine, Professor, 85
description: Madeline Levine, a retired professor of early childhood education at New York University, died of Parkinson's disease Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: McDonald's Is Urged to Alter Packaging
description: New York State asked the McDonald's Corporation today to take its Big Macs, Chicken McNuggets and other foods out of Styrofoam and serve them in biodegradable materials.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Prepared or Fresh?

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; High-Flying Snow Goose
description: More than 800 paintings of North American ducks and geese were in competition yesterday in the United States Fish and Wildlife Service's annual Duck Stamp contest. The winning entry, of a lesser snow goose flying over an early morning marsh, was painted by Daniel Smith of Eden Prairie, Minn.

title: EASTGROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes gains of $895,000 and $1,550,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, on the sale of investments. c-Includes gains on the sale of investments of $49,000 for the quarter and $1,971,000 for the 9 months.

title: Soldier Killed by Jersey Trooper
description: One soldier was fatally shot and a second soldier was wounded in a fight with a state trooper who tried to arrest them for marijuana possession on the New Jersey Turnpike, the authorities said today.

title: Prince Weighs Cambodia Talks
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk is planning to travel to France this week amid reports that he may meet there before the end of the year with Cambodia's Prime Minister, a spokesman for the Prince said here today.

title: AON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After investment losses of $18,553,000 for the quarter and $11,489,000 for the 9 months. c-After investment gains of $7,654,000 and $66,642,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Allied Names President
description: As expected, the Allied Stores Corporation has appointed Robert H. Morosky, who resigned as a top official of The Limited Inc. in June, as its president and chief operating officer. Mr. Morosky, 46 years old, will join Allied on Nov. 30. The Campeau Corporation of Toronto purchased Allied Stores in December in a $3.5 billion leveraged buyout and sold most of its division. Its holdings now are the specialty retailers Brooks Brothers and Ann Taylor, along with the department stores Maas Brothers in Florida, The Bon in Seattle, Jordan Marsh in New England and Sterns in New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Maine Educational Loan Bonds
description: The Maine Educational Loan Marketing Corporation is offering $100 million of educational loan revenue bonds, with an initial seven-day yield of 5 7/8 percent, through underwriters led by Chase Capital Markets.

title: Bond Prices Decline Modestly
description: Bond prices declined modestly yesterday, as investor demand remained slack before Veterans Day.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article and a picture caption on the Washington Talk page on Tuesday, about American efforts for an easing of Soviet emigration policies, misidentified a Soviet official from the Institute of U.S.A. and Canada Studies. He was Vasily A. Vlasikhin.

title: Devils Continue Rangers' Plunge
description: Lucien Deblois called it a vicious circle, and a Ranger newcomer, Michel Petit, discerned an atmosphere of panic. John Vanbiesbrouck termed it a constant struggle, and from Alain Chevrier's vantage point, the depths of the Ranger problem over their winless streak, which last night ballooned to eight games, made for a desperate team.

title: RADIOACTIVE LEAK IDLES 400
description: Leaks of low-level radioactive water contami-nated the clothing and skin of several workers at the closed Pilgrim nuclear plant over the weekend, and the Boston Edison Company ordered a work stop-page Monday and sent about 400 em-ployees home.

title: 3 Die as Police Clash With Protesters in Bangladesh
description: At least three people were shot and killed by the police here today as thousands of rioters set fire to cars and buildings, and threw bricks and homemade bombs in an attempt to force President H. M. Ershad from office.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''If Reagan invites me to talk, I would be willing. If he wants to be joined by Secretary Shultz, by Calero or by the contra leadership, that is up to him.'' - President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua. [ A1:2. ]

title: AIDS PANEL HEAD SAYS RIFT IS OVER
description: The chairman of a Presidential commission on AIDS said today that the panel had put controversy behind it and would finish an interim report by its Dec. 7 deadline.

title: The Dance: Desrosiers Theater
description: The image's the thing for Robert Desrosiers, a Toronto-based choreographer and dancer who happily turns every stage into a hallucinatory playpen.

title: Italian Chefs Come to U.S. Bearing Regions' Bounty
description: FROM neighborhood pizza parlors to big brassy dinner clubs, Italian restaurants have been among America's favorite dining-out choices throughout much of this century. But the very words ''Italian restaurant'' have meant different things at different times to different people. The most recent change is producing some of the most interesting and exciting eating places in years.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
RESTRAINT DEVICES CHOSEN BY POLICE
description: New York City police officials, seeking to equip the department with something more powerful than a nightstick but less deadly than a gun, have chosen five devices to be used in dangerous situations.

title: Insider Purchases Soaring
description: Executives are putting their money where their mouths are. Ever since Oct. 19, the day the stock market plunged 508 points, they have been insisting that their companies are fundamentally sound. Now a survey shows that executives have been putting their own money into their companies' stock at an unprecedented rate.

title: Trump and Saudis
description: To the Editor:

title: Claire Boothe Luce Saw Herself as a Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Poles Seize Underground Leader
description: The police have arrested a fugitive leader of the opposition underground, Kornel Morawiecki, the founder of a clandestine group called Fighting Solidarity, for ''using false identity cards,'' the Government's spokesman said today.

title: Abrams Asked to Study Ex-State Official's Case
description: The Inspector General of New York State said today that he had asked Attorney General Robert Abrams to consider whether legal action was warranted against a former state insurance official who is accused of giving business to private companies controlled by his son.

title: TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss is primarily attributable to a strike at its main plant in Union, N.J., and to curtailed capital spending by customers during the periods in 1985 and 1986 which would have resulted in orders for delivery in 1987.

title: Japanese Dominate Auction Bidding
description: Japanese dealers and collectors dominated bidding last night at Christie's auction of Impressionist and modern art - purchasing paintings by Renoir, Kandinsky and Chagall at record prices for these artists and buying other major works by Monet, Miro, Rouault and Laurencin.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE super-stretch limousine, when Jennifer Dierckx de Casterle spotted it, had stopped for a light on Madison Avenue in the upper 60's. Dimly discernible through the rear smoked-glass windows was a chic-looking woman. At the wheel was a liveried chauffeur. He was impeccably clad, from cap on down. The enormous, bright pink bubble-gum balloon coming from his mouth was visible to everyone except, of course, his elegant passenger.

title: Moscow Hints At Longer Visit By Gorbachev
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev may extend his American visit next month by a few days to see more of the nation and the public, a senior Soviet official said today.

title: Why Stein Plan for Board of Estimate Is Flawed
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Wins 2d Term in Miami Runoff Vote
description: Mayor Xavier Suarez of Miami was re-elected today to a second two-year term, repulsing the comeback try of former Mayor Maurice Ferre in a runoff election.

title: From the Czars to Glasnost, A Russian Princess Endures
description: The faded photographs of the old southern Russian estate, rendered three-dimensional by an antique stereoscope, flipped soundlessly around the cylinder. Princess Yekaterina A. Meshcherskaya was taking another tour of her childhood in the time of the czars.

title: Oriole Officials Named
description: Edward Bennett Williams, the owner of the Baltimore Orioles, completed his restructuring of the team's front office yesterday. Roland Hemond was named vice president of baseball operations; Frank Robinson was named a special assistant to the owner; Doug Melvin was named director of the farm system, and Calvin Hill was named vice president for administrative personnel.

title: Car Doors Spring Open In Sudden Subway Stop
description: All the doors on one side of a 10-car subway train unaccountably sprang open yesterday when the operator slammed on the brakes to avoid striking a man on the tracks in a Manhattan station, the Transit Authority said.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: LETTER to a Friend Who Smokes:

title: IROQUOIS BRANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain from discontinued operations of $314,000. c-Net income and after gains from discontinued operations of $513,000 for the quarter and $2,137,000 for the 9 months.

title: Major Airlines Are Ranked On Delays and Other Woes
description: Under heavy pressure from Congress to do something about flight delays, the Department of Transportation today issued its first comprehensive monthly ranking of major airlines' on-time performance.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Deficit of Another Sort
description: Representative Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan, chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, mailed a solicitation letter to potential donors last week in which he admitted that the committee was ''seriously behind in our fund-raising.''

title: The Big Congressional War Powers Surrender
description: To the Editor:

title: TALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $544,000 and $358,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; a loss of $19,765,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations for both periods; restructuring costs of $5,000,000 for both periods; and for the quarter includes a tax credit of $1,330,000. c-Net income and includes income from discontinued operations of $3,577,000 and $4,045,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the quarter includes a tax credit of $306,000. Share earnings are after payment of preferred stock dividends, if any, and reflect a 5-for-4 stock split approved in April.

title: Woman Ordered Held In Special Mental Unit
description: While a state judge pondered the future of Joyce Brown, the first person hospitalized under Mayor Koch's new program, another judge yesterday denied a second homeless woman's request to be released from a psychiatric ward at Bellevue Hospital Center.

title: Boy Brings Loaded Gun to School
description: A 6-year-old boy, assigned to bring something for show and tell in his first-grade class, arrived at a Manhattan elementary school on Monday with a loaded .25-caliber semiautomatic pistol tucked in his belt, officials said yesterday.

title: First Executive Won't Issue Shares
description: The First Executive Corporation said it was dropping a plan made last month to issue 10.5 million shares at $17.15 each, or $180.1 million, to the ICH Corporation. First Executive's stock has declined sharply since the market's collapse, and closed today at $9.75, down 12.5 cents, in over-the-counter trading.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: IT was a summer night when I heard the running footsteps behind me. I ran, too, and slipped into the hallway of my building, a locked door and a pane of glass insulating me from the outside. The woman was only a few steps behind me. Her face on the other side of the glass was black with mascara mixed with tears. She said that someone had tried to rape her and that she thought he was following close behind.

title: Film: Exoticism in 'Siesta'
description: ''SIESTA'' is the kind of excitingly bad, artily experimental film that has become an endangered species, and as such it can be greeted with more warmth than would otherwise be warranted. Bad? Arty? Here is how ''Siesta'' begins: with the image of Claire (Ellen Barkin) in a skimpy red dress lying motionless in a field of dead grass. The dead grass proves to be next to an airport runway because a plane passes almost directly above her. With this, Claire breathes a deep, heaving breath and springs to life.

title: Air Force Missile Blows Up
description: Air Force officials aborted the launching of an unarmed Minuteman 2 missile, blowing it up seconds after it left its pad Monday evening. The aborted launching, which also set a brief brush fire, did not represent a major setback to the test program, but no immediate details were available on the reason for the failure.

title: NEW TALKS TODAY
description: White House and Congressional negotiators are near agreement on an outline of a plan to reduce the deficit by $25 billion to $30 billion, several officials involved in the budget talks said today.

title: Jury Seated in Cocaine Trial
description: A jury was seated today after five and a half weeks of selection for the cocaine-smuggling trial of Carlos Lehder Rivas, the reputed head of a Colombian drug ring. Federal District Judge Howell W. Melton set opening arguments for Monday, and testimony is expected to last three months. Mr. Lehder, who is 38 years old, is charged in a 1981 indictment with smuggling 3.3 tons of cocaine from Colombia to Normans Cay in the Bahamas and then to Georgia and northern Florida in 1979 and 1980.

title: SCITEX CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a realized gain of about $888,000 on the sale of the company's 50 percent investment in Contex Graphic Systems Inc. c-Net loss

title: Stocks Fall Sharply Abroad
description: The French and West German stock markets suffered some of their heaviest losses ever today as investors worried about the falling dollar and Washington's difficulties in cutting its budget deficit. [ Tokyo stock prices fell 649.70 points, or 3 percent, on Wednesday following the declines in Europe and in New York. ] The Bourse in Paris closed with a drop of 6.2 percent on the day, one of its sharpest falls of the year.

title: Notes From an Iconoclastic Wine Critic
description: IN the old days, say about five years ago, a newspaper advertisement for wine might have read something like this:

title: Manila Forms Band to Fight Rebel Groups
description: As 200 residents of the city's Tondo slum area looked on, police Maj. Romeo Maganto, with a quick twist of his forearm, flipped one of his lieutenants onto the grass outside his station house.

title: Herzog Confers With Reagan
description: President Chaim Herzog of Israel met with President Reagan and addressed a joint meeting of Congress today during the first official visit of an Israeli President to the United States.

title: Wshington Talk: Briefing; Don't Invite 'Em
description: It was unusual enough that top officials of the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua should be attending a diplomatic reception at the State Department. But the event, in honor of the Organization of American States, quickly turned undiplomatic as Adolfo Calero, a leader of the American-backed rebels who are trying to topple the Sandinistas, sought to shake hands with Victor Tinoco, the Nicaraguan Deputy Foreign Minister.

title: WINE TALK
description: THESE days, restaurants and rented halls in Manhattan bring to mind caravan stops along the ancient Silk Route between China and the West. The modern nomadic traders are vintners and their representatives, with visions of holiday sales dancing in their heads.

title: A CHEERY GIFT FOR THE PUBS
description: Breweries, bartenders and imbibers toasted a vote by the House of Commons today to scrap a provision requiring pubs in England and Wales to close for two and a half hours in the afternoon.

title: INDIANA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago per share earnings are not available because the company went public in February.

title: EXCHANGES OPEN TODAY
description: Stock and commodity exchanges in New York and Chicago will be open today, Veterans Day. In New York most leading banks will be closed, so foreign-exchange markets will be vir-tually inactie in the United States. In the credit markets, Treasury issues will not be traded, but corporate, mu-nicipal and futures issues will be.

title: THERMO INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
KEY RATES
Chip Indicator Shows Gain
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rose in October, as market conditions remained favorable for manufacturers based in the United States, Europe and Japan, a trade group reported today. The Semiconductor Industry

title: Pot, and Public Pieties
description: The Age of Aquarius dawned in the late 60's; now it's noon. As the stir over Douglas Ginsburg's marijuana smoking demonstrates, the anti-authoritarian generation born after World War II has begun to assume authority in a conservative, non-permissive era. As long as the resulting conflicts and contradictions concerned purely private foibles, society could avoid coming to grips with them. The Ginsburg case, in which several social trends conjoin, makes evasion unavoidable. It all creates a noisy clash of generational values - but it's likely quickly to recede.

title: CANADA'S ECONOMY UP
description: Canada's leading composite indicator rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in Au-gust, mainly because of manufactur-ing, after a July gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent, the Government said to-day.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Bunge Advances: Seventh-seeded Bettina Bunge of Switzerland overcame Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday in the first round of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Chicago. Savchenko's doubles partner, Natalya Zvereva, survived her first-round test by eliminating Betsy Nagelsen, 6-3, 6-2. In other first-round action, Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia eliminated Rosalyn Fairbank of San Diego, 6-1, 6-4, and Mary Joe Fernandez defeated Carol Christian, 6-1, 6-1. (AP) Mansdorf and Hlasek Gain: The $375,000 Benson and Hedges tournament at Wembley, England, opened yesterday with victories by a pair of seeded players. Amos Mansdorf of Israel, seeded No. 6, downed Tony Mmoh of Nigeria, 6-2, 7-5, while seventh-seeded Jacob Hlasek of Switzerland beat Karel Novaceo of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 6-4. Aleksandr Volof the Soviet Union defeated Peter Fleming, 6-2, 4-6, 6-2, to set up a likely second-round meeting with the tournament's top-seeded player, Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia. Another Soviet player, Andrei Chesnokov, eliminated Mikael Penfors of Sweden, 6-3, 7-5. (AP) Squash Racquets Talbott Is Upset: Mark Talbott of Marblehead, Mass., the top-ranked North American squash professional, was eliminated in the first round of the $50,000 Rolex United States Open yesterday as he lost to the No. 8-seeded player and former World Open champion, Qamar Zaman of Pakistan, 15-14, 15-4, 15-5. The No. 3-seeded player, Jahangir Khan of Pakistan, opened with a 15-13, 15-7, 15-5 victory over Stuart Hailstone of South Africa. Fourth-seeded Chris Ditmar of Australia struggled to a 15-13, 15-8, 7-15, 11-15, 17-15 victory against his countryman, Ricki Hill.

title: A Time to Recognize Women Are Veterans Too
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in some copies on Nov. 3 about foreign Communist leaders who listened to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech at the Central Committee meeting in Moscow omitted the identity of the guest shown at the right of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua. He was Gus Hall of the American Communist Party.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: American consumers last year saved $2.75 billion on their shopping bills through the use of cents-off coupons, according to the A.C. Nielsen Company, which monitors such activity.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: The share earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split issued in August.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT always amuses me that the foods I prepare with the least effort are often the most appealing to my guests. I am speaking, in particular, of fish and seafood stews. Once the ingredients are assembled, I can prepare a fish stew in 20 minutes.

title: Ford Is Penalized $325,000
description: The Ford Motor Company has paid $325,000 in penalties assessed by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration for alleged record-keeping violations at two plants. Ford paid $305,000 for ''willful violations of OSHA's record-keeping standards'' at its Hapeville, Ga., plant, and $20,000 for similar violations at its St. Louis plant, the agency said Monday. Ford, in accepting the settlement, did not admit violating the standards, the agency said.

title: Contrasting Styles in Dealing With Loss
description: Mark Breland and Michael Olajide share the dubious distinction of being hot young fighters from New York who have recently lost for the first time as professionals.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IMAGINING ARGENTINA. By Lawrence Thornton. 214 pages. Doubleday. $16.95.

IOWA SOUTHERN UTILITIES CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit from an accounting change of $2,928,178.

title: Citicorp Paper Rates Down
description: Interest rates declined at Citicorp's regular weekly commercial paper auctions yesterday. It marked the fourth straight week that rates have fallen, bringing the total decline during that period to about 1 1/4 percentage points.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $537,000 and $1,105,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes an extraordinary gain from a tax credit and gain on termination of a pension plan of $1,117,000 and $1,588,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

description: A group led by the Fort Worth financier Rob-ert M. Bass said it had met with offi-cials of the Bell & Howell Company to discuss the investment in the com-pany by the Mawell Communica-tions Corporation. The British compa-ny, headed by the publisher Robert Maxwell, has said it would seek to buy more that 50 percent of Bell & Howell, an information services com-pany based in Skokie, Ill.

DATA-DESIGN LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pre-tax gain of $9,414,000 on sale of marketable securities.

title: Baptist Fundamentalists in the South Suffer 2 Defeats in Battles for Church
description: Fundamentalists here and in North Carolina suffered defeats today at the hands of moderate Southern Baptists in a struggle for power over the nation's largest Protestant denomination.

title: Government Clears British Air Merger
description: British Airways, Britain's biggest airline, received the Government's conditional approval today to acquire British Caledonian Airways, the No. 2 carrier.

title: COMPUTER IDENTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tide Is Out for Risky Debt
description: The last month has been a tough time for the junk bond market as the drop in the stock market and fears of a recession discouraged many buyers. That anxiety culminated Tuesday in the withdrawal of a proposed $1.5 billion financing for the Southland Corporation.

title: PAGE AMERICA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest second quarter included a gain of $886,200 from the sale of assets in the latest period. The 1987 and 1986 6 months' results included gains from the sale of assets of $2,127,000 and $948,500, respectively.

INTERMARK GAMING INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $148,000 for the quarter and $268,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Stage: By Durang, 'Laughing Wild'
description: JACKIE MASON puts theatergoers in a laughing mood by reassuring them that they will get no ''theater'' in his show - just jokes, lots of them, that circumscribe the world according to the comedian at center stage. Although Christopher Durang's new comedy at Playwrights Horizons is mostly in the form of stand-up monologues and might also be titled ''The World According to Me!,'' the laughter does not come nearly so easily. Mr. Durang, as funny a writer as Mr. Mason or nearly anyone else, is determined to give us his free-associative comic riffs in the more pretentious form of A Play. The evening's actual title, ''Laughing Wild,'' is a reference to Samuel Beckett's ''Happy Days'' - and, Mr. Durang's past ribbing of Beckett notwithstanding, that is not necessarily a joke.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Mary Kay Founders Acquire New Titles
description: LEAD: Richard R. Rogers is moving up to chairman of Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc., the direct-sales cosmetics company he and his mother, Mary Kay Ash, founded in 1963.

title: SOUTHERN MINERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
They're First to Fight But Second to Sing
description: A directive that the Navy's theme song be played before the ''Marine Corps Hymn'' at all Marine ceremonies has hit a sour note with some marines.

title: Baker Seems to Be Vindicated, But the Cost Is Proving High
description: President Reagan's announcement today that he would nominate Judge Anthony M. Kennedy to the Supreme Court comes as a vindication of sorts for Howard H. Baker Jr., the beleaguered White House chief of staff. But it has been a costly vindication.

title: The Third Time, With Charm
description: President Reagan's choice of Anthony Kennedy for the Supreme Court, formally announced yesterday with pride but in an appropriately lowered voice, marks a victory for an orderly nomination and confirmation process. Mr. Reagan at last showed appreciation that, given the Constitution and political reality, he has the first word - and that the Senate has the last.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1 million from a stock sale by an affiliate for both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also includes a tax credit of $340,100. c-Includes tax credits of $59,600 and $323,600 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August.

title: Percentage of Jobless Lacking Benefits Is Highest in 30 Years
description: Almost three-quarters of the nation's jobless workers received no unemployment insurance benefits last month, the greatest percentage recorded in more than 30 years, a private research group said today.

title: LANDMARK AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Swiss Creditor Plea On Dome Rejected
description: An Alberta court has rejected a bid by Swiss creditors of Dome Petroleum Ltd. to force quick payment of $1 million (Canadian) plus interest that the company owes them. The decision by the Alberta Court of Queen's Bench not to resolve the lawsuit in summary fashion gives Dome more time to conclude its $5.2 billion acquisition, or about $3.95 billion in American dollars, by the Amoco Corporation's Amoco Canada Petroleum Company.

title: Taste Test for Giants
description: The Giants' offensive line has been scolded and scrutinized by Coach Bill Parcells. But today, as snow fell outside, the subject was ice cream.

title: Military Magistrate Confines the Private Who Fled to Russia
description: A military magistrate ruled today that an Army soldier who defected to the Soviet Union earlier this year should be detained at the Philadelphia Naval Yard.

title: Eastern Air Eliminates 3,500 Jobs
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc., in a drastic move to cut costs, said yesterday that it would lay off 3,500 employees, or 9 percent of its payroll.

title: Japan Warns U.S. on Tariffs
description: Japan warned the United States today to remove the $165 million of tariffs still imposed on its electronic goods or face a GATT dispute panel.

title: SYNERGEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $2,100. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $1,400 and $165,700 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Not Only the Budget Worries Money Managers
description: Even if the budget negotiators in Washington agree to a compromise, the stock market may only get a temporary lift from the money managers whose purchases had been such a propellant this summer.

title: METROPOLITAN FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $4,269,000. c-After an extraordinary loss of $432,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: CMS ENHANCEMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Two M.T.A. Rail Lines Plan Smoking Limits
description: The Long Island Rail Road is to announce a plan today to eliminate smoking on trains that operate on its five shortest branches. These trains constitute more than 300 of the 700 daily trips on the L.I.R.R.

title: Next We'll Need to Have Art Officially Defined
description: To the Editor:

title: A Collector of Old Buildings
description: LEAD: FOR Stephen Mack, the business of conserving early New England buildings, which he collects, restores and often moves for safekeeping to his 18th-century farm in rural Ashaway, R.I., goes beyond the care and repair of their hand-hewn timbers.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny and Western Energy Corp., Charleston, W.Va., an oil and gas exploration concern, said Anthony F. Altmann had resigned as president and a director to pursue other interests. Assuming his title of president will be John G. McMillian, chairman and chief executive of the company.

title: Svetlana Alliluyeva Allowed To Settle Once More in Britain
description: Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, has been given permission to resettle in Britain from the United States, the Home Office said today.

title: Iran Panels in Congress Seek to Retrieve Files
description: Without any real hope of success, the Congressional committees on the Iran-contra affair are taking a final stab at retrieving files that were erased from the White House computer, according to committee members and staff assistants.

Excerpts From Meeting In Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 11 (AP) -Following, in official translation, are excerpts from the final declaration issued here today at the end of the Arab summit conference:

title: Tom Manning; F.B.I. Official, 65
description: Tom Manning, who played a key role in the Federal Bureau of Investigation role in the D. B. Cooper airliner hijacking in 1971, died Tuesday. He was 65 years old.

title: TPI ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $437,000 and $495,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the quarter also includes net from discontinued operations of $575,000, and the 9 months include a loss from discontinued operations of $15,748,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $4,404,000 and $2,371,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: C.P.A. Fights Florida Soliciting Ban
description: A certified public accountant in Florida has sued the state's Board of Accountancy, seeking to overturn two laws that prohibit him from soliciting clients or quoting prices for audits.

title: DATA MEASUREMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said this years first quarter net was adversely affected by unusual expenses relating to the proposed $18.50 a share takeover bid by Kane-Miller Corp., which was rejected. These non-operating expenses reduced net by about 4 cents a share.

title: Frey Replaces Green
description: Jim Frey, who three years ago managed the Chicago Cubs to the National League East Division championship, their first title since 1945, was named the team's director of baseball operations yesterday. Frey, after spending last season as a broadcaster of Cub games, largely replaces Dallas Green, who resigned last month as president and general manager.

title: 26 Hurt as Jet From New York Hits Turbulence
description: A Pan Am jetliner hit heavy turbulence 33,000 feet over the Atlantic Ocean tonight, but landed safely in Miami after the pilot radioed that 26 people had been injured.

title: DECORATOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: NOVO INDUSTRI A/S reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The figures are translated at the Sept. 30 exchange rate of U.S. $1 equals Danish kroner 7.0625. The company said its 1987 earnings include an acquisition of A-S Ferrosan, 75 percent of which was acquired in November 1986. In July 1987, the company acquired a further 15 percent of the share capital of Ferrosan, and now owns 90 percent. Also in July 1987, the company acquired I.Q. (Bio) Ltd., a U.K. diagnostics company specializing in development and production of test kits using monoclonal antibodies. I.Q. and Novo Biolabs Ltd. have combined operations and are consolidated in the Novo results starting with the 1987 third quarter.

title: KERKHOFF INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $265,200, primarily from a tax credit. The company completed its initial public offering in October. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cairo Journal; People Not Ready to Ride in a Hole in the Ground
description: If news is made by things that seem so strange as to be anomalies, then Cairo's newly opened subway, just under three miles long and the first in all Africa and Arabia, is news. Good news, even.

title: INSIDE
description: Van Gogh's ''Irises'' was sold at Sotheby's last night for $53.9 million, a record for an artwork. Page C23. Building Collapse Kills One A 13-month-old boy died in the collapse of a Greenwich Village building, which officials said was being renovated illegally. Page B1. Modest Hopes on Trade Economists say the volume of imports is leveling off and exports are rising. But reliance on foreign oil slows the progress. Page D1.

title: Southland Stock Edges Up After Tuesday's Slide
description: Shares of the Southland Corporation edged up yesterday by $2.50, to $54, after plummeting $16.25 on Tuesday.

title: Speaker's First Year: Triumph, Turmoil
description: What a roller-coaster ride of a year this has been for the Speaker of the State Assembly, Mel Miller - jolts of sudden victory followed by sudden failure followed by sudden victory.

title: A Vast Drought Disaster Theatens Ethiopia Again
description: Ethiopia, once again crippled by drought, is on the brink of a famine that could rival the calamity that took hundreds of thousands of lives barely three years ago, relief officials and Western donors say.

title: Dollar Up in Slow Day; Trade Report Awaited
description: The dollar rose in world currency markets yesterday in light trading that dealers said was not terribly significant. Because United States banks were closed in observance of Veterans Day, almost all of the day's activity took place overseas, where there seemed to be some positive reaction to President Reagan's comment on Tuesday that the dollar did not need to decline further.

title: Cash Troubles at GATT
description: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade narrowly averted a cash crisis when Italy announced it had paid its 1987 contribution of about $2 million to the trade body, a GATT spokesman, David Woods, said today. Arthur Dunkel, Director General of the 95-nation GATT, told delegates, however, that 27 million Swiss francs, or $19.7 million, were still owed by two dozen countries and that there was enough money in the bank to pay salaries and expenses only until Dec. 14.

title: REAGAN NOMINATES ANTHONY KENNEDY TO SUPREME COURT
description: President Reagan, stung by the failure of two nominations to the Supreme Court in the last three weeks, today nominated Judge Anthony M. Kennedy and expressed the hope that he could be confirmed quickly in a spirit of bipartisan cooperation.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Mario Cuomo of New York says it's hard to be governor of a major state and run for President at the same time. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts says it's a piece of cake.

title: Santa Fe Delays Public Sale
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation, which has received two takeover offers, said today that it was postponing a plan to sell part of its oil and gas operations to the public. It cited market turmoil.

title: ICM PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Sixers Sign Robinson
description: The Philadelphia 76ers came to terms with Cliff Robinson yesterday, signing the forward to a two-year contract, said General Manager John Nash. Other terms of the contract were not disclosed. The agreement settled a dispute that kept Robinson from playing in eight exhibition games and the season opener.

title: Iran and Iraq Seem Ready to Send Officials to U.N.
description: Iran and Iraq are apparently preparing to send their Foreign Ministers here for talks with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on the Security Council's cease-fire plan for the Persian Gulf war, diplomats here say.

title: CABARET: ANDREA MARCOVICCI
description: ANDREA MARCOVICCI, the singer and actress who made her first New York nightclub appearance in 10 years on Tuesday at the Algonquin Hotel, calls herself a torch singer. To Miss Marcovicci, the term does not imply the masochism epitomized by Helen Morgan, Libby Holman or even Billie Holiday. Instead it is synonymous with a longstanding tradition of movie love song evocative of a genteel, high-styled romantic sensibility.

title: Dual Role Reported for Blood Protein
description: A discovery that may suggest a surprising and unexpected contributor to coronary heart disease was reported yesterday by scientists of Genentech Inc., a biotechnology company, and the University of Chicago.

title: Wrigley Field Journal; Night Ball Debate: Heat But (So Far) No Light
description: The sparks are flying at old Wrigley Field again, and the hubbub has nothing to do with Cubs' hitting or pitching, which even the most dutiful fans admit doesn't cause this big a stir most seasons anyway.

title: Catering to a Couch Potato's Every Need
description: The tom-toms are beating a new trend-watching message: the hot place to be this year is at home. The young and the stylish, now the professional and the tired, are spending supine evenings in front of the television. ''Couch Potatoes'' like these are rapidly gaining attention as the new ''in'' crowd, and they are inspiring a raft of novelty items.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Oct. 22 about Harry Shearer's act at Caroline's misidentified a target of Mr. Shearer's impersonations. The Los Angeles cable-television personality impersonated by Mr. Shearer in his act is Richard Blackwell.

title: Business Under Fire as Brazil Drafts Constitution
description: Brazilian private-sector organizations have started an urgent campaign to temper what they view as the nationalist and antibusiness tone of a new constitution that is being drafted here.

title: ASEA Merger Gets Approval
description: Shareholders of Switzerland's BBC Brown Boveri & Company and ASEA A.B. of Sweden approved the proposed merger of the two companies to form the world's largest electrical engineering group.

title: Corrections

description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua combined a sharp attack on the United States today with a renewal of an offer to negotiate directly with the Reagan Administration on security issues.

description: A fast-moving medley of snow, sleet and rain blustered up the East Coast yesterday, disrupting travel and social schedules, playing havoc with Veterans Day parades and sending shivering pedestrians to their closets for warmer clothes.

title: Market Place; Chip Makers Finding Favor
description: SEMICONDUCTOR stocks rank among the most prominent victims of the recent market collapse, which sliced the value of leading chip makers almost in half. But some Wall Street analysts suggest the selling has been overdone.

title: Concert: Soviet Emigre, Vladimir Feltsman
description: BECAUSEBECAUSE of the circumstances of his arrival in the United States, after spending eight years trying to emigrate from the Soviet Union, Vladimir Feltsman finds himself something more than a pianist. Like it or not, for a while he will have to bear the burden of being a political hero as well. His first public performance in this country, which took place last evening at Carnegie Hall, attracted an unusually broad spectrum of society and took on the air of a cultural happening. Nancy Reagan was scheduled to be on hand but had to cancel, presumably owing to the snow storm. However, the audience included not only pianists and other musicians of all stripes but also politicians, art critics, television celebrities, dancers and, no doubt, just plain music lovers and curiosity seekers.

title: Dollar Drop For Months Is Predicted
description: The dollar's value is likely to continue to decline for at least the next few months, many economists and participants in the foreign-exchange markets say.

title: Hallmark Cards
description: Hallmark Cards Inc., which took control of the nation's largest group of Spanish-language television stations in August, is now negotiating to buy Univision Inc., the Los Angeles-based unit of Mexico's Televisa, a report said. Univision is a television programmer that supplies its stations with Spanish-language programming. A spokeswoman for Univision said ''we're aware of the rumor,'' but declined to comment further. An official of Hallmark, based in Kansas City, Mo., also declined to confirm or deny the report, which appeared in The Los Angeles Times.

title: Bridge: Tournament Sex Bias Case Is Set for Courtroom Today
description: A bridge paradox is to come before a judge in Los Angeles today. It is the climax of a three-year effort by a Manhattan couple, Robert and Gillian Blanchard, to prevent the American Contract Bridge League from conducting gender-based events, which they claim breach California's Unruh Act, which bars discrimination based on race, sex, religion or national origin.

title: BROWN, ROBERT C & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fine Weaving That's Functional
description: TODAY Lisa Wagner, right, opens Treadles, a shop that features handwoven goods - rugs, blankets, placemats, napkins and pillows -made by 70 artisans. The idea came to her two years ago, when she took up weaving as a hobby and noted that except in museums, fine weaving was not easily available. ''Weavers tend to work in isolation,'' said Ms. Wagner, 33 years old. ''Even the best ones are not being exposed to the general market.'' To fill that void, she conceived of a store where the weavings had to be beautiful yet functional, and she spent the past year looking for artisans.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SQUEAKY, wobbly stairs aren't just a nuisance. They can be hazardous if trouble spots are allowed to worsen. Squeaks are caused by stair parts rubbing against each other. You can silence many staircase noises merely by applying powdered graphite or some other dry lubricant to reduce the friction. But stair parts shouldn't move at all, and while lubricating them may mask the symptoms, it is not a cure for the disease.

title: MONOCLONAL ANTIBODIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Power Rationed in Rumania
description: Rumania announced strict rationing of power and natural gas today as the Communist country prepared for a fourth straight winter of restrictions and hardships for its 23 million people. The Government declared a 30 percent reduction in natural gas and electricity quotas for private households until March 1. Quotas for public institutions, state-run stores, schools, theaters and other ''non-productive'' establishments were lowered by 30 percent.

title: New York City Hospitals to Stop Shackling Inmates to Their Beds
description: Prison inmates held in New York City hospitals will no longer be shackled to their beds under a change in policy announced yesterday by city correction officials.

title: With Eagles Winning, Ryan Changes His Tune
description: Buddy Ryan's meaning is often obscured by his folksy Oklahoma drawl. But he is coming across loud and clear these days as the hard-driving coach of the Eagles, whose regulars have won four straight games and who face the Giants Sunday in Philadelphia.

title: Three to Make Ready
description: LEAD: What does a stubborn President do when he fails to win Senate confirmation of his choice for the Supreme Court and then deliberately casts his next nominee in the same mold, only to fail again? Until Ronald Reagan, that double trouble had befallen only two Presidents in 100 years: Grover Cleveland, a Democrat, and Richard M.

title: Sikh Leader Slain in London
description: Two gunmen burst into a London school today and opened fire on a mixed Hindu and Sikh congregation, killing a moderate Sikh leader and wounding three others, the police said. The police were questioning two men held by members of the congregation after the incident, which occurred during a religious service in the Southall district. Witnesses said Darshan Das Vasdev, who died of head wounds, was a leader of the moderate Sikh Namadharia sect in Britain which has opposed the campaign in India for a separate Sikh homeland. Separatism supporters have reportedly carried out a number of attacks on moderate Sikhs in Britain.

title: Building Collapse Kills Baby and Traps 4 in Greenwich Village
description: A five-story building in Greenwich Village collapsed yesterday morning, trapping five residents and causing the death of one of them, a 13-month-old boy. Officials said the building had been undergoing renovation without proper construction permits and supervision.

title: TV Review; Cinemax 'Blues Session,' Program With B. B. King
description: Pay cable has been doing extremely well - for itself and its customers - by comedy and music specials. The latest example of truly first-rate entertainment comes from Home Box Office's Cinemax service. The hourlong program is called ''A Blues Session: B. B. King and Friends'' and it can be seen tonight at 11:30.

title: Europeans Disagree On U.S. Budget Cut
description: European officials and economists welcomed the news from Washington today that an announcement on reducing the budget deficit might be imminent, but they differed over whether a cut of about $25 billion would calm the turbulent financial markets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Cash Advances: Pat Cash of Australia, the Wimbledon champion, made a triumphant return to Britain yesterday with a 7-5, 7-6 victory over Jonas B. Svensson of Sweden in the first round of the $375,000 Benson and Hedges championships at Wembley, England. Ivan Lendl downed Ronald Agenor of Haiti, 6-2, 6-1, in a match interrupted for 20 minutes because of rain seeping through a hole in the roof at the arena. Miloslav Mecir of Czechoslovakia, seeded second, eliminated Kelly Evernden of New Zealand, 6-2, 6-4. (AP) Navratilova Beats Fernandez: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova, seeded first, defeated Mary Joe Fernandez, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in a second-round match at the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament. In another match, the Soviet Union's 16-year-old sensation, Natalya Zvereva, stunned fifth-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany, 6-4, 6-2. Earlier, Zina Garrison, topped Poland's Iwona Kuczynska, 7-5, 6-2.(AP) Squash Racquets Khan to Face Khan: Jansher Khan of Pakistan, the world champion, defeated Chris Robertson, the No. 5 player from Australia, 8-15, 12-15, 15-11, 15-12, 15-13, yesterday and advanced to the semifinals of the $50,000 Rolex United States Open tournament in Manhattan. The 18-year-old Jansher will meet the world's No. 1-ranked player, Jahangir Khan of Pakistan, who was beaten by Jansher in last month's world championship. Chris Dittmar of Australia also reached the semifinals, beating Quamar Zaman of Pakistan, 15-8, 15-4, 15-7. Jahangir Khan beat Phil Kenyon, England's top player, 15-2, 10-15, 15-1, 15-4, despite being given a warning by the referee for angrily banging his racquet on the backwall in the second game. The other semifinal will be between Dittmar and Ross Norman of New Zealand, last year's world champion. Norman beat Rodney Martin of Australia, 14-17, 15-6, 17-16, 15-7.(AP) Golf Lyle Leads in Hawaii: Sandy Lyle of Scotland shot a bogey-free, 7-under-par 65 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Andy Bean in the first round of the $600,000 Kapalua International. Nick Faldo of England, the British Open champion, was stranded by darkness on the 18th green with a birdie putt that could leave him tied with Bean. Faldo was the only player unable to finish. Lyle won here in 1984 with a tournament record 266. Jack Nicklaus, making a rare late-season appearance, shot a 73.(AP)

description: Activity in the credit markets was subdued yesterday because the New York cash market for Treasury securities was closed for Veterans Day.

title: Bahrain Exchange Set
description: Bahrain hopes to open its first stock exchange during the first quarter of 1988, Fawzi Behzad, stock exchange adviser at the Ministry of Commerce and Agriculture, said today. The exchange, which will replace a telephone market for local shares, was announced in August 1986 as part of a package of measures to strengthen Bahrain's economy. The only formal stock exchange now trading in the Persian Gulf region is in Kuwait.

title: Accord Near on Aid to Poorest Africa Nations
description: Major aid donors are close to agreement with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund on an emergency package of financial assistance for the poorest African countries that would probably give them more than $1 billion a year in additional aid over the next three years, according to officials involved in the negotiations.

title: New York Democrats, Lacking Signs From Cuomo, Prepare to Back Others
description: Convinced that they will receive no signals soon from Governor Cuomo, New York Democratic leaders are preparing to endorse Presidential contenders in the next six weeks. The three candidates likely to win the most support are Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Senator Paul Simon, both of Illinois.

title: Tempo Enterprises
description: The board of Tempo Enterprises Inc. tenatively approved a takeover offer from Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable television system operator. The offer provides for an exchange of TCI common stock for Tempo common stock valued at $8 a share. Tempo shareholders will be given the option of receiving $8 in cash a share for each of their shares or converting to TCI stock. Tempo's board approved the offer contingent upon a definitive merger agreement. With about 5.75 million Tempo shares outstanding, the offer is worth about $46 million. Tempo, a satellite communications company based in Tulsa, Okla. owns and manages 17 cable television systems in the Southwest with about 16,000 customers. Tele-Communications Inc., based in Denver, serves 4.2 million subscribers in 45 states.

description: Copper producers raised their prices yesterday for the second consecutive day, taking their lead from the surging prices on the world's metal exchanges.

title: Cholesterol-Altering Drug Found To Reduce Risk of Heart Attack
description: A study of a popular anti-cholesterol drug has shown for the first time that it dramatically reduces heart attacks in men with high levels of cholesterol in their blood.

title: ITT and Units Settle Fraud Suit
description: The ITT Corporation and its loan subsidiaries have agreed to settle a fraud and racketeering suit by refunding up to $2.6 million to about 50,000 Arizona borrowers and to pay additional penalties to end a potential Government case against them, officials said. The companies, accused of raising profits by packing unneeded and largely useless insurance into consumer loans, did not admit or deny guilt.

title: BIRD'S 42 LEAD 4-0 CELTICS

title: Restrained Pragmatist - Anthony McLeod Kennedy
description: SAN FRANCISCO -- In the modern world of family turmoil, the life of Judge Anthony McLeod Kennedy seems almost like a living Norman Rockwell portrait of provincial constancy and familial loyalty. He has been married to the same woman for 24 years, has sent all three of his children to his alma mater, Stanford University, and lives in the same white colonial-style house in Sacramento, behind a camelia bush and a neat row of gardenias, where he was born 51 years ago.

title: Youmans Checks Out
description: Floyd Youmans, the Montreal Expo pitcher, has left an alcohol rehabilitation center he checked into last month and has made ''great progress,'' the club's general manager, Bill Stoneman, said yesterday. ''I've spoken with him and I'm very encouraged,'' Stoneman said. ''He sounded like a totally different man.'' Youmans, 23, voluntarily checked into a center Oct. 13. He had a 9-8 record this season.

title: Dr. Abner H. Rosenthal; Phoenix House Staff Physician, 81
description: Dr. Abner H. Rosenthal, a physician who practiced family medicine in Queens for nearly 50 years before joining Phoenix House, a drug-abuse services agency, as a staff physician, died of complications Tuesday following a stroke at his home in Flushing, Queens. He was 81 years old. Dr. Rosenthal, a graduate of City College, received his medical degree from the University of Maryland in 1930. He began his general practice in 1931 with offices in Richmond Hill, Queens, and in Flushing. In World War II he was a captain in the Army medical corps.

title: Q&A
description: Q.The shingles on our house are dark and weather-beaten. We are uncertain as to how to paint them and how often to do it. Can you help? A.Assuming they are wood shingles or shakes, they should be stained or treated with a clear wood preservative. Using a paint on shingles almost always results in peeling and flaking. True stains (not the so-called heavy-bodied stains that are really opaque paints) cannot peel or flake. And because of the pigment they contain, stains provide more protection against discoloration than do clear sealers or preservatives. They need to be renewed every four to eight years, depending on how the stain weathers. Q.I want to paint the aluminum siding on my house. What is the best way to remove the powdery buildup on the surface, and is there a special type of paint I should use? A.The powdery residue can be scrubbed off with a strong detergent and water, or you can use a high-pressure washer. Several companies make a latex house paint that is designed for use on aluminum siding, but many regular latex house paints can also be used. Read the label to make sure that the paint is suitable. Where powdering is severe, a special primer or sealer may be recommended for the first coat. Q.My table leaves were stored in a damp spot and as a result they have warped. Can this be corrected -perhaps by applying a damp covering and putting weights on top? A.In some cases this technique works, but usually mild heat is also required. Lay the leaves on a stack of wet towels or burlap near a source of mild heat (a radiator or wood stove) with the concave side facing up. Then apply weights on each end. This usually requires several days and the towels will have to be remoistened periodically.

Van Gogh's 'Irises' Sells for $53.9 Million
description: Van Gogh's glowing ''Irises'' -painted in 1889 during the artist's first week at the asylum at St.-Remy - was sold at Sotheby's in New York last night for $53.9 million, the highest price ever paid for an artwork at auction. The sale of 100 artworks, in which 75 were sold, totaled $110 million, a record total for an art auction.

title: Transplant Patient Alert
description: The 3-year-old girl who received five organs in a transplant operation Nov. 1, was reported awake, alert and resting comfortably today after undergoing further surgery this week. Tabatha Foster, of Madisonville, Ky., remained in critical but stable condition at Children's Hospital, s spokesman said. The transplant surgery was performed to correct short gut syndrome, a fatal congenital deformation of the intestines.

Hogeboom to Start
description: Coach Ron Meyer of the Indianapolis Colts said yesterday that Gary Hogeboom would start at quarterback for the first time in four weeks when the Colts play the Dolphins in Miami on Sunday. Hogeboom suffered a broken rib and a punctured lung in a game against the Jets during the National Football League strike and has since been replaced by Jack Trudeau. . . . Mike Junkin, a linebacker who was the Cleveland Browns' No. 1 draft choice this year, will miss the rest of the season because of a broken wrist

title: 3 Banks in West Fail
description: Three banks in the Western United States have failed, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today, bringing the year's total to 159. The F.D.I.C. said it was seeking to arrange a takeover for the Middle Park Bank of Granby, Colo., and its affiliate, the Bank of Winter Park in Winter Park, Colo., which had assets of $35.4 million and $25.9 million, respectively. The Tri-State National Bank of Belle Fourche, S.D., an agricultural bank with assets of $10.8 million, was transferred to the First Western Bank in Sturgis, S.D., in an insured deposit transfer, the F.D.I.C. said.

title: Air Cleanup: Clash of Aims; Help for One Region May Harm Another
description: For environmental and public health groups seeking to strengthen the Clean Air Act, this seemed to be the year to do it. It has been 10 years since the last major revisions were made in the antigress seemed to have several compelling reasons for making changes this year. The first is a Dec. 31 deadline by which cities must lower smog and carbon monoxide to levels deemed necessary to protect human health, as prescribed in the current law. As many as 60 of the cities may not meet the deadline, and many of them could face damaging economic sanctions unless the law is changed to extend the deadline.

The Detroit Free Press said the nation's largest auto maker would close the $600 million plant for three weeks as workers begin converting it for production of 1989 Buick Riviera and Oldsmobile Toronado models.

title: A.T.&T. Expansion
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it plans to spend about $3 billion next year and a similar amount in 1989 to expand its long-distance telephone network. The amount represents a $1 billion increase over two years from the $2.5 billion A.T.&T. announced last January that it would spend annually in 1988 and 1989. The announcement was made today by A.T.&T.'s chairman, James E. Olson, at the opening of the company's new network control center here. Mr. Olson said that the company had stepped up its plans to expand its network because of the increase in the number of long-distance telephone calls and demand for digital business services, which allow companies to send voice and data message.

This week the massive 19th-century brick structure is helping preview audiences in the more blithe task of suspending disbelief: Ten rooms on three floors of the south wing have been transformed into the interiors of an Italian villa, the set for the play ''Tamara,'' by John Krizanc, which is to open Dec. 2.

description: First comes the snow; then, instantly comes the salt. In a typical winter, highway departments spread about 10 million tons of it to keep roads safe and dry. Homeowners spread more on driveways and sidewalks. The corrosive effects are well known but for years they've been dismissed with the argument that at $25 per ton, salt is far cheaper than any alternative.

description: Predicting 110,000 New Yorkers will be suffering from AIDS or AIDS-related complex by 1991, a mayoral panel has prepared a series of proposals to prevent the spread of the epidemic and to provide care and other services to the infected.

title: PORTAGE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Man in the News; Restrained Pragmatist Anthony M. Kennedy
description: In the modern world of family turmoil, the life of Judge Anthony McLeod Kennedy seems almost like a living Norman Rockwell portrait of provincial constancy and familial loyalty. He has been married to the same woman for 24 years, has sent all three of his children to his alma mater, Stanford University, and lives in the same white colonial-style house in Sacramento, behind a camelia bush and a neat row of gardenias, where he was born 51 years ago.

title: Mets Trade Blocker
description: The Mets traded Terry Blocker, a minor-league outfielder, to the Atlanta Braves yesterday for a player to be named. Blocker, 27 years old, was the Mets' No. 1 selection in the June 1981 draft. Last season, playing at Tidewater of the International League, he he was among the league leaders in average (.312, tied for third), hits (164, tied for second), steals (33, tied for fifth), and runs (89, third). Blocker's only major-league experience came in 1985, when he was 1 for 15 in 18 games for the Mets.

title: Lucas Joins Blazers
description: To bolster a front line that was weakened by the loss of Sam Bowie, the 7-foot-1-inch center who suffered a broken leg in the exhibition season, the Portland Trail Blazers yesterday obtained Maurice Lucas. The 6-9 Lucas was acquired from the Seattle SuperSonics for a second-round pick in the 1990 draft. Lucas, 35 years old, averaged 7.9 points and 4.9 rebounds in 63 games for Seattle last season. In 1977, he helped the Blazers win the National Basketball Association title.

title: Cadbury Objection
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. said it would reject any request for management involvement from the General Cinema Corporation, a United States company that has more than doubled its stake in the British candy and beverage maker. As yet, it has received no approach from General Cinema, Cadbury said, but it described the share purchase as a highly opportunistic move by an American corporation with a market capitalization little more than half of Cadbury's. General Cinema, a leading theater operator and soft-drink bottler, said Tuesday that it had lifted its stake in Cadbury to 18.5 percent, from 8.5.

This is presumably good for morale, good for the budget (since members usually cost less than high-profile virtuosos) and maybe even good for the audience, since the musicians are often excellent and the orchestra's esprit de corps is theoretically reinforced.

title: Book Awards Are Pondered
description: Although the literary and publishing communities have had two days to recover from the surprise of seeing ''Paco's Story'' win the 1987 National Book Award for fiction, they continue to express astonishment that the novel by Larry Heinemann beat the widely celebrated and praised novels by Toni Morrison and Philip Roth.

title: Mexico Talks With Canada
description: Mexico and Canada may negotiate a new trade agreement similar to the one that Mexico just signed with the United States, legislators from both countries said today. Speaking at talks that began here on Tuesday, the legislators said that existing bilateral trade arrangements should be extended.

title: 2 More Hopefuls Take Loans
description: Two more Democratic Presidential hopefuls, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator Paul Simon of Illinois, are borrowing money from banks to finance their campaigns, aides said today.

title: Cabinet Divided on Japan Bids
description: President Reagan's Cabinet is deeply divided over whether the United States should press Japan to permit foreign participation in $62 billion worth of Japanese public works projects, Congressional and Administration officials said today.

title: Aggressive, At Least for A Flower
description: Though the Payson van Gogh does not rank among the greatest paintings of its period in France, it is a very beautiful picture. A dense, up-front horizonless image in which every stroke tells, ''Irises'' has a confrontational quality.

title: AIDE WHO ASSAILED GORBACHEV'S PACE OUSTED IN MOSCOW
description: Boris N. Yeltsin was removed today as head of the Moscow Communist Party organization in the first public dismissal of a senior official who had been promoted by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Critic's Notebook; Bottom-Line Economics and the Burial of Opera
description: THE Metropolitan Opera faces its precarious independence with such resourcefulness that one winces a little at all the criticism it's been getting this year. While the Met earns - has to earn - 70 percent of its income, the box office of the Teatro Communale in Florence earns about 5 percent. Eighty-five percent of Florence's opera money comes from the ''Man in Rome.'' From its Federal Government, the Met gets only 2 percent.

title: MATHIAS RUST'S PLANE TO TOUR
description: The plane that Mathias Rust landed near Red Square in Moscow has been brought to Paris by the author Paul-Loup Sulitzer, who plans to take it on a tour of France and the United States, a Frenh maga-zine said today. ''For me this plane is a symbol of a feat of peace and free-dom,'' Mr. Sulitzer was quoted as hav-ing told the magazine, Paris-Match. He said he hoped the tour would generate support for the young pilot from Ham-burg, West Germany, who is serving a four-year sentence in a Soviet jail.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The experience of the last several months has made all of us a bit wiser,'' - President Reagan,

title: The Dance: Chinese Performers
description: WHEN the curtain rose Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater and performers stepped smartly onstage to a peppy tune, one could almost have been watching a circus parade or the opening ensemble of a television variety show. Instead, this was the start of a program called ''Chinese Festival of Song and Dance,'' and its participants constituted the first performing-arts group from China to visit the United States under the terms of a new cultural-exchange agreement between the two countries.
