Iran Announcement: Offensive Is Due
description: The Teheran radio said today that Iran was preparing to mobilize troops for a major new offensive against Iraq, and American and Iraqi officials here said they believed it would begin soon.

title: A LITERATE NIGHT OF DINING AND LIONIZING
description: Garrison Keillor is currently reading Roy Blount Jr.'s book ''Webster's Ark'' and Lillian Ross's ''Reporting.'' But, like the other 250 or so literate people attending the seventh annual Literary Lions dinner at the New York Public Library on Wednesday night, Mr. Keillor spent this particular evening engaged in a far more active pursuit: reading the crowd.

title: ISS INTERNATIONAL SERVICE SYSTEMS (DANISH, CO)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: ISS said the latest quarter's revenue increase was mainly because of the December 1986 acquisition of the service contracts of Macke Building Services Inc.

title: The Guggenheim Collection Celebrates Itself and Its Art
description: HARDLY since the Diamond Jubilee of Queen Victoria in 1897 has an anniversary been as thoroughly celebrated as the 50th birthday of the Guggenheim Museum. People by the hundreds danced, dined, drank, talked, reminisced. The staff got to forget what day it was, and virtually every foreign artist who has ever shown at the Guggenheim flew in to pay tribute to Thomas M. Messer, who last week announced his retirement after 27 years as director of the museum. (His fief also extended, in recent years, to the Peggy Guggenheim collection in Venice.) They got to see some great art, too. It would be hard to find more compelling works of their kind and date than Roy Lichtenstein's ''Preparedness'' (1968), Giacometti's ''Nose'' (1947), Brancusi's ''Muse'' (1912) and Neil Jenney's ever more pertinent ''Media and Man'' (1969). From earlier days, there were paintings and drawings in profusion by Cezanne, Pissarro, Seurat, van Gogh, Gauguin and the Douanier Rousseau. At both ends, and in the middle, the Guggenheim looked strong.

title: Arizona Bid to Cards
description: Arizona State University in Tempe, and the cities of Tempe and Phoenix, have joined to offer the St. Louis Cardinals football team a $10 million package in an effort to lure Bill Bidwill, the owner, and his National Football League team to Arizona. Bidwill, who has said the Cardinals would move after completing this season, has also investigated Jacksonville, Fla., Baltimore and Memphis. Jim O'Connell, the executive director of public events for Arizona State, said that Bidwill was shown figures that indicate $10 million could be generated from ticket sales, loge seats, parking and concessions next season. The calculations were based on an average attendance of 50,000 in the 70,021-seat Sun Devil Stadium for eight regular season games and one exhibition.

title: THEATER: A MUSICAL, 'TEDDY AND ALICE'
description: FOR those who worried that Broadway might be nothing more than a carnival fairway offering mindless fun, along comes ''Teddy and Alice,'' a show that fearlessly puts pedagogy back into the American musical. An extravagant treatment of the life of our 26th President and his terminally spunky daughter, the production at the Minskoff is full of fascinating footnotes to our nation's proud history. Did you know that Teddy Roosevelt actually said ''Great Scott!'' more often than ''Bully!''? Or that Eleanor Roosevelt caught the corsage at her cousin Alice's wedding? Or that Alice considered wearing white and red gowns to her coming-out party before settling on blue? That last item alone accounts for a good half-hour of nail-biting dramatic suspense in ''Teddy and Alice.''

description: NO matter how sick many people may be of the swagger and theatrics of Julian Schnabel, and of the publicity machine fed by him and his work, his show at the Whitney Museum of American Art is welcome. It has enough information and flair to encourage a fresh look at a 36-year-old artist who seems to have been so much with us for so long that we never had a chance to decide if we wanted him or not.

title: British Jobless Rate Dips
description: Britain's unemployment rate fell to a seasonally adjusted 9.8 percent in October, dropping below 10 percent for the first time in six years, the Department of Employment said today. Total seasonally adjusted unemployment was estimated at 2.71 million people in October, down from a revised 2.77 million in September and 3.16 million in the comparable period a year ago.

Among other things, the Australian-made movie suggests there's nothing inherently evil about being a werewolf that a little human understanding wouldn't cure. Mr. Mora and his associates are blunt about it: this anti-werewolf hysteria must stop.

Name That Bill
description: On the theory that a rose by some other name might smell sweeter, Representative Richard A. Gephardt has renamed the amendment that he succeeded in attaching to the trade bill now being studied in a House-Senate conference committee. The Gephardt amendment would require the President to negotiate with a country that has erected trade barriers against United States products and, if that country refuses to modify those barriers, authorize the President to retaliate with comparable action.

title: Top Skier Sidelined
description: Tamara McKinney, who would give the United States its best hope for a medal in Alpine skiing at the Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta, in February, will be sidelined at least six weeks with a hairline fracture of her lower left leg that she suffered while training Monday at Copper Mountain, Colo. McKinney, 25 years old, the only American woman to win a World Cup overall title (in 1983), fell on a slalom run, fracturing the lower fibula where it meets the ankle of her left leg. Chris Tucker, the Olympic team trainer, said that McKinney could resume skiing in late December, which would cause her to miss about 10 World Cup races in Europe. The Winter Olympics run from Feb. 13 through 28.

title: Suez Canal Revenues Up

An increase in ship tolls, scheduled for next year, has been canceled because of the world financial turmoil, he said.

Assets of the 111 institutional funds increased $598.2 million, to $73.58 billion. Assets of the 207 general-purpose funds were down $641.5 million, to $78.77 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds increased $601.3 million, to $108.77 billion.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Lakers 111, Clippers 82: James Worthy scored 20 points and A.C. Green added 17 last night in Inglewood, Calif., as the Lakers remained the only unbeaten team in the Western Conference. The defending league champions need a victory Saturday at Golden State to equal the best start in their history. They began the 1980-81 season with a 5-0 mark, but did not win the title. (AP) Spurs 123, SuperSonics 118: Johnny Dawkins scored 28 points and Alvin Robertson scored 20, including 10 in the fourth quarter, to help San Antonio hold off Seattle at home. (AP) Nuggets 126, Trail Blazers 113: Alex English scored 14 of his 24 points in the third quarter to help Denver break away from Portland in a home victory. The Blazers have not defeated the Nuggets at McNichols Arena since Dec. 16, 1983. Denver broke open a a 59-59 halftime tie by outscoring the visitors, 20-8, to begin the second half. The Nuggets were never threatened. (AP) Tennis Cash, Lendl Advance: Ivan Lendl and Pat Cash moved a step closer to a rematch of their Wimbledon final when both reached the last eight of the $375,000 Benson and Hedges indoor championships in Wembley, England. Cash had to struggle before beating Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-4, 3-6, 6-3. Another Russian, Alexander Volkov, fell, 6-4, 6-3, to Lendl. Volkov, a qualifier and ranked 116th in the world, matched Lendl early, , often dominating the rallies. But he lost his serve in the ninth game and one chance was all that Lendl needed. (AP) Bunge Loses in Upset: Leila Meskhi of the Soviet Union, ranked 66th in the world, defeated seventh-seeded Bettina Bunge of Switzerland, 6-4, 6-2, in a second-round match at the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament. In today's quarterfinals, Meskhi will meet third-seeded Helena Sukova, who struggled to victory in her second-round match against a fellow Czechoslovak Jana Novotna, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2. Sixth-seeded Lori McNeil of Houston eliminated Etsuko Inoue of Japan, 6-2, 1-6, 6-1. (AP) Squash Khan to Face Dittmar: Jansher Khan of Pakistan, the World Open champion, scored a fourth straight victory over his countryman Jahangir Khan last night to move into today's final of the $50,000 Rolex United States Open at The Palladium in Manhattan. The 18-year-old Jansher simply wore down Jahangir, who was playing on a sore right leg, and prevailed, 17-16, 8-15, 4-15, 15-10, 15-4. Johnsher's opponent in the final will be fourth-seeded Chris Dittmar of Australia, who ousted Ross Norman of New Zealand, 15-11, 15-7, 15-3. Boxing Reid Topples Hines: Chris Reid of Little Silver, N.J., the International Boxing Federation's 12th-ranked light heavyweight, recorded his 17th knockout by stopping Irvin Hines at 2:27 of the fourth round of a scheduled 10-round bout last night at the Felt Forum. In the fourth, Reid knocked Hines down with a right to the head. Hines took the mandatory 8 count from Referee Luis Rivera. With another right to the head , Reid (18-1-1) knocked Hines (17-14-1) to his knees to end the fight. Golf Bean Leads in Hawaii: Andy Bean, the defending champion, shot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday to take a three-stroke lead after the second round of the Kapalua International in Kapalua, Hawaii. ''I feel like it's January and I'm just starting the season,'' said Bean, who missed most of the year with an elbow injury. He has completed 36 holes without a bogey. Bean reached the halfway point in a tournament-record 131, 13 under par on the Bay course at the Hawaiian resort. The leader after the first round, Sandy Lyle of Scotland, a previous winner of this title, was tied for second with Lanny Wadkins at 134. .(AP)

title: Met Opera: Pavarotti and Sutherland in 'Trovatore'
description: NORMALLY it takes a new opera production years to decline to the point of terminal weariness and ineptitude, but the Metropolitan Opera's ''Trovatore'' reached that sad state in one evening, at last night's premiere. Placing the blame precisely is not easy, simply because there is so much blame to go around. However, let us start with Richard Bonynge, who conducted lifelessly, apparently concerned with little more than keeping the orchestra down. That expedient did allow the famous voice of Joan Sutherland, his wife and the evening's Leonora, to be clearly heard. Unfortunately, it also helped drain most of the vitality from a Verdian score that must either overflow with the stuff or fall embarrassingly flat.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: KLAUS FUCHS: The Man Who Stole the Atom Bomb. By Norman Moss. 216 pages. Illustrated. St. Martin's Press. $16.95. KLAUS FUCHS, ATOM SPY. By Robert Chadwell Williams. 267 pages. Illustrated. Harvard University Press. $25.

title: HOME OFFICE REFERENCE LABORATORY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
KEYSTONE CAMERA PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $225,000 on the sale of operations for the quarter and 9 months.

title: BULL & BEAR GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: Carlucci Hints Budget Plan Portends Shrinking Military
description: Frank C. Carlucci, President Reagan's choice to be the new Defense Secretary, said at his confirmation hearings today that continuing reductions in military spending are likely to lead to a smaller American military force.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stock Price of Drug's Maker Jumps on Word of Clearance
description: The price of Genentech Inc. shares rose $3.25 today, to $42.75, on anticipation that the company would receive Government approval on Friday to market its drug for dissolving blood clots, called tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A.

title: CORRECTIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Let's Party
description: The nation began celebrating its bicentennial in 1976, and activities continued off and on through this Sept. 17, the 200th anniversary of the signing of the Constitution. Just when one might have thought the bicentennial had run its course, the Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution issued an advisory this week stating that the ceremony in Philadelphia in September ''was only the beginning of our celebration of this great document.''

title: Film: Schwarzenegger In 'The Running Man'
description: THE year is 2019. In the fascist state that America has become, Ben Richards (Arnold Schwarzenegger) is a helicopter pilot with the Federal police. One night, while on a routine patrol, he's ordered to terminate a food riot in Bakersfield, Calif. Some 1,500 unarmed women and children are running amok in search of nourishment.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday on an anti-cholesterol drug misstated the cost of another drug, lovastatin. Its costs range from $700 to $3,000 a year per patient.

title: A Boon for Broadcasting
description: LEAD: The Senate Commerce Committee, chaired by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, has recently proposed legislation that would help reduce the Federal deficit and at the same time create a Public Broadcasting Trust Fund. Although the measure has encountered strong opposition from commercial broadcasters, it is fiscally responsible, because it raises revenues to help offset the Federal deficit.

title: FILM: 'HYPOTHESES,' FROM FRANCE
description: IN connection with the French Film Institute's retrospective devoted to the work of Raoul Ruiz, the Chilean-born fabulist, the Bleecker Street Cinema today presents the American premieres of ''Hypothesis of the Stolen Painting,'' a 1978 feature, and the short, ''Dog's Dialogue'' (1977), both made in France, where the filmmaker now lives.

title: CUSTOMEDIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $153,700. c-Includes a gain on a debenture exchange of $1,394,958 and a tax loss carryforward of $1,250,000.

title: Houston Post Sale Nearly Completed
description: Media News Group Inc., the owner of The Dallas Times Herald and 27 other daily newspapers, is expected to complete next week its $150 million purchase of The Houston Post, the company said. Originally announced Sept. 10, the all-cash purchase of the newspaper from the Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation was expected to close by Nov. 1.

title: ANECO REINSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized gains of $65,625 for the quarter and $145,757 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized gains of $105,076 and $721,757 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Mortgage Buying Set by Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association announced yesterday that it would buy adjustable-rate mortgages whose interest rates are tied to an index measuring the cost of funds for savings and loans in the district of the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco.

title: No Winners at Tourney
description: The yearly records of the Volvo International tennis tournament in Stratton Mountain, Vt., will show no singles or doubles champions for 1987. Final matches in both events were rained out last Aug. 9 and, despite efforts by tournament officials to arrange for the finalists to return and complete the matches, the organizers announced yesterday they had given up. In the singles event, John McEnroe was leading Ivan Lendl, 7-6, 1-4, when the two-day downpour began. Both players will receive runner-up money of $20,000. In the doubles event, the team of Paul Annacone and Christo van Rensburg was scheduled to play Ken Flach and Robert Seguso. Each will receive the runner-up payoff of $6,750. Jim Westhall, the tournament director, said the unpaid purse money of $26,750 would make up the bulk of a gift of $30,000 and an automobile that the tournament will donate to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, the players' charity.

title: Hite's New Book Is Under Rising Attack
description: Shere Hite's new book, ''Women and Love,'' is coming under increasing attack by academic specialists who contend that its statistical conclusions that a great majority of women are unhappy with their male partners are based on badly flawed methodology.

title: Tales of the Pioneers
description: Even before they could vote in national elections, women sometimes attained positions of responsibility and authority in the Federal Government. But they rarely received public recognition for their work.

title: Bridge: Event This Weekend Gives Rare Chance at Par Contest
description: Perhaps the most difficult task that any bridge expert ever undertakes is the construction of par hands, prepared deals designed to test the bidding, play and defense skills of a group of contestants. The difficulty lies largely in guaranteeing that alternative plays will not succeed.

title: ARSON AT THE FRANKFURT OPERA
description: The Frankfurt Opera House was badly damaged today by a fire started by an unemployed and homeless East German refugee, officials said.

title: The Working Woman's Dream
description: What do women really want? Many of them want to go to work, and therefore also want houses that are easier to keep clean. A New Jersey housing developer asked women what conveniences they'd install in a house of their own design.

title: DUKAKIS SAYS GOVERNMENT CAUSED STOCK PLUNGE
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts charged yesterday that last month's stock market plunge was ''a government-made disaster.''

title: Nominee Comfortable in the Spotlight
description: On Wednesday, Judge Anthony M. Kennedy became a nominee for the Supreme Court. Today he became a media event.

title: TGX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The latest third quarter and 9-month results include Louisiana Energy & Development Corp., which was acquired in November 1986.

title: Tremors on Wall Street Don't Make New York City Quake
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks, Dollar Advance In Asia on U.S. Report
description: Share prices climbed this morning, as traders, buoyed by news of a shrinking American trade deficit and a stronger dollar, flooded the market with buy orders.

title: Senator Lugar Hurt in Fall
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, broke a bone in his face and suffered a cut over his eye when he slipped today on his icy driveway in McLean, Va., a spokesman said. Mr. Lugar was treated at Bethesda Naval Hospital and released but will have to return Wednesday to have the facial bone set, the spokesman, Andy Fisher, said. ''It's not very comfortable for him to speak or chew,'' he said.

title: DANGER: QUOTATIONS
description: For 50 years, illustrations in newspapers, magazines and books have carried the credit line of the Bettmann Archive. The person behind the New York-based archive, it turns out, is a man not only of pictures but also of words.

title: An Export Assault on Europe
description: The rush to Europe is on. With the dollar sinking to postwar lows, making American products ever cheaper, United States companies are flocking across the Atlantic to cash in.

title: A Walk on the Wild Side of the Stock Market
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Movies
description: Kapoor's London Talkie

title: ALL AMERICAN SEMICONDUCTOR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company completed its initial public offering in August.

title: Debentures Placed For Holiday Inns
description: The Holiday Corporation yesterday announced the private placement of $100 million of the 7 1/2 percent, 10-year subordinated debentures of Holiday Inns Inc. to Bass P.L.C., a British brewer.

title: 85 Soldiers Reported Dead In Raid on Ethiopia Convoy
description: Ethiopian rebels said today that they killed 85 Government soldiers on Wednesday in an attack on a famine relief convoy escorted by the Ethiopian Army in Eritrea Province.

title: U.S. Bars Visit by Jackson to Servicemen in Gulf
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson will not be allowed to make a planned Thanksgiving visit to United States forces in the Persian Gulf, the Defense Department said today.

title: Cleveland-Cliffs
description: David F. Bolger, the New Jersey investment banker seeking control of Cleveland-Cliffs Inc., has hired Donaldson, Lufkin, & Jenrette Inc. as his financial adviser. Mr. Bolger, who holds 1.05 million, or 8.5 percent, of Cleveland-Cliffs's shares, is soliciting proxies to replace the board of the Cleveland-based iron ore and gas drilling concern. The meeting is scheduled for Dec. 15 in Cleveland. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Bolger said that if he was elected to the board, he would try to have Donaldson hired as the company's investment banker.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE Lincoln Center area is always a challenge for those seeking interesting dining before or after performances. A spiffy new Italian trattoria just across the street, called Poccino, is a welcome addition. The sleek, glass-enclosed dining room and its futuristic bar look out on the Lincoln Center complex and the nonstop urban opera along Broadway. The menu has a few good pastas - I've sampled only a few, including a fresh and lusty maccheroni all'Amatriciana with pancetta, peppers and tomatoes ($9) - and a tasty veal tonnato ($10). Entrees, which I have not yet tried, run from pounded steak with stewed peppers ($15) and broiled chicken ($12.50) to veal saltimbocca ($15) and fish of the day.

title: After Summit, a New Look for Egypt
description: Egypt nudged a small way farther from isolation today after an Arab League summit meeting lifted a prohibition on diplomatic ties with Cairo because of its 1979 peace with Israel.

title: TRANS LEASING INTERNAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Brokers' New Ads Offer Reassurance
description: The stock market's collapse in mid-October shook the confidence of seasoned Wall Street veterans and small investors alike. It also presented financial institutions with a daunting challenge: How to restore investors' faith in the market.

title: Advertising; A Label For Johnnie Walker
description: JOHNNIE WALKER Black Label, in hopes of continuing its forward motion, is spending an extra $1 million for a pre-Christmas print advertising spectacular.

title: Holmes a Court Is Under the Gun
description: After being badly hurt by last month's stock collapse, the investor Robert Holmes a Court is searching the world for buyers for his 9.6 percent stake in Texaco Inc. and his other holdings as well.

title: MICRO MASK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $93,000 for the quarter and $294,000 for the year.

title: City Opera: Mozart and Knussen Duo
description: ''WHERE THE WILD THINGS ARE,'' a children's opera for adults (and an adult opera for children, too) by Oliver Knussen and Maurice Sendak, lumbered happily into the New York State Theater last night. Playing on a double bill with a version of Mozart's incomplete opera ''L'Oca del Cairo,'' it will close out the New York City Opera season with five more performances through Sunday evening. It's a real delight, one of the best things the company has done. But it needs a better partner than the decidedly ungilded goose with which it now shares the stage.

title: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
61.01 Rise Puts Dow At 1,960.21
description: The stock market surged yesterday, and analysts laid the stock rally firmly at the door of the September trade figures released by the Commerce Department.

title: TRADITIONAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Islander Thrill Show Goes On
description: The script was being followed: a 4-1 cushion for the Islanders had become a 4-3 tightrope in the third period at St. Louis Arena. In their three previous games, the Islanders had been outscored by a total of 9-1 in the third period, yet had won twice in overtime.

title: The Monthly Trade Figures: A Closely Watched Barometer
description: The monthly trade figures have become a litmus test of sorts for the health of the overall United States economy. This is why investors and traders in all the financial markets pay so much attention to the report - and, correspondingly, why the prices of stocks and bonds and the value of the dollar in relation to other major currencies can rise or fall, depending on how the actual figures stack up against expectations.

title: PRONET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $59,000 and $150,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $4,000. d-Net loss and includes a tax credit of $4,000.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about Mel Miller, the Speaker of the New York State Assembly, misstated the circumstances that led an Assemblywoman, Gerdi E. Lipshutz, to resign from the Assembly last March. Ms. Lipshutz, a Queens Democrat, quit after testifying at the trial of an Assembly staff member that she had carried two ''no show'' jobs on her payroll. No charges were filed against Ms. Lipshutz.

title: Filipino Rebels Tied to Deaths
description: The commander of the Philippine Constabulary said today that Communist rebel gunmen were responsible two weeks ago for the killing of three Americans outside Clark Air Base.

title: Informer at Westies Trial Admits Frequent Lies Under Oath
description: A convicted killer who turned informer at the racketeering trial of several members of a West Side gang testified under cross-examination yesterday that he had frequently lied to authorities, even under oath.

title: AIDS Tests Suggested For Infants of 1980-85
description: Parents whose infants had transfusions before the nation's blood supply was routinely screened for the AIDS virus should consider blood tests for their children, a California researcher said today.

title: G.M. to Export Cars to Japan
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would export three car models to Japan through the Suzuki Motor Company, in which it has held a 5.3 percent interest since 1981.

title: No Headline
description: The Salvadoran Air Force bombed parts of central Cuscatlan province and left-wing guerrillas attacked the army during a unilateral Government cease-fire, civilians and the Government said today.

title: COMMONWEALTH MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: LOUISIANA GENERAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes gains from the sale of land of $928,000. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $679,000 from the redemption of debentures. The latest year net includes a gain of $485,000 from the sale of land. The results for the prior year include a non-recurring pre-tax charge of $17.5 million related to an adjustment of the carrying value of the company's oil and gas reserves.

title: Whiteheads Divorce and Cite Battle For Baby M, Not Pregnancy, as Cause
description: Richard and Mary Beth Whitehead were divorced here today, eight days after she formally revealed she was two months' pregnant by another man.

title: Ambassador of Rock Visits Leningrad
description: To the Editor:

title: Shell and B.P Report Gains
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies, the world's largest oil enterprise, reported a 27 percent increase in its third-quarter profit yesterday, while the British Petroleum Company reported an 8 percent gain.

title: Art: 67 Years of Works By Latin Americans
description: ''ART of the Fantastic: Latin America, 1920-1987,'' at the Queens Museum, is an effective and, at times, impressive exhibition, even though it is not a consistently good one. The chopped-up galleries of the museum and the chaotic, often cheek-by-jowl installation are a detriment; the fact that the exhibition, organized by the Indianapolis Museum of Art to celebrate the 10th Pan American Games, has been cut is a disappointment. The show's contents are extremely erratic in quality and are divided into three generations of artists (early modernist, postwar and contemporary) that frequently overlap confusingly.

title: Devils' Streak: End Is No Loss
description: The winning streak at home came to end for the Devils tonight after eight victories. But the ninth game was not a total loss and the Devils are still the only National Hockey League team that is undefeated at home.

title: 4 Airlines Order 7 Boeing Jets
description: Four airlines have ordered seven jets for a total of about $240 million from the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company, the company said. Germania, a charter airline based in Cologne, West Germany, ordered three 737-300's for delivery in November and December 1988, doubling its fleet. KLM Royal Dutch Airlines ordered two 737-300's for delivery in December 1988. The airline already operates 10 737-300's.

title: Art People
description: Just an Artist's Dream?

title: Graf Draws Garrison in Slims
description: Her serve is in need of improvement and her net game is still in its infancy, but Steffi Graf said she was generally satisfied with the progress she has made this year. Imagine, then, how formidable she will be when she reaches her full potential.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday CHINESE FESTIVAL

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT was a week to honor First Ladies. The celebrations began gently

title: Interest Rates Finish Mixed
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, rising for some short-term securities due in less than two years but falling or holding steady for longer-term issues.

title: WOMEN'S DANCE SERIES
description: Melanie Slater and Pamela Hoff-man are to open the Working Women dance festival tonight at 8 at Middle Collegiate Church, 50 East Seventh Street. The choreographers will present ''Lore,'' which they describe as a concert of human tales. Others scheduled to present dances in the festival are Amy Sue Rosen, tomor-row and Sunday at 8; Sally Silvers, from Dec. 3 to 6 at 8, and Ruth Fuglis-taller and Estelle Eichenberger, Dec. 3 and 5at 10. Tickets are $7; Theater Development Fund vouchers accept-ed. Information and reservations: 228-8108.

title: The Inspired, the Silly and the Useless
description: Ken Hakuta used to export ironing board covers to Japan.

title: Iran Unites the Arabs
description: The communique adopted at the Arab summit meeting in Jordan is astonishing: it thunders at Iran in tones once reserved for Israel. It calls for an international peace conference, in which Arab participants would have to deal with Israel, and leaves the door open for its members to renew ties with Egypt. And perhaps of greatest significance, Syria - enemy of Israel and Egypt and ally of Iran and the Soviet Union - has signed on.

title: ARCHIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Net loss

title: Comings and Goings
description: The World Boxing Association junior-featherweight champion, Louie Espinoza, has signed contracts for two fights - in Puerto Rico Nov. 28 against the eighth-ranked contender, Julio Gervacio, and Jan. 15 against Bernardo Pinango, the No. 1-ranked contender. . . . Pernell Whitaker, a 1984 Olympic gold medalist, will fight Jose Luis Ramirez in Paris in March for the World Boxing Council's lightweight crown, according to Dan Duva, Whitaker's promoter. . . . The San Antonio Spurs have signed Leon Wood, a guard the Nets released last Thursday.

title: 'MAYFLOWER MADAM,' FROM THE BOOK, ON CBS
description: ON CBS this Sunday at 9 P.M., ''Mayflower Madam'' provides perhaps the ultimate, certainly the most unintentionally hilarious, example of commercial television caught in a vise between cupidity and hypocrisy. The network and the producer, Robert Halmi, were quick to snap up the rights to ''Mayflower Madam,'' the best-selling book by Sydney Biddle Barrows, former debutante, about the swank call-girl service she ran in Manhattan for about five years. But then the production had to go through CBS Program Practices for purification rites that would protect the network from any accusations of endangering public morals. The result: a madam who looks as if she is auditioning for a remake of ''The Song of Bernadette.''

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 13, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: A Big Fund Ready to Capitalize on Hard Times
description: In major articles in The Atlantic and Newsweek, Peter G. Peterson, a former Commerce Secretary and a former head of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, has warned of troubled economic times ahead.

title: CELLO CONCERTO
description: The New York Chamber Sympho-ny, conducted by Gerard Schwarz, is to perform works by Mozart and the premierof a cello concerto by and Sunday at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y. Soloists for the concert are to be the pianist Alicia de Larrocha and Andre Emelianoff, cellist. Tickets are $15 to $22.50. Information: 966-1100.

title: Allan C. Bernstein, 76, Office Systems Inventor
description: Allan C. Bernstein, who invented a series of office communications systems, died of a heart attack Sunday at the inpatient unit of Hospice Inc. in Tamarac, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in Tamarac.

title: BP CANADA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Senate Backs A-Waste Site Plan
description: The Senate today approved an overhaul of the nation's program for dealing with high-level nuclear waste that virtually chooses Nevada as the most likely state for a permanent repository for such waste. The vote was 63 to 30.

title: Get the Hostages Out
description: LEAD: For a year, the United States Government has been frozen in its approach to the plight of the Americans held hostage in Lebanon. Eight imprisoned Americans have been devalued by their Government - there are few other words to describe the hostage policy followed in Washington since disclosure of the Administration's arms deal with

title: Film: 'Cross My Heart,' a Date in Detail
description: IF a date were a thing that could be examined under a microscope, then ''Cross My Heart'' offers some idea of what it might look like, warts and all. The entire film concentrates on the all-important third encounter between David (Martin Short) and Kathy (Annette O'Toole), an event that the film deems critical for several reasons. David and Kathy, who are thirty-ish, liked each other a lot on their first two dates. Each of them is very eager, and very nervous. Each has a few key biographical facts he or she would rather keep under wraps. And the third date, by this film's reckoning, is the one on which it's obligatory to go to bed.

title: Boy Playing Between Cars Falls to Death on Subway
description: A teen-age boy fell to his death from between two cars of an IND C train yesterday afternoon in the Bronx, officials said.

title: 3M Realigns Its Divisions
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company announced a realignment that would separate its consumer and commercial businesses from its industrial products lines. The shuffling will not result in any shrinkage of the businesses, the company said.

title: 2 American Mountaineers Tell Of Witnessing Tibet Protests
description: Two American mountaineers, who had gone to climb the remote peaks of Tibet, found themselves witness to violent demonstrations six weeks ago calling for independence.

title: Mine Kills 25 in Sri Lanka; Autonomy Bill Passes
description: A bus carrying ethnic Tamils hit a land mine planted by Tamil rebels and exploded today, and all 25 passengers were killed, a military official said.

title: JACOBS ENGINEERING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $500,000, or 11 cents a share, from litigation settlement. c-Net loss

title: The Elis Can Wait
description: Justice Department officials say Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d is in relatively good spirits and fully engaged in his duties. This despite his mounting legal problems in connection with grand jury investigations of the Wedtech and Iran-contra scandals and despite such pressures of office as having to advise President Reagan on three Supreme Court nominees.

title: ELBIT COMPUTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Honeywell Bull Inc. said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,600 staff positions, about 8 percent of its staff, during the next year as part of a domestic restructuring.

title: Police Begin Stopping Drivers Of Cabs to Insure Their Safety
description: In an effort to reduce crimes against taxicab drivers, the New York City police will stop hundreds of cabs each night for random ''safety checks,'' Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday.

title: Trainer Banned Over Drugs
description: Peter Ferriola's training license was suspended for 120 days yesterday by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board because three of his horses tested positive for Lasix after racing at Aqueduct last week.

title: Call Is Issued for New Policy
description: A group of American and European business leaders today called on governments to reduce the trade imbalances that have fueled turmoil in the financial markets.

title: Kirkpatrick Is on the Fence In G.O.P. Presidential Race
description: She dined the other night with Bob Dole and his wife. She showed up at Jack Kemp's home for dinner a couple of nights later. And Vice President Bush telephoned her recently and said, essentially, let's have lunch.

description: b-Includes income of $24,636,000 and $52,378,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations. c-Includes income from discontiniued operations of $19,975,000 for the quarter and $34,101,000 for the year.

title: 253 Pounds of Trouble for Jets
description: On Sunday in Kansas City, the Jets will meet one of the more interesting new players in the National Football League, Christian Okoye of Enugu, Nigeria.

description: The Swiss mime group Mummen-schanz is to appear on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, Lehman College, Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx. Members of the troupe use masks, costumes and lighting to form living sculptures. Tickets are $13, $15 and $17.50. Information: 960-8833.

title: Moscow Talk: Leader's Fall From Heights
description: Maksim, a computer worker, spotted the real news tucked five minutes beyond the headlined stories, offered by the state-controlled television announcer in the minimalist form that Muscovites are alert for: Boris N. Yeltsin, the city's leading politician, had been suddenly ousted.

description: Ruby Braff Is Back

title: Homeless Woman Sent to Hospital Under Koch Plan Is Ordered Freed
description: A New York State judge yesterday ordered the release of the first person involuntarily hospitalized under a new Koch administration plan to remove seriously disturbed homeless people from the streets. The judge ruled that the city had failed to prove that the homeless woman was mentally ill or unable to care for herself.

title:
Market Place;
Rate Cuts Aid Savings Units
description: LEAD: WHILE the recent stock market collapse has created an uncertain outlook for equities, some analysts see a silver lining for savings and loan associations in the Federal Reserve's effort to spur the economy with lower interest rates.

description: John Lydenberg, a retired professor of American literature at Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y., died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 74 years old.

description: A podiatrist has been indicted by a Westchester County grand jury on a charge of stealing $1.8 million in fraudulent Medicaid billings for special footwear, it was announced today.

title: DR. ENDERS WEDS MICHAEL SOUTHAM
description: Alice Talcott Enders, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas O. Enders of New York was married in a civil ceremony at Old City Hall in Toronto yesterday to Michael Cargill South-am, the son of G. Hamilton Southam and Jacqueline Lambert David, both of Ottawa.

title: ADDISON WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago quarter and 9-month results are restated to reflect a change in accounting for certain pension costs.

description: About 300 people, the vast majority of them strangers, came out to mourn the tangled life and brutal death of Lisa Steinberg yesterday as the 6-year-old was buried by relatives and clergymen who never knew her.

title: AMERICAN TRAVELERS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Drug Report Assailed
description: Jeannie Longo of France, who holds more than 10 world records in cycling, had never tested positive in drug tests in nine years of competition until traces of ephedrine were found in her system after she won a 3-kilometer race in September at Colorado Springs. ''I'm the most sane athlete about drugs, amphetamines,'' she said yesterday in Grenoble, France, after the drug report from the American Cycling Federation was received by the French Cycling Federation and made public. ''I have never wanted to touch forbidden products,'' Longo said. ''I will not accept a suspension because a suspension for me is a condemnation.'' Longo said that the source of the minute quantities of ephedrine came from taking exosuline as part of her program of phytotherapy, an herbal medicine treatment popular in France. She faces a possible suspension of up to six months, which might threaten her chances of winning a berth on the French Olympic team.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Purchased the contracts of Craig Worthington, third baseman; John Hoover, pitcher, and Sherwin Cijntje, outfielder, from Rochester of the International League. CINCINNATI (NL) - Named John Cox director of scouting. CLEVELAND (AL) - Released Miguel Roman, outfielder. Sent Reggie Ritter, pitcher, outright to Buffalo of the American Association. METS (NL) - Purchased the contracts of Todd Welborn, pitcher; Chris Jelic, catcher, and Joaquin Contreras, outfielder, from Jackson of the Texas League, and Rich Rodriguez, pitcher, from Lynchburg of the Carolina League. MINNESOTA (AL) - Waived Jeff Bittiger, pitcher, for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. Purchased the contracts of Paul Abbott, Jeff Bumgarner, Steve Gosse, Jeff Satzinger and Jim Davins, pitchers, and Brad Bierley, outfielder, from Portland of the Pacific Coast League. Sent Larry Blackwell, outfielder, outright to Portland of the Pacific Coast League. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Waived Logan Easley, pitcher. Purchased the contracts of Tony Chance, outfielder; Mike York, pitcher; Jim Reboulet, infielder, and Ruben Rodriguez, catcher, from Vancouver of the Pacific Coast League. TORONTO (AL) - Purchased the contracts of Juan Guzman, pitcher; Pat Borders, catcher; Jimy Kelly and Norm Tonucci, infielders, and Kevin Batiste and Eric Yelding, outfielders, from Syracuse of the International League. Sent Joe Johnson and Craig McMurtry, pitchers, and Santiago Garcia, infielder, outright to Syracuse. YANKEES (AL) - Purchased the contracts of Mitch Lyden, catcher; Darren Reid, outfielder; Chris Alvarez, third baseman, and Amalio Carreno, Troy Evers and Steve Frey, pitchers, from Columbus of the International League. Signed Mike Kinnunen, pitcher, to a minor-league contract. BASKETBALL KNICKS (NBA) - Traded Rory Sparrow, guard, to the Chicago Bulls for a 1988 second-round draft choice.Signed Johnny Newman, guard-forward.

title: Yankees Fill Roster
description: The Yankees filled their 40-player winter roster yesterday by buying the contracts of six players from their Columbus minor-league team. The players are Darren Reed, an outfielder; Mitch Lyden, a catcher; Chris Alvarez, a third baseman, and three pitchers, Amalio Carreno, Troy Evers and Steve Frey. The Yankees also signed Mike Kinnunen, a former Baltimore pitcher, to a Columbus contract.

title: BRITISH PETROLEUM CO PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR); each ADR represents 12 British Petroleum ordinary shares. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: A Lion in Winter on Wall St.
description: Many investors are boasting these days that they sold stocks before the market collapsed on Oct. 19. But few of them are now stepping forward to be big buyers of stocks again.

title: THRIFTY RENT-A-CAR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Restaurants
description: NINE-MONTH-OLD Remi is one of those rare places that combine a striking setting, attentive service and distinctive food. Remi in Italian means oars, and both the menu and the design theme reflect maritime Venice.

title: 3 on Election Panel to Oppose Bypassing Contribution Limit
description: Three of the six members of the Federal Election Commission indicated today that they would oppose a request to allow political action committees to bypass Federal restrictions on political contributions.

title: GLOBAL NATURAL RESOURCES PROPERTIES LC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a charge of $48,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $632,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-Includes tax credits of $1,315,000 and $3,350,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: William Clay Ford Named to Key Post
description: William Clay Ford, who has spent most of his business life in the long shadow cast by his older brother, Henry Ford 2d, was named yesterday as chairman of the finance committee of the Ford Motor Company's board. He succeeds his brother, who was chairman of the powerful committee until his death at 70 on Sept. 29.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Kasparov Maintains His One-Point Lead
description: Neither Gary Kasparov nor Anatoly Karpov was able to upset the balance of the 12th game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, on Wednesday, and they agreed to an early draw.

title: SEAWAY FOOD TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Dance: Nina Wiener Troupe
description: ENVELOPED by the sound of sensuous sighs, a woman is dwarfed by a Futurist landscape and recalls a relationship with a man that went sour. This, in a sketch, is ''Fierce Attachments,'' Nina Wiener's new dance work, and its look and sensibility are uncomfortably close to Calvin Klein's perfume commercials.

title: Giants Brace for a Tough One
description: For the first time in years, a Giants-Eagles game is taking on the dimension of a true division rivalry.

title: BOONTON ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ex-Judge Gets 8-Year Term On a Racketeering Charge
description: A former New York City Civil Court judge who pleaded guilty last spring to committing crimes before he was elected to the bench was sentenced yesterday to eight years in Federal prison, despite his emotional appeal for mercy.

title: SCHOOL IN MISSOURI BASKS IN SUCCESS
description: Topping off six exhilarating months, this little Missouri River town's parents, grandparents and students rolled out the welcome mat and a brand new sweatshirt today for the most prominent visitor anyone here could recall.

title: David Rockefeller Heads Modern Museum Board
description: David Rockefeller was elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Museum of Modern Art at a board meeting on Wednesday, the museum announced yesterday. Mr. Rockefeller, who has been a trustee of the museum since 1948, is the former chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: For Ex-Police Officer, New Life After Drugs
description: His hands are steady now. His voice is firm. The police officer who became a cocaine addict and entered a drug treatment center 15 months ago is beginning to talk about returning to the world outside again, this time without a uniform, without a gun and without a secret life.

title: Lab Wars, Star Wars
description: There is trouble in one of the key atomic weapons labs working on ''Star Wars,'' over an issue of greater importance than seeking a defense against missiles. It is about whether defense of scientific integrity can be maintained against a push to make even the most technical questions political, if they can be exploited.

title: FIRST CITY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $2,306,000 and $21,733,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the quarter also includes net from discontinued operations of $7,864,000, and a gain of $92,110,000 from disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after net from discontinued operations of $5,842,000 and $8,929,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest third quarter.

title: MGM/UA Loss Grows
description: MGM/ UA Communications Inc. reported losses today of $46.2 million for its fiscal fourth quarter ended Aug. 31, bringing the cumulative losses for the year to $88.1 million. No comparison figures are available since the reconstituted MGM/UA is in its first year of operations. Based in Culver City, Calif., the movie and television producer had revenues of $118 million for the quarter and $427.6 million for the year. The losses were expected as the company worked to replenish its inventory and released only two movies, ''Spaceballs'' and ''The Living Daylights.''

title: COLOROCS CORP reports earnings for
CLAIRSON INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: The company said because it went public in November 1986, which terminated its S corporation status, net income is presented on a pro forma basis as if the company had accrued an income tax liability prior to the public offering.

title: Stroh to Buy Back Tampa Brewery
description: The Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit said today that it would buy back a Tampa, Fla., brewery it traded to the Pabst Brewing Company of San Antonio five years ago.

title: PAMELA B. RUBIN AND JON R. CARTER WED
description: At Temple Emanu-El in New York, Pamela Beth Rubin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic P. Rubin of Old Westbury, L.I., was married yes-terday to Jon Robert Carter, the son of Arthur L. Carter of New York and Linda Gordon of Newfane, Vt. Rabbis Ronald B. Sobel and Eugene Lipsey officiated.

title: Erratic Session Ends With Gains for Dollar
description: The dollar moved higher in active, choppy trading yesterday. Traders said the currency was bolstered by an improvement in the United States trade deficit and by rumors that the Administration and Congress were near agreement on a package to cut the Federal budget deficit.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Business People column in Business Day last Friday, about the appointment of Frank Harrison 3d as a vice chairman of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company Consolidated, listed his college history incorrectly. He received his bachelor's degree from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and his M.B.A. from Duke University.

title: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain from the sale of a leasing subsidiary of $13,829,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $12,296,000 for both the quarter and year, and both the quarter and year include a gain of $4,268,000 on the issuance and sale of subsidiary stock. The company said the 1986 share earnings results are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 8.

title: Patrick J. Growney; Lawyer, 81
description: Patrick J. Growney, a retired partner of the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, died Monday at a convalescent home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 81 years old and lived in Gladwyne, Pa.

title: U.N. Repeats Debt Warning
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has told the United States representative here that the United Nations will run out of funds unless Washington pays $87 million of its annual contribution by early December, United Nations officials said today.

title: Lessons of the Koch Mission
description: The mission of a nine-member delegation headed by Mayor Koch of New York City made it clear that fact-finding in Central America is a formidable undertaking.

title: Wilbur Dale Talley, An American Dancer
description: Wilbur Dale Talley, a ballet dancer who performed with the Harkness Ballet and Ballet Internacionale de Caracas, died on Wednesday at the General Hospital South in Maracaibo, Venzuela, from injuries sustained when he was thrown from a horse on Sunday. Mr. Talley, whose stage name was Dale Talley, was 39 years old.

MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for 13wks to Oct 31
description: The sales are exclusive of sold divisions and non-replaced closed stores.

title: 110 Boston Commuters Injured in Train Crash
description: A commuter train crashed into another that was stopped at an underground station this morning, injuring at least 110 people, 6 of them seriously, officials said.

title: Truck Safety Record Is, Unfortunately, Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: For Disarmament Chief, a Man of Arms?
description: After months of disagreement within the Reagan Administration and typical buzzing on the Washington rumor mill, a retired Navy admiral who is little known beyond the circle of professional military experts is now a leading candidate to succeed Kenneth L. Adelman as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

title: Cyprus Awarded Victory in Soccer
description: Europe's soccer authority today overturned a victory by the Netherlands against Cyprus last month in a game of the European Championship qualifying tournament in which a smoke bomb was thrown at the Cypriot goalie.

title: Brunch Spots Where Music Is on the Menu
description: GOING out to eat long ago ceased having much to do with simply eating. From the power breakfast to the hot date, the number of variations on the general theme of dining out have mushroomed into a veritable smorgasbord of possibilities.

title: LYNCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: 'Though Homeless, She Copes, She Is Fit, She Survives'
description: Following are excerpts from the decision by Acting Justice Robert D. Lippmann of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ordering the release from the Bellevue Hospital Center of Joyce Brown, a homeless woman involuntarily hospitalized by New York City mental-health authorities:

title: BUDGET TALKS HIT LAST-MINUTE SNAG
description: The budget negotiations, earlier reported to be near completion, hit a snag today, and Democrats accused the White House of changing its demands at the last minute.

title: Giamatti's Report
description: Speaking to students at Yale, the university he formerly was president of, A. Bartlett Giamatti, now the National League president, said last night that the most serious problem that baseball has before it is the unruliness of spectators that threatens to ''take the game away from the American family.'' Giamatti said one half of a 15-page report that will be sent to clubs in the National League next week was devoted to the problem. ''At the heart of it, I think, is alcohol management,'' he said, aligning himself with those who have called for alcohol-free seating at baseball and other sporting events. If the situation in ball parks is left unchecked, Giamatti warned, ''the incentives not to go out to the park are going to be enormous.''

title: Witness's Home Is Bombed; Two Are Charged in Queens
description: Two people have been charged with firebombing the home of a man who complained to the police about drug dealing in his South Jamaica, Queens, neighborhood.

description: b-After investment gains of $100,000 for the quarter and $7,289,000 for the 9 months. c-After investment losses of $632,000 for the quarter and investment gains of $5,909,000 for the 9 months.

title: Stalin's Daughter Isn't Moving
description: Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, said today that she had no plans to move to Britain, although she inquired informally about a work permit.

title: Gorbachev Accuses Former Ally Of Putting Ambition Above Party
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, backing the removal of a former ally as Moscow party chief, accused him of mismanagement and undisciplined behavior, Tass, the official press agency, reported today.

title: SILICON SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Polling, Communist-Style
description: The Chinese long ago dismissed public opinion polling as a trapping of bourgeois liberalism: Why would a party that embodies public opinion need polls? But on the eve of their recent congress, party leaders decided that Deng Xiaoping's creed, ''Seek Truth from Facts,'' would be well served by the bourgeois device.

title: U.S. TO BACK GENE-ENGINEERED DRUG FOR CLOTTING
description: The Food and Drug Administration plans to announce approval of a new drug Friday that can reduce the damage of heart attacks by dissolving harmful blood clots, Government officials said today.

title: Threadbare Economics?
description: Some months ago stock analysts were delighted to learn that, in the world of women's fashion, miniskirts were back in style. There was a correlation, said the statistical pundits, between short skirts and bull markets.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; A Move to Switch Breeders' Mile to Dirt
description: Afleet, Gulch, Polish Navy, Stacked Pack and Very Subtle going a mile on the dirt later this month would be a sensational race and a fitting part of the Breeders' Cup Day. It will not happen this year, but a similar race could be part of the cup within a year or two.

title: Coors Biotech
description: The Coors Biotech Products Company, a division of the Adolph Coors Company of Golden, Colo., said it would form a venture with Meiji Seika Kaisha Ltd., a Tokyo confectionery company. The venture would market a food additive that the Japanese company had developed and sold in its country for more than three years. The product would be marketed early next year to animal feed producers and the health food industries in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean.

title: Pan Am Board Rejects Kerkorian's Airline Bid
description: The Pan Am Corporation yesterday rejected a proposal by the investor Kirk Kerkorian to take over Pan American World Airways.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1987
description: International A3-12

title: San Francisco Fire Dept. Job Pact Faces Challenge
description: A Federal district judge tentatively approved a settlement today establishing goals for hiring and promoting women and blacks in the San Francisco Fire Department.

title: Canadians Cool To Tunnel Plan
description: The international underwriters of the $:750 million ($1.34 billion) Eurotunnel share issue said today that they had withdrawn plans to seek financing in Canada because of low interest among investors.

title: Deaver's Illness Delays Trial
description: Michael K. Deaver's second painful kidney stone attack in two weeks forced the adjournment today of his perjury trial until at least Wednesday while he undergoes surgery and recuperation.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOROUGHRED BREEDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Iowa Union Backs Dukakis
description: A union that represents state workers said Tuesday that it had endorsed Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, becoming the first major labor group in Iowa to back a Presidential candidate.

title: 8 Charged With Mafia Drug Plot, Including Murders and Extortion
description: Eight men with ties to organized crime were charged yesterday with conspiring to control drug sales at locations in Brooklyn and Staten Island in a pattern of racketeering that included murder, extortion and bribery.

title: From New Talent, Bold New Images
description: IT sometimes seems that the exhibition scene in photography is characterized by an endless repetition of familiar names and images. The names bring in the crowds, and the images help pay the rent. But at the moment, as if by an unspoken, collective urge, the focus has shifted to the young and the undersung, giving them a showcase they sorely need if they are to follow in the footsteps of giants like Henri Cartier-Bresson and Edward Weston.

title: Judge Sets Aside Mandel Verdict In Mail Fraud
description: A Federal district judge in Baltimore today overturned convictions that sent former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and five co-defendants to jail 10 years ago on charges of mail fraud.

HOSPOSABLE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Dollar Perplexes Candidates
description: What the Republican and Democratic candidates for the Presidency are saying about the dollar is, mostly, the obvious: it will remain weak until a workable long-term agreement is reached to reduce the nation's budget deficit.

description: b-Net income

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bank of America, San Francisco, named Barbara Rambo a senior vice president. Colgate-Palmolive Co. elected as a director Ronald E. Ferguson, president and chief executive of General Re Corp., a reinsurance company. Holiday Corp., Memphis, a hotel and casino concern, said Richard J. Goeglein would retire as president, effective Dec. 31, and would be succeeded by Michael D. Rose, chairman and chief executive. Laurentian Capital Corp., Mobile, Ala., elected Claude Bruneau chairman, replacing Claude Castonguay, who will remain a director of Laurentian Capital and chairman, president and chief executive of its parent company, Laurentian Group Corp. Mr. Bruneau will continue as president and chief executive of Imperial Life Assurance Co. of Canada, also a unit of Laurentian Group. ORFA Corp. of America, Cherry Hill, N.J., named Thomas S. Rooney president, succeeding Robert D. Kohn, who resigned to pursue personal interests. Provident Life and Accident Insurance Co., Chattanooga, Tenn., said Willard H. Wyeth would retire as executive vice president and a director, effective Dec. 1. The company has not yet named a replacement. Software Publishing Corp., Mountain View, Calif., named James J. Heffernan to the new post of chief financial officer. U S West Inc., Englewood, Colo., a telecommunications concern, elected Charles M. Lillis to succeed the late John C. Willemssen as executive vice president and chief planning officer.
