HEALTH-CHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes losses on the disposal of discontiunued operations of $145,000 for the quarter and $318,000 for the 9 months, an allowace for loss of $4,700,000 on the anticipated repurchase of the company's stock for both the quarter and 9 months, allowances for unrealized losses on investment in U.S. treasury bonds of $516,000 and $1,097,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an allowance for unrealized loss on investment in preferred stock of $409,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income and includes income of $7,000 for the quarter and a loss of $199,000 for the 9 months both from discontinued operations; an allowance for unrealized loss of $95,000 on investment in U.S. treasury bonds for both the quarter and 9 months and the 9-month also includes a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $80,000.

title: Priest's Mission Is Contras' Surrender
description: The Rev. Enrique Oggier has come to regard the Central American peace plan with a faith nearly equal to that he holds for the church's teachings.

title: Shell Resists Bid
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group has threatened to leave Brazil if a proposal to put the distribution of petroleum products solely in the hands of Government companies becomes law. It is the second economic issue this month pitting Government interests against those of multinational companies. Autolatina, a venture of the Ford Motor Company and West Germany's Volkswagenwerk A.G., has challenged the Brazilian Government's system of price controls in court.

title: GF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $220,000 for termination in early retirement benefits. c-Net income

title: JUILLIARD DANCE GROUP
description: Four world premieres are to be danced by the Juilliard Dance En-semble as part of its fall performance series, which begins tonight at 8 o'clock at the Juilliard Theater, 144 West 66th Street. The program fea-tures ''Prom Story'' by Benjamin Harkarvy; ''Monday Morning'' by David Parsons; ''Light, Part 24'' by Kei Takei and ''Reeks with Class!'' by Francis Patrelle. Performances are today andtomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $10 (free for students and the elderly). Infor-mation: 874-7515.

title: TRIPLE BILL AT THE RITZ
description: Three groups - That Petrol Emo-tion, World at a Glance and Salem 66 - play a rock triple bill tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Music begins at 11; tickets are $13.50.

title: Chrysler Unit Offering 1 Billion of Securities
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation is using underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation to offer about $1 billion of securities backed by automobile loan receivables. The financing is the largest public offering of loan receivables by the Chrysler unit, about twice the size of a similar financing arranged in June.

title: MARKETS REBOUND
description: The nation's deficit in international trade shrank by a hefty $1.6 billion in September, improving against all major trading partners except Canada, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about Governor Cuomo's attendance at a conference in Tarrytown, N.Y., on the plight of minority-group children, reversed the identities of two of the women shown with Mr. Cuomo. Yveline Sylvain of the Youth Leadership Conference, was at the right, and next to her was Meredith Carey of the Manhattan Borough President's Youth Advisory Committee.

title: Dining Out Guide: Cucina Nuova
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ALO ALO, 1030 Third Avenue, at 61st Street (838-4343) - **(June 21, 1985) The whimsically chic dining room resembles a grand cafe. The chef's spirited style is modern yet not affected. An unusual antipasto is a warm salad of smoked buffalo mozzarella, sun-dried and fresh tomatoes, red and yellow roasted peppers, red onions and fresh thyme. A star among the pastas is fusilli with broccoli and pancetta. A standout fish dish is steamed salmon on a bed of steamed yellow squash and tomatoes, served with a tomato coulis. Pastas $10.50 to $15 and entrees $15 to $21. Fridays, 11:45 A.M. to 2 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 2 P.M. ARQUA, 281 Church Street (334-1888) - **(April 24, 1987) This airy and minimalist restaurant is named after a village in northeastern Italy. An unusual appetizer is fresh fillets of sardines pickled with sweet and sour onions. The trinity of northern Italian cuisine - gnocchi, risotto and polenta - is beautifully executed here. The feathery gnocchi are usually bathed in some variation of light tomato sauce. Polenta is creamy and lusty, blended with sausage and wild mushrooms. An enticing entree is roasted baby pheasants served with champagne grapes. For dessert, the ricotta cheesecake has a lively lemony touch. Entrees $15 to $22. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 6 to 11:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 6 to 11:30 P.M. CONTRAPUNTO, 200 East 60th Street (751-8616) - *(Nov. 23, 1984) This restaurant, while limited in scope, puts considerable energy and imagination into making its pastas truly distinctive. Try the capelli marina piccola, strands of al dente angel hair pasta flecked with dried tomatoes, shallots, leeks and basil, all crowned with little neck clams. For seafood lovers, there is also ravioli stuffed with lobster and scallops or crabmeat. All the appetizers, which include air-dried beef with Parmesan cheese, are good. For dessert, the best choice is a homemade sorbet. Pastas $11.75 to $15.75. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to midnight; Sundays, 4 P.M. to midnight. ORSO, 322 West 46th Street (489-7212) - **(July 18, 1986) This is a sunny and casual Italian restaurant in clean tans and oak. The menu changes daily, but one can usually find the delicious salt-crusted grilled shrimp served in the shell - the sweet meat is heady with smoky nuances. Pizzas have thin, yeasty crusts and vibrant toppings: Gorgonzola, prosciutto, onion and garlic; sausage, mozzarella, garlic and tomato. Succulent little grilled quails with a light sauce are stellar; so, too, is a rolled veal tenderloin stuffed with spinach and mildly tart goat cheese. Among the desserts is a semolina pudding with strawberry sauce. Entrees $12 to $19. Fridays and Sundays, noon to 11:45 P.M.; Saturdays, 11:30 A.M. to 11:45 P.M. UNION SQUARE CAFE, 21 East 16th Street (243-4020) - **(Jan. 24, 1986) The main dining room is characterized by simple rustic touches, kind lighting and well-spaced tables. The food is genuine and eclectic. A light way to begin is with pappardelle of zucchini, thin flat strips of zucchini in a fresh tomato sauce flecked with garlic and shallots. The most unusual dish on the menu is the marinated fillet mignon of tuna, a whale-size slab of florid tuna seared on the outside and progressively rare toward the center. A confetti of ginger shavings adds a vibrant dimension. For dessert, there is a semifreddo bianconero, a frozen mousse of dark and white chocolate with chocolate chips in an espresso cream sauce. Entrees $17 to $22. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 6 to midnight. What the stars mean, page C24.

title: School Parents Wrestle With Lisa's Death
description: United in their grief over the death of Lisa Steinberg, but differing over the questions it raised, about 40 parents of the girl's classmates met this week with staff and counselors at Public School 41.

title: Rat Nerves Repaired and Rejoined With Spine
description: Scientists report that for the first time they have repaired crushed nerves connecting the extremities to the spinal cord in mammals, in this case rats.

title: Woody Allen Talks of Films And Fatherhood on the BBC
description: Woody Allen, the actor and director, who is about to become a first-time father, discussed his films and hopes for a baby girl in a television interview that appeared today on the BBC.

title: PROGRESS IS MADE ON BUDGET TALKS
description: The budget negotiations got back on track today, and Congressional leaders began to consider ways to delay the $23 billion in spending cuts that are to take effect automatically next Friday.

title: LAURENTIAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $741,000 for the quarter and $2,658,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes realized investment gains of $1,695,000 for the quarter and $3,170,000 for the 9 months. The 1986 results restated for the inclusion of Loyal American Life Insurance Co. as a combination of previously separate entities under common control.

title: Stage: At Yale Reportory, 'Melons' Explores Indian Issues
description: In the second act of Bernard Pomerance's ''Melons,'' there is a confrontation between a once fierce Apache chief now posing as a peaceful Pueblo farmer and a young Indian doctor who has a pragmatic attitude about the achievement of equal rights for their people. It is 1906, wars are over but old wounds remain raw. The meeting of the two Indians - in a melon field in the New Mexico countryside - is both sharp and succinct, and strikes at the heart of the conflict in Mr. Pomerance's otherwise discursive play.

title: Ungermann-Bass Bars Digital Offer
description: Ungermann-Bass Inc., a computer network manufacturer based in Santa Clara, Calif., said its board had unanimously rejected an acquisition proposal from Digital Communications Associates Inc. Digital, a computer parts maker based in Alpharetta, Ga., had said on Thursday that it might begin a hostile tender offer if Ungermann did not accept its offer of $9.75 a share, or about $172.6 million, but the company told Reuters today that it had no immediate plans to take further action.

title: Chief for Dow Chemical
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that its board of directors had appointed Frank P. Popoff as its chief executive officer, succeeding Paul F. Oreffice, who will remain chairman. Mr. Popoff has also been elected chairman of the board's executive committee, replacing Mr. Oreffice, who remains on the committee. Mr. Popoff, who is 52 years old, became president and chief operating officer of Dow in May, when today's promotion was also foretold. He became a director in 1984.

title: Inflation Would Result
description: To the Editor:

title: Pasqua Traded; Dotson a Yankee
description: The Yankees, who hadn't made a deal with the Chicago White Sox in 11 weeks, bolstered their starting pitching corps yesterday by acquiring Richard Dotson in a five-player trade with the White Sox. Dan Pasqua, the enigmatic young power hitter, was the most significant of the three players the Yankees shipped out.

title: PAINEWEBBER RESIDENTIAL REALTY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FUDDRUCKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: SUNSHINE MINING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Somehow, Chargers Win
description: Two months ago, Les Miller was working the graveyard shift in Arkansas City, Kan., affixing handles to picnic coolers for $5 an hour. Tomorrow, he'll line up as a starting defensive end against the Los Angeles Raiders, epitomizing all that has become wonderful and unbelievable for the San Diego Chargers.

title: Dutton Released
description: Another 36-year-old N.F.L. defensive standout with 14 years' experience might have seen his season end yesterday. The Dallas Cowboys released John Dutton, a defensive tackle who spent the last eight seasons with Dallas. Dutton has been replaced as a starter by Kevin Brooks.

title: MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Beech-Nut Is Fined $2 Million for Sale Of Fake Apple Juice
description: The Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges that it had sold phony apple juice intended for babies and agreed to pay a $2 million fine.

title: 6 Parkway Workers Held in Drug Cases
description: Four toll collectors on the Garden State Parkway have been arrested and charged with selling drugs inside their booths at three toll plazas in northern New Jersey, according to the state police.

title: Bad Turn for a Slalom Star
description: Cheery pink and yellow hair bands, a navy sweater, aquamarine sweat pants, a lavender sock, a pink sneaker: these were the colors of Tamara McKinney today as she sat in the cafeteria of a resort where other members of the United States ski team were finishing a week of practice.

title: CHARTING A COURSE WITH A FINANCIAL PLANNER
description: On Tuesday, Oct. 20, the day after the stock market took its historic tumble, Gregory Smith sat down with a pile of folders and papers that represented his financial portfolio, haphazardly arranged as it was. He had invested $15,000 in stocks here and there, and had placed some money in mutual funds. But like many Americans, Mr. Smith was left a bit dazed by what had happened on Wall Street, and his financial outlook was muddled.

title: LIBERTY HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dance: Michele Anne de Mey, of Belgium, at the Kitchen
description: After the Germans, the French and the Japanese, the newest group epitomizing the extraordinary worldwide spurt in dance innovation comes from Belgium, a country that has generally had little impact upon dance history. After Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker, the revelation of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival last year, there are others obviously who have something to offer on their own. Michele Anne de Mey, a Belgian dancer in the Keersmaeker troupe, presented her choreography at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, on Thursday night.

title: Bush Facing Robertson in Florida Poll
description: The campaigns of Vice President Bush and Pat Robertson today prepared for a showdown in a straw poll of Florida Republicans Saturday.

title: No Headline
description: Atlanta officials are hoping that a scarred, five-block area in the heart of the downtown area can mimic the city that surrounds it by rising from the ashes of its own destruction.

title: LE PEEP RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GENERAL NUTRITION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter includes about a $300,000 gain resulting from an accounting change relating to the company's overfunded pension plan. Year-ago 9-month revenue included about $6 million from a discontinued Canadian subsidiary.

title: Cuomo Rules Out a Late Race In Primaries, but Still Hedges
description: Governor Cuomo, faced by persistent rumors that he is considering a last-minute Presidential bid in 1988, said yesterday that he would not participate in the late primaries in California and New Jersey.

title: Payment by Venezuela
description: The Venezuelan Government will repay $250 million in principal owed to private foreign banks by mid-December, Finance Minister Hector Hurtado said today. He told reporters the amount would be sent within 30 days from Monday as specified under terms of Venezuela's $20.3 billion rescheduling accord with private foreign banks. The accord, reached in principle with private banks on Feb. 27, became binding today after all of Venezuela's 450 private creditor banks signed the pact.

title: JACKSON NAMES 2 TO LEAD CAMPAIGN
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, seeking to strengthen his Presidential campaign organization, today introduced two new campaign officials whose selection appeared aimed at broadening his appeal.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $500,000 loss from litigation settlement. c-Includes a net gain of $7.3 million, or 62 cents a share, on the sale of real estate.

title: Yeltsin Affair Is Raising New Speculation On Soviet Leader's Commitment to Change
description: The public humiliation of a Communist Party official once regarded as one of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's closest political supporters has raised critical questions about the Soviet leader as he prepares for his first visit to the United States next month.

title: South Korea Denies Report on Leader's Purchase
description: The Government of South Korea has denied that President Chun Doo Hwan has bought an apartment in New York City in a newly renovated building owned by Donald J. Trump.

title: Jordan Has 36 in Rout of Nets
description: Michael Jordan continued to take charge -but only when necessary - and the Chicago Bulls continued unbeaten tonight.

title: 60 People Flee A Gas Pipe Rupture
description: About 60 people were evacuated from the center of North Branford, Conn., yesterday after a construction company doing excavation ruptured a natural-gas pipe, the police said.

title: ELRON ELECTRONIC INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said its losses in 1987 are a result of a provision of $2.2 million for writing off of the balance of its investment in Elscint Ltd., and a previously reported write-off of $1.7 million against guarantees given by Elron for Elscint obligations.

title: MANUFACTURED HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Library for Reagan Papers Finds a Home in the West
description: A $30 million library to house Ronald Reagan's Presidential papers will be built on 100 acres of donated land near here, library and Ventura County officials announced today.

title: MID-AMERICA INDUSRTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FALCON CABLE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Results for the latest 9-month include a $774,000 gain on the sale of stock in QVC Network Inc.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Late Drop Pushes Dow Down 25.20, to 1,935.01
description: Stock prices pulled back yesterday, ending a two-day mini-rally attributed to a firming dollar and encouraging news on the trade front.

title: Trustco Buys 8.6% of Glenfed
description: Royal Trustco Ltd., a leading Canadian financial institution, disclosed today that it had purchased an 8.6 percent stake in Glenfed Inc., and said it might decide to seek control of Glenfed, the fifth-largest savings and loan holding company in the United States, with nearly $19 billion in assets and 176 branch offices in California and Florida.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article on a new American export drive in Europe mislabeled the two main components. The labels for imports and exports, in the chart showing trade in capital goods, should have been reversed.

title: John H.F. Haskell, 83, Ex-Finance Executive
description: John H. F. Haskell, a retired banker and a former diplomat and officer of the New York Stock Exchange, died of heart failure Tuesday aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2 en route to New York on a visit. He was 83 years old and lived in Grasse, France.

title: AGS COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Gore Cuts His Iowa Staff to Four People From 21
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr.'s Presidential campaign announced today that it had cut its staff of paid workers in Iowa to four from 21.

title: Psychiatrists Debate Role in Legal System
description: As they did in the case of Joyce Brown, as they do in hundreds of civil and criminal cases every day, consulting psychiatrists pondered the vicissitudes of their inexact science yesterday and disagreed over the role of their profession in court. How accurate are psychiatric diagnoses? Should psychiatrists, with the power to deprive people of liberty, continue to work for one side or another in court, or should they work exclusively for the court itself?

title: MEI DIVERSIFIED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Soviet Purchases in U.S.
description: The Soviet Union made additional agricultural purchases in the United States today, contracting for 500,000 metric tons of wheat and 150,000 tons of soybean meal, the Agriculture Department announced.

title: Iraqis Resume Diplomatic Relations With Egypt
description: Iraq said today that it had restored full diplomatic relations with Egypt.

title: 9 Killed in India Hurricane
description: A hurricane lashed coastal areas of India's southern Andhra Pradesh state today, killing at least 9 people and forcing the removal of about 29,000, the United News of India reported.

title: Air Wisconsin Is Being Sought
description: Air Wis Services Inc., the parent of the commuter carrier Air Wisconsin, said that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer from an unidentified party for $11.50 a share in cash, or $85.1 million. An Air Wis spokesman said the buyers are a venture capital group and two individuals but refused further identification. The airline serves 30 cities in the Middle West and East.

title: LPL INVESTMENT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,027,000 for the quarter and $3,234,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss The results of operations of Amphenol Corp., acquired June 2, are included in earnings since that time.

title: Court Bars The Release Of Woman
description: A New York State appellate court yesterday barred the immediate release of a woman found by a state judge to have been inappropriately hospitalized under a Koch administration plan to remove seriously disturbed homeless people from the streets.

title: Rutledge Likely to Be Starter
description: Phil Simms looked fit, didn't limp and didn't throw today.

title: Girl, 14, Wounded As Boy Shows Gun
description: A 14-year-old Manhattan girl was shot in the head Thursday night when she and two friends handled a gun in a Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: LIQUID AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $224,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $51,000 for the quarter and a gain of $241,000 for the 9 months, both from the disposal of discontinued operations. The year-ago periods were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title:
Patents;
Light-Producing Pen For Video Screen
description: LEAD: A light-producing pen that was patented this week for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories of Murray Hill, N.J., is said to detect the scanning beam of a video screen in a highly accurate manner. Patent No. 4,705,942 was granted to Z. L. Budrikis, an Australian, and three New Jersey staff inventors.

title: Your Money; Yields Stressed By Investors
description: DAVID PEARL, a New York apparel manufacturer, has been selling some of his stocks since the steep October market decline. ''I decided to redirect my allocation of assets that were geared toward growth into income-oriented securities,'' he said. ''You look for some security.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: British Inflation at 4.5%
description: Retail prices in Britain rose five-tenths of 1 percent in October from the previous month, bringing the inflation rate to 4.5 percent, the Department of Employment announced today.

title: TWINKIES FANS COPE
description: While some of us may be fretting about the stock market and others about the Persian Gulf, there is one segment of the population that has been undergoing a far more serious personal crisis this last week.

ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page TK.

description: There are no year-ago comparisons because the company is in its first year of operations.

title:
Patents;
A Control System for Aircraft
description: LEAD: AN aileron system for the roll control of an airplane at both high and low speeds has been invented for the Boeing Company, the Seattle aircraft manufacturer. Patent No. 4,705,236 was awarded this week to Peter K. C. Rudolph, a staff member.

title: ORTEGA PROPOSES TRUCE BUT REBELS OBJECT TO TERMS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua presented a detailed proposal today for a cease-fire with the contras that would oblige the rebels to surrender their weapons after one month and accept a political amnesty.

title: Reagan Imposes Punitive Tariffs Against Brazil
description: President Reagan announced today that he would impose punitive tariffs covering more than $100 million worth of imports from Brazil in retaliation for Brazilian curbs on American computer and software products.

title: Korean War Memorial Site
description: The Reagan Administration has approved plans to erect a memorial honoring veterans of the Korean War on the mall between the Capitol and the Lincoln Memorial. Representative James J. Florio, a New Jersey Democrat who backs the memorial, said Tuesday that Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel had approved the site. Legislation authorizing a Korean War memorial was signed by President Reagan last year.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the risks of options trading misidentified in the first mention the type of investor who would suffer big losses if the underlying security turned down. As the article correctly explained thereafter, it is the seller, not the buyer, of an options put contract who risks the heavy losses.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a production error, a Washington dispatch on Wednesday, about the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association and its attitude on air safety, omitted the association's position on collision-avoidance equipment. Edmund Pinto, an association vice president, said his organization supported the use of ''supplementary equipment'' that would alert air traffic controllers to the position and altitude of a private plane in congested areas.

title: Kaisertech Leader Sets Loan Accord
description: Allan E. Clore, the financially troubled chairman of Kaisertech Ltd., disclosed today that a group of his creditors had agreed to forbear his $99 million defaulted loan. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Clore said that the forbearance period expires on Dec. 31, unless Mr. Clore has entered into an agreement to sell his Kaisertech shares.

title: COMMONWEALTH MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are not available; the company went public Nov. 12, 1986. Share earnings represent units.

title: Ginsburg's Role in Cable TV Case Is Investigated
description: The Justice Department is investigating whether a special prosecutor should be appointed to look into possible conflicts of interest by Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg while he was a Justice Department official, a Federal law enforcement official said today.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $103,000.

title: Mildred Smith Huser  Lawyer, 94
description: Mildred Smith Huser, a Brooklyn lawyer who was a delegate to the 1920 Republican state convention, died Monday at the New Rochelle Medical Center. She was 94 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: A Necessary War
description: THE KOREAN WAR. By Max Hastings. 389 pages. Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: QVC NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Comparable figures are unavailable because the company went public in June 1986.

title: 'Pow! Right in the Kisser!'
description: True, Ralph Kramden of ''The Honeymooners'' never did hit his wife, Alice. But Jackie Gleason commonly punctuated episodes of the television show with a clenched fist and the threat: ''One of these days, Alice - Pow! Right in the kisser!'' The routine and the laughter it elicited reflected wide public insensitivity to the violence that continues as terrible reality in millions of households. Poverty exacerbates domestic tensions, but such violence is by no means confined to the poor.

title: U.S. Won't Alter Policy to Bolster Gorbachev in Rifts, Officials Say
description: Administration officials, who are divided in their assessment of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's political problems, say American policy will not be influenced by internal maneuvering in the Soviet leadership.

title: Syracuse Goes for 10 Out of 10
description: Mike Power, the Boston College quarterback, has revived memories of Doug Flutie, a former star for the Eagles. Against undefeated Syracuse on Saturday, Power may well be spending most of the day doing a Flutie-like impression of a scrambling quarterback.

title: Film Forum 2 Will Show 2 1930's French Movies
description: ''Crime and Punishment'' and ''The Man From Nowhere,'' two French films of the 1930's, will be shown Nov. 20 through 26 at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street. The films were directed by Pierre Chenal, who supervised the recent striking of new prints from the original negatives.

title: Old Hats and Strains Between New York's Finest and Bravest
description: There was a time when New York City police officers and firefighters wore virtually the same hats.

title: PLACER DOME reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: ATICO FINANCIAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an income tax credit of $4,596,000 from the reduction of deferred tax liability related to gains in the company's portfolio of marketable securities for both the quarter and 9 months. The company said the latest quarter included the acquisition on July 31 of 100 percent of the common stock of Pan American Mortgage Corp. and the acquisition on Aug. 31 of 93.12 percent of the common stock of Intercontinental Bank.

title: Soviet Union Allows Visit By Nureyev
description: Rudolf Nureyev said today that he had received permission to visit his elderly mother in the Soviet Union. It will be the first visit by the star dancer to his native land since he defected in 1961.

title: Grant for Mentally Disabled
description: A Chicago foundation has awarded $2 million to a nonprofit group that works to assure the rights of mentally disabled people, the foundation said Thursday. The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation made the award to the Mental Health Law Project, a Washington-based public interest organization that recently helped restore Social Security benefits to thousands of mentally disabled people, a statement said.

title: To the Aid Of an Old Typewriter
description: ACCORDING to conventional wisdom in the computer age, the typewriter is obsolete. Indeed, many would call it a veritable dinosaur when it comes to producing the printed word.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The next step is up to them.''- President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua, referring to the contras. [ 4:4. ]

Patents;
Designing Proteins
description: LEAD: Gary E. Frashier, president of the Genex Corporation, a biotechnology company in Gaithersburg, Md., told a meeting of analysts in New York this week that Genex holds rights to a pioneering patent, the first issued covering the use of artificial intelligence-based methods to design proteins. The patent is No.

title: Norman Applezweig  Biochemist, 70
description: Norman Applezweig, a consulting biochemist and the founder of Progenics Inc., a health care research and development company, died of a heart attack Monday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Homicide Experts Meet: Gruesome Cases and a Bit of Fun
description: Call them what you will - the mavens of murder, the doyens of death. They are 125 of the country's leading experts on homicide, and for three days they have met here to compare cases and swap stories, talking of knives and cyanide and killings in the night.

description: b-Net loss

title: Drug Approval For Genentech
description: Genentech Inc. received approval today from the Food and Drug Administration for its blood clot-dissolving drug, tissue plasminogen activator, or T.P.A. The approval comes just five months after an F.D.A. advisory committee recommended against licensing Activase, as Genentech calls the drug, and asked for additional information about the its ability to save lives.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Student Newspapers Need Some Limits
description: To the Editor:

title: Arthur Miller Reading
description: To mark the publication of his autobiography, ''Timebends: A Life,'' Arthur Miller will give a reading from the work on Monday at 8 P.M., at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center. The book is published by Grove Press, which is sponsoring the reading with Lincoln Center Theater. Admission is free.

title: Military Spending Bill Approved by Conferees
description: House and Senate negotiators today approved a compromise military budget that makes sharp cuts in several weapon programs.

title: No Damage Is Seen to Homeless Plan
description: Mayor Koch's program to remove mentally ill homeless people from the streets has not been damaged by the Joyce Brown decision, and New York City does not plan to broaden existing laws to gain wider latitude to pick them up for treatment, the city's chief assistant corporation counsel said yesterday.

title: Big Loss, Big Gain for the Jets
description: In a surprising turn of events, the Jets have lost Johnny Hector, their leading runner, for at least one game, but have regained the services of Joe Klecko.

title: ABITIBI-PRICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a $2.3 million special charge for both the quarter and 9 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Old Brook Bed Is Discovered Under Rubble
description: Somewhere beneath Washington Square Park, under asphalt, sand, gravel, shards of brick and old water pipes, lies the bed of a brook. Yesterday two geology professors and a graduate student from New York University set out to find it without moving so much as a pebble. They used radar. Their equipment, called ground penetrating radar, has penetrated sand, gravel, clay and solid rock, but it nearly met its match yesterday with the urban debris under New York City. Despite all the interference, it worked. Long-Missing Stream

title: Excerpts From Moscow Speeches by Yeltsin and His Critics
description: Following are excerpts from a report in Pravda yesterday about a Moscow Communist Party meeting Wednesday at which Boris N. Yeltsin was dismissed. The section quoting Mr. Yeltsin was translated by The New York Times; the section quoting others was translated by Reuters. YELTSIN FOES' REMARKS

NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-7, 28 A Nicaraguan cease-fire plan was presented by that country's president. It would oblige Managua's rebel opponents to surrender their weapons after one month and accept a political amnesty. Page 1 News analysis: Boris Yeltsin's ouster has raised questions about the Soviet leader as he prepares for his first visit to the United States. Mr. Yelstin was once regarded as one of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's closest political supporters. 1 U.S. policy toward Moscow will not be influenced by internal maneuvering in the Soviet leadership, officials said. They are emphatic that it would be a mistake to tailor policy to try to bolster the Soviet leader. 6 Tariffs against imports from Brazil totaling more than $100 million will be imposed, President Reagan said. The punitive action is aimed at a Brazilian requirement effectively barring foreign participation in their computer market. 1 West German and French leaders concluded a two-day meeting with agreements to jointly develop a combat helicopter and to set up joint councils on military and economic policy. 3 In the Iran-Contra investigation, seven House Democrats on the Con-gressional committees will attach a statement to the panels' report disagreeing with its conclusion that theWhite House was fully cooperative with the inquiry. 3 Iraq restored relations with Egypt, the official Iraqi press agency reported. The agency said both countries would nominate ambassadors immediately. Links were severed after Egypt signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979. 7 Arsonists and looters in Bangladesh will be shot on sight, President H. Ershad declared after days of sporadic unrest in several cities. ''We are not going to tolerate any more of this nonsense,'' he said. 28 U.N. body calls for widening of test ban treaty 3 Buenos Aires journal: Timerman in strange lands 4 Chinese dissident said to die in jail 5 Alexandria recovering its Arab soul 7 NATIONAL 8-9, 35-36 Consumers are still spending freely, seemingly unworried by the stock-market plunge that began in mid-October, the Government's monthly report on retail sales indicates. 1 Beech-Nut sold phony apple juice intended for babies from December 1981 to March 1983. The Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that it violated the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act through the sales. 1 Scientists repaired crushed nerves connecting the extremities to the spinal cord in mammals for the first time, they reported. The research is pointing the way toward treatment of what are now intractable neurological problems. 1 Charges of parental sexual abuse are made in thousands of cases every year across all class lines. The dispute over one girl could almost be an object lesson in how convoluted such cases can become. 1 The budget talks got back on track as negotiators set aside disagreements and began to consider ways to delay the automatic spending cuts that are to take effect next Friday. 9 A compromise military budget that cuts sharply into several weapon programs was approved by Congressional negotiators. The bill sets priorities indicating which military programs will be cut, but it does not set a final spending total. 9 A partisan fight in Florida is deepening. The state Legislature and the Governor continue to be mired in a battle over the state's 5 percent tax on services and bogged down even more on medical malpractice insurance. 35 George Bush and Pat Robertson prepared for a showdown in a straw poll of Florida Republicans by staking out positions designed to minimize possible setbacks. About 2,500 delegates will vote at the state Republican convention. 35 Reagan papers find a home 8 Exclusionary club may pose problems for Judge Kennedy 8 Ginsburg role in cable television case under scrutiny 9 Escape tests set on space shuttle 9 Coal miners open labor talks 9 Shake-up expected in Dole campaign 35 Dupont and Bush taking off gloves 35 Dukakis release personal records 35 Jackson adds 2 officials to campaign 35 REGIONAL 29-32, 34 A new state investigative agency to combat ''systemic corrupution'' and racketeering in New York City's construction business was called for by Governor Cuomo as part of a campaign to clean up the industry. 1 Leading experts on homicide are meeting for three days in Albany to swap stories, talking of knives and cyanide and killings in the night. In other words, they have been having a wonderful time. 29 The release of a homeless woman was temporarily barred by a New York State appellate court. The woman, Joyce Brown, was the first person hospitalized under a plan to remove disturbed homeless people from the streets. 29 The judge in the Joyce Brown case has long been known for his interests in housing for the poor. Acting Justice Robert D. Lippmann ruled Thursday that the homeless woman should be allowed to return to a life on the streets. 30 No damage seen to homeless plan 30 Lisa Steinberg's violent death has left parents of her schoolmates with differences over the questions it raised. The parents have struggled to find ways to explain the girl's death to their children. 29 A radar search for a bed of a brook was conducted in Washington Square Park by two geology professors and a graduate student. By using the radar equipment, the team could search for the underground brook without moving so much as a pebble. 29 A Connecticut woman was murdered in August after her 16-year-old daughter ''begged'' her boyfriend to do the killing and they discussed several nights on which to do it, according to an arrest warrant. 31 In the Howard Beach murder trial, an expert on the effects of drugs on human behavior testified that Michael Griffith had used cocaine too long before he died for it to have influenced his decision to run onto a highway. 31 Times Company and pressmen's union in tentative accord 31 Verdict set aside in mercury case 31 Officers and firefighters have history of ties 31

title: Exchanges' Merger Bid Advances
description: Efforts to combine New York's two biggest futures exchanges have moved one step closer to fruition, officials at the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Commodity Exchange Inc. said yesterday.

title: The Meeseful Wonder
description: Senator Orrin Hatch says there are gutless wonders at the White House. President Reagan says there isn't a single gutless wonder on the premises. Since these two usually see eye-to-eye on everything, the gutless-wonder dispute is a big, big story.

title: Knicks Foul Up, Bullets Convert
description: On a night when they expected Bernard King to make an emphatic statement concerning his feelings about being discarded, the Knicks were instead victimized by the dramatic performance of another familiar player.

title: REPLIGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a reversal of a tax credit of $291,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $831,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: FIRST FAMILY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss resulting from a $2,550,000 charge against earnings incurred when the company withdrew from the Southern California market. The company said during the first quarter of last year, when sales from the company's California ATA stores were included, First Family reported consolidated sales of $18.9 million.

title: Tech Star Ineligible
description: Riccardo Ingram's football and baseball career at Georgia Tech ended yesterday after the star senior admitted taking money from sports agents and signing a representation contract in violation of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. Athletic Director Homer Rice said the violations were reported to the N.C.A.A. and Ingram was declared ineligible for the remaining football games against Wake Forest and Georgia, as well as for the 1988 baseball season. ''I'm very sorry for what I did,'' said the defensive back, the leading tackler for the Yellow Jackets this fall and a .426 hitter with 17 home runs last spring.

title: Charges of Parent Sex Abuse, And a Family Left in Tatters
description: Elizabeth Morgan had a difficult choice: She could deliver her 5-year-old daughter for a court-ordered visit to the former husband she contends had been sexually abusing the child since infancy, or she could hide her, be held in contempt of court and go to jail.

title: COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Fourth Time Is a Charm
description: Eddie Robinson, the coach with the most victories in college football history, said he had never seen anything like it in 46 seasons at Grambling State University. On his fourth attempt, William Wrighten, a freshman, kicked a 21-yard field goal with no time remaining Thursday night to give South Carolina State a 15-13 victory over Grambling.

title: Exclusionary Club May Pose Problems for Judge Kennedy
description: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy's resignation from an all-male club here came after its members refused to admit women despite a threat of a lawsuit by the city.

title: MR GASKET CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: 7 Democrats Say White House Resisted Iran Panel
description: Seven of the nine House Democrats on the Congressional Iran-contra committees will attach a separate statement to the panels' report next week taking issue with the report's conclusion that the White House was fully cooperative with the Congressional inquiry.

title: William N. Bannard, Investment Counselor
description: William N. Bannard, a New York investment counselor, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. He was 69 years old.

title: 2 Government Aides Charged In Brazil Radiation Disaster
description: Two Government officials have been charged in connection with a radiation accident that has killed four Brazilians, the police said today.

title: GALA GOWNS ON A BUDGET: THE APPEAL OF RENT-A-DRESS
description: LEAD: Christine Birnie had been invited to a black-tie ball to celebrate a friend's 50th birthday. But she had a classic problem: nothing to wear. So on a rainy Tuesday morning three days before the party she went to One Night Stand, a shop in southwest London, where for $85 she rented a red-sequined, black-crepe Terence

title: DUCOMMUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net loss The company said the 1986 third quarter had benefited from the profitable performance of the Metermaster and Airdrome Parts Co. divisions, which were sold in the first quarter of 1987 for a gain of $8,291,000 and from $783,000 of deferred tax benefits, which sheltered part of last year's loss.

title: TV: Learning Channel Series on Cable
description: The Learning Channel is a cable service specializing in educational programs, offering formal and informal instruction, business and career information and assorted hobby and how-to series. The service is not available to cable subscribers in New York City, but one of its series, ''Likely Stories,'' has now been picked up in a one-time-only arrangement by Manhattan Cable.

title: CONSUMER GAS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

Ballet School's New Guiding Hand
description: Last spring, when Robert Lindgren was appointed to the new post of general manager of the School of American Ballet, the school of the New York City Ballet, no one was more surprised than Mr. Lindgren himself.

title: NELSON HOLDINGS INTERNAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company noted that prior to October 1986, it was a development stage entity and that comparison of operations with the year-ago period is not meaningful.

title:
Patents;
New Laser Gyroscope For Better Navigation
description: LEAD: A navigation instrument described as the world's first five-sided ring laser gyroscope was patented this week for the Northrop Corporation, which is based in Los Angeles. A spokesman predicted that the device would provide 10 percent to 30 percent more accuracy than the existing three-sided or four-sided laser instruments.

title: Quiet Day for the Dollar As Budget Talks Go On
description: The dollar was little changed in quiet trading yesterday.

title: Patriot Retiring
description: Steve Nelson, a mainstay at linebacker for the New England Patriots since coming out of North Dakota State as a second-round draft pick in 1974 and three times a Pro Bowl selection, said yesterday that he would retire after this season, his 14th in the National Football League.

title: MATRIX MEDICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Sees Progress With Allies
description: The Reagan Administration is confident that it will soon be able to promise its biggest allies lower Federal budget deficits and to assure them that it will avert a restrictive trade law, senior Administration officials said today.

title: City Opera: A Mozart and Knussen Pairing
description: ''Where the Wild Things Are,'' a children's opera for adults (and an adult opera for children, too) by Oliver Knussen and Maurice Sendak, lumbered happily into the New York State Theater Thursday night. The work, playing on a double bill with a version of Mozart's incomplete opera ''L'Oca del Cairo,'' will close out the New York City Opera season with four more performances through Sunday evening. It's a real delight, one of the best things the company has done. But it needs a better partner than the decidedly ungilded goose with which it now shares the stage.

title: Home Resales Off in Quarter
description: Sales of existing homes, hurt by rising mortgage rates, fell in 28 states during the peak summer sales season, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: Bangladesh Chief Talks Tough as Rioting Subsides
description: President H. M. Ershad, declaring he would no longer tolerate anti-Government riots, vowed today that arsonists and looters would be shot on sight.

title: Bronx Man Slain in Holdup
description: A 49-year-old grocery worker was fatally shot in a Bronx holdup yesterday evening, the police said. A spokesman, Officer Peter O'Donnell, said the robbery took place at 7:15 P.M. in a bodega at 1792 Westchester Avenue, in the borough's Clasons Point section. He said one of two intruders shot the worker, Jose Hernandez, of 1310 Rosedale Avenue in the Soundview section, in the right eye, and the victim died shortly thereafter at Bronx Municipal Hospital. The robbers escaped with between $200 and $300, Officer O'Donnell said.

title: ATLANTIC RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Times and Its Pressmen Tentatively Agree on a Pact
description: The New York Times Company and leaders of the newspaper's pressmen's union have tentatively agreed on terms of a labor contract considered crucial to proceeding with the newspaper's plans to invest $400 million in a new plant in New Jersey that will include color presses.

title: Give the 60's Generation a Break
description: With President Reagan's nomination of Judge Anthony M. Kennedy to the Supreme Court, the Ginsburg marijuana episode is gone, but not forgotten.

title: MIDWEST ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pretoria Reports 5 Died in Angola
description: Pretoria announced today that five more of its soldiers had been killed in southeastern Angola, in a further indication of a growing South African role in the 12-year-old Angolan civil war.

title: NECO ENTERPRISES reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $270,114. Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect the adoption of an accounting change related to the recognition of unbilled revenues.

title: 3 Devils Who Chased Fans Are Fined
description: The National Hockey League yesterday penalized the three Devils players who tried to climb out of the penalty box and get to spectators in Pittsburgh during New Jersey's 5-4 victory over the Penguins Oct. 21.

title: Singer Acts to Bar A Bid by Bilzerian
description: Determined to fight off a $1.1 billion hostile takeover bid by Paul A. Bilzerian, the corporate raider from Tampa, Fla., the Singer Company said yesterday that directors had instructed senior executives to open discussions with potential buyers -including those who have indicated an interest in the company.

title: Expert Rejects Drug Claim In the Howard Beach Death
description: An expert in the effects of drugs on human behavior testified yesterday that Michael Griffith had used cocaine too long before he died for the drug to have influenced his decision to run onto a highway in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: Dr. Lehan K. Tunks  Law School Dean, 72
description: Dr. Lehan K. Tunks, a former dean of law at Rutgers University and the University of Washington, died of lymphoma and acute respiratory distress in a Seattle nursing home Monday. He was 72 years old and lived in Seattle.

title: BROUGHER INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains on investments of $626 and $2,048 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a gain on stock sale by a subsidiary of $352,029. c-Net income and includes gains on investments of $7,984 for the quarter and $84,017 for the 9 months.

title: Michael S. Comay Is Dead at 79; An Influential Diplomat in Israel
description: Michael S. Comay, Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations in the 1960's and one of his nation's most influential diplomats, died Nov. 6 in Jerusalem. He was 79 years old.

title: Recital: Sandra Miller
description: Sandra Miller's Wednesday evening performance at Weill Recital Hall was the second of two concerts offering the solo flute Fantasias of Telemann and the accompanied sonatas of his contemporary and colleague, J. S. Bach. Ms. Miller played the flauto traverso, the valveless, largely wooden predecessor of the ''modern'' flute Boehm designed at the beginning of the 19th century.

title: The Editorial Notebook; By How to Invest Without Anxiety
description: Several years ago, while visiting Australia, I bought the remnants of what must have been an enormous 1930's dinner service: 41 pieces in all, some of it oddly and wonderfully shaped. I knew its age and its maker, and that I loved it. What I didn't know was the kind of money such stuff pulled in New York: a lot.

title: LANDS' END reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
10 Arrested in South Africa
description: The South African police arrested 10 youths at the Soweto township houses of anti-apartheid activist Winnie Mandela today. Mrs. Mandela, wife of the imprisoned black leader Nelson Mandela, said the police had surrounded one of her two houses, searched it and taken away five youths who had been staying there. She said they later went to a second house she owns and arrested another five youths. The police said the arrests were linked to an investigation of a robbery.

title: For Muscovites, Pravda Account of the Yeltsin Ouster Is Riveting Reading
description: Pravda offered Soviet citizens a rare look today at the purging of Boris N. Yeltsin by his peers in the Communist hierarchy.

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $3,372,000 and $11,041,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $6,434,000 and $15,456,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; tax credits of $398,000 for the quarter and $3,605,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also includes a pre-tax gain of $5,772,000 relating to Guaranty National Corp.'s public offering of common stock.

title: Strike Ends At Big Board
description: A three-day-old strike against the New York Stock Exchange ended yesterday when both sides agreed to a request from a Federal mediator to resume talks on Monday.

title: Hearth at Harvard, Heart and Soul at High Court
description: Laurence H. Tribe may have his office in the bookish confines of the Harvard Law School. But in a sense, his heart and soul lie 380 miles to the southwest, in Washington, at the United States Supreme Court.

title: Richard Rhodes and the Bomb
description: It took Richard Rhodes five years to research and write ''The Making of the Atomic Bomb'' - or two years longer than it took the nuclear scientists in New Mexico to make the bomb that was dropped on Hiroshima.

title: Buenos Aires Journal; Timerman, Stranger in Two More Strange Lands
description: Jacobo Timerman's impassioned pen, which once gave voice to the victims of repression in Argentina, has turned to two other troubled Latin American nations, Chile and Cuba.

title:
Patents;
Verifying Currency
description: LEAD: Authentication of currency is offered by a thin film device using optical interference and providing a color shift from gold to green. Patent No. 4,705,300, assigned to Optical Coating Laboratory Inc., of Santa Rosa, Calif., was granted this week to Peter H. Berning and Roger W. Phillips of the company staff.

title: Met Opera: Pavarotti Stars In New 'Trovatore' Staging
description: Normally it takes a new opera production years to decline to the point of terminal weariness and ineptitude, but the Metropolitan Opera's ''Trovatore'' reached that sad state in one evening, at Thursday night's premiere. Placing the blame precisely is not easy, simply because there is so much blame to go around. However, let us start with Richard Bonynge, who conducted lifelessly, apparently concerned with little more than keeping the orchestra down. That expedient did allow the famous voice of Joan Sutherland, his wife and the evening's Leonora, to be clearly heard. Unfortunately, it also helped drain most of the vitality from a Verdian score that must either overflow with the stuff or fall embarrassingly flat.

title: SAXON OIL DEVELOPMENT PARTNERS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Brock Is Planning a Shake-up Of Dole Campaign, Aides Say
description: A major shake-up in Senator Bob Dole's troubled Presidential organization is planned, aides to the Republican leader said tonight.

description: b-Net income

title: Simmer Adjusts To Here and Now
description: HE hasn't sought them out, but sports cliches have seemed to follow Charlie Simmer throughout his 14 seasons in the National Hockey League. Now that he's in Pittsburgh, they're still after him, still prominent even in his self-descriptions.

title: Hong Kong Inquiry
description: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange said today that in the wake of the global stock collapse it had appointed an accounting firm to help with market surveillance and that the financial position of seven small brokerages was being investigated. The exchange's senior chief executive, Robert Fell, said the trading activities of all seven had been suspended pending the findings of the accountants, Coopers & Lybrand.

title: GRANGES EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: RETAIL SALES BRISK AS PRICES DECLINE AT PRODUCER LEVEL
description: The nation's shoppers seem to have been largely unfazed by the stock-market plunge that began in mid-October, continuing to spend freely, the Commerce Department's monthly report on retail sales indicated today.

title: Senator Lugar Hurt in Fall
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, broke a bone in his face and suffered a cut over his eye when he slipped Thursday on his icy driveway in McLean, Va., a spokesman said. Mr. Lugar was treated at the Bethesda Naval Hospital and was released but will have to return next Wednesday to have the facial bone set, the spokesman, Andy Fisher, said. ''It's not very comfortable for him to speak or chew,'' he said.

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a reversal of a tax credit of $61,000 for the quarter and tax credits of $284,000 for the 9 months.

title: MICROBIOLOGICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1.1 million from the sale of the separations technology unit.

title: Mike Nichols to Receive Abbott Theater Award
description: Mike Nichols, who has won six Tony awards for directing and two more as a producer, will receive the third Mr. Abbott Award for lifetime achievement in the theater. The award will be presented Monday during a ceremony at the Astor Ballroom of the Marriott Marquis Hotel.

title: Vehicle Sales Rise In Period
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks totaled 228,665 units in the first 10 days of November, up 2.2 percent from the comparable period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today. There were eight selling days in the period both this year and last year.

title: Mother of Slain Girl, 6, Denied Visit With Son
description: A Family Court judge yesterday denied a request, at least temporarily, by Hedda Nussbaum to visit the 16-month-old boy whom she and her companion have been accused of abusing.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Elvis Franks, a defensive lineman who played seven National Football League seasons with the Cleveland Browns, the New York Jets and the Los Angeles Raiders, has pleaded guilty in Cleveland to conspiracy to distribute cocaine. He was arrested July 20 when police confiscated from his car four ounces of a substance believed to be cocaine and seized six ounces of the powder at his residence. Franks, 30 years old, faces up to 20 years in prison and a fine of up to $1 million. . . . Darryl Dawkins, the reserve center obtained from the Nets before the season, was reactivated by the Utah Jazz after an eight-day suspension without pay and was scheduled to be in uniform for the game last night against Phoenix. Dawkins, who left Utah after the death of his estranged wife, was placed on indefinite suspension last Saturday.

title: Girl Begged to Have Her Mother Killed, Document Reveals
description: A Glastonbury woman was murdered in August after her 16-year-old daughter ''begged'' her boyfriend to do the killing and they discussed several nights on which to do it, according to an arrest warrant unsealed today.

title: Who Are These Homeless People New York Is Hospitalizing?
description: To the Editor:

title: Push for Lights
description: Mayor Harold Washington of Chicago said yesterday that he would introduce an ordinance allowing the Cubs to play 18 home games at night in Wrigley Field, the only major-league ball park without lights. The proposal, which will be introduced in a City Council meeting next week, calls for 18 of the National League team's games to be played at night and seven in the late afternoon.

title: Factory Owners Guilty; Judge Sets Aside Verdict
description: A Brooklyn jury convicted the owners of a thermometer factory yesterday of assault for exposing workers to unsafe levels of mercury fumes, but a judge immediately set aside the verdict, saying Federal safety statutes pre-empt the state's jurisdiction.

title: Bring the Others in From the Cold
description: Joyce Brown's claim that she has a right to live on the street, supported this week by a judge, may stimulate dinner parties and Philosophy I discussions. But in practical terms, her case is beside the point. Sweeping the mentally ill off the streets makes no sense unless the authorities are in a position to care for them properly.

title: CHESS GAME IS DRAWN
description: The 13th game of the world chess championship between Gary Kasparov, and the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, ended in a draw today after 36 moves.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES CORRUPTION UNIT
description: Governor Cuomo called yesterday for the creation of a state investigative agency to combat ''systemic corrupution'' and racketeering in the multibillion-dollar construction industry in New York City.

title: JACK HENRY & ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Physician Awareness of Home Care Increasing
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Sans Graininess, A New Focus On Howdy Doody
description: In those days the picture was never good except in the showrooms and the studios but the people lucky enough to own a television always seemed to have gotten crystal clear reception the night before - the night before you were invited to look at the new marvel. ''Never seen it so bad,'' the hosts would say, fiddling with the rabbit ears.

title: FRANCE AND WEST GERMANY TO SET UP JOINT COUNCILS
description: The leaders of West Germany and France concluded a two-day meeting today with agreements to jointly develop a combat helicopter and to set up joint councils on military and economic policy.

title: CHINESE DISSIDENT SAID TO DIE IN JAIL
description: Amnesty International said that Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent political prisoner, is reported to have died in prison while serving a 15-year sentence for ''counterrevolutionary crimes.''

title: Big Hong Kong Bank To Buy 14.9% of Midland
description: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation has agreed to buy 14.9 percent of Midland Bank P.L.C., Britain's fourth-largest bank, for nearly $680 million, the two banks announced today.

description: Homeless Woman Still Held An appellate court stayed the release of a homeless woman who a judge said was inappropriately hospitalized by New York City. Page 29.

title: AM International Stake Purchased
description: AM International Inc. said that the Komori Printing Machinery Company, a Japanese printing concern, had purchased 6.4 percent of the company's common stock on the open market. In a filing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Komori said it had acquired the shares for ''investment purposes.''

title: Rift in Florida Government Deepens
description: Mired in a battle over the state's 5 percent tax on services and bogged down even more over medical malpractice insurance, the Florida Legislature and Gov. Bob Martinez are drifting deeper into a partisan fight with widespread consequences.

title: In the Heavy Rain and Fog
description: HE remembers coming out of a movie theater and suddenly hearing the news that would change his life, and now - whether in a work situation, or at a social function, or simply in a coffee shop - people still ask, ''Aren't you the one who missed that plane crash?''

title: Du Pont and Bush Taking Off Gloves
description: In the view of many Republican regulars, Vice President Bush landed an effective verbal punch on Pete du Pont at the first debate of the six candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination in Houston two weeks ago.

The company said this year's second quarter loss if after a $45 million writedown for its motion picture division. The writedown is a result of losses and reserves taken on the remaining five movies that were initiated under prior management of that division.

title: Alexandria Recovering Its Arab Soul
description: The myths have been stripped from this city, and the outsiders' fables of love and war are lost in the land they saw as only backdrop and metaphor.

description: * ARX Inc., Plainview, L.I., announced that it would purchase an additional 25 percent of common stock of VTX Electronics Inc., increasing its ownership in VTX to about 55 percent.

title: A SELECTION OF STYLISH SAMPLES
description: For the last two years, Honora Horan has run a small evening-dress rental business in New York called Pret-a-Party. She works by appointment, made by calling 212-696-9260, and charges from $75 to $150 for a rental, with a refundable deposit of $100 to $250, depending on the value of the dress and its fragility.

title: U.N. Body Calls for Widening of Test Ban Treaty
description: The United Nations moved today to expand a 1963 treaty into a complete ban on nuclear testing.

description: b-Includes a gain of $129,000 primarily from a tax credit for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes gains of $145,000 and $1,395,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, primarily from tax credits.

title: The Poor a Major Concern Of Judge in Homeless Case
description: Acting Justice Robert D. Lippmann of State Supreme Court, who ruled Thursday that a homeless woman, Joyce Brown, should be allowed to return to a life on the streets, is a well-respected judge and a former lawyer with the Legal Aid Society who has long been known for his interest in housing for the poor.

title: Soviet to Let 2 Women Join Husbands in U.S.
description: Two of three Soviet citizens who appealed to join their spouses in the United States have been given permission to leave the Soviet Union, one of the three said today.

title: NVRYAN LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The partnership said that the increase in sales and net is due to the acquisition of Ryan Homes Inc. in June. The shares outstanding are in units.

title: Rent Control as a Cause of Homelessness
description: LEAD: Not long ago, a New York City housing expert observed that the city was by no means suffering a shortage of low-income housing. The problem, he said, is that it is occupied by the rich. In posing the city's housing problems this way, he put his finger (perhaps unwittingly) on what may be the major cause of homelessness - rent controls, which stymie the natural development of the housing market.

The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect the 2-for-1 split in the form of a dividend paid Nov. 17, 1986.

title: U.S. Closes Savings and Loan And Shifts Insured Deposits
description: Federal regulators today closed the Tri-County Savings and Loan Association because it was insolvent and transferred its insured deposits to a Pennsylvania-based savings institution.

title: Trainer Appealing Ban
description: Peter Ferriola, whose training license was ordered suspended for 120 days Thursday after charges he violated state medication rules, has obtained a stay of the ruling that will allow him to continue training pending a hearing Nov. 23.

title: Zhao Ziyang, on Mao and China's Future
description: Three days after becoming Secretary General of China's Communist Party, Zhao Ziyang relaxed over dinner at the leadership compound of Zhongnanhai in the Forbidden City and told how Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader, had insisted on stepping down ''before my mind becomes confused.''

title: Eastern's Shuttle to Be Autonomous
description: Eastern Airlines is turning its famous and profitable shuttle into an autonomous division with its own budget, work force, fleet and management, an Eastern official said yesterday.

title: Two Women Killed In Jersey House Fire
description: A woman honored for saving a friend from fire has died along with the friend in another blaze in their home here, the authorities said.

title: Bridge:; Couple Denied an Injunction In Tournament Sex Bias Suit
description: The American Contract Bridge League scored a significant, although not decisive, legal victory Thursday in a Los Angeles court.

Welfare's Day Care Corollary
description: Welfare reform legislation working its way through Congress reflects a developing national consensus: Benefits for poor families ought to be linked to their willingness to work. That's all to the good, so long as the lawmakers recognize a crucial corollary. Most of those families are headed by women. It's meaningless to talk of work for them without equal enthusiasm about day care.

title: Random House Head To Get Rights Award
description: Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Random House, has been named this year's recipient of the Human Rights Award from the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. The award is given annually to individuals who work for the cause of human rights; last year's recipient was Corazon Aquino.

title: TV Dumping Cited by U.S.
description: The Commerce Department said today that color television picture tubes from four countries were being sold at unfairly low prices in the United States.

title: Dukakis Political Campaign Releases Personal Records
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, a Democratic Presidential contender, reported $87,714 in income in 1986, finished 71st in a class of 468 at Harvard Law School and graduated with highest honors from Swarthmore College, despite a D in physics. In addition, he was never tardy in high school.

title: ESCAPE TESTS SET ON SPACE SHUTTLE
description: Small rockets that could eject astronauts through a hatch in the space shuttle and a telescoping pole on which they could slide through it will be tested later this month as possible escape systems, the space agency reports.

title: 40 Are Killed in Mexico City As Bus Overturns Into Lake
description: A city bus packed with schoolchildren and workers skidded off a dirt road and flipped onto its roof in a shallow lake today, killing 40 people and injuring 5, the authorities said.

title: INVESTMENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Investment Technologies is a development stage company.

description: In the desert mountain ranges dotted with creosote bushes and prickly pear cactuses, the Phelps Dodge Corporation has helped bring about a fundamental change in the economics of mining copper.

title: Valery A. Belikov  Soviet Commander in East Germany, 62
description: Gen. Valery A. Belikov, commander in chief of Soviet forces in East Germany, died of a heart attack Thursday, the official East German press agency reported today. He was 62 years old.

title: Young 49ers' Starter
description: Steve Young will start at quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers on Sunday, Coach Bill Walsh announced after yesterday's practice, and Joe Montana's status remains in doubt for the important game against the New Orleans Saints.

title: Rates on Treasury Issues Rise
description: Interest rates for Treasury issues of all maturities rose yesterday. Investor demand was lackluster and many securities dealers were unwilling to support the market if it meant accumulating large inventories.

title: Khan Beats Dittmar in 4 Sets
description: Jansher Khan of Pakistan reasserted his claim as the world's top squash racquets player last night with a 15-7, 11-15, 15-1, 15-7 victory over Chris Dittmar of Australia in the Rolex United States Open championship at the Palladium nightclub in Manhattan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. North Stars Win: Brian Bellows's power-play goal with 6 minutes 28 seconds to play last night gave Minnesota a 5-4 victory at Buffalo. The Sabres, trailing by 4-2 after two periods, tied the score on early third-period goals by Phil Housley and Scott Arneil. But with Calle Johansson of Buffalo in the penalty box for tripping, Steve Payne trapped the puck along the boards and relayed it to Brian Lawton, who immediately found Bellows. Bellows fired a 15-footer from the slot past Darren Puppa for his 12th goal.(AP) Kings Score 7, but Flames Score 10: In Calgary, Alberta, Carey Wilson scored twice in a five-goal second period as the Flames outscored the Kings, 10-7. Wilson triggered the five-goal outburst with a power-play goal at 1:42 to give the Flames a 4-2 lead. After Tom Laidlaw of the Kings made the score 4-3 at 3:03, Gary Roberts, Jim Peplinski, Neil Sheehy and Wilson scored in an 8:50 span to give the Flames an 8-3 lead. The Flames outshot the Kings, 44-43.(AP) Tennis Cash Falls to Jarryd: Anders Jarryd defeated Pat Cash, 3-6, 7-6, 6-2, yesterday in a controversy-filled quarterfinal match at the Benson and Hedges indoor championship in Wembley, England. Earlier, Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, outlasted Paul Annacone, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, to advance to a semifinal match against Henri Leconte, who had defeated sixth-seeded Amos Mansdorf. Jarryd's semifinal opponent will be Jacob Hlasek, who upset second-seeded Miloslav Mecir, 6-3, 6-3.

title: MMI MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Correction
description: A picture caption on Friday with an article about the Literary Lions dinner at the New York Public Library Wednesday night misidentified the woman pictured with Harold Pinter and Marietta Tree. She was Kathleen Tynan.

title: MODERN CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Correction
description: A Travel Advisory report in the Travel section today about Dublin's 1,000th birthday lists an incorrect address for the Irish Tourist Board. The correct address is 757 Third Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017.

title: Bokassa Sentence Upheld
description: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal for a retrial by Jean-Bedel Bokassa, sentenced to death last June for crimes committed during his 13-year rule. His lawyers had argued that a former head of state could be tried only on treason charges.

title: A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
description: Ever since reading Edwin Abbott's Victorian science-fiction classic ''Flatland'' during my college days, I've held that modern man's belief in science and his faith in religion were not contradictory mindsets. I'm even more convinced after reading K. C. Cole's article ''A Theory of Everything'' (Oct. 18), on physicist Edward Witten and string theory.

title: A SAMPLER OF SOURCES FOR HOLIDAY FOOD SHOPPING
description: LEAD: AS the most exuberant time of the year unfolds, hosts and hostesses everywhere will be carving out hours from their busy schedules in order to celebrate with family and friends the joys of the season. It is a time for treats and surprises. Clearly something more than workaday comestibles are in order.

title: Correction
description: ''Home Remedies,'' an article about indoor pollutants on Sept. 27 in The Good Health Magazine, part 2 of The Times Magazine, misidentified a harmful substance released in excessive amounts by malfunctioning gas appliances. It is carbon monoxide.

title: 8-TO-5:30 SCHOOL IS PRAISED
description: LEAD: WHEN a neighbor of the new Cold Spring School in Fair Haven learned that the school was in session from 8 A.M. until 5:30 P.M., she said that ''children should not sit at desks looking at a blackboard all day.'' On visiting, however, she found no desks or blackboards, and she concluded, mistakenly, that it was a school for youngsters with learning problems.

title: FICTION
description: JACOB'S LADDER. By John A. Williams. (Thunder's Mouth Press, $13.95.) If John A. Williams had simply written a political thriller set in West Africa in the 1960's, then ''Jacob's Ladder'' might have emerged as a well-written genre novel featuring a number of sensitive evocations of landscape and mood. But Mr. Williams, a former journalist in Africa and the author of numerous books of fiction and nonfiction, has something to say about blacks who are caught between Africa and the West, and to get it across he has contrived a plot that never allows belief to settle in. Jake Henry, the son of black American missionaries, has been sent as a military attache to Pandemi, the African country where he spent his boyhood. As an agent of the United States, his mission is to destroy the nuclear reactor his long-lost friend Fasseke, now President of Pandemi, is about to unveil. But the African past begins to reach out and arouse Jake's deeply suppressed anger. Through this gradual awakening, which may or may not occur in time to enable Jake to thwart the C.I.A.'s plot, Mr. Williams introduces his basic message: that no matter how far a black goes in America he will never be respected and that his soul inevitably lingers among his brothers across the ocean. Most American thrillers have a right-wing bias without really acknowledging it. ''Jacob's Ladder'' belongs to the sentimental left, and is so persistent about its point that the story hits a roadblock at every turn: Halt for the meaning. But the themes of African independence and black identity are too important and too complex to be presented in such a fashion.

title: GUSSYING UP THE PLAIN BLACK BOX
description: TODAY, the person buying a radar detector often drives a Mercedes or BMW; a decade ago detectors were purchased by truckers and would-be auto racers. It took a while, but detector makers gradually tuned in the upscale market, and business hasn't been the same since.

title: BUS DRIVERS TAKING RIDER-RELATIONS CLASSES
description: AFTER a long day in heavy traffic, it is easy for a bus driver's nerves to frazzle, and learning to deal with stress and not take it out on overbearing passengers takes training, say NJ Transit officials.

title: Boulez Forgets To Forget
description: I KNOW IT ISN'T FAIR TO FOLLOW CELEBRATED thinkers around waiting for them to contradict themselves. But who ever said critics were fair? Of all living composers, perhaps Pierre Boulez has put the most stock in logical argument. Even his famous polemics in behalf of his own works, though transparent propaganda of an elevated sort, have always had an air of indisputable rationality about them. From the deliberately inflammatory essay ''Schoenberg Is Dead'' in 1951 to the recent encyclicals in behalf of his experiments in high-tech acoustical research, he has worked hard at sustaining the image of the composer as logician.

title: CAR PHONE USE RISES RAPIDLY
description: LEAD: ONE day last October, Art Barber, the owner of an excavation company in Ellington, was driving his truck down Omelia Road in East Windsor. He noticed that a trailer truck, traveling in the opposite direction, carried some equipment that he had recently reported stolen. He picked up his celluar telephone, called the East Windsor police and followed the trailer.
