title: CUNY Official Sees Problems in Cutting Loan Default Rates
description: The City University of New York will be hard-pressed to meet proposed Federal goals to reduce student loan default rates at many of its colleges, according to the university's director of financial aid.

title: Portfolio Insurance Poses the Danger
description: IN a recent interview, Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested that program trading was a major cause of the Oct. 19 crash in stock prices. ''It's very hard not to rail at the index futures markets - I don't think these techniques add much to the sum of human endeavor,'' he said. Many individual investors and institutional money managers share Mr. Volcker's view.

title: A NEWCOMER FOR AUTO-FOCUSING
description: NO sooner do I finish complaining about the limitations of auto-focusing cameras than one camera maker makes me eat my words. Specifically, I recently groused that auto-focusing sensors always aim dead center in the middle of the picture. This forces picture takers either to frame their subjects accordingly, or to use the pesky ''focus hold'' feature (if the camera provides it). For all that trouble, one might as well focus manually.

title: CHAMPION PIANISTS AND COMIC OPERAS
description: TWO comic operas by Donizetti, in Hartford and Bridgeport, are vying for attention with the three prize-winners from the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition, in Hartford, New Haven and Greenwich.

title: Question Of the Week; Will Free Agents Be Signed in Baseball?
description: There will be dozens of free agentssigned in baseball, just like last year, and they'll sign with the same team they played for this year, except for one major player, Jack Morris. George is fed up with his second-banana status, and he'll make Jack an offer he can't refuse. JEFF MARINER New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: Social Events
description: Evenings on the Town New Plays Nov. 16 - The Circle Repertory Theater, a leading Off Broadway showcase for new American plays, will present six short new works by playwrights including Lanford Wilson and Terrence McNally at a benefit for the company at the Equitable Center, 787 Seventh Avenue near 51st Street. Cocktails at 7 P.M. will be followed by the performance, dinner and dancing to a 17-piece swing band. Tickets $250; 212-691-3210. Blues at the Palladium Nov. 16 - The Association to Benefit Children provides a day-care program at the Martinique Hotel, the city's largest welfare hotel, and facilities for 220 homeless preschool children at 12 East 96th Street. Starting at 9 P.M. at the Palladium, 126 East 14th Street, the association will hold a ''Night of Blues'' with John Hammond, the Bluesbusters, Dr. John and Bobby Radcliff and the Homewreckers to raise funds for the programs. Tickets are $75 including buffet, $40 for general admission or $50 at the door; 212-996-4166 A Broadway Salute Nov. 16 - A ''Star-Spangled Broadway Salute to James N. Nederlander'' will establish an endowment fund for the National Hypertension Association and honor the Nederlander Organization, owner of 11 Broadway houses. The evening at Avery Fisher Hall starts with a Champagne reception at 6 P.M., followed by the performance with Peter Allen, Ann Reinking, Frank Langella, Jackie Mason and Jerry Herman and then dinner. Tickets $500, $250 for reception and performance or $125 for the performance; 212-889-3557. Briefly Noted: Nov. 16 - Mayor Koch; the Ambassador to Hungary, Mark Palmer, and officials from Hungary head the speakers' list at a tribute to the heritage of Eastern European Jewry. The black-tie dinner at the Grand Hyatt Hotel, starting with 6:30 P.M. cocktails, will benefit the Emanuel Foundation for Hungarian Culture and the World Federation of Hungarian Jews. Tickets $150; 212-302-6677. Nov. 16 - Mike Nichols, the director, will be honored with the ''Mr. Abbott Award'' for lifetime achievement in the theater at a black-tie benefit for the Stage Directors and Choreographers Workshop Foundation at the Marriott Marquis Hotel. Cocktails at 7 P.M. followed by dinner and a celebrity tribute. Tickets $200; 212-865-1812. Nov. 16 - Toni Morrison, Benno C. Schmidt Jr. and Jacobo Timerman are due to be the guests of honor at a black-tie benefit dinner for the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights at the New York Hilton. Cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets $500; 212-861-7084. Nov. 17 - Zoe Caldwell, Hume Cronyn and Jose Ferrer are due to be honored at a dinner benefit for Theater for a New Audience, at the starting with 6:30 P.M. cocktails at the Regency. Tickets $300; 212-505-8345. Nov. 17 - Tony Randall will be the toastmaster and Phyllis Hyman will entertain at the annual human services award dinner of Cancer Care at the Waldorf-Astoria. Tickets $350; 212-997-0100. Nov. 17 - Cocktails at 7:30 P.M. followed by dinner, dancing and boutique shopping at the Grand Hyatt Hotel will benefit the Jewish Guild for the Blind. Black tie. Tickets $300; 212-769-6240. Nov. 17 - The pianist Byron Janis will play at the New York Arthritis Foundation's annual black-tie founder's award dinner at the Pierre, starting with 6:30 P.M. cocktails. Dennis Weatherstone, president of J. P. Morgan & Company, will be honored. Tickets $500; 212-477-8347. Nov. 17 - The American Red Cross in Greater New York will honor Dina Merrill, the actress, at its annual black-tie dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria's Starlight Roof. Cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets $350; 212-870-8896. Nov. 18 - From 6 to 10 P.M. at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street there will be a Champagne buffet to preview the exposition ''Modernism: A Century of Style and Design, 1860 to 1960.'' The evening will benefit the Brooklyn Museum. Tickets $100; 718-638-5000, extension 326. Gamboling at the Hilton Nov. 20 - There will be games of chance with such prizes as new cars, furs, Mexican vacations, luggage, perfume and linens. Over the past 26 years, the annual ''Gamboling Gala'' has raised more than $6 million for United Cerebral Palsy at one of the city's more freewheeling benefits. The black-tie party starts with 7 P.M. cocktails at the New York Hilton and proceeds through a buffet dinner, dancing, games of chance and an early morning breakfast. Tickets $500; 212-683-6700, extension 206. Literary Dinners Nov. 20 - Isaac Asimov, Roy Blount Jr., Mary Higgins Clark, Gael Greene and Calvin Trillin are some of the writers who will attend nine dinner parties in Manhattan. Starting with 7:30 P.M. Champagne, the dinner parties, sponsored by the New York Book Fair for the Homeless Committee, will benefit the Goddard-Riverside Community Center. Tickets $125; 212-873-6600.

title: Detroit Symphony's Future Clouded by Strike
description: When General Motors and the United Automobile Workers settled their contract negotiations earlier this year without so much as a threat of a strike, both sides proclaimed that a new era of labor-management relations had arrived in the Motor City.

title: REAGAN AND WRIGHT CAUGHT UP IN FEUD
description: The relationship between President Reagan and Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, has deteriorated so badly that it is complicating efforts to arrange compromises on domestic and foreign policy, officials in the White House and on Capitol Hill say.

title: Louise Law Is Married To David Wayne Hoyle
description: Kathryn Louise Law, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Teets Law Jr. of Tenafly, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Wayne Hoyle, a son of the late Rev. and Mrs. Wayne Edmond Hoyle of Excelsior, Minn. The Rev. John Croneberger performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Atonement.

title: New Routes, New Rooms
description: JUDGING by the investment in major new resorts on seven islands and the expansion of hotels and inns on most of the others, optimism on the prospects for tourism in the Caribbean and the Bahamas seems to be as pervasive as straw hats and tanning lotion. Islands where big new resorts have or are about to open are Anguilla, Antigua, Grand Cayman, the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, the French side of St. Martin and the Turks and Caicos.

title: LOCKBAUM LIFTS HOLY CROSS TO 10-0
description: Jeff Wiley and Gordie Lockbaum led unbeaten Holy Cross, the No. 1 team in Division I-AA, to a 40-7 rout of William & Mary today.

title: Abbie Hoffman Sues for Vote
description: Abbie Hoffman filed suit in Federal court here Thursday to force election officials to count his absentee ballot in the town of New Hope, which could decide the community's deadlocked borough council race.

title: Atlanta Expects $60 Million From Convention
description: Businesses in Atlanta could earn nearly $60 million from the Democratic National Convention next summer, and even more if the party's Presidential nomination has not been decided by the time delegates arrive July 18.

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
N.A.A.C.P. SUIT
description: LEAD: Judge S. Anthony Gibson of Atlantic County Superior Court has refused temporarily to hear arguments in a suit challenging the election of the president of the New Jersey chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. The election took place last month at the association's state convention in Atlantic City.

title: LAW OFFICES FOR NEWARK
description: THE Newark Legal and Communications Center, a $73.8 million project to provide downtown office space for law firms, is finally becoming a reality.

title: Wintering On Florida's Panhandle
description: RACHEL JACKSON, accompanying Andrew when he took control of Pensacola in 1821, prayed to be delivered from the ''vast, howling wilderness'' of the Florida panhandle. Shortly after the Civil War, residents of Florida's peninsula seriously considered ridding their state of a nuisance by ceding its entire western arm to Alabama for a million dollars. But even that largely landlocked state rejected what many Alabamians scornfully described as ''a sand bank and gopher region.''

title: PRESERVATION OF TESTS IN DRUNKEN DRIVING RULED UNNECESSARY
description: Police officers are not required to preserve breath samples for drunken driving suspects who may want to challenge the validity of Breathalyzer tests later, New York's highest court has ruled.

title: FOOLING AROUND AND OTHER FAMILY HABITS
description: TIME WITH CHILDREN By Elizabeth Tallent. 158 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Syracuse Rolls On To 10-0
description: Trailing Boston College by 17-0 early in the second quarter today, the undefeated Syracuse football team gave its fans, its coaches and the Sugar Bowl officials something to worry about. But not for long.

title: Negotiations Continue On Jersey Beach Trash
description: Attorneys for New Jersey and New York City negotiated by telephone today in an effort to settle out of court the dispute about trash that washed up on New Jersey beaches over the summer.

title: Classical Music
description: When music followers talk about the good old days of instrumental performance, it is never quite clear what they mean. In general, this is intended as a reference to the Romantic school and its progeny, but what was that? After all, there are those who grew out of this 19th-century tradition with a taste for frank emotionalism and textual liberty-taking, and there also are those who favor removed, intellectualized interpretations. Two musicians scheduled to play this week in the city, both of them famed veteran players, illustrate the point rather well.

title: Helms Expresses an Interest In Running for Vice President
description: Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, one of the Senate's most outspoken conservatives, said Friday he might be interested in the Republican vice presidential nomination if the job could be tailored to his liking.

title: MUSIC
description: Bobby McFerrin: Spontaneous Inventions Directed by Bud Schaetzle. 1986. HBO/Cannon Video. 48 minutes. $29.95. Bobby McFerrin's array of vocal techniques - hums, clicks, hisses, glottal stops, chest thumps - enables him to mimic a cappella an entire jazz ensemble. In each tune he seems to find a new way to accompany himself.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-22

title: Jet Crash Hearing to Focus on Alarm Failure
description: If the pilots of the Northwest Airlines jetliner that crashed in Detroit in August forgot a key step needed for a safe takeoff, as almost all safety experts agree, why did the plane's automatic warning system fail to sound the alarm?

title: Albany Plan for Pesticide Warnings Is Criticized
description: Proposed state regulations that would require businesses and homeowners to post warnings of pesticide sprayings are being challenged by a coalition of restaurant owners, farmers and the pest-control industry.

title: INSIDE
description: Covert Action Curb The Congressional Iran-contra committees' report will recommend new rules for reporting covert operations, Congressional officials say. Page 20. Role for Afghan King After 14 years of exile, the Afghan King is being mentioned as a possible key figure in a pact to end the Soviet presence in his country. Page 3. Turmoil in Dole Campaign Bob Dole is shaking up his campaign organization; a review found it far weaker than the candidate. Page 36.

title: Dr. Susan Mandel Engaged to Wed Dr. B. J. Kashdan
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Perry R. Mandel of Glen Cove, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Susan Elizabeth Mandel, to Dr. Bennett Jay Kashdan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kashdan of Fort Lee, N.J. A February wedding is planned.

title: On Language; Too Clever By Three-Quarters
description: SOVIET SUMMITRY:

title: Heidi Solomon Is Married
description: Heidi Gretchen Regina Solomon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Solomon of Media, Pa., was married yesterday to Peter Robert Barnett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Barnett of Hobart, Australia. Rabbi Mayer Selekman performed the ceremony at Temple Sholom in Broomall, Pa. The bride is director of sales promotion at the American Society of Chartered Life Underwriters and Chartered Financial Consultants in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: WHY 'ONCE A HERO' IS NO MORE
description: DUSTY KAY COULDN'T EVEN produce an ashtray. ''I don't have a thing left here except this can of Hawaiian Punch,'' the television producer said with a scowl, surveying his large, virtually barren corner office for a place to discard his cigarette. He found only packing cartons.

title: MOTEL'S RATRES FOR HOMELESS DRAW CRITICISM
description: LEAD: ''THIS is Howard Johnson's?''

title: Chicago Man, 22, Is Charged With Anti-Jewish Vandalism
description: A 22-year-old man charged with breaking windows and painting swastikas on the walls of a Jewish meat market may have been involved in other vandalism acts against Jewish-owned businesses, the police say.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Suspense spreads over varied locales in this week films - a desolate Los Angeles police station, a small-town Texas bar, a high-rise Manhattan publishing office, a ski resort in St. Moritz and a London theater.

title: Dole Enters, Targeting Bush
description: SENATOR BOB DOLE, Republican of Kansas, last week became the last of the people who have said they are running for President to make his race official. Mr. Dole's aim is to wrest the Republican nomination from Vice President Bush, and his message was carefully chosen to highlight the frontrunner's vulnerabilities as a man of privilege and as a second-in-command.

title: 'Safer Sex' Shop at Stanford
description: ''Ye Olde Safer Sex Shoppe'' has opened at Stanford University, offering information and products aimed at slowing the spread of AIDS. The shop, which is actually just a table where condoms and other items are sold, is sponsored by an AIDS education project with approval from administrators and student groups. Customers wanting more privacy may obtain the materials at the project headquarters. All products are sold at cost.

title: Carla Friedman Weds Robert Karen, Banker
description: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue, Carla Renee Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philmore H. Friedman of Jericho and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married last night to Robert Karen, a son of Mrs. Murry Schulman of Hollis Hills, Queens, and the late Joseph Karen. Rabbi Louis Bernstein performed the ceremony.

title: Irving Lazar Is to Auction Hite's New Book
description: Shere Hite has retained the literary agent Irving Lazar to auction the paperback rights to her book ''Women and Love,'' which has come under increasing attack by academic specialists.

title: Iraqis Say Warplanes Hit Iranian Oil Targets
description: Iraqi aircraft attacked and set ablaze three oil sites in northwestern Iran today, Iraq's high command said.

title: HERE COMES NOBODY
description: LEAD: XMAN By Michael Brodsky. 539 pp. P.O. Box 548, Village Station, New York: Four Walls Eight Windows. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: PRESENTING KABUKI FOR THE COMMON MAN
description: ''TAISHU ENGEKI'' IN JAPANESE means theater for the masses. Some people call it working-class Kabuki, and that's exactly what it is.

title: IN DEFENSE OF THE DINER
description: Barbara Klaus's ''Therapy at the Diner'' [ Long Island Sound, Oct. 25 ] attempts to malign the diner, an institution that students of American culture, artists and photographers have recognized as a most significant expression of the American way of life. So much so that the Smithsonian has gone to great length to locate an early classic version to be shipped to Washington and displayed there.

title: Dr. Cathy A. Colt Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A. Colt of Sharon, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Cathy Ann Colt to Dr. Roger James Pomerantz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pomerantz of Scarsdale, N.Y. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: Toxic Cleanup Puzzle Pondered at Conference
description: The conference was billed as a search to unlock ''environmental gridlock'' - to quicken the pace of cleanup of polluted land, air and water.

title: The Dream House
description: To the Editor:

title: Claudette Irene Gabriel Weds Omer T. Karabey
description: Claudette Irene Gabriel, a daughter of Serge G. Gabriel of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Irene Brofos Gabriel, was married yesterday to Omer Turhan Karabey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ismet Karabey of Istanbul, Turkey. The Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: WORLD WAR II AS A SOVIET PLOT
description: STALIN'S WAR A Radical New Theory of the Origins of the Second World War. By Ernst Topitsch. Translated by A. Taylor and B. E. Taylor. 152 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $19.95.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
Fresh Start for a Newark Neighborhood
description: LEAD: IN the two decades since Newark fell on economic hard times, the city has slowly been struggling back. Signs of its progress are evident in the downtown business district, where a half dozen new office buildings have been built and work is progressing on several others.

title: POSTINGS: Battery Park City; 180 Units in 9 Stories
description: Most anywhere in Manhattan, a 180-unit condominium project would likely climb 30 or 40 stories high. But not in Battery Park City. A few days ago, construction crews began excavating a one-acre foundation for a building that will rise only nine stories - in accordance with design guidelines established by the Battery Park City Authority.

title:
GARDENING;
THE CHALLENGE OF PROPAGATING PLANTS
description: LEAD: FOR the person who is really into gardening, there is a special satisfaction that comes from propagating one's own plants. Annuals, of course, are pretty easy, some perennials are a bit more difficult, but the woody plants are really a challenge.

title: SYRACUSE IS TOUGH AGAIN: KNIGHT IS TOUGH, AS ALWAYS
description: IT was a matter of 1 point, but the difference between the champion and runner-up is always greater than the margin of the final score. To a certain extent, making up that difference is why Rony Seikaly returned to Syracuse this season, when the Orangemen will attempt to win the national championship that slipped away last spring. If they are to be successful, Seikaly must live up to his billing as the best big man in college basketball.

title: Question Of the Week; Will Free Agents Be Signed in Baseball?
description: No. I sincerely do not think free agents will be signed in baseball.

title: Trumpet: Frank Gordon
description: FRANK GORDON, a jazz trumpeter, put together a bristling sextet for ''Clarion Echoes,'' his debut album on the Soul Note label. But for his concert Friday at Cooper Union, Mr. Gordon chose to work in a quartet format, playing standards and blues backed by James Williams on piano, Victor Gaskin on bass and Victor Jones on drums.

title: ONE COMMUTER'S CHOICE: GO BY BIKE
description: LIFE is a process of choices, most people like to believe.

title:
DINING OUT;
ALLAMUCHY: LEBANESE? NO, ITALIAN
description: LEAD: HACKETTSTOWN is known more as the home of Centenary College than for its few restaurants. And so we were intrigued when we began to get recommendations from, among others, a member of the college faculty for an Italian continental restaurant in nearby Allamuchy called Villa Mattar.

title: Managua Accepts American Role in Truce Talks
description: The Nicaraguan Government has agreed to accept a four-member team of American mediators as part of its effort to reach a cease-fire with United States-backed contra guerrillas, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today.

title: Salvador Frees Two Guerrillas
description: Two leftist guerrillas linked to the 1983 slaying of a United States military adviser have been ordered released under an amnesty program that is part of the Central American peace plan.

title: GROWING UP TO BE A FIREMAN: REALITY MATCHES THE DREAM
description: IMAGINE volunteering to be a surgeon, a pilot or a train engineer. Imagine if every man could spend some of his time doing what he aspired to do as a boy. Just by offering. Just for the fun of it. I do. I'm a volunteer firefighter.

title: IMMUNIZATION IS THE THEME OF A NEW SERIES
description: ON Friday the United Nations Postal Administration will issue a six-stamp set with the theme ''Immunize Every Child.'' The release publicizes efforts of the World Health Organization (W.H.O) and the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef) to immunize children by 1990 against the six major communicable diseases: diptheria, measles, poliomyelitis, tetanus, tuberculosis and whooping cough.

title: THE LINDBERGH KIDNAPPING: ANOTHER BOOK, ANOTHER CHAPTER
description: IT'S Jersey Justice on trial again - or so it seems to Jim Fisher, author of ''The Lindbergh Case'' (Rutgers University Press, New Brunswick, $22.95).

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Beautiful Swamp
description: LEAD: REALM OF THE ALLIGATOR National Geographic special, 1986. Vestron Video. 59 minutes. $29.98.

title: Hong Kong
description: To the Editor: We recently traveled to Hong Kong and took a copy of the article ''What's Doing in Hong Kong'' (Travel, April 26) with us.

title: Giving New Life to Philadelphia's Skyline
description: THE WAY PEOPLE TALKED about One Liberty Place when plans for this skyscraper were announced a few years ago, you would have thought that this was not a new building but some sort of nuclear weapon. One Liberty Place would be the ruination of Philadelphia, cried the project's opponents, the sign that this somewhat genteel city had sold out to real-estate developers and become just like anyplace else.

title: Planned Parenthood Warns of Abortion Surge
description: A study by Planned Parenthood projects a rapid increase in live births, maternal deaths and self-induced abortions worldwide if the Reagan Administration proceeds with a planned cutoff of funds for the group's international division.

title: Benevolent Boxer
description: IT was just a four-round exhibition to raise money for charity, and, appropriately enough, Mike Tyson seemed to be in an especially charitable frame of mind when he squared off against James (Quick) Tillis in Chicago Friday night. Anything but his usually fierce self, Tyson played around in the ring, caressing Tillis with weak jabs and flimsy punches.

title: The Embattled Mrs. Aquino
description: A GLIMPSE OF THE BEDSIDE READING OF President Corazon C. Aquino only deepens the riddle presented by this most unusual and misunderstood leader. On a low table, beside her bed with its flowered coverlet, in her cool and quiet house surrounded by sandbagged bunkers, light reading is notably absent. Along with books on Philippine politics and Jimmy and Rosalynn Carter's ''Everything to Gain'' are two volumes of sharply contrasting political philosophies: a collection of quotations from Mohandas K. Gandhi alongside ''The Prince'' by Niccolo Machiavelli.

title: 'I DO NOT BELIEVE IN GHOSTS'
description: ANGELS FEAR Towards an Epistemology of the Sacred. By Gregory Bateson and Mary Catherine Bateson. 224 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95.

title: FINDING A ROLE IN A QUEST FOR PEACE
description: FOR Bianca Jagger, the year 1979 was portentous. That was the year she divorced the rock star Mick Jagger and the Somoza dictatorship was overthrown by Sandinista revolutionaries in her native Nicaragua.

title: AS AMERICAN AS CHEESECAKE
description: MISS AMERICA, 1945 Bess Myerson's Own Story. By Susan Dworkin. Illustrated. 229 pp. New York: Newmarket Press. $18.95.

title: MILESTONE MARKED IN ADULT EDUCATION
description: LEAD: IN 1962, Sarah Lawrence College opened its doors wider, becoming the first private college in the country to create a degree program for adult women. Thirty-three students, most from Westchester and most in their 30's and 40's, enrolled at the Center for Continuing Education.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THROUGH DIFFERENT EYES: Two Leading Americans - A Jew and an Arab - Debate U.S. Policy in the Middle East. By Hyman Bookbinder and James G. Abourezk. Moderated by David K. Shipler. (Adler & Adler, $18.95.) What a nice idea for a public affairs book, someone must have thought. Bring together a leading American Jewish spokesman and an American Arab counterpart.

title: Booklet Seeks to Lower School Dropout Rate
description: The Reagan Administration and school superintendents from large cities have issued a guide to combat the problems that lead more than 3,700 teen-agers to drop out of high school every day.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CHERNOBYL. By Frederik Pohl. (Bantam, $18.95.) According to his afterword, much of the technical information in Frederik Pohl's fictional account of the catastrophic accident at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant comes from the unusually forthcoming report the Russians submitted to the International Atomic Energy Authority in September 1986 and from interviews he conducted on a visit to the Soviet Union.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a large bluestone patio about 10 years old, and some of the cement between the flags is coming out of the joints. Can you tell us how to handle this problem?

title: Looking Away At Marathon
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE GOLD CADILLAC Mildred D. Taylor. Illustrated by Michael Hays. 43 pp. New York: Dial Books. $11.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Gale D. Kaufman Engaged to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Kaufman of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gale Deborah Kaufman, who is studying for an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University, and Steven Charles Helman, a first-year student at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University. A June wedding is planned.

title: The Mafia and the Bigots
description: Yes, there is a Mafia, an organized crime network largely made up of Italian-American mobsters. But Americans haven't yet learned to stop stigmatizing all Italian-Americans because of it. The positive development is that at last - after years of subterranean murmurings - the subject, and the prejudice, can be openly confronted.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BROOKFIELD, WIS.;
Builder Caters To Transferees
description: LEAD: A BUILDER of custom homes in this well-to-do Milwaukee suburb of 33,000 people is cashing in on an influx of corporate executives transferred from East and West Coast cities.

title: Mary Martha Keeley Wed To R. W. Beckler, Lawyer
description: At the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington, Mary Martha Keeley was married yesterday to Richard William Beckler in a ceremony performed by the Rev. Peter Ryan.

title: Chaminade Holds Off Farrell
description: Gary Wilkos, the senior quarterback for Monsignor Farrell, sparked a furious fourth-quarter rally yesterday, throwing for two touchdowns and plunging 1 yard for another in the Catholic High Schools Football League playoffs. But the comeback fell 1 point short as Chaminade foiled a late 2-point conversion attempt and held on for a 21-20 semifinal victory that eliminated Farrell, the defending champion.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: WINNING FRANCO-RUSSIAN ENTENTE
description: WOODMERE can now boast one of the best new restaurants to open on Long Island in recent years. The food at La Petite Maison Russe harks back to the old Franco-Russian alliance, when Russian Czars imported French chefs. This small storefront restaurant has reversed those roles. The chefs are Russian. The food, whether fine French or rousing Russian, is inspired.

title: FUNERAL HOMES ACCUSED OF BIAS ON AIDS
description: IN a practice that has angered advocates for people with AIDS, some Connecticut funeral homes are charging up to $500 extra to handle the bodies of AIDS patients, while others are turning the bodies away.

title: STATION MAKES A QUIET DEBUT
description: LAUREL VLOCK knew Bridgeport needed its own commercial television station after a 1978 survey showed that a majority of the city's elementary schoolchildren thought the mayor of Bridgeport was Edward Koch.

title: Chess Match: Tough Fight Ends in Draw
description: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov fought sharply on the terrain of a disputed ending before agreeing to a draw in Game 13 of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, Friday.

title: Dance: Two by Arpino In a Joffrey Bill of Four
description: FROM time to time in recent years, it has been the fashion to talk of the depersonalization of dancers in the face of rapidly rising technical demands. Some of that talk has been of the Joffrey Ballet, but the present company is filled with performers in whom expressive personality and technical expertise are merged. And those dancers were much in evidence when the company performed on Thursday at City Center.

title: Some Houseplants Like It Cool
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the number of my houseplants is always on the rise, the assortment that I can grow successfully seems to be on a steady decline. The decline began a few winters ago when plants that had normally done well were suddenly unable to grow in low house temperatures.

title: Miss Ashton Has Wedding
description: Katherine Ashton, a daughter of Mrs. and Mrs. Robert W. Ashton of New York, was married at Trinity Episcopal Church in New York yesterday to Brian David Young, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Young of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Robert Cowperthwaite performed the ceremony.

title: MOVIES
description: The Silver Chalice With Paul Newman, Virginia Mayo, Jack Palance, Pier Angeli, Lorne Greene, E. G. Marshall, Natalie Wood. 1954. Warner Home Video. 135 minutes. $19.98. ''Introducing Paul Newman,'' the opening credits proclaim, and the Biblical-epic buff doesn't need more of a reason than that to sit through this New Testament saga. Home viewers may want to study the 29-year-old Mr. Newman's film debut for hints of future greatness. They'll be disappointed at his wooden performance in the role of a Greek sculptor; but surely it must be more than hindsight that detects an Oscar-winning sparkle in his blue-eyed gaze?

title: MACK LOBELL WINNER BY 12 3/4 LENGTHS
description: ''A horse like him comes along only once in a lifetime,'' John Campbell said after driving Mack Lobell to a 12 3/4-length victory in the $442,662 Breeders Crown Trot for 3-year-old colts Friday night at Pompano Park.

title: OUT OF A DARKNESS
description: I identified with Frank Wolkenberg's feelings of relief. That is what I felt when our son was recently diagnosed as having Attention Deficit Disorder. We received a brief explanation from his psychologist and advice from a neurologist, but Frank Wolkenberg's article was the most I have read on the subject.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: EARLY PAINE Clive Phillpot, director of the library at the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan, will give a talk about one of his countrymen - Thomas Paine - at the New Rochelle Public Library, 8 P.M. Tuesday. An emigre from England himself, albeit two centuries later, Mr. Phillpot will explore Paine's early life in Thetford, Alford and Lewes, which is seldom discussed. His slide show and lecture will cover Paine's progress through his arrival in America.

title: HOW TO INSTALL A WALL CABINET
description: INSTALLING hanging cabinets against a framed wall is a task that many do-it-yourselfers view with trepidation. Not only must the cabinet's horizontal surfaces be level and its vertical surfaces plumb, but also, for strength, at least some of the fasteners must penetrate the studs that make up the core of the wall.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'BUTTERFLY' PREMIERE

title: OUR PERENNIAL SONGBIRDS
description: IT IS SOMETIME AFTER MIDNIGHT IN THE Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on West 44th Street. In this pleasantly faded monument of Manhattan gentility, with its red leather banquettes and oak-paneled walls, the gaze of the late-night audience is fastened on a dark-haired sliver of a woman tautly poised beside a piano.

title: Elaine La Roche Engaged to Marry Dr. P. R. Donovan
description: The engagement of Marie-Elaine La Roche, a managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, to Dr. Peter Richard Donovan, an exploration geologist with the United Nations Development Program in New York, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Andre La Roche of Cresskill, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Yugoslavia
description: To the Editor: Having spent a week in Yugoslavia this summer, I am surprised by Nick Yapp's ''Lost Among the Carnivores in Yugoslavia, a Vegetarian's Beef'' (Travel, Sept. 20).

title: Bob Dole's Problem
description: Senator Robert Dole is a formidable candidate for President: sensible, knowing in the ways of Washington, a conservative who has no time for the fantasies of Reaganomics. He has shed the meanness of the past, showing us instead a man with compassion for the dependent and rejected in society.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: EAST BURKE, VT.;
Economic Lift For Ski Area
description: LEAD: A MASSACHUSETTS developer who bought the Burke Mountain ski area at a bankruptcy auction in September expects to give the region known as the Northeast Kingdom, which is largely wilderness, an economic shot in the arm.

title: Recognizing Gaddis
description: I FIRST CAME TO KNOW WILLIAM Gaddis at a writers' conference in the Soviet Union in 1985. I had heard that he was shy and averse to publicity, but I found that this reputation was based only on his belief that a writer's life and personality should be as little as possible associated with his work. As a conferee, he was both eloquent and precise.

title: 2 VETERAN JETS FIND THEY CAN READJUST
description: Bobby Humphery and JoJo Townsell were chosen by the Jets in the 1983 National Football League draft. Full of vim, vigor and ambition, they figured, as most rookies do, that their talents were exactly what the Jets had ordered.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THERE have been, heaven only knows, mountains of words devoted to family problems, to the stresses and strains that threaten the tight weave of the domestic fabric. There have also been wise tomes issued on the effect of television as an isolating agent that can destroy togetherness in the home. But none of them have touched upon the particular matter that comes between man and wife in our otherwise serene situation.

title: Guest Observer; Paint It Black
description: THESE BLACK TIMES are getting blacker.

title: ART GRANTS ON THE RISE
description: LEAD: FIGURES released last week by the National Assembly of State Arts Agencies, as part of its annual survey, rank New Jersey seventh in the United States in per-capita spending by the state arts agencies, based on their legislative appropriation, and fifth when ranked according to the percentage of the total state general fund expenditures allocated to the arts agencies.

title: Preserving Duke Forest
description: PLANNING steps taken by governmental jurisdictions around Duke University are expected to complicate the university's efforts to bring residential and commercial development to parts of Duke Forest.

title: Correction
description: An interview with the author Mary Helen Washington on Oct. 4 incorrectly identified her college affiliation. She graduated from Notre Dame College of Ohio, Cleveland.

title: Anne Congdon to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Congdon of Nantucket, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Anne Chapin Congdon, to Whitney Adams Gifford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Gifford Jr. of Perrysburg, Ohio, and Nantucket. Miss Congdon, a graduate of Connecticut College, is the Estee Lauder representative at the Higbee Company in Cleveland. Her fiance, who graduated from Denison University, is a law student at Case Western Reserve University.

title: Eve Gordon, Actress, Wed to Todd Waring
description: The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Eve Gordon, a daughter of Dr. Mary McDougall Gordon of Saratoga, Calif., and Richard Bennett Gordon of Arlington, Va., to Todd Waring, a son of Douglas Waring of Ballston Spa, N.Y., and the late Gretchen Schoonmaker Waring. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: U.S.-Soviet Group Discusses Textbook Versions of History
description: Soviet textbooks should spend less time dwelling on poverty and urban crime in the United States, and the Russians want publishers of American textbooks to present a more balanced discussion of Lenin, a leader of a joint textbook study project says.

title: PLAN FOR A FABULOUS WEEKEND
description: FOR ALL OF MY FRIENDS WHO HAVE been living out of town for too long, who have been promising each other a splurge on the ultimate, go-for-broke weekend in ''the City'' and asking me for suggestions: here is my Christmas present to you all. (And maybe a couple of ideas for the friends who are here every day.) It's an itemized itinerary for a lively four-day weekend, accompanied by a list of addresses, prices, hours, phone numbers for reservations and information - everything you'll need. I have supplied the master plan (I've personally checked out everything in it, though maybe not all in the same weekend); now it's up to you. Bring plenty of money and don't worry about sleep. THURSDAY: Befitting a weekend of ''glitter and swank,'' as they used to say on the radio show ''Grand Central Station,'' arrive by train at that Beaux-Arts terminus through which half a million people pass on an average workday. Since you won't be rushed commuters but visitors, afford yourselves the luxury of a leisurely stroll across the marble floor and through the long, vaulted concourse. Ease your transition over a cup of cappuccino at the cafe on the west balcony of the main concourse (watch people, study the stars on the ceiling -there are more than 2,500 lights forming the constellations of the winter sky) or check your bags at the lost and found desk and plunge right into a main event: Lunch.

title: Roger Lewis, Amtrak's First Chief And an Executive in Many Fields
description: Roger Lewis, a former Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation and the first president of Amtrak, died Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 75 years old. Mr. Lewis' career, which began in 1934 in the sheet metal shop of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, took him over the next 40 years to top jobs in aviation, aerospace, military contracting, railroading and the Federal Government.

title:
WINE;
EXPLORING SAUVIGNON BLANC
description: LEAD: WINE made from sauvignon blanc grapes provides cost-conscious consumers an excellent alternative to pricey French and California whites. In fact, while local shops sell many scarcely decent white Burgundies for upward of $30 a bottle and the highest rated California chardonnays often cost more than $15 a bottle, top-quality products made from the sauvignon blanc varietal usually can be found at area retail outlets for less than $10 a bottle.

title:
RECORDINGS;
THE HARVEST OF A RESIDENCY PROGRAM
description: LEAD: TWENTY YEARS AGO, AUDIENCES, composers and orchestras were locked in a mutually destructive cycle of alienation and mistrust. Audiences, convinced that comprehensible symphonic music had died with Mahler and Sibelius, resisted the introduction of new works. Orchestra managers and conductors, sensing their audiences' mood, included less contemporary music in their programs.

title: THAT QUESTIONNAIRE AT THE DOCTOR'S
description: The questionnaire [ ''In Doctor's Office, on Trial for AIDS,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 27 ] was ''disquieting.''

title: Dec. 19 Wedding For Miss Danzig
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leonard S. Danzig of Little Silver, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Phoebe Danzig, to Reed Graham Schneider, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin H. Schneider of New York and Sharon, Conn. The couple plan to marry Dec. 19.

title: Look to Liquidity
description: To the Editor:

title: DIONNE, 36, CARRYING LOAD FOR RANGERS
description: These are stressful times not only for the Rangers, who as a group have been somewhat cowed by a seven-game losing streak, but also for Marcel Dionne, who because of injuries to his younger teammates is playing about twice as much as he'd like to.

title: Opera: 'Walkure' Recast
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's production of Wagner's ''Walkure'' returned to the stage Wednesday evening with a new conductor, Max Epstein, and several new singers in principal roles. Timothy Jenkins, a man of Wagnerian physical proportions, stepped into the part of Siegmund opposite the Sieglinde of Sabine Hass.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: NOVEMBER 15, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 GARDEN OF SHADOWS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The beginnings of the evil that beset the Dollanganger family in four previously published novels. 2 1 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $4.95.) Nightmarish experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania. 3 3 WHIRLWIND, by James Clavell. (Avon, $5.95.) Iran during the month following the Shah's departure. 4 6 THE GOLDEN CUP, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.95.) Continuing the saga of a turn-of-the-century New York family begun in ''Evergreen.'' 5 5 FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts. (Pocket, $4.95.) Navy aviators in the Vietnam War. 6 7 A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Warner, $4.95.) Comdr. Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder. 7 1 THE PRINCESS, by Jude Devereaux. (Pocket, $3.95.) A European princess's passionate affair with a United States naval officer. 8 13 IT, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town. 9 6 FOUNDATION AND EARTH, by Isaac Asimov. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.95.) The hero of the ''Foundation'' series searches for Earth. 10 18 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) The West tries to stave off the Russians in World War III. 11 4 PAPER MONEY, by Ken Follett. (Signet/NAL, $3.95.) Crime, high finance and journalism form the threads of this newly reissued 1977 thriller. 12 3 KENTUCKY! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $4.50.) The latest in the ''Wagons West'' series tells of a plot to assassinate President Grant. 13 79 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A submarine driver brings Soviet nuclear secrets to the United States. 14 7 VALE OF THE VOLE, by Piers Anthony. (Avon, $3.95.) Esk, the son of an ogre and a nymph, defends the inhabitants of a paradise. 15 1 ALL THAT GLITTERS, by Thomas Tryon. (Dell, $4.95.) Five Hollywood sex goddesses and the agent who helped their careers. Weeks This On Week List Nonfiction 1 6 ECHOES IN THE DARKNESS, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Bantam, $4.95.) A case involving the 1979 murder of a high school teacher. 2 1 DANCING ON MY GRAVE, by Gelsey Kirkland with Greg Lawrence. (Jove, $4.50.) The ballerina recalls her checkered career. 3 212 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 4 38 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 5 54 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) A woman's adventures flying in Africa and across the Atlantic in the 30's. 6 29 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Berkley, $6.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations by the television star. 7 1 SNAKE, by Ken Stabler and Berry Stainback. (Charter, $3.95.) The memoirs of the Oakland Raiders' roguish quarterback. 8 * 2 PAT NIXON: The Untold Story, by Julie Nixon Eisenhower. (Zebra, $4.50.) The biography of the former First Lady, written by her daughter. 9 * 4 ONE KNEE EQUALS TWO FEET, by John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Jove, $3.95.) Observations on football. 10 2 WORD FOR WORD, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Berkley, $3.95.) Essays on contemporary life by the journalist and television commentator. 11 * 11 KAFFIR BOY, by Mark Mathabane. (Plume/ NAL, $8.95.) Coming-of-age in South Africa. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 3 THE FAR SIDE OBSERVER, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) A new collection of cartoons. 2 12 BILLY AND THE BOINGERS BOOTLEG, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) More ''Bloom County'' cartoon strips. 3 29 CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $6.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 4 2 GARFIELD SWALLOWS HIS PRIDE, by Jim Davis. (Ballantine, $5.95.) The 14th collection of cartoons about a fat cat. 5 * 75 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: House Panel Suggests a Ban On Georges Bank Oil Drilling
description: The Interior Department should indefinitely suspend plans to lease tracts in the Georges Bank off the New England coast for oil and gas drilling, a House subcommittee recommended Monday.

title: City Hall Notes; Koch's Views Travel South Of New York
description: Mayor Koch is a man of many opinions, some of which have to do with municipal affairs.

title: Youth's Death in Capital Fans Debate on Curfews
description: On a chilly Saturday night last month, 17-year-old Wendell Heard defied his parents' warnings and went to Celebrity Hall, a go-go dance club here.

title: 2 MAN PLAY FROM SOUTH AFRICA
description: If purity of purpose were all, ''The Other Side of Newark,'' which is at the Foundation Theater here through next Sunday, could be hailed as an honorable play.

title: Reagan Is Skeptical on Peace Effort by Sandinistas
description: Only 24 hours after the Nicaraguan Government offered a cease-fire proposal to the contras, President Reagan accused the Sandinistas today of dragging their feet as they put into effect the Central American peace agreement.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ROYAL REDUX
description: LEAD: ''HEAR YE! Hear ye! Today is a day of celebration in honor of the birthday of our gracious King, His Majesty, George II of the House of Hanover, the true king of Great Britain and of the Empire, and the noble defender of the faith!''

title: A CANDIDATE'S 'POSITIVE ATTRIBUTES'
description: In my opinion the Oct. 25 article ''Garbage Is Issue in Two Races'' was unfair in its treatment of Ben Zwirn, Democratic candidate for supervisor of Town of North Hempstead.

title: A Victorian Monument To Hawaiian Culture
description: IF you are approaching the Bishop Museum by car, soon after you pass Punchbowl Crater in downtown Honolulu you will begin to see tropical vegetation bordering the crowded lanes of traffic -flame trees, mangoes, coco palm. Just before you reach a major intersection, where the H-1 freeway meets a cross-island trunk route, you get your first glimpse. Narrow windows and green, peaked roofs of weathered copper come rising over the treetops like something from a Dickens novel - a vicarage perhaps, or the ancestral mansion.

title: Outdoors; The Wonders of a Small Marsh on the Harlem River
description: ''THIS marsh is so rich I can show kids things here that people in rural areas won't see,'' said Miguel Padilla, a 28-year-old biologist who serves as the chief science adviser for the Inwood-Heights Parks Alliance, a community organization that looks after parks in northern Manhattan.

title: Islanders' Bottom Line Is Coming Out on Top
description: On many National Hockey League teams, the fourth line is the professional assignment of either last resort or initial opportunity. Whichever, it can often be a lonely way station at the end of the bench and just a short hop from the minors.

title: YALE'S EASY VICTORY SETS UP SHOWDOWN
description: Yale's quarterback and captain, Kelly Ryan, had his most productive game of the season today as the Elis easily defeated Princeton, 34-19. This victory, Yale's sixth in a row, set up a grand finale for the Ivy League championship: Harvard against Yale at the Yale Bowl on Saturday.

title: Upstairs/Downstairs
description: ON THE STREETS OF NEW York, it pays to look up and look down, and not always for the reasons you might think. Some of the city's most colorful restaurants, shops, clubs and galleries are tucked away in basements or perched in second floors, where lower rents enable entrepreneurs to be more than usually inventive about whatever it is they purvey. These imaginative establishments are often offbeat, and occasionally even eccentric - but they are certainly worth a visit.

title: Miss Pagnani Has Wedding
description: At St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., Allyson Anne Pagnani, a daughter of Virginia Marie Riley of Greenwich and Frederick J. Pagnani of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Sloan Martin, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Martin of New Canaan, Conn. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN RADAR DETECTORS
description: THE radar detector business is not for the timid. Makers of the little black boxes, which alert drivers to the presence of police radar and help them avoid speeding tickets, have come under fire from traffic safety organizations, politicians and police. Their technological adversaries, the makers of police radar equipment, consistently find new ways to circumvent detectors. Certain states have outlawed detectors, and manufacturers have fought hard to keep such bans from spreading.

title: MOVIES
description: Tough Guys With Burt Lancaster, Kirk Douglas, Charles Durning, Alexis Smith and Eli Wallach. Directed by Jeff Kanew. Touchstone Home Video. 103 minutes. $79.95. Harry Doyle and Archie Long are a couple of venerable thieves who have just finished a 30-year stretch for train robbery. When the gates of the state penitentiary are finally opened for them, Harry and Archie, played by Burt Lancaster and Kirk Douglas, find that the world outside has changed a bit since their last visit.

title: CLAMOR FOR CUTS IN STATE TAXES QUIETS
description: THE clamor for state tax cuts, which echoed loudly through the State Capitol in late summer and early fall, has quieted in recent weeks after the plunge in the world stock markets and the resulting increased caution about the future pace of consumer spending in Connecticut and the nation.

title: INMATES BEHIND WHEEL
description: Officials at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility, the maximum-security prison in Ossining, are helping inmates make their getaway - by teaching them driving skills.

title: Sandinistas Launch an Offensive on Capitol Hill
description: FOR more than a hundred years, the United States has done virtually what it pleased in Central America. And for six years the conflict between the Reagan Administration and the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua has lurched and sputtered inconclusively. But last week, Reagan policy makers watched events accelerate sharply and sought to keep them from getting out of their control.

title: RECITALS COMPETE FOR ATTENTION
description: STARTING off today's generous offering of concert opportunities is Philharmonia Virtuosi's ''Bach's Lunch'' series, with a 2 P.M. recital at Concordia College in Bronxville (or come at 12:30 and have an informal luncheon beforehand). Two glowing Quintets make up the program: Paul Peabody, the concertmaster, and four more of the group's principal string players line up for Schubert's C Major and the guest pianist, Stephanie Brown, joins in for the Brahms F Minor (693-5595).

title: Frankfurt
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed ''What's Doing in Frankfurt'' (Travel, Oct. 18). I do regret, though, that the article failed to mention two sites that I consider main attractions. The first is the zoo, with about 6,000 animals. It is one of the first zoos to attempt natural habitats, a children's zoo and a large house for watching nocturnal animals. The second is the Palmengarten, the botanical garden, with regional, tropical and subtropical flora in a beautiful setting with huge early 1900's steel and glass construction and frequently changing special flower shows, afternoon promenade concerts and a good restaurant. MICHAEL NUDLING Atlanta

title: DEVELOPERS CATER TO THE AFFLUENT ELDERLY
description: LEAD: FOR the elderly of comfortable economic means, it is a good time to be looking for housing. The choices are many and attractive, as developers rush to fill a long-overlooked market niche.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: YOUTH SCENE Despite their peers' obvious preoccupation with pop music, some teen-agers are still interested in the classics. Just how well this interest is translated into achievement should become apparent today, when two youth orchestras and winners of the Great Neck Symphony's Young Musicians Competition take to the stage. Soloists who captured seconds and honorable mentions (first-prize winners performed last week) in the 33d annual Great Neck contest play at 2:30 P.M. at the local library on Bayview Avenue.

title: If Horseshoe Fits . . .
description: IT has become a familiar ritual among National Football League owners seeking a better stadium deal at home, the grand tour of cities seeking an N.F.L. franchise. It was just such a mission that took Bill Bidwill, the owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, to Baltimore, which has been clamoring for a team ever since the Colts' midnight departure for Indianapolis in 1984.

title: The Trouble With 'Freedom'
description: Before he went to South Africa in 1983 to see for himself what life under apartheid was like, Sir Richard Attenborough was a self-described ''well-intentioned liberal,'' the sort who protests by not buying South African oranges. His heart was in the right place.

title: SCHOOL SPORTS: Preps; HOPKINS STOPS FIELDSTON TO RETAIN FAIRCHESTER LEAGUE TITLE
description: Hopkins, the defending champions in the Fairchester League, retained its title with a 31-18 victory over the Southern Division winner, Fieldston.

title: AT INDIANA, A WEEK IN KNIGHT'S CLASSROOM
description: Bob Knight called Joan Mellen last January, tracking her down at Temple University after reading her review for The St. Petersburg Times of John Feinstein's book, ''A Season on the Brink.'' No formalities, no introductory pleasantries: he just wanted to let her know that he thought she understood what he was about, the motives behind how he coached, how hard it was to make people learn. ''You're a professor of literature?'' he asked, amused. She had never seen a college basketball game. The idea of writing about him was her idea, not his. These are some of her personal observations based on five days she spent in Bloomington, Ind., last month.

title: The White World of College Sports
description: LEAD: WITH the baseball season now behind us, among our many memories will be the controversy regarding racism in sports. We've seen how bad the pros are at hiring blacks off the playing field. Yet now, as our attention focuses on the big college football games and the opening of college basketball, no one is talking about the issue of black employment on the collegiate level.

title: Extending the Reach of Schools - Down to Infants, Up to Parents
description: THOMAS Sobol was inaugurated last month as New York State's 11th Commissioner of Education, the chief executive officer of the Board of Regents. In this post, Mr. Sobol, a 55-year-old former superintendent of schools in Scarsdale, bears the responsibility for guiding probably the most diverse network of local school systems in the country at a time when the quality of public education has become a major political issue. Among the priorities Mr. Sobol has set forth is the expansion of educational and other services for pre-school children, giving teachers more responsibility in deciding curriculums and other academic matters, and increasing parental involvement. Recently, Mr. Sobol expanded on these and other themes in an interview with Edward B. Fiske of the New York Times. Following are excerpts from that discussion.

title:
GARDENING;
THE CHALLENGE OF PROPAGATING PLANTS
description: LEAD: FOR the person who is really into gardening, there is a special satisfaction that comes from propagating one's own plants. Annuals, of course, are pretty easy, some perennials are a bit more difficult, but the woody plants are really a challenge.

title: President Predicts Pact on Budget; Delay of Benefit Rises Considered
description: President Reagan said today that he expected an agreement on a budget compromise next week as Congressional and White House negotiators considered a three-month delay in Federal pay increases, cost-of-living increases for Social Security and other Federal benefit programs.

title:
IN THE REGION: LONG ISLAND;
Industrial Buildings Yield Office Bargains
description: LEAD: AARON ZUTLER, president of Marketing Congress, an advertising agency and marketing-consulting company, decided to move from Manhattan to Long Island six years ago when his office rent went up to $38 a square foot.

title: Report From Milan
description: LET THE FRENCH roll out their bell skirts, pouf sleeves and stiff hoops. Italy's arsenal of seduction is formed of gentler stuff. This year, Milan's fashion leaders, a handful of shrewd nonconformists, demonstrated pointedly that sex appeal can be a subtle thing.

title: 4 Rochester Hospitals Tie Costs to Quality of Care
description: A group of Rochester hospitals has decided to let the amount of money they are paid for their services be determined in part by the quality of care.

title: PLAN FOR A FABULOUS WEEKEND ... AND WHERE TO TAKE THE KIDS
description: WHILE NEW YORK CITY is always a source of education and fun for kids, during the holiday season it becomes a wonderland. The weather is often fine in December, so it could be the perfect month for you and your children to explore and rediscover New York City while savoring a enchanting time of year.

title: MENTOR PROGRAM AIDS NEW TEACHERS
description: ''I THINK every new teacher should have a mentor,'' said Linda Prince, a first-year science teacher at Syosset High School. ''In the beginning there are so many questions, and with a mentor you can ask for help without feeling like you're imposing.''

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THE IDEA of imposing a tax on the generation of hazardous waste - a plan designed to discourage production -has been around for a while, but it may achieve added legislative impetus next year for an unrelated reason: the Department of Environmental Protection needs the money.

title: Pronouncing on Moscow
description: It's tempting to see the Boris Yeltsin story as the end of Soviet ''new thinking'' and a slide back to the days of Stalin's purges. But caution is in order. It's fine to applaud loosening of controls and to condemn the old Soviet ways. It makes little sense, however, to draw profound conclusions about the fate of glasnost, or openness, and perestroika, or reform, on the basis of daily or even monthly events.

title: Mao and Deng: Competition for History's Judgment
description: SINCE the West first encroached on China in the Opium War of 1840, awakening the Chinese to their backwardness, Chinese patriots have searched for the elusive secret of modernization. Many tried, and failed, leaving China only farther behind. But in the view of an increasing number of Western specialists, one leader has finally succeeded: Deng Xiaoping.

title: Originality Isn't Everything
description: AT THE METROPOLITAN Museum of Art's Hudson River School exhibition, there's a wonderful bit of diplomacy-cum-criticism among the annotations on the walls. A painter named Jasper Cropsey, one placard says, ''tended to model his work on that of his colleagues, using their compositions and techniques as catalysts for change in his own style.'' At the Met, that amounts to an art-historical shrug of the shoulders, as Cropsey's canvases appear alongside those of his more inspired colleagues. But in the context of music criticism, those would be fighting words.

title: 4 Killed and 4 Are Hurt as a Car Hits Con Ed Truck on F.D.R. Drive
description: Four people were killed and four others were seriously injured early yesterday morning when a car lost control and crashed into a Consolidated Edison work site on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in upper Manhattan, the police said.

title: BOUNDARIES OF DESIRE
description: LEAD: MAPS By Nuruddin Farah. 246 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $11.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: ACCOUNTANTS SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE
description: ACCOUNTING, an industry whose expansion has mirrored that of Long Island's economy, continues to see a growing demand for its services. But leaders in the field now fear that recent criticism of mistakes in the industry, as well as the increasing workloads brought on by the new tax law, will hinder their efforts to find enough qualified young recruits.

title: Julius Gabris, Bishop in Czechoslovakia, 74
description: Julius Gabris, one of four Roman Catholic bishops in Czechoslovakia, has died, the official Czechoslovak press agency reported Friday. He was 74 years old.

title: Seeking a Pardon For Eddie Slovik
description: FORTY-TWO YEARS after Pvt.

title: FAIRFIELD SEEKING SOLUTION
description: LEAD: ALL of Fairfield County's 840,000 residents are invited to what organizers say will be the least exclusive get-together on the Gold Coast.

title: Stage: The 'Christmas Spectacular,' at Radio City
description: LIKE the giant Christmas tree that adorns the plaza at Rockefeller Center each holiday season, the Radio City Music Hall's ''Magnificent Christmas Spectacular,'' is one of the most visible and popular symbols of cultural continuity in a city where almost everything else seems subject to jarring change.

title: Massachusetts Towns Duel for Nonexistent Honor
description: After two centuries two small Massachusetts towns are still vying for the title ''birthplace of the American Navy.''

title: Dance: The Joffrey In a Humorous Quartet
description: ONE of the Joffrey Ballet's many virtues is an ability to entertain, which it does through the most serious of artistic enterprises - a repertory that includes the great ballets of all time.

title: F. R. Frank Wed To Ms. Donovan
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Gregory the Great in Harrison, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Maryclaire Donovan, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. W. Denis Donovan of Harrison, and Frederick R. Frank, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Willy K. Frank of Hammondsport, N.Y. The Rev. Leonard diFalco performed the ceremony.

title: Correction
description: A dispatch from Philadelphia Oct. 25 about the restoration of a former department store misidentified the leader of a campaign to save the building and misstated her age. The woman, Eleanor Gesensway, is 51 years old.

title: POLITICIANS, PECKSNIFFERY AND PUBLIC TV
description: THERE IS NO END TO IT; EVERYBODY wants to get into the act. If it's not sex, drugs and rock-and-roll, then clearly there's too much violence. Politicians, moralists and other interested parties have always wanted to regulate television. Pecksniffs love to testify at hearings. What's different now, however, is that the impulse to regulate television entertainment is being extended to television news. Congress seems determined to write the Fairness Doctrine into law, while penalizing broadcasters who violate it by making them pay fines.

title: COUNTY PONDERS MOTOR-AGENCY ROLE
description: LEAD: THE motor-vehicle agency here is the only one among the 54 in the state manned and operated by a county government - Atlantic - and county officials, who are satisfied with the setup, are wondering whether it may be nearing an end.

title: Family Court Is Struggling With Caseload, Experts Say
description: New York City's Family Court, created 25 years ago to handle family matters and youthful offenders, is being overwhelmed by a new generation of children more abused and neglected than ever before, according to experts addressing a special seminar yesterday.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A BEAUTIFUL, CRUEL COUNTRY. By Eva Antonia Wilbur-Cruce. Illustrated by Michael McCurdy. (University of Arizona, $19.95.) At the age of 5, in 1909, the author could herd livestock, tame a bronco and brand a cow, although she still needed help getting on and off her steed. Eva Antonia Wilbur-Cruce came by these skills in Indian country near the Mexican border on a ranch homesteaded in the 1860's by her doctor grandfather.

title: SORENSEN REFLECTS ON CHANGING ROLE OF AMERICAN PRESIDENCY
description: LEAD: ''THE Presidency has changed from my days in the White House,'' Theodore C. Sorenson said, ''and it changed from earlier times -and that's good.''

title: Marine Spy Rebuts Idea of Moscow Embassy Ring
description: A marine convicted of espionage has convinced Government counterintelligence agents that there was no extensive spy ring in the security detachment at the American Embassy in Moscow and that no Soviet agents were admitted to the embassy, military officials say.

title: Question Of the Week; Will Free Agents Be Signed in Baseball?
description: Definitely. First of all, the owners were found guilty of collusion last season and a repeat performance on their part is highly unlikely. Secondly, in our society, the name of the game is winning and several contending teams, including the Yankees, who desperately need frontline pitching, are a free agent or two away from capturing it all. NICHOLAS D. DECURTIS New York

title: The AIDS Secret Worth Keeping
description: Testing to help curb the AIDS epidemic can be either voluntary or compulsory, but that's a choice only in theory. A compulsory program would drive underground the intravenous drug abusers and gay men who most need to be reached. No wonder public health officials overwhelmingly prefer voluntary tests.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: NASA to Get Disney Center

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GHOST'S HOUR, SPOOK'S HOUR By Eve Bunting. Illustrated by Donald Carrick. Unpaged. New York: Clarion Books/ Ticknor & Fields. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) I WON'T GO TO BED! By Harriet Ziefert. Illustrated by Andrea Baruffi. Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $10.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: 37,000-Unit Rise in Housing Seen in New York City
description: New York City gained 37,000 units of housing between 1984 and 1987, according to city officials.

title: NURSE WHO DIED IN VIETNAM REMEMBERED
description: MATCHING Fieldcrest towels, sweaters and a wedding gown filled Capt. Eleanor Alexander's hope chest. The 27-year-old Army nurse from River Vale had put off marriage until she returned from her six-month stint in Vietnam.

title: Giverny
description: To the Editor: In regard to MacDonald Harris's article on Giverny (Aug. 30), my husband and I also traveled there in May; however, we had an experience of which readers of the Travel section should take notice.

title: Maine Faculty Votes C.I.A. Ban
description: The faculty of Colby College in Waterville, Me.,has voted to ban the Central Intelligence Agency from recruiting students on its campus. The student government opposes such a ban.

title: WITH STRINGS, HANDS AND TUBES, PUPPETRY LIVES IN WATERFORD
description: IN the basement of a barn in Waterford, two students sculptured eyes on clay heads. Outside, four people lifted and waved six-foot-long forms of copper tubing.

title: In Bangkok, Prize Winners Talk of Future
description: The hotel was one of Bangkok's most glittering; the buffet tables were heaped with the great cuisines of Asia. But Abdul Sattar Edhi, in his worn, homespun jacket, chose only a bowl of soup and a piece of flat bread known as naan.

title: THE WORLD: Terrorism; With Latest Bomb, I.R.A. Injures Its Own Cause
description: THE Irish Republican Army rarely second guesses itself about the violent attacks that have claimed hundreds of lives in Northern Ireland in the last 17 years. But after one of its bombs killed 11 people at a memorial service for veterans in Enniskillen last Sunday, the outlawed organization issued its second apology in five years.

title: Vietnam
description: To the Editor: Having left Vietnam in 1975, my heart is still poignant with memories from Dalat, the city briefly mentioned in ''Vietnam for Visitors'' (Travel, Sept. 13).

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a large bluestone patio about 10 years old, and some of the cement between the flags is coming out of the joints. Can you tell us how to handle this problem?

title: College in Ohio Covets 'Neglected Park' in Florida
description: Old-timers still tell tales about Hugh Taylor Birch, who at the turn of the century collected three miles of of isolated beachfront property when land was cheap and settlers were few and far between.

title: CREATIVE EXPORTER: Fred P.C. Chao; Taking Laundromats and Chopstick Factories to China
description: LATE in life, Fred P. C. Chao has developed a new career, one that looks a little like taking sand to the beach.

title: Dole Said to Plan Top-to-Bottom Shake-Up of His Campaign Staff
description: Amid signs of increasing turmoil within his Presidential campaign, Bob Dole plans to announce a virtual top-to-bottom shake-up of his organization next week.

title: High-End Audio Within Reason
description: WE WAITED A WHILE for things to settle.

title: Devils Lose First At Home
description: The Devils allowed five straight power-play goals to the Detroit Red Wings this afternoon and suffered their first loss of the season at home, 6-4.

title: FATAL CONNECTIONS
description: THE PEARLKILLERS Four Novellas. By Rachel Ingalls. 215 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: THE WORLD: Familiar Epithets; In Moscow, the Fall of a New Soviet Man
description: BORIS N. YELTSIN seemed the quintessential new Soviet man, a chest-thumping advocate of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's openness and restructuring and an irrepressible critic of past party failures and hidebound ideology.

title:
RECORDINGS;
One From the Flip Side of David Johansen
description: LEAD: THERE WAS A TIME, AND IT wasn't that long ago, when rock-and-roll was widely considered something distinct from entertainment. Entertainers dressed up in flashy stage attire, donned funny hats, and attempted to dazzle their audiences while pretending to emote. Rock-and-roll performers wore their street clothes, or, like the New York Dolls and the British glam-rockers, they dressed up in powder and paint and thrift-shop finery as a way of poking fun at show business traditions.

title: REFLECTIONS ON HANUKKAH
description: HANUKKAH IS ABOUT THE MIRACLE of a little clay lamp - the kind of primordial object, commonplace enough, that has turned up by the score in archeological digs in the old lands surrounding the Mediterranean. It happened once that a lamp of this character - a simple jar hung with a wick - contained only enough oil to last a single day. Providentially, it burned for eight; and that is the miracle of Hanukkah.

title: FIVE ENGLISH ARTISTS IN A GLASS SHOW
description: ''IN ENGLAND, we have three years of cut-knuckle training, but in America you just go into the studio and get on with it.''

title: TIFFANY MUSEUM: BENEFIT OR REVENGE
description: WHILE residents in other Connecticut communities lock horns over such social problems as where to construct prisons, put garbage dumps and build low-income housing, here in the tiny western town of Sherman, they argue about Tiffany lamps.

title: Haig Asserts Cuomo Will Run
description: The movement to draft Governor Cuomo of New York for President got a push today from an unlikely source: former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., a Republican candidate for President.

title:
ANTIQUES;
DEPRESSION-ERA GLASS IN LAMBERTVILLE
description: LEAD: EIGHTEEN years ago, Fran Jay, a leading dealer in Depression-era glass, bought a set of green dishes at a Morristown thrift shop because, she said at her shop here recently, ''they matched the green in my wallpaper.''

title: WITH STORIES, BRINGING BOOKS TO BABIES
description: LEAD: ONE weekday morning, six babies sat in a semicircle at the Ferguson Library in Stamford as Connie Rockman read them Mother Goose nursery rhymes and tales of ''piggies'' and ''Mr. Thumbkin.'' Some babies, ages 7 to 11 months, listened - if only for a few moments - while the others crawled into the center of the semicircle, untied the adults' shoelaces, sucked on bottles and pacifiers and grabbed one another's rattles.

title: A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
description: Prof. Edward Witten's new constructions may tie in to earlier, undisputed, findings. In 1982, a team of researchers, led by Alain Aspect, found that it is possible for particles to communicate instantaneously over great distances. This violates a long-held theory that nothing travels faster than light. But if we accept Professor Witten's theory of an additional six, tightly-wound dimensions - dimensions in which both chronometric and spatial continuity are irrelevant - then we may be able to understand more readily the concepts of instant communication. It is possible that, in one of these dimensions, the discrete particles which appeared to be in communication were merely points along the same compressed string. GLORIA D. HOWARD Boston

title: ARMY SEEN AS KEY FOR BANGLADESH
description: Immediately before this week's anti-Government riots, President H. M. Ershad dropped in on some of his constituents. Among the stops was the Ninth Division headquarters of the Bangladesh Army, where he announced financing for a new mosque.

title: EXPERTS TO CONVENE ON THE NIXON YEARS
description: HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY, adding to its reputation as the leading academic conference center on Long Island, will assemble 150 scholars, politicians, historians and journalists this week for what is believed to be the first major re-examination of the Presidency of Richard M. Nixon.

title: POSTINGS: West St. Gamble; Back Offices
description: For a bigwig in the major leagues of sports, an empty warehouse might seem like a bush way to buy into the Manhattan real estate game. But John McMullen figures he can take the 60-year-old building on the northeast corner of Hubert and West Streets, whip it into shape by next November and charge about $25 a square foot to downtown companies that need back-office space.

title: Data From Paper? It's Elementary
description: THE problem is elementary, but deucedly difficult. The 56 short stories and four novels that Sir Arthur Conan Doyle wrote about Sherlock Holmes exist on paper - 11,000 pages' worth. Many Baker Street Irregulars and other admirers of the great detective would like to see the works available in an electronic data base. There they could be searched and examined for clues using the most powerful analytical engine available today, the personal computer.

title: A Soprano, a Violinist and an Organist
description: Edith Wiens

title: Community Rises From Boston Slum
description: A new waterfront community is rising from the remains of the Columbia Point housing project, which has long been considered symbolic proof that public housing has failed.

title: MOVIES
description: Tin Men Starring Richard Dreyfuss, Danny DeVito and Barbara Hershey. Written and directed by Barry Levinson. 1987. Touchstone Home Video. 112 minutes. $89.95. Just as certain foods are relished by the Chinese more for their texture than their flavor, so must ''Tin Men'' be savored for its very special texture rather than for its plot. The story of this comedy defies easy summary, and to say it's about a feud between two aluminum-siding salesman (Richard Dreyfuss and Danny DeVito) over a minor automobile accident is to miss the point. Mr. Levenson has imbued his 1963 Baltimore setting with the same genuine sense of lifestyle that he instilled in his earlier film, ''Diner.'' It is funny, tough and yet quite warm. Unlike seeing it in a theater, where the attention is naturally focused on performance, a viewing from the living room requires some special concentration lest one shrug it off, casually, as just another prolonged sitcom.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Oct. 31 MANHATTAN Greenwich Village $81,000 304 West 10th Street 275-sq.-ft. studio co-op in a renovated prewar building: fireplace, Hudson River view; maintenance $241, 51% tax-deductible (Broker:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A GUEST IN THE JUNGLE. By James Polster. (Mercury House/Kampmann, $15.95.) At the center of ''A Guest in the Jungle'' by James Polster is Whitehill, a yuppie lawyer from Pittsburgh who seeks adventure in the Amazon. And, sure enough, once this Brooks Brothers-bedecked tourist disappears into the wilderness, he encounters a tropical welcome wagon that includes vampire bats, pit vipers and less than noble Indians.

title: OPPOSITION IN STATE IS WANING
description: LEAD: GROUPS opposed to nuclear energy are apparently on the wane in New Jersey.

title: WHY WED? THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
description: THE WORD THEY USE IS ''SCARY.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: IF the third time's a charm, Joe Dudek should have quite a season with the Denver Broncos next year.
