title: Gulliver's Travails
description: Ever since the Wall Street plunge demonstrated the financial world's interdependency, Asian opinion leaders have been viewing the U.S. with the same condescension as the brisk Lilliputians saw big Lemuel Gulliver: an amiable, clumsy giant whose profligacy is awful but whose strength could still prove useful.

title: GIANTS CATCHING UP ON PLAYING CATCH
description: A half-season after the Super Bowl, the Giants will finally begin to take the measure of the slick wide receivers they drafted this year.

title: How to Sell the Land, Yet Safeguard It
description: FOUR years ago, when Dr. Philip Wiedel, a surgeon at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, began to plan for retirement, he and his wife, Monique, decided that they would eventually take up permanent residence in their country home in the southeast corner of Danbury.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BRAVE TALK. By Stephen Molton. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) Stephen Molton's first novel starts slowly, as if he is feeling his way into the spaciousness of the form. One is annoyed by the hipness of the young protagonist, who seems knowing beyond his years, and by the dialogue, which doesn't sound like natural conversation.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lendl and Jarryd in Final: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia and fifth-seeded Anders Jarryd won their semifinal matches yesterday in the $375,000 Benson and Hedges championships at Wembley, England. Lendl eliminated Henri Leconte of France by 6-4, 7-6 and Jarryd defeated unseeded Jacob Hlasek of Switzerland by 7-6, 6-1. The final will be held today. Jarryd was never behind after breaking Hlasek's serve in the first game of the match. Lendl wore down Leconte with his big serve and steady groundstrokes. ''I played better than I thought I would,'' Lendl said after stretching his record against Leconte to 8-5. (AP) Gomez and Mayotte Advance: Second-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador defeated Jim Pugh of the United States by 6-3, 6-3 yesterday in the semifinals of the $74,000 Frankfurt Cup tournament. Gomez's opponent in the final will be fourth-seeded Tim Mayotte, who beat a fellow American, Derrick Rostagno, 6-4, 6-1, in the other semifinal. (AP) Navratilova Beats McNeil: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova dispatched sixth-seeded Lori McNeil, 6-1, 6-4, Friday night to advance to the semifinals against third-seeded Helena Sukova in the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament. Navratilova, the world's second-ranked player, took one hour to eliminate, McNeil of Houston, who is ranked 11th in the world. Sukova was extended to three sets for her third straight match as she eliminated Leila Meskhi of the Soviet Union, 7-6, 0-6, 6-0. (AP) Soccer Arsenal Turns Back Norwich: Arsenal defeated Norwich, 4-2, yesterday to recapture the lead in the First Division of the English League. It was Arsenal's 13th consecutive victory. Queens Park Rangers hung on to third place after a 1-1 tie at Tottenham Hotspur. The defending champion, Everton, posted a 3-1 victory over West Ham United.(AP) Golf Bean Captures Hawaii Event: Andy Bean shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday to successfully defend his title at the $600,000 Kapalua International tournament at Kapalua, Hawaii. Bean, bothered by an elbow injury most of the year, finished with a 72-hole score of 21-under-par 267 - a tournament record on the Bay course at the Kapalua resort - beating Lanny Wadkins by three shots. Bean won only $73,808 in the official PGA Tour season that ended two weeks ago. This victory, however, was worth $150,000 and went with the $93,000 he earned in Japan last week to give him $243,000 in earnings for the last 14 days. (AP) Suzuki Rallies to Take Lead: Koichi Suzuki birdied the last two holes yesterday, shot a 69 for 206 and has a one-stroke lead over Tom Watson and Craig Stadler of the United States entering the final round of the $667,000 VISA Masters tournament. Stadler took the lead when he sank an eight-foot birdie putt at the 15th hole before losing it with a bogey at the 16th. He shot 70. Watson had a bogey-birdie-par finish en route to a 68. (AP) Cross-Country Penn State Senior Is Winner: Eric Carte

title: Eileen M. Kenny Weds M. E. Helmer in Jersey
description: Eileen Mary Kenny, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Kenny of Basking Ridge, N.J., was married there yesterday to Michael Edward Helmer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William F. Helmer of Morrisville, N.Y. The Rev. John Davis, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Bush Beats Back Robertson Challenge in Florida
description: Vice President Bush won a key ''straw poll'' today, turning back a strong challenge from Pat Robertson, the former television preacher who twice embarrassed Mr. Bush in highly visible party votes in the last year.

title: HARVARD ROUTS PENN AND HEADS TO TITLE MATCH
description: Harvard gave Yale cause for concern about next week's Ivy League showdown when the Crimson trounced the defending champion, Pennsylvania, 31-14, today at Harvard Stadium.

title: A June Wedding For Janet Lunine
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Lunine of Philadelphia of the engagement of their daughter Janet Lunine to Jonathan Barzilay, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Barzilay of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: White Supremacist on Radio
description: A radio personality who pays for his own air time has publicly acknowledged white supremacist beliefs and renamed his weekly radio talk show ''Aryan Nations Hour.''

title: IN SAN JOSE, THIS YEAR'S SLEEPER
description: Bill Berry was an assistant coach at Michigan State when Magic Johnson led the Spartans to the national championship, a 6-9 guard who opened the backcourt to the big man. Berry eventually became head coach at San Jose State where, five years ago, he had an opportunity to offer a scholarship to his son, Rickey, a 6-5 guard who reminded some people of Johnson.

title: Bix by Kirk
description: YOUNG MAN WITH A HORN Starring Kirk Douglas (in photo), Lauren Bacall, Doris Day. Directed by Michael Curtiz. Warner Home Video. 112 minutes. $19.98.

title: Let Reagan Be Reagan
description: LEAD: In the present moment of economic alarm, the public looks to the White House for a dramatic act of leadership as if there is a magic curative stashed away in a secret cave known only to Presidents.

title: Comparing Costs to 24 Destinations
description: PACKAGE tours are a good way to cut costs and save time arranging a vacation in the sun. In addition to air fare and hotel accommodations, most include Federal departure tax and airport transfers. Some, known as all-inclusive packages, include meals, drinks, recreational activities, taxes and tips. The following is a sampling of package tours available in the Caribbean and the Bahamas.

title: Breaking Through a Murderous Silence
description: HUNDREDS of mourners, many weeping, stood in line late last week to pay respects to 6-year-old Elizabeth Steinberg, the Greenwich Village girl who died Nov. 5 after what the police said was a brutal beating by her adoptive parents.

title: Passage to Two Continents, Via the Imagination
description: THE GARDENS BETWEEN THE entrances to the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery and the Museum of African Art are now the colors of late fall, dark reds and yellows and evergreen. When I revisited those newest additions to the Smithsonian Institution, the long queues of the opening weeks had disappeared. There seemed to be no crowds, and yet there were hundreds of people. As they wandered through the galleries, I realized that they had caught the peace and spaciousness the complex was designed for. I saw a Buddha head I had not seen on my earlier visit, and in the main entrance hall of the Sackler, a seventh-century Tang horse, about two feet high. It cast the message of quality and stillness that Eastern art embodies.

title: Julius Lane Wilson, Doctor, 90
description: Dr. Julius Lane Wilson, first director of medical education of the American Thoracic Society, the medical section of the American Lung Association, died of an aneurysm Tuesday at his home in Tryon, N.C. He was 90 years old.

title: 2 More Arab Nations Renew Full Ties With Egypt
description: Kuwait and Morocco became the latest Arab nations to resume full diplomatic relations with Egypt today. Iraq and the United Arab Emirates took similar steps this week.

title: Music: 'Lost in the Stars,' at City College
description: A GENERATION of consciousness-raising makes Kurt Weill's ''Lost in the Stars'' seem ponderous today. Racial hostility's broad themes are too powerful and pervasive to need simple restatement anymore, making this musical version of ''Cry the Beloved Country'' an all too black-and-white rendering of recent social history. Modern theater is more likely to hold our attention with the subtle, peripheral skirmishes in this ongoing war.

title: Special Today: The World of New York/Magazine Part 2
description: In the holiday World of New York, these special reports:

title: MYTH AND THE TITANIC
description: William F. Buckley Jr. was reported to have said that his descent to the Titanic as a guest of the French expedition would be done to ''give himself something new and different to write about'' (''Down to the Great Ship,'' Oct 18). So be it! But his article addresses the unique philosophical problems attending this discovery/salvage affair only perfunctorily. In fact, Mr. Buckley says that ''the sensation [ was ] uncomplicated by any philosophical misgivings'' and, ''I did not feel any kinship to the voyeur.''

title: THE IRISH CRUISE AGAINST THE TIDE
description: Notre Dame is on a mission to win the national college football championship, but may never get the chance to fulfill it.

title: A Marathon On Pynchon Stirs Readers

title: Q&A
description: English Colleges Question:I am interested in attending the summer school sessions offered by Oxford or Cambridge University in England. Where can I get information on classes and arrangements? - P. E., Woodside, Queens Answer:There are several sources to approach - aside from writing to individual colleges in both cities. One is the Institute of International Education (809 United Nations Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10017; 212-883-8200), the largest international educational agency in the United States. It administers a British universities summer schools program that offers, in July and August, four-week courses at Oxford as well at London University and in Stratford-upon-Avon under the auspices of the University of Birmingham. The Oxford course is on British literature and society from 1870 to the present. Undergraduates, graduates and university faculty members may obtain application forms from the institute. Information about summer courses at Oxford and Cambridge is given in ''Study in the United Kingdom and Ireland,'' published by the institute at $12.95.

Dugan of Orangeburg, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Dr. Dugan, was married yesterday to Kenneth Richard Stevens, a son of Mrs. H. John Stevens of New City, N.Y., and the late Mr. Stevens. title: FLYING FISH FROM BARBADOS
description: TO an American raised to revere the bald eagle, the notion of eating a national symbol might sound less than appetizing. But in Barbados, the self-proclaimed land of the flying fish, the emblem that adorns all the tourist brochures turns up at lunch, dinner and even breakfast, steamed, sauteed, deep-fried and every which way but blackened.

Ms. Wiley is at Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler and her fiance at Shea & Gould.

description: A shortage of beechnuts and acorns, food of choice of New Hampshire's black bears, is driving the bruins to ruin apple orchards and cornfields in territory more populated than their usual mountain terrain.

title:
GARDENING;
THE CHALLENGE OF PROPAGATING PLANTS
description: LEAD: FOR the person who is really into gardening, there is a special satisfaction that comes from propagating one's own plants. Annuals, of course, are pretty easy, some perennials are a bit more difficult, but the woody plants are really a challenge.

title: In Afghan King, a Soft Voice for a Soviet Pullout
description: After 14 years of quiet exile, the king of Afghanistan, Mohammad Zahir Shah, has emerged as a key figure in efforts to negotiate a Soviet withdrawal from his country.

title:
ART;
The Legacy of Marcus Garvey
description: LEAD: THIS year marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of Marcus Garvey, the black nationalist leader whose philosophy of racial pride is credited with instilling in his people an awareness of and respect for their African heritage. At the height of its popularity in the 1920's, his movement helped spark the celebrated Harlem Renaissance, during which black artists, writers, dancers and musicians gained unprecedented prominence in both highbrow and popular culture throughout the United States and

title: WHO HAS THE TALENT AND DRIVE?
description: The talent in college basketball has become fairly evenly distributed in recent years, primarily among two dozen or so of the nation's strongest programs.

title: POSTINGS: In Goldens Bridge; When the Times Call for Flexibility
description: With a sharp contemporary twist, the town-house project of Katonah Close takes its architectural cue from Victorian homes built in nearby Katonah, N.Y., around the turn of the century. But the unit prices of $325,000 to $375,000 are thoroughly modern - and a bit daunting to some prospective buyers.

title: THE WORLD: Terrorism; Army of Scholars Study Terrorists' Visions
description: TERRORISM, since it burst anew on the international scene in the early 1970's, particularly in the Middle East, has spawned a small army of researchers and specialists, including government officials, political scientists, journalists, psychologists, and others, trying to understand its causes and the best ways of putting a stop to it. Among the basic questions they are asking are these: What pushes some people over the boundary from dissatisfaction and protest into terrorist activity? Is each terrorist group a case apart, or do they belong to common patterns? Are there things that can be done to identify people who are prone to terrorism and draw them away from the terrorist groups that encourage them? Finally, in a world where the same violent killers are described as terrorists and freedom fighters, what is the most accurate definition of terrorism?

title: Vienna
description: To the Editor: Your article on ''Vienna's Love of the Trolley'' (Travel, Aug. 23) reminded me of my own experience. First of all it was very amusing to see official signs along the Ringstrasse track saying ''Warum so schnell'' (Why so fast). At one point we were tooling along at a very comfortable speed when coming around the corner on a narrow street we were stopped by a small car parked halfway across the tracks. All the clanging of bells was of no avail so the conductor and two passengers stepped out and lifted the car onto the sidewalk, and off we went again at a not-too-fast clip. HEDWIG GROSS Port Washington, L.I.

title:
MUSIC;
2 NEW JERSEY ORCHESTRAS TO PLAY IN CARNEGIE HALL
description: LEAD: THE Westfield Symphony Orchestra, under its music director, Brad Keimach, will give its second Carnegie Hall performance Saturday at 2 P.M.

title: Correction

title: A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
description: K. C. Cole's informative essay on the latest developments in mathematical physics left out only an explanation of why physicists believe that the new and remarkable theory of strings is, as they call it, the theory of everything. The history of science demonstrates that all progressive research programs not only explain the anomalies left unaccounted for by existing theories, but also reinterpret the domain of observable facts in the application of new conceptual models. At times of major scientific advance, what counts as ''everything'' is, therefore, itself thrown into flux, and will eventually falsilfy - at least in part -those very ideas that nurtured it into existence. JOHN KADVANY Santa Cruz, Calif.

title: After 17-Month Delay, Fans Attend Kate Smith Memorial
description: In the flag-draped sanctuary of St. Agnes Church here, before a two-foot portrait of the late singer Kate Smith, the Rev. Albert Salmon, looked out on the 700 people who had come to pay to the woman who gave voice to American patriotism.

Such celebrated cases as the Community Book Store - whose owner put a $53.88 price on Mayor Koch's book ''Mayor'' three years ago to protest a 300 percent rent increase -have directed the spotlight on this narrow street in Brooklyn Heights, where changing needs and catapulting rents have reshaped the mix of merchants.

title: NONFICTION
description: AN URCHIN IN THE STORM: Essays About Books and Ideas. By Stephen Jay Gould. (Norton, $18.95.) This collection of reviews is a perfect volume for fans of Stephen Jay Gould. For everyone else serious about writing or thinking, ''An Urchin in the Storm'' is nearly a perfect study in method. Mr. Gould, a paleontologist with a bent for the subtleties in arguments about nature and nurture and the intricacies of evolutionary theory, teaches at Harvard. He also writes about other people's writing the way it should be done. ''Each of these chapters,'' he says in a little preface that lays out his approach to knowledge, ''uses an individual book to pursue a general theme, but organizes its discussion as a critique of content.'' A chapter entitled ''Deep Time and Ceaseless Motion,'' a review of two works on geology, explores how facts and ideas commingle in creative science. A review of a biography of a Nobelist, Barbara McClintock, whose work led the way to modern molecular genetics, is about the ''initial rejection (or, more frustratingly, simple incomprehension) of great insights.'' And ''Exultation and Explanation,'' a review of two books by the ecologist G. E. Hutchinson, is about diversity and its limits. It is also a celebration of the richness of the world. Indefatigable in his determination to fight reductionism, Mr. Gould is proof of his own postulate in Chapter Three, ''Misserving Memory,'' a review of an attack on Darwin's originality: ''The analogy between childhood wonder and adult creativity is biology, not metaphor.''

title: CHILDREN WITH CANCER DESIGN HOLIDAY CARDS
description: LEAD: WHEN 6-year old Francesca, a patient of Yale-New Haven Hospital's Comprehensive Cancer Center, arrived home one January morning after completing the first phase of treatment for her illness, her flagging spirits were considerably revived by the large papier-mache snowman that greeted her.

title: BAKED VEGETABLES OF AUTUMN CELEBRATE THE HARVEST SEASON
description: TURKEY may be the star of the Thanksgiving table, but vegetables play an effectual supporting role. And since this holiday is the celebration of the harvest, I like to serve a selection. I bake whole acorn squashes in the oven, not cutting them open until after they are cooked. Then I slice them in half, scoop out the seeds and add a little butter, salt and pepper. Nothing else is needed. Winter squashes develop much more flavor baked his way than they do when they are cut open beforehand - and they are ridiculously simple to prepare.

title: Headliners; New Ending
description: Former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland is no longer an ex-convict. Mr. Mandel was governor when he was convicted in 1977 of taking $380,000 in bribes in return for influencing racetrack legislation. He served 19 months in jail, paid a $40,000 fine, resigned his office and was disbarred. Last week, a Federal district judge in Baltimore overturned the convictions of Mr. Mandel and five co-defendants. The judge said that under a recent Supreme Court ruling, the Federal mail fraud statute under which the six were convicted did not apply to the acts of which they were accused. Mr. Mandel, now 67 years old, said he was vindicated. The Federal prosecutor in Baltimore, Arnold M. Weiner, saw things differently. ''Whatever the decision, the man is guilty,'' Mr. Weiner said.

title: OLD HOUSE AT ISSUE IN EAST HAMPTON
description: LEAD: A PUBLIC hearing next Friday in East Hampton may determine the fate of one of the most important historic structures in the village, the Lyman Beecher House.

title: WITH OUR MOVING WEAPNS, FIGHTING FOR TERITORY ALONG THE MERRIT
description: LIKE most Americans, I own an advanced state-of-the-art weapons system. Mine is a 1 1/2-ton missile propelled by a finely tuned, highly sophisticated, computer-controlled power plant that, with the slightest touch of the controls, is capable of generating forces several hundreds of times the force that I, alone, a normal mortal, unassisted, can produce. I drive a car. Every weekday morning, along with several hundred thousand other weapons-system operators, I slide behind the controls of this sleek machine and guide it easily onto the Merritt Parkway missile path for the ''50-Mile Challenge'' that winds serpentinely through the Connecticut hills and valleys to my office in Stamford.

title: Picking Out Handcrafts in the Markets of Acapulco

An impressive part of the population of this tropical resort, estimated at nearly one million, is involved in the production, promotion or sale of handcrafts. Acapulco, with its magnificent natural bay, has always been an important trading center and was known for an annual spring fair as early as the 16th century.

title: Yugoslavia
description: To the Editor: I traveled extensively in Yugoslavia, visiting the country more than 10 times since the early 70's. Although, I must agree with the author that Yugoslavs are carnivorous, as much as Americans and most of the other Europeans, what struck me the most is the abundance of fruit, vegetables, cheese, yogurts and seafood along the Adriatic coast. I even discovered some vegetables that were new to me. A favorite of mine was blitva, which I describe as a gourmet version of spinach. I could go on about the melons, grapes, plums and last, but not least, the figs of Yugoslavia.

title: PUBLIC HEALTH PERSONNEL GET AN UPDATE ON AIDS
description: BECAUSE they confront AIDS daily in their jobs, 700 New Jerseyans gathered here recently for an official update on the state's No. 1 health concern.

title: FICTION
description: KALEIDOSCOPE. By Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) In her 21st novel, Danielle Steel continues her forays into the life styles of the rich and heartsick. This time, readers are led to war-torn Europe, where they witness the burgeoning friendship of two Americans, Sam Walker and Arthur Patterson, as well as the heady love affair between Sam and Solange Bertrand, an exquisite Frenchwoman. When the war ends, Sam and Solange marry. Their union, complete with three beautiful daughters, is a love for the ages - until Sam kills Solange in a jealous rage and commits suicide. This unhappy turn of events leaves his friend Arthur with the task of finding homes for the three orphan girls - Hilary, Alexandra and Megan. At first Arthur farms them out to their alcoholic aunt; then he separates the three girls, leaving each ignorant of her sisters' widely divergent fates. Hilary, the eldest, who remains with her aunt, endures all manner of indignity and abuse but holds onto the dream of one day finding her sisters. Ms. Steel's familiar themes of love and loss are here in abundance, along with exotic locales, expensive restaurants, titled Frenchmen, antique furniture and fresh flowers in every room. There's even the atypical addition of social awareness when baby Megan grows up to become a doctor in poverty-stricken Appalachia. As one might expect, Ms. Steel is on shaky ground here and quickly returns to the traumas she knows best: rape, incest, abortion and unfaithful husbands. Will Hilary find her grown-up sisters? Will Alexandra's titled husband abandon her once he knows the truth about her past? And what deep secret will forever alter Megan's life? The fun of ''Kaleidoscope'' lies in discovering the answers to these and other questions. So make a pot of tea, curl up under a favorite quilt - and keep a box of tissues close at hand.

title: VISIT TO PLANET OF THE FIT
description: I MADE a surprise landing on Planet of the Fit. It was a surprise for me because I was unaware of this alien region, only a short drive away, orbiting a remote hemisphere in a nearby mall.

title: A SMALL DOOR OPENS FOR QUALITY EVENT
description: BRIDGE administrators have argued about processes of selection for almost as long as biologists, and like them continue to disagree.

title: Downhill Hockey
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Weeds In the Garden
description: FOR anyone suffering from exhaustion from trying to pull the weeds out of the Garden, take two spoonfuls of Mets and Giants history and relax. Chances are that the Knicks and the Rangers will get even worse before they get better.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Singing Socialist Of Burlington

title: Joe Mantegna, Bad Egg For Hire
description: JOE MANTEGNA REVELS IN shady characters: slimy gamblers, cutthroat salesmen, lecherous dentists, mercurial mobsters and Hollywood hucksters. He plays the type of men who snarl, ''You say I acted atrociously? Yes I did. I do it for a living.'' Even his less raffish roles are rarely saintly - a New York actor impersonating an ex-con, an ambitious attorney who ''wants to be Senator after he's President.''

title: The Call's Not Close
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Moderates at Arab Talks Seize the Day
description: AS he stepped to the meeting table, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria stumbled into the seat reserved for his rival Baath Party comrade and now bitterest of enemies, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: Backfield Bickering
description: The problem with having two top running backs on the same football team is that the game is played with only one football. That is the conundrum that has been befuddling Coach Tom Landry of the Dallas Cowboys as he has tried to figure out how to get the most out of his two former Heisman Trophy winners, Tony Dorsett, the 33-year-old star who has gained more than 1,000 yards in 8 of his 10 seasons, and Herschel Walker, the 25-year-old comparative newcomer who has been designated as the team's running back of the future.

title: A NETWORK FOR REVOLT
description: APARTHEID'S REBELS Inside South Africa's Hidden War. By Stephen M. Davis. 238 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. Cloth, $27.50. Paper, $8.95.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: MANAGING FOR INCREASED COMPETITIVENESS;
Make Decisions Like a Fighter Pilot
description: LEAD: CORPORATE strategy goes through phases. Companies have been restructuring their business portfolios and operations through the mid-1980's to raise stock prices and cut costs, and many are asking what to do next. How will the next round of competitive advantage be created? Leading-edge companies across a variety of industries are beginning to give the answer: build an organization with fast response time in serving customers and pre-empting competitors, and you will grow profitably.

title: The Splintering of Finley, Kumble
description: LEAD: AS RECENTLY as two months ago, Steven J. Kumble and Harvey D. Myerson boasted to anyone who would listen that their law firm, Finley, Kumble, Wagner, Underberg, Manley, Myerson & Casey, had taken just 19 years to reach a size that others would have needed 190 years to achieve.

title: SITTING OUT THE DANCE OF LIFE
description: THE YEAR OF SILENCE By Madison Smartt Bell. 194 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $15.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: ON OTHER DAYS WHILE GOING HOME. By Michelle Carter. (Morrow, $15.95.) Excitement, total freedom and a sense of being ''born to ride the highways'' are prized by Annie, the headstrong adolescent maverick who is the heroine of Michelle Carter's uneven first novel. This orphaned girl develops unconventional tastes while living in the back rooms of her aunt Marie's San Francisco bail bond office, which is located in a dilapidated neighborhood frequented by outcasts and upstarts, a place that heightens Annie's affinity for what Marie calls life's ''dark side.

title: Jazz: Braff on Trumpet
description: RUBY BRAFF objects to being called a jazz musician. He is, he says, an entertainer with a horn. He once made an album called ''Adoration of the Melody,'' and that is the way he approaches his music.

title: THAT GREAT BLANK PAGE, THE SCREEN
description: LEAD: THEY say I'm cinematic. Since I make most of my living as a cinematographer, it would appear that when I write, I do so under the influence of movies.

title: 'WHAT DID YOU EAT?'
description: LIVING HUNGRY IN AMERICA By J. Larry Brown and H. F. Pizer. Illustrated. 212 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95.

title: Maryland Considering A Computer Photo File
description: In an effort to keep drivers with excessive traffic violations off the road, the state of Maryland is considering storing photographs of drivers in a computer to prevent people from getting several licenses.

title: Risky Markets
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
THE RUSH IS ON FOR NEW EAGLE COINS
description: LEAD: THE deadline for ordering proof examples of the 1987 American Eagle gold and silver bullion coins is Dec. 1. The United States Mint is offering proof versions of the gold American Eagle in the 1-ounce and 1/2-ounce sizes. It also is offering a proof of the 1-ounce silver American Eagle. Each of the three coins can be purchased individually.

title: OUT OF A DARKNESS
description: Reading Frank Wolkenberg's article ''Out of a Darkness'' (Oct. 11) was a remarkable experience for me. I felt he was describing my life.

title: WHY CAN'T A MAN BE MORE LIKE A WOMAN?
description: WOMEN AND LOVE A Cultural Revolution in Progress. By Shere Hite. 922 pp. New York: Alfred A Knopf. $24.95.

title: JAPAN: For Its Retirees, Tokyo Is Relying on Self-Reliance
description: IT is not just in the United States that people worry about who is going to pay for social security. Throughout the industrialized world, because of the baby boom's huge presence and low fertility rates, the classic demographic pyramid is narrowing at the base and swelling at the top. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development projects that in its 24 member nations the proportion of the population aged 65 and over will rise from 12 percent now to 22 percent in 2040. In the seven largest O.E.C.D. countries, there is now one elderly person for every five of working age; in 2040 the ratio will be 2 to 5.

title: A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
description: The article on Edward Witten and string theory excited the mystic in me. As Malcolm W. Browne pointed out in the accompanying box, ''Mathematics and Magic,'' the 16th-century cabalists postulated that the world was created by an outpouring of divine emanations, 10 in number, called the Sefirot. The ''vibrations'' of these realms are accessible to the human senses only in their lowest manifestations.

title: 'HOUSE OF BLUE LEAVES,' TRAGICOMEDY
description: ARTIE SHAUGHNESSY has been infected with the American dream of making it big in show business. In John Guare's surreal tragicomedy, ''The House of Blue Leaves,'' the only impediment's to Artie's rise to songwriting fame are Bananas, his insane wife; Ronnie, his AWOL son, and -well, that's just the beginning. Suffice it to say that Artie is having a very, very bad day.

title: Gunman Surrenders After Detaining Former Wife
description: A North Brunswick man ordered customers out of a post office at gunpoint and held his former wife hostage there for about eight hours today before releasing her and surrendering, according to the police. The police said no one was injured. The incident began shortly after noon when the man, Daniel Alfrey, 38 years old, apparently angry that his former wife had a boyfriend, walked into the post office, the authorities said.

title: The New Allure of Treasury Securities
description: WITH the continuing turmoil in the stock market, Treasury securities have taken on new allure. The biggest attraction is their safety - Treasuries are backed by the full faith and credit of the United States. But demand for the securities, especially those with maturities of six months or less, has become so strong that it has depressed yields. Professionals in the fixed-income market say some of the best deals right now are not straight Treasuries but rather their close relatives, zero-coupon Treasuries.

title: Alarming Rise in Breast Cancer Indicated by Data
description: Breast cancer may become an increasingly serious problem for women as those of the baby boom generation grow older, Federal health researchers report.

title: Music: Kent Nagano Makes Philharmonic Debut
description: FRESH from leading a Steve Reich program for the Next Wave Festival in Brooklyn, the 36-year-old Kent Nagano is making his New York Philharmonic debut at the orchestra's current Avery Fisher Hall subscription concerts - the only conductor to appear for the first time with the Philharmonic this season.

title: About Men; A Fear of Lawyers
description: WHEN MY SON DECIDED several years ago to turn his back on a budding career as a rock saxophonist and become a lawyer, the first question I, who had practiced law for three decades, asked myself was: ''Where have I gone wrong?'' He was accustomed to a profession in which every amplified blast of his horn, every adroit bit of body language on stage, was greeted by an adoring audience with hoots of pleasure and shouts for more. ''Law's a different bag,'' I warned. ''Nobody will like you.'' Being liked, he replied, should not be a man's top priority. Besides, he argued, pop music was essentially a kid's world; law was a man's world.

title: Iran Panels to Seek Stricter Rules on Covert Acts
description: The report by the Congressional Iran-contra committees will recommend new rules for covert operations that go further than the changes announced earlier this year by President Reagan, according to Congressional officials.

title: DATA BANK: November 15, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Harvard Chagrined by Agreement With Donors
description: Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government was embarrassed this week when the university's undergraduate student newspaper printed internal documents revealing that the graduate school had tentatively agreed to offer special status to a couple in exchange for a $500,000 donation.

title: NONFICTION
description: FATSO: Football When Men Were Really Men. By Arthur J. Donovan Jr. and Bob Drury. (Morrow, $15.95.) Reading Arthur Donovan's account of what it was like playing pro football in the 1950's is as close as most of us will ever get to sitting around a big-league locker room, opening a few cool ones and listening to the big guys talk about the legendary wars and warriors of the good old days, before million-dollar contracts, before the Super Bowl, when there was still at least one player (Chuck Bednarik) who played both ways, offense and defense, for 60 full minutes per game. It is a book full of nostalgia, some insights on how the great ones played the game, and how Mr. Donovan, a defensive tackle who weighed more than 300 pounds, thumped his way from the Bronx to the Baltimore Colts, for whom he made a key tackle against the New York Giants to help the Colts win (23-17) the 1958 championship game that is often called the greatest game ever played in the National Football League. The strength of the book is its honesty: Mr. Donovan admits he was flat on his back at another key point in the big game; that he despised Coach Weeb Ewbank; that he admires hard-drinking, violent men, although his father, a famous boxing referee, punched out a friend, who later died, in a drunken brawl. The story is told in locker-room expletives, conscientiously picked up by Mr. Donovan's co-author, Bob Drury, a reporter for New York Newsday and a former sports columnist for The New York Post. But there are many insider's nuggets: how Notre Dame Coach Frank Leahy pulled Mr. Donovan out of a sickbed to play; how, before face masks became widely used, Johnny Unitas would punch those about to tackle him; how the hated Ewbank froze up in a crisis. Mr. Donovan, a member of the game's Hall of Fame, does not at all pretend to be the thinking man's old pro. ''If Shula and Lombardi were generals,'' he says of those two great coaches, ''we wouldn't be worrying about the Soviet Union today. It would be part of the United States.'' Or at least the Bronx.

title: Snowfall Cancels Suffolk Racing
description: The Sunday racing card at Suffolk Downs was canceled because of the snowfall last week, but a regular schedule will resume on Monday, officials said.

title: WHY WIDENING CONGESTED HIGHWAYS IS THE WRONG ROUTE TO FOLLOW
description: FOR more than 30 years, highway departments have been selling us the same old bill of goods: ''building more highways to ease congestion.'' After spending billions upon billions and paving over countless acres of valuable land, congestion is worse than ever. None of the state transportation department's proposals will ease the jams for long. Let them widen Route 287 to 20 lanes and congestion will soon return.

title: CASUAL AMBIANCE IN NEW CANAAN
description: AT the crossroads between the fast-food getaway and a formal dining experience is the neighborhood family-style restaurant, the place for an informal meal away from home, hearth and kitchen stove. Every town needs at least one, a place where children are welcome and you can drop by for a hamburger or a steak and feel comfortable wearing jeans.

title: Braids and Flowers
description: BLACK and white in almost infinite variations is the key to Gloria Sachs's spring collection.

title: Robin Drake Cameron Married to Richard Steen
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Englewood, N.J., Robin Drake Cameron, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Cameron of Englewood, was married yesterday to Richard Spencer Steen, a son of Mrs. George Voutsas of Carmel, Calif., and the late Dr. Sigvart J. Steen. The Rev. Jack M. McKelvey performed the ceremony.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
VIDEOS FOR READING
description: LEAD: If the youngsters in the reading-encouragement commercials on cable television look familiar, it may just be that you have seen them at your own local library. The Westchester students, from 12 to 17 years old, won their parts in auditions at the Warner Library in Tarrytown.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: East Burke, Vt.;
Economic Lift For Ski Area
description: LEAD: A MASSACHUSETTS developer who bought the Burke Mountain ski area at a bankruptcy auction in September expects to give the region known as the Northeast Kingdom, which is largely wilderness, an economic shot in the arm.

title: Recent Sales
description: East Islip $230,000 11 Meadow Farm Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old split level; den, solarium, fully carpeted, country setting; taxes $4,200. Kings Park $189,000 43 Juniper Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; den, new kitchen, finished basement, oak floors, 0.5 acre; taxes $5,400. Lake Grove $182,500 28 Patricia Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; den with fireplace, finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $3,500. Plainview $250,000 8 Oakwood Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split level; den, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $5,200. Sayville $422,000 123 Benson Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old waterfront colonial; family room, dining room, fireplace; taxes $6,300. Wantagh $169,000 2833 Michael Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; whirlpool, basement; taxes $2,900. OTHER AREAS Aberdeen, N.J. $170,000 125 Van Brackle Road 3-bedroom, 2 bath, 12-year-old ranch; family room, 2 patios; taxes $2,395. Peekskill, N.Y. $236,000 8 Avenue A, Quarry Acres 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, walk to station, 2-car garage; taxes $3,411. Norwalk, Conn. $235,000 4 Morningside Place 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old Cape Cod; near water, hardwood floors, windowed porch; taxes $1,500.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
ART
description: LEAD: The Cubist Epoch Museum Without Walls. Kartes Video Communications. 53 minutes. $14.95. This film begins with energetic vintage footage of Paris at the turn of the century -pedestrians dodging traffic, dancing girls onstage - and a voice-over about progress and how it was all the rage. Then it unaccountably slips into what seems like slow motion.

title: THE LIFE AND SLOW DEATH OF A CITY CHURCH
description: NEWARK'S Central Ward is a collection of fragments: institutions that have stayed put and grown while most fled, shiny new suburban-style housing built for homeowners, the darker remains of the city of the poor and much cleared land.

title: A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
description: I am impressed by Edward Witten's accomplishments. However, I think he misses the point when he says: ''One lesson you can learn is don't make mistakes.'' The history of science is fraught with mistakes, made, in some cases, by eminent scientists, including Newton and Einstein. It is from these mistakes, in most cases, that we learn. BENJAMIN ALTMAN Royal Palm Beach, Fla.

title: HEMPSTEAD CLUBS SUE OVER ZONING
description: LEAD: TWO beach clubs in Atlantic Beach have filed suit in State Supreme Court to overturn the Town of Hempstead's marine recreational district rezoning along the oceanfront, which halts development.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BANGKOK
description: When the day is clear or the moon is bright, the traveler descending on Bangkok from the air can see right through one of Thailand's disguises.

title: Chirac in Lisbon for Talks
description: Prime Minister Jacques Chirac of France arrived in Lisbon today for a day of talks with Portuguese leaders on the European Community and international issues, a Portuguese Government spokesman said.

title: THE WAR ON AIDS TAKES TO THE STREETS
description: LEAD: THREE social workers trained to be at ease in the frenetic world of drug addicts are beginning to comb the streets of New Haven in hopes of stopping the spread of AIDS among intravenous drug users.

title: G. W. Bayer Wed To Joanne Blum
description: At the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club last evening, Joanne Lori Blum, the daughter of Gary L. Blum of Manhattan and Harriet E. Blum of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married to Glenn Warren Bayer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Bayer of Lawrence, L.I. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony.

title: Wagner Put on Hold
description: Susan Wagner tentatively won the Staten Island division of the Public School Athletic League's A Conference yesterday and took its first step toward repeating as league champion. The eligiblity of one of its players is in question, and the league expects to make an announcement tomorrow that could mean Wagner would forfeit all its games.

title: Alexandra Bloch Engaged to Wed Lawrence Jeydel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Bloch of New York and Southbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Bloch, to Lawrence Alan Jeydel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Jeydel of Fair Haven, N.J. A March wedding is planned.

title: An Adoption Proposal
description: To the Editor:

title: Eurotunnel's Day of Reckoning
description: WANTED: Investors. Must be willing to pony up $1.4 billion for a company that will collect no money for at least six years but will, all the while, stuff billions into a hole in the ground.

title: Andrea J. Curran Planning to Wed
description: Prof. and Mrs. Ward S. Curran of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Andrea Jannett Curran to Brian Cullinan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Cullinan of North Conway, N.H.

title: POETS UNDERFOOT
description: CLOSE CONNECTIONS Caroline Gordon and the Southern Renaissance. By Ann Waldron. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.

title: Joseph H. McMahon, Wesleyan Professor, 57
description: Joseph H. McMahon, Hollis Professor of Romance Languages and Literatures at Wesleyan University, died Thursday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn., where he was hospitalized after a heart attack on Oct. 21. He was 57 years old and lived in Middletown.

title: Of Jams And A Family
description: PAUL H. SMUCKER WAS worried when he looked down the table during a board of director's meeting of his little country company some years back. To be sure, he knew everyone there. Seated around him were Willard E. Smucker, his father; Welker J. Smucker, his uncle; Aunt Winna Smucker; Aunt Wilma Smucker, and her husband, Harold Good.

title: BREAKING THE CRACK MURDERS
description: ON FEB. 15, THIS MAGAZINE published my article ''Crack Murder,'' the story of a veteran homicide detective, Albert E. Cachie, and his investigation of the killing of a Brooklyn crack dealer, James Baker. Baker had been found dead in the passenger seat of his Mercedes with a bullet wound in his chest and four others from another gun in his head and neck. At the request of the police, so as not to jeopardize their investigation, I gave Baker the fictional name of ''Halfback'' in the article. As the story went to press, Cachie and his partner on the case, Detective Donald Gregori, had developed leads to the motive for the slaying: two bitter feuds Baker was conducting - one with a drug supplier, another with a man police believe to be a rival crack tycoon, Donny Smallwood (''Eddie Holmes'' in the original article).

title: A Korea Candidate Is Forced to Leave Rally for Campaign
description: Kim Young Sam, the South Korean presidential candidate, abandoned a campaign rally today after being shouted down by tens of thousands of supporters of his opposition rival, Kim Dae Jung.

title: Italy's Government Falls as Small Party Quits
description: The 15-week-old Government of Prime Minister Giovanni Goria resigned today after the small Liberal Party withdrew from the governing coalition in a dispute over measures to reduce the huge budget deficit.

title: Markets Welcome Smaller Trade Gap
description: The trade deficit shrank in September, with the value of the nation's imports exceeding that of exports by $14.1 billion, down $1.6 billion from August. The September number was at the low end of what had been expected and financial markets were pleased, especially when traders recalled that the ''October massacre'' began with the release of the August number on Oct. 14. For September, exports grew 3.8 percent, with manufactured goods posting a solid gain. The import side did improve, with a drop of 2.4 percent, but most of that was attributed to declining oil imports, a situation that could be temporary. The differential with Western Europe narrowed sharply and there was a lesser improvement with Japan. The one area of deterioration was with Canada.

title: Co-ops Make Inroads in Isolated Inwood
description: LYING amid bridges at Manhattan's northern tip, Inwood is connected to the rest of the island by Broadway and two subway lines, to Washington Heights often by a hyphen, and to several Caribbean islands by a stream of packages that leaves the post office on Vermilyea Avenue from the neighborhood's large Hispanic community. But it has always led a somewhat isolated existence.

title: SANTA CLAUS TO ARRIVE ON A CARROUSEL
description: SANTA CLAUS has come to other towns in shiny convertibles, in helicopters that land on country-club lawns and at railroad stations, but Woodbridge Center's St. Nick will arrive this year on a new carrousel that will become a permanent attraction.

title: O'Neill Remains Hospitalized Amid Reports He Has Cancer
description: Former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. remained hospitalized in satisfactory condition today and his son would not comment on published reports that his father suffers from cancer of the large intestine.

title: Bombing at Hospital in Beirut Kills 7 and Wounds 31
description: A bomb hidden in a box of chocolates blew up in the American University Hospital in West Beirut today, killing 7 people and wounding 31, the police said.

title: UNSPOILED FESTIVAL IN OYSTER BAY
description: Contrary to the article on Long Island street festivals [ ''Success Spoils Annual Street Fairs, Oct. 25 ] , the annual Oyster Festival is neither spoiled nor unmanageable.

title: OPERA: CITY ENSEMBLE IN 'TURN OF THE SCREW'
description: BRITTEN'S operas - ''The Turn of the Screw'' among them - test small opera companies but also reward the virtuous among them. The orchestra parts are finely made, and their original touches speak most clearly through equally fine chamber groups. Britten's words demand the same kind of clarity; they are meant to be heard and understood at close quarters.

title: A la Carte
description: WHERE are the best onion rings on Long Island?

title: STREETSCAPES: The Coney Island Parachute Jump; For the Boardwalk's 'Eiffel Tower,' Restoration or Regulating a Ruin?
description: AMONG the many advances in military aviation in the 1930's was a tower to train paratroopers patented by Comdr. James H. Strong in 1936. He licensed one such six-chute tower for a Chicago amusement park. But for the 1939-1940 World's Fair in New York, Commander Strong developed a 250-foot high version with 12 parachutes.

title: STATE REVIEWS BULKHEADS, FEARING POSSIBLE HARM
description: LEAD: THE use of bulkheads has long been a primary method of minimizing erosion of shorelines and damage to homes from storms. However, because of environmental concerns, the Long Island office of the State Department of Environmental Conservation is re-evaluating its policy on bulkheads, particularly on the southeastern shore, where there are indications that these structures may be ineffective or even harmful.

title: Debra L. Wolf Weds M. A. Koenig, Teacher
description: Debra Lynn Wolf and Mark Akulin Koenig were married yesterday at their home in New Rochelle, N.Y., by Rabbi Sandy Bogin.

title: COOKING FOR ONE, FOREVER
description: I HAVE decided to embrace, provisionally, advice to go on living as much as possible as I did before. So yesterday at the supermarket I bought loin lamb chops.

title: WHO WILL CONTROL POPULATION GROWTH?
description: This letter is in response to the Oct. 25 Opinion Page article ''The Population Bomb Is Still Ticking.'' I agree with Diana Gerhardt's assessment that Long Island is overcrowded; we do have too much garbage, too much population and too many shopping centers being built. Our traffic situation is deplorable during midday and the rush hours try the patience of many.

title: A Wedding Is Planned By Dr. Jennifer S. Hock
description: Dr. Jennifer Suzanne Hock and Dr. Bruce Brod, who are residents at the Rhode Island Hospital in Providence, plan to be married in March.

title:
DINING OUT;
ITALIAN, AT A NEW YONKERS ADDRESS
description: LEAD: AFTER two-and-a-half years on narrow New Main Street, Paolo's has moved around the corner to one of the county's wider boulevards in an up and coming neighborhood. That move has changed not only the restaurant's address but its status as well. Erstwhile ''cafe,'' Paolo's is now clearly a full restaurant, taking its place among the county's serious eating establishments.

title: Best Brand Of Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a large bluestone patio about 10 years old, and some of the cement between the flags is coming out of the joints. Can you tell us how to handle this problem?

title: NEW OPERA PREMIERE
description: LEAD: STEPHEN Dickman, whom critics have called a gifted American composer, has a theory about music.

title: Bank Closings
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: SOUNDS FROM THE '60'S

title: Judge Delays Transfer of Inmates to a Barge
description: An appellate judge has temporarily barred the New York City Department of Correction from transferring inmates to a former troop barge, but the agency will continue to seek to use the barge as a jail, an agency spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: NEW HELP ON FEARS OF LEAVING THE HOUSE
description: LEAD: A NUN, a short-story writer, a homemaker, an accountant and a nurse may appear to have little in common. But these patients at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center's Phobia Clinic do share one of the most frequent emotional problems: fear of leaving home alone.

title: Why Say No to 1,500 Warheads?
description: The centerpiece of next month's superpower summit meeting is to be the signing of a treaty eliminating intermediate-range nuclear forces. The public and Congressional debate about ratifying the treaty will greatly influence future arms control efforts and our relations with Europe and the Soviet Union. While informed opinions on the merits of the treaty differ, a few basic considerations can help guide the debate.

title: Ib Andersen and the Seasons of a Dancer
description: DESPITE GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''NO-STAR'' policy at the New York City Ballet, the company produced many stars during his 35 years as benevolent dictator. The last male artist on whom Balanchine created major roles is Ib Andersen, who, almost five years after Balanchine's death, has come into his prime - with little fanfare.

title: A Tribute To a Man Of Charity
description: Great deeds were not Donald Savio's lot in life. Small kindnesses were.

title: Left and Right
description: To the Editor:

title: MICHIGAN STATE WINS
description: The flowers were bought, sold and fastened to lapels long before the Michigan State Spartans took the field for their historic afternoon. Lorenzo White's record-setting runs for the roses merely made them appropriate.

title: Suspected Nazi Fugitive Seized in Argentina
description: Acting on a 14-year-old request from a West German court, the Argentine authorities have arrested a man they identified as Josef Franz Leo Schwammberger, an accused Nazi war criminal, at a ranch in the province of Cordoba.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in a listing of Trans-Panama cruises on Nov. 1 misidentified the cruise line that operates the Bermuda Star; it is the Bermuda Star Line.

title: REDS' DAVIS HAS TOP AVERAGE AT PUTTING RUNS ON SCOREBOARD
description: HIS statistical status will provide little solace to the Cincinnati Reds, who squandered their chance to win a division title, but Eric Davis attained a remarkable level of run production efficiency this year.

title: The Imaginary Hero: Don't Leave Home Without Him
description: CAPTAIN VINEGAR'S COMMISSION By Philip Glazebrook. 333 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: Practical Traveler; Approach With Caution: Mopeds for Novice Riders
description: THE entry on getting around by cycle in Bermuda in the 1988 edition of a well-known guidebook includes the following sentences about motorized bicycles, or mopeds: ''If you've never ridden before, don't worry. You'll have as much time as you need to practice in an open area before hitting the road.''

title: Deaf Teacher Sharpens His Students' Sensitivity to Others
description: LEAD: RICHARD KOENIGSBERG, a high school humanities teacher here, was checking attendance, calling the names of students who obviously could not hear him above the din.

title: A RUNNER STUMBLES INTO FITNESS
description: A STUDY disclosed that most women dislike their bodies. It reported, however, that men tend to see themselves as just about perfect. This startled me at first. Then I laughed. Then I thought about it.

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY BASEBALL

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: It's How You Play the Game Screaming and clapping, the home-team crowd was going wild in the balcony overlooking the college's tiny gymnasium. The entire student body was on its feet. (Actually, they had to be, since there weren't any seats.) But euphoria was rampant, for it was the opening home basketball game and their team was winning, as in scoring more points than the opponent, a feat most students had only dreamed about.

title: From Sinkhole To Wildlife Lake
description: SIX years ago it was a murky sinkhole that swallowed a three-bedroom bungalow, half a municipal swimming pool and five new sports cars in Winter Park, Fla. Authorities said then that it was the biggest known sinkhole, about 100 feet deep, 350 feet wide and 300 feet long.

title: SCHOOL SPORTS: New Jersey; Linden Squeaks By
description: Linden's star running back, Kelvin Johnson, scored on a 27-yard run with three minutes left in the game to lift his team to a 19-13 victory over Westfield yesterday at Linden. It was the eighth success for unbeaten Linden, a strong contender for the North Jersey Section 2, Group IV championship in the playoffs.

title: When Artistic Rebels Set England Aglow
description: ONE OF THE MOST POWERFUL works of art to have been produced in Britain during this century is the ''Hieratic Head of Ezra Pound'' by the very young French sculptor Henri Gaudier-Brzeska. Carved in 1914, and now the centerpiece of ''British Modernist Art: 1905-1930'' at the Hirschl & Adler Galleries, 21 East 70th Street, it stands for a key moment in the history of the cosmopolitan London that was to be dispersed and demoralized by the outbreak of World War I in August 1914.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: LEAD: New Books: For Sale And Discussion Next Sunday at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at Purchase a book-signing reception and a discussion of new books by Dick Higgins, Warren Lehrer, Judy Tomkins and Richard Martin will take place beginning at 3 P.M. The $4 admission fee is applicable toward the purchase price of any featured book (the fee is $2 to Friends of the Neuberger Museum and $1 for State University students, faculty and staff).

title: William Rion Bonham, Comptroller, 65
description: William Rion Bonham, comptroller for the law firm of Goldberg & Finmann, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Glen Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Sea Cliff, L.I.

title: DOORS ARE OPEN AGAIN AT THE COUNTY CENTER
description: LEAD: THE roof needs further repair, the floor is not finished and the restrooms, while indoors, are on another floor. Still, after two years away from it, Diane Wendy said she was happy to be back home at the County Center.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Nov. 1 with an article about a museum in Vermillion, S.D., reversed the labels for two neighboring states; they were Iowa and Minnesota.

title: Far From the Madding Crowd
description: VACATION sweepstakes to Tahiti. Robert Goulet at the mall. Ticket giveaways. These are hardly the techniques used to promote Broadway blockbusters. But Spokane and Tulsa are a long way from Times Square, and when Pace Theatrical Group Inc. takes such touring productions as ''South Pacific,'' starring Mr. Goulet, on the road, it uses aggressive marketing tactics - as much as popular tunes - to pack the house.

title: Karole Armitage Readies a Fresh Duality
description: JUST ABOUT ANYTHING OUTRAGEOUS could happen when a renowned punk ballerina and a provocateur of the art world collaborate. But when Karole Armitage and David Salle convene at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival for a four-day engagement beginning Wednesday to display their latest endeavors - ''The Tarnished Angels'' and ''The Elizabethan Phrasing of the Late Albert Ayler'' - they'll tackle, instead, the somewhat immaculate tradition of ballet with what appears to be reverence.

title: Opera Gives Its Regards to Broadway
description: THE TERM ''CROSSOVER'' MIGHT SEEM AL-most synonymous with ''music'' in this age of fusion, eclecticism and cross-cultural borrowings. Everybody mixes genres these days, as old traditions crumble and new ones arise. But the most controversial and prominent form of crossover of late has been the incursion of opera singers into the linked worlds of the Broadway musical and the pre-rock popular song. And the serene queen of this incursion has been Kiri Te Kanawa, the diva who put out a Linda Ronstadt-style album of pop standards arranged by Nelson Riddle called ''Blue Skies'' (Miss Ronstadt's three Riddle albums were crossover ventures from the other direction) and who has dominated the recent spate of operatic musicals.

title: When Best-Laid Plans Go Awry
description: THE THEATER HAS A THOUSAND and one ways of doublecrossing the people who work in it, and woe betide the actor or writer or composer or designer who doesn't keep a cautious eye on his exposed left flank. The theater doesn't mean to trip up any of its attractive inhabitants, of course. It's just that in an activity so collaborative it's very easy to get some of the signals mixed.

title: New Yorker Seeks Symbol of Season
description: Carl Miller, a tall, white-haired man in his mid-50's, often spends weekends driving through the countrysides of New York, Connecticut or New Jersey. Unlike other weekend drivers, Mr. Miller is not on a pleasure trip. He is tree hunting.

title: WELCOME TO MY PHANTASMAGORIA
description: THE ARABIAN NIGHTMARE By Robert Irwin. Illustrated. 282 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: SHOPPERS IN PANIC
description: Poland has announced that average consumer prices will rise by 40 percent in 1988.

title: Pop Music
description: It's a good week for New York bands with international tastes. Saqqara Dogs, a trio that performs Monday and Tuesday at Dance Theater Workshop (219 West 19th Street), keep the world on a guitar string. Their songs, mostly instrumentals, are built on repeating riffs that might come from Africa, the Middle East or the Bronx; the spiky, danceable tunes mix exotic instruments - especially dumbek (drum) and mbira (thumb piano) - with Western electronics, for sparse, minimal funk. The Dance Theater Workshop shows, part of the ''New Song'' series, provide comfortable surroundings, clear sound and an early-evening (8 P.M.) starting time.

title: CLOSELY KNIT
description: IT WAS LIKE HALLOWEEN. PEOPLE WERE knocking pigs and chickens out of the way and stirring skeins of yarn with a long stick.'' Laura Pearson talks animatedly about the days when her handmade sweaters were dyed in a cauldron over an outdoor fire. Now only a handful of her designs for Tijuca, her New York knitwear company, are produced under comparably rugged conditions. All the same, they've managed to retain the slightly uneven stitching and thick burly feel that reveal a human touch.

title: Army's Leader in Niger Is Appointed President
description: The army Chief of Staff was appointed as Niger's head of state today in a unanimous vote of the ruling Supreme Military Council, an official statement on state radio said.

title: Samuel Ach Engaged To Catherine D. Zinke
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William K. Zinke of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Catherine Duryee Zinke to Samuel W. Ach, the son of Sarah C. Ach of Cincinnati and the late Roger W. Ach. A spring wedding is planned.

title: AGENT ORANGE PANEL AIMING TO FINISH IN '90
description: FOURTEEN years after American troops withdrew from Vietnam, a state commission continues to struggle with one of the most controversial results of the war. The Vietnam Herbicides Information Commission was established by legislation in 1982 for what was to have been a five-year program. Last July, the commission was reappointed under new legislation for three years to finish its work.

title: Judge Rejects Dismissal of Charges in Slaying of Denver Radio Host
description: A Federal judge has rejected defense motions for acquittal of four defendants accused of killing Alan Berg, the host of a radio talk show, and closing arguments are scheduled Monday.

title: The Real Dutch?
description: To the Editor:

title: Next Week; Can the Giants and Jets Still Make the Playoffs?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: DON JUAN IN MANHATTAN
description: Don Juan's a hero with a hundred faces: For some he's mostly Mozart, or Moliere. He shows up in a hundred different places, He's profligate, Byronic, debonair. He goes to Hell, so heavy his disgrace is, In ''Man and Superman'' we see him there - A daring Shavian variant on the pattern; So after that let's send him to Manhattan. Picture our hero, then - he wings his way With seat belt buckled, and with heart aglow. He's dreamed for years of this auspicious day, His first taste of the fabled land below. The wheels touch tarmac - this is JFK! The glittering gateway to earth's greatest show! And everything comes up to expectation (Save for the three-hour wait in Immigration). A courteous cabbie speeds him through the dusk. ''So this is Queens . . . And Brooklyn can't be far . . . I'll visit them. . . .'' Right now, though, it's crepusc- Ular, and he pursues a single star - The place that makes all others look subfusc, Manhattan! Vibrant as a Last Hurrah, An apple pie, oh my, reach for the sky borough, Whether approached by Queensboro Bridge or Triborough. He's whisked through shining streets, past flashing signs; Billboards and neon names whiz by pell-mell - David's Cookies, Dunkin' Donuts, Duncan Hines, Crazy Eddie, Kinney, Cartier, Carvel. At length, before he even wines or dines, He checks in at a far from small hotel - No wishing well, no trace of distant steeple, But lots and lots of people (we the people). He mingles with the throng: they're talking turkey, Cranberry, sweet potato, pumpkin pie. At first he's baffled, and it all seems murky, But gradually he grasps the reason why, And when he does, it makes him feel quite perky. He gazes on with an approving eye, And thinks, ''Unless I'm very much deceived, They're giving thanks for benefits received.'' ''Some annual celebration, I'll be bound. Well, they've got good reason for their gratitude. Signs of prosperity are all around, And signs of liberty (or even latitude). The patriotic claims they make are sound, It's not a case of pious platitude. They should all be grateful, every son and daughter -'' (Then a man came up and begged him for a quarter.) Let's skip a day or two - Juan's installed. He takes his ease, and saunters through the city, Amused, amazed, and (once or twice) appalled, And moved to admiration, or to pity. He learns exactly what each landmark's called, Acquires the facts, masters the nitty-gritty. He hunts for unicorns up at the Cloisters, And in Grand Central he consumes his oysters. He learns to tell a Tishman from a Tisch, The difference 'twixt New York and The New Yorker; He dines on pasta, egg foo yong and knish, Washed down with Stoli, sake, Johnny Walker; Reads novelists licked in shape by Gordon Lish; Tunes in to Donahue (a mighty talker); Lunches at Mortimer's with ageless ladies, And rides the subway (not as hot as Hades). The local citizens proclaim their views, For most of them are bold, and few seem shy. They make him offers that he can't refuse, They take his arm, they poke him in the eye, Update him on the news behind the news, Discuss their diets till he wants to die. They mostly welcome him with warmth and graciousness, But sometimes leave him smothered with loquaciousness. Winter draws on apace, the last leaves flutter - A time for Jets and Giants and skating rinks. Bag ladies search for treasures in the gutter, And proud possessors bundle up in minks. The city gleams, a gem fresh from the cutter (With here and there a flaw), and Juan thinks: ''The more I see, the more I like the look of it. I'll get to know each cranny and each nook of it.'' He wanders round the Village and TriBeCa, Inspecting every artwork and antique. He cuts through SoHo like a Black & Decker (To list its galleries would take a week). Zabar's, the West Side gourmet's mecca, Ungaro, Valentino, chic by chic, And streets where the most useful arts are martial - He tours them all, objective and impartial. He roams through Wall Street, home of trust and trader, Where some talk bull, some find it hard to bear; He marvels when he meets a corporate raider (Earth hath not anything to show more fair). It makes him feel as virtuous as Ralph Nader - Then he decides he'd rather like his share. He learns the market game, and how to play, And makes his money the new-fashioned way. And now the festive season's almost here, With constant exhortations to be jolly. The old familiar symptoms reappear - Sleigh bells and Hallmark cards and plastic holly. Bing Crosby's tones still ring out loud and clear; And, lest it all seem earthbound fun and folly, Each window sports a Christmas tree and/or a Branched candlestick (more rightly called ''menorah''). What of Don Juan? It must be confessed Our hero's really quite a worldly fellow. He sets out to enjoy himself with zest, Looks on the wine that's red (and also yellow). He's fond of clothes, too - nothing but the best: The thought of buying new ones makes him mellow. He's born to shop - it puts him in good humor: An unashamed conspicuous consumer. He spends his money like a drunken sailor, Buys toys from Schwarz, and sporting goods from Herman, While not content with purchasing a trailer He buys a car (the engineering's German). And in the full-length mirror at his tailor He gazes at himself like Cindy Sherman. He samples the delights of Fiorucci, Of Gucci, Pucci and of Grace Balducci. Of Broadway's magic oft has he been told, And owns himself a trifle disappointed. Perhaps it's only that he's growing old, Perhaps (oh wretched spite!) the time's disjointed. At any rate, he sits there good as gold Through plays by critical acclaim annointed, And sometimes laughs, or (when they're tragic) mourns, And sometimes yawns and yawns and yawns and yawns. It's Christmas - things speed to their appointed ends, It's a time of hope, and sugarplums as well, A time of strangers longing to be friends: Carols peal, and slowly fade, and anthems swell And die away. A final hush descends. A last bedraggled Santa clangs his bell. Presents are set down, waiting for first light; A last mouse stirs, and silent is the night. Soon it will be New Year. It's time to go. Up in his lonely room Don Juan packs, And takes one last look at the scene below, The whole great Babylonian ball of wax. City of boom or bust, of high and low, Of Bloomingdale's, and big brown bags, and Saks, Of servings that are almost too substantial And analysts (both psycho and financial). City of Mary Boone and Geoffrey Beene, Sondheim, and Suzy, and the Circle Line, Temple Emanu-El, Tavern on the Green, Calvin Tomkins, Calvin Trillin, Calvin Klein. City of Witter (not forgetting Dean), Of two Saul Steinbergs and of Andrew Stein, Of Rudolph Giuliani and Hizzoner, Of Dr. Ruth, and Cardinal O'Connor. A moment of New Year irresolution, Then Juan's on his way - ring out, wild bells! Ring out for every well-loved institution, Ring out for Limelight, and ring out for Nell's! But Juan feels far from tranquil or Confucian, The sobs that shake him are like ocean swells. Still, all's not lost, or cause for lamentation: He's working on his Green Card application.

title: HALPIN DUE TO PICK TRANSITION GROUP
description: LEAD: WHEN Patrick G. Halpin begins work tomorrow, planning how he will govern in Suffolk County, the 34-year-old County Executive-elect won't lack for advice.

title: Miss Olson Weds Dan Hofstadter
description: At the Swedish Seamen's Church in New York, Nancy Ann Olson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin R. Olson of Glenview, Ill., was married yesterday to Dan Hofstadter, the son of the late Felice Swados Hofstadter and the late Richard Hofstadter of New York. The Rev. Jan Madestam, a Lutheran minister and the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Program Trading Smoothed the Market
description: SINCE Oct. 19 traders, regulators and the investing public have been searching for an explanation for the stock market plunge. Perhaps we will never understand exactly why this ''correction'' was so violent and why it took place when it did. Nevertheless, the usual suspects have been rounded up. High on the list of the accused are stock index futures ''program traders.''

title: IN EUROPE: The Bill's Due Next Century
description: IT is not just in the United States that people worry about who is going to pay for social security. Throughout the industrialized world, because of the baby boom's huge presence and low fertility rates, the classic demographic pyramid is narrowing at the base and swelling at the top. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development projects that in its 24 member nations the proportion of the population aged 65 and over will rise from 12 percent now to 22 percent in 2040. In the seven largest O.E.C.D. countries, there is now one elderly person for every five of working age; in 2040 the ratio will be 2 to 5.

title: GHOSTS TO BELIEVE IN: RECALLING BATESON AND MEAD
description: THE true exorcism of ghosts occurs when they are gradually absorbed into the lives of the living. All last year I was writing dialogues with my father, Gregory Bateson, who died in 1980, an ironic activity because he also wrote dialogues -called by him ''metalogues'' - between a father and daughter, dialogues that were largely but not entirely fictional. Because there seem always to be changing fashions in mediumship, I want to be quite clear that the reality of these seances is exclusively mental, a setting for clarifying ideas. Gregory is gone in an entropy of ash and ocean, but his ideas have an ongoing life.

title: HAWKS, DOVES AND OWLS
description: THE LONG PEACE Inquiries Into the History of the Cold War. By John Lewis Gaddis. 332 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Computers That Listen

title: Counting the Hungry - a Contentious Census
description: EVEN after five years of economic expansion, there are reports of hunger in America, among farmers in Kansas, elderly people in the Ozarks and homeless people in big cities from Houston to New York. But no one knows how many Americans are hungry, and attempts to estimate their number are highly controversial.

title: Tickets on Sale Today For Pavarotti Classes
description: Luciano Pavarotti will give two master classes at the Juilliard School, Thursday from 2 to 6 P.M. and next Sunday from 3 to 5:30 P.M. He will work with singers presently studying at the school.

title: Elisa Gribin to Wed Michael Litchman
description: The engagement of Elisa Margaret Gribin and Michael Jay Litchman has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel D. Gribin of Kings Point, L.I. Mr. Litchman is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry M. Litchman of Providence, R.I. A summer wedding is planned.

title: America's Paradoxical Relationship With Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: If Foreign Investment Ends, So Does Our Binge
description: To the Editor:

title: IN CONCERT WITH SOUSA ON 'TEDDY AND ALICE'
description: WHEN a performance of the Philharmonia Virtuosi Chamber Orchestra in April 1985 turned into a rollicking rendition of Broadway-style tunes, few in the Westchester audience were surprised.

title: Headliners; Starting Over
description: Mary Beth Whitehead, who says her marriage fell apart in the course of the landmark Baby M custody case, has started two new lives. As Mrs. Whitehead was divorced from her husband, Richard, last week, her lawyers disclosed that she plans ''very soon'' to wed Dean Gould, the father of a baby Mrs. Whitehead expects in the spring. Lawyers for the Whiteheads said the pressures of the Baby M case, in which the couple sought unsuccessfully to win custody of the baby daughter Mrs. Whitehead had agreed to surrender under a $10,000 surrogate agreement, were the main factor in their decision to divorce. Mrs. Whitehead's lawyer, Joel D. Siegal, said she had been ''tremendously involved in the surrogacy question and hasn't devoted herself to the marriage as she did before.''

title: F.A.O. SCHWARZ: THE 12 WEEKS OF CHRISTMAS
description: EXCEPT FOR THE SPINDLY HIGH heels no Christmas shopper would wear, and the lack of a black mink coat, Gale Jarvis could be any of the frantic young upscale parents nervously pondering the goods at F.A.O. Schwarz, racing from one department to another, ferreting out what's hot and what's not. But instead of just reading the price tags, Gale Jarvis is changing them. She's repositioning the Talking Big Bird, shuffling the Captain Power sets, counting the customers at the cash register to see if it's time for the doormen, dressed as Nutcracker soldiers, to let in more eager toy buyers. The potential customers, sipping on-the-house cocoa served from a cart, are in a line that curves up Fifth Avenue, in front of the General Motors building and around to 59th Street.

title: Helms Cleared on Chile Leak
description: Senator Jesse Helms, decrying what he called ''the anatomy of a smear,'' said Friday that the Justice Department had cleared him of accusations that he or a member of his staff leaked classified information to officials of Chile's authoritarian Government.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bedford Hills, N.Y. $275,000 31 Dwight Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old frame ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, cul de sac, walk to station; taxes $2,907. Peekskill, N.Y. $236,000 8 Avenue A, Quarry Acres 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, walk to station, 2-car garage; taxes $3,411. Purchase, N.Y. $525,000 Cypress Point Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; den, maid's room, abuts nature preserve, 0.5 acre; taxes $4,820. Farmington, Conn. $202,100 146 Tunxis Village 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new town-house condominium; cathedral ceiling in den, crown moldings; common charges and taxes not available. Norwalk, Conn. $235,000 4 Morningside Place 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old Cape Cod; near water, hardwood floors, windowed porch; taxes $1,500. Stratford, Conn. $318,000 420 Prayer Spring Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 15-year-old ranch; finished basement, in-law apartment, 1 acre; taxes $2,855. OTHER AREAS Wantagh, L.I. $169,000 2833 Michael Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; whirlpool, basement; taxes $2,900. Aberdeen, N.J. $170,000 125 Van Brackle Road 3-bedroom, 2 bath, 12-year-old ranch; family room, 2 patios; taxes $2,395. Livingston, N.J. $575,000 5 Bushkill Drive 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; deck, C/A, 2-car garage; taxes $7,013.

title: HONDURAS SAID TO RE-EVALUATE HELP FOR CONTRAS
description: The airstrips used to supply Nicaraguan guerrillas are still operating in Honduras, but continued Government support for the rebels is no longer certain, according to Honduran political analysts and several diplomats here.

title: Is Mbeki's Release a Prelude to Mandela's Return?
description: THE release earlier this month of Govan A. Mbeki, the black leader imprisoned for 24 years, has already changed the chemistry of South African politics and opened a new debate about the prospect of black unity against the Pretoria Government's divide-and-conquer tactics.

title: HOFSTRA REACHES PLAYOFFS
