description: Mike Codella scored touchdowns on runs of 1-yard each and carried 28 times for 191 yards to set a Hofstra single-season rushing record at 1,187 yards as the Flying Dutchmen defeated the Merchant Marine Academy, 35-14, yesterday at Hofstra Stadium, Hempstead, L.I., to clinch a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III Eastern Regional playoffs.

title: Stacy S. Jannis Is Wed To George Tamerlani
description: Stacy Simon Jannis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Paul Jannis of Pittsburgh, and George Tamerlani, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Tamerlani of Brooklyn, were married yesterday. The Rev. Garret D. Dorsey, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Elliot Burk officiated at the First Unitarian Church in Pittsburgh.

title: Raised Consumer Consciousness Can Lower Credit-Card Interest
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCUMENATARY
description: Roses in December The Story of Jean Donovan. A film by Ana Carrigan and Bernard Stone. Narrated by John Houseman. First Run Features. 55 minutes. $29.95. While serving as a lay missionary in El Salvador in 1980, Jean Donovan and three close friends, the Maryknoll Sisters Maura Clarke and Ita Ford and the Ursuline Sister Dorothy Kazel, were murdered by the Government's security forces. More than any battle or political incident, the deaths of the four American women who were serving the poor pointed up the repression of the Salvadoran regime at the time.

title: Affordability: How's New York Doin'?
description: AS part of his commitment to help developers produce more affordable housing, Mayor Koch set up the Office of Housing Coordination 18 months ago to expedite projects through New York's complicated regulatory system.

title: A THEORY OF EVERYTHING
description: Recently, Edward Witten returned to his alma mater (Brandeis), where he received an honorary degree. Many on campus were surprised to discover that Witten, the enfant terrible of physics, was a history major as an undergraduate.

title: Visions Shared By Britain's Artists and Poets In the Days Of Wordsworth
description: TRY NOT TO MISS THE current exhibition at the New York Public Library, ''William Wordsworth and the Age of English Romanticism.'' It would be worth making the effort to see it for the sake of the Turners alone, or for the work of any one of half a dozen of the other artists on view.

title: Dance: Company of Men
description: TERRY CREACH and Stephen Koester explored the choreographic possibilities of male movement in an energetic and invigorating program Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. If one could sometimes question the uses to which their energy was put, one had no doubts about these dancers' abilities.

title: The Politics Of the Deficit Outlasts Call For Action
description: TO hear them talk, one would think that Congress and the White House are worried about the crash of the stock market, the fall of the dollar, and the United States budget and trade deficits.

title: MORE THAN A CATHEDRAL: ST. JOHN THE DIVINE By ARI L. GOLDMAN; Ari L. Goldman writes on religion for The Times.
description: EIGHTEEN YEARS AGO, THE RIGHT Rev. Paul Moore Jr., the newly elected Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, looked through a window of his apartment on the desolate grounds of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in upper Manhattan and lamented: ''What am I going to do with this place? It's dead in the water. I can't even sell it.''

title: AUTO CRACKDOWN
description: The Superintendent of the State Police, Col. Clinton L. Pagano, has issued a special bulletin to troopers advising them that the state's experimental ''no-flunk'' motor-vehicle inspection program in northern counties does not mean they should be lax in enforcing safety regulations.

title: The Two-Woman Opposition in Bangladesh
description: AFTER the police fired on anti-Government protesters here last week, the leading opposition party in Bangladesh scheduled a prayer service for three slain partisans. But its leader was unable to attend. Sheik Hasina Wajed, the Awami League's head, is a woman, and Moslem tradition dictates that women be barred from ceremonies for the dead.

title: Mary Voyatzis, a Teacher of Classics, Is Married to Frederick Frelinghuysen
description: Mary Elis Voyatzis, an assistant professor of classics at the University of Arizona, was married yesterday in Tucson, Ariz., to Frederick Frelinghuysen, a management consultant. The Rev. James Tavlarides performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of St. Demetrios, assisted by the Rev. Paul W. Buckwalter, an Episcopal priest.

title: Louise March, a Folk Art Guild Founder, Is Dead
description: Louise March, a founder of the Rochester Folk Art Guild, a nonprofit artisan's collective farm in Middlesex, N.Y., died of a heart attack yesterday at the Soldiers and Sailors Hospital in Penn Yan, N.Y. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan and Middlesex.

title: BATTEN DOWN FOR THE COLD WEATHER
description: THE lawn should be as short as possible for winter to eliminate the chances of disease, especially snow mold; if the grass was not cut before storing the mower, set the cutting blade at 1 1/2-inches or a bit lower, if possible, and mow one more time; if a few leaves remain, they will be chopped up by the blades and can remain as mulch, but rake off thick layers of leaf mulch. Pull up and compost annuals wilted by the recent freeze; cut to the ground tops of perennials such as phlox, hostas, rudbeckia, peonies, platycodon, asters. QUESTIONS/ANSWERS POISONOUS PLANTS

title: Choreographic Riches Are Reborn
description: THIS HAS BEEN AN AUTUMN OF extraordinary revivals. The Joffrey Ballet has offered ''Le Sacre du Printemps,'' a conjectural reconstruction by Millicent Hodson and Kenneth Archer of the epoch-making production of 1913, choreographed by Vaslav Nijinsky and designed by Nicholas Roerich. Martha Graham's ''Celebration'' received its first New York performances in 50 years during the Graham company's recent season. And in Tulsa, Okla., Tulsa Ballet Theater gave the North American premiere and the first performances anywhere in two decades of ''Mozart Violin Concerto,'' which George Balanchine created in 1942 as a guest choreographer for the Ballet of the Teatro Colon in Buenos Aires.

title: A Battle Report Direct From the Lower Depths
description: ALTHOUGH LAURIE POVOD HAS not undergone amniocentesis, she and her husband, the young playwright Reinaldo Povod, already know the child she is carrying is a boy. They know this because Rei's ''buelita,'' his grandmother, follows the ways of santaria, a folk practice that combines yoruba - a mixture of African tribal religions - and Christianity, to which many Caribbean island people subscribe.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DANCE
description: LEAD: The Ballerinas Directed by Beppe Menegatti and Tazio Tami. Kultur. 108 minutes. $39.95. It is a delight to see the veteran dancer Carla Fracci in excerpts from ballets made famous by the stars of the past (Pavlova, Grisi, Taglioni among them). One wonders, therefore, why the producers felt the need to drape these excerpts upon a hopelessly contrived scenario.

title: HOUSING PLAN CITED IN YONKERS ELECTION
description: LEAD: YONKERS voters in predominantly white neighborhoods on the east side turned out in large numbers in the recent City Council elections and re-elected by a wide margin school and housing integration opponents.

title: WITH PREGNANCY, ONE WOMAN BECOMES MORE CONFIDENT
description: I AM a good girl. Too good. I've always knuckled under the nearest available authority. I did what my parents told me to do, then my teachers, then my employers, lawyer and doctors. A course in assertiveness training helped me to figure out how to get what I want, usually without sacrificing any of the peace I find in following the most recent advice offered by anyone who might be an expert.

title: Honor In Trying
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Assault With a Chicken And Other Researches
description: The duel of the frozen chickens is among the claims on file at the Insurance Library Association of Boston.

title:
GARDENING;
THE CHALLENGE OF PROPAGATING PLANTS
description: LEAD: FOR the person who is really into gardening, there is a special satisfaction that comes from propagating one's own plants. Annuals, of course, are pretty easy, some perennials are a bit more difficult, but the woody plants are really a challenge.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm well, I'm happy, I'm excited to be here.'' - Rudolf Nureyev, in Moscow. [ 4:1. ]

title: Youth Killed in South Africa
description: A 15-year-old youth was killed by fellow blacks as more political violence swept Natal Province in South Africa, the police said today. A police statement said the boy was killed in the Pietermaritzburg township of Flangspruit on Friday night. It gave no details.

title: The Handicapped
description: To the Editor: In a Practical Traveler column on July 5 by Dennis Hevesi about adventure trips for the disabled, there was brief mention of the Blue Spruce Lodge in Trout Creek, Mont. I sent for a brochure and decided to make the trip. It turned out to be the greatest vacation of my life.

title: Boy's Killing Unnerves New Hampshire Town
description: This small New England town struggled with despair after learning that a 9-year-old boy had been shot to death and one of his friends was accused of murder.

title: JAMES FENIMORE COOPER WROTE HERE
description: I enjoyed reading Roberta Hershenson's article on Scarsdale's historic Wayside Cottage and the Varian family who occupied it from 1763 to 1853. [ ''In Scarsdale, a Dig Reveals the Past,'' Oct. 25 ] Your reporter did not mention the following interesting tidbits. The Wayside Cottage was at one time a Drover's Inn during the Revolutionary period. James Fenimore Cooper, who married into one of the prominent Scarsdale families (the DeLanceys of Loyalist persuasion), resided in Scarsdale (and Mamaroneck) for a number of years, was known to have visited the Drover's Inn - as well as the (Underhill) house across the Post Road from it, and still in existence.

title: Risky Markets
description: To the Editor:

title: Share the Indian Museum
description: The protracted struggle over the Museum of the American Indian now comes down to a confrontation between Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Senator Daniel Inouye of Hawaii. Senator Moynihan leads forces that would put the museum in the old U.S. Custom House in Lower Manhattan. Senator Inouye argues for transfer to the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

title: Soviet May Address Congress
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, has formally invited Mikhail S. Gorbachev to address a joint session of Congress while the Soviet leader is in Washington next month for the planned summit meeting with President Reagan, a spokesman for Mr. Byrd said today.

title: More Bad Luck
description: THERE'S no such thing as a good time for an injury, but Gary Stevens, the jockey, seems to find particularly bad ones. In 1985, he suffered broken ribs in a spill three weeks before the Breeders' Cup and missed those races. Then yesterday, Stevens suffered a broken ankle in an accident at the starting gate before the fourth race at Santa Anita, and will miss the Breeders' Cup races at Hollywood Park Saturday. Stevens, who had another kind of Breeders' Cup hard luck last year when he finished second in three of the day's seven races, will miss six scheduled mounts Saturday.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: House of Representatives

title: Nuclear Plant Closed by U.S. Is Set to Reopen
description: The Oyster Creek Nuclear Power Plant, which was shut down by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission two months ago because of safety violations, will resume normal operations in about two weeks, according to officials at the plant.

title: Headliners; Surprise Ending
description: Larry Heinemann was not looking for much more than a free meal, some conversation and perhaps a cocktail or two. Instead, Mr. Heinemann, a Chicagoan, emerged from the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre Hotel last week as the surprise winner of the National Book Award for fiction.

title: Vermont's Republican Party, Shaken by Losses, Adopts More Liberal Line
description: Vermont's Republican Party, the colossus of state politics for more than a century but struggling in recent years, is planning for a political comeback by recasting its image in a new, more liberal light.

title: WHO WILL CONTROL THE POPULATION?
description: In reply to the ''Population Bomb'' article: I suggest we first think of all the land improperly used because we grow tobacco. Some of the food we grow is converted into alcohol.

title: 'A BUSINESSOF SECONDS'
description: LIKE their counterparts in instant publishing, executives who produce instant video cassettes tend to describe themselves as high-stakes gamblers.

title: Jill Nisbet Gilbert, A Student, Is Wed To James Callahan
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York, Jill Nisbet Gilbert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy H. Gilbert of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday to James Callahan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Callahan of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Victor J. Sivore performed the ceremony.

title: A WOMAN'S STYLE FOR ALL SEASONS
description: THERE are women whose taste and bearing project the sort of easy self-assuredness that guarantees they will never look out of style. Such a woman is Eleanor Graham, who, in the time we have observed her, has yet to look anything but terrific.

title: Choosing the Right Island
description: THERE are more than three dozen Caribbean islands, stretching across a body of water one-third the size of the United States. The choice presents a perennial problem: which island suits you best.

title: CONSUMER AGENCY NEEDS RESTRUCTURING
description: LAST April, 7-year-old Michele Snow of Riverside, Calif., was struck in the head by a heavy metal object. She died three days later.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: WHY would a man like Larry Leeds have scores of letters and numbers, like PACETLDTOOC and 3714326598, imprinted on his memory so indelibly that they're still there after more than 30 years? Especially since Mr. Leeds is a man who hasn't a clue about the numbers on his license plate, his safe-deposit box or his Social Security card.

title: SPORTS AUTHORITY FACING SCRUTINY
description: AS IF losing the vote to build a baseball stadium in the Meadowlands was not enough, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority faces increased skepticism in the Legislature.

title: Rock: Love and Rockets
description: A Song by Love and Rockets proclaimed ''No New Tale To Tell'' in the group's concert Thursday night atthe Beacon Theater, and truer self-descriptions were rarely sung.

title: U.C.L.A. NEARS A SHOWDOWN
description: Troy Aikman ran for a touchdown and passed for another in a 17-point third quarter today as U.C.L.A. erupted for a 47-14 victory over Washington to remain unbeaten in the Pacific-10 Conference.

title: PLAN TO USE OUTSIDERS TO TEACH STIRS FIGHT
description: A PLAN to allow liberal-arts graduates who are not education majors to teach in Connecticut schools has attracted attention from hundreds of people interested in changing careers to teaching. But it has also split educators.

title: The Stage: 'Scooncat,' A Mother and Son Effort
description: BOBBY, or Scooncat, as he prefers to be known, lives in a high-tech room, into which the world keeps intruding in mostly disagreeable forms.

title: Discussing Sibling Rivalry
description: LEAD: WHEN Adele Faber and Elaine Mazlish met at the Bryant Library 26 years ago, it was as suburban housewives in a Great Books discussion series. Thursday, when they return to the library in Roslyn to conduct a workshop on sibling rivalry, it will be as successful authors and communicators.

title: With the Kennedy Nomination, The Center Holds
description: THERE was none of the usual suspense or drama to President Reagan's announcement on Wednesday that Judge Anthony M. Kennedy was his latest choice for the Supreme Court.

title: If It Never Rains Here, What's That?
description: EVERY November, when the calendar insists it's fall but it begins to feel like winter in Washington, D.C., my husband and I start to think about our annual week or two of guaranteed sunshine on the Pacific coast of Mexico.

title: CORRECTION
description: The gazetteer accompanying an article on Turtle Bay on Nov. 1 omitted the name of a New York City Council member who serves the neighborhood. She is Carol Greitzer.

title: Carolyn G. Logan, Ph. D. Candidate, Is Married to Christopher Foy Rupp
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan, Carolyn Gisele Logan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis D. Logan of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Foy Rupp, a son of Cynthia Foy Rupp of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York, and the late Albert G. Rupp. The Rev. Jane Henderson performed the ceremony.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE Paterson City Council is expected to sign a contract next spring with Goldberger, Moore, Novick & Albanese for its long-awaited Superblock, a $254 million project designed to signal the city's revitalization.

title: Pieter N. Menten, War Criminal And Art Collector, Is Dead at 88
description: Pieter Nicolaas Menten, the Netherlands' most notorious Nazi war criminal, died here today in a nursing home, according to Dutch television. He was 88 years old and no cause of death was given.

title:
If You're Thinking of Living in:;
Franklin Lakes
description: LEAD: WHAT first catches the eye in Franklin Lakes is the water -lakes and ponds almost everywhere, tucked deeply into the landscape, dodging elegant homes in the woods or winding along country roads.

title: Folk-Art Legacy of a Lady of Quality
description: ELECTRA HAVEMEYER Webb's legacy of collecting the best in American folk art - achieved with Yankee determination, her share of her family's sugar fortune and a keen eye for hearty, homespun Americana - comes alive in miniature in the exhibition opening today at the National Gallery of Art. The show, remaining through March, marks the 40th anniversary of the Shelburne Museum, the repository Mrs. Webb created in a northern Vermont village to accommodate the overflow of what she had collected over a lifetime.

title: Bucks Have New Look; Same Old Story for Knicks
description: Don Nelson, who traded 11 seasons of coaching the Milwaukee Bucks for part ownership in the Golden State Warriors, would never recognize the starting lineup his successor, Del Harris, has put together.

title: AVOIDING CHRISTMAS
description: THE 25TH OF DECEMBER WAS THE DAY on which I was born, but that's not the only thing I have against it. Personally, I never believed in Mr. Claus. At least I have no recollection whatsoever of any traumatic moment of disillusionment with the myth. When his name was finally scrubbed from the tedious list of people to whom I ought to be grateful and, worse, to whom I was compelled to write, I think I was relieved to be free of yet another part of that general collusion between children and parents by which all parties strive to keep alive the wilting hope that the young are guileless. Like most infants, I realized, even in my cradle, that an affectation of innocence was the best defense against the intrusion of the adult world.

title: RECORDS SPOTLIGHT KENNEDY LOBBYING
description: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, President Reagan's latest nominee to the Supreme Court, spent at least $65,332 as a part-time lobbyist from 1963 to 1975, when he was named to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, state records show.

title: GIANTS OF THE ROD AND REEL
description: Paul Schullery's history of American fly fishing, like the sport itself, is not for everyone. Primarily, it's for those who think that ''fly fishing is the best thing there is.'' It might also interest nonangling history buffs, who will be amazed to discover that fly fishing has given rise to as many competing schools of thought as the Weimar Republic. Fly fishing, which has attracted a disproportionate share of mystics and pedants since at least the 15th century, has its Great Men theorists, its divine rightists, its environmental and technological determinists, as well as its social, literary and institutional historians. In AMERICAN FLY FISHING: A History (Nick Lyons Books, $29.95) Mr. Schullery, former director of the American Museum of Fly Fishing, gives due respect to all schools of thought and even to other types of fishers, including ''worm drowners and hardware flingers.'' If he has a bias, it is toward fly fishing technology - the evolution of American rods, reels, lines and flies over the last 200 years. Words like genius, hero and giant are applied to the innovative rod builders and line makers who led ''the great tackle revolution of the late nineteenth century.'' Many of the book's historic photographs, prints and drawings illustrate this aspect of fly fishing. Readers will learn, for instance, that a good, oil-soaked, all-silk tapered line took six months to manufacture in the 1880's and required daily care if it were to last. The greater revelation is that, however newfangled our tackle may be, the issues that engage fly fishers' passions - the relative merits of strict imitationist versus impressionist fly tying, the bass/trout rivalry, the upstream/downstream debate, the what-you-cast versus how-you-cast approach to fishing - are as old as the nation.

title: TALKING: Mortgages; Changes That Affect A Loan
description: MANY homeowners who have taken out mortgages think their only obligations to the lender are to make timely payments on the loan and to pay taxes and insurance premiums. Not so.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a large bluestone patio about 10 years old, and some of the cement between the flags is coming out of the joints. Can you tell us how to handle this problem?

title: AIRPORT STUDY RAISES FEARS
description: LEAD: THE Town of Hempstead wants a more complete study on the effects of an expansion of Kennedy Airport, fearing that noise levels will be greater than a draft study has suggested.

title: WATERBURY SYMPHONY BUILDS 'GLOWING YEAR'
description: WHEN Mario DiCecco, a violinist, founded the Waterbury Symphony 50 years ago, a great brass section was at hand. Musicians moonlighted in the mills for income.

title: Dollars vs. Diplomacy: Austerity at State Dept.
description: The American Foreign Service is in trouble. Experienced diplomats, unsure about their futures, are casting about, sending out resumes in search of late-in-life careers.

title: Dance
description: The New York City Ballet returns to the New York State Theater on Tuesday for its 87th season in the city. The highlights of this first week of the new winter season include two revivals and performances by a new member of City Ballet and several newly promoted dancers. A centerpiece of the opening-night gala benefit for the company is ''The Concert,'' that goofy but poetic evocation of concertgoing choreographed by Jerome Robbins and last performed by the company in 1984. George Balanchine's bittersweet ''Divertimento from 'Le Baiser de la Fee,' '' a small jewel of City Ballet's 1972 Stravinsky Festival, will also be revived after a three-year absence from the repertory. Performed for the first time this season on Friday, ''Divertimento'' contains especially inventive choreography for the male lead that captures the bittersweet quality of the ballet.

title: CUTTING A DEAL WITH THE INQUISTION
description: GALILEO HERETIC By Pietro Redondi. Translated by Raymond Rosenthal. 356 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $29.95.

title: Physician Is Wed To Dr. Scharfman
description: Dr. Beth Karen Scharfman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin A. Scharfman of Great Neck, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. Uri R. Shabto, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Avtalion Shabto of New York. Rabbis Mordecai Waxman and David Lincoln officiated at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York.

title: Explosions Rock Texas Chemical Plant, Killing 3
description: Two explosions ripped through a chemical plant near here today, touching off massive fires that burned out of control all afternoon and left at least three people dead and more than 30 injured, the authorities said.

title: Judge Kennedy's Legal Views, in His Own Words
description: Sexual Privacy

title: A New Image for the Virtuoso
description: THEY MIGHT NOT THINK of themselves quite this way, but they constitute a distinctive group - Murray Perahia, Radu Lupu, Richard Goode, Peter Serkin, Krystian Zimerman, Andras Schiff, among them - prominent pianists who are altering the traditional image of the keyboard virtuoso.

title: Good Values in Thrift Units
description: FEW stock groups have as many handicaps to discourage investors as the savings and loan industry. Accounting rules are quirky. Regulatory burdens are onerous. And a number of the group's bolder players are hip-deep in loans that may not be repaid. If that were not enough, well-run savings units, selling at historically low valuations compared with their book values and earnings, are plentiful - more plentiful, in fact, than bargain hunters bidding for their stock.

title: BEST SELLERS: NOVEMBER 15, 1987
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 4 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 2 3 7 LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) A collection of Lake Wobegon monologues, from the radio program ''A Prairie Home Companion.'' 3 2 21 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) TIMEBENDS: A Life, by Arthur Miller. (Grove, $24.95.) An autobiography that passes through moments of numbing despair ends up close to rhapsodic as the playwright - a Jewish-American Don Quixote? - brings all his characters on at once. REUBEN, by John Edgar Wideman. (Holt, $16.95.) A timeless and cryptic link in the fragmentary tales that form this novel, Reuben is narrator, listener, interpreter and guardian spirit as the author revisits Pittsburgh's black Homewood district. FELICITY, by Coral Lansbury. (Dutton, $16.95.) This campus novel about academics, and a beautiful and intelligent art historian in particular, is full of relish at the absurdities of humankind and unkind and ultimately joyful about the whole mess. IF YOU CAN'T SAY SOMETHING NICE, by Calvin Trillin. (Ticknor & Fields, $16.95.) Essays that take the gentle high road to humor, most of which cannot be stamped NOT NICE. THE RABBI OF LUD, by Stanley Elkin. (Scribners, $17.95.) In this novel, the title character, God's Hebrew stringer in New Jersey, rarely stops looking at the bright side of the bad side. A SONG OF LOVE AND DEATH: The Meaning of Opera, by Peter Conrad. (Poseidon, $19.95.) An unconventional, colorful approach to the song of our irrationality in three acts, from the first tenor (Orpheus), through repertory to performance, with echoes of that archromantic, Wagner. BALTASAR AND BLIMUNDA, by Jose Saramago. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $17.95.) A full-bodied novel from Portugal, knitting together harsh realism, jokes, aphorisms, a more than convincing love story and an 18th-century flying machine.

title: SHARING ADOPTION EXPERIENCE
description: LEAD: EIGHT years ago Alan and Noreen Spiegelman went to Colombia to adopt their son, Joshua, now 8 1/2. Three years later they made the same trip to pick up a baby girl, Marisa, now 5. The dates on which they brought the infants home - Nov. 7 and June 18 -are treated as holidays, replete with cake and festivities, in the

title: OKLAHOMA ELUDES MISSOURI
description: Rotnei Anderson, a fullback, rushed for 118 yards, and Oklahoma made two late drives for a 17-13 victory over Missouri in a Big Eight Conference game.

title: IF I WERE A KEY, WHERE WOULD I BE?
description: I'VE added a new activity to my morning routine. I call it the key hunt. After years of feeling that daily searching for my keys is an intrusion, I have given in and officially made room for hunting in between bathing and breakfast. Now I have a full seven minutes of detective work before I begin to panic.

title: 'SPLIT SECOND' EXPLORES JUSTICE
description: LEAVE it to the gutsy Boston Post Road Stage Company to come up with a play that is intended to stir things up. For openers - indeed, in its first explosive scene - ''Split Second'' by Dennis McIntyre presents a harrowing confrontation, rife with racism, and then winds up raising provoking moral and legal issues.

title: In Tough Campaigns, the Tough Start Early
description: AT this point in the 1960 campaign, not one candidate had formally announced that he was running for President of the United States. John F. Kennedy waited until Jan. 2, 1960, to make formal his intentions. Lyndon B. Johnson, the Senate majority leader, runner-up to the Senator from Massachusetts at the Democratic convention and ultimately his Vice President, did not announce until July 5, 1960, right before the delegates gathered.

title: Beauty; SHADES OF EVENING
description: THE SMOOTH SWOOP

title: MOB TIE SUSPECTED IN SLAYING OF BROOKLYN MAN
description: A Brooklyn man was shot and killed in his family's restaurant late Friday in an incident that the police said might have been mob-related.

title: For Nureyev, An 'Inevitable' Return Home
description: Rudolf Nureyev, the ballet star who defected from the Soviet Union 26 years ago, returned home for the first time today under an unusual two-day visa that will allow him to see his ill mother.

title: Cheryl Solomon Is Wed
description: Cheryl S. Solomon, an associate in the Brooklyn law firm of Headley & Zeitlin, and David R. Rappaport, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, were married last evening at Temple Gates of Zion in Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Harold Halpern performed the ceremony. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Solomon of Brooklyn and Dr. and Mrs. Melvin Rappaport of Whitehall, Pa.

title: NORTHERN DEMOCRATS ASSESS GAINS IN ELECTION
description: LEAD: ''AMAZING as it seems, we won the election.''

title: CHILDREN'S HEALTH
description: Taking its cue from the success of programs like ''Sesame Street,'' the Kaiser Permanente Medical Care Program - a national health-care plan - has developed a theatrical troupe that travels nationwide to teach elementary-school children about health and safety.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE LOST LANGUAGE OF CRANES, by David Leavitt. (Bantam, $8.95.) Philip's parents don't know that their son is a homosexual, but he doesn't know that his father is also gay. Last year, our reviewer, Phillip Lopate, found the author's preoccupation with sexual orientation ''obsessively repetitious'' but said that the novel ''lingers in the mind, greater than the sum of its problematic parts. If you don't mind watching some on-the-job training, this book is readable and literate.'' THE SEARCH FOR SOLUTIONS, by Horace Freeland Judson. (Johns Hopkins, $9.95.) ''Science is our century's art,'' writes Horace Freeland Judson in his disquisition on how such magnificent works as Murray Gell-Mann's theory of quarks came to be made. Mr. Judson is best known for ''The Eighth Day of Creation,'' his history of molecular biology.

title: OUT OF A DARKNESS
description: I am the mother of a 9 1/2-year-old boy who has ADD with hyperactivity. After our son was diagnosed three years ago, we decided not to use medication, and our pediatrician backed us up on this. We work on teaching him appropriate behavior and self-control.

title: Bronx Man Is Charged With Abusing His Son
description: A Bronx man has been charged with child abuse after hospital officials said his 4-month-old son had suffered brain damage caused by a severe shaking.

title: SAG HARBOR EYES MUSIC CURB
description: THE Sag Harbor Village Board has proposed a law that would require certain businesses in the village that play recorded music or feature live entertainment to obtain a license. But the measure has been called unconstitutional by lawyers, racially motivated by minority business owners and an example of overzealous government regulation by business leaders.

title: USING SCARECROWS TO SPOOK SPEEDERS
description: THE opening shots were fired in 1968, when the first commercial radar detector - bearing the inflammatory name ''Fuzzbuster'' - made its debut. In the 20 years since, the war between Smokey and the detectors has shown no sign of abatement.

title: JUDGE KENNEDY: TILTING RIGHT BUT NOT FAR
description: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy could slightly shift the balance of the Supreme Court on criminal law and perhaps some civil rights issues, a review of several of his decisions suggests.

title: Q & A
description: Dissatisfied With Broker Question: Earlier this year, we used a mortgage brokerage firm to get a loan. Our broker told us that it would take about eight weeks to obtain a mortgage. The agent who started our work became ill and a replacement took over. He was incompetent and as a result four months later we had no mortgage. At the last minute, we had to settle for a mortgage at another brokerage, with a less favorable interest rate. Even though the original broker did not get a mortgage for us, he denied our request for a partial refund of the $400 application fee. Is there any state agency or professional organization to which we can complain? . . . B. G., Merrick, L.I. Answer: Yes. To file a complaint contact the Consumer Services Division of the New York State Department of Banking. Last year changes in the banking law made mortgage brokers and mortgage bankers more accountable for the way they do business.

title: On the Endangered List: The 'Instant Book'
description: THE stock market took a tremendous tumble on Oct. 19, but in the publishing industry, at least, no one was prepared to jump.

title: Tea-Leaf Scatology
description: LEAD: THE MALDIVE CHRONICLES By Kenneth Bernard. 167 pp. New York: PAJ Publications/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: Saving a Cemetery For Famous Pets
description: FRANCE'S oldest pet cemetery, one of the most lavish in the world, faced an uncertain future two months ago in Asnieres, outside of Paris. The owner had locked its gate on an island in the Seine and was threatening to plow up the land and sell it to apartment builders.

title: Growth Overtakes Calm And Culture of Ozarks
description: When Rudolph Crouse arrived in these remote Ozark hills in 1920 in search of a new home, he knew he had found ''the best place in all creation.''

title: DATA UPDATE: November 15, 1987
description: VALUE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS (Residential in millions of dollars)

title: PERSPECTIVES: Bedford-Stuyvesant; New 2-Family Houses Without Subsidies
description: IN 1868, the Vincentian Order of the Roman Catholic Church founded a parish and college on Brooklyn farmland and named it after St. John the Baptist. The order built a school and a priests' residence and an immense Romanesque church, with a nave 10 stories high and seating for 1,200.

title: THE BARTLEBOOTH FOLLIES
description: LIFE, A USER'S MANUAL By Georges Perec. Translated by David Bellos. 581 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $24.95.

title: RATES TIED TO NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: LEAD: TWO OF the state's largest utilities - the Public Service Electric and Gas Company and Jersey Central Power and Light - sought rate increases in the 80's because of the extended downtime of their nuclear plants, as well as soaring construction and maintenance costs.

title: America's Paradoxical Relatinship With Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: KEEPING COSTS DOWN ON BUSINESS TRAVEL
description: THE marketing director of one division of a major food company in White Plains logs 24,000 miles a year visiting company production facilities. An oil broker in Purchase, operating in international markets, estimates he travels 66,000 miles a year in airplanes.

title: Focus: Cleveland; Downtown Making a Comeback
description: WHEN partners in Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue, a law firm, began looking for new offices after 60 years in the same downtown Cleveland location, they never seriously considered a site outside the city's center.

title: Managua Cardinal Sees Talks Within 3 Weeks
description: Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, expressing guarded confidence in the success of peace efforts in Nicaragua, said here today that he expected formal cease-fire negotiations between the Managua Government and the contra rebels to begin before Dec. 5.

title: PARENT INVOLVEMENT IN SCHOOLS PRESSED
description: IN WHAT is the largest public-relations campaign the Kean administration has ever started on behalf of public schools, New Jersey is trying to increase the role parents play in education.

title: AFTER QUICHE
description: This classic French country dish sits proudly on my kitchen counter, ready to be served (Food: ''After Quiche,'' by Patricia Wells, Oct. 4). Now I read that this brilliant marriage of the flavors of beef, red wine and herbs has become a culinary has-been.

title: DO NEW LIMITS MEAN NEW TRAPS?
description: WHEN the speed limit on some highways returned to 65 miles an hour earlier this year, manufacturers of radar detectors were more than a little concerned. After all, while commercial radar detectors had been around for 20 years, their business came to life only in 1974, when the highway speed limit was cut to 55 m.p.h. because of the oil embargo and for safety reasons. The lower speed limit was a major factor in spurring demand for detectors, so manufacturers did not welcome the increase.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ON THE PREJUDICES, PREDILECTIONS, AND FIRM BELIEFS OF WILLIAM FAULKNER. By Cleanth Brooks. (Louisiana State University, $16.95.) His three previous books on Faulkner have established Cleanth Brooks as one of the novelist's leading critics in the last 30 years. Still, Mr. Brooks's interpretations of major works have not always been as influential as his insights into less studied aspects of the Faulkner canon.

title: Ellen O'Neill Beach, Teacher, Weds George Mares
description: Ellen O'Neill Beach, a daughter of Victoria Gorcoff Beach of Schenectady, N.Y., and John Arthur Beach of Albany and Syracuse, was married yesterday to George Mares. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marin Mares of Bucharest, Rumania.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: ON THEIR TOES
description: SPREAD A LITTLE HAPPINESS The First Hundred Years of the British Musical. By Sheridan Morley. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: Thames and Hudson. $29.95.

title: Plane Crashes in Snow at Denver; 26 of the 82 Aboard Are Killed
description: A Continental Airlines DC-9 jetliner crashed this afternoon while taking off in a severe snowstorm here, killing 26 people and injuring 56, officials said.

title: Pakistani Persecution Charged
description: The spiritual leader of the Ahmadi Moslem sect, on a visit to the United States, has blamed the Government of Pakistan and some Moslem clergymen there for what he calls ''the continuing legalized persecution'' of the Ahmadis in Pakistan, where the sect is concentrated.

title: ARTHUR MILLER READING
description: To mark the publication of his auto-biography, ''Timebends: A Lift,'' Ar-thur Miller is to give a reading from the work tonight at 8, at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center. The book is published by Grove Press, which is sponsoring the read-ing with Lincoln Center Theater. Ad-mission is free.

title: Judge Delays Decision In 'Platoon' Video Case
description: A Federal judge has let stand for the time being an appeals court decision that halted the distribution of ''Platoon,'' last year's best-picture Oscar winner, for the home video-cassette market.

title: Payment by Venezuela
description: The Venezuelan Government will repay $250 million in principal owed to private foreign banks by mid-December, Finance Minister Hector Hurtado said Friday. He told reporters the amount would be sent within 30 days from Monday as specified under terms of Venezuela's $20.3 billion rescheduling accord with private foreign banks. The accord, reached in principle with private banks on Feb. 27, became binding today after all of Venezuela's 450 private creditor banks signed the pact.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, named Ronald E. Compton executive vice president.

title: Wshington Talk: Briefing; Protecting the Press
description: Soviet officials are scheduled to come to the United States next week to inspect an installation in Utah intended to dispose of chemical weapons. The idea is to demonstrate the technology for getting rid of chemical weapons if a treaty banning them is signed. But the Washington press corps may want to think twice before trying to cover this inspection.

title: 2 New Features In Sports Monday
description: On Your Own: Skiing. If you give your skis a regular tuneup, you'll be able to leave your skiing partners in a cloud of powder, page C10. Keeping Fit. Many scientists agree that, to be fit, you should burn 2,000 calories a week. How to stoke your furnace, page C11.

title: WALTHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months' share earnings was not available; the company became public May 22, 1986.

title: Spy Scandal: U.S. Embassy Still Troubled
description: Diplomats who glance up on their way to the handball court or the hair salon at the new American embassy residential compound in Moscow see a defiant exclamation overhead.

title: Lawmakers Are Wary Of Delaying Benefit Rise
description: Republican and Democratic legislative leaders refused today to rule out reductions in cost-of-living increases in Social Security and other benefit programs, but agreed that major political hurdles stood in the way of such cuts.

title: Dance: Jamaica Troupe Celebrates Anniversary
description: THE stage came alive with the first and closing dances on a program presented by the National Dance Company of Jamaica on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College. But there were some fairly long stretches in between.

title: STENDIG INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-After a credit of $114,000 representing a partial reversal of a provision for loss on disposal of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $643,000. c-Net loss and after a loss of $823,000 from discontinued operations and a $896,000 provision for the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: After Year as Cooperative, Hunts Point Assesses Gains
description: Market results on a recent morning at the Hunts Point Terminal in the Bronx were, as always, mixed: radishes and papayas closed higher, spinach and cantaloupes took a dive, while leeks and lemons held about steady.

title: EATON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Robert D. Moss; Lawyer, 70
description: Robert D. Moss, a trustee and assistant to the president of the New York-based F. W. Olin Foundation, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 70 years old.

title: Horse Racing; It's Off to the Races (or to Rest) for the Breeders' Cup
description: ''THERE is only one day,'' begins the advertisement that is saturating national magazines this week, ''when the world's finest Thoroughbreds come together on the same track and championships are decided. That one day is the Breeders' Cup.'' That one day is Nov. 21, a date that has invalidated the advertisment's claims. Come Saturday, the nation's best 2-year-old, 3-year-old and 3-year-old filly will indeed be at the same track: at Belmont Park on Long Island, resting in their stalls, instead of running in Breeders' Cup IV at Hollywood Park in Los Angeles.

title: AMERICAN TECHNICAL CERAMCS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: UPPER PENINSULA POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo Sept 30
Belgrade Raises Prices, Freezes Wages
description: The Federal Government sharply increased the prices of basic foodstuffs and other necessities and froze wages at midnight Saturday in an effort to hold down Yugoslavia's extraordinarily high inflation.

title: Rangers Halt Losing Streak
description: For the first time in three weeks, the Rangers skated away from a game with something other than sinking spirits and a premonition of disaster. In the locker room afterward, instead of sulking and guilt, there were handshakes and laughter and, at long last, cause for congratulations.

title: TSO FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BARRISTER INFORMATION SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Net loss

title: Outdoors; Casting Calendar Aside
description: HAVING bade summer farewell, I was startled by the three-day warm spell earlier this month that ended the night the moon was full.

title: How to Reach Out and Vote for Someone
description: To the Editor:

title: Apple Sets Repurchase
description: Apple Computer Inc., like many other companies taking advantage of lower share prices, said Friday that it would repurchase up to an additional five million shares of its common stock. Based on Friday's closing price, the repurchase would be valued at about $186.3 million. Apple's stock closed down $1.50 a share Friday, at $37.25, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Brazil Parley Rebuffs Sarney
description: In a major setback for President Jose Sarney, a special commission preparing a final draft of Brazil's new constitution called today for presidential elections to be held next year.

title: WHEELABRATOR TECHNOLOIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: There were no share earnings for the year-ago periods because the company went public in September 1987.

title: Rock: Petrol Emotion
description: WITH a tangle of guitar riffs and shouts of defiance and frustration, That Petrol Emotion played a high-adrenalin set Friday night at the Ritz. That Petrol Emotion hails from Northern Ireland and was founded by Sean O'Neill, formerly the guitarist for a punk-pop band, the Undertones. And while Mr. O'Neill's songs for That Petrol Emotion still have the economy of pop, their guitar lines layer on dissonances and the lyrics are filled with fury, political as well as personal. ''You think I should show some respect,'' one taunts, ''I'd rather tear down all I can wreck.''

title: FIRST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings are not available, the company went public in April.

title: L.I. Hospital Investigates 11 Cases
description: The authorities are investigating at least 11 cases in which elderly patients at a Long Island hospital either died or encountered serious breathing difficulties while under the care of the same registered nurse, the president of the hospital said yesterday.

title: Congress Says El Salvador Misuses U.S. Aid
description: A bipartisan Congressional caucus charged today that United States aid to El Salvador was being largely misused by the Salvadoran military and ruling party to conduct the civil war against rebel forces.

title: Sports World Specials; Spring Tourists
description: For baseball fans who went into a slump after the World Series, the start of the basketball and hockey seasons has brought the annual reawakening. It is a sure sign, they know, that spring training is a mere three months away and the exhibition season just a few weeks beyond.

title: People
description: * Michael T. Rogers is joining Campbell-Mithun, Chicago, as executive vice president/director of creative services.

title: Soneni D. Bryant Marries David M. Smith, an Editor
description: Soneni Denise Bryant, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James O. Bryant of Piscataway, N.J., was married yesterday to David M. Smith, a son of Martin J. Smith of the Bronx and the late Selma Smith. Presiding Judge Joan Robinson Gross of the Municipal Court of Union County, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Hyatt Regency hotel in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Music: Chamber Group
description: PUTTING Franz Schreker and George Perle side by side on Saturday night's New York Chamber Symphony program at the 92d Street Y seemed at first a miniature history lesson in cause and effect. The bond between them is Alban Berg. Schreker's music early in this century opened Berg's imagination to the stage devices he would later use in ''Wozzeck''; Mr. Perle took up Berg's conciliatory approach to the 12-tone method in the late 1930's - composing music in which serialism becomes less an aberration in the broad world of harmonic thinking, more a natural constituent of it.

title: AMPLICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'85 Soviet-U.S. Talk Led To First Joint Venture
description: It was Independence Day in the United States when the first Soviet-American business joint venture began.

title: New Questions About Louvre Pact
description: As calls for a new international meeting to help reassure world financial markets have increased in recent days, so has the debate about whether a currency agreement reached last February was the underlying cause of the stock market plunge last month.

title: Mexico City Journal; Grandfather Fed the Rabbits as He Battled Stalin
description: Lenin lies in his tomb on Red Square, and Stalin is interred at the Kremlin Wall. But the ashes of Leon Trotsky, theoretician of the Bolshevik Revolution and founder of the Red Army, remain in exile and oblivion in the quiet garden of the small house here where he was assassinated by a presumed Soviet agent 47 years ago.

title: INTEGRATED GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Just How Far, And How Fast, For Fitness?
description: HOW fit is fit?

title: Nimble Soldiers of the Commercial Wars
description: On commercial issues they are the Government's elite force, striking at Japan, the European Community, Brazil and others that maintain barriers against imports from the United States.

title: Judy Wolf Is the Bride Of Dr. Jeffrey S. Nevid
description: Judy Wolf, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mayer Wolf-Racker of Fresh Meadows, Queens, and Dr. Jeffrey S. Nevid, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Nevid of Brooklyn, were married yesterday in New York Harbor aboard the yacht Tampa VI. Rabbi Allen Block officiated.

title: CADMUS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reflects the accrual accounting method for healthcare benefits, which reduced net by $425,000.

title: Wildlife Fund Executive Named to Smithsonian
description: Thomas E. Lovejoy, executive vice president of the World Wildlife Fund, has been named by the Smithsonian Institution as its assistant secretary for external affairs.

title: BBDO Worldwide Gets Pepsi International Job
description: In an unrelated development BBDO Worldwide, a Pepsi-Cola agency for 24 years, has been assigned headquarters advertising responsibilities for Pepsi-Cola International, a job it had six years ago.

title: EX-SPEAKER FACES SURGERY
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the former Speaker of the House of Representatives, left a Wash-ington hospital today and was admitted to a Boston hospital for rectal surgery., hospital officals said. The 74-year-old Massachusettes Democrat is scheduled to undergo surgery of the rectum in several days, said Kathleen O'Donnell, a spokeswoman for Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. She said it was premature to say whether the sur-gery was for cancer, as Boston newspa-pers reported Saturday.

title: We All Know What's Wrong With High School
description: To the Editor:

title: DIMENSIONAL MEDICINE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARDEN INTERNATIONAL KITCHNS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dance: Juilliard Performs
description: PROGRAMS presented by the Juilliard Dance Ensemble, the performing group of the Juilliard School's dance division, have sometimes seemed intended less to entertain audiences than to give as many students as possible the chance to get on stage in dance of suitable technical levels choreographed by associates of the school. But the accent was definitely on entertainment in a thought-provoking program presented by the ensemble on Friday at the Juilliard Theater.

title: Colts Beat Dolphins As Dickerson Stars
description: Eric Dickerson rushed for 154 yards and one touchdown, and Dean Biasucci kicked four field goals today as the Indianapolis Colts routed the Miami Dolphins, 40-21.

title: COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $141,341.

title: COAST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $300,000 for the quarter and $2,200,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $800,000 and $2,100,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9-month also includes a write-off of $883,000 FSLIC secondary reserve.

title: T ROWE PRICE ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-recurring pension related gain of $2,468,000. The company said that because of the curtailment and adoption of new accounting standards for pension costs, it had pension credits of $150,000 for the latest third quarter and pension costs of $304,000 for the 9 months. For the comparable 1986 periods, pension costs were $429,000 and $1,243,000, respectively.

title: Converted Radioactive Waste Used to Fertilize in Oklahoma
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation, after years of tests and studies, is spraying thousands of acres of pastureland in eastern Oklahoma with a fertilizer recycled from radioactive wastes.

title: WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Opera: 'Don Pasquale'
description: THE Western Opera Theater, the touring wing of the San Francisco Opera that has been visiting the boroughs outside of Manhattan regularly in recent seasons, brought ''Don Pasquale'' to Queens College on Saturday night. Between Donizetti's sparkling score, the energy of four lively performers in the leads, the reasonably trim orchestra under Patrick Summers and the generous sprinkling of gags from old movies and new sitcoms, this ''Pasquale'' had enough going for it to give the audience a thoroughly enjoyable evening, even though the soul of the opera is something more tender and touching than this performance ever hinted.

title: STAR TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $363,000 for the quarter and $618,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $324,000 for the quarter and $379,000 for the 6 months.

title: AIRLINE AND UNION REACH AN ACCORD
description: United Airlines and the union representing 21,000 mechanics and ground workers reached a tentative contract agreement late today, averting a nationwide strike that threatened to shut down the airline, a union official said.

title: Giant European Fund's Cautious Stance
description: At the headquarters of the Robeco Group, the largest group of investment funds under single management outside the United States, its managing director, Nicholas Veer, has decided that it is ''too late to be bearish'' on America, so he plans just to let the dust settle from the stock market collapse.

title: Municipal Bond Units In Retreat
description: Having suffered for months from a dearth of new bond issues and ruinous price-cutting, municipal bond departments on Wall Street predict a further contraction of the industry.

title: The Other Victims: Four Case Studies of Fatal Child Abuse
description: In the last weeks of her life, 5-year-old Tamika Greene had repeatedly been whipped with an electric cord, forced to overeat until she threw up, and finally poisoned. Last summer, her father was convicted in Manhattan of murdering her and another child.

title: Critic's Notebook; Did 'PACO'S STORY' DESERVE ITS AWARD?
description: WHAT happened? That was the question everyone was asking last week, following the news that ''Paco's Story'' by Larry Heinemann had won the 1987 National Book Award for fiction. Members of the literary community had widely regarded Toni Morrison's novel ''Beloved'' as a virtual shoo-in for the prize (with ''The Counterlife'' by Philip Roth also a strong contender) and the announcement last Monday evening that Mr. Heinemann's novel had walked away with the prize was greeted with expressions of surprise and astonishment.

title: Williams Leads Redskins By Lions
description: Doug Williams, replacing an ineffective Jay Schroeder, threw first-half touchdown passes to Kelvin Bryant and Gary Clark today to spark the Washington Redskins to a 20-13 victory over the Detroit Lions.

title: Iowa Poll Shows Simon and Dole as Leaders
description: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois has emerged as the clear leader in Iowa in the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, according to a new poll that was made public today.

title: INSIDE
description: Conflicting Computer Policy Although the U.S. barred M.I.T. from buying a Japanese computer, the Air Force had previously installed a unit from the same company. Page D1. Arc Is a Space Illusion An enormous blue arc in the distant universe turns out be an optical illusion, astronomers said. Page A16.

title: SOUTHWEST WATER COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Law That Expunges Child-Abuse Complaints Needs Changing
description: To the Editor:

title: The Move to Ban Chemical Weapons: Big Strides and Many More Hurdles
description: For years, talks on banning chemical weapons have been stymied by Moscow's refusal to accept extensive on-site verification measures.

title: WATTS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FAMILY SHOPPING NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GRAPHIC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The U.S. Role in Haiti's Debacle
description: LEAD: As Jean-Claude Duvalier headed for exile in a United States Air Force jet on Feb. 7, 1986, the world rejoiced at Haiti's sudden opportunity to escape from tyranny and to embark on democracy. Hopes that elections scheduled for this month would fulfill that dream grew when a powerful coalition of grassroots organizations joined the Roman Catholic Church to support the process.

title: G.M. Market Outlook for '88
description: The General Motors Corporation will not regain the market share it lost last year in its 1988 model year, according to Lloyd E. Reuss, the company's executive vice president.

title: Books of The Times
description: SPANGLE. By Gary Jennings. 869 pages.

title: Military Contractors Squeezed
description: The military contracting industry, which was riding high only several years ago as the Reagan Administration pursued the largest arms buildup in American peacetime history, is now heading into what may be its most difficult and competitive era.

title: Jackson Supporters Block Efforts By Black Democrats on Strategy
description: The formal establisment of a black Democratic group in the South foundered somewhat this weekend as supporters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson labeled its efforts a ''stop Jesse movement'' and defeated resolutions that they said would dilute their candidate's strength.

title: Vast Cosmic Object Downgraded to a Mirage
description: An enormous glowing blue arc in the distant universe, observed earlier this year and thought to be one of the largest objects yet detected in the cosmos, turns out to be an optical illusion caused by the light-bending effects of gravity, astronomers reported yesterday.

title: GRAF IS BASKING AS OTHERS PURSUE
description: THE thought crossed her mind when she was in Los Angeles recently, basking in the sunshine, savoring her accomplishments this year. Only 18, Steffi Graf of West Germany has already accumulated enough fame and fortune to last a lifetime, and fulfilled her ambition to become the No. 1 tennis player in the world. Life at the top, she understood, presented a different set of challenges. She could never be one of the girls again.

title: Peter Bogyo Married To Ahna McCracken
description: Ahna McCracken, the daughter of James McCracken and Sandra Warfield of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Bogyo, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen W. Bogyo of Tarrytown, N.Y. Dr. Barbara Raines, an Ethical Culture leader, officiated at the Lotos Club in Manhattan.

title: Beatrice Reassigning 4 Brands to West Coast
description: Beatrice/Hunt-Wesson has reassigned four brands to its West Coast ad agencies that had been handled by the J. Walter Thompson Company, Chicago. Beatrice and J.W.T. announced earlier last week that they had agreed to part company after five years.

title: Hospital Workers' Chief Loses in Power Struggle
description: A divided hospital workers union, announced voting results yesterday that gave a narrow victory to union officers urging lessened authority for the local's president.

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH REALTY INOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The trust began operations in December 1986.

title: Marlene Dietrich Sells Jewelry Items at Auction
description: Collectors of Marlene Dietrich memorabilia bid eagerly for the movie star's cigarette cases and powder compacts during a jewelry auction late last week night.

title: Departure at Case Unit Of Tenneco Is Surprise
description: The announcement that Jerome K. Green, the 51-year-old president and chief executive of the J. I. Case Company would resign, effective Dec. 1, has surprised most industry analysts.

title: Jazz: Town Hall Concert
description: FOUR young musicians were given a push into the spotlight by three established performers in a concert at Town Hall on Friday evening. Sponsored by a take-out food service, the concert's title, ''Culinova and All That Jazz,'' was a bit misleading.

title: Falling Dollar Leaves Pentagon Facing Deficit
description: The recent tumble in the dollar's value has left the Pentagon facing a deficit of at least $325 million in the fund used to pay overseas allowances to American military personnel, the Defense Department's comptroller says.

title: SEIBELS BRUCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a capital gain of $704 for the quarter and capital losses of $4,585 for the 9 months. c-After capital gains of $24,983 for the quarter and $2,326,902 for the 9 months. d-Net loss

description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Industrial Production... Oct. Capacity Utilization... Oct. Tuesday Inventory-Sales... Sept. Wednesday Housing Starts... Oct. Thursday None Friday Consumer Price Index... Oct.

title: Music: Russell Sherman Plays Beethoven
description: RUSSELL SHERMAN has long held a special niche in Beethoven interpretation in this country. He is a pianist whose interpretations seem to be continually renewed by intellectual and imaginative inquiry, whose response to the issues posed by the music at hand is always specific. The Beethoven Society presented him Saturday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall with the New England Conservatory Chorus and Orchestra, in the Fourth Piano Concerto and the Choral Fantasy; in both, his assured, concentrated approach brought rewards.

title: Fordham Receives Chance to Play On
description: Fordham was selected for the Division III playoffs yesterday, and the invitation put the Rams in a postseason football game for the first time in 46 seasons.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Why the Underclass Is Still Under
description: Explanations for the appearance of a black urban underclass have ranged from the fanciful to the frivolous, from behavioral distortions wrought by the welfare system to the transplantation of a Southern sharecropper culture to big-city ghettos.

title: Petras P. Griskevicius; Lithuanian Chief, 63
description: Petras P. Griskevicius, the longtime Communist Party leader in the Soviet Baltic republic of Lithuania, died suddenly Saturday, the official Tass press agency reported today. He was 63 years old. Tass did not give the cause of death. The son of a tailor, Mr. Griskevicius had been leader of the Lithuanian party since February 1974. He was also a deputy in the Supreme Soviet, the nation's Parliament.

title: 7 Unlikely Nations Join Winter Games
description: Among the record 60 countries who expect to compete in the Calgary Winter Olympics, which begins in mid-February, are seven who have no prior experience in the Winter Games.

title: 'Onion Field' Killer, On Parole, Is Arrested
description: One of two men convicted in the 1963 slaying of a policeman that was chronicled in the book ''The Onion Field'' has been arrested on a drug charge, the police reported Saturday.

title: Business and the Law; Big Courtroom For Toxic Web
description: A FORMER school building near San Francisco became a court house earlier this month for one of the largest pollution lawsuits ever brought.

title: Ordeal for Homeless Students in Suburbs
description: While most of her classmates are still asleep, Tareebia Wakley is up at 6 A.M. each weekday to get ready for a 45-minute bus ride from a motel in Poughkeepsie to Oakside Elementary School here.

title: EARTH TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Includes a non-recurring, non-taxable refund of $306,000 and related taxable interest of $140,000, totaling $389,300, which increased share earnings by 14 cents a share.

title: How Jersey Dealt With Child Abuse
description: Responding to a series of child-abuse deaths over the last six years, New Jersey has strengthened its capability to detect, investigate and prevent such cases, according to Thomas Blatner, the former director of New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services.

title: Moonshine Is Undermining Moscow's Temperance
description: The Government's heralded crackdown on liquor sales has apparently spurred a compensatory boom in the home-brewed vodka known as samogon, with hundreds of thousands of thirsty Soviet citizens arrested this year as moonshiners.

title: Fuchs to Play Carnegie Hall
description: Joseph Fuchs, violinist, is to play works by Tartini, Beethoven, Mozart, Tchaikovsky and Ernst on Wednesday at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. In addition to his performing career, Mr. Fuchs is on the faculty at the Juilliard School. Katsurako Mikami is to appear with Mr. Fuchs as pianist. Tickets cost from $5 to $17. Information: 247-7800.

title: U.S. Policy Conflict on Computers
description: Two months before the Defense Department blocked the Massachusetts Institute of Technology from obtaining a Japanese-made supercomputer, the Air Force installed a $33 million computer system built largely by the same manufacturer, according to Government and industry officials.

title: A Mourning Ulster Abstains From Violence
description: Solemn memorial services replaced demonstrations as the focus of attention here today as Northern Ireland marked the anniversary of a landmark treaty signed two years ago by Britain and Ireland in an effort to bring peace to this troubled province.

title: ARMY WILL CLOSE CHILD-CARE CENTER
description: The Army announced it is closing and demolishing a child-care center at its base at the Presidio after allegations that as many as 60 youngsters were sexually abused there.

title: Taft? Hartley? The Names Ring a Bell, but Why?
description: Anybody remember Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr.? A New Jersey Republican with 20 years in the House who was briefly chairman of the Education and Labor Committee? Wait a minute, wasn't he Hartley of the Taft-Hartley Act, the restrictive 1947 labor law that the unions bitterly fought and are still mad about?

title: AMERICAN SCIENCE & ENGIEERING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW TESTS IN RIVALRY FOR SLICE
description: THE J. Walter Thompson Company and Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne made creative presentations to Pepsi-Cola U.S.A. for its Slice soft drink last Thursday and were sent back to the drawing boards, according to agency sources.

title: O'Rielly Leaves Year-Old Shop
description: Curvin G. O'Rielly, partner and creative director of the French-owned O'Rielly O'Brien Clow/RSCG, is quitting the year-old company he helped found.

title: REAGAN VOWS VETO
description: The Senate is poised to approve a major housing bill for the first time in seven years, setting up a possible veto battle with President Reagan, who says the legislation is a budget-buster.

title: Novel Recruits
description: Among the myriad of National Collegiate Athletic Association rules governing the recruitment of athletes is one that prohibits a college from identifying the players it hopes to sign.

title: Where School Is More Than School
description: What's the most valuable public resource in New York's poor communities? In many, it's the school building, and New York's Board of Regents thinks it could be used more extensively. The board has launched an experimental program whose results could have interest far beyond New York.

title: Cadillac's Allante Is Struggling to Find Its Niche
description: The two-seater, $55,000 Allante model was billed as the ''new spirit of Cadillac'' when it was introduced last March. But judging from sales thus far, the spirit may still be willing, but consumer interest is weak.

title: The Stage: Tom Cayler In Performance Works
description: ''DID you know that the French used to write etiquette books on when and where it was proper to pick their body lice?'' asks Tom Cayler, an actor and writer, early in his performance piece, ''Jerkismo and Other Male Myths.''

description: ''The price is high - but it is to prevent us having to pay an even higher price later.''

title: A $1.62 Billion Deal at Age 26
description: While other students at the Harvard Business School were merely studying mergers and acquisitions, Warwick Fairfax was buying $22 million worth of shares in Australia's oldest media company.

title: Panel Says N.S.C. Post Should Be Civilian Job
description: The Iran-contra Congressional committees are expected to recommend in their final report that national security advisers should not be selected from among the ranks of military officers, according to Congressional officials.

title: Knicks Learning At Last
description: A common pre-game ritual in National Basketball Association dressing rooms is watching films of an opponent's previous game.

description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $483,000 and $1,469,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: WHEN SKIS ARE WELL TUNED, THEY HUM AS THEY GLIDE
description: TUNE-UPS. We give them to our cars, our bodies, our golf and tennis games. Why should skis be any different? They're not. And the tune-ups they need are every bit as sophisticated as those we seek in the body shops.

description: b-Net loss

title: INSTITUFORM EAST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Still Big After All These Years
description: SOONER or later, the cycles get them all. The Game - Harvard versus Yale - is a good excuse to tailgate, but usually produces little more than the bragging rights for beleaguered heads of commerce. The Big Game - California versus Stanford - makes national news only when a student musician is run over at the end of a last-second kickoff return. Army and Navy have impressive parades, but coast-to-coast impact of their game requires the recruiting advantage provided by a world war, or at least a good police action.

title: BALCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Deficit Talks: Politics Takes Seat at Table
description: Since the day President Reagan sent his $1 trillion dollar 1988 budget to Congress last January, Democratic leaders and some Republicans in Congress have called for a meeting with Mr. Reagan on deficit reduction.

title: EQUIPMENT COMPANY OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $32,000. c-Includes tax credits of $88,000 for the quarter and $242,000 for the 9 months.

title: U.S. Diver Dies in Antarctica
description: A 22-year-old California research assistant died Saturday in a diving accident under the ice of Antarctica, the National Science Foundation announced. The diver, Mark T. Macmillan of San Jose, was pronounced dead by Navy doctors at McMurdo Station, the American scientific outpost on the continent.

title: AMERIBANC INVESTORS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Debt Delay For Wheeling
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has granted the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation another extension giving management the exclusive right to file a plan for settling the company's debts. Judge Warren W. Bentz made the decision Friday over the objection of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, Wheeling-Pittsburgh's largest creditor, with a claim estimated at $500 million.

title: STAGE: 'BREAKING THE CODE'
description: ''BREAKING THE CODE,'' the new London import at the Neil Simon Theater, is yet another English drama about a sensitive genius whose homosexuality leads to his crucifixion by the hypocritical establishment. But if Hugh Whitemore's flawed, discursive play shares many of the symptoms of its well-worn genre, it finally pulls away from the sentimentality of ''Another Country'' and ''Prick Up Your Ears'' and all the recent rest. ''Breaking the Code'' is a work about a gay martyr that moves the audience precisely because its protagonist, as presented by Mr. Whitemore and as beautifully acted by Derek Jacobi, never thinks of himself as a martyr. When the story of a badgered nonconformist is told as a tale of proud self-assertion rather than maudlin self-pity, one finds not a saintly victim, but a stirring hero, at center stage.

title: Lintas Relinquishing Timberland Account
description: Lintas: New York announced Friday that it had resigned the account of the Timberland Corporation because it could not agree with the new management on basic strategy. The account, billing about $4 million a year, came to the agency in 1985.

title: No Headline
description: Hard experience has taught the nation's bankers to be skeptical of Congress. Still bitter about the moratorium on expanded banking businesses that was imposed by Congress last summer, they have started a new lobbying campaign to defend their industry's interests on Capitol Hill.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1987
description: The Economy

title: INQUIRY IS BEGUN ON BLASTS IN TEXAS
description: A damage assessment team today began investigating two explosions that ripped apart a chemical plant, blowing out windows six miles away and touching off a huge fire and killing three people.

title: No to a Veterans' Department
description: President Reagan, who rode into office as the nemesis of Big Government, now rides around Washington as the defender of an indefensible cause: elevating the Veterans Administration to a cabinet-level department. Yet that seems likely; bipartisan majorities in Congress appear ready to roll.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1987
description: International A3-12
