All 1987 figures includes results of Contempri Homes Inc., which acquired Dec. 30, 1986. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 5 percent stock dividend payable Nov. 18.

title: Market Place; Using Odd Lots As an Indicator
description: FOR a brief period last month, small investors who buy in odd lots - that is, fewer than 100 shares - greeted the plunging prices of Black Monday as a buying opportunity.

title: Tornadoes Hit Eastern Texas, Leaving 9 Dead
description: Tornadoes swept across more than 200 miles of eastern Texas today, leveling scores of homes and buildings and leaving nine people dead and at least 132 injured.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A recent Sports of The Times column on free agency in pro football mentioned the Dayton Triangles as being among teams that had moved to other cities. What happened to them?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Lendl Overpowers Jarryd: Ivan Lendl captured his seventh Grand Prix title of the year yesterday, defeating Anders Jarryd, 6-3, 6-2, 7-5, in the final of the $375,00 Benson and Hedges championship in Wembley, England. The first prize of $75,000 increased the 27-year-old Lendl's earnings for 1987 to just short of $1 million. Lendl, who has been the world's top-ranked tennis player for two years, dropped only 17 points on his service, 5 in the first set, 4 in the second and 8 in the third. (AP) Navratilova Triumphs: Martina Navratilova was surprised that she was facing a 16-year-old from the Soviet Union in the championship of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Chicago tournament. But it didn't shake her game. ''I was a little more creative from the baseline,'' Navratilova said after beating unseeded Natalya Zvereva, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday to capture her eighth Chicago title. Zvereva, speaking through her coach, Olga Morozova, said she didn't play her best. She was seeking to become the first Russian to win a tournament on the Virginia Slims circuit since Morozova defeated Billie Jean King in Philadelphia in March 1974. (AP) Mayotte Tops Gomez: Fourth-seeded Tim Mayotte beat second-seeded Andres Gomez, 7-6, 6-4, yesterday in the final of the $174,000 Frankfurt Cup in West Germany. The victory was the 27-year-old American's fifth on the Grand Prix circuit this year. (AP) Golf Marsh Edges Watson: Graham Marsh of Australia birdied the last hole and shot the day's best score, a six-under-par 66, to beat Tom Watson by one stroke yesterday in the $667,000 Taiheiyo Club Masters tournament in Gotemba, Japan. Marsh, who started the final round four shots back, finished with a 276 total, 12 under par on the club's 7,072-yard, par-72 Gotemba course. He won $120,000. Watson, who started the final round one shot back, fired a 70 for 277. (AP) Soccer C. W. Post Advances: Jamal Hassan scored off a feed from Jimmy Posillico to give C. W. Post a 1-0 victory over New Hampshire College in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II soccer playoffs yesterday in Manchester, N.H. In winning its first N.C.A.A. tournament game in the 32 years that it has played soccer, C. W. Post (13-6-1) was outshot, 15-8. But the senior goaltender, Robert Podeyn, had seven saves. C. W. Post advanced to a quarterfinal game against Southern Connecticut next weekend. Horse Racing G'Day Mate Wins by a Neck: G'Day Mate held on to win by a neck in the $86,700 General Douglas MacArthur Handicap for 3-year-olds and up yesterday at Aqueduct. Carrying 114 pounds, ridden by Frank Lovato Jr., the 4-year-old colt posted a stakes-record time of 1:48 4/5 for nine furlongs while registering his fourth victory in 10 starts this year. Easy 'n' Dirty, the favorite, finished second, 1 3/4 lengths ahead of Summer Tale. G'Day Mate earned $52,020 for Carolyn Chernick and paid $16.60 for $2 to win. In the other featured race, La Polonaise, the favorite, took the Schenectady Handicap for New York-bred fillies and mares 3 years old and up, in a stakes-record time of 1:09 3/5. She paid $5.40 for $2 to win. Auto Racing Second in a Row for Berger: Gerhard Berger of Austria led virtually all the way yesterday and captured the Australian Grand Prix in Adelaide. Berger, winner of the Japanese Grand Prix two weeks ago, became the first Ferrari driver to win consecutive Grand Prix races since the late Gilles Villeneuve of Canada did it in 1981 by winning in Monaco and Spain. Berger completed the 82-lap, 192.498-mile circuit through Adelaide's streets in 1 hour 52 minutes 56 seconds, at an average speed of 102.26 miles per hour. (AP) N.B.A. Celtics 103, Pacers 98: Larry Bird scored 11 of his 24 points in the first quarter as undefeated Boston beat Indiana, 103-98, last night for its sixth victory of the season. Boston, off to its best start since it went 10-0 in 1972, made 10 of its first 13 shots, shot 68 percent in the first quarter and took the lead for good at 26-24 on a layup by Robert Parish. Reggie Miller led the Pacers with 23 points.(AP) N.H.L. Sabres 5, Maple Leafs 4: Phil Housley, a defenseman, scored his 12th and 13th goals of the season to spark Buffalo to a 5-4 victory over Toronto last night. The Buffalo goaltender, Jacques Cloutier, stopped 31 of the 35 shots he faced, including 13 in the third period.(AP)

description: Elizabeth W. Lawrence, a member of the New York State Hospital Review and Planning Council from 1973 to 1982, died of cancer of the pancreas on Thursday at the Elizabethtown (N.Y.) Community Hospital. She was 78 years old and lived in Elizabethtown.

description: With Otis Birdsong and Orlando Woolridge, the injured offensive guns, back in the lineup, the Nets came closer to victory tonight than at any other time this season. But in the end, the Nets lost to the Washington Bullets, 113-109, and remained the only team without a victory.

description: LEAD: With the junk-bond market wounded and slowly dying, it is clear that the merger party is over. It's time now to assess the damage, not just on Wall Street but for the country at large.

description: The fatal accident involving a Continental Airlines jet in Denver yesterday represents another serious setback to the nation's third-largest airline, which has been plagued by a stream of consumer complaints and negative publicity all year.

description: From outside, the building in Corona, Queens, looked as if it had been abandoned years ago. A layer of grime coated the windows and a rusting metal grate stretched across the storefront. But Charles DeSiervo knew better. He found a battered door on the side and pushed it open.

description: A punishing, back-and-forth struggle between the Giants and Eagles that sidelined Lawrence Taylor, Joe Morris and Brad Benson came down to a bare-footed kicker's 39-yard field-goal attempt today.

title: 11th-Hour Pact Sought On Jersey Beach Debris
description: Lawyers for New Jersey and New York City worked down to the wire today to avoid going to court to settle their dispute over garbage that fouled the state's beaches in the summer.

title: GOVERNOR ENTERS HOSPITAL
description: Governor William A. O'Neill checked into St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center in Hartford this afternoon, suffering a very high temperature and flu-like symptoms, Jon Sandberg, his press secretary, said. Mr. O'Neill's tempera-ture reached 103 degrees and his doc-tors ordered him to stay overnight for observation, Mr. Sandberg said. He stressed there was no indication the 56-year-old Democrat was suffering from anything serious.

title: Ballet: Joffrey in 4 Works by Arpino
description: THE Joffrey Ballet devoted its program Saturday night at the City Center to four works by Gerald Arpino, its resident choreographer and associate director. They were not the same four works that had been originally announced. Injuries to dancers made the scheduled program impossible to present. Nevertheless, ''Birthday Variations,'' ''Valentine,'' ''L'Air d'Esprit'' and ''The Clowns'' were all by Mr. Arpino.

After three weeks of deficit-reduction negotiations it's still politics-as-usual. description: BUDDY RYAN might as well have slapped Lawrence Taylor across the face with a glove. description: Members of Congress and representatives of the White House are negotiating a modest deficit reduction that may be necessary to restore ''the confidence of the market'' - assuming anything can do that. But even a strong attack on the deficit would not approach the underlying problems of the U.S. economy.

title: The Tennis Racquet, Reshaped Another Time
description: It has been close to a decade since the first oversized tennis racquets came onto the market, and two decades since Jimmy Connors played with his first steel racquet. Now comes another oddity: a racquet that its manufacturer, Wilson Sporting Goods Company of River Grove, Ill., says will set a new standard. A side view of the racquet shows a tapered midsection that bulges out in the middle to twice the size of a standard racquet. When seen head-on, it has a conventional shape. Marketed as the Profile, the racquet is made with high-grade graphite. It is designed to be extremely stiff but low in vibration. Zina Garrison of Houston, ranked among the top 10 in women's tennis, has tried the Profile. She sees it as a big help for players looking for more power in their stroke; for her, it is a matter of learning to harness the power. The racquet has alleviated her chronic arm problems, she said. The first shipments are due in tennis stores next month; quantities will be limited. It will be available in two head sizes (95- and 110-inch) and will retail for $225.

title: Bowl Picture Clear Despite Restriction
description: Notre Dame fans tossed oranges onto the field when the Irish soundly whipped Alabama, 37-6, at South Bend, Ind., Saturday, but Notre Dame is headed for the Cotton Bowl, according to its associate athletic director.

description: Adelaide L. Sanford remembers when her nephew was suspended from a Roman Catholic high school in Queens. He had been handed a brand-new textbook by his teacher, who later retrieved it, presented the book to a white student instead and gave her nephew a frayed copy in its place.

title: Pieter Menten Dies; Nazi War Criminal Was Collector of Art
description: Pieter Nicolaas Menten, the most notorious Nazi war criminal in the Netherlands, died here Saturday in a nursing home, according to Dutch television. He was 88 years old. No cause of death was given. Mr. Menten, a wealthy art collector, was convicted in the killings of dozens of Jews in the Polish village of Podhoroce while he was a translator with an SS unit of the German Army in 1941.

title: 'Frankie and Johnny' To Get Commercial Run
description: The Manhattan Theater Club production of Terrence McNally's ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune'' is to begin a commercial Off Broadway run on Dec. 4 at the Westside Arts Theater, 407 West 43d Street. The comedy, which stars Kathy Bates and Kenneth Welsh, opened at the theater club's main stage at the City Center on Oct. 27 and drew strongly favorable notices. The final performance there will be on Nov. 29.

title: Walter C. Iooss Sr.; Jazz Bassist, 73
description: Walter C. Iooss Sr., a jazz bassist, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Riverhead, L.I. He was 73 years old.

title: Careers; Managers Found by Computer
description: MOVE over, management recruiters. Stanford University is going to poach on your territory with a computerized system to help companies find managers.

title: Mitterrand Knew of Iran Arms Sales
description: President Francois Mitterrand acknowledged tonight that he had been informed of a French company's illegal arms sales to Iran in 1984 and said that he tried to have them stopped.

title: The Making of a Scholarly Best Seller
description: Simon & Schuster gave Allan Bloom a modest $10,000 advance and published an equally modest 10,000 copies of his scholarly and somewhat abstruse book. Eight months later, ''The Closing of the American Mind'' has been a best seller for 29 weeks, has sold an astonishing 445,000 copies and is about to make its author a millionaire.

title: HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $1,415,000 and a gain of $3,242,000 from an accounting change.

title: Bridge: Covering Honor With Honor Can Be a Fiendish Problem
description: The beginner learns some guidelines that tell him when to cover an honor with an honor, and thinks he understands the subject.

title: Moscow Was Caught Between Cuba and U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $29,400,000 writedown on drilling equipment.

title: Measuring Knowledge
description: REPORTS on what American students don't know always get top billing. Adults, overlook what they themselves don't know, urge schools to get tough. Lost in the process are proposals to make schools better rather than tougher.

title: When the Mind Dies But the Brain Lives On
description: MIRACULOUS recoveries from prolonged comas are the stuff of movies and fairy tales. But although medical advances have opened the way for more coma patients than ever to survive, most linger in a limbo state of unconsciousness, somewhere between life and death. Few of these patients, even if they can be kept alive indefinitely and even if they appear to awaken and sleep regularly, have any hope of full recovery.

title: MONARCH MACHINE TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Zoos Act To Restore Bali's Birds
description: IN an effort to replenish the population of Jalak Bali birds on their native island in Indonesia, 10 zoos in the United States have shipped 40 of the birds to Indonesia.

title: COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: McMahon Is Hot, But Elway Is Hotter
description: John Elway won a quarterback duel with Jim McMahon tonight, throwing for 341 yards and three touchdowns as the Denver Broncos rallied twice to beat the Chicago Bears, 31-29.

title: Harmonic Choir Offers A Musical Alternative
description: David Hykes and the Harmonic Choir make music that encourages new modes of listening. A number of recent musical developments have been leading in a similar direction. Very long compositions, static compositions, and process compositions all suggest alternatives to the linear cause-and-effect mode of listening appropriate to classical music.

title: Wallace G. Taylor, Corporate Treasurer, 68
description: Wallace G. Taylor, former treasurer of the American Cyanamid Company, died Nov. 8 of complications resulting from a heart ailment at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Networks vs. Birth Control
description: LEAD: When all three television networks recently rejected a 30-second paid ad on birth control submitted by the Association of Reproductive Health Professionals, the problem of broadcasting censorship clashed with the requirements of public policy.

title: Yeltsin Is Hospitalized, Editor of Izvestia Says
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the former ally of Mikhail S. Gorbachev who was dismissed last week as head of the Moscow Communist Party organization, has been hospitalized, the editor of the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia was quoted as saying today.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEC Chip Output
description: The NEC Corporation plans to start mass production of four-megabit dynamic random access memory chips, the next generation of computer chips, in late 1989, an NEC spokesman said. It seems that NEC will be the first producer to be able to make the chips available commercially. The company also plans to increase production of one-megabit D-RAM's from 500,000 units a month, to 2 million units a month by March 1988.

title: Campaign Scorecard
description: For those who are ''having trouble keeping track of who's done what'' in the Presidential campaign, the Washington publication Roll Call is offering what it bills as a ''Moral Scorecard.''

title: LAWRENCE INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DIVERSIFIED HUMAN REOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: IGI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $140,043 for the quarter and $154,087 for the 9 months, and tax credits of $18,498 and $271,506 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: LEISURE CONCEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 Named to Key Campaign Posts As Shakeup of Dole Staff Begins
description: Two longtime Republican workers were named today to key positions in the Bob Dole Presidential campaign amid signs that the organization would undergo further shifts in the next few days.

title: IDB COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago third quarter and 9 months nets reflect the retroactive elimination of the use of investment tax credit for the first 9 months of 1986. The adjustment resulted in an additional provision for income taxes of $163,000, or a reduction in earnings of 5 cents a share for both the third quarter and 9 months.

title: JONES INTERCABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CONCERT: NEW WAVE COMPOSERS
description: ELLIOTT SHARP and Peter Zummo, the two composers who led ensembles last weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave program, share a taste for Minimalism and guided improvisation; they're both grouped with downtown New York new music. But the two halves of their shared program at Carey Playhouse were as different as a stroll in Central Park and a subway odyssey - one whimsical and ruminative, one visceral and noisy.

title: Cello-and-Piano Pieces By Bennington Teacher
description: Lionel Nowak was born in 1911 and has taught for many years at Bennington College. Mr. Nowak is a composer as well - a fact his Bennington colleagues chose to honor at Merkin Hall Sunday night.

title: FOR JULIE ANDREWS, THE SOUND OF A DIFFERENT MUSIC
description: Julie Andrews, Hollywood's perennial beacon of sweetness and light, is busy rediscovering her identity as a singer. The 52-year-old star, who has not given a concert in nearly a decade, is bringing a lavish one-woman show to the Westbury Music Fair tomorrow for four nights.

title: NOVAR ELECTRONICS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: KUHLMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Sports of The Times; Ewing in the Crunch
description: ''ROBERT PARISH said you're a new Patrick Ewing,'' a Boston reporter, who had just returned from the Celtics' locker room, informed the once and future and present Patrick Ewing. ''He said you're playing hard, more aggressive.''

title: Aliens Balk at Old 'Skeletons'
description: Neftali Valencia, a Colombian who has worked steadily since he arrived in New York City in 1980, should have been the perfect candidate for citzenship under the new United States immigration law. Instead he believed that applying would alert agents to an earlier run-in with the law and end with his being thrown out of the country.

title: Garvey in Second Senate Bid
description: Edward R. Garvey announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for the Senate seat being vacated by Senator William Proxmire. Mr. Garvey, a former deputy State Attorney General and onetime executive director of the National Football League Players Association, made an unsuccessful bid last year to oust Senator Robert W. Kasten, a Republican. Mr. Proxmire, a Democrat, is retiring next year after serving since 1957.

title: F.T.C. Acts to Bar Acquisition by Dun
description: The Federal Trade Commission voted unananimously to have its staff seek a preliminary injunction blocking the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation's acquisition of Information Resources Inc.

title: Political Memo; JACKSON AND ROBERTSON: 'BOOKENDS' OF '88 RACE
description: A remarkable piece of political symmetry has emerged between the otherwise very different contests for the Republican and Democratic Presidential nominations.

title: Saudi Arabia Resumes Full Ties With Egypt
description: Saudi Arabia announced today that it had resumed full diplomatic relations with Egypt, becoming the seventh Arab country to do so in the last six days.

title: CARPENTER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,700,000 for the closing of a division.

title: Nurse Accused of Killing L.I. Patients With Drugs
description: A 25-year-old registered nurse, who officials said was trying to pose as ''a hero,'' was accused today of injecting fatal amounts of muscle-paralyzing drugs into several patients at a hospital here.

title: Lansing Warren, 93, Ex-Reporter
description: Lansing Warren, a former correspondent for The New York Times in Paris, died of a heart ailment Saturday in Pasadena, Calif. He was 93 years old and had lived in Pasadena since 1980.

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Results Plus
description: Horse Racing

title: Elayne H. Varian, Art Curator And Show Organizer, Dies at 74
description: Elayne Hanley Varian, an art curator and exhibition organizer, died of cardiopulmonary arrest on Nov. 4 at her home in Orlando, Fla. She was 74 years old.

title: CALIFORNIA WATER SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,196,000 from a change in accounting. The company said shareholders at a special meeting approved a 2-for-1 stock split, payable Oct. 30 to shareholders of record Oct. 20.

title: In a Tiny Town, News of Crash Hits Everyone Special to The New York Times
description: Just before 3 P.M. today, the American flag in front of the tiny Town Hall here was lowered to half staff.

title: LIFECORE BIOMEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the first quarter results reflect the acquisition of Orthomatrix Inc. in February, and the restatement of financial figures to include Orthomatrix's results.

title: Webb Names Chief
description: As expected, directors of the Del E. Webb Corporation today elected Philip J. Dion as chairman and chief executive of the gaming, real estate and recreation concern based in Phoenix. Mr. Dion, who is 42 years old and has been a Webb executive since 1982, succeeds Robert K. Swanson, who resigned unexpectedly for health reasons earlier this month.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Bowater Industries P.L.C., London, a maker of paper products, said about 3.6 million, or approximately 97 percent of Rexham Corp.'s common shares outstanding, had been tendered and accepted under its tender offer that had expired Friday. Crown Central Petroleum Corp., Baltimore, will sell assets of its oil and gas exploration and production division to an Amoco Corp. unit and affiliates of Cross Timbers Oil Co. for about $166 million. Dow Chemical Co., Midland, Mich., said it would buy United Agriseed Inc. for a price in the mid-$40 million range. KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Amsterdam, a Dutch-flag carrier, said it was not considering taking a stake in British Caledonian Airways if a planned takeover of Caledonian by British Airways P.L.C. failed. Liberty Corp., Greenville, S.C., engaged in insurance, television, radio and real estate, said its board had authorized the company to start a tender offer, beginning today, for up to 350,000 shares of its common stock, or about 3.8 percent of the total outstanding common stock, at $42 a share. Teradyne Inc., Boston, a producer of electronic test equipment, said it had reached an agreement to acquire Case Technology Inc., a closely held electronic design software company based in Mountain View, Calif.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., a diversified energy company, named G. William Jones senior vice president in addition to his position as president of APAC Inc., Atlanta, a contract construction and construction materials subsidiary. Bangor America Inc., a diversified sweater and knitwear maker, appointed David M. McDermott executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Knitwear division and Maine Gear Inc., a small group of specialty stores in Maine. Cardis Corp., Beverly Hills, Calif., a distributor of automotive parts, elected James E. Lane president and chief operating officer. Chemical New York Corp. and Chemical Bank appointed as a director Helene L. Kaplan, counsel to the New York law firm of Webster & Sheffield. Finalco Group Inc., McLean, Va., a leasing company that also sells data-processing, aircraft, communications and medical equipment, named Robert W. Bertrand president and chief operating officer, replacing as president John C. Cotton, who will remain chairman and chief executive. Financial News Network appointed John F. Berentson senior vice president, retail enterprises. Liz Claiborne Inc., a clothing manufacturer, appointed Jay Margolis president of the new Sportswear Group, Harvey L. Falk to the new position of executive vice president of operations and corporate planning, and Arthur Ortenberg and Jerome A. Chazen, formerly co-chairmen, as vice chairmen. It also named Liz Claiborne, president and founder of the company, to the new post of vice chairwoman in addition to her current positions. Metropolitan Reinsurance Co., a subsidiary of Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., appointed Franklin D. Haftl chief executive. Sears, Roebuck & Co., Chicago, elected Charles F. Moran senior vice president, chief information officer and a member of the Corporate Management Committee, and David Shute senior vice president, secretary and corporate general counsel.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in SportsMonday this week showing the College Top 20 in football listed Oklahoma State incorrectly.

title: BISHOPS GATHERING FOR SUBDUED TALKS
description: After a year of emotional and often rancorous relations with the Vatican, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops gathered here today for their annual meeting in a subdued and business-like atmosphere.

title: New Tiffany Strategy Pays Off for Chairman
description: Since last month's stock market plunge, William R. Chaney, the chairman and chief executive of Tiffany & Company, has watched his company's stock fall from more than $30 a share to under $20.

title: Not All Viewers Are Back From Strike
description: SOMETIMES your dreams come true. And sometimes your nightmares do.

title: HENDERSON WAIVED BY KNICKS
description: General Manager Al Bianchi continued the process of composing his own version of the Knicks yesterday. Gerald Henderson, the playmaker with two championship rings who arrived from Seattle a year and four days ago, was waived, and the Knicks picked up Tony White, a rookie who was waived last week by the Bulls.

title: MAXXAM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pre-tax gain of $133,363,000 from the sale of Maxxam's cutting and welding products operations for the quarter and 9 months; the 9 months also included a tax credit of $8,120,000 and a pre-tax gain of $18,355,000 from the termination of a pension plan. c-Net loss and the 9 months is after amortization of deferred financing costs of $16,112,000 related to costs which were incurred and substantially paid in December 1985 in connection with Pacific Lumber acquisition indebtedness that was refinanced in June 1986.

title: Giuliani Sees Case Aiding Prosecution
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, said yesterday that the United States Supreme Court's ruling against R. Foster Winans meant that his office ''was free to go ahead now'' with insider trading cases.

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the increase in revenue reflects the acquisition of United Artists Communications Inc. and a portion of Group W Cable, as well as the acquisition of Heritage Communications and an increase of subscriber levels and rates within the company's cable television systems.

title: ZENITH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $554,000.

title: Fed Aide Sees Better Feeling
description: The Federal Reserve Board's vice chairman, Manuel Johnson, said today that confidence in the financial system was returning after the stock market plunge of Oct. 19.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Charter Medical Gets Bid by Chief
description: LEAD: William A. Fickling Jr., who at 6 foot 4 inches was a star forward for Auburn University's basketball team in the 1950's, said he did not think he was tall enough to be successful in basketball today.

title: BERKEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $129,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Disbarred Lawyer Is Sentenced in Weapons Case
description: A disbarred lawyer convicted of plotting to export a stockpile of weapons to Thailand was sentenced today to four years in prison by a Federal judge.

title: Niwata and Tahmisian, Violinist and Pianist
description: The violinist-pianist duo of Kaoru Niwata and Emma Tahmisian made a debut in Weill Recital Hall Sunday afternoon with a program of works by Debussy, Franck, Prokofiev and Toshiro Saruya. Ms. Niwata's string tone was big and pleasing, and her energetic phrasing was invariably correct; Ms. Tahmisian presented a more restrained approach at the piano that was no less reasonable. Well-trained players (bo th have done graduate studies at Juilliard), the two musicians reflected the high level of proficiency that has become a norm on concert stages today.

title: Having, and Sharing, It All
description: A woman who considers herself one pillar of a two-career-couple-with-kids finds herself fed up with the bleak image accorded this kind of family.

title: Chun Says Violence Threatens Election
description: President Chun Doo Hwan, formally announcing that South Korea's presidential election would be held Dec. 16, warned today that repeated incidents of campaign violence had created a ''serious threat to a fair election and a frontal challenge to development of genuine democracy.''

description: Year-ago amounts are not available; the company went public Dec. 31, 1986.

title: Handouts of Cheese, Milk and Rice Face 50% Cut Next Year
description: Government policies to reduce surpluses of cheese, milk and rice have succeeded so well that the Reagan Administration plans to cut distribution of these commodities in half in the coming year, Federal officials said today.

title: Susan Wagner Appeals
description: Susan Wagner High School, which had the only undefeated football team in the Public School Athletic League, announced yesterday that it has appealed a decision by the league's commissioner that forced Wagner to forfeit eight of its nine victories this season because it used an ineligible player.

title: The Dance: Charles Moore, Ghana to Vaudeville
description: THE Charles Moore Dance Theater went from a festival in Ghana to American vaudeville theaters and dance halls during its program Sunday afternoon at the Triplex of Manhattan Community College. It was a pleasure to watch the company make that journey.

title: CANDIDATE SCRUTINY GIVING NEXT GENERATION PAUSE
description: Every now and then in her teen-age years, Andrea Kramer, a student at Harvard Law School, used to wonder whether her carousing would ever hurt her if and when she decided to run for political office.

title: The Sexy Look: Why Now?
description: Necklines plunge or open out in sweetheart effects not seen since the 1950's. Shoulders are bared, waistlines snugly fitted, and skirts are rounded in an egg shape, tightly draped, or flared and poufed with myriad petticoats. Some tops are translucent if not transparent, and some dresses look like lingerie, with slip tops and lacy edges.

title: COMPUTER ENTRY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest 9-month include a pre-tax gain of $323,000 from the sale of a building in the first quarter. The company also said revenue and earnings for the latest quarter were lower than expected due to a delay in obtaining parts for the new 9400 product, which delayed scheduled shipments of approximately $2 million until the first day of the fourth quarter.

title: Treasury Bonds on Upside
description: Despite unanswered questions about the outcome of negotiations to reduce Federal budget deficits, Treasury bond prices ended the day with gains of about 3/8 point and yields still in the 8 7/8 percent to 9 percent range that has prevailed for more than a week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1987
description: International A3-14

title: Prudential Real Estate Chooses Backer
description: Backer Spielvogel Bates, one of the largest components of Saatchi & Saatchi, announced yesterday that it had become the agency for Prudential Real Estate, which will franchise a nationwide chain of real estate offices a la Century 21.

title: Harry Greenwald; Coin Meter Inventor, 75
description: Harry Greenwald, who invented the coin meters on coin-laundry washing machines and dryers, died of a stroke Friday at Flushing Hospital in Queens. He was 75 years old and lived in Whitestone, Queens.

title: Presidential Candidates Find No Cure For 'Absentee Legislator Syndrome'
description: In May, the House of Representatives voted on an amendment to establish a bipartisan commission empowered to close unneeded military bases.

title: ANDERSON JACOBSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Open School Obligation
description: Parents in many communities find plenty of reason to complain about schools, but only those who make a point of getting involved deserve a hearing. And their numbers are dwindling as more and more parents work outside the home. In New York City this week, they have a chance to regain their grip on that crucial involvement: It's Open School Week, when parents are invited to visit schools and meet with teachers.

title: At Annual West Side Party, Tenants Renew Ties
description: There was a dinner party Sunday night at 905 West End Avenue, a grand affair on the calendars of the residents in the 53 apartments there.

title: How Many in Babylon?
description: To the Editor:

title: Going For Inner Gold
description: THE Mahre brothers have retired, leaving Bill Johnson - the 1984 downhill champion - as the only member of the United States men's ski team with an Olympic souvenir.

description: The year-ago figures are reported on a pro forma basis since the company had an initial stock offering in October 1986.

title: EXPERTS VOICE HOPE IN ALZHEIMER'S FIGHT
description: ALZHEIMER'S disease, the brain disorder that robs millions of people of their memories and minds, is beginning to yield secrets at a pace that scientists call dramatic and exciting.

title: Tokyo Stocks Rise 0.7%
description: Stock prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today as optimism increased that the United States would devise a deficit-cutting plan. The 225-share price index gained 167.18, to 22,615.43. But the volume of 300 million shares was down from Friday's 600 million.

title: Problem at Seabrook Utility
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire could face an involuntary bankruptcy petition at any time, the company acknowledged today, but a spokesman said that negotiations with creditors were continuing and that the utility was hopeful that it could reach agreement without bankruptcy.

title: LSB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net charge of $392,000 representing the estimated cost of the settlement of certain litigation which is pending. c-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $270,000 in connection with the early extinguishment of drafts payable for the quarter and 9 months.

title: To Envoys: Go Directly to Congress
description: It was a most unusual pilgrimage. Nine foreign ambassadors, from France to Fiji, filed into the office of Deputy Secretary of State John C. Whitehead earlier this month, cast aside their diplomatic politesse and protested that the United States was not paying its bill for the United Nations peace-keeping force in southern Lebanon.

title: FIRST ESSEX BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a special dividend of $1,948,000 from the State Mutual Savings Central Fund. The bank converted to stock form in August.

title: Bank Drops Eurobonds
description: Toronto Dominion International, a unit of the Toronto Dominion Bank of Canada, has withdrawn from the Eurobond market, it said today. Eurobonds are bonds that pay interest in a currency outside the country of issue. Several banks have reduced Eurobond activity as unprofitable.

title: Denver Inquiry In Crash Centers On Role of Snow
description: Officials investigating the fatal crash of a Continental Airlines jet in Denver said yesterday that prime interest had focused on the hazards of snow buildup on early-model DC-9 aircraft such as the one that crashed Sunday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: As the World Turns

title: Chemical Cuts Jobs At Credit Card Unit
description: The Chemical New York Corporation said it would eliminate 575 jobs by transferring its credit card operations in Chicago to its main processing facility at Jericho, L.I. and by closing its unprofitable merchant credit card processing services in Chicago. The company said it expects to begin consolidatng its credit card operations in January and to complete the process by March 31.

title: A Sincere Form of Flattery
description: Until recently I.B.M. and Apple, the big two of personal computers, have turned out models that were as different as a utilitarian Volvo and a sporty Porsche. Now, they risk becoming as alike as a Pontiac and a Chevy.

description: b-Includes pre-tax gains of $49,765,867 for the quarter and $50,094,785 for the 9 months from the sale of interests in cellular partnerships. c-Net loss Year-ago 9 months' loss includes a $2,102,423 gain on the sale of land and ''miscellaneous income'' of $1,030,000.

title: Oil Rigs Increase in U.S.
description: The number of operating rotary rigs, an indicator of the oil industry's health, rose by 33 last week, to 1,174 -a big jump over last year's 910 rigs, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. In Canada, the weekly rig count fell by 38, to 277, compared with 113 a year ago, when oil prices touched bottom.

description: b-Includes a U.K. tax credit of $90,000 for both periods. The 9 months includes a $325,000 credit from the recovery of unrealized losses on marketable securities, a $945,000 credit from the curtailment of salaried pension plans, and a $260,000 credit related to the partial settlement of a previously reserved receivable from an affiliated company. c-Net loss

title: RUSSIANS REPORTED TO BE WITHHOLDING KEY MISSILE DATA
description: Three weeks before the scheduled meeting of President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, major verification issues remained unresolved today in talks aimed at wrapping up a treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles.

title: GRAHAM-MCCORMICK OIL & GAS PARTNERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV Review; A&E OFFERS 'THE STORY OF FASHION'
description: WHAT'S new? Fashion, of course; it must be new by definition. When its moment is gone, it is history. ''The Story of Fashion,'' a six-part series on cable's Arts & Entertainment Network, has been looking at the last 100 years or so of haute couture. The third episode, at 8:30 tonight, concentrates on winds of change: what forces sweep fashion?

title: Brodsky to Read in Queens
description: Joseph Brodsky, winner of this year's Nobel Prize in Literature, is to read from his work on Nov. 30 at 7 P.M. at the Student Union of Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway. Mr. Brodsky gave his first reading at the college shortly after his arrival from the Soviet Union in 1972. A $2 donation is requested. Information: (718) 520-7323.

title: Modern Bride Sold For $50 Million
description: Reed International, the British parent of the Cahners Publishing Company, said it had acquired Modern Bride from Diamandis Communications Inc. for $50 million in cash. Additionally it agreed to pay Diamandis $13.7 million in consulting fees.

description: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov agreed to a draw today after 21 moves in the 14th game of their world chess championship match.

title: Israel Says Arab Boat Taken
description: A military spokesman said today that the Israeli Navy had intercepted a boat belonging to Al Fatah, a Palestinian guerrilla organization, forced it to dock at an Israeli port and arrested all of its passengers. The 250-ton tugboat Nadija, flying a Honduran flag, was stopped last Saturday somewhere west of the Israeli coast, the announcement said. The boat, en route from Cyprus to Yemen, was brought to the northern port of Haifa, according to Israel's Army Radio.

description: The nation's factories, mines and utilities raised their output by six-tenths of 1 percent in October, the strongest gain since July, the Federal Reserve reported today.

Put More Teeth in Parole
description: There's nothing wrong with parole that adding teeth won't solve. For the last year and a half, New York has tried tougher enforcement. It works, handsomely, but needs to be made tougher still.

title: James C. Brennan, 77, Retired Bank Official
description: Joseph Cantwell Brennan, a retired chairman and trustee of the Emigrant Savings Bank in New York and a prominent Roman Catholic layman, died last Thursday after a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: O'Neill's Doctors Confident as He Faces Surgery
description: Former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. will undergo surgery for rectal cancer on Wednesday, and his outlook is ''very favorable,'' his doctor said today.

title: Scouts Aide Held in Sex Case
description: An executive with the New York Council of the Boy Scouts of America was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually abusing an 11-year-old Scout over a two-year period, the police said. The official, James Vila, 39 years old, of Annandale, N.J., was accused of threatening and fondling the Scout at Public School 155 at 319 East 117th Street in Manhattan. A Boy Scouts official, Lyle Antonides, said Mr. Vila was suspended without pay. Mr. Vila has worked for the Scouts for more than five years, Mr. Antonides said, and he is primarily responsible for recruiting and training adult leaders.

Figures for 1986 are restated for the discontinuance of apparel operations.

description: A witness to the Aug. 16 crash of a Northwest Airlines plane that killed 156 people testified today that the wing flaps were in the proper takeoff position but the jet took longer to get off the ground than expected.

title: Stage: 'Romance Romance,' 2 Plays
description: HE market of the heart is wryly charted in ''Romance Romance,'' the bright new musical that opened last night at the Actor's Outlet Theater. Barry Harman, who wrote the book and lyrics for ''Olympus on My Mind,'' has found inspiration in a pair of Continental writers of another era. Arthur Schnitzler and Jules Renard may have been only boulevard psychologists, but their comments on the pulls and tugs of sex are as up to date as the latest Hite Report, and probably more reliable.

title: Advertising; Skepticism On Saatchi Rumors
description: A REPORT that Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. of Britain might take steps to return to privately held status was greeted with skepticism yesterday by knowledgeable members of the Wall Street and agency communities.

title: U.S. AIDE DELAYED CONTRA ARMS CASE
description: A Federal prosecutor acknowledged today that he briefly held up an investigation last year into arms smuggling to the Nicaraguan rebels but said he did so only because the case had become clouded by unfounded allegations against a United States Senator.

title: Mesa Reports Its Holdings
description: Mesa Limited Partnership, the oil-and-gas concern headed by T. Boone Pickens, disclosed today that it was part of a group of investors that owned 4.8 percent of the Homestake Mining Company, a gold production company, at the end of September.

title: S.E.C. Files Payout Plan On Levine
description: Dennis B. Levine's insider-trading activities in 54 companies over a five-year period have led a myriad of investors, corporate acquirers and creditors to assert they have been injured by his illegal use of confidential information.

title: Sports People; Doug Williams to Start
description: Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins' quarterback, has been granted his wish to start for a contender, and it did not take a trade to do it. For months, Williams has expressed a desire to be traded so he could start for a winning team. Coach Joe Gibbs repeatedly denied the request.

title: Bonn May Let Deficit Rise
description: The West German Government, under pressure from abroad to contribute to the world's economic growth, said today that it was prepared to risk a higher than projected 1988 budget deficit.

To complement the exchange of words, according to preliminary planning, there is to be an exchange of art, and the Russians are to lend a Rembrandt painting to be displayed at the National Gallery of Art.

description: The Koch administration said yesterday that it would seek to acquire a 750-room hotel near Times Square as a long-term residence for the homeless, and as the site of a work-release program for New York City jail inmates.

title: Turning Point Nears In Production of Fuel For Hydrogen Bombs

title: Israeli Writers at the Y
description: Three Israeli writers - Amos Oz, Anton Shammas and Natan Zach -will read from their works at 8 P.M. on Dec. 7 at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. In addition to his writing, Mr. Oz - who won Israel's Bialik Award for literature last year - also teaches English and works on a kibbutz. Mr. Shammas, an Israeli Arab who writes in Hebrew and Arabic, also produces television programs. Mr. Zach, a poet and teacher, won the Bialik Award in 1981. Tickets are $8. Information: 996-1100.

title: Spanish Trawler Carrying 34 Missing Near Newfoundland

description: An ancient metropolis being excavated by archeologists at this site 20 miles southwest of Jerusalem is providing evidence that the Philistines - long associated with hedonism and a lack of culture - may actually have been an urbane and industrious lot.

title: Simon Cites Character
description: If this is the year of the character issue in Presidential politics, then Senator Paul Simon's first set of television commercials, which begin running in Iowa this week, suggest that he may be out to corner the market.

title: Concert: Pomerium Musices
description: WILLIAM BYRD'S vast, legacy of Tudor music was the subject of a Sunday afternoon concert by Pomerium Musices and the New York Consort of Viols at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. Five pieces for viols (or, in one case, reconstructed for viol consort from a keyboard piece) alternated with five Latin hymns and three English madrigals, and voice and viols combined for two larger concerted pieces: ''Out of the Orient Crystal Skies'' and the verse anthem ''Christ Rising Again.''

title: Meese's Record of Failure
description: Edwin Meese 3d should never have been named Attorney General in the first place. Now, with a record in that office of monumentally poor judgment and of ethical insensitivity, the most dignified contribution Mr. Meese could make to prop up this faltering Presidency would be to resign.

title: Joseph F. Heffernan; Opera Photographer, 64
description: Joseph F. Heffernan, the photographer for the Metropolitan Opera House, died of lung cancer Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Hunt Hearing Kept Open

title: Recital: Anthony Newman Inaugurates a Church Organ
description: THE Church of the Holy Trinity on East 88th Street inaugurated a new organ Sunday afternoon. It is a 33-stop tracker instrument by Rieger Orgelbau of Austria, designed for a particular kind of versatility: registrations historically appropriate for French and North German Baroque music are accommodated, while string work for the French Romantics is available on the third manual.

title: Safeguards Seen as Effective In Hospitals Despite L.I. Case
description: The New York State Department of Health and the 280 general hospitals it regulates have safeguards to protect patients from mistakes by medical personnel, accidents and improper or inappropriate care, state officials said yesterday.

title: After a Half Century in Office, Carolinian Is Calling It Quits
description: Thad Eure, North Carolina's Secretary of State, who says he has held statewide elective office longer than anyone in the nation, said today that he would not seek another term.

title: Diabetics' Risk From Exercise
description: Regular exercise is one of the best prescriptions for maintaining good health, but even this can have unexpected risks for young diabetics.

title: Violin: Nathan Milstein Plays at Fisher Hall
description: IT should come as no surprise that, at the age of 82, Nathan Milstein is not the steely-sure violinist he once was. But if he struggled at various points during his recital Sunday afternoon in Avery Fisher Hall to keep the bow steady and the tone full and even, Mr. Milstein got across the essential aspects of his artistic vision.

title: 6 Arrested in Violence Against Cabbies
description: Six men were arrested in three days in a crackdown on violence against cabdrivers, the police said yesterday.

title: Three String Players Of Vienna Symphony
description: The Vienna String Trio displays many of the best traits of musicians steeped in the Austro-German tradition. The ensemble, made up of principal players in the Vienna Symphony Orchestra, gave a concert sponsored by the Austrian Institute Saturday evening in Weill Recital Hall.

title: Old Planes Restored for a Journey Into the Past
description: AS the first century of powered flight approaches its completion, historians and technical experts are redoubling efforts to save and restore a few of the aircraft that helped to shape modern history.

description: The most endangered of all sea turtles, Kemp's Ridley turtles, are washing up on Cape Cod beaches because the unaccustomed cold water prevents the animals from functioning, marine experts say.

title: The Speaker of State
description: Diplomacy abhors a vacuum, which is just what the Reagan Administration has left concerning Central America - and just why there's such a hollow ring to its complaints about freelance diplomacy by Speaker of the House Jim Wright. Diplomatic involvement by members of Congress raises truly troubling questions. But in this case, the Administration asked for it.

title: ACTING OUT ONE'S PRIVATE FEARS
description: They are not young, not beautiful, simply two ordinary people in their 40's, both of them alone. They met at work - she's a waitress, never married; he's the short-order cook, divorced - and for six weeks they observed each other warily before he finally asked her out. They enjoyed the date and ended up in bed - but now that the love-making is over, she wants him to leave.

description: The Kenyan Government today closed the University of Nairobi, the country's main university campus, after two days of battles between security forces and students demonstrating over the arrest of their leaders.

title: Bus Crash in Spain Kills 10

title: Status of Taylor Not Yet Determined

description: In the first major publishing transaction since the stock market's collapse, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its magazine and school supply operations for $334.1 million to a management group led by Robert Edgell, the executive who has run the company's book operations for 15 years.

title: JUSTICES ALLOW SCRUITINY OF AGENT ORANGE DATA
description: Over the protest of seven chemical manufacturers, the Supreme Court today let stand an appeals court order that the companies allow Vietnam veterans who sued them see research documents on the herbicide Agent Orange.

title: New Storms Strike Gulf Coast; Death Toll at 12
description: New storms with heavy rain and high wind struck the Gulf Coast from East Texas to Mississippi today, causing new damage and stalling efforts to clean up wreckage left by tornadoes. An oil worker was killed in Texas.

title: By Design
description: Pouf Proof: Wearing one of the new party dresses, poufed and frothy, is a heady experience. Coping with it between wearings is another story, however. If the souffle of the skirt falls, much of its allure is lost.

title: Small Plane Crashes on Hillside In Wisconsin, Killing 8 on Board
description: A corporate airplane flying from Chicago apparently broke up in flight and crashed on a wooded ridge near here today, killing all eight people aboard, the authorities said.

title: Smoking Out Smokers
description: During this week of the Great American Smokeout, countless smokers are taking a break from cigarettes that could be permanent. Look at what happened when New York City's Beth Israel Hospital imposed a smoking ban last spring.

title: COCAINE TRIAL NEARS FOR WEST VIRGINIA MAYOR
description: Jury selection began today in the drug trial of Mayor Mike Roark after the judge ruled that prosecutors could not present evidence of cocaine use unless it was included in the indictment.

title: Swedish Train Crash Kills 9
description: Nine people were killed and more than 100 were injured today when two trains crashed head-on in western Sweden and burst into flames, rescue workers said. The crash occurred near the town of Lerum, about 12 miles east of Goteborg, when an express from Stockholm to Goteborg ran into a passenger train traveling on the same track in the opposite direction. A total of about 250 people were aboard the two trains. Many were trapped in the wreckage.

title: EVERT, DRAINED AND TIRED, LOSES TO HANIKA, 6-4,6-4
description: At 9:03 last night, Sylvia Hanika of West Germany punched a forehand volley winner past Chris Evert into the open court and took one small step toward a victory that had eluded her for 10 years.

title: SOLIDARITY ASSAILS INCREASE IN PRICES
description: Solidarity leaders today denounced the drastic price increases announced by the Government over the weekend, saying the proposals ''could well push broad circles of society into poverty and a feeling of hopelessness.''

title: MYCOGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rock: Squeeze, At Garden
description: EVERY few years, a band comes along to take up the Beatles' challenge: How much cleverness can be slipped between the lines of a catchy, concise rock song? Since 1974, Squeeze's songwriters and guitarists, Glenn Tilbrook and Chris Difford, have been packing their songs with bright ideas. Mr. Tilbrook's music makes implausible chords, tricky melodic lines and even full-fledged dissonance sound natural; Mr. Difford's lyrics sketch characters and situations from the down-to-earth details left out of most pop songs. Yet Squeeze rarely sacrifices melody for literary or musicianly sophistication.

title: Sports People; Too Much Glasnost?
description: John Thompson, coach of the 1988 Olympic basketball team, sees no harm in American college teams playing teams from the Soviet Union. But he's not too keen on teaching Soviet teams the finer points of the game.

description: A 20-year-old mother was arrested last night and charged with killing her 2-year-old daughter, the police said.

title: After a Brief Retirement, Classic Winner Tries Again

It would give them something to brag about when they deliver his first sons and daughters next spring.

The venture, to be called the Detroit Diesel Corporation, will take over the heavy-duty diesel manufacturing business of G.M.'s Detroit Diesel Allison division.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why doesn't the stomach digest itself? A. Cells lining the stomach and duodenum produce a mucous-like substance that separates the stomach wall from digestive enzymes and acids, according to Dr. Averil Ma, a gastroenterology fellow at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. ''We're not completely sure of all the constituents of this barrier,'' he said.

title: 'Composers on Stage,' Series at Town Hall

Appearing in the first part are to be the composers Milton Babbitt and Mario Davidovsky, with Judith Bettina, a soprano; John Hollander, a poet; Edward Rothstein, a music critic, and the group Speculum Musica, which will perform ''Philomel'' and ''Phonemena'' by Mr. Babbitt, and ''Romanceros'' and ''Synchronisms, No. 6'' by Mr. Davidovsky.

title: Our Towns; Playing to Win: Java, Kittatinny And a Headache

The eighth-grade teacher kept worrying that he hadn't told his star pupil, Bob Herbstzuber, every last fact for the state geography championship. Had he mentioned that Cairo is the biggest city in Africa? That Java is the most densely populated island in Indonesia?

description: Six unmanned locomotives traveled more than 30 miles today at speeds up to 55 miles per hour before dispatchers were able to guide them onto a siding where they crashed into empty boxcars and stopped, officials said.

title: Major Decisions in Insider Trading Law
description: Trading of securities by company executives based on inside information has been illegal throughout much of the history of corporate America. It was not until the 1960's that Federal authorities sought to broaden the notion of ''insider'' to include printers, financial analysts and journalists. Following are some of the major developments - before yesterday's Winans decision - in insider trading law. 1909: The United States Supreme Court establishes a rule that the director of a company must either disclose the inside information or abstain from trading. Although the case, Strong v. Repide, made it clear than an executive could not use privileged information for profit, it did not address the issue of who is an insider. 1934: Congress passes the Securities Exchange Act, which contains a key provision, Section 10, broadly outlawing certain forms of stock fraud. Based on Section 10, the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1942 adopts Rule 10b-5 making the fraud provisions applicable to purchases as well as sales of securities. Section 10 and Rule 10b-5 become the key provisions to prosecute illegal insider trading. Neither provision actually defines insider trading. 1968: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York rules that anyone who possesses inside information of a consequential nature must either disclose it to all of the investing public or abstain from trading until that information is public. Acting on a tip that the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company had discovered a site near Timmins, Ontario, rich with copper ore, company officials traded heavily in the stock before disclosing the find.

title: Cyprus-LTV Steel
description: The Cyprus Minerals Company said it had filed claims totaling $1.07 billion against the LTV Steel Company and alternate claims of $722 million against its parent company, the LTV Corporation. Cyprus, based in Englewood, Calif., said the claims stem from LTV's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing in July 1986 and its subsequent rejections of two long-term coal supply contracts. It said LTV was once its biggest coal customer and the claims are based on the present value of damages from lost profits over the lives of those contracts and the value of coal delivered but not paid for at the time of the bankruptcy filing.

description: Players who have been traded often speak of the difficulty in making the transition from one team to another, especially in the midst of a season.

He died Friday night of a heart attack, said his stepdaughter, Lucy Bell. ''Thursday was the greatest day of his life,'' she added.

title: 'Seeing' Inside Rocks
description: A new acoustic scanning device developed by a Stanford University geophysicist is enabling scientists to ''see'' the internal structure of rocks. The instrument is proving effective in predicting the fluid permeability of rocks, knowledge that can be useful in oil exploration, hydrology and the disposal of hazardous wastes.

description: One of the cleansing properties of American music's turn toward simplicity is a literal respect for one's sources. Ever since Haydn, composers have been transforming popular art to meet their more esoteric needs, but it was nice to come upon Robert Beaser's seven ''Mountain Songs'' for flute and guitar at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon.

Worldwide sales in the third quarter rose 11 percent from the period a year ago, to $:4.65 billion, or about $8.09 billion.

title: Black Witness Describes Beating in Howard Beach
description: A 37-year-old black man vividly testified yesterday that he was repeatedly beaten with bats and tree limbs by a gang of white youths who, yelling racial slurs, chased him and two other black men through the streets of Howard Beach, Queens.

title: Expanding Oceans
description: Two British scientists have predicted that the warmer global temperatures caused by the ''greenhouse effect'' will cause the world's oceans to rise in the next 40 years by at least four to eight centimeters (1 1/2 to 3 1/4 inches). This would result purely from the expansion of the water caused by the higher temperature. The calculation, they said, does not take into account the melting of polar and glacial ice that may also occur with a warming atmosphere, which would further raise the sea level.

title: Citizens Want to Know
description: Whitty Cuninggim started by explaining what had first moved her. ''I was a bride in 1939. My playhouse was disrupted and I didn't know why. When my husband was sent off to war, my mother-in-law said: 'Don't worry. God will send him back.' I wasn't satisfied. He came back, but I decided by cracky, I may not be able to do anything about it but from now on I'm going to know why.''

title: Southmark In Merger Pact
description: The Southmark Corporation has signed a letter of intent to merge with a subsidiary of the I.C.H. Corporation, creating an insurance and financial services company with more than $20 billion in assets, the companies said today.

title: JUSTICES, 8-0, BACK U.S. ON CONVICTION OF WALL ST. WRITER
description: The Supreme Court today upheld, by 8 to 0, the convictions of a former Wall Street Journal reporter and two other men on Federal mail and wire fraud charges for using advance knowledge of articles about publicly traded stocks to make illegal profits.

title: New York City Reaches Accord With Jersey on Floating Garbage
description: Officials of New York City and New Jersey announced today that they had reached an understanding on the broad outline of a plan to help assure that garbage from the city does not wash up on the Jersey Shore.

description: Earle Bruce, dogged by criticism after three consecutive losses, was dismissed today as the head football coach at Ohio State. Shortly after the administration's action, Rick Bay, the school's athletic director, resigned in disagreement.

description: FOR years Kaiser Permanente has proudly proclaimed that it could supply good medical care at a reasonable rate. Its promotions have been wildly successful, and Kaiser has become by far the nation's largest prepaid-health-care organization, with more than five million members.

description: Joseph M. White, a consultant to pharmaceutical companies for 30 years, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 67 years old.

The tests will be marketed under the trade name Sure Cell. Kodak said they are able to produce results in three to 15 minutes.

In order to sell the notes when market conditions are most favora-ble, the city plans to give prospective underwriters 24 hours' advance no-tice of the bidding deadline.

Instead, she returned to her hotel room where a friend catered a private dinner party. ''It was all Czech food,'' she said. ''Roasted duck with caraway seeds, dumplings, cabbage and sauerkraut.''

description: The Supreme Court's ruling in the case of R. Foster Winans was unclear concerning securities law and inconsistent concerning fraud law, yet it produced a roughly just result. Now it's up to Congress to clarify both areas of the law.

title: NETS FINALLY WIN
description: Through a year of pain from nerve damage in his left leg and tendinits in his left knee, Otis Birdsong dreamed of a night when he might again be in the position to win a game. It finally came tonight. With 49 seconds remaining and the Rockets ahead, 110-109, Birdsong sank a 14-foot jumper over Allen Leavell that put the Nets ahead to stay en route to a 114-111 victory over Houston at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

description: ''LA VIE EST BELLE'' is a genial musical comedy film from Zaire, and there are two striking things about it: how very African it is, and how very African it is not.

title: Western Union Again Delays Vote
description: The Western Union Corporation again put off a shareholder vote on its restructuring plan. A shareholder meeting that had been set for Nov. 11 and then adjourned until today was adjourned again until Dec. 10, the company said. Shareholders were to vote on merging the corporation with its principal subsidiary, the Western Union Telegraph Company. The move would lower the status of certain preferred shareholders.

title: About New York; Ah, Such Tastes: A Chef's Spirit Is Triumphant
description: Elizabeth Terry telephoned from the late James Beard's kitchen the other day. Mr. Beard, the chef and cookbook writer, once said that if he were forced to practice cannibalism, ''I might manage if there were enough tarragon around.'' Mrs. Terry, a fine Savannah chef, said it was ''definitely intimidating'' cooking at Mr. Beard's.

title: HOUSING MEASURE BLOCKED IN SENATE
description: Senate Republicans today delivered a surprising and potentially fatal blow to major housing legislation that was expected to be passed and sent to the President.

description: Madeleine Kamman, a chef and cooking instructor, said she came to California because ''there is a much younger spirit, a sparkle out there.'' And the state was just right, she said, for her newest project: a ''finishing school'' for chefs.

title: Court View Seen as Bar To Leaks
description: The Supreme Court decision in the Winans inside trading case is likely to discourage leaks of an array of corporate information, from product designs to financial projections, legal experts said yesterday.

description: OUR refrigerator used to develop a nervous tic at Thanskgiving and Christmas. Not because it was stuffed with food - which it was -but because my children were home from school for vacation and opened it every time they passed it.

title: Greenville Journal; It's Harvest Time for Christmas Tree Farmers
description: Gary Riessen stood on a hill near this small town in western Michigan and smiled as he listened to the sounds of Christmas: the whine and sputter of chain saws, carrying on the brittle November air.

title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS NETORK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports People; Griffin Relents
description: Alfredo Griffin, the Oakland Athletics' shortstop who is being pursued by a number of teams, including the Yankees, has rescinded his demand for a trade. So now there is a greater chance than ever he will be traded. The explanation? Last week, Griffin exercised a clause in his contract demanding a trade, presumably in an attempt to gain a lengthy contract extension but also making difficult any attempts by the Athletics to trade him by saying he would veto deals with the Yankees, Los Angeles, Mont-real, Philadelphia, Houston and Bos-ton. The first four of those teams were all known to be interested in the 30-year-old player. The A's now can entertain any trade offers, although Griffin is sure to seek an extension since he can become a free agent at the end of next season. Griffin has one year left on his current contract at a $750,000 salary.

title: Legislators Seek Bistate Council On the Economy
description: Three legislators from New York and New Jersey, calling for a ''cease-fire'' in the states' battle for business development, said yesterday that they would propose a new bistate economic cooperation council.

title: Sports People; Hearns-Hagler Near
description: A contract for Thomas Hearns to defend his World Boxing Council middleweight title against Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the former undisputed champion, could be completed by the end of next week, according to the Hearns camp. Emanuel Steward, Hearns's manager, said that negotiations with Hagler got under way last weekend and that there was a 95 percent chance for a fight this spring. Hearns, the only boxer to win titles in four different weight classes, wants to fight either Hagler or Sugar Ray Leonard. Both scored knockouts over Hearns, the only blemishes on a 46-2 pro-career.

title: Howard Beach Witness Holds to Story of Attack
description: Under intense cross-examination by defense lawyers yesterday, a 37-year-old black man vigorously stood by his story that he was attacked and severely beaten by a gang of whites who confronted him and two other black men in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: Amoco Raises Its Dome Offer
description: The Amoco Corporation said its Canadian unit had raised its takeover offer for Dome Petroleum Ltd. to $5.5 billion Canadian, or about $4.2 billion in United States currency. The previous bid was $5.1 billion Canadian, or about $3.9 billion.

title: Iran Says Iraqis Raided a Nuclear Plant
description: Iranian news outlets reported that Iraqi warplanes raided an unfinished Iranian nuclear power plant today, and that an Iranian nuclear official said the attack could lead to a release of radiation across international borders.

title: Deer Season: A Time for Counting Herds
description: LEAD: ''Once you pull the trigger, the party's over,'' Jim Alex said on a recent Sunday as the 130-pound buck shot by his hunting partner, John Walsh, was lifted off the scales at a deer check station here. ''It took seven guys three hours to drag it out of the woods.''

description: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. said today, before leaving for an official visit to Tokyo, that if Japan did not raise export prices to reflect the lower value of the dollar it could face new trade retaliation from the United States.

description: b-Net loss and includes $331 million writedowns for both the quarter and 9 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Trump Urged To Head Gala Of Democrats
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate magnate and a registered Republican, has been asked by Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, to be the host at the 25th annual Democratic Congressional dinner in Washington in March, Congressional officials said yesterday.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.1 million and $6.9 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a $19.7 million charge for dept redemption for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Troubled Bronx School's Fate Now Rests With Students
description: In what has become a fight to save Junior High School 123 in the Bronx from closing, parents led the opening charge. But if the battle is to be won, it will be up to their children to finish the task.

title: NEOAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes non-recurring gains from the disposition of businesses of $900,000 and $5.8 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also include a charge of $1 million for accretion. Latest and year-ago third quarters have no share earnings because of preferred dividend requirements. Latest periods reflect the acquisition of Fairfield Manufacturers Co. in March.

title: At the Nation's Table; Boston
description: THE Zagat Boston Restaurant Survey is almost ready for publication. Like its counterparts in New York, Los Angeles and elsewhere, the survey is based on responses from committed diners-out. More than 700 people in the Boston area offered opinions on some 325 restaurants.

title: Panel Denounces Cost of Antimissile Research
description: After a three-year study, a panel of analysts said yesterday that the program for a defense against missile attack should be vastly scaled back to a low-level research program, much as it was before President Reagan called for an all-out effort in 1983.

title: Weinberger Departs To the Cannon's Roar
description: Amid the roll of drums, the boom of cannon and with banners fluttering in a cool breeze, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger marched out of office today after nearly seven years as steward of the nation's largest military buildup in peacetime.

title: Joseph C. Brennan, 77, Retired Bank Official
description: Joseph Cantwell Brennan, a retired chairman and trustee of the Emigrant Savings Bank in New York and a prominent Roman Catholic layman, died Thursday after a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: For Hungarian, Yeltsin's Fall Is a Reminder of Things Past
description: A founding father of Hungary's first wave of economic innovation says the downfall of Boris N. Yeltsin in Moscow is a ''shocking'' reminder of the limits to possible change in the Soviet Union and the rest of Eastern Europe.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on Monday about ''Spangle,'' by Gary Jennings, misidentified his 1984 novel. It was ''The Journeyer.''

title: INTERNATIONAL AMERICAN HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 6 months' revenue and net income from the sale of investment land were $402,000 and $15,000, respectively, compared with revenue and net of $7,663,000 and $606,000, or 10 cents a share, for the year-ago period. The latest 6 months also includes after-tax expenses of $323,000 attributed to a debenture offering that was withdrawn and to acquisitions not completed. The year-ago 6 months includes comparable expenses of $81,000.

title: Letters; Overburdened Painters
description: To the Living Section:

title: CARDINAL'S VIEWS ASSAILED BY JEWS
description: A new strain in relations between Catholics and Jews has arisen in recent days because of published remarks by the Vatican's monitor of theological orthodoxy about the dialogue between the faiths.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Micheal Ray Richardson, the guard formerly with the Knicks and Nets, has signed a contract to play for the Albany Patroons of the Continental Basketball Association. He was banned from the National Basketball Association in 1986 for repeated drug use. . . . The Philadelphia Flyers have signed Ron Hextall, the goaltender, to a new multiyear contract. Terms were not disclosed.
