title: PRINCE AND PRINCESS VISIT BOMB SURVIVORS
description: The Prince and Prin-cess of Wales made an unexpected visit to Enniskillen today to comfort survivors of an I.R.A. bomb blast that killed 11 people and wounded 63 dur-ing a memorial to British war dead.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effected in August in the form of a dividend.

title: P.S.A.L. Forfeits Upheld
description: Susan Wagner High School, the only undefeated football team in the Public School Athletic League, will forfeit eight of its nine victories this season because it used an ineligible player, the league's director ruled yesterday.

title: 6 Victims From Connecticut Identified in Wisconsin Crash
description: The eight people killed when a light plane broke up and crashed were identified today as six officials of a Connecticut company and executives of companies in Wisconsin and Illinois, company spokesmen said.

title: Jo Jo White Makes a Return at 41 With a Helping Hand as His Goal
description: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Ortega Snowed In
description: Last week's snowstorm here may have killed an audacious notion of the Nicaraguan President, Daniel Ortega Saavedra, to visit the Vietnam War memorial on Veterans Day last week.

title: Bern Police Fight Squatters
description: Riot policemen firing tear gas, water hoses and rubber bullets stormed barricades of burning tires and furniture today to break up an illegal squatter camp in the center of the Swiss capital. Earlier, officers ringed the so-called Zaffaraya Free State with barbed wire after settlers ignored repeated orders to close it for breaching building regulations.

title: PIANO: CHERKASSKY
description: SHURA CHERKASSKY, the Russian-born pianist who's lived long enough to be called ''legendary'' in advertising copy, is known as one of the last of the Romantics, and also as a somewhat erratic performer, given to incandescence one night (or in one piece) and eccentricity in the next. His recital Monday night at Carnegie Hall showed us both sides, but made one wonder if to be Romantic and erratic aren't somehow the same thing.

title: Homesteading Projects' Potential for Housing Rehabilitation
description: To the Editor:

title: TJX COS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in June.

title: Bid to Dismiss Silver Suit Fails
description: A Federal judge yesterday rejected a motion to throw out a lawsuit brought in 1981 by a Peruvian commodities trading company against the Hunt brothers of Texas and leading brokerage firms. The ruling means that the suit will be heard in Federal court beginning Feb. 3, 1988.

title: M/A-COM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,235,000 for the quarter and $6,060,000 for the year. c-Net income and after a gain of $58,582,000 from the sale of discontinued operations for the quarter and a gain of $19,636,000 from discontinued operations for the year, and an extraordinary loss of $4.1 million for the both periods. The latest fourth quarter is after a pre-tax charge of $25 million related to a special purpose semiconductor facility, a pre-tax provision of $27 million for adverse developments on several fixed price defense contracts, and a $9 million pre-tax provision for severance pay and other employee costs. The prior year results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Personal Health
description: The Personal Health column, by Jane E. Brody, will now appear on the new Health page:

title:
At the Nation's Table;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: WHEN asked why they keep coming back, Alix Kenagy's customers mention the food, attentive service and amusing decor in her restaurants. But mostly they talk about Miss Kenagy, about her sixth sense for fashion trends and publicity, and lately, about the gas station she is renovating into a flamingo-pink residence and the takeout food business she opened last month.

title: PRICE COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Concert: Marlboro Group
description: THE Music From Marlboro concert at Alice Tully Hall Monday evening began oddly, with a seventh chord so poised and well blended that it took an instant to realize it should have been a C major triad instead. The foreign B flat was contributed, I think, by Philipp Naegele, the fine violist who proceeded, once the group had begun afresh, to give a handsome account of his melodies in Boccherini's Quintet (Op. 60, No. 5).

title: MCGRATH RENTCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Breeders' Cup Notebook; Eclipse Award at Stake for Lukas and Whittingham
description: Two trainers, D. Wayne Lukas and Charlie Whittingham, have dominated the nation's Grade I races all year long and may continue in the seven Breeders' Cup races at Hollywood Park Saturday.

title: Nebraska Suffers Scouting Setback
description: A seemingly insignificant agreement between members of the football coaching staffs at Nebraska and Oklahoma has apparently prevented the Cornhusker coaches from seeing film of Charles Thompson, the new Sooner quarterback, in his first game as a starter last week.

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances; Rebuilding Planes to Cut Airport Noise
description: A DRIVE by the Federal Aviation Administration to impose more stringent noise abatement rules at airports is causing the airlines concern about the future usefulness of 70 percent of the nation's air fleet.

title: INSIDE
description: New on Wednesdays: The Education Page The decline of the college interview. And a new column, Lessons, looks at old-fashioned teaching in a modern-day classroom. Page B6. Also today: Eating Well, a column about food safety, health and nutri tion. The Living Section, page C10. Insider Case's Broad Reach The Supreme Court decision in the Winans case is likely to discourage leaks of an array of corporate information, even in cases unrelated to insider trading, scholars said. Page D1. Dollar Lifts Industry At long last, the falling dollar is helping American companies regain their competitiveness. Page D1. Progess on Deficit Seen Budget negotiators, facing a Friday deadline, said they were near agreement on a new deficit plan. Page A16. Inquiry Into L.I. Deaths Investigators are searching hospital records that involve a nurse accused of giving fatal injections. Page B1.

title: Life in the 30's
description: SOME years ago my editors decided that I should write a story about the atmosphere on Wall Street. This was fine except that all I knew for sure about Wall Street was how to get there on the subway. So I sought out a writer who made it his business to know everything on the subject and asked him if he could spend an hour educating me.

title: Greek Police Break Up An Anti-U.S. Protest
description: The police fired tear gas and water cannon to disperse leftist demonstrators after an annual march on the United States Embassy here tonight to protest purported collusion between Washington and the colonels who ruled Greece from 1967 to 1974.

title: Town's Outdoor Holiday Feast Draws 150 From Far and Near
description: NESTLED in the northeast corner of Connecticut, about five miles from the Massachusetts border, Woodstock is so remote and so quiet that when the writer Theodore H. White flew over it in 1967, he said it was the only place between Washington and Boston where there were no lights at night.

title: Nussbaum Is Taken To Another Hospital
description: Hedda Nussbaum, who is accused of murder in the death of 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg, was transferred yesterday to the Presbyterian Hospital.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The GTE Corporation is offering $200 million of 10.3 percent debentures, due in 2017, at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: No Stock Dealings For Rooney, Pace
description: Rooney, Pace Inc. has agreed to leave the securities industry after the Securities and Exchange Commission found numerous violations in three of its public stock offerings. The concern was once a leading underwriter of initial public offerings. The S.E.C. also suspended Randolph Pace, chairman of the firm, from the securities business for nine months.

title: Industrial Capacity Is Up to 81.3%
description: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 81.3 percent of capacity in October, the highest operating rate in more than three years, the Government reported today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HEY JACK! By Barry Hannah. 133 pages.

title: The Dance: Showcase Of 11 Works
description: THE ''Choreographer's Showcase'' that Evolving Arts Inc. presented Sunday night at Dance Space Inc. (622 Broadway, between Bleecker and Houston Streets) contained 11 dances by 12 choreographers. The apparent discrepancy between the number of creators and the number of works created is explained by the fact that one of those dances had two choreographers. Even so, 11 dances is a lot.

title: LIVINGWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: TV Reviews; 'BUSTER KEATON: HARD ACT TO FOLLOW'
description: KEVIN BROWNLOW and David Gill have probably done more than anybody else in the world for the restoration and preservation of silent movies. As a film historian, Mr. Brownlow has written ''The Parade's Gone By . . .'' and ''The War, the West and the Wilderness.'' Together, Mr. Brownlow and Mr. Gill created and produced for Britain's Thames Television the 13-episode series ''Hollywood'' and the three-part ''Unknown Chaplin.'' They are following those award-winning efforts with the three-part ''Buster Keaton: A Hard Act to Follow.'' The first two hours can be seen tonight, beginning at 9, on Channels 13, 49 and 50. The final hour will be shown next Wednesday at 9. The entire production is extraordinary.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I was an apprentice chef in France many years ago, one of the first dishes I learned to create was sauteed chicken with tarragon. When I came to America to work at the restaurant of the French pavillion at the World's Fair in New York more than 45 years ago, the same dish was considered to be one of the most sophisticated on any menu.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,979,000 for the quarter and $5,410,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $562,000 for the quarter and $1,234,000 for the 9 months. d-Net income The latest third-quarter loss from discontinued operations includes a one-time charge of $4,518,000 for the termination of the company's Holland-based subsidiary. title: About Real Estate; At Last, a 5th Ave. Hotel Gets Ready for Reopening
description: After years of on-again, off-again plans and renovations that have cost almost $200 million, yet another group of investors has announced the reopening of the Gotham Hotel - this time under the name Hotel Maxim's de Paris.

title: G.M. Layoffs
description: General Motors of Canada Ltd. said it would indefinitely lay off 200 employees at its Windsor transmission plant in January because of declining car sales. The unit also said there would be weeklong layoffs of 3,000 transmission plant workers in December and January.

title: Eating Well
description: ADULTS who as children balked at downing their weekly ration of fish oil can't get enough of the stuff today: not cod-liver oil, mind you, but its modern-day successor - concentrates high in substances called omega-3 fatty acids.

title: Breakfast of Wimps
description: Do Americans really eat breakfast cereal? Grown-up, adult, mature, yuppie-age Americans, eating breakfast cereal? And even old, worn-out, graybeard Americans born too late to be investment bankers, eating breakfast cereal?

title: New York's New Culture Chief
description: Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, the first to admit she was ''brazen'' in seeking the job as New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, has now spent seven weeks in office, and she does not seem a bit daunted by the task. ''I am a political animal,'' she says, adding that she feels comfortable with the political system and intends to use it to help the arts, starting from the grass roots on up. She will be sworn in at City Hall next Monday as head of the embattled Department of Cultural Affairs.

title: Interest Rates Turn Mixed
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday, with short-term rates falling and long-term bond yields rising slightly.

title: 'HOOVER VS. THE KENNEDYS,' MINI-SERIES ON CHANNEL 11
description: IT'S not the bad taste; it's the frivolity. ''Hoover vs. the Kennedys: The Second Civil War'' seems to be a face-off between two yuppies and old Scrooge. President John F. Kennedy dallies, while Robert F. Kennedy pouts and J. Edgar Hoover has snits. The two-part, four-hour mini-series, which begins on Channel 11 at 9 o'clock tonight, is a kind of gumshoe's view of the White House.

title: From Just One Man, A Dynasty of Cellarers
description: THE last thing Kevin Zraly had in mind in the old days was creating a dynasty. But there they all were, kissing, hugging, ribbing their old mentor (well, he's 36), acting like any other alumni group whose members had not seen one another for a few years.

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,890,000.

title: Market Place; Street Weighs N.A.S.D. Plan
description: AFTER an unsettled stock market closed on Oct. 22, managers of some of the top over-the-counter stock trading desks met at a private room above one of Wall Street's best-known watering holes, Harry's Bar, to air their grievances about widely perceived problems in their trading system.

title: Image and Reality Of Contras' Character
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Tests for Larouche
description: Pierre Larouche, who has been out of the Ranger lineup since Oct. 28 with a lower back strain that has been traced to a damaged disk, will undergo further tests today. The tests will be done by Dr. Gerald Smallberg, the neurologist who last week ordered the CAT scan that confirmed suspicions of nerve damage. The injury to Larouche, who turned 32 Monday, is more serious than the originally diagnosed muscle strain and could mean a lengthy rehabilitation. The tests today are to create a treatment plan by determining the amount of pressure being exerted on the nerves and the extent of the damage to the disk. Conservative rehabilitation for injuries of this type include bed rest, traction and a mild exercise program. Surgery, including spinal fusion, is the radical treatment, but Dave Smith, the team trainer, said he did not anticipate that. The Rangers did have some good news - both Ron Greschner and Don Maloney will make the road trip to Minnesota and Winnipeg for games tomorrow night and Friday night. Tomas Sandstrom, who still has trouble gripping his hockey stick because of a broken finger, should return by next Wednesday, when the Rangers play Toronto.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Baxter Travenol Laboratories, Deerfield, Ill., a developer of health care products, systems and services, named as a director Martha R. Ingram, director of public affairs and director at Ingram Industries.

title: Washington Talk: National Women's Political Caucus; Carrying Word of a Women's Agenda

title: 'FEARSOME AND INTIMIDATING' TEXTS
description: Following are excerpts from a report called ''American History Textbooks: An Assessment of Quality,'' released recently by the Educational Excellence Network. The report, based on reviews of 11 5th-, 8th- and 11th-grade texts by a panel of 12 historians, authors, editors and journalists, was written by Gilbert T. Sewall, a researcher at Teachers College of Columbia University and co-director of the network.

title: The Last Place to Cut the Budget
description: White House and Congressional negotiators are still struggling to reduce the budget deficit in fiscal 1989 and 1990 by Friday, when the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law requires automatic cuts. They search for the courage to touch politically untouchable programs like Social Security.

title: EDUCATION: INCREASINGLY, COLLEGE INTERVIEW IS OUT
description: Like the white gloves, small talk and parental presence that once characterized it, the campus interview has become irrelevant to most students' chances of finding a place in next year's college freshman class.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We cannot simply snap our fingers and hope that the gar-bage will disappear from our beaches or dead patches of sea will be brought back to life.'' -Governor Kean of New Jersey. [ A1:2 ]

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Parting Shot
description: Passengers on the New York-Washington shuttle were delayed 30 to 60 minutes yesterday morning by what was announced as ''military traffic.'' The traffic turned out to be Air Force fighter planes flying over the Pentagon as part of the ceremonies saluting Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger on his last day in office.

description: An evening of poetry and music, with Galway Kinnell and the Canterbury Trio, is planned at 8 P.M. on Dec. 14 at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

description: George Bell, the moody but gifted Toronto Blue Jays outfielder who regularly spurned reporters during his finest season in the major leagues, was voted the American League's most valuable player yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America in a close decision over Alan Trammell of Detroit.

At the Nation's Table;
Seattle
description: LEAD: THERE is a drought in the Pacific Northwest and thus a dearth of wild mushrooms in the marketplace.

description: ''SHE looks like she's lost weight,'' said the woman in the blue jacket, ''and a little tired.''

title: Jet in Emergency Landing
description: A Northwest Airlines Boeing 727 jetliner made an emergency landing at Bismark Municipal Airport today after the pilot radioed that the plane's rear stairway might have lowered in flight, an airport official said. None of the 44 passengers and 6 crew members were hurt, said John Van Middlesworth, the airport manager. The plane, Flight 223, was flying from Billings, Mont., to Minneapolis-St. Paul.

title: Gillis Purcell; Canadian Journalist, 82
description: Gillis Purcell, a Canadian journalist who spent 41 years with The Canadian Press, 24 of them as general manager, died Monday in Toronto. He was 82 years old and had a stroke last summer.

title: Bundesbank's Optimistic Chief
description: When economic crises arise, Karl Otto Pohl can usually be found between the nearly irresistable Washington and the almost immovable Bonn - and looking for all the world as if he enjoys it.

title: The Tentacles of Soviet Reform
description: LEAD: The removal of Boris Yeltsin as Moscow party leader has again raised questions about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's strength and the future of reform in the Soviet Union. The West's understanding of this development is complicated by an oversimplified view of reform politics in the Soviet Union and of the balance of social forces there.

description: To the Editor:

title: More German Growth Urged
description: A majority of the members of the Economic Policy Committee of the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development today called on West Germany to do more to stimulate its economy.

description: American Express began a $4 million advertising campaign this week to introduce a new product, the American Express Gift Cheque, with advertising by Ogilvy & Mather.

title: Soviet Confirms That Yeltsin Is Ill and in Hospital
description: The Government confirmed today that Boris N. Yeltsin, the high-ranking official who was purged from office last week, had been hospitalized but said his health was not a cause for concern.

title: Boeing Pension Fund Shifting Out of Stocks
description: The Boeing Company is selling a good deal of the stock held by its multibillion-dollar pension fund, and market sources say Rockwell International is doing the same. The moves explain some of the selling pressure on the stock market in recent days.

title: Jim Brewer, Ex-Dodger Reliever
description: Jim Brewer, a former star relief pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers, died of injuries suffered in an automobile accident here today, the National League club said.

title: Avoiding Pitfalls Of the Holiday Feast
description: LEAD: THE traditional Thanksgiving meal can be a nutritional mine field, full of fat, salt and calories cleverly disguised beneath marshmallow glaze, giblet gravy and pools of cream.

title: Letters; The Best Bread
description: To The Living Section:

title: Greeks Show Basketball Skill
description: Panos Fassoulas, Fanis Christodoulou, and Agamemnon Ioannou are not exactly household names - at least not in American households. They are, however, heroes in Greece, where they form the nucleus of the national basketball team. The aggressive and well-coached team, which beat the Soviet Union to win the European Cup this year, is in the midst of a one-week, six-game exhibition tour against American college teams.

title: Ireene Wicker Hammer Dies, 86; Storyteller to Millions of Children
description: Ireene Wicker Hammer, who as ''The Singing Lady'' told fairy tales over radio and television to millions of American children, died yesterday in a nursing home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 86 years old.

title: Climbers Plan to Place Devices Atop Everest
description: Mountain climbers, including sons of the first two men to reach the summit of Mount Everest, plan to scale the Himalayan peak next spring in the first attempt to plant equipment there for making precise measurements of its elevation, expedition organizers announced last week.

title: No Warrants Needed To Give Urine Tests
description: An appeals court ruled yesterday that police officers who believe suspects are under the influence of drugs can demand urine samples from the suspects without search warrants.

title: U.S. TV BROADCASTS BANNED BBC DATA
description: Portions of a television documentary barred in Britain on security grounds have been shown to American audiences on two occasions in recent days.

description: The USLife Corporation, a life insurance holding company, said yesterday that it had named James F. Betts president and chief operating officer, as well as a member of its board.

title: Pilots in Crash Had Little DC-9 Time
description: The pilots of the Continental Airlines DC-9 jet that crashed in a snowstorm Sunday in Denver had relatively little experience flying that type of plane, particularly in snow, according to data given investigators yesterday.

title: Koch Backs Unit to Fight Corruption
description: Mayor Koch urged yesterday that broad prosecutorial powers be granted to a proposed state agency that would oversee the construction industry in New York City.

title: Gov. O'Neill Better; Will Undergo Tests
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, described as feeling much better after being hospitalized Sunday with a temperature of 103 degrees, will undergo more tests today and tomorrow to try to find the cause of the fever, hospital officials said yesterday.

title: Sports People; Patriots to Be Sold
description: The attorney for two Philadelphia businessmen who have an option to buy the New England Patriots for $63 million said yesterday that his clients, Fran Murray and John Charlton, will exercise it ''within two weeks.'' Robert Popeo, the attorney, said he expected the league to approve the purchase, after which Murray and Charlton will be joined as owners by Joe O'Donnell, who runs a Boston-based concessions business, and perhaps by some other New England businessmen ''to solidify the New England control of the Pa-triots.''

title: House Approves Plan To Elevate V.A. Status
description: The House overwhelmingly approved legislation today that would turn the Veterans Administration into a Federal department with Cabinet-level status.

description: System Energy Resources, a financing subsidiary of the System Energy Corporation, a utility holding company, is offering a 14 percent yield on a new issue of seven-year bonds, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

Directly From Italy to Broadway
description: IF the expense makes you think twice about using an excellent extra-virgin olive oil with abandon, look for the Dal Raccolto brand. The Fairway market at 2127 Broadway (74th Street) has begun importing olive oil and other Dal Raccolto items directly from Italy.

title: E.P.A. SEEKS DELAY IN USING SANCTIONS OF POLLUTION LAW
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed delaying economic sanctions against areas that will not meet a statutory Dec. 31 deadline for reducing smog and carbon monoxide levels. It would be the third major delay since 1977.

MAXCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: The Genetic Factor in Coronary Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruce's Ouster Is Questioned
description: The president of Ohio State University declined yesterday to be specific about his reasons for dismissing Earle Bruce as the school's football coach, saying only that the decision was a ''personnel issue'' that had nothing to do with the team's record.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LEAD: Dixie Days

title: Rates Up a Bit At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday at Citicorp's regular weekly commercial paper auctions.

title: Ivy League Eases Standards To Bolster Columbia Football
description: Columbia University, whose varsity football team has not had a winning season since 1971, has been allowed for the last two years to admit players who do not meet the Ivy League's minimum academic requirements, school and league officials said last night.

title: A Home-Style Thanksgiving That Avoids All the Fuss
description: A THANKSGIVING to go is ideal for those who are short of time or have no inclination to prepare a dinner from scratch. Traditional menus as well as vegetarian, French, Italian, delicatessen and low-calorie are available. You can choose complete dinners or just the fixings to accompany the turkey.

title: Guidelines for Healthful Meals
description: BY modifying eating habits during the holidays and beyond, you can savor many Thanksgivings to come. The following guidelines were suggested by Susan Kinzler, assistant director of patient services in the department of food and nutrition services, Sentara-Norfolk General Hospital in Norfolk, Va., and other hospital dietitians. 1. Exercise portion control. Eat half a slice, not half a pie, and let a little gravy go a long way. Remove as much fat from the gravy as possible. 2. To baste a turkey, use plain broth, apple juice or sherry, not butter or oil. 3. Use herbs freely, but stay the hand that shakes the salt. Avoid canned foods, which tend to be salty. 4. Serve raw vegetables instead of peanuts before a meal, to curb appetites in a nutritional way. 5. Do not add sugar, salt, marshmallows or butter to foods to make a glaze. Use light salad dressings, with a yogurt base, for example. 6. Serve fresh fruit for dessert. If you make cranberry relish from scratch using fresh berries and oranges, you can control the sugar content. 7. Stay away from bacon and sausage, which have a way of sneaking into holiday meals. 8. Make stuffings from whole-grain breads, and flavor them with fruits, fruit juices, herbs and vegetables. Moisten with stock, wine or other nonfat liquid.

title: NUCLEAR METALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BEAR STEARNS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $3.3 million for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Spear, Leeds Seeks More of Allegheny
description: Spear, Leeds & Kellogg said it had asked the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department for permission to increase its stake in Allegheny International Inc. to more than 15 percent, from about 5.2 percent.

title: Court of Appeals Backs Police Officers' Ouster
description: New York State's highest court ruled today that the word of an admitted ''rogue cop'' was sufficient to prove that two other police officers should be dismissed from the New York City force for illegal behavior.

title: Yields 5.20%-7.75% On Missouri Bonds
description: A $120 million issue of Missouri general obligation bonds was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Capital Markets Corporation, with yields ranging from 5.20 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 6.60 percent in 1997, 7.55 percent in 2007 and 7.75 percent in 2010 through 2012.

title: EDUCATION: COLLEGES OPEN NEW MINORITY DRIVES
description: Concerned over new evidence of a persistent and sharp decline in black and Hispanic high school graduates' going on to college, universities around the country have turned to junior high schools in their efforts to recruit minority students.

title: Helen Hallet Kennedy; Civic Leader, 80
description: Helen Hallet Kennedy, a civic leader in Bedford, N.Y., died Sunday at her daughter's home in Bedford after a brief illness. She was 80 years old.

title: A Golf Ball That Avoids the Woods?
description: Most golfers, from weekend duffers to low-handicap regulars, play with balls covered with a substance called Surlyn. Surlyn is durable and can be whacked a long way, but it doesn't provide the exquisite control that the touring professionals crave.

title: Yugoslav Devaluation
description: Yugoslavia devalued the dinar by almost 25 percent today in an effort to expand exports. The currency action followed recent price rises of 30 to 70 percent on fuel, food, transport and some raw materials, with a freeze at the new levels. Prime Minister Branko Mikulic's Government also imposed limited wage controls.

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $32,000 for the quarter and $11,439,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $74,000 for the quarter and $394,000 for the 9 months.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Organotins: Read This
description: How do you add spice to the discussion of anadromous fish and the debate over organotins and antifoulants?

title: Kasparov Puzzle: Why So Passive?
description: What meaning did the 14th game of the world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, have for the titleholder, 24-year-old Gary Kasparov? Why, with the slight advantage of the white pieces, should he not have made some attempt to avoid a toothless draw on Monday?

title: Letters; Menu Alternatives
description: To The Living Section:

title: Anita Brielke Stafford; Executive, 61
description: Anita Brielke Stafford, senior vice president of Hermes of Paris Inc., the North American subsidiary of the Paris-based fashion boutique, was killed Friday in a car accident near Newtown, Conn. She was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Bethlehem, Conn.

title: For Emigrants to Soviet, Best and Worst of Times
description: If expatriation is mainly a state of mind, then Dr. Arnold Lockshin - until a year ago a medical researcher from Houston - is alive and well and sane, he emphasizes, as he settles his family into their new life in the Soviet Union.

title: Charleston, W.Va., Mayor Admits Cocaine Guilt
description: Mayor James E. (Mike) Roark, on the morning his drug trial was to begin, pleaded guilty today to six misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and agreed to resign.

title: LOW DOLLAR LIFTS U.S. SALES
description: At long last, the falling dollar is helping American companies to regain their international competitiveness.

title: CONGRESS REACHES ARMS COMPROMISE WITH WHITE HOUSE
description: Congressional leaders announced today that they had reached a compromise with the White House on arms-control issues that removes a major obstacle to the passage of a new military spending bill.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the New Jersey Guide column of the New Jersey Weekly on Sunday about a ''Teach-In on Homelessness'' sponsored by the Student Volunteers Council in Princeton misstated the dates. The two-day program starts today, not tomorrow.

title: Earnings Rise at 3 Retailers
description: Three leading retailing chains yesterday reported improved earnings for the third quarter.

title: Advertising; Agencies Greet New Business
description: THREE good-sized advertisers announced new agency alliances yesterday. The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company is returning to Young & Rubicam, the agency that served it from 1945 to 1975. DDB Needham, Chicago, is getting the Discover credit card from Sears, Roebuck & Company. And Grey Advertising and its subsidiary, Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, are getting big pieces of work from Panasonic.

title: Cuomo Says Kirk Told Him His 'No' Was Plain Enough
description: Governor Cuomo, who has been urged by some Democratic figures to end speculation about his Presidential intentions by ruling out the possibility of a draft, said today that he had been assured by the head of the national Democratic Party that such a declaration was unnecessary.

title: AL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest period results include gains of $200,000 in the third quarter and $375,000 in the 9-month related to collections of previously reserved Middle East receivables. Year-ago third quarter includes a $600,000 tax benefit related to a research and development grant from the Danish government.

title: Budget Negotiators Report They're Close To Accord Cutting Deficit by $30 Billion
description: Budget negotiators, facing a Friday deadline, said tonight that they were very close to agreement on a plan that would reduce the Federal deficit by about $30 billion in the current fiscal year.

title: U.S. Arrests 14 as Members of Cocaine Ring
description: A ring that sold 220 pounds a week of cocaine was broken up today with the arrests of 14 people in New York and New Jersey, the authorities said.

title: Letter: On Foreign Aid; Trickle-Up Is No Drop in the Bucket
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Confidant Urged Pardons in Iran Case
description: William P. Clark, the former national security adviser, said today that he wrote President Reagan at the end of the Iran-contra hearings in August asking him to grant pardons to Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

title: At the Nation's Table; Chicago
description: MANY Chicagoans who appreciate fine food served in relaxing settings are starting to believe that they are victims of a conspiracy engineered in New York, Los Angeles and other culinary centers.

title: Bear Stearns Manages To Post a Tiny Profit
description: Despite a net loss of $8.6 million in October, the Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that it eked out a $413,000 profit for its latest quarter, ended Oct. 30, a 99.2 percent decline from the year earlier.

title: A Magazine On Addictions
description: By his own admission James V. Trotta of the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx was a compulsive gambler until 10 years ago. He has also spent some 24 of his 44 years in the magazine business, most of it on the circulation and distribution side.

title: Quake Hurts 3 in Nicaragua; Thousands Flee Their Homes
description: A strong earthquake rocked Nicaragua, injuring at least three people and driving thousands from their homes, officials said today.

title: NEXT WEEK
description: If you have neither the time nor the willpower to prepare ahead for Thanksgiving, there is no need to despair. Next week The Living Section will offer a last-minute strategy. Thanksgiving meal-in-a-day. For best results, however, or-der a turkey now (10 to 12 pounds to serve 8) and have 12 ounces of fresh cranberries on hand.

title: Kenya Charges a Plot by the Klan
description: Seven United States missionaries have been deported from Kenya amid local news reports that they were involved in a plot supported by the Ku Klux Klan to overthrow the Government of President Daniel arap Moi.

title: Bridge: Longtime League Counsel Poses a Question of Law
description: Lawyers are accustomed to thinking about new legal angles. Consider for example the diagramed deal which occurred in a social game.

title: Soviet Gets Glimpses of U.S. on Canvas
description: A 70-year sampling of American painting was unveiled for the Soviet public here Monday with a splash of Luminism, a blush of Tonalism and a dash of glasnost.

title: O-Day Minus 300
description: The name of the game here is ''polympics,'' where the struggle for South Korean political power merges with the chance to use the 1988 summer Olympics to gain international prestige.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 18, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Gdansk Journal; Mood Over Dockyards Is New Mirror for Poland
description: Down along Dock Street, Poland's powder keg, there is an air of uncertainty.

title: MAI BASIC FOUR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $989,000. c-Net loss d-After a charge of $7,830,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and year.

title: Harte-Hanks Sets Sale of Businesses
description: Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. said it would sell six direct marketing units, along with a shopper publication in Florida. Charles H. Everill, senior vice president of Harte-Hanks and chief executive of the Direct Marketing Sector, and Cal Ingram, a consultant to Harte-Hanks, plan to buy the direct marketing operations. Terms were not disclosed.

title: N.A.S.D. Fills Top Board Job
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday that it had named Stephen L. Hammerman, a Merrill Lynch executive, to be chairman of its 31-member board of governors for 1988.

title: Park Is Searched After Report About a Young Girl
description: More than 50 police officers, including a scuba team and helicopter pilots, fanned out across a park on the Brooklyn-Queens border yesterday after three young children said they had seen a young girl carried into the park by a man who left her there.

title: RUSSIAN PREDICTS ARMS ACCORD SOON
description: The chief Soviet arms-control negotiator predicted today that a treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles would be completed within six days. But important verification issues reportedly remained unresolved after two days of high-level talks here.

title: Washington Talk: Justice Department; Conservative Ranks No Longer in Step on Meese
description: The smile on the face of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d had never looked so genuine.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of an obituary in some editions yesterday about a retired chairman and trustee of the Emigrant Savings Bank in New York misidentified him. He was Joseph C. Brennan.

title: Tokyo Market Memberships
description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange has received applications from 40 securities companies, including 20 foreign firms, for the 22 new exchange memberships to be created by next May, the president of the exchange said today.

title: Trivializing the Iran-Contra Affair
description: Eight Republican members of the Iran-contra committees say of President Reagan's role in the affair that he made ''mistakes in judgment, and nothing more.'' They appear, in a minority report, to be more vexed at their committee colleagues for reaching harsher conclusions than at Mr. Reagan, Lieutenant Colonel North and others for bringing the nation low.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Withdraws Its Bid
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation yesterday withdrew its offer for Information Resources Inc., a market research company, after the Federal Trade Commission said it opposed a merger.

title: Toyota's Imports
description: The Commerce Department said it had recommended that the Toyota Motor Company be granted a free trade zone in Louisville, Ky., enabling the Japanese concern to import parts for its Georgetown plant without paying a duty.

title: Sanitizing a Novel for the Screen
description: In the novel ''Less Than Zero,'' passionless Los Angeles rich kids, spaced out on drugs and affluence, drift from Ferraris to glitzy clubs, from cocaine to bisexuality. In the movie made from Bret Easton Ellis's book, most of the sex is missing, and the earnest message is a warning that drugs can kill.

title: 2 White Racists Convicted in Killing of Radio Host
description: A jury in Federal District Court here today found two white supremacists guilty and acquitted two others in the 1984 assassination of the host of a Denver radio talk show.

title: Mehl Reactivated by Jets
description: Lance Mehl, the linebacker who has been out for a year after undergoing reconstructive knee surgery, was reactivated by the Jets today. In another move, Jerry Holmes, the cornerback, was placed on injured reserve with a cracked rib. Holmes was hurt last Sunday in the team's 16-9 victory over Kansas City.

title: Ex-Head of Lotus Forms a Company
description: A year after he left his post as chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation, where he helped to revolutionize the software industry, Mitchell D. Kapor says he is still nagged by the unnecessary complexity of current computers.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Additive-Free Turkeys

title: TOTAL RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: To Indianians, if It's Not Hearty, It's Not Food
description: HOME to 15,000 people and Wabash College, this town sits near the center of the state and at the center of Indiana's culinary heritage.

title: Sports People; Lineman Has Surgery
description: Ted Gregory, the Syracuse University nose guard who early in the season was considered a candidate for the Outland and Lombardi Trophies for outstanding linemen, has undergone arthroscopic surgery to remove torn outer cartilage from his left knee. Dr. Bruce Baker, the Syracuse team physician who performed the surgery on Monday, said he ''couldn't make a categorical statement'' about Gregory's availability if the Orangemen play in the Sugar Bowl at New Orleans on Jan. 1, but said there was a reasonably chance that he would be able to play.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Backs Schools in Drug Tests Without Suspicion
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the public schools in the nation's capital may legally test certain employees for evidence of illicit drug use even if the school authorities had no reason to suspect the particular employees.

title: China-Australia Project
description: Australia and China signed a joint-venture agreement today to mine iron ore in Western Australia. The project at Mount Channar, worth $250 million (Australian), or about $170 million (United States), is China's biggest overseas investment, Prime Minister Bob Hawke said after the signing ceremony here. The venture between Channar Mining and the China Metallurgical Import and Export Corporation is designed to produce high-grade iron ore for export by 1990.

title: PANAMA FOES GIRD FOR LONG STRUGGLE
description: After five months of street demonstrations and general strikes, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's military regime and its civilian political opposition appear to be hardening their positions and preparing for what both sides expect to be a long and bitter struggle.

title: FILM: HOLOCAUST'S BIRTH, 'WANNSEE CONFERENCE'
description: HISTORIANS of the Holocaust appear to fall into one of two schools of thought these days. The more traditional ''intentionalists'' see a direct connection between Hitler's ideology, expressed in his anti-Semitic speeches of the 1920's as well as in ''Mein Kampf,'' and the eventual implementation of the ''final solution'' during World War II.

title: Dollar Down Sharply Amid Budget Doubts
description: The dollar fell sharply yesterday in selling that began on Asian and European foreign-exchange markets and carried over into New York. Business was relatively quiet in all markets, currency dealers said, but sales of dollars were persistent enough to erase the gains made by the dollar on Monday.

title: A Cult Champagne in Europe Comes to America at $100
description: A PRESTIGE Champagne that sells for $100 a bottle is arriving at carriage-trade stores across the nation. It is the 1979 A. Salon Le Mesnil blanc de blancs, a white wine from white grapes. Its finesse rivals its price.

title: Terrence Des Pres, 47, A Writer and Professor
description: Terrence Des Pres, a writer and college professor, died at his home in Hamilton, N.Y., on Monday. He was 47 years old. The cause of death is undetermined, pending completion of an autopsy, but Neal Rose, the Madison County District Attorney and Coroner, said the death appeared to have been accidental.

title: Film Retrospective At French Institute
description: The French Institute-Alliance Francaise is presenting the second New York French-American Film Workshop, through Saturday at the institute, 22 East 60th Street. Nine films by Samuel Fuller, an American director considered by many French film makers and critics as a seminal cinematic influence, will be shown, and he will be present at a discussion tomorrow at 6 P.M.

title: A.T.&T. Proposes 3.6% Rate Cut For Long Distance, to Start Jan. 1
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today proposed a 3.6 percent reduction in long-distance rates. It said the plan was contingent on the Government's reducing the access charges it must pay to local telephone companies by that amount.

title: Dirk Bell Kuzmier; Lawyer, 61
description: Dirk Bell Kuzmier, a New York trial lawyer, died Saturday in the crash of a private plane near Dorset, Vt. Mr. Kuzmier was the pilot; his passenger, Duffi Tomkeil of the Bronx, also was killed, the police said.

title: Abused Boy's Mother Said to Want Custody
description: The biological mother of Mitchell Steinberg, the 16-month-old boy found in the same Greenwich Village apartment where the police say Lisa Steinberg was beaten to death, is expected to seek custody of the boy today, according to a lawyer in the case.

title: Japan Cuts Overseas Investment
description: The flow of money from Japan, a stream that has helped to finance the United States budget deficit and to influence stock prices on Wall Street, is slowing dramatically as investors here wait to see what steps the United States will take to cut its budget and trade deficits.

title: UNITED BANCORP ALASKA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Music: Chamber Works By the Da Capo Players
description: THE music of George Crumb is always threatening to break out of the concert hall and into the theater. The orchestra is asked to take part in mysterious processionals in ''Echoes of Time and the River.'' In ''Ancient Voices of Children,'' the boy soprano is offstage until the last page of the score, when he joins the mezzo-soprano for a poignant vocalise. For ''Vox Balaenae'' (''Voice of the Whale''), the musicians wear masks and perform under blue stage lighting. ''Lux Aeterna,'' for five black-masked and robed musicians and a masked dancer, is played in red lighting and calls for a soprano to extinguish a candle at the end of the performance.

title: Kean Proposes A Cleanup Plan For Jersey Shore
description: Governor Kean proposed today a 14-point, $200 million program to clean up the ocean off the Jersey Shore, but said local communities and Congress must also act if the effort is to succeed.

title: Runaway Train Chief Left to Get Candy Bar
description: Six unmanned locomotives that went out of control for 30 miles until they were deliberately crashed into a row of boxcars slipped away from their engineer when he left to buy a candy bar, a police officer said today.

title: A New IUD on the Way as Suits Linger
description: Although intrauterine devices became one of the most widely used types of birth control during the 1970's, their inventors were unclear about how such devices interacted with the body.

title: Paul Derringer; Former Reds Pitcher, 81
description: Paul Derringer, who won 161 games during 10 years with the Cincinnati Reds, died today in Sarasota, Fla., the team announced. He was 81 years old.

title: COMFORTS OF A SOUTHERN THANKSGIVING
description: IT was a case of holiday serendipity, and it started over a couple of glasses of chilled Chardonnay shared with Lee Bailey, the cookbook author, host and entrepreneur of good things for table and kitchen.

title: Red Wings Win, 1-0
description: Glen Hanlon made 32 saves for his eighth career shutout, and Steve Yzerman scored 33 seconds into the game tonight as the Detroit Red Wings defeated the Washington Capitals, 1-0.

title: Convicted Drug Dealer, Freed in Error in '78, Held in Queens
description: A convicted narcotics dealer who was mistakenly freed in 1978 from the state prison in Ossining, N.Y., was arrested yesterday in Flushing, Queens, Federal law-enforcement officials said.

title: Bird Injured in Loss
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers, exploiting the absence of the injured Larry Bird, outscored the visiting Celtics, 26-15, in the third quarter last night to send Boston to its first loss of the season.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $14,341,000 from the extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months. All share earnings and shares outstanding reflect the 2-for-1 stock split April 13.

title: Slaying Inquiry Builds Against L.I. Nurse
description: Investigators focused their attention today on building what could become a multiple-murder case against Richard Angelo, the registered nurse accused of injecting fatal amounts of a muscle-paralyzing drug into one of his patients at Good Samaritan Hospital here.

title: Jones Intercable To Buy 4 Systems
description: Jones Intercable Inc. said it had agreed to acquire four cable television systems with 97,000 subscribers for $170 million, or about $1,752 per subscriber.

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $200,000 and $12,108,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: KEY RATES
St. Louis Fete Marks Reopening of Museum Wing
description: Like a reunion of old friends, Missourians were reunited with their treasured artworks Monday night as the St. Louis Art Museum reopened its west wing after years of renovation and unveiled works that had not been seen in years.

title: Wimbledon Profit At $12.5 Million
description: This year's Wimbledon championships, the only Grand Slam tennis event played on grass, made a profit of more than $12.5 million. The All England Club announced today that the profit was $12,592,782, which will go to the British Lawn Tennis Association for the benefit of the game in Britain. The figure is up about 15 percent over last year's profit of $10,913,492.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
COACHMEN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: ASHTON-TATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are restated to reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: To Cut the Deficit, Keep '87 Tax Rates
description: If President Reagan is serious about everything being on the table, there are $50 billion in deficit reductions that the budget negotiators have left untouched and, indeed, undiscussed. This $50 billion is not money that would be extracted from taxpayers but money that will be lost unless something is done.

title: Address by Gorbachev To Congress Is Weighed
description: The Reagan Administration wants Mikhail S. Gorbachev to be allowed to speak to a joint meeting of Congress during the summit meeting next month only if Moscow permits President Reagan to address the Soviet people, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Carbide Settlement On Bhopal Is Seen
description: Lawyers for the Indian Government and the Union Carbide Corporation were scheduled to appear at a court hearing in India today, amid wide speculation that they were close to an agreement on compensation to be paid the victims of the Bhopal disaster.

title: Walter F. Thomas, 77, Retired Bank Executive
description: Walter F. Thomas, a retired vice chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, died of cardiac arrest Nov. 7 in a nursing home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 77 years old and lived in Boca Raton.

title: Arthur E. B. Tanner; Legislator, 78
description: Arthur E. B. Tanner, former speaker of the Connecticut House of Representatives and past president of the Waterbury Foundry Company, died Sunday at his home here. He was 78 years old.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: CONVERSATION overheard by Hinda Gonchor going downtown on an M104 bus.

title: SILVER KING MINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Strong Quake in Alaska
description: A major earthquake followed by dozens of aftershocks jarred portions of Alaska today and forced hundreds of coastal residents to flee their homes. No serious injuries or damage were reported in the quakes, which began with a temblor measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale. The quake was centered in the Gulf of Alaska, about 270 miles east-southeast of Anchorage and 90 miles southwest of Cape Yakataga, between Yakutat and Cordova. Emergency sirens wailed in many communities, and the police using loudspeakers and pounding on doors rousted people out of bed after the authorities issued a tidal wave alert for most of the Alaska and British Columbia coasts.

title: CAROLCO PICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes pre-tax equity in losses of $487,000 and $122,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from minority interests. c-Includes $725,000 of pretax equity in loss of an affiliated company for both the quarter and 9 months. The 1986 9-month results were restated to reflect the Orbis Communications transaction accounted for as a pooling-of-interests.

title: Actmedia Growing
description: Actmedia Inc. of Westhampton Beach, L.I., has become a giant among companies that arrange for promotions within supermarkets -the last mile of consumer purchase decision-making. Always seeking to grow even more, it has now reached an agreement to acquire Shelfvision Inc., a concern whose actual promotion melieu is the market shelves themselves. Since Actmedia already has a ShelfTalk program, it plans to merge the Shelfvision into it. Then Larry Wojclechowski, president of Shelfvision, becomes a senior vice president of Actmedia.

title: SOVIET HINTS MOVE ON AFGHAN ACCORD
description: A recent flurry of diplomatic activity has raised new speculation that the Soviet Union may be ready to compromise on a timetable for the withdrawal of the 115,000 troops it has stationed in Afghanistan.

title: Ortega vs. Contra Aid: Sandinistas Near a Victory?
description: As he returned to Managua Monday night from a trip to the United States, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra believed he was closer than ever to a goal he did not think was possible even a few months ago: a Congressional vote to cut off aid to the contras.

title: Bookmaker Sets Odds On Cuomo Bid in '88
description: A London bookmaking firm, William Hill, says it has succumbed to popular demand and included Governor Cuomo of New York on the list of favorites to win the White House next year.

title: EDUCATION: LESSONS
description: The father was suspicious. The son had been sent to the public schools, soaking up six years of ''enrichment'' programs, ''Creative I'' classes, ''skill processing'' sessions - the pot-au-feu of argot that passes for an elementary curriculum.

title: IT'S NOT SO EASY FOR NAVRATILOVA
description: All the computer points have been counted, thus assuring Steffi Graf of finishing the year as the No. 1 player. But last night, Martina Navratilova began her quest for the popular vote at Madison Square Garden, hoping that winning the Virginia Slims championships would strengthen her claim that she is still the best player in the world.

title: Ralph Rice Boyer; Former Nuclear Official, 83
description: Ralph Rice Boyer, retired chief of contracts finance for the Atomic Energy Commission, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Sandy Spring, Md. He was 83 years old.

title: A Wealth of Worries About Federal Deficits
description: To the Editor:

title: US FACILITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net gains on securities of $83,000 and $183,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes net gains on securities of $70,000 and $95,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Billy Owen, a 6-foot-8-inch center at Carlisle (Pa.) High School who has led his team to three straight Pennsylvania state championships, has announced he will enroll at Syracuse next fall, following his brother, Michael, who is a tailback on the unbeaten Orange football team. Owen, averaged 29.7 points and 12 rebounds as a junior last season. . . . After reviewing tapes of the fight, the International Boxing Federation has denied the protest filed by the former I.B.F. light-heavyweight champion Bobby Czyz in his Oct. 29 title fight against Charles Williams. Williams, who was knocked down in the second and third rounds, rallied to stop Czyz in the 10th round.

title: For Grandfather Clocks, Spare but Gentle Care
description: LEAD: THE order of the day as far as grandfather clocks are concerned seems to be: ''If it's working, don't fix it. If it's standing, don't touch it.''

description: Japan's labor movement, bedeviled by shrinking membership and dwindling influence, is about to take a bold, last-gasp step to end years of steady decline.

title: Health; Parents of Premature Infants Thrust Into a Life-Saving Role
description: The house is peaceful as the college student, a mother's helper, feeds a premature baby her bottle of formula. The only hint of anything unusual is a small electronic monitor that rhythmically flashes two green lights, indicating that the baby's heart rate and breathing rate are normal.

title: Bipartisan Qualms Create New Doubts About Plan on Deficit
description: Democrats and Republicans in the House and Senate expressed unhappiness today with the outline of the emerging plan to reduce the budget deficit by $30 billion.

description: Strip weaving, one of West Africa's oldest art forms, is the subject of a new exhibition here at the National Museum of African Art.

description: Year-ago share earnings are not available; the company converted to a stock concern Dec. 18.

title: Nomura No. 1 in Japan
description: The Nomura Securities Company, Japan's largest brokerage firm, has surpassed the Toyota Motor Corporation as the nation's most profitable company, a Nomura official said today. Nomura's pretax earnings in its fiscal year ended Sept. 30 rose 26.8 percent, to 493.8 billion yen, or $3.6 billion, topping Toyota's 488.3 billion yen, or $3.56 billion.

title: PINNACLE PETE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN PACIFIC MINT reports earnings for
description: b-After a gain of $48,000 from forgiveness of debt. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: CADEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pickens Withdraws Bid for Newmont
description: T. Boone Pickens said he would withdraw his $6.3 billion offer for the Newmont Mining Corporation after the Delaware Supreme Court upheld a lower court ruling that Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. could keep its 49.7 percent stake in Newmont.

title: SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,611,000 on security conversion. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $3,688,000. The company said it converted a portion of its investment in preferred stock of a subsidiary of Tyco Toys Inc. into Tyco common stock and subsequently sold it during the period from Oct. 2 through Oct. 7, realizing a gain in excess of $740,000, which will be included in thecompany's fourth-quarter results.

title: Chrysler Raises Some 1988 Prices
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it had raised the prices of its 1988 domestic car models an average of 1 percent over those of its comparably equipped 1987 models. But prices were cut on the Dodge Daytona and Aries, the Plymouth Reliant and the Chrysler LeBaron coupe. The price of its New Yorker model rose by more than $2,000, to $17,416.

title: ENERGY DEVELOPMENT PARTERS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and the 9 months includes a charge of $41,505,000 from the writedown of oil and gas assets.

title: Ansel E. McL. Talbert; Aviation Writer
description: Ansel Edward McLaurine Talbert, an aviation writer and editor for 50 years, died Oct. 7 at his home in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 75 years old.

title: THE YOUNG ALSO BURDEN A WORKING POPULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
Colorado's Troubled Banks Special to The New York Times
description: A multimillion-dollar deficiency in Colorado's private deposit insurance fund has put thousands of savings accounts in jeopardy and forced state regulators to seize 13 of the 89 industrial banks in the state.

title: Russian Immigrant Dies Gangland-Style In Car in Brooklyn
description: A Russian immigrant on probation for drug and weapons convictions was shot to death gangland style early yesterday in a car in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: CONVENIENT FOOD MART INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1986 revenue in both periods are restated to reflect corporate store sales. Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for 10 percent stock splits paid June 1 and Sept. 14, 1987.

title: Peso Hit By Panic In Mexico
description: The Bank of Mexico halted its efforts today to support the value of the peso against the dollar on the open market here, setting off a panic that sent the peso's value down as much as 59 percent.

title: NATIONAL-STANDARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. Aides Say Panama General Proposed Sabotage in Nicaragua
description: Panama's military leader offered to undertake sabotage and possibly assassinations in Nicaragua for the Reagan Administration, Government officials said today, explaining a veiled allusion to the matter in the Iran-contra report.

title: Crash Inquiry Focusing on Taxiing Mix-Up
description: Investigators looking into the fatal crash of a Continental Airlines jetliner in Denver sought an explanation yesterday for a taxiing mix-up that might have caused the plane to be exposed to snowfall longer than necessary after ice was removed from the wings.

title: TIERCO GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Three Tons of Cocaine Seized By U.S. in Florida Warehouse
description: Federal agents today confiscated more than three tons of cocaine hidden in hollowed-out lumber at a suburban warehouse, according to Government officials who called it the biggest single seizure of the drug in the United States. No arrests were made immediately. Paul A. Teresi, agent in charge of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Fort Lauderdale, said the wholesale value of the 6,292 pounds of cocaine was estimated at $62 million.

title: First City Group Acts to Halt Bailout
description: A small group of stockholders of the First City Bancorporation of Texas has made an 11th-hour threat to block the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's plan to bail out the troubled bank holding company. Banking analysts, however, said today that the effort might not succeed.

title: SMALL BUDGET CUT MAY HURT MARKETS
description: The financial markets are bracing for a decline should Congress and the Administration cut the budget deficit by only $20 billion to $23 billion, as many analysts and economists now think is likely.

title: Smith Barney Reports Loss
description: Smith Barney Inc., the big securities firm owned by the Primerica Corporation, had a net loss of $43 million in October, caused primarily by its risk arbitrage activities.

title: LATVIAN PROTEST REPORTED CURBED
description: A planned Latvian nationalist demonstration in Riga, the capital of the Baltic republic, never got started as hundreds of policemen and civilian militiamen, standing shoulder to shoulder, cordoned off the central square today, according to reports from Riga.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on brunches and a related picture caption in Weekend last Friday misidentified a group performing at the Barking Fish restaurant. It was the Big Mamou, not Loup Garou.

title: Injured Jet Defense Is Bracing for Bills
description: The click of Joe Klecko's knee brace brought sweet music to the Jets' locker room today. It is a sound the tattered defense will need to hear to keep the club's resurgence going.

title: Breeders' Draws 85 Starters
description: A record 85 horses, and 6 additional alternates, were entered today to run in the fourth annual Breeders' Cup Saturday at Hollywood Park.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After investment gains of $112,000 for the quarter and $372,000 for the 9 months. c-After investment gains of $886,000. The company said increased revenue reflects the acquisition of Standard Life Insurance Co. in November 1986.

title: Cardinal Seeks to Clarify Remarks About Jews
description: The Vatican office of Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger sought late today to clarify a controversial statement the Cardinal made about dialogue with Jews, according to a Roman Catholic interfaith offical here.

title: The 1970's Industrial Look: What Became of High Tech?
description: High tech, the revolutionary design movement that brought the industrial style into thousands of American homes and apartments, seems to have vanished without a trace after a life span of less than 15 years. The look that celebrated innovation and resourcefulness, it was expressed in the beauty of exposed pipes, the plainness of restaurant ware and the practicality of hospital equipment. High tech's birth was greeted with acclaim by the young and the avant-garde, yet today it is no more than a dim memory. Services will be minimal. Please omit flowers. ANONYMOUS equipment borrowed from its humble settings and given a second life by inventive interior designers became the basis for a full-fledged style that flourished internationally in urban lofts and chic apartments.

title: Always With Us
description: Oct. 19, Black Monday on Wall Street, produced a lot of talk, if not much action, about fixing what's wrong with the economy. Too little is being said or heard, however, about the nation's most egregious economic problems - the persistence of so much poverty amid so much wealth, and the declining standard of living for the middle class.

title: NMR OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $304,952.

title: PRINTS SET PRICE RECORDS IN 2 AUCTIONS
description: Japanese and European bidding continued to help propel art prices to record levels at the auctions of Old Master, modern and contemporary prints held last weekend and this week at Sotheby's and Christie's. When the gavels fell on the final lots, however, Americans had purchased the majority of prints at both houses.

Included in that provision is an after-tax amount of $11.1 million reflecting the realized and unrealized loss on the resale of its position in British Petroleum Co. shares.

title: Key Sections of Document: The Making of a Political Crisis
description: Following are key sections of the majority report, issued today, of the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair: EXECUTIVE SUMMARY SUMMARY OF THE FACTS Nicaragua

title: The Laws, Unfaithfully Executed
description: The Iran-contra committees charge Ronald Reagan with the second worst offense for a President. They conclude that he did not fulfill his constitutional oath ''to take care that the laws be faithfully executed.'' The judgment by the committees' Democrats and three Republicans could have been more harsh, but only if they judged that the President knew about the illegalities committed by trusted subordinates or, like Richard Nixon, actively joined their cover-ups.

title: MPSI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sports of The Times; Tim Brown's Heisman Trophy
description: AS part of its 100th anniversary celebration early next year, Notre Dame intends to display each of the Heisman trophies that its football players have won. Asked to return his trophy for the exhibit, Paul Hornung preferred to bring it to the campus himself rather than risk shipping it. So not long ago the 1956 winner was walking through the South Bend, Ind., airport, carrying the bronzed statue of a running back as if it were a football. Suddenly a stranger stared at him. ''Showoff,'' the man said. Must've been a South Bend old-timer who remembers when the Heisman Trophy was considered a campus fixture. Angelo Bertelli, Johnny Lujack and Leon Hart have also returned their trophies. Johnny Lattner and John Huarte have yet to comply. But before the exhibit opens, Notre Dame is expected to be applauding its seventh Heisman winner, its first in 23 years: Tim Brown, the wide receiver and kick-returner on the 8-1 team apparently on its way to the Cotton Bowl in only Lou Holtz's second season as coach.

title: Warfare in Queens G.O.P. Reported Crippling Its Leadership
description: The Queens Republican organization, once a bellwether in statewide elections, is so torn by dissension that its leadership has been unable to function, politicians say.

title: A Designer In Untrodden Byways
description: ''THERE'S something seductive about the Yellow Pages,'' said Richard Saul Wurman, the New York graphic designer, cartographer, architect and guidebook guru. ''They're so pervasive. They're like a street curb. You can look at them your whole life and never really see them.''

title: William M. Swartz; Retired Businessman, 75
description: William M. Swartz, a retired Chicago businessman, died of a stroke Nov. 11 at his home in Highland Park, Ill. He was 75 years old.

title: Death Sentence in Moscow
description: A former Soviet police officer has been sentenced to death for his part in an armed raid on a Moscow department store, the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda said Wednesday. A court was told that Valery Fineyev, 28 years old, led a gang that shot a policewoman, a driver and a cashier after seizing more than $470,000 from the store last November.

title: SENATE APPROVES WATER PROJECTS
description: The Senate voted today to spend $4.26 billion on Federal water projects this fiscal year, including $13.5 million for a dam repair that the Reagan Administration says could set a costly precedent.

title: From Abrams to Weinberger: The Cast of the Iran-Contra Drama
description: Elliott Abrams

title: Antoine Magnin, 86, French Chef Noted for Wood-Fire Cuisine, Dies
description: Antoine Magnin, a French chef whose wood-fired cuisine at his bistro, L'Ami Louis, attracted generations of avid followers, died of a heart attack Friday at a medical clinic in Versailles. He was 86 years old.

title: Strong Quake in Alaska
description: A major earthquake followed by dozens of aftershocks jarred portions of Alaska Tuesday and forced hundreds of coastal residents to flee their homes. No serious injuries or damage were reported in the quakes, which began with a temblor measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale. The quake was centered in the Gulf of Alaska, about 270 miles east-southeast of Anchorage and 90 miles southwest of Cape Yakataga, between Yakutat and Cordova.

title: Designer Whispers, Fashion Listens
description: GIVE Marc Audibet an inch and he'll make a dress. Five years ago the Parisian designer began traveling to Italy, where he became a leader in the development of new stretch fabrics. He took Lycra, which was first used in bathing suits in the 1950's and ski clothes in the 1960's, and blended it into fabrics with yarns like wool, cotton, cashmere or linen.

title: Mystery Death At L.I. Hospital Torments Son
description: When Sam Falabella buried his mother, Nancy, at Calvary Cemetery in Woodside, Queens, last month, he thought he had put her to rest.

description: The stubbornly high trade deficits in recent months are making the United States rediscover an old nemesis: oil imports.

title: Frederick R. Kearns; Ex-Canadair Executive, 63
description: Frederick R. Kearns, a former president and chief executive of Canadair Ltd., died Saturday in London, Ontario, of complications from a liver transplant that he had in September. He was 63 years old and lived in Montreal.

title: Whalers Triumph
description: Ron Francis registered his sixth career hat trick tonight as the Hartford Whalers beat the Buffalo Sabres, 9-1, to end a six-game streak without a victory.

title: Back on Trial
description: Denny McLain, major-league baseball's last 30-game winner, will be tried for a third time on Federal charges of cocaine trafficking and loan sharking, according to a spokesman for the United States Attorney's office in Tampa, Fla. United States District Judge Elizabeth Kovachevich, who was cited for judicial error in an August ruling that overturned the former Detroit Tiger pitcher's 1985 conviction, will preside at the Jan. 4 trial in Tampa. ''I knew it was coming, but it's a chilling feeling,'' said McLain, who is free on bond and working in Fort Wayne, Ind. ''When is enough enough?'' McLain's first trial ended in a mistrial. Before his conviction was overturned, McLain served 29 months of a 23-year sentence in the Federal Correctional Institute in Talladega, Ala.

description: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, took a timeout today, postponing until Friday the 15th game of his championship match with Anatoly Karpov.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: HE was given three rules to live by when he was 4 years old. Pick up your toys. Clean up your room. Don't talk with your mouth full. Apparently he felt that one out of three was good enough. His speech was clear, but his room was a mess and his toys followed the law of entropy and were scattered all over the house. He was not a neat child.

The acquisition by Amoco's subsidiary, the Amoco Canada Petroleum Company, had been deadlocked for seven months as creditors withheld approval of the initial offer of $5.1 billion (Canadian), or about $3.8 billion (United States).

Health; Some Tricks To Aid Memory
description: Memory enhancing tricks, called mnemonics, have been popular since ancient times. One of the most effective, committing information to rhyme, was used to transmit culture in ancient Greece. Homer's Iliad, an epic poem, was originally only recited. To this day, most people use ''Thirty days hath September . . .'' to remember how long each month is. On the other hand, rote repetition is one of the least effective mnemonics.

title: Stressing Safety When Choosing Toys
description: A toy train with 300 times the legal amount of dangerous lead in its paint will not be on the shelves this holiday season.

description: The company said it incurred about $3 million of additional annual depreciation and amortization costs and $6 million of additional annual interest expense as a result of the acquisition of Texas Industrial Sevices earlier this year.

title: Rock: Sting in Preview of World Tour
description: STING offered New Yorkers a preview of his world tour on Sunday and Monday at the Ritz, introducing the seven-member backup band that will play at an arena in Rio de Janeiro this weekend. ''We might make some mistakes, we might get it wrong,'' he told the $20-a-ticket audience Monday, ''but what the hell.''

title: Dried-Flower Designs For Year-Round Color
description: ''THIS is a very hard city to live in because everywhere you look, especially in winter, all you see is concrete,'' said Madi Heller, co-owner of Galerie Felix Flower. She and her husband, Felix Blume, combat the grayness by surrounding themselves with dried flowers, long-lasting remnants of the natural world.

title: GRAF STRUTS HER NO. 1 STUFF IN 47 MINUTES
description: The toughest part was the waiting, Steffi Graf said. Chris Evert was already on the way home, Hana Mandlikova was forced to retire because of an injury and Martina Navratilova -No. 2 and not enjoying it one bit - had reaped the benefit of a competitive opening-round match. Graf, meanwhile, was limited to practice sessions that were probably doing her more harm than good.
