title: Tips for Those Trying to Quit
description: For people who want to quit smoking, there are steps to take that may ease the craving for nicotine, according to June Walzer of the American Cancer Society's New York City division. She offered these suggestions:

title: All in the Game
description: To the Editor:

title: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
New Yorkers Urge Plan for Museum
description: In a rare and strong expression of unanimity, New York State and city officials today argued in favor of a plan to keep the Museum of the American Indian in New York while pledging to lend its holdings liberally to other museums, in Washington and around the country.

title: ALTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PVC CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE COUNTRIES HAVE NUMBERS
description: Congressional investigators used numbers to identify countries that might be embarrassed by public disclosure of their secret dealings with the United States. According to officials familiar with the report, these are the countries in question:

title: PRICE PUT AT $900 MILLION
description: Kuwait said today that it owns a 10 percent stake in the British Petroleum Company, Britain's largest corporation and the world's third-biggest oil company.

title: 15% of People With AIDS Survive 5 Years
description: Researchers studying AIDS patients in New York City found that about 15 percent of them survived at least five years after diagnosis with the disease, indicating a less dire outlook for some patients than is commonly assumed.

title: Makarova Narrates 'Ballerina'
description: ''BALLERINA,'' to be shown on the Arts & Entertainment Network tonight at 9 P.M. and 1 A.M.and on Sunday afternoon, is a feast. Part of a four-hour series written and narrated by Natalia Makarova and produced for the BBC and A&E, this homage to the ballerina begins a little slowly with looks at Marcia Haydee and Miss Makarova performing in ballets by Maurice Bejart and Roland Petit. There is an extended - and funny -rehearsal session for Miss Makarova with Jerome Robbins.

title: REVISIONIST LOOK AT PRAIRIE ARCHITECT
description: MUCH of what is known about Frank Lloyd Wright comes from the architect himself. But the master, who wrote his autobiography in 1932 and revised it in 1943, was a source of misinformation.

title: House Panel Clears Bill On Family Leave Policy
description: Legislation requiring large companies to allow their employees to take unpaid family or medical leave and return to their jobs has cleared a Congressional committee but has yet to achieve broad bipartisan support.

title: Indians Rehire Edwards
description: Doc Edwards, the bullpen coach who took over as manager of the Cleveland Indians after Pat Corrales was let go July 16, was rehired yesterday for the 1988 season by Hank Peters, the newly appointed president of the team who was putting in his first official day of work. Edwards, 51 years old, who signed a one-year contract, turned in a 30-45 won-lost record as the Indians, considered a pennant contender by some preseason forecasters, turned in the worst record in baseball, 61 victories and 101 defeats. Peters, a former executive for the Baltimore Orioles, indicated that no one else was seriously considered for the job as manager, saying ''the incumbent always has the advantage.''

title: Bridge: Head of U.S. League Faced Counterpart From Britain
description: The custom of the American Contract Bridge League, and its forerunner, the American Bridge League, has been to elect a new president each year.

title: Heart Surgery for Betty Ford
description: Betty Ford will undergo coronary artery bypass surgery at Eisenhower Medical Center on Friday. A spokeswoman, Ann Cullen, said the decision to operate on the former First Lady was not prompted by an emergency but was ''a preventive measure.'' Mrs. Ford, who is 69 years old, underwent surgery on a carotid artery at the medical center on July 24.

title: Yes to Tibbetts Gardens
description: The Board of Estimate votes today on Tibbetts Gardens, a 1,000-unit condominium to be built on vacant land in the Kingsbridge section of the west Bronx. This expansion of middle-income housing deserves approval.

title: Treasury Issues Move Slowly
description: The Treasury securities market endured another extraordinarily slow day with minor price changes as traders and investors waited for more information about the budget deficit, the economy and policies of central banks around the world.

title: A Suspect in 2 Murders Is Killed by a Detective
description: A 22-year-old man wanted in connection with two Bronx murders last December was shot to death yesterday afternoon during a struggle with two detectives.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1987
description: International

title: QUAREX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
Jacques Anquetil; Former Cyclist, 53
description: Jacques Anquetil, a five-time winner of the Tour de France bicycling race, died of stomach cancer today in a Rouen hospital, his doctors said. He was 53 years old.

title: Market Place; Merck-Squibb Rivalry's Effect
description: DESPITE the October market plunge, drug stocks have been big winners so far this year, thanks to promising new products, rising earnings and a falling dollar that enhances their income from overseas. But what helps one company in this high-stakes business often works to the detriment of a competitor.

title: Devils Win on Verbeek's Goal
description: The Flyers drew the Devils into the grabbing, pushing and shoving game that suits their style tonight, not allowing the Devils to get into a rhythm.

title: Bay Talks to Michigan
description: Two days after resigning as athletic director at Ohio State University, Rick Bay said he had been in touch with the University of Michigan about the athletic director's job there. ''They contacted me,'' Bay said. ''I don't know if I'd classify myself as a candidate because I'm not sure I'm going to stay in intercollegiate athletics.'' Bay submitted his resignation Monday in protest after the president of Ohio State, Edward Jennings, dismissed the football coach, Earle Bruce. Don Canham is currently the athletic director at Michigan, but will retire effective July 1, 1988. Canham did not immediately return a phone call to The Associated Press.

title: ENSCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are on a pro forma basis to reflect the Sept. 30, 1986, reverse takeover of Rose Group.

title: Dollar Ends Day Mixed; Gold Prices Edge Down
description: The dollar closed narrowly mixed in New York yesterday after a day of erratic mood changes among traders in the global foreign exchange market.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest periods include the addition of $2,481,000, or 48 cents a share, to a loss reserve for the balance of the trust's Jackson-Shaw investment in Texas.

title: Handicapping the Breeders' Cup
description: Following are the fields for the seven Breeders' Cup races Saturday at Hollywood Park in Inglewood, Calif. The entrants are not listed in post-position order but instead are ranked in order of preference by Steven Crist of The New York Times, who wrote the comments and calculated the speed figures for each horse's last three races. The most recent figure is shown first.

title: House Approves Plan To Raise V.A. Status
description: The House overwhelmingly approved legislation Tuesday that would turn the Veterans Administration into a Federal department with Cabinet-level status.

description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $382,700 on sales of offices. c-Net loss and includes a pre-tax gain of $171,600 on sales of offices.

title: DESIGN TO HONOR SPACE PIONEERS
description: IN 1980, the National Capital Commission in Washington staged a competition for the design of a Vietnam War monument. Maya Lin, then a student at Yale University, won with a simple V-shaped form with the names of American casualties inscribed on its marble walls. It was a controversial design, but today, as thousands visit the monument every week, few doubt its success.

title: AMERICAN CABLESYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MERRIMAC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 10
House Approves Compromise on Military Spending
description: The House today approved a bipartisan compromise measure on military programs costing up to $296 billion while imposing some arms restrictions on the White House. The vote was 264 to 158.

title: DOC OPTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Walsh Sees Little Effect Of Report on His Inquiry
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair said today that his investigation had ''its own momentum now'' and would not be significantly affected by the reports from Congressional committees that investigated the affair.

title: Two Geochemists Win Prizes in Earth Science
description: Two geochemists who did pioneering work on the chemical relationships of the oceans and the atmosphere and the land have been awarded the 1987 Vetlesen Prize in the earth sciences.

description: Several of the world's largest institutional investors defended computerized program trading today at a meeting in Washington.

title: Smokers Hide and Drag Harder As Society Makes Them Outcasts
description: Andrea Green, a marketing and promotion consultant for banks, was on the telephone with a man who helps companies develop programs for employees who want to quit smoking. She lit a cigarette, quietly, she thought. But she was not quiet enough.

description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said that E. F. Hutton & Company and four current or former employees had paid civil penalties totaling $145,000 involving 14 purported violations of commodities law.

description: A Federal appeals court today ordered the reinstatement of a teacher with AIDS, ruling for the first time that discrimination against victims of the disease is barred under civil rights laws protecting the handicapped.

description: California Democrats prefer Governor Cuomo of New York to any of the declared candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination, a new California Poll says.

title: Amfac Considers A Restructuring
description: Amfac Inc., the largest private employer in Hawaii, said its directors would consider a corporate restructuring on Friday. Some analysts said the plan could lead to a breakup of the diversified company.

description: The Economy

title: Let Banks Enter Securities Field, Greenspan Says
description: The Federal Reserve Board called today for repeal of legislation enacted during the Depression that places a barrier between the banking and securities industries.

description: House Speaker Jim Wright arrived at a luncheon at the Hyatt Regency Hotel yesterday to present the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs' third annual W. Averell Harriman Democracy Award to the Argentine President, Raul Alfonsin.

Japan Air Lines Offering
description: Japan Air Lines is being privatized after 34 years of Government control. Shareholders met Tuesday and approved a sale of 48.1 million Government-held shares - 34.5 percent of the total outstanding - to the public next month.

title: Worst Is Past For President: Damage to Reputation Was Done Long Ago
description: Even with its arresting descriptions of ''pervasive dishonesty'' and ''disarray at the highest levels of Government,'' the Congressional report on the Iran-contra affair is not likely to do significant new harm to the Reagan Presidency because the damage is already done.

title: Knicks Waste 28-Point Lead
description: For one incredible evening in November, it was like pro basketball in June inside steamy Boston Garden, a game ending in the kind of draining emotion more typical of playoff time.

title: Law's 'Stradivarius'; Inside Trader Ruling Saves Mail Law As Key Tool for Federal Prosecutors
description: ''To Federal prosecutors of white-collar crime, the mail fraud statute is our Stradivarius, our Colt .45, our Louisville Slugger, our Cuisinart - and our true love,'' Jed S. Rakoff wrote in a 1980 law review article. Prosecutors may flirt with other laws, he said, but they always come home to mail fraud, ''with its simplicity, adaptability, and comfortable familiarity.''

title: DOME PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The company said foreign exchange gains for the latest quarter and 9 months amounted to $43 million and $112 million, respectively, and were largely unrealized. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: MICROBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Gullickson Negotiates
description: The Yankees have begun preliminary talks with Doug Baldwin, the agent for Bill Gullickson, the right-hander who had a 4-2 record with a 4.88 earned run average in eight starts after he was acquired in a late-season trade with Cincinnati. Baldwin said that he had spoken with Bob Quinn, the Yankees' vice president for baseball administration, although terms of a new contract were not discussed. The Yankees are not expected to offer the 28-year-old Gullickson more than a two-year pact. The agent said he had not been contacted by any other clubs about Gullickson.

title: A Taxing Rule Sends Youths to Social Security
description: Social Security Commissioner Dorcas R. Hardy looked out at the roomful of teen-agers and summed up in seven words why each youth must have a Social Security number: ''Every one of you is a deduction.''

title: MESTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago figures are restated to reflect the retroactive reduction of goodwill, which was realized from the utilization of operating loss carryforwards during the 9 months ended Sept. 30. Mestek, on July 31, 1986, merged with Reed National Corp. and for accounting purposes Reed was treated as the acquiring company. The results for 1987 periods reflect increased revenue and earnings from three post merger acquisitions and from inclusion for the full quarter and full 9 months of 1987 of the pre-merger operations of Mestek.

title: NEW JOB BIAS LAW URGED FOR ULSTER
description: While violence and political conflictseem to run in cycles here, job discrimination has remained a constant and intractable reality.

title: UNIVERSITY GIVEN ORDER ON RESEARCH
description: A Superior Court judge today ordered the University of California to establish a process to assure that Federal tax money it receives under a 100-year-old law is spent on agricultural research that primarily benefits small family farms.

title: After the Fall, Yeltsin Gets a Top Industry Post
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, removed last week as head of the Moscow Communist Party organization, was given a senior position in the construction industry, Tass reported today.

title: Police Still Searching Park for a Young Girl
description: More than 30 police officers are to search a park on the Brooklyn-Queens border for a fourth day today in response to a report from three children that they had seen a young girl carried there and left by a man.

title: Argentina Loan Plans
description: As expected, Argentina has sent to the International Monetary Fund a list of economic adjustments it has designed to insure continued availability of a $1.4 billion I.M.F. loan. Terms of the loan, originally agreed upon in February, were adjusted in July. Since then, Argentina's deficit has mushroomed and inflation has soared, requiring the country to undertake additional economic adjustments to remain on favorable terms with the I.M.F. Monetary sources said that the I.M.F. board would probably approve continued availability of the loans at its next meeting.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said share earnings are for series A common stock and have been adjusted for intervening stock dividends.

title: Encor Rejects Bid
description: The Encor Energy Corporation said its board rejected a $980 million Canadian, or $742 million, bid from Transcanada PipeLines Ltd. Encor, which is 42 percent owned by Dome Petroleum Ltd., called the offer ''inadequate from a financial point of view.'' An Encor director abstained from the vote because of a potential conflict of interest, the company said, but all of its other directors, including those representing Dome, were unanimous.

title: CHEEKS HELPS 76ERS END 3-LOSS STREAK
description: Maurice Cheeks scored 11 of his 25 points in the fourth quarter tonight to help the Philadelphia 76ers break a three-game losing streak with a 113-109 victory over the Detroit Pistons.

description: Ted Aceto, the athletic director at Villanova, knew that a football team would not lack support when he surveyed the crowd at a scrimmage at Villanova Stadium on Nov. 3, 1984.

title: Obstetrician in Queens Shot to Death in Office
description: An obstetrician was shot and killed yesterday by a well-dressed man who walked into his Queens office, the police said.

title: New Hotel Planned For Atlantic City
description: Broadway Holdings Inc., a unit of a New Jersey developer, said it would develop a 800-room hotel and casino in the Marina area of Atlantic City. The hotel will be developed and managed with a partnership formed by Carnival Cruise Lines Inc., the world's largest operator of cruise ships, and the Continental Companies, a hotel-management concern. Terms were not disclosed. Broadway Holdings was formed last year by the American Midland Corporation of Englewood Cliffs to develop its 8.2 acres of real estate in the Marina area. American Midland also manages hotels and nursing homes.

title: UAS AUTOMATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Much Too Quick
description: The fast hands of Steve Largent, the Seattle Seahawk wide receiver known for his speed afoot, worked so quickly in the game against the Jets Nov. 9 that what had been scored as a 12-yard pass reception for Largent had to be erased. On the play in the game's closing minutes, Largent leaped to catch a ball thrown by Dave Krieg, the Seattle quarterback. Largent was hit by a Jet defender as he caught the ball and then, before his feet touched the ground, he lateraled to John L. Williams, who ran for an additional 14 yards. National Football League rules specify that a caught pass is not an official reception until the receiver's feet touch the ground. The play has now been officially recorded as a 26-yard pass from Krieg to Williams. Fortunately, for Largent, his feet were on the ground on four other catches that night, so his streak of consecutve games with a pass reception, now at 146, stayed intact.

description: More than half the students who entered New York City public high schools in 1982 failed to graduate on schedule in 1986, according to a revamped dropout report released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: The Stage: 'Fun,' 2 One-Act Plays
description: HOWARD KORDER creates significant characters, pithy dialogue and taut scenes, then has trouble putting his talents together. That, at any rate, is the feeling left by ''Fun,'' the two related one-acters that opened this week at the Judith Anderson theater. The first, ''Fun,'' was previously staged at the Actors Theater of Louisville; the second, ''Nobody,'' received a reading at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf United States Takes Early Lead: Ben Crenshaw and Payne Stewart shot 70's yesterday to give the United States a one-stroke lead in the opening round of the 33d World Cup. The combined 140 total, four under par on the Bay course at the Kapalua, Hawaii, resort, led the Irish team of Ronan Rafferty and Eamonn Darcy. England, with Howard Clark and Mark James, was next at 142. (AP) Horse Racing Dream Launch Is Winner: Dream Launch, ridden by Julio Garcia, scored a three-length wire-to-wire victory in the $33,000 HighFiz Purse for fillies and mares at Aqueduct yesterday. Dream Launch, who earned $19,800 for Jayeff B. Stables, returned $44, $14.40 and $5.20. (AP) Tennis Cash and Gomez Advance: Pat Cash of Australia, seeded first, and Andres Gomez of Ecuador, seeded second, scored straight-set victories yesterday in their opening-round matches at the South African Open championships in Johannesburg. Cash defeated Michael Robertson of South Africa, 6-2, 6-2, and Gomez beat Danie Visser of South Africa, 6-1, 7-5. (AP)

title: 'CABAL OF ZEALOTS'
description: The Congressional committees on the Iran-contra affair blamed President Reagan in their final report today for failing to live up to his constitutional mandate to ''take care that the laws be faithfully executed'' and said he bore ''the ultimate responsibility'' for wrongdoing by his aides.

title: U.N. Toning Down an Anti-Israeli Resolution
description: A resolution criticizing Israel's links with South Africa has been presented in a form sharply toned down from versions approved in previous years.

title: Arms, Hostages and Contras: How a Secret Foreign Policy Unraveled
description: 1984 March 16: William Buckley, C.I.A. station chief in Beirut, is kidnapped and held by Islamic Holy War, pro-Iranian extremists, in Lebanon. May: Duane Clarridge, a C.I.A. officer who has contacts with the Nicaraguan rebels, introduces Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, a National Security Council aide, to contra leaders in Honduras. Mr. Clarridge tells them, in effect, that if Congress cuts off aid to the contras in light of revelations that the C.I.A. mined Nicaraguan harbors, Colonel North will continue to work with the contras. May 8: The Rev. Benjamin Weir is kidnapped. Aug. 31: President Reagan's national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, asks Government agencies to reassess policy toward Iran. Oct. 12: Congress bans direct or indirect military aid to the contras. Dec. 3: Peter Kilburn of the American University of Beirut is kidnapped. 1985 Jan. 8: The Rev. Lawrence M. Jenco is seized. March 16: Another American, Terry A. Anderson of The Associated Press, is kidnapped in Beirut. May 3: Michael A. Ledeen, a consultant to the National Security Council, meets with Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel to discuss Iran. He tells Israel that Washington would approve Israeli shipments of artillery or ammunition to Iran. May 28: David P. Jacobsen of the American University Hospital in Beirut is kidnapped. June 3: Mr. Buckley dies, according to Mr. Jacobsen, who is freed in November 1986. June 9: Thomas M. Sutherland of the American University of Beirut is kidnapped. Early July: David Kimche, Director General of the Israeli Foreign Ministry, tells Mr. McFarlane that Iranian officials want to open a ''political discourse'' with the United States. Mid-July: President Reagan authorizes Mr. McFarlane to make contact with Iran. Aug. 6: Mr. McFarlane briefs Mr. Reagan on the Israeli proposal to sale American anti-tank missiles to Iran through Israel. There is dispute on whether the President approved this sale. August: The President approves the shipment of arms by Israel to Iran, according to his initial statement to the Tower Commission. Later he says ''I don't remember'' when asked about approving the shipment. Aug. 20: Israel sends 96 TOW anti-tank missiles to Iran. Sept. 14: Israel sends 408 more TOW missiles to Iran. Mr. Weir is released the same day. Oct. 4: Islamic Holy War says it killed Mr. Buckley. His body is never found. November: Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force major general, is deeply involved in setting up a supply operation for the contras under the name Airlift Project. He later testifies that the project's money came from private donations and friendly foreign governments. Nov. 24-25: The C.I.A. arranges for a shipment of 18 Hawk anti-aircraft missiles from Israel to Iran aboard a C.I.A. front company plane. Iran rejects the missiles within days after test firing one of them and finding that they do not meet Iran's requirements. Later, some of the American officials involved in arranging the flight said they thought the plane carried oil-drilling parts, not weapons. Nov. 25: John N. McMahon, Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, says the C.I.A. cannot provide any more covert assistance without an explicit authorization from the President. On Dec. 5 the President signs a finding retroactively authorizing the operation. Later, Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter testifies that he destroyed this order when he was Mr. Reagan's national security adviser. Dec. 4: Mr. McFarlane resigns as national security adviser. His deputy, Admiral Poindexter, is appointed his successor. Dec. 6: Colonel North tells Israeli Defense Ministry officials that he plans to use profits from future arms sales to support the contras. Dec. 7: A meeting is held at the White House with Mr. Reagan, Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, Mr. McFarlane and Admiral Poindexter at which the Iran initiative is discussed. Participants at the meeting have different recall of what took place. Some suggest that a consensus was reached to end arms shipments to Iran. Mr. McMahon has said no such consensus was reached. Dec. 8: Mr. McFarlane flies to London with Colonel North for a meeting with Manucher Ghorbanifar, an Iranian middleman and arms dealer; Mr. Kimche, from the Israeli Foreign Ministry, and Yaacov Nimrodi, an Israeli arms dealer. Mr. McFarlane tells Mr. Ghorbanifar that the United States does not want to take part in any more arms transfers to Iran, although it is willing to continue diplomatic contacts. 1986 Jan. 17: President Reagan signs an order authorizing arms shipments to Iran in an effort to both improve relations with officials in Iran thought to be moderates and to bring about the release of the hostages. This order authorizes the C.I.A. to assist ''third parties'' as well as friendly foreign countries in shipping weapons. Feb. 17: The United States sends 500 TOW missiles to Israel, from American stocks, for shipment to Iran. No hostages are freed. Feb. 27: Another shipment of 500 TOW missiles are sent to Israel, once again for shipment to Iran. Again no hostages are freed. April 4: In a memorandum, Colonel North outlines a plan to have $12 million in profits from the Iran arms sales diverted to the contras. The memo is prepared for Admiral Poindexter to relay to the President. Admiral Poindexter later testifies that he never showed the memo to the President. Mr. Reagan has denied knowing anything about the diversion to the contras until November 1986. April 17: Mr. Kilburn's body is found. His kidnappers say he was killed in retaliation for the American bombing of Libya two days before. May 23-24: 508 TOW missiles and 240 spare parts for Hawk missiles are shipped to Israel. May 25: Mr. McFarlane, Colonel North and other American officials fly to Teheran, carrying with them spare parts for Iran's Hawk anti-aircraft missiles. They spend four days meeting with Iranian officials in trying to win the release of all the American hostages. They are unsuccessful. June 11: Admiral Poindexter tells Colonel North that Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams has asked the Sultan of Brunei to donate money for the contras. June 26: Congress approves $100 million in military and non-arms aid to the contras beginning Oct. 1. July 26: Father Jenco is freed. Aug. 4: The United States sends Iran a shipment of spare parts for Hawk anti-aircraft missiles. September: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica closes the secret airstrip used by the North-Secord contra supply operation. Sept. 9: Frank Herbert Reed is kidnapped. Sept. 12: Another American, Joseph James Cicippio, is taken hostage. Oct. 5: A cargo plane carrying arms to the contras that is part of a supply operation set up by General Secord is shot down over Nicaragua. Three crewmen are killed and a fourth, Eugene Hasenfus, is taken captive. Oct. 21: Edward Austin Tracy is kidnapped. Oct. 28: Another 500 TOW missiles are sent from Israel to Iran. Nov. 2: Mr. Jacobsen is released. Nov. 3: A Lebanese magazine, Al Shiraa, discloses that the United States sent arms to Iran and that Mr. McFarlane visited Teheran. Nov. 25: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d announces the diversion of money from the Iran arms sales to the contras. President Reagan announces Admiral Poindexter's resignation and Colonel North's dismissal. Dec. 19: Lawrence E. Walsh is named special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair. 1987 Jan. 6-7: The Senate and the House set up committees to investigate the Iran-contra affair. Jan. 24: Four teachers - Alann Steen, Jesse J. Turner and Robert Polhill, Americans, and Mithileshwar Singh, an Indian-born U.S. resident alien - are kidnapped at Beirut University College. Feb. 26: The Tower Commission issues its report. Among its conclusions is that the President's top advisers were responsible for creating the chaos that led to the Iran-contra affair. It asserts that President Reagan was largely out of touch with the operations undertaken by his National Security Council staff. May 5: Public testimony begins before the Senate and House committees on the Iran-contra affair. General Secord is the first witness. July 7: Colonel North begins six days of testimony before the Congressional committees. He says he has no idea if the President had any knowledge of the diversion of funds to the contras. He also says that William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence during the Iran-contra period, was aware and approved of the diversion and that the arms sales were originally intended as an exchange for the hostages. July 15: Admiral Poindexter begins five days of testimony before the committees. He says he never told the President of the diversion of funds to give him ''plausible deniability'' about the affair. Aug. 3: The Iran-contra hearings end after more than 250 hours of testimony from 28 public witnesses. Nov. 18: The Congressional Iran-contra committees issue their report.

description: Following is a transcript of a statement, as recorded by The Associated Press, that was delivered today by Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, in reaction to the report of the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair:

title: Truce and Consequences in Washington
description: Under pressure from abroad and through intermediaries at home, the White House and the Democratic majority in Congress seem to have declared a truce - one that suggests how the Government may work for the next year or so.

description: b-Net income The company said the increase in sales for the quarter and 9-month periods is primarily attributable to the inclusion in its 1987 results of its subsidiaries Olympic Mills Corp. and Estampados Deportivos Inc., acquired Dec. 2, 1986.

AMERICAN REAL ESTATE PARTERS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Washington Talk: Deficit Reduction; Automatic Cuts: What They'll Affect
description: If White House and Congressional negotiators fail to reach a budget compromise by the Friday deadline, a series of spending cuts are scheduled to take effect that will indiscriminately affect almost everything from AIDS research and the anti-missile program to the number of weather forecasters in the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We recently moved into a home that had carpet in the bathroom. This carpet was held down with double-faced tape that has left a gummy residue on the floor. I tried scrubbing this off with denatured alcohol, but it didn't work. Do you have any suggestions? A. This residue can almost always be removed by rubbing with a rag moistened with rubber-cement thinner (sold in art-supply and stationery stores), then with a dry cloth. If the floor is ceramic tile you can also use acetone, but this is much more volatile and more flammable (it will also remove paint). Another method that often works is heating the gummy residue with a hair dryer to soften it, then rubbing off with a dry cloth. Q. Our house, which was built in 1928, has front entrance steps and a front walk made of brick. Some of these bricks are flaking, leaving shallow depressions on the front of the brick, as well as on the top of some. I have tried filling in these depressions, but the filling pulls out after one or two winters. The rest of the mortar is in excellent condition and the bricks are not crumbling. Is there any way of refacing these bricks, short of replacing them? A. Chances are that no patch will really last for many years, but you would have a better chance for longer-lasting ones if you use a vinyl- or epoxy-fortified patching cement. These patching materials bond better in thin layers, so they will last longer. However, for a permanent cure you will probably have to replace the bricks. Q. The stucco on the back of our house has turned partly green behind one of our shrubs. I suspect this is from the sprinkler water that strikes both the shrub and the house wall. Is there any way to remove this green stain from the stucco? A. The discoloration is probably from the green leaves rubbing against the stucco when the wind is blowing, especially when the foliage is wet. Try scrubbing the stains off with a stiff brush dipped into detergent solution. If this won't remove them, try scrubbing with a bleach solution (one part bleach to five parts water). Be sure to test this first in a small corner as it will lighten the finish and may cause the washed spot to stand out.

title: NORTH AMERICAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes capital gains of $263,969 and $397,833 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes capital gains of $384,025 and $786,209 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Gifts for Gardeners: Fanciful and Useful
description: IT doesn't matter if the gardener on your holiday list fancies house plants on a city sill or alpines in a country retreat. For the horticulturally inclined, ideas can range from practicalities like a sturdy trowel or a sleek watering can to the fanciful - a leaded-glass terrarium or a fine botanical print. Here are some gift possibilities for the gardener, all as close as the nearest mailbox or telephone. Early ordering is advised. Prices listed do not include shipping costs, which will vary. Lion Fountainhead A 10-inch cement lion head, light gray with a matte acrylic finish for weather resistance, is available as a fountainhead or a relief sculpture. It is $18.99, prepaid, from the Brooklyn Botanic Garden Shop, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11225; telephone 718-622-4433. British Garden Tools Of Enameled Steel A sturdy set of hand tools is essential for turning soil, digging and setting out transplants. The fork and trowel combine handles of ash wood with green-enameled carbon steel for durability and strength, and are $9.50 each at Zona, 97 Greene Street, New York, N.Y. 10012; telephone 212-925-6750, Swiss Watering Can To cope, decoratively, with thirsty plants, there is a cobalt-blue watering can of Swiss design made of heavy plastic. It holds nearly two quarts, has a long narrow spout that gets in under leaves, and costs $7.95. A larger size, with two-gallon capacity, is $15.95. Both are from Clapper's, 1125 Washington Street, West Newton, Mass. 02165; telephone 617-244-7909. A Terrarium Made of Leaded Glass Since its invention in the 19th century the terrarium has proved its worth as a practical indoor ornament. A case of leaded glass, 5 inches square at the base and 12 inches high at the tip of its pyramidal cap, is $60 from the New York Botanical Garden Shop at the I.B.M. Building, 590 Madison Avenue (57th Street), N.Y., N.Y. 10022; telephone 212-980-8544. Floral Wraps Whatever gift you chose, you can wrap it in an appropriate floral pattern from a booklet of 16 different designs by the 18th-century English botanical printmaker William Kilburn. Use the tear-out sheets individually, or give the booklet as a gift. It is $16.95, published by Harry N. Abrams, and is available, along with other gift wraps by artists, at bookstores or by phone from Abrams special sales department. In New York state, to order call 212-206-7715, ext 506; out of state call 800-345-1359. Flower Lithographs When not tending real plants, some gardeners amuse themselves with pictures of them. Limited editions of four lithographs of flowers, signed and numbered by the British horticulturist Graham Stuart Thomas, are available at $65 each. A folio lined with acid-free paper is included with purchases of two or more prints. Wayside Gardens, Hodges, S.C. 29695; telephone 800-845-1124. Miniature Roses With good light miniature roses will produce flowers indoors all winter on hybrids like ''Amy Rebecca'' (yellow), which costs $4.25, and ''Choochoo Centennial'' (pale pink), at $4. The plants come in three-inch-high pots of black-gray plastic. A collection of three species selected for their fragrance costs $10.95. Free catalogue is available from Rosehill Farm, Gregg Neck Road, Galena, Md. 21635; telephone 301-648-5538. Froggy Sundial The shadow of a bronze cattail counts the sunny hours on an eight-inch lily pad that also supports a bronze frog. It is $33 from Wind and Weather, Albion Street Water Tower, P.O. Box 2320, Mendocino, Calif. 95460; telephone 707-937-0323.

title: ENERGYNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $293,000 from a change in accounting method for revenue.

title: Amos Comay; Jewish Cultural Leader, 72
description: Amos Comay, a Pittsburgh businessman who was a member of several Jewish cultural and educational associations, died Nov. 12 in an automobile accident. He was 72 years old. He was president of the National Foundation for Jewish Culture from 1978 to 1982, and was a board member of the Council of Jewish Federations, the Jewish Education Services of North America and the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee.

title: ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $191,000 and $212,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The results include the company's 96 percent owned subsidiary, EVI Inc. generated net income of $287,000 on revenue of $5,231,000. Net income for the period from EVI Inc.'s inception, March 6, through Sept. 30 was $553,000 on revenue of $7,139,000.

description: b-Includes merger expenses of $300,000. c-Net loss

SOONER DEFENSE OF FLA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TWICE AS LESS. Black English and the Performance of Black Students in Mathematics and Science. By Eleanor Wilson Orr. 240 pages. Norton. $15.95.

title: Umpire Is Killed In Auto Mishap
description: Dick Stello, a National League umpire since 1968, was crushed to death today when the two cars he was standing between were hit by another car, the Florida Highway Patrol said.

title: CAMBRIDGE ANALYTICAL ASOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Manager Is Leaving Retirement Fund
description: As investment manager of the $40 billion California Public Employees Retirement System, Greta E. Marshall, 50 years old, guides the investment policy of one of the largest pools of assets in the country. But after two and a half years on the job, she has decided that the administrative responsibilities take too much time away from what she really likes best, investing.

title: A Lush Musical by Villa-Lobos
description: ''Magdalena,'' the only Broadway musical with a score by the Brazilian musical giant Heitor Villa-Lobos, occupies a singular niche in the annals of music-theater history. When the lavish folk operetta opened at the Ziegfeld Theater on Broadway on Sept. 20, 1948, after wildly successful engagements in Los Angeles and San Francisco, it was the most expensive show to have been produced on Broadway. When it disappeared 11 weeks later, there was not even a Broadway cast album to remember it by because of a musician's strike.

title: KEY RATES
Seizing of Truants Upheld
description: Detaining suspected truants is among the duties New York City police officers can legally carry out, the state's highest court ruled today. In a 6-1 decision written by Chief Judge Sol Wachtler, the Court of Appeals said the city's charter gives officers in New York City responsibility for guarding the ''public health'' and preventing ''the violation of all laws and ordinances in force in the city,'' Judge Wachtler wrote. That provision, the judge decided, gives police the power to act, in effect, as truant officers in some cases.

title: DE LARROCHA RECITAL
description: The pianist Alicia de Larrocha will perform works by Schumann, Mompou and Granados tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College, one block from the intersections of Nostrand and Flatbush Avenues. Tickets are $10 to $20. Information: (718) 434-1900.

title: Starting Children on a Lifelong Reading Habit; Television's Influence
description: To the Editor:

title: Views From Miami
description: As everyone knows, Miami is an odd place. It is definitely part of the United States, but it is also the capital of a misty Latin American republic called Exilia, Refugia or Nostalgia, according to choice. It lives steadily preoccupied with Cuba, some 90 miles and a world away, but Cuba can be approached from various directions.

title: New Attack on Iranian Nuclear Plant Is Reported
description: Iran said today that Iraqi warplanes had raided an unfinished nuclear power plant for the second time this week, and Iraq said it bombed three tankers in Iran's waters and shot down two enemy planes.

title: 1931 Bugatti Fetches Record Price in London
description: A 1931 Bugatti 41 Royale, owned originally by the Bugatti family, was sold yesterday for $9.8 million, a record at auction for an automobile. The buyer at the Christie's sale, held at London's Royal Albert Hall, was Nicholas Harley, a British vintage-car dealer.

title: Our Towns; Amid Growling, 14 Neurotics Try To Defeat Angst
description: ''This kind of neurotic behavior is not usually handled in groups,'' Dr. Perry Frantzman explained. His 14 patients were in a circle. The doctor had agreed to take them on because he knew otherwise it might mean death.

title: Perfect 11-0 Ending For Lockbaum Era
description: Gordie Lockbaum finished an incredible career, and Holy Cross finished its first unbeaten season since 1918 tonight.

title: Film: 'Boy From Calabria'
description: LUIGI COMENCINI'S ''Boy From Calabria,'' opening today at the Carnegie Screening Room, is an inoffensively sentimental Italian movie about a poor peasant boy's efforts to become a marathon runner, much to the horror of his hard-pressed father.

title: Economic Scene; Assumptions Of U.S. Growth
description: HOW valid are the assumptions that underlie the relatively hopeful forecast of most American economists and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris that the United States economy will continue growing slowly next year?

title: A British Policy on Hemophiliacs And Doctors Infected With AIDS
description: The British Government has made two public policy decisions this week that organizations representing AIDS-infected individuals are hailing as important and enlightened steps in dealing with the needs of AIDS-sufferers in Britain and in helping check the spread of the disease.

title: Mr. Gorbachev and Congress
description: It's certainly arguable whether inviting Mikhail Gorbachev to address a joint meeting of the United States Congress is a good idea. But indisputably the confused squabble between the White House and Congressional leaders over that invitation is a shameful global embarrassment.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 20, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: F.T.C. PURSUING TRUMP
description: The Federal Trade Commission has asked the Justice Department to prosecute Donald J. Trump, the New York developer and investor, for making use of a ''parking'' agreement to facilitate an acquisition.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf

title: U.P.I. PICKS TEAM OF NEW EDITORS
description: United Press International, which has reeled from crisis to crisis in its struggle to survive, announced yesterday that it was making its third change of top editors in less than a year.

title: On the Surest Footing
description: The most accurate kickers in National Football League history are playing right now. And two of them are performing for New York teams.

title: Bid for Tesoro
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, already the object of overtures from a Hong Kong oil-trading concern, said it had received an unsolicited $15-a-share takeover offer from Pentane Partners L.P., a New York investment group. The offer from Pentane, which owns 9.7 percent of Tesoro's stock, values Tesoro at $206 million. The large San Antonio-based oil and gas refiner, producer and marketer has about 13.7 million shares outstanding. The stock closed down 37.5 cents, at $11.25, in trading today before the offer was announced. Tesoro said it had referred the unsolicited proposal to a committee of its board. Earlier this month, Oakville N.V., a unit of Hong Kong-based Kuo Investment Ltd., said that it had raised its stake in Tesoro to 6.2 percent and that it might seek control.

title: DYNAMIC ACTING DUOS ON NEW YORK STAGES
description: One of the great joys of Laurence Olivier's professional life was watching John Gielgud and Ralph Richardson act together onstage. Seeing those two knights in tandem was ''a dream,'' observed Lord Olivier, ''a brilliant double act'' with ''all guns blazing.'' In modern theatrical history, there have, of course, been other twinned performances of the highest caliber, though perhaps not with the astonishing symbiosis - and contrast of opposites - of these theatrical eminences.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Weinberger Postscript
description: Amid the military pageantry of the farewell ceremony for Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger on Tuesday came a poignant reminder of military reality and a footnote to recent history.

title: 'Advid,' A Key to College
description: LEAD: It's that time of year and things don't look good for the kid. Your investment portfolio is down, and you won't be able to endow your alma mater with a new library. Your child has just scored in the low 300's on the S.A.T.'s and can't write an acceptable essay because you were too mean-spirited to buy a word processing program with thesaurus add-ons.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlas Corp., Princeton, N.J., a natural resources company, appointed Keith R. Hulley president of the mineral division.

title: Capital Gains Taxes: the Long and Short of It
description: To the Editor:

title: Monk and McFerrin Harmonize in Brooklyn
description: ''LAST spring I was feeling very strongly that I wanted to try something I'd never done before,'' Meredith Monk recalled the other day. ''So I called Bobby McFerrin and asked him if he wanted to do some singing together. We just started singing, and working out the best way to proceed. He likes to improvise from zero, whereas I like to have more of a structure. But our common ground was that we both loved the human voice. So we kept working until we had a series of songs that were free enough for him and structured enough for me. And in the process, we've had a great time. That's the main thing: we really enjoy singing together.''

title: Wayne Newton Libel Award Is Cut to $5 Million by Judge
description: A Federal district judge has reduced to $5.3 million the $22.8 million libel judgment that the entertainer Wayne Newton won against NBC, ruling that the evidence did not support Mr. Newton's assertion that television broadcasts linking him to organized crime figures had hurt his reputation or income.

title: William A. Sutherland; Law Firm Founder, 91
description: William Anderson Sutherland, a founding partner of Sutherland, Asbill & Brennan, an Atlanta and Washington law firm, died Nov. 7 of a heart attack at his home in Washington. He was 91 years old.

title: Dining Out Guide: Thanksgiving
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. THE BALLROOM, #253 West 28th Street (244-3005) - *(Nov. 8, 1985) This restaurant-cum-cabaret is holding its fifth annual Festival of the Birds on Thanksgiving Day. This means an unusual gamut on the menu: both wild and domestic turkey, goose, duck, quail, squab, pheasant and rock Cornish hen, all undergoing various preparations and served with vegetables and a salad. The prix-fixe menu - from $28.50 for domestic turkey to $42.50 for pheasant - also includes a choice of tapas from the long wooden tapas bar (Moroccan eggplant salad, baked squid, garlic sausages and the like) and a choice of pumpkin soup, black bean soup or turkey consomme. Seatings at 1, 3:30, 6 and 8:30 P.M. CAFE LUXEMBOURG, #200 West 70th Street (873-7411) - **(May 9, 1986) This Art Deco haute cafeteria offers sprightly, imaginatively executed food and genial service. From 2 to 8 P.M., the prix-fixe $37 four-course Thanksgiving Day meal is a tasteful orchestration of cream of wild mushroom soup, an oyster dish, roast young turkey with wild rice and cornbread stuffing, a Brussels sprout puree, baked sweet potatoes, an apple and cranberry relish and, finally, pumpkin cheesecake with brandy whipped cream. CAROLINA, #355 West 46th Street (245-0058) - *(Feb. 14, 1986) For Thanksgiving, this smart little restaurant, with its arching skylight, elegant banquettes and wraparound mirrored walls, will continue its tradition of focusing on regional American cuisine. From 1 to 8 P.M., for $40, one could put together a feast of, for example, black bean soup, crab cakes, roast pheasant with cornbread and apple stuffing, accompanied by maple walnut sweet potatoes, mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce and vegetable, and pecan pie. THE ODEON, #145 West Broadway, at Thomas Street (233-0507) - *(Aug. 29, 1986) This Art Deco former cafeteria, with its casual and stylish ambiance, good food and congenial service, would be an appealing spot to spend Thanksgiving Day. From 2 to 8 P.M., the prix-fixe menu of $35 includes four courses. Pumpkin soup with green peas and bacon lardons is followed by a fried oyster salad with a caper and cornichon dressing. The roasted young turkey is stuffed with cornbread and foie gras and garnished with cranberry mousse, mashed potatoes and green beans. Dessert offers a choice of a sour cream apple tart or pumpkin ice cream. THE SIGN OF THE DOVE, #1110 Third Avenue, at 65th Street (861-8080) -

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It will have an enormous effect on the floor of the House and the Senate and help us capture the votes we need to pass a compromise.'' - Representative Pat Williams, Democrat of Montana, on the prospect of automatic budget cuts. [ A1:6. ]

title: McCann Gets Studio Work
description: McCann-Erickson, New York, has been assigned the retail media account of Columbia Pictures for the New York region. The billings are around $10 million.

title: Nurse in L.I. Deaths Indicted on 3 Assault Counts
description: A Suffolk County grand jury indicted a 25-year-old nurse today on three counts of assault, and the authorities exhumed two bodies in what could become a multiple-homicide case against the nurse, Richard Angelo.

title: Talks Held By Bell & Howell
description: The Bell & Howell Company disclosed yesterday that it was negotiating with an investor group headed by Robert M. Bass of the wealthy Texas family on a management buyout of the publishing and information services company.

title: College Drug Test Barred
description: A Superior Court judge, declaring a National Collegiate Athletic Association drug-testing unconstitutional, today barred the N.C.A.A. from testing Stanford athletes for drugs, with the exception of the men's basketball and football teams, where limited testing, probably for cocaine and steroids, will be permitted.

title: TIFFANY TREASURES AND HOMEY WARES IN MODERNISM SHOW
description: FORESTS of Tiffany lamps cast a color-pulsing glow on Bauhaus chromed metal tables, Art Deco frosted-glass vases and vehemently Victorian carved desks. The bazaar called ''Modernism: a Century of Style and Design, 1860 to 1960,'' one of New York's youngest and liveliest antiques and decorative arts fairs, returned yesterday for its second visit to the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 66th Street. The show remains through Sunday. The wealth of furnishings from Rococo Revival through Italian Modern - including lighting, tablewares, paintings, sculpture, posters, jewelry, toys, radios and cameras - is far more varied than it was a year ago. Virtually all of the movers and shakers of design movements that have emerged over the last century are included in the presentation.

title: Hill Samuel Withdraws
description: Hill Samuel & Company said today that its brokerage would no longer act as a primary market maker in gilt-edged securities, as British Government bonds are called. Several other British brokerages have pulled out of the unprofitable gilts market in recent months. Hill Samuel said the move was part of a plan to sell or close its debt-trading activities.

title: At the Bar
description: The money might come from drug trafficking or insider trading or loan sharking or embezzlement. But until recently, two things about it were always true. First, no matter how ill-gotten it might be, the wrongdoer was always free to spend it on a lawyer. Second, that lawyer was always free to accept it - and keep it.

title: Auctions
description: Egyptian Goddesses

title: U.S. Communists May Not Field a 1988 Slate
description: The Communist Party U.S.A. is not likely to run candidates for President and Vice President next year to protest what it says is a ''very undemocratic electoral system'' in the United States, the party leader announced yesterday.

title: Rookie Scores 4 Goals
description: Joe Nieuwendyk, a rookie, scored four goals as the Calgary Flames routed the Quebec Nordiques tonight, 9-1.

title: Lives of Amerasian Children Studied on ABC's '20/20'
description: A father and daughter, strangers to each other, are united on ABC's ''20/ 20'' tonight. The father had fought in Vietnam; the daughter, in a way, was one of the war casualties. The program, on Channel 7 at 10 P.M., is touching.

title: The Board of Education Plays Truant
description: School may be the only source of stability in the lives of New York City's homeless children. Yet the city's Board of Education has lost track of several hundred school-age children in emergency hotels and shelters. No one checks up on them to make sure they go to class. Children already ''at risk'' are thus put in further jeopardy. That's inexcusable.

title: Canada Accord On Drug Bill
description: After an impasse of several months, the Canadian Government today enacted into law a measure sought by the United States that will give 10 years' patent protection to drug manufacturers marketing their products in Canada.

title: Rangers Lose To Stars
description: Marcel Dionne was correct: The Rangers should not have assumed that they could reproduce the work ethic that brought them out of their slump just by writing it into their game plan.

title: New York Bonds Upgraded Despite Worries on Economy
description: New York City's bond rating was raised yesterday to its highest level since 1975, despite concerns that recent declines in stock prices and employment at securities concerns would weaken the local economy and strain the city's financial condition.

title: MEXICO REASSURES PUBLIC ON ECONOMY
description: Mexico's Finance Minister appealed for confidence in the economy today as the peso fluctuated in chaotic trading after Wednesday's plunge.

title: Issue for '88: Who Is George Bush?
description: When Vice President Bush told reporters early this year that he had ''expressed reservations'' to the White House about the secret sale of arms to Iran, many officials in the Reagan Administration were surprised.

title: Tourists Face Mixed Picture
description: Americans traveling to Mexico may not see hotel rates or air fares reduced immediately by the plunging value of the peso, but they will be able to find shopping bargains, travel agents said yesterday.

title: Simon Discovers It's Lonely at the Top
description: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois found today that the problem with becoming a front-runner is that competitors start snapping at your heels.

title: Art: Paintings and Drawings by Andre Derain
description: IT has never been easy to make an exhibition of Andre Derain that validates the very high regard in which he was held by those who knew him. Derain the man was clearly a man of good will, a marvel of intelligence and the best of companions in the Louvre. As a young man, he wrote some of the most vivid and amusing of all artists' letters.

title: IN THE NIGHT
description: Choir in the Park

title: U.S. Catholic Bishops Set Policy Backing Central American Talks
description: The country's Roman Catholic bishops today threw their moral and political weight behind efforts to bring peace to Central American, in particular backing the mediation of their fellow prelate, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo of Nicaragua.

title: For Collectors, New Sites For Antiquities and Art
description: This was a bustling week for the antiques market in New York. Manhattan's newest and most elaborately designed antiques center - Place des Antiquaires, at 125 East 57th Street -opened to the public yesterday after many delays, and an ambitious show of period art, furnishings and decorations opened Wednesday at Didier Aaron, 32 East 67th Street.

title: A Reporter Brings Glasnost to Connecticut
description: After telling the Soviet television reporter what they knew about her country - it is part of both Europe and Asia and Moscow is its capital -the geography class at a school in the rural town of Litchfield had some questions.

title: Jewish Anger With Vatican Brings Postponement of Talks
description: A Catholic-Jewish conference scheduled to be held here next month to explore the role of the Roman Catholic Church in Europe during the Nazi Holocaust has been indefinitely postponed at the request of Jewish leaders who are angry about recent Vatican actions.

title: N.B.A.-TBS Extension
description: The National Basketball Association and the Turner Broadcasting System have reached a two-year contract extension granting TBS exclusive national cable rights to games through the 1989-90 season for $50 million. The fee is double that of the current contract, which expires at the conclusion of the present season.

title: What the Iran-Contra Committees Wish They Had Done Differently
description: While most members of the Iran-contra committees think their inquiry was a success, many of the lawmakers and their staff assistants say in hindsight that various aspects of the investigation should have been done differently.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Quarterback Is a Sore Spot
description: Injured quarterbacks abound this week, many of them limited in practice or not able to make it at all. They have hurt their ankles or shoulders or knees or egos. So the backups will become major factors Sunday. And that means teams with sophisticated defenses could fool some of the inexperienced second-stringers. Local Teams

title: Diner's Journal
description: NOT many restaurants serve the rustic French appetizer called rillettes de canard, which is a spread made with shredded duck and spices. At six-week-old L'Ecluse, a snug French bistro on Avenue of the Americas at King Street, a ramekin of delicious rillettes (this one combines duck and pork) comes as an appetizer along with grilled garlic toast and a little green salad. It is terrific with a bottle of Beaujolais, Cotes-du-Rhone or perhaps a gutsy Cahors from southwestern France.

title: O'NEILL STABLE AFTER SURGERY
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the former Speaker of the House, was alert and in stable condition today after undergoing surgery that removed a cancerous tumor, hospital officials said. The 74-year-old Massachusets Democrat un-derwent nearly seven hours of surgery for cancer of the rectum at Brigham and Women's Hospital on Wednesday. Doctors will not know until Friday if the cancer spread to other parts of the intestinal system.

title: Villa-Lobos Concert
description: The Villa-Lobos Music Society will present an all Villa-Lobos concert, including several premieres, tonight at 8 o'clock in Cami Hall (165 West 57th Street). Tickets are $10. Information: 427-5103.

title: Sports People; Paiement Demoted
description: Wilf Paiement, who has not played in the minor leagues since 1974, was assigned yesterday to the Muskegon Lumberjacks of the International Hockey League by the Piitsburgh Penguins.

title: Starting Children on a Lifelong Reading Habit; Written Words' Value
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: The Mets have signed Larry Milbourne, a former major-league infielder, as an instructor in their minor-league system. Milbourne, who retired after the 1985 season after 11 seasons in the big leagues, including two stints with the Yankees, will be assigned specific duties later. . . . Norm Drucker, former supervisor of officials for the National Basketball Association and the American Basketball Association, has been named assistant director of basketball operations in charge of officiating for the new International Basketball Association, the league for players who are 6 feet 4 inches and under. . . . Johnny Moore, who had played all of his seven N.B.A. seasons with San Antonio, was released by the Spurs in order to create a roster position for Charles Davis, who was acquired in a trade with Milwaukee. Moore, the Spurs' career leader with 3,783 assists, contracted desert fever two years ago and missed parts of the last two seasons, but completed medical treatments this summer. . . . Dick Crum will remain head football coach at North Carolina unless he chooses to relinquish the job, Athletic Director John Swofford announced yesterday. Crum, the leading coach in Tar Heel history with 72 victories in 10 seasons, has been criticized this season for his conservative offenses and failure to win big home games against Auburn and Clemson.

title: Bridge: Book by Australian Expert Is Filled With Good Advice
description: If an intermediate player is considering buying a bridge book, he is entitled to ask, ''How much will it tell me that I did not know before?'' The answer may be, ''Nothing, a little, quite a lot or a great deal.''

title: If Reagan Were F.D.R.
description: The immediate economic outlook hinges on confidence. Will consumers, businesses and investors continue their healthy patterns of spending and investment or will Black Monday and its aftermath frighten them into retrenchment and bring on recession, or worse?

title: 43.77 Drop Sends Dow Below 1,900
description: Stocks continued their seesaw course yesterday, falling broadly amid worries that a deficit-reduction plan would not be reached. The Dow Jones industrial average, which rose nearly 17 points on Wednesday, plunged 43.77 points, or 2.26 percent, to close below 1,900.

title: Savvy Record Chief for Sony
description: As one of the world's largest manufacturers of consumer electronics, the Sony Corporation knows plenty about the hardware side of the music business. But it has had little experience with the recording side, which includes the delicate task of handling temperamental artists.

title: Singer in Talks
description: Pressing its defense against a $1.1 billion takeover bid from Paul A. Bilzerian, the Singer Company said it had begun preliminary discussions with a number of domestic and foreign companies. Singer added that it could not give any assurance that anything would develop. Singer said it had begun talking to suitors ''as a possible alternative'' to the Florida corporate raider's $50-a-share tender offer and had been furnishing these suitors with confidential data on Singer. As he did in several other unsuccessful takeover bids, Mr. Bilzerian would profit heavily if he were outbid for Singer. He heads a group with 9.99 percent of the company. T. Boone Pickens, the Texas corporate raider, is the leader of a separate group with a similar stake in Singer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1987
description: International A3-13 khail S. Gorbachev, to address a joint meeting of Congress when he is in Washington next month was strongly criticized by Republican Congressional leaders. Page A1

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Wednesday gave an incorrect figure for the amount of omega-3 fatty acids in certain fish.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Experts Declined
description: George Washington University turned down a request from White House officials to allow the press corps to use the university's gym as a media center for the upcoming visit of the Soviet Leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but that doesn't mean the university would mind having some of its experts in Soviet culture be used as press sources.

title: Rosario Hopes Stock Keeps Rebounding
description: In August 1980, Wilfredo Gomez, the World Boxing Council superbantamweight champion, knocked out Derrik Holmes in five rounds in a nationally televised bout.

title: Report Doubles the Estimate Of U.S. Radiation Exposure
description: New calculations of the average amount of radiation an American is exposed to in a year have doubled the estimate. For the first time, the calculations include the effects of radon gas seeping into houses.

title: SAVINGS ENVISIONED IN HOME AIDS CARE
description: The cost of caring for some AIDS patients could be reduced to less than $100 a day from about $800 a day if public and private health insurance plans would pay for home care of AIDS patients, health care officials say.

title: Sports People; Alcohol Awareness
description: A series of mandatory lectures on drinking and driving is being lined up for Minnesota Vikings players by General Manager Mike Lynn after the arrests of several players for drunken driving.

title: NEW LAWYERS: WHERE THEY WORK
description: The growth of large law firms and the salaries they pay is having a logical effect: in a survey of 1986 law school graduates, the National Association for Law Placement has found that 61.6 percent entered private practice, the highest percentage since the association started keeping records in 1974, when 52.2 percent went into private practice.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Not Off the Record
description: When William E. Brock 3d took over as chairman of Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign two weeks ago he stressed the need for an ''open campaign.''

title: Starting Children on a Lifelong Reading Habit
description: To the Editor:

title: Gas Company to Cut Rates
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company has agreed to lower its rates by $8.2 million or 1.6 percent a year, Governor Cuomo's office announced today. The agreement, worked out between the utility and state officials, will mean a savings of about $1.20 a month through Oct. 1, 1989 for the typical Brooklyn Union customer, the Governor's office said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 25 about a program to assign police liaison officers to some New York City hospitals incorrectly described the history of the program at Bellevue Hospital Center. A liaison officer has been assigned to Bellevue for many years.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES TO END PANAMA AID
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, increasing American pressure on Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, voted unanimously today to cut off all but humanitarian aid to Panama until civilian rule is restored.

title: Pressure On Broker Fees Seen
description: At a closed-door meeting in New York this week, executives controlling several hundred billion dollars of corporate pension funds vowed to take steps to reduce the amounts they pay Wall Street brokers and investment management organizations.

title: Senate Waste Proposal Upsets House Panels
description: Influential House committee chairmen are upset over Senate legislation that would scuttle a plan establishing two dump sites for the accumulating tons of high-level nuclear waste.

title: INSIDE
description: New on Fridays: The Law Page

title: At the Movies
description: Mora's 'Communion'

title: KNICKS BEATEN AS NETS RALLY
description: As the Knicks broke out of their timeout huddle with 4 minutes 56 seconds remaining in the fourth period tonight, holding a lead of 101-93 over the Nets, Coach Rick Pitino's final words were, ''Forget the score, keep playing offense.''

title: Deaver's Client Tells of Business Call From Plane
description: Three months after he left his post as White House deputy chief of staff in 1985 to become a private lobbyist, Michael K. Deaver apparently used the radio telephone on Nancy Reagan's official airplane to conduct his consulting business, witnesses at Mr. Deaver's perjury trial said today.

title: Art: Gothic Sculpture of Giovanni Pisano at Met
description: ''GIOVANNI PISANO IN GENOA'' is a slightly smaller version of a show that took place this spring in Genoa. It brings together the recently restored marble fragments of the last two works by Giovanni Pisano, the great Gothic sculptor who had never before had an exhibition in the United States. There are around 20 works, some by Pisano's contemporaries and students. Tucked away in the Robert Lehman Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, it is an example of how informative a limited show can be.

title: Advertising; Lintas's 'Hot' Idea For Lipton
description: ''WE'RE out to make hot tea hot,'' exclaimed Susan Read, effusive executive vice president and executive creative director of Lintas:New York, as she turned to the VCR to bring the new campaign for Lipton tea to the screen. It was, she promised, a big idea. In any event it was big enough to supplant Don Meredith, the one-time Dallas Cowboys quarterback who had been spokesman for the flow-through tea bags for more than a decade. The new campaign, at the moment two 30-second spots and a 60, is shooting at the younger side of the 18-to-54-year-old target audience but will continue to use daytime and prime-time network TV to reach them.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ONCE UPON A TIME, ETC.

title: Jersey Parkway Plans to Double Its 25-Cent Tolls
description: The New Jersey Highway Authority voted today to double the 25-cent tolls on the Garden State Parkway.

title: Stage: 'House Arrest'
description: LET writers of other epochs contemplate the myths of antiquity or the deaths of kings as they struggle with the fine points of existence. For American playwrights of a certain generation, ''I Love Lucy'' is a deeper commentary on the family constellation than ''Oedipus''; ''Wheel of Fortune'' says more about democracy's drift than ''Leaves of Grass.'' To these dramatists - and they are legion right now - the Rosetta Stone of human behavior and aspiration is not the Old Testament or even ''Ulysses'' but the labyrinthine listings of TV Guide. Only last week, one of the pioneers of the genre, Christopher Durang, unveiled a new comedy at Playwrights Horizons, ''Laughing Wild,'' which telescopes many of the life-and-death philosophical concerns of our age into a parodistic episode of the Sally Jessie Raphael talk show.

title: Koch Modifies Proposal For New Units in Bronx
description: Mayor Koch yesterday scaled back his proposal for 1,000 new apartments for middle-income New Yorkers in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, in the hopes of winning the Board of Estimate's approval for the disputed plan.

title: Lebanese Suspect Linked to '85 T.W.A. Hijacking
description: A Lebanese citizen awaiting trial in the United States on charges that he took part in the June 1985 hijacking of a Jordanian airliner was also involved in the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet the same month, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Senate Panel Backs Burnley
description: The Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee today approved the nomination of James H. Burnley 4th as Transportation Secretary and sent it to the full Senate for confirmation. The committee also approved Mary Ann Dawson, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, to replace Mr. Burnley as Deputy Secretary of Transportation. Both nominations were passed by voice vote without objection.

title: 18th-Century Music
description: The Orchestra of the 18th Century will perform at the Fine Arts Center of the State University campus at Stony Brook, L.I., tomorrow at 8 P.M. Tickets are $14 to $18. Information and directions: (516) 632-7235.

title: Washington Talk: The Iran-contra Hearings; ALL OVER BUT THE CLEARING-OUT OF PIECES OF HISTORY
description: For the 181 lawyers, investigators, clerks and secretaries on the staffs of the Iran-contra Congressional committees it is all over but the cleanup - a 10-month whirlwind in which strangers came together and shaped a piece of history, ''It's a once in a lifetime experience - once you do this, what could ever be as exciting again?'' said Richard Leon, deputy Republican counsel to the House committee.

title: Uganda Reports a Clash
description: Ugandan Government forces killed 30 rebels Wednesday when the guerrillas ambushed a military convoy near the eastern town of Mbale, army sources said. They said nine soldiers guarding the 21-vehicle convoy and seven civilians were also killed.

title: Reagan and Democrats Split On Using Pressure on Haiti
description: The Reagan Administration and a small group of Democratic Congressmen are divided over how the United States should use its leverage to insure a free and fair election in Haiti this month.

title: British Gas Drops Bow Valley Offer
description: British Gas P.L.C. called off its bid of $940 million (Canadian), or $717 million (United States), for a controlling interest in Bow Valley Industries. But British Gas said it would try to modify its offer to satisfy shareholders and the Canadian Government, and analysts said the Canadian energy company was still vulnerable to a takeover by another suitor.

title: Capitol Gains Taxes: the Long and Short of It
description: To the Editor:

title: Duro-Test Refusal
description: The board of the Duro-Test Corporation said it had rejected a tender offer of $14 a share, or $66 million, from a partnership led by William P. Lyons, a Yale University professor, and said it was considering a sale of the company to a third party or in a leveraged buyout. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Duro-Test said it had provided information about the company to others who had expressed an interest in the light bulb manufacturer, based in North Bergen, N.J. The company had rejected a $13-a-share offer from the partnership, the TCA Acquisition Corporation. Duro-Test's shares closed unchanged at $14.125 today.

title: Numbers Game Flourishes Despite Lotteries and Raids
description: Despite police raids and the advent of state lotteries and offtrack betting, numbers - a time-honored form of illegal gambling as easy as buying a pack of cigarettes - continues to thrive in poor neighborhoods of New York City.

title: Godfrey Bloch; Manufacturer, 86
description: Godfrey Bloch, a former carpet manufacturer, died at Lenox Hill Hospital on Wednesday. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: L.I. Man Found Slain Near Queens Highway
description: A Long Island man was shot to death gangland style early yesterday in Bayside, Queens, and the police said he might have been an associate in the Colombo organized-crime family.

title: G.O.P. Leaders Oppose Address By Gorbachev
description: Republican Congressional leaders today strongly criticized a proposal to invite Mikhail S. Gorbachev to address a joint meeting of Congress.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a mur-der suspect who was fatally shot in a struggle with two New York City Po-lice detectives misidentified the sus-pect and the detective who shot him. The suspect was Stephen Randol; the detective was Mark Hembury.

title: CITING BIAS ORDER, U.S. CURBS YONKERS ON AID TO BUILDERS
description: A Federal judge yesterday barred Yonkers from aiding ing commercial and residential development until the city complies with his desegregation order by planning new public housing.

title: Doubles Match Steals Show
description: This was one night when the sneak preview took top billing over the featured attraction. What a pair of quarterfinal matches of the Virginia Slims championships lacked in intrigue, drama and excitement was more than compensated for in a doubles confrontation between the team of Steffi Graf and Gabriela Sabatini against Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver. Forehands and backhands were the language spoken, one understood by all.

title: New Compound Seen as Weapon Against Tumors
description: Researchers at the National Institutes of Health said today that an amino acid compound had proved in laboratory tests to be a ''very, very promising'' drug for the treatment of tumors.

title: Washington Talk: The Summit Meeting; Capital Trying to Squeeze In Visitors
description: The summit meeting is less than three weeks away and much of this city is in a bit of a dither.

title: Crazy Eddie Deficit In Inventory Found
description: The new managers of Crazy Eddie Inc. said yesterday that they had discovered an inventory shortfall estimated at $45 million and that the consumer electronics retailer expected a ''substantial'' third-quarter loss.

title: British Plan Inquiry Into Subway Fire
description: As transportation experts and opposition politicians pointed to possible safety lapses, the Government announced today that it would hold an inquiry into a fire that killed 30 people at London's busiest subway station.

title: President Gets Compromise Military Measure
description: The Senate today approved legislation establishing military programs, at a cost of up to $296 billion, that restricts President Reagan's space-based anti-missile program and halts missile deployments that exceed a 1979 treaty limiting strategic arms.

title: Film: Streisand In 'Nuts'
description: IN ''Nuts,'' Barbra Streisand has the kind of downscale role that has been known to win Oscars, a role in which a star forsakes her usual cocoon for the mud streaks, the tattered clothes, the rude invective that prove she has grit. Luckily, Miss Streisand's performance is better than that, but it's the showboating aspects of ''Nuts'' that attract the most attention.

title: Dance: Armitage Ballet
description: ''STRETCH your arm no farther than your sleeve,'' as the old French saying goes.

title: Film: 'Teen Wolf Too,' Family Curse
description: WHEN a clean-cut college student turns into a werewolf, he does unspeakable things. Nothing violent, but this monster cuts classes! He starts hanging around with a frivolous crowd - oh, no! college students who like to dance! - so his jilted girlfriend confronts him in biology class. ''They don't like you, only the wolf,'' she warns. Then she throws her frog at him.

title: Record Federal Bailout For Texas Savings Unit
description: Federal regulators pledged $1.3 billion today to resolve the difficulties of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association in Dallas, the largest such Government bailout of a savings institution.

title: Lee Byung Chull, 77, Industrialist of Korea
