description: Lee Byung Chull, chairman and founder of the Samsung Group and one of the fathers of modern industrial South Korea, died of lung cancer today. He was 77 years old. Mr. Lee started his business in 1938 and rebuilt it after the Korean War into a high-technology manufacturer and South Korea's first major trading company.

title: Former Belfast Councilman Critically Hurt in a Shooting
description: A former Protestant city councilman who once said Roman Catholics should be burned was shot in the head and critically wounded today, the police said.

title: More Killings Laid to Police In Argentina
description: What the judicial authorities describe as a kidnapping-for-ransom network within the Argentine federal police force has come to light with the discovery in recent days of the bodies of three missing businessmen.

title: Westfield Symphony
description: The Westfield Symphony will give a free performance of works by Mahler and Tchaikovsky tomorrow at 2 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The symphony, based in Westfield, N.J., and conducted by Brad Keimach, will perform Mahler's Symphony No. 4 and Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto. The soloists are Peter Winograd, violinist, and Cheryl Parrish, soprano. Information: 247-7800.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; I.R.S. Snips Snacks
description: It's now official. The Internal Revenue Service had ruled that Election Night parties, assuming they are given by a candidate's campaign committee for the candidate's campaign workers, are an ''exempt function'' under Section 527(e)(2) of the tax code.

title: Piedmont Orders Warning Devices for Airliners
description: Piedmont Airlines today became the first airline to order devices for its planes to warn against collisions. The Government has said it will require the equipment on all large airliners by 1991 or 1992.

title: Bid Fails to Block Custody of Boy
description: An appellate judge in Manhattan strongly rejected a bid yesterday by Joel B. Steinberg and Hedda Nussbaum to prevent the biological mother of 17-month-old Mitchell Steinberg from taking custody of him.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Prices Up Slightly
description: Prices of Treasury debt issues moved slightly higher yesterday in what dealers described as the slowest session of an uncommonly dull week, as market participants continued to wait for the Administration and Congress to resolve their differences over the Federal budget deficit.

title: Detective Cites an Admission Of Beating in Howard Beach
description: A defendant in the Howard Beach murder and assault trial admitted the day after the incident that he and two other white teen-agers beat one of three black men involved in the case, a detective testified yesterday.

title: Occidental in Joint Deal To Build Plant in Soviet
description: The Occidental Petroleum Company, in a consortium with an Italian chemical company and a Japanese trading house, signed an agreement today with Moscow to build a petrochemical plant near the Caspian Sea that could cost as much as $6 billion.

title: TV Weekend; Three Wimsey Dramatizations, on 13
description: PUBLIC television's ''Mystery!'' series, broadcast on Channel 13 Saturdays at 9 P.M., is heading into the stretch this weekend of what has turned out to be a first-rate Dorothy L. Sayers festival. Dramatizations of three of her Lord Peter Wimsey novels have been scheduled back to back, the collection recounting, even as assorted mysteries have to be solved, Lord Peter's persistent wooing of Harriet Vane, herself an Oxford-educated writer of mystery novels. Skillful adaptations and splendid performances in the lead roles by Edward Petherbridge and Harriet Walter, both members of the Royal Shakespeare Company, have made these BBC productions exceptionally clever exercises.

title: Restaurants
description: A SPLENDID Provencal flower has taken root in the craggy industrial terrain of TriBeCa. Called Bouley, it is the creation of the French-schooled David Bouley, who made his mark at nearby Montrachet. The three-month-old restaurant has the potential for greatness, although a wobbly kitchen prevents it from reaching its potential.

title: The Quarterback Who's Now Crucial
description: STILL breathing hard after a practice last week in Norman, Okla., Charles Thompson was saying that nothing had changed in his existence as a quarterback for the football team at the University of Oklahoma.

title: Goldman, Sachs Layoffs
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company laid off several employees yesterday in two divisions.

title: Recycling of New York City's Garbage Is Safer Than Incineration
description: To the Editor:

title: Film: Prince in 'Sign o' the Times'
description: ''SIGN O' THE TIMES,'' which opens today at the Warner and other theaters, is mostly a concert film, but it also plays like science fiction: a visit to the Prince planet, where life is strange indeed. And madly, viscerally exciting, peopled by red-hot, inexhaustible Princelings whose onstage excesses become the perfect backdrop for the star's own antics. Prince himself, this time with a retinue as crazily galvanizing as Sly Stone's, has never seemed more the man of vision, however fanciful and impudent that vision may be. Anyone who has not yet had occasion to take Prince seriously will find ''Sign o' the Times'' a real surprise.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the high level of oil imports incorrectly described the Institute for International Economics. The Washington-based group is a nonprofit research organization, financed by foundations, corporations and government.

title: Films From the 30's
description: Two films from the 1930's by the French director Pierre Chenal - an adaptation of Dostoyevsky's ''Crime and Punishment,'' and ''The Man From Nowhere,'' a comedy based on Pirandello's ''Late Mathias Pascal'' - will be screened through Thursday at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street. The actor Pierre Blanchar was featured in both films; at the 1935 Venice Film Festival, he was named best actor for his role as Raskolnikov in ''Crime and Punishment.'' Both films are new prints and have English subtitles. Screenings this weekend begin today at 4 P.M. Admission is $5 for the double bill. Information: 431-1590.

title: United Nations Journal; On World Stage, a Wake, and a Villain in the Wings
description: This year's General Assembly session opened on an upbeat note, with a Security Council peace initiative in the Persian Gulf and signs that the United Nations was shaking off its reputation as a hot air machine, grinding out endless resolutions that no one reads, much less acts on.

title: Verity Urges Shift by Japan
description: United States Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. accused Japan of seeking to destroy foreign industries in the past with floods of exports and said the practice must be stopped, Japanese officials said today.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 411 money market mutual funds increased $1.54 billion, to $262.91 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 111 institutional funds were up $781.2 million, to $74.37 billion. Assets of the 207 general-purpose funds were up $294.5 million, to $79.12 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds increased $459.4 million, to $109.42 billion.

title: Thomas W. Eglin, 55, Dean at Lawrenceville
description: Thomas W. Eglin, the dean of students at the Lawrenceville School, died of a brain tumor Wednesday at his home in Lawrenceville, N.J. He was 55 years old.

title: Lincoln Journal
description: Lettered high on the tall facade of Nebraska Stadium here is a noble tenet: ''Courage, generosity, fairness: These are the true awards of manly sport.''

title: Film: 'Honeymoon,' Frenchwoman in Manhattan
description: ''HONEYMOON'' was made in English, but it seems to have been designed as a cautionary tale for European audiences, a warning about hellish New York. It stars Nathalie Baye, and from the first shots of Miss Baye's trim little high-heeled legs making their way through ruffian-filled Manhattan, it's clear that this gentle French heroine is desperately out of place.

title: Biden Says Final Vote on Court Nominee Is Unlikely Until February
description: The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that, although he expected the confirmation process for Judge Anthony M. Kennedy to ''move pretty swiftly,'' the full Senate was unlikely to vote on his nomination to the Supreme Court until early February.

title: News Corp. Profits Rise
description: The News Corporation, the media group headed by Rupert Murdoch, today reported a 31 percent jump in after-tax profits for the first quarter, ended Sept. 30.

title: Allegis to Prepay Big Boeing Note
description: The Allegis Corporation, parent corporation of United Airlines, has agreed to prepay a $700 million convertible note issued by the Boeing Company last spring when United placed an order for 36 Boeing jets. Boeing said Allegis would be required to pay the $700 million plus accrued interest of $50 million before Jan. 5.

title: Judge Removes a Juror Holding Out for Acquittal
description: An 11-member jury convicted six defendants on drug charges yesterday shortly after a Federal judge, in an unusual action, removed the lone juror who had been holding out for acquittal.

title: Art: Martin Kippenberger Sculptures
description: SCULPTURE is so abundant in New York art galleries these days that it may well qualify as the season's dominant art form. Nowhere is it more plentiful than at Metro Pictures in SoHo, where Martin Kippenberger's exhibition threatens to spill out onto the street. Mr. Kippenberger, a 34-year-old artist who lives in Cologne, West Germany, has exhibited paintings and sculpture in Europe for nearly a decade. His paintings were seen at Metro Pictures in 1985. The current exhibition, the first in New York of his sculpture, resembles, upon first encounter, an overcrowded fire sale. The show has an air of disarming nonchalance and irrationality. This accounts for its strength - a careening, chaotic energy - and also for its frequent descents into self-indulgent silliness.

title: MARCOVICCI: ESSENCE OF ROMANCE
description: ''THERE is a Portuguese word, saudades, that means nostalgia for people, places and things that may never have existed,'' Andrea Marcovicci said the other day. ''In my singing, I've stretched that to mean nostalgia for a time we never lived in. My father was 63 and my mother 29 when I was born. Because he was a creature from another era, I grew up surrounded by musical influences that were not of my own time. To me, Fred Astaire is the essence of romance.''

title: Coach Has 2 Winners
description: Anson Dorrance, the head coach of both the men's and the women's varsity soccer teams at the University of North Carolina, may face an unusual decision Saturday night.

title: U.S. Doctor Challenged on Brazil Radiation Aid
description: An American physician's assertion that he led an international medical team treating victims of a recent radiation accident here has been challenged by American diplomats and Brazilian doctors and officials.

title: Art People
description: Glasnost for Lunch

title: CONTRAS SPURNING BID FOR CEASE-FIRE
description: Senior contra officials say that they reject a recent Sandinista cease-fire proposal and that they will probably make a counterproposal to an intermediary for the Nicaraguan Government sometime next week.

title: Jets Will Get a Close Look at Bennett
description: Cornelius Bennett wishes people would stop comparing him with Lawrence Taylor. But Kurt Sohn, who will run against Bennett on Sunday, said today there wasn't any comparison.

title: Wherehouse Bid
description: Shamrock Holdings Inc. said it planned a hostile tender offer of $12 a share, or $91.9 million, for the interest it does not already own in Wherehouse Entertainment Inc. In addition, Shamrock, based in Burbank, Calif., sued Wherehouse in a state court over the company's anti-takeover plan. Wherehouse, one of the nation's largest video, record and computer software chains, rejected an unsolicited $14.25-a-share bid from Shamrock last month. Its stock closed today at $10.375, up $1.875. Analysts said Wherehouse, based in Torrance, Calif., might be on the rebound after two years of poor earnings. Shamrock, an investment vehicle for the Roy E. Disney family, owns 10.17 percent of Wherehouse and hinted that it might be willing to sweeten its bid.

title: 3 OFFICIALS SUE KOCH ON SHELTERS
description: The Borough Presidents of Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx yesterday sued Mayor Koch and the Board of Estimate, of which they are members, to stop the Mayor's plan to build shelters for the homeless in their boroughs.

title: Violin-Piano Duo
description: Avram Weiss, a violinist, and Joseph Seiger, a pianist, will perform works by Handel, Grieg, Bach, Kreisler, Bloch and others on Sunday at 8 P.M. in Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street). Tickets are $12, or $6 for students and the elderly. Information: 362-8719.

title: Official Support Growing for Haitian Election
description: With 10 days remaining before the scheduled date for presidential elections in Haiti, election officials say the Government has finally begun lending its support, and concern about a possible postponement appears to be fading.

title: Peru Extends Emergency
description: The Government extended a 60-day state of emergency in 18 provinces in the southern Andes today to combat Maoist guerrillas.

title: Plan for School Review Is Criticized by Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo last night criticized and refused to participate in a ''sweeping review'' of the New York City school system by the State Board of Regents.

title: On Stage
description: Big Money From a Small Country

title: Louisiana Governor-Elect Acts Early
description: Louisiana's Governor-elect, Buddy Roemer, faced with a four-month waiting period before he takes office and with a budget crisis that he said would empty state coffers by Inauguration Day, moved this week to try to get control over state policy and spending.

title: Champion International Selects Next President
description: L. Clark Heist, who has been with the Champion International Corporation for 30 years, has been named president and chief operating officer, effective Dec. 1.

title: DEFENDENT TELLS OF ONE NIGHT IN THE HOSPITAL WARD
description: J. Angelo made the following written statements to the Suffolk County police: FIRST STATEMENT

title: Delta Jet Lands in Honolulu After Losing Power in Engine
description: A Delta Air Lines jet with 112 people aboard lost power in an engine over the Pacific but landed safely after flying 400 miles on its two remaining engines with a military escort, officials said today.

title: Award and Job Set By Magazine Publishers
description: The Magazine Publishers of America yesterday heralded the names of the 1987 Publisher of the Year and of the group's new executive vice president/ marketing development.

title: REAGAN PLANNING TO CUT SPENDING ON DEADLINE TODAY
description: The White House said today that President Reagan would put $23 billion in automatic spending cuts into effect to reduce the Federal budget deficit even if Administration and Congressional negotiators agree on alternatives before the Friday deadline.

title: Starting Children on a Lifelong Reading Habit; Textbooks' Objectives
description: To the Editor:

title: Shultz Is Expected to Meet Shevardnadze Next Week
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet next week in Geneva with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, to resolve remaining differences on a missile treaty and to review the agenda for the summit meeting next month, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a rehearsal for a concert production of Heitor Villa-Lobo's ''Magdalena'' misidentified the woman standing at left. She was Dona D. Vaughn, co-col-laborator and director of the musical.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: From Courtroom Wars, Battle Fatigue
description: John Martel has stalked the courtrooms of America for 28 years, compiling a record other lawyers admit places him in the upper realms of America's top corporate trial lawyers. In an era when few cases reach final trial, Mr. Martel has battled nearly 100 to conclusion, representing such major clients as the Bank of America and the Hearst Corporation.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE VELVET PRISON: Artists Under State Socialism. By Miklos Haraszti.

title: 2 Chosen to Lead New Gillette Units
description: The Gillette Company created two new operating units from three existing groups yesterday and said each would be led by a vice chairman.

title: 1,155 G.M. LAYOFFS
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would indefinitely lay off about 1,155 of its hourly employees in January, when it will slow auto production at three of its United States plants. The cut would increase the company's list of indefinitely laid-off workers by 2.5 percent. A Lansing, Mich., plant that makes the Buick Skylark and Oldsmobile Cutlass will lay off 850 of its 4,350 workers. The Bowling Green, Ky., plant that makes the Chevrolet Corvette will lay off 225 of 1,300 employees. The Pontiac, Mich., plant that produces the Pontiac Fiero will lay off 80 of 1,200 employees.

title: Topics of The Times; Cruelty in the Name of Life
description: Several years ago, having listened hard to America's right-to-lifers, the Reagan Administration found a way to throw them a bone. The Agency for International Development would not renew its contract with Planned Parenthood unless the birth control agency pledged not to help any overseas programs that also offer abortion services. Never mind that Planned Parenthood has at no time used grants for abortion programs in this country. Or that this and similar Administration initiatives added up to an abandonment of America's long commitment to helping poor nations control population growth.

title: Let Moscow Expose Stalin's Wave of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Samuel Engle Burr Jr.; Professor, 89
description: Dr. Samuel Engle Burr Jr., a former professor of education at the American University in Washington, died Monday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 89 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Film: 'Last Emperor,' an Epic
description: PU YI (1906-1967), the last Manchu emperor of China, came to the Dragon Throne at the age of 2 and some months. Four years later, the prince regent, Pu Yi's father, was forced to abdicate all imperial authority to republican forces. The boy-emperor continued to stay on in lonely, unreal splendor in Beijing's Forbidden City for another decade or so. He was attended by 1,500 eunuchs, the various members of his extended household, their hangers-on and, toward the end, by Reginald Johnston, his faithful and sometimes acerbic British tutor, a Scot with a deep admiration for Chinese civilization and nothing but ridicule for salvation-mongering Christian missionaries.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Down 8.8% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short and not yet covered in the month ended Nov. 13 decreased from the previous month by 44.7 million shares, or 8.8 percent, to 465.5 million.

title: Sports of The Times; Cup Running Over With Lasix?
description: MORE than anyone else, the nation's horse breeders should care about the medication crisis in thoroughbred racing. Instead, when they present their $10 million Breeders' Cup extravaganza at Hollywood Park tomorrow, they will be perpetuating the sport's most unsavory aspect.

title: Russians Tour U.S. Chemical Arms Stockpile
description: Six Soviet scientists and diplomats toured a chemical weapons installation in the western Utah desert today, an event that some officials said could lead to a treaty banning the weapons.

title: Taylor Remains A Question Mark
description: Will he or won't he? Will Lawrence Taylor, despite an injured hamstring, be well enough to play for the Giants Sunday against the Saints in New Orleans?

title: 56 HURT AS BUS RAMS INTO STORE AFTER COLLISION
description: Fifty-six passengers on a city bus in Brooklyn were injured yesterday morning when, after a collision with a car, the bus driver swerved to avoid a crowded bus stop and crashed into a storefront, the police said.

title: Sports People; World Cup Bid
description: The United States made a formal request yesterday to host the 1994 World Cup Championship. President Reagan made the bid in a meeting with Joao Havelange, president of FIFA, soccer's governing body, at the White House.

title: About Real Estate; A 20's Feature Returns: The Servants' Quarters
description: Around the turn of the century, in a period of opulence somewhat similar to today's, it became customary for builders to include servants' quarters in middle-class houses in the growing industrial cities of the Northeast. That practice continued until the Depression, when homes and living styles started to grow simpler.

title: Elizabeth Corday Producer, 75
description: Elizabeth Corday, the longtime executive producer of the daytime drama ''Days of Our Lives,'' died of respiratory failure Monday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center here. She was 75 years old.

title: Concert: Julie Andrews
description: NEAR the end of her one-woman retrospective show at the Westbury Music Fair, Julie Andrews sings a piece of special material called ''50 Words or Less,'' by Larry Grossman and Buzz Kohaan, in which she rattles off a list of adjectives that have been applied to her. They range from ''sweet'' to ''wholesome'' to ''cold.'' Miss Andrews caps the song with her own adjective, ''lucky.'' Indeed, in hearing her tell her story, one has the sense that at 52 years old, Miss Andrews is a contemporary ''Cinderella'' living out a happily-ever-after existence.

title: New Intimidation in Chile
description: Fourteen years after Gen. Augusto Pinochet's military coup destroyed democracy in Chile, his reign of terror not only is continuing but has noticeably worsened in the last month.

title: Film: 'Jean Renoir'
description: ''Jean Renoir, the Boss'' was shown as part of the 1985 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 5, 1985. The film opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema.

title: Film: 'Loyalties,' On Friends
description: ''Loyalties'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times March 21. The film opens today at the Quad Cinema.

title: Campus Rally for Yeltsin, a Rare Sight
description: Several hundred students gathered Tuesday at Moscow State University in an unusual expression of public concern over the Soviet hierarchy's ouster of the popular Moscow Communist Party chief, according to a participant.

title: Season of Worry for El Paso Stores
description: The $14 slacks and blue jeans are stacked high at the Starr Western Wear store here, a few blocks from the Mexican border, in preparation for the annual rush of holiday shoppers.

title: The Budget Deficit Disgrace
description: The stock market collapse and the dollar's decline created the urgent need and the opportunity for Washington to prove that tough budget issues could be resolved through bipartisan negotiation, that national interests could transcend parochial ones. Now, after a month of buck-passing, Congressional and White House leaders propose to reduce the deficit by less than the automatic cuts scheduled in the Gramm-Rudman law, and to run away from the hard and necessary decisions.

title: Bundesbank's Rate Silence
description: The Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, made no announcement today about its short-term interest rates after a meeting of its central committee. Many economists had predicted that the bank would announce a reduction today.

title: Christopher Wilmarth, 44, Dies; Sculptor Is an Apparent Suicide
description: Christopher Wilmarth, a critically acclaimed sculptor whose works are on permanent display at many of the nation's best-known museums, apparently hanged himself yesterday in his studio-home in Brooklyn, the police said. He was 44 years old.

title: Topics of The Times; Fashion Footnote
description: The phrase ''de rigueur'' no longer applies to clothing styles - that's clear to anyone watching the eclectic parade on any city street corner, at any downtown movie house, at any urban cocktail party. But in a small town in southern New England, the tyranny of fashion remains alive and well.

title: S.E.C. Submits Plan On Insider Trading
description: Three days after an inconclusive Supreme Court decision on insider trading, the Securities and Exchange Commission and prominent securities lawyers today submitted a proposal to Congress to define illegal trading in securities using confidential corporation information.

title: OSHAP TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Stage: At American Place, 'That Serious He-Man Ball'
description: In ''That Serious He-Man Ball,'' three old friends from high school meet on a suburban basketball court and compare the failed game plans of their lives. Graduating with high ambition, each has, in a different fashion, pursued a path toward failure. In common, the three are black men, and ethnicity remains a principal issue.

title: Carnegie Hall Tower On Its Way
description: On a lot just to the east of Carnegie Hall, city officials and representatives from the hall gathered yesterday afternoon to break ground for the construction of a 59-story office tower. The building will provide the concert facility with an additional area of 25,000 square feet in which to create new rehearsal spaces, dressing rooms and an enlarged backstage.

title: This Year in Moscow, a Kosher Feast
description: For the first time in more than 50 years, kosher food is available again in Moscow, imported in regular shipments from Hungary and served up with the care and reverence that come of long decades of attacks on the traditions of Soviet Jews.

title: Tenneco Units Get New Chiefs
description: Tenneco Inc. has named new chief executives at two of its divisions: J. I. Case, a maker of farm and construction equipment, and Tenneco Automotive.

title: Editors' Note
description: A picture caption on Thursday with an article about eased admission requirements for athletes at Columbia University carried an incomplete quotation from Stanley Broussard, a freshman football player, reversing the meaning of what he said. ''It annoys me to think the only way I could get in is to play football,'' the caption quoted Mr. Broussard as saying. It should have included the rest of his comment, as the accompanying article did in most editions: ''And it's really not true.''

title: ORMAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Transcript of Comments by the Principals on Agreement to Reduce Deficit
description: Following is a transcript of a news conference at the White House yesterday announcing a bipartisan agreement on reducing the Federal budget deficit, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network: OPENING STATEMENTS

title:
Patents;
Reducing Aircraft Friction
description: LEAD: THE National Aeronautics and Space Administration received a patent this week for a structure described as reducing friction on the surface of an aircraft.

title: Texaco Spurns Bid By Pennzoil
description: The Pennzoil Company has proposed a provisional settlement of its longstanding dispute with Texaco Inc., but Texaco yesterday called the amounts involved ''clearly unreasonable.''

title: Film: 'Flowers in the Attic,' From V. C. Andrews Novel
description: The scary thing about ''Flowers in the Attic,'' now playing at the National and other theaters, is that the novel by V. C. Andrews that inspired the movie has sold more than 4 million copies.

title: LACLEDE GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of about $5 million from the sale of half-ownership in an apartment project and the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Stung on Yeltsin, Gorbachev Renews His Call for Change
description: Faced with an unexpectedly strong public backlash against the recent dismissal of one of his political allies, Mikhail S. Gorbachev today renewed his call for change in the Soviet Union.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6, 28 A Cuban immigration understanding with Washington will be revived by that country's Government. They will accept nearly 2,600 Cubans who are to be deported from the United States, State Department officials said. Page 1 The top arms control official in the Pentagon, Frank J. Gaffney Jr., announced that he was leaving the Government and leveled a blast of criticism at the Reagan Administration for seeming to rush to conclusion of an arms treaty with Moscow. 1 Kosher food is available in Moscow for the first time in more than 50 years. The food is being imported in regular shipments from Hungary. 3 Mikhail Gorbachev renewed his call for change in the Soviet Union. The Soviet leader has been faced with an unexpectedly strong public backlash against the recent dismissal of a former political ally. 1 An address by Mr. Gorbachev to a joint session of Congress will not be supported by the White House. Instead, Administration officials want Mr. Gorbachev to meet directly with lawmakers and encourage support for an arms treaty. 6 Two Salvadoran rebels will return from exile soon to test the terms of the Central American peace treaty. The two Salvadorans, lead the Democratic Revolutionary Front. 1 A U.S.-Laotian pact was reached under which the United States will consider the ''humanitarian problems'' of the country as Laotians step up the search for Americans missing since the Vietnam War, the two nations announced. 3 Belem journal: Amazon tribe braves the wilds of the city 4 On-site test monitoring questioned 6 Shamir is offering to meet Hussein 6 Police raid frees abducted girl on Costa del Sol 28 NATIONAL 7, 33, 48-49, 54 A bipartisan agreement on the deficit was reached that, if implemented, would reduce the Federal deficit by $30 billion this year. President Reagan signed the accord and an order to activate $23 billion in automatic spending cuts. 1 The first mandatory spending cuts ordered by President Reagan will reduce Government payments to doctors and dairymen, and raise students' cost of acquiring a Government-subsidized loan. 49 News analysis: The deficit reduction may not impress the marketplace. The agreement still has to be go to Congress, and it encompasses estimates of savings that economists find exaggerated. 49 A major effort to reduce ozone by requiring changes in the gasoline sold in the warmer months will begin next summer in New York, New Jersey and six New England states. The changes would increase gasoline costs by 1.5 cents a gallon. 1 Volkswagen will close its U.S. plant by the fall of next year. The company said that the Pennsylvania plant had been losing money for five years because of sluggish sales and had little prospect of becoming profitable. 1 A capitalist-Marxist love feast of sorts was held in Washington, as the Soviet Ambassador honored Blanchette Rockefeller, the widow of John D. Rockefeller 3d, and celebrated the return of two Russian art treasures to the Soviet Union. 7 The Consumer Price Index climbed four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Labor Department reported. Although the October increase was twice that of September, analysts expressed little concern. 35 Organized groups are more involved than ever in trying to influence the Presidential campaign in Iowa. Many groups, representing everyone from the unborn to the elderly, are national organizations. 33 Senate confirmation hearings for Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, the nominee to the Supreme Court, will begin on Dec. 14. The hearings should take no more than a week, the commitee chairman said. 54 Haig in new battles 7 Moderate Governor pleases New Mexico 7 Reagan opposes bill to reduce indoor air pollution 33 Shultz makes points for Deaver in trial testimony 33 Plane's engines had normal power 33 REGIONAL 29-32 A plan to build 750 apartments for middle-income families in the Bronx was approved by the New York City Board of Estimate, after nearly 20 hours of negotiations. The proposal is part of a plan to build 66,000 apartments citywide. 1 A panel from the Board of Regents of New York State will explore whether minority-group students have distinct ''learning styles'' that may call for teaching techniques that are different from those used for whites. 29 The plan to name the task force to study the New York City school system was criticized by state officials as a needless effort that would only delay solutions to the problems of the city's schools. 31 AIDS testing for prostitutes and sex and drug offenders may be required as well as a heavy crackdown on all forms of prostitution because of the AIDS epidemic, New York's City's Health Commissioner said. 29 In the Howard Beach murder trial, the prosecution rested its case. The final witness was an ophthalmologist, who testified that one black man who, the prosecution says, was attacked by white teen-agers suffered a contusion in his eye. 31 Mario Cuomo met supporters who told him that he had not done enough to help the homeless, to build affordable housing or to make real the eloquent vision of his speeches. Mr. Cuomo defended his record. 29 A judge's decision to bar Yonkers from assisting developers until it complies with a court order calling for the construction of public housing was met with confusion and anger by city officials. 30 A nurse suspected of killing patients at a Long Island hospital was ordered held without bail on assault charges, as authorities said it might take ''at least weeks'' to obtain evidence needed to lodge murder charges. 31 Hard times for dairy farmers in New York state 29 Radiation level cut outside plant in Queens 30 M.T.A. urges end to one-way tolls on Verrazano-Narrows 30 Boy's presence renews mother's confidence 31 Daily News and Guild reach pact 32 AIDS virus in pregnancy studied 32

title: Your Money; Tax-Swapping Confusion
description: THE technique of municipal bond tax swapping traditionally reaches its peak this time of year. But the mid-October stock market plunge and a proposal in Congress to change the way certain bonds are taxed has added substantial confusion to the process this year.

title: COPING: With Personal Records
description: This is the time of year when many Americans feel as if they are drowning in a sea of paper, as dresser drawers and shoe boxes overflow with the year's accumulation of sales receipts, canceled checks and assorted other financial scraps.

title: Encouraging a U.S. Space-Launch Service
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Getting Personal And Eating Tripe Among the Stars
description: The celebrity interview used to be a simple affair: the interviewer published or broadcasted any self-serving thing the interviewee chose to pass along. Then the rules changed. The gaga press concluded, and rightly so, that vigorous, aggressive reporting turned up material with more pizzaz.

title: HANA BIOLOGICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $6,000.

title: STIFEL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-Net income

title: UNIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: TV: 'King of the Birds' Offered on Channel 13
description: As African birds go, the hammerkop, or hammer-headed stork, is not prepossessing. It is dull brown and middle-sized, and wears, as George Page, the narrator, says, ''a guilty look.'' So, why is it called the king of the birds? ''Nature,'' on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tomorrow night, tries to explain why. It never quite does, but it's still a good show.

title: AGREEMENT SIGNED TO REDUCE DEFICIT $30 BILLION IN 1988
description: After four weeks of tortuous talks set off by the stock market plunge, White House and Congressional negotiators reached a bipartisan agreement today on a plan to reduce the projected Federal deficit by $30 billion this year.

title: Wells Fargo Loses Ruling
description: A Federal judge has ordered the Wells Fargo Bank to stop offering a financial instrument that the Government contends is illegal and to repay investors, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today.

title: Breeders' Cup: Coastal Clash
description: Anyone who thinks that New Yorkers are parochial about the importance of their own racing should spend a few days at a California track. By comparison, New Yorkers seem positively broad-minded.

title: Goldman, Sachs Chief Names 2 Vice Chairmen
description: John L. Weinberg, the chairman and chief executive of Goldman, Sachs & Company, yesterday named his two closest associates, Stephen Friedman and Robert E. Rubin, as vice chairmen, making them the heirs apparent to run one of the nation's most influential investment banking houses.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The At the Movies column in Weekend on Nov. 13 misidentified the producer and director of ''Heart of Midnight.'' They are Andrew Gaty and Matthew Chapman.

title: FONAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $435,000 for the latest quarter and $171,000 for the year-ago period. The share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in August.

title: Mr. Reagan's Deficit, and History
description: Deficit-reduction negotiators delivered the anticipated turkey yesterday amid reports that Congressional Republicans would refuse to choke down even this scrawny, pallid bird.

title: Tax Rises Expected Primarily for Corporations and the Rich
description: The $9 billion of tax increases included in the budget package announced today were not designated, but they will likely be relatively limited in scope, with corporations and wealthier individuals shouldering most of the burden, according to Congressional tax writers.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Nov. 13 about a Guggenheim Museum exhibition, ''Fifty Years of Collecting:

title: OSHAWA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $4,023,000. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dance: At Joyce Theater, American Ballroom Group
description: The American Ballroom Theater swept into the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street,) on Tuesday night to open a two-week season. And that is reason to cheer, for the company is one of our most unusual and delightful dance groups.

title: HADRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTHEAST OPENS DRIVE TO CUT BACK OZONE POLLUTION
description: Impatient with Federal efforts to control smog, New York, New Jersey and the six New England states are starting a major effort to reduce ozone by requiring changes in gasoline sold in the region in warmer months, beginning next summer.

title: The Danger of Debt: How Much Is Too Much?
description: Installment debt can creep up at this time of year, endangering your credit rating. Credit-card companies and lenders will not extend credit to consumers in the danger zone whose payments amount to 20 percent to 30 percent of their gross income. Consumers, moreover, cannot get a mortgage if their total debt payments exceed 36 percent of their gross income. Following are national household averages for credit payments. *2*NATIONAL AVERAGE Gross Monthly DANGER income a credit month payments If you earn about $25,000 a year: $2,083 $172 $416-625 If you earn about $50,000 a year: $4,166 $287 $833-1,250 If you earn about $100,000 a year: $8,333 $467 $1,666-2,50 0 (Source: Federal Reserve Bank)

title: Holiday 'Mahabharata'
description: A special New Year's Eve performance of Peter Brook's production of ''The Mahabharata'' has been added to the show's run at the Majestic Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, at 651 Fulton Street, in the Fort Greene section. The performance begins Dec. 31 at 12:30 P.M. and ends at 10:45 P.M. There will be two intermissions. The show, which opened Oct. 18, will run through Jan. 3. Tickets are $96 and $30. Information: (718) 636-4100.

title: Bolipata Piano Recital
description: Jaime Bolipata, a pianist, will perform works by Haydn, Beethoven, Ravel and Liszt today at 2 P.M. at Theodore Roosevelt's Birthplace (28 East 20th Street). The concert is free. Information: 866-2086.

title: Belem Journal; An Amazon Tribe Braves the Wilds of City Life
description: Chief Poropot and 96 other Kaiapo Indians had come to the big city and stunned everyone with their body paint, their war clubs and their headdresses. But they found the townsfolk pretty strange, too.

title: Cubs Pick Zimmer
description: Jim Frey, who 10 days ago was named director of baseball operations for the Chicago Cubs, yesterday selected Don Zimmer, a boyhood friend from Cincinnati, as the team's manager. Zimmer, who will be taking on his fourth managing job, recently signed a two-year contract as the third-base coach with the San Francisco Giants, but was allowed to negotiate with the Cubs.

title: ELGIN NATL INDUS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Silent 1925 'Phantom' At Donnell Library
description: The auditorium at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street, has reopened after six months of renovation. The hall is now called the Bankers Trust Company Auditorium.

title: Devils and Rangers Come Out on Top; RANGERS 4, JETS 3
description: The score was tied, 3-3, which was acceptable to the Rangers, but instead of relaxing, they used the final two minutes to bear down and avoid the strain of an overtime session so close after Thursday night's loss in Minnesota.

title: TPA OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
From Agreement to Law
description: These are the steps needed for the budget agreement reached yesterday to become law:

title: Cities Group Says U.S. Policies Hurt Development Efforts
description: Changes in the tax law and other Federal policies are undercutting the two economic incentives that cities use most often to lure development, municipal leaders said today.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Film: 'Date With an Angel'
description: ''Date With an Angel,'' which opened yesterday at the subterranean, shoeboxy Criterion 4 and other theaters, is about a breathtakingly lovely creature with feathers on her large, fluffy wings. Unfortunately, she's also got feathers in her head. The angel lands on earth and affixes herself to Jim Sanders (Michael E. Knight), a soon-to-be-married man. Jim feels he should resist her, but the angel spends the rest of the film gazing adoringly at him and following him everywhere.

title: N.B.A. Building Code
description: The heat is on the Miami Heat, a National Basketball Association franchise due to begin play in the 1988-89 season. Heat officials were told this week by the N.B.A. that the number of bathrooms in its new arena now under construction must be increased from the present 76 to 125 or the city could lose the franchise. Cesar Odio, the Miami city manager, said the demand was ridiculous because the building is well into construction and such alterations, if they could be made, might cost another $1.5 million.

title: OPTICAL SPECIALTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Includes a writedown of inventory of about $1,000,000.

title: Officer Leaving Pacific Post
description: James S. Gallagher, president of the Pacific Stock Exchange since 1981, said today that he would resign Jan. 19.

title: ELECTRONIC ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
President's Proclamation
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's 1987 Thanksgiving Day proclamation: T HE WHITE HOUSE By the President of the United States of America A Proclamation

title: DYATRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $98,000 for the quarter and $162,000 for the 9 months.

title: Carlucci Is Confirmed As Defense Secretary
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to approved President Reagan's nomination of Frank C. Carlucci to become Defense Secretary.

title: Judge Denies Bail for Nurse Suspected in L.I. Hospital Deaths
description: A nurse suspected of killing several patients at a West Islip hospital was ordered held without bail on assault charges today.

title: It's Not Elitist for Hunters to Pay a Fee
description: LEAD: Hunting isn't what it used to be. On public land, game is scarce or limited in variety.

title: Two Salvador Rebels Plan to Return Home To Test Latin Treaty
description: The two senior leaders of the civilian wing of the Salvadoran rebel movement say they will return to El Salvador from exile in the next few days to test the the Central American peace treaty.

title: INSIDE
description: New on Saturdays: Consumers' World A shaky economy means bargains for shoppers. And Coping, a new column, talks about personal records you don't have to keep. Page 56. Prices Up 0.4% in October Led by costlier shelter, cars and clothes, consumer prices rose again last month, putting inflation at a 4.8 percent rate this year. Page 35. A Study of 'Learning Styles' Do minority-group students learn differently from whites? The New York Board of Regents will examine that question, despite warnings that its results might seem racist. Page 29. Shultz Takes the Stand Secretary of State George P. Shultz testified to the ''integrity, honesty and truthfulness'' of Michael K. Deaver at latter's perjury trial. Page 33. Navratilova Upset, 6-4, 7-5 Martina Navratilova, seeking her fifth straight Virginia Slims tennis title, was eliminated by Gabriela Sabatini in the quarterfinals. Page 51. AIDS Tests Weighed The AIDS epidemic may force New York City to impose mandatory AIDS tests on prostitutes and sex and drug offenders, officials said. Page 29.

title: M.T.A. Urges End to One-Way Toll on Verrazano
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority recommended yesterday the repeal of the Federal law that introduced one-way tolls last year on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge between Staten Island and Brooklyn.

title: Malaysian Car for U.S.
description: Malaysia's money-losing national auto manufacturer, Proton, signed an accord today to distribute its Proton Saga car in the United States. Proton America Inc., headed by Malcolm Bricklin of Bricklin Industries, will import the car. ''Production of the models bound for the United States will begin in October 1988, once modifications to meet U.S. requirements are completed,'' a Proton executive vice president, Dan Prior, told reporters.

title: Concert: Dresden Orchestra
description: The Dresden Staatskapelle, which traces its history to 1548 and hence can claim to be the world's oldest orchestra, arrived in Carnegie Hall Thursday night for the first of three Manhattan concerts. (The two others, conducted by Colin Davis, will be Wednesday at Carnegie and Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall.) For this first program, the orchestra was led by Hans Vonk, who comes from the Netherlands and who became the Staatskapelle's principal conductor two years ago. Mr. Vonk is not a well-known name in New York, but on the basis of Thursday's performance of Bruckner's Symphony No. 4 in E flat (''Romantic''), in the Nowak edition, he deserves to be.

title: Chicago Party Spurns Ex-Mayor in Clerk Bid
description: Former Mayor Jane M. Byrne has failed to get the endorsement of the Cook County Democratic Party to seek election as Circuit Court Clerk.

title: ROSS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: For a Broader New York Policy on AIDS
description: The New York City Department of Health has increased dramatically its projection of AIDS cases for 1991 and its official count of the cumulative number of AIDS cases in the city. Unfortunately, those revisions, while welcome, come as no surprise because they are long overdue.

title: Devils and Rangers Come Out on Top; DEVILS 5, BLACKHAWKS 2
description: The Devils are becoming spoiled by their continued success at home and obsessed by their failure on the road.

title: Consumer Prices Up By 0.4%
description: The Consumer Price Index climbed four-tenths of 1 percent last month as the cost of shelter, new cars and clothing rose, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Betty Ford Has Surgery For the Heart and Neck
description: Betty Ford underwent six hours of heart and neck surgery today but was expected to be well enough to be home for Thanksgiving, officials said.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $57,000. c-Net loss

title: KEY RATES
NORSTAN reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $34,000 and $41,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $107,000 and $164,000 for the same periods, respectively.

title: FOODMAKER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Drawbacks Found in Deficit Package
description: A month ago the markets sent a brutal message to Washington demanding credible cuts in the Federal budget deficit. Prominent legislators promptly said the rout of the stock market was a cry for leadership., Special to the New York Times

title: MANAGEMENT CO ENTERTAINENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said since the acquisition of two of its four subsidiaries occurred subsequent to the initial public offering, figures for the year-ago periods are not comparable.

title: OSHKOSH TRUCK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue represents shipments. The company said the major cause of the decrease in fourth-quarter earnings was a one-time adjustment of 20 cents a share for undercosting of shipments. The latest fourth quarter also included a warranty expense of five cents per share against a recently concluded Air Force contract. The company said the year-ago fourth quarter net was helped by a decrease of six cents a share in the LIFO inventory reserve.

title: DEL LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bank of New York Trims Bid for Irving
description: The Bank of New York Corporation yesterday reduced its bid for the Irving Bank Corporation to $68 a share in cash and stock from $80 a share. Analysts said the new offer would do little to reduce the Irving board's opposition to a takeover.

title: ANDREW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $3.7 million from the sale of land for the quarter and year; the year also includes a restructuring charge of $11.4 million.

title: Two Novelists Awarded Strauss Livings for '88
description: Diane Johnson and Robert Stone have been named the 1988 recipients of ''The Mildred and Harold Strauss Livings.'' Each will receive $50,000 annually for five years, for purposes of allowing them to devote their time exclusively to writing.

title: Verity Warns Japan on Curb
description: The United States could retaliate if Japan continues to bar American companies from participating in public works projects, Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. said today.

title: Christopher Keating Weds Jeanne Conte, a Copywriter
description: Jeanne Marie Conte, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Henry Conte of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Christopher Ball Keating, a son of Cornelius Francis Keating of New Canaan, Conn., and Elizabeth Ball of Washington Depot, Conn. The Rev. Stanley M. Koziol, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Waveny in New Canaan.

title: VICON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Peter Serkin Recital
description: The pianist Peter Serkin will give a benefit performance for the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity, at the corner of Clinton and Montague Streets in Brooklyn Heights, tomorrow at 4 P.M. The recital is intended to raise funds for restoration of the church. Tax-deductible tickets are $100. Information: (718) 834-8794.

title: AIDS Virus in Pregnancy Studied
description: One in 50 pregnant women was found to have antibodies to the AIDS virus in tests on 602 pregnant women at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn, according to a report in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: For Dairy Farmers, Debt, Sadness and Loss
description: Before dawn today, Robert Podris milked his cows for the last time and went out of the dairy-farming business.

title: Wait on a New High Court Justice Till After '88
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 457287 -- No Title
description: Paperback rights to ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' Tom Wolfe's critically acclaimed first novel about a Wall Street investment banker who becomes embroiled in a criminal investigation with political overtones, have been bought by Bantam Books for more than $1.5 million. Several other participants in the auction said they bid $1 million or more.

title: Here's Where the Ax Will Fall Today
description: While the mandatory spending cuts ordered by President Reagan today could affect a wide range of domestic and military programs over the course of the current fiscal year, they will immediately lower Government payments to doctors and dairy farmers and raise the price that students pay for Government-subsidized loans.

title: U.S. AND HAVANA AGREE TO RESTORE IMMIGRATION PACT
description: The Cuban Government, in a policy reversal, has agreed to restore an immigration understanding with Washington that will allow the deportation of nearly 2,600 Cubans from the United States, State Department officials said today.

title: PHYSICIANS INSURANCE CO OF OHIO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $1.1 million second quarter net loss caused by a special addition to loss reserves.

title: Women as Witches
description: THE DEVIL IN THE SHAPE OF A WOMAN. Witchcraft in Colonial New England. By Carol F. Karlsen. 360 pages. W.W. Norton & Company. $22.95.

title: CHANCELLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Boy's Presence Renews Mother's Confidence
description: Beaming and confident after her first night with her baby, Nicole Bridget Smigiel said yesterday that she hoped to combine college and motherhood in a new life dedicated to the child she surrendered at birth 17 months ago to Joel B. Steinberg.

title: Agony and Ecstasy for Syracuse Fans
description: One night in early October, David Bennett, huddled and freezing, squeezed into a lonely telephone booth in a small coastal town in England. The surf pounded the shore in the distance and the rain lashed the booth's windows as Bennett, bathed in darkness and uncertainty, dialed the number.

title: DYANSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SHAMIR IS OFFERING TO MEET HUSSEIN
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel offered today to meet with King Hussein of Jordan, but he rejected both an international conference and territorial compromise as ways toward peace.

title: LOWE'S COS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Circus: Big Apple Version, In 1 Ring at Lincoln Center
description: Still flashing only one ring, like any faithful spouse after a decade of living together, the Big Apple Circus is celebrating, up at Lincoln Center, its 10th anniversary. It is a pretty splashy affair for the modest circus, not in terms of large-scale Madison Square Garden three-ring splashiness maybe, but certainly big and bold for the radiant blue and yellow tent in Damrosch Park.

title: Japanese Call Move on Budget an Important Step
description: Japanese officials today welcomed the news of an agreement to cut the United States budget deficit as an important step that might calm troubled world markets.

title: Big Texas Bailout Seen As Start of Aid Effort
description: A $1.3 billion Federal bailout for the Vernon Savings and Loan Association, the costliest in the nation's history, is a step toward dealing with ailing savings institutions in Texas, analysts said today.

title:
Patents;
Faster-Chip Procedure
description: LEAD: A semiconductor deposition method patented this week for the University of Illinois is expected to lead to faster chips that successfully process electrical and light impulses. Patent No. 4,707,216 was awarded to Prof. Hadis Morkoc and Russ Fischer after research financed by the Air Force. Licenses are being offered to industry by University Patents Inc.

title: Lagos Patrolled After Riots
description: The police patrolled the city center and the old section of the capital today after three days of rioting by gangs of youths. The riots started on Tuesday, but residents said no incidents had been reported since Thursday afternoon. The police arrested 60 people during the clashes, touched off by the killing of two brothers who tried to mediate between the police and a motorist arrested by a traffic officer.

title: PETRIE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Clarinet and Voice
description: The clarinetist Gervase de Peyer, Lucille Beer, a mezzo-soprano, and others will perform works by Schubert and Schumann tonight at 7:30 in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine (112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue). The concert is free. Information: 662-2133.

title: 'Watch the Gate' in Construction
description: Conversation between a teamsters' union official and a developer putting up an office tower in Lower Manhattan:

title: PAN ATLANTIC RE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment losses of $812,159 and $840,275 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $8,008 and $1,059,692 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary gains from tax credits of $61,875 and $919,235 for the same periods, respectively. Corrected from Thursday, Nov. 19, editions.

title: New York Working and Learning
description: Can big business help young people find jobs? Yes, if they're qualified. Can big business help young people qualify for jobs? Yes, with the cooperation of the schools. Those two aims describe an ambitious experiment just launched in New York by business leaders with state and foundation support: New York Working and New York Learning.

title: John A. McCandless, Investment Manager, 82
description: John A. McCandless, a retired president of Vance, Sanders & Company, an investment management concern in Boston, Mass., died Wednesday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old and a resident Delray Beach.

title: BALDWIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bruce Would Return
description: Earle Bruce, who will apparently end his career as head football coach at Ohio State this afternoon when the Buckeyes close their season against Michigan, has admitted that he could be talked into returning as coach of the Buckeyes. Bruce, who was dismissed on Monday by Edward Jennings, the university president, said Thursday night on his weekly radio program, in response to a question, that he would return if asked.

title: J. R. Ewing and Captain Furillo in Paris
description: The world, they say, gets smaller all the time.

title: Guggenheim Decision Appealed by Coalition
description: A coalition of preservationist and neighborhood groups have appealed the decision last month by the New York City Board of Standards and Appeals to allow the Guggenheim Museum to proceed with a planned 10-story addition to its building at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street.

title:
Patents;
A Method to Detect Certain Cancers
description: LEAD: A method of detecting certain forms of cancer has been invented by staff members of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., and is being used by that agency.

title: Reagan Opposes Indoor Clean-Air Bill
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it opposed pending legislation intended to protect the public from indoor air pollution.

title: Saints Try to Limit Euphoria
description: In their 20 previous seasons in the National Football League, the New Orleans Saints never finished with a winning record. They have never made the playoffs. They have never won four games in a row.

title: Stop the Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Officials Arrest Six In Crack-Selling Ring
description: Law-enforcement officials have arrested six people who reportedly sold an average of 12,000 vials of crack a week in the Albany region over the last two years, according to a spokesman for the Capital District Drug Enforcement Task Force.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A foot injury that has caused Joe Barry Carroll of the Golden State Warriors to miss the team's last three games will also sideline the 7-foot-1-inch center tonight when the Warriors play the Knicks at Madison Square Garden. . . . The Yankees completed their 40-man roster Thursday by signing Steve Shields, a pitcher and a minor-league free agent. Shields, 28 years old, has pitched in the Boston, Atlanta, Kansas City and Seattle organizations. He had a 2-0 record with a 6.60 earned run average last season with the Mariners. . . . Rod Strickland, De Paul's No. 2 scorer last season, has been declared academically ineligible to play basketball in the fall quarter. Strickland will be able to continue practicing with the team. . . . Walt Hriniak, a coach with the Boston Red Sox for 11 years, has signed a two-year contract, General Manager Lou Gorman said yesterday. Hriniak, 44 years old, has been credited for his work as hitting coach by such Boston players as Carl Yastrzemski, Dwight Evans and Rich Gedman.

title: CYANOTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wait on a New High Court Justice Till After '88; In Defense of Ginsburg
description: To the Editor:

title: The Daily News And Guild Have Tentative Pact
description: The Daily News and the Newspaper Guild have reached a tentative agreement that would reduce the newspaper's editorial and commercial staff by 64, including 10 of the paper's approximately 120 reporters.

title: U.N. Passes Measures to Combat Apartheid
description: The United Nations adopted a package of anti-apartheid resolutions today that call for an oil embargo against South Africa and criticize Israel for doing business with the Pretoria Government.

title: Rockefeller Gift Stirs Warm Soviet Response
description: The Rockefellers dined out Thursday night at the home of their newest admirers: the Soviet Embassy in Washington.

title: LCS INDUS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest periods' nets included a writeoff of $165,000 from certain deferred charges relating to the prepayment of a $5 million convertible subordinated note.

title: OPPENHEIMER CAPITAL L P reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Figures are pro forma. The company completed its first full quarter of operations Oct. 31, since going public July 9. The share earnings are in units.

title: WACOAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Latest year figures represent translations of the Japanese yen at the approximate exchange rate on Aug. 31 of 142 yen equals $1. Prior year figures represent the prevailing exchange rate on Aug. 31, 1986, of 156 yen to each U. S. dollar. Each American depositary share equals five shares of common stock.

title: STEINBERG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 17
description: The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange. The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CARMIKE CINEMAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
New York Approves Plan to Build 750 Apartments for Middle Class
description: The New York City Board of Estimate, after heated testimony and almost 20 hours of negotiations, approved a plan early yesterday to build 750 condominium apartments for middle-income families in the Bronx.

title: BIO-RAD LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PRODUCTION OPERATORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $511,000 on the purchase and retirement of debentures. uf92c-Net loss

title: Backward Can Be Forward
description: BEYOND the coincidence of mere place, there is a connection between Andre Dawson, who took a chance in accepting a 50 percent salary cut and went on to win the most valuable player award in the National League, and Billy Williams, who rejected a chance to manage the Cubs' Triple-A farm club in Des Moines.

title: Top 40 for 'the Shave Crowd'
description: LEAD: The bandleader Mitch Miller once warned a group of radio announcers in the 1950's that financial ruin awaited those stations that played rock-and-roll music, then a newcomer on the scene. ''You have abdicated your programming to the pre-shave crowd that makes up zero percent of the country's buying power, once you eliminate ponytail ribbons,

title: MMR HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Revenue represents contract revenue.

title: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NBC and Turner In Venture Talks
description: The National Broadcasting Company and the Turner Broadcasting System are discussing a range of possible joint ventures, according to sources at both companies.

title: Nebraska Will Try to Stay No. 1
description: The bus was waiting to leave the Orange Bowl. It was about 1:30 in the morning on that memorable night in Miami nearly 16 years ago. The cheering had stopped, if only temporarily. And the football players and the coaches at Nebraska had reached that quiet moment when celebration turns to exhaustion and giddiness to satisfaction.

title: Navratilova Out In 6-4, 7-5 Upset
description: The applause began when Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina was still 4 points away from perhaps the biggest victory in her career. This would be her second opportunity of the match to end Martina Navratilova's four-year reign in the Virginia Slims championships, and most in the crowd of 13,854 at Madison Square Garden sensed that she would not fail. With a newly found determination and a net game to back it up, Sabatini lived up to those expectations.

title: Figure In Winans Case Guilty
description: David W. C. Clark, a former New York lawyer implicated in the insider trading circle that included R. Foster Winans, a former Wall Street Journal columnist, was found guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan on all but one of 17 counts of fraud, tax evasion and perjury.

title: Pentane May Add To Tesoro Offer
description: Pentane Partners, a New York-based investment partnership, said that it would be prepared to raise its $15-a-share offer for the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation ''if additional value can be demonstrated.''

title: Bridge:; More Than 2,000 Entrants Converge for Fall Nationals
description: The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began here this afternoon, with more than 2,000 players from all parts of North America assembled for 10 days of events ranging from national championships to one-session side games.

title: U.S. and Laos in Accord on the Missing
description: The United States and Laos announced today that Washington would begin considering the ''humanitarian problems'' of this isolated country as Laotians step up the search for Americans missing since the Vietnam War.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Climb
description: Treasury bond prices advanced yesterday as traders expressed relief that Administration and Congressional leaders had reached an agreement on ways to reduce the Federal budget deficit. The most pronounced gains came among bonds with longer maturities.

title: Top Arms-Control Official Quits; Criticizes Haste in Seeking Treaty
description: The Pentagon's top arms-control official announced today that he was leaving the Government and criticized the Reagan Administration for what he called its rush to conclude an arms treaty with Moscow.

title: Merger at Tulane University
description: The faculties at Tulane University and Newcomb College, separate institutions for 100 years, are to merge. While Newcomb will maintain its campus and remain a school for women, the merger of the faculties will enable conflicts on tenure, promotion and other issues to be resolved.

title: Cuts Seen at N.Y.U. Business School
description: In a move that could affect thousands of New York business people, including hundreds on Wall Street, New York University will reduce by nearly a fourth the part-time student body at its Graduate School of Business Administration, according to faculty members at the school.

title: Four More Banks Fail
description: State banking regulators have closed four banks, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said. The closures bring the number of American bank failures to 164 so far this year, compared with last year's total of 138, the F.D.I.C. said. The banks that were closed were the Republic Bank of Oklahoma City; the Peoples Bank and Trust of Iberia Parish, New Iberia, La,; the Timken State Bank in Timken, Kan., and the Alexander State Bank in Alexander, Kan.

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tears In the Ruins
description: Arriving in New York, I was amazed to find the streets still clogged with ultimate driving machines. News reaching the hinterland had led me to believe that the fall of the stock market had wiped out 97 percent of the great city's famous yuppie population, and I could not believe they would have gone to the final wipe-out without taking their beloved ultimate driving machines with them.

title: Hallmark Adds Univision
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. and a Chicago investment concern, as expected, have agreed to acquire Univision, the nation's largest supplier of Spanish-language television programs, for nearly $300 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1987
description: The Economy

title: GWC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Haig, the Old Warrior, in New Battles
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. has been working hard to become a politician. But sometimes the soldier in him shines through.

title: Hygiene in Nail Salons Termed Risk
description: Hygiene in grooming establishments is drawing increasing attention from dermatologists and health officials.

title: SILVER STATE MINING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Marian Van Tuyl, A Dancer, Educator And Writer, Is Dead
description: Marian Van Tuyl, a noted dance educator, writer and performer, died of cancer at her home in San Francisco on Nov. 10. She was 80 years old.

title: Boy, 2, Is Crushed to Death By Tombstone in Cemetery
description: A 2 1/2-year-old boy was crushed to death by a tombstone today while he and his sister played hide-and-seek in a cemetery.

title: BEGLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Dow Up on Budget Pact, But Wall St. Is Cautious
description: The news that the White House and Congress had finally hammered out a budget-cutting agreement was greeted as somewhat of an anticlimax on Wall Street late yesterday afternoon.

title: Harry Liman, Dress Manufacturer, 89
description: Harry Liman, a retired New York dress manufacturer, died of complications after surgery Thursday at New York University Medical Center. He was 89 years old and lived in Lawrence, L.I.

title: EQUATORIAL COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ATWOOD OCEANICS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a non-cash after-tax charge for a loss on the disposition of drilling vessels of $5.1 million. The latest year's revenue includes $6.3 million in after-tax gains realized from the sales of equity investments and various drilling equipment.

title: After 6 Weeks, Prosecution Rests in Howard Beach Trial
description: After six weeks of testimony by 60 witnesses, the prosecution rested its case yesterday in the Howard Beach, Queens, murder and assault trial.

title: PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,809,000 from sales of properties.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
2 Promoted At Seafirst
description: The Seafirst Corporation, the Seattle bank holding unit of the BankAmerica Corporation, said today that its board had named Luke S. Helms president and Roy A. Henderson vice chairman, effective Jan. 1. Seafirst also said that Richard P. Cooley would remain as chairman for approximately three years.

title: Employee Benefit Changes by Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company has changed the way it compensates its salaried employees by increasing the role of profit-sharing, replacing some health-care benefits with cash allowances and tightening the rules on overtime pay, the company said.

title: Bargain Forecast, Christmas and Beyond
description: Anxiety about how much consumers will cut back spending is likely to produce unusually vigorous price cutting this Christmas selling period.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 21, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Economic and Financial Committee - 10 A.M.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Held In Killing of a Doctor
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday in the slaying of a Queens obstetrician during an unsuccessful robbery Wednesday afternoon, the police said.

title: Liberals vs. Cuomo: Debating His Record
description: In a cramped and sweltering loft on West 72d Street in Manhattan, Mario M. Cuomo met his match Thursday night: a group of his earliest supporters who told him that he had not done enough to help the homeless, to build affordable housing, to make real the eloquent vision of his speeches.

title: TV for Cowboy Fans
description: A cable television network has agreed to buy the remaining tickets to the Sunday night game between the Miami Dolphins and the Dallas Cowboys. The action will keep the game from being blacked out in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

title: Parking Non-Violation, Looking-Glass Hearing
description: To the Editor:

title: PLANE'S ENGINES HAD NORMAL POWER
description: Both engines of the Continental Airlines DC-9 jet that crashed while taking off in a snowstorm in Denver Sunday produced normal power until the plane hit the ground, officials with knowledge of the inquiry said yesterday.

title: AIDS Test Is Weighed In Sex Cases
description: New York's City's Health Commissioner said yesterday that the AIDS epidemic may require the city to consider mandatory AIDS testing for prostitutes and sex and drug offenders, as well as a heavy crackdown on all forms of prostitution.

title: Volkswagen to Shut U.S. Plant
description: Volkswagen, the first foreign automobile company to build cars in the United States since the end of World War II, announced today that it will close its American assembly plant by next autumn.

title: Raid by Police Frees Kidnapped Girl, 5, in Spain
description: A kidnapped 5-year-old girl was freed unharmed and one of her abductors was wounded today when the police stormed a hideout on the Costa del Sol.

title: Carlesimo Retiring
description: Pete Carlesimo, who is credited with revitalizing the National Invitation Tournament, the oldest postseason basketball competition, announced his retirement yesterday as the tournament's executive director, effective June 30. The announcement came several hours before the start of the Big Apple N.I.T. last night at eight college sites throughout the nation, a Carlesimo innovation.

title: Colgate Coach Quits
description: Fred Dunlap, who played fullback at Colgate in the late 1940's and later returned to direct a Red Raider football resurgence, announced his resignation as head coach on Friday. Dunlap, 59, has been athletic director and head coach since Jan. 10, 1976. He will continue in the former position, university officials said. He underwent double-bypass surgery last year and stayed in the press box while Assistant Coach Mike Foley ran the team for eight games.

title: Further Revival Of Jets' Regulars
description: This is the time of year the Jets are supposed to be going the other way - to the hospital. The club has a history of damaging injuries in the second half of the season.

title: On-Site Test Monitoring Questioned
description: The House intelligence committee today challenged the Reagan Administration's assertion that new on-site monitoring measures are needed to verify Soviet adherence with nuclear testing limits.

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $698,000 for the latest period and $633,000 for the year-ago period. Cumulative preferred stock dividends exceeded the nets in both 9-month periods.

title: Amfac Ousts Its President
description: Amfac Inc., a diversified company with operations in distribution, retailing, hotel and land development, said today that Ronald R. Sloan had been removed as its president and chief executive officer. Henry A. Walker Jr., the company's chairman, has resumed his former positions as president and chief executive officer. Neither Mr. Walker nor Mr. Sloan was available for comment, and the company offered no explanation for Mr. Sloan's ouster. In a statement, Mr. Sloan said he ''will continue to serve as a director so long as I feel my presence will assist the shareholders in achieving their objectives.''

title: DEC. 14 HEARINGS SET ON JUDGE KENNEDY
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee decided today to begin confirmation hearings on Dec. 14 for President Reagan's latest nominee to the Supreme Court, Judge Anthony M. Kennedy.

title: TERRA MINES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Letter: On Government; Cabinet Should Have a Veterans' Seat
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Yields to Protest On Gorbachev and Congress
description: In the face of fierce opposition from conservative lawmakers, the White House backed away today from a suggestion that Mikhail S. Gorbachev address a joint meeting of Congress during his summit meeting with President Reagan next month.

title: Music: Pavarotti Gives Master Class
description: Luciano Pavarotti's master class at the Juilliard Theater on Thursday reminded us that doing and teaching are not necessarily the same thing. Mr. Pavarotti, perhaps the most famous operatic tenor of our time, sat behind a desk at one side of the stage wrapped in an enormous red, white and blue scarf. Before - and eventually past him - paraded a series of young singers at the school. They sang; John Wustman played the piano; Mr. Pavarotti offered a few words (occasionally none) and often sang lightly by way of demonstration.

title: Seton Hall Gains
description: Daryll Walker scored 20 points and Martin Salley added 18 tonight as Seton Hall opened its season with an 85-63 victory over George Mason in the first round of the Big Apple N.I.T.

title: Yale and Harvard Do the Unexpected
description: A year ago, when Harvard and Yale completed losing seasons and both finished in the lower half of the Ivy League, there was much moaning and groaning.

title: TECHNOLOGY FOR COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $185,000 charge from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.
