The company said its previously announced acquisition of BR Communications has been delayed until at least late December since the SEC has not yet completed its review of BR's proxy materials. The company said it has acquired additional shares and it now owns 1,859,205, or 46 percent, of BR communications' shares.

title: QUBIX GRAPHIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dollar Little Changed; Precious Metals Climb
description: The dollar was little changed yesterday in a session marked by wild, erratic swings, as market participants fell prey to trading on remarks by politicians about what had - and what had not - been achieved in cutting the Federal budget deficit.

title: ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax credits of $246,000 for the latest first quarter and $750,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Army Tank Contract
description: The Army has awarded a $605.4 million contract to the General Dynamics Corporation for 624 M-1A1 Abrams tanks. The award, the latest installment in a four-year, fixed-price deal announced last spring, calls for delivery of the tanks by March 1990.

title: Guinness Seeking Stock Buyback
description: Guinness P.L.C., the scandal-plagued brewer, said it would seek shareholder approval to repurchase up to 10 percent of its stock. ''In the light of current stock market levels, it's now a very attractive time'' to purchase the shares on the open market, a Guinness spokesman, Alan Stewart, said.

title: COMPUTER SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
OVONIC IMAGING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Oil Scandal In Norway
description: The six state-appointed members of the board of Statoil, Norway's biggest company, resigned today in an industrial scandal in which the company experienced a $780 million overrun on a refinery project.

title: NORTH ATLANTIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Mary Riordan and Timothy Gollin Wed in Houston
description: Mary Elizabeth Riordan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice A. Riordan of Houston, was married there yesterday to Timothy John Gollin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Gollin of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Chilmark, Mass. The Rev. Victor Brown, assisted by the Rev. Francis X. Murphy, performed the ceremony at Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church.

title: Illegal Aliens Need More Time to Emerge
description: To the Editor:

title: Shultz, as Prosecution Witness, Makes Some Big Points for Deaver
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz gave high marks today to the ''integrity, honesty and truthfulness'' of Michael K. Deaver.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 34.

title: Actors Get 3-Year Pact
description: Representatives of the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers and the Actor's Equity Association have negotiated a three-year contract that will increase earnings for some actors and stage managers by more than 20 percent over the next three years.

title: ALLIS-CHALMERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes pre-tax bankruptcy costs of $3,460,000. c-Net income and includes a $2.2 million gain from the adoption of new pension accounting standards. d-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $4,401,000. Preferred stock dividends exceeded net in the year-ago quarter.

title: Officials Criticize New Plan For a Task Force on Schools
description: A New York Board of Regents plan to name a task force to study the New York City school system has been criticized by state officials as a needless effort that would only delay solutions to the problems of the city's schools.

title: British Airways Revises Offer
description: In a revised offer, British Airways said yesterday that it was willing to pay about $260 million to buy British Caledonian Airways. The new bid, which involves a swap of stock, is considerably less than the $417 million that was offered originally.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Copies of Popular Toys Are Often Hazardous
description: Imported toys that resemble popular brand-name products can pose serious safety hazards, toy experts say. These toys can even find their way onto the shelves of reputable stores across the country.

title: Timerman Did Not Link His Arrest and Imprisonment to Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Radiation Level Is Cut Outside Plant in Queens
description: A radium supply company in Queens has all but totally reduced radiation outside its plant to what the state regards as a safe level, state officials said yesterday.

title: Brand Blanshard Is Dead at 95; Teacher and Writer of Philosophy
description: Brand Blanshard, a philosopher, writer and Sterling Professor Emeritus of Philosophy at Yale University, died after a long illness Thursday at his home in New Haven. He was 95 years old.

title: Bilzerian Talks On Singer Bid
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor, disclosed that his financial advisers had contacted unidentified third parties about purchasing all or a part of the military electronics and training systems divisions of the Singer Company if Mr. Bilzerian succeeded in his $1.1 billion tender offer for the aerospace concern, based in Montvale, N.J.

title: Learning Style Of Minorities To Be Studied
description: The New York State Board of Regents has appointed a special panel of three of its members to explore whether black and other minority-group students have distinct ''learning styles'' that may call for teaching techniques that are different from those used for whites.

title: Entitlements Do Not Equate With Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Gunnar Idenstam
description: Gunnar Idenstam, a young organist from Stockholm, played a brief recital at the Park Avenue Christian Church Wednesday night. Mr. Idenstam's program was easy to digest. Indeed, its mix of Bach, Schumann, Vierne, and contemporary Swedish music, with some improvising at the end, all seemed aimed at the organ-shy listener rather than the experienced colleague.

title: REPUBLIC RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SIGMA DESIGNS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Curbs on C.I.A. Said Opposed
description: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today that the Reagan Administration would oppose legislation to restrict the Central Intelligence Agency in the aftermath of the Iran-contra affair, according to Congressional officials.

title:
Patents;
Controlling Engines With Fuel Mixtures
description: LEAD: Methods of controlling engine operation with mixtures of fuels having different qualities were patented this week for the Ford Motor Company. Ford has conducted a study of flexible fuels for more than five years while Congress has been considering regulation of fuels.

title: Organized Groups Flock to Iowa Trying to Gain Influence in '88 Campaign
description: Organized groups representing causes ranging from the unborn to the elderly are more involved than ever in trying to influence the Presidential campaigns in Iowa.

title: Moderate Governor Pleases New Mexico
description: To the west in Arizona is Evan Mecham, the beleaguered first-term Republican Governor facing efforts to oust him from office that appear likely to lead to a special election.

title: WESTERNWORLD-SAMUEL COMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company attributed increased revenue primarily to the acquisition of Video Tape Co. and to increased international television and U.S. home video sales. The company said it acquired J. C. Williamson Film Distributors Pty. Ltd., for a combination of common stock, warrants and a non-interest bearing note of $250,000; the total value of the acquisition was about $775,000.

title: FAIRFIELD-NOBLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Boulanger Remembered
description: Marie Sirot, a violinist, and Olivier Sorenson, a pianist, will present a concert in honor of the 100th anniversary of Nadia Boulanger's birth, today at 5 P.M. at the Maison Francaise (16 Washington Mews) of New York University. The concert is free. Information: 998-8750.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''A balanced package.'' - Representative Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas and Speaker of the House. [ 48:1. ]

title: Music: Bernstein Conducts Mahler and Schubert
description: Leonard Bernstein speaks several musical languages fluently, but Mahler is to him like a native tongue. Though that is hardly news by now, his conducting of the Mahler Symphony No. 1 Thursday evening with the New York Philharmonic reminded one how effortlessly he seems to slip under that composer's skin. He coaxed an impassioned, richly idiomatic performance from the orchestra, which played as if suddenly awakened after a long nap.

title: Pretoria Ousts Photographer
description: South Africa announced today that it was expelling an American news photographer, accusing him of sending ''biased photo material'' overseas. The Government said the photographer, David Turnley of The Detroit Free Press, must leave when his work permit expires on Nov. 30. Mr. Turnley is the 11th foreign journalist expelled since President P. W. Botha declared emergency rule in June 1986.

title: GALAXY CARPET MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
LEWIS, PALMER G, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bid for Encor
description: TransCanada Pipelines Ltd. has enough support from shareholders of the Encor Energy Corporation to proceed with its hostile bid of $980 million (Canadian), or about $745 million (United States), even though it was rejected by the company as too low, Gerald Maier, TransCanada's president, said. Several institutional holders of Encor stock have indicated they are satisfied with the $8.75-a-share (Canadian) offer, Mr. Maier told reporters. TransCanada began its takeover offer for all of Encor's shares on Nov. 13. The unsolicited bid, conditional on 50.1 percent of Encor's shares being tendered, expires Dec. 8.

title: For Soviet Mezzo, Politics And Music Aren't in Tune
description: ''It's a pity that stupid politics can prevent artists from performing,'' Elena Obraztsova said last week. ''Politics are politics and art is art. The two shouldn't be mixed.'' The Russian mezzo-soprano was in New York to prepare for her Carnegie Hall recital Monday night, her first appearance in the city in eight years. With John Wustman as her accompanist, she will sing songs by Tchaikovsky and by Rachmaninoff, with some opera arias for encores.

title: N.C.A.A. to Proceed With Drug Testing
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association said yesterday that it would begin drug tests next Monday for athletes at all championship events despite a California judge's ruling that the tests generally violate both the California and United States constitutions.

title: Yonkers Unsure How to Satisfy Judge's Ruling
description: City officials expressed confusion and anger today over a Federal judge's decision to bar the city from assisting developers until it complies with a court order calling for the construction of public housing.

title: Met Opera: 'Traviata,' With Two Stars Out With the Flu
description: When undertaking a trip in a car with two flat tires, just getting out of the garage is something of an accomplishment. Viewed in that light, a concertgoer might be inclined to look sympathetically on the Metropolitan Opera's bumpy traversal of Verdi's ''Traviata'' Thursday evening.

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $104,000 for the quarter and $123,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: The Winners Take a Lot
description: All sorts of clinchings will be available on television today, starting at 1 P.M. on Channel 13, which will show the Ivy League football title game between Yale and Harvard at the Yale Bowl in New Haven. At 3:30, Channel 2 will televise the clash between unbeaten Oklahoma and unbeaten Nebraska, which will result in an Orange Bowl berth for the winner, and Channel 7 will show the U.C.L.A.-Southern California game, the winner of which will go to the Rose Bowl.

title: Chess Game Adjourned
description: The 15th game of the world chess championship between Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov was adjourned today after 42 moves.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title:
Patents;
Phone Booth Ads
description: LEAD: An advertising display unit to be installed next to a public telephone was patented this week. The owner of the phone booth receives fees from the advertisers. R. Craig Martin, an engineer, assigned patent No. 4,706,399 to his employer, JM Industries of Houston. The sales display, which is reported to be in wide use, is covered by rigid plastic and is described as vandal-resistant.

title: Mexican Holiday Calms Peso Chaos
description: After four days of turmoil, calm returned to Mexico's foreign-exchange and stock markets today, thanks to a national holiday that closed all banks, Government offices and businesses until Monday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. 76ers 116, Celtics 85: Charles Barkley had 22 points and 14 rebounds as Philadelphia routed Boston last night, the Celtics' worst loss to the 76ers in 21 years. The last time Boston lost by as many as 31 points to Philadelphia was Nov. 29, 1966, when the 76ers won, 138-96. Reggie Lewis and Mark Acres, two rookies, each had 14 for the Celtics, who were playing without the injured Larry Bird.(AP) Nuggets 156, Spurs 142: In Denver, Alex English scored 30 points, Danny Schayes had 26 and Jay Vincent had 25 last night for the Nuggets in the highest-scoring N.B.A. game of the season. Greg Anderson led the Spurs with 31 points. The two teams share the record for the highest-scoring N.B.A. game without an overtime. It was played on Jan. 11, 1984, and Denver won, 163-155. (AP) Pistons 131, Warriors 108: In Pontiac, Mich., Isiah Thomas and Vinnie Johnson led seven Pistons in double figures with 19 points each as Detroit handed Golden State its fifth consecutive defeat. The Warriors' 1-8 start is their worst since moving to the West Coast for the 1962-63 season. They were led in scoring by Rod Higgins with 22 points and Chris Mullin with 18. The Warriors were playing without their starting center, Joe Barry Carroll, who missed his third consecutive game with a foot injury, and Larry Smith, who was placed on the injured reserve list yesterday with a strained right thigh.(AP) N.H.L. Sabres 5, Capitals 3: Dave Andreychuk, Mike Foligno and Lindy Ruff scored third-period goals to rally Buffalo to victory over visiting Washington last night. With Buffalo trailing by a goal entering the third period, Andreychuk tied the score at 3-3 at 3 minutes 39 seconds while the Sabres had a two-man advantage. Andreychuk took three shots before beating Pete Peeters on the short side for his eighth goal of the season. Foligno scored the game-winner at 9:57 when his 20-foot slap shot appeared to fool Peeters and went into the net over the goaltender's left shoulder.(AP) Golf Scotland Leads in World Cup: Sandy Lyle and Sam Torrance both birdied the final hole yesterday and gave Scotland a one-shot lead after third round of the 33d World Cup of Golf in Kapalua, Hawaii. Lyle and Torrance each had 71's in occasional showers, and the two Scottish golfers finished three rounds at 425, seven strokes under par on the Kapalua Bay course. (AP) Six Tied for Lead in Seniors Event: Orville Moody, a United States Open champion, and five others shot 69 yesterday to tie for the lead in the first round of the inaugural Gus Machado Senior Classic in Key Biscayne, Fla. Lee Elder, Bill Johnston, Bob Charles, Pat Schwab and Bob Brue also were two under on the Key Biscayne Golf Course. (AP) Ueno First, Stadler Third in Japan: Tadami Ueno, who has won only five minor tournaments in a 15-year pro career, shot a bogey-free 68 yesterday to maintain a one-shot lead halfway through Japan's richest golf tournament, the $1 million Dunlop Phoenix in Miyazaki. Ueno completed the two rounds at 134, 10 under par. Craig Stadler of the United States fired the day's best score of 65 for a total of 136 and jumped from 21st to 3d.(AP)

title: ASEA GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are in U.S. currency.

title: T.C.U. Runner Banned
description: Tony Jeffery, a senior running back at Texas Christian University, was declared ineligible for his final collegiate game because of improper relations with an agent, school officials said yesterday. T.C.U. officials received new evidence on Thursday from a National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation that Jeffery had improper relationships with an agent. Jeffery has admitted to wrongdoing.

title: Europe Is Hopeful on Plan
description: Nigel Lawson, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, welcomed the American budget plan today and said the industrialized nations should now prepare their response and call a meeting.

title: Park Plan Draws Fire
description: ACCUSED of advancing a foolhardy scheme by critics, Southampton Village Mayor William J. Hattrick Jr. has scheduled a public hearing for Tuesday on the proposed condemnation and public acquisition of the last parcel of open space in the heart of the village business district.

title: Land Sale To Lab Debated
description: THE Nature Conservancy's plan to sell 10.3 acres to the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory has raised concerns among some local residents.

title: BRINGING FORTH A DEFICIT 'MOUSE'
description: IT was no grand design for Federal budget deficit reduction that was brought forth after four grueling weeks of top-level negotiations. It was, as some members of the team themselves dubbed it, a ''mouse.''

title: Can the Giants And the Jets Still Make The Playoffs?
description: The Giants lost twice to a team (Dallas) that lost to the hapless Detroit Lions. They're going to be lucky to break even -and it serves them right for going to New Jersey. As for the other team in the Garden State - their chances are much better. I'd prefer, however, that they're passed by the only football team in New York State - the Bills. Let's have the professional champs and collegiate football champs (Syracuse) in our great state. ROB HOMA Brooklyn

title: Roerich's 'Sacre' Shines in the Joffrey's Light
description: SEVERAL KEY POINTS COME TO mind with the Joffrey Ballet's vibrant reconstruction of ''Le Sacre du Printemps.'' One is that this unprecedented attempt to revive Vaslav Nijinsky's lost choreography succeeds in revealing the full meaning of the ballet. Dropped shortly after its premiere in 1913, the first ''Sacre'' and its content have been difficult to visualize over the decades, difficult to comprehend.

title: Forestry Group Seeks Tougher Pollution Controls
description: The American Forestry Association says acid rain and other air pollution are harming the nation's forests and has called on Congress to act to strengthen controls on the pollutants.

title: Before Turkey, a Soup Course
description: ONE of the most convenient first courses to serve for Thanksgiving dinner is soup. Most soups lend themselves to advance preparation, if not several days beforehand at least early in the day. They can be reheated when dinner is ready to serve.

title: Lawns Turn Brown, Pockets Are Green
description: In an emotional response to two articles appearing on Oct. 25, I must write you this letter. The articles were titled ''Nassau Water Restrictions Are Here to Stay'' [ Long Island Weekly ] and ''Hempstead Opens Tap on Development,'' subtitled ''Water Curb Over, 3 Projects Planned For Mitchel Field'' [ Real Estate ] . The headlines alone seem to contradict.

title: SPECIALTIES APPEAL TO COLLECTORS
description: THE degree of acceptability of ''philatelically prepared'' material, which includes covers or related items manufactured for collectors, varies greatly. Advanced collectors of postal history avoid prepared pieces whenever legitimate postal usages are available.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: IN THE WAKE OF THE BUDGET TALKS;
Social Spending Can Avert a Recession
description: LEAD: DON'T cut Federal social programs - particularly not now - as Congress and the President are preparing to do. Social spending can help stave off a recession, or at least reduce its severity.

title: Madison Avenue's Baby Boom
description: THE baby, clad in a diaper and man-sized wingtips, carries a rattle in one hand, a briefcase in the other and a message from the Prudential Insurance Company of America: Small-business executives, the ad proclaims, should protect themselves from takeovers by heirs of deceased partners. You've come a long way, baby. Once just relegated to pitches for diapers, baby food, clothing and toys, babies are turning up in the oddest advertising places these days: They have graduated from the pages of women's magazines to business journals, touting products ranging from tires and computers to I.R.A.'s and sophisticated insurance plans. Advertisers seem to have concluded in the last year that there's nothing like a baby to make even the most jaded baby-boomer sit up and take notice.

title: Jeanne L. Walker Becomes a Bride
description: Jeanne Lockwood Walker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fisk Halsted Walker of Laurel, Miss., was married there yesterday to William Evans Hannum 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hannum 2d of Alexandria, Va., and Siasconset, Mass.

title: ROUTE 9 REMAINS AN ISSUE
description: LEAD: POLITICAL activity on Routes 9 and 9A, slowed first by this fall's elections and now by municipal budget deliberations, is expected to increase after the first of the year. At that time local officials are expected to renew pressure on the State Department of Transportation to improve conditions on the heavily traveled state-owned roads.

title: JAZZ QUARTET: RON ODRICH
description: THE jazz quartet that Ron Odrich leads at Charlie O's (Park Avenue at 39th Street) on Thursdays from 6 to 9 P.M., might be viewed merely as an interesting novelty group if it were not also one of the best small jazz groups playing today.

title: Martha Victoria Suits Marries M. C. Schram
description: St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church was the setting in New York yesterday for the wedding of Martha Victoria Suits, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Suits of Muttontown, L.I., to Michael Christopher Schram, a son of John Michael Schram of New York and Betty Dabbs Schram of Memphis. The Rev. Walter F. Modry performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Richard A. Burnett, an Episcopal priest.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The red brick floor in our sunroom is 11 years old and has become soiled. How should we clean this brick and what can we do to keep the bricks clean without painting?

title: Gay Groups Win Equal Privileges at Georgetown
description: Georgetown University must provide homosexual student groups with the same privileges given other campus organizations, an appeals court here has ruled.

title: Tar Heels Knock Off Orange
description: What a classic way to begin the college basketball season: Syracuse, last season's runner-up in the N.C.A.A tournament and the top preseason pick this season, against North Carolina, a glamour team acknowledged to have one of the best coaches in the business.

title: AFTER YELTSIN, GORBACHEV?
description: LEAD: With Boris N. Yeltsin, the deposed Moscow party chief, tucked safely into a senior post in the construction industry, the Kremlin's spin-control artists are hard at work minimizing the affair. The West should not fall for their wiles.

title: TRAVEL INSPIRES ARTIST AND AUTHOR
description: LEAD: TRAVELING all over the world revives the creative spirit of Marcia Brown of Redding. India and Africa, for example, were the settings for two of the three works that earned her a national award for children's picture books.

title: Rights Group Links India to Moslem Deaths
description: Amnesty International has charged that local provincial policemen were directly involved in the slaying or disappearance of dozens of unarmed Moslems during several days of Hindu-Moslem rioting in northern India last May.

title: Ferdinand Wins by a Nose
description: Two Kentucky Derby winners strained for the wire in the world's richest horse race today, and it took a photo finish to show that Ferdinand had nosed out Alysheba to win the $3 million Breeders' Cup Classic at Hollywood Park.

title: BIOGRAPHY SERIES AT 11 SITES
description: JOHN BURTON, an anthropology professor at Connecticut College, wanted to know more about the anthropologist Margaret Mead. He said he wanted to ''delve into her personal side, to understand something about the person who has created such a powerful image.'' So he read her biography, ''With a Daughter's Eye,'' written by her daughter, Katherine Bateson, also an anthropologist and Mr. Burton's first anthropology professor.

title: Dance: A New Work By Wim Vandekeybus
description: TOUGH, brutal, playful, ironic and terrific. Adjectives seem unduly passive in describing ''What the Body Does Not Remember,'' the extraordinarily innovative dance piece that concludes the ''New Work From Belgium'' series at the Kitchen.

title: Rumanians Riot Over Pay Cut and Shortages
description: Several thousand rioting workers ransacked the city hall in the industrial city of Brasov last Sunday, driven to the streets by severe pay cuts and the prospect of a third consecutive winter of food and energy shortages.

title: 3 Alliances Head Standings In Fall Bridge Championship
description: Three top-ranked partnerships headed the standings going into the final session of the American Contract Bridge League's Life Master Men's Pair Championship here tonight.

title: MS. PUGH TO WED W. G. FILMYER JR.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roger V. Pugh Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin Marie Pugh to William George Filmyer Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Filmyer of Philadelphia and Loveladies, N.J.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Hovnanian Planning a Mixed-Use Project
description: LEAD: THE tract in North Brunswick invited development - 189 acres of vacant land off Route 1 in the center of the state, an area already bustling with office buildings and shopping centers.

title: Miss Speranza Marries Bruce Andrew Wiener
description: Karen Elaine Speranza, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony R. Speranza of Springfield, N.J., was married last evening at the Plaza Hotel in New York to Bruce Andrew Wiener, a son of Ethelind Wiener of New York and Seymour Wiener of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I. Rabbi Shimon Berris and the Rev. John Sweeney, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: RIGHTIST PARTIES FORMING IN EUROPE
description: Exploiting mounting resentment over refugees and workers from third world nations, small right-wing parties have cropped up across the northern tier of Western Europe demanding the expulsion of foreigners who are said to be taking jobs from Europeans.

title: Finding The 'Key Link'
description: Too many Westerners are accepting the idea that communism can achieve prosperity by employing a form of controlled capitalism. Buyers of this notion find few sellers, resulting in a wild run-up in the market of political optimism.

title: TAKING THE MEASURE OF VLADIMER FELTSMAN
description: WHAT IF, BEFORE ALEXAN-der Solzhenitsyn arrived in this country in 1976, all we knew of his work was one chapter of ''The Gulag Archipelago.'' Imagine the curiosity, the aura of mystery, the political speculation, the cultural glamour that would have surrounded the publication on these shores of the entire, all but legendary, book.

title: Downfall of a Mayor
description: Anyone keeping a list of drug-blighted careers these days would have to add that of 42-year-old James E. (Mike) Roark, the popular mayor of Charleston, W. Va.

title: Can the Giants And the Jets Still Make The Playoffs?
description: ''Can the Giants and the Jets still make the playoffs?'' Only if Charlie Conerly and Joe Namath assume quarterback duties for the Giants and Jets, respectively, for the remainder of the season. Otherwise, wait till next year! NICHOLAS D. DECURTIS New York

title: Donna L. Kaplan Is Wed To David E. Rabinowitz
description: Donna Leigh Kaplan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Kaplan of Old Westbury, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married last evening to David Edward Rabinowitz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul J. Rabinowitz of Bridgewater, N.J. Rabbi Joseph Sternstein officiated at the Glen Head (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Fatal Attraction Indeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Harvard First in Soccer
description: Harvard and Yale played to a 0-0 tie in soccer today and the result gave the unbeaten Crimson the Ivy League championship for the first time since 1970.

title: SCHOOLS EXTENDING KINDERGARTEN DAY
description: THE State Education Department thinks that for kindergartners, two and a half hours is not enough. The department, with a grant of $1 million, has helped 17 local school boards to start or to expand a variety of extended kindergarten programs this year beyond the two and a half hours a day that many districts offer and plans to ask the legislature for more money to start or expand such programs next school year.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
THE CLASSIC COUNTY
description: LEAD: The county has started a new marketing campaign and its success may be measured as much in miles as in money.

title: MOVIES
description: Westfront 1918 Directed by G. W. Pabst. Nelson Entertainment-International Collection. 90 minutes. $29.95. You can't help thinking about ''All Quiet on the Western Front'' while watching ''Westfront 1918.'' Both are antiwar movies from the point of view of German troops in the World War I trenches; both were made in 1930, ''All Quiet'' in the United States, ''Westfront'' in Germany. Although the German work, directed by G. W. Pabst (''Pandora's Box,'' ''The Threepenny Opera''), isn't nearly as moving as ''All Quiet,'' it has a power of its own.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
ART
description: LEAD: Crete and Mycenae Museum Without Walls. Kartes Video Communications. 54 minutes. $14.95. This complex, fascinating film traces what is known of the history of the Minoan civilization, which flourished peaceably on Crete around 2100-1500 B.C., and relates it to Heinrich Schliemann's famous archeological finds at Mycenae, on the Greek mainland, in 1876.

title: Access of Young to Telephone Pornography Faces Key Challenge in
description: One day last June, a 12-year-old boy spent two and a half hours calling and listening to sexually explicit messages on telephone pornography services. Two weeks later he sexually assaulted a 4-year-old girl.

title: WESTPORT'S BOOM STRAINS PARKING
description: LEAD: PEOPLE who live and work in Westport say they have been shuffling, circling and schlepping. They have just been trying to park their cars and go to jobs, stores or amusements.

title: James E. Folsom, Colorful Politician and Twice Governor of Alabama, Is Dead at 79
description: James E. Folsom, a Democrat who served twice as Governor of Alabama, died yesterday at his home in Cullman, Ala. He was 79 years old and had been in failing health in recent years.

title: FAIRFIELD U. EYES N.C.A.A. SPOT
description: LEAD: THE Fairfield University campus was thrilled the past two winters as the men's basketball team, for the first time, earned berths to the N.C.A.A. tournament. This year there is a hope that the women's team will also gain a trip to the tournament.

title: D-DAYS AND THE END OF WORLD WAR II
description: Sarah Clayton's moving essay, ''What Will Happen to My Sons'' [ Opinion page, Oct. 11 ] , was in error when she referred to June 6, 1944, as the day ''when the allies began their long-awaited advance on Europe that eventually brought World War II to an end.'' Historically, this was not the case.

title: Koreans in U.S. Stump for Their Men in Seoul
description: At a rally in Queens last week for a presidential candidate in South Korea, Kim Young Sam, the largest bouquet of red and yellow crysanthemums came from supporters of his chief rival in the opposition, Kim Dae Jung.

title: James Howard, Production Director, Is Planning to Wed Ris Miller in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. William R. Miller of New York and Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mr. Miller's daughter Marissa Harris Miller to James W. Howard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Howard of Gill, Colo. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Catering to the 'Four-Wheel Religion' Folks
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Group Proposes Construction Tax to Finance Housing
description: The New Jersey Economic Policy Council has proposed a statewide tax on new construction to finance housing for low- and moderate-income families.

title: F.A.A. Begins Review of Standards for Pilots
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is reviewing its pilot certification rules and looking at the flight experience of airline pilots.

title: Liquor Smuggling to Canada Is Brisk
description: Philip Letourneau Sr. returned to his dairy farm in Derby, Vt., one evening early this month to find two trucks bearing Canadian license plates abandoned in mud in a hayfield.

title: Redevelopment Regaining Momentum in Asbury Park
description: EVEN for this depressed Shore city, it seemed a particularly cruel blow late last September when fire destroyed 16 town houses along Wesley Lake.

title: Patricia Gillette To Marry in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stanley C. Gillette of Kent, Conn., and New York of the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Gillette, to Steven R. Norman, the son of JoAnn Mickler-Bischoff of Sarasota, Fla., and stepson of Gustave Bischoff. A May wedding is planned.

title: CAN WE ASK MOR OF OUR LEADERS THAN WE ASK OF OURSELVES?
description: To the Editor:

title: FUNK ROCK: DAVID MOSS'S DENSE BAND
description: IN 1985, David Moss released ''Dense Band,'' an album that distilled downtown noise improvisation into song-length chunks and added a funk beat now and then. It was a showcase for Mr. Moss's precise, clattery drumming and his peculiar specialty: improvised vocal gibberish that can evoke anything from a newscast in Lithuanian to a soprano wrestling a hyena.

title: Lee Nicholson Martin, Journalist, 71
description: Lee Nicholson Martin, a journalist who covered some of the pivotal events of her era in the United States, Europe and Asia, died Wednesday of cancer at her home in Washington. She was 71 years old.

title: Gina Capella Has Wedding
description: Gina M. Capella, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rafael F. Capella of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., and Michael E. Martin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Martin of San Francisco, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Tuxedo, N.Y. The Rev. John F. Breen performed the ceremony.

title: Oklahoma (11-0) Rises to Occasion
description: For two weeks, the Nebraska fans who regularly pack Memorial Stadium with their red outerwear listed the factors that would win this year's game of the century.

title: Streetscapes: The Audubon Theater; On Upper Broadway, the Genesis of the Fox Empire
description: AFTER the completion of the city's first subway in 1904, Upper Broadway saw accelerated building of apartment houses, theaters and stores as the street became a sort of regional rialto. The West Side's new housing and river views attracted more and more people from older neighborhoods who could still commute to the business districts on the clean, safe IRT subway extending down to City Hall.

title: Lyrical Mist
description: SHAKESPEARE WALLAH Starring Shashi Kapoor and Felicity Kendal (both in photo). Produced by Ismail Merchant. Directed by James Ivory. Written by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala and James Ivory. 1965. Embassy Home Entertainment. 120 minutes. $39.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The red brick floor in our sunroom is 11 years old and has become soiled. How should we clean this brick and what can we do to keep the bricks clean without painting?

title: A HUNGER FOR JUSTICE
description: WHERE SIXPENCE LIVES By Norma Kitson. Illustrated. 326 pp. Topsfield, Mass.: The Hogarth Press/Salem House. Paper, $7.95.

title: Stage: Redd Foxx And Pals
description: THE entertainment world of Las Vegas is so far removed in spirit from Broadway that performers who have become fixtures in Nevada often arrive in New York pathetically unprepared to translate their showroom acts into theatrically coherent variety shows. One of the most painful illustrations in recent memory was provided on Thursday evening by Redd Foxx, the 64-year-old pioneer of blue humor, who arrived at the Academy Theater, 234 West 43d Street, for a limited engagement.

title:
MUSIC;
A Wide Choice of Chamber Music
description: LEAD: STRING QUARTET enthusiasts will have their choice of programs today, with performances this afternooon and evening by the Franciscan, Eder and Orion Quartets.

title: California Spa Town With an Earthy Touch
description: SEVENTY-FIVE miles north of San Francisco, Mount St. Helena looms over the northern Napa Valley town that the Wappo Indians called ''Colaynomo,'' or ''oven place,'' because underground heat warmed the local hot springs.

title:
GARDENING;
2 Easily Forced Bulbs to Brighten Winter
description: LEAD: FEW winter gardening activities bring greater satisfaction than forcing bulbs. While most spring-flowering bulbs require lengthy treatment under special conditions before they will force, two exceptions, giant amarylis and polyanthus narcissus, may be forced easily and quickly.

title: IOWANS STRUGGLE WITH GROWING WATER POLLUTION
description: Ever since he discovered that his farm well was contaminated with fertilizers, Steve Shivvers had been carrying his drinking water home in a plastic jug, filled from the tap at his family's business in this small town in southern Iowa.

title: Defensive Error Sinks Seton Hall
description: A miscommunication between a defender and the goalkeeper cost Seton Hall dearly in its 2-1 loss to Rutgers this afternoon in the Mid-Atlantic final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.

title: Paying Attention To Fighting
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Social Events
description: A Time for Thanksgiving Notables at the Waldorf Nov. 23 - Paul A. Volcker is scheduled to present an award to Jimmy Carter, Henry A. Kissinger will make a presentation to Gerald R. Ford, and Patti LuPone and Robert Merrill will entertain at the 33d annual Humanitarian Awards Dinner of United Cerebral Palsy of New York at the Waldorf-Astoria. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. will begin the black-tie benefit, which has raised a total of $8 million for the charity. Tickets, $400 or $500, from 212-683-6700. Brazilian Evening Nov. 23 - Brazilian music and food at Avery Fisher Hall will mark the 10th anniversary of the Brazilian Cultural Foundation and will benefit its programs that strengthen cultural ties in the Americas. A concert of Brazilian popular music and classical guitar selections will begin at 8 P.M., followed by dinner. Black tie. Tickets, $300 or $20, $25 and $30 for the concert alone, from 212-661-9860. For Children in Need Nov. 24 - Founded in 1869, St. Vincent's Services in Brooklyn has provided a haven for homeless children and other services, including adoption, foster care and counseling. The charity's annual benefit will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria, starting with cocktails at 6 P.M., followed by dinner and music. Tickets, $250, from 718-522-3700, extension 204 or 358. Teen-Agers' Dance Nov. 28 - The 8th annual Churchill Dance is scheduled from 8 P.M. to midnight at the the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The nonalcoholic evening is for preparatory-school students in the 9th, 10th and 11th grades. The Churchill School and Center, founded in 1972 for learning-disabled children in kindergarten through the 8th grade, will be the beneficiary. Black tie requested. Tickets, $100, from 212-722-0610. Briefly Noted: Nov. 30 - The Visiting Nurse Service of New York will present its annual Lillian D. Wald Award at a dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria, starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Black tie. Tickets, $500, from 212-794-9200. Nov. 30 - Madre, a project of the Women's Peace Network that promotes friendship and assistance for women and children in Central America, will hold a benefit screening of ''Walker,'' starring Ed Harris and Marlee Matlin, at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. A Champagne reception with the movie's cast will follow. Tickets, $100 and $250, from 212-627-0444. Nov. 30 - Broadway performers will salute St. Clare's Hospital at a benefit dinner and awards presentation at the Marriott Marquis, starting with cocktails at 7 P.M. Black tie. Tickets, $250, from 212-459-8414. Dec. 1 - The 13th annual awards gala of the Association of Tennis Professionals will begin at 6 P.M. with cocktails at the New York Hilton. Peter Allen will entertain at the black-tie dinner-dance, a benefit for the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. Tickets, $300, from 212-751-5847. Dec. 1 - To complete its new studio, the Eric Hawkins Dance Company has scheduled a 7 P.M. benefit performance that will include the New York premiere of ''God the Reveller.'' The performance at the Joyce Theater, 178 Eighth Avenue (19th Street), will be followed by dinner at Rogers & Barbero restaurant. Tickets, $125, from 212-255-6698. Dec. 1 - Bill Blass will present selections from his fall collection at 11 A.M. on the third floor of Saks Fifth Avenue at a benefit for the Boys' Club of New York. Lunch at the ''21'' Club will follow. Tickets, $85 or $45 for show alone, from 212-677-1105. Dec. 1 - The Hebrew Arts School, which operates the Merkin Concert Hall at 129 West 67th Street and presents programs of music, dance, art, theater and Jewish culture, is holding an 8 P.M. benefit concert at the concert hall, followed by a Champagne reception. Tickets, $250 a pair, from 212-362-8060. Dec. 2 - The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater will open its four-week season at City Center with the United States premiere of ''The Magic of Katherine Dunham'' at 7:30 P.M., followed by cocktails and supper at the Grand Hyatt (transportation will be provided). Tickets for the black-tie evening, $350, from 212-921-8977. Dec. 2 - Sidney Lumet, E. L. Doctorow and Saul Steinberg - last year's winners of lifetime achievement awards presented by Guild Hall, a cultural center in East Hampton, L.I. - are scheduled to present this year's awards to Joseph Heller, Jerome Robbins and Roy Lichtenstein at a 7:30 P.M. benefit dinner at Tavern on the Green. Tickets, $225, from 516-324-0807. Dec. 2 - The American Berlin Opera Foundation, which awarded scholarships last year to three Americans to study at the Berlin Opera, is holding a dinner-dance and musical presentation at the Pierre. The black-tie benefit will begin with cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets, $225, from 212-664-0140. Crossroads Africa Dec. 2 - Since its founding in 1957, Operation Crossroads Africa has sent over 8,000 young Americans to rural African and Caribbean communities to work on small development projects in medicine, agriculture, education and construction. And over the past 23 years, more than 3,200 young African political leaders and professionals have visited the United States. Under a new program sponsored by the Ford Foundation, minority graduate and postgraduate students will spend a year working and studying in Africa. The 30th anniversary awards dinner of the organization will be held at the Marriott Marquis, starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Black tie or national dress. Tickets, $200, from 212-260-1070.

title: Women Advised to Seek State Posts
description: Women aspiring to political power would do best right now to pursue state, not national, office, if they want to work at the cutting edge of public policy.

title: Cross Raised in Memory Becomes a Town Issue
description: Rhoda Levesque remembers well when village workers placed a wooden cross atop a Christmas tree on the county courthouse lawn in 1958. The cross was in memory of her young husband, a local sports star who died that year in a mill accident.

title: Felicia Walker Plans To Wed Law Student
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul T. Walker of South Salem, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Felicia Louise Walker to Jeffrey David Saferstein, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald R. Saferstein of Paramus, N.J.

title: Mets Will Open At Home April 12
description: There are just 142 days to go before the Mets' 1988 home opener at Shea Stadium, an afternoon game (1:35 P.M.) on Tuesday, April 12, against the Montreal Expos.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
PILGRIMS' PROGRESS
description: LEAD: THE only thing missing was the aroma of roasting turkeys. Thanksgiving was around the corner, and on the Sisqua campus of the Rippowam-Sisqua School pupils, teachers and even the principal were aflutter with preparations.

title: TO BE RAPED, BRED OR ABUSED
description: LEAD: INCIDENTS IN THE LIFE OF A SLAVE GIRL Written by Herself. By Harriet A. Jacobs. Edited by L. Maria Child. New edition edited by Jean Fagan Yellin. 306 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Cloth, $37.50. Paper, $9.95.

title: MOVIES
description: Defense of the Realm Starring Gabriel Byrne, Greta Scacchi and Denholm Elliott. Directed by David Drury. 1986. Embassy Home Entertainment. 97 minutes. $79.95. If moodiness was all that counted, this film might be a blockbuster. It captures, with great success, the gray, somber, claustrophobic atmosphere that characterizes the best British espionage films. There is also a handful of those deft, understated performances we've come to associate with this sort of undertaking.

title: Winter and Repentance Descend Upon Moscow Again
description: A VISITOR who never really expected shades of Dostoyevsky's creatures to loom amid the slanting snow is surprised to sense Koestler's Rubashov - a more likely ghost in the city these days. This was the fictitious character of ''Darkness at Noon'' modeled on Bukharin, who was expelled from the Party in 1937 and executed the next year, the doomed star of Stalin's infamous purge trials and one of the more articulate Bolsheviks, who finally received a few words of rehabilitation last month from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the current Soviet leader. They came decades after Bukharin's demise in the ''absolutely black vacuity'' of fate he anticipated, his execution and official ignominy.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Jail Barge Blunder
description: It seemed like a good idea last spring: Turn a floating barracks from England into instant New York City jail cells. Today, all too late, it looks like an enormous blunder.

title: The Legacy
description: It was just about as exciting as the Al Capone vault caper.

title: TROVES FOR RESEARCHING AT HISTORICAL SOCIETY
description: Tessa Melvin's article, ''1917: When Women Won Right to Vote'' [ Nov. 1 ] , did a fine job of presenting the highlights of an article written by Elizabeth Fuller, librarian of the Westchester County Historical Society.

title: Europe Hailing Plan on Deficit; Meeting Sought
description: European officials today hailed Washington's plan to cut its budget deficit, saying the plan would help restore confidence to the world's nervous stock markets.

title: Miss Balfour Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Kimberly Elizabeth Balfour, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thurston Theodore Balfour of Newport News, Va., and Annapolis, Md., to Hugh Franklin Bennett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Franklin Bennett of Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday in Newburyport, Mass. The Rev. Richard Gosselin performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church.

title: Bounty of Concerts Heralds Thanksgiving
description: THE rush to clear the musical decks before Thanksgiving is most decidedly on, with at least half a dozen attractive entries on today's concert calendar. Squeezing in half an hour ahead of most of the competition is another of the New Rochelle Library's ''Music, Wine and Cheese'' recitals, the 2:30 P.M. program divided between arias and songs by the soprano Jolanta Rajewska, and chamber performances by the violin-cellopiano trio of Harold Silverstein, Marjorie Borgia and Janet Sussman Gartner (632-7878).

title: In the Right Case, Jury Duty Can Pay
description: WHEN Mark Lesly learned that he had been selected to serve as a juror in the trial of Bernhard H. Goetz, he decided to dictate his daily impressions of the case into a tape recorder.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: BOSTON;
Renovation For Art's Sake
description: LEAD: CITY LIGHTS, a nonprofit performing arts school and production house, has taken an unusual approach to the redevelopment of a burned-out building it acquired from the Boston Redevelopment Authority.

title: Ellen C. Shapiro Is Married to Bruce A. Wolfson
description: Ellen Carol Shapiro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Shapiro of Lawrence, L.I., and Bruce Alan Wolfson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Theodore Wolfson of Northbrook, Ill., were married last evening. Rabbi Allan Blaine officiated at the Hotel Pierre in Manhattan.

title: TRAVELS IN THE QUIRKY LATITUDES
description: IT'S RAINING IN MANGO Pictures From a Family Album. By Thea Astley. 208 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: Underwear Magnate Rules Out an '88 Bid
description: An underwear magnate who has roundly criticized President Reagan and the Democratic Presidential candidates has decided against seeking the Democratic nomination himself because ''there is not time enough to run.''

title: Q AND A
description: Mitchell-Lama Rents Question: I have requested the rent history of my apartment, but I was told by the district rent office that since Ruppert-Yorkville Towers is a Mitchell-Lama building the managment is not required to give it to me. Are increases on these buildings limited as they are for rent-stabilized housing? . . . J. G., Manhattan Answer: Ruppert-Yorkville Towers is a city Mitchell-Lama housing project and as such comes under the jurisdiction of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. According to Catie Marshall, a spokesman for the agency, there are limits on rent increases for Mitchell-Lama housing but those limits are not in accordance with the Rent Stabilization Code.

title: Hildi Rosenfeld to Wed Richard Silbert in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Isadore Rosenfeld of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hildi Victoria Rosenfeld, to Richard W. Silbert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald F. Silbert of Boston and Chestnut Hill, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Orchestra, and Conductor, Steeped in the Past
description: THE ORCHESTRA OF THE EIGHT-eenth Century has been touring the Midwest by bus of late - pneumatic tires, diesel engines and state-of-the-art suspension systems bearing the weight of 200-year-old instruments, styles and sensibilities.

title: Telltale Pantyhose Purchase
description: WHAT a microcosm of human behavior (not all of it good) can be found in a large store's hosiery department on a Saturday morning, as I well know from working there.

title: The Military Spurns the Temptation Of a Draft
description: MILITARY conscription, an issue that never quite goes away, and the closely related idea of having all young people devote a term of service to their country, are increasingly under discussion.

title: Who's In Charge Here?
description: TO HIS SUPPORTERS in the early 1980's, Army Col.

title: Union Gains In Overtime
description: Union, regarded as perhaps the best team in the state, responded to a Linden touchdown in overtime with one of its own yesterday and won, 10-9, at Union to gain the final round of the North Jersey Section 2, Group IVplayoffs.

title: Which Way Public TV?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Scheck To Wed in May
description: Jennifer Jane Scheck, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank F. Scheck of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Gary Wayne Lee, the son of Mrs. James Mallicoat and Alton Lee, both of Spokane, Wash., plan to marry in May, the future bride's parents have announced.

title: Dr. Swan to Wed Fellow Physician

title: CAREER SERVICES AT COLLEGES
description: Regarding the article ''Fairfield U. Program: 10 Years of Career Help'' [ Oct. 18 ] , I would like to call attention to the fact that Fairfield University is not the only institution in Fairfield County to offer such career counseling and related services to the general public.

title: A MAGAZINE JUNKIE
description: I thought I was the only such magazine junkie. I, too, have classics and fine books waiting to be read - someday. They wait on the end table beside my bed, but stacked on the floor is an even taller pile of magazines. I subscribe to 11 regularly and buy four more each month.

title: How I Was Rescued, Like It or Not
description: I HAVE discovered that if you fall down and knock yourself out in a public place on Long Island, you become part of a rescue system. You are a cog in a wheel, and you can't escape until the system is finished.

title: NONFICTION
description: MIXED BLESSINGS: Marriage Between Jews and Christians. By Paul Cowan with Rachel Cowan. (Doubleday, $18.95.) After 15 years of marriage, Rachel Cowan converted to Judaism, her husband's religion, and she is now studying to be a rabbi. Paul Cowan, a reporter for The Village Voice, is the author of ''An Orphan in History,'' an exploration of his Jewish identity. Drawn from their own experience, cases from the intermarriage workshops they conduct and interviews, their book is a revealing look into the hearts, minds and souls of intermarried couples. The authors offer a historical perspective by examining previous generations of the interfaith families of Max Lerner and Ken Auletta, the political writers, as well as the relatives of the conflicted and never-married poet Emma Lazarus. In the present time, the Cowans address the emotional time bombs that erupt when an intermarried couple confronts their religious roots. The book probes the complexities of intermarriage with detail and candor, and many readers will recognize themselves in the stories. Of intermarriage in general, the Cowans assert, ''the Jewish community is preoccupied with it. The Christian world barely notices it.'' They explain that because of anti-Semitism and the Holocaust, Jews feel a strong need to preserve their legacy, but go on to imply that gentiles don't feel as strongly as Jews about preserving their heritage. There is an imbalance of interviews in favor of converts to Judaism, and even the Cowans' reading list makes the argument that the gentile spouse in a mixed marriage should convert to Judaism. In a book that skillfully uses psychological insight to illuminate its subjects' motivations, one must question the underlying message of its one epigraph, preceding the chapter on children and intermarriage. A 4-year-old boy tells his friend, ''I'm half Jewish and half nothing.'' A highly perceptive examination of intermarriage, ''Mixed Blessings'' nevertheless sometimes seems to tell only half the story.

title: RACE-CAR DRIVER STRESSES SAFETY
description: LEAD: THOSE who assume that race-car drivers are a wild, reckless lot will have to rethink their stereotypes if they meet A. J. (Buddy) Pugliese of New Rochelle.

title: Bears of Summer
description: To the Editor:

title: Storm Surprises Truk Island; 5 Are Dead Amid Wide Ruin
description: A tropical storm with 70-mile-an-hour winds slammed into the capital island of the Pacific archipelago of Truk early today, killing five people and destroying most of the buildings.

title: THE COURSING HUDSON GIVES SOLACE AND CARRIES AWAY A FRIEND'S SORROW
description: THE autumn winds bring fierce whitecaps to Haverstraw Bay. Even on the calmest days, I've yet to see another rowing shell scudding along the Hudson. On the wild days, the whitecaps transform the smooth precision of rowing to a delicate balancing act that slams spray over the bow and threatens to overturn my slender craft.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on the film page of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect title for a movie directed by Leonard Nimoy that is to open on Wednesday. It is ''Three Men and a Baby.''

title: Eve Parish Chilton Marries Film Company Executive
description: Eve Parish Chilton, the director of family program acquisitions for the Miramex Films Corporation, a distribution and production company in New York, and Harvey Weinstein, a co-chairman of Miramex, were married last evening at the Lotos Club in Manhattan. The Rev. Fred Baldwin, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Charles D. Lippman officiated.

title: Headliners; Reaching Out
description: Not since former Mayor John V. Lindsay abandoned his upbringing to become a Democrat in 1971 had the Democrats made such a fuss over a New York Republican. Donald J. Trump, the billionaire investor and real-estate developer, last week was asked by Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House of Representatives, to be the host at a major fund-raising event, the 25th annual Democratic Congressional dinner in Washington in March. ''He's young, dynamic, successful,'' said Representative Beryl Anthony Jr. of Arkansas, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, noting that at least some of Mr. Trump's views do correspond with the Democrats'. Mr. Trump said he had no plans to change parties, but would consider the invitation to come to the aid of one.

title: CALLING ON PROFESSIONALS IN SPECIAL EDUCATION
description: In a world where television and stereo compete for children's attention, I would say that any positive endeavor to entice children to read is to be applauded. Your article on the ''Debate on Tutoring Centers'' [ Nov. 1 ] , however, needs to be addressed from broader perspective. As a professor of education and a private practitioner, I would urge parents whose children need additional academic help to investigate all supportive services in their community and not merely those who advertise and make public claims.

title: Spanish Leader Is Firm in Opposing U.S. Jets
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said Friday that Spain would stick to its decision to bar United States F-16 jet fighters from Spanish soil, despite strong pressure from European allies on behalf of the United States.

title: In Clifton, a Fantasy World Where Santa Would Feel at Home
description: LEAD: FROM the outside, Bond Parade Floats here is a nondescript garage on a long street that also is home to other warehouses and industrial buildings.

title: The Aulenti Uproar
description: GAE AULENTI WAS THE last person to arrive. It was midnight on a balmy September evening in Milan, and guests clad in fashionable short silk dresses and tailored suits were finishing their gelato or strolling through the grand 17th-century palazzo home of their host, the furniture designer Mario Bellini.

title: Rent Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WONDERFUL ART OF VULGARITY
description: PSYCHOTIC REACTIONS AND CARBURETOR DUNG By Lester Bangs. Edited by Greil Marcus. 386 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: READING THE CARDS
description: WHEN a worldclass player in a team match picks up his hand at the start of a deal and examines it, he is normally full of confidence. He expects to outbid and outplay the opposition.

title: KRASDALE'S 'NIGHTWORKS': AN URBAN-RURAL NOCTURNE
description: FOOD Center Drive in the Bronx could be renamed Alimentary Avenue or even De Gustibus Road but it would still be gentry-proof. All things considered, this is a mercy, because the drive is the very aorta of Hunts Point and without its warehouses and processing facilities New York City, Westchester, Long Island, southern Connecticut and a large part of New Jersey might starve to death in a matter of weeks.

title: Correction
description: The By the Numbers statistical feature in Sports last Sunday inaccurately described the Oklahoma winning streak that was ended by Nebraska in 1959 and gave an incorrect figure for the length of the streak.

title: L.I. Coach Homes
description: In the Midwest, where winters can be mean, an attached garage is seen by many home buyers as a necessity, not a luxury.

title: Interpreting A Russian Poet's Cosmic Language
description: DAVID WARRILOW, WHO HAS made a career of interpreting the compressed poetry of Samuel Beckett's minimalist dramas, is currently assuming the challenge of a play by a Revolutionary-era Russian poet that has words enough to spare, including those of the author's invented language.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A WORLD TOO WIDE. By Gregory Mcdonald. (Hill/ Kampmann, $17.95.) About a third of the way through Gregory Mcdonald's new novel, one character asks another: ''What the hell are you and I doing sitting here this June morning by a swimming pool on a farm in Tennessee?'' An apt question, and one the reader has likely asked about 60 pages earlier.

title: CHOOSING THE RIGHT PAINTBRUSH
description: MANY homeowners give little thought to choosing a paintbrush. Others find the array of brushes confusing and the choice difficult.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Pass the Chopped Liver, It's Thanksgiving
description: LEAD: THANKSGIVING: the very word fills me with warm anticipation. ''Be thankful'' is the only holiday edict (subtitle: ''and do something with a turkey''). It is still as simple, joyous and unstructured as in Colonial times.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WEAVEWORLD. By Clive Barker. (Poseidon, $18.95.) In ''Weaveworld,'' the 35-year-old English novelist Clive Barker reveals his prodigious talent for erecting make-believe worlds in the midst of Mrs. Thatcher's tumbledown kingdom of Windsorian privilege and secretly policed ghettos. Reaching into its degraded and strangely fertile streets, he creates a fantastic romance of magic and promise that is at once popular fiction and utopian conjuring.

title: States Act to Provide Health Care Benefits To Uninsured People
description: States around the country are taking action to make health care more available for millions of people who lack insurance, according to state officials and health researchers.

title: THE WOMAN WHO BEAT THE KLAN
description: I thank Jesse Kornbluth for his gripping account of Michael Donald's tragic death and of his mother's commitment to justice. I lived in the South at the time and was outraged that a pack of social misfits like the Klan could get away with such treacherous acts in the 1980's.

title:
INVESTING;
Strategists' Latest Obsession: Cyclicals
description: LEAD: WALL STREET strategists, portfolio managers and analysts have a tendency to become obsessed with certain figures or industries. At various times, they have been single-minded about the money supply figures, the price of oil and, recently, the trade deficit figures.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE LETTERS OF BERNARD BERENSON AND ISABELLA STEWART GARDNER, 1887-1924: With Correspondence by Mary Berenson. Edited by Rollin van N. Hadley. (Northeastern University, $49.95 until Jan. 1; $65 thereafter.) This is a volume for specialists in the life of Bernard Berenson, the renowned and recently much written-about art critic and business partner to the rapacious art dealer Joseph Duveen. The letters published here begin in 1887, when Berenson was a 22-year-old Harvard prodigy on his Grand Tour of Europe, writing back to his patron, the American heiress Mrs. Isabella Stewart Gardner, in Boston. The vast majority of the letters published are Berenson's; the longest and strongest are the early ones, when B.B., as he was known, fancied himself a writer. In tirelessly ingratiating and grandiloquent prose, he wrote of the books he was reading on his travels. Gradually, though, paintings caught his attention, and we see the transformation from struggling writer to professional connoisseur. Curiously, the letters most evocative of time and place are those written by Berenson's wife, Mary, during World War I, when she vividly and despairingly told of life in a deserted Florence, waiting out the ''tragic Manquake'' of the war. For his part, most of Berenson's passion shows up in his dogged pursuit of masterpieces for his patron. An altogether typical exchange between them goes: ''Dear Berenson, . . . Some day, by the way, you must say a little to me about that heart of yours. What does it do for you in this world?'' ''Dear Mrs. Gardner, . . . You ask me about my heart. It exists, but it is not to be written about. . . . Meanwhile a good bit of it throbs for your museum, and again I come with a proposition.''

title: A New Cafe Sets a New Tone for a Street in Portland
description: Congress Street blossomed as this city's central, downtown business strip in the early 19th century, but since World War II much of it has fallen into decline.

title: PAIRING OFF IN TUSCANY
description: LEAD: DREAMHOUSE By Kate Grenville. 170 pp. New York: Viking. $14.95.

title: CHILDREN
description: Classic Tales Retold Hi-Tops Video. 90 minutes. $29.95. This is an amiable collection of a dozen animated (and in some cases abridged) familiar stories, originally produced by BFA Educational Media. The voiceover narrator credits the origin of the individual stories - ''Jack and the Beanstalk'' is English, ''The Little Match Girl'' and ''Thumbelina'' come from Hans Christian Andersen, ''Hansel and Gretel'' from the Brothers Grimm, and so on. Given the fact that they are classic stories, some odd changes have been made in a few tales. In ''The Wild Swans,'' for instance, all 11 jackets are completed, so no brother is returned to manhood with one swan wing. Jack climbs the beanstalk, steals the bag of gold, and returns for the chicken and the harp, but there is no old woman who serves the giant and who hides Jack. While the animation is rather ordinary, the musical score is consistently sprightly. A preschooler home with a cold might enjoy all 90 minutes. Others may grow bored.

title: Amy Cifrino Plans Marriage in April To W. A. Rooney
description: Amy Cifrino and William Anthony Rooney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Rooney Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., plan to marry in April, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. James P. Cifrino of Cohasset, Mass., have announced.

title: Can We Ask More of Our Leaders Than We Ask of Ourselves?
description: To the Editor:

title: JOANNE KING WEDS
description: The Roman Catholic Church of the Presentation in Upper Saddle River, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Joanne K. King, a daughter of Ruth Glener of Hawthorne, N.J., and Carl J. King of Chicago, to Dr. Kambiz Noruzi, a son of Sonia Noruzi of Upper Saddle River and the late Naghi Noruzi. The bride is a dental hygienist. Her husband, a dentist, is a graduate student in periodontics at the University of Illinois School of Dentistry.

title: Perspectives: 34th Street Growth; Stores Play a Pivotal Role in Mixed Uses
description: ''THE more good retail you have, the better,'' says Robert H. Rodgers, a principal in Devon Properties. ''It improves the economics.''

title: Julia A. Thomas to Wed Marc Johnson
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John L. Thomas of Exeter, N.H., of the engagement of their daughter Julia Anne Thomas to Marc V. Johnson, a son of Anne F. Ryan and C. R. Johnson Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn.

title: INDIA IS PRESSING BATTLE AT PAPER
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Government stepped up its campaign against the newspaper Indian Express this week, assuming financial control over the building that houses its editorial offices and printing press and collecting rents once paid to The Express.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HARLEM TROUPE IN BERGEN

title: The Cost of Divided Government
description: It is useful that Congressional negotiators and the White House have reached a two year, $76 billion deficit reduction plan. The agreement, however, does not eclipse the problem of institutional frictions between the President and Congress that had deadlocked the talks. Another more important part of the story is the persistence of divided Government: the condition that exists when one party holds the White House while the other holds a majority of one or both houses of Congress.

title: MILLION-MILE VOLVO IGNORES STOP SIGNS
description: I WATCHED the man go in circles, trying to put a million miles on his car. Indian summer had come and gone, so it was cold in New York. I stood inside, inhaling a warm bloody mary and taking note of this silliness through the window, watching him go round and round.

title: Eastern Europe
description: To the Editor: I have been to the East Bloc countries and would like to add a few useful notes:

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Brick Town 172,000 32 Bay Bridge Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, new colonial; family room, wall-to-wall carpeting, 1.25 acres, central air-conditioning; taxes $1,800. Freehold $212,500 55 Ethan Allen Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 14-year-old expanded ranch; fireplace, wooded backyard, 2-car garage; taxes $2,387. OTHER AREAS Ridge, L.I. $125,000 105 Wauwepex Trail 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 12-year-old ranch; fireplace, 1-car garage, landscaped; taxes $2,000.
