title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE SKUNK paused when it reached the edge of the woods, puzzled and cautious.

title: Lions Valiant in Defeat
description: Leading by 16-6 with less than 10 minutes to play, Columbia appeared today to be on the verge of beating Brown, a 26-point favorite, and ending a 40-game losing streak spanning four years.

title:
DINING OUT;
At That 'Small Hotel' in Stockton
description: LEAD: COLLIGAN'S STOCKTON INN, the small hotel with a wishing well of ''On My Toes'' fame, has expanded in all directions in recent years. From its 19th-century days hosting the carriage trade, the inn now has room for the tour-bus brigade in its two bars and several dining rooms.

title: Farm Sale May Menace Wetlands
description: TWO Old Field properties considered of vital environmental significance to the West Meadow wetlands could be developed following the untimely death of their owner.

title: Fashion; JEWELED ARTISTRY
description: BARRY KIESELSTEIN-CORD RE-members being ''somewhat taken aback, even apprehensive,'' at being ushered into the private vault of an investment banker client. Assembled there in radiant profusion were some 35 pieces of jewelry he had designed. When Kieselstein-Cord expressed his astonishment, the client replied, ''Your work is part of my investment portfolio.''

title: Preschoolers and Ph.D.'s Plug In
description: ''WHEN I first arrived here,'' said Bruce MacCombie, who took over as dean of Manhattan's Juilliard School last year, ''I went around to check out our electronic music department. What I found was an archaelogical dig.'' He immediately set out to bring Juilliard into the electronic music age.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: A Wren Church Is Reopened In City of London A church designed by Sir Christopher Wren that was considered a model for St. Paul's Cathedral has reopened in the City of London after a 20-year restoration.

title:
THE TALK OF GM;
EMBARKING ON A NEW ERA IN NORTH TARRYTOWN
description: LEAD: IT is 8 A.M. and down at the end of Beekman Avenue, a stretch of road that winds through the business district of this pleasant village on its way to meet the Hudson River, that means only one thing. Lunch. Not for everyone, of course. Among the 4,500 workers at the General Motors assembly plant there are the ''purists'' who still wait until a more ''decent'' hour - 10 A.M.

title: Concert: The Atlantic Sinfonietta
description: AS part of its program Wednesday evening in Alice Tully Hall, the Atlantic Sinfonietta presented two text settings by English composers, both written for soprano and orchestra and both completed while the composers were still in their 20's.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., about Antioch College's effort to acquire a state park omitted attribution for the opinion that the park was badly managed. It was the college's opinion.

title: Teletext Use Is Growing
description: TELETEXT INFORMA-tion services, long established in Europe, are now being carried on an increasing number of cable TV systems in this country, and American viewers can now, for the first time, buy television sets with built-in teletext decoders at virtually no added cost. Until now, consumers had to buy a separate decoder to gain access to these news and feature services, which present pages of print and graphic displays on the screen.

title: FICTION FICTION
description: NIGHT NEVER FALLS. By Bud Shrake. (Random House, $17.95.) Bud Shrake's sixth novel, set at the time of the Vietminh assault on Dien Bien Phu in 1954, uses the early stages of the war in Southeast Asia as a backdrop for a gritty romantic adventure. Harry Sparrow, the central character, is a tough, hard-drinking American foreign correspondent. In quest of a Pulitzer Prize, he leaves the comfort of London and slips into Indochina just prior to the Communist onslaught. Mr. Shrake vividly re-creates both the entrenched French Army's frustration as it helplessly awaits the Vietminh attack and the carnage of the final battle. Harry escapes, along with Claudette, a nurse who is the daughter of a French Government official, and manages to file the best stories of his career. He also falls in love with Claudette. Back in London, Harry attempts to integrate his macho life style into the genteel domestic world of his new bride. But Claudette's mysterious connections with the Vietminh and with a German mercenary fighting in Indochina ultimately lead Harry and Claudette to the novel's quick-paced conclusion in Algeria, which is torn by its struggle for independence. Mr. Shrake renders the details of a reporter's life in the mid-50's with authenticity, and the action in the final scenes moves expediently if not always convincingly. Elsewhere, however, the story is clogged with turgid soliloquies on the relative merits of fascism and communism. In the end, though, ''Night Never Falls'' is illuminating on some aspects of the beginnings of the Vietnam conflict and often entertaining as an adventure tale - if one ignores Mr. Shrake's occasionally heavy-handed prose and gratuitous philosophizing.

title: Unbalancing the Scales of Justice
description: THE judge glared at the defense attorney seated at the litigants' table before him and ordered him to stand up.

title: Conversion of 3 Hotels
description: Lots of families, when planning for the future, think about one day having a little place at the shore. A new conversion project in Westhampton Beach on Long Island that is under review by the Attorney General's office presents such an opportunity but on a scale many may not have imagined. Goodstein Development, a Manhattan company active in commercial and residential projects, has purchased three beachfront hotels on Dune Road and is converting them into cooperative units. The units, all without heat, range from deluxe suites, which will sell for around $120,000, to tiny cabins with about 50 square feet - in essence, just changing rooms - that will sell for $15,000.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE JULES VERNE STEAM BALLOON. By Guy Davenport. (North Point, Cloth, $21.95; Paper, $11.95.) There are essentially two narrative forms in Guy Davenport's latest book. The first, featured in several short vignettes, is similar in voice to Plutarch's ''Parallel Lives'' and concerns fictional perspectives of historical figures.

title: Stage: Meredith Monk's Melange
description: THE human voice is a paradox among musical instruments, being both infinitely flexible and totally beyond our control. We cannot look at the larynx, repair it or adjust its components as we sing. It is a part of us in whose function we take no part.

title: Storytelling
description: LEAD: CRAIG JORGENSEN, chief of the Pound Ridge Town Police, stood in full uniform before a gaggle of little boys and girls and read aloud.

title: The Door Is Opened, but Sandinistas Keep the Keys
description: THE former President of Venezuela, Luis Herrera Campins, came to Managua recently on an important mission. As a leader in the worldwide Christian Democratic movement, he had been asked to mediate between contending factions in the Social Christian Party, which is one of many opposition groups trying to wrest power from the Sandinista Government. He quickly accomplished his task, persuading the factions to make peace. But not long after he left the country, the hostilities broke out anew. Last week, one faction seized the party headquarters in Managua and prevented its adversaries from entering.

title: A Killer Nurse?
description: ''I had to prove myself to the staff and to myself,'' Richard Angelo was quoted as telling Suffolk County prosecutors last week as they began exhuming the bodies of patients he may have killed in the course of his duties at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip. According to the authorities, the 25-year-old registered nurse admitted injecting powerful muscle-paralyzing drugs into patients, then working frantically to revive them. As Mr. Angelo was being held without bail on assault charges, the families of possible victims began waiting for the results of a testing process described as difficult, time-consuming and not necessarily conclusive. How many bodies would be exhumed? The prosecutors could describe the prospective total only as ''quite a few.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: COLUMBUS, OHIO;
Rising Higher Downtown
description: LEAD: NEXT spring, Katheleen and Waldemar Haase are to be among the first residents of Waterford Tower, this city's first downtown high-rise residential building.

title: 'THE WILD ONE' TAMED
description: PLEASE take your seats, students of fashion, because we are ready to discuss this week's mixed metaphor. To wit, the leather motorcycle jacket, made famous by Marlon Brando in ''The Wild One,'' that is now making the rounds in some very up-to-date company. This jacket has a well-earned tough-guy reputation, but pair it with a miniskirt or baggy trousers, and it looks positively chic. Sorry, Marlon. The re-emergence of such a punk favorite should hardly come as a surprise, given the current interest in retro styles from the 1950's. But if you're looking for someone to pin it on, you might try the French designer Jean-Paul Gaultier, who has come out with his own version of the motorcycle jacket, reproportioned with more feminine lines. The Gaultier version most nearly resembles the high-waisted spencer jacket, only in leather. Sorry, Marlon.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: To The Manor Reborn
description: A WELL DATED JUNE 21, 1887, COM-memorating Queen Victoria's jubilee as the British sovereign, is the newest addition to Heydon, an estate village in Norfolk, three hours outside of London. This tiny hamlet consists of several cottages nestled in a widow's row, a miniature post office, a 14th-century church, a park and a village green. The setting could well be lifted from the kind of provincial English country life depicted by Jane Austen or George Eliot.

title: '92 GOAL IN DOUBT
description: Facing a research budget substantially smaller than they had envisioned, officials in charge of President Reagan's program to develop a ''Star Wars'' missile defense system say they are planning sharp cutbacks and delays of up to two years in key experiments and development projects.

title: Conferees Urge More Local Input in Land Use
description: Participants in a conference on land-use issues in New York City that ended yesterday came with an array of ideas. Among all the opinions, one came closest to a consensus: neighborhoods should have a greater say in their own development.

title: The Art Advances at Warp Drive
description: MUSICIANS have been synthesizing sound electrically since the turn of the century, when Thaddeus Cahill invented the Telharmonium, a mostly mechanical piano-like contraption. The advancing art went into warp drive about eight years ago, however, with the arrival of digitally synthesized music.

title: For the Macy's Parade, the Work Never Stops
description: IN A cavernous warehouse and four support buildings just off the entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel here, a group of artisans and craftsmen have the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays on their minds 365 days a year, even though their work is on display for only a few hours.

title: THE END OF A MARRIAGE, LIVE FROM TIMES SQUARE
description: CLEA & ZEUS DIVORCE By Emily Prager. 259 pp. New York: Vintage Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: ISLANDERS SCORE 5 IN THIRD TO RALLY OVER FLYERS By ALEX YANNIS
description: The Spectrum was rocking with cheers after two periods, but they turned to jeers for the Flyers tonight after Philadelphia yielded five straight goals to the Islanders in the last period.

title:
TV VIEW;
AN URBAN FABLE GOES BENEATH THE SURFACE
description: LEAD: IT TELLS US SOMETHING ABOUT television or about ourselves, probably both, that the one new series this season to touch on such unsettling urban issues as the homeless, the neglected elderly and powerful real-estate juggernauts is a series that describes itself as ''a fable.'' Prime-time television prefers to limit its contemporary violence to shoot-outs and car chases.

title: SYNTHESIZING A NIGHTMARE
description: THE HOLOCAUST IN HISTORY By Michael R. Marrus. 267 pp. Hanover, N.H. University Press of New England/ Brandeis University Press. $16.50.

title: Wedding Planned For Ms. Norville
description: Deborah Anne Norville, a correspondent for NBC News, plans to be married Dec. 12 to Karl G. Wellner, president of JS Products in New York.

title: The View From: The American Indian Archaeological Institute; AT THANKSGIVING, STUDENTS TASTE A BIT OF ALGONQUIAN LIFE
description: EACH November, turkeys, football games and early glimpses of Christmas tinsel herald the nearing of Thanksgiving. In the town of Washington, the season is also marked by the sight of bright yellow school buses traveling along the narrow roads, bringing groups of children eager to learn about the first Thanksgiving to the American Indian Archaeological Institute.

title: Susan Katz Is Married
description: Susan Ellen Katz and Lee Gordon Schulman, 1984 graduates of Union College, were married last night at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel by Rabbi Mordecai Waxman. The bride, the daughter of Leon A. Katz of New York and Joan Katz of Floral Park, Queens, graduated from the Brooklyn Law School and is an associate at the Albany law firm of Carter, Conboy, Bardwell, Case & Blackmore. Mr. Schulman, a fourth-year medical student at Albany Medical College of Union University, is the son of Dr. Martin L. Schulman of Floral Park and Mickie Schulman of Great Neck, L.I.

title: Train Students in the Art of War
description: MONTHS before I started teaching a class at the Columbia University Business School, I described to my faculty superior a class that would be eccentric by the business school's standards.

title: No Justification For Racism
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Freeholders Seek Rail Investigation
description: LEAD: OFFICIALS in three northern New Jersey counties have asked for an investigation of a regional freight railroad that has been involved in more than two dozen derailments in three years and in several grade-crossing accidents, including three fatal ones.

title: FROM GUATEMALA, FURNITURE INSPIRED BY MAYAN THOUGHT
description: TUCKER ROBBINS maneuvered his four-wheel-drive vehicle over 20 miles of rough, mountainous Guatemalan terrain, where the foliage is lush and thick with cedro - a tree similar to oak whose wood is ideal for making furniture.

title: 'Susie Finkel,' Comedy
description: WHEN the Arena Players Repertory Theater opened its Second Stage theater, it was as a space in which to produce more challenging drama than the lightweight comedies and mysteries offered in its Main Stage theater. Currently, however, Arena has reversed itself by offering the complex and innovative ''House of Blue Leaves'' by John Guare on the Main Stage, and ''Except for Susie Finkel'' by Joe Manchester on the Second Stage.

title: From Subway Graffiti to the Canvas: Bronx Program Transforms Vandals
description: They used to paint subway cars. Now they paint on canvases, and their works have sold for up to $200 each.

title: IT HAD THAT SWING
description: DUKE ELLINGTON By James Lincoln Collier. Illustrated. 340 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: State's Role in Religious Pluralism
description: THIS bicentennial year of our Constitution comes at a time of sharp public debate over the appropriate role of religion in American life. There is much discussion about the meaning of the First Amendment's religion clause. Did it, as some say, merely prohibit the establishment of an official state religion, or did it erect an impenetrable wall between church and state?

title: The Beggar: Vanished With His World
description: There is a Gimpel in every human being.

title: BEST SELLERS: NOVEMBER 22, 1987
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Last List Fiction 1 1 5 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 2 4 3 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) An investment banker caught in the jungles of New York. 3 2 8 LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) A collection of Lake Wobegon monologues, from the radio program ''A Prairie Home Companion.'' 4 3 22 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 5 6 17 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 6 5 8 HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A tale of two families in the aftermath of the Civil War. 7 7 10 BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio. 8 9 14 SARUM, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Crown, $19.95.) Ten thousand years of English history, seen through the experiences of five families. 9 10 6 A SOUTHERN FAMILY, by Gail Godwin. (Morrow, $18.95.) The effect of a violent death on the Quicks, an eccentric North Carolina clan. 10 12 4 BLUEBEARD, by Kurt Vonnegut. (Delacorte, $17.95.) A painter's life in the artists-and-writers world of Long Island's Hamptons. 11 * 8 9 HOT FLASHES, by Barbara Raskin. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) At a friend's funeral, three women who had it made in the 60's reflect on their past and future. 12 13 12 LEGACY, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $16.95.) The ordeal of a military officer, charged with high crimes, whose family heritage covers 200 years of constitutional history. 13 11 25 MISERY, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is held captive by a psychotic fan. 14 14 3 RUBBER LEGS AND WHITE TAIL-HAIRS, by Patrick F. McManus. (Holt, $14.95.) Humorous tales about an outdoorsman's life. 15 1 THE SPLENDID OUTCAST: Beryl Markham's African Stories, compiled by Mary S. Lovell. (North Point, $14.95.) Eight tales that the legendary aviator either wrote or collaborated on. Weeks This Last On Week Last List Nonfiction 1 1 20 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 2 3 8 TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $15.95.) Counting his blessings and his losses, the television star muses on life at 50. 3 4 17 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former member of the British secret service. 4 1 FREE TO BE . . . A FAMILY, edited by Marlo Thomas with Christopher Cerf and Letty Cottin Pogrebin. (Bantam, $19.95.) Stories, poems and drawings about family relationships. 5 2 6 VEIL, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The inside story of William Casey's years at the helm of the C.I.A., 1981 to 1987. 6 7 11 FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill, $15.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children. 7 5 11 MAN OF THE HOUSE: The Life and Political Memoirs of Speaker Tip O'Neill, with William Novak. (Random House, $19.95.) The former Speaker of the House tells his story. 8 6 5 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses how companies can survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 9 9 4 THE DISCOVERY OF THE TITANIC, by Robert D. Ballard with Rick Archbold. (Madison Press/ Warner, $29.95.) Recent findings about the sinking of the legendary ship 75 years ago. 10 12 2 AND THE BAND PLAYED ON, by Randy Shilts. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) The medical mysteries and the political activity surrounding the AIDS epidemic. 11 8 30 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 12 13 2 A DAY IN THE LIFE OF THE SOVIET UNION. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The vast country on May 5, 1987, as recorded in pictures by 100 of the world's leading photojournalists. 13 11 10 THE MAKING OF ''THE AFRICAN QUEEN,'' by Katharine Hepburn. (Knopf, $15.95.) The actress's experiences while filming the classic movie. 14 1 CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY, edited by Clifton Daniel. (Chronicle Publications, $49.95.) Profusely illustrated history of the world, month by month, from 1900 through 1986. 15 * 10 33 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. Weeks This Last On Week Last List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 20 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 2 3 SUPER MARITAL SEX, by Paul Pearsall. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Counsel derived from interviews with 1,000 couples. 3 3 115 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 4 5 23 WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD DICTIONARY. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) The Second College Edition of a standard work, updated in 1982. 5 4 16 HOW TO MARRY THE MAN OF YOUR CHOICE, by Margaret Kent. (Warner, $14.95.) Ways to find a mate. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) SINGERS AND THE SONG, by Gene Lees. (Oxford, $18.95.) An elegy for lost time and dispersed tunes, these essays on the ebullience and uplift of song - mostly popular - are by a critic who knows that lyricism is the genius of a language. LIFE, A USER'S MANUAL, by Georges Perec. Translated by David Bellos. (Godine, $24.95.) Intellectual games, allusions and puns are among the pieces in this prodigiously entertaining jigsaw puzzle of a book, admirably translated from the French into a deft and clear prose, that can be read as a parable about the mind's efforts to impose order on the world. TIME WITH CHILDREN, by Elizabeth Tallent. (Knopf, $15.95.) Human nature's tendency to want more than it can get is the theme of these 13 stories on the state of the family today. GALILEO HERETIC, by Pietro Redondi. Translated by Raymond Rosenthal. (Princeton, $29.95.) The author argues that, in a sense, Galileo pleaded nolo to Copernicanism so as not to burn for a greater heresy, atomism. THE ARABIAN NIGHTMARE, by Robert Irwin. (Viking, $16.95.) A witty and convoluted phantasmagoria of 15th-century Cairo in which a traveler, snagged in his own dreams, is freed by an author who allows him to wake up. THE YEAR OF SILENCE, by Madison Smartt Bell. (Ticknor & Fields, $15.95.) In his fourth novel, set in a bleak New York not unlike Celine's Paris, the author explores the violence that lurks under the surface of lives, especially those that end in suicide. APARTHEID'S REBELS: Inside South Africa's Hidden War, by Stephen M. Davis. (Yale, Cloth, $27.50; Paper, $8.95.) The African National Congress is portrayed as the central, active, politicizing force of black opposition in this valuable and controversial study.

title: Streaking Canadiens Edge Devils
description: Bobby Smith scored 17 minutes 5 seconds into the second period tonight and the Montreal Canadiens made the goal stand up for a 2-1 victory over the Devils.

title: O'Neill Improving
description: Former House Speaker Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr. was moved from intensive care to a private room today at Brigham and Women's Hospital, where he is recuperating from bowel cancer surgery, said Kathleen O'Donnell, a hospital spokeswoman. She said the 74-year-old Mr. O'Neill was in good condition.

title: Wagner and Philip Glass: Two of a Kind?
description: IN THE SUMMER OF 1986, THE AMER-ican conductor Dennis Russell Davies ruffled a few feathers by pairing the music of Richard Wagner and Philip Glass on the Philadelphia Orchestra's programs at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in upstate New York. Taking our cue from this illustrious maestro, let us discuss the two composers together once again, this time by reviewing new recordings of Wagner's ''Lohengrin'' and ''Parsifal'' along with the first recording of Mr. Glass's ''Akhnaten'' - the last conducted by Mr. Davies.

title: Income of Doctors Rises 6.5%
description: The mean income of physicians rose 6.5 percent last year to almost $120,000 annually, says the American Medical Association.

title: Top Historian Takes Helm at French Library
description: Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie, who has been appointed the director of the Bibliotheque Nationale, France's national library, is one of the few European scholars whose name is known to American readers as well as historians. He is ranked as the foremost French historian of his generation and one of the two or three most influential historians in the world today.

title: U.S. and Soviet Agree to Site Inspections
description: The United States has decided to allow the Soviet Union to station inspectors on United States soil outside an American installation in return for monitoring rights at a Soviet missile assembly facility, senior Administration official said today.

title: THE WOMAN WHO BEAT THE KLAN
description: When I read that ''the woman who beat the Klan'' locked eyes with her son's murderer and said ''I do forgive you,'' I know the next time I am asked to name the woman I most admire, I will say ''Beulah Mae Donald.'' LINDA ABELSON Minneapolis

title: For Equatorial Guinea, the Yoke of Freedom
description: In 1913, as a cocoa boom began to transform this West African island, a Spanish planter erected La Barcelonesa, a mansion with curving balustrades and verandahs cooled by sea breezes.

title: Elizabeth Debra Halpert To Wed Todd D. Watson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Phillip Halpert of Livingston, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Debra Halpert, to Todd David Watson, the son of Robert E. Watson of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Ann Watson of West Orange, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Coming to Grips With Crack Abuse
description: LEAD: AT the age of 11, he began drinking with friends. ''But it really started for me with marijuana, when I was 12,'' he said. ''Everyone was doing it. Then I started meeting new people in town. I partied with dealers, guys my age and older.''

title: GOONS AND GINKS AND COMPANY FINKS
description: I fail to see much humor in William Safire's column ''Goons and Ginks and Company Finks'' (On Language, Nov. 1). Perhaps Mr. Safire is not aware that Fink is also a surname - one, I might add, not always easy to live with. In the Manhattan telephone directory alone, you'll find almost 200 people listed, to say nothing of the Finck or Finke variety. Multiply that out across the United States and you've got a sizable group.

title: BANKS AWAIT MOVE TO COMPLETE INTERSTATE RULES
description: WITH the planned merger of the Hartford National Bank Corporation and Shawmut Bank Corporation of Boston approved last week by shareholders of both banks, the midsize bank has almost disappeared from the state.

title: Commercial Property: Building Crowns; Bold New Flourishes Embellish the Tops of Towers
description: SEVEN HUNDRED feet above street level, steel workers will soon begin bolting beams into a crazy-quilt of angles to form the crown of a skyscraper at 60 Wall Street.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TINYTOWN Little houses made of glass, ceramic, wood, stone and paper go on display today at The Gallery in the Municipal Building in Hastings-on-Hudson. They have been constructed by 25 artists and craftsmen as dollhouses, sculptures or scale models. One ''English cottage'' was built for the creator's cats and another artist's dog lives in the Art Deco dwelling on view.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S true that Meghan Robinson is an actress, that she's in something called ''Psycho Beach Party,'' and that the campy mother she plays is based not so loosely on ''Mommie Dearest.'' All of which might lead one to the conclusion that Ms. Robinson is a trifle offbeat (or even more than a trifle), and that it's no wonder that she would spurn any normal menu for Thanksgiving.

title: Bikers Trying to Steer Others to Sober Living
description: With their black Harley-Davidson jackets, stubbly beards, hard-tipped boots and tattoos, the big men clomping through the gym looked more than a little out of place at the Y.M.C.A.

title: A FORUM FOR ISSUES ON YOUTHS
description: ''THE Children's Association has been focusing on topics relating to young people for several years,'' said Eve Landau. ''In part, the topics for our conferences, come out of the interests of people who have attended previous programs and in part from our desire to hear from young people again as we've done in the past.''

title: Which Way Public TV?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CONTRADICTIONS OF BOB DOLE
description: I want to correct a misimpression created by the remarks attributed to me in the article on Republican Presidential candidate Robert Dole (''The Contradictions of Bob Dole,'' by Martin Tolchin and Jeff Gerth, Nov. 8). The remarks quoted in the article were accurate - as far as they went. What was left out were my other remarks, on Bob Dole's great strength: his ability to bring together opposing sides and mold a consensus on tough issues. This, in fact, is why I strongly support Bob Dole for President.

title: Why Diminish Columbia?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Dispute on Taxing College Sports
description: STRAPPED for funds, Morgantown, W. Va., moved to levy a 2 percent amusement tax on big-time football, basketball and public concerts at West Virginia University. The result was a legal battle between the state university and the city.

title: Learning to Live With A Coalition Government
description: THE American system of government usually proves more ingenious than the men and women who run it. So it seemed last week, as the suppleness of the system permitted some self-correcting accommodation and compromise in the struggle between the legislative and executive branches over control of foreign policy. In arms control, the Central American peace process and the Iran-contra scandal, Congress moved, respectively, to impose moderation, fill a policy-making vacuum and turn toward the curative sunlight a festering sore of secrecy.

title: CLOSED WINDOWS, GOOD NEIGHBORS
description: I AM thinking of burglar alarms, barking dogs and other fences. In this neighborhood you're bound to, you can't avoid it.

title: Rye Leads All the Way
description: Rye defeated Kennedy, 34-20, in a Westchester B-Bowl game yesterday. Rye opened the scoring early, when Trey Flood ran for a 9-yard touchdown on a trap play, and never lost the lead.

title: Boy, 5, Stabs Girl, 2
description: A 5-year-old boy took a kitchen knife and stabbed a 2-year-old girl his grandmother was caring for, then told the police he was inspired by two horror movies he saw on television, the police said today. The girl, stabbed Tuesday, was released from the hospital after treatment for several wounds, the police said. The Department of Social Services is investigating.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE SLIPPER. By Jennifer Wilde. (McGraw-Hill, $16.95.) The title of this, Jennifer Wilde's first hard-cover book, may sound very tame compared with ''Love's Tender Fury'' and ''Angel in Scarlet,'' two of her paperback best sellers. Right away, however, we learn that this slipper is nothing less than the glass one Prince Charming placed on Cinderella's foot, thereby assuring her of true love and happiness.

title: DEBORAH OESTREICH TO MARRY
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Arthur Oestreich of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Deborah Ann Oestreich to Jason Seth Rubin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mel Rubin of Great Neck, L.I. Ms. Oestreich is an assistant vice president in the international department at Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York. Her fiance is a senior associate at Adams & Rhinehart, a public relations firm in New York. A January wedding is planned.

title: Rikers I. Inmates Protest Security Measures
description: Nearly 500 of 2,530 inmates at a city jail on Rikers Island refused the noon meal yesterday on the second day of a peaceful protest against more searches and other security measures initiated last week to reduce violence at the institution, the New York City Department of Correction reported.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A FEW GOOD VOICES IN MY HEAD: Occasional Pieces on Writing, Editing, and Reading My Contemporaries. By Ted Solotaroff. (Harper & Row, Cloth, $22.50; Paper, $10.95.) Writers have been sounding the warning for years: publishing is becoming a crass, bottom-line business in which bad writing drives out good.

title: Can the Giants And the Jets Still Make The Playoffs?
description: As much a chance as downhill skiing in Saudi Arabia. EDWARD W. BRADLEY Milltown, N.J.

title: Costantino Will Retire From Federal Court
description: Mark A. Costantino, who has served as a Federal judge in the Eastern District of New York since 1971, will retire from regular active service on Nov. 30 and assume the status of a senior judge. In that capacity, he will continue to handle cases in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Salvador Rebel Returns Home, Asking 'Dialogue'
description: A civilian leader of the Salvadoran rebels returned home today after seven years in exile and struck a conciliatory note, calling on his countrymen to work together ''to build a road to peace through dialogue.''

title: Charm, Down by the Old Mill Inn
description: THE North Fork is as lovely in November as it is in June. Blazing autumnal color, acres of vineyards, farm stands bursting with pumpkins, squash and cauliflower, and white-frame farmhouses line the country roads leading to Rosie's Old Mill Inn on the Mattituck Inlet.

title: On the Fringe of Switzerland
description: YOU can never understand a Swiss town unless you understand Switzerland as a whole. And a whole is something that Switzerland does not seem to be. To talk of the Swiss language is a joke, like talking of the Swiss Navy (though we ought to remember that there is a sizable merchant marine registered at Basel: there are at least Swiss sailors).

title: Penn State Stops Notre Dame, 21-20
description: Blair Thomas rushed for 214 yards and a touchdown on 35 carries, and he set up two other touchdowns today as unranked Penn State upset highly ranked Notre Dame, 21-20. The Irish missed a 2-point conversion attempt with 31 seconds left.

title: St. Lucia's Gallic Flair
description: EVERYONE on St. Lucia seems to be a charter member of the Chamber of Commerce, led by the cabdrivers. Rarely does one meet drivers so in love with their country, so knowledgeable - and yet so willing to charge the correct fare. They will tell you about the hiking trails that wind through the interior's rain forest, about the orchids and Amazon parrots, and the volcanic range that rises to more than 3,000 feet and includes the pyramidical cones of the twin peaks called the Pitons. They'll also be happy to tell you about their walk-in volcano.

title: Mary Minton Eitel Marries L. H. Horne Jr. in Louisville
description: Mary Minton Eitel, the daughter of Mary Minton Cregor Eitel and Paul Theodore Eitel Jr. of Louisville, Ky., was married there yesterday to Leon Hilary Horne Jr., the son of Margot Scheffler Horne of Atlanta and Mr. Horne of New York. The Rev. Stewart M. Joy performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Eugene Prior, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: TRENDY NEWCOMER IN NEW HAVEN
description: NEW HAVEN is developing into a real diner's delight. While there have always been many restaurants in town, the range, variety and quality seem to have improved over the last couple of years.

title: Rudolf Serkin Cancels
description: Rudolf Serkin has canceled the recital he was to give at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 9, on the advice of his doctor, who said the 85-year-old pianist was suffering from fatigue. No replacement date has been set. Ticket refunds will be given only at the box office, before Jan. 9. Hours are 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. daily.

title: BANKERS OFFERING A PERSONAL TOUCH
description: WHEN the Country Bank opens its doors for business in the ShopRite Plaza Mall in Carmel after the first of the year, its president, Ross M. Weale, intends to have his desk on the banking floor, in full view and accessible to customers.

title: They're Still Cheating Housing
description: A badly needed housing bill, the first in seven years, blew up in the Senate last week after passing the House, 391-1. The charge of budget-busting did it. Reducing the budget deficit is Washington's primary goal at the moment, but housing, whose share of Federal spending has shrunk substantially in the last eight years, is no place to look for residual extravagance. Budget-busting is bad; people-busting is worse.

title: Ms. Levin Weds A Fellow Lawyer In Massachusetts
description: At the Ledgemont Country Club in Seekonk, Mass., Joan Susan Levin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Levin of Providence, R.I., and Charles Dewey Lohrfink Jr., a son Mr. and Mrs. Lohrfink of Yonkers, were married last evening. Chief Judge Albert DeRobbio of the District Courts of the State of Rhode Island performed the ceremony.

title: Gallup Poll Shows Rise in Compassion For Victims of AIDS
description: Attitudes of Americans toward AIDS have shifted dramatically since last summer, marked by increased compassion for the victims of the disease, rising support for protecting them from being dismissed from their jobs and a growing opposition to requiring them to carry special identification cards, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Verbatim; A Proper Process
description: ' There has been considerable criticism over the perceived excesses of the confirmation process; without in any way deprecating that criticism I think that in the United States, at any rate, we recognize that there is apt to be some inquiry by the Senate as well as by the President into what may be called the ''judicial philosophy'' of a nominee to our Court. . . . This has always seemed to me entirely consistent with our Constitution and serves as a way of reconciling judicial independence with majority rule. '

title: Q&A
description: Orient Express Question:Whom should we contact to learn about a trip on the Orient Express? - R. K., Lake Forest, Ill. Answer:Several trains go by the name Orient Express. One is called the Venice Simplon-Orient-Express, which is run by Orient-Express Hotels, using original, restored Orient Express cars. The train runs between London and Venice and, next July and August, between London and Vienna. The original Orient Express, which went out of service in 1977, ran between Paris and Istanbul. There is a daily international train between Paris and Budapest that is named the Orient Express but this a regular, modern train. Occasionally there are package tours offering train journeys along the old route to Istanbul.

title: Lie Detectors Used, Despite Illegality
description: LEAD: ''IT WAS a real-life nightmare,''

title: West Islip Rolls, 34-15
description: P. J. Feeney gained 205 yards and scored three touchdowns to lead the West Islip Lions past Connetquot, 34-15, in a semifinal of the Suffolk County Division I football playoffs yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Ex-Gov. Folsom Dies at 79 James E. Folsom, a colorful figure in Alabama politics for nearly five decades, was a Democrat with a reputation as a moderate on race issues who twice served as Governor. Page 52. Koch Faults School Board Mayor Koch has accused the Board of Education of taking too long to pick a new schools chancellor. Page 46. Los Angeles Schools Crisis An overcrowded and financially strapped school system is the focus of a political debate over whether to keep schools open all year. Page 30.

title: ANNALS OF EMPIRE
description: THE GOLDEN ORIOLE By Raleigh Trevelyan. Illustrated. 536 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title: Brick by Brick, A Polish Company Rebuilds the Past At Home And Abroad
description: BRICKLAYERS CLAMBER-ing over spare wooden scaffolds were setting large Gothic-style brick.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The agreement will have its critics. But it should reduce the number of skeptics who thought Congress and the White House couldn't work together.'' - Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida. [ 38:3. ]

title: Betsy L. Osborne Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Betsy Lane Osborne to James Edwin Doherty took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew J. Mullins officiated.

title: Two Suspected Prostitutes Slain in New York
description: Two women believed to be prostitutes were killed in separate incidents in New York City yesterday morning and Friday evening, the police said.

title: THE WOMAN WHO BEAT THE KLAN
description: I would like to have seen Michael Donald pictured as he was when he was alive -smiling, happy, full of the life that was stolen from him. MARTHA PETKAS Houston

title: New Law Buoys Volunteers
description: VOLUNTEER groups in the state are hoping that a bill signed into law earlier this month will revitalize membership in volunteer ambulance and first-aid squads while protecting them from frivolous suits.

title: New York May Forfeit Housing Grants
description: THREE years after the Federal Government gave New York City 13 housing grants worth nearly $30 million, the city has spent less than $2 million of it and faces the possibility of losing almost half of what is left unless construction can start on several projects by Nov. 30, a prospect city officials consider unlikely.

title: MOVIES
description: River's Edge Starring Crispin Glover, Keanu Reeves, Dennis Hopper. Directed by Tim Hunter. 1987. Embassy Home Entertainment. 99 minutes. $79.95. The first scenes of ''River's Edge'' evoke a horrifying triptych: a doomed baby doll, a tattered sex doll and a dead teen-ager. The group connected with their fates is the crux of this harrowing vision of adolescence.

title: Hofstra Is Upset by Fordham in Playoff
description: It took Fordham 60 minutes today to rid itself of nearly 46 years of frustration as the Rams stunned eighth-ranked Hofstra, 41-6, in a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III playoff game.

title: Angola Drive On the Rebels Is Said to Fail
description: An offensive started by Angolan Government forces last summer against American-supported rebels led by Jonas Savimbi has failed, according to American officials and independent experts.

title: Duck Hunters Taking Flak
description: HUNTING season for most species of waterfowl began Friday on Long Island, and at one duck habitat, Cold Spring Pond in Southampton, sportsmen and waterfront homeowners are contesting one another's notions of how best to enjoy the public body of water. But this is to be a political battle in which the weapons are petitions and the warfront is at Town Hall.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AUGUST WILSON ENCORE August Wilson's new play, ''The Piano Lesson,'' opens at the Yale Repertory Theater, York and Chapel Streets in New Haven, this week. Mr. Wilson's ''Fences,'' which also had its premiere at Yale Rep, won a Pulitzer Prize and Tony Award after it was transferred to Broadway, where it is still running.

title: Civil Service And an End Run
description: AFTER appointing a planning director, Huntington, L.I., faced an embarrassment. The director flunked the Civil Service test for the job.

title:
ART;
VIDEOTAPES BY ARTISTS, IN HARTFORD
description: LEAD: THERE is a large library of video art by now, and it is no longer contradictory to speak of video classics. Real Art Ways, the alternative space in Hartford, has recently acquired some of these classics and is showing one each week through Dec. 18. The screening room is a short, narrow corridor holding but two plastic chairs and a video monitor, but the advantage of video art is that it can open up wide worlds.

title: U.A.W. Members at Navistar Approve a New 3-Year Pact
description: Members of the United Automobile Workers in Illinois and four other states have voted to ratify a new three-year contract agreement with the Navistar International Transportation Corporation, officials said.

title: Bringing Food and the Hungry Together
description: LEAD: FOUR afternoons a week, volunteers from five churches in Amityville gather at St. Martin of Tours Church to begin preparation of the meals for their soup kitchen. But unlike the situation at any other such facility, people who are hungry do not have to travel to the soup kitchen; in Amityville the kitchen travels to the people - in this case to a welfare motel in the area.

title:
GARDENING;
2 Easily Forced Bulbs to Brighten Winter
description: LEAD: FEW winter gardening activities bring greater satisfaction than forcing bulbs. While most spring-flowering bulbs require lengthy treatment under special conditions before they will force, two exceptions, giant amarylis and polyanthus narcissus, may be forced easily and quickly.

title: Subtle Racism On the Mets
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Koch Urges More Speed in Picking Schools Chancellor
description: After months of virtual public silence on the search for a new schools chancellor, Mayor Koch has accused the New York City Board of Education of taking too long in its quest. And he put forth two candidates of his own.

title: 21 Are Reported Killed In Attacks by Contras
description: Twenty-one people were killed today during attacks by United States-backed contra rebels on two settlements in southeastern Nicaragua, local radio said.

title: Customer Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Court Upholds Lawyer-Client Privilege
description: The attorney-client privilege protects lawyers from divulging the whereabouts of their clients, an appeals court has ruled.

title: Jefferson and His Slave: A Relationship in Doubt
description: The widespread belief that Thomas Jefferson, the great theorist of American freedom, maintained an intimate 38-year relationship with one of his slave women, has been cast into doubt by new historical research.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-25

title: Cover-up of Spill Is Charged
description: A tape recording proves that officials at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base tried to cover up a radioactive spill at the base, Ohio's two Senators said today.

title: 'DO THE SICK NO HARM'
description: THE CARE OF STRANGERS The Rise of America's Hospital System. By Charles E. Rosenberg. Illustrated. 437 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.

title: NEUROLOGY, NEUROSIS AND ALL THAT
description: THE OXFORD COMPANION TO THE MIND Edited by Richard L. Gregory with O. L. Zangwill. Illustrated. 856 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $49.95.

title: HIKE BOOK DESCRIBES 38 TRAILS
description: THE 15th edition of the Connecticut Walk Book, a hikers' guide for 50 years, is being published this month by the Connecticut Forest and Park Association.

title: MARGARET BREWER IS WED
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., Margaret Jane Brewer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn A. Brewer Jr. of Pennington, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Alan Libbey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Libbey of Portland, Me. The Rev. Jean R. Smith officiated. The bride was until recently the director of social work services at the Community Memorial Hospital in Toms River, N.J. The bridegroom is the sales manager for the Western region at Porsche Cars North America in Reno.

title: DANGEROUS TIME OF THE YEAR FOR THE JETS
description: This is the time of year the Jets have collapsed under Coach Joe Walton - the second half of the season.

title: SYRACUSE IS ADDED ATTRACTION
description: Syracuse University officials formally accepted an invitation to the Sugar Bowl today just five hours before its undefeated team staged a rousing comeback to complete the second perfect regular season in the school's 98-year football history.

title: Danny Kaye's Widow Backs Theater
description: The plaster is discolored and crumbling and the seats are worn thin, but Sylvia Fine Kaye sees a brilliant future for the Hunter College Playhouse.

title: VIDEOTAPE ON MYTHS AND LEGENDS IS FREE
description: I read with interest Tessa Melvin's article, ''Tracing Steps of Leather Man'' in the Westchester Weekly on Sunday, Nov. 8.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: Francesca da Rimini The Metropolitan Opera. Renata Scotto, Placido Domingo. James Levine, conductor. Paramount Home Video. 155 minutes. $59.95. Even if the music weren't good, this video of the Met's 1984 revival of Francesco Zandonai's opera, based on Dante's famous tale, would be worth seeing for the magnificence of Ezio Frigerio's sets and Franca Squarciapino's costumes.

title: Designing Women: A Piece Strikes a Nerve
description: Regarding ''Decorate Till You Drop,'' Long Island Sound, Oct. 11, and responses in letters to the Long Island editor, Nov. 1: The piece by Barbara Klaus must have contained enough truth to be truly effective humor - enough to encourage two designing women to take pens in claws and dash off biting, inappropriate responses to an article tat was plainly spoof; good-natured humor.

title: Correction
description: An article on Nov. 15 about the homeless misstated the amount the county expects to spend this year on its homeless population. It is $35 million.

title: A LIZARD FOR THE AGES
description: THE IGUANA By Anna Maria Ortese. Translated by Henry Martin. 198 pp. Kingston, N.Y.: McPherson & Company. $14.95.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL O'ROURKE ON BUDGET PLAN
description: DEMOCRATS on the Board of Legislators wasted little time last week in challenging County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's proposed 1988 budget, which calls for a 10.3 percent increase in spending, as being ''wasteful'' and containing ''misleading'' information.

title: Carter Says 'Moral Hunger' Is Key to '88 Race
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that there is a recurrence of a ''moral hunger'' in the nation that he said helped him win the Presidency in 1976 in the wake of the Watergate scandals, the Vietnam War and revelations of abuses by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Limit the U.N. to Be Monitor of the Persian Gulf
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: KAL 007: THE COVER-UP. By David E. Pearson. (Summit, $19.95.) At least six books have now been produced on the shootdown of Korean Air Lines 007 by a Russian fighter. None, including this one, has satisfactorily explained why the airliner strayed deep into Soviet airspace. David E. Pearson has, however, made a significant contribution to the controversy over the incident. Though his technical analyses are occasionally less than thorough, he has pulled together massive research and made some provocative revelations. More important, he has used the data to construct a compelling case for a Congressional inquiry. What makes his argument so compelling is the evidence of what the author says is a ''clear pattern of obfuscation in how the case was, and continues to be, presented to the public.'' He is talking about such things as: the Air Force action in letting radar records be automatically erased; discrepancies in tapes of conversations ostensibly between the plane and Japanese controllers; and the gag order imposed by a Federal judge on discussion of trial issues. (The book alludes briefly to a similar fogging of the Iran-contra affair.) Mr. Pearson, an expert on military affairs whose articles on the KAL flight have appeared in The Nation, believes it very unlikely that the penetration of Soviet airspace was just your average accident. He notes that the shootdown proved a bonanza for United States foreign policy, especially in overcoming objections to Pershing and cruise missiles in Europe. That could be reason enough for the Administration not to want the whole Korean 007 story told, whatever the merits of the missile policy. The author concludes that a government whose citizens acquiesce in silence about facts they have a right to know ''will be constantly tempted to act arbitrarily and in secret.''

title: SABATINI-GRAF FINAL OFFERS A GLIMPSE OF THE FUTURE
description: The record has been one-sided, suggesting that what was being heralded as the next great rivalry in women's tennis is still several months away. Quite unexpectedly, Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina has given herself another opportunity to show that the record is a bit misleading, and that she is closer to Steffi Graf than many tennis fans might think.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BOSTON;
Renovation For Art's Sake
description: LEAD: CITY LIGHTS, a nonprofit performing arts school and production house, has taken an unusual approach to the redevelopment of a burned-out building it acquired from the Boston Redevelopment Authority.

title: On the Road to Biloxi
description: AS DAWN BREAKS on New Year's Day, a new, customized GMC medium duty truck is scheduled to tool southward past sleeping cities on Interstate 95, en route from New York to Winter Park, Fla., carrying precious cargo. In the truck's pristine environment, climate-controlled at 68 to 72 degrees Fahrenheit and 50 percent humidity, will nestle two bulky, nine-foot bundles, snugly wrapped in form-fitting, padded canvas covers, trussed securely against sudden shocks, weighing in at a thousand pounds apiece and insured for a total of $87,400 - the current market price of a couple of Steinway concert grand pianos.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ELECTRONIC MUSIC
description: AMERICANS will spend nearly $3 billion this year on musical instruments and equipment, from million-dollar violins to 25-cent guitar picks. But in 1987, for the first time, more than half the money will be spent on electric and electronic instruments, as opposed to acoustic instruments.

title: JUSTICE GAGLIARDI IS BID FAREWELL
description: ''SAYING goodbye to Joe Gagliardi is very heavy business,'' said Sol Wachtler, the state's Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, during a recent well-attended dinner for the popular 75-year-old Larchmont jurist. But it did not seem such a serious matter to most of those present that evening.

title: On Language; Character Issue
description: ON ''SATURDAY Night Live,'' the comedian Al Franken asked Bruce E. Babbitt, a Democratic Presidential candidate, ''Governor, what about the character issue?'' Babbitt: ''What about it?'' Franken: ''I'm referring to your long history of going into supermarket express lanes with more than 10 items.''

title: Sports of The Times; A Bit of a Chill in the Ivy League
description: IT began with a traffic jam that was like something out of the Dark Ages - and this in one of the brain capitals of the modern era, yet.

title: Steelers Lose Lipps
description: MORE than a month after he suffered a seemingly minor strain to his left hamstring, Louis Lipps, the Pittsburgh Steeler wide receiver, has reinjured the hamstring and been placed on the injured reserve list. Lipps, who suffered the injury on Oct. 19, the first day of practice after the players' strike, thought he had recovered, but when he tried to run Tuesday he felt pain once again.

title: South Korea's Rivalries Are Provincial as Well as Political
description: THE people of Kyonggi Province, which surrounds Seoul, are said to be cultured, but also vain. In North and South Cholla Provinces, in the southwestern part of the country, they are supposed to be untrustworthy. Over in North and South Kyongsang Provinces, to the southeast, folks have a reputation for hot tempers.

title: On the Prowl For Tigers In India
description: GETTING into a machan from the back of an elephant isn't easy.

title: Guest Observer; Salad Days
description: YOU NEVER MEET A serious jogger under the age of 20 or so (why should they mortify themselves that way?), but youngsters are not indifferent to health. And suddenly every one of them has an opinion about food.

title: Land and Polaroid
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Jayne Oppenheim To Wed R. D. Schultz
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Jay Oppenheim of Greenwich,, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Jayne Oppenheim, to Robert David Schultz, a son of Mrs. David H. Schultz of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Schultz. The couple plan to marry in February.

title: Hempstead Groups Fight Development
description: LEAD: MORE than 20 South Shore civic groups have united in a Coalition to Save Our Suburbs to bring the issues of overdevelopment to the attention of Town of Hempstead officials.

title: Battle by Candidates Over Rules Divides Republicans in Michigan
description: What was intended among state party leaders here as a kind of showcase event, the first national test of delegate strength among Republican Presidential contenders, has dissolved into an acrimonious battle over party rules that has left Michigan Republicans confused and badly divided.

title: Leaving His Imprint On Broadway
description: WHEN LLOYD Richards was 9 years old, in the early 1930's, his father died of diphtheria. It suggests something of the trauma of the event that Richards, a man with precise memories of childhood, can conjure up few of the details surrounding Albert Richards's passing. The elder Richards had been a strong and secure man, a follower of the black nationalist Marcus Garvey, a breadwinner who moved from Jamaica to Toronto to Detroit in search of a $5-a-day wage on which to raise his family of seven. He was buried on the 13th birthday of his eldest child, Allan.

title: IT'S TIME TO TEACH CONNECTICUT HISTORY AGAIN
description: THIS year, as America has celebrated the bicentennial of the Constitution, the people of Connecticut have been made aware of the significant contributions their state made in that process.

title: Jay Leno, Common-Sense Comedian
description: ''DON'T YOU JUST LOVE IT?'' says the comedian Jay Leno, beginning another of those hard-nosed, common-sense riffs that sound as effortless as a cool bop solo. ''I had Donna Mills on 'The Tonight Show' with me and she says [ launching into a coquettish voice ] , 'I was just voted one of the 10 sexiest women in America, and I don't know what that means.' Doesn't know what it means? I said to her, 'Take a guess. What do you think it means? Duh. . .' Give me a break. It means the publicist that she hired to get her name out there is doing his job.'' Mr. Leno stops and chuckles at the ''Knots Landing'' star's corny false modesty.

title: Stephanie Flagel Is Engaged to Andrew Serowitz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald P. Flagel of Dayton, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter Stephanie E. Flagel to Andrew J. Serowitz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Serowitz of Jericho, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: LEGISLATOR FOSTERS TOURISM PROPOSAL
description: I read, with great interest, your article, ''New Efforts Seek to Tap County's Potential for Tourism'' [ Nov. 8 ] . And I agree that there is a real need to promote our historic and cultural locations.

title: U.S.C. Catches the Roses
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 21 (AP) - Rodney Peete passed for two fourth-quarter touchdowns today as Southern Cal upset U.C.L.A., 17-13, to earn a Rose Bowl rematch with Michigan State, a 27-13 victor over the Trojans in the season-opener.

title: LAWMAKERS WEIGH AGRICULTURE CUTS
description: A 2 percent cut in target prices for farmers' crops is being strongly considered by lawmakers searching for ways to reduce the agriculture budget as part of the deficit-reduction agreement.

title: Focus: Kansas City; Housing Just a Walk From Jobs
description: IN the 1940's and 50's, the area adjacent to downtown was one of the nation's largest clothing-manufacturing districts. But foreign competition and labor problems closed much of it down. Few firms survived into the 1960's and many of the solid old buildings began to decay.

title: AN UGLY FEELING
description: Feelings of triumph and dominance are part of a long heritage of primate evolution and human social development. That Sam Toperoff should fear and hate himself because he experiences these natural feelings is a pathetic comment on the way contemporary social ideologies alienate us from ourselves. Sexual egalitarianism requires self-hatred.

title: GRANDMASTER TIMMAN FINALLY BREAKS THE HOMETOWN JINX
description: THERE are players in any sport or game who have quite a time showing what they can do in front of their home-country crowd. The pressure is so great to please those who root hard for their favorite that he may freeze up again and again, year after year, until it may be wondered whether he will ever escape what amounts to a jinx.

title: Dartmouth Trustees Endorse More Women in Student Body
description: Dartmouth College trustees have endorsed a call by the school's president to seek more female undergraduates, but they say the effort will not mean considering gender in admissions.

title: Official Tells How Social Security Was Spared
description: The White House and Congressional leaders who negotiated the $76 billion Federal budget compromise were constantly fearful of the financial markets' judgment of their agreement and would have preferred cuts in spending for Social Security to produce a bigger reduction, the President's budget director said today.

title: Can the Giants And the Jets Still Make The Playoffs?
description: The owners' use of replacements and the counting of substitute games has raped and ruined the reputation of the N.F.L. Their arrogance is sickening. Therefore, I don't care if the Jets or the Giants make the playoffs. Nor do I care if there are playoffs or the Super Bowl. There is as much integrity in the N.F.L. as there is in professional wrestling. STANLEY R. POLLAKOFF Lincoln Park, N.J.

title: Eastern Europe
description: To the Editor: I found the articles on ''Europe's Other Half'' (Travel, Oct. 4) most interesting, but there are a few notes I should like to add, based on a recent trip (self-guided).

title: Miss Bitar Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Samir Bitar of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter Karen Yasmine Bitar to Lawrence Charles Liebers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Liebers, also of Brooklyn. Miss Bitar, an assistant district attorney in Kings County, graduated from Vassar College and the Temple University School of Law. Her fiance, who graduated from Brooklyn College, is a financial consultant for corporate and institutional services at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in New York. A March wedding is planned.

title: A MAGAZINE JUNKIE
description: I was surprised and pleased to read James Atlas's article ''A Magazine Junkie'' (Guest Observer, Nov. 1). I thought I was alone in my affliction. There is a pile of Penguin classics sitting atop my coffee table, and on a bookshelf. I've even stopped buying magazines. But can I help it if every day, when I arrive home from work, my mailbox is crammed with mail-order catalogues? O.K., so I don't need any gardening tools - it doesn't hurt to see what's available. Someday I may need a hoe. MARIN GAZZANIGA New York, N.Y.

title: Nobody At Home
description: For some years now Washington has been the site of a fascinating controlled experiment. The study has been seeking the answer to this question: Can the American system of government work, in the modern world, with no one in charge?

title: MS. BERMINGHAM, A LAWYER, IS WED
description: The marriage of Amy G. Bermingham and Charles M. Wilson, 1980 graduates of Holy Cross College, took place yesterday at the Chapel of the College of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas V. Bermingham, an uncle of the bride, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: John Schuyler Linen, Retired Banker, Dies
description: John Schuyler Linen , a retired New York banker, died Thursday at his home in Lake Wales, Fla. He was 93 years old.

title: PET THERAPISTS SAY BUSINESS IS UP
description: LEAD: PETS that can't cope with the modern life styles of Westchester residents are prompting pet owners and veterinarians to seek the help of a new breed of animal expert called the ''pet therapist'' or ''animal behaviorist.''

title: Unsnarling the Traffic Court
description: UNDER the present Traffic Court system in the unincorporated areas of Nassau County, if you receive a parking violation, you have one of three choices. You can simply pay the ticket, you can go to traffic court and wait on a crowded line for countless hours to fight it, or you can forget about it. If you choose the last alternative, you will get one warning notice and then probably get your name lost with the thousands of others who have done the same thing and never heard from the county again.

title: The City Casts Its Theaters In Stone
description: THE second-best Broadway ticket this month would put you in a 22d-floor hearing room overlooking Foley Square, where the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission has been methodically and quite rapidly casting a net over the theater district. When November began, six theaters in and around Times Square had landmark status. Today, that figure is 21 and destined to rise.

title: 85 Minutes That Scarred History
description: THERE IS NOTHING EXCEPT the plaque on the gatepost that hints of the infamy perpetrated here.

title: FOR BRIGHT BLOOMS
description: THIS would be a good week to apply fertilizer to dogwood trees; rake up remaining leaves and discard them, do not compost, as a precaution for disease control; scatter acid-type fertilizer on the ground around the root zone according to rates on bag label; rain and melting snow will seep nutrients in during winter. Apply fertilizer to young evergreens to spur new root growth in early spring. Last call to plant bulbs; they are better in the ground, at this late date, rather than forgotten. Cape Primroses

title: Knight Causes Forfeit
description: Coach Bob Knight pulled his Indiana players off the court with him after he drew his third technical foul and automatic ejection tonight, and the Hoosiers forfeited an exhibition basketball game with the touring Soviet national team.

title: Where Hopes Run as Deep as Roots
description: Jim White, the state forester for Bennington County, walked into a stand of red pines a few days ago and saw a disaster area. The tree crowns that were once 60 feet high and shaded the forest floor were at his feet.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: 'KING OF NOSTALGIA': Joe Franklin; Television's Master of Memory Lane Goes Public
description: THE company's plans are ambitious and more than a little curious. There's the idea for a ''Nostalgicize'' exercise video, featuring young women performing aerobic routines to a 1940's beat. There's the Memory Lane Club of America, ''a basic service'' for collectors of old records and movies, to be specially marketed to retirement communities in Florida and other parts of the nation. And there are proposals for a telephone number to call for old jokes and pieces of trivia, cruises and tours to ''Hollywood, Europe and other exotic entertainment centers'' - even a $100,000 life insurance policy specially pitched to ''nostalgia buffs.''

title: ENEMY OF MYSTERY
description: VLADIMIR'S CARROT Modern Drama and the Modern Imagination. By John Peter. 372 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $24.95.

title: Storm Builds Over Commercial Rent Law
description: MAYOR Koch and real estate lobbyists are pitting themselves against a majority of the City Council seeking rent protections for every retail, office and manufacturing concern in New York City.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Television is kind to ''Gandhi,'' which CBS will show in two parts Wednesday and Thursday, beginning at 9 each night. If the physically grand scale of the film does not look squeezed or even much reduced on the video screen, it may be because we're used to seeing the sorts of spectacle we get here in television news programs. One thing to remember, however, is that the movie was made to be seen at one sitting, and not split by a 22-hour intermission.

title: 133 IN COUNTY FACE CRIMINAL CHARGES ON ABUSE
description: THERE are 133 parents and care-givers facing criminal charges of child abuse in the county.

title: MUSEUM REOPENS ITS PLANETARIUM
description: ''KEEP looking up,'' declare the bright blue and white buttons worn by members of the Hudson River Museum staff, and for two good reasons a lot of museum supporters last week were doing just that.

title: Belt-Tightening At Army Corps
description: THREE aircraft operated by the Army Corps of Engineers were bought for use in emergencies, but when the Army Audit Agency checked, it found that ''virtually all of the flights were for routine matters and could have been accomplished with commercial aircraft.''

title: Snuffed Out
description: FOR most of its 15 years it attracted the top thoroughbreds in the nation to Belmont Park, but according to Gerard J. McKeon, the president of the New York Racing Association, the Marlboro Cup will be run no more. McKeon said the mile-and-a-quarter race, which was named for a cigarette, had been canceled because a new marketing team had taken over at the cigarette company, Philip Morris USA Inc., and the race did not fit into their promotional plans.

title: Officers Arrest a Man Outside White House
description: An unarmed man was arrested by uniformed Secret Service officers today after he scaled a White House fence and ran to near the foot of a stairway that leads to the West Wing where President Reagan's office is situated, the authorities said.

title: PACT LEAVES MIAMI BRACING FOR A NEW WAVE OF CUBANS
description: The prospect that a quarter-million more Cubans may immigrate here by the mid-1990's has roiled emotions in a city still struggling to absorb earlier waves of refugees from that nation.

title: Philadelphia to Pay Bail for at Least 300 Inmates
description: The city of Philadelphia has pledged to put up more than $150,000 bail to free at least 300 inmates in an effort to ease prison overcrowding. But prosecutors and finance officials are challenging the plan.

title: 'The Enterprise' and Public Trust
description: President Reagan accepts nominal responsibility for the Iran-contra affair - yet still won't acknowledge the heart of the scandal: his irresponsible privatization of Government's most sensitive functions.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: WESTERLY, R.I.;
Renewed Vigor For Downtown
description: LEAD: LOCAL officials consider the opening of the Two Canal Street restaurant this month in a long-vacant downtown building as a sign of new energy in the business district of this shore town of 18,500 people.

title: Christy Friz, Teacher, Is Married to Kirk Baugher
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L.I., Christy Anne Friz, the daughter of Mrs. Frank Graf Oswald of Port Washington, L.I., and Richard Gerhard Friz of Peterborough, N.H., was married yesterday to Jonathon Kirk Baugher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Baugher of Plandome, L.I. Bishop Robert P. Varley performed the ceremony.

title: A Motley Extended Family For Annual Giving of Thanks
description: THREE years ago in a modest ceremony in Manhattan, a Methodist from Texas married a Jew from Ohio. It was the second marriage for both. Both had lived and worked in the city for more than a dozen years. Both had happily stored Christmas tree balls and Hanukkah candles in the rarely opened little cabinets above their separate fridges.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: PITTSBURGH;
Project Gets A New Address
description: LEAD: LOCATION is a key factor in evaluating real estate, and neighborhood name recognition helps, too.

title: Trade Gap
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
ESTABLISHED SPOT FOR CHINESE FARE
description: LEAD: WHILE a number of county restaurants serving Chinese cuisine have closed over the last year, A Taste of China seems to have established a solid place for itself down county. Well into its fourth year, this dining spot continues to offer formal service in attractive surroundings, and recent visits have found the food considerably better than it was in the restaurant's early days, more deserving of prices that seem a little high for this cuisine.

title: THE DAY AFTER THE FEAST BEFORE
description: LEFTOVERS are not, by nature, inferior foods. In a professional kitchen, for instance, a good chef finds a use for nearly every bone, morsel and scrap. With a little imagination, the home cook can transform those foods that remain at the end of a meal into festive, serendipitous dishes the day after.

title: AGENCY FACES RISING CHILD ABUSE REPORTS
description: AS reports of child abuse in the county reach a record level, officials in the Department of Social Services say the higher numbers reflect an increase in family stress that affects every area of the county and all income groups.

title: Italy
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from Italy we would like to advise its prospective visitors of yet another risk.

title: DATA BANK: November 22, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY

title: THE ACCENT IS SPANISH
description: YELLOW roses everywhere - on gloves, hats, handbags and stoles - are just one of the lighthearted fashion accents supplied by Isabel Canovas for spring and summer. Other frippery includes yellow satin cummerbunds embroidered with black braid, black lace fans on hand-cut Bakelite frames and even fluffy yellow silk bows to clip on the fronts of shoes.

title: Can the Giants And the Jets Still Make The Playoffs?
description: No they can't. The Jets will be inconsistent as usual. The Giants will come on strong. They will come into their final game 8-6. They will play to a 10-10 tie. The Jets appear to be headed for victory, but Mark Gastineau roughs Phil Simms and the Giants drive for the tying field goal. In overtime, Ken O'Brien is picked off three times. Since they tie, the Oilers and the Saints make the playoffs. Joe Walton will blame the loss on injuries and Bill Parcells will say it's hard to repeat. MARK KRIEGEL Matawan, N.J.

title: ONE FAMILY'S WAR OVER SMOKING
description: FOR many years, my family was a family divided. We weren't divided by family squabbles or political or philosophical differences. We were separated into smokers and nonsmokers.

title: COUNTY, BANK JOIN IN PLAN FOR LOANS
description: CITIBANK has agreed to match $750,000 to $1 million of the county's community-development funds each year to provide low-interest loans to individuals and groups to rehabilitate apartments and commercial buildings in declining areas.

title: In Laos, Anne Gets a Royal Welcome
description: A European diplomat was searching to explain why the Government of Laos, which by most accounts allowed the Laotian royal family to perish miserably in prison camps less than a decade ago, would even consider welcoming a British Princess.

title: Teen-Age Rocker At Top of the Charts
description: LEAD: SHE'S at the top of the pop music charts, but still under the watchful eye of her mother.

title: DEAVER TESTIMONY DETAILS HIS ACCESS
description: The picture of Michael K. Deaver that is emerging at his perjury trial is one of an amiable, former small-town California public relations man who became one of the most trusted members of President Reagan's inner circle.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Kent
description: KENT'S 49 square miles of breathtaking scenery, which has not undergone major change since the Connecticut town was incorporated in 1739, has an irresistible lure.

title: Copter Crashes in Colombia
description: Two American soldiers were injured when their Army CH-47 Chinook helicopter crashed and burned Friday in Colombia, the Pentagon said today. The helicopter's pilot reported engine failure while it was returning to its base in Panama from a refueling mission. The soldiers suffered first- and second-degree burns over about 30 percent of their bodies when the Chinook crashed near the city of Monteria, Colombia, the Pentagon said. Names of the injured were being withheld pending notification of their families. Three other crew members were not injured.

title: SOMETHING OLD AND NEW IN HARTFORD
description: SOME of the youngest symphony players in the state and the world's oldest orchestra have Hartford performances coming up in the next couple of days as the Greater Hartford Youth Symphony plays tonight at Millard Auditorium, and the Dresden State Orchestra appears Tuesday at Bushnell Hall.

title: Elections in Haiti: A Struggle and a Feud
description: Holding elections in Haiti, after nearly 30 years of dictatorship, was expected to be a difficult task. But it has become even more difficult because of a feud between Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, the head of Haiti's provisional Government, and the nine-member Electoral Council that has been trying to organize the elections.

title: From the Start, the Rules Weren't Clear
description: THE controversy at the Columbia University Business School is now big news. It stems from an offer of $100,000 made by Adjunct Prof. Asher B. Edelman to the students in his class who provide him with information that leads to a successful corporate takeover. The offer, which the Columbia administration asked him to withdraw, presents an opportunity for ethical rumination.

title: Miss Barnett Wed To J. D. Schmidt In Pennsylvania
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., Elizabeth Anne Barnett, a daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Hoffman Barnett of Haverford, Pa., and the late Mr. Barnett, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Dean Schmidt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Schmidt of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony.

title: Wethersfield Show On Art of Sewing
description: LEAD: HAND-SEWN objects, in contrast to their factory-made cousins, conjure up an era of self-sufficiency and an invitation to delve into the romance and pride of the maker.

title: Shaping the Dialogue of Mind and Matter
description: IN A NOVEMBER LOADED WITH sculpture, there are three solo shows concentrated around 57th Street that are particularly worthy of attention. All three sculptors make discrete objects. Their approaches, however, and the complex issues with which they are concerned, are very different. Each challenges prevalent ways of thinking. Together they help define the tension between conceptual and sensual experience - which remain distinct no matter what concepts are used to run them together - that is a big issue in contemporary art.

title: Jazz: J. J. Johnson's Trombone and Quintet
description: J. J. Johnson was the definitive modern-jazz trombonist in the late 1940's and early 50's, when his recordings with Charlie Parker and other be-bop innovators showed how graceful, fluid and hard-driving his often-cumbersome instrument could be.

title: AN UGLY FEELING
description: I believe I understand Sam Toperoff's ugly feeling and its source. The key for me was his repeated use of the word ''umbilical.''
