What could be more reminiscent of the fetal situation than his hard-hat dive, and what more evocative of primal fears of being left alone without a basic life support? K. TRACY MUNN Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Cameras Click, Rhinos Roam In Nepal Park
description: A BULKY gray mass, just discernible in the late afternoon light, lumbers through the dense elephant grass at the edge of the shallow river. Jag Dish, the mahout driving our elephant, whispers ''rhino.'' He thwacks the side of the elephant's head with a wooden stick to turn her toward the rhino, and the other three elephants in our group also approach, forming a broad arc. As we converge, the rhino turns into a small gully, then suddenly emerges, stops short and fixes us with a myopic stare. Rhinos have to stand still to assess a situation because they can't see well, and when they're on the move they can't hear anything but their own crashing.

title: All-Year Schools: Complex Debate in Los Angeles
description: A nearly full moon still hangs heavily over Los Angeles at dawn as Tommy Pinon, Bol Puth, Glen Pambuena and about 35 classmates gather at the bus stop on Temple Street, just opposite the Good Time Donuts shop, on the edge of downtown. The yellow bus picks them up and lumbers onto the Hollywood Freeway and over the hill for the half-hour ride into the San Fernando Valley to the Ulysses S. Grant High School in Van Nuys.

title: SOUTH AFRICA LOOKS EAST, AND EXTENDS ITS MARKETS
description: ALTHOUGH trade with its customary partners is slackening under pressure from economic sanctions, South Africa has managed an overall gain in commerce so far this year, the Government reports. Experts here say that the country's recent 45 percent drop in exports to the United States, which was its largest trading partner, has been offset by trade with other nations, particularly in Asia. ''Trade with countries like Taiwan has been boosted very much by the political isolation of South Africa,'' said John Barratt, director of the South African Institute of International Relations, a research organization.

title: AN EYE FOR RICH GEOLOGY
description: STAN GABY of Colchester shows people those places in Connecticut where contintents collided, glaciers melted, striking rock patterns were formed and mysterious stone ruins were left. He is a professor of geosciences at Mohegan Community College in Norwich, and he wants his students, and others, to notice the geological features around them.

title: Harvard Captures Ivy Title
description: Harvard kept hitting Yale where it hurt today. And the hit that hurt the most came with 90 seconds to play when Tom Aubin tackled the Elis' Troy Jenkins and the ball flew loose. Harvard recovered the fumble, and the Ivy League championship belonged to the Crimson with a 14-10 victory before a crowd of 66,548 in the Yale Bowl.

title: PLAZAS, LIKE COMPUTERS, ARE BEST IF USER-FRIENDLY
description: NO BUILDING IS STATIC; ALL OF them change over time, both in their physical reality and in our perceptions of them. And buildings take a long time to settle in, to find their natural relationship to their users and to their surroundings. Sometimes years of use can bestow a depth and a resonance to a building that had seemed thin and facile when new, and just as often those years can see initial promise turn sour.

title: FOOD INSPECTION RESULTS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 26 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: SPACE AT THE END OF THE TUNNEL
description: THE LIFE BELOW THE GROUND A Study of the Subterranean in Literature and History. By Wendy Lesser. 207 pp. Boston: Faber & Faber. $19.95.

title: Correction
description: A review of Victoria Glendinning's ''Rebecca West: A Life'' on Oct. 18 misidentified Francis Biddle. He was a judge on the war crimes tribunal at Nuremberg. Robert H. Jackson was the United States' chief counsel for the prosecution at the trials.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Time for Temps

title: Data Update: November 22, 1987
description: MEDIAN HOUSE PRICES

title: Jazz Injustice: Genius in the Shadows
description: MUSICIANS TEND TO dislike being categorized and labeled; many resist it strenuously. How harmful can such pigeonholing be? Consider the cases of two composer-pianists, men of extraordinary talent and originality who were misperceived, dismissed as derivative early in their careers and lived out the remainder of their lives in frustrating obscurity.

title: A Producer's Gershwin Coup
description: STILL stage- and star-struck after all these years, the 47-year-old Arthur Whitelaw, who at 23 was described as ''perhaps the youngest producer in the theater'' - and at 17 was indisputably the youngest, and reportedly the first, to bring professional live theater to Smithtown - is scoring a coup in television.

title: State Courts Find Night Hours Unpopular
description: LEAD: ''NIGHT COURT,'' NBC-TV's prime-time situation comedy, may have a large following, but New Jersey's night courts do not seem to. State court officials say that most New Jerseyans involved in civil disputes would rather not have their cases heard during off hours.

title: U.S. Requires Safety Devices on Northeast Trains
description: The Transportation Department has ordered that all freight trains traveling in the Northeast rail corridor be equipped with automatic braking devices by July 1990. Amtrak passenger trains already have the equipment.

title: PICTURES FROM A WOBBLY LIFE
description: It's on the cover of Tony Mendoza's pictorial autobiography, STORIES (Atlantic Monthly Press, Paper, $6.95): a photo, which might pass as a snapshot if it weren't in formal black and white, of three women, up to their necks in water, wearing beach hats, all smiling. They're friendly. The caption, steaming with paranoia, reads ''Yeye's sisters, Magda, Tota, and Manana, used to make me nervous. Every time I saw them, they were always laughing. I was afraid to talk to them and run the risk of not being considered funny.'' Like all good autobiographers, Mr. Mendoza, a photographer of some renown, has constructed a persona. He's the outsider, a guy who uses his ''aw shucks'' naivete and alienation to con people into laughing. He does it by writing short, self-deprecating, seductive sentences, the verbal equivalent of his photographs. But there's a lot more going on here than deadpan family portraits, a big dog about to attack an ant and an alarm clock soon to be swimming in Boston Harbor. Mr. Mendoza, 46 years old, grew up in Cuba in a privileged family that got the boot from Fidel Castro. Suddenly, the photos become a document of exile, outsider culture, one which bumps into Mr. Mendoza's own wobbly flight into the second generation. He becomes an architect, gives it up to become a photographer, lives in a commune, doesn't marry until he's 45, tries to find commercial photography work. None of this pleases his businessman, Nixon-supporting father, who's in here, being examined by a doctor. The caption: ''My father has overeaten, overdrunk, and oversmoked for over 50 years. Whenever my mother warns him 'Miguel, you've had enough to drink!' he replies, 'Conchita, you want to live forever?' ''

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
OHIO STATE THROWS PRINCIPLES FOR A LOSS
description: LEAD: IF ever there was a time when I could be cynical and disillusioned about intercollegiate athletics it would be now. Last Monday I resigned as director of athletics at Ohio State University rather than dismiss my football coach. Earle Bruce was dropped anyway by my president, who cited pressure from supporters as the reason.

title:
INVESTING;
Bargains by Many Standards
description: LEAD: JUST before the stock market's plunge, a small newsletter called The Astute Investor was having a hard time finding deeply undervalued stocks. Not anymore. ''Bargains abound,'' said Charles E. Cardwell, the letter's editor, in his November issue.

title: 6 Democrats Jockey for Support in New Hampshire
description: The six Democratic Presidential candidates jockeyed for position at the New Hampshire Democratic convention today, heating up a cold autumn afternoon with tough talk about the Reagan Administration, the Federal budget and the importance of this state's primary.

title: Catherine Grant Keggi Plans to Marry Howard Hunter of New Orleans in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Kristaps J. Keggi of Middlebury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Grant Keggi to George Howard Hunter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Hunter Jr. of New Orleans. A June wedding is planned. Miss Keggi, a career counselor at the A. B. Freeman School of Business of Tulane University, was formerly the director of Ithaka, a cultural program in Greece for high school students. She graduated from the Emma Willard School and magna cum laude from Tufts University, and received a master's degree from the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

title: THE WOMAN WHO BEAT THE KLAN
description: Jesse Kornbluth's article ''The Woman Who Beat the Klan'' (Nov. 1) focuses attention on the importance of civil rights at a time when the Supreme Court's balance is being called into question. The story of Beulah Mae Donald demonstrates that discrimination remains an issue and that racism continues to plague the lives of many. ''The Woman Who Beat the Klan'' is an example of one woman's victory.

title: BORGES'S 'TO THE MIRRORS' ON STAGE IN NEW HAVEN
description: IT is no wonder that the mysteries and the fantasies that encompassed childlike exploration and intense eroticism - in short, the wonderment of the world of Jorge Luis Borges - should inspire a so-called avant-garde troupe, for Borges's word puzzles, perceptions, paradoxes and plotlessness are not the stuff of conventional theater.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Bounty at a Boutique Called Nicole Favella Nicole Favella is a new boutique in Larchmont that features French- , Italian- and some American-made women's shoes, boots, belts and handbags, leather fashions, evening wear and jewelry. The owners have a Madison Avenue shop called La Difference with a similar range. Sizes are 5 1/2 to 10 in medium and narrow widths for footwear and 6 to 12 in clothing.

title: NEW LONDON MALL SEEN AS URBAN FAILURE
description: LEAD: WHEN the city of New London decided 14 years ago to take a two-block stretch of a major thoroughfare back in time, the purpose was to inject life into the languishing downtown area.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; What $2 Million or So Gets a Home Buyer
description: THREE Russian wolfhounds in northern Westchester have a room of their own, with seven-foot-high casement windows reaching almost to the floor so they can look out at the rose garden from their beds.

title: Marina Gundlach Weds John French 3d
description: Marina Kellen Gundlach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Kellen of New York, and John French 3d, a son of Mrs. Frank H. Teagle Jr. of Woodstock, Vt., and the late Mr. French Jr. of New York, were married yesterday.

title: A Chore for the Pope
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPOSTING MADE EASY
description: LEAD: A friend of mine, who lives in a Fifth Avenue apartment, carefully wraps in plastic the day's accumulation of garbage. Each weekend she faithfully takes it to a compost pile behind her country home in the Hamptons.

title: South Shore Surprises, Adams Breezes in Playoffs
description: Arthur Davis ran for four touchdowns and 320 yards yesterday as South Shore of Brooklyn upset second-seeded Port Richmond, 42-12, in the quarterfinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League Division A playoffs. Port Richmond (8-0) was one of two undefeated teams in the P.S.A.L. during the regular season.

title: THE FAT MAN'S GARDEN AND OTHER LANDMARKS
description: NEW YORK CITY is a treasure trove of ''X-marks,'' even though the term is, to put it mildly, not very well known. The reason for its lack of familiarity is that I have never used it since inventing it on a tour of Europe 25 years ago with a party of city planners.

title: WHEN A PAINTING BRINGS MILLIONS, IT'S ART FOR HYPE'S SAKE
description: NOW THAT RECORD PRICES ARE SET AL-most daily in the auction rooms, statisticians may find the idea of compiling a ''Top 10'' listing of prices irresistible; those who truly care about art will place such lists among the silliest and most misleading formulations of our time. ''Those people had to be crazy,'' posterity will say. ''What kind of a lopsided, nonsensical list is that? Was this really what people in the 1980's wanted most and rated most highly?''

title: Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $185,000 164 South Ocean Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 90-year-old Victorian; fireplace, study, original moldings; taxes $4,100. Copiague $280,000 50 Gateway Drive 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 14-year-old ranch; fireplace, c/a, pool, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600. Massapequa $382,000 121 Harbor Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; pool, brick patio and deck, 2-car garage; taxes $6,400. Nissequogue $520,000 136 South Path 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 15-year-old farm ranch; attic, family room, heated pool, beach rights; taxes $7,000. Ridge $125,000 105 Wauwepex Trail 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 12-year-old ranch; fireplace, 1-car garage, professionally landscaped; taxes $2,000. Shoreham $155,000 68 North Country Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old ranch; den, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $1,800. OTHER AREAS Freehold, N.J. $212,500 55 Ethan Allen Road 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 14-year-old expanded ranch; fireplace, wooded backyard, 2-car garage; taxes $2,387. Bridgeport, Conn. $225,000 241 Lake Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, fireplace, 68- by 100-foot lot; taxes $2,990. White Plains, N.Y. $250,000 31 Garretson Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 52-year-old stucco Tudor/Norman; eat-in kitchen, brook, pond, walk to station and schools; taxes $1,874.

title: A WORD ON BEHALF OF THE PRONOUN
description: While I agree with Mary Humphrey's article, ''Preserve the Preposition!'' [ Opinion Page, Nov. 1 ] , I would like to point out an omission in grammar. She states that ''our language is made up of seven parts of speech.''

title: Seeking a Buyer For Slave Museum
description: TIME and money appeared to be running out earlier this year for the Old Slave Mart Museum in Charleston, S.C., whose collection included dolls and quilts made by slaves and bills of sales for human ''property.''

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW MEDAL SHOWS TWO HANDS CLASPED IN FRIENDSHIP
description: LEAD: A NEW silver commemorative medal, struck at the Leningrad Mint, was jointly designed by Alexander Polodkin, chief designer of the Moscow Mint, and Tim Haskin, a well-known American wildlife artist. The obverse design by Mr. Polodkin shows two hands clasped in friendship with the United States and Soviet Union flags in the background.

title: Syracuse Finishes 11-0, Barely
description: Five weeks ago, Joe Paterno walked into the Syracuse locker room and congratulated the Orange on their 48-21 thrashing of his Nittany Lions. Before leaving, he turned and told them to keep the final No. 1 ranking, which had been his last season, in the East.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Landscape Closes at Lunchtime The classical British traveler goes abroad to suffer as well as to enjoy other countries. This is Cyril Connolly writing to a friend from Greece in 1963. It is quoted in ''The Norton Book of Travel,'' edited by Paul Fussell.

title:
GARDENING;
2 Easily Forced Bulbs to Brighten Winter
description: LEAD: FEW winter gardening activities bring greater satisfaction than forcing bulbs. While most spring-flowering bulbs require lengthy treatment under special conditions before they will force, two exceptions, giant amarylis and polyanthus narcissus, may be forced easily and quickly.

title: Alvin Ailey Dancers Follow The Steps of a Trailblazer
description: ''I HAVE A STRONG SENSE of wanting to be original,''

title: Next Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Carol A. Cheswick Marries R. T. Ross
description: At the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn., Carol Ann Cheswick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Reid Cheswick of Darien and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Thomas Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Ross Jr. of Darien. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence McCall Horton, pastor emeritus of the church, and the Rev. James Kirchner, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Veterans' Cabinet Agency Unlikely
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY veterans received a bonus of sorts on Nov. 12 - a day after their official annual holiday - in the form of approval for a state Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: The Growing Need for Bridge Loans
description: MANY home buyers are still feeling shockwaves from last month's stock market collapse. Some were relying on now-devalued securities for the down payment while others lost buyers for their own homes. Now, unwilling or unable to back out of contracts for new homes, they are scurrying for quick cash to close their deals.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Sign of the Times?

title: AN UGLY FEELING
description: What Sam Toperoff describes in his article ''An Ugly Feeling'' (About Men, Oct. 25) is something that I've witnessed often enough to name the Male Operational Definition of Maleness. By this, I mean that at an elemental level men define their maleness as ''triumphing over women.''

title: A Missing Connecticut Judge Is Found Dead
description: A Danbury, Conn., probate judge who had been missing for four days was found dead in a hotel room in Washington Friday evening, the police there said yesterday.

title: Court Upholds Winans Verdicts
description: R. Foster Winans lost his appeal in the Supreme Court, which unanimously upheld the mail and wire fraud convictions of the former Wall Street Journal reporter and two other men. In 1983, Mr. Winans was a writer of the ''Heard on the Street'' column, a Journal feature that often influences stock prices. Mr. Winans supplied his associates with advance knowledge of his columns' contents and they traded securities based on that knowledge, making profits of $690,000. The Court said the trading violated statutes covering mail and wire fraud, but it deadlocked, 4-to-4, on whether securities laws were violated. Those convictions stand, but no precedent was established. That left some ambiguity about what constitutes insider trading, and the S.E.C. submitted to Congress a proposal to more precisely define the offense. Some lawyers said the case would have its most far-reaching implications in the area of employees' handling of information companies consider confidential.

title: New Warmth for New Plays
description: REVIVALS once were the mainstay of regional theaters, with an occasional obligatory nod to the new play, about which artistic directors have traditionally felt an understandable ambivalence.

title: YOUTH BRIGADES OF ANOTHER KIND ARE GAINING FAVOR
description: PAST proposals for national service have languished in Congress, but the idea that young people could learn valuable lessons while serving their country seems irrepressible.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The red brick floor in our sunroom is 11 years old and has become soiled. How should we clean this brick and what can we do to keep the bricks clean without painting?

title: Gleaming Jewelry From Three Eras
description: WHETHER BEADED, shell-covered or crafted of gold, ancient, medieval and tribal jewelry have much in common with each other, as can be seen in the 40 austere yet robust selections on view at the Edward H. Merrin Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue (at 57th Street) through Dec. 24.

title: GOONS AND GINKS AND COMPANY FINKS
description: William Safire missed a chance to deal with the grammar problem of the Donna Rice campaign. The jeans are labeled ''No Excuses''; therefore, the phrase ''No Excuses'' is synonymous with the product. Ms. Rice doesn't manufacture the product, does she? Therefore, to be accurate, the copy line should read, ''I don't make No Excuses. I just wear them.'' This would give Mr. Safire a whole column on the double negative and would give even more play to an ad campaign that seems to be fraught with public-relations opportunities. MARY LOIS TIMBES New York, N.Y.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SAN FRANCISCO;
After Closing, The Lawsuit
description: LEAD: SOME months ago, a professional home inspector in the San Francisco area was hired by prospective buyers to look over a house built in the 20's. He gave it a passing grade.

title: For Paralyzed Officer, a New Home
description: In bitter, bonechilling weather, Steven McDonald returned home today to a warm welcome from friends, family and fellow police officers.

title: BIRD'S UNDERSTUDY STARS AS CELTICS DEFEAT NETS
description: The Boston Celtics, minus Larry Bird, bounced back from their 31-point loss 24 hours earlier to the Philadelphia 76ers and defeated the Nets, 107-97, tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: For Mac Owners With Wanderlust
description: PORTABLE computers are an increasingly common sight on airliners these days. Even so, I was amused on a recent flight to see a businessman sitting nearby hugging an Apple Macintosh to his chest like a baby. He was still hugging it and smiling vacantly as he wandered off the plane.

title: STAMFORD ADS IRK BORWALK
description: A MAN, presumably an executive, is at his desk crying.

title: Diane Arlington Engaged to Wed
description: Diane Elizabeth Arlington, the assistant director of the Institute for Health, Health Care Policy and Aging Research at Rutgers University, plans to be married Dec. 31 to Russell C. Leaf, an associate professor of psychology at Rutgers.

title: Doubts Voiced on Murder Case Against L.I. Nurse
description: As he ordered Richard Angelo held without bail on assault charges, Suffolk County Judge Alfred C. Tisch suggested that the 25-year-old nurse may have ''perpetrated the largest series of mass murders in the metropolitan region, if not the nation.''

title: Fishermen Criticize Boat Ramp Plan
description: LEAD: A PLAN to remove abandoned gasoline tanks along the Mattituck Inlet and replace them with a public boat ramp has drawn fire from residents who say that an influx of recreational boaters would create parking and navigational problems.

title: A DAY-CARE CENTER FOR AILING CHILDREN
description: A PEDIATRICIAN and a physician's assistant are hoping to transform a small white house in Bristol into Warm Fuzzies, the first day-care center in the state for sick children.

title: Gifts of Gear And Gadgets
description: THE best travel gift we ever got was a set of compact, high-quality folding binoculars. They are now the second thing written on the family packing lists, after the plane tickets.

title: Music: Parnassus Group Plays Harvey's 'Bhakti'
description: THERE has probably been no more startling event this young music season than Jonathan Harvey's ''Bhakti'' at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night. As played by the members of Parnassus under the direction of Anthony Korf, this 12-part, 50-minute work is a triumph of exuberance.

title: Hunting Decried At Higbee Beach
description: An Oct. 25 article by Pete Dunne about encounters between birdwatchers and hunters at Higbee Beach in cause for concern in its content and its omissions.

title: Fire In Tibet
description: SINCE OCT. 1, JOHN ACKERLY HAS BEEN CARRYING IN HIS pocket a handful of bullet casings. He says it is important for him to have these tangible reminders of the day when the Tibetan capital of Lhasa erupted in one of the bloodiest demonstrations against Chinese rule since Tibet was invaded in 1950. A 30-year-old Washington lawyer, Ackerly had gone to Tibet with an old college friend, Dr. Blake Kerr, for mountain trekking and an introduction to an ancient culture. At the ''roof of the world,'' rock-throwing demonstrators answered by gun-firing policemen were the last things they expected to see. But on Oct. 1, the two men were caught in an escalating violence that took the lives of at least nine Tibetans and six Chinese policemen. Detained briefly by the police for possessing pro-Tibetan literature, Ackerly and Kerr were expelled from the region on Oct. 10.

title: OFFERS INUNDATING ATHLETE
description: IT was bad enough that Watertown High School had just beaten his team 58-0. To make matters worse, Theo Byrd, a tackle for John F. Kennedy High School, had missed the team bus back to Waterbury.

title: Updating Rights
description: Beginning Dec. 1, owners of rent-stabilized apartments must attach a new form outlining tenant rights to all new or renewal leases.

title: Shock Therapy's Return to Respectability
description: IN A SMALL OFFICE IN the department of psychiatry at the State University of New York's Stony Brook, L.I., campus, an anxious man and a withdrawn woman face a blank television screen. Irene Carasiti, a registered nurse, slides a 22-minute tape into a video-cassette player. The man hunches forward; his wife remains apathetic.

title: INSIDE THE CONTINENT
description: EUROPE A Tapestry of Nations. By Flora Lewis. 587 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Bradley Proposes Cut In U.S. Sugar Subsidies
description: WHAT this country needs, says Senator Bill Bradley, is a good 5-cent candy bar, and to get one he has written legislation that would slash price supports for United States sugar production and allow more sugar to be imported.

title: City Ballet: Lindsay Fischer in Debut
description: THE New York City Ballet has a promising addition to its roster in Lindsay Fischer, a young American dancer who left the Dutch National Ballet to join the City Ballet as a principal dancer this season. Mr. Fischer made his debut with the company on Thursday in the ''Theme and Variations'' section of George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3,'' presented by the City Ballet at the New York State Theater.

title: GOONS AND GINKS AND COMPANY FINKS
description: I would like to point out that there is more to fink and schmier than meets the eye. The English ''canary'' is about the equivalent of the German ''fink'' - meaning ''to sing,'' thereby breaking the rule of ethics not to tell.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Can the Giants And the Jets Still Make The Playoffs?
description: Only if they play their remaining games against the Knicks. TOD COOPER New York

title: Melissa Lighthill Wed in Greenwich
description: Melissa Duncan Lighthill and Elliston Perot Bissell 4th were married yesterday at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Sydney Wood-Cahusac performed the ceremony.

title: New York to Deploy Cameras Against Red-Light Violators
description: In its latest offensive against drivers who run red lights, New York City will soon begin deploying a new weapon at three intersections: cameras.

title: Iran-Contra Panels Find Fault, but Not in the System
description: IN terms of evidence, the final report issued last week by the Congressional Iran-contra committees added little to the startling public testimony last spring and summer about the secret activities of the Reagan White House. But the committees' analysis of that evidence was devastating. The report spoke of ''confusion and disarray at the highest levels of Government,'' of ''pervasive dishonesty and inordinate secrecy,'' of ''deception and disdain for the law.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LEAD: CLARINETS APLENTY

title: Chavez Takes Lightweight Crown
description: Julio Cesar Chavez won the World Boxing Association lightweight title tonight when he stopped Edwin Rosario, the defending champion, at 2 minutes 36 seconds of the 11th round of a scheduled 12-round fight at the Las Vegas Hilton outdoor stadium.

title: NONFICTION
description: VINCE: A Personal Biography of Vince Lombardi. By Michael O'Brien. (Morrow, $19.95.) For years, football fanatics and non-football fanatics have said that Vince Lombardi, the legendary head coach of the once-great Green Bay Packers, was a godsend to the sport. His motto was ''Winning isn't the most important thing; it's the only thing'' and some have proclaimed that he was the personification of success. In his ''personal biography'' of the coach, Michael O'Brien says all this, but that is about all he says. Using interviews with almost anyone who may have known Lombardi, Mr. O'Brien, a professor of history at the University of Wisconsin Center/ Fox Valley shows that Lombardi's diligence and his ''do-it-right'' ethic affected many people in a positive way. ''Vince'' also gives a satisfying look at Lombardi's personal history; he was proud but sometimes frustrated by his southern Italian heritage, and he rarely missed a Sunday Mass. Still, after eight years of researching Lombardi, with the help of the coach's family and the players he taught, Mr. O'Brien does not contribute a new understanding of a man whom some players and sportswriters refused to deify. ''Vince'' fails to examine any alternative insights into the ''play-to-win'' philosophy, or to provide a complete account of how this folk hero dealt with failure and frustration.

title: CRIME
description: You finish THE JERICHO RUMBLE by Christopher Murphy (Walker, $16.95) and then turn back to the first page. Facing it is a Xerox copy of a ''brevet d'invention'' from the French patent office dated Feb. 12, 1965. It appears to be the real thing. (Later in the book an English translation is provided.) It is the patent of an invention that can scramble brains and destroy buildings by an ultrasound device. Then questions arise. Is this for real? Does it work as described? If so, why hasn't it been used? Why haven't we heard about it? Or is it in the secret arsenal of the great powers?

title: South Korean Soldier Shot in a Border Clash
description: A South Korean soldier was wounded today when North Korean troops opened fire inside the demilitarized zone, the South Korean Defense Ministry said.

title: Joanne Cestone Marries
description: Joanne Cestone, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo Cestone of East Hanover, N.J., was married there yesterday to Michael Farrell McHugh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McHugh of Brick Town, N.J. The Rev. Richard Carlson, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. McHugh is a music teacher in the East Hanover public school system. Mr. McHugh is an associate at the New York law firm of Lian, Geringer & Dolan.

title: STEPFAMILIES GATHER TOGETHER FOR SUPPORT
description: WHEN Gerald and Carole Shaff said ''I do'' six years ago, they were agreeing to share not only their lives, but also the nine children from their previous marriages.

title: Decomposed Body Is Found; A Suspect Is Held in Bronx
description: A 31-year-old man was arrested and charged with killing a woman whose decomposed body was found behind the suspect's apartment building in the Bronx yesterday, the police said.

title: ONE-BRAND AUDIO CAN BELIE THE RULE
description: STAUNCH, TRUE-BLUE audiophiles commonly regard so-called one-brand systems with contemptuous disfavor. Their attitude is clearly prejudiced, but not without its reasons.

title: THATCHER DISPENSES ECONOMIC ADVICE FOR ALL
description: WHEN Margaret Thatcher's advisers are asked about her international role, they modestly assert that she realizes the limitations of a ''second-rate power'' as a platform for world leadership. But whenever Mrs. Thatcher speaks for herself it is always in the voice of a woman who, in her heart of hearts, thinks of herself as the senior guardian of Western interests. Now, with Europeans increasingly convinced that the Reagan Presidency is a spent force, Britain is going through one of those periods when the tight little island seems too small for its Prime Minister.

title: Theater
description: The Holocaust is given a deeply personalized dramatic treatment in ''A Shayna Maidel'' by Barbara Lebow. The focus of her poignant new play (at the Westside Arts Theater, 407 West 43d Street) is the relationship between two sisters, separated for almost 20 years. The younger sister emigrated to America with their father while the other one remained in Poland with their mother and was traumatized by a tortuous incarceration in Nazi prison camps.

title: SUSAN S. MORRILL WED TO CLAY C. WOMMACK
description: St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Susan Shay Morrill, a daughter of DeWitt Crawford Morrill of Darien and the late Jane Ball Morrill, to Clay Carter Wommack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Forrest Sinclaire Wommack of Suffolk, Va. The Rev. Walter H. Taylor performed the ceremony.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: ALICE'S NECK. By Barbara Novak. (Ticknor & Fields, $17.95.) This first novel by the art historian Barbara Novak is yet another college story about searching for one's identity. This time it's graduate school, Harvard, 1979. Anna Bernstein is a young woman strangely innocent and ignorant - especially of her Jewishness, despite her Brooklyn background.

title: READERS ASK THE QUESTIONS
description: OF the things that can make a columnist happy, letters from readers are second only to paychecks. But there are times when they serve as reminders of how a simple thing like photography can be made to seem enormously complex.

title: Italian Policemen Arrested
description: A prosecutor announced here today that 10 police officers were among 36 people charged with being members of a heroin trafficking ring in the northwestern Veneto region. The prosecutor, Roberto Staffa, identified the ring's leader as Edoardo Ceresi, 25, a brigadier in the paramilitary Caribinieri force. Brigadier Ceresi was also accused of particpating in the robbery of about $400,000 in checks and cash from a postal van in April.

title: WHAT MAN HAS DONE TO A HOSPITABLE PLANET
description: SCIENTISTS and scholars met recently at Clark University in Worcester, Mass., to report on what man has done to the planet. In dozens of papers, they described how the pressures of human population and industrial activity had not only changed the face of the earth but also altered its physical elements. The experts agreed that while man has been transforming the earth for centuries, the pace and scope of change have increased radically just in the last half century. They looked ahead as well; Paul Demeny of the Population Council presented projections that the world population would grow from 5 billion now to between 8 billion and 16 billion in the next century. The participants seemed concerned that such changes may be exceeding the ability of people and their institutions to adjust, but there was little consensus on what the changes meant or what could be done about them. Excerpts from some of the papers follow. BILLIONS OF PEOPLE

title: Film; Bill Forsyth's Rorschach Test
description: IT STARTED INNOCENTLY enough. Bill Forsyth was in town to pick up a New York Film Critics'

title: Talking: Meetings; Getting A Good Turnout
description: EFFICIENTLY run, well-attended meetings often seem to the officers of condominiums and cooperatives to be an impossible dream, much like an entire month free from complaints.

title: A Pair of Pop Albums Hit a Political Groove
description: THE IRAN-CONTRA HEARINGS have made it to the dance floor.

title: Sizing Up Moscow
description: THE SIXTH CONTINENT Russia and the Making of Mikhail Gorbachov. By Mark Frankland. 292 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.95.

title:
ANTIQUES;
Small Community Reflects Its History
description: LEAD: STILL enclosed within its original 1683 boundaries in what has since become lower Bucks County, this small borough within a burgeoning township is a remarkable reflection of American history.

title: THE WORLD AND OUR MOTHERS
description: IT was the tone of ''Sons and Lovers,'' not the subject matter, that came as a shock when the novel was published in 1913. The directness of the writing established the erotic hold the mother and the son had on each other. People were amazed, but 10 minutes after the book had been published everyone who could read said, ''Of course.'' Two things had happened at once: a writer able to speak had appeared in a world ready to hear and, as timing is all, that which had been felt was now understood.

title: Eastern Europe
description: To the Editor: During 11 adventurous days our family explored by car parts of Czechoslovakia and Hungary. While restrictions on the personal freedoms and economic choices of the citizenry were obvious, no limitations were placed on our very unstructured travels.

title: U.S. Stiffens Rule on Formaldehyde Exposure
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has ordered a two-thirds reduction in the amount of formaldehyde that workers can be exposed to on the job.

title:
About Men;
A Love Affair
description: LEAD: I REMEMBER THE WAY THE LIGHT touched her hair. She turned her head, and I saw her face. She turned still more, and our eyes met and held. We saw each other, a momentary awareness in that raucous fifth-grade schoolroom to which I'd just been assigned. I felt as though I'd been struck a blow under the heart.

title: Weapons Builders Face New Tests As U.S. Retrenches
description: LEAD: IN a crowded ceremony inside a cavernous Grumman Corporation hangar in Calverton last week, the Navy formally accepted the first of 70 upgraded versions of the F-14A, the Grumman-built fighter jet that has become a front-line defender of American foreign policy around the world.

title: Plans to Expand a Maine Ski Resort Stir Debate
description: For Charles Rinaldi, an official with the National Park Service, hiking the three-mile stretch of Appalachian Trail along Saddleback Mountain's treeless summit ridge is ''a kind of euphoria.''

title: Fire Officials Criticize Tax Breaks
description: LEAD: A GROUP of fire commissioners has criticized the Town of Brookhaven's offers of property tax breaks to attract industries, saying that the program deprives fire departments of money while increasing their burdens.

title: EVERY STRAW WAS THE LAST
description: THE DEVIL AND DR. BARNES Portrait of an American Art Collector. By Howard Greenfeld. Illustrated. 306 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Bruce Goes Out a Winner
description: Matt Frantz made a 26-yard field goal with 5 minutes 18 seconds remaining today to give Ohio State a 23-20 victory over error-prone Michigan that sent out dismissed Coach Earle Bruce as a winner.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
In Suffolk, Privacy Is Offered - for a Price
description: LEAD: WHEN Eric Neitzel, vice president of De Barbieri Associates, real estate brokers in St. James, began showing model houses last month at a Smithtown development called Meridian Manors, a potential buyer arrived on horseback.

title: CONGRESS IS SEEN AS LIKELY TO BACK DEFICIT AGREEMENT
description: Despite strong opposition from conservative Republicans, Congress seems likely to adopt the deficit-reduction plan announced Friday by President Reagan and Congressional leaders, officials in the White House and on Capitol Hill said today.

title: Lynda Clarizio, a Lawyer, to Marry Mark Foulon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Attavio Clarizio of Verona, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynda Clarizio, to Mark Foulon, a son of Janet Foulon of Spokane, Wash., and the late Max Foulon.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: The Statehouse Is Soiled

title: When Chaos Rules the Market
description: THAT the stock market embodies turbulence, mayhem and unpredictability, no survivor of October 1987 can doubt. Some economists, borrowing the vocabulary of a new branch of science, now believe that it also represents chaos.

title: AN UGLY FEELING
description: I was struck by Sam Toperoff's need to continue to press for an answer to the disturbing question of why he ''somehow needed to make women, as a class, the defeated foes of [ his ] triumph.'' He experienced, in all its ugliness, the real nature of the power-worshiping system of male dominance (and female subordination) on which our social order is based. Such clarity of perception is of the highest importance. Recognition of the deep and largely unconscious structures that shape our thinking and our social order may be the only way those structures will be changed. DOROTHY TUCK MCFARLAND Leverett, Mass.

title: Genteel Playwright, Angry Voice
description: IN CARYL CHURCHILL'S VITRIOLIC NEW COME-dy, ''Serious Money,'' greed, corruption and self-interest share equal billing. Venality is a way of LIFFE (an acronym for the London International Financial Futures Exchange). Money is the key to more money - and to power - and on this boardroom battlefield even sex takes a holiday. In one of the play's more absurd scenes, a banker and a businesswoman try to arrange a tryst and find they do not even have time for a quick lunch date in their tightly scheduled, yupwardly mobile lives. So they forget sex and return to the stimulation of profit-making in ''the City,'' the London equivalent of Wall Street that is the bull-and-bear pit for Ms. Churchill's satire.

title: A Dog Bark or a Choral Crescendo
description: THE array of devices now available to professional musicians, from $100 drum machines to $500,000 digital audio systems, has tranformed both the art of music and its practitioners.

title: Dow Chemical Wants to be Your Friend
description: TURN the clock back 25 years or thereabouts. The Dow Chemical Company is making napalm - jellied gasoline that kills in a particularly painful way - for use in Vietnam, and American students are chasing Dow recruiters off campus. Dow's reaction: part annoyance, part indifference.

title: Using Technology
description: To the Editor:

title: Delay Seen in New York Rent-Control Rises
description: For the second time since 1985, a problem in New York State's handling of the rent-control program could delay approval of standard rent increases for several months.

title: Zoning Dispute Stirs Valley Stream
description: RESIDENTS of a Valley Stream neighborhood backing up onto one of the village's busiest streets are fighting the latest of many battles in which Long Island residents are trying to change zoning laws they think are distressingly antiquated.

title: A Jazzman Plays His Life in His Own Key
description: A BRIEF MUSICAL PHRASE FROM ''All the Things You Are'' spirals up through the dark theater.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FAMILY LIFE. By Mary Elsie Robertson. (Atheneum, $18.95.) Away at camp, 17-year-old Chrissy Sloan suspects from her mother's letters that something is terribly wrong at home. And, sure enough, she arrives at the family cottage on Nantucket to find that her father has taken a lover. Thus Mary Elsie Robertson's fourth novel unfolds in a painful tale of domestic drama as the tensions created by Philip Sloan's philandering entangle his wife, Estella, their three children, even the family dog.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Confidential business information has long been recognized as property.''

title: North Korea Floats a Revolutionary Ideology: Realism
description: NORTH KOREA has lost faith in its ability to reunify Korea under Communist rule and is prepared to negotiate peace with South Korea and the United States following next month's presidential election in the South. This was my conclusion after 10 days of conversations in Pyongyang last month with a variety of North Korean leaders, including Prime Minister Li Gun Mo, Foreign Minister Kim Yong Nam and Hwang Chang Yop, the powerful secretary of the Workers (Communist) Party Central Committee responsible for foreign policy. Economic pressures appear to be compelling North Korea to pursue two closely related priorities: a reduction of military spending through an accommodation with Seoul and Washington, and a rapid influx of advanced industrial technology, facilitated by a China-style economic opening to the West.

title: A Family's Legacy on Show In Amsterdam
description: THE van Loon Museum offers visitors the opportunity to step inside one of Amsterdam's great homes and discover how the 17th- and 18th-century merchant princes of the Netherlands lived.

title: State to Acquire the Site Of Battle in War of 1812
description: A group of local historians and veterans has persuaded the state to preserve a tiny Lake Champlain island that was the scene of a significant battle in the War of 1812.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Soccer North Carolina Extends Streak: Top-ranked North Carolina, extending its unbeaten streak to 48 games, easily beat third-ranked California, 4-0, yesterday in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's soccer final four at Amherst, Mass. The Tar Heels (22-0-1) advanced to the title game today against the University of Massachusetts (20-1), which defeated Central Florida, 2-1, in the other semifinal. The final will be played on the campus of UMass, which has a 34-game home unbeaten streak.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 1 about stock market risk incorrectly explained a trading strategy. As the value of stocks falls below the value of matching futures indexes, portfolio insurers sell stock index futures. This strategy can inadvertently lead to further stock declines, because it may create an opportunity for program traders to buy index futures and sell the corresponding stocks.

title: Indulging A Passion For Piazzas
description: AGE, the weak dollar and Italian intransigence have conspired, happily, to change our travel strategy for good. Late in life, my husband and I have learned to shape the days to our new interests and lesser energies, and thereby discovered a new and even nicer Italy. We've exchanged the cities, with their rudely expensive hotels and restaurants, raucous traffic and endless ''chiuso's'' (''closed'') for the quieter pleasures of its hill towns, seductive landscapes and, above all, its piazzas.

title: Development and the Environment
description: THE would-be New Jersey homeowner is fast becoming a prime candidate for the official list of endangered species in the Garden State.

title: Betty Ford Is Reported Doing Well After Surgery
description: Betty Ford, the wife of former President Gerald R. Ford, was doing ''exceptionally well'' today after undergoing quadruple coronary artery bypass surgery, a spokeswoman for the family said.

title: THE PERILS OF A READY-MADE AUDIENCE
description: THE VELVET PRISON Artists Under State Socialism. By Miklos Haraszti. Translated by Katalin and Stephen Landesmann with Steve Wasserman. 165 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/ Basic Books. $14.95.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Odie Goldies
description: LEAD: The medium is pure 1980's, but the message is old-fashioned. Pupils at the William B. Ward School, which serves 865 kindergarteners through sixth graders in New Rochelle, have been watching music videos designed to put them in touch not with Madonna or Bon Jovi but with some of the traditional music of America.

title: WALSH MAKES HIS MOVE
description: In Philip Shenon's article ''Walsh Makes His Move'' (Oct. 25), on the long hours being put in by the special prosecutor Lawrence E. Walsh and his staff in their $3 million effort to indict and prosecute Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and others in the Iran-contra affair, we read that Mr. Walsh ''left the office each night with stacks of classified documents to read after a room-service dinner in his hotel.''

title: Music
description: The work of two Brazilian musical giants, Antonio Carlos Jobim and Heitor Villa-Lobos, will be featured in Lincoln Center concerts Monday evening. At Avery Fisher Hall, Mr. Jobim, the architect of bossa nova and composer of ''Desafinado'' and ''The Girl From Ipanema,'' will sing and play guitar in a concert celebrating the 25th anniversary of the introduction of bossa nova to American concert halls. Mr. Jobim has just released ''Passarim,'' his first album in the United States since 1980, which features seven new songs with lyrics in both English and Portuguese. Sharing the bill are Gal Costa and Carlos Barbosa-Lima. Showtime is at 8 P.M.

title: Out of Sight, Out of Soul
description: To the Editor:

title: From Kim Young Sam, Appeal for the Safe Road
description: As he demonstrated today before a thin crowd in front of the Chonju rail station, Kim Young Sam is no stem-winding orator.

title: AIDS Helps Rescue Ailing Hospital
description: St. Clare's, a small general hospital near the theater district of Manhattan, has had so many brushes with financial oblivion that the staff has lost count. But lately, St. Clare's has begun to thrive, and officials say it is because of AIDS.

title: G.O.P. SEES SIGNS OF A ROBERTSON INCURSION
description: Bob Dole's campaign chairman in Iowa, Steven Roberts, says that while Vice President Bush is still the major target, Dole forces are ''real concerned'' about Pat Robertson. John Buckley, who does public relations for Jack Kemp, says, ''We have always taken Pat Robertson seriously.'' Lee Atwater, Mr. Bush's campaign manager, is more blunt: Anybody who doesn't take Mr. Robertson seriously, he says, ''is crazy.''

title: Partch Recordings
description: To the Editor:

title: Broader View Of the World
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Business, B.C.
description: NEARLY 4,000 YEARS AGO, A COU-ple of business partners in Anatolia, (Turkey, in modern parlance) had a dispute in court. ''When I was in Kanesh, you went off to Durhumit,'' one said, ''and there you entered my guesthouse and took out two containers, sealed.'' In other words, according to Dr. Ira Spar, research Assyriologist at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art, ''the guy stole a safe.''

title: Taylor Still on Active List
description: Despite an injured hamstring, Lawrence Taylor of the Giants may play Sunday against the Saints here.

title: THEATER: STOPPARD DUO OF ONE-ACT RADIO PLAYS
description: IF it takes one man, working alone, eight years to paint a railway bridge, the bridge will need repainting by the time he has completed his task. Therefore, the authorities decide, it would be more efficient to hire 1,800 men to do the project in a single day. Naturally, the structure cannot support the weight of an army of painters, and, with a loud cracking, the bridge collapses. Tom Stoppard's fanciful radio play, ''Albert's Bridge,'' ends with this sound-effect of astronomical proportions.

title: EXCELLENT SCHOOLS REQUIRE EFFORTS OF ALL
description: IN the late 1960's and the early 1970's, there were two efforts in the educational professions taking place simultaneously but parallel to each other. The first was the movement toward humanizing American education and establishing a greater relevance in the educational process to the experiences of young Americans. In this climate, alternative schools began to flourish. The benefits of the smaller, more intimate climates of the alternative schools found their way into traditional schools and they, in turn, became more responsive to the needs of students.

title: Soviet Afghanistan Veterans Call For End of Neglect and for Honor
description: Soviet veterans of the war in Afghanistan have started a nationwide organization to combat official neglect of those who served in the war and to press for monuments honoring soldiers killed there, organizers of the group said today.

title: D-DAYS AND THE END OF WORLD WAR II
description: Sarah Clayton's essay sharpened an indelible picture that has remained in my mind for many years.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SKINWALKERS, by Tony Hillerman. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $3.95.) In Tony Hillerman's eighth mystery novel set among the mesas and arroyos of the Navajo Nation, Joe Leaphorn and Jim Chee are faced with a multiple murder involving a strange mix of Indian witchcraft and modern medicine. Earlier this year, Newgate Callendar said here that the story is told ''in sensitive prose that once in a while approaches poetry.'' CITIES ON A HILL: A Journey Through Contemporary American Cultures, by Frances FitzGerald. (Touch-stone/Simon & Schuster, $8.95.) By examining four sub-cultures - the San Francisco homosexual community in the area known as the Castro, the Rev. Jerry Falwell's Baptist congregation in Lynchburg, Va., the Sun City retirement enclave in Florida and the Rajneeshpuram commune in Oregon - Frances FitzGerald explores the peculiarly American notion that it is possible to join with kindred souls and ''reinvent'' ourselves. Although our reviewer, Carl N. Degler, said last year that the links drawn among these communities were a little weak, he admired the book's ''lucid, often entertaining detail'' and ''evenhanded'' prose. THE FLAME BEARERS, by Kim Chernin. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $6.95.) Drawing on the kabbala and other sources of Jewish mysticism, Kim Chernin tells of Rae Shadmi, a successful academic who returns to San Francisco to take over the family business: a centuries-old cult run by women. By ''turning the rabbinic tradition inside out,'' Anne Roiphe said here last year, Ms. Chernin has created a novel that ''will be read with delight by those who enjoy good ideological revenge.'' THE BIG BOYS: Power and Position in American Business, by Ralph Nader and William Taylor. (Pantheon, $8.95.) Unlike much business journalism, these profiles of nine corporate leaders avoid celebrating the rich and powerful, our reviewer, Mark Singer, said in 1986. The authors ''have conducted their research in a tirelessly thorough manner, along the way cataloguing every discernible wart and scar.'' ULTRAMARINE, by Raymond Carver. (Vintage, $6.95.) Like his stark short stories, many of Raymond Carver's poems are about the silences that act like glass walls keeping people forever apart. ''He has the astonished, chastened voice of a person who has survived a wreck,'' Patricia Hampl said here earlier this year. No one else's ''brevity is as rich, as complete.'' END PAPERS: Essays, Letters, Articles of Faith, Workbook Notes, by Breyten Breytenbach. (McGraw-Hill, $8.95.) Many of the Afrikaaner poet and painter's musings on the tension between politics and art were written while he was in a South African prison because of his antiapartheid activities. In 1986, our reviewer, Bruce Robbins, said the author seemed to appreciate the ironies of being ''a prison-produced celebrity'' and has written ''an eloquent appeal for solidarity'' between blacks and whites in his homeland. RAT MAN OF PARIS, by Paul West. (Collier/Macmillan, $6.95.) Among the characters who have haunted the streets of Paris in recent years is the Rat Man, who would annoy tourists by flashing a live rodent in their faces. Lore Segal said here last year that in using this real-life eccentric as his subject, Paul West has written a novel whose prose is ''gorgeous and hilarious.'' TAKEOVER, by Moira Johnston. (Penguin, $7.95.) With the crash of the Dow, this account of Carl Icahn, T. Boone Pickens and the phenomenon of the involuntary merger may be more interesting historically than as a topic of current affairs. While our reviewer, Anthony M. Solomon, said last year that the book was not sufficiently analytical, it ''touches all the bases . . . and provides enough material for a generation of aspiring investment bankers to ponder.'' BLUEBEARD'S EGG: And Other Stories, by Margaret Atwood. (Fawcett, $4.95.) The most engaging pieces in this collection by the author of ''The Handmaid's Tale'' are those that seem the most autobiographical, Robert Towers said in The Book Review last year. ''In writing of [ her parents ] , the daughter allows herself to rise from time to time to a kind of visionary eloquence.'' WRITING IN RESTAURANTS, by David Mamet. (Penguin, $6.95.) In these essays, the playwright David Mamet, whose ''Glengarry Glen Ross'' won a Pulitzer Prize in 1984, wanted to show that ''the purpose of the play is to bring to the stage the life of the soul.'' Last year, our reviewer, Gib Johnson, said that while some of the essays seemed rather weak, others were ''clear and enormously entertaining.'' THE WOMAN WHO ESCAPED FROM SHAME, by Toby Olson. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) Using tales told by a trio of sailors traveling in the Baja with three prostitutes, Toby Olson constructs a labyrinth of interconnected stories all revolving around horses. ''The landscape is that of Carlos Castaneda's Don Juan novels,'' Robert Kelly said here last year. ''The mysterious cult of the horse, the crisscrossed affinities, stand before us with the innocence of dreams.'' MICHAEL FARADAY: A Biography, by L. Pearce Williams. (Da Capo, $13.95.) Michael Faraday's discovery in the 19th century that moving a magnet along a wire generates electricity helped set the first cornerstone in the continuing attempt to devise a grand unification theory: if electricity and magnetism are related, then why not gravity and the nuclear forces as well? ''Anybody who knows enough about electricity to screw in a light bulb can follow most of Faraday's experiments as they are described in this book,'' one reviewer said in 1965, ''and the occasional puzzling paragraph can only intensify the suspense of a scientific epic that is also a harrowing intellectual thriller.''

title:
GARDENING;
THEIR LEAVES ARE EVERGREEN
description: LEAD: NOW, when most plants are bare, a handful remain courageously green. These are perennials that provide an optimistic note in the landscape, a reminder of other seasons.

title: 60 Protesters Stalk Connecticut Deer Hunters
description: Some 60 animal rights protesters, many of them carrying flash cameras and grisly photographs of freshly shot deer, stalked hunters in the Yale-Myers Forest today in an effort to disrupt the start of Connecticut's annual controlled deer hunt here.

title:
ART;
Paper Potpourri Offers Diversity
description: LEAD: THE annual works-on-paper competition sponsored by the Firehouse Gallery at Nassau Community College is one of the oldest of these traditions on Long Island as well as one of the largest. Jurors are usually encouraged to select 100 entries from those submitted.

title: Homeless Group Is Scattered From the Grounds of M.I.T.
description: The police rousted more than a dozen homeless people from their makeshift shelters and tents on Massachusetts Institute of Technology property today, arresting several when they balked at leaving in the rain, school officials said. A spokesman for the institute, Robert C. DiIorio, said people at the tent city had been warned since last month that they could not stay.

title: BEARINGS CALLED CAUSE OF LONDON SUBWAY FIRE
description: Investigators said today that overheated bearings in an escalator probably ignited the fire in a London subway station in which 30 people died Wednesday evening.

title: Indian Troops Begin Cease-Fire in Sri Lanka
description: Indian troops began a unilateral 48-hour cease-fire today to give ethnic Tamil rebels time to comply with an accord aimed at ending the four-year-old civil war in Sri Lanka, an Indian spokeswoman said.

title: Gooden Weds
description: DWIGHT GOODEN was married to Monica C. Harris last night in Tampa, Fla., in a private ceremony attended by some 600 guests, including Gary Carter, Dave Magadan and a few other of Gooden's teammates on the Mets.

title: Correction
description: A listing last Sunday in The World of New York, part 2 of The Times Magazine, about places to take children in New York City, misstated the phone number of Theaterworks/USA.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DOCTOR COYOTE A Native American Aesop's Fables. By John Bierhorst. Illustrated by Wendy Watson. Unpaged. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $14.95. (Ages 7 to 10) DEATH OF THE IRON HORSE Written and illustrated by Paul Goble. Unpaged. New York: Bradbury Press. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 8) INDIAN CHIEFS By Russell Freedman. Illustrated. 151 pp. New York: Holiday House. $15.95. (Ages 10 to 14) THEY DANCE IN THE SKY Native American Star Myths. By Jean Guard Monroe and Ray A. Williamson. Illustrated by Edgar Stewart. 130 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $12.95. (Ages 9 to 13)

title: Corrections
description: A table on Oct. 25 comparing stock market averages misstated the percent change of the American Stock Exchange market value index from Aug. 12, 1982, to Oct. 22, 1987. It was 127 percent.

title: ODD ONES OUT
description: LEAD: SPIRIT SEIZURES By Melissa Pritchard. 182 pp. Athens: The University of Georgia Press. $13.95.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Bridgeport, Conn. $225,000 241 Lake Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 52-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, fireplace; taxes $2,990. Kent, Conn. $92,000 South Kent Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old cottage; 0.5-acre property facing pond, needed work; taxes $711. Ridgefield, Conn. $485,000 836 North Salem Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; family room, spiral staircase to loft, deck, 3.4 acres; taxes $4,590. Peekskill, N.Y. $421,000 15 Elena Court 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 2-year-old contemporary; family room, office, wraparound deck, 1 acre, taxes $5,200. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $320,000 Cradle Rock Road East 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old Cap Cod, eat-in kitchen, dining area, large patio, 2 acres; taxes $3,600. White Plains, N.Y. $250,000 31 Garretson Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 52-year-old stucco Tudor/Norman; brook, pond, walk to station; taxes $1,874. OTHER AREAS Ridge, L.I. $125,000 105 Wauwepex Trail 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 12-year-old ranch; fireplace, 1-car garage, landscaped; taxes $2,000. Shoreham, L.I. $155,000 68 North Country Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 13-year-old ranch; den, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $1,800. Rockaway, N.J. $155,000 36 Richard Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old split level; new roof, deck and a large yard; taxes $2,295.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: IN THE last year, state and Federal officials have begun warning of a phenomenon they call ''environmental gridlock,'' an inability to reach consensus on solutions to solid waste and other problems.

title: Gasoline-Tax Rise Proposed in Trenton
description: NOW that the legislative elections are over and the shape of the Senate and Assembly are set, lawmakers are talking about something that has been on their minds all year but not on their tongues, at least during the recent campaign: raising the tax on gasoline.

title: Music: Ridge Quartet
description: THE question about John Cage is whether he should be considered a composer or a critic. Tuesday evening at the 92d Street Y, the Ridge String Quartet offered his ''String Quartet in Four Parts,'' which dates from 1949-50. Even then, before developing the random-choice musical procedures most associated with his name, Mr. Cage seems to have been asking questions - ''Why not try this?'' ''Who are we to choose sounds?'' - more than creating music.

title: Thailand's Crafts Abound At Chiang Mai
description: IT was late on a Saturday afternoon on Sankampaeng Road in Chiang Mai, the second largest city in Thailand, famous as a center for crafts and decorative arts. The road was under construction and there was just room enough for one lane of traffic in either direction - plus the ubiquitous motorcycles that make their own rules. It was rush hour, and one local bus was in a rush. Seeing an opening in the line of oncoming cars, it pulled out in front of us to create three lanes going out of town, effectively eliminating the one lane going in.

title: Oh, for the Spice of Eccentricity
description: IN ''NUTS,'' BARBRA STREISAND PLAYS A WOMAN who curses frequently, exhibits violent mood swings and lashes out angrily at those she loves. This behavior is supposed to convince an audience that a judge might find her certifiably insane, but by some latter-day, urban standards, it's really all in a day's work. The fact is that true craziness, however easy to spot on the street, is a rarity on the screen, and its absence grows more regrettable all the time. Unless one considers the systematic manufacture of prefab, predictable film product a form of institutionalized lunacy, the film business has rarely been more sanity-conscious than it is today.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Nov. 7 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $335,000 155 East 93d Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. co-op in a prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, large kitchen, high ceilings; maintenance $750, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: A.J. Clark) Chelsea $640,000 434 West 23d Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,309-sq,-ft. duplex co-op in a recently renovated prewar brownstone; large kitchen, 2 fireplaces, terrace over garden; maintenance $475, no tax-deduction (Broker: Wells & Gay) Gracie Square $2.3 million 10 Gracie Square 4-bedroom, 4-bath, 4,500-sq.-ft. duplex co-op in a prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, formal dining room, 5 maids' rooms, 4 fireplaces, East River view; maintenance $3,400, 29% tax-deductible (Broker: Joan Schlank Real Estate) Upper East Side $1.38-million 17 East 63d Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, co-op in a prewar brownstone; entry foyer, 3 fireplaces, private elevator; maintenance $2,242, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Sulzberger-Rolfe) Upper East Side $225,000 301 East 87th Street (Corniche) 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 925-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining area, terrace, East River view; maintenance $947, 70% tax-deductible (Broker: Arthur P. Brooks Realty) Washington Heights $221,000 160 Cabrini Boulevard (Castle Village) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft. co-op in a prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, dining foyer, roof deck, Hudson River view; maintenance $745, includes utilities, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: C-Uptown Realty) BRONX Riverdale $165,000 2575 Palisades Avenue (Riverview) 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 870-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; part-time doorman, dining room, terrace, Hudson River view; maintenance $636, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Kahan & Kahan Realty) Wakefield $195,000 4356 Edson Avenue 2-family, detached, frame house; 3 bedrooms, 2 baths, dining room in primary unit; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath in other; large kitchens in both; 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker:

title: Tureens: Functional, Fanciful, Fantastic
description: AN IDEA first cooked up at the Campbell Soup Company complex here in 1976 is proving able to retain its zest the third time around.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: WITH HIS LATEST PLAY, ''Lettice and Lovage,'' Peter Shaffer has happily rediscovered something he mislaid so long ago we'd quite forgotten he ever possessed it: a sense of humor.

title: Ballet: 'La Sonnambula' Pairs Kistler and LaFosse
description: IN ''La Sonnambula,'' performed by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday at the New York State Theater, George Balanchine has created a dark, almost satanic version of a romantic narrative ballet, set to sweeping and melodic music by Vittorio Rieti after themes from three Bellini operas. Alain Vaes frames the action, a party attended by an unannounced Poet and a mysterious Sleepwalker, with a solid, bourgeois country home in his new set. On the Sleepwalker's final retreat, the glow of her candle is now seen moving past windows in a gallery overlooking the stage.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
ART
description: LEAD: The Hudson River and Its Painters Directed by Lee Savage. Produced by the Hudson Company in association with the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Home Vision. 60 minutes. $39.95. Putting nine-foot paintings of the Hudson River on video is a little like putting the Hudson River on nine-foot paintings.

title: All That Jazz
description: A prison guard, a chemical engineer, a realtor, the representative of the Dutch bulb industry in the United States, a computer expert and a consulting engineer - all accomplished jazz musicians after business hours - are members of a group playing together in a newly formed jazz band. The group, was organized by Norman Liss, who heads his own public relations firm in Hartsdale, and Peter Bard, a Westchester newspaper advertising executive.

title: ON FINANCIAL BRACKET OF PRESCHOOLERS
description: I read your article, ''Baby Boom Hitting Nursery Schools'' [ Nov. 1 ] , with great interest. I would like to make one important correction. The article states that in the Prekindergarten Program of New Rochelle ''all 215 children fall below the income guidelines to qualify.'' This is inaccurate and was probably a misunderstanding; 10 percent of the 215 children do exceed the financial guidelines. NANCY BOGIN Coordinator Prekindergarten Program Of New Rochelle

title: Sloppy Knicks Get Their 2d Victory
description: It won't be very often this season that the Knicks benefit from such charity. Last night, they found themselves matched against the Golden State Warriors, a team that was both drained from a road trip and debilitated by injuries. Still, it was three full periods before the Knicks could manage their second victory of the season.

title: Tailback Leads Chaminade to C.H.S.F.L. Title
description: Considering his performance in Chaminade's 28-6 victory over St. John the Baptist in yesterday's Catholic High Schools Football League championship at St. John's University, Ellery Roberts had little competition as the game's most valuable player.

title: A Wedding of Darkness and Light
description: CICELY COTTINGHAM is a landscapist who works at night using charcoal, which she massages into her paper until it resembles impacted soot. Light is present in these drawings, but only to the degree that it defines the masses of darkness.

title: Northrop's Struggle With the MX
description: DAVID N. FERGUSON peered through a plate-glass window into the pristine room where technicians, clad from head to toe in surgical garb, pieced together the spherical devices that would guide nuclear MX ballistic missiles through their globe-spanning trajectories.

title: What Has a Weasel Ever Done to You?
description: To the Editor:

title: Students Say Syrians Raided At American Beirut Campus
description: Syrian soldiers patrolling West Beirut stormed dormitories at the American University of Beirut Thursday night, students said.

title: Allison J. Constantine To Wed Rick Beispel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Constantine of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Allison J. Constantine, to Rick Allen Beispel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Beispel of New York. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Sports of The Times; A Sense of Class, Anyone?
description: FOR anyone interested in the Mets and college football, all gall was divided lately into three parts:

title: BARBARA KAGAN TO WED THOMAS A. KORNREICH
description: Mrs. Charles M. Kagan of New York and Southampton, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Barbara Lynne Kagan, to Thomas Adam Kornreich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. Kornreich of Harrison, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Rock: John Lydon and Public Image Ltd.
description: JOHN LYDON could not believe the audience response when Public Image Ltd., his band, played Wednesday at the Beacon Theater. The sold-out house stood and watched him perform, then applauded each song warmly - but it neither joined in on choruses nor sneered back at Mr. Lydon's taunts. As Johnny Rotten, the voice of the Sex Pistols, and then as the cynical, corrosive leader of Public Image Ltd., Mr. Lydon has claimed a role as rock's agent provocateur. Meeting no reaction beyond bemused tolerance, he was nearly undone. ''What is this, passive resistance?'' he fumed.

title: Taking the Pulse of the Aging Williamsburg Bridge
description: In high winds and swirling snow flurries, the Williamsburg Bridge took an engineering ''electrocardiogram'' yesterday morning.

title: Armagnac From the South of France
description: ROBERT CAME, seated among the damp wood barrels in the darkened barn that houses the cellars of Cles des Ducs, one of the many producers of the brandy known as Armagnac, talked of noses, tongues and mouths. Cles des Ducs is in Panjas, a tiny crossroads in the western part of Armagnac, that roughly rolling district of southwestern France that the French call Gascony.

title: Injury-Riddled Giants Are Not Dead Yet
description: A year ago, when the National Football League neared the middle of the season, the Giants were moving along smartly with a 5-2 record. After that, they won every game they played -nine in the regular season and three in the playoffs - and became the Super Bowl champions.

title: 'WE'RE NOT REALLY IN GREAT SHAPE'
description: NORTHEAST UTILITIES, which supplies electricity and gas to most of Connecticut through its operating subsidiary, Connecticut Light and Power, recently announced that it would seek to cut its budget by 15 percent before 1990 by selling surplus property, cutting 600 jobs and eliminating unnecessary programs. The company maintains that unless it is able to keep its rates under control, it risks driving more and more customers away with higher and higher rates.

title: BLUE DYE IN LAKE CURTAILS WEEDS
description: LEAD: FOR the last two years, visitors to Artist Lake in Middle Island have noticed a blue tinge to the water, the result of an experiment by the Town of Brookhaven to curb vegetation growth.

title: Dr. Elizabeth A. Jonas Plans to Wed in March
description: Dr. Saran Jonas and Dr. Ruth H. Jonas of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Elizabeth Ann Jonas, to Dr. Thomas Eisen, a son of Dr. Herman Eisen and Dr. Natalie Aronson Eisen of Newton, Mass. A March wedding is planned.

title: WHEN HE HITS THE BALL, BO JACKSON RIVALS BOGGS, IN THEORY
description: BO JACKSON is just about as good a hitter as Wade Boggs - when he hits the ball.

title: POLLUTERS NOW PAY FOR FISH THEY KILL
description: THE State Department of Environmental Protection is now charging polluters for the fish they kill with spills of chemicals or toxic materials.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ALBUQUERQUE
description: After travels in greener climes, flying back into Albuquerque always gives a high-desert dweller a feeling that must parallel the thrill of a landlocked sailor suddenly whisked to the oceanside and offered a boat.

title: Sir John Colville, 72, Secretary to Churchill
description: Sir John Colville, principal private secretary to Sir Winston Churchill and two other prime ministers, has died, family death notices said today. He was 72 years old.

title:
GARDENING;
2 EASILY FORCED BULBS TO BRIGHTEN WINTER
description: LEAD: FEW winter gardening activities bring greater satisfaction than forcing bulbs. While most spring-flowering bulbs require lengthy treatment under special conditions before they will force, two exceptions, giant amarylis and polyanthus narcissus, may be forced easily and quickly.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Art
description: LEAD: ''Outside In'' commemorates the first 10 years of the Athena Foundation, started by the sculptor Mark di Suvero. The foundation has been consistently inventive in its support of artists in many media, including sculpture, painting, video and performance. Last year it inaugurated the Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens, which has just opened its third show, ''Artists Choose Artists,'' in its difficult and spectacular site alongside the East

title: Half a Million 1983 Vehicles Are Being Recalled by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation is recalling more than a half-million 1983 Chevrolet, Pontiac and G.M.C. vehicles to replace an emission control switch.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: SHAKESPEAREAN PHOTOS

title: AT HOME WITH WRIGHT-BUILT HOUSES
description: LEAD: IN the late 1940's, Frank Lloyd Wright, then almost 80 years old, designed a site plan for a group of houses to be built in a wooded and hilly area of Westchester that he and his disciples called Usonia. Usonia was a term for the United States used by Samuel Butler in his 1917 Utopian novel, ''Erewhon.

title: WINTER SALMON RIVER FISHING
description: IF considerable physical discomfort doesn't depress you and you can also persuade yourself that winter fishing in the snow belt is not a sport for idiots, you might enjoy trying for the big brown and steelhead trout that are even now surging up New York State's Salmon River, which enters Lake Ontario near Pulaski.

title: DOCUMENTARY
description: Vietnam: In the Year of the Pig Produced and directed by Emile de Antonio. MPI Home Video. 103 minutes. $39.95.

title: U.S. Policy on Panama Faces Key Tests on Aid and Joint Exercises
description: United States policy toward Panama will soon face two key tests whose outcome is certain to affect the deepening political crisis here, Panamanian political leaders and foreign diplomats say.

title: Tears Mix With Optimism for Town's Future
description: Collette Pustay fought back tears Friday as she finished her shift at the Volkswagen plant here. Three hours earlier, she was among 2,500 employees who learned that the West German automobile maker would close the plant next year because of slumping sales.

title: Hunters Warned About Eating Birds
description: LEAD: LIKE commercial and recreational fishermen, hunters are now being told that what they capture and eat may harm them.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The red brick floor in our sunroom is 11 years old and has become soiled. How should we clean this brick and what can we do to keep the bricks clean without painting?

title: Milosz and the Polish-Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A report in ''Headliners'' last Sunday about former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland misattributed a quotation about his 1977 conviction in a case of mail fraud and racketeering. After the conviction was set aside on Nov. 12, Breckinridge Willcox, the United States Attorney in Baltimore, said, ''Whatever the decision, the man is guilty.'' The quotation was not from Mr. Mandel's lawyer, Arnold M. Weiner.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Keep Chuckling
description: LEAD: HERE'S GOOFY Walt Disney Home Video. 22 minutes. $14.95.

title: Kasparov Accepts Draw in Game 15
description: Game 15 of the world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, ended in a draw yesterday, and with a wrangle.

title: Radioactive-Waste Talks Set
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY and Connecticut will begin formal deliberations this week on how they will manage low-level radioactive waste. The most immediate question will be: Which state gets the waste?

title: Jersey Finds No Link Between Ocean and Illness
description: The first phase of a $1 million health study at the Jersey Shore has found no definitive links between ocean swimming and illness, state health officials reported today.

title: MURDER, ANYONE? A WEEKEND FOR THE AMATEUR SLEUTH
description: LEAD: AFTER the fourth murder, Anita Luery, the public relations director for the Bridgeport Hilton, sat back and relaxed. Everything had gone according to schedule.

title: Holmes at Age 38: Confident as Ever
description: ON a Wednesday night earlier this month, at the Larry Holmes Commodore Inn on United States Route 22 in Phillipsburg, N. J., friends and relatives of the proprietor gathered in a ballroom there to throw him a surprise birthday party.

title: Bruce Files Suit Against Ohio St.
