description: Earle Bruce has sued Ohio State and its president, Edward Jennings, because of the anguish his family felt after his dismissal as football coach, his attorney said today.

title: Let Banks Sell Securities
description: Does the stock market crash undermine the case for allowing commercial banks to compete in the securities business? No, say two financial heavyweights, William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve. They conclude that the potential benefits of a careful liberalization far outweigh the risks to the stability of the banking system.

title: Iranian Boats Are Reported To Hit 2 Greek-Flagged Ships
description: Iranian naval gunners fired on two Greek-registered vessels in the Persian Gulf over the weekend in apparent retaliation for Iraqi attacks on shipping bound for Iran.

title: Junk Bonds - A Positive Force in the Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank Board Sees Hope In Texas
description: After organizing the largest Federal liquidation of a thrift institution - the $1.3 billion shutdown of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association of Dallas - thrift regulators do not intend to close any other large Texas institution in the near future, said M. Danny Wall, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: U.S. Leader Is Picked By Asea Brown Boveri
description: A newly formed electrical equipment company called Asea Brown Boveri has named Klaus E. Agthe president and chief executive for United States operations.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Program Trader Backs Curb on Computer Use
description: LEAD: Louis I. Margolis, the managing director of equity, options and futures at Salomon Brothers Inc., is one of the leading practitioners of the highly automated trading strategies known as program trading.

title: Hanging on Yeltsin's Unheard Words
description: The most persistent popular demand resounding in this capital, aside from the never-ending search for basic foodstuffs, is for the Government to make public the words of Boris N. Yeltsin, the outspoken politician who swept into control of the city two years ago only to fall from grace in a severe test of the Soviet hierarchy.

title: S.A.S. May Bid For Caledonian
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System is expected to make a counter offer for the British Caledonian Group, which received a revised offer of $:147 million (about $262 million) on Friday from British Airways P.L.C.

title: Elephant Kills Moped Rider
description: A wild elephant trampled a school teacher riding a moped and sat beside the man's body until chased away by the police, the United News of India reported today. The elephant, which had strayed from a herd in Orissa State in eastern India, killed the teacher, Prabhakar Sahu, 45 years old, on a highway Saturday then squatted beside the body until it was forced back into the forest.

title: Heeding Eastern Europe Now
description: For decades, Eastern Europeans who wanted reforms found the Soviet Union standing in the way. Now Moscow takes the lead and beckons, while Eastern Europe's leaders balk. Their economies are in crisis, their people dispirited. Most of the leaders are old or ailing and to them, the future looks uncertain and reform risky.

title: Argentina Seeking Private Help on Oil
description: The administration of President Raul Alfonsin has abandoned Argentina's decades-old policy of state domination of the oil industry and is appealing to private enterprise, both foreign and national, to help exploit the country's energy potential.

title: Montana and Rice: A Winning Recipe
description: Joe Montana threw for 304 yards and Jerry Rice caught three touchdown passes today to lead the San Francisco 49ers to a 24-10 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: New York Shifts Debate on Homeless Problem
description: After years of frantic scrambling for beds and blankets, New York City's system of shelters for the homeless has grown into a vast bureaucracy that city officials and critics alike say is becoming increasingly competent in providing at least the bare necessities to all who need it.

title: A Survey of the Troubled
description: A new survey of the single men and women in the city's shelter system conducted for the city by the New York State Psychiatric Institute, and based upon interviews with a cross section of shelter residents, depicts a deeply troubled population, in which most people may never be capable of living entirely on their own. Here are some key findings:

title: ARMS INSPECTION FOR 13-YEAR SPAN IS SEEN BY SHULTZ
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he had received encouraging signs that the Soviet Union wanted to resolve the main differences remaining over a new missile treaty.

title: Pretoria Ousts 47 Black Troops
description: The South African Defense Force acknowledged today that 47 members of a black battalion with previous service in Angola were discharged last month but denied that there had been a mutiny.

title: Reslts Plus
description: Auto Racing

title: State Attorney General Seeks to Abolish Westchester Child Abuse Prevention Society
description: Charging that members of the Westchester County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children have abused their powers as peace officers, State Attorney General Robert Abrams is seeking a court order to dissolve the society.

title: Keeper of the Federal Purse for 50 Million People
description: He is 39 years old, presides over one-tenth of the Federal budget and supervises health programs that serve more than 50 million people.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is like running a town. The only difference is, rather than providing normal municipal services, we are also providing food, clothing, shelter and all the basic necessities of life.'' William J. Grinker on New York City's homeless shelter program. [ B6:3. ]

title: A Push for International Market Rules
description: In the wake of last month's stock market plunge, world financial regulators have intensified their effort to change outdated national regulations to cope with an increasingly global market.

title: Brazil Exporters Move To Stop U.S. Sanctions
description: Major Brazilian exporters, alarmed by an American threat to impose punitive tariffs on their products, are quietly urging the Government to find ways of dealing with United States objections to this country's controversial computer policy.

title: BAKER DENIES SEEKING FORUM FOR GORBACHEV
description: The White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., denied today that he formally asked Congressional leaders to allow the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to address a joint meeting of Congress next month.

title: Ranger Parts Mesh for Once
description: Many players were limping, and several faces were marked by cuts and bruises, souvenirs of connections with the opponents' sticks. But the Rangers, who had lately taken an emotional battering as well, flew home from Winnipeg without the hangdog demeanor they had worn for the last three weeks.

title: Commercial Broadcasters' Services (and Duties)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Trade: Wary Outlook
description: United Nations economists said Friday that the world would risk a recession if cuts in the United States budget deficit were not combined with moves by Japan and West Germany to stimulate demand for imports.

title: Advertising; TV Guide Retirement And a Promotion, Too
description: As Eric G. Larson announced his planned retirement as publisher of TV Guide last week, he also announced the promotion of William Deitch, a longtime magazine research specialist, to the position of general manager of TV Guide. By tradition at Triangle Publications, the job outranks publisher.

title: Peter Norman Ruben And Miss Benson Wed
description: The marriage of Karen Hilary Benson and Peter Norman Ruben took place yesterday at the Pierre Hotel in New York. Rabbi Joel Gore performed the ceremony.

title: Recapturing the High School 'Glory Days'
description: In an old mill town that makes lifetime heroes of its high school sports stars, Michael Considine was a quarterback on the football team, co-captain of the basketball team and captain of the baseball team.

title: Why Break In? Magruder Offers Answer
description: The three conferences here on the Nixon Presidency produced a tantalizing moment when Jeb Stuart Magruder, the deputy director of Mr. Nixon's 1972 campaign, offered a clear explanation of why Nixon loyalists ordered the break-in at Democratic National Committee headquarters in the Watergate building in June 1972.

title: Music Noted in Brief; George Russell Sextet At Sweet Basil
description: George Russell's music has had a pervasive influence in jazz circles since the 1940's, when compositions such as ''Cubano Be, Cubano Bop'' and ''A Bird in Igor's Yard'' pointed out intriguing parallels between Afro-Cuban rhythms, be-bop and Stravinsky. His sextets of the 60's, which included musicians such as Eric Dolphy, made some innovative and enduring records, and the news that Mr. Russell would be introducing a new sextet this week at Sweet Basil was cause for rejoicing.

title: Carolyn Pomerantz Weds
description: At Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I., Carolyn Sue Pomerantz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Pomerantz of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to Michael Elliott Rosenbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Rosenbaum of Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Robert Widom, assisted by Cantor Henry Weintraub, performed the ceremony. The bride is a vice president of True-Color Inc., a graphic arts and printing company in New York. Mr. Rosenbaum is a telecommunications specialist at Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: La Rochelle Journal; The Anti-Monarchist: His Majesty the Mayor
description: More than three centuries ago, La Rochelle's turreted city hall was a genuine fortress besieged by an army led by Cardinal Richelieu, the stern incarnation of the centralizing French state. Mayor Michel Crepeau today likes to show visitors the crease in a marble table top where in 1628 Admiral Jean Guiton, accepting the post of mayor, slammed his sword and demanded that no one surrender.

title: On Your Own: Running; Finding Out That Less Can Sometimes Be More
description: JIMMY BEHR is not one to talk, but the fact is, he is running less and enjoying it more. Like so many other runners, Behr, a 40-year-old A.T.&T. supervisor from Staten Island, got caught up in the mileage mania of the 1970's and at one point was training twice a day. He ran - rather, consumed - over 100 miles a week. Now that he takes it easy, he feels a lot better.

title: Article 824487 -- No Title
description: The highlight of Treasury financing in this holiday-shortened week is tomorrow's $7.5 billion auction of five-year notes.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PERESTROIKA: New Thinking for Our Country and the World. By Mikhail Gorbachev. 254 pages. A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Few New Airlines Survive
description: When the airline industry was deregulated in 1978, the unfettered market was expected to give rise to scores of low-cost carriers that would create a bonanza for consumers, put the existing companies on the defensive and even run some of them out of business.

title: Stage: Elizabeth Ashley In 'Milk Train' Revival
description: INCH for inch, measure for measure, there is, proportionately, more acting on stage at the small WPA Theater than in any other theater in New York - and most of it is being done by Elizabeth Ashley. The play is ''The Milk Train Doesn't Stop Here Anymore,'' and the stars are Ms. Ashley, Marian Seldes and Amanda Plummer. Histrionics are, of course, the life blood of this Tennessee Williams play, the story of the disintegration of Flora Goforth during her last summer of life on Italy's Divina Costiera.

title: 100 Layoffs At Drexel
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. dismissed about 100 employees late last week, a spokesman for the company said yesterday. The privately held securities firm has about 11,000 employees.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 George Shultz received signs that Moscow wants to resolve the main differences remaining over a new missile treaty when the Soviet Foreign Minister, Edward A. Shevardnandze, meets him for two days of talks in Geneva. Page A1 El Salvador's President criticized returning rebel civilian leaders and demanded that they break their links with the military wing of the guerrilla front. The rebels returned home after seven years in exile. A1 Nicaragua freed political prisoners as one of its moves to comply with a regional peace plan. The 985 political prisoners, suspected of ties to the contras, were granted pardons by the National Assembly. A6 A Nazi labor camp commandant was portrayed by survivors as brutal in files turned over to Argentina, which is holding the suspect. The fugitive, Josef Schwammberger, faces extradition to West Germany. A1 The diminished fortunes of Nigeria, the giant of black Africa, are marked by entrepreneurial hustle amid continued economic depression, a fraying social fabric amid a liberalizing political climate. A1 Boris Yeltsin's words are the subject of popular demand. People want to hear the speech the former Moscow party chief made last month when he declared that the program of basic Soviet reforms was not working. A3 South African troops remain in Angola in the southern part of the country after the fiercest fighting in a decade between Angolan and South African soldiers, an official said. A8 47 black soldiers were discharged last month by the South African Defsense Force, but authorities denied published reports that there had been a mutiny. A8 Norodom Sihanouk plans to meet Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia. Prince Sihanouk, the former Cambodian head of state, will meet the Prime Minister around Dec. 10 as part of a new peace effort, diplomats said. A12 Hundreds of Greek Cypriot women bearing white banners stormed across the line dividing their country, scuffling with armed Turkish soldiers to protest the division of the island. A3 La Rochelle journal: His majesty the mayor A4 NATIONAL A14-20, B10-14, D15 Cuban inmates rioted in Louisiana, They took over the Federal detention center Saturday night, setting fires throughout, and holding dozens of employees hostage. A1 Reinstated agreement set off the riot by Cuban inmates B14 The odyssey of the Cuban refugees imprisoned at the detention center in Louisiana began at a fishing port near Havana seven years ago. B14 Court-ordered Caesarean sections are posing harrowing problems for lawyers and doctors, forcing them to balance a woman's right to refuse treatment against society's desire to protect fetuses. A1 A Nixon Presidency retrospective was held this weekend. Historians and participants in tumultuous events of the Nixon era debated their meaning and the life of a man who was a dominant figure in American political life. A14 George Bush's management style would be hands-on if elected President, he said. The Vice President said he would focus on a limited set of objectives including sharp reductions in Soviet conventional forces. B12 Many upstart airline carriers have disappeared. The high failure rate among airlines has many in the industry believing that the door to new entries is virtually shut. D1 Reserve and National Guard units across the country managed to reach almost 94 percent of their members in a emergency readiness test, the Pentagon said. Of those reach, 1.5 percent failed to report for duty without having a valid excuse. A20 Cerrillos journal: A Prospector's search for a dream A14 Rear passengers survived Denver air crash A16 Crash survivor's mother unduly creditedA17 Lapse is conceded on AIDS insurance A20 Louisiana's runoff election held B10 Schroeder and politics: The problems of gender B12 WASHINGTON TALK A18 Rumors of Iran-contra pardons Keeper of the health care purse REGIONAL B1-6 The debate about homeless people has shifted from whether the Koch administration can provide food, clothing and shelter to what it should be doing to help people move out of temporary shelters and toward permanent homes or independence. A1 In the Howard Beach murder trial, two of the four defendants will not testify in their own behalf and a third is unlikely to, their attorneys say. The lawyer for the fourth defendant says he is considering the matter. B3 Custody right were surrendered by Hedda Nussbaum to the 17-month-old boy she and Joel B. Steinberg had raised as Mitchell Steinberg. Ms. Nussbaum said the child's place was with his biological mother. B1 Black cultural artifacts will be collected and preserved at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. More than 200 people gathered Saturday in the center overlooking the heart of Harlem to start the collection campaign. B1 Basketball players held a reunion at Torrington High School. Players on teams from the 1950's to the 1980's put on an exhibition game in honor of the school's track and football coach, Bob Frost, who died in July. B1 Stamford's transportation center, often ridiculed by Amtrak and Metro -North rail commuters as a monument to miscalculation, started service three years after its first projected opening date. But it was still only partly completed. B1 A court order to dissolve a group in Westchester is being sought. The move against the Westchester County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children is being made because some of its members abused their powers as peace officers, state officials said. B3 A pilot suffered a heart attack while landing an American Airlines jetliner with 94 people on board, but the co-pilot brought the plane safely to a stop at Newark International Airport, the airline said. B3 Manhattan men's shelter is a place of despair B6

title: Sports of The Times; Jets Need a New Leader
description: ABOUT the only nice thing to be said about the American Conference East is this: it's so bad, it's good. With the Indianapolis Colts losing to the New England Patriots yesterday, the Jets had an opportunity to take over sole possesion of first place. But when the Jets lost to the Buffalo Bills, 17-14, and the Miami Dolphins defeated the Dallas Cowboys last night, 20-14, a five-way tie at 5-5 was created. And in assessing the Jets' inconsistency, Coach Joe Walton put his finger on the primary problem.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Westfield Plays Mahler And Tchaikovsky
description: The Mahler Fourth Symphony and the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto, which made up the Westfield Symphony Orchestra's program Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, pursue different routes heavenward. Mahler's symphony takes roughly an hour wending its way toward a gentle fourth movement for soprano and orchestra that is a child's vision of paradise. There is a sudden E major chord toward the close of the third movement, an isolated exuberant gesture in the midst of long stretches of quiet music. The familiar concerto ends up at the gates of heaven by more strenous means.

title: DUARTE DEMANDS RETURNING REBELS DISOWN FIGHTERS
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte strongly criticized returning rebel civilian leaders today and demanded that they break their links with the military wing of the guerrilla front.

title: Dr. Jeffrey L. Bishop, Lecturer, 29
description: Dr. Jeffrey L. Bishop, a lecturer in astronomy at Columbia University, died Nov. 13 when a car struck him as he jogged near his home in Rockland County. He was 29 years old.

title: JETS STUMBLE; PLAYOFF CHANCES VIRTUALLY GONE
description: Lawrence Taylor, injured hamstring notwithstanding, played today for the Giants - not a lot, but enough to help and inspire. But it was not enough to win the game, and the playoff hopes of the Super Bowl champions vanished.

title: FILE ON SEIZED NAZI RECOUNTS HORRORS
description: An elderly Austrian arrested this month on a remote ranch in Argentina has emerged as one of the most brutal commandants of the Nazi labor camps, according to Austrian police files now made public.

title: Mexican Rightist Party Chooses Candidate
description: In an unexpectedly decisive vote, Mexico's principal opposition party today chose a wealthy rancher with a reputation for aggressive oratory as its candidate for President in next July's general election here.

title: Hanover's Mutual Fund Role
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation is expected to announce today that it will begin distributing some 20 different mutual funds, including products from Dreyfus, Federated, Franklin and Putnam, through 10 of its New York area branches.

title: Graf Hold Off Sabatini
description: There was an occasional sign of frustration as Steffi Graf muttered to herself in German, swatted a ball or two in annoyance and all but abandoned attempts to coax her backhand slice over the net. For one of the few times during a remarkable year, the 18-year-old West German appeared vulnerable, and the prospect of an Agatha Christie ending to the tennis season filled the air at Madison Square Garden with anticipation yesterday.

title: From Hideout to Hideout for Survival
description: ''Amigo, look out, tonight it will be bad.''

title: Nigeria Trying to Start Over Amid Recession and Turmoil
description: Through a car window, a Lagos ''go slow,'' or traffic jam, offers a snapshot of the diminished fortunes of Nigeria, the giant of black Africa.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Luanda Aide Asserts South Africa Still Has 3,000 Troops in Angola
description: A high Angolan official says 3,000 South African soldiers remain in southern Angola after the fiercest fighting in a decade between Angolan troops and South African and guerrilla forces.

title: Quick-Change Mugging
description: A man was waiting to buy a plant at the counter of an Upper West Side store when another approached asking for a $20 bill in exchange for four fives. Yes, the plant buyer said, he did have a twenty, and handed it over.

title: Concert: Orchestra Of 18th Century at Tully
description: LIKE the early-music movement as a whole, the Orchestra of the 18th Century is fast outgrowing its name. Frans Bruggen's Amsterdam-based, internationally assembled ensemble played a concert yesterday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall that marked the most significant advance thus far in this city of highly skilled, large-scaled playing of the standard repertory.

title: Mother May Not Have Saved Lone Survivor of Plane Crash
description: Documents made available during a hearing on the Aug. 16 crash of a Northwest Airlines jetliner suggest that its sole survivor, 4-year-old Cecelia Cichan, was not saved by her mother, as had been believed.

title: Deficit Pact Called a 'First Step'
description: Some Congressional leaders today called the proposed deficit-reduction package a starting point, while others said they were disappointed and would seek modifications.

title: Beyond the Budget Compromise
description: The world economy is headed in the right direction. Galvanized by the stock market plunge, the Administration and Congress have begun to agree on cuts in the budget deficit. American and West German interest rates have fallen. Domestic demand in Japan had already turned up smartly.

title: College Football; Unfinished Business in East
description: Although most of the East's college football players took their helmets off for the last time this season on Saturday, there are playoffs and bowl games ahead for some.

title: Advertising; Australian Sign Joins Times Sq.
description: SOME important Australian brewery officials made a stop in Times Square on Friday to light up a sign for Foster's.

title: Dance Archivists Meet To Discuss Field's Crisis
description: Dance organizations moved into the technological age with varying degrees of enthusiasm. But there has been a growing sense that technology could be used to preserve the ephemeral art of dance, an awareness suggested in the Martha Graham Dance Company's recent bid for direct Federal subsidy of its archival programs.

title: Different Strokes in the Eastern Bloc
description: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent a strong signal to Eastern Europe when he said that ''unity does not mean identity and uniformity.'' His more flexible approach toward the Soviet Union's allies also tacitly acknowledged the very real differences that already exist within the bloc.

title: A Theater Changes Direction
description: THE Second Stage has begun its ninth season with a 17-year-old play, which seems par for the course laid out in 1979 by its artistic directors, Robyn Goodman and Carole Rothman. Their mission was to give a second chance to works by major playwrights that were unsuccessful or little-noticed the first time out.

title: 'Rhapsody in Blue'
description: A rare 1926 concert version of Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' is among the works to be performed by the Harmonie Ensemble on Dec. 8 at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street. The program, called ''Americans and Paris,'' also features Ravel's ''Bolero''; Poulenc's ''Aubade for Piano and 18 Instruments''; Ibert's ''Paris Suite'' and Milhaud's ''Creation of the World.'' Tickets are $15 ($7.50 for students and the elderly.) Information: 362-8719.

title: Lynn Robin Friedrich Is Wed to K. E. Librot
description: Lynn Robin Friedrich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Friedrich of Clifton, N.J., was married yesterday at Edgewood Country Club in River Vale, N.J., to Kenneth Edward Librot, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Irwin E. Librot of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Herman, assisted by Cantor William Lieberman, performed the ceremony.

title: Howard Beach Defense Taking Over
description: Two of the four defendants in the Howard Beach murder trial will not testify in their own behalf and a third is unlikely to, their lawyers say as they prepare to call their own witnesses in the two-and-a-half-month-old trial.

title: Dance: Beverly Blossom
description: BEVERLY BLOSSOM is one of those rare solo performers who can indicate the most complex of situations and emotions with the simplest and most purely physical of moves and gestures. And ''Beverly Blossom, Again,'' a program seen on Saturday night at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace, was the performer and choreographer at her best.

title: Going Out Guide
description: Cultural Affairs

title: On Your Own: Running; Right Kind of Knee Bends Help Prevent Wrong Kind
description: PITY the poor downhill skier's knee, so vulnerable to twisting and tearing. Here comes its owner, clad in the latest pants and parka and armored by the best technology in boots and bindings. He's plunging recklessly through the moguls, skiing on the ragged edge with too much speed and too little control.

title: Rumors Abound of Thanksgiving Pardons
description: For months, there have been rumblings that President Reagan might pardon Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and Robert C. McFarlane, key participants in the Iran-contra affair.

title: 94% of Reservists Are Reached in a National Drill
description: Reserve and National Guard units across the country managed to reach almost 94 percent of their members in an emergency readiness test last month, the Pentagon said.

title: 4 Trapped in an Apartment Are Killed in a Cleveland Fire
description: A woman and three children died early today in a fire that gutted a two-story apartment building.

title: Dollar Down In Pacific
description: The United States dollar lost ground in both Australian and New Zealand trading early today as foreign exchange dealers expressed disappointment over the American deficit-reduction package. There was no trading in Tokyo because of a national holiday.

title: Metro Matters; After 15 Years, Housing Message Is Still the Same
description: In 1972, Oscar Newman criticized the overwhelming scale of a proposed public housing project in Forest Hills, Queens. But he concluded that while its neighbors might have some reasonable grievances, their concerns were greatly inflated.

title: Broker Dies in Apparent Leap From Balcony on 32d Floor
description: A stockbroker who suffered heavy losses on Wall Street last month apparently leaped to his death from the 32d-floor balcony of his Upper East Side apartment yesterday, the police said.

title: Only Morality Will Effectively Prevent AIDS From Spreading
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tenpak Peril
description: Shove a $10 bill at a New York City subway token clerk and he's likely to shove back a Tenpak, a little plastic bag containing 10 tokens. The Transit Authority likes to promote this modest gesture toward efficiency. But riders participate at their peril.

title: Stamford Rail Center Opens, Off Schedule
description: The Stamford Transportation Center, a structure often ridiculed by Amtrak and Metro-North rail commuters as a monument to miscalculation, started service today, three years after its first projected opening date and still only partly completed.

title: TV Review; 'Lena: My 100 Children,' a Post-Holocaust Drama
description: OUT of television's often murky ''based on fact'' catalog comes ''Lena: My 100 Children,'' the movie on NBC at 9 tonight. Linda Lavin plays Lena Kuchler-Silberman, who after World War II dedicated herself to helping the surviving children of Holocaust victims in Poland. As might be expected, the story of the children is explored for maximum heart-tugging. In the process, however, crucial details tend to be smudged, at the very least.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 22, 1987: MONDAY American Express...Detroit Edison BellSouth Corp...Walt Disney Co Connecticut Nat Gas...NWA Inc Continental Ill Corp...San Diego Gas & Elec TUESDAY Angelica Corp...Interlake Corp BRE Properties...Kansas Gas & Elec Bank of Boston...Medtronic Inc Becton, Dickinson & Co...Merck & Co Brush Wellman...Morgan Keegan Inc Certain-teed Corp...J.C. Penney Co E-Systems Inc...Technitrol Inc Gap Inc...Westvaco Corp WEDNESDAY Bairnco Corp...Pennsylvania Pwr & Lt Northern States Pwr MN...Philip Morris Cos FRIDAY EG & G Inc...Zemex Corp EDO Corp

title: 7 Poems by Dickinson to Be Sung at 92d St. Y
description: Seven poems by Emily Dickinson that have been set to music by six composers are to be sung by the soprano Dawn Upshaw on Dec. 2 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: NICARAGUA FREES 985 FROM PRISONS
description: The Government freed 985 political prisoners nationwide today as one of its moves to comply with a regional peace plan.

title: Advertising; McCann and Others Win More Accounts
description: A bunch of bouncing business.

title: Lapse on AIDS Is Conceded
description: Wisconsin insurance regulators have confirmed that they granted two insurance companies permission to market policies that limited or denied payments to state clients who have AIDS or AIDS-related illnesses.

title: Budget Plan Expected To Leave Investors Cold
description: Investors are expected to be unimpressed with a tentative agreement to trim the budget deficit by $76 billion over two years, Wall Street experts said yesterday.

title: Commercial Broadcasters' Services (and Duties)
description: To the Editor:

title: ''Total War' Doesn't Justify Killing Civilians
description: To the Editor:

title: Victor J. Herwitz, Manhattan Lawyer, Dies
description: Victor J. Herwitz, a Manhattan lawyer for more than 50 years and former chief assistant Corporation Counsel of New York City, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital Center after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Music: Bream Guitar Recital
description: JULIAN BREAM'S recital at the 92d Street Y Saturday evening found the famed guitarist in something less than his top form. Both fallibility of finger and a certain muted quality to the interpretations worked against appreciation of playing that was at best thoughtful, caring and expert.

title: Hawks Smash Chargers
description: Dave Krieg passed for two touchdowns and ran for another, and Curt Warner had his second straight 100-yard rushing game today as the Seattle Seahawks routed San Diego, 34-3, ending the Chargers' eight-game winning streak.

title: College Football; Syracuse Gets Some Big Help
description: When Michael Owens ran into the corner of the end zone for a 2-point conversion with 10 seconds left to give Syracuse a thrilling 32-31 victory over West Virginia Saturday night, he enabled the Orange to complete an undefeated season and kept alive the team's chances for the final No. 1 ranking.

title: Cerrillos Journal; A Prospector's Search For an Elusive Dream
description: For perhaps 1,000 years, the windswept mesa here has drawn dreamers. First came the Indians, then the Spanish explorers, then 19th-century American miners, all drawn by what the Indians called ''the sky in the stone,'' the delicate turquoise mined here.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Nov. 7 about organizations that prepare students for Scholastic Aptitude Tests misstated the policy of the Stanley H. Kaplan Educational Center. Students in the Kaplan preparatory course may retake the course free for up to a year regardless of their scores on the test.

title: Pressmen Ratify Contract
description: The pressmen of The New York Times voted yesterday to ratify the tentative contract settlement negotiated earlier this month by management and their union, New York Printing Pressmen's Union Local 2. The president of the union, Lenny Higgins, said that the pressmen voted 216 to 44 to accept a 33 percent increase in wages over six years and a 10-year agreement on staffing levels.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Company News column of Business Day on Thursday, about Chrysler's 1988 model cars, misstated their price change from the previous year. Prices have been cut 1 percent, on average, on comparably equipped cars made in the United States.

title: Outdoors: Time for Waterfowling
description: ALTHOUGH it might seem ludicrous to some nonhunters, this is the time of year when grown men devote considerable time, money and physical energy attempting to outwit ducks and geese.

title: Music: Schiff and Oslo Philharmonic
description: PIANOPHILES were especially well represented in the audience that gathered for the Oslo Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall Friday evening: Andras Schiff, guest soloist for the Grieg Piano Concerto, has established a real following among the listeners who know and care most about the piano literature. His thoughtful, sometimes penetrating interpretations have earned him that distinction, even if on this occasion the orchestra and its conductor, Mariss Jansons, seemed better matched to their showpieces than Mr. Schiff to his.

title: Reinstated '84 Plan Provided For Return of 2,700 to Cuba
description: The immigration agreement that set off the riot by Cuban inmates at a detention center in Louisiana reinstated an understanding between the two countries that was reached in December 1984. The State Department announced the reinstatement Friday.

title: JETS STUMBLE; SEVEN PASSES DROPPED IN LOSS
description: The Jets lost another game today to the team that seems to give them the most trouble: themselves.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption Saturday about a speech in Washington by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel misidentified the man with Mr. Shamir. He is Avi Pazner, the Prime Minister's media adviser.

title: Nixon Revisited
description: A three-day conference on the Presidency of Richard Nixon was drawing to a close at Hofstra University when Roger Wilkins of the Institute for Policy Studies spoke up during a panel on the Nixon record in civil rights.

title: Schroeder and Politics: The Problems of Gender
description: Five months ago, Representative Patricia Schroeder set out to see if the country was ready to accept a Presidential contender ''who was not the woman's candidate, but a candidate who happened to be a woman.''

title: REAR PASSENGERS SURVIVED AIR CRASH
description: None of the 20 passengers in the last four rows of Continental Airlines' Flight 1713 died when the DC-9 crashed just after takeoff a week ago today, a survey shows.

title: Homeless Man Stabs 5, Then Is Injured, In a Texas Church
description: A homeless man panhandling for money stabbed at least five worshipers who tried to stop him from approaching a priest today during a mass.

title: Midway Finds a Niche By Trial and Error
description: Just three years ago, Midway Airlines seemed on the verge of succumbing to the forces that have swallowed almost all the airlines that sprang up after the industry was deregulated in 1978.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Home Products Corp. named John D. Feerick, dean of Ford-ham University's Law School, a direc-

title: What Congress Didn't Ask
description: Lieut. Colonel Oliver L. North said during the Congressional hearings into the Iran-contra affair that he has fought in two American wars, Vietnam and Angola. During his examination by the Iran-contra committees, he proudly offered information about his service in Vietnam but never mentioned what he was doing in Angola. And no one on the committees bothered to ask him.

title: Soccer; Women's Final To North Carolina
description: North Carolina's reign as the top team in women's college soccer continued today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: There have been two Heisman Trophy winners from Yale, Larry Kelley in 1936 and Clint Frank in 1937. Which professional football teams did they play for?

title: Lost Dole Documents
description: The Federal Election Commission has lost internal documents that would shed light on why it dropped a case against Senator Bob Dole's 1980 Presidential campaign and Mr. Dole's wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole.

title: Bush Envisions Hands-On Presidency
description: Vice President Bush says he would adopt a hands-on management style if elected President and would focus on a limited set of objectives including sharp reductions in Soviet conventional forces.

title: Sports World Specials; Gambling Racquets
description: No sooner had the high-stakes Skins Game become a golfing fixture than you could almost hear the wheels of copycat creativity grinding. If it works for golf, why shouldn't it work for tennis?

title: Susan Rosenholtz Becomes a Bride
description: Susan I. Rosenholtz and Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer were married last evening at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi Morris Friedman and Cantor Charles Ritter officiated.

title: A 'Silly' Sock Idea Makes Millions
description: Four years ago, a 27-year-old named Sophie Mirman had a silly idea for a new business here: shops that sold only women's tights, stockings and socks.

title: Bridge: A 'Consistent Partnership' Wins Men's Championship
description: The American Contract Bridge League celebrated its 50th birthday here Saturday night with a party honoring a long list of people who have played a role in the game as players and administrators.

title: Sports World Specials; Update on Sticks
description: Five years after the introduction of sticks with aluminum shafts ushered in the era of high-tech hockey, wood is still king in the National Hockey League. Only about 80 players have adopted the aluminum sticks, but the number has been rising, for an obvious reason: several sharp-shooters claim that since switching to aluminum they are stick-handling better, shooting harder, and playing a more consistent game.

title: Deficit Plan Impact Assessed
description: The announcement Friday of a compromise plan on the Federal budget deficit removed one uncertainty from the credit markets, but many analysts said it was not enough to cause a quick, substantial decline in interest rates.

title: Nussbaum Withdraws Right to Boy
description: Hedda Nussbaum said yesterday that she was surrendering all rights to custody of the 17-month-old boy she and Joel B. Steinberg had raised as Mitchell Steinberg. She said the child's place was with his biological mother, Nicole Smigiel.

title: Dear Judge Kennedy
description: When Federal judges have questions about their ethical duties they ask the ''Dear Abby Committee,'' the informal name for the Committee on the Codes of Judicial Conduct of the Judicial Conference of the United States.

title: George L. Perry Wed To Dina Needleman
description: Dina Needleman and George L. Perry were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York by Acting Justice Richard Lee Price of State Supreme Court.

title: Amoco Seems on Verge Of Finishing Dome Deal
description: After seven months of legal wrangling and secret negotiations, the Amoco Corporation appears close to wrapping up the biggest corporate takeover in Canada's history.

title: Dance: LaFosse in 'Baiser de la Fee'
description: LIKE many ballets by George Balanchine, ''Divertimento from 'Le Baiser de la Fee' '' is named after its music. Yet it is a far from typical Balanchine ballet, as was vividly reaffirmed Friday night when Robert LaFosse made his debut in the work's only male role.

title: Horse Racing; Cup Only Increases Title Speculation
description: The championships remain unsettled, but almost all of the champions will be back.

title: New Leader in Washington
description: Two years ago, in a Monday night game, Lawrence Taylor of the Giants hit the Washington Redskins' quarterback, Joe Theismann, with a clean but jarring tackle that broke Theismann's leg. The young, strong-armed Jay Schroeder came off the bench to lead the Redskins to a victory and to win the job as the starting quarterback.

title: Olympic Notebook; China Looks Past Its Asian Games
description: Chinese Olympic officials are well along in their plans for staging the 1990 Asian Games in Beijing, an event they expect to enhance their chance of winning a bid to become host for the Summer Olympic Games in 2000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Business and the Law; A Green Light In Boesky Suit
description: A MAMMOTH civil lawsuit by shareholders against Ivan F. Boesky, the fallen Wall Street speculator, is expected to proceed expeditiously now that the United States Supreme Court has decided a securities case that had threatened to delay the Boesky matter.

title: Music: Stern, Ax and Ma at Carnegie
description: THOUGH it hardly seems possible, Emanuel Ax, Isaac Stern and Yo-Yo Ma were making their New York debut as a trio Saturday evening in Carnegie Hall. They have played together elsewhere in this country as well as abroad, but they had not yet not done so here.

title: From Tiny Cuban Port to Rampage in Louisiana
description: The odyssey of the Cuban refugees who went on a rampage Saturday at a Federal detention center in Oakdale, La., began at a quiet fishing port near Havana seven years ago.

title: Concert: Alvin Lucier
description: ALVIN LUCIER, who opened the Alternative Museum's music series Wednesday night, composes scores that combine true Minimalist austerity (devoid of the kinetic impetus of a Philip Glass or Steve Reich) with conceptual-art ingenuity and a fascination for acoustical experimentation. The results can range from the meditatively compelling to the downright alluring to the academically arid, and Wednesday's concert had a little of all those attributes.

title: Pilot of Jetliner Fatally Stricken While Landing
description: An American Airlines pilot suffered a fatal heart attack while his jetliner was landing Saturday night, but the co-pilot brought the plane safely to a stop, the authorities said yesterday.

title: No Discussion, Period!
description: The White House has refused to discuss the possibility of pardons in the Iran-contra affair, no matter how many ways reporters bring it up.

title: Market Place; Stocks of Fund Managers
description: PUBLICLY owned companies that manage mutual funds shared handsomely in the fund industry's swelling popularity during the 1980's. But they have been battered more severely than most stocks since the market reached record highs in late August.

title: Korea's Growth Survives a Summer of Strikes
description: Despite ample hand-wringing here last summer about the potential harm created by a surge of labor unrest, South Korea's economy has weathered the crisis with aplomb.

title: Mexico's Border Plants Thrive on Weak Peso
description: The rapid spread of foreign-owned assembly plants along the Mexican border will likely be sustained because of the latest plunge in the peso's value, industry officials here said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AM International Inc. said it had reached a four-year standstill agreement with Komuri Printing Machinery Co., which holds 6.7 percent of AM's common stock. Komori agreed to limit its ownership to less than 8 percent of AM's stock in the next six months and to less than 5 percent for the duration of the agreement.

title: Found Art: Pollock's Floor
description: In the converted barn here that for years was Jackson Pollock's studio, something resembling one of his famous drip paintings has been unexpectedly discovered - under some floorboards.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 23, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Political and Security Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Special Political Committee - 10 A.M. Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. Legal Committee - 3 A.M.

title: Boxing; Chavez Finally Commands the Spotlight
description: When he climbed into the ring Saturday night at the Las Vegas Hilton outdoor stadium, Edwin Rosario had a conspicuous addition to his entourage.

title: How Families Cope With the Terminally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Chamber, at Merkin
description: FOR THE LOVE OF MUSIC, a chamber music society directed by the violinist Richard Sortomme, gave four trios at Merkin Concert Hall yesterday afternoon. One was a classic - Schubert's expansive Op. 100, attacked with big-boned vigor by Mr. Sortomme, Semyon Fridman (cello) and John Klibonoff (piano). Each of the others was for a different instrumental combination, and each was a relative novelty.

title: Republican Is Louisiana Lieutenant Governor
description: Paul Hardy, a Republican who campaigned as a reformer in the mold of Governor-elect Buddy Roemer, ousted Lieut. Gov. Bobby Freeman in the Louisiana runoff election Saturday, while the state's Attorney General, William Guste, won a fifth term.

title: Call for Extradition
description: Alois Brunner, the Nazi fugitive who has lived in Syria for the last 30 years was quoted earlier this month in The Chicago Sun-Times as saying he ''would do it again'' and that Jews ''deserved to die because they were the devil's agents and human garbage.''

title: Harcourt Sells 3 Units
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. will sell its History Book Club and two smaller clubs for $25 million to the Book-of-the-Month Club, a division of Time Inc., Harcourt's chairman, William Jovanovich, said Friday. The sale, which includes the Pre-School and Instructor book clubs, will be concluded Tuesday, he said. A spokeswoman for the Book-of-the-Month Club declined to comment on the deal.

title: 17 Cubans Escape Texas Center; 14 Recaptured
description: Seventeen Cuban inmates escaped from a detention center early today by climbing through a steel roof grating, but all but three were recaptured within hours.

title: 5 Said to Die in Lagos Rioting
description: Five people were killed last week in Lagos when gangs of youths fought street battles with riot policemen, national newspapers reported on Saturday.

title: Greek Cypriot Women Cross Turks' Line
description: Hundreds of Greek Cypriot women bearing white banners stormed and scrambled across the line dividing their country today, scuffling with armed Turkish soldiers in protest against the division of the island.

title: Tennis; Bueno Brings History Onto the Court
description: She arrived on the junior tennis circuit in 1957, a 17-year-old from Sao Paulo, Brazil, who spoke no English and had only limited experience in competition. Although she had captured the Brazilian national title at age 14, Maria Bueno was young and her style seemed too unorthodox to threaten tennis's elite: Maureen Connelly, Doris Hart and and Althea Gibson.

title: Throgs Neck Bridge Closed After a Call About Dynamite
description: The Throgs Neck Bridge was closed to traffic last night between 9:31 and 11:40 after a man called the police and said 125 sticks of dynamite had been placed on the bridge and were set to explode, the authorities said.

title: Homeless Man Found Frozen to Death on S.I.
description: A 66-year-old homeless man living under an oceanfront boardwalk on Staten Island died, apparently of exposure, in the frigid temperatures over the weekend, the police said.

title: The Dance: 'Torn' From Mark Dendy, at P.S. 122
description: MARK DENDY choreographs as if he were devising kinetic comic strips. Some of his images are witty. Others are crude. Yet, for all his bumptiousness, he is a serious choreographer.

title: Nixon Skips Conference, but the Enigma Attends
description: The issue under debate here for three days was one of the central political questions of the age: What was the true meaning of Richard M. Nixon's Presidency and how will he be judged before the bar of history?

title: A Better Place for the Cyclist to Sit
description: One bane of a bicyclist's existence - the seat that begins to feel like a concrete slab 15 minutes into a ride - may not be worth complaining about anymore. A marriage of technology between the Spenco Medical Corporation and Avocet Inc., a producer of cycling components, has come up with a bike saddle that has thick gel at its core. Used by Spenco for bed pads, wheelchair cushions and cold packs, the gel behaves like a layer of muscle tissue. Rather than crushing like foam when a rider sits, the gel reacts to pelvic pressure by redistributing itself within a flexible shell. The gel is controlled in a Y-shaped form that spreads support evenly and reduces hard spots. The gel goes back to its original shape when the rider gets off the seat. Sold under the Avocet label as the GelFlex saddle, it is available at most bicycle stores. The seat comes in three models: men's, women's and racing. The women's saddle is wider and shorter than the men's to conform to a different pelvic structure; the racing saddle is thinner than the others. The saddle has a retail price of $29.95.

title: Robert Lawrence Judson Weds Robin Ellen Platzer
description: Robin Ellen Platzer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Platzer of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Lawrence Judson, the son of Mrs. Morris Judson of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Judson. Rabbi Morris Goldberg officiated at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Seraphim Trio Offers Bela Varkonyi Works
description: Bela Varkonyi was a much-played young composer in turn-of-the-century Hungary, but this early reputation seems to have been swallowed up by his move to and subsequent life in the United States. Even as exhaustive a reference as the New Grove Dictionary of Music makes no mention of him.

title: COURTS ACTING TO FORCE CARE ON THE UNBORN
description: Ayesha Madyun, a 19-year-old Washington woman, had been in labor two days when she arrived at D.C. General Hospital to give birth to her first child. Eighteen hours later, her labor had not progressed and the doctors decided that Mrs. Madyun needed an immediate Caesarean section: the baby's likelihood of developing a fatal infection was steadily rising.

title: Sihanouk to Meet Cambodian Official in Peace Bid
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian head of state, plans to meet Prime Minister Hun Sen, the most powerful figure in the Vietnamese-backed Communist Government in Phnom Penh, around Dec. 10 in Paris in a new peace effort, according to Cambodian and other Asian diplomats.

title: Sports World Specials; No Stopping Him
description: Most skiers are happy if they can ski every day during a week-long vacation or every day for a few weekends each season. Paul Schipper was not content with that. Every day that Sugarloaf/USA in Maine was open over the past six seasons, he has skied. On Saturday, a week into a seventh season, his streak reached 1,000 days.

title: Advertising; Scali Losing A Partner
description: Alan Pesky will leave Scali, McCabe, Sloves at the end of the year - the third of the five founding partners to do so.

title: Schomburg Center Acts to Halt Loss of Black History
description: Bright with morning sunlight and adorned with photographs of a black leadership long past, the archives search room of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture bustled with the business of history over the weekend.

title: Gregory Muhlin, Scientist, 42
description: Gregory Muhlin, a research scientist at the New York State Psychiatric Institute at the Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan, died at the hospital Tuesday after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 42 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Cetus Gene System
description: The Cetus Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., has introduced an automated gene amplification system as part of its joint venture with the Perkin-Elmer Corporation. The system, which represents the first commercial introduction of Cetus-developed technology, relies on an enzyme to make as many as a million copies of a specific gene sequence, allowing the amplification of a DNA sequence in hours rather than the days or weeks typically required. The company anticipates that the system will be routinely used in institutions doing research in genetic engineering.

title: Nynex Names Chief For Directory Unit
description: Donald B. Reed is stepping into a competitive slot at the Nynex Corporation. The company has named him president of the Nynex Information Resources Company, which publishes white and yellow page directories.

title: Advertising; Former Ogilvy Official Joining Bozell, Jacobs
description: Jay Schulberg, an Ogilvy & Mather 20-year man who quit last April as executive vice president, creative head, is joining Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Cuban Inmates Riot in Louisiana Over New Threat of Deportation
description: More than 1,000 Cuban inmates, outraged at the prospect of being deported under a new immigration agreement, took over a Federal detention center here Saturday night, seized about 30 hostages and set fire to most of the prison.

title: School Football; Saturday to Forget For Staten Island
description: The Staten Island division might have been the toughest in the Public Schools Athletic League this football season. At one point or another, it qualified four of its six teams for the A League playoffs. But after last Saturday's P.S.A.L. quarterfinals, none remained.

title: Struggling to Survive Amid Despair And Violence at Care Center for Men
description: Near the shadows of the neon glare on lower Broadway in Manhattan, the will to survive drives men without homes and sometimes without hope to a dingy building on East Third Street.

title: INSIDE
description: Fitness

title: Advertising; Spin Magazine Finds Investor and Chairman
description: Camouflage Publishing, publisher of Spin magazine, of which Robert Guccione Jr. is president and chief executive, has welcomed David H. Horowitz, 58, as an investor and chairman.

title: Joseph W. Stehn, General Manager, 66
description: Joseph W. Stehn, retired general manager of the Breezy Point (L.I.) Cooperative, an association of homeowners on the Rockaway Peninsula, died of a stroke Saturday at Peninsula Hospital Center in Queens. He was 66 years old and lived in the co-op.

OVERLAND EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: The fungus that almost wiped out the American chestnut is threatening the live oak tree in the South.

title: AGOURON PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Badges for Godfathers
description: Over at the United Nations, the states that specialize in murder and kidnapping are working out a particularly bizarre and dangerous piece of political strategy. The idea is to legitimize international terrorism.

title: BROWN-FORMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1987
description: Companies

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Nov. 14 of ''Likely Stories,'' a program carried by the Learning Channel, misstated the availability of that cable service in New York City. It is available to some cable subscribers in Queens and Brooklyn.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Tax Expert's Exit
description: David H. Brockway, perhaps the single most influential Congressional staff member, is leaving his job at the end of the year. Mr. Brockway is chief of staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation, which is not really a committee at all but rather a collection of lawyers, economists and accountants who provide expertise on tax policy for both the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee.

CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Cuban Hints Leniency To 2,500 U.S. Deports
description: A Government official suggested today that 2,500 Cubans who are to be deported from the United States will be treated leniently on their return.

title: Flames Overwhelm Devils
description: Mike Bullard scored two goals to guide the Calgary Flames to a 9-2 romp over the Devils tonight.

title: Gorbachev's Visit: Handle With Care
description: The approaching visit by General Secretary Mikhail S. Gorbachev to sign an agreement on intermediate-range nuclear weapons comes at a perplexing, even dangerous time for the Administration.

title: Shalala Successor Is Named
description: The trustees of the City University named Tilden J. LeMelle as acting president of Hunter College yesterday. Dr. LeMelle, provost and vice president of Hunter, will succeed Donna E. Shalala, when she resigns Jan. 1 to become chancellor of the University of Wisconsin. Dr. LeMelle is not a candidate for the Hunter presidency.

Spurs Accurate in Stretch As Knicks' Defense Fails
description: The San Antonio Spurs, a team with one of the league's worst records on the road, defeated the Knicks at Madison Square Garden last night, 117-112, because they have all the pieces to the puzzle that the Knicks are still searching for.

description: b-Net income

title: Elizabeth Kray, Patron and Friend Of Poets and Their Art, Dies at 71
description: Elizabeth Kray, a friend and patron of poets for more than 30 years, died of cancer Saturday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dickenson Mines
description: An investment group led by Pamour Inc., a gold mining concern based in Timmins, Ontario, has purchased a 8.2 percent stake in Dickenson Mines Ltd. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Pamour said it ''may decide that it is desirable to seek control'' of Dickenson, a gold mining concern in Toronto. Pamour, which is controlled by a group of Austrialian companies, including Ariadne Australia Ltd., told the S.E.C. that it intends to request ''30 percent representation'' on the Dickenson board.

description: * Adams-Russell Co., Waltham, Mass., a maker of microwave products, said its shareholders had approved its acquisition of Cablevision Systems Corp., based in Woodbury, L.I. Under the agreement, each Adams-Russell shareholder would receive $43.075 per share in cash.

title: Narrowing The Search For a Printer
description: IF you think computers are confusing, take a peek at the choices in printers. More than 100 new printers have been introduced in the past year, and they join more than 250 older models still on the market.

German Panel Urges Stimulus
description: The nation's Council of Economic Advisers said today that the recent worldwide fall in stock prices would dampen economic growth in West Germany, and it called for measures to increase domestic output.

description: b-Includes a charge of $334,915 and $730,211 related to redemption of debentures for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

description: The Soviet Union tentatively plans to invite leading United States business executives to meet with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, when he visits Washington next month, a group promoting American and Soviet trade said today.

description: ''I could talk for hours about women,'' Emanuel Ungaro said. ''Why are they so incomprehensible?''

HERITAGE ENTERTAINMENT YEAR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Secrets of The Mongoose
description: ARCHIE MOORE, born Archibald Lee Wright, a k a The Old Mongoose, was seated at breakfast yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club and was reminded of a line that was attributed to him years ago.

title: Cliffs Board Considers Sale
description: The board of Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. has decided to try to sell or recapitalize the company that has been the object of a proxy fight by David F. Bolger, the New Jersey investor, officials said.

title: U.S. Oil Rigs Fall by 22
description: The number of oil drilling rigs operating in the United States fell by 22, to 1,152, in the latest week but was still above the 952 working in the comparable week a year ago, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.

title: 11 Are Hurt As Verdict Spurs Melee
description: Three defendants, after hearing a jury find them guilty of murder charges, pulled out hidden razor blades and a sharp piece of metal and battled with court officers in Brooklyn yesterday, leaving 11 of them injured, none seriously.

title: Planned 'City of God' Unsettles a Jersey Town
description: A realtor here recently got a call from a West Virginia man who said he would like to come up and look at a good-sized plot of land, 300 acres or so, for building purposes. That was hardly unusual. But when the man arrived a few days later, his head shaved and his body draped in saffron robes, and announced that he wanted the land to build a walled ''City of God'' for 12,000 people, surrounded by a moat and served by a transportation network of rickshaws and elephants, and topped by a 260-foot ''temple of understanding,'' townspeople started asking questions.

title: Market Place; Higher Returns Found Abroad
description: THE five-year bull market that scaled record heights by the end of August proved a bonanza to United States investors. But in hindsight, these investors would have fared considerably better had they ventured abroad with their dollars, especially to the Tokyo stock market.

title: Treasury Rates Up Modestly
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities rose modestly in extremely quiet trading yesterday as traders and investors waited for fresh economic data and actions by central banks around the world to give a clearer direction to interest rates.

title: Macmillan Filing On Bell & Howell
description: Macmillan Inc., the publishing concern, said it was seeking Federal clearance to join the bidding for Bell & Howell Company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Macmillan, which holds 7.9 percent of Bell & Howell's shares, said it had filed notice with the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department of its intention to buy enough additional shares that ''may result in Macmillan holding more that 50 percent'' of Bell & Howell.

title: E.F. Hutton, Losing Two-Year Struggle, Is Looking for Buyer
description: Losing a two-year struggle to remain independent, E. F. Hutton, for years a pre-eminent name on Wall Street, has put itself up for sale.

title: Music: American Symphony in Strauss
description: PERHAPS it is the upshot of enduring decades of serialist music, but audiences today look on Richard Strauss's orchestral works with a more sympathetic eye than did many listeners when they were written. The American Symphony Orchestra's concert Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, which concluded with Strauss's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra,'' put one in a bygone frame of mind. It first offered a good deal of melodious music that, while not from the 19th century per se, borrowed heavily from its conventions. Having come after all of that, the Strauss sounded as it might have to early audiences - like Romanticism carried to excess.

title: Client Sues Kidder, Charging Insider Trading
description: The Maxus Energy Corporation, formerly part of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, said today that it was suing Kidder, Peabody & Company for what it called the firm's link to insider trading activities during Diamond Shamrock's acquisition of the Natomas Company in 1983.

title: 4 Coaches Dismissed
description: Because Idaho State finished 3-7-1 with a 53-37 loss Saturday to Weber State, Jim Koetter, the coach, was dismissed yesterday, barely a year after being inducted into the school's sports hall of fame. With him went his five assistants. Koetter, 49, compiled a 23-32-1 record in five seasons. He was not aware of the decision when he attended the weekly luncheon with fans earlier in the day. He was one of four coaches dismissed yesterday. The others were Bob Valesente, who was 3-8 and 0-10-1 in two seasons at Kansas; Bob Otolski, who was 30-41-3 in seven years at Illinois State; and Rick Gilstrap, who was 8-24-1 in three years at Wofford.

title: Olympia & York Stake in Campeau
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd., the Canadian real estate and investment company, has purchased the equivalent of a 10.48 percent stake in the Campeau Corporation, for $82.29 million (Canadian). In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Olympia & York said that it had bought the Campeau shares for investment purposes only, but added that it ''intends to continue to review and monitor'' its investment in the department store chain, which is based in Toronto.

title: The Stage: '3 Lives of Lucie Cabrol'
description: IN the Talking Band's theatrical collage ''The Three Lives of Lucie Cabrol,'' the usually demure Tina Shepard plays the title role of a dwarflike French peasant woman whose family cruelly nicknames her ''the cocadrille,'' after a mythical animal born in a dungheap. Ms. Shepard strikingly transforms herself into a hunched, thick-skinned beast of burden who speaks in harsh, guttural cadences and survives through a combination of native shrewdness and a mystical attunement to the natural world.

ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Topics of The Times; Village Life in the Big Apple
description: The mother of a family that recently moved to New York City from a smaller city in the heartland finds herself defending the Big Apple to folks back home. To them, New York means bustle, crime, noise and anonymity. ''Not true,'' the new immigrant protests. ''We've found that family life in New York comes closer to old-fashioned small-town America than little-city life does - at least in some ways. ''Back in the old hometown, we had two cars. We drove almost everywhere. But one look at garage and car-insurance costs in New York was enough. We sold both cars, and now we walk. City life makes it easy. Even our toddler can handle the distances comfortably: the pediatrician, the playground, the cleaner's, the bookstore, the post office, the library, the nursery school.

title: James Atherton Dies; A Tenor and Director
description: James Atherton, a Metropolitan Opera tenor and, more recently, an operatic stage director, died of an AIDS-related illness last Friday, according to his manager, Dorothy Cone. Vice President Bush agrees. Tampering with Social Security is not a new idea, Mr. Bush said in the Houston debate among Republican candidates, but it is still ''a nutty idea.''

RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bulls 107, Celtics 102: Michael Jordan scored 31 points and Scott Pippen scored 7 of his 20 points in the final four minutes as Chicago rallied last night in Hartford. (AP) Horse Racing Yankee Affair Wins by a Length: Yankee Affair, the odds-on favorite, raced to a one-length victory yesterday in the $55,000 Endurance-By-Name Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Yankee Affair, ridden by Angel Cordero Jr., was timed in 1:52 3/5 for one and one-eighth miles on turf and earned $33,000 for Jujugen Stable. Yankee Affair returned $3.20 for $2 to win.(AP) Cross-Country Falcon Leads Arkansas to Title: Joe Falcon easily won the men's individual title yesterday in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I championships in Charlottesville, Va., and led Arkansas to a second-straight team crown. Falcon completed the 10,000-meter course in 29 minutes 14.97 seconds.(AP) N.H.L. Nordiques 4, Canadiens 3: Anton Stastny scored a power-play goal at 1 minute 44 seconds of overtime to give Quebec the victory. Montreal's goalie, Patrick Roy, made the initial save when Michel Goulet tipped Peter Stastny's shot from the slot. But Anton Stastny, standing to the side of the net, picked up the rebound and scored his sixth goal of the year, ending Quebec's four-game losing streak. (AP) College Basketball Florida and New Mexico Advance: In Gainesville, Fla., Livingston Chatman came off the bench last night to ignite a 16-2 first-half burst and finished with 25 points to lead Florida (2-0) to an 80-69 victory over Georgia Tech in the second round of the Big Apple N.I.T. The triumph sends the Gators to Madison Square Garden for the semifinals.

title: Ballet: Balanchine by Purchase Troupe
description: WATCHING the young performers of the Purchase Dance Corps in ''Serenade'' on Friday night at the Performing Arts Center of the State University College at Purchase, N.Y., it seemed appropriate that the earliest performances of this first American ballet by George Balanchine should have been presented at an estate in nearby White Plains by a troupe of performers about as young and new as the Purchase dancers. And the fresh, clean way these performers of the 1980's danced made ''Serenade'' stand out in bold relief as a ballet that Balanchine created as a new emigre to the United States.

title: Banco de Bilbao
description: Spain's banking community speculated that Banco de Bilbao might revise its takeover offer for the nation's second-largest bank, Banesto, which Friday rejected its first offer. In announcing that the bid by the smaller bank had been turned down, a spokesman for Banesto, whose formal name is Banco Espanol de Credito, said that the bank was prepared to consider another offer if one were made. Spanish banks are dwarfed by foreign competitors, and a merger of the two banks would create Spain's largest bank and one that would rank within the top 20 in Europe.

Sunday, people began lining up outside the Majestic Theater on West 44th Street, blanket-wrapped against subfreezing temperatures and eager to invest $50 each (no one seemed interested in anything less than the top tickets) in a show they wouldn't see for nearly a year.

title: Topics of The Times; Banner Therapy in Moscow
description: First-time travelers to Moscow or Leningrad are always struck by the banners. Huge letters, usually red, are strung across the road or hung from windows proclaiming love of party and country: ''Glory to the Communist Party!'' ''Our Policy, the Policy of Peace!'' But recent visitors found a new variation on the upper-floor windows of the unfinished United States Embassy office building. Spelled out in humble masking tape, it said: ''God Bless America.''

description: What a strangely confusing message Secretary of State Shultz sends from Geneva about a strategic nuclear arms treaty. description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States plans to sell almost one-quarter of its money management affiliate, the Alliance Capital Management Company, in a public offering next year. It will also sell an 18 percent stake to 70 Alliance employees by year-end.

title: Verification Still Focus of Geneva Arms Talks
description: American and Soviet officials worked into this evening in an effort to resolve verification issues holding up a missile treaty that is supposed to be signed at a summit meeting in Washington in two weeks.

title: ECI TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Trainer Appeals
description: An appeal hearing sought by Peter Ferriola, the thoroughbred racing trainer, of a 120-day suspension imposed by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board began yesterday in the board's offices in Manhattan. Earlier this month, three of Ferriola's horses tested positive for Lasix, a diuretic thought to improve performance. Its use is banned for racing in New York State. Ferriola has obtained a stay of the ruling until his appeal is completed.

title: SPEC'S MUSIC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago figures are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in October.

title: REAGAN REAFFIRMS 'STAR WARS' STAND
description: Two weeks before his summit conference with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, President Reagan vowed today to deploy the space-based antimissile system that the Soviet Union adamantly opposes.

title: Historic Ships Rotting At Maritime Museum
description: The world's largest assembly of historic ships lies rotting and covered with rust along the waterfront here, a victim of inadequate maintenance that officials attributed to insufficient Federal financing.

title: Steinberg Won't Try to Maintain Custody of Boy
description: Joel B. Steinberg said yesterday that he would not try to seek custody of the 17-month-old boy he had been raising as Mitchell Steinberg, who was returned last week to the baby's biological mother.

title: Dollar Edges Lower; Gold Has Strong Gain
description: The dollar inched lower in light trading yesterday, as dealers, particularly in Europe, reacted negatively to the Federal deficit-reduction package announced in Washington Friday.

title: Soviet Jews Ponder Exit-Visa Denials
description: About 100 Soviet Jews, united by their inability to emigrate, crowded into a two-room apartment today to discuss state secrets: the secrets that keep them from leaving the Soviet Union, the secret process by which the holders of secrets are identified, and the reason the secrets themselves are secret.

title: Contras, Defying Ortega, Plan Managua Visit
description: The main group of anti-Sandinista rebels announced today that two of its leaders were planning to travel to Managua on Tuesday to deliver their first official reply to a cease-fire plan proposed by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua.

title: 2 Cycle Magazines Unite Sales Operations
description: Diamandis Communications, formerly CBS Magazines, has decided to unify the sales and marketing departments of its Cycle and Cycle World magazines. So it has named James A. Hansen, vice president and publisher of Cycle World, to head the joint effort, while Larry M. Little, who is ad director of Cycle World, will be national ad director.

title: Haydon Burns Is Dead; Ex-Governor of Florida
description: Former Gov. Haydon Burns, who served a special two-year term in the 1960's, died Sunday at Regents Park Nursing Home here. He was 75 years old and lived in Jacksonville.

description: Siamese twins separated in a 22-hour operation two and a half months ago have a potentially serious vision problem, doctors said today.

title: Authors on Beginnings
description: The way Harold Brodkey sees it, ''The question of the beginning really has a great deal to do with the question of the middle.'' Robert Towers says the idea is ''not to begin with an epigram but with an image.'' And Joyce Carol Oates says finding the inspiration to begin is ''like walking out in the middle of a field and waiting to be hit by lightning - it doesn't happen very often.''

title: U.S. to Pay $90 Million Owed To U.N. to Ease Budget Crisis
description: The Reagan Administration promised today to give at least $90 million to the United Nations next month so that it could avoid insolvency and continue to pay its 6,500 employees in New York.
