title: RJR's Choice For Tobacco
description: Dolph W. von Arx, an executive at Thomas J. Lipton Inc., has been named president and chief executive of R.J. Reynolds Tobacco U.S.A., which is RJR Nabisco Inc.'s domestic tobacco unit. The appointment of Mr. von

title: Lasers 'Weld' Damaged Arteries
description: RESEARCHERS in California have successfully tested a new method to repair damaged blood vessels, closing the ripped arteries with lasers, rather than the traditional stitches. Dr. John Crew of the Seton Medical Center in San Francisco and Dr. Rodney White of Harbor U.C.L.A. Hospital in Los Angeles reported at a recent meeting of the American Heart Association that they had successfully used ''laser welding'' in 15 patients. The laser, an intensely blue ray of light, fuses blood vessels together without heating them and does not appear to cause damage.

title: Corrections
description: An article from Geneva yesterday about arms negotiations involving Secretary of State George P. Shultz misstated his assessment of the prospects for an agreement on long-range nuclear weapons. He has said such an accord could be concluded and approved next year, not this year.

title: '88 Japan Car Limits Debated
description: Skirmishing over next year's limits on Japanese car exports to the United States is already under way. Some top executives of Detroit's auto companies are arguing that the Japanese Government should take into consideration the increasing output from Japanese-owned plants in the United States in setting the limits.

title: TRUMP TURNS DOWN DEMOCRATS' DINNER
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate magnate who is an enrolled Republican, said yesterday that he would decline an invitation by the House Speaker, Jim Wright, to be the host at the 25th annual Democratic Congressional dinner in Washington next March.

title: A NEW YORK LAW TO SUPPLY ROOMS FOR POOR IS UPSET
description: A New York City law that ordered the owners of vacant single-room-occupancy hotels to rehabilitate them and rent the rooms to low-income tenants is unconstitutional, a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

title: Met Painting Traced to Nazis
description: A famous 18th-century painting hanging in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, ''Boy Blowing Bubbles'' by Jean Baptiste Simeon Chardin, was confiscated by the Nazis from the home of a Dutch Jew in Rotterdam during World War II, according to a professor who has spent months studying World War II records of Nazi war loot.

title: Stage: 'Zangezi,' Russian Futurism at Next Wave
description: AS a visionary artist and thinker, Velimir Khlebnikov was obsessed by words, regarding them ''like minute building blocks'' that serve ''as the construction units of a story.'' In his play ''Zangezi: A Supersaga in 20 Planes,'' he extended that definition to include bird sounds, noises and an invented language called ''beyonsense'' (''zaum'' in Russian), all of them united as methods of communication.

title: GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $569,000 for the quarter and $1,011,000 for the year. c-Net loss The company said the increase in earnings and revenue for this year is because of the completion of restructuring and the acquisition of Advance Process Supply Co.

title: Iran Shells 2 Ships in Gulf; Three in Crew Are Wounded
description: The Iranian Navy opened fire on two ships in the gateway to the Persian Gulf today, setting both ablaze and wounding three crewmen, gulf-based salvage executives said.

title: Cuban Riots and Human Rights
description: It's not hard to understand why Cubans held prisoner by U.S. immigration officials would run amok at sudden news they are to be deported. Reasonably or not, many believed they would remain here, whatever their problems with the immigration and criminal justice systems.

title: CUBANS IN 2D JAIL RIOT OVER FEARS OF DEPORTATION
description: Cuban inmates fearing deportation seized hostages and set fires in a riot that left one person dead at a Federal prison in Atlanta yesterday, while a tense siege of other Cubans holding 28 hostages at a riot-scarred detention center in Louisiana continued for a third day.

title: Fairness of Seoul Election Campaign Questioned
description: Many South Koreans say they are worried that their country's democratic progress could be endangered if next month's presidential election appears tainted by vote-buying and other dubious campaign tactics.

title: AMERICAN CONSULTING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Superfund Cleanups Termed Lax
description: The Reagan Administration was charged today with violating the tough toxic cleanup and human health requirements of the 1986 law that was intended to revive the ''Superfund'' program.

title: Reagan Refuses to Discuss Issue of Pardon for Ex-Aides
description: President Reagan refused today to rule out pardons for key participants in the Iran-contra affair, saying ''that's a question no one can answer.''

The company said the latest fourth quarter includes a provision for loan losses of $200,000; there was no such provision in the year-ago fourth quarter. The latest year and prior year include a provision for possible losses of $300,000 and $345,000, respectively.

title: Golden Oldies for Gifts
description: NOW that the official Christmas shopping season is upon us, the computer industry, like just about every other industry, is straining for a holiday angle. Among the more successful and economical efforts are the Holiday Stocking Software Classics packages from Thunder Mountain.

title: GOODEN CONTRACT TALKS
description: The Mets will open contract negotiations with Dwight Gooden today in West Palm Beach, Fla., with preliminary talks between James Neader, the pitcher's agent, and Al Harazin, senior vice president of the team. The Mets have said that money will not be discussed until the length of the contract has been set, but they are expected to suggest one year in the vicinity of the $1.5 million that Gooden is being paid this year. Gooden, who was married to Monica Harris in Tampa on Saturday, won 15 games and lost 7 last season after missing the first two months while undergoing treatment for cocaine use.

title: Koch Seeks Bigger School Board To Allow for a Hispanic Member
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would seek permission from the State Legislature to appoint two more members to the seven-member Board of Education. He said that would allow him to keep a member of the Board of Education whom he described as ''maybe the best'' and at the same time appoint a Hispanic member.

title: Dance: A Finn Makes His Debut With City Ballet
description: THE New York City Ballet surprised dancegoers on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater by offering an unscheduled debut in a major work. Jukka Aromaa, a young Finnish dancer, took over the leading male role in the ''Tema con Variazioni'' movement of George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3.''

description: The 16th game of the world chess championship was adjourned today with the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, a pawn ahead in an endgame.

title: Role Seen For Boron In Curbing Bone Loss
description: BORON, a mineral long considered inessential to nutrition, apparently affects blood levels of certain hormones and may play a major role in preventing bone loss, Government scientists have reported.

description: Robert Keith Gray, a fixture on the Washington political and social scene since the Eisenhower Administration, wears out one each year. Ambassador Allan E. Gotlieb of Canada is on his second since coming here. Many senators keep one at home and one in the office.

Joseph C. Palamountain Jr., 66, Ex-President of Skidmore College>
description: Joseph Cornwall Palamountain Jr., who retired in June after 22 years as the fourth president of Skidmore College, died of cardiac arrest yesterday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Dr. Palamountain, who had triple bypass surgery within the last year, lived in Saratoga Springs and was 66 years old.

title: AT LEAST 14 DEAD IN ALASKA CRASH
description: A commuter aircraft crashed while landing at Homer, Alaska, tonight killing at least 14 people and injuring seven others, the authorities said.

title: Helen G. Scott, 72, Writer for Truffaut And Other Directors
description: Helen G. Scott, an American writer and translator who was a close associate of Francois Truffaut and other French New Wave film directors, died of a heart attack Friday in Paris, where she had lived for many years. She was 72 years old.

title: Teacher Quits in Race Dispute
description: A teacher who told two black students they would not get the leading roles in a high school play because of their race has resigned, officials said.

title: DOW ADVANCES 9.45 IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market moved higher in desultory trading yesterday that was enlivened only by renewed takeover speculation, particularly among brokerage stocks.

title: Tar Heel Women A Soccer Dynasty
description: Mention collegiate dynasties, and we tend to think of John Wooden's U.C.L.A. basketball teams, which captured seven consecutive championships from 1967 through 1973. Or perhaps we recall the greatest success streaks in college: Iowa's nine consecutive wrestling titles from 1978 through 1986, or Southern Cal's nine consecutive track and field titles from 1935 through 1943.

title: Futuristic Treatments For the Hair and Skin
description: DERMATOLOGISTS are developing futuristic treatments for some widespread and distressing conditions previously thought to be beyond their help. The experimental treatments may restore natural color to graying hair, prevent poison ivy rashes and restore even skin tone to patients with the pale patches of vitiligo.

title: Outside the Prison, Sobbing Wives
description: While Cuban detainees held hostages inside the Federal penitentiary here today, the families of several inmates gathered outside the prison walls to follow the course of the siege and plead with Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, to be allowed to assist in the negotiations with the authorities.

title: Lost Score By Liszt To Be Sold
description: A major and previously unknown score by Franz Liszt is to be auctioned at Sotheby's in London on Friday. The work for piano bears no title, date or signature but has been identified by Liszt experts as having been written by the composer between 1830 and 1832, when he was in his late teens and early 20's and was active throughout Europe as a concert pianist. It is full of the extravagantly virtuosic writing that characterized his work in this period.

title: Collisions on Foggy Road
description: Dozens of vehicles collided today in separate accidents on a fog-bound stretch of Interstate 215, and at least seven people were injured, a California Highway Patrol commander said. Estimates ranged from 30 to 40 vehicles involved in the crashes, said Capt. Ralph Limon. He said several accidents had occurred, some involving six to eight vehicles and another with as many as 15 to 20.

title: Risks of 'Learning Disabled' Label
description: CHILDREN, like adults, have individual ways of learning, and educators who do not recognize them can undermine their chance for success or even wrongly label them as learning disabled, according to a new book by Thomas Armstrong, a psychologist. ''We're shutting the door to millions more who possess untold inner riches,'' he said.

title: U.S. BEGINS SEARCH OF WAR CRIME FILES
description: The war crimes archives of the United Nations were fully opened to a member nation for the first time yesterday as Justice Department historians began methodically poring over files containing 40,000 names of accused or suspected war criminals.

description: A week before the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19, James S. Gallagher, the president of the Pacific Stock Exchange, informed the chairman that he planned to quit.

title: New Tests on Joints Sought for Booster Before a Launching
description: The redesigned joints of the space shuttle's booster rockets should undergo a new series of tests before being declared ready for flight, but the additional testing need not delay resumption of flights next year as planned, an expert panel said today.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Contra Fund-Raisers: Dispute Over Payment
description: Just how much is a meeting with President Reagan worth?

title: SPECIALTY EQUIPMENT COS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
LIONEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Tax Watch; Party and Gift Deductibility
description: WITH the holiday season approaching, tax practitioners have been trying to sort out how the Tax Reform Act of 1986 affects business gifts, office Christmas parties and other festivities. It is no simple matter.

title: Linguists Dig Deeper Into Origins of Language
description: PALEONTOLOGISTS ponder their fossils, archeologists turn over ancient stones, and now scholars of linguistics are joining the search for human origins with a systematic analysis of the roots of the world's known languages. They are seeking ultimately to reconstruct the primordial language, the mother tongue of all humans.

title: Carlucci Is Sworn In
description: Frank C. Carlucci 3d, praised by President Reagan as someone who could work with Congress and the bureaucracy, was sworn in today as Secretary of Defense. Mr. Carlucci, 57 years old, had been Mr. Reagan's national security adviser, taking over the National Security Council in January after disclosure of its covert role in the Iran-Contra scandal. He succeeds Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: Dance: The Mimi Garrard Company
description: THE works the Mimi Garrard Dance Theater offered Sunday night at La Mama were certainly diverting. But they did not strike this viewer as being rich in choreographic events to savor or ponder.

title: Music: Jersey Symphony in Bernstein
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN is becoming 70 years old for an awfully long time this season. The actual birthday isn't until late next summer, but the list of celebrations is long. Nearly at the head of the queue stands the New Jersey Symphony, which played an all-Bernstein program at Carnegie Hall Sunday night. The great man was in attendance himself, helping the America-Israel Cultural Foundation formally thank the Helena Rubinstein Foundation for its support of Israeli artists.

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Tennis Notebook; Graf and Sabatini Win Fans' Respect
description: Although they are already two of the dominant players in the world, Steffi Graf of West Germany and Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina are relatively new to tennis fans in the United States. As recently as a year ago, they faced each other in the opening round of the Virginia Slims championships at Madison Square Garden. On Sunday, they met in the final, no longer supporting actors in a sport that had been monopolized by Chris Evert and Martina Navratilova.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,415,000 and $1,788,612 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes net from discontinued operations of $77,000 and $114,869 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Brother of Top Afghan Is Said to Defect to Rebels
description: The younger brother of Afghanistan's Soviet-backed leader has defected to the Afghan rebels, according to American intelligence reports and foreign diplomats.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer error, an article on Friday from Tooele, Utah, about the visit of a Soviet delegation to a chemical weapons installation misattributed a quotation in some editions. It was Yuri K. Nazarkin, the chief Soviet negotiator on chemical weapons, and not Max L. Friedersdorf, the American representative at the Disarmament Conference in Geneva, who said: ''It's a confidence-building measure. And confidence building is very important now when we are at the final stages of our negotiations on chemical weapons.''

title: Concert: U. V. Khan, Sitarist
description: ONE of North India's most distinguished sitarists, Ustad Vilayat Khan, gave his first New York performance since the late 1970's on Saturday at the Triplex Theater. Mr. Khan, who is 59 years old, brought exultant technique and a playful spirit to the occasion.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BancTexas Group Inc., Dallas, elected as directors Anthony J. Gumbiner, chairman of the Hallwood Group, a merchant banking firm, and James G. Cairns, managing director of Hallwood.

title: BRANDON SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in November 1985, and a 6-for-5 split in September 1986.

title: In Remote Laos, Soviet Changes Trickle Down
description: In the early morning, when temple gongs and roosters are the only sounds to be heard on this side of the Mekong, Laos seems to be living in a timeless world of its own.

title: Officials See Harshness of Iran Panel's Finding as a Blow to Meese
description: The criticism of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d in the majority report of the Congressional Iran-contra committees is a serious blow to the Attorney General, Justice Department officials say.

title: SUNSTATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Carbon Dioxide Census
description: The rate of increase of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere matches the rate of global population growth with precision that is ''amazing,'' two paleontologists have found. Dr. Norman D. Newell and Dr. Leslie Marcus, both of the American Museum of Natural History in New York City, cited data gathered from 1958 to 1983 for their study. Their results were published recently by Palaios, the journal of the Society of Economic Paleontologists and Minerologists.

title: Town Duels Bank to Save Sole Plant
description: Anxious and confused by a New York bank's apparent decision to liquidate a local company, leaders of this rural town of 10,000 people have used some big-city tactics to protect their sole manufacturing plant.

description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $145,517 and $170,837 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $201,813 for the quarter and $561,659 for the 9 months.

title: Koch Pledges Inquiry on Arrests by Transit Police
description: Likening the incident to a tale out of Kafka, Mayor Koch said yesterday that the New York City Police Department would investigate accusations that four transit police officers made scores of false or improper arrests on the Lexington Avenue subway and other lines during 1983 and 1984.

title: Restructuring Plan for Cliffs
description: The New Jersey investment banker David F. Bolger today proposed a restructuring plan for Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. that he valued between $18.72 and $20.22 a share, or a total of $250.7 million. Cleveland-Cliffs announced

title: Stage: 'The Racket' Opens SoHo Rep's Season
description: ''THE RACKET,'' which opens a season of ''lost American plays'' at the SoHo Rep, is 60 years old and shows it. Michael Bloom, who directed, has done his darndest to put some kick into this watered-down version of ''The Front Page'' (even though it was written a year earlier). Wisecracking reporters dash for the telephone and holler, ''Get me the desk!'' Cops clump out to catch crooks or get coffee. Suspicious-looking types pop in and are hustled off. The set's three exits are as busy as rush hour on the Chicago El. All the activity, however, cannot cover up the lack of interesting action; the big cast (18 men and a woman) cannot conceal the lack of interesting characters.

title: Woman Dies in Ansonia Fire
description: A 91-year-old resident of the Ansonia Hotel died in a fire in her apartment last night, according to authorities. The woman, identified as Susan Breisach, was a long-time resident of the landmark building at 2107 Broadway, between 73d and 74th Streets. The cause of the fire, which occurred around 6 P.M. and was quickly extinguished, was under investigation.

title: Congressman to Shun Race
description: Rep-resentative Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota announced today he would not challenge Senator Quentin Burdick for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate next year, but would seed re-election to the House. The announcement ended months of speculation as to whether the 45-year-old Congressman would seek the par-ty's endorsement. Senator Burdick, 79, announced earlier this month that he was seeking re-election.

title: Finding Contentment
description: To The Living Section:

title: Article 414587 -- No Title
description: Payment for mammograms of older women by Medicare would save hundreds of lives and reduce medical costs for some women, a new Congressional study shows. But it would ultimately cost the Medicare system $1.5 billion a year.

title: Smoking Ban in Pittsburgh
description: The City Council approved a bill Monday to ban or restrict cigarette smoking in restaurants, offices and public buildings. Mayor Richard Caliguiri, who as a Councilman 12 years ago failed to win passage of a similar bill, said he would sign the measure into law.

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
INDIANA REPRIMANDS KNIGHT
description: Bobby Knight, the Indiana University basketball coach, was reprimanded today by the university for pulling his team off the court during an exhibition game Saturday night against the Soviet Union's national team.

title: NASA's Gargantuan Riveter
description: THERE are some wondrous machines under the 43-acre roof of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Michoud assembly complex here. In pursuit of its contract to assemble space shuttle fuel tanks that are almost 28 feet in diameter and half the length of a football field, the Martin Marietta Corporation has developed massive welders, a cleaning device it describes as the world's biggest washing machine and, recently, a giant riveter unlike any others in the industrial world.

description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn has won the $20 million Slice brand soft drink from Pepsi-Cola, already the largest client in its New York office.

title: Of Time and Professors And the Cost of College
description: Higher education in this country is a $124-billion-a-year industry built around the free exchange of ideas. But there is one idea, frequently discussed by executives of other large industries, that is rarely debated in faculty clubs. That is productivity.

description: To the Editor:

title: City and Country Meet to Eat
description: IT was an occasion that had something for everyone: for restaurants, which loved the exposure; for farmers, who could display their wares, and for the New-York Historical Society, which played host last week to the event, the Thanksgiving Food Festival, part of the Farm-City Week Celebration held nationwide every year.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: CIRCA '87 Dear Pilgrims, at the very least At sevens and at sixes You'd be at OUR Thanksgiving feast Among the instant mixes. And, when we carve the noble bird Electrically this Autumn, Your ghosts would shout ''Absurd, absurd!'' Confronted with the cheerful word That, just before we cooked the bird We thawed 'm! MAUREEN CANNON

title: When a City Defies a Judge
description: What should a court do when a community under a desegregation order continuously drags its feet? In barring Yonkers, N.Y., from aiding commercial and residential development until it complies with his order, U.S. District Judge Leonard Sand offers a creative answer that merits support.

title: Recital: Elena Obraztsova, Mezzo
description: ONLY when the official part of her program was done and she had begun the encores did Elena Obraztsova give her fans at Carnegie Hall what they most wanted. Singing ''O mio babbino caro'' from ''Gianni Schicchi,'' ''Voi lo sapete'' from ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and the Habanera from ''Carmen,'' the Russian mezzo-soprano provided the kind of visceral, flamboyant vocalism that she had kept pretty much under wraps during the bulk of her recital Monday evening.

title: Pritzkers in Talks On Pan Am Unit
description: Representatives of the Pritzker family have been working with officials of the Pan American Corporation to develop a takeover offer for its airline unit that could be presented to the Pan Am board when it meets on Dec. 1, union and sources close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Sooners Led TV Ratings
description: Last Saturday was a busy day for sports on television, and according to Arbitron Ratings of 13 metered markets, these were the five highest- rated sports programs for the day, with network, rating and share (the rating is a percentage of households with televisions tuned into a program and the share is the percentage of households with televisions in use tuned in): 1 - Nov. 21, Oklahoma vs.

title: SANDERSON FARMS reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Irving Levitas Is Dead; Jewish History Scholar
description: Irving Levitas, a scholar and lecturer in Jewish history, died yesterday of lung cancer at the Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: TERRORIST LEADER IS SEIZED IN JAPAN
description: After a long manhunt, the Japanese police have arrested a leader of the Japanese Red Army, the terrorist group responsible for the massacre at Lod Airport near Tel Aviv in 1972.

title: Latest Quakes Differed From One at Los Angeles
description: The two earthquakes that shook southern California late Monday and early yesterday differed basically in nature from the quake that struck the Los Angeles area on Oct. 1, scientists believe.

title: China Names Acting Prime Minister
description: Li Peng, a 59-year-old Soviet-educated engineer, was named Acting Prime Minister of China today. He succeeds Zhao Ziyang, who gave up the post to devote himself full time to his duties as head of China's 46-million-member Communist Party.

description: b-Net income

title: Ben C. Birdsall, Retired Arizona Judge, 64
description: Ben C. Birdsall, a retired judge who presided over two of Arizona's most publicized criminal cases, died Sunday of cancer. He was 64 years old.

title: Books of The times
description: PSYCHOTIC REACTIONS AND CARBURETOR DUNG. By Lester Bangs.

title: Film: 'Planes, Trains and Automobiles'
description: THE circuitous journey that is embarked upon in John Hughes's ''Planes, Trains and Automobiles'' is supposed to range from New York to Chicago, but its final destination is surprising. The two traveling companions, Neal Page (Steve Martin) and Del Griffith (John Candy), do indeed make it to the Windy City, but they also reach the place where confidences are voiced, insecurities are expressed and friendships are formed.

The company said fiscal 1987 results are restated for comparative purposes to conform to 52-week accounting for the fiscal year.

title: G.O.P. Governors Back Deficit Plan
description: Republican Governors urged Congress today to ratify ''without delay'' the bipartisan budget compromise worked out between Congress and the White House that would reduce the Federal deficit by $76 billion over the next two years.

title: College Football Notebook; Fordham Sporting Philadelphia Look
description: During the decade that Larry Glueck spent at Harvard as an assistant football coach, he was assigned the Philadelphia area for recruiting purposes and built contacts there.

title: Beverly Hills Listed As a Distressed Area
description: This glamorous city whose boulevards are lined with luxury shops is down in the dumps over a Federal rating that defines it as economically distressed.

description: b-Includes a $4.7 million gain from the reversal of a deferred tax expense, previously reported as a deferred tax liability for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: PENTAGON PLANS FIRST LASER TEST IN SPACE IN 1990'S
description: Defense Department officials said today that they planned to conduct the first test of a laser weapon in space in the early 1990's, as part of one of the costliest and probably most disputed experiments in the Reagan Administration's effort to build a defense against nuclear missiles.

title: MORGAN KEEGAN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Crackdown Is Ordered In Bangladesh Strikes
description: President H. M. Ershad ordered a fresh crackdown on his opponents today as their national strike against his Government continued to cripple the country.

title: Oilers Send Coffey to Penguins
description: Paul Coffey, the all-star defenseman who refused to report to the Edmonton Oilers because of a contract dispute, was sent to the Pittsburgh Penguins today in a seven-player trade in which the Oilers obtained Craig Simpson, a promising young forward.

title: In Italy, Walnuts Are Prized by Home Cooks
description: Each fall, the harvesting of walnuts generates nearly as much excitement among Italians as the hunt for wild porcini mushrooms.

title: Frances F. Vandivier, Child Care Educator, 61
description: Frances Finnell Vandivier, a child care educator, died Thursday at Goergetown University Hospital in Washington of ovarian cancer. She was 61 years old.

title: Irving Bank Adopts 'Tin Parachutes'
description: In its latest effort to fend off a hostile $1.2 billion takeover attempt by the Bank of New York, the Irving Bank Corporation has adopted a policy assuring all its employees substantial benefits in case they are laid off after an unfriendly takeover.

title: ADELPHIA COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6 months reflect certain acquisitions completed from October through December 1986.

title: Colleges' S.A.T. Lists Can Be Creative Works
description: They are known in college admissions jargon as N.I.P.'s, for Not in Profile. They are those members of the freshman class whose Scholastic Aptitude Test scores are not included in the class profile because they would pull down the class average.

title: Bell Atlantic Makes Key Appointments
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, wrapping up an extensive restructuring, named Raymond W. Smith yesterday to the newly created positions of president and chief operating officer and Philip A. Campbell as vice chairman and chief financial officer.

title: GENERAL EMPLOYMENT ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter includes a pre- tax charge of $60,000 related to certain costs associated with the closing of the company's Toronto agency operation. The latest year includes a second quarter charge of $74,000 related to the moving of the corporate headquarters.

title: VIGILANTES EMERGE AMID HAITI STRIFE
description: As more violence broke out in Haiti and Government security forces remained mainly on the sidelines, some Haitians began organizing themselves as vigilantes this week to try to insure that presidential elections would take place as scheduled in five days.

title: A Big Item In Tax Plan Is Dropped
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, today complicated the task of piecing together a $9 billion package of tax increases by setting new ground rules for the negotiations.

title: Real Estate; Ad Firms' West Side Migration
description: FOR decades advertising agencies were a mainstay in the office towers on the East Side of midtown Manhattan.

title: Jack Lawrence Theater Is Sold to a Developer
description: The Jack Lawrence Theater, a 499-seat house at 359 West 48th Street, has been sold to a commercial developer, the owner, Jack Lawrence, said yesterday.

title: Gene Blakely, Actor, 66
description: Gene Blakely, an actor who worked on and Off Broadway in the 1940's and 50's, died of bone cancer Monday at the Greater Community Hospital of Creston, Iowa. He was 66 years old and lived in Phoenix.

title: Ex-Client Says He Was Disappointed With Deaver
description: A former client of Michael K. Deaver testified today that he felt disappointed when he realized that as a private lobbyist Mr. Deaver might not be able to work million-dollar miracles through his access to high Reagan Administration officials.

title: Child Abuse Made Legal
description: LEAD: There has been a lot of hand-wringing over the death of Elizabeth Steinberg. Without blaming anyone in particular, neighbors, friends, social workers, the police and newspaper editors have struggled to define the community's responsibility to Elizabeth and to other battered children. As the collective soul-searching continues, there is a pervading sense that the system failed her.

title: KEY RATES
RECORDS AT THE MET DISPROVE CHARGE OF ACQUIRING 5 PAINTINGS IMPROPERLY
description: Officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday disproved a suggestion that the museum illicitly acquired five paintings that had been stolen by the Nazis in World War II. The museum acknowledged that one of the paintings had once been stolen by Nazis, but said it had legally and properly acquired that painting and two others from the rightful owners and had never owned the remaining two at all.

title: Boxing Notebook; Early '88 Calendar Lists Big Title Bouts
description: With pro football dominating television's sports calendar until the end of the year, the big fights are mostly deferred until early 1988.

title: Dinkins and Rangel Backing Jackson's Candidacy
description: Standing on the steps of New York's City Hall yesterday, the Rev. Jesse Jackson won support for his Democratic Presidential candidacy from two of the city's leading black elected officials, Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem and Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan.

description: Brush Wellman Inc., a Cleveland-based company that has a lock on the beryllium market, announced yesterday that it had named its president and chief operating officer, Raymond A. Foos, to the added position of chief executive, effective Jan. 1.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Thanksgiving is tomorrow and closings vary. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Begins at 9 A.M. at 77th Street and Central Park West. Proceeds down Central Park West to Columbus Circle and then down Broadway to 34th Street. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No refuse collection or street sweeping. Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on holiday schedule, but with extra trains. Schools: Closed tomorrow and Friday. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal offices closed. State and municipal offices closed tomorrow and Friday. Post offices: Closed. Banks: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on holiday schedule. Schools: Closed tomorrow, most closed Friday. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Municipal offices closed, some closed on Friday. Post offices: Closed. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed tomorrow and Friday.

title: New Nuclear Follies?
description: For nearly 30 years, countries have sold nuclear materials around the world with the requirements that the importing nations promise to use them for peaceful purposes and permit on-site inspection. These two pledges are the main barrier between civil and military use of the atom.

title: How NBC Got Gorbachev Interview
description: Tom Brokaw, the NBC anchor, said yesterday that Soviet officials had been telling his network for two years that it was ''at the head of the list'' in the quest by American networks for a one-on-one interview with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. NBC announced Monday that Mr. Gorbachev had agreed to be interviewed by Mr. Brokaw in Moscow for a one-hour program to be broadcast at 8 P.M. next Monday, one week before Mr. Gorbachev is scheduled to arrive in the United States for meetings with President Reagan beginning Dec. 7.

title: New York Court Upholds Conjugal-Visit Ban for Inmate With AIDS
description: New York State's highest court ruled 4 to 3 today that prison officials can deny conjugal visits to inmates with AIDS.

description: John Jensen called Bruce Babbitt one day to give the Democratic Presidential candidate some advice. Mr. Jensen thought Mr. Babbitt, the former Governor of Arizona, was good on the issues, but he was worried about the candidate's pig-holding policy.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Market Place; High Returns Of Junk Bonds
description: ARE junk bonds a better deal than ever? The author of a new study on the high-yield securities thinks so.

title: At Monell, It's All in the Taste and Smell
description: LEAD: THE large sculpture with the full lips and prominent nose that sits in front of 3500 Market Street here is a good tip to the activities inside.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

title: Davis Injuries Halt Jury Selection
description: Jury selection was interrupted yesterday in the trial of Larry Davis while the defendant was treated for injuries he received in jail, the authorities said.

title: Adele Miller, Advertising Executive, 91
description: Adele Miller, who with her late husband, Samuel, founded the Miller Advertising Agency in 1919, died Monday of complications from Alzheimer's disease at Beth Israel Hospital. She was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Koch Nominee Backed For Chief of Tax Panel
description: The New York City Council yesterday approved Mayor Koch's nomination of David Goldstein to be president of the city's Tax Commission.

title: Howard Will Sue
description: James Cheeks, president of Howard University, says that the school is going to sue the National Collegiate Athletic Association because it was passed over for postseason play despite having the second-best record in Division I-AA football. The suit, scheduled to be filed today, will charge antitrust and contract violations. It will also ask a Federal judge to bar the first Division I-AA playoff games scheduled this weekend until the case is heard in court. ''What we are about to embark upon is not a skirmish, but an all-out war,'' said Cheeks. Howard, which had a 9-1 record, won the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference title, its first championship ever. However, the school was ranked 18th nationally among Division I-AA teams, missing the playoffs by one spot. Holy Cross, the top team, does not particpate in bowl games. Although Howard had a better record than all but one Division I-AA team, its ranking suffered because of a weak schedule, including four opponents below the Division I-AA level. ''You try to tell your kids about rules and regulations, but when it's time for them to receive accolades and honors and a group of adults make something like this happen, it's hard to talk to them,'' said Willie Jeffries, the Howard coach.

title: In Manhattan, It'll Be No Holiday For Drivers, Traffic Officials Say
description: New York City officials are expecting major traffic problems during the holiday season and are taking steps to prepare for as many as 200,000 extra vehicles a day.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Pass the Chablis
description: At this stage of the Presidential competition, it is unclear which candidate will launch the most effective appeal for the support of the young upwardly mobile professionals.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday about the Metropolitan Museum of Art discussed paintings looted by the Nazis during World War II and strongly suggested that the museum had obtained some of them illicitly. The suggestion - based on information provided by a Rutgers University professor - was wrong.

title: Queens Man Guilty In the 1986 Slaying Of a Rookie Officer
description: A 34-year-old man described by the police as a low-level drug dealer was convicted yesterday of killing a rookie police officer in a gun battle in Queens last year.

title: Doubts on Rates Hurt Bonds
description: Bond prices plunged yesterday, depressed by doubts that international interest rates would move much lower and worries about the stability of the dollar.

description: In what might be the last flicker of the fiscal and oil crises, thousands of lights along New York City's highways, darkened a decade ago to cut costs, will be blinking back on over the next few months.

title: Ethnic Albanians Suffer Under Yugoslav Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: G.N.P. Rises 4.1%; Profits Up Sharply
description: The economy expanded faster than had been thought in the months before the October stock market crash and corporate profits surged, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: Reagan Administration officials today signaled a willingness to relent on sending some Cuban prisoners back to Cuba.

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances; Software For Design Engineers
description: ''MACHINE TOOLS for the mind'' is how A. Wayne Snodgrass, president of the Computer and Automated Systems Association, describes the new generations of software becoming available to mechanical design engineers.

title: 61 Groups given Hunger Aid
description: A $3.8 million final installment of money raised by the cross-country ''Hands Across America'' charity drive has been distributed to 61 groups aiding the hungry and homeless in 28 states and the District of Columbia, USA for Af-rica, the parent foundation, said Mon-day. The money was raised in the May 25, 1986, Hands Across America drive in which an estimated six million peo-ple joined hands in symbolic support of the nation's hungry and homeless.

title: Bridge: Rosenkranz Team and Four From Seattle Capture Titles
description: An experienced team led by Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City scored a solid victory in the men's Board-a-Match team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals Monday night, and a foursome from the Seattle area led by Shirley Edelson won the women's Board-a-Match title by a big margin.

title: New Security Measures Planned After Court Melee
description: New York City correction officials said yesterday that they were planning additional security measures for inmates brought to court as a result of a melee in Brooklyn Monday during which three prisoners took out hidden razor blades and a makeship knife and injured 11 court officers.

title: FEDERAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $483,000 for the quarter and $636,000 for the 9 months, and gains of $11,000 and $185,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the termination of a pension plan. c-Net loss Federal Resources said the increase in revenue for the latest quarter and 9 months was because of the acquisitions of Mid-West Spring Manufacturing Co. in October 1986 and New Generation Inc. in June 1987. The company changed its fiscal year to end Dec. 31 beginning with the year 1986. Previously, its fiscal year ended April 30.

title: Service for Elayne Varian
description: A memorial service for Elayne Varian, former director of the contemporary wing of the Finch College Museum of Art, will be held Tuesday at 2 P.M. at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, at 71st Street. Mrs. Varian died Nov. 4 in Orlando, Fla.

title: RAX RESTAURANT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 26
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $267,000.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Interior Department; At the Wildlife Service, an Extinction With Irony
description: The Office of Endangered Species has gone the way of the dusky seaside sparrow and the Sampson's pearly mussel. Like six of the species that it was created to protect in 1973, it has become extinct.

title: Thousands of Estates in New York Are Mismanaged, a Report Says
description: The New York State Attorney General and the State Comptroller yesterday accused New York City's public administrators of ''significant deficiencies and questionable practices'' in handling the estates of people who die without wills.

title: MAPPING OUT ETHNIC MENUS
description: THE savory ingredients of New York's melting pot have been assembled in a new book called ''The Food Lover's Guide to the Real New York'' by Myra Alperson and Mark Clifford (Prentice Hall Press, $12.95). This borough-by-borough guide explores the ethnic neighborhoods from the venerable Lower East Side of Manhattan to a newly established pocket of Cambodian settlements in the Bronx. Equipped with this guide, you can explore them, too.

title: 6 Concertgoers Injured, And 15 Are Arrested
description: Six teen-agers were injured, one critically, and 15 youths were arrested in a melee that broke out during a rap music concert last night in New Haven, the authorities said.

description: BOBBY KNIGHT cried, ''No mas, no mas,'' in deed if not in actual word, and removed his Indiana University basketball team from the court, forfeiting the game Saturday night to the Soviet Union.

The company said the latest periods' nets from continuing operations are after LIFO charges of $1,647,000 for the quarter and $3,658,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago periods had a small credit for the quarter and a LIFO charge of $441,000 for the 9 months.

title: Concert: Villa-Lobos's 'Magdalena'
description: SIFTING through the detritus of history in hopes of turning up neglected masterpieces is an activity for which only congenital optimists need apply. The success rate is guaranteed to be between low and nil. However, even the slimmest hope of excavating a deserving old work is often enough to rally a dedicated band of musical archeologists.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: WHILE I was away on a business trip, my husband introduced prayer in the home. I returned to find that the bedtime routine had been altered, that sandwiched between the drink of water and the hugs and kisses was a short conversation with the Almighty. It even included the sign of the cross, although as performed by my children, the sign of the cross looks more like one of those fraternal lodge handshakes.

title: A Communist Long on Tradition: Li Peng
description: For Li Peng, who was named Acting Prime Minister today, it is a question he has come to anticipate with metronomic regularity, and the answer, as it was earlier this month, is on the tip of his tongue.

When first planned, the concert, celebrating the 10th anniversary of the Brazilian Cultural Foundation, was to have reunited the composer with the tenor saxophonist Stan Getz, who was instrumental in popularizing the bossa nova in the United States 25 years ago. Illness unfortunately prevented his participation.

As did his father and other men in his family, he belongs to a men's club, where others of his ilk gather for a round of squash, a steam bath, luncheon, backgammon and other rituals of male camaraderie.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ron Wood, An Artist In 3 Media
description: ''In the back of my head I always knew I'd be a musician first and an artist later,'' begins a recently published book of paintings, drawings and informal autobiography, ''Ron Wood by Ron Wood: The Works.'' But after spending five years playing in the Jeff Beck Group, seven years with Rod Stewart and the Faces, and 12 years as a member of the Rolling Stones, Mr. Wood, a British guitarist, decided it was time to get back to his original career as an artist. So last week, he interrupted the tour that he is currently co-headlining with Bo Diddley to show up for the opening of his first one-man art show, in a gallery that is part of the Peabody Hotel here. Mr. Wood and Mr. Diddley will be playing in New York City at the Ritz tonight.

title: WINE TALK
description: WHAT is all the fuss over Burgundy? According to an article in the Oct. 31 issue of The Wine Spectator, a paper for wine buffs, American consumers are boycotting Burgundy wines. ''Burgundy Boycott Is Working,'' the article's headline read.

title: Panama Journal; A Justice Is Slain: Did Regime Turn a Blind Eye?
description: The mysterious shooting death of a Supreme Court Justice here has become a cause celebre that has raised questions about the ability of a military Government already accused of political assassination, election rigging and vast corruption to administer justice impartially.

description: ''HOUSEKEEPING,'' Bill Forsyth's fine adaptation of Marilynne Robinson's 1981 novel, is a clear-eyed, brow-furrowed, haunting comedy about impossible attachments and doomed affection in a world divided between two kinds of people.

title: Scare for Elliott
description: Bill Elliott, the race-car driver, was a passenger in an Air Force F-16 jet that clipped a Georgia Air National Guard F-15 over Jefferson County yesterday. No injuries were reported although the F-15 crashed after the pilot, Lt. Col. Bruce MacLane, was forced to eject. The pilot of the plane carrying Elliott, Maj. Wayne F. Conroy, managed to bring his damaged F-16 back to Dobbins Air Force Base in Marietta, where it landed without incident. ''Everything happened so fast I couldn't tell you what happened,'' Elliott said. ''The impact was there. The pilot got the plane back with the wings level. We made a pass over the pilot and saw he had ejected out and saw he was safe. Then we did some maneuvers to see if we'd be able to land it.'' Capt. Robert Coffman, public affairs officer at Dobbins, did not have an explanation or description of the mishap. He said Elliott had done a recruiting commercial for the Air Force Reserve and was being given an ''orientation ride'' when the collision occurred.

title: About New York; For Boat Owner, An Ill Wind On the Hudson
description: There is a theory that the two happiest days in a man's life are the day he buys a boat and the day he sells it. Doug Ashley got only the first satisfaction. His vessel sank. Then, as he tried to raise it, the Government towed it off to be burned.

description: b-Net income The company said share earnings reflect a 20-to-1 reverse stock split paid in October.

4 Aid Laos Against Bombis and Other Horrors
description: There are only four of them, if you don't count the children.

description: Interest rates at Citicorp's regular weekly commercial paper auction yesterday were off only slightly.

title: Contras Give Cease-Fire Response to Papal Envoy
description: Nicaraguan rebels delivered their first official response to President Daniel Ortega Saavedra's cease-fire plan today to the Papal Nuncio in Costa Rica, after two of their senior leaders were unable to fly to the Nicaraguan capital to hand over the document.

title: AIDS Epidemic Won't Spare Asia, Parley in Manila is Told
description: The worldwide AIDS epidemic, which so far has mostly spared Asia, is likely to spread through this continent in the coming years, according to doctors speaking at a conference on the disease today.

title: 76ers Sign King
description: The Philadelphia 76ers signed Albert King, the free-agent guard who last played for the Nets, to a two-year contract yesterday. The Nets, who agreed not to exercise their right of first refusal, received a second-round draft selection in 1988 and a conditional second-round choice in 1990 from the 76ers. Terms of King's contract were not disclosed. He averaged 13.6 points per game in six seasons with the Nets but missed 20 games last season because of ankle and knee injuries, and he underwent arthroscopic knee surgery in the off season.

title: WAREHOUSE CLUB reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
At Our Saviour High, Small Stands Tall
description: Everybody loves a good David and Goliath story, so they should doubly love the story of Our Saviour Lutheran High School.

title: Antiques Shops Open With Period Buffet
description: EDIBLE art objects in 18th-century French style were the center of attraction last week at a gala cocktail party for the opening of the Place des Antiquaires.

title: Major Contributor to Cuomo To Testify at a Bribery Trial
description: A major contributor to Governor Cuomo's 1982 election campaign, who is also a law client of the Governor's son Andrew, will play a key role in a complicated conspiracy and bribery trial that began in Manhattan yesterday, a defense attorney said in his opening statement to the jury.

title: Film: 'Three Men and a Baby'
description: IT'S even clearer in the big, splashy, good-humored American version of ''Three Men and a Baby'' that it was in the French original (entitled ''Three Men and a Cradle'') that this story is about four babies, not just one. Aside from the infant girl left on their doorstep, the three fun-loving bachelors who grudgingly adopt her are children too. When the story begins, they have not a care in the world, just a life filled with revelry and a penthouse apartment that is a monument to their frolicsome ways. The American film makes this especially evident by filling the place with things like a jukebox and a pool table, the grown-up equivalent of toys.

title: KIMMINS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV Review; Tributes to Art of Norman Rockwell
description: THIS being the week of Thanksgiving, television has appropriately decided to pay unusual attention to Norman Rockwell, the popular illustrator who combined an optimistic approach to life with a sentimental view of the world that is almost always innocent and sweet.

title: Deaths of Unattended Children Spur Day Care Bills in Congress
description: A year ago this month two Miami children, 3 and 4 years old, were left unattended at home while their mother worked. They climbed into a clothes dryer with tumbling laundry, closed the door and burned to death.

title: Crash Near an Alaska Airport Leaves 17 Dead and 5 Injured
description: A Ryan Air commuter plane crashed and skidded through a fence while trying to land, killing 17 people and injuring the four others aboard, the authorities said today.

title: ALL-AMERICA HONOR DOES NOT APPEASE OHIO STATE LINEBACKER
description: Chris Spielman of Ohio State has always been an emotional football player, one who relied on extreme intensity more than physical prowess to become one of the best inside linebackers in college football. But this last week has been an emotional roller coaster that has had too many turns even for Spielman.

title: Transplant of a Human Knee Is Achieved for the First Time

description: Following similar moves by other futures exchanges, the Chicago Board of Trade last week approved the adoption of daily price limits for its stock index futures contracts.

Bilzerian, the Florida investor, said today that the Singer Company, an aerospace concern based in Stamford, Conn., had offered him access to certain nonpublic information if he agreed to purchase no more of the company's shares for 18 months. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Bilzerian, who has begun a $1.1 billion offer for Singer, said that he was not prepared to agree to such an arrangement.

description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci 3d insisted today that the Reagan Administration would not negotiate limits on ''Star Wars'' research and rejected Soviet proposals on limiting tests of defenses against nuclear missiles.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Basketball Soviet Team Loses in Finale: Winston Bennett sank two free throws with 17 seconds left last night to lift Kentucky to a 75-72 victory over the Soviet National team in Lexington. The loss marked the end of a 10-game tour by the Russians, who compiled a 6-4 mark against American college teams. Bennett was fouled while Kentucky was working for a final shot with the score tied at 72-all. (AP) Tennis Gomez and Gilbert Win: Top-ranked Andres Gomez of Ecuador and Brad Gilbert of the United States won their opening-round matches in Rio de Janeiro. Gomez, ranked ninth in the world, beat Derrick Rostagno, 6-3, 7-6, and Gilbert beat Roberto Saad of Argentina, 5-7, 7-6, 6-2.(AP)

title: A Thanksgiving Feast in Many Languages
description: At least a half-dozen of the kindergartners who took part in the Thanksgiving feast at Public School 162 in Bayside, Queens, yesterday had never tasted turkey before. Some did not have a word for it in their native language.

title: Black Leader Freed by Pretoria Gives the Rebels' Terms for Talks
description: A freed leader of the African National Congress, the main black nationalist rebel group, says the South African Government would have to drop all apartheid laws and its state-of-emergency powers before the group would be prepared to negotiate with it on the issue of political power.

title: Koch Asks Agencies to Prepare Budget Cuts
description: Citing the recent stock market collapse and fears of a slowdown in the national economy, Mayor Koch yesterday asked the heads of all city agencies to propose budget cuts for the next fiscal year.

title: Allied-Lyons Move
description: The British food and drink company Allied-Lyons P.L.C. said it would expand its 51 percent ownership and take full control of Hiram Walker-Gooderham & Worts Ltd., the Canadian distiller, in a cash and share deal worth $1.01 billion. Allied-Lyons is buying the interest from the Toronto-based GW Utilities Ltd. Under the deal, GW Utilities will acquire 10 percent of Allied-Lyons.

title: Opera's Constellation Is Fading
description: By all traditional measures except one, the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Trovatore'' with Joan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarotti is a bust.

title: Hutton Said to Weigh Sale of Some of Its Parts
description: The discussions about the sale of E. F. Hutton & Company have grown more complex, with the investment firm contemplating a dismemberment and the sale of its capital markets division separately from its retail brokerage system, according to Wall Street professionals close to Hutton.

title: Second Quake Hits California; Damage Slight
description: A strong earthquake rocked residences and injured about two dozen people in Southern California near the Mexican border this morning, just hours after the desert region was hit by a comparable tremor Monday night.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1987
description: International

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Picture captions on April 5 and Nov. 16, about the new United States Embassy compound in Moscow, misidentified the building shown at the left, behind the compound. It is an apartment building, not the Hotel Ukraina.

title: Stage: 'Boys Net Door' at Lamb's
description: IN ''The Boys Next Door,'' Tom Griffin has written a sweet-tempered comedy of social concern. The subject of his play (at the Lamb's Theater) is the mentally handicapped and their place in society. Mr. Griffin's principal characters are four young men living together in an apartment in a New England city. With the supervision of a social worker, the roommates are able, in varying degrees, to act as participating members in their own apartment and in the world at large.

title: Advertising; The National Enquirer Goes to D.M.B.&B.
description: The National Enquirer, which spends between $15 million and $20 million a year to sustain and increase its 4.5 million circulation, has put that advertising assignment in the hands of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, according to Patrick N. Linskey, the publisher.

title: FINANCIAL BENEFIT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses on investments of $338,000 for the quarter and $227,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and after gains on investments of $239,000 for the quarter and $1,177,000 for the 9 months.

title: OAKWOOD HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After about $4.4 million of after- tax chargeoffs. c-Net income

title: AMERICAN WOODMARK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Two Stars of 'Burn This' To Appear in Benefit
description: John Malkovich and Joan Allen, now starring on Broadway in of Lanford Wilson's ''Burn This,'' are to appear with the playwright at a benefit performance of three of Mr. Wilson's one-act plays on Dec. 6 at the Sanford Meisner Theater, 164 11th Avenue, between 22d and 23d streets.

title: New York Ordered to Find Care for Homeless Woman
description: A state judge yesterday directed New York City to discharge a 41-year-old woman who was picked up under a Koch administration program to involuntarily hospitalize severely mentally ill homeless people living on city streets.

title: DIGILOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Odorless Garlic: Admiration Isn't Universal
description: Two Japanese companies say they have a method of treating garlic so it does not linger on the breath, but some domestic growers say they are not impressed.

title: Day Care for Infants: Debate Turns to Long-Term Effects
description: While lawmakers face the issue of how society should respond to the growing demand for child care, researchers are engaging in a debate about the effects of day care on America's youngest citizens, the 3.7 million children under a year old.

title: REAGAN TO PRESS SENATE ON TREATY
description: President Reagan said today that he would begin a drive to win Senate approval for the emerging treaty to eliminate medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: Litton's Navy Pact
description: Litton Industries said it had received a $352.7 million contract to build an amphibious Navy assault ship at its yard in Pascagoula, Miss., where a similar vessel is being outfitted and a sister ship is in early stages of production. Construction on the third ship is not expected before 1989.

title: Court Is Picked For LTV Case
description: Federal District Judge Robert Sweet has ruled that a dispute over who has financial responsibility for the LTV Corporation's pensions would be litigated in Federal district court rather than bankruptcy court.

title: KIMBARK OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MAPLE LEAFS SLIP PAST ISLANDERS
description: Bill Smith talks the same way he tends goal. Language therefore is not much more than a stick with which to bluntly and effectively go about clearing away ambiguity.

title: CALSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $5,000 for the quarter and $118,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $36,000 and $190,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,113,000. c-Net loss

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Bankers Wanted
description: The World Bank, which has just laid off 10 percent of its staff in its deepest restructuring of the last two decades, is now putting out a ''help wanted'' sign to fill certain specialty posts, for example in environmental protection. But, according to its president, the bank is having trouble filling vacancies.

title: Domestic Vehicle Sales Slip
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks totaled 282,177 units in the second 10 days of November, down 2.1 percent from the comparable 1986 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a $1.8 million writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: The Larger Crime of False Arrests
description: Thomas Dargan's story of false arrests by the Transit Police does not involve dramatic allegations of torture or wrongful death as in other New York City police misconduct cases, but it would be a grim mistake to dismiss it as trivial. The false arrests feed a larger cynicism about the police that criminal justice officials in New York and elsewhere dare not ignore.

title: ENGLISH GREENHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

title: Wolf Creek Journal; Idealists With a Knack For Being Prosperous
description: More than a century after their ancestors settled here, the Hutterite people still live together in communes, speak German as a native tongue and teach their children that capitalism is inherently an evil system.

title: DEVON RESOURCES INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Advertising; A New Woman For Chanel
description: AFTER about eight years of doing without, Chanel No. 5 has a new woman.

title: Duarte Tries to Deal With Violent Legacy
description: El Salvador's frail political system is undergoing one of its most severe tests in recent years as it confronts challenges from the left and the right and an unresolved past of violence.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing; Senator Smoke
description: Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the top Republican on the Budget Committee, used to vow with each passing budget that he would give up smoking. He hasn't yet, and during the four weeks of tense negotiations that led to the budget-cutting compromise last Friday, he blew his smoke into a tiny machine designed to suck up nasty fumes.

title: NUI CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and includes writedowns of assets of $17,636,000 relating to oil and gas activities.

title: LEVER'S 14 ASSISTS HELP DEFEAT NETS
description: Lafayette Lever scored 21 points and had 13 rebounds and 14 assists tonight as the Denver Nuggets routed the New Jersey Nets, 132-104.

title: Rock: Aztec Camera
description: AZTEC CAMERA, a group led by the singer and songwriter Roddy Frame, brought a brisk, surprising show to the Ritz last Friday. The fragile, introspective lyricism that has been such a fundamental ingredient in Mr. Frame's recordings was overshadowed by slick, unsubtle pop-soul arrangements and relentless pacing. Even a brief solo set that found Mr. Frame alone with his guitar halfway through the show proceeded crisply and efficiently. Aztec Camera's albums encouraged one to expect a kind of upbeat Nick Drake; in this latest incarnation, the group has more in common with the Style Council.

title: Dollar Falls on Report of Deficit Plan Criticism
description: The dollar ended lower in active New York trading yesterday after a West German central banker reportedly said the deficit-reduction plan reached Friday fell far short of American commitments to its trading partners.

title: Hyundai Duty Set by Canada
description: Cars made by South Korea's Hyundai Motor Company are being dumped in Canada at unfairly low prices, Canada's Revenue and Customs Department said today in a preliminary ruling that puts an import duty on future imports. A department spokesman said that at current prices the duty would result in a 36 percent price increase on the cars. Hyundai, one of South

title: Cuomo Seeks Altered Schools Panel
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he would ask the State Legislature early next year to restructure the New York City Board of Education so that the Mayor would control it.

title: Advertising; People
description: William J. Liss is joining RJR Nabisco as senior vice president, public affairs.

title: Basic Costs Up For Cable Use
description: Deregulation of cable television rates has resulted in higher prices for basic service and a small drop in the cost of premium channels, an industry group survey has shown.

title: Another State Joins Right-to-Die Issue
description: One day soon, perhaps in a month or two if all goes as the family and its lawyer have asked, the Cruzans may be released from an ordeal that has seemed more tormenting than an endless prison sentence and sometimes as restrictive.

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CDI CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Year-ago second quarter and 6 months includes charges of $252,000 and $111,000, respectively, to account for investment tax credits that were eliminated under the new tax law. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August.

title: Horner May Return
description: Bob Horner, the former Atlanta Braves slugger who played baseball in Japan this year, might be coming home next season. The 30-year-old Horner said on Monday that he has been offered a contract to return to the Braves and that he no longer wants to play in the Japanese league. ''You grow up with an idea of what baseball should be,'' he said. ''Then you're forced to go halfway around the world to play something that isn't baseball. I'm glad I did it, and the Japanese people were good to me, but I'm ready to come back and play in the U.S.'' Horner, a free agent, played for the Yakult Swallows, a Tokyo team, after the Braves would not meet his contract demands and no other teams made offers. This year, he said, ''four of five other teams have been in touch with us.'' Horner played third base and later first base for the Braves.

title: Advantages of New Ski Lifts
description: OVER the last few years, words like quad, triple and detachable have crept into the skier's vernacular. The terms describe the design and mechanics of new ski lifts.

title: Keeping Most Likely Dropouts in School
description: For 95 dropout-prone students here, high school is in a hidden corner of a downtown department store and important lessons are as likely to come from a salesperson as from a teacher.

title: High Noon in El Salvador
description: Two brave experiments are under way in El Salvador, the bloodiest and most fragmented of the countries engaged in the Central American peace effort. Putting their skins at risk, a pair of exiled leftists have returned to test the reality of reconciliation. With matching boldness, no doubt to upstage his rivals, President Duarte is at last holding the violent right accountable for the 1980 murder of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero.

title: Fruit Fly Quarantine Lifted
description: The Agriculture Department has lifted an agricutural quarantine imposed in July to prevent the spread of Oriental fruit flies from parts of Los Angeles County and Orange County in California, the department said today. Department officials said recent trapping surveys indicated that the areas were free of the flies, which can destroy fruit and vegitable crops. The quarantine restricted the movement of about 100 kinds of fruits, nuts and vegetables that serve as hosts for the the flies.

title: Lynn Freeman Olson, Composer, Dies at 49
description: Lynn Freeman Olson, a composer of works for children, college students and television, died of cancer last Wednesday in New York City. He was 49 years old.

title: MLX CORP reports earnings for
description: b-Net income The company said the sales increase is due to the inclusion of the MLX refrigeration and air conditioning distribution group's operations acquired by MLX in October 1986.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Hold the Press

title: 3 EUROPEAN ALLIES REDUCE KEY RATES TO SPUR ECONOMIES
description: In a forceful sign of international economic coordination, the central banks of West Germany, the Netherlands and France today announced reductions in key interest rates to help spur their economies.

title: CUBAN PRISONERS IN ATLANTA TAKE 25 MORE HOSTAGES
description: In less than an hour early today, rioting Cuban inmates released five hostages from a prison in Atlanta, then seized another 25.

title: Wide Appeal Filed on Forced Caesarean Delivery
description: Thirty-nine organizations, including the American Medical Association, asked the District of Columbia Court of Appeals today to reconsider a ruling that a gravely ill pregnant woman could be forced to undergo a Caesarean delivery against her wishes.

title: KIDDIE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
First Chicago In Acquisition
description: To strengthen its position in consumer banking, the First Chicago Corporation said today that it had signed a letter to acquire the Gary-Wheaton Corporation for $136.4 million in First Chicago common stock.

title: Oslo and Bonn at Odds on New NATO Chief
description: Opposition from Norway has delayed the designation of Manfred Worner, the West German Defense Minister, as the next Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Western diplomats say.

title: 5 Invited for Heisman
description: Craig Heyward, the Pitt junior tailback who leads all Division I-A rushers with 1,655 yards in 11 games, was one of five players invited yesterday to the Heisman Trophy dinner Dec. 5 at the Downtown Athletic Club in New York. Also attending will be Tim Brown, the Notre Dame wide receiver; Lorenzo White, the Michigan State running back; Don McPherson, the Syracuse quarterback, and Gordie Lockbaum, the Holy Cross wide receiver and saftey.

title: INSIDE
description: The Education Page

title: AARON BROTHERS ART MARTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Pact Reached On Project In Times Sq.
description: New York State and city officials said yesterday that they had reached final agreement with the developer of four huge office towers that would anchor the controversial, long-delayed Times Square redevelopment plan. They said demolition of buildings at the intersection of 42d Street, Broadway and Seventh Avenue might begin early next year.

title: Advertising; Sport Care Is Planning A New Trade Magazine
description: Sport Care Inc. in Wilmington, Del., is planning a new trade publication called Sport Care and Fitness that will be sent free to 30,000 interested parties outside the health care field, such as coaches, trainers and operators of fitness clubs.

title: Arab Novelist Falls in Love With French
description: Tahar Ben Jelloun approves of polygamy - with languages, not women, he hastens to add. ''My wife is Arabic,'' the 43-year-old Moroccan novelist explained, ''and my mistress is French, and I maintain a relationship of betrayal with both of them.''

title: Open Positions on Nasdaq Short Sales Fall by 9%
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the number of shares sold short, and not yet covered, in the month ended Nov. 13 fell by 21.1 million, or 9 percent, to 213.2 million shares, from a revised 234.3 million shares in the previous month. The figures cover the late October period, in which stock prices plunged sharply.

title: Ford Completes Divestment in South Africa
description: The Ford Motor Company completed its disinvestment from South Africa today with a deal that involves donating a 24 percent equity interest in its former subsidiary to an employee trust.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1987
description: International A3-13 Agreement on an arms treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles was reached between the United States and the Soviet Union in negotaitions in Geneva. The treaty is scheduled to be signed in two weeks in Washington. Page A1

title: E.C.A.C. Bowl Canceled
description: Franklin and Marshall and Plymouth State have played - and won - too many times this season and will not be allowed to play for the Eastern College Athletic Conference football title. The first-ever E.C.A.C. Championship Bowl was canceled today when the schools discovered that National Collegiate Athletic Association rules prevented them from playing a 12th game.

title: Rate Cuts In Europe Spur Dow
description: Stock prices moved higher yesterday, after West Germany, France and the Netherlands said they were cutting certain key interest rates to bolster their economies.

title: The Pop Life
description: 2 Events for Island

title: Stage:'Puta Vida Trilogy,' One-Act Plays by Povod
description: IT isn't as easy as it once was for white middle-class theatergoers to get a quick fix of guilt, so there may well be a crying need for ''La Puta Vida Trilogy,'' the Reinaldo Povod bill of one-act plays at the Public Theater. In the evening's prologue, a hostile young Hispanic monologuist (Michael Carmine) waves a knife at the audience, accuses us of hating ''spics,'' and threatens to commit a random murder, possibly in our privileged neighborhoods, if his ailing offstage mother is allowed to die. Has there been a play this naked in its moral one-upsmanship since the late 1960's? ''La Puta Vida Trilogy'' (''This Bitch of a Life'') reminds me of nothing so much as Brian De Palma's satirical film ''Hi, Mom,'' in which a black-militant theater company earns the raves of a well-heeled Off Off Broadway audience by beating it up.

title: TEMPO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a pretax gain from the sale of cable systems of $2,035,000.

title: Brazil Debt Stance Upheld
description: Brazil's President Jose Sarney said in an interview published today that he would repeat a suspension of payments on his country's foreign debt if merited.

title: Books: View of Theater
description: THE SHIFTING POINT. By Peter Brook.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BIOTHERAPEUTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Investigation Continues
description: The Southwest Conference is investigating reports that Randy Thornton, a safety for the University of Houston, played in two football games this month while he was ineligible. Fred Jacoby, the conference commissioner, said yesterday that he could not say whether Houston would have to forfeit victories over the University of Texas and Temple University because of Thornton's possibly illegal participation.

title: A 1789 PROCLAMATION BY WASHINGTON... F.D.R.'S VIEW
description: In 1932, in the midst of the Depression, New York's Governor, Franklin D. Roosevelt, then President-elect, issued a Thanksgiving Day proclamation that included words from an old prayer: ''Remember in pity such as are this day destitute, homeless or forgotten of their fellow men.''

title: Bonds Only Collectors Love
description: Last month's stock market collapse may have left a trail of walking wounded on Wall Street, but it pales when compared with the financial flops of Victorian times. A reminder of those freebooting, all-or-nothing days surfaced Tuesday at Sotheby's, the London auction house, when a huge cache of 75,000 antique bonds was sold for about $630,000. The bonds were issued more than a century ago by a self-proclaimed nation, the Confederate States of America.

title: Jazz: Tribute to Lopez
description: ISRAEL (CACHAO) LOPEZ made lasting contributions to Latin music beginning in the late 1930's, when he helped introduce the hot Afro-Cuban rhythms of the mambo into the more urbane dance idiom known as the danzon.

title: County Ordered to Pay For Prisoner Abortions
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that a New Jersey county must pay for abortions for prison inmates if no other public or private financing is available.

title: Resignation At Texas Bank
description: The First Republicbank Corporation, the largest bank-holding company in Texas, with $33.6 billion in assets at the end of September, announced this week that one of its four vice chairmen, Ronald G. Steinhart, planned to resign at the end of the year.

title: Edelman Reduces Telex Bid
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, lowered his hostile bid for the Telex Corporation yesterday, to $55 a share, from $65, and reduced the shares he is seeking to 75 percent of the company.

title: After Quakes, Coping With Fear and Damage
description: Residents of Southern California struggled today to overcome fear and to repair damage from two severe earthquakes as aftershocks died down.

title: 2 Convictions Upset As Court Cites Police For Lack of Lineups
description: New York State's highest court overturned criminal convictions in two New York City cases today because police officers had allowed crime victims to identify suspects in situations other than police lineups.

description: BASEBALL
