description: b-Net loss

title: Erie Mills Prepares for Debut at Met
description: ''When I was 5,'' said Erie Mills, ''I thought I was going to be Shirley Temple. At 12 I wanted to be Barbra Streisand. I was certainly going the musical comedy route.''

SUN COAST PLASTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Comings and Goings
description: Terry Bross, a 6-foot-9-inch senior center for St. John's, suffered a ligament sprain of his right ankle during practice Monday and will be sidelined for a minimum of three weeks. Bross started 29 games last season, averaging 4.2 points and 3.6 rebounds per game. . . . The Air Force Academy has suspended indefinitely three of its basketball players - Eric Kjome, a junior forward; Chad Kimble, a junior center, and Jeff Bowling, a sophomore guard - for what Coach Reggie Minton called internal reasons. Air Force opens its season tomorrow night when it plays Manhattan College in the Freeedom Bowl Invitation in Irvine, Calif. . . . Gerald Murray, a basketball center for San Diego State University, has been arrested on drug charges for the second time in two months. He was charged with selling cocaine to an undercover police detective in San Diego Tuesday and is being held at the county jail on $10,000 bail.

title: Ultrasound Held to Detect Down's Syndrome
description: Doctors say they have found a way to use ultrasound tests to spot fetuses with Down's syndrome. But other experts warned that the technique should still be considered experimental.

title: G.M. Discounts
description: Three divisions of the General Motors Corporation announced new buyer incentive programs, with discounts ranging from $550 to $900 on selected models. The Pontiac division said buyers of Pontiac 6000's, Firebirds, Fieros, Safari wagons and Bonnevilles may choose either free air-conditioning or a $600 cash allowance; buyers of Pontiac Grand Ams qualify for discounts of $550 to $775, depending on the options package. The incentives for Grand Ams apply to those produced before April 1, and for other models up to Jan. 11. The Chevrolet division said buyers of 1988 Camaro and Celebrity cars may also choose between a $600 rebate and free air-conditioning; this offer expires on Jan. 11. Buyers of 1987 G-series vans qualify for $900 cash rebates; this offer expires on Jan. 31. The Oldsmobile division offered the free air-conditioning or $600 cash rebate to buyers of 1988 Cutlass Ciera and Cutlass Calais cars through Jan. 11, and for 1987 and 1988 Delta 88 cars through March 31.

title: HMG-COURTLAND PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

DEVILS TOP OILERS IN OVERTIME N.H.L.
description: Aaron Broten scored 13 seconds into overtime to give the New Jersey Devils an 8-7 victory over the Edmonton Oilers tonight.

title: REGENCY EQUITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of 3 cents a share for the quarter, and an extraordinary credit of 1 cent a share in the 9 months. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of 1 cent a share and 3 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the increase in net for the latest third quarter and 9 months was attributable substantially to a one-time dividend totaling about $9,655,000 of E-11 Holdings Inc. shares and a related cash distribution with respect to the company's indirect interest through a limited partnership in BCI Holdings Inc.

title: Home Resales Rise by 3.2%
description: Sales of existing homes climbed a surprising 3.2 percent in October, the biggest increase in five months, a real estate trade group said today.

title: CONVERGENT SOLUTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARCHITECT TRIES ON NEW SHOES
description: AT a recent lecture he delivered, the Princeton architect Michael Graves found that his shoes were attracting more than their share of interest. Not surprising, since Mr. Graves is appearing in an advertisement citing ''the significance of classic structures,'' in which footwear by the Dexter Shoe Company of West Newton, Mass., is paired with the architect's post-modernist ideas. According to Woody Kay, the co-creative director and executive vice president of Pagano, Schenck and Kay, the agency in Providence, R.I., that created the advertisement, the architect is one of those ''very interesting people who have had extraordinary success in their own field'' whom they will be using in their campaign. Others include Ted Williams, the legendary baseball player, and David Tedrick, a yacht designer. Mr. Graves readily agreed to the project. He said the company paid him ''some money'' for it and sent along a pair of boat shoes, and that was that. ''The only ad I've done,'' he said, adding that he and his staff ''rewrote some of the copy.'' After it appeared, ''there was a lot of grief from my peers,'' Mr. Graves conceded.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Barnett Banks Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., said it had extended its $70-a-share tender offer for the common shares of First Fulton Bancshares Inc. through Jan. 8.

title: Larry King's Interviews, on CNN
description: ''LARRY KING LIVE'' is a radio program that just happens to be on television. In fact, it suggests as much itself. When it begins each weekday night, on the Cable News Network at 9 o'clock, it does so without musical fanfare, fancy graphics or shouts and screams from an audience. Instead, we see a microphone, and then we see Mr. King, with his elbows on a desk. Immediately he gets to business. This may be Vice President George Bush, the airplane crash in Denver or the Penthouse pet of the year. The other night Mr. King interviewed the economist Milton Friedman and the actress Melissa Gilbert. The next night he devoted his entire program to the rioting by Cuban detainees. Mr. King is eclectic. He is also one of the best interviewers on television.

title: KEY RATES
Korea in Airline Talks
description: South Korea's Transport Ministry said today that it had held talks with several airlines that want to start service here before the 1988 Seoul Olympics. The interested airlines include British Airways, Air Canada and Dragon Air, which is based in Hong Kong, the officials said. In addition, All Nippon Airways of Japan, Gulf Air of the United Arab Emirates and Air-India are conducting studies on service to Seoul, the officials said. Delta Air Lines of the United States is scheduled to begin flying three flights a week to South Korea next month. Northwest Airlines and United Airlines already fly here.

description: b-Net income

title: CURBS ON SMOKING ARE STRUCK DOWN IN NEW YORK STATE
description: An emotional nine-month legal battle over stricter smoking regulations in New York State ended today as the state's highest court declared the regulations invalid because they had been issued without the approval of the Legislature.

title: When Shopping for a Down Comforter
description: SHOPPING for a down comforter can be a confusing proposition. Down bedding, often heavily promoted, is available in numerous versions and at many different price levels. To get the best value, the wise shopper should be armed with as many facts as possible before setting out.

title: Italians Strike Against Deficit-Cutting Drive
description: Italy's labor federations staged a nationwide general strike today in an attempt to unify their fractured ranks with a protest against the Government's deficit-reduction program.

Protecting Family Assets: A New Breed of Medicaid Counselors Steps In

title: U.N. Chief May Drop Gulf Cease-Fire Effort
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar may abandon his effort to negotiate a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war if an Iranian diplomat does not arrive here for talks by next week, United Nations officials and diplomats say.

description: International A2-13, A32

title: Colangelo Won't Sell
description: Jerry Colangelo, the president of the Phoenix Suns, who headed a group that bought the National Basketball Association club for a record $44.5 million last month, said he would turn down an offer to sell the team for $60 million. Colangelo said he received the offer Tuesday from an out-of-town businessman he would not identify.

title: VANDERBILT GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes $1,308,000 in restructuring costs due to mergers completed in the first quarter of 1987. c-Net income and for the 9 months includes a $1,724,000 gain from the sale of investments.

title: Francis Keil Decker, Lawyer, 84
description: Francis Keil Decker, a lawyer active in Westchester County civic affairs, died of leukemia Monday at his home in Somers, N.Y. He was 84 years old.

title: Restraint Urged Amid Confusion Ruling Atlanta
description: Hours after a team of Army advisers arrived at the Federal Penitentiary here today, one of the hostages being held in the prison hospital urged officials not to do ''anything foolish'' because rebellious Cuban inmates ''are willing to take us down if they have to die.''

title: MAGMA COPPER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,091,000 and $3,984,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: For Sheik Yamani, Oil Is Not a Topic
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the elusive and legendary force behind Arab oil domination, turned up at Harvard Law School the other night to make his longest public statement since being ousted a year ago as Saudi Arabia's oil minister.

title: TV Reviews; Jerome Kern's Music at White House
description: THIS year's series of ''In Performance at the White House,'' a classy public-television photo opportunity for Washington's top political echelons, has been focusing exclusively on popular American composers. George Gershwin was one. Cole Porter was another. And now, tonight at 10 on Channel 13, there is Jerome Kern (1885-1945). According to a joint resolution passed years ago by Congress, Kern is ''the father of American musical theater.''

title: SIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the sales increase is primarily due to the acquisition of its franchisor, Sisters International Inc., in April.

title: NBC Is Said to Seek 25% of Turner Broadcasting
description: The National Broadcasting Company and the Turner Broadcasting System are discussing a deal in which NBC would buy about 25 percent of the cable television network and entertainment company for approximately $400 million, people familiar with the talks said yesterday.

title: VEGA BIOTECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the net loss in the latest 6 months is primarily due to a $209,000 writeoff in the first quarter as a result of a terminated public offering.

title: Avram Weiss Plays Handel, Grieg and Bach
description: The first notes of Avram Weiss's violin recital at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday evening - the vaulting arpeggio that opens Handel's familiar D major sonata - bespoke musical confidence and authority, and these qualities stayed with him through the evening, even though it quickly became apparent that technical problems would limit his expression.

title: Simms Will Probably Start for Giants
description: When the Giants play the Redskins Sunday in Washington, the starting quarterbacks will be Doug Williams for the Redskins and probably Phil Simms for the Giants.

title: The Woman in the Race Gives Korea a Jolt
description: Barring miracles, which occur with about as much frequency here as anywhere else, Hong Sook Ja will not become South Korea's next President.

title: Ward in Talks On Investigating Subway Arrests
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward met with the acting chief of the New York City transit police yesterday to begin an investigation into accusations that four transit police officers made scores of false or improper arrests in the subways in 1983 and 1984.

title: Kew's Faceted Conservatory Is Home to 10 Microclimates
description: The gale that ripped across southern England on Oct. 16 hit Kew Gardens in west London just before 4 A.M. By sunrise the magnificent 300-acre garden was scarcely recognizable. About 1,000 trees had been destroyed or badly damaged.

title: INACOMP COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Haiti Vigilantes Lynch 4 Men Suspected of Election Terror
description: As election officials, hampered by violence and a lack of government support, struggled today to organize the presidential elections scheduled for Sunday, neighborhood defense groups lynched four men suspected of anti-election terrorism.

title: Cambridge Journal; M.I.T. Faces a Problem And Can't Find Answer
description: It should have been an evening for doing physics problems in the library, or listening to the new Stevie Wonder album or heading down the street to Toscanini's to sample some of its renowned Grand Marnier ice cream.

description: The John Fluke Manufacturing Company, which makes electronic test and measurement instruments, said yesterday that George Winn had been named chief executive.

description: The mutual fund industry absorbed, rather than increased, much of the pressure to liquidate giant holdings of stocks on Oct. 19 by using billions of dollars in cash reserves to meet shareholder redemptions, the industry's trade group said today.

title: Bomb Goes Off in Kuwait
description: An explosion apparently caused by a small bomb ripped through a building housing an American insurance company in downtown Kuwait today, the Kuwaiti news agency reported. There were no casualties.

description: Following is a Thanksgiving Proclamation issued by George Washington on Oct. 3, 1789.

title: Ben C. Birdsall, Retired Arizona Judge, 64
description: Ben C. Birdsall, a retired judge who presided over two of Arizona's most publicized criminal cases, died Sunday of cancer. He was 64 years old.

description: Two suspects in a dozen muggings at the 23d Street PATH station in Manhattan were arrested yesterday by the Port Authority Police, officials said.

title: Pro Hockey Notebook; 18-Year-Old Sabre Is Making Transition
description: Pierre Turgeon's English is still slightly broken, a reality that can often confound reporters during his first National Hockey League season. Thankfully, he admits with a laugh, there hasn't been all that much to explain, certainly nothing for which to apologize. His transition on the ice has been quietly fluent.

title: Audelco Awards Given For Black Theater
description: Three productions won four awards each at the 15th annual Audelco Recognition Awards last week. The prizes are presented by the Audience Development Committee to honor excellence in black theater.

title: Fire Unions Sue Over Koch Emergency Plan
description: New York City's firefighter and fire officer unions filed a joint lawsuit yesterday challenging Mayor Koch's decision to subordinate the Fire Department role to the police role at all emergencies except fires.

title: HERS
description: A NEW friend has asked me why my oldest friends are also my political adversaries.

title: Expert at Assault Trial Says Drug Was Factor
description: A toxicologist called by the defense in the Howard Beach murder trial testified yesterday that Michael Griffith had been under the influence of cocaine when he dashed to his death on the Belt Parkway.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Embassy Row; Executive of Apartheid, Advocate of Reform
description: It is always a frustrating experience for opponents of the South African Government when Pretoria's representatives do not defend the very system they administer.

title: Riots Discomfit the Cubans of Miami
description: ''It's no good for my people,'' Jose Lopez said today of the uprisings of Cuban detainees at Federal prisons in Atlanta and Louisiana, echoing the feelings of many of the 650,000 Cuban-Americans who call Miami home.

title: SEAFOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will take no invasive steps so long as the hostages are not harmed. My patience is endless.'' - J. Michael Quinlan,director of the FederalBureau of Prisons, on theAtlanta prisoner rebellion. [ D17:4. ]

title: Talking Deals; Premium's Size In Takeovers
description: WHEN stock prices tumbled Oct. 19, many a takeover expert went back to the drawing boards. After all, a company is only worth its value on the stock exchange and the extra premium a potential acquirer is willing to pay.

title: I.O.C. Puts Out Warning
description: Countries that accept Olympic invitations and then decide to boycott the Games face the punishment of not being invited to the next Olympics, according to Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee.

Winter Palace 'Stormed' Only in a Soviet Movie
description: To the Editor:

Orders for Durables Up by 0.3%
description: Orders for big-ticket durable goods edged up three-tenths of 1 percent in October with much of the strength coming from a sharp jump in demand for civilian aircraft, the Government reported today.

title: Family of Slain Youth Files Negligence Suit
description: The family of a 16-year-old boy killed on a camp trip last year filed suit against the camp and the parents of the accused murderer yesterday, charging them with negligence in allowing the alleged killer to attend camp despite his history of violent behavior.

title: Chess Game Adjourned; Draw Likely
description: The 17th game of the world chess championship between Gary Kasparov and the challenger, Anatoly Karpov, was adjourned today after 42 moves.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Human Rights; U.A.W. Takes a Look At Pretoria's Justice
description: For several years, Washington has struggled, without great success, over how best to spur changes in South Africa's apartheid Government. In September 1986, it imposed an array of penalties against Pretoria, including denial of bank loans to South African Government agencies, a ban on strategic mineral imports and a cessation of direct airline flights.

title: A Quiz on Victorian Silver: Test Your Tableware Knowledge
description: SOMETIME after the dawn of civilization and before the invention of plastic and Styrofoam, there was a glorious period when human beings ate and drank with utensils made of silver.

title: Reality and the Light Fantastic
description: He is elegant, whether fox-trotting in a sleek tuxedo or doing the twist in fashionably baggy clothes, his face wreathed in a tantalizingly inscrutable smile. She is elegant, waltzing through the night in a cloud of marabou feathers and wistful fragility. He is Pierre Dulaine. She is Yvonne Marceau. Romance is in the air at the Joyce Theater, where the two are performing with the American Ballroom Theater through Sunday.

description: b-Net income

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Monday, about Manufacturers Hanover's plans to offer mutual funds to customers, misstated the timing of Chase Manhattan Bank's activity.

title: Bogota Moves Drug Suspect
description: A reputed drug baron, Jorge Luis Ochoa, was secretly transferred from one army barracks to another on Tuesday night for fear that his lieutenants might try to help him escape, the Colombian press said. Since his capture on Saturday, the Colombian police say they have detected the arrival in Bogota of a large number of people linked to the Medellin cartel said to be responsible for 80 percent of the cocaine exported from Colombia.

title: ASHES OF GARBAGE ARE FOUND TOXIC
description: Ashes from incinerated garbage contain significant amounts of lead, cadmium, dioxin and other toxic substances that can threaten health and the environment, according to a report prepared for the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Parents Held in Burglary
description: A man served as a lookout and his wife drove a getaway car as the couple sent their 10-year-old son to hold up an audio store Tuesday night, the police said. The couple were being held today on charges of burglary, criminal conspiracy and corruption of a minor. They were identified as Howard Bucahanon, 34, and his wife, Stormy Bucahanon, 29. The boy and two other sons were turned over to the juvenile authorities.

title: Philippine Typhoon Devastates Province; Toll Is Put at 1,600
description: A typhoon struck the main Philippine island today, and a Roman Catholic priest said that local authorities and church groups put the number of dead at 1,600 in the province hit hardest.

title: PARENTS CHARGED IN DEAH OF YEAR-OLD GIRL
description: The parents of a year-old Brooklyn girl who died earlier this week of malnutrition, pneumonia and dehydration were arrested last night and charged with criminally negligent homicide, the police said.

description: b-Net loss

The company also said the latest 9-month loss is primarily attributable to losses incurred in the vision division prior to the acquisition. Since the acquistion of Tristar and Office Automation was accounted for as a purchase transaction, the Compucom Systems division operating results are included from July 1, 1987.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A sleekly dressed woman in her 30's thought it odd when the physician she consulted about her frequent headaches asked if she usually tried to hold in her stomach. The resulting muscular tension, he told her, could cause the pain in her head. She has since allowed herself to show a little belly and, much to her surprise, has been virtually headache-free.

title: Giants Sign LaCoss
description: Mike LaCoss, a right-handed pitcher whose 13 victories for the San Francisco Giants was the highest total on the National League Western Division pennant winner's staff last season, has signed a two-year contract with the Giants, whose longest agreements are for that length. ''He's very competitive and always ready to take the ball, and having him for two years pleases me,'' said Al Rosen, the general manager. This past season, the second for LaCoss with the Giants, the 31-year-old native of Glendale, Calif., pitched 184 innings in 39 games, turning in a 13-10 won-lost record and a 3.68 earned run average.

title: Sentence Pared in Home State Case
description: The former president of the Home State Savings Bank had his prison sentence reduced today in return for guilty pleas to four charges resulting from the savings and loan institution's 1985 collapse.

title: U.S. Judge Steps Aside In P.L.O. Office Case
description: Citing a possible conflict of interest, Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin today stepped down from a case on whether the Government should be allowed to close an information office for the Palestine Liberation Organization here because the organizastion advocates terrorism.

title: Collapse Fails to Stop An Investment Team
description: John K. Castle and Leonard M. Harlan, with their new company and financing in place, are all set to start making leveraged buyout deals. But is this a good time, in the wake of the stock market collapse, to be starting a buyout company?

title: For Travelers, An Evening Of Miseries
description: The food in the snack bar sold out, not to mention the beer. The power failed, and the passengers sat in darkness. A conductor said anyone who left the train would be electrocuted.

title: 5 Reagan-Gorbachev Sessions Are Planned in Summit Talks
description: President Reagan's summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev will include five direct meetings as well as a state dinner at the White House, the Administration announced today.

title: Howard U. Sues, Asks Playoff Halt
description: As expected, Howard University sued the National Collegiate Athletic Association today and asked a Federal judge to stop the Division I-AA playoffs this weekend because its team, with a 9-1 record, was excluded.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Becker Advances: Boris Becker defeated Claudio Pistolesi of Italy, 6-1, 6-2, in a second-round match yesterday at the $150,000 Young Masters tournament in Friedrichshafen, West Germany. The 20-year-old West German, who served several aces and was in total control of the match, has won all three of the previous Young Masters tournaments in Friedrichshafen.(AP) Racing Sound Reasoning Is Winner: Sugar Maple Farms' Sound Reasoning led virtually from wire to wire yesterday and scored a one-length victory in the $44,000 Dresden Doll Purse at Aqueduct. Timed in 1:11 4/5, Sound Reasoning finished in front of the favorite, Spring Beauty. Left Court finished third in the six-furlong race for fillies and mares 3 years old and up. All carried 115 pounds. It was the fourth victory in eight starts for Sound Reasoning, who paid $24.20 for $2 to win.(AP) Bowling McGerr Takes Early Lead: Kevin McGerr of Lincoln, Neb., took the early lead after the first round of the $150,000 Budweiser Classic yesterday in Columbus, Ohio. McGerr, who never has won a Professional Bowlers Association title, knocked down 1,367 pins in six games for a 227.8 average. Chris Warren of Dallas, held second place, 17 pins back with a pinfall of 1,350. Steve Lang of Indianapolis, also a nonwinner on the tour, was third with a 1,327 total.(AP)

description: Year-ago results are restated.

Thank-You Notes
description: IN a prelude to Thanksgiving Day thank-you notes to sports people here several years ago, it was suggested that certain villains should be ignored on this holiday. About a week later, one of the principal villains who had been mentioned was heard to say:

title: Ex-Manhattan,inc. Aide Joining Alfred A. Knopf
description: Jane Amsterdam, a founding editor of Manhattan,inc., will join Alfred A. Knopf as a senior editor, according to an announcement yesterday from Sonny Mehta, president of Knopf.

title: NORTH AMERICAN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Prior year figures are not comparable because the company went public in May 1986 and has made acquisitions since then.

title: Potential Buyer For Shoe-Town
description: Shoe-Town Inc., a discount footwear chain, said a potential buyer had indicated an interest in the company. The news sent Shoetown shares up $1.625, to $7, on the New York Stock Exchange. At yesterday's closing price, the sale price would be about $75 million. Shoe-Town, which operates 200 stores in 11 states, earned $5.5 million last year on sales of $142.4 million.

title: LAUREN SHEETS HAVE 40'S CHIC
description: THE introductions of the new bed linens that will be in stores next season are never modest. Extravagantly dressed beds in showrooms are meant to transport buyers into never-never land, far from the humdrum of budgets and thread counts. The crop introduced this month was no exception. For his first foray into sheet design Hubert de Givenchy, Martex's celebrity catch, journeyed to a French chateau, while at J.P. Stevens the English designers Susan Collier and Sarah Campbell chose Morocco. But one collection proved that home is really where the heart is -the Ralph Lauren Home Collection's evocative Bungalow, presented in a setting suggesting ''The Honeymooners'' at the seaside. There were fly swatters and flypaper, a housedress draped over a lawn chair, a spiky plant in a chamber pot, an old Coca-Cola cooler, flower-covered linoleum and the kind of refrigerator that kept people awake at night. As for the sheets and comforters: pale green stripes, nearly faded flowers and funky thrift-shop patterns with names like Arcadia. And, above, Heartland - they are especially nice, too.

title: THE HAMMACHER GADGETEERS
description: After trying out a few thousand possibilities, Hammacher Schlemmer & Company has come up with its annual list of Christmas surprises - for instance, the new remote-control videocassette recorder for the forgetful viewer that can be programmed by telephone, and the ski helmet for the tuned-in sportsman that comes with its own built-in two-way radio.

description: b-Net income

description: The year-ago share earnings not available; the company went public in April.

title: Cuban Refugees Adjust to Life in Jersey
description: After hearing another news report of the prison rebellions by Cuban inmates fearing deportation, Jose Follaco vividly recalled his 21 months in prison upon his arrival in this country from Mariel.

title: 2 Seized in Sale of Counterfeit Eau de Toilette
description: A counterfeiting operation that made and distributed eau de toilette fragrance purported to be Opium, by Yves St. Laurent Perfumes, has been broken up with the arrest of two men, Federal authorities announced yesterday.

title: TIME MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Security Pacific
description: Security Pacific Corporation said it would consolidate the administrative functions of its three international securities operations. As part of that integration, Anthony Greayer, the chief executive of Hoare Govett Ltd., the London stock trader primarily owned by the bank holding company, has resigned. An unspecified number of other senior positions may also be affected, Susan B. Taha, a spokeswoman, said. Under the consolidation, Security Pacific intends to buy the remaining 15 percent of Hoare Govett for about $20 million. The London holding company for Security Pacific's merchant bank will now be responsible for international interests, which had operated independently. Besides Hoare Govett, these include McIntosh Securities Ltd. of Australia and the Burns Fry Corporation of Toronto, in which Security Pacific has a 30 percent stake.

title: Mayor of Charlestown, W.Va., Steps Down
description: Mayor James E. (Mike) Roark has resigned, fulfilling the agreement he made with Federal prosecutors in pleading guilty last week to charges of possessing cocaine.

title: Chicago's Mayor Washington Dies After a Heart Attack in His Office
description: Harold Washington, the first black Mayor of Chicago, the nation's third largest city, died today of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: Europe May Lift Steel Quotas
description: The European Community proposed today to scrap quotas for most steel products by July 1988 and return the industry to free-market competition.

title: Holiday Today: Many Closings
description: Businesses, banks, exchanges and government offices will be closed today for Thanksgiving.

title: Bird Returns as Celtics Pound Hawks
description: Larry Bird, back after a four-game absence with Achilles' tendinitis, came off the bench and sparked a decisive spurt in the fourth quarter tonight, helping the Boston Celtics to a 117-102 victory over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: 2 Killed by Tornado in Texas
description: Two people were killed and two others were injured by a tornado that swept across a rural area of the central Texas coast today, ripping the roofs off houses, tearing apart trees and pushing cars off roads. Officials said a 10-year-old girl and a 23-year-old woman died when the tornado struck a mobile home about six miles east of Bay City. Two children were hospitalized, a 3-year-old boy who was listed in stable condition and a 7-month-old boy who was in good condition.

title: BIOSEARCH MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains of $95,908 and $122,309 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the early retirement of convertible subordinated notes, and tax credits of $50,500 for the quarter and $248,100 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after tax credits of $87,800 and $252,900 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: U.S. to Send Official Delegation To Observe Haiti's Voting Sunday
description: President Reagan will send an official delegation to Haiti this weekend to observe its first presidential election in 30 years, the White House announced today.

title: Armed Forces Report Safe Aviation Records
description: For the second year in a row the armed forces had unusually safe flight records, but the number of deaths rose despite the relatively low number of accidents, reports show.

title: Connecticut Official To Challenge Weicker
description: State Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman, a Democrat, said today that he would run for the United States Senate seat now held by Lowell P. Weicker Jr. Mr. Lieberman did not formally declare his candidacy, saying he would do that early next year. Instead, he announced the formation of a committee that will let him start raising funds for the 1988 campaign.

title: Oral Roberts Recuperates
description: Oral Roberts, the television evangelist, was recovering today at home after receiving a corneal transplant Monday, a spokesman said. Dr. James Winslow, the spokesman, said the evangelist received a new cornea for his left eye in an out-patient procedure at City of Faith Medical and Research Center.

title: Seton Hall Savors Its Victories in N.I.T.
description: College basketball tournaments usually rely on either glamour teams or local teams for box-office appeal. The Big Apple National Invitation Tournament is down to just local appeal - Seton Hall.

title: Fire Strands Commuters At Rush Hour
description: Tens of thousands of commuters heading home from New York City for the Thanksgiving holiday were stranded yesterday evening when a smoky electrical fire forced officials to halt rail service on three major railway lines.

title: ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said results include the operations of NCA Corp., which was acquired effective Aug. 19.

NYTEST ENVIRONMENTAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Irish Aid Funds for Ethiopia
description: Ireland announced today that it would provide $375,000 in emergency aid for Ethiopia. The Irish Foreign Ministry said the funds would be chaneled through Red Cross and United Nations relief agencies. ''Indications are that the situation could be as bad as in the 1984-1985 famine when an estimated one million people died,'' it said.

title: Erick Hawkins to Get Scripps Dance Award
description: Erick Hawkins is to receive the 1988 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award. Mr. Hawkins will be given the award, established to honor American modern dance choreographers who have made a lifetime contribution to the art form, in a presentation ceremony and performance on June 15 at the festival in Durham, N.C.

title: MSA REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $335,000.

title: Jog Away Jet Lag? Maybe?
description: Humans suffering from jet lag, their nervous systems battered by the unreasonable sunlight of a new time zone, may want to consider the recent experience of 20 hamsters at the University of Toronto. A single three-hour round of exercise - running on a wheel in a cage - allowed hamsters to adjust to a severe case of jet lag surprisingly fast, within a day and a half. Hamsters left alone took eight days to recover.

title: AMERICAN HEALTH PROPERIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the 9 months represents year-to-date; year-to-date results reflect only 40 days of operations in the first quarter, which followed the company's inception Feb. 20.

title: Endless Questions, Loving Answers
description: LEAD: MY grandmother taught me about time. Not clock time, but what Octavio Paz refers to as ''original time,'' which ''rests on its own infinity,'' that space in which we do what we do until it's complete. I spent quite a lot of my childhood in my grandmother's company. There was no press, no urgency. She had time, great, glorious swatches of it, and she gave me armfuls of this silken substance.

title: CANDIDATES SPLIT ON MISSILE TREATY
description: Presidential candidates took sharply differing views of the treaty to eliminate shorter- and medium-range nuclear missiles today, underscoring a dispute that is expected to take on increased intensity in the 1988 campaign.

title: Dr. Edgar Berman Is Dead at 68; Writer and Humphrey Confidant
description: Dr. Edgar Berman, an author, newspaper columnist, surgeon and personal physician to former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey, died of a heart attack yesterday at Sinai Hospital in Baltimore. He was 68 years old.

title: Sudan Seeks Write-Off
description: The Sudan said today that it had called on creditors to write off foreign loans or ease repayment terms in a new bid to reduce its $11 billion debt and a growing threat of mass starvation. Finance Minister Beshir Umar Muhammad said the impoverished African nation, which has been unable to meet debt repayments in full since the early 1980's, wanted all loans by foreign governments canceled. The country was $2.6 billion in arrears on debt repayments at the end of June.

title: WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: The Two Americas
description: When we celebrate Thanksgiving, the America we think of is a generous country, optimistic, open. It is the self-confident country that Thomas Jefferson had in mind when he said in his first inaugural:

title: Bilson and Nelson In Early-Music Series
description: The ghost of ''early music'' as a semi-amateur activity descended now and then at the sometimes fine concert in Merkin Concert Hall's ''On Original Instruments'' series Monday evening. In the last section of Schubert's ''Shepherd on the Rock,'' Malcolm Bilson hit a left handful of wrong notes on his replica of an 1815 Dulcken piano, Judith Nelson hit a tentative sounding high note and looked uncomfortable about it, and Lawrence McDonald flubbed the final flourish on his early 19th century clarinet. All three made beautiful, apt, transparent sounds, but reminded us at the same time where the responsibility for music-making, on whatever instruments, really lies.

title: Knicks Finally Win on Road
description: Mark Jackson and Kenny Walker led an 18-7 surge in the fourth quarter tonight as the Knicks defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 104-101.

title: Unwrapping Of Enigmas; Long After Spy Plane, Soviet Opens Its Door

title: N.F.L. Matchups; 49ers vs. Browns May Be a Super Bowl Preview
description: Of all the games in one of the biggest television weeks in National Football League history, the Browns-49ers matchup Sunday night might be the best: it could be a preview of Super Bowl XXII.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: NORMAN ROCKWELL'S famous painting of a Thanksgiving dinner makes a lot of children uncomfortable. Everyone at the table - with the probable exception of the turkey, who was given no voice in the matter -looks as if he or she belongs.

title: Met Asks Obraztsova To Join 'Trovatore' Cast
description: Elena Obraztsova, the Soviet mezzo-soprano who has been absent from the Metropolitan Opera for eight years because of the suspension of cultural exchanges following the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, will return to the house next week. She will sing Azucena in ''Il Trovatore'' with Joan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarotti on Tuesday, on the evening of Dec. 5, and on Dec. 10.

title: Storm Leaves Woodlands In Shambles
description: From the Taconic State Parkway, Ray Helm's pine plantation looks as if it was attacked by a maniac wielding a chain saw. What was once a lush, seven-acre pine forest on a gentle hill is now a field of jagged stumps.

title: Talks With Cubans in Louisiana Go On as Siege Is Said to Stabilize
description: The standoff at a Federal detention center here, where Cuban refugees are holding 28 hostages, continued for the fourth day today.

title: 6 Are Accused In Racial Fight At High School
description: A Brooklyn grand jury has charged six black youths with a series of misdemeanors, including aggravated harassment and rioting, in what the police described as a racial disturbance outside a high school in June.

title: Stranger Shakes Up Honolulu Politics
description: A mysterious lawyer with a checkered past comes to Hawaii from the mainland and wins a dramatic fraud suit against the powerful silver-haired Mayor of Honolulu, threatening his anticipated bid for re-election.

title: Icahn to Get Big Block Of Texaco
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. agreed yesterday to pay $348 million for 12 million shares of Texaco stock and the voting rights of an additional 12.1 million shares.

title: 6 Found in Nursing Home Filth, Florida Says
description: Six elderly people, one with deformities caused by neglect, others who had been found strapped into urine-soaked chairs, have been placed in state custody after being removed from an unlicensed nursing home, state officials say.

title: Metro Matters; TV in the Court: Titillation Or Education?
description: Stephen Murphy, a defense lawyer in the Howard Beach trial, was asked yesterday whether the presence of television cameras in the courtroom would inspire him to behave any more flamboyantly than he already does. ''Get serious,'' Mr. Murphy grinned. ''I don't think you could be more flamboyant than I usually am without getting the judge down off the bench with me,'' he said. ''If there were cameras in here it would have no effect on me whatsoever. If television cameras cover the summations, people would hear the nuts and bolts of this trial for the first time.''

title: Triangle Stake Being Sold
description: The Primerica Corporation announced today that it had agreed to sell its entire common stock investment of nearly five million shares of Triangle Industries to CJI Industries.

title: Harold Washington's Chicago
description: Mayor Harold Washington of Chicago, who died yesterday at 65, loved to tweak political enemies and delight supporters by declaring, ''I'm going to be Mayor of the City of Chicago for 20 years.'' After his re-election to a second term last spring, it looked as if he might. Now, with his sudden death, assessments are in order, and they underline an important point: More than race, problems of the underclass are the challenge for city governments today.

title: SIZELER PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in January.

title: Bridge: Partners From Middle West Lead Blue Ribbon Pair Event
description: A mixed pair from the Midwest was in the lead at the midpoint of the prestigious Blue Ribbon Pair Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals here tonight.

title: COLLEAGUES APPLAUD JACOBI'S QUIET CRAFT
description: When Derek Jacobi opened on Broadway in ''Breaking the Code'' last week, his performance in the starring role won praise not only from the critics, but also from his peers - among them an opening night audience that included such actors as Bernadette Peters, Frank Langella, Jeremy Irons, Sinead Cusack, Jim Dale, Rex Harrison and Simon Jones.

title: Translation Prize Awarded
description: Richard Howard, poet, translator and critic, has been awarded the annual translation prize by the French-American Foundation for his English version of George Duby's ''William Marshal: The Flower of Chivalry,'' published by Pantheon Books. An honorable mention was given to Nancy Amphoux for her translation of ''Cat's Grin'' by Francois Maspero, published by Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Edward Maxwell, 77, Real-Estate Executive
description: Edward C. Maxwell, a realty and economic development executive, died of prostate cancer Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 77 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Deaver Said to Give Message From Reagan to Top Korean
description: A former ambassador to South Korea testified today that Michael K. Deaver handed a letter from President Reagan to the President of South Korea when Mr. Deaver was soliciting Seoul as a private lobbying client.

title: Rangers Are in Control As They Defeat Leafs
description: There hadn't been much for the Rangers to feel invincible about of late. In the course of winning just twice in their previous 12 games, they had rarely been in charge of any contest. Last night at the Garden, however, a sense of composure characterized their play against the Toronto Maple Leafs and helped them put together their first two-game winning streak after more than a month of unhappiness and, at least in the standings, regression.

title: C. Gordon Lamude, Lawyer, 84
description: C. Gordon Lamude, a lawyer, died of bronchial pneumonia Saturday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 84 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Tiny House, Big Design
description: ARTHUR ANDERSSON faced a formidable challenge when he and Charles Moore bought their sloped, woody site in Austin, Tex. Not many young architects build a house within swimming distance of their mentors. There were also ''some unwritten rules,'' said Mr. Andersson, who runs Mr. Moore's Austin studio.

title: Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK Parade: Begins at 9 A.M. at 77th Street and Central Park West. Proceeds down Central Park West to Columbus Circle and then down Broadway to 34th Street. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No refuse collection or street sweeping. Government offices: Federal, state and municipal offices closed. Post offices: Closed. Banks: Option to open. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on holiday schedule, but with extra trains. Schools: Closed today and tomorrow. Libraries: Closed. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Federal offices closed. State and municipal offices closed today and tomorrow. Post offices: Closed. Banks: Closed. Transportation: N.J. Transit on holiday schedule. Schools: Closed today, most closed tomorrow. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Federal and state offices closed. Municipal offices closed, some closed tomorrow. Post offices: Closed. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed today and tomorrow.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: BRIEFING
description: No Joke For the last several years, creators of some of the best-known comic strips have marked Thanksgiving Day by giving those strips a serious message about people who are hungry. The effort moved off the funny pages today, with a number of prominent editorial cartoonists using their spots on the nation's editorial pages to deliver a Thanksgiving message about the homeless. Beyond that, several of the cartoonists decided to leave their desks and come to Washington to serve a Thanksgiving dinner to the homeless in a park behind the Capitol.

title: Moscow Journal; At Co-op Cafe, More From Lenin Than Escoffier

He was yearning, he says, for the comforts of crisp napery, subtle ambiance and the ''dirty capitalist principles'' he now fondly emulates.

title: Social Worker Took Children of Deaf Woman
description: Two small children were taken from their mother, a 28-year-old deaf woman, and held in foster care for almost three weeks without authorization from the courts or the mother, New York City officials said yesterday.

title: Ovation for Knight
description: Bob Knight received a standing ovation from 2,700 Indiana University basketball boosters yesterday after saying he was wrong to pull his team off the floor in an exhibition game against the Soviet Union last Saturday. The Indiana coach did not mention the reprimand issued by the university the day before, nor was he asked about it when he took questions from the audience.

title: Going Crazy on Schools
description: What a week for the troubled New York City school system! Governor Cuomo suggests revamping the Board of Education, giving control to the mayor . . . Mayor Koch says he wants responsibility for the schools and wants to appoint a Hispanic to the board . . . board members call for its restructuring. Richard Beattie, one of the ablest members, resigns to make way for Mr. Koch's Hispanic appointee. Meanwhile, though Chancellor Nathan Quinones's retirement is now only five weeks away, the board has not yet considered final candidates to succeed him.

description: AFTER 350 years, the first play written about Don Juan -''El Burlador de Sevilla y El Convidado de Piedra'' (''The Rake of Seville and the Stone Guest'') by Tirso de Molina - still has more dramatic force than any other version of the famous story, and the stylish, modern-dress performance of it given in Spanish by the Repertorio Espanol at the Gramercy Arts Theater often exploits that power effectively.

title: Corrections
description: An article from Denver yesterday about President Reagan's drive to win Senate approval for a treaty banning medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles misstated the scope of the treaty. It would ban all such weapons in the American and Soviet arsenals, not just those based in Europe.

description: WOBBLY chairs are more than just annoying; a weakened chair can lead to accidents. Most wobbly chairs have broken glue joints. title: Holly Reconsiders
description: The Holly Sugar Corporation, after agreeing to a merger proposal from an investor group before the stock market's plunge, said it was discussing renegotiating terms of the $95-a-share, or $106.4 million, deal. Last month, Holly, based in Colorado Springs, had rejected a proposal from Plum Associates to lower the price of the acquisition to $85 a share in light of stock market volatility. The company's directors are now willing to reopen talks because Plum's financing arrangements are more advanced, making its proposal ''more convincing,'' one individual close to the talks said. A decision by Holly's directors could come as early as next week.

description: A New York court issued a ruling yesterday that could mean a return to the big-boat era in America's Cup yacht racing and force the next series to be held in 1988, three years earlier than expected.

title: The Stage: 'Memories,' A Comedy
description: PEARL CLEAGE'S ''Come and Get These Memories,'' which opens the repertory season of the Billie Holiday Theater in Brooklyn, is a type of comedy once popular in theater (it still is on television), in which the happy ending is everything, never mind how you get there. This one is much less than the sum of its parts, and when it works, it does so only because director and cast concentrate on the characters and treat the muddle of incident as a distraction best ignored when it can be.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some editions on Saturday about reduced radiation levels outside a Queens radium plant misstated the results of Geiger-counter measurements last September. At that time, the radiation was found to be as much as 40 times above what New York State regards as safe.

title: A DOCTOR TREATS ANTIQUE RADIOS
description: PETER THOMASHOW explained that by restoring old radios that he found in ''almost destroyed condition'' in flea markets and junk shops, he felt he was ''almost bringing them back from the dead.'' Dr. Thomashow is a psychiatrist who is also an artist, and his latest project has a twofold purpose. First, he puts the vintage radios -most date from the late 40's and the 50's - back into working order. Then he gives them a thorough facelift -sanding or stripping, painting, replacing speaker grilles and knobs, and adding such fanciful decorations as polka dots, stickers and colorfully painted computer chips. ''I call them techno-primitive artifacts,'' Dr. Thomashow said. ''They're a combination of old technology and new design flavor. Not only were the old radios in bad shape, but they were just too drab.'' His palette runs from primaries to pastels. ''In some cases I even try to create the Bakelite look,'' he added. Now that he has done quite a few radios, Dr. Thomashow is eyeing other objects. ''I may expand to all household appliances,'' he said. The radios, ranging in price from $175 to $800, are on view through Dec. 8 at Civilisation, 78 Second Avenue, between Fourth and Fifth Streets.

title: Boat Racer in Florida Charged in Drug Case
description: Benjamin Barry Kramer, an international powerboat racing champion and a builder of racing boats, was charged today in a 44-count indictment stemming from a Federal investigation into drug smuggling.

description: Following are excerpts from the New York State Court of Appeals decision striking down smoking rules imposed by the Public Health Council. The majority opinion was written by Judge Vito J. Titone and the dissent was written by Judge Joseph W. Bellacosa. MAJORITY OPINION

description: The Trailmobile Group of Companies, of Brantford, Ontario, intends to make a tender offer of $39 (Canadian), or about $29.70 (United States), for each of the outstanding shares of Fruehauf Canada, the company said.

description: This ancient city beside a placid Nile, long used to tending its plundered antiquity, has become embroiled in a modest effort to build a little modernity, too, so as to beautify the visage it presents to visitors when the sightseeing is done.

title: Editors' Note
description: A brief Associated Press article from Washington on Nov. 15 reported that Senator Jesse Helms had made public a letter from the chairman and vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee absolving the Senator and a staff member of having given sensitive intelligence information to the Government of Chile.

Certain positive illusions, the data suggest, promote a sense of well-being and happiness and the capacity for productive work.

title: IN MANHATAN, A TRIP TO THE TROPICS
description: IT'S not just the mix of merchandise, it's also the message. For overstressed New Yorkers, the next best thing to a trip to the tropics could be a stop at Tropica Island Traders, a new shop where the sights, sounds and smells that evoke distant isles include Hawaiian coffee; seashells; fresh orchids; painted wooden Balinese fish, left, and videos of rolling waves. The store is the result of the passion its owners, Lou and Nancy Serkez, feel for the tropics. ''In the way the islands were our respite, this shop makes people feel relaxed,'' Mrs. Serkez said.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I once saw an advertisement for door hinges that raise the door slightly as it opens so that it won't rub against carpeting or where there is weatherstripping along the bottom edge. Can you tell me where to find these hinges? A. You should be able to find them in some of the better hardware stores and lumberyards. Try those catering to professional builders and carpenters if you cannot find them in other stores. The hinges can also be ordered from mail-order houses like Constantine's, 2050 Eastchester Road, Bronx, N.Y. 10461; 212-792-1600. Outside New York, call 800-223-8087. Q. We are having a problem with the stall shower on the second floor. The ceiling in the room below shows water damage. About 25 years ago the tile floor in the shower was removed and the pan around the drain replaced. Since then the tiles have been regrouted every few years, but we have this persistent staining problem. What do you advise? A. It sounds as if the pan needs replacing again. It might pay to install a fiberglass shower pan; this type seems to last almost indefinitely. Q. My house is heated by hot water. A radiator on the top floor gets very little heat because it is only half filled with water. A plumber advised me to open the bleeder valve; he said it would take anywhere from a day to a month for the radiator to fill. I opened the valve four months ago, but the radiator is not filled. Can you give me any advice? A. he bleeder valve on a hot-water radiator is designed to let trapped air escape so that hot water can enter. Letting the air out should take only a few minutes, not days.

title: From North Korea: Faint Rays of Light
description: Is it possible to imagine a North Korea whose leaders admit their economic difficulties, acknowledge South Korea's successes and disavow the dream of reuniting the peninsula under their strange brand of Communism? That's the remarkable portrait painted by Selig Harrison, an American writer, in The New York Times last Sunday, after a recent stay in Pyongyang.

Though she was shown in 1983 and 1986 at the Salvatore Ala Gallery in New York, this is her first solo appearance in an American museum. In its thoughtful, reticent, nuanced and strikingly individual way, it is a great success.

title: EASTERN ENVIRONMENTAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Diner's Journal
description: THE wide-eyed curiosity seekers have been flocking to Sam's Restaurant, the latest American bistro by Mariel Hemingway and her family, in the Equitable Tower at 152 West 52d Street. (The other is Sam's Cafe, Third Avenue at 80th Street.) Opened just a month, the restaurant still has a good deal of fine tuning to do on its moderately priced menu, which focuses on pastas, pizzas and grilled meats and fish. Too many items come off the grills overcooked or cold from sitting at the waiters' station. Among the better options sampled on two recent visits were the bulbous golden crabcakes ($9.50) spiked with lots of pepper (the tomato chutney with it, though, is inedibly sweet), deftly grilled salmon ($17.50) and excellent lamb chops with grilled eggplant and pearl onions ($23).

At first it will all be in print - magazines probably - but before the end of the year there could be some dabbling in radio.

description: THE wild swings in the stock market last month, with a threatened ''meltdown'' on Black Monday and Terrible Tuesday, force attention to the question of what can be done to prevent crisis-born pessimism from jeopardizing the economy's real growth.

title: Cruise Missile Launched
description: An Air Force B-1B bomber has successfully launched a cruise missile for the first time, the Pentagon said Wednesday. In the test, conducted Tuesday at the Utah Test Range outside Salt Lake City, the plane fired the weapon from its bomb bay while flying at low altitude. The missile's warhead had been removed and replaced with an instrument test package. The jet-powered missile is designed to fly close to the ground to evade radar.

title: Advertising; Presidency Is Theme For A.I.G.
description: WHEN Michael Drexler, the agency media mogul, transferred his allegiance to Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt from Doyle Dane Bernbach he brought with him his concept of ''event media,'' a panacea for advertising clutter. His new bosses welcomed it.

title: Tuition Aid Program Helps to Retain Staff
description: When Herb Schervish, a Burger King restaurant owner, found that his employees were turning over almost as fast as the burgers on his grill, he thought of a way to get them to stay: pay their college tuition.

title: EAGLE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company went public in February.

title: New Face: Linda Hart; EVER THE SEXY GUN MOLL
description: ''IT'S the easiest thing I have ever done in my life, and the most fun.'' That is Linda Hart's report on her critically praised role as Erma the gun moll in ''Anything Goes,'' the Cole Porter revival at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: CUE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After tax credits of $246,000 for the quarter and $292,000 for the 9 months. There were no share earnings available for the latest 9 months' operating net because of preferred dividend requirements.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1987
description: International

title: Question To a Judge
description: I used to see Joyce Brown almost every day but I never knew her name. She would be lying huddled on the sidewalk on Second Avenue, across the street from my apartment. I would look at her, stop sometimes, but usually just walk on, restless in my mind about what it told about the city, about the woman, about myself, that a person could lie amid the rubbish of the street and her own filth, day after day, night after night, for a full year, and nothing done.

title: . . . But Wherehouse Appears Uninterested
description: It should be no surprise that Louis A. Kwiker, the chairman of Wherehouse Entertainment Inc., has so far expressed little interest in a $92 million takeover offer from Shamrock Holdings Inc.

title: Gush Katif Journal; Sun and Fun in Gaza: See the 'Friendly Bedouin'
description: Occupied Gaza Strip - Of all the bizarre contrasts that make up the Gaza Strip, of all the paradoxes per square mile that confront the visitor to Israel each day, surely nothing can top the clash between the Katif Beach Hotel and its surroundings.

title: TV Weekend; 'Celebrating Gershwin,' in Two Parts
description: THE 50th anniversary of George Gershwin's death -in 1937 at the age of 38 - is being noted this year with television specials the world over. Public television here has been especially active and is now capping its efforts with a two-part music extravaganza entitled ''Celebrating Gershwin.'' Presented under the ''Great Performances'' umbrella, the first 90-minute segment can be seen tonight at 9 on Channel 13. The second will be broadcast next Friday.

title: Pearson Up On Rumors
description: Pearson P.L.C. was the biggest gainer on the London Stock Exchange today, sparked by rumors that the publisher Rupert Murdoch was about to increase his stake of nearly 15 percent and might begin a takeover bid, brokers said.

title: 'We're Going to Vote Anyway, 'Haitians Insist
description: By nightfall, the streets of this city rapidly drain of their bustle and traffic, giving way to an eerie stillness, as Haitians abandon public places to avoid the violent death that each night claims more victims.

title: Propane Leak Delays Amtrak Service
description: NIANTIC, CONN

title: New Face: James Wilby; The Vision of a Gay Hero
description: E.M. FORSTER'S vision of the hero for his novel of homosexual love was a man quite unlike himself: ''someone handsome, healthy, bodily attractive, mentally torpid and rather a snob.'' Except for the ''mentally torpid,'' James Wilby, the relative unknown who plays the title role in the movie adapted from Forster's ''Maurice,'' fits the description to a T. Mr. Wilby was in the United States recently to promote the latest Merchant-Ivory movie, a Venice Film Festival award-winner now running at the Paris cinema. The actor is a tall, well-built, golden-haired, educated Englishman, glowing with physical energy and emotional exuberance. He is 29 years old, could pass for 20 and looks not only younger but also slimmer and even better looking than his screen image. He is on view almost every moment of the critically acclaimed movie in what the director, James Ivory, called ''the biggest role we've ever given a young actor.''

title: ABENDMUSIK
description: Abendmusik, a chamber group, will perform works by Christian Fried-rich Witt, Bach, Cimarosa, Mozart, Schubert and J.C. Bach Sunday at 3 P.M. in Lenfell Hall on Fairleigh Dickinson University's Florham-Madison campus in Madison, N.J. Tickets are $7; $5 for students and the elderly. Information and direc-tions: (201) 593-8620.

description: For the second time in less than two months, Darryl Dawkins, who was with the Nets before the season began, has been traded. The Utah Jazz sent Dawkins to the Detroit Pistons yesterday for second-round draft picks in 1988 and 1990 and an undisclosed amount of cash.

description: LEAD: Mayor Koch's most recent program for the homeless uses roving teams of psychiatrist and social workers to comb the streets of New York City in search of severely disturbed individuals. Those who are thought to pose a ''foreseeable'' danger to themselves or to others are forcibly removed to a special ward at Bellevue Hospital.

description: Nine people were injured early yesterday when a stolen van eluding a police car plowed into a taxicab on Columbus Avenue at 75th Street, propelling it onto the sidewalk and through a restaurant window, the police said.

description: Jeff Seal, the sports information director at Tulane University, was in stable condition after surgery yesterday at Tulane Medical Center for wounds he suffered after he was kidnapped, robbed and shot through the lower back, the police said. Three men were later arrested by the police in downtown New Orleans and charged in the incident.

title: N.J. Transit Warns of Possible Fare Increases
description: An unexpected decline in bus ridership could force N.J. Transit to reduce service or increase fares on both its buses and trains, the executive director of the state-supported agency says.

title: 'I Like Gorby' Buttons
description: President Gustav Husak and Foreign Minister Bohuslav Chnoupek of Czechoslovakia donned buttons today, proclaiming ''I Like Gorby'' when greeting Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany in Prague. A West German diplomat said Mr. Genscher presented Mr. Chnoupek with one of the buttons praising Mikhail S. Gorbachev when the two Foreign Ministers dined together Wednesday night. Mr. Husak was presented with a similar button by a West German photographer.

title: For the Seabrook Plant, The Numbers Are Grim
description: When the Seabrook nuclear plant was conceived, the power it produced was to be competitive with oil at $12 a barrel. Now that Seabrook is finished, it could still save consumers money - if oil were to rise above an improbable $130 a barrel.

title: 8 Latin Presidents in Acapulco for Summit Talks
description: With a variety of political and economic problems on their agenda, the Presidents of eight nations arrived at this Pacific Ocean resort today for the first large-scale Latin American summit conference without the participation of the United States.

title: SOVIET SPUR SEEN IN CAMBODIA TALKS
description: The Soviet Union has apparently played a major role in persuading Cambodia's Communist leaders to begin negotiating with Prince Norodom Sihanouk, according to foreign residents in this isolated capital.

title: Holiday Stargazing at Hayden Planetarium
description: THOUSANDS of flickering stars appear overhead, as artificial twilight gives way to mechanized night. Tiny spacecraft dart through a sparkling cosmos of whirling planets, eerie, undulating nebulas and supernovas exploding in a flash of light.

description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the White Housechief of staff, said today that the Congressional committees' report on the Iran-contra affair was ''personally hurtful'' to President Reagan and that he ''didn't like it a bit.''

title: Death Draws Public's Eye To Adoption
description: The death of 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg has focused attention on New York State's complex adoption laws. While many experts in the field say the Steinberg case has nothing to do with adoption, others say it highlights flaws in the system.

title: Jersey Struggles to Aid Its Homeless Families
description: Nine months after a landmark court decision expanded the rights of homeless families in New Jersey, county welfare agencies are struggling with a flood of new cases, and in many instances are providing fewer services than before the ruling.

title: Money Fund Assets Dip
description: Assets of the nation's 411 money market mutual funds decreased $665.2 million, to $262.05 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 111 institutional funds were down $224.3 million, to $74.15 billion. Assets of the 207 general purpose funds fell $256.8 million, to $78.86 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds decreased $184.1 million, to $109.05 billion.

description: Much as the swallows return to Capistrano and Old Faithful spouts off, ''Walkin' Lawton'' returns to this Florida Panhandle town every six years.

description: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would offer buyer incentives on some of its 1987 and 1988 cars. Buyers can choose a $770 rebate or 7.7 percent financing on 1988 Dodge Lancers, Dodge 600's, Plymouth Caravelles and Chrysler LeBaron GTS's or coupes, as well as on 1987 Plymouth Caravelles and Dodge 600's.

description: At Thanksgiving Day church services and prayer vigils today, Chicago mourned the death of Mayor Harold Washington, even as his longtime supporters and politicial rivals quietly began positioning themselves for the battle over his succession.

description: A combination of protectionist worries, a falling dollar and a strong consumer base is continuing to encourage more foreign companies to build production plants in this country.

description: or the ecumenical Thanksgiving Day service at the Chapel of the Snows at McMurdo Station, the American scientific research base in Antarctica, the Gospel was taken from the sixth chapter of St. Mark. It is the story of the loaves and the fishes that fed 5,000 people in what the Disciples termed ''a remote place.''

description: Harvard and Yale are tied for No. 1, but Michigan, Stanford, and Columbia are not far behind. Penn has dropped to 10th, followed by Texas at 11th and Duke at 12th. Perennial Pac-10 rivals U.C.L.A. and U.S.C. are 14th and 17th, while Big Ten conference mates Minnesota and Wisconsin are neck and neck at 19 and 20.

title: Policewoman Shoots Her Son, an Officer
description: A 22-year-old off-duty New York City police officer was shot in the knee yesterday, apparently accidentally, by another police officer, his mother, at the home they share in Brooklyn.

title: 2 Youths Quit School in S.A.T. Tampering
description: Two students withdrew from a private boys academy after admitting that they had broken into a school and opened sealed copies of a college entrance exam the day before it was to be administered, officials said today.

title: Stage: 'About Face,' Dario Fo Comedy
description: THE funniest scenes in ''About Face'' owe more to the gadgetry of burlesque than to Dario Fo's semblance of plot or his politics. Most of Act I, for example, takes place in a hospital room occupied by a patient who has a way of flying out of bed at the jerk of pulleys operated by several jerks who like to jig while they work. In Act II, a man finds himself being fed a meal through a meat grinder on his head, tubes up his nostrils and a funnel down his back.

description: A tightening embargo on purchases of Iranian oil by the United States, France and to some extent Japan has been choking Teheran's exports and straining its financial lifeline in recent weeks.

title: Transplant Recipient Nears One-Month Mark
description: As 3-year-old Tabatha Foster struggles to survive one month with five transplanted organs, a milestone never before reached, her family and doctors are fretting over her latest complications.

title: 8 MORE DIE IN HAITI AS CONCERN GROWS OVER VOTE SUNDAY
description: Three days before Haiti's first presidential election in 30 years, eight people were found shot to death today on the streets of the capital after a night of patrols by heavily armed Government troops.

title: Sri Lanka Emergency Stays
description: Sri Lanka's Parliament voted today to extend the state of emergency for a further month as Indian troops continued their drive to disarm Tamil guerrillas in northern and eastern areas. Members supported the extension after Acting Parliamentary Affairs Minister M. D. Premaratne said political assassinations were on the increase in the south and rebel violence still flared in Tamil-dominated areas.

description: The nation's stock and commodity markets were closed Thursday in observance of Thanksgiving Day. Government offices, banks and most businesses were also closed. All stock exchanges and most commodity markets will be open today, as usual. However, the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange will be closed.

description: Robert B. Hudson, a retired educator and public broadcasting executive, died of pulmonary failure Sunday at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 82 years old.

description: Kleinwort Benson Ltd., the merchant banking subsidiary of Kleinwort Benson Lonsdale P.L.C., has named David Peake chairman, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Michael Hawkes, 58, who becomes the company's executive deputy chairman. Mr Peake will also become the executive chief chairman of the Kleinwort Benson holding company when Robert Henderson, 70, retires Dec. 31.

title: Prices Up in Europe
description: Consumer prices in the European Community jumped five-tenths of 1 percent in October, pushing the annual inflation rate to a provisional 3.4 percent, its highest since June 1986. The community's annual inflation rate is below the 4.5 percent rate of the United States but well above Japan's rate of 1.6 percent.

title: George W. Korngold, Record Producer, Dies
description: George W. Korngold, a record producer and son of Erich Wolfgang Korngold, the Austrian composer, died of cancer Wednesday night at his Los Angeles home. He was 58 years old.

description: Mayor Koch should appoint an independent commission to investigate ''systemic corruption'' in the Transit Authority police, said the lawyer for people who say they were falsely arrested by transit police officers.

title: Lord Duncan-Sandys, 79, Dead; Smoothed Way to End of Empire

Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 mini-mum.

description: A Great Neck, L.I., man charged with molesting boys enrolled in his computer school was ordered held on $1 million bond or $500,000 cash bail in a hearing yesterday at which his son was ordered jailed on similar charges, the authorities said.

description: A court decision two days ago upholding New Zealand's challenge for the America's Cup next summer has left the guardian of the cup - the San Diego Yacht Club - in turmoil. But officials of the New York Yacht Club, which held the trophy for 132 years, have said that they expected the court to rule as it did.

title: School Opener A Sellout
description: What with the Big Apple N.I.T. final being held at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, the Knicks playing the Cleveland Cavaliers there in the afternoon, and St. John's opening its Joe Lapchick Tournament against Harvard, it might seem that the toughest basketball ticket to get in town this weekend would be at either the Garden or Alumni Hall.

title: Topics of The Times; Happy M10
description: Some People are to the psyche what warm socks are to cold feet, and one of them was driving the M10 bus up Eighth Avenue Wednesday. He greeted oncoming passen-gers with a ''Good morning'', and saluted departing ones with a ''Happy holiday''. They all left smiling.

title: LIKE THE NEW PAPER? YOU'LL SOON PAY
description: For two years Steven Brill's publishing company has bought successful legal publications, added some gloss and some more reporters, and then notched up circulation and prices, in that order.

title: BIOGEN N.V.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Restaurants
description: THE cross-pollination of Eastern and Western cuisines over the last decade has spawned some electrifying food, particularly by leading proponents of contemporary California-style cuisine. One of the most impressive practitioners of this genre in California is Wolfgang Puck, whose Chinois on Main in Santa Monica blends the esthetics of Oriental cuisines with the whimsy of so-called New American cooking. Its great appeal is derived from the imaginative combinations of seasonings blended with playful textures.

title: Art: The Apprenticeship Of Stuart Davis as a Cubist
description: IT might be said that Stuart Davis's career was a protracted love affair with Cubism that began well and ended better. The end is well known: the bright conglomerations of jagged forms, meandering lines and cursive writing that Davis painted in the decade before his death in 1964 are among the last masterpieces built upon a Cubist foundation. But the story of Davis's beginnings during the decade following World War I constitutes one of the best-kept secrets of early American modernism. At the moment, two of its chapters are being told in a pair of small, focused exhibitions at Salander-O'Reilly Galleries Inc. and the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris.

title: Men in Black Unite to Fight Mafia in Palermo
description: Exuding a sense of past glory with its frayed damask, chipped gold leaf and overcrowding of memorial plaques, Palermo's city hall is now occupied by a long-haired Mayor who says he has brought the ideals of 1960's student protests back to life and into power.
