title: Touring a Tranquil Haven For Medieval Treasures
description: THOUGH - architecturally speaking -much of the Cloisters, the Metropolitan Museum of Art's medieval outpost in Fort Tryon Park, is close to a thousand years old, it's about to celebrate only its 50th birthday. If that seems slightly out of sync, let it pass. What the birthday - next May 10 - commemorates is the opening of the Cloisters in 1938 and the feat of putting together this ambitious pastiche of ancient ecclesiastical parts, a job so well done that today it's hard to picture the banks of the Hudson without it.

title: Swiss Ready to Face Armageddon, in Comfort
description: In a matter of hours, an ordinary expressway tunnel can be transformed into one of Europe's biggest bomb shelters: a spick-and-span netherworld with its own water supply, air filters, a jail and even a studio pumping out soothing music to the evacuees inside.

title: BAKER, J, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a tax loss carryforward of $1,596,000. The year-ago share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid April 17, 1987.

title: Suriname Voters Give a Strong Rebuff to Military
description: A three-party opposition coalition in Suriname won a landslide election victory today in a popular rebuke of the South American country's seven years of military dictatorship.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 6
description: The year-ago periods' share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable Oct. 6.

title: Advertising; Two Agencies Receive Travel Accounts
description: Just in time for the winter travel season, McCann-Erickson has heard a far-off aloha and Warren/Kremer has felt the caress of a Caribbean breeze.

title: Smoking Ban in Los Angeles
description: Smoking would be banned in stores and other public places here and most restaurants would be required to set aside half their seats for nonsmokers under an ordinance awaiting the mayor's signature.

title: HANCOCK FABRICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results for the latest 9 months and both year-ago periods are pro forma. The company was spun off from Lucky Stores Inc. May 4.

title: Iranian Who Escaped Appears at U.N. to Tell of Torture in Prison
description: An Iranian who says he escaped from Iran last month after five years of imprisonment and torture in Iranian prisons came to the United Nations this week to describe his ordeal.

title: PIANO, FOUR HANDS
description: Millette Alexander and Frank Day-kin will perform works for piano, four hands, by Schubert, Schumann, Webber and Faure on Sunday at 3 P.M. at St. Bartholomew's Church (Park Avenue and 51st Street). Tickets are $5. Information: 751-1616.

title: In the Labyrinth of Soviet Internal Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: DERMA-LOCK MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $160,000 of income not related to the company's regular business. Year-ago results not applicable because the company merged with LMCG S.A. in December 1986.

title: Japan Steps Up Security After Arrest of Terrorist
description: The Japanese police intensified security for the imperial family and other prominent figures today after the arrest this week of a leader of the Japanese Red Army.

title: TARO VIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The translation into U.S. dollars was at the exchange rate of $1.00 equals 1.6 shekels for the 1987 results and $1.00 equals 1.5 shekels for the 1986 results.

title: FORU DEBUTS DURING A 'SPECTACULAR' PARADE
description: Four giant balloons made their debut yesterday at the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, and so did a 3-week-old boy.

title: Woman Who Killed a Mother To Steal Baby Is Sentenced
description: A 19-year-old woman obsessed with having a child was sentenced to life in prison without parole Wednesday for shooting a young mother to death and stealing her 4-day-old baby.

title: Dining Out Guide: Casual
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication, or a Diner's Journal designation. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE UN DEUX TROIS, #123 West 44th Street (354-4148) - *(May 15, 1987) For its reliably animated atmosphere and straightforward bistro fare, this 10-year-old cafe in the theater district continues to be one of the better bets in the area. The best appetizers are the creamy and well-seasoned duck-liver mousse and the beef sate, two thick, tender strips of beef paired with a brassy peanut sauce. Of the entrees, recommended options are breaded chicken breast with mild mustard sauce and julienne carrots and zucchini; steak tartare, and the special house mixed grill of calf's liver, boudin blanc and lamb chop. Dinner entrees $7.50 to $18.50. Fridays noon to 4 P.M. and 4:30 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays 10:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 5 P.M. to midnight; Sundays, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M. CINCO DE MAYO, 45 Tudor City Place, between 41st and 43d Streets (661-5070) - *(April 10, 1987) The flamboyant SoHo restaurant has opened a midtown outpost, which is colorful and convivial. Good starter choices are camarones al chipotle, which translates to sauteed shrimp in a piquant sauce made with smoked chilies; ceviche, the assortment of lime-marinated raw fish, and black bean soup with do-it-yourself garnishes. Entrees rotate daily, but you might choose budin de tortilla, a Mexican casserole with alternating layers of soft corn tortillas, shredded chicken, cheese and hot chilies, or try the sauteed shrimp over a nutty and peppery pumpkin sauce. Entrees $8.95 to $19.95. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5 to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. GREAT SHANGHAI RESTAURANT, #27-29 Division Street (966-7663) -

title: Our Towns; Geese Are Bright But Turkeys Put Cash in Register
description: That turkey you ate yesterday? It wasn't as smart as a goose.

title: Pop/Jazz; Judy Collins, A Concern And a Bond
description: FOR the contemporary pop singer who must woo and win the ear of a new generation every few years in order to survive, career longevity is a rare blessing. Judy Collins, who celebrates her 25th anniversary of concertizing in New York at Carnegie Hall this evening, is certainly one of the blessed, having recorded continuously since 1961, beginning in folk music, and branching out into rock, country, theater and art songs.

title: In Spite of All, He Remains Quite English
description: Leaving England seemed to be the thing to do in 1937, said the old man whose life of adventure has brought him at last to a cramped duplex apartment in this Wiltshire village.

title:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
'CONGREGATE-CARE' PROJECT IN YONKERS FOR THE ELDERLY
description: LEAD: It is more fitting than it might seem that a three-acre site in Yonkers once occupied by a secondary school should be developed as an apartment complex for the elderly.

title: MAY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a writedown of $400,000 related to the value of marketable securities at Sept. 30. c-Net loss

title: PRESSER IS CALLED INFORMER SINCE '74
description: Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has been providing the Federal Bureau of Investigation with information since 1974, documents filed in Federal court here indicate .

title: ALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Markets Mark Time In European Trading
description: The dollar marked time and the prices of stocks were mixed and hardly changed in Europe today, with markets still uncertain about the value of recent Western efforts to shore up the dented global economy.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; Publication From Omni Is Aimed at Physicians
description: Omni magazine, published by Penthouse International Ltd., is bringing out a special edition for physicians this week that will carry only health-care advertising.

title: Kasparov and Karpov Agree To a Draw in the 17th Game
description: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov played just four more moves before agreeing to a draw yesterday in the 17th game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain.

title: New Jersey Fights the Trash Tide
description: People enjoying the sea and sand along New Jersey's shore one day last August had a nauseating surprise. From Sandy Hook to Cape May, a 50-mile slick washed ashore carrying used hospital syringes, bags of household trash and thousands of empty crack bottles. The gruesome garbage was just one of many incidents that closed New Jersey's beaches a record number of times. Now Governor Kean proposes a thoughtful, far-reaching program to help clean up the shore, setting an example for other states.

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $487,000 gain from a minority interest.

title: CCX NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Man Killed Inflating a Tire
description: A man was killed Wednesday when his spare tire exploded while he was inflating it, the authorities said. The man, Jimmie Henagan, 27 years old, suffered injuries to the face and chest when he was filling the tire at a service station in this town east of New Orleans. He died an hour later at a nearby hospital.

title: COMPUTER MICROFILM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago share earnings adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid August 1987.

title: Hyundai Announces a Recall Of Some 1986 and 1987 Cars
description: The Hyundai Motor Company, the South Korean automobile manufacturer, said Wednesday that it would voluntarily recall more than 320,000 cars to correct a possible deficiency in their brakes.

title: AMERICAN CAPACITY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $93,383.

title: BANGOR HYDRO-ELECTRIC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $30,000 from investment in the Seabrook Nuclear Plant.

title: N. Alabama Coach Out
description: Robert Guillot, the president of the University of North Alabama, announced Wednesday that the contracts of Wayne Grubb, the head football coach, and five of his assistants would not be renewed. Guillot refused to elaborate on the reasons for the dismissals but said that the use of an ineligible player that caused the team to forfeit two games it had won was ''just the tip of the iceberg.''

title: DYNAMIC HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Markets In Role of Watchdogs
description: The stock markets' collapse last month has forced governments to take politically unpalatable steps to manage their economies more soundly.

title: Fordham Philosophy: Mix Old and New
description: Tucked away in his tiny office on the sprawling Rose Hill campus of Fordham University, Larry Glueck breathes tradition.

title: Advertising; Drug Chain to Cargill
description: Cargill, Wilson & Acree/Tracy-Locke of Atlanta has become the agency for the Drug Emporium, a retail company based in Worthington, Ohio, that operates 130 health and beauty outlets in 36 markets in 25 states. The budget is $10 million, the agency said, and the advertising will break on a market-by-market basis. The former agency was Don Lea & Associates of Toledo, Ohio.

title: Eyewitness Is Disputed On Alaska Air Crash
description: Disputing a witness' account, investigators today said the landing gear appeared to have been down on a commuter plane that crashed short of a runway here, killing 18 people and injuring three.

title: A Resignation In Greece
description: The national economy minister, Kostas Simitis, resigned today and said Greece risked losing the benefit of its austerity program because of sudden changes in incomes policy announced by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.

title: Reagan's Aide Savors Intrusion-Free Holiday
description: As he prepared for a tennis game beneath the eucalyptus trees here, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's chief spokesman, said today that he was thankful for a relatively calm Thanksgiving at the Western White House.

title: War On Pennsylvania Avenue
description: The fight between Congress and the Administration is trickier even than it seems. Modest last-minute budget compromise isn't yet assured of adoption. In fact, the threat of Gramm-Rudman cuts is still the main hope for making it stick.

title: Why Doctors Treat Alcoholism as a Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Hopefuls Get Headstart in TV Ads
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. assures Americans that he is not trigger-happy. Paul Simon tells voters that he is tough enough to lead. Pat Robertson pictures himself as an unsolved jigsaw puzzle. Michael S. Dukakis portrays the nation as a battered Revere bowl ready for caring hands. Jack F. Kemp criticizes Bob Dole and Vice President Bush. Pete du Pont takes aim at just about everybody.

title: Fewer Meals Served On Eastern Air Lines In Effort to Cut Costs
description: Passengers on Eastern Air Lines will have to survive some flights without hot meals, or in some cases with no food at all, to help cut the costs of the financially ailing carrier.

title: Saudi Princess Burned
description: Shoaa Al-Farhan, a Saudi princess and cousin of the late King Faisal, was in critical condition today with third-degree burns over 93 percent of her body, a hospital spokesman said. The princess, who is believed to be in her early 40's, was flown here by private jet Wednesday night and taken by ambulance to the Baltimore Regional Burn Center at Francis Scott Key Medical Center, Lee Kennedy, the spokesman said. He said that details of how the burns were suffered were unavailable but that they occurred in the princess's native country. He said the princess has relatives in the Washington area.

title: Events
description: FRIDAY Music

title: George W. Barton, Transportation Planner, 81
description: George W. Barton, founder of an international transportation planning firm, died Nov. 12 at his home in Sarasota, Fla., of a stroke. He was 81 years old.

title: INVESTMENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Investment Technologies is a development stage company.

title: CANADA MAY DROP NUCLEAR SUB PLAN
description: Only five months after it was announced, Canada's plan to join the small group of nations that operate nuclear-powered submarines has run into difficulties with budget planners at home and among officials in Washington who could veto the transfer of American nuclear technology for the submarines.

title: Which Holiday Events Are Available
description: A recent telephone survey of some of the city's popular holiday attractions indicated that tickets for many still remained. Here are the results of the survey: ''THE MAGNIFICENT CHRISTMAS SPECTACULAR,'' Radio City Music Hall (757-3100). All weekend shows are sold out from now until Dec. 26; after that, tickets to weekend shows are available up to the show's last performance on Jan. 6. However, seats still remain for many weekday performances, with the greatest number of seats available during the weeks of Dec. 14 and Dec. 21. ''THE NUTCRACKER,'' the New York City Ballet. New York State Theater (870-5570). Partial-view seats - which cost $15, $25 or $30 - are available for scattered performances through Jan. 3. There are full-view seats for some performances on Dec. 24, 28 and 30. AVERY FISHER HALL (874-2424). Tickets are available to many of the hall's holiday shows, including performances of Handel's ''Messiah'' by Musica Sacra (Dec. 14 and 18); a ''Messiah Sing-In,'' sponsored by the National Choral Council (Dec. 16 and 28); an appearance by the Vienna Choir Boys (Dec. 20), and concerts by the New York Philharmonic, with the Boys Choir of Harlem (Dec. 29 and 30). CARNEGIE HALL (247-7800). Tickets are available to most holiday shows, including Honegger's ''King David'' (Dec. 11); Handel's ''Messiah'' by the Oratorio Society of New York (Dec. 14); Handel's ''Messiah'' by the Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra (Dec. 19 and 20); Bach's Christmas Oratorio by the Orchestra of St. Luke's (Dec. 21), and the New Year's Eve benefit, with Victorian song and music. ROCKEFELLER CENTER ICE-SKATING RINK (757-5730 or 757-5731). The rink is open daily 9 A.M. to 10 P.M.; the crowds are generally lighter early in the day. Weekend admission is $8 ($6.50 for those under 12); skate rentals, $3.50. 92D STREET Y, at Lexington Avenue (996-1100). Tickets are available for the New York Chamber Symphony's presentation of the Brandenburg Concertos, conducted by Gerard Schwarz, on Dec. 26, 27, 30 and 31. There are also tickets, at $7.50, for ''A Gift of Light,'' a Hanukkah celebration, on Dec. 13. ''CHRISTMAS REVELS,'' Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street (864-5400). A Russian-Slavic celebration of the winter solstice, with music and drama (Dec. 10 to 13).

title: 4 Asian Economies Assailed
description: The Reagan Administration is putting new pressure on the four most powerful economies in the developing world - Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore - to alter the policies that have made their surpluses the fastest-growing segment of the American trade deficit.

title: U.S. Plans Tariffs to Punish Europe
description: The Reagan Administration is preparing to raise tariffs on $100 million of annual food imports from the European Community if the 12-nation bloc goes through with a ban it has announced on imports of the meat of animals treated with growth hormones.

title: Comeback Halted
description: An attempted comeback by Kermit Washington after a five-year absence from competition has apparently ended after the Golden State Warriors requested waivers on the 36-year-old power forward. Washington was released after the Warriors' 10th defeat in 11 games, the worst start in the team's history.

title: L.I. School District Strives to Integrate
description: Education officials here have approved magnet programs for three high schools in an effort to satisfy the state's demands to integrate the schools while keeping local control over the suburban district.

title: More Victims Sought In Nurse Case
description: Six more bodies will be exhumed by Suffolk County authorities in a search for possible victims of a nurse suspected of injecting lethal drugs into patients at Good Samaritan Hospital, the Suffolk County District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Antarctica's Ozone Loss Is Duplicated in Lab
description: Scientists report that they have duplicated in the laboratory the same ice-cold chemical reactions that many of them believe lead to the annual hole in the ozone high above Antarctica.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Becker Upset in Third Round: Magnus Gustaffson of Sweden, ranked 51st in the world, upset top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany, 2-6, 6-4, 6-2, yesterday in the third round of the $150,000 Young Masters tennis tournament in Friedrichshafen, West Germany. The defeat eliminated the 20-year-old Becker, a two-time Wimbledon champion who has been suffering lately from the effects of a lingering cold and a knee injury. Becker, ranked fifth in the world, has won the last three Young Masters tournaments. Becker made a promising start against Gustaffson, winning the first set, 6-2. But as the match wore on, he seemed to become more and more tired and had several faults called against him. He said after the match, ''At the moment I'm taking medicine for throat and ear pain, for sniffles and for my knee injury.''(AP) Golf Two Tied With 67: An American, David Ishii, and Sam Torrance of Scotland carded five-under-par 67's yesterday to share the lead after the opening round of the $666,700 Casio World Open tournament in Kaimoncho, Japan. Ishii, of Hawaii, the second leading money-winner on the Japanese tour this season with four victories, had six birdies and one bogey on the 6,985-yard, par-72 course. Next were an American, George Burns, and three Japanese - Masahiro Kuramoto, Tsukasa Watanabe and Nobumitsu Yuhara - at 69.(AP) Horse Racing Personal Flag Scores: Personal Flag returned from a four-and-a-half-month layoff with a five-length victory yesterday in the $84,450 Queens County Handicap at Aqueduct. Personal Flag, ridden by Randy Romero and carrying 116 pounds, had not raced because of a back problem. The 4-year-old son of Private Account and Grecian Banner went a mile and three-sixteenths in 1:59 for his second victory in three starts this year. Easy 'N Dirty was second, three lengths ahead of Gold Alert. Personal Flag earned $50,670 for his owner-breeder, Ogden Phipps, and paid $3.80, $3 and $2.40 for $2 across the board. (AP)

title: School Football; Iona's Victory Brightens a 20th Reunion
description: The 1967 Iona Prep football team might have been the best the school ever had. It was undefeated and the top team in the metropolitan area. But the one game its players still talk about is the 13-0 victory over New Rochelle in the rain on Thanksgiving Day that year.

title: LET'S REFORM THE O-T-C MARKET
description: The stock market collapse was significantly aggravated by structural and regulatory failings in the over-the-counter marketplace.

title: TV: 'Next President,' With David Frost
description: David Frost begins a 13-part series tomorrow night with the men who would be President. The first program, however, on Channel 9 at 11 o'clock, is about what happens to a candidate after he is elected. Mr. Frost speaks with President Reagan and former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford. Mr. Frost is earnest; Mr. Reagan and the two former Presidents are reasonably relaxed. They are also, one thinks, mindful of their places in history.

title: DOLLAR GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago third quarter and 9-month results are restated to reflect inventory shrinkage and other adjustments.

title: Family Split 58 Years Ago Has Reunion
description: Five siblings put up for adoption 58 years ago by parents who were unable to feed them reunited over a Thanksgiving feast Thursday and found they had more in common than physical features.

title: BEAR AUTOMOTIVE SERVICE EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $28,000 and $981,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also includes a loss from an accounting change of $67,000.

title: The Nonplussed Vexation
description: Among matters that leave me nonplussed is the question why nobody says ''nonplussed'' anymore. Now someone will want to write a letter saying: ''Wrong again, Mister Know It All. I said 'nonplussed' just last Tuesday.''

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-Net income The company said latest quarter results include direct and deferred costs associated with its decisions to cancel its major television advertising campaign, discontinue certain store displays, close several stores in Washington and replace and upgrade portions of the store P.O.S. Equipment. The year-ago periods' results include an estimated LIFO adjustment based on current prices and inventory levels.

title: DIBRELL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Music: Audubon Quartet
description: The Audubon String Quartet earned more gratitude for its introduction of a lucid new piece - Ezra Laderman's Quintet for Clarinet and Strings, with James Campbell as guest soloist - than for its playing of the standard repertory Tuesday at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Economists Caution on Risks In Continued Drop of Dollar
description: Despite widespread support within the United States for a deeper and deeper depreciation of the dollar, many economists are beginning to warn that, along with the potential benefits, there are significant costs and some substantial risks.

title: Chopped to the Bone at State
description: The cliche has it that the State Department has no domestic constituency and is therefore vulnerable to ruinous Congressional budgetary cuts. But the department does have a constituency, though it's amorphous and diffuse. Every traveler is a constituent; so is every travel agent and every international airline. All who do business abroad are constituents; so is everyone who is involved in telecommunications, or foreign imports, sales or royalties. So is every citizen who thinks of foreign policy as the shield of the republic.

title: HARLEYSVILLE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After capital gains of $6,000 for the quarter and $377,000 for the 9 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $599,000 for the quarter and $1,654,000 for the 9 months, and capital gains of $75,000 and $2,117,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: EASTOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains of $257,000 and $455,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from the sale of real estate. c-Includes gains of $14,000 for the quarter and $560,000 for the 9 months both from the sale of real estate.

title: Your Money; O-T-C Issues: New Wariness
description: DANIEL ZIRINSKY, a Long Island City property owner, has long been an investor in over-the-counter stocks, but after the collapse of the stock market in October he plans to concentrate on securities listed on the major exchanges.

title: About New York; Hail to the City: A Media Show Hits Hard Times
description: About five million people have seen ''The New York Experience'' since the tribute to the city opened in 1973, and lately some have been complaining that the sound and light blitzkrieg is getting a little long in the tooth. This is perfectly understandable, says a spokesman for the enterprise; extensive, expensive updating was planned, but lease troubles have taken priority. Why sink money in a business about to lose its roof?

title: 3 Players Banned
description: Three football players at Northeast Louisiana University have been suspended for violation of team rules, Coach Pat Collins said yesterday. The announcement came a day before Northeast Louisiana faced North Texas State in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA playoffs. The three seniors are the starting strong safety, Perry Harper; the second-team fullback, Kenneth Johnson, and the third-team defensive end, Rick Upshaw. Collins said the suspensions were for an indefinite period, and declined to say which rules had been broken.

title: ALLSTAR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings represent units. The company went public in April.

title: Peter Hujar Dies at 53; Made Photo Portraits
description: Peter Hujar, a photographer known for his portraits of personalities in the cultural world, died of AIDS-related pneumonia at Cabrini Medical Center on Thursday. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Air Canada Halts Flights
description: Air Canada began a systemwide shutdown today after the Government-run carrier was crippled by a ground workers strike, stranding thousands of passengers from Vancouver to Montreal. The airline's 8,500 ground workers have been holding rotating walkouts throughout the country because they have been without a contract since June.

title: CHARTER-CRELLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PAULEY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $154,000. c-Net income

title: SIGMA RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
More Wheat for Soviet
description: United States farmers will be able to sell an additional 2.35 million metric tons of wheat to the Soviet Union under an expanded export program announced today by the Agriculture Department. The Government had previously given farmers approval to sell nearly 6.4 million metric tons of wheat to the Soviet Union. Since April, more than 5.7 million metric tons have been purchased under that program. The wheat is bought by the Soviet Union at competitive world prices, but the export is subsidized by the United States Commodity Credit Corporation to enable American exporters to compete with prices on the Soviet market.

title: Miss Rose, a Producer, Marries Alan D. Lafer
description: Susan Robin Rose, a Broadway producer and a partner in ERB Productions, an entertainment production company, and Alan David Lafer, a general partner and the director of research for Lafer Amster & Company, a New York Stock Exchange member firm, were married yesterday. Rabbi David Lincoln performed the ceremony at the New York home of Mr. and Mrs. Barry S. Lafer, the bridegroom's brother and sister-in-law.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1987
description: International 3-6 The White House pressed for support in the Senate for the American-Soviet missile treaty by providing data to show that the pact contains tighter verification provisions than any previous accord. Page 1 President Reagan is prepared, ''very well briefed'' and ''confident in our positions'' in advance of his meeting next month with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, a senior White House official said. 6 16 missionaries and children died at the hands of anti-Government guerrillas in Zimbabwe. Farm workers said the assailants sang ''revolutionary songs'' as they hacked the bound missionaries and their children to death. 1 Two Frenchmen gained freedom after being held for months by a shadowy Lebanese group. Diplomats said the freeing of Jean-Louis Normandin, a cameraman, and Roger Auque, a photojournalist, followed extensive talks involving France, Syria and Iran. 1 More gunshots in Haiti's capital frightened residents, but no new killings were reported two days before the country's first presidential election in 30 years. 5 Haitian motorists were terrorized outside the town of St.-Marc by a ragged band of men armed with machetes and knives that residents feared were remnants of the Tontons Macoute, the militia of the Duvalier regime. 1 Japan may have to modify policies on the economy, taxes and trade to maintain smooth relations with other countries, the new Prime Minister, Noboru Takeshita, said in his first major policy speech. 29 Increased supplies of oil have put the industrial countries in a position to withstand even a major disruption of the flow of petroleum from the Persian Gulf, according to senior Western officials. 29 Seoul ordered no interference by the country's military chiefs in next month's presidential election. The defense chief also said soldiers must vote by secret ballot. 3 South Africa's censors approved the release of Sir Richard Attenborough's movie, ''Cry Freedom,'' without any cuts or restrictions. The major theaters that will screen the film about South Africa were desegregated last year. 6 Bangladesh declares state of emergency and bans strikes 3 Israeli army harshly criticized over glider raid 3 East Berlin journal: Marxists embrace Nietzche 4 Malaysia to issue new press bans 5 NATIONAL 7, 24, 28, 46 Freedom for 26 hostages met a delay and talks with Cuban inmates at the Federal prison in Oakdale, La. who were holding them seemed to have halted. But Federal officials said they believed a settlement might occur soon. 1 14 Cuban-American leaders, including Mayor Xavier Suarez of Miami, spent seven hours conferring with officials of the Federal prison in Atlanta, but were not allowed to see the Cuban inmates who are holding 94 hostages. 28 The dollar continued to slide and gold prices advanced in quiet trading. Treasury bond prices dropped sharply and stock prices also declined in a very slow semiholiday turnover. 38 A cheaper dollar helps sales for United States-made products at home and abroad, but many economists are beginning to warn that, along with the potential benefits of a falling dollar, there are significant costs and some substantial risks. 1 Developers play an increasing role in metropolitan America and are now providing social services, financing of school and cultural facilities, preserving the environment and aiding low-income housing. 1 University-think tank links are under increasing strain. One conservative study organization with close ties to the Reagan Administration has had angry exchanges with liberal faculty members. 46 Mine closings in West Virginia have impoverished McDowell County, in a corner of Appalachia where coal is no longer king. 7 Changes in the Dukakis campaign involve the resignation of the Presidential aspirant's press secretary, Patricia O'Brien, and a new assignment for a second top staff member, Jack Corrigan. 7 A divided family reunites 7 Survey challenges standardized test results 7 Illinois gets a large share of Federal road funds 24 REGIONAL 25-27 Arrests and summonses won rewards from a transit police commander, with the prizes based on the highest numbers. Four of the subordinates are suspected of making scores of false or improper arrests. 25 News analysis: the school crisis in New York City has prompted a sense of disintegration at the Board of Education, and many officials, including three key members of the board, seek its dissolution. 27 Catholic schools are changing, admitting more children of other faiths, particularly in New York City. The parents are registering their children because of what they consider poor academic quality and lack of discipline in public schools. 25 Officers guarding prisoners in courts in New York state will adopt stricter security procedures, even if the new policy increases greatly the time needed to process cases, union leaders said. 27 The fate of a homeless woman was debated in court. The Koch administration urged the tribunal to permit it to continue to hospitalize Joyce Brown, whom the administration considers to be mentally ill. 26 A surrogate vowed an inquiry beginning Monday of assertions that a Manhattan court official through mismanagement and dereliction of duty had delayed the settlement of thousands of estates lacking wills and worth millions of dollars. 27 The Friars' Club practices sex bias, Gloria Allred, a Los Angeles lawyer, complained. She said the policy of excluding women set by the all-male Manhattan club violated New York City antidiscrimination laws. 27 High-rise Newark public housing is being razed because of crime and waste. In a city where one-third of the population gets public aid, officials say they cannot meet everyone's needs for public housing. 25 A key F.B.I. official will retire at the age of 50 to take a better-paying post as a private security consultant. The highly regarded official is Thomas L. Sheer, head of the bureau's New York City office. 26 At Jersey mall, tinsel and frenzy 25

title: Stores Rush to Automate for Holidays
description: As shoppers surge into department stores this holiday season many will encounter a new phase of technology at the checkout counter.

title: U.N. Chief Frustrated Over Gulf Peace Effort
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is frustrated by Iran's delay in sending an envoy for talks on the Iran-Iraq war but he will continue trying to bring peace to the area, his spokesman said today.

title: Despite Success, Research Centers Are Rebuffed by 2 Major Universities

title: FOR ZIMBABWE MISSIONARIES, A NIGHT OF TERROR AND DEATH

description: To walk around midtown Manhattan this week was a lot like touring a theater a few days before opening night. The set was more or less in place, but some of the furniture was still in shrouds and several of the props were still en route.

description: Frank E. Schwartz, a book publisher and marketing innovator, died of a heart attack Wednesday while on vacation in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 40 years old and lived in Manhattan.

It is intended to protect people if an electrical appliance is accidentally immersed in water. Bernard Gershen, Saul Rosenbaum and James N. Pearse were granted patent 4,709,293.

title: London Subway Toll at 31

Miss Vaness, who made her New York City Opera debut in October 1979 and her Met debut four years later, will sing the New York premiere of a song cycle written for her by John Kander, the Broadway composer, as well as works by Richard Strauss, Rossini, Tosti and Chausson. Her accompanist is Warren Jones, a pianist. Tickets are $16. Information: 362-1911.

It said in a statement that this decision had been taken ''in view of the significant changes which have taken place in the world equity markets since the middle of October.'' The bank said the decision would be kept under review.

title: MET OPERA: MOZART'S 'ENTFUHRUNG'
description: The return of Mozart's ''Entfuhrung aus dem Serail'' Thursday night does not add to the Metropolitan Opera's season. Jocelyn Herbert's two-dimensional cutouts against a bright blue sky must have had charm when fresh. Today they look frayed and shabby. The production is eight years old and has not aged well. The Met might consider removing it from the repertory or else submitting it to a major refurbishment. In its present state, it does no one much good.

description: The Famous People Players, a troupe of Canadian puppeteers who use life-size puppets of Barbra Streisand, Michael Jackson, Liberace and other celebrities, will perform at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Whitman Hall of Brooklyn College at 2 P.M. tomorrow. The 13-member company uses classical and popular music, black lights and other props for an eclectic program of musical revues and fairy tales called ''A Little Like Magic.''Tickets for the show - the first in Brooklyn College's season of ''Family Time'' programs for children and their parents - are $5. The auditorium is one block from the Flatbush Avenue station of the IRT No. 2 train. Information: (718) 434-1900.

title: Like the Oakdale Deal, 26 Yellow Balloons Remain Grounded
description: Twenty-six yellow helium balloons, each inscribed with the name of one of 26 hostages, were set to be released from their ground harness yesterday at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Center in Oakdale, La. The cause of the celebration was the apparent agreement between Government negotiators and rebellious Cuban inmates at the town's Federal detention center to set the hostages free.

description: Since the Big East Conference came into being in 1980, Seton Hall has usually been the league's doormat, counting success by the few victories it could eke out each season.

Residents in Harlan and in Wise and Lee Counties in Virginia reported feeling tremors, the Federal agency said.

Pop: Bo Diddley Tour
description: Keith Richards of the Rolling Stones made a movie with an idol, Chuck Berry. Perhaps by coincidence, the other Stones guitarist, Ron Wood, is now touring with another rock-and-roll pioneer, Bo Diddley. The Bo Diddley beat - part mambo, part blues - is a cornerstone of rock, and the thick, raunchy sound of Mr. Diddley's rectangular-bodied guitar inspired generation after generation of garage bands. But where Mr. Richards paid homage to Mr. Berry, the Bo Diddley-Ron Wood show Wednesday at the Ritz was a disorganized jam session - and a star trip for Mr. Wood, who took the stage after four songs by Mr. Diddley.

title: Bilzerian Seeks Auction for Singer
description: An investment group led by Paul A. Bilzerian, a Tampa, Fla., financier, has proposed that the Singer Company be auctioned to the highest bidder by Dec. 15. The military electronics concern had rejected an unsolicited takeover offer of $1.1 billion from the group. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Bilzerian's representatives said that they had proposed the auction to Singer on Tuesday and that the Stamford, Conn., company had said on Wednesday that it was not ready to respond.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Italian Wins Special Slalom: Alberto Tomba of Italy opened the men's World Cup ski season by scoring his first World Cup victory yesterday in the special slalom in Sestriere, Italy. Jonas Nilsson of Sweden and Guenther Mader of Austria finished second and third. Felix McGrath, Alexander Williams, Tiger Shaw and Troy Watts, all Americans, all dropped out in the first heat. The 20-year-old Tomba, who had notched his previous personal bests in the giant slalom, stunned his opponents with two aggressive and strong heats down the tricky Kandahar course. (AP) Horse Racing Native Wizard Triumphs: After trailing early, Native Wizard, ridden by Frank Lovato, Jr., circled the field on the turn and went on to a 4 3/4-length victory yesterday in the $35,000 Fappiano Purse for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Strong Performance, with Jean Cruguet aboard, was second, a half-length ahead of Landyap, ridden by Eddie Maple. Native Wizard covered the mile on the fast but dull racing strip in 1:38 3/5 for his second victory in five career starts.(AP) Tennis Muster and Svensson in Final: Thomas Muster of Austria defeated Magnus Gustafsson of Sweden, 6-2, 6-4, yesterday in the second semifinal match at the $150,000 Young Masters tournament in Friedrichshafen, West Germany. In today's final round, Muster will face Jonas Svensson of Sweden, who defeated Alex Antonitsch of Austria, 6-1, 6-1.(AP) Golf Three-Way Tie in Japan: Naomichi Ozaki carded a 66 yesterday and joined the first-round leaders, David Ishii of the United States and Sam Torrance of Scotland, to share a one-shot lead in the Casio World Open tournament in Kaimoncho, Japan. Ozaki shot the best round of the day, gaining the tie with a 7-foot birdie putt on the final hole at the 6,985-yard par-72 Kaimon course. The leaders were eight under par at 136. (AP) Norman Gains Tie: Greg Norman, the two-time champion, shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to tie Terry Price, the first-round leader, for the lead at 136 in the Australian Open tournament in Melbourne. They are eight shots under par and a stroke ahead of Wayne Smith of Australia, who carded a 68.(AP) Boxing Lalonde Captures Title: Donny Lalonde of Winnipeg, Manitoba, knocked out Eddie Davis of Freeport, L.I., with 30 seconds gone in the second round of a scheduled 12-round bout last night to claim the vacant World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title in Port-of-Spain, Trinidad. The title was vacated when Thomas Hearns stepped down to the middleweight ranks. The 27-year-old Canadian ended the fight, which was held in the open-air National Stadium, with a flurry of punches that put the 36-year-old Davis down for the third and final time. Lalonde's record is now 30-2. Davis, ranked No. 1 in the division coming into the fight, is 38-6. Lalonde will defend the title in January against Leslie Stewart of Trinidad, a former World Boxing Association champion. (AP)

A strong six-man band was augmented by a horn section and three tambourine-shaking female backup singers. Together, they kicked up the kind of pop-blues furor that inevitably reminded one of the 1970 ''Mad Dogs and Englishmen'' tour from which the singer emerged a major star.

title: Passing the Test
description: In 265 drug tests administered at random to athletes competing in track and field events throughout Britain over the last 18 months, two positive results were obtained, according to an announcement yesterday in London by the British Amateur Athletics Board. Sue Howland, an Australian javelin thrower, was suspended after testing positive for steroids at a meet in Belfast, Northern Ireland, last summer, and Jayne Andrews, a British sprinter, tested positive for a stimulant, but appealed successfully because she was taking the drug for a chest infection. Among 131 top British stars who passed were Steve Ovett, a former world-record holder in the mile; Fatima Whitehead, the women's world champion in the javelin, and Linford Christie, the European sprint titlist. The board said that five international competitors, all now retired, declined to take the test, but none were of the stature of Ovett, Whitehead or Christie. Among athletes not subjected to the tests were Sebastian Coe, an Olympic 1,500-meter champion, and Steve Cram, the former mile world-record holder. The board said that it was taking the unusual step of releasing names of athletes who had passed the test because of growing reports that drug use was increasing at the top levels of track and field. ''We intend to be as open as possible about our drug-testing program,'' said Tony Ward, a board spokesman. ''We do not say it is perfect, but it is much better than most.''

title: Businesses Don't Need Rent Control
description: As markets for office space tighten up, local governments are tempted by talk of commercial rent control. In New York City, 19 members of the City Council have succumbed: they offer a bill allowing commercial rents to be set by arbitrators. The potential for damage to the city's economy from such a restriction on the free market far outweighs any conceivable benefit.
