title: Doctors Check Wilkins
description: Doctors at the Hughston Sports Medicine Hospital in Columbus, Ga., said yesterday that Dominique Wilkins, the Atlanta Hawks' star forward, does not have structural damage in his sore right knee. They prescribed exercise and said Wilkins could be back in action soon. Wilkins was flown to Columbus from Indianapolis, where the Hawks played the Pacers last night, for the examination by Dr. Jack Hughston. ''The diagnosis is reported to be soreness in the knee as a result of weakness in the quadriceps muscle in the right leg,'' said Bill Needle, a Hawks spokesman. Wilkins was listed as questionable for tonight's game against San Antonio in Atlanta.

title: Regina Garruto Is Wed To Edward W. Nugent
description: At Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J., Regina Rose Garruto, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony R. Garruto of Monmouth Beach, N.J., was married yesterday to Edward William Nugent, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward E. Nugent of Old Bridge, N.J. The Rev. Frank Bruno performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge; Players From Accord, N.Y., Win the Blue Ribbon Pairs
description: The Blue Ribbon Pair Championship, one of the most prized titles in the annual calendar, was won here Thursday night by two quiet men from Accord, N.Y. Playing in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, this pair, Fred Stewart and his stepson, Steve Weinstein, scored 62 percent in the final session and surged past the leaders.

title: HEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $250,000 for the quarter and income of $1,529,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $215,000 for the quarter and $198,000 for the 6 months.

title: Fate of Homeless Woman Is Debated in Court
description: The Koch administration urged an appellate court yesterday to permit it to continue to hospitalize Joyce Brown, the first person picked up under a new city program for the mentally ill homeless.

title: COPING: With Charity Appeals
description: This is the season of charity appeals, as anyone with a mailbox knows.

title: Thomas G. Lanphier Jr., 71, Dies; U.S. Ace Shot Down Yamamoto
description: Thomas G. Lanphier Jr., the World War II fighter pilot who shot down the Japanese airplane carrying the architect of the attack on Pearl Harbor, died Thursday at the San Diego Veterans Administration Hospital at La Jolla, Calif. He was 71 years old.

title: Ex-Judge John F. Scileppi, Author Of Opinion Banning Miller Novel
description: John F. Scileppi, a former associate justice of the New York State Court of Appeals, died of a heart attack Thursday at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I. He was 85 years old.

title: Lillian B. Phipps, 81, Active in Horse Racing
description: Lillian Bostwick Phipps, who was active in horse racing and the performing arts in New York for several decades after World War II, died yesterday at her home in Summerville, S.C. She was 81 years old.

title: ADAMS-RUSSELL ELECTRONICS CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After pretax charges of $4.9 million and $7.7 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from amortization costs related to certain intangible costs associated with four acquisitions made over the last two years. c-Net income

title: New York Is Becoming a City We Don't Want
description: LEAD: New Yorkers are finally awakening to the realization that the city of their future is a city they do not want.

title: Jerry Carlson, Conductor, 31
description: Jerry Carlson, conductor of the Gay Men's Chorus of Los Angeles, died of complications from AIDS on Monday at his home here. He was 31 years old.

title: Developers Expanding Role in Social Services
description: For decades real estate developers have played a catalytic, often decisive part in creating the economic character, social profile and sometimes even the government of much of metropolitan America.

title: Broadway's First Black Acting Star Is the Subject of a Play
description: Charles Gilpin, who became the first black actor to star on Broadway when he won acclaim in the title role of ''The Emperor Jones'' by Eugene O'Neill, is the subject of a new play, ''The Emperor Charles,'' by Spencer Vibbert.

title: Tax and Eased Trade May Be Urged by Tokyo
description: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, in his first major policy speech, said today that he might have to call on the Japanese ''to forbear and endure'' in the interest of smooth relations with other countries.

title: NESBITT THOMSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Marianne Faithfull
description: Marianne Faithfull will perform at 8 and 11 P.M. tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 14 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Tickets are $13.50.

title: Strategic Development
description: To the Editor:

title: Rock: John Cougar Mellencamp
description: ''Growing up leads to growing old and then to dying,'' John Cougar Mellencamp sang on his 1983 album, ''Uh-huh,'' ''And dying to me don't sound like all that much fun.'' Yet since then, Mr. Mellencamp, now 36 years old, has been making an effort to grow up.

title: Illinois Got a Third of U.S. Road Repair Fund
description: Illinois got one-third of all the Federal money earmarked for interstate highway repairs in the last two years, a statistic that its officials attribute to the state's old roads and its ability to ''work the system.''

title: Bruce, Ohio State Settle
description: John Elam, an attorney for Ohio State, said today that Earle Bruce, who was dismissed as the football coach Nov. 16, had dropped a lawsuit against the university in return for a settlement of $471,000 to be paid in three business days.

title: AUDEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Four in Inquiry Were Lauded On Arrest Rate
description: The commander of four New York City transit police officers suspected of making scores of false or improper arrests in the subways used a rating system to reward those who made the most arrests and issued the most summonses with the best assignments and work schedules.

title: Just the Trimmings
description: Paul Dugal's relatives had come from as far as Texas for Thanksgiving dinner, but dinner did not go quite as planned. ''I proceeded to roast my turkey on the barbecue pit and I was about ready to dig in,'' Mr. Dugal said. ''I came in to freshen up and went out to baste it one last time, but when I did the turkey was gone. We had a trimmings dinner.''

title: E'TOWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Harvard Takes Acting to a Higher Level
description: Over the last 200 years, Harvard University has been producing lawyers, doctors and business professionals. Now, for the first time, it is also producing actors, directors and designers - and they are producing plays.

title: Surrogate Will Investigate Management of Estate Settlements
description: The surrogate who supervises the activities of the Manhattan Public Administrator said yesterday that she would begin an inquiry on Monday of allegations that the Administrator through ''profound mismanagement and a dereliction of duty,'' delayed the settlement of thousands of estates worth millions of dollars.

title: Sports of The Times; No Tuxedo for Earle Bruce
description: THIS is the season for turkeys to be fixed and football coaches to be dismissed. What, after all, would the holidays be without such traditional fare?

title: The Speaker Who Ruled With an Iron Fist
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Ready to Sail
description: In 1983, Alan Bond led the Australian challenge that wrested the America's Cup from the United States after 132 years of domination by the New York Yacht Club. Bond said yesterday in Perth that in view of the decision this week by the New York State Supreme Court to allow America's Cup races to be contested by yachts longer than the models used exclusively for the last 30 years, the San Diego Yacht Club should abide by that finding and announce its intention to conduct a multinational and multichallenger series. The court decision ruled valid a New Zealand challenge for 1988 in boats 90 feet long at the waterline. Bond said he hopes that the San Diego syndicate does not restrict the competition to New Zealand. Bond's syndicate is prepared to contest at the 90-foot length. ''The court has upheld the tradition of the deed of gift and now it's impreative that Sail America uphold the international status of the event and not restrict it to a one-on-one match with the Kiwis,'' he said. ''There is no further need for the courts. The judgment is precise and clear. There's no doubt the San Diego Yacht Club should cease stalling and start sailing.''

title: Alma M. Santoso Marries Jonathan Lawrence Katz
description: Alma Maria Santoso, a daughter of Virginia Santoso of Jakarta, Indonesia, and the late Vince Santoso, was married yesterday to Jonathan Lawrence Katz at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Katz, in Fairfield, Conn. Robert Gillette, a justice of the peace in Fairfield, officiated.

title: PRUDENTIAL REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CORDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $476,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $463,000.

title:
Patents;
System for Helicopters Adds to Torque Control
description: LEAD: Helicopters are subject to twisting and turning pressure, called torque, due to rotation of the helicopter blades. A system patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reduces the size and power requirements of anti-torque equipment.

title: Latin Chiefs Denounce 'Rich Countries' on Debt
description: In sharp and insistent terms, the Presidents of eight Latin American countries today condemned what they characterized as intransigence on the part of the United States and other ''rich countries'' and called for concessions on the region's spiraling foreign debt.

title: Officers Vow to Tighten Security In Courts, Even if It Slows Cases
description: Officers assigned to guard prisoners in New York State courts will adopt stricter security procedures, their union leaders said yesterday. They acknowledged the move may greatly increase the time needed to process cases.

title: Adams Thrives Little by Little
description: The football team at John Adams High School in Queens has an advantage in size over its opponents, even though its players are smaller than most in the Public Schools Athletic League.

title: In a Haiti Town, A Time to Vote Is a Time of Fear
description: Two miles short of St.-Marc, a sleepy coastal town, traffic came to a screeching halt.

title: ENERGAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $585,000 from repeal of investment tax credits and a one-time pretax charge of $1.2 million for costs associated with an early retirement program. The 1986 year includes the results of Trans La for the period Jan. 1, 1986, through Sept. 30, 1986.

title: KEY RATES
Two Frenchmen Freed in Beirut; Talks Reported
description: Two Frenchmen held hostage in Lebanon were released today by a shadowy group identifying itself as the Organization of Revolutionary Justice.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $463,000 and $1,524,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and after income of $379,000 for the quarter and a loss of $921,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations, and the 9 months also includes an investment gain of $2,158,000.

title: CONSOLIDATED FIBRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $274,000.

title: Belzberg Company Has Textron Stake
description: The First City Financial Corporation, which is controlled by the Belzberg family of Canada, has purchased a small stake in Textron Inc. and is seeking regulatory clearance to buy even more.

title: Pop: Rosanne Cash Sings
description: Rosanne Cash's warm, tremulous voice and her taste for intelligent lyrics have raised hopes that she will emerge as Nashville's answer to the 1970's Linda Ronstadt - someone who will win country, pop and rock listeners with well-written songs. In her early set Tuesday at the Bottom Line, the material was carefully chosen as always: nearly every song had something telling to say about jealousy or longing or suppressed rage. But in the attempt to follow the Ronstadt model, Ms. Cash and her musical advisers too often try to turn a good ballad singer into a rocker.

title: Dukakis Staff Is Changed, But a Shake-Up Is Denied
description: The press secretary for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's Presidential campaign resigned today and another top staff member was given a new assignment.

title: Effect of Inflation On Capital Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $1,911,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Flanagan and Mraz
description: The duo of Tommy Flanagan on piano and George Mraz on bass will perform at 9:45 tonight and tomorrow at Bradley's, 70 University Place (228-6440). There is no cover charge or minimum.

title: Books of The Times; God as a Nuisance
description: OUR FATHER. By Bernice Rubens. 212 pages. Delacorte Press. $16.95. ''Veronica Smiles was crossing the Sahara desert, minding her own business, when she ran into God.''

title: U.S. AIDES SAY PACT HAS STRICT TERMS ON VERIFYING ARMS
description: In a campaign to build Senate support for the missile treaty with the Soviet Union, the Administration provided details today to show that the pact contains tougher verification provisions than those agreed to in the past.

title: TALKS ARE PUT OFF
description: A tentative agreement was reached today to free 26 hostages held by Cuban detainees here, but it fell apart at the last minute.

title: BALTIMORE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for 12mo Oct 31
U.S. Cable Agrees To Acquire Essex
description: The Essex Communications Corporation said it had reached a definitive agreement to merge with a subsidiary of the U.S. Cable Television Group L.P. for $102.7 million in cash. U.S. Cable will also buy the assets of four partnerships affiliated with Essex for $122.3 million.

title: Shopping Hours at Stores and Malls
description: More than 20 million shoppers will troop into stores and malls in the metropolitan area in the next month.

title: Losses Seen At Allegheny
description: Allegheny International Inc. today estimated its net losses at $215 million for the third quarter and $285 million for the first nine months of 1987. The company also said it would pay no dividends for the sixth consecutive quarter.

title: Seoul Bars Electioneering in Military
description: The South Korean Defense Minister told his top commanders today not to interfere in next month's presidential election and to allow their soldiers to vote by secret ballot for the candidate of their choice.

title: AMERICAN SHARED HOSPITAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Settlement in Bhopal Case
description: District Judge M. W. Deo said today that he would consider a request for interim relief to help surviving victims of the 1984 gas leak from a Union Carbide plant in Bhopal that killed more than 2,800 people and injured more than 200,000.

title: Syracuse Trounces Anchorage by 95-76
description: Stephen Thompson scored 19 points as Syracuse bounced back from a season-opening loss by routing Alaska-Anchorage, 95-76, tonight in the 10th Great Alaska Shootout.

title: Forwood Wiser Jr., Aviation Executive Who Led 3 Carriers
description: Forwood C. Wiser Jr., an aviation executive whose career included stints as president of three airlines, died of Alzheimer's disease Monday at Foothill Acres Nursing Home in Neshanic, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12..

title: West Held Immune To Gulf Oil Shocks
description: New realities affecting world oil supplies have put the industrial countries in a position to withstand even a major disruption of the flow of petroleum from the Persian Gulf, according to senior officials in the United States and other Western countries.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the worst, most terrifying massacre we've ever seen, and that's including the war years. This is quite barbaric.'' - Ted Kirby, of the Commercial Farmers Union of Zimbabwe. [ 1:2. ]

title: APPLIED BIOSCIENCE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said the year-ago third quarter and 9-month earnings are on a pro forma basis reflecting the elimination of certain charges by the company's former parent, and they reflect certain other adjustments necessary to present the company on a stand-alone basis.

title: Youth Symphony
description: The New York Youth Symphony, conducted by Peter Rubardt, will perform works by Stravinsky, Vaughan Williams and Dvorak, along with the premiere of ''American Slick,'' by William Doerrfeld, at 3 P.M. tomorrow in Carnegie Hall. The concert is free. Information: 581-5933.

title: Israeli Army Assailed Over Glider Raid
description: The army is traditionally viewed here as a national symbol above reproach, but today its command came under harsh criticism from Israeli newspapers for its failure to stop a Palestinian guerrilla on a motorized hang glider from penetrating the northern border and attacking a military base.

title: OPPENHEIMER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter's loss is attributed to the results of its Oppenheimer & Co. investment banking and brokerage subsidiary.

title: Runner Appeals
description: Sandra Gasser, a Swiss runner who was banned from competition for two years by the International Amateur Athletic Federation on Sept. 29 after failing a test for steroids at the world track championships in Rome, has filed an appeal that seeks to overturn that penalty as well as the revocation of her bronze medal in the women's 1,500-meter race at the world competition in Rome. Gasser showed traces of testosterone, a banned synthetic hormone that can improve an athlete's performance, in two tests. Gasser's appeal cites discrepancies between the results of the two samples. The Swiss Athletic Federation filed a virtually identical appeal in support of Gasser, according to George Kennel, the S.A.F. president. The I.A.A.F. has three months to consider the appeals.

title: There Is No 'Just Price' for Art
description: LEAD: For some years now in the United States, it has been fashionable in artistic circles to advocate a rather unsophisticated version of the concept of a just price. This concept was first enacted into law in California and is now proposed by Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

title: Hyundai Duty Protested
description: Trade Minister Rha Woong Bae protested today to Canada about a preliminary anti-dumping ruling against South Korea's popular Hyundai cars, a ministry spokesman said. Canada's Revenue and Customs Department decided earlier this week that the Hyundai Motor Company was selling cars in Canada at unfairly low prices. They imposed an average 36 percent provisional duty on the vehicles. Mr. Rha told the Canadian Ambassador, Reginald Dorrett, and the visiting Assistant Deputy Foreign Minister for Asian and Pacific Affairs, Jean McCloskey, that he hoped the duty would be lowered sharply in a final ruling.

title: New York's School System in Crisis
description: The burst of pronouncements this past week by Mayor Koch, Governor Cuomo and others about what is wrong with the New York City Board of Education and the all-but-forced resignation of perhaps its most talented member brought into the open what some have long thought: that the school system is in crisis.

title: TRUST AMERICA SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rationale for Testing a Flawed Alzheimer Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; Balloon Used in Clamp For Vascular Surgery
description: Dr. Howard C. Baron of New York received a patent this week for a vascular balloon clamp to be used in surgery involving arteries and veins. He explains that it is necessary to set clamps above and below an operation site, but hard-jaw metal clamps now in use can injure the artery wall.

title: East Berlin Journal; Strange Bedfellows: Marxists Embrace Nietzsche
description: A re-evaluation of the 19th-century philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche has begun here with the endorsement of the Communist authorities, despite Nietzsche's reputation as one of the principal spiritual fathers of Nazism.

title: CHAMBERS DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $131,000 from early retirement of debt for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES

title: Why the Cubans Riot
description: Of course the United States has the right to send back to Cuba refugees who never qualified for admission and who have committed crimes in America. But should it do so? Not necessarily.

title: Howard Loses Injunction Bid
description: A Federal judge today denied Howard University's request that Saturday's Division I-AA football playoff games be halted while Howard sues the N.C.A.A. over its exclusion from postseason play. United States District Judge

title: FINE HOMES INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results are Fine Homes' first quarter as a public company, which went public in June.

title: Weather Service Predicting A Stormy Winter in the East
description: Winter should be wet and stormy on the East Coast, cold in the Midwest and the Deep South, and warm and dry in the Southwest, the Government's chief long-range forecaster said today.

title: ALOETTE COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BARRIER SCIENCE & TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A POPULAR CHOICE FOR FLORAL DESIGNS
description: TRIM hedges, and if evergreen, store the clippings outdoors to use for making wreaths, door swags or table centerpieces. Clean out the tool shed. Go over catalogues and discard those no longer needed to make room for new ones due in January. Popular Flower

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Oct. 18 about a bust on display at the Palais des Beaux-Arts in Brussels, misidentified the work. It is of Philip the Good, Duke of Burgundy.

title: FROMNEW COMPANY, A MODERN SCROOGE
description: HOW to save the American musical theater? Kevin Connors thought he'd found a way. And when Roger Ludlowe High School in Fairfield, Conn., was closed last year, Mr. Connors knew he'd found the place.

title: CORRECTION
description: Credits were reversed on two cartoons in The Week in Review last Sunday. One, showing President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua sitting on a shipment from Moscow, was drawn by Steven Turtil of the Charleston (W. Va.) Daily Mail. The other, showing a contra leader as a puppet on President Reagan's foot, was by Rainer Hachfeld of the Hamburger Rundschau in West Germany.

title:
IN THE REGION: NEW JERSEY;
A 'New City' Will Rise Along the Ramapo
description: LEAD: AFTER 13 months of delays and tough negotiations, Oakland officials and a developer have agreed on a plan to carve a residential community from 297 acres of woodlands along the Ramapo River.

title: From Vivaldi, Operatic Morsels
description: LEAD: ONE TENDS TO THINK OF Vivaldi as a composer of concerti; after all, he wrote about 500 of them, and his ''Four Seasons'' violin concerti have been at the top of the hit parade for years. Yet the redhaired Venetian priest and violinist, who got his start training the girls of a Venetian orphanage as musicians, also wrote quantities of sacred music, cantatas, and nearly 50 operas.

title: WE OWE THE WILD THINGS A WARMER WELCOME
description: AN extraordinary sight met my eyes one evening in late summer. My two cats were on the lawn facing something sitting between them. That ''something'' was black with white stripes. All three animals were frozen into immobility; the cats weren't taking their eyes off the skunk and the skunk wasn't certain just where to turn or what to do next. The air as yet was still sweet with the scent of honeysuckle and nicotiana.

title: Kevin Roche Finishes a Trio And Changes His Tune
description: WHEN KEVIN ROCHE'S 1 United Nations Plaza, the hotel and office tower at the corner of First Avenue and 44th Street, was finished in 1976, the most notable thing about it was the extent to which the tower's shimmering glass-and-metal form broke rank with everything around it. The building is an exquisite minimalist sculpture; its abstract form has nothing to do with any of the buildings near it, except for the allusions its blue-green glass makes to the United Nations Secretariat building across First Avenue. When the building gained a comrade in 1984, with the completion of the adjoining 2 United Nations Plaza just to its west on 44th Street, the effect did not change - the two towers merely joined visually to form a larger abstract composition that still stands apart.

title: POSTINGS: Co-op Seminar; Sponsors And Boards
description: Thirty-five years ago, long before apartment ownership took hold in New York City, a small group of residential cooperatives in Queens formed a support group, the Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives.

title: DOUGLAS'S LETTERS CAST LIGHT ON LIFE
description: Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court thought Federal agents were trying to plant marijuana at his ranch in the West and he thought a Pennsylvania mob was going to lynch him for his role in the Rosenberg spy case, according to a new book, ''The Douglas Letters.''

title: Celebrations of the Season; In Germany, Markets Full Of Toys, Tinsel and Sweets
description: TO say that the Germans invented Christmas undoubtedly taxes the imagination - and patience - of historians beyond the tolerable, even if many trimmings of the event, including its celebration around the winter solstice, have undeniable pagan Teutonic elements. But even skeptics will acknowledge that, in all likelihood, Christmas markets had their origins somewhere between the Rhine and the Oder, the North Sea and the Alps. Of that there's reasonable proof: some of them have pedigrees reaching far back into the Middle Ages.

title: NOT MANY JUDGES PRACTICE WHAT THE PRESIDENT PREACHES
description: ALTHOUGH no President since Franklin Delano Roosevelt has been able to appoint more judges than Ronald Reagan, the Federal court system has not yet become the conservative bastion that he and his supporters had intended. It has not been for lack of trying. By the end of his term, Mr. Reagan will probably have named more than half of the nation's 743 Federal judges. So far, he has won Senate confirmation of 332 judges - 249 of the 575 judges on the Federal District Courts, or trial courts, 75 of the 168 judges on the Federal appeals courts and six of the nine judges on the International Trade Court. Of the nine Supreme Court Justices Mr. Reagan has appointed two, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia. Hearings are to begin Dec. 14 on Mr. Reagan's nomination of Judge Anthony M. Kennedy to the Court; barring major revelations, his confirmation is likely to come in February.

title: Pointing Toward Vietnam
description: THE KOREAN WAR By Max Hastings. Illustrated. 389 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: Practical Traveler; What You Can Expect From a Travel Agent
description: YOU'RE a smart person; do you really need a travel agent for your vacation trip? An agent is probably not going to save you a lot of money on an air trip, unless you are shy about calling a lot of airlines on 800 numbers and asking what the cheapest fare is to that place. But if you would rather do something other than this research, you probably need a travel agent.

title: Moves to Make Before Yearend
description: AS the year 1987 winds down, millions of Americans are casting about for last-minute ways to minimize the tax burden that awaits them April 15. Although year-end opportunities for tax savings are not so plentiful now as they were prior to the Tax Reform Act of 1986, they do exist. For one thing, all tax benefits have not been abolished: Retirement savings plans, for example.are still available. Also, the new tax system is not fully in place, and tax rates for individuals are set to drop even further next year. Similarly, many deductions will be phased out over a period of years rather than overnight.

title: The Falling Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: Don McPherson led Syracuse to an undefeated season, thus ending a 24-year absence from a New Year's bowl date. Consider another aspect of McPherson's exemplary season. Back in 1961 Syracuse University's Ernie Davis became the first black man ever to receive the coveted trophy. Would it not be judicious and historically correct to award the Heisman to the first black quarterback from that same fine university? KEVIN F. McMURRAY Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: ARTS AGENCIES SEEK SHARE OF BOND ISSUE
description: AT A SMALL Italian restaurant here, Allen W. McCracken fidgeted during a recent lunch and conceded he was somewhat nervous.

title: REAGAN WANTS END OF TWO-TERM LIMIT
description: President Reagan says that after leaving office he ''would like to start a movement'' to repeal the constitutional amendment that limits Presidents to two terms.

title: Military Supplier to Plead Guilty in Parts Scheme
description: A military contractor and its president have agreed to plead guilty to charges of passing off used electrical connectors as new ones for military aircraft, a Federal prosecutor said Friday.

title: Bay Area Bread
description: To the Editor: S. Irene Virbila's article about the wonders of Bay Area bread (Travel, Nov. 1) could only bring a feeling of self-righteousness and I-told-you-so to those of us who always brought an empty suitcase to San Francisco in order to fill it with bread to bring back to New York.

title: Rather Stay Flabby Than Fit
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LORENZO BRAVES THE AIR WARS
description: FRANK LORENZO, CHAIRMAN OF THE TEXAS AIR CORPO-ration, personifies the grand social experiment called airline deregulation. Pioneer of the low fares that brought air travel within reach of millions of Americans, ruthless competitor and union-buster, he has since 1980 transformed a feisty regional carrier into the largest airline enterprise in the non-Communst world. His empire encompasses two major carriers, Eastern and Continental, plus the remnants of People Express, New York Air, Frontier and several small, regional carriers. Yet even as Texas Air has mushroomed, its chief executive has increasingly withdrawn from public view.

title: Rights Group Reports Continued Abuses of Liberty in Turkey
description: Despite steps taken by the Turkish Government to stop human rights abuses, violations of citizens' liberties still continue, according to a 1987 report issued last week by the Helsinki Watch Committee.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: WOULD ANYONE ARGUE AGAINST THE proposition that the ear is the body's most important organ in the perception and evaluation of music? Not likely. Even the more presumptuous opera directors might concede, at least in principle, that there is more to music than meets the eye. But it is also true that seeing while listening can sometimes add a dimension to a problematical work and make a believer of a skeptic. That happened to me recently when Oliver Knussen's fantasy opera ''Where the Wild Things Are'' arrived at the New York City Opera. This work, with its whimsical libretto, scenery and costumes by Maurice Sendak and its captivating staging by Frank Corsaro, had been picking up good notices for several years before New York imported it. In fact, for a contemporary opera, it had received an uncommon amount of critical and other attention since its appearance in 1982. Whatever the work's merits, anything like surprise seemed out of the question.

title: WHEN THE DAY NEVER ENDS
description: THE SUN WAS JUST RISING OVER MY tiny garden apartment in Tokyo when I placed the call to my boss in New York. I was in urgent need of some instructions to complete a multimillion-dollar deal. My sleeves were rolled up, my morning coffee was steaming on the kitchen table and I was in high gear.

title: CHANGING SYNAPSES: TEACHING OLD NEURONS NEW TRICKS
description: DURING the last eight years, the number of research reports presented at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience has more than doubled, exceeding 6,600 this year. In an attempt to keep up, more than 11,000 scientists and onlookers gathered for the 1987 convention, which was held in New Orleans this month. What follows are reports on some of the ascendant ideas in the continuing attempt to learn how the brain generates the mind, and how the mind controls the body.

title: City Island
description: IN 1895, the seafaring residents of City Island were promised a new school building and bridge to the mainland if they would leave Westchester County and join New York City. With 900 ballots cast, the city beat the county by only two votes.

title: Texas and New Mexico Battle Over Remains of Fallen Confederate Soldiers
description: When a landowner digging a foundation for his new house uncovered a mass grave here last summer, Civil War enthusiasts immediately guessed its contents: the remains of Confederate soldiers slain at the battle of Glorieta. The brief but intense encounter, part of an ill-fated Confederate campaign in the Far West, was fought on March 28, 1862.

title: C.E.O.'S ARE HIS NECTAR
description: AT 10:15 ON A SPARKLING AUTUMN morning, Gerard R. Roche - the Old Master, the High Priest, the Grand Acquisitor, the King of the Executive Headhunters - is seated at his desk on the 32d floor of the American Brands Building on Manhattan's Park Avenue, doing the thing he does better than anyone else. Half-moon glasses on the tip of his nose, phone propped on a shoulder, wing-tip shoes on the corner of his desk, Roche is pouring oil on the troubled waters of a major American ego. A large and distressed corporation needs a chief executive officer, needs one badly, needs one now, but there has been a hitch. On the other end of the phone line, a candidate for the position is fighting paranoia.

title: A Jury Sides With Vermont In Sex Discrimination Case
description: A jury has ruled in favor of the state in the sex discrimination case brought by Nancy Graff, a former acting editor of the magazine Vermont Life.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE GHETTO OF VENICE. By Riccardo Calimani. Translated by Katherine Silberblatt Wolfthal. (M. Evans, $19.95.) In 1516, Venice compelled the Jews of the city to live in a separate walled-in area called the ghetto - a word whose derivation may have come from a foundry in the area. From then until the tearing down of the ghetto's gates and walls in 1797, the fortunes of Venice and the ghetto were linked by economic, political and religious ties.

title: On to Judgment
description: Even in the horrific company of Nazi concentration camp commanders, Josef Schwammberger stood out as a bestial man, according to wartime Austrian police files that were recently made public. Mr. Schwammberger, now 75 years old, admitted shooting 35 Jews during questioning in 1945. He escaped from detention that year and later surfaced in Argentina, where he was arrested this month and now faces extradition to West Germany.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I have been advised that when I close my summer home for the winter, I should leave the heat on at a low setting of about 40 degrees to protect the wood paneling, built-ins and furniture. Do you think heating is necessary when the house is unoccupied?

title: Amy Jill Maneker To Wed in March
description: Announcement has been made by Deanna C. Maneker of Westport, Conn., and Morton M. Maneker of New York City of the engagement of their daughter Amy Jill Maneker to Dr. Brian Robert Herts, a son of Dorothy Herts of Roslyn, L.I., and Harry Herts of Scottsdale, Ariz. A March wedding is planned.

title: On Ice Skates, 'Sleeping Beauty' Wobbles
description: ''THE SLEEPING BEAUTY,'' A ballet on ice conceived for television, which will be shown next Sunday evening at 7 on Channel 13, banks on the current popularity of three key elements within the production: dance, skating and a renewed interest in fairy-tale themes. These are supposedly magic ingredients, but they do not automatically jell into a unified result. In this instance, each part remains greater than the whole.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about the belief that Thomas Jefferson maintained a long intimate relationship with one of his slave women misstated the history of Frances Trollope's book ''Domestic Manners of the Americans.'' It was published in 1832.

title: CAN THE MENNONITES SURVIVE SUCCESS?
description: I enjoyed Paul Cohen's thoughtful article on the Mennonites. A considerable number of your readers are not attracted to yuppie-type articles about Wall Street, fashion or Madison Avenue. ADAM PENENBERG New York, N.Y.

title: TEATOWN GETS GRANT FOR GUIDES
description: LEAD: TEATOWN Lake Reservation has received a $25,000 grant to develop a training program in communciations for guides and naturalists who work at county and state nature centers and historic sites. It was awarded by the New York State Natural Heritage Trust Fund, which administers grants totaling $4 million annually.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-29 Preparing for a vote on contra aid, the White House is trying to determine if Congress will allow $30 million in nonlethal supplies to be used for military training. to the polls today for their first presidential election in 30 years. 1 Haitians are shaky but ready 16 The Argentine government has been thrust into crisis and confusion by the loss that President Raul Alfonsin's Radical Civic Union suffered in the September by-elections. 22 The Soviet presence in Afghanistan is at a crucial moment, Western diplomats say, with Moscow desperate to find a way to title: Father Held in Slaying Of 2 Sons in Foundry
description: A father stopped by the foundry where he works on his way to Thanksgiving dinner and killed his two young sons by putting them in a large ladle and heating it, the authorities charged Friday.

title: CAN LEGACY OF VIOLENCE BE VOTED OUT?
description: IT was nearly midnight when two young men, one carrying a piece of pipe, the other a length of lumber, marched down the middle of a deserted boulevard in the heart of the Haitian capital. They were members of one of the many neighborhood patrol groups that sprang up briefly last week in Port-au-Prince and other Haitian towns to fight an intensifying terror campaign aimed at disrupting the presidential elections scheduled for today.

title: Smoking-Rule Smoke
description: When New York's highest court last week upheld two previous court rulings, it did not uphold smoking in public. It said that the State Public Health Council had gone too far in issuing new rules on public smoking. The council, said six of the seven judges on the Court of Appeals, had ''usurped'' legislative power.

title: REAGAN AIDES SEEK WAY FOR CONGRESS TO HELP CONTRAS
description: The Reagan Administration, preparing for a crucial vote on renewed aid to the Nicaraguan rebels early next month, is trying to determine if Congress will allow a requested $30 million for non-lethal supplies to be used for helicopters and military training, according to officials in the White House and Congress.

title:
TO START WITH...;
GETTING TO KNOW YOU
description: LEAD: Wanda Ferragamo, the Tuscan shoe industrialist, was the hostess as 48 members of the Committee of 200, an American network of women entrepreneurs and executives, sat down to lunch last month with three dozen Italian counterparts in the Hotel Baglioni in Florence. It was time for introductions, but Saundra K.

title: What the Amazons Taught Her
description: THE FIREBRAND By Marion Zimmer Bradley. 608 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Two to Cross The Country
description: When the best high-school cross-country runners in the nation gather for the Kinney National Championships Dec. 12 in San Diego, it will mark the second visit for Nnenna Lynch but the first for Ramon Espinosa. They qualified yesterday by being among the top eight finishers in their divisions during the Northeast Regional championships at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THINKING IN PICTURES: The Making of the Movie ''Matewan.'' By John Sayles. (Houghton Mifflin, Cloth, $21.95; Paper, $9.95.) If you've ever wondered how some of the sillier dialogue gets into movies, John Sayles has a convincing explanation. Give a studio executive a script for a western, and there will come a time when, unable to visualize the stampeding buffalo herd, he will wonder, ''Couldn't one of the Indians say, 'Here come the buffalo'?'' ''Thinking in Pictures'' aims to wipe out such cinematic illiteracy. Mr. Sayles, the writer and director of ''Matewan'' (and several earlier movies), takes us through his creation of this current, critically praised film about a violent feud between mine owners and union activists in 1920 West Virginia. The true film artist, he demonstrates, must be thoroughly practical to put his vision on screen. Raising money is a Sisyphean job; in the three years it took to get backers for ''Matewan,'' production costs rose from $1.8 million to $3.6 million. Even that is a paltry amount for a period film, so Mr. Sayles lets us in on his small economies. (Shoot crowd scenes early in the day, and avoid paying extras overtime.) He talks about casting, gives pithy definitions of what grips and gaffers do, reproduces the film's shooting script, recalls how the crew pushed a car so the motor's noise wouldn't interfere with dialogue. All that's missing is a sense of the pain and bloodletting often involved in a film maker's practical compromises, but for the curious movie viewer this is a lively tale of how some of the smarter movies get made.

title: Near the Oakdale Center, a Long Vigil but Not a Lonely One
description: Scott Sutterfield was never afraid of his job as a guard at the Federal detention center in Oakdale, La., but he had a feeling that something unwelcome might happen when he went to work Nov. 21.

title: Pension Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: TEMPORARY FRIENDSHIP IS NO CAUSE FOR LAMENT
description: IN ''A Little Visit With a Big Surprise'' [ Opinion Page, Oct. 25 ] , Herbert Hadad laments the apparent failure of a bond, built during a holiday encounter with some beautiful people, to survive separation.

title: On the Wild Side
description: THERE WILL BE NO STEEL BARS. There will be a walk-through rain forest with birds flying freely overhead. There will be state-of-the-art artificial trees, designed by Jonquil LeMaster-Rock (above). There will be 200 species, including polar bears, penguins, puffins, muntjac, macaques and leaf-cutter ants. Manhattan's Central Park Zoo, the $29 million renovation of which began in 1985, is to reopen late this spring, a wholly different place. ''The point we're driving home,'' says Richard L. Lattis, director of the City Zoos Project, which, under the auspices of the New York Zoological Society is revamping zoos in Brooklyn and Queens as well, ''is conservation of wild animals and wild habitat.''

title: FOR CHRISTMAS, GIFTS MADE BY HAND
description: THE mail-order catalogues have been examined, the local shops resplendent with Christmas displays explored, and you've still not found the definitive gifts for those very special people on your Christmas list. It's obviously time for a fresh approach.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
ART
description: LEAD: Raphael Three-part film special (''The Apprentice Years,'' ''The Prince of Painters,'' ''Legend and Legacy''). Produced and directed by Ann Turner. Home Vision. Three cassettes, 58 minutes each. $39.95 each. Forming volumes 15 to 17 of Home Vision's ''Portrait of an Artist'' series, ''Raphael'' is the video equivalent of a coffee table art monograph, and an admirable one well worth owning.

title: INVESTOR PROFILES: Yields Improve the Quality of Life; Funding An Active Retirement
description: BARBARA and Joseph Suarez started life with very little money. But late last year, when they decided to retire and move to Florida, they found that their house in Westchester County - for which they had paid $50,000, 20 years before - was worth close to $300,000. Between that and some savings, they had a lump sum of $325,000.

title: A 'LABOR OF LOVE' IN POUND RIDGE
description: LEAD: REFLECTING on his four years as Pound Ridge Supervisor, Peter Robohm, who is about to leave office, recalled some unusual accomplishments.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transcription error, a phrase was dropped in last week's article by Robert J. Geiger. The complete sentence is as follows: The time has come to switch places if we are to move effectively into the 21st century: The builder must think like an environmentalist and the environmentalist must think like a pragmatic business person.

title: SARI LYNN KALOMEER WED TO GREGORY SHOLOM ON L.I.
description: At Temple Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., Sari Lynn Kalomeer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kalomeer of Matawan, N.J., was married last evening to Gregory Seth Sholom, a son of Ronald Sholom of New York and Cornwall Bridge, Conn., and Susan Norwalk of Floral Park, Queens. Rabbi Ephraim Buchwald officiated.

title: Salzburg
description: To the Editor: While it is no doubt possible to spend $100 for dinner for two at the places Mr. Millard mentioned, prospective visitors to Salzburg should not be discouraged by the prices quoted.

title: NEW YORKERS, etc.
description: ACCORDING to a certain genre of romantic novel, there's a ''no better than she should be'' seductress simmering inside many a discreet black dress, and an adventurous swashbuckler lurking behind a lot of blue pin-stripe suits. Stick with these romances and inevitably passion flares, a volcano erupts.

title: A PROTEIN IS IMPLICATED: NEW CLUES TO ALZHEIMER'S
description: DURING the last eight years, the number of research reports presented at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience has more than doubled, exceeding 6,600 this year. In an attempt to keep up, more than 11,000 scientists and onlookers gathered for the 1987 convention, which was held in New Orleans this month. What follows are reports on some of the ascendant ideas in the continuing attempt to learn how the brain generates the mind, and how the mind controls the body.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: The Trophy should go to one of the outstanding and most overlooked running backs of this season, Kenny Gamble of Colgate. This season he broke several school and Division I-AA yardage and scoring records. Even when compared with the better-known players from larger schools, Gamble has shown himself to be almost a one-man team. KURT NIELSEN Roselle, N.J.

title: Adopted School
description: IT'S always nice when an alumnus makes good and gives a little something to his alma mater, even nicer when a virtual stranger makes the gift. It was especially nice the other day then when Benoit Benjamin of the Los Angeles Clippers presented a $10,000 check to Southern University in Baton Rouge, La., and promised to send another fat donation to the school every year he plays in the N.B.A.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsfield, Mass.;
Breathing Life Into Downtown
description: LEAD: FOR almost 20 years, this city had tried unsuccessfully to bring major retail development to a vacant 11-acre site in the center of downtown. The property had been cleared for urban renewal in 1968 and was owned by the Pittsfield Housing Authority.

title: PLANS FOR HOMELESS GET MIXED REVIEWS
description: A PLAN to expand services for homeless people in Nassau County reverses years of denial by county officials that a problem exists but falls woefully short of what is needed, advocates for the homeless say.

title: A Landlord-Tenant Vendetta on East 89th
description: CROWDED into a New York State hearing examiner's room on John Street one Friday afternoon this month were enough big guns to fight a major battle, even though only a skirmish was at hand.

title: This Feast Leads To Famine
description: WE'RE BEING OVERRUN. THEY'RE COM-ing from Paris, London, Rome, Hollywood, New York, Seattle, Hoboken and Palermo -from Zimbabwe, Mexico, China, Zaire, Japan, Sweden, Canada, Israel, plus points in between, as well as out of the woodwork. Some arrive preceded by dignified, majestic pronouncements as to their Importance. Some are accompanied by all of the circus-style hoopla that money can buy. Others slip in unannounced, as if tossed over the transom or pushed under the door. A very few are firm and fresh, but most have already gone soft.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
Sculpture's 'Saint'
description: LEAD: SAINT GAUDENS: MASQUE OF THE GOLDEN BOWL Home Vision. 60 Minutes. $39.95.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO PREPARE FOR FREEZING WEATHER
description: LEAD: With the advent of freezing weather imminent, it's time to provide a rundown of last-minute gardening chores.

title: Miriam Was One of His Secrets
description: LEAD: SHIMONI'S LOVER By Jenifer Levin. 378 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $18.95.

title: PLAYGROUNDS, DEEMED UNSAFE, GET NEW LOOK
description: LEAD: MANY of the playgrounds and much of the equipment in the 17 Nassau County parks are now deemed unsafe under new guidelines from the Federal Consumer Products Safety Commission.

title: Scientists Hope to Solve Riddle of the Ice Ages
description: By drilling to the bottom of the ice sheet in the heart of Antarctica, Soviet and French scientists are determined to solve the riddle of the ice ages by acquiring a year-to-year record of climate for the last half-million years.

title: HIDDEN ASSETS
description: Embroiled in divorce proceedings, the dress manufacturer's wife was struggling to get what she considered to be her fair share of the assets accumulated over 12 years of marriage. Her husband claimed that his company's annual sales had dropped from $2 million to $800,000, but she suspected there was more there than met the eye - in the form of off-the-books cash sales.

title: Talks on Gibraltar Airport
description: Britain and Spain failed to settle their dispute over Gibraltar Airport today, but said they would hold fresh talks next week. Foreign Secretary Sir Geoffrey Howe of Britain told reporters he would meet his Spanish counterpart, Francisco Fernandez-Ordonez, in London on Wednesday for a previously unscheduled round of negotiations with both countries' transport ministers. Disputed sovereignty over the British colony's airport is blocking a European Community plan for cheaper air fares.

title: PSYCHOLOGY IS DELICATE IN STRATEGY OF ARMS CUTS
description: BEHIND the esoteric acronyms and intricate statistics that dominate the Soviet-American negotiations on arms control, there stands a psychological equation, one so delicate that it seems strangely out of place amid the awesome power of mutual destruction held by the leaders in Washington and Moscow. It is the search for a carefully drawn balance of incentives, deterrents and expectations designed to lead each side to conclude that it cannot ultimately gain by being the first to launch a devastating nuclear attack against the other.

title: CANS CASHED IN FOR SMOKE DETECTORS
description: THE Stamford Fire Department is running a program to collect returnable bottles and cans and to cash them in for money to buy smoke detectors.

title: SUSAN WILLIAMS WEDS DANIEL SCHECTER IN MARYLAND
description: Susan Williams, a research analyst at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., and Daniel Schecter, a management consultant for the LEK Partnership in Los Angeles, were married yesterday at the Chapelgate Presbyterian Church in Ellicott City, Md. The Rev. Dr. Donald Kinloch performed the ceremony.

title: INVESTOR PROFILES: Yields Improve the Quality of Life; Payouts For Social Concerns
description: RUTH SHEREFF, now 44 years old, bought stock on her own for the first time just two years ago. Her father, who had been managing her money until then, said that it would have been better had she lost money the first time out so she would learn caution and humility. Instead, she made a killing.

title: FOR NEARLY 90 YEARS, MUSIC IS CLUB'S CAUSE
description: LEAD: The caption under her picture in the 1943 yearbook of Watertown High School reads ''Music is the core of her existence.'' Forty-four years later, that is still true for Jean Dowling of Fairfield, a piano teacher, organist, choir director and director of a 10-member bell choir. Now, as the new president of the Wednesday Afternoon Musical

title: A Stage Wizard Conjures Much From Little
description: THERE ARE SEVERAL MO-ments in Hugh Whitemore's ''Breaking the Code'' when Derek Jacobi fulfills our conventional expectations of a major actor. He expresses pain, anger, grief, desolation and, once or twice, a curious mix of them all, making one's eyes pop at the authenticity of his emotions and the potency of his performance. And yet it's his playing of the small moments, not the big ones, that we should perhaps be treasuring the most. Again and again he reminds us that the art of acting is the art of conjuring much out of little, or more out of less, or something out of nothing. It's the art of making silence articulate and platitude eloquent. It's the art of taking a line as flat as a parking lot in a small Midwestern town and somehow suggesting that there's an abundance of animal life in the fissures and crannies beneath its surface.

title: HUNTER SLOAN HAS WEDDING
description: At the Trinity College Chapel in Hartford, Mary Hunter Sloan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Sloan 3d of Farmington, Conn., was married yesterday to Mario A. Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Terrence B. Smith of New Milford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Borden W. Painter Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE CARE OF STRANGERS: The Rise of America's Hospital System, by Charles E. Rosenberg. (Basic, $22.95.) A splendid history of the place it is always startling to find oneself in, and which the author interprets, rightly, as a microcosm of American society. SPIRIT SEIZURES, by Melissa Pritchard. (University of Georgia, $13.95.) Dispassion holds such sway in these 17 unpredictable tales that resignation and realization seem not only human but normal. INCIDENTS IN THE LIFE OF A SLAVE GIRL: Written by Herself, by Harriet A. Jacobs. Edited by L. Maria Child; new edition edited by Jean Fagan Yellin. (Harvard, Cloth, $37.50; Paper, $9.95.) A superbly researched edition of an 1861 female slave narrative, itself the crowning achievement of the genre, by a writer who once seemed lost, but now is found, never to be lost again. THE DEVIL AND DR. BARNES: Portrait of an American Art Collector, by Howard Greenfeld. (Viking, $19.95.) There could be no fairer portrait of the terrible-tempered Dr. Barnes, who with a magnificent eye for modern art built his stunning collection. PSYCHOTIC REACTIONS AND CARBURETOR DUNG, by Lester Bangs. Edited by Greil Marcus. (Knopf, $19.95.) Writings in a major key by the rock critic, novelist manque, who died in 1982. THE VELVET PRISON: Artists Under State Socialism, by Miklos Haraszti. Translated by Katalin and Stephen Landesmann with Steve Wasserman. (New Republic/Basic, $14.95.) A Hungarian dissident ruefully explains why glasnost as he defines it (toleration disguised as openness) is mightier than the ICBM. DREAMHOUSE, by Kate Grenville. (Viking, $14.95.) A novel that captures states of feeling as one would snare wild birds in a net.

title: SARAH VALENTINE BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Sarah Gray Valentine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Massie Valentine of Richmond and Virginia Beach, Va., was married last evening to Jesse Thompson Ellington 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellington Jr. of San Marino, Calif. The Rev. Frank F. Fagan performed the ceremony at St. James's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

title: Verbatim; Remembering Nixon
description: ' I have long held and often expressed the view that Richard M. Nixon had it within his grasp to be our greatest post-World War II President. . . .

title:
HOME VIDEO;
MUSIC
description: LEAD: Zoot Sims Quartet Zoot Sims, Roger Kellaway, Larry Bunker, Chuck Berghofer. Rhapsody Films. 28 minutes. $29.95. The owner of the club in Los Angeles where ''Zoot Sims Quartet'' was filmed can be forgiven for viewing the resultant video as a half-hour advertisement. Between the numbers, shots of the neon sign out front alternate with shots of patrons eating and drinking.

title: Maine Addresses Child Deaths
description: Maine's rate of accidental deaths of children, nearly twice as high as in some other New England states, is prompting questions and some answers from the state's pediatricians.

title: 8 Latin Chiefs Urge Cuba Role In Their Region
description: The presidents of eight Latin American countries, meeting here for their first conference held without the participation of the United States, agreed today that Cuba should be invited to rejoin regional organizations from which it has been excluded for more than two decades.

title: KRISTINA L. DAHL WEDS JOSEPH G. HYLAS ON L.I.
description: Kristina Louise Dahl, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Robert Dahl of Manhasset, L.I., and Hancock, Mass., and Joseph Gerard Hylas, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Hylas of New York, were married yesterday. Bishop Robert P. Varley performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset.

title: Injury Keeps Taylor Out
description: For the first time in his seven years with the Giants, Lawrence Taylor will miss a regular-season or playoff game for which he was on the roster.

title: ATTEMPTING TO RELIEVE JOB-RELATED STRESS
description: AN unmarried man in his early 30's gets a big promotion.

title: Nastique Is $16.20 Winner
description: Nastique scored a mild upset when she rallied from seventh in a field of 11 to win the 117th running of the Ladies Handicap by 8 1/2 lengths yesterday at Aqueduct. The race, which had a purse of $244,800 this year, is the country's oldest stakes race for fillies and mares.

title: Lighting the Way in Iceland
description: LEAD: CHRISTMAS in Iceland is likely to be white and certain to be dark. Although the lack of light is initially daunting, one soon discovers that it is precisely this darkness (20 hours at the solstice) that lends to the season its unusual sense of excitement and intimacy and its pervasive aura of drama.

title: CHARITY BRINGS OUT IVAN LENDL
description: IVAN LENDL is doing everything he can to get Cindy Davenport to hit a tennis ball back across the net at the Tennis Club of Trumbull. But the 7-year-old Bridgeport girl, despite encouraging words of advice from the world's best tennis player, can barely get her racket on the ball, let alone hit it over the net.

title: KITCHEN FOR POOR IS IN ITS 10TH YEAR
description: Soup is no longer served at the Community Soup Kitchen of New Haven. Ten years after they opened a modest once-a-week soup and sandwich program at the Salvation Army they are able to provide nutritious multi-course hot meals. ''Soup just isn't a hearty enough meal and now we have more to offer,'' explained David O'Sullivan, coordinator of the Kitchen, currently celebrating its 10th anniversary.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: Don McPherson of Syracuse wins hands down. He accounted for well over half of the Orangemen's touchdowns and total yardage this season. When McPherson's game was on, (as was the norm), the team won easily. When he struggled (as in the West Virginia game) so did the team. Overall, he combined great running with great passing to lead Syracuse to an undefeated season. McPherson's the outstanding player. Tim who? JEFF LIVINGSTON New York

title: Town Near Plant Waits New Evacuation Drill
description: Winter will bring another season of anxiety to those who live within breathing distance of a chemical plant that has drawn wide attention.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FALL OUT OF HEAVEN: An Autobiographical Journey. By Alan Cheuse. (Peregrine Smith, $17.95.) This book, in form as well as in content, is a dialogue between the author and his Russian immigrant father. The central narrative consists of the elder Cheuse's memoirs: Philip had flown Russian fighter planes in the unpublicized 1928 battle against Moslem rebels in Turkestan, earning a medal for saving a comrade under fire.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Prose Buds in Spring Too Part sermon, part celebration, nature writing is like taking one's prose style mountain climbing. This is Gretel Ehrlich observing spring in Wyoming. She is one of many writers in ''The Best American Essays 1987'' (Ticknor & Fields), edited by Gay Talese.

title: LIBERTY STATE PARK IS IMPERILED
description: ON JULY 4, 1986, Liberty State showcased to a national television audience. Millions of Americans saw a prime-time Boston Pops concert and fireworks show that highlighted Liberty Weekend.

title: CALCULATING THE PRICE OF A VIEW
description: LEAD: Can the construction of a building be stopped because it would block a scenic view? That question could have far-reaching consequences for the state's landscape and for property owners, according to lawyers involved in a court case on the issue.

title: Beaverkill
description: To the Editor:

title: OUTLOOK FOR THE MARKETS: Equities at Risk; Bonds Promising; Picking Funds to Match Objectives
description: WHATEVER its impact upon the public's psyche and pocketbook, the recent stock market collapse does not alter the basic argument for investing in mutual funds, provided individuals consider the funds' shortcomings as well as their advantages.

title: N.I.T. Honors
description: HIS team didn't make it to the Big Apple N.I.T. finals this weekend, but Troy Lewis, the standout Purdue guard, was acclaimed at Madison Square Garden, anyway. Lewis, whose team was knocked out of the N.I.T. tournament by Iowa State last week, was one of four men honored by the tournament before last night's championship game. He got the Big Apple's Champion student-athlete award for his outstanding athletic and academic accomplishments.

title: MARK BYRNE WED TO MISS COCHRAN
description: Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Ann Lovejoy Cochran, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Cochran of Summit, to Mark James Byrne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Byrne of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. William Strain performed the ceremony.

title: Recent Sales
description: Amityville $227,000 289 South Bay Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old contemporary; den, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,600. Hauppauge $182,000 58 Heller Place 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old ranch; basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700. Massapequa $366,500 5 Bay Link 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 27-year-old split level; family room, finished basement, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $5,600. Northport $174,000 5 Bark Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 28-year-old split level; family room, cathedral ceilings, sun porch; taxes $3,400. Setauket $235,000 70 Saddle Rock Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 17-year-old ranch; family room with fireplace, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $3,200. Williston Park $210,000 172 Colonial Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; new kitchen, unfinished attic, basement; taxes $2,000. OTHER AREAS Ridgefield, Conn. $450,000 93 Hunter Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; new kitchen cabinets, superior insulation, 2 acres; taxes, $3,658. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $355,000 101 Burns Place 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 15-year-old frame raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, deck, walk to stores; taxes $7,180. Rockaway, N.J. $205,000 12 Calumet Avenue 3 bedrooms, 2 1/2 baths, 29-year-old ranch; fireplace, deck, family room; taxes, $2,937.

title: Recent Sales
description: Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $355,000 101 Burns Place 5-bedroom, 3-ath, 15-year-old frame raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, deck, walk to stores; taxes $7,180. South Salem, N.Y. $352,000 Hoyt Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 16-year-old contemporary; cathedral ceiling, deck, greenhouse, lake rights; taxes $3,350. Tuckahoe, N.Y. $226,500 17 Warren Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 58-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, den, fenced yard, walk to station; taxes $2,908. Monroe, Conn. $310,000 76 Hillside Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 4-year-old ranch; ceramic tile floor in entry, deck, 0.75 acre; taxes $3,263. Ridgefield, Conn. $450,000 93 Hunter Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; new kitchen cabinets, superior insulation, 2 acres; taxes, $3,658. Stamford, Conn. $460,000 147 Dogwood Court 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 23-year-old colonial; remodeled kitchen, finished playroom, basement, 1 acre; taxes $4,130. OTHER AREAS Maplewood, N.J. $152,000 30 Manley Terrace 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 52-year-old colonial; finished basement, W/W carpeting, 2-car garage; taxes, $3,080. Metuchen, N.J. $144,500 72 East Walnut Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old colonial; deck, front porch; taxes, $1,856. Hauppauge, L.I. $182,000 58 Heller Place 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old ranch; basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700.

title: Under Fire: Once-Praised New York Blood Center
description: Almost 20 years ago, New York City's hospitals and medical institutions helped create the world's largest regional blood supply organization.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: New York State Offices; The Tainted Move From the World Trade Center
description: AS New York State nears the end of its colossal move of agencies from the World Trade Center, a former official is standing trial on bribery charges, while relocated employees are complaining of leaky pipes, frontier locations and excessive rents.

title: At the Met, a Bedchamber Fit for a King
description: MUCH WAS EXPECTED OF the Louis XIV state bedchamber that has just been inaugurated, together with its adjoining entrance gallery, at the Metropolitan Museum. Thanks to Pierpont Morgan, Louis Untermeyer and other collectors of an earlier generation, the Met had some majestic Louis XIV pieces. For years, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Wrightsman were known to have been adding to the Met's Louis XIV holdings with pieces of the highest quality.

title: Students Get Rare Lesson At School Zoo
description: A passer-by on West 18th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues might never imagine what hides behind the doors of the High School for the Humanities. On its second floor, enclosed within an old storage room, is Manhattan's only student-run zoo.

title: Future of Bowdoin Fraternities Is Being Weighed
description: The president of Bowdoin College, A. Leroy Greason, has asked a special panel to study whether fraternities on campus should be allowed to continue in light of recent reports of excessive drinking and abusive behavior in the houses.

title: CELIA P. REA WED TO W. F. GIBNEY
description: Celia Paige Rea, the director of membership for the American Medical Women's Association in New York, was married in New York yesterday to William Francis Gibney, a community associate and a public health educator with the New York City Department of Health. The Rev. Kevin Madigan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus.

title: BOWEN REVIEWS HIS YEARS AT PRINCETON
description: WITH the same quiet efficiency that has been the hallmark of his presidency, William G. Bowen of Princeton University is spending his final weeks in office conducting business as usual, and then some, as he gets ready to leave on Jan. 8 to head the Mellon Foundation.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ACROSS, by Peter Handke. Translated by Ralph Manheim. (Collier/Macmillan, $6.95.) The Austrian writer Peter Handke uses fiction to explore the ways in which we can escape from the labyrinths of language into subjective realms. His novel about Andreas Loser, an archeologist who literally gets away with murder, is ''one of the most arresting and expansive'' of his books, Lawrence Graver said in The Book Review last year. RISING FROM THE PLAINS, by John McPhee. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $7.95.) Journalism to John McPhee sometimes seems an excuse for making interesting new friends - experts on plutonium recycling, for example, or birchbark canoes. Recently Mr. McPhee has been spending time with geologists, and his third book on earth's ancient history is as good as the first two, our reviewer, Evan S. Connell, said in 1986. ''You need not have passed Geology 101 to enjoy 'Rising From the Plains,' but it might help. . . . Nevertheless, this instructive account . . . is a delight.'' NO COUNTRY FOR YOUNG MEN, by Julia O'Faolain. (Carroll & Graf, $8.95.) A Californian who goes to Ireland in the early 1970's to write a screenplay about a 50-year-old murder case finds himself on a terrorist group's hit list. The novel ''is a stunning performance,'' Julian Moynahan said here earlier this year. MAKING HAY, by Verlyn Klinkenborg. Illustrated by Gordon Allen. (Vintage, $5.95.) At a time when American agriculture is in a decline and farmers are giving up hope, Verlyn Klinkenborg tells of the beauty of life in the Midwest. ''In writing in loving detail about one part of farming - making hay - [ he ] gives the reader some understanding of why . . . those of us who do farm stay on the land,'' Sue Hubbell said here last year. GOD'S SNAKE, by Irini Spanidou. (Penguin, $6.95.) Anna, a girl growing up in Greece during the 1950's, is treated by her father, a military officer, as though she were one of his recruits. Irini Spanidou's first novel ''freshly evokes the beauties and terrors of childhood,'' Nicholas Bromell said in The Book Review last year. THE FIFTIES: From Notebooks and Diaries of the Period, by Edmund Wilson. Edited and with an introduction by Leon Edel. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.95.) The personal writings previously published in ''The Twenties,'' ''The Thirties'' and ''The Forties'' may have detracted from the critic Edmund Wilson's reputation as ''the human equivalent of the Modern Library: a one-man institution for the propagation of serious writing,'' Joseph Epstein said here in 1986. With ''The Fifties'' matters seem to be improving. The book's literary portraits of T. S. Eliot, Isaiah Berlin, Andre Malraux and W. H. Auden are ''the sort one hopes for from the journals of a literary man.'' FOOLS CROW, by James Welch. (Penguin, $7.95.) In this novel about a young Blackfoot warrior and medicine man living in the Montana Territory in the late 1800's, James Welch artfully blends the real with the unreal ''until neither we nor the characters themselves can tell the difference,'' Peter Wild said here last year. ''To a rather loose and, some might argue, episodic plot . . . Mr. Welch fastens . . . compelling aspects of the culture -the prayers, ghosts, dreams and waking visions that make up a warrior's spiritual life.'' CITY OF NETS: A Portrait of Hollywood in the 1940's, by Otto Friedrich. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $10.95.) Hollywood, a land of palm trees that look artificial and stuccoed houses perched precariously atop hills, is often used as a symbol for all that is crass and ephemeral about American culture. No one has ''flogged the metaphor quite so remorselessly'' as has Otto Friedrich, Neal Gabler said here in 1986, ''and few . . . have done it quite so well. . . . This is the Scheherazade of Hollywood - a spellbinding incantation of every adventure and misadventure within the film community.'' TUXEDO PARK, by Laura Furman. (Fawcett, $4.50.) Opposites supposedly attract, but Sadie, who loves domesticity, and Willard, a restless intellectual, are so fundamentally different that their marriage seems flawed from the start. This novel about a mismatched pair ''generates very little heat,'' our reviewer, Frances Taliaferro, said last year. But it ''has the agreeably static quality of [ the author's ] very good short stories.'' PAT NIXON: The Untold Story, by Julie Nixon Eisenhower. (Zebra, $4.50.) It hasn't been easy being Richard Nixon's wife, as Julie Nixon Eisenhower shows in this book about her mother. Although Mrs. Eisenhower spends too much time defending her father, her ''buoyant spirit, coupled with some impressive research, provides fresh insights into a much maligned and misunderstood woman,'' Judy Woodruff said here last year. TO THE LAND OF THE CATTAILS, by Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Jeffrey M. Green. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) The word ''Nazi'' never appears in this novel about a Jewish woman and her son who flee Vienna in 1938 for her Central European homeland. ''But the quiet pathos of this futile journey . . . powerfully realizes the awful helplessness of a European Jewry trapped among enemies,'' Robert Alter said in The Book Review last year. Aharon Appelfeld ''conveys an almost hallucinatory sense of the Holocaust as an irrevocable historical divide.'' THE LEAGUE: The Rise and Decline of the NFL, by David Harris. (Bantam, $4.95.) Since football is a business as much as a game, David Harris has chosen to focus not on the players but on the people who run and profit from it. ''There are those who will find the business practices Mr. Harris ascribes to many of the owners shocking,'' Ron Rosenbaum said here last year. ''Still, his painstakingly detailed accounts . . . cumulatively attain a kind of comic-epic grandeur.''

title: BRITONS ON THE PROWL
description: LATE IN THE FALL OF 1973, A 6-FOOT, 4-INCH BRITON named Gordon White marched into the Pierre hotel in Manhattan, took over a one-bedroom suite on the 37th floor and set about building an empire.

title: Flight Attendants' Union Asks for Strike Vote
description: Leaders of the flight attendants' union at American Airlines are asking members for authorization to call a strike before the busy holiday travel season.

title: About Men; A Case of Colic
description: THE TIGHTER I HELD HER, THE more she stiffened, arching her back and pummeling her heels into my midsection. And her continuous high-pitched shriek made my skull reverberate. It had been going on for nearly five hours. Seldom in my life had I felt so rejected by anyone. My 6-week-old daughter had colic.

title: Sunday Observer; Name That Carcass
description: MRS. CARLA P. OF Houma, La., writes to ask, ''What is this Iowa carcass I keep hearing about politicians running in? A friend told me they have the world's biggest hogs up there in Iowa and every year they slaughter the biggest one they can find, clean out the carcass and make all the politicians run around in it to show they have real Iowa grit. Can this be true?''

title: The Making of 'Mac Tonight'
description: BRAD A. BALL couldn't get the melody out of his mind. For months during early 1986 he was haunted by ''Mack the Knife,'' written by Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht for ''The Threepenny Opera'' and a No. 1 hit for Bobby Darin in l959. What made the song stick was its irresistible connection to one of his biggest clients, the McDonald's Operators Association of Southern California - and, of course, to the Big Mac.

title: PERFORMING ARTS CENTER: REVIEWING A DECADE
description: After a decade of presenting theater, dance, classical music and jazz in the county, the Performing Arts Center of the State University of New York at Purchase celebrates its 10th anniversary to mixed reviews from its audiences.

title: Irish Blown Away by Miami
description: All week long, the talk leading up to today's game between Miami and Notre Dame centered on the last meeting between the teams. Two years ago, Miami stomped the Irish by 51 points, and memories of that were supposed to fuel Notre Dame's bid for an upset.

title:
RECORDINGS;
The Many Pleasures of Top-Flight Handel
description: LEAD: HANDEL HAS NEVER BEEN A neglected composer, but who could have foretold the currrent widespread interest in his long-dormant operas? We now have the first digital recording of ''Rodelinda'' (1725) and the first-ever ''Imeneo'' (1740) added to the catalogue, both on compact disks in respectable performances.

title: FOR ELECTION, TURKEY WEARS ITS WESTERNNESS
description: TURKEY'S 22 million voters are going to the polls today in their first civilian-supervised general elections since the military relinquished its hold over NATO's easternmost member in 1983. The outcome, however, is less of an issue than how the election will affect the country's long and flawed campaign for membership in a Western community of nations that are inspired, in Turkey's eyes, by ideals of democracy and economic advance.

title: AIR FORCE SENDS UP MILITARY SATELLITE
description: An Air Force Titan 34D, the nation's most powerful unmanned rocket, roared into space tonight with a secret military satellite that a civilian expert said would provide instant warning of an enemy missile attack on the United States.

title: Q AND A
description: Passports Question: On the immigration forms of foreign countries, I have always written ''U.S.A.'' in stating where my passport was issued. Recently, on entering Thailand, I was asked to be specific. What is the proper way of answering this question? - D. W., White Plains Answer: The correct response is to name the city, the passport division of the United States Bureau of Consular Affairs says. Where to find the city in your passport - if you cannot remember where it was issued - depends on whether you have one of the machine-readable passports, made with the help of automation, or the earlier model, which was produced manually. On a newer passport - the first were issued in Washington in February 1981 and they are still being phased in - the city is given on the inside front cover below the words Passport Agency. An older passport has the city in perforated printing, after the words Department of State, on the side of the owner's photograph on page 3.

title: 3 U.S. Legislators Barred
description: Haiti has barred three members of Congress from taking part in an official American delegation to monitor the election Sunday. An official here said the three - Representative Benjamin A. Gilman of upstate New York, a senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee; Representative Jaime B. Fuster, a nonvoting Democratic member from Puerto Rico, and Walter E. Fauntroy of Washington, D.C. - had been told ''not to come'' to Haiti because of a letter that they and 43 other members of Congress sent to Port-au-Prince on Oct. 14 accusing the provisional Government of failing to protect the election process.

title: Advice About Radon Called Ill-Advised
description: In his Oct. 18 Opinion Page article, ''Bad Advice About the Problems of Radon,'' Prof. Leonard A. Cole [ of Rutgers-Newark ] criticized the state's Department of Environmental Protection for its adoption of the 4-picocurie/liter of air standard for radon remediation.

title: WHEN MONEY SLOSHES 'ROUND THE WORLD
description: Speculative disasters are an ancient curse. Even the Roman Forum most likely had its Black Fridays and Shattering Mondays.
