Now we have experienced our own panic, whose history cannot yet be written, but whose place in history can perhaps be tentatively assessed. A glimpse of the past may even help us peer into the future.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Basketball Tolentine Upsets Molloy: A standing-room only crowd of 1,200 squeezed into the gym at Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens last night to see the Stanners upset by St. Nicholas of Tolentine, 76-72, in the season opener for both teams. Tolentine, a school with an enrollment of 400, one-quarter the size of Molloy, outmuscled the Stanners with their bench strength. Five Tolentine players scored in double figures, led by the 6-foot-7-inch Malik Sealy's 19 points, 7 rebounds 3 blocks and 2 steals. Golf Nicklaus Wins 3 Holes and $75,000: Jack Nicklaus, who had not won a skin in 35 holes dating back to 1983, won three holes and $70,000 yesterday in the first half of golf's Skins Game at La Quinta, Calif. Fuzzy Zoeller won only one hole but, with carryovers, it was worth $70,000 and pushed his Skins Game earnings to $695,000. Lee Trevino, the shortest hitter in the Hall of Fame foursome that is competing on the extremely difficult PGA West course, won the only other skin, worth $25,000, with a birdie on the par-5 eighth hole. Arnold Palmer was shut out. But he, along with the other three players, will have another chance today with another $285,000 up for grabs over the final nine holes.(AP) Tennis Lendl and Cash in Final: Ivan Lendl and Pat Cash, the United States Open and Wimbledon champions, respectively, qualified for today's finals of the $1 million Stakes Match tennis tournament in West Palm Beach, Fla., by finishing two days of round-robin play with the most money yesterday. They eliminated Stefan Edberg and John McEnroe in this new concept in which each of the four players was staked to $250,000 at the start. Edberg finished third and McEnroe was last, earning $182,000(AP) Muster Beats Svensson: Thomas Muster of Austria won the $150,000 Young Masters tournament yesterday by defeating Jonas B. Svensson of Sweden, 6-4, 4-6, 7-5, 6-2, in 2 hours 33 minutes in Friedrichshafen, West Germany. The 20-year-old Austrian received $30,000 for his victory, and Svensson earned $20,000.(AP) Agassi Topples Mattar for Title: Andre Agassi of the United States beat Luiz Mattar, Brazil's top player, 7-6, 6-2, yesterday to win the $516,000 Sul America Open on Itaparica island in northeastern Brazil. Agassi, 17 years old and ranked No. 44 in the Association of Tennis Professionals world rankings, earned $90,000 for the Grand Prix victory. Mattar received $45,000.(AP) Skiing Wolf Wins World Cup Race: Sigrid Wolf of Austria won the World Cup super-G race and her teammate, Sylvia Eder, finished third yesterday in Sestriere, Italy. Mateja Svet of Yugoslavia was runner-up for the second time in two races in this first World Cup event of the season. Edith Thys of Squaw Valley, Calif., skied her best World Cup race ever, a seventh-place finish, in an overall time of 1 minute 17.93 seconds. Debbie Armstrong of Seattle was 37th in 1:19.78; right behind her was Pam Ann Fletcher of Acton, Mass. Farther back were Diann Roffe of Williamson, N.Y., Kristin Krone and Adele Allender of Olympic Valley, Calif. Wolf's victory was her third in World Cup competition, and it came with a clocking of 1:16.64. The 19-year-old Svet trailed by only five-hundredths of a second down the 1,545-meter-long Kandahar course.(AP)

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: GROUND will be broken Tuesday for a 44-acre town house and condominium complex in Newark's Central Ward, a project that is expected to advance the residential components of the city's revitalization program.

title: Philippine Typhoon Toll Said to Be At Least 500
description: At least 500 people were killed when giant waves churned up by Typhoon Nina smashed coastal towns and villages in southern Luzon, a provincial governor said today.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Air Force Wins On Tower Issue

title: Garcia's 12 Barns at the Noyes
description: ALL EVIDENCE to the contrary notwithstanding, everything has not been said and done about Abstract Expressionism and its derivatives. Bearing witness to this is a show of the works by the late Mario Garcia that comes to the Noyes Museum here courtesy of the Princeton Gallery of Fine Arts.

title:
MUSIC;
ALUMNUS RETURNS TO LEAD ORCHESTRA
description: LEAD: PETER LEONARD, a candidate for music director of the Colonial Symphony, will conduct that orchestra Friday night at Madison Junior School.

title: Headliners; On the Rise
description: When Li Peng was named Acting Prime Minister of China last week, some Western diplomats voiced concern not only with his plans for the future, but also with his schooling in the past. Mr. Li, who is assured of being named Prime Minister on a permanent basis at the National People's Congress next spring, is a 59-year-old Soviet-educated engineer who, in the eyes of some Westerners, has not enthusiastically supported the economic policies of China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, and might even have ''pro-Soviet'' leanings. But, as quoted by the New China News Agency, Mr. Li seemed willing to assuage any fears about his loyalties and intentions. ''I am a Chinese and a member of the Chinese Communist Party,''

title: Giving Away A Jetliner
description: FOR three months, the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia tried to give away a prime exhibit, a 70-ton Boeing 707 jetliner. There were no takers.

title: Albany Notes; Meeting Set to Weigh Special Session
description: Governor Cuomo has summoned top legislators to Albany tomorrow to discuss whether to reconvene the Legislature in special session.

title: DEMYSTIFYING POP-UP DRAINS
description: POP-UP drains in bathroom basins may seem mysterious, but actually they are simple to repair. Knowing how they operate is useful.

title: NEW YORK
description: LEAD: ONE OF MY HAPPIER memories of New York theatergoing last year is of ''The Golden Land,'' a revue that recounted (in a mixture of Yiddish and English) the story of Jewish immigrant experience in America from the 1880's onward. It was an altogether exceptional show: exceptional in its brightness and raciness, in its ability to touch deeper chords without lapsing into sentimentality (or at any rate the wrong kind of sentimentality), and in its general sureness of touch.

title: SUSPENDED PUPILS FIND A PAL IN P.A.L.
description: LEAD: FOR children who persist in behaving so badly that teaching them becomes almost impossible, suspension from school is a last resort.

title: DATA UPDATE: November 29, 1987
description: HOUSING COSTS: N.Y.-Northeast N.J. area*

title: Bridge Players From New York Region Lead Reisinger Field
description: Three players from the New York metropolitan region led the field at the end of qualifying play in the Reisinger Board-a-Match team championship here Friday night.

title: A Showcase for Art Of Children's Books
description: SOME of the most enchanting art has been in children's books. Until recently it remained between covers, haunting the memories of the adults and children who had turned the pages. However, in 1984 Emily and Sam Bush of Norwich, Vt., brought it off the shelves and onto the wall.

title: The Neediest, Visible and Invisible
description: A New York woman named Joyce Brown recently achieved national notice for persuading a judge that the city had no right to hospitalize her, even though she lived on the streets. While the case inspired policy debate, it also distorted the problem of the homeless. Whatever one makes of their civil rights, few of the homeless enjoy life on the street. Ms. Brown herself now says she would like to live in a group home. The homeless are homeless because they are poor. Again this year, they are the best evidence of the enduring need for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which begins its 76th annual appeal today.

title: Teen-Age Shoppers: Desperately Seeking Spinach
description: QUIETLY, with few people noticing apart from a handful of social researchers, the economic power of America's teen-age population is mushrooming, changing the nation's consumer tastes as well as its family life.

title: Incinerator Project Is a Divisive Issue in Vermont
description: The idea seemed seductively simple five years ago. The City of Rutland and neighboring towns would pool their garbage and burn it in a huge incinerator, producing electricity. The garbage, which had been threatening to overflow landfills, would be gone and the electricity would be cheap.

title: 160 Die at Sea in South Africa Jet Crash
description: A South African Airways Boeing 747 crashed into the Indian Ocean 125 miles southeast of Mauritius early today. Transport Minister Eli Louw said all 160 passengers and crew aboard were feared dead.

title: SATIRIST TEES OFF ON NEW TARGET, GOLF
description: THERE are more than 17 million men and women in the United States who spend endless hours during the day negotiating multimillion-dollar deals or managing sensitive operations or even performing life-and-death surgery so that on weekends and vacations they can perfect the art of trying to hit a dimpled, rubber-covered, solid- or composite-cored high-compression sphere weighing 1.62 ounces into a hole on the ground that is roughly four inches in diameter and impossible to see without the help of a small red flag.

title: Shaky but Ready, Haitians Are Mapping Voting Strategy
description: A money-changer sat in the shade of a tree overhanging the Rue Pavee, ordinarily one of the capital's busiest commercial strips, yesterday.

title: THE SONGS CARRY 'SOUND OF MUSIC'
description: SOMEWHERE the hills may be alive with the sound of music, but at Theater Three they are barely humming.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: For the first time in college football history, the Heisman Trophy should be awarded to an outstanding football team, not an individual. A team truly representative of amateur athetics with enough guts to get on the field with anybody -win or lose. . . Columbia University. MURRAY H. SALIT New York

title: OUTLOOK FOR THE MARKETS: Equities at Risk; Bonds Promising; It's Win-Win For Bonds Now
description: THE rout on Wall Street has reversed last summer's bond slump. ''We think it's win-win for bonds now,'' said Robert J. Barbera, senior vice president and chief economist for E. F. Hutton & Company.

title: STREETSCAPES: 95th Street Rowhouses; Central Park West Anomalies In a Landmark Battle's Vortex
description: THE five rowhouses at the northwest corner of 95th and Central Park West are not obviously anything special. But these structures, done in a rather tame neo-Renaissance style, are now the focus of a legal and preservation battle that casts light on the strengths and weaknesses of New York City's landmarks law.

title: Kemp's Combative Tone Sounds Off Key to Some
description: After months of showing the voters what a smart guy he is, Representative Jack F. Kemp is now trying to prove that he can be a tough guy as well.

title: ON LAND, CADETS CONQUER SEA
description: Cadets at the U.S. Coast Guard Academy in New London are learning how to steer a ship without having to set foot on one.

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
description: THIS time of year, many companies are afflicted with the Peter Pan syndrome.

title: Augustana Streak Is Ended at 60
description: Dave Jones rushed for 219 yards and three touchdowns today as Dayton ended Augustana's 60-game unbeaten streak with a 38-36 victory in a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III quarterfinal game.

title: GERSHWIN PASTICHE IN MILLBURN
description: IN COMMEMORATION of the 50th anniversary of the composer's death, the Paper Mill Playhouse is having its own George Gershwin celebration, presenting the breezy pastiche ''My One and Only.''

title: A 'Real' Supply-Sider Views Reagan's Legacy; Don't Focus on Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: A Continent Left Behind
description: SQUANDERING EDEN Africa at the Edge. By Mort Rosenblum and Doug Williamson. Illustrated. 326 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JAZZ BAGPIPER Rufus Harley, who says he is the world's first professional jazz bagpiper, will perform tomorrow - St. Andrew's Day, no less - at Princeton Theological Seminary.

title: MOVIES
description: La Ronde With Simone Signoret, Danielle Darrieux, Gerard Philippe, Jean-Louis Barrault. Directed by Marcel Ophuls. Nelson Entertainment. 97 minutes. $29.95. Sex is the subject of ''La Ronde,'' Marcel Ophuls' memorable 1950 treatment of the popular Arthur Schnitzler play. The place is Vienna, in spring 1900, but the movie is given a strong Gallic flavor by such luminaries as Danielle Darrieux, Simone Signoret, Gerard Philippe and Jean-Louis Barrault.

title: Wilkins Leads As Knicks Click
description: With the Knicks at 1-7 and Gerald Wilkins not into the flow of Rick Pitino's motion offense, the coach made a change in his starting lineup. He replaced Wilkins at shooting guard with Trent Tucker, the better outside shooter.

title: WHAT WE KNOW: OUR INTERNAL UNIVERSE IS EXPANDING
description: DURING the last eight years, the number of research reports presented at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience has more than doubled, exceeding 6,600 this year. In an attempt to keep up, more than 11,000 scientists and onlookers gathered for the 1987 convention, which was held in New Orleans this month. What follows are reports on some of the ascendant ideas in the continuing attempt to learn how the brain generates the mind, and how the mind controls the body.

title: BATTEN DOWN THE GARDEN
description: THE thermometer acts like a yo-yo at this time of year. Its up-and-down readings should remind gardeners that more of the same lies ahead. To help plants survive, here are some reminders to get the garden ready.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: DUET. By Kitty Burns Florey. (Morrow, $16.95.) Kitty Burns Florey's absorbing, densely detailed fifth novel chronicles both a love story and the 1960's. Anna Nolan mostly performs a solo narration in ''Duet,'' telling a tale of unrequited love for Will Westenberg, her passion ''since the day in third grade when he stood by me waiting for a turn at the pencil sharpener and smiled at me his shy smile.

title: Art: 'Arches for Galveston,' at the Cooper-Hewitt
description: AS part of a general effort at urban renewal and civic image-building, the city of Galveston, Tex., commissioned seven architects to design arches for its 1986 Mardi Gras celebration , the first held in the city since 1946. Their widely varying results, shown in photographs, models and drawings, make up the amusing ''Arches for Galveston'' exhibition on view at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum through Jan. 31.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WHITE LIGHT. By Patricia Volk. (Atheneum, $18.95.) This inventive if flawed first novel is half comic strip, half yuppie spiritual crisis. When 35-year-old May Graves, an art director at a magazine for teen-agers, makes an ill-received comment at a meeting, trouble begins. A month away from New York City is what she needs, and soon May is in a hotel in the Adirondacks trying desperately to return to a simpler state. She is the only guest, but no matter. There is a caretaker, a young man whose father drowned minutes after he was conceived and who is convinced the body still lies at the bottom of the lake. Another young man, with a tattoo and a red Peugeot, is nearby in a cabin in the woods. Then May's boring but adoring dentist husband shows up unexpectedly. There is also an enclave of Orthodox Jewish dwarfs in the neighborhood, and when May is not worrying about the men in her life - and the dwarfs aren't asking her husband to check the overbite on their new spiritual leader - she calls her mother, precipitating lots of motherly advice conversations. Barring the first chapter, which gratuitously combines statistics about working women and IUD-related blood clots, ''White Light'' is entertaining and occasionally funny. But though May's wish to confront her spiritual and physical emptiness (a sort of death, or ''white light'') seems genuine, she and most of the other characters are either not well developed or too outlandish, and fail to elicit much sympathy.

title: HAITI VOTES TODAY FOR A PRESIDENT
description: Twenty-two months after the collapse of the Duvalier family dictatorship, Haitians vote Sunday in their first presidential election in 30 years.

title: 40% of Americans Fear They Will Contract AIDS, a Poll Indicates
description: More than 40 percent of American adults are concerned that they will contract AIDS, and fear of having the deadly disease is prompting many people to change their sexual behavior and take other precautions, the latest Gallup poll indicates.

title: HEARINGS SET ON PARKWAY TOLL PLAN
description: THE proposal to double the tolls on the Garden State Parkway has inspired the predictable adverse public reaction and calls for hearings and investigations by state lawmakers.

title: Whose Words?
description: To the Editor:

title: A TIMES POLL OF M.B.A.'S
description: THE REAGAN ADMINIS-tration's tolerant attitude toward increasing size and concentration in American business finds considerable favor with a select group of business people. They generally approve of the recent wave of corporate mergers, and the Government's less-than-aggressive enforcement of antitrust laws. They welcome deregulation of industries, too, with one notable exception: Many of them want firmer Federal controls on the airlines they frequently fly.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 27 about Chicago misidentified the architect of Lake Point Tower. The architects were Schipporeit-Heinrich Associates, not Mies van der Rohe; George Schipporeit and John Heinrich, principals at the time of design, were students of Mies.

title: RAKE, RAKE, RAKE. THEN BAG, BAG, BAG.
description: AN unwritten law of nature requires that falling leaves must be gathered and properly disposed of, or the grasses underneath will die. ''Rake, rake, rake!'' cautions the garden editor. ''Bag, bag, bag!'' says the Town of Brookhaven.

title: A STORE HE BUILT HIMSELF
description: ALL that afternoon, as I followed Robert Pucciariello through the labyrinthine aisles of his Book Emporium in Sea Cliff, I was reminded of my son Frederick the Younger. Fred does not sell books. He is a cabinetmaker and master carpenter; he works with his hands and his head. But so does Mr. Pucciariello. They are both the kind of men who like to know where they can put their hands on what they work with, and sell. As Mr. Pucciariello led me past Astronomy, Fiction, Health, Architecture, Art, Literature, he could have been Fred showing me his augers, planes, saws, hammers, house jacks and more special tools that do nothing but mystify his red-thumbed father.

title: South Shore Gets A Place in Final
description: South Shore lost its star tailback for almost half the game, and its star wide receiver in the final period. But the Vikings managed to battle back from a 26-12 deficit and defeat John F. Kennedy of the Bronx, 29-26, in an overtime shootout yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League semifinal football playoff.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THE BUBO CHRONICLES
description: LEAD: The world may not be tensed to know exactly why birds will mob and attack a single owl in the wild, but Bernd Heinrich wanted to find out - and in ONE MAN'S OWL (Princeton, $19.50), he tells the tender story of a very small animal experiment. The experiment is clearly a ruse - an excuse for indulging the infatuation that blossoms when a man stumbles over a baby owl.

title: A CLARIFICATION ON LAMOTTE STATEMEBT
description: The article ''Northern Democrats Assess Gains in Election'' [ Nov. 15 ] reported on Patty Hotchkiss's victory over Ursula LaMotte in County Legislative District 2. It said some believe ''Mrs. Hotchkiss was greatly aided by a last-minute campaign by some who portrayed Mrs. LaMotte as an opponent of legalized abortion. Mrs. LaMotte acknowledged that the misrepresentation of her views contributed to her defeat.''

title: HOW NOW TO SELL A COW?
description: IN A PASTURE ON A WELL-tended ranch near North Zulch, Tex., John J. Francis stood in 100-degree heat, watching three black bull calves. ''This is very exciting,''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE TWILIGHT OF THE PRESIDENCY: From Johnson to Reagan. By George E. Reedy. (NAL, $17.95.) When George E. Reedy, who had been President Johnson's longtime press secretary and special assistant, first published this book in 1970, it was fairly hailed as a distinguished and thoughtful - and sometimes frightening - essay on government. The Presidency, said Mr. Reedy then and says Mr. Reedy now, is an institution designed to shield its occupant from reality, to isolate him from the nation and to make sure that he responds, responsibly or not, to impulse and personal doctrine. It is not, in Mr. Reedy's view, a great way to run a country. By 1970, the White House had reduced Lyndon Johnson, a canny politician by anyone's standard, to a political jelly and Richard Nixon remained insulated from the continued popular demand for the end of the Vietnam war. In this astute updated edition, with four more Presidents (including Mr. Nixon) under our national belt, Mr. Reedy finds little to cheer him. Presidents Ford, Carter and, curiously, Reagan he sees as ''caretaker'' Chief Executives, who give the impression of being more dynamic than they actually are. Gerald Ford at least had nothing up his sleeve; Jimmy Carter's background equipped him to be a mover and shaker, but the country didn't want that. Ronald Reagan is ''the epitome of the caretaker'' - someone who can keep various groups from organizing to depose him while simultaneously creating ''the illusion of action when not very much is actually going on.'' While Mr. Reedy sees no changes likely in the institution of the Presidency itself, he does see America as resilient, ultimately constructing ''counterbalancing forces that are bringing us back to reality.'' Somehow, he believes, we will lurch along.

title: Lively Follow-Up to the Short Dress
description: SOMETHING has been added to the new shorter-length dresses for evening. Often, it is a long train of taffeta, shaped like a fishtail or an icicle. Sometimes, it is a cascade of ruffles made of netting.

title: Call It an Awakening
description: I HAD just finished interviewing Henry Roth, the author of ''Call It Sleep,'' when as if by some dramatic design, a large, flat package was delivered to his New York hotel room. It was an advance copy of Mr. Roth's first book in 53 years, ''Shifting Landscape,'' a complete collection of his shorter writings along with many excerpts from letters and interviews, lovingly assembled by his gifted Italian translator, Mario Materassi.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS; Q&A;: William Julius Wilson;
HOW THE URBAN POOR GOT POORER
description: LEAD: THE plight of a black underclass in America's cities - indeed, the idea of an underclass - became a matter of public discussion in part because of William Julius Wilson's 1978 book ''The Declining Significance of Race.'' His new book, ''The Truly Disadvantaged,'' observes that things have only become worse.

title: Food; WINTER VEGETABLES
description: FOR ME, FALL IS A TIME OF nostalgia. Cascading leaves and a nip in the air remind me of the impending holidays and the comfort of home. It is a season for moving indoors, crackling fires and celebration of robust fare. Tables laden with juicy roasted game birds, thick soups and stews laced with hearty winter vegetables reflect our need to stave off the cold.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Waterfront Development; City Efforts Trapped in Multiple Reviews
description: By ALAN S. OSER

title: 'THE HUNGARIAN AVANT-GARDE 1914-1933,' IN STORRS
description: THERE are Hungarians galore in 20th-century art - Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, Victor de Vasarely, Zoltan Kemeny and the photographers Brassai and Andre Kertesz are some that come immediately to mind. But famed though it is for its emigres, who also include Franz Liszt, Bela Bartok and several movie moguls, not to mention the Gabor sisters, Hungary itself hasn't had so much as a walk-on part in the European cultural drama.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Chester, Pa.;
Vacant Houses Used for Poor
description: LEAD: AT least 600 homes in Chester are empty and boarded up, a constant reminder of the blight and rising unemployment that have plagued this city of 45,000, a dozen or so miles south of Philadelphia, over the last 15 years.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: A RARE U.S.-CUBAN DEAL BRINGS VIOLENT CONSEQUENCES
description: AS prison disturbances in Atlanta and Oakdale, La., lurched toward an uncertain ending last week, Washington policymakers were again confronting the consequences of America's fractious relationship with Cuba's Fidel Castro.

title: In Maine, Much Rides on Whether a Forest Is Also Called 'Wilderness'
description: From atop Caribou Mountain in western Maine, hikers see the towering peaks of the Presidential Mountain Range sweeping north to south 20 miles in the distance. They see sparkling lakes and huge tracts of forest land.

title: IMITATION OF LIFE
description: It is gratifying to see that fashion designers are beginning to realize that furs and animal skins can be utilized in fashion without inflicting the cruelty that accompanies the use of genuine animal skins (Fashion: ''Imitation of Life,'' by Linda Wells, Nov. 1). The message is that real people wear fake furs. MICHAEL G. SCHWARZ Dallas

title: WHEN TO KEEP AND WHEN TO DISCARD
description: LAST weekend I attended a conference of photography curators and archivists. They were not exactly a typical bunch of photo buffs even though many were carrying point-and-shoot cameras. But one of the most hotly contested topics of conversation involved a question that every photographer has to face at one time or another: how to decide which pictures to keep and which to throw out.

title: 42 KILLED IN INDONESIAN QUAKE
description: At least 42 people were killed and many were missing after an earthquake caused landslides and a tidal wave on a remote island in eastern Indonesia, officials said today.

title: TAINTED WATER MYSTERY
description: LEAD: PASQUALE and Mary Trunzo of Sag Harbor are an elderly couple retired and living on a fixed income. When they moved to Meadow Street 45 years ago, they had to dig a well for their drinking water.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Nov. 1 with a guide to cruises misidentified a ship off Grand Cayman. It was the Holiday of the Carnival Cruise Lines, not the Norway of the Norwegian Caribbean Lines.

title: Inquiry Into Alaska Air Crash Looks at Weight Distribution
description: Investigators looking into the crash of a heavily loaded commuter plane that killed 18 people have turned their attention to the question of how the weight was distributed, a Federal official says.

title:
ART;
PRIVATE PIECES ON PUBLIC VIEW
description: LEAD: CURIOSITY about the possessions of others, and awareness that they are rarely seen by the public, usually whets our appetite for the occasional museum exhibition of a private collection. A collector's taste interests us - it is often so personal - and we wonder about the quest for those examples, and perhaps why one decision was made and not another.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
COUNTERING THE HYSTERIA ON ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: LEAD: OUR region has experienced phenomenal growth in income, employment and property values in the 1980's. This growth has raised legitimate concerns about unchecked development, environmental degradation, traffic congestion and related concerns.

title: Mush From the Wimps
description: Tomorrow, Congress and the Administration will start trying to keep their timid promise to cut the Federal budget deficit by a token $30 billion. Just how timid and just how token can be gauged by comparing their promise with the economic plan that Jimmy Carter proposed in his last year in office. Here is how the lead story in The Times described it on March 15, 1980:

title: Bryan Ferry's Scenes of Obsession and Consequences
description: THE MAN IN FORMAL EVENING wear pauses to adjust one of his gold cuff links, and listens. From the balcony of his hotel he can hear drumming, muffled but insistent, borne by the breeze from somewhere beyond the perimeter of the new town's stark electric lights and flickering neon. ''Voodoo Warning is calling, down in Limbo,'' he croons softly to himself. ''Moonlight lush life bears strange fruit, down in Limbo.''

title: In 'Flora' Two Music Men Return to an Early Love
description: ONE AFTERNOON NOT LONG ago, John Kander and Fred Ebb were attending a rehearsal at the tiny Vineyard Theater of a revised version of their first Broadway musical, ''Flora, the Red Menace.'' As Veanne Cox, who plays the title role, began singing ''It's a Quiet Thing,'' the composer and lyricist, who were sitting in different parts of the theater, each began to weep.

title: A FANTASY MEN DECLINE: TO BE WOMAN FOR A DAY
description: A GROUP of female friends, who happen to be therapists, were discussing Marilyn French's latest book, ''Beyond Power,'' at a cocktail party recently. When asked if I had read it, I had to confess that I hadn't, although I scored points for having read her two novels, ''The Women's Room'' and ''The Bleeding Heart.'' (As an acknowledged feminist of the male gender, one can appreciate my occasional defensiveness.) Anyway, my friends insisted that I read it as soon as possible if I wanted to stay current on women's psychology. Because I teach psychology at a women's college and am the only male member of the Women's Studies Committee, I borrowed it from the college library the very next day.

title: Venice
description: To the Editor: We had a trouble-free trip to Italy this May and great pleasure and excitement until we arrived at the Troncetto, the artificial parking island for the trip to Venice.

title: FOE OF APARTHEID SEEKS UNIFIED LAND
description: Govan A. Mbeki, a prominent leader of the outlawed African National Congress, talked of political hope and reconciliation in his first public speech since being freed from a South African prison early this month.

title: SARAH HOFSTADTER MARRIES DOV WISNER
description: Sarah Katherine Hofstadter, the daughter of Mrs. Theodore H. White of Bridgewater, Conn., and the late Richard Hofstadter, was married yesterday to Dov Wisner, a son of Tova Wisner of Haifa, Israel, and the late Moishe Wisner. Judge Stuart R. Pollak of the San Francisco Superior Court performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Oakland, Calif.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN FUND RAISING
description: LAST year, Americans gave $87.22 billion to charity, a 9.4 percent increase over 1985, according to the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, which represents fund-raising advisers. For 1987, experts predict somewhat smaller increase in the wake of the October stock market collapse.

title: >DONNA GOLDBACH IS WED
description: Donna E. Goldbach, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Goldbach of New York, was married in New York yesterday to Paul Stephen Appelgren, the son of Charles Appelgren of Montrose, Colo., and Irma Appelgren of Lakewood, Colo. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. The couple graduated from Loretto Heights College in Denver. Mrs. Appelgren is a pediatric nurse at New York Hospital and her husband is a sales official for Minolta in New York.

title: CHARGES DISMISSED
description: FEW tennis players think of calling their game ''lawn tennis,'' a name inappropriate except at Wimbledon and a few tradition-minded places, to distinguish it from the historic game of ''real tennis.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Make no mistake. The Soviets are and will continue to be our adversaries, the adversaries indeed of all who believe in human liberty.'' - President Reagan [ 6:3. ]

title: Ward Melville Gains Title
description: The Ward Melville Patriots upset the West Islip Lions, 27-14, yesterday to win the Suffolk County Conference I championship.

title: When Money Talks, Athletes Whine
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In the End, a Hero
description: THEY CALL ME MOSES MASAOKA An American Saga. By Mike Masaoka with Bill Hosokawa. Illustrated. 383 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: Against the Master and His Men
description: A MIND OF HER OWN The Life of Karen Horney. By Susan Quinn. Illustrated. 479 pp. New York: Summit Books. $22.95.

title: NEW BROADER LOOK AT ANTIQUES SHOW
description: LEAD: SOME things never change and you might not want them to.

title: NEW YORK FAULTED ON NO-BID TOWING PACTS
description: A system of no-bid contracts for emergency towing on limited-access highways in New York City has been allowed to remain in place despite a New York City Comptroller's audit in 1981 that showed it had engendered widespread fraud, a Bronx grand jury asserted yesterday.

title: THE DUCKS STOP HERE NO LONGER
description: LONG ISLAND duck farmers say they know when they and their ducks are not welcome.

title: Zola Family Battles the Dreyfus Affair Anew
description: Emile Zola's famed newspaper expose, ''J'accuse,'' which defended Capt. Alfred Dreyfus from charges of treason, has once again become a cause celebre - this time within the Zola family.

title: Wagner Rolls by Fordham to Gain National Semifinal
description: Wagner, a big, fast football team with many skills, swept Fordham aside yesterday, won its second postseason playoff game and advanced to the N.C.A.A. Division III semifinals.

title: 150 Anti-Abortion Protesters Seized in Jersey
description: More than 150 anti-abortion protesters were arrested on trespassing charges today during a rally in front of a women's health clinic that performs abortions here.

title: U.S. TAKES A LOSS OVER 3 WINDMILLS
description: Three of the world's largest windmills, which less than a decade ago cost a total of $60 million, are being torn down by a contractor who bought them at a Government surplus sale for $28,000.

title: ACCOLADES FOR ITALIAN FARE
description: A DISTINGUISHED silver-haired couple are entertaining a friend from England at La Pace restaurant in Glen Cove. It's apparent that these people are familiar with the restaurant and its menu. They choose knowingly.

title: HALPIN PRESSES POLICE CHIEF SEARCH
description: As he continued preparations to name a transition team that will help cement the structure of a new Suffolk County government, Patrick G. Halpin, the incoming County Executive, last week announced a restructured search committee for a new police commissioner and outlined some changes he thinks are necessary for the beleaugured department.

title: MARY KIRK, CHEF, WEDS N. L. EASTMAN, ACTOR
description: Mary Elizabeth Kirk, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elijah Thomas Kirk of Louisville, Ky., was married there yesterday to Nicholas Lieder Eastman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffery Eastman of Essex Fells and Bay Head, N.J., and Stratton Mountain, Vt. The Rev. David Searfoss performed the ceremony at the Calvin Presbyterian Church, assisted by Msgr. Edward J. Fleming, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: HISTORIC TRANS-ATLANTIC COVERS TO BE AUCTIONED
description: PORTIONS of a collection made by the late David Beals will be offered at public auction by Richard C. Frajola, Inc. on Saturday at 12:15 P.M. at the Danbury Hilton Inn, Danbury, Conn. The auction will feature items of United States and Confederate States postal history. Included are Kansas and Missouri Territory, military history, trans-Atlantic and Confederate States covers. Other major sections include autographed manuscripts, postmarks by state and patriotic covers.

title: 'Assassination Is the Sincerest Form of Flattery'
description: STALIN IN THE BRONX And Other Stories. By Suzanne Ruta. 154 pp. New York: Grove Press. $16.95.

title: OPPONENTS VOW TO BLOCK AIRPORT TERMINAL
description: LEAD: LEADERS of the County Board of Legislators are predicting approval for County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's new proposal to expand the passenger facilities at the County Airport, but angry opponents of the plan are vowing to go to court to block any construction.

title: The Fine Art of Managing Change
description: SOME day one of our advanced business schools will offer a graduate course in how to become a chief executive. It will probably attract armies of the brightest of the bright. But of course it will not work because in no office in the business universe is the crucible of experience more essential. Nor is experience itself the answer. Few executives, no matter what their backgrounds, come to the chief executive's office prepared for the full scope and rigors of decision-making that are required.

title: MAINE LOSES IN OVERTIME, 31-28
description: Tim Foley's 42-yard field goal in overtime completed a comeback from an 18-point halftime deficit today as Georgia Southern, seeking its third consecutive national championship, edged Maine, 31-28, in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA playoffs.

title: Retirees Resettling in College Towns
description: WHEN John K. Kittredge retired as an insurance executive early this month, he and his wife, Betty, sold their home in Summit, N.J., and moved, not to Florida or Arizona, but to Chapel Hill, N.C., a town with which they had no ties.

title: The Importance of Being Affectionate
description: THE HEALTH OF NATIONS True Causes of Sickness and Well-Being. By Leonard A. Sagan. 233 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Exploring Audio's Outer Limits
description: UNLIKE THE HUGE EX-hibits of electronic home equipment staged each year in Chicago and Las Vegas, the much smaller Hi-Fi Show held last month in New York City was not just meant for the trade. It was open to anyone.

title: Florida State Overcomes 14-3 Deficit and Wins
description: Derek Schmidt kicked four field goals, and Dayne Williams scored twice on 1-yard runs today as Florida State rallied to beat Florida, 28-14, and end a six-game losing streak in the rivalry.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DOCUMENTARY
description: LEAD: Millhouse: A White Comedy Produced and directed by Emile de Antonio. 1971. MPI Home Video. 90 minutes. $39.95. In 1987, this view of Richard Milhous Nixon's political career is more disheartening than funny. Familiarity has declawed the irony. ''Millhouse'' - a play on Mr. Nixon's middle name - now seems a relatively conventional if satirical documentary of the rise and fall and rise again of a uniquely

title: TV SHOW EXAMINES NEWARK RIOTS
description: THE black-and-white film is grainy, but its impact is as powerful today as it was nearly 20 years ago.

title: 'THE PROBLEM IS GETTING WORSE'
description: THE death of a 5-month old baby in New Britain after he spent the night in a car with his homeless parents has focused attention once again on the plight of Connecticut's homeless and the fear that winter will bring more tragedy. Typically in winter, there is more attention focused on the homeless, a group whose number appears to be increasing as the state's stock of low-income housing and residential hotels diminishes.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO PREPARE FOR FREEZING WEATHER
description: LEAD: With the advent of freezing weather imminent, it's time to provide a rundown of last-minute gardening chores.

title: QUESTIONS ABOUND IN HOSPITAL DEATHS
description: IN the two weeks since the arrest of Richard J. Angelo, the former Good Samaritan Hospital nurse charged with injecting a patient with a powerful muscle-paralyzing drug, more questions have been raised than resolved.

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: The naming of Gordie Lockbaum, Holy Cross' great scholar and two-way star, will greatly enhance the Heisman Trophy.

title: Sid Caesar: Ich Speaken German at Met
description: THE SCENE IS THE SITTING room of a suite in a midtown hotel, where a 65-year-old man sits in an old-fashioned flowered chair. He is Sid Caesar -noticeably older and somewhat balder than the Sid Caesar we remember from ''Your Show of Shows'' and ''Caesar's Hour'' in the 50's, but also a lot trimmer and much more in shape - even though he's not quite recovered from a broken hip he suffered in September when he fell while walking his dog. There is a gold chain around the open neck of his sports shirt, a gold bracelet on one wrist and a gold watch on the other. A reporter is seated on the ornate sofa next to his chair.

title: The Stakes Are Too High
description: THE kinds of investments that get the most publicity are often the least appropriate for the average investor, say the experts. Because they involve too much risk, have poor potential for return or require the time and attention that only the most sophisticated professionals can devote to them, these investments are best avoided by anyone whose primary attention is elsewhere, for instance, on a demanding job.

title: Giants' Fans Find a Separate Peace at Last
description: ON this Sunday last year, we were 9-2 and coming off ''Fourth and Seventeen'' and the whole world could see we were headed for Pasadena. I didn't know one Giants' fan, however, who believed we would make it to Pasadena.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BLACK HISTORY MUSEUM
description: LEAD: The Madame C. J. Walker Committee is not about to be deterred from raising funds to establish a black history museum in Westchester.

title: Giants-Redskins a Ho-Hum-er
description: Last season, the Giants played (and beat) the Redskins three times, and each team played each game as if it were for a championship. On Sunday, they will meet again before the usual sellout crowd at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in a game means little in the standing.

title: TURKEY SURPLUS LOWERS PRICES
description: The main course at holiday meals this season is costing less because of a surplus of turkeys.

title: Cubans in Louisiana Insist On Bishop to Mediate Talks
description: The refusal of Government negotiators to allow rebellious Cuban inmates to meet with outside mediators appears to have become a stumbling block to the release of 26 hostages held at a Federal detention center here.

title: 2 Big West Side Projects Fuel Anti-Development Sentiment
description: Two gigantic building projects proposed for the West Side of Manhattan have prompted a groundswell of opposition so broad and deep that a number of urban experts and politicians say it has changed the way New Yorkers look at their skyline and feel about their government.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: IN HER book ''The Biological Clock'' (Doubleday, New York, $18.95), Molly McKaughan of Montclair gives a new meaning to the term ''clock watchers,'' her phrase for most of the 5,000 women who replied to a 1985 survey on motherhood in Working Woman magazine.

title: Defending Met Trades
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FUTURE IS DEBATED ON 8 IDLE REACTORS
description: Eight reactors that helped put the punch in the United States arsenal of nuclear weapons sit silent along the Columbia River today as Federal officials ponder a report that suggests what could be done with them.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CIRCLES OF DECEIT. By Nina Bawden. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) The British novelist Nina Bawden's latest work is aptly named, since most of its characters are deceiving someone, not infrequently themselves. The unnamed narrator, a painter, has even elevated the practice to an art. He makes finely detailed copies of important works by the masters - always for legitimate purposes - and uses the income to finance his smaller output of originals. He is, however, also frequently engaged in less wholesome deceit, as is his family. His first wife, a dentist, precipitates the end of their marriage by having an affair with a colleague. His second hides her abuse of her illegitimate son. The narrator's mother may be hiding the real reason she left his father; her sister meddles in other people's lives. Only the painter's son by his first marriage is relatively lacking in guile, possibly because he's schizophrenic. Ms. Bawden makes comic use of these characters' foibles, but there is considerable sadness beneath her evocative scenes and lively dialogue. Really a meditation on the nature of art, the novel argues that there is little the creative process can do to relieve human suffering. Art, Ms. Bawden implies, may be the grandest deception, enabling the artist to portray the world as he wishes it to be rather than as it is. She reveals her point subtly - so subtly the novel occasionally seems plodding. But although very little happens, she makes the reader care about these people's trials. However much her characters deceive, it's refreshing to see that Nina Bawden's own talent is nothing less than genuine.

title: Daughter of Ex-Governor Is Found Drowned
description: A daughter of former New Jersey Gov. William T. Cahill was found dead in her apartment here after drowning in a bathtub, the woman's family and law-enforcement authorities said Friday.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: RUBBER LEGS AND WHITE TAIL-HAIRS. By Patrick F. McManus. (Holt, $14.95.) Patrick McManus's sixth book follows such successes as ''Never Sniff a Gift Fish'' and ''They Shoot Canoes, Don't They?'' Mr. McManus has become celebrated as an outdoor humorist, which is perplexing because his work isn't all that hilarious.

title:
IN THE REGION: LONG ISLAND;
Bringing New Life to Those Aging Malls
description: LEAD: LIKE many of the shopping centers built on the Island two and three decades ago, the Mid-Island Plaza, a 1.5 million-square-foot mall on North Broadway in Hicksville, was growing seedy.

title: Fight to Overcome A Criminal Past
description: EDWARD LOSS graduated near the top of his class in law school, was certified by the Illinois Supreme Court's Committee on Character and Fitness to become a lawyer and was waiting for a swearing-in date when the court barred his certification.

title: Get a Prudent Edge
description: WHILE many Wall Street professionals were looking for ever-greater rewards in a bull market that was defying economic gravity earlier this year, Lawrence A. Krause, one of the nation's leading financial planners and head of his own firm in San Francisco, was busily writing ''Sleep-Tight Money,'' (Simon & Schuster, 300 pages, $17.95).

title: Spain Sees Arrests Damaging Basque Separatists
description: Government officials here believe they have permanently damaged the Basque separatist organization E.T.A. after a second round of arrests this week of several of the group's major figures.

title: The Business World/Magazine Part 2
description: These special reports:

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I have been advised that when I close my summer home for the winter, I should leave the heat on at a low setting of about 40 degrees to protect the wood paneling, built-ins and furniture. Do you think heating is necessary when the house is unoccupied?

title: CHORAL CONCERTS AND DANCE TAKE CENTER STAGE
description: CHORAL concerts and dance programs are moving to the front, starting Wednesday with the first of four consecutive 8 P.M. performances by the Manhattanville Dance Ensemble.

title: IN MT. KISCO, MASTER PRINTER AT WORK
description: A QUIET intensity marks the atmosphere at Tyler Graphics Ltd., the industrial-sized workshop in Mount Kisco where editions of prints by some of America's leading artists are produced.

title: ARTFUL MIX OF 3 CUISINES IN NORWALK
description: THE highway strip along Route 7 in Norwalk has never been a source of prime-time dining. With the arrival of Three Flags, that has changed. You might not know it from the exterior of the new brick building, which could easily suggest a fast-food eatery. The name rings bells that evoke a theme park more than a first-class restaurant.

title: Collecting Art? Beware the Wrinkles
description: COLLECTING art requires a great deal of faith. One has to trust one's tastes, the art dealer and the market. But even with art prices soaring - a trend underscored earlier this month by the astronomical $53.9 million that Van Gogh's ''Irises'' brought at auction - faith can take you just so far. Increasingly, buying and selling is being regulated through legislation and case law, and consumers need to be aware of their rights to negotiate better deals.

title: One-Man Luge Team With Tale of 2 Flags
description: IT wasn't much more than a year ago that the final approval was granted, and the Philippines had itself a Winter Olympics team for the first time since 1972. Although there were dark moments in the campaign, like the time a government official was detained at the airport in Manila and forced to turn over important papers intended for the nation's Olympic Committee, persistence and sincerity won out.

title: MISS BONA PLANS TO WED STUDENT
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Bona of Boonton Township, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Dawn Elaine Bona to Robert A. Rizzo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Amedeo A. Rizzo of Broomall, Pa.

title: Life as a Rehearsal
description: LEAD: A DREAM OF PASSION The Development of the Method. By Lee Strasberg. Edited by Evangeline Morphos. Illustrated. 201 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95.

title: CHRISTMAS CONCERT
description: The Orchestra of St. Peter by the Sea, whose founder and maestro, the Rev. Alfonse Stephenson, is the former conductor of the musical ''A Chorus Line,'' will return to its home at St. Peter's Church in Point Pleasant Beach for a Christmas concert Saturday.

title:
ANTIQUES;
Historic Homes Open for Holiday Tours
description: LEAD: SOME of the finest examples of early New Jersey architecture survive as beautifully restored house museums, nine of which be decorated for the holidays and opened to the public for special tours scheduled within the next two weeks in Morristown and Princeton.

title: Simon Stumps in Oklahoma
description: Senator Paul Simon, seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that the Reagan Administration's farm policies had helped only the corporate farming industry. In a 90-minute stop here, the Illinois Senator told a crowd of about 100 people that farm programs should be redesigned to benefit the family farmers. He also said he would support an oil import fee to bolster the nation's energy industry.

title: On Wilde's 'Salome'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ACTS TO PROTECT ISLAND TERN
description: THE roseate tern, which nests in the Stewart B. McKinney National Wildlife Refuge off southwest Connecticut, has been declared an endangered species by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, effective Dec. 2.

title: HILL HOMES ARE FOUGHT IN CROTON
description: PRICKLY PEAR HILL was not supposed to be mentioned at a recent public meeting in Croton-on-Hudson, under ground rules set by the chairman. But every so often, the words slipped out.

title: Soviet Voice Grows Clearer
description: TELEVISION AWAITS MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV; the Soviet leader arrives in Washington on Dec. 7, but already there are arguments. Soviet officials had suggested that Mr. Gorbachev make a 10 A.M. speech to a joint session of Congress. The time difference would have allowed him to appear live and in prime time in Moscow. Conservative Republicans, however, blocked Mr. Gorbachev's Congressional appearance. Meanwhile, CBS says that Mr. Gorbachev declined to give the network a one-on-one interview. Soviet officials, the network says, objected to a CBS documentary on Afghanistan last July and to a question Dan Rather asked Mr. Gorbachev at a 1985 news conference in Paris. (''Why not let everyone of Jewish heritage who wants to emigrate from the Soviet Union do so, and secondly, sir, would you tell us how many political prisoners there are in the Soviet Union?'') Governments take television seriously; vanity, self-promotion and ideology are at stake.

title: MAKING HAY IN IOWA
description: FRED GRATZON, FOUNDER AND CHAIR-man of The Great Midwestern Ice Cream Company in Fairfield, Iowa, doesn't follow politics closely. But he's hoping to turn a sweet profit on the battle for the Presidency. He has established the nation's first and only Presidential ice cream poll.

title: Persistent Rent Control
description: To the Editor:

title: AN INN REVIVES COLONIAL COOKING
description: LEAD: A couple's passion for antique cooking utensils helped transform a North Stonington farmhouse into a country inn and restaurant dedicated to keeping the art of Colonial openhearth cookery alive.

title:
IT'S A BIT LIKE MARRIAGE;
Dealing With Your Broker
description: LEAD: WALL STREET'S ''Black Monday'' was blacker for some investors than for others, and brokers were partly to blame. In the wake of the stock market collapse, complaints to the Securities and Exchange Commission's Office of Consumer Affairs and Information Services in Washington dramatically increased, according to Bonnie Westbrook, the director.

title: DID MADAME BOVARY DO DISHES?
description: DID Madame Bovary take arsenic to avoid doing dishes? While I was washing the previous night's dinner-party plates and platters, this question raced through my mind like turbulent waters through the Proustian floodgates of memory.

title: Books From The Times
description: CHOREOGRAPHY OBSERVED. By Jack Anderson. (University of Iowa, $25.) In this anthology of criticism, the New York Times dance critic Jack Anderson concentrates on the one aspect of dance that fascinates him most - choreography. Choosing among his articles in The Times and other publications to form this collection, Mr. Anderson ranges from Fokine and Balanchine to Bausch as he describes the way ''choreographers employ time, space, and motion so that each dance becomes a little world all its own.'' With black-and-white photographs.

title: Fear of AIDS Prompts State Department to Act
description: Fear of AIDS has come to the State Department.

title: YOUTHS WARN PEERS ON DRUG USE
description: Seven teenagers climbed out of a station wagon and a Toyota and walked into the Branford High School recently. As they walked down a couple of long hallways, they blended right in with the students, wearing denim jackets, untied sneakers and t-shirts sporting names like Bon Jovi and Beastie Boys.

title: A LA CARTE
description: LEAD: AT last, busy White Plains has a pretty and convenient place for shoppers to set down holiday shopping bags and re-energize for the busy evening to come - and it's about time. Following a national trend set by hotels, B. Altman & Company offers afternoon tea in its second-floor restaurant, Charleston Gardens.

title: In New Mexico, Pinon Fires And Pueblo Dancers
description: ON Christmas Eve at the San Juan pueblo in northern New Mexico, every family puts up a small pile of logs in front of their home. As the sky darkens over the pueblo, the wood is ignited into fires called luminarias. Dancers known as Matachines appear, in many-colored silk capes and streaming ribbons, led by a blanket-draped figure holding a cross.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Writers deserve star billing in a handful of films on the small screen this week. Harold Pinter's adaptation of ''The French Lieutenant's Woman'' (1981) - Saturday at 8 P.M. on Channel 11 - entwines John Fowles's story of a Victorian outcast with a modern tale of illicit love, not always successfully. But the result is interesting, colorful, surprising (if you don't know the book) and beautifully performed by Meryl Streep, Jeremy Irons, Leo McKern and the others.

title: Lisa B. Brinkman Marries Reporter
description: Our Lady of Fatima Roman Catholic Church in Wilton, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Lisa Benson Brinkman, the daughter of Richard Gene Brinkman of Wilton and Jensen Beach, Fla., and the late Audrey Benson Brinkman, to Michael Charles Jensen Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jensen of New York and Peekskill, N.Y. The Rev. Charles Carr performed the ceremony.

title: CHRISTMAS CONCERTS IN AN EARLY START
description: CHAMBER Music Plus is continuing its Thanksgiving tradition this afternoon at 3 with its eighth annual post-holiday concert at the Old State House in Hartford.

title: DRAWING UP PLANS TO FIGHT CORRUPTION IN CONSTRUCTION
description: WITH 14 Federal and local agencies scrambling - sometimes competing with one another - to expose corruption, New York City's construction industry seemingly has a plethora of watchdogs. But top aides to Governor Cuomo now say the administration is poised to add two more units to clean up and regulate the diffuse mix of developers, contractors, suppliers and labor unions.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: CHENNAULT. By Jack Samson. (Doubleday, $19.95.) Claire Chennault, a retired Army Air Corps fighter pilot, went to China in 1937 to advise its Government and created the American Volunteer Group, popularly known as the Flying Tigers. Using Chennault's brilliant tactics, the AVG defended Chinese cities and knocked down scores of enemy aircraft over Southeast Asia.

title: Turning the Other Cheek
description: LEAD: BOTTOMS UP! A Pathologist's Essays on Medicine and the Humanities. By William B. Ober. Illustrated. 335 pp. Carbondale: Southern Illinois University Press. $19.95.

title:
TO START WITH...;
FUNNY BUSINESS
description: LEAD: More than 800 partners of Deloitte Haskins & Sells, the nation's seventh-largest accounting firm, had gathered for a six-day conference in the pink stucco Boca Raton Hotel and Club in Boca Raton, Fla. On this fall morning, 100 of them were laughing, shouting, stomping their feet and making faces at one another.

title: MICHIGAN SHOCKED BY ARIZONA, 79-64
description: It was the Big Ten against the Pac-10, and the bodies were flying. But it wasn't the Rose Bowl. It was the semifinals of the 10th Great Alaska Shootout. Arizona beat Michigan, 79-64, today to advance to the title game.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A STEP IN TIME Having trouble perfecting your schottische, quadrille, turkey trot or galop? Not to worry. The Vintage Music & Dance Society of West Hartford will hone your skills in workshops from 10 A.M. to noon and from 1:30 to 4 P.M. Saturday, then give you an opportunity to show off at a grand ball from 8 P.M. to midnight. Advanced dancers will be taught by Patri Pugliese and Hannah Roberts, co-directors of the Commonwealth Vintage Dancers of Boston. The waltz, polka, one-step, tango, grizzly bear and cakewalk are included in the program.

title: A WALK THAT OPENED MY EYES
description: I HAVE never tallied the hours I spend driving on errands or playing chauffeur, but sometimes it seems that the car is an extension of my body and I am connected to the gas stations along Route 25A by a giant umbilical cord.

title: DIANE W. HUNTER WED TO WILLARD MACKEY JR.
description: At St. Michael's Lutheran Church in New Canaan, Conn., Diane Webb Hunter, a jewelry designer, was married yesterday to Willard Clyde Mackey Jr., former chairman of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, an advertising agency in New York. The Rev. Elwood L. Stark performed the ceremony.

title: BEHIND-THE-SCENES DRAMA
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND STAGE opens ''Children,'' a sophisticated contemporary comedy, Tuesday, but it took some backstage melodrama to get the production, the company's second of the season, on the boards.

title: Message for Dorsett
description: IN case Tony Dorsett hasn't gotten the message, Tom Landry, the coach of the Dallas Cowboys, made it all but explicit last week. While he stopped short of saying the 33-year-old running back would be asked to retire after the season, Landry told The Dallas Times Herald that Herschel Walker represented the team's future. ''Right now,'' Landry said, ''the position belongs to Herschel Walker. He just fits in with our plans.'' As for Dorsett, Landry said, ''we will have to make a decision about him at the end of the season.''

title: King Olav Visits Minnesota
description: King Olav V of Norway says he is thrilled to be making his sixth visit to Minnesota, where one-sixth of the state's residents are of Norwegian descent. ''I have been enormously impressed by the unfailing interest in Norway here in this country,'' the King said at a dinner in his honor Friday night. The dinner was one of the few public appearances the 84-year-old King made in his five-day visit. He is to meet with President Reagan in Washington on Monday and return to Norway the same day.

title: J. J. PERTICONE JR. AND SUSAN TELLIER TO MARRY JAN. 16
description: Susan Elizabeth Tellier and Joseph James Perticone Jr., a son of Mary C. Perticone of Baltimore and the late Mr. Perticone, plan to marry Jan. 16, the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Tellier of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Gift Mart at Temple Features 35 Vendors The Larchmont Temple Gift Mart is next weekend - opening Saturday at 7 P.M. and closing at 10 P.M. and reopening next Sunday, when the hours are 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. The price range is $5 to $600, and 35 vendors are participating this year. Gift certificates are available.

title: Girl Found Alive Among Dead
description: An 18-month-old girl was found alive Friday in a house with an infant and two adults who had apparently been dead for several weeks, the police said.

title: McNeil Finally Finds the Key
description: The brawny, but quick, outside linebackers have become such an intimidating power in the National Football League that even the slithery Freeman McNeil has been forced to change his style.

title: 17 Inmates Protest Internment in Manhattan
description: Seventeen inmates at the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in Manhattan have gone on a hunger strike to protest their internment.

title: Next Week; Is Larry Holmes Too Old To Fight?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: POSTINGS: 35-Story Office Tower
description: For years, the New York Hilton Hotel on Avenue of the Americas at 53d Street held on to a site it owned to the west of its parking garage in case it wanted to expand.

title: Donations Are High In Coat Drive for Poor
description: A laundry owner who offered to clean used coats and distribute them to the poor said Friday he was overwhelmed by the response.

title: BUSINESS AFFAIRS
description: There is no book of sexual manners in the office, because sex simply doesn't belong in the office. - 'Letitia Baldriges's Complete Guide to Executive Manners'

title: THE CONTRADICTIONS OF BOB DOLE
description: I read with astonishment that Senator Dole whispered to me, during a House-Senate conference, that I should ignore his pronouncements on austerity and press for expansion of Medicaid coverage of prenatal care. No such conversation took place.

title: SOUTHERN SUMMIT REKINDLES OLD DREAMS OF LATIN UNITY
description: FOR the first time, the presidents of eight Latin American nations are meeting without a United States presence to discuss solutions to their regional problems. The agenda for the conference, which is to conclude today, ranges from the conflicts in Central America to the region's foreign debt of nearly $400 billion. But, for many participants, just the achievement of bringing together the leaders of the so-called Group of Eight made for a moment of no small emotion.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CANDLELIGHT CONCERTS Richard Kapp and his Philharmonia Virtuosi chamber orchestra will open the Candlelight Concerts of Larchmont series at 7:30 P.M. today in St. Augustine's Church, on Larchmont Avenue. The 13-year old ensemble has performed at Alice Tully and Avery Fisher Halls in Manhattan, the Kennedy Center in Washington, on tour throughout the Far East, and at the State University of New York at Purchase every year since the college's Performing Arts Center opened in 1977.

title: A MODERN SCROOGE BY A NEW COMPANY
description: How to save the American musical theater? Kevin Connors, who lives in Westport, thinks he's found a way.

title: A 'Real' Supply-Sider Views Reagan's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: In Scotland, a Double Portion of Cheer
description: THE celebration of the New Year is usually here today and gone tomorrow, except in Scotland, where the joys of the season and the pleasures of the flask linger a full two days. Scots allow Jan. 2 as well as Jan. 1 for a double measure of oblivion, and count their blessings twice over. Not till Jan. 3 does the customary round resume - trains, planes, buses, postal deliveries, painful sobriety.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'BASICALLY BASSOON' Whether he's playing Vivaldi, Scott Joplin, Mozart or Beethoven, Daniel Smith does it all on the bassoon. And no wonder; these days, the Syosset resident is known as the world's most recorded (and lauded, by critics) bassoon soloist. Naturally, he's determined to spread the news and the sound of what he considers a wonderfully expressive solo instrument. So when he takes to the stage he calls his concerts ''Basically Bassoon''. Today, when he appears at the Freeport Memorial Library at 3 P.M., cellist Stephen Green, and pianist Barbara Kupferberg will provide some of the other basics in a program that also includes works by Galliard, Jacob, Miroshnikov and Kriesler, and even some ''Londonderry Airs'' and ''Yankee Doodle''. The Library is on South Ocean Avenue and the concert, under the aegis of the Nassau County Office of Cultural Development, is free. HOLIDAY TOURS All decked out for the holidays, area homes provide a tempting destination for folks who like to see how others live. This week there are three house tours on tap. Tuesday, the Nassau County Women's Division of the Salvation Army gains from a tour of four houses in the Bellmore-Wantagh neighborhood (including a farmhouse, circa 1644, q and a 1794 Georgian mansion that's an historic landmark); a 125-year-old Quaker meeting house; and an 1885 Long Island Railroad Station. The buildings will be open from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and for reservations call 747-4902. In Amityvile, the Junior League of the local Woman's Club holds its 32nd annual Holiday Homes Tour Saturday. Three local homes -an old Victorian, an ultra-modern contemporary,and a '50's ranch house -- will be on display from 1 to 4 P.M. and for ticket information call 842-2891. Finally, artists and craftspeople in the quaint village of Sea Cliff open their homes, studios and workshops Saturday, next Sunday and December 12 and 13 to folks who'd like to wander by from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. There's no charge -- they'd like visitors to buy their wares -- and free maps are available at the Village Gift Shop on Sea Cliff Avenue. MODEL TRAINS

title: A MACHINE LEARNS TO SPEAK: MIMICKING THE NEUROLOGICAL NETWORKS
description: DURING the last eight years, the number of research reports presented at the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience has more than doubled, exceeding 6,600 this year. In an attempt to keep up, more than 11,000 scientists and onlookers gathered for the 1987 convention, which was held in New Orleans this month. What follows are reports on some of the ascendant ideas in the continuing attempt to learn how the brain generates the mind, and how the mind controls the body.

title: 'Dear Mr. Emerson'
description: THE SELECTED LETTERS OF LIDIAN JACKSON EMERSON Edited by Delores Bird Carpenter. Illustrated. 343 pp. Columbia: University of Missouri Press. $42.

title: Reagan to Stress Regional Conflicts at Talks
description: President Reagan asserted today that military intervention by the Soviet Union in other nations was ''a major impediment to improved U.S.-Soviet relations.''

title: DONNA RAYNER IS WED TO BRANDON BALTHAZAR
description: Donna Rayner, a daughter of Alice Rayner and Ahmed Rayner Jr., both of Chicago, was married there last evening to Brandon Balthazar, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Don J. Balthazar of White Plains. The Rev. Michael Ivers performed the ceremony at St. Columbanus Roman Catholic Church.

title: CAN THE MENNONITES SURVIVE SUCCESS?
description: As a Mennonite and as a law student at Columbia University, I found Paul W. Cohen's description of Mennonites in his article ''Can the Mennonites Survive Success?'' (Nov. 8) insightful and disturbing.

title: Old Van Cortlandt Yields U.S. Titles
description: The grave site, complete with a number of family members and a little of the history of New York City, stands in disrepair squarely in the middle of Van Cortlandt Park. The iron fences are collapsing, the monuments are badly twisted, the name Van Cortlandt is barely legible amid the weeds.

title: Sondheim's Winding Paths
description: ''THERE'S SOMETHING ABOUT A WAR'' goes the title of a song that was written for, but never used, in Stephen Sondheim's first musical as a Broadway composer, the 1962 ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.'' There's something about a Stephen Sondheim musical that's something like a war - and, until the arrival of his latest and perhaps most tranquil show, ''Into the Woods,'' that war had threatened to rival the Thirty Years' War in duration. People have never been neutral about the work of Stephen Sondheim. He leaves some theatergoers elated and others enraged. At the theaters where his musicals are playing, the heat and tension of battle seem to charge the air.

title: Delay in Plans
description: THE San Diego Yacht Club has delayed until Wednesday any announcement of its plans for dealing with New Zealand's challenge for the America's Cup. Club officials are apparently trying to enlist the support of other potential United States syndicates in a unified stand against New Zealand.

title: PORTENTS OF TURNS FOR THE WORSE-OR THE BETTER
description: EVER since the Oct. 19 stock market collapse, most analysts have been saying that the economy would slow down as a result, perhaps enough to send the nation stumbling into recession. They argue that consumers, who account for two-thirds of the gross national product, have lost both wealth and confidence and will pull in their horns accordingly. Business executives could also dampen the economy by deciding to scale back production or to carry smaller stocks of goods.

title: New-Age Music Booms, Softly
description: NEW-AGE MUSIC IS OOZING TOWARD THE big time. Once found alongside seaweed and Tarot cards at an occasional macrobiotic outlet, new-age music has evolved from a shared secret to a trendy commodity. In the last year, two of its stars, the Swiss ''electroacoustic harpist'' Andreas Vollenweider and the Japanese synthesizer player Kitaro have played to full houses at Radio City Music Hall. George Winston, perhaps the only pianist who performs shoeless at Avery Fisher Hall, is to return there on Wednesday and again on Dec. 12.

title: Aftershocks for Silicon Valley
description: LEAD: The aftershocks of the United States Supreme Court's decision to uphold the conviction of The Wall Street Journal reporter R. Foster Winans and two co-conspirators are likely to be felt dramatically in the high-tech world of Silicon Valley.

title: New Drives Are On to Restore Walden Pond
description: Across the road from this town's dump is a fenced-off pond where marked walking trails lead to a public bathhouse with emergency medical facilities, and at the shoreline a sign reading ''No lifeguard on duty'' juts from greenish water.

title:
MUSIC;
Unlikely Team Behind an Unlikely Opera
description: LEAD: IT'S A STEAMY DAY IN HOUSTON, where, in a warehouse across the street from the Southern Noodle Company, the director Peter Sellars is running through a scene from ''Nixon in China,'' John Adams's opera about Richard Nixon's 1972 landmark visit to the People's Republic of China. The scene is Pat Nixon's tour of a Peking glass factory, and the cast includes the soprano Carolyann Page as Pat Nixon and three contraltos known as ''Maoettes,'' a Motown-style back-up group comprised of Mao Zedong's private secretaries, who echo his pronouncements like a Greek chorus.

title: E. F. Hutton Goes on the Block
description: E. F. Hutton is for sale. The stock market collapse last month and the likelihood of a downgrading in its credit rating were the final blows to a securities firm that has been struggling since it pleaded guilty two years ago to a check-kiting scheme that defrauded banks of millions of dollars. Last year, when most of Wall Street was awash in profits, Hutton had a loss of $90.3 million. The potential bidders for Hutton include TransAmerica, Dean Witter and Shearson Lehman. The strongest overture came from Shearson, which had offered to buy Hutton a year ago for $50 a share, or a total of $1.6 billion. That bid was spurned by Hutton officials. Analysts said that now, in the aftermath of the market plunge, Hutton would probably fetch about $1 billion.

title: Music: Kronos Quartet in Contemporary Program
description: LINCOLN CENTER'S Great Performers series took a leap into the 20th century Friday night when the Kronos Quartet played the first in its three-concert series at Alice Tully Hall. Like most Kronos concerts, the program featured premieres and recent compositions (the oldest, Bill Evans's ''Waltz for Debby,'' dated back to 1956). It brought together composers from five continents, and it also included the first music ever commissioned by the Great Performers series, a practice that shouldn't stop with Kronos.

title: A Hot Medium for the Message
description: AT this time of year, mailboxes overflow with requests for charitable contributions. Before long, however, your mailman may be bringing you something more eye-catching than a letter - a videotape.

title: TRY PASTA DISHES AS A FIRST COURSE
description: THE problem of choosing a first course at a small dinner is easily solved by pasta.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Border War THERE'S a mini-border war going on between Smithtown and Huntington, and since the United Nations is otherwise engaged, the towns are taking their dispute to Suffolk County.

title: SHOWS AND SALES FOR THE HOLIDAY SEASON
description: SEASONAL flurries of craft fairs and sales are scheduled next weekend in different parts of the state and just across the border.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RINGER. By Marshall Terry. (Corona/ Texas Monthly, $16.95.) ''Ringer'' is a self-conscious retelling of the biblical story of the prodigal son, with characters who never rise from their flat landscape. An elderly widow, Eliza MacDuff Ringer, has been transplanted from a small Texas town to an apartment in Dallas so she can be close to her one responsible son, Bill. He, however, is only living off his reputation for responsibility. In reality, no one has any idea ''how close to the edge . . . Bill Ringer was.'' Eliza has it in her head that she is going to die and asks Bill to find his long-lost brother, Joe. Bill is not thrilled with his mother's request, but begins making a few lame inquiries. When the reader finally meets Joe it is easy to see why no one except his mother cares much about his absence. He is the kind of guy who can - and does - steal a friend's credit card and is sure the friend won't mind. Not a lot is happening in ''Ringer,'' a state of affairs that would be more palatable if Marshall Terry, the author of two previous novels, compensated by providing fascinating characters who create some emotional tension. Unfortunately the story stays slack, and the characters are so lifeless they seem to be interested in one another only out of a sense of duty. Fortunately, the reader has no such obligation.

title: Bulls Rule Texas Freeway
description: Twenty-one Brahman bulls escaped from a corral at the Mesquite Rodeo Arena Friday in a bull-riding lesson and swarmed across the Lyndon B. Johnson Freeway and lawns in this Dallas suburb. Motorists slammed on their brakes. Some took photographs. One bull made his way into a subdivision and was roped in front of a $500,000 home. The escape came as Don Gay, an eight-time world champion bull rider, was about to show students a film when he learned that the prized animals had broken loose. Mr. Gay chased the bulls on horseback, but was thrown when his horse fell in a ditch. Neither was injured.

title: HOME FOR MENTALLY ILL WORRIES GLEN COVE
description: LEAD: HUGUETTE CLEMENCON of Glen Cove and 99 of her neighbors, who recently received a letter from the city's Mayor informing them that a group home for the mentally disabled was planned for their neighborhood, all want to know the same thing.

title:
OUTLOOK FOR THE MARKETS: Equities at Risk; Bonds Promising;
But Certain Issues Win Favor
description: LEAD: ON Oct. 19, the bull market met the matador.

title: Pass Along the Costs to the Consumer
description: OUR firm recently conducted an investigation into the issue of unfunded liabilities associated with retirement medical benefits. Among 40 major corporations studied, most cited liabilities ranging from $25 million to $1.5 billion. So far, these liabilities remain a closely guarded secret, but the situation is rapidly changing.

title: ANGEL POWER
description: ROBERT C. MCCRAY STEERS HIS gray Chevrolet slowly around the common in Amherst, N.H., taking in favorite details: the swings in the yard of the brick schoolhouse, the steeple atop the Congregational Church, the white rail fence that hugs the town green. There's a Civil War monument, of course, and an old water trough and a flagpole. ''I come here at the end of the day,'' he says, his voice a soft, steady monotone, not giving too much away. ''This place is a touchstone. It gives me confidence in my country and myself.''

title: A Ballet's New Clothes
description: SOME people find Christian Lacroix's fashion designs overly theatrical. But that is precisely why Mikhail Baryshnikov, the artistic director of the American Ballet Theater, chose Mr. Lacroix to design costumes for a revival of Leonide Massine's ''Gaiete Parisienne,'' which will be on the bill for the company's season opening gala at the Metropolitan Opera House on April 18.
