title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: STEAL THIS URINE TEST: Fighting Drug Hysteria in America. By Abbie Hoffman with Jonathan Silvers. (Penguin, Paper, $5.95.) Drug abuse is a serious national problem, but part of that problem is public and governmental misunderstanding and over-reaction: that is the important theme of ''Steal This Urine Test,'' and it's one that the book documents thoroughly. There have been repeated Federal wars on drugs, but their lasting impact has been doubtful at best. Abbie Hoffman, a pillar of the anti-Establishment establishment for a quarter of a century, and Jonathan Silvers, who has written extensively on politics and culture, argue that the useful impact of such campaigns has been zero. There have been much-publicized ''billion-dollar'' captures of drugs destined for the American market, yet that market remains vigorous. The book castigates the present Administration for cutting back funding for drug rehabilitation programs, and it notes the tragic disparity between an estimated 200,000 heroin addicts in the New York metropolitan area and a capacity to treat 35,000. But the authors' prime target is the use of urine testing to detect illegal drug use - a practice that certainly raises serious problems of violation of privacy and civil liberties. Mr. Hoffman and Mr. Silvers offer frightening incidents, gleaned from recent court cases. ''This is a call to arms against a ritual that has nothing to do with drug abuse and a lot to do with controlling citizens,'' Mr. Hoffman says in the introduction. It is an argument that deserves a hearing.

title: Protecting the Chesapeake's Striped Bass
description: ALTHOUGH there has been an improvement in the spawning of striped bass in many of the rivers entering Chesapeake Bay, the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission announced earlier this fall that it would continue its current recommendation for a 33-inch minimum-length limit for migratory coastal stocks of the species.

Hoy of Bethesda, Md., and Clyde Edwards Reetz, a son of Gay Edwards Reetz of Bronxville, N.Y., and John H. Reetz of Bradford, Pa. The Rev. Peter Beck performed the ceremony.

title: Shopping in London For Record Bargains
description: NOT too many moons ago, a visitor had merely to step off the train or bus from Gatwick Airport at Victoria Station to find a W. H. Smith book-and-record shop with long-playing record treasures beyond imagining. Alas, the W. H. Smith store at Victoria contains no records these days. And the Our Price Records shop in the same station (now a subsidiary of W. H. Smith) deals mainly in compact disks and cassettes. What a shock to the music lover who always honored London for its five reigning symphony orchestras of the first rank (London Philharmonic, London Symphony, Royal Philharmonic, New Philharmonia and BBC Symphony Orchestra), not to mention for such matchless chamber orchestras as the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields.

title: Q & A
description: Credit Report on a Tenant Question: I am trying to rent a one-family home. I plan to use a standard application form for prospective tenants. Aside from checking to see if people are employed, is there any way that I can get a report from a credit-reporting company to learn about the finances of people I might rent to? . . . P. E., Elmhurst, Queens Answer: Although you have the right to seek credit information on prospective tenants, credit-rating services might not respond to inquiries that come directly from you. Marvin Kaplan, a spokesman for Associated Credit Bureaus, a trade organization representing credit information companies, suggests that you ask prospective tenants to have a credit service report sent to them, which they then could show to you. Anyone who has ever applied for a credit card, charge account, bank loan or mortgage is likely to have a credit rating. Taking Over a Lease Question: About 15 years ago my daughter moved into a rent-stabilized apartment. At the time the building's management insisted that I sign the lease because she was not working. I have been paying the rent but she and her children have been living there continuously. Is there any way that the landlord can be compelled to issue the lease in her name if her credit is worthy? Will she have succession rights in the event of my death or if the building goes co-op? . . . J. S., Manhattan Answer: There are no rent-stabilization regulations that obligate the landlord to add your daughter's name to the lease or give her the right to succession.

title: TAP DANCE TO SCIENCE
description: Crossroads Africa Dec. 2 - Since its founding in 1957, Operation Crossroads Africa has sent more than 8,000 young Americans to rural African and Caribbean communities to work on development projects in medicine, agriculture, education and construction. And over the past 23 years, more than 3,200 young African political leaders and professionals have visited schools and other institutions in the United States. Under a new program sponsored by the Ford Foundation, graduate and postgraduate students who are members of minority groups will spend a year working and studying in Africa. The 30th anniversary awards dinner of the organization will be held at the Marriott Marquis, starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Black tie or national dress. Miriam Makeba will be among the entertainers. Tickets, $200, from 212-260-1070. Ice-Skating Party

A year ago, he talked of creating a Clean Ocean Authority, with broad but vaguely defined powers to address a wide variety of coastal problems ranging from dumping to overdevelopment. By summer, the proposal had evolved into a Coastal

title: Dance
description: Among the most stimulating of choreographers are those whose productions combine intellectual curiosity with theatrical flair. One choreographer known for her flamboyant theatricality is Katherine Dunham, whose achievements will be honored during the season by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater that opens Wednesday night at City Center, 131 West 55th Street. Ms. Dunham attracted attention during the 40's for fast-paced revues based on African and Caribbean folklore. She certainly knew how to set audiences cheering. Yet she also always did her homework. A graduate student in anthropology at the University of Chicago in the 30's, she based her productions on authentic source materials. The Ailey company is presenting her ''Afro-American Suite,'' ''L'Ag'Ya'' and ''Americana Suite'' on a special program called ''The Magic of Katherine Dunham,'' which will be danced at various times throughout the season, including opening night.

title:
NEW JERSEY JOURNAL;
New Law Center
description: LEAD: The $6 million New Jersey Law Center, a two-story, 32,000-square-foot conference center on the Rutgers University campus in New Brunswick, is scheduled to open next month.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BERKUT. By Joseph Heywood. (Random House, $18.95.) Adolf Hitler killed himself in the spring of 1945 as the Red Army advanced on his bunker in Berlin. Or did he? Groan. Not another novel about how Hitler or one of his henchmen survived to sin another day. But don't despair. Joseph Heywood's second novel isn't your run-of-the-mill Nazi-hunting twaddle. If you're willing to ignore a few facts and accept that a double, not Hitler, died beneath the Third Reich's Chancellery, ''The Berkut'' is a pretty good thriller. Mr. Heywood has done a lot of research, stitching fact and fiction together with few traces of thread. And though the book is a bit long, he manages to keep up the pace. Most important, he writes better than he has to. One even wonders why he doesn't take a few more chances and write himself out of the genre entirely. This isn't a typical thriller pitting good against evil. It's hard to love or hate the characters. They are thugs or wimps, and just as you get to like one he coldly knocks off an innocent bystander or whines about the weather. Hitler is a sniveling twit, not a monster. And he's as batty as Stalin, who orders his top agent, a mystic manque with a savage streak, to haul the Fuhrer, alive and kicking, to the Kremlin. The book's title comes from the name of a golden eagle used by the Kirghiz Tatars to hunt wolves. Hitler, a k a Herr Wolf, diminishes in importance, as both a character and a man, as he flees across Europe with the help of two SS commandos. We fear him, then pity him and, finally, we exorcise his ghost.

Rabbi Robert S. Widom officiated aboard the yacht Paco Rabanne at the Water Club in New York.

title: Planners Must Take the Offensive
description: WE SHOULD be demanding more from our planners. Not necessarily longer hours at the meetings of the planning boards, but more in the sense that we look to them for the quality of life in the built environment.

title:
DINING OUT;
In the County Seat of Somerset
description: LEAD: BECAUSE we can cover only a limited number of restaurants each year, we are inclined to give precedence to those that sound the most interesting or are in areas where there are few restaurants.

title: WHAT ARE WE DOING WITH A UNIFORM IN THE HOUSE?
description: THE 7-year-old boy can not sleep tonight. His uniform is laid out beside his bed, and he keeps getting up to put on his blue and yellow cap, to finger the engraved buckle of his blue webbed belt, to gaze at the insignias decorating his brand-new blue shirt. My husband had bought the entire outfit, including the yellow kerchief and various metal buttons, for more money than he had paid for his own fall jacket. But what are we doing with a uniform in the house?

title: Because It's There
description: THERE are certain people who cannot see a mountain without wanting to go up it. I am one of those people.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
TRAILSIDE MEMORIES
description: LEAD: IN the 1920's, Bill Wheeler, first curator of the Trailside Nature Museum at Ward Pound Ridge Reservation in Cross River, made a living working for the telephone company but spent much of his time sharing his real love -nature - with the public. ''He used to arrive late for work at the phone company in a black limousine,'' Ed Kanze, the nature museum's current curator, reported.

title: INSIDE
description: 160 Die in Plane Crash A South African jet crashed into the Indian Ocean near Mauritius, and all 160 people aboard were believed to have been killed. There was no sign of survivors in the sea where floating debris was spotted. Page 3. AIDS and Diplomats The State Department has started trying to keep its employees from being exposed to the deadly AIDS virus and to keep infected people from serving in most posts. Page 26. Moscow Crackdown Members of several Moscow groups say city authorities have begun to crack down on unofficial political groups since Boris N. Yeltsin was dismissed as city party leader. Page 22.

title: Luggage
description: To the Editor: Apropos your Practical Traveler ''Finding Lost Luggage'' (Travel, Sept. 27), I would like to share our experience with your readers. On Sept. 24 we checked in at the Eugene, Ore., airport bound for Kennedy International Airport by way of San Francisco. The cheerful, courteous United Airlines clerk agreed that the layover of half an hour might be too short if there were a delay at Eugene and rerouted us to Denver where the layover was a bit longer. My husband needed a wheelchair at that time.

title:
CELEBRATIONS OF THE SEASON;
In Sweden, a Smorgasbord Of 150 Dishes for the Yule
description: LEAD: A TABLE laden with seasonal fare plays a starring role in Ingmar Bergman's ''Fanny and Alexander.'' The story is set in Sweden in the early 20th century, and in a memorable scene a troubled upper-class family has gathered for the traditional Christmas Eve meal, to eat and sing away the cold and darkness of winter.

title:
TELEVISION;
Locale: Occupied Holland. Scene: The Franks' Attic
description: LEAD: IT IS A COLD, GRAY DAY AND ON a quiet residential street away from the canals, a modest, self-possessed woman named Miep Gies is reliving the Nazi Occupation, remembering her daily visits to the secret hiding place of Anne Frank and her family.

title: CASE HISTORY OF A FOREIGN TRADE ZONE
description: LEAD: THE Foreign Trade Zone in Mount Olive is not on a waterfront, like those in Port Newark, Port Elizabeth and Port Salem, but at the International Trade Center, a 670-acre office and commercial park built by the Rockefeller Center Development Corporation in suburban Morris County.

title: OVERPASS SPARKS FIGHT ON LAND USE
description: LEAD: A PLANNED bridge and a proposed high-technology industrial park are at the center of a land-use controversy involving residents along a road in Setauket, state and local officials, environmentalists, developers and the State University of New York at Stony Brook. and private developers.

title: LILCO IS PURSUING SHOREHAM LICENSE
description: LEAD: DESPITE pressure from the State Public Service Commission to negotiate an end to the impasse over the Shoreham nuclear plant, the Long Island Lighting Company is moving instead to hasten Federal licensing of the facility.

title: French Report Seizing Terrorist in Gunfight
description: The French police announced today that they had arrested the last fugitive leader of Direct Action, the left-wing terrorist group that shook France for years with dozens of bombings and the shooting of police officers and business leaders.

title: ZONE PROLIFERATION ASSAILED
description: LEAD: THE proliferation of Foreign Trade Zones is drawing fire from domestic manufacturers of steel and automobile parts, who say that the zones remove needed protection from imports.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''This is more fallout from the crash.'' - eter Cohen, chairman of Shearson Lehman, potential bidder for E. F. Hutton

title: BANGLADESH BANS PROTEST COVERAGE
description: The Government banned all reports on the political opposition or on anything deemed to be criticism of the authorities today, a day after President H. M. Ershad imposed a nationwide state of emergency.

title: Salzburg
description: To the Editor: In two articles on Salzburg and environs (Travel, July 5 and Aug. 16), Oscar Millard correctly described what the females wear as Dirndls. What the men wear he called flannel. The stuff is Loden. The only resemblance is that both are gray. PAUL SINGER Summit, N.J.

title: Students Told to Lift Grades Or Give Up Dormitory Rooms
description: Officials at Southern Connecticut State University are taking a new attitude toward the overwhelming demand for student housing these days - put up or get out.

title: ELIZABETH MURDOCH TO WED PHYSICIAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. Murdoch Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Patterson Murdoch to Dr. Henry Clinton Maguire 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Maguire Jr. of Merion Station, Pa. A January wedding is planned.

title: MICHAEL JAKUBIK AND MISS TRENT PLANNING TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Trent of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Trent to Michael Jakubik, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Jakubik of Dover, Mass.

title: At Fort Dix, Video Games Go to War
description: LEAD: SGT. ROBERT STODNICK'S touch on the controls of the big TOW missile seemed as light as a feather as he took aim at an armored personnel carrier several hundred yards away. His thumb flicked off the trigger's protective cap, and he all but disappeared in a burst of smoke and flame.

title: Affordable-Housing Model Emerging in Somerset County
description: LEAD: AFFORDABLE housing in all of the state's 567 municipalities is still far in the future, despite repeated court decisions - the so-called Mount Laurel rulings - mandating it, but a workable model is emerging in Somerset County.

title: SPECIAL EDUCATION WITHN AN ARTISTIC TOUCH
description: LEAD: IT does not take much to make the students in Carolyn Bernstein's music class happy.

title: Rooting for Armageddon
description: ARMED AND DANGEROUS The Rise of the Survivalist Right. By James Coates. 294 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $17.95.

title: Inmate Drowns in Escape
description: An inmate who tried to escape by crawling through a drainage culvert drowned after a night of heavy rain, officials said Friday. Jean Ulysses, 29 years old, formerly of Haiti, had pried loose a grate leading to the pipe Thursday night at Tomoka Correctional Institute, and heavy silt hampered Volusia County sheriff's divers who tried to rescue him, the authorities said. The inmate had been serving 20 years for second-degree murder.

title: TALKING: Modulars; Assessing The Jigsaw Alternative
description: BUYERS seeking a new home -whether a single-family house or a town-house-style unit - are increasingly likely to find that builders are offering modular construction.

title: Two Tell of Harsh Captivity in Beirut
description: The hostages spent months chained to a wall, told to keep silent in the solitude of their dark, windowless rooms. They were treated, one of them said, ''like an animal, like a dog,'' often not able to get a drink, to wash, to go to the bathroom. They saw only masked gunmen.

title: THE CONTRADICTIONS OF BOB DOLE
description: Martin Tolchin and Jeff Gerth intimated that Senator Dole had ''championed'' the right-to-life position only in recent years to earn more support from the conservative wing of the Republican Party. Nothing could be further from the truth.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: NOVEMBER 29, 1987
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $4.95.) Nightmarish experiences befall a woman appointed Ambassador to Rumania. 2 4 GARDEN OF SHADOWS, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $4.95.) The beginnings of the evil that beset the Dollanganger family in four previously published novels. 3 5 WHIRLWIND, by James Clavell. (Avon, $5.95.) Iran during the month following the Shah's departure. 4 8 THE GOLDEN CUP, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.95.) Continuing the saga of a turn-of-the-century New York family begun in ''Evergreen.'' 5 3 THE PRINCESS, by Jude Devereaux. (Pocket, $3.95.) A European princess's passionate affair with a United States naval officer. 6 7 FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts. (Pocket, $4.95.) Navy aviators in the Vietnam War. 7 6 PAPER MONEY, by Ken Follett. (Signet/NAL, $3.95.) Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder. 11 3 ALL THAT GLITTERS, by Thomas Tryon. (Dell, $4.95.) Five Hollywood sex goddesses and the agent who helped their careers. 12 * 8 FOUNDATION AND EARTH, by Isaac Asimov. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.95.) The hero of the ''Foundation'' series searches for Earth. 13 * 81 THE HUNT FOR RED OCTOBER, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.50.) A case involving the 1979 murder of a high school teacher. 2 3 DANCING ON MY GRAVE, by Gelsey Kirkland with Greg Lawrence. (Jove, $4.50.) The ballerina recalls her checkered career. 3 214 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 4 31 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Berkley, $6.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations by the television star. 5 56 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) The aviator's adventures. 6 * 40 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Confronting life's losses. 7 * 4 WORD FOR WORD, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Berkley, $3.95.) Essays on contemporary life. 8 4 PAT NIXON, by Julie Nixon Eisenhower. (Zebra, $4.50.) The biography of the former First Lady. 9 19 MAYFLOWER MADAM, by Sydney Biddle Barrows with William Novak. (Ivy/Ballantine, $4.95.) Stories of the world's oldest profession. Q$10 18 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) A veterinarian's tales. 11 * 1 POOR LITTLE RICH GIRL, by C. David Heymann. (Pocket, $4.50.) The life of the Woolworth heiress Barbara Hutton. 12 * 6 ONE KNEE EQUALS TWO FEET, by John Madden with Dave Anderson. (Jove, $3.95.) Observations on football. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 5 THE FAR SIDE OBSERVER, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) A new collection of cartoons. 2 1 CATMOPOLITAN, by Ilene Hochberg. (Pocket, $9.95.) Humorous celebrations of the cat in the format of Cosmopolitan magazine. 3 14 BILLY AND THE BOINGERS BOOTLEG, by Berke Breathed. (Little, Brown, $7.95.) More ''Bloom County'' cartoon strips. 4 31 CALVIN AND HOBBES, by Bill Watterson. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, $6.95.) Cartoons about a boy, his toy tiger and his parents. 5 4 GARFIELD SWALLOWS HIS PRIDE, by Jim Davis. (Ballantine, $5.95.) The 14th collection of cartoons about a fat cat. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: WEDBING PLANNED BY LISA GRUNWALD
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Anatole Grunwald of New York and Vineyard Haven, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mr. Grunwald's daughter Lisa Grunwald to Stephen J. Adler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Adler of Baldwin, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: UNION;
NO GROCERY, BUT WHO CARES?
description: LEAD: YOU can't buy a quart of milk in Union. Nor can you purchase postage stamps, cash a check or fill a prescription in this, the state's smallest town.

title: DR. P. P. VESSA JR. AND MS. OZIMEK ENGAGED TO WED
description: The engagement of Kimberley Cordeaux Ozimek to Dr. Paul Peter Vessa Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vessa of Bergenfield, N.J., and Del Ray Beach, Fla., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Ozimek of Rye, N.Y.

title: On Language; Old and Novel
description: IN TODAY'S BOOK-stores and libraries, you can get hold of just about any kind of dictionary, from the 12-volume-plus-supplements Oxford English to dictionaries of foreign languages and back-and-forth dictionaries (English-Swahili, Francais-Esquimau, etc.) to dictionaries of slang, of computerese, of dirty words and even of multilingual insults. The one kind of dictionary you cannot yet find - or I can't, anyway, and I would rush to buy the first one off the press - is what I might call an English-Olden-Archaic-Obsolete Dictionary. Or, to give it a catchier title, ''What People Used to Call Things.''

title: Seton Hall Falls to Florida in Final Seconds
description: Vernon Maxwell promised to lead his Florida teammates to a championship if they reached the semifinals of the preseason National Invitation Tournament, and last night, he made good on his word.

title: A Children's Museum Adjusts to a New Brooklyn
description: Nearly 100 years ago the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences built a museum where children from the surrounding middle-class neighborhood of Crow Hill could ''stimulate their powers of observation and reflection.''

title: Goetz Confession Offered as Stocking Stuffer
description: When Bernhard H. Goetz surrendered to the police in Concord, N.H., almost three years ago and admitted shooting four teen-agers on a Manhattan subway, he probably never imagined that his confession would one day become a home videocassette, sold in stores alongside such films as ''Rambo'' and ''Death Wish.''

title: PANHANDLING LAW IN USE IN SEATTLE
description: The city's new law against aggressive panhandling has gone into effect, but the police say they did not have to use it the first day of the holiday shopping season.

title: The Uses of Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: Grocers' Gifts Found To Go to Farm Panels
description: Political action committees representing the interests of the grocery industry have been aiming substantial sums of campaign money at members of the Congressional Agriculture Committees, two consumer advocacy groups said in a report today.

title: ADVICE ABOUT RADON CALLED ILL-ADVISED
description: Leonard Cole's article focuses on the uncertainties surrounding the radon issue. It fails to take into consideration one of the certainties about radon: By and large, people are asleep about the problem.

title: On the Phone?
description: Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, made a point of keeping the Federal Bureau of Investigation up to date on certain Teamster activities for more than a decade, according to documents filed in Federal Court in Cleveland last week. Mr. Presser, who has headed the Teamsters since 1983, was said to have kept the bureau informed of ties between union officials and organized crime groups since 1974. The Presser-F.B.I. arrangement came to light when one of the labor leader's co-defendants in a payroll padding case - Mr. Presser and two others are on trial for allegedly participating in a no-show job scheme at Cleveland Local 507 -demanded the release of F.B.I. files on Mr. Presser, saying the files would show that the payroll padding was done with the acquiescence of the F.B.I.

title: TIMETABLE SET FOR YONKERS HOUSING SITES
description: A FEDERAL judge rebuked Yonkers last week for ''continuing intransigence and defiance of a court order'' to build public housing and he set a new timetable that he said was intended to have construction begin by next spring.

title: The Make-Over at Estee Lauder
description: LEONARD A. LAUDER, president and chief executive officer of the Estee Lauder cosmetics empire, is barreling through a Bullock's department store in Southern California, an entourage of a dozen trying to keep pace. It is the sixth store he has visited today to critique the way his products are displayed. Before he dons black tie for dinner tonight, he will see at least four more.

title: For the Near-Term, Allocate Assets Conservatively
description: In the wake of the stock market collapse of Oct. 19, and its fallout on the economy, investors are reassessing their financial and investment strategies. To help them do so, Fred R. Bleakley and Jan M. Rosen of The New York Times staff discussed these issues with two Wall Street professionals: Jonathan A. Berg, president of the Berg Capital Corporation, and Steven G. Einhorn, partner in Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Soviet Beginning to Crack Down On the Unofficial Political Clubs
description: The Moscow authorities have begun to crack down on unofficial political groups in the aftermath of the Yeltsin affair, breaking up meetings and making some arrests, according to members of several groups.

title: WHERE COWS PLODDED, HORSES NOW CANTER
description: WHILE most dairymen have fled Fairfield County for environs where real estate is less costly, horsemen have stepped in to fill the void.

title: 92-YARD RUN DEFEATS WASHINGTON & JEFFERSON
description: Rodney Beville's 92-yard touchdown run highlighted a 17-point third quarter that carried Emory & Henry to a 23-16 victory over Washington & Jefferson in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III South Regional playoff final today.

title: SIGHS OF ANOTHER CONNECTICUT WINTER
description: CHANGE is not merely in the air, it is here. Just look at what happened Oct. 4. Talk about a harbinger of worse things yet to come! I get depressed enough between November and April. I don't need a freak snowstorm in the first week of October to remind me that winter is on its way.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
THE CALL OF BROADWAY
description: LEAD: USE the imagination: a suburban living room, filled with sofa and chairs and coffee table covered with little ornaments, becomes a Broadway theater. The piano in the center of the room is a full orchestra. The handful of singers multiplies to a full cast, singing, dancing, emoting so they'll tear your heart right out.

title: Chad Reports Troops Fought Libyan Soldiers From Sudan
description: Chad said today that Government troops had clashed with Libyan forces that entered Chadian territory from Sudan, the second time in less than a week Chad has reported fighting with Libya in violation of a cease-fire accord.

title: 'Tamara' From the Ground Floor Up
description: ''I'M DEVELOPING A NEW THEORY of 'Tamara,' '' says the 31-year-old Canadian playwright John Krizanc.

title: CORRECTION
description: An art review last week about an exhibition at the Firehouse Gallery of Nassau Community College carried an incorrect identificaton for an artist, supplied by the gallery. She is Shoshana Ron.

title: Congressmen Urge 'Marshall Plan' for Manila
description: A bipartisan group of legislators, fearful of the consequences of mounting economic problems on the fragile democracy of the Philippines, called on President Reagan today to put together the equivalent of a Marshall Plan to channel $1 billion more a year to that country over the next five years.

title: Comparing Feminisms
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW-TO
description: Touche Ross Video Tax Guide 1988 MasterVision. 75 minutes. $29.95. Similar to the one made by Touche Ross and MasterVision last year, this video guides individuals through a number of the intricate elements of present-day tax planning. The forward look this time is toward 1988, when additional changes stemming from the 1986 tax reform act become effective and new rules affecting taxpayers and their tax returns come into play.

title: Adams Storms Into Title Game
description: Arthur Dennis was as surprised as anyone. He had just scored six of the eight touchdowns John Adams made in beating Midwood, 55-21, yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League semifinal game in Ozone Park.

title: A SCHOOL DAY AT THE OPERA
description: Connecticut has found itself with about 7,000 new opera aficionados in recent weeks, and they are all between the ages of 5 and 12.

title: INVESTOR PROFILES: Yields Improve the Quality of Life; Saving for Kids And College
description: IF Steven and Susan Moel's investment strategies work according to plan, their children, 5-year-old Andrew and 2-year-old Erin, will have a substantial financial cushion for college and beyond.

title: Two Artists Tempered in the Crucible of War
description: OTTO DIX AND HANNELORE Baron would not exactly seem to have a great deal in common.

title: GENERATIONS
description: King Lear. Pygmalion. The Old Testament. Greek tragedies. If you substitute the nouns and verbs, you could write the family business owner's story. . . . His problems are the problems of humanity, and the business funds and fuels them. It's a family passion play, with the business founder center stage, usually alone. - Leon Danco, a consultant to family businesses

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article about Iceland in today's Travel section incorrectly gives the times of sunrise and sunset on the winter solstice, Dec. 21. The sun rises at 11:23 A.M. and sets at 3:34 P.M., resulting in about 20 hours of darkness.

title: Hitting the Skids (and House)
description: Cars skidding out of control on an iced parking lot struck Kathleen Dauphin's automobile and her home twice on Thanksgiving night, but her sense of humor survived serious injury.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: LANDIS VALLEY CHRISTMAS

title: Dinkins Says Report Ignores Effect of Racism on New York
description: In a written rebuttal to the report of Mayor Koch's Commission on the Year 2000, the Manhattan Borough President, David N. Dinkins, said the commission had failed to recognize racism as a factor in the city's persistent problems of poverty, crime and homelessness.

title: ETHICS QUESTION VEXES REP. LENT
description: REPRESENTATIVE Norman F. Lent of East Rockaway, the ranking Republican on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, is known in Washington as a man who can work with the opposition and shepherd complex commercial legislation through his panel.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I have been advised that when I close my summer home for the winter, I should leave the heat on at a low setting of about 40 degrees to protect the wood paneling, built-ins and furniture. Do you think heating is necessary when the house is unoccupied?

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GOOD-BYE AND KEEP COLD By Jenny Davis. 210 pp. New York: Orchard Books/Franklin Watts. $12.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: 4 MUFFLERS LATER, A LOVE STILL STRONG
description: LIKE your first kiss, I guess you never forget your first new car. It inspires memories of pleasure and pride, shiny metal and lusty acceleration that linger.

title: Nevada Allows Ousted U.S. Judge to Practice Law
description: The State Supreme Court has decided that Harry E. Claiborne, removed as a Federal district judge by the Senate through impeachment last year because of his conviction for income tax evasion, may practice law in Nevada.

title: Pollsters Try To Tap Mind Of the Chinese
description: Wu Xin thinks the Government ought to know how people feel, and he is not alone.

title: A Disaster That Didn't Wait
description: LEAD: A KILLING WIND Inside Union Carbide and the Bhopal Catastrophe. By Dan Kurzman. Illustrated. 297 pp. New York: McGraw-Hill Book Company. $19.95. THE BHOPAL SYNDROME Pesticides, Environment and Health. By David Weir. 210 pp. San Francisco: Sierra Club Books. $17.95.

title: From Generation to Degeneration
description: CIGARETTES By Harry Mathews. 292 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $17.95.

title: Simple Fruit Pies From Tuscany
description: THE dough that is the basis of the Tuscan crostata, a shallow one-crust pie usually topped with fruit or homemade fruit jam, is to an Italian what pate a foncer fine is to a French pastry chef, a classic sweetened crust for a tart. Any Italian knows know to make pasta, mixing eggs into a mound of flour, but only the most able cooks can create the flaky, butter-laden base that is the truth of a celestial crostata.

title: Argentina's Government Is Shaken by Setbacks
description: The Argentine Government has been thrust into crisis and confusion by the loss that President Raul Alfonsin's Radical Civic Union suffered in September by-elections, according to critics and supporters of the Government.

title: ELISE UDOLF AND MICHAEL LEOPOLD, LAWYERS, WED
description: Elise Michelle Udolf, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Udolf of West Hartford, Conn., was married there last evening to Michael Douglas Leopold, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer Leopold of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Harold Silver officiated at Temple Beth Israel.

title:
ART;
PRENDERGAST SKETCHES AT LEHMAN GALLERY
description: LEAD: AN artist's sketchbook is almost never a throwaway thing, but few are as rich as the rather large one kept by Maurice Prendergast from 1895 to 1897 and referred to as ''The Large Boston Public Gardens Sketchbook.'' It is on loan through Dec. 12 to the Lehman College Art Gallery from the Lehman collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: JERALEA F. HESSE WEDS A PROFESSOR
description: The marriage of Jeralea Fooshee Hesse, the director of social services at the Silver Hill Foundation in New Canaan, Conn., to Dr. Robert John Levine, a professor of medicine at the Yale University School of Medicine, took place yesterday at the couple's home in Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. William B. Bryant of the Greens Farms Congregational Church in Westport, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: BRIDGET E. FARRELL TO WED F. DAVID CAMPBELL IN MAY
description: Bridget Elizabeth Farrell, an associate at the New York law firm of Bower & Gardner, and F. David Campbell, a senior vice president of Key Bank of Central New York in Syracuse, plan to be married in May.

title: Borg's First Return
description: POOR Bjorn Borg. When the former tennis champion moved back to Sweden a couple of years ago after a decade of tax-happy exile in Monte Carlo, he apparently had to leave most of his money behind. That, at least, is one conclusion suggested by some figures from the first income tax return Borg has filed in 11 years.

title: Cutter Sunk to Create Artificial Reef Off Keys
description: The first of two aging Coast Guard cutters was scuttled Friday night to create an artificial reef for marine life and a new attraction for divers off the Florida Keys.

title: JOHN BASSETT WED TO LILLIAN FRIEND
description: Lillian McClure Friend, a daughter of Charles Wood Friend of London and Mrs. Michael Turnure of Salisbury, Conn., was married in San Francisco yesterday to John Washington Bassett, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John Washington Bassett of Portland, Ore. The Rev. Thomas Cummins performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Cathedral.

title: From Russia With Scorn
description: THE CENTRAL FIGURE OF ''Repentance'' is Varlam the dictator - the mayor of a Georgian city who looks vaguely like Mussolini but also has some of Hitler's madness and Stalin's cunning and something, too, of the Georgians' own Lavrenti P. Beria, Stalin's murderous secret police chief with his glittering pince-nez. Varlam's rise to power is relentless. As his grip on his people tightens, fear and corruption are made palpable.

title: Children Were Only Allowed to Whisper
description: THE THIRTIETH YEAR By Ingeborg Bachmann. Translated by Michael Bullock. 181 pp. New York: Holmes & Meier. $19.95.

title: One Was Found
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA BANK: November 29, 1987

BUSINESS FORUM: CONTAINING RETIREE HEALTH CARE EXPENSES;
Company Liabilities Are Soaring
description: LEAD: ''AT American Airlines, we are spending $16 million annually on medical benefits for retired employees,'' Robert L. Crandall, the chief executive, said recently. ''We expect these costs to reach over $100 million in less than 10 years.''

title: Man Charged With Impersonating a Nurse
description: A man that authorities said had been impersonating a nurse at a Harlem hospital for three months has been arrested, setting off a review by the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation of the credentials of about 3,500 nurses registered with a referral agency, officials said yesterday.

title: Less Strain, More Gain
description: WITHIN THE EVER-WIDEN-ing stylistic spectrum of modern dance, the art of Erick Hawkins remains steadfast. Although his dances are charged with variety, their underlying esthetic and physical premise never alters. For Mr. Hawkins, whose company begins a six-day engagement at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, to dance is to move naturally, without strain, without tension and without artifice.

title: STARTING OVER: TV'S GRANT TINKER
description: ''Starting Over: TV's Grant Tinker'' (by Diane K. Shah, Oct. 25) - give me a break. When you have Mr. Tinker's money and connections, you do not start over; you move on. KAY KAUFMAN Forest Hills, Queens

title: OVERLOOK IS TREATING AFGHAN REBEL, 20
description: ''BY THE grace of God, I am here in this country,'' the young man said. ''By His grace, I am still alive. And by the same grace of God, I will return to carry on the fight.''

title: A LA CARTE
description: The hunting season makes serious eaters start thinking of game. In spite of easy, year-round availability, game is rarely found in home kitchens on Long Island. As a result, people who enjoy game dishes, eat them at restaurants.

title: Lynda Eisenstat Is Married
description: At the Beth Israel Congregation in Vineland, N.J., Lynda Luby Eisenstat, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Eisenstat of Vineland, was married last evening to Mitchell Alan Dorf, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon Dorf of Fox Point, Wis. Rabbi Murray Kohn and Cantor Miriam Frishman officiated. The bride is a sales representative in Atlanta for Vie de France, a bakery chain based in McLean, Va. Her husband is the studio manager for New Age Sight and Sound, an Atlanta recording studio.

title: Federal Judge, Facing Impeachment, Ties Woes to Racism and Vows Fight
description: A thousand miles south of Washington, where a Congressional subcommittee is slowly putting together pieces of a puzzle that will decide his fate, Federal District Judge Alcee Lamar Hastings is a troubled and angry man.

title: Photography
description: Mitch Epstein and Len Jenshel are leading members of a generation of photographers who are not afraid of the sensual, picturesque qualities of color film. Because their pictures are lush and luminous, they are often paired in their audience's mind. But as their shows on opposite sides of Spring Street this month suggest, their styles and their sensibilities are quite distinct.

title: AUDIO VISIONARY: Ray M. Dolby; The Quest to Build a Better Noise Trap
description: AS befits the inventor of the most successful noise-reduction system in the recording business, Ray M. Dolby speaks with a soft voice.

title: ATLANTA INMATES AND AGENTS SHARE TENSIONS
description: Cuban inmates late Saturday delivered a list of demands to officials at the Federal penitentiary here and said that they would release the 94 hostages they are holding if all demands are met.

title: Foreign Coins Push 'Change for Good'
description: YOU'VE just come home from a vacation abroad, and your pockets jingle with pfennigs, francs or other foreign coins. While they accept bills, most banks will not exchange coins for you - the amounts are small and the sorting can be tedious.

title: COURT BATTLE CONTINUES OVER VALUE OF PET DOG
description: NOW 16 years old, Tucker is quite deaf, nearly blind and walks very slowly. But his owner, Elissa Zager, said recently that the family pet ''still has a sparkle in his eyes.''

title: KATHERINE HOWARD ENGAGED TO MARRY WILLIAM BINGHAM BOLTON IN THE SPRING
description: The engagement of Katherine Howard to William Bingham Bolton, a son of Mrs. Edward L. Meister of Waite Hill, Ohio, and the late Representative Oliver Payne Bolton of Ohio, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert G. Howard of Marblehead, Mass. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: An Ambitious Plan to Revitalize Meriden
description: LAST month, Mayor Joseph J. Marinan Jr. of Meriden announced a $48 million plan to bring 19 downtown acres out of the doldrums. ''Those five square blocks are an untapped resource,'' Mayor Marinan said. ''They produce only $130,000 in property taxes - the same as two residential streets.''

title: The Mideast's New No. 1 Problem
description: LEAD: Why has the Arab-Israeli conflict disappeared? The conflict is no longer the No. 1 problem in the Middle East. That is the message from Amman, Jordan, where kings, presidents and emirs from all over the Arab world met earlier this month.

title: OUT OF THE CELLAR
description: YOU'RE SITTING IN the office doing the books when the phone rings. A guy you know says, ''How'd you like to get your hands on some terrific old stuff, maybe 10,000 bottles in all?'' This happened to Peter Morrell and his sister, Roberta, about a year ago. Both of them are involved in Morrell & Company, the wine and spirits retailer at 535 Madison Avenue. The caller was Alan Stillman, the owner of Smith & Wollensky, a well-known steak house in Manhattan. Mr. Stillman, who also owns the Post House and the Manhattan Ocean Club, was eager to enhance Smith & Wollensky's reputation as a place for good wines. He had gotten word that the wine stock from Oscar's Delmonico's restaurant, a Wall Street standby that closed in 1977, was being auctioned off. The owner of Oscar's, Mario Tucci, had shipped all the wines to his home in Greenwich, Conn., where they remained un-til he decided to sell them about two years ago.

title: NEW ACADEMIC LEVELS SOUGHT
description: IF the thought of job security was ever far from the mind of Jimmy Johnson, the University of Miami head football coach, it was brought back with a shiver last week with the news out of Columbus, Ohio.

title: ST. JOHN'S SMOTHERS HARVARD IN OPENER
description: Jayson Williams, a sophomore reserve forward, scored all of his game-high 22 points in the second half yesterday to lead St. John's to an easy 105-60 victory over Harvard in the opening round of the 13th annual Joe Lapchick Tournament at Alumni Hall. In the championship game today, the Redmen will face Loyola Marymount, which defeated Tennessee Tech, 114-78.

title: POSTINGS: For Preservation; Window Workshop
description: To many people, windows are commonplace artifacts of urban life that require attention only when they get too dirty to see through. But to those sensitive to architectural values, windows are prime design features that must be maintained with care and replaced with even greater care only when the originals no longer serve.

title: Using Plastic to Rev Up Revenues
description: SOME consumers have recently received solicitations for ''affinity cards'' - bank credit cards offered in conjunction with a nonprofit charity or association. The sponsoring bank promises to help the organization every time the customer charges a purchase with the card.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: NEW JERSEY will not face sanctions for failing to meet Federal ambient air standards for ozone but will have to speed efforts to reduce levels of the smog-causing gas anyway.

title: DOCUMENTARY
description: The Gospel According to Al Green Produced and directed by Robert Mugge. 1984. Magnum Entertainment 94 minutes. $29.95. From the opening ballad (''I Love You With All My Heart'') to the rafter-raising sermon and gospel hymn (''The Lord Will Make a Way Somehow''), Al Green carries this marvelous film along with his voice and his smile. He performs as intensely in the interviews as on stage, speaking with passion and precision, slipping into falsetto and sighing laughter. There isn't a dull number or dull character to be seen or heard. Robert Mugge, the producer-director-writer-editor, tidily analyzes Mr. Green's transition from soul star to evangelist and presents without editorial comment some of the stranger aspects of his story - the born-again conversion in a Disneyland hotel, a girlfriend who threw hot grits on him and then shot herself. Mr. Green emerges as genuinely forthcoming and weirdly objective about himself. Willful and gracious, he seems mysteriously empty: a vessel for the ecstatic power of black gospel.

title: Deaf Writer Asks Questions That Echo for Young
description: The class of elementary and junior high school students at the Pennsylvania School for the Deaf kept up a volley of questions for the novelist who had come to call. Courteously and with humor, the novelist, Douglas Bullard, tried to answer them all.

title: Nancy Shrair Is Wed
description: At Temple Beth El in Springfield, Mass., Nancy Shrair, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Shrair of Longmeadow, Mass., and Michael Schreiber, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Schreiber of Brooklyn, were married last evening by Rabbi Herbert Schwartz. The bride, an associate editor at the Book-of-the-Month Club in New York, graduated from the Boston University College of Communications. The bridegroom graduated from the Boston University School of Management and is the vice president of Royal Farms Inc., owner of supermarkets, in Brooklyn.

title: New M.I.T. Police Chief Is Ready for Stern Tests
description: When Anne P. Glavin began patrol work for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Campus Police in 1975, her supervisor would insist that she be picked up by a squad car every night after her beat on a remote area of campus that then was considered dangerous for women, but not men.

title: OLD MASTERS, NEW TYCOONS
description: IT USED TO BE A FAIRLY QUIET BUSINESS,'' SAYS a veteran London purveyor of Old Master paintings, describing the field he has tilled for more than 30 years. ''That is,'' he adds with a sportsmanlike smile, ''until Mr. Feigen came along.'' He is referring to Richard L. Feigen, a hyperactive, high-profile New York dealer, who spends a good deal of time in the staid art precincts of St. James's, the nerve center of the Old Master trade. An art dealer with an M.B.A. from Harvard, the fast-stepping Feigen - his elegant tailoring enhanced by his never-fading suntan -has brought the style and pressure of Wall Street to a trade still steeped in the notion of aristocratic gentility.

title: Mystery Envelops Case Of Judge Found Hanged
description: Until last week, Richard L. Nahley was a pillar of this city's legal and political structure - a popular 51-year-old lawyer with a seemingly successful practice, a former corporation counsel and the city's Probate Court judge. He was active in raising money for charities and was an avid golfer and churchgoer.

title:
DINING OUT;
EARNEST ENDEAVOR IN TARRYTOWN
description: LEAD: BEYOND The Gallery's homely exterior, amateurish management and uneven service lies a serious restaurant. Taking care of the business end of the establishment these days is Pat Trama, a chef concerned as much with artistic presentation as he is careful food preparation, and many of the dishes that issue from this kitchen are high achievements indeed.

title: MS. BUSSIERE MARRIED TO SUNG-IL CHOI ON L.I.
description: Elizabeth Bussiere, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Bussiere of East Setauket, L.I., was married yesterday to Sung-il Choi, the son of Shin-jae Kim of Reston, Va., and In-kyu Choi. The Rev. Stephen Eddington performed the ceremony at the Unitarian-Universalist Fellowship Hall in Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Strikeouts and Hits Allowed Show Correlation
description: GIVE a manager his choice and he'll pick a pitcher who can strike out batters over one who uses other means to secure outs. Results of pitchers' performances this past season support that choice.

title: Power at the Work Site
description: THE FALL OF THE HOUSE OF LABOR The Workplace, the State, and American Labor Activism, 1865-1925. By David Montgomery. 494 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $27.95.

title: ROBIN RUSKIN TO MARRY BRIAN LINDER IN MARCH
description: Mr. and Mrs. M. Ronald Ruskin of New York and Menands, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Hope Ruskin, to Brian David Linder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Linder of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. A March wedding is planned. Ms. Ruskin, the consumer marketing director of American Baby, a monthly publication and a division of Cahners Publishing Company in Manhattan, graduated from the University of Colorado. Her father is president of Cohoes (N.Y.) Specialty Stores Ltd. Her mother is president of Myrna Ruskin Associates Inc., a stress management counseling concern in New York.

title: MORE AND MORE, AMERICANS ARE CHOOSING TO SAVE LESS
description: WHEN Eben Price became a father, he and his wife did what his parents had done for him 17 years earlier: They opened a savings account. ''After three and a half years of a marriage in which we'd never managed to maintain a savings account,'' said Mr. Price, a 32-year-old Dallas lawyer, ''we knew we'd never develop that kind of financial discipline any other way.''

title: Gospel: McIntosh Shouters
description: THE McIntosh County Shouters, who gave their first New York concerts Friday and Saturday at Washington Square Church under the auspices of the World Music Institute, perform ring shouts, an archaic black music tradition that was long thought to be extinct. The ring shout, which was first described by visitors to plantations in the deep South as early as the 1840's, seems to have survived longest in isolated island communities off Georgia and South Carolina.

title: N.F.L. Notebook; PROPOSAL IS BREWING TO KEEP CARDINALS IN ST. LOIUS
description: A BEER company may ultimately have more clout than three major cities that are attempting to induce the football Cardinals to leave St. Louis.

title: THE GIFT OF GARB
description: Weekly, I look forward to the humor in your magazine, and ''The Gift of Garb'' (Works in Progress, Nov. 1) gave me an extra, albeit choked, laugh. Costume designer Patricia Zipprodt reports her ''hideously materialistic'' costume plans for ''The Sleeping Beauty'' are patterned after the 17th-century French, and reflect the ''ornate tastelessness of these people.''

title: WILLIAM WEGMAN: THE ARTIST AND HIS DOG
description: IN WILLIAM WEGMAN'S STUDIO in New York's Hudson Valley, the blond floors appear to be stenciled in an abstract floral pattern. In fact, after prolonged efforts to keep his dog out of the way of workmen during construction, Wegman took a different tack: he painted his dog's feet green and let her loose inside. It is an example of what Wegman means when he says of his work in painting, drawing, video and photography, ''I pay a lot of attention to what the format is actually doing rather than what I want it to do.''

title: Question Of the Week; Who Should Win the Heisman Trophy?
description: One great athlete stands alone:Craig Heyward of the University of Pittsburgh. ALEXANDER N. COLONNA Amagansett, L.I.

title: 10 Policemen Die in Beirut
description: Ten policemen were killed and 19 were wounded today when two tank rounds from militia fighting hit their barracks, the police said. The police said the rounds slammed into the Warwar Police Academy barracks, 10 yards from the line that separates the predominately Christian and Moslem sections of Beirut. The police said the victims were Moslems and Christians alike. There was no immediate explanation for the fighting.

title: MOUNTIES SEEK HELP WITH COSTS
description: A few years ago, thanks to a fund-raising campaign, that included bumper stickers reading ''Hot to Trot,'' the Hartford Mounted Police was established. A 10-horse stable was built, the horses were donated, and, before long, a police officer astride a horse became a familiar sight in city parks.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 24 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Exeter, N.H.; Condos Replace Riverfront Mill
description: FOR more than a century, this city's mill complex, perched downtown on the Squamscott River, churned out millions of yards of cotton fabric and formed the backbone of the local economy.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
OF NEW MEDALS AND MONTHLY SALES
description: LEAD: A MEDAL from the Vatican commemorates the international ''prayer for peace'' meeting, which took place last year at Assisi, Italy. Leaders of religious denominations lifted their hands in prayer on Oct. 27, 1986 to dramatize a universal desire for peace. The meeting is symbolized on the medal by a portrait of St.

title: LIVING AND WRITING THE PEASANT LIFE
description: NO one goes to the Vallee du Giffre. In the Michelin Guide to the French Alps, it is mentioned only in passing, a place to get around or quickly through. There are no curiosities in its tiny villages, and its mountains - its jagged, hulking mountains - offer few gentle slopes for le ski moderne. It is one of those parts of the region known as the Haute-Savoie that time has left to the Savoyard peasants; and that, I was told more than once in Paris, where I was to get my train to the Alps, was reason enough to stay away. The Savoyards are closed, backward, I should understand: they keep cows and keep to themselves.

title: THE CONTRADICTIONS OF BOB DOLE
description: Between George Bush (''I've already been everything, so you might as well make me President'') and Pat Robertson, I was beginning to take a shine to Robert Dole, as perhaps the least dangerous and most pragmatic Presidential candidate. (''The Contradictions of Bob Dole,'' by Martin Tolchin and Jeff Gerth, Nov. 8).

title: Chairs With Some Backbone in Them
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON furnished the porch of his Mount Vernon home with 27 bow-back Windsor chairs. Thomas Jefferson is said to have sat swiveling in a Windsor as he drafted the Declaration of Independence. And Charles Eames told a reporter in the 1970's how much he admired this furniture: ''I have always hoped my chairs would be regarded as the Windsors of the 20th century,'' he said.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO PREPARE FOR FREEZING WEATHER
description: LEAD: With the advent of freezing weather imminent, it's time to provide a rundown of last-minute gardening chores.

title:
ART;
THE COMMONPLACE MADE UNCOMMON
description: LEAD: IN the three-person exhibition on view in the art gallery at the Ammerman Campus of Suffolk County Community College in Selden, the commonplace is elevated to extraordinary dimensions. The scale of the works by two printmakers, Robin Gibson and Carol Wax, and Bill Burke, a ceramic sculptor, is modest, but the impression is of an expanded consciousness that causes them to loom large in the imagination.

title: West Bank Choice
description: In a region of extremity and violence, Mubarak Awad is a curious political being. He is an Arab, born in Jerusalem, who tells his fellow Palestinians that nonviolent methods offer the best hope of ending Israel's 20-year occupation of the West Bank.

title: Recent Sales
description: Lakewood $84,000 1360 Lanes Mill Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; 2-car garage. W/W carpets, 2-car garage; taxes, $1,179. Livingston $205,000 37 Grand Terrace 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 47-year-old Tudor; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, full basement, den; taxes $2,543. Maplewood $152,000 30 Manley Terrace 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 52-year-old colonial; finished basement, W/W carpets, 2-car garage; taxes, $3,080. Metuchen $144,500 72 East Walnut Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 45-year-old colonial; deck, front porch; taxes, $1,856. Park Ridge $234,000 7 Sulak Lane 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old contemporary; family room, patio, 2-car garage, all appliances; taxes $2,743. Rockaway $205,000 12 Calumet Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 29-year-old ranch; fireplace, deck, family room; taxes, $2,937. OTHER AREAS Ridgefield, Conn. $450,000 93 Hunter Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; new kitchen cabinets, superior insulation, 2 acres; taxes, $3,658. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $355,000 101 Burns Place 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 15-year-old frame raised ranch; eat-in kitchen, family room, deck, walk to stores; taxes $7,180. Hauppauge, L.I. $182,000 58 Heller Place 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old ranch; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,700.

title: MARCIA NEUHAUS WED TO DAVID SPECK
description: Marcia Eve Neuhaus and David G. Speck were married last evening at the bridegroom's home in Alexandria, Va., by Rabbi Sheldon Ezring.

title: 'Brain Gain' From Europe Is Hurting Young American Professors
description: To the Editor:

title: Lelia Pardee Has Wedding
description: Lelia Erdice Pardee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Trevor Pardee of New York and Rio Dulce, Guatemala, was married yesterday to John Frederick Haller, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Boyd Haller of Carmel Valley, Calif. The Rev. Robert Jensen of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints performed a nondenominational ceremony at the home of David Bates, a cousin of the bride, and Mrs. Bates in Carmel, Calif.

title: ADOPTION MEETING LOOKS AT CONCERN
description: LEAD: THE specter of Elizabeth Steinberg hung heavily over the seventh annual conference of the Adoptive Parents' Committee.

title: FIRST AID FIRST AID
description: FACING a gloomy fiscal picture, the Monmouth County community of Roosevelt held an Arts and Crafts Fair last Sunday to raise money for its First Aid Squad.

title: Howard Ruling Pleases N.C.A.A.
description: Dick Schultz, the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said today that he felt relief when a Federal judge in Washington denied a request by Howard University to delay the start of the Division I-AA playoffs.

title: POSTINGS: $2.5 Million Infusion; A Major Renovation for Mahopac Mall
description: It seems that the Mahopac Outlet Mall in Putnam County was jinxed from the start. Since it opened on Route 6 and Miller Road in 1973, three anchor stores in succession closed after the bankrupt chains of which they were a part went out of business. Those failures crippled smaller retailers there.

title: Social Policies
description: To the Editor:

title: The Professionals' Edge
description: IN the heat of a bull or a bear market, when investors are experiencing the pleasure of profit or the pain of loss, it is hard to keep emotions out of decisions.

title: DESPITE SPOTTY PLAY, KORCHNOI WINS PRAISE
description: ''KORCHNOI is the only grandmaster in the world from whom I can still learn a lot, especially about the middle game,'' said the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman after the Interpolis International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands.

title: WITH TIME, A MOTHER GROWS ACCEPTING
description: THE phone call to my mother would not, I was sure, be the easiest I'd ever made. She was then in her early 80's, but enjoyed making people think of her as quite a bit younger.

title: STARTING OVER: TV'S GRANT TINKER
description: Today's television sitcoms are a far cry from what one used to think of as ''recreation,'' defined by Webster as ''refeshment of strength and spirits after work.''

title: Hanging On in the 'Muni' Market
description: EARLY in the morning in an outrageously messy office at the New York headquarters of the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, the talk was about airplanes and money. To expand, the Memphis International Airport had to raise about $100 million. The five men sprawled in the sloppy office sipping from Styrofoam coffee cups were municipal bond specialists. They wanted the assignment.

title: Sweet Judy Blue Eyes
description: TRUST YOUR HEART By Judy Collins. Illustrated. 275 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title: GORBACHEV SEES VISIT AS A CHANCE TO DO BUSINESS
description: DURING his short visit to Washington next week, Mikhail S. Gorbachev plans to spend two hours with 60 American business leaders - a sign of the importance the Soviet leader attaches to an improved economic relationship with the United States.

title: RESIDENTIAL RESALES
description: Closings in the week ended Nov. 14 MANHATTAN Gramercy Park Area $136,000 201 East 25th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 650-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, parquet floors; maintenance $469, 40% tax-deductible (Broker:

title: Sports of The Times; PARCELLS, WALTON IN DOUBT
description: IN the autumn of their discontent, Bill Parcells doesn't want to talk about next year's Giants team and Joe Walton doesn't want to talk to this year's Jets team. Perhaps without realizing it, each has put a question mark on his future.

title: >PAMELA KOVAR TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold S. Kovar of Clifton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Ann Kovar, to Dr. Baruch Toledano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Toledano of Brooklyn. Miss Kovar is a physical therapist and a doctoral student at Teachers College of Columbia University. Her fiance is a resident in orthopedic surgery at the New York University Medical Center. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: KEY ROLE FOR THE STATE IN TRADE ZONES KEY ROLE FOR THE STATE IN TRADE ZONES
description: LEAD: WHEN Cargill Citro-America Inc., a Minneapolis-based fruit-juice company, imports 800,000 gallons of frozen orange juice concentrate from its groves in Sao Paulo, Brazil, it saves up to $35,000 in customs duties by receiving the shipment at a Foreign Trade Zone in Port Newark and adjoining Port Elizabeth, holding it there until it is blended with juice from Florida.

title: Teen-Ager Is Killed by Police In Shootout in Portland, Ore.
description: A 14-year-old boy was killed by the police in a shootout Friday after he chased his mother from his home, the police said.

title: BOOS, CHEERS AND YAWNS FOR NEW STATION
description: THE new Stamford Transportation Center made little impression on Eli Halpern last Monday. The Stamford resident, who regularly commutes to New York City on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, was unaware that the long-awaited and oft-troubled train station had finally started service.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: BAD EGG The True Story of Humpty Dumpty. By Sarah Hayes. Illustrated by Charlotte Voake. Unpaged. Boston: Joy Street Books/ Little, Brown & Company. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 5) THE COMPLETE STORY OF THE THREE BLIND MICE By John W. Ivimey. Illustrated by Paul Galdone. Clarion Books/Ticknor & Fields.

title: MARY GANNON MORAN IS WED TO MADISON L. FORD
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, Mary Gannon Moran, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Thomas Moran of Holland, Mich., was married yesterday to Madison Lewis Ford, a son of Mary Hope Lewis and F. Richards Ford 3d, both of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Heidi Hudnut-Beumler officiated.

title: Photo of Israeli soldiers at funeral for one of six soldiers killed by a Palestinian guerrilla (AP)THE WORLD; ISRAEL PAYS THE PRICE OF TAKING A BREAK
description: THE Palestinian guerrilla crossed the electrified Lebanon-Israel border fence on a moonless night last week, dangling from a motorized hang glider, passing the shimmering lights of the town of Qiryat Shemona, landing in a thorny field next to the Gibor Israeli army base. Within minutes, the guerrilla killed six Israeli soldiers and wounded seven more before dying in hail of machine-gun fire.

title: THE MAKE-OVER AT ESTEE LAUDER
description: LEONARD A. LAUDER, president and chief executive officer of the Estee Lauder cosmetics empire, is barreling through a Bullock's department store in Southern California, an entourage of a dozen trying to keep pace. It is the sixth store he has visited today to critique the way his products are displayed. Before he dons black tie for dinner tonight, he will see at least four more.

title: VICTORIAN HOUSE IS A PRODUCT OF CHANGE
description: Maria Stieglitz suggests painting our old houses in bright San Francisco colors [ ''Why Victorian Drab? Try Tangerine Gables!'' Opinion Page, Nov. 1 ] . It might be a good idea.

title: An End to El Rukn Chic?
description: In Arabic, El Rukn means ''the foundation.'' On Chicago's South Side, it means trouble. Thanks to a tough Federal prosecutor and a two-and-a-half-year investigation, El Rukn may have foundered.

title: On Doctorow
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE MAN'S KIDS
description: I felt the warm rush of support from a kindred spirit as I read Daniel Meier's essay ''One Man's Kids'' (About Men, Nov. 1), about his life as a first-grade teacher. A newly minted clinical psychologist, I recently chose among several job offers, settling on a child-care agency run largely by women. At the interview, I found myself comfortably expounding on the rewards, the fun, of working with kids. This was in contrast to other facilities, at which I found myself giving what Mr. Meier called ''male'' responses.

title: The Times's Neediest Cases Fund Opens 76th Annual Appeal
description: Against a backdrop of heightened urgency, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opens its 76th annual appeal today on behalf of the hungry, the homeless and the underprivileged in the New York metropolitan region.

title: SCOTT I. ROSEN IS WED TO DEBRA LYNN STEIN
description: The marriage of Debra Lynn Stein, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Stein of Allentown, Pa., and Scott Ira Rosen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Rosen of Wayne, N.J., took place last evening at Loews Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Moishe Cohen officiated.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: After his first five years in the major leagues, how does Darryl Strawberry compare with Mickey Mantle and Willie Mays regarding home runs and runs batted in?

title: U.S. SUSPENDS AID
description: The United States announced tonight that it had suspended virtually all military assistance and some economic aid to Haiti after violence there caused the cancellation of elections.

title: Esposito Timetable Moving Too Slowly
description: PHIL ESPOSITO, a man who admits he is in a hurry but contends he does not feel rushed, has found himself under the burden of a skewed timetable ever since he assumed control of the Rangers last year in midsummer.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Last Call

title: Light Slate of New Issues This Week
description: This week's calendar of new debt issues is relatively light and headed by today's regular weekly Treasury auctions of new three- and six-month bills. While the slate of new corporate and tax-exempt issues appears light, underwriters said that if market conditions improve and interest rates decline, issuers might bring existing shelf-registered issues to market.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aaron Rents Inc., Atlanta, a renter and seller of furniture, named M. Lee Hulsebus president and chief operating officer, succeeding R. Charles Loudermilk Sr., who has been elected a director and continues as chairman and chief executive.

title: 49ers Defeat Browns, 38-24
description: Joe Montana threw four touchdown passes, three to Jerry Rice and one to Dwight Clark, as the San Francisco 49ers cruised to a 38-24 victory over the Cleveland Browns tonight.

title: If He's in the Swing of It, Rope-Jumper Can Have Serious Sort of Workout
description: THE rope slaps the pavement rhythmically and sets the cadence as the little girls chant: Cinderella Dressed in yella Went upstairs To kiss a fella

title: Seoul Candidate Faces Violence at Kwangju Rally
description: In the worst outbreak of violence yet in this country's presidential campaign, the ruling party candidate, Roh Tae Woo, dodged rocks, sticks and tear gas canisters today as he faced crowds aflame with bitter memories of the harsh Government suppression of a 1980 uprising here.

title: Grocery Store Owner Killed
description: A man was killed yesterday morning in an apparent robbery attempt at his grocery store in the Bronx, the police said. The man, who was identified as Hector Borrayo, 38 years old, of 5360 Broadway in Manhattan, was shot once in the head around 8:30 A.M. at the Metro-One-Superette at 2070 Clinton Avenue in the Tremont section of the Bronx, said Sgt. Maurice Howard, a police spokesman. Two male suspects are being sought in the shooting, Sergeant Howard said.

title: Air Force's Titan Is a Success In Lofting a Military Satellite
description: An Air Force Titan 34D, the nation's most powerful unmanned rocket, roared into space Saturday night with a secret military satellite that a civilian expert said would provide instant warning of an enemy missile attack on the United States.

title: Bowl List Has Its Share of Inconsistency
description: Texas and Tulane are included and Colorado and Wake Forest are excluded. With the last options for college football's bowl games closed over the weekend, the 18-match lineup has the usual mix of deserving and undeserving teams.

title: Pressure on Bonds Expected
description: The bond market is expected to come under renewed downward pressure this week, largely because of the weakening dollar and soaring prices of basic commodities and precious metals.

title: How Much Authority for Indian Tribes?
description: Donald Hodel, the Secretary of the Interior, and Ross Swimmer, the Assistant Secretary for Indian Affairs, touch a responsive chord when they call for a new relationship between the Government and Native Americans that is based on Indian ''self-determination.'' Such a relationship is a desirable goal, but also a distant one.

title: Marla Frances Wald Weds Dr. Oren Cohen
description: At Congregation Kehilath Jeshuran in New York, Marla Frances Wald, the daughter of Eve Wald of New York and the late Dr. Philip M. Wald, was married yesterday to Dr. Oren J. Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Cohen of Washington. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated.

title: Taiwan Studies Joining GATT
description: Taiwan is considering applying to rejoin the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade 37 years after withdrawing from GATT membership, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said Friday.

title: Giants Lose Their Honor, Too
description: FOR the Giants, it was an opportunity to defend their honor as Super Bowl champions. In this strike-snarled National Football League season, the Giants were all but out of the playoffs. But if they could win, they would remind the Redskins and themselves of what might have been had there been no strike. Even the Redskins' coach, Joe Gibbs, had viewed the Giants as if their impostor teams had never played each other earlier this season.

title: Korean Plane, 115 Aboard, Crashes in Southeast Asia
description: A South Korean airliner with 115 people on board disappeared as it flew near Burma from the Middle East Sunday.

title: Trade Surplus Rises in Mexico
description: Mexico had a trade surplus in the first 10 months of this year of $6.81 billion, well more than double the $2.83 billion surplus over the corresponding period in 1986, the Planning and Budget Ministry said Friday.

title: Devils Salvage Tie
description: Jim Carson's power-play goal just 40 seconds into the third period earned the Los Angeles Kings a 2-2 tie with the Devils tonight.

title: At a Harlem Rink, Skaters Resist the Success of Wollman
description: At the northern end of Central Park, where the landscape is rocky and wild, Charles Heuer and his daughter glided freely across the Lasker Memorial Skating Rink yesterday afternoon, sharing the ice with a dozen neighborhood cognoscente.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1987
description: International A3-15

title: Detentions in Malaysia Harm Its Stability
description: To the Editor:

title: Proof of Blood Cholesterol Theory May Be Near
description: To the Editor:

title: FIVE BODIES FOUND AFTER JET CRASH
description: Search teams pulled five bodies from the Indian Ocean today in the area where a South African Airways jet crashed with 159 people aboard.

title: Spain: A Land of Problems and Progress
description: Before last month's stock market plunge, Spain's economy was zipping along in Europe's fast lane.

title: West Berlin Journal; The Proletarian T-Shirt (Making Kitsch of Lenin)
description: As if it wasn't enough that Mikhail S. Gorbachev has elbowed past Ronald Reagan in popularity polls, his glasnost is now crowding America off the T-shirts.

title: Federated Names Chief For Foley's Store Chain
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. has named John B. Utsey chairman and chief executive of one of its major department store chains, the Houston-based Foley's.

title: Gift to Neediest Cases Honors a Bar Mitzvah
description: One of the first gifts to the 76th appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which formally opened yesterday, came from Lisa Sheiman of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Becker Finds a Few Potholes Along the Yellow Brick Road
description: IT was good to be in Leimen, West Germany, Boris Becker said, where he could sample his mother's cooking and spend time with friends he rarely sees. The past three years have been like a trip to Oz, as Becker was swept off his feet in a whirlwind of events that were often beyond his control. Clicking his heels, returning home on occasion, gives him a chance to catch his breath and reflect on a relatively brief but tumultuous tennis career.

title: Release of 4 in Atlanta Viewed as Good-Faith Move
description: In what negotiators interpreted as a good-faith gesture, Cuban inmates controlling the Federal penitentiary here released four hostages early today. The action surprised Federal officials and led them to hope for a break in negotiations.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Chicago Milwaukee Corp., Chicago, said it had extended its self-tender offer and withdrawal rights for any and all of its outstanding $5 prior preferred stock at $55 a share until midnight Tuesday.

title: A Lonely Death on Halloween Haunts a Pennsylvania Town
description: While goblins and ghouls roamed this tiny borough over the Halloween weekend, 19-year-old Christopher Fabiani and three friends left a beer-drinking party, piled into a pickup truck and started to cruise the twisting back roads.

title: Lack of British Interest Seen in Eurotunnel Sale
description: Despite a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign appealing both to national pride and to private gain, British private investors have apparently shown only limited interest in the shares of Eurotunnel, the British-French consortium that plans to build a tunnel beneath the English Channel.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1987
description: The Economy

title: TV Review; 'The Secret Garden,' A New CBS Adaptation
description: AMONG the hardiest of perennials, ''The Secret Garden'' is back - tonight at 9 on Channel 2 - with its story of a bratty little orphan girl who undergoes magical transformation in a gloomy Yorkshire manor called Misselthwaite. Published in 1911, the story was written by Frances Hodgson Burnett, an amateur gardener who specialized in minor literary classics, including ''Little Lord Fauntleroy.''

title: A MighMy 'Wallflower' at NBC
description: Were it not for his red ties, Henry S. Kanegsberg could easily disappear in a crowd. Even his employer, the National Broadcasting Company, describes him as ''a wallflower.''

title: Text of Oakdale Agreement
description: Here is the text of the agreement signed today, ending the eight-day uprising at the Federal Detention Center here. The agreement was typed on the stationery of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d. Upon the release of all remaining officers being held on the compound at F.D.C. Oakdale, the following agreement will immediately be enforced.

title: Dollar Hits New Low; Stocks Drop in Tokyo
description: The dollar fell to a record low today on the Tokyo foreign exchange market. Stock prices also declined.

title: Whitehead Is Married In Ceremony in Jersey
description: Mary Beth Whitehead, the surrogate mother in the landmark Baby M custody case, has married the father of a child she expects to give birth to in the spring.

title: Author Turns 80 With Roman Timelessness
description: ''I always live in the present, and so it seems that my life is always the same and that my age is always the same.''

title: Chestnut Prepares Ads For New Diet Product
description: On Dec. 30 CCA Industries of East Rutherford, N.J. - already the national marketer of such brands as Nutra Nail, Pro Perm and Hair Off -will go onto two of the three commercial television networks to advertise Eat 'n Lose, another contribution to a diet-conscious nation.

title: Lois Perelson Wed to Stewart K. Gross
description: Lois Marion Perelson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Perelson of New York, and Stewart Koerner Gross, a son of Merle Gross-Ginsburg of New York and New Milford, Conn., and Bernard Gross of Plainfield, N.J., were married yesterday. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, assisted by Cantor Richard Botton, officiated at the Central Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: DOZENS ARE SLAIN
description: Haiti's first attempt in 30 years at a presidential election was abruptly called off by election officials today after a frenzy of attacks on voting stations, churches and radio stations in which more than two dozen people were killed.

title: Windows at A-Weapons Lab Hit by Debris in Bomb Blast
description: A bomb exploded Saturday outside a laboratory where nuclear weapons are designed, blowing out dozens of windows, and a man saying he belonged to a group called the Nuclear Liberation Front today claimed responsibility for the blast.

title: Dance: Moscow Ballet Performs in Trenton
description: The Moscow Ballet closed its two-month American debut tour tonight with a first-rate performance at the War Memorial Auditorium here.
