Founded in 1979 as a local touring ensemble by Irina Tikhomirnova, a former Bolshoi ballerina, the Soviet company is now directed by Vyacheslav Gordeyev, a leading dancer with the Bolshoi. It is a small jewel of a company, with the familial unity of focus that tends to identify small touring groups. Overall, there is a compelling seriousness to the dancing. Like Mr. Gordeyev, the dancers look as if they having a wonderful time. But, as was the case, again, with Mr. Gordeyev, there was also a refreshing hint of devotion to the classical ballet in the simplicity with which most of the performers dance.

title: Choo San Goh, a Choreographer Hailed for Inventive Dance Forms
description: Choo San Goh, the ballet choreographer and associate artistic director of the Washington Ballet, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 39 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: South Korean Jet Vanishes

title: Rebels in Mozambique Said to Kill 42 Civilians
description: Right-wing rebels have killed at least 42 civilians in an ambush on the main road north of the capital, Maputo Radio reported today.

title: Music: Chamber Group In 'Alexander's Feast'
description: THE revival of ''Alexander's Feast'' at the 92d Street Y Saturday evening afforded a welcome opportunity to hear one of Handel's freshest and most inventive works, and so was a welcome event even if the performance did not quite take wing in the way one had hoped.

title: A Rite Is Going Wrong Way
description: A few years ago, Harold Ballard, owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs, outraged many Canadians when he passed the word that a female reporter would be welcome in the team's locker room if she joined the hockey players in removing her clothes. Nobody could be sure that the 84-year-old Ballard, who has made a career of cantankerousness, was joking.

title: CUBAN INMATES IN LOUISIANA FREE ALL 26 HOSTAGES
description: Cuban inmates today released 26 hostages they had held for eight days in the Federal detention center here.

title: Informal Capitalism Grows in Cameroon
description: When Samuel Nansi needed $35,000 to open his Joie de Vivre Bar here, he did not bother with banks. Instead he turned to the tontines, an informal credit system rooted in African tradition. Without signing a paper or filling out a form, Mr. Nansi emerged from his monthly tontine meeting with $35,000 in cash.

title: Columbia Contenders
description: The last time Columbia won an Ivy League basketball championship was in the 1967-68 season. Since then, Penn and Princeton have dominated the league, while Columbia's fortunes have sagged.

title: The U.N. Today: Nov. 30, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IT'S easy enough to pick out as a gift a book you simply read, for gosh sakes! The trick is to give a book the recipient can use, can keep going back to and consulting until the pages fall out and another gift is required to replace it. The following books, arranged by cost from cheap to expensive, are useful for everything from collecting classic baseball cards to identifying James Bond movie villains to practicing Chinese calligraphy to choosing the right electrical appliance to give as a gift instead of a book.

title: Mark D. Lazarus Married To Deborah L. Kozupsky
description: Deborah L. Kozupsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Kozupsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark D. Lazarus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Lazarus of Rye Brook, N.Y. Cantor David Rosenswieg officiated at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y.

title: 2 Returning Salvador Rebels Make Quick Political Impact
description: They will not win an election anytime soon. But in their first week home from exile, El Salvador's two top civilian rebel leaders appear to have already had an impact on political thinking here that outweighs their potential showing at the polls.

title: Pop: Judy Collins at Carnegie Hall
description: FROM the moment Judy Collins stepped onto the stage of Carnegie Hall Friday evening and opened with an a cappella rendition of ''Amazing Grace,'' it was apparent that the singer's 25th anniversary concert in New York would be markedly different in tone from her annual post-Thanksgiving concerts.

title: Corporate Profitability Rising, Reversing 15-Year Downturn
description: After 15 years of decline, the profitability of American business - measured as a return on investments - is rising again, and the future health of the economy is riding on whether the turnaround can be sustained.

title: Hostage Was More Afraid of Happenings Outside
description: Throughout his eight-day ordeal as a hostage, Scott Sutterfield was more afraid of what was happening outside the Federal detention center in Oakdale, La., than he was of what was happening inside.

title: THAT WOLFISH GRIN IN 'WOODS'
description: Among the arresting sights in ''Into the Woods,'' the fairy-tale musical by Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine, is the wolf's eerie grin as he pursues Little Red Ridinghood.

title: Recycling Helps Avoid Wasteful Incineration; It's Energy-Efficient
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Player From Bombay Leads In Fall National Title Event
description: Until this year no foreign player had ever won a major American team title, but that barrier was broken four months ago at the American Contract Bridge League's summer nationals in Baltimore. And the successful player, Jaggy Shivdasani of Bombay, India, was on track to repeat the success when the final day's play began at the fall nationals here today.

title: Infant Survives on Chips When Family Dies
description: A 17-month-old girl survived for two to three weeks apparently by eating potato chips and drinking water from a toilet while her parents and infant sister lay dead nearby, the authorities say.

title: Their Crimes Vary, but Most Cubans Are Serving Sentences of Frustration
description: Many of the Cuban inmates in the Federal penitentiary here are unsophisticated rural people who have been hardened by years in prisons for infractions as minor as disagreeing with the Government of Fidel Castro while in Cuba or failing to pay traffic tickets in the United States, according to those who know them.

title: OUTDOORS: NO DEER BAGGED, JUST LEFTOVER GROCERIES
description: HAD there been snow for tracking, had the deer that walked past my son, Steve, been a buck instead of a doe, had the season on black bear not been closed, had moose been legal game, the six of us who recently journeyed to the northeastern tip of New Hampshire for two and one-half days of hunting could have come back with more than a box of leftover groceries.

title: South Shore Needs 2 Injured Players
description: As the South Shore football coach, Marty Senall, prepares his team for Saturday's Public Schools Athletic League Division A championship game against John Adams, a couple of big questions remain. How's Arthur Davis? And how's Marc Senall?

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Farm Prices... Oct. Tuesday Construction Spending... Oct. Leading Indicators... Oct. Wednesday New-Home Sales... Oct. Thursday Factory Orders... Oct. Friday Unemployment... Nov.

title: In Defense of Defaults On U.S. Student Loans
description: To the Editor:

title: Running Strong
description: Six months have passed and Sean Nelson can still hear the gunfire. The 17-year old football player was walking home from his girlfriend's house on a Friday night in May when six shots rang out. One of the bullets hit him in the back. By the time he was taken to a hospital, Nelson realized he was lucky to be alive, but he had another dread - that he would never play football again.

title: Bombing in Manila
description: A bomb went off tonight behind the Philippine International Convention Center, where leaders of Southeast Asian nations are to meet from Dec. 14 to 16, the police said. There were no reports of casualties. The police said the blast damaged a fire hydrant and broke the building's windows. Three weeks ago, the police found more than 80 sticks of dynamite inside the building.

title: For Haitians In New York, Trying Times
description: In one Brooklyn neighborhood, what might have been a day of joy for its Haitians yesterday was instead a time of sadness, somber reflection and desperate but largely futile attempts to reach relatives back in Haiti by telephone.

title: Faster Revamping Expected at Amfac
description: Henry A. Walker Jr. was chief executive officer of Amfac Inc. from 1967 to 1982, a tenure he now calls long enough. But last week, following the abrupt dismissal of Ronald R. Sloan as president and chief executive officer, Mr. Walker resumed those titles and duties in addition to his role as chairman.

title: Recital: Carol Vaness
description: THE thoughtfulness of Carol Vaness's recital at Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon began with her choice of music. There were such tender little Rossini masterpieces as ''La Promessa'' and ''L'Invito''; then four Strauss lieder of solid substance followed by three elegant desserts by Tosti. Nowhere in French song is despair so eloquent or nostalgia so touching as in Chausson's ''Temps des Lilas'' and ''Colibri.'' Miss Vaness sang these and three other Chausson songs as well.

title: Lincoln Journal; Artist's Brush Is a Plow, His Canvas Is the Soil
description: The sun, small and red as a copper penny on a hot stove lid, rose this morning over a gently sloping hillside where a giant American farm breakfast was spread.

title: Economic Outlook Stable, Poll Shows
description: Americans, reassured by the financial markets' steadier performance during November, have not changed their minds about the economy, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Washington Talk: Court Politics; Nursing the Wounds From the Bork Fight
description: A month after the Senate's defeat of Judge Robert H. Bork, life has yet to return to normal for many of the conservative Southern Democrats who voted against President Reagan's Supreme Court nominee.

title: Metro Datelines; 2 IRT Work Trains Collide During Test
description: BRONX: Two subway work trains collided yesterday in the Bronx during a test of their propulsion systems.

title: David G. Cherna Wed To Shari R. Schonfeld
description: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., Shari Rita Schonfeld, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Schonfeld of Brooklyn, and David Gary Cherna, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Cherna of Livingston, N.J., were married yesterday. Rabbi Dr. Manfred Fulda officiated.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 29, 1987: MONDAY Albertson's Inc Watkins-Johnson United Industrial TUESDAY Alaska Air Group MCA Inc First Mississippi Corp Premier Industrial WEDNESDAY Corning Glass Works Peoples Energy Federal Co Starrett (LS) Co Heilig-Meyers Tektronix Inc Louisville Gas & Elec Times-Mirror Milton Roy USF&G CorM Pacific Scientific U.S. Shoe Pennwalt Corp Wynn's Intl THURSDAY Allegheny Pwr Sys Marriott Corp Atlantic City Elec RLI Corp Brown Group SPS Technologies General Host Supermarkets Genl Illinois Pwr Universal Leaf Tobacco Lucky Stores Washington Natl Corp FRIDAY Chubb Corp Roper Corp

title: Bronx Grand Jury Critical of No-Bid Towing Pacts
description: A system of no-bid contracts for emergency towing on limited-access allowed to continue despite a 1981 City Comptroller's audit that showed it had engendered widespread fraud, a Bronx grand jury has asserted.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Tomba Wins Again: Alberto Tomba of Italy won his second consecutive World Cup ski race in three days yesterday with a victory in the giant slalom at Sestriere, Italy. Tomba, 20 years old, won the special slalom Friday.

title: Co-op City Sets New Goal: Attract More Whites
description: Co-op City, the huge, integrated apartment complex in the northeast Bronx, is about to begin a marketing campaign - even though it has a waiting list of several months for an apartment. The objective is to persuade more white people to live there.

title: Blacks Entering New Era in Chicago
description: The death of Harold Washington has ushered in the next chapter in the evolution of urban black political power, what the late Mayor called simply, ''The Movement.''

title: Premier's Party Leads Turkish Vote
description: For the first time in seven years, Turks voted today in national elections free of military supervision, a poll depicted as reinforcing the revival of democracy.

title: Clarence E. Unterberg, An Investment Banker
description: Clarence E. Unterberg, an investment banker, died Saturday at his home in Tinton Falls, N.J. He was 86 years old.

title: Relief Plane in Ethiopia
description: A Belgian Air Force Hercules transport plane arrived in Ethiopia today to airlift emergency food to drought victims in the northern province of Tigre, where rebel ambushes are hindering transport by road. Jean-Jacques Fresard, the delegate of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Ethiopia, said the plane would start work Monday, ferrying more than 70 tons of food each day from Asmara, the capital of Eritrea province, to Mekele, the capital of Tigre.

title: Talks Seek to Avert Milk and Trash Hauler Strikes
description: Labor negotiations in two industries - milk distribution and private refuse carting - were scheduled today in an effort to avert strikes tonight that would halt the delivery of milk and the collection of all commercial garbage in New York City and many suburban areas.

title: Mr. Reagan's Treaty
description: All Democratic Presidential candidates, in varying degree, are supporting the arms control treaty Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev are about to sign. All Republican candidates except Vice President Bush are opposing the treaty, or reserving judgment.

title: Top Afghan Offers New Charter; Insurgents Answer With Rockets
description: Invoking Islam, but interrupted by Islamic guerrilla rockets, Afghanistan's Communist leader, Najibullah, introduced a new constitution today in an effort to legitimize his shaky Soviet-backed regime.

title: DEATH ON RAILROAD PROMPTS A STRIKE
description: When a veteran railroad worker was hit by a locomotive while trying to stop a runaway car, his death prompted not only a Federal investigation but also a strike over safety issues.

title: 60 Are Missing as Avalanche Hits Valley in Chilean Andes
description: An avalanche roared into an Andean valley near Santiago today, burying a workers' camp and a picnic area. The Government television said up to 60 people were missing and feared dead.

title: Bishop Who Speaks for Downtrodden
description: Auxiliary Bishop Agustin A. Roman, who was flown to Oakdale, La., this weekend to make a videotaped appeal to Cuban inmates holding 26 hostages at a Federal detention center, is a man who has never forgotten his humble roots, according to those who know him well.

title: Heifetz Is Hospitalized For Undisclosed Illness
description: Jascha Heifetz, the violinist, has been at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center here for several weeks with an undisclosed illness, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Retailers Pleased by Weekend
description: Helped by weather conducive to shopping in New York, California and other places, sales rose considerably from a year earlier during the weekend that traditionally begins the holiday shopping season, some major retail chains reported.

title: Business and the Law; Slower Growth Seen at Firms
description: THE steady trend of law firms growing larger appears to have stalled, as partnerships have recently experienced a series of dissolutions and collapsed deals.

title: HOLE-IN-ONE EARNS $175,000 FOR TREVINO
description: There was a moment of silence. Stunned silence. ''I think that's the first time in my life I've heard him shut up,'' Jack Nicklaus said. ''He was speechless. For once, he was at a loss for words.'' But the silence didn't last. Lee Trevino - who watched in something like disbelief today as his 6-iron shot trickled into the cup for a hole-in-one - began bounding about the 17th tee, hopping into the air, waving his cap.

title: Metro Matters; In High School, A Chance to Test Wall St. Waters
description: When the stock market collapsed last month, Vadim Krys's portfolio declined by about 30 percent from a high of $14,000.

title: Explosive Growth Crowds Schools and Leads to Conflict in a Jersey Town
description: Robert Hunter School is ''bursting at the seams,'' said James Gamble, its principal. In six years, enrollment has grown to 631 from 485, and when more children come next year there will be no room to add classes. Some teachers will have as many as 30 pupils.

title: A Treacherous Paradox: AIDS Tests
description: Present tests for the AIDS virus antibody are highly accurate. Yet if applied to the population at large, they could falsely brand nine people infected for every true case identified. The President's AIDS commission had better be sure it understands this treacherous paradox if it intends to recommend the widespread testing favored by some Administration officials.

title: Belgians Puzzle Over a Future When Missile Sites Vanish Like Sand Castles
description: The first snow of winter was falling, fat wet flakes in the headlamps of the construction trucks. The distant cruise missile base, floodlit and overhung with cranes, glowed in the dusk.

title: 100 Haitians, Trying To Vote, Encounter 'Utter Blood Bath'
description: About 100 Haitians lined up to vote at a small school near the downtown area of the capital this morning, and, according to witnesses, were set upon by a mob of 50 to 100 men believed to be remnants of the Tontons Macoute, the old bodyguard of the deposed dictator, Jean-Claude Duvalier.

title: In East Berlin, Dissenters Resist a Crackdown
description: Candles were burning Saturday evening in Zion Evangelical Church, and bunches of flowers were tied to a metal fence outside. Young men and women were holding a protest vigil, while uniformed policemen patrolled outside and secret policemen mingled with the onlookers.

title: Account
description: * Long Island Rail Road to Christopher Thomas Associates, Garden City, L.I.

title: BATTERED DREXEL SWEATS IT OUT
description: Senior executives of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., like those at other major Wall Street firms, often engage in spirited debates about strategy. Recently, Drexel's officials have been arguing about an issue generally not considered to be controversial: its image advertising.

title: Honda's U.S. Imports
description: The Honda Motor Company said it would import and sell American-built motorcycles in Japan. Next spring, Honda said, it would start importing 500 units a year of its Goldwing GL1500 model, which is produced by Honda of America Manufacturing Inc. in Marysville, Ohio.

title: Martha Kurshan, Lawyer, Marries
description: Martha C. Kurshan, an associate at the New York law firm of Shea & Gould, and Carl Stine, a second-year student at the Fordham University School of Law, were married yesterday at the bride's home in Manhattan. Rabbi Jacob Reiner officiated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is a consensus on two things. One is that the debt has to be paid, and the other is that the debt cannot be paid.''

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Haig Joke Irks Marines
description: Floyd Smith, a railroad clerk with the New York Transit Authority and a sergeant in the Marine Corps Reserve, did not take kindly to a joke that Alexander M. Haig Jr. made about on the campaign trail recently at the Marines' expense.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Held in Slaying Of Gypsy Cab Driver
description: TREMONT: The driver of a gypsy cab was shot and killed in the Bronx Saturday night in an apparent robbery attempt, the police said.

title: Social-Service Breakup Is Suggested by Perales
description: The New York City Human Resources Administration has become mired in bureaucracy and should be broken into smaller, localized units with more accountability, the State Commissioner of Social Services said in a television program aired yesterday.

title: Electronics Sales Rise
description: United States factory sales of electronic equipment, components and related products during the first nine months of the year increased 6.7 percent over the corresponding period last year, an industry association said Friday. Sales for the 1987 period totaled $165.5 billion, compared with last year's nine-month record sales of $155.2 billion, according to figures released this week by the Electronic Industries Association here. The association predicted that sales for the year would top $220 billion.

title: Union, Seeking To End Strife, Readies Accord
description: The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. called Local 1199 of the hospital workers' union ''the conscience of the labor movement.''

title: Trial of Crime Boss to Open
description: Jury selection begins Monday for the trial of Nicodemo Scarfo, the reputed head of organized crime in Philadelphia and southern New Jersey, on charges of masterminding a multimillion-dollar drug ring. Selection of the 12 jurors and four alternates is expected to take most of this week. They will be sequestered in a hotel until the trial is over, which the authorities hope will come before Christmas. Mr. Scarfo was sentenced to 14 years in prison after his conviction last May for trying to extort $1 million from a Philadelphia developer.

title: France Lets Bombing Suspect Go In Step to Restore Ties With Iran
description: France allowed an Iranian sought for questioning in terrorist bombings to leave the country today, a step in restoring relations between Paris and Teheran after their bassies and diplomats have been under police siege for nearly six months.

title: Why the Watergate Break-In?
description: H. R. Haldeman shrugged. ''To this day I still don't know why that was done,'' Richard M. Nixon's former chief of staff told a questioner at Hofstra University the other day. ''And I don't know anybody who does. Why they would hit the National Headquarters is beyond me, because nobody in that place knows anything anyway.''

title: Greenwich Village Battles PATH Plan
description: The smaller scheme is generating the larger debate as the New York City Planning Commission reviews proposals for a 36-story tower on the East River and a pair of 46-foot-high shafts on the Hudson.

title: Lee Rich's Stubborn Optimism
description: Lee Rich believes in MGM/UA, even if many of his own employees are skeptical.

title: Korean Plane, 115 Aboard, Crashes in Southeast Asia
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, Nov. 30 -- A South Korean airliner with 115 people on board disappeared as it flew near Burma from the Middle East Sunday.

title: Down the Stretch, Giants Fizzle and Jets Sizzle; REDSKINS WIN, 23-19
description: For the first 30 minutes, the Giants played what Coach Bill Parcells said was probably their best half of the season. Then the momentum swung, and in the last 17 minutes of the game the Redskins charged back with three touchdown passes by Jay Schroeder and took the lead. In the last minute of the game, the Giants charged back, only to have Tony Galbreath stopped on the Redskins' 2-yard line on the last play.

title: 2 Connecticut Men Die in Fire
description: Two Connecticut men, a groom and his best man, were killed early today along with the bride and eight other people when a fire erupted toward the end of their wedding party in a luxury hotel on the resort island of Margarita.

title: Babe Herman, 84, Former Outfielder With the Dodgers
description: Babe Herman, the popular Brooklyn Dodger star of the 1920's and early 1930's, died Friday at the age of 84. Mr. Herman died of complications from pneumonia and a series of strokes, his son, Charles Robert Herman of Miami, Fla., said.

title: The Editorial Notebook; 'Sidney Is Trying'
description: Sidney Flax was wounded in a dive bombing attack while serving with the U.S. Army in Naples in World War II. He recovered, returned home, married, raised a family and worked in a bank until he suffered a stroke two years ago. His right arm and side are paralyzed; his right leg had to be amputated.

title: For Crime Detection, 'Genetic Fingerprinting'
description: The conviction of Robert Melias on a rape charge in a Bristol court two weeks ago appeared routine, except that vital evidence came from a technique called ''genetic fingerprinting,'' which is acclaimed as the biggest advance in the science of crime detection in a century.

title: Wagner Urges Legislation to Alter School System
description: The president of the New York City Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., called yesterday on the Governor and the State Legislature to enact legislation that would ''provide a context for sweeping reform of the city's school system.''

title: How New York City Balances Pension Demands
description: To the Editor:

title: A Poor Parish Strains To Help the Homeless
description: Most of the people who worship at St. Luke's Church in the South Bronx have very little money to spare. But yesterday, as they filed out after the service, they were asked to give to a group that is even poorer than they are - the homeless.

title: Jews' Summit Message to Gorbachev
description: One of my first Gulag cell mates was a professional swindler. After a career of enterprising scams, Leonid had exhausted his opportunities for ''work'' in the Soviet Union. As he served his sentence, he was studying English with the hope of living in the United States.

title: European Plan To Tax Fats
description: A controversial proposal to tax vegetable oils and fats, which is opposed by Europe's trading partners, will be submitted to the European Community summit meeting this week.

title: Lease Cost Affecting Hutton Sale
description: The competition to buy E. F. Hutton & Company, which continued through the weekend, is being complicated by the amount of capital the brokerage house has tied up in its new Manhattan headquarters building, according to several Wall Street professionals close to the bidding.

title: Bills Clobber Dolphins
description: Buffalo limited Miami to 229 yards - just 23 on the ground - and stopped Dan Marino's streak of 30 straight games with at least one touchdown pass as the Bills beat the Dolphins today, 27-0.

title: Lendl Wins Stakes And $583,200 Prize
description: From their grim expressions and animated, sometimes caustic, reactions to critical lapses and controversial line calls, one might have thought Ivan Lendl and Pat Cash were playing in the past.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Phones at State
description: State Department officials who are facing a possible cutback of $60 million and the possible loss of some 1,200 jobs in a budget-cutting effort were annoyed to discover a slow but sizable leak of money over the years in a corner of the room used by correspondents who cover the department.

title: Concert: Youth Symphony
description: THE New York Youth Symphony began its Carnegie Hall concert Sunday afternoon with ''American Slick,'' a work by the young composer William Doerrfeld, who said in a program note that he ''set out with one thing in mind . . . to make the orchestra boogie.'' That he does, in loud-louder-loudest terms that leave this observer inclined to wait and hear what other arrows Mr. Doerrfeld has in his quiver before offering an opinion on his abilities.

title: Recycling Helps Avoid Wasteful Incineration; It Cuts Toxic Residues
description: To the Editor:

title: St. John's Holds On To Take Lapchick
description: St. John's University survived a scare today to win the 13th annual Joe Lapchick Memorial tournament at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens. The Redmen, who have never lost a game in the history of the tournament, held off a late rally by Loyola Marymount University to win, 88-85.

title: Dance: The City Ballet in a Pair Set to Gounod
description: THE New York City Ballet presented audiences with a generous sampling of varied works from its repertory at weekend performances at the New York State Theater.

title: Advertising; Big Plans In Sales Promotion
description: PETER H. ENGEL's American Consulting Corporation announced a small acquisition last week. It's only the beginning. The former Procter & Gamble, Philip Morris and Colgate-Palmolive marketing executive has had big growth plans for his eight-year-old company, especially since it went public last August.

title: Market Place; Mixed Views On Aerospace
description: IN a market grown increasingly hostile toward the stocks of giant aerospace companies, the General Dynamics Corporation and the Boeing Company are selling at their lowest prices in three years.

title: THE HAITIAN TRAGEDY: 30 YEARS OF MISRULE
description: Oct. 22, 1957: After a military coup and five interim regimes, Dr. Francois Duvalier, a country physician, is elected President. His administration rapidly deteriorates into a dictatorship.

title: Purchasers Report Gains in Activity
description: The stock market may still be down in the dumps, but those who expected a downturn in business activity so far have been proved wrong. According to the National Association of Purchasing Management, the economy continued to grow in November, but at a slightly slower pace than was reported the previous month.

title: Moynihan Weighs Favorite-Son Bid
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said yesterday that he had been asked to consider running as a favorite-son candidate in the New York Democratic primary in April. If he decides to do run, he said, it would be to help keep the 1988 Democratic Presidential race open until the convention in July.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Miracle for Saints: A Winning Season
description: The New Orlean Saints assured themselves of the first winning season in their 21-year-history today, beating the Pittsburgh Steelers, 20-16.

title: Dresser's Energy Focus Emphasized by New Bid
description: John J. Murphy, president, chief executive and chairman of Dresser Industries, has underscored his company's focus on the energy industry with the announcement that Dresser plans to acquire the N. W. Kellogg Company.

title: Metro Datelines; 2 Workers Injured In Store Explosion
description: SOUTH JAMAICA: Two men working in a Queens grocery store were injured Saturday night when an incendiary device exploded in the shop, the police said.

title: Rehabilitate Bukharin, Widow Asks Moscow
description: Nikolai I. Bukharin's widow has asked Mikhail S. Gorbachev for the political rehabilitation of her husband, who was executed in 1938 after he was ousted from the Kremlin hierarchy by Stalin, a journal appearing today reported.

title: U.S. Rates Non-Atom NATO Arms
description: While outnumbered by Soviet forces, NATO has sufficent conventional strength to make a Soviet attack highly unlikely, according to a classified ''net assessment'' of opposing strengths and weaknesses prepared by the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: People
description: * John Kelleter has joined Caravetta Allen Kimbrough, Miami, part of the Omnicom Group, as senior vice president, director of marketing.

title: Historic Goal Sparks Rangers
description: From Bob Froese's vantage point, all that could be seen were raised sticks, sticks pointing his way, usually a menacing sign at Madison Square Garden but in this case an indication that he had just made hockey history.

title: READER'S DIGEST MAN JOINS ANTI-DRUG EFFORT
description: The Media-Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America, advertising's biggest voluntary effort since the bond drives of World War II, has announced thet Lynn C. Mapes, recently retired Reader's Digest executive, has joined the organization as a volunteer to serve in the important job of media director. He will lead the forces that line up the free space and time without which this campaign could not get off the ground.

title: Working a Gift List Into Shape
description: THERE is more to the physical-fitness craze than muscle tone and target heart rate. At no other time of year is this more apparent than during the holiday season, a period when life as we know it turns into a frenzied shopping spree. No longer will a necktie do when it could have been a pair of running shoes. And who now would think twice about seeing two bicycles under the Christmas tree - one for the 9-year-old in the family, and one for the 42-year-old? The preoccupation with sport allows us to think differently - to see adults as children, and children as themselves. Here are some ideas to get you started. Prices do not include shipping costs or sales tax.

title: Shultz Sees No Snags For Signing Arms Pact
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that work on the final language of the treaty on medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles has been ''going on in a good way, and there isn't any particular problem about that I know of.''

title: Clemson Defeats Pesky Rutgers, 3-2
description: Bruce Murray of Clemson, proving he possesses the characteristics of an efficient striker, found the right time to get free inside the opposing penalty area as the Tigers scored a 3-2 victory today that eliminated Rutgers from the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament.

title: LATIN CHIEFS URGE OVERHAUL OF DEBT AND OF O.A.S. TOO
description: The presidents of eight Latin American countries ended a four-day conference today by calling for a sweeping overhaul of the Organization of American States and demanding a ceiling on repayment of their foreign debt.

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS JUMPED 46.2% IN OCTOBER By STEPHEN LABATON
description: Orders for American-made machine tools surged 46.2 percent in October from the previous month, to $267.3 million, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.

title: A Conservative Call for Compassion
description: An influential conservative group is issuing a major new manifesto this week that chastises some in the movement as lacking compassion toward the needy.

title: Barbara Anne Perry Wed To Dr. Jean-Marie Bind
description: The marriage of Barbara Anne Perry to Dr. Jean-Marie Bind took place yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn. Cantor Mark Lipson officiated.

title: Rekindled Dodgers
description: It's been three decades since the Dodgers decamped for Los Angeles, and since then, it seems, Brooklyn's beloved Bums have become more beloved than they ever could have been when they were breaking the borough's heart with depressing regularity.

title: Cuomo Guard Defends Actions in Assault Inquiry
description: A New York City police detective who is a security officer for Governor Cuomo has defended actions he took in the first hours of an investigation of the robbery and assault of the Governor's father-in-law, Charles Raffa, three years ago.

title: BLOCKED KICK TOPS BENGALS
description: Well, why not?

title: Blazers Hand Nets 5th Straight Loss
description: Clyde Drexler and Steve Johnson scored 28 points each tonight, leading the Portland Trail Blazers to their fifth consecutive victory, a 125-104 decision over the Nets. It was the fifth straight loss for New Jersey.

title: AUSTERITY LIKELY AFTER POLISH VOTE
description: Poland's Communist Government appeared ready today to announce that the public had approved a program of severe economic belt-tightening, after the nation's first referendum in more than 40 years.

title: Washington Talk: Foreign Affairs; A 6-Pointed Star and Mozambique
description: It has been a hard several years for Mozambique, the southern African nation beset by drought, famine, a tattered economy and a persistent insurgent movement.

title: Books: Legacies
description: FATHERS AND CHILDREN. By C. L. Sulzberger. 304 pages. Arbor House. $19.95.

title: Irene Handl Dies at 85; Comedienne in Britain
description: Irene Handl, one of Britain's best-loved actresses and comediennes, who perfected the role of a slightly eccentric cockney old lady, died today at her home here, according to her agent, Peter Graham. She was 85 years old.

title: If Group of 7 Meets: Industrial Nations Favor Cooperation On Dollar but Disagree on Formality
description: Most European officials want Washington to stablize the dollar and Bonn to keep stimulating its economy whether or not those things happen within the framework of a formal meeting of the world's industrial leaders. Japan, for the moment, seems to be off the hook.

title: Music: Christmas Songs
description: STEPHEN PAULUS, the young American composer, wrote ''So Hallow'd Is the Time'' for the Greenwich Choral Society eight years ago. The Connecticut singers - by the look and sound of them, a group of about 100 amateurs - brought this music to the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Saturday night. It is described as a Christmas cantata. Its 11 sections set old texts by English and Scottish poets.

title: Recycling Helps Avoid Wasteful Incineration
description: To the Editor:
